column2: The New York State Bankers Association announced yesterday that it would hold its convention next year on an ocean liner cruising to Bermuda and back over the Memorial Day week-end. For several years the association has held its convention at Bolton Landing on the shore of Lake George.

BERLIN, Nov. 18. -- The tangled web of European politics became still more disarranged today through formal recognition by Germany of Generalissimo Francisco Franco's revolutionary junta in Spain as the legitimate government.

The Columbia University Club scored a sweep for its fifth straight victory to remain on top in Class A of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis Association standing yesterday. The New York A.C., also unbeaten, had a harder time but accounted for its fourth triumph in the weekly team matches.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP). -- Reiterating that work rather than a dole is "the American way" to provide relief, the United States Conference of Mayors asked Congress and the President today to provide sufficient funds to continue WPA through the fiscal year ending June 30, 1937.

SAN MATEO, Calif., Nov. 18. -- Black Sleeve, Henry C. Hatch's brown colt, captured the handicap for 2-year-olds, fourth race on the card and one of the features at Bay Meadows today. With Jockey Young handling him, he came through to pay his backers $4, $3.40 and $2.80 for $2 mutuel tickets.

Play for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup team-of-four contract bridge championship started last night at the Hotel Commodore. Entrants were divided into five sections, each of which played four matches of six boards each. The three leading teams in each section and one other team on the basis of last night's and tonight's play will enter the knockout rounds tomorrow.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 18. -- Newspapers here today, reporting President Roosevelt's departure for South America, lay stress on the meaning of his trip for closer Pan-American relations, political, cultural and economic.

Credit collections in October showed an increase of 0.44 per cent, according to the index of twenty local "key stores," issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. The increase follows decreases in each of the three preceding months and compares with a rise of 1.90 per cent in October a year ago over the comparative 1934 month.

Federal authorities are prepared to take drastic action to keep employers and employes from deliberately paying too much tax under the Social Security Act, it was disclosed yesterday at the regional offices of the Social Security Board, 45 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Dr. W.W. Alexander, one of the assistant administrators of the Resettlement Administration, is expected to succeed Rexford Guy Tugwell as Administrator, although no official announcement of Mr. Tugwell's successor has been made.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18. -- Prices of hogs were mostly 10 cents a hundredweight higher in early trading today, but the demand diminished later and toward the end sales were regarded as steady to 5 cents higher. The top advanced 10 cents early to $9.80, but it was hard to get more than $9.65 at the close.

The annual three-day bazaar arranged by the Daughters of the British Empire in the State of New York for the benefit of the Victoria Home for Aged British Men and Women was opened formally yesterday afternoon in the ballroom of the Biltmore by Sir Gerald Campbell, British Consul General at New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- The international executive board of the United Mine Workers of America today warned United Mine Worker William Green, who is president of the American Federation of Labor, to stop opposing his own union and associating with its adversaries in the present craft-industrial union labor dispute or suffer the consequences -- presumably expulsion from his own union.

ROME, Nov. 18. -- A communique today announced that Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Italian Foreign Minister, had received the French Charge d'Affaires, who had called to urge the Italian Government to join France in protesting Germany's most recent breach of the Treaty of Versailles in denouncing international control of her waterways, and that Count Ciano had informed him that Italy saw no way of acting in the manner suggested.

The newest contribution to the Technicolor field, "The Garden of Allah," with Marlene Dietrich and Charles Boyer and directed by Richard Boleslawski, makes its New York appearance at the Radio City Music Hall this morning. "Tarzan Escapes."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Retail sales in department stores during the holiday season already begun probably will exceed $920,000,000, only 10 per cent less than in 1929, Secretary Roper predicted today, after studying reports from thirty-one of the largest cities.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Contending that some of the activities assailed had been approved by the NRA and had been terminated since the dissolution of that organization, Ralph H. Sartor, commissioner of the Metal Window Institute, made public today a statement critical of the recent complaint issued by the Federal Trade Commission against the institute and its members charging price fixing.
Determination of whether or not the city's sales tax constitutes a prior lien against a business is soon to be decided by the Court of Appeals, it was explained yesterday.

Alice Mock, soprano, and Herbert Carrick, pianist, appeared in joint recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. Miss Mock, a native of California, has sung with the Chicago Civic Opera and on the radio. This was her New York recital debut. Mr. Carrick, who was born in Worcester, Mass., and who studied abroad, has appeared here as an accompanist but not as a solo recitalist.

LETCHWORTH VILLAGE, N.Y., Nov. 18. -- A demonstration was given here today of dust-trapping devices which are being tested in connection with a campaign by the State of New York for the prevention of silicosis and the elimination of general dust-disease hazards in industry.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 18. -- Governor Earle tonight issued the following statement:

CHICAGO, Nov. 18. -- The grain and soy-bean markets developed reactionary tendencies on the Board of Trade today, but not until all deliveries with the exception of July wheat and December and May oats had sold at new high prices for the season.

The coming of the Federal social security blanks accentuates the grind of form-filling with which we are afflicted. To the professional man and woman and all those in unincorporated, uncapitalized and individual business who may have a few employes the act is a great burden.

Leases of a number of largo apartments were reported yesterday. A triplex with private street entrance and elevator in River House, 435 East Fifty-second Street, was leased by Herbert G. Wellington, a member of the Stock Exchange, from William Rhinelander Stewart. Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., was the broker.

With Mrs. Rogers Dunn coming through in the No. 1 singles match to break a 2-2 deadlock, the Junior League conquered the Cosmopolitan Club, 3 -- 2, at the latter's courts yesterday to finish in first place in the women's Class A division of the New York section of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association interclub tournament.

Holiday promotions by leading liquor houses will be the most extensive since repeal, several announcements indicated yesterday. In an effort to get the pre-Christmas selling season off to a strong start, the House of Schenley last night introduced a new type patented container, known as the "Protect-All Bottle," and two new blended whiskies at a dinner at the Paramount Hotel Grill.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 18. -- An appropriation of $1,308,439 for its work in 1937 was approved today by the Board of Foreign Missions of the Methodist Episcopal Church. The sum is the same as was appropriated for 1936. The board closed its three-day annual meeting at the Robert Treat Hotel here at noon.

The United States liner Washington pulled away from her North River pier for Europe yesterday at 12:48 P.M. with 291 passengers, while 750 seamen who have quit their ships in protest against their union leadership paraded in the street near by, warning her passengers that the ship was improperly manned.

LONDON, Nov. 18. -- Cheering thousands of poverty-stricken dwellers in the South Wales mining area welcomed their King today on his tour to see the miserable conditions that have shocked the Cabinet and Parliament into seeking means for the population's permanent re-employment.

Engaging in both indoor and outdoor sessions, the New York University football squad went through a diversified workout yesterday in preparing for its game with the City College eleven at the Yankee Stadium on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- The question whether a group of farm publications in the Midwest combined in restraint of trade in violation of the Sherman Anti-trust Act was debated today before the Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- The New York City Housing Authority has adopted a resolution refusing to operate the two slum clearance projects now under construction by the Public Works Administration, at the rents tentatively projected by the PWA in negotiations between the two bodies.
Today will write the final chapter of THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair in the International Building, Rockefeller Center.

Income tax reports showing losses by the National Title Guaranty Company during the years 1931 and 1932 were read into the record yesterday at the trial of the company and eight former officers on charges of conspiracy and use of the mails to defraud.

The Embassy Room and Garden of the Ambassador formed the setting last night for a dinner dance given in behalf of the West Sixty-third Street Community House, philanthropic organization for needy families, which formerly was known as the Riverside Day Nursery.

Seven of the twenty-three manufacturers of women's hats who were arrested last week in the investigation by James J. Wilson, Assistant District Attorney, into the so-called "ashcan hat" racket, pleaded guilty in Special Sessions yesterday to violating Section 438a of the Penal Law.

Winning the final two blocks of his six-block three-cushion match with Ralph Greenleaf yesterday at the Strand Academy, Willie Hoppe took the match, 300 to 284, in 236 innings. In the fifth block Hoppe was the victor, 50 to 39. in fifty stanzas. He followed this with a 50-to-42 triumph in fifty-two innings.

LONDON, Nov. 18. -- What the Laborite Opposition is bound to seize upon as the first government hint that military conscription is only just around the corner in Great Britain was dropped tonight by Earl Stanhope in a debate in the House of Lords.
C.T. Loo Co. have announced the opening of the new gallery in the Fuller Building, 41 East Fifty-seventh Street, tomorrow with an exhibition entitled "Chinese Art Through the Ages."

PARIS, Nov. 18. -- Roger Salengro, Minister of the Interior in the Cabinet of Premier Leon Blum, committed suicide by gas last night in circumstances which are likely to have enormous social and political consequences.
Year-end declarations of extra and special dividends continued in large volume yesterday. At the same time several companies announced wage increases and bonus payments to employes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Efforts of Texas to control the output of natural gas in the vast Panhandle gas and oil field were debated before the Supreme Court today in a case of major interest to students of such State legislation and to corporations controlling natural re sources.

The correspondence which has followed upon your editorial "High Cost of Funerals" proves the timeliness and great importance of this subject. Letters in the files of the City Affairs Committee since we initiated discussion of the subject show widespread public interest.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 18. -- The annual fair of Trinity Episcopal Church was opened today with the slogan, "Meet your friends in the lobby of Hotel Trinity Biltmore." The parish house was turned into a hotel lobby. Mrs. Brison Howie and Mrs. Ernest Watson were co-chairmen.

The consolidated income account of the Bulova Watch Company and subsidaries for the third quarter of this year, based partly on an estimate, was issued yesterday. It showed a net profit of $778,015 after provision for doubtful accounts, depreciation and Federal income taxes.

Professor TUGWELL has resigned as Under-Secretary of Agriculture, in order to accept a position with a large corporation identified with that capitalistic system which he must now hope will endure longer than he had predicted. Justly or unjustly, Mr. TUGWELL had become a heavy burden for the Roosevelt Administration to bear.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18. -- Evidence that tiny amounts of the metal cobalt are essential for the formation of the red blood cells was presented here today before the closing sessions of the Autumn meeting of the National Academy of Sciences by Professor Katsuji Kato of the University of Chicago.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

S.P. Boochever of the Fraternity Club, the unexpected threat in the Eastern amateur squash racquets tournament at the New York Athletic Club, continued his winning ways last night when he toppled M.W. Metzler of the City A.C. in straight games in the first of the three third-round matches listed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Wallace Groves, whose investment trust activities featured the opening hearings of the Security and Exchange Commission's investigation and study of investment trusts and investment companies, reappeared today before the commission to tell the story of the Phoenix Securities Corporation of New York, control of which he and his associates acquired in 1934.

BURGOS, Spain, Nov. 18. -- Although Colonels Serrano, Barron and Asensio have now consolidated Insurgent positions in the northwest corner of Madrid and are fighting on toward the Royal Palace, still more dangerous for the government army, it is declared here, is a lightning thrust made by General Jose Moscardo from the Siguenza front toward Guadalajara, thirty-five miles northeast of Madrid.

MADRID, Nov. 18. -- Sosthenes Behn, president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, which operates the Spanish telephone system, is helping to take care of refugees in the cellar of the telephone building here.

In an interview with THE TIMES'S representative, Governor EARLE of Pennsylvania revealed an odd conception of his office. Some of the large anthracite companies of his State allege that unemployed miners have been stealing the coal on their properties, digging it, marketing it, underselling legitimate coal dealers and pocketing the proceeds for themselves.
MADRID, Nov. 18. -- The nerves of Madrid are being sorely tried by day and by night, but there is no sign of quailing.

The New York Rangers will encounter the champion Detroit Red Wings in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. The Patrick skaters, fresh from their smashing 6-to-1 triumph over the Boston Bruins on Tuesday night, are confident that they have hit a winning stride, and hope to even the score with the Wings.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 18.-- When President Roosevelt left this port aboard the cruiser Indianapolis this morning it was for the longest voyage ever undertaken by a President of the United States, in order to lend the force of his presence to the opening session of the Pan-American Peace Conference, which will start in Buenos Aires Dec. 1.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 18. -- A threat by Dr. Ray Lyman Wilbur, president of Stanford University, to call off the big game scheduled for Saturday at Memorial Stadium, Berkeley, hung over the heads of Stanford and University of California students tonight as hostile spirit seethed on both campuses.

Samuel Samuels, 44 years old, of 504 West 160th Street, one of the Nicholas (Nick) Montana vice ring leaders, said to have amassed $300,000 in the last five years through thirty-eight houses of prostitution in this city, pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions after being on trial five weeks on a compulsory prostitution indictment.

Columbia's football squad was out in full force yesterday at Baker Field to start practice for the game with Stanford at the Polo Grounds a week from Saturday. After two days of rest following their victory over Syracuse, the Lions seemed eager to get under way and the result was a very snappy session.

PEAPACK, N.J., Nov. 18. -- Blind of Arden, first American field trial champion Labrador retriever, today repeated his victory of last year when he received first prize in the open all-age stake of the sixth annual Labrador Retriever Club meeting.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- After a four-hour conference between a committee representing the New York Stock Exchange and the Securities and Exchange Commission, James M. Landis, chairman of the commission, stated this evening that the commision intended to go ahead without unnecessary delay to put into effect the suggestions that it had made in its report to Congress last Summer on the feasibility and advisability of the segregation of the functions of dealer and broker.

With the production of steel ingots virtually unchanged at 74 per cent of capacity, the attention of the steel trade is centered on the expected increase in prices according to the weekly summary by the magazine Iron Age. The publication says the new prices probably will be $2 a ton higher on semi-finished steel, $3 on bars, shapes and plates, and either $3 or $4 on sheets and strip.
The seismograph at Fordham University recorded severe tremors in the vicinity of uptown New York yesterday.

TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 19. -- The coincidence of the Mongol uprising in the borderland between China and Manchukuo with the deadlock in Chino-Japanese negotiations has not been publicly noted here, although the newspaper Asahi predicts that the negotiations will be suspended and warns its readers that a conflict may involve Manchukuo.

LONDON, Nov. 18. -- The sudden recognition of the Spanish Rebels by Germany and Italy was accepted here today as part of the anti-Communist "holy war" now being organized with such sound and fury by all Fascist countries, great and small.

Opposition to any plan for lifting the moratorium on mortgages on large properties in this State where the interest rate has been reduced to less than 5 per cent, as suggested at the hearing on Monday before the Joint Legislative Committee investigating guaranteed mortgages, was expressed yesterday in a letter addressed by Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, to Senator Lazarus Joseph, chairman of the legislative committee.

A well-known recipe for long life advises us to pick out the right kind of grandfathers and grandmothers. Now comes Dr. WILLIAM F. PEDZRSEN of the University of Illinois Medical School and recommends, for intellectual eminence, the right month to be born in.

WALLINGTON, N.J., Nov. 18. -- The mystery of the masked man of Grammar School 2, which had kept twenty police and WPA workers of this borough on guard at the school since Nov. 10 and had caused the arrest of one suspect, was solved today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 18. -- Because of a frozen stadium football field, Harvard's next to last workout before starting for New Haven again was held in the baseball cage. The program today, however, was varied in that most of the time was spent in signal drill on offensive plays, with the defensive work being a secondary consideration.

The first step in what is regarded as a program to involve eventually the refunding of about $230,000,000 of Argentine Government dollar bonds will be taken today with the public offering of $23,500,000 of Republic of Argentina sinking fund 4 1/2 per cent bonds due on Nov. 15, 1971, by a banking group headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc.

For the third time in five years the New York University School of Architecture and Allied Arts has won the medal for having the best record of accomplishment in teaching architecture along the lines followed by l'Ecole Nationale et Speciale des Beaux Arts in Paris.

Before his departure on his cruise is South American waters yesterday President Roosevelt issued two statements on national problems. One, issued in Washington, related to re-employment of the jobless by private industry, and the second was a plea for cooperation of business and government in promoting world trade, made in a message sent to the National Foreign Trade Council at a meeting in Chicago.

AT the last Princeton-Dartmouth game an intoxicated spectator staggered out and followed the Green line into the thick of a goal-zone scrimmage. It was his own idea. But if any more men on the Princeton and Dartmouth squads come down with sickness or injuries, the referee of this year's encounter may have to halt the game and call for volunteers from the stands, not necessarily intoxicated.

The feature of trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday was the concentrated liquidation of 20,000 bales of the December position which eased the whole market 8 to 12 points on the day. Commission house interests released the near month, with spot houses taking the contracts.

An appeal for a strong merchant marine both as a commercial necessity in peace time and as a naval auxiliary in time of war was made yesterday at the Federal Day sessions of the third annual Marine Exhibition at the Maritime Exchange, 80 Broad Street.
THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair in the International Building, Rockefeller Center, will close tonight at 10 o'clock.

TORONTO, Nov. 18 (Canadian Press). -- Canada's three-man team defeated Chile in a jump-off tonight in the first event of the international army officers' jumping competition at the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show. Third place went to the United States and fourth to Great Britain.

A cold wave from Central Canada froze a large section of the United States yesterday, gave this city a record-breaking low temperature for the date, with a reading of 18 degrees above zero at 11 P.M., one less than the record set twelve years ago, and threatened even colder weather in the early hours of this morning.

President Roosevelt's plurality over Governor Landon in New York City was 1,375,406, it was announced yesterday by the Board of Elections upon completion of the official canvass of the vote cast for the two major party candidates in the recent election.

Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag refused yesterday to compel the board of examiners of the Board of Education to grant a high school teacher-in-training license to Miss Gertrude Epstein, former Barnard College honor student and editor-in-chief of The Barnard Bulletin, but declared that she should not be denied a license because of her political or economic views or her expression of them.

In a dream early yesterday morning, Bertrand Lascoff, 20 years old, a pharmacist, crept to the bed where his father slept in their apartment at 200 West Ninety-third Street and stabbed him eight times.

Broad gains continued in active trading in most of the commodity futures markets yesterday, with coffee, sugar, cocoa and silk the leaders of the advance. On the cash markets many new high records were set, including those for wheat, cocoa, coffee, wooltops, hides, silk and printcloths.

Desiderius Erasmus, Dutch scholar who died 400 years ago, was praised as one of the outstanding philosophers and theologians in the history of civilization by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, in an address yesterday afternoon at the special convocation held in Seth Low Memorial Library, Columbia University.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 18. -- Ambassador Alexander Weddell called upon Saavedra Lamas, Argentine Foreign Minister, today and formally presented a request from President Roosevelt that his reception here be as simple as it is possible to make it.

It is a matter of common knowledge that in questions relative to improvement of their sport, fishermen talk much but do little. Anglers are great ones for calling protest meetings and passing resolutions. So far as translating their indignation into concrete action is concerned, however, they are notoriously lax.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- The United States Government is giving no consideration to the question of recognizing the Rebel movement in Spain as the government of that country, it was said authoritatively today when reports were received of the recognition of General Francisco Franco by Italy and Germany.

Representatives of financial and church groups analyzed the effect of the government's program upon large investments of these and similar organizations at the closing session yesterday of the Church Pensions Conference. Delegates representing twenty-four denominations attended this twenty-second annual meeting, which opened on the preceding day at the Hotel Governor Clinton.

MADRID, Nov. 18 (Censored). -- Firemen were still struggling valiantly this afternoon with the numerous blazes started in the center of the city by the incendiary bombs dropped last night from Rebel planes.

Clutching a box of crackers and proudly exhibiting a shiny new quarter, 5-year-old Lucy Peluso smiled happily yesterday afternoon when told in Children's Court that she could stay with her Negro "mammy," whose custody of the white child has been questioned, until her parents can take care of her.

MADRID, Nov. 18 (Censored). -- Firemen were still struggling valiantly this afternoon with the numerous blazes started in the center of the city by the incendiary bombs dropped last night from Rebel planes.

Clutching a box of crackers and proudly exhibiting a shiny new quarter, 5-year-old Lucy Peluso smiled happily yesterday afternoon when told in Children's Court that she could stay with her Negro "mammy," whose custody of the white child has been questioned, until her parents can take care of her.

Stockholders of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company, at a special meeting here yesterday, approved the merger with it of the Associated Oil Company and the Tide Water Oil Company. Previously, the stockholders of Associated Oil and Tide Water Oil, subsidiaries of Tide Water Associated Oil, had approved the merger.

Steps taken by the New York Stock Exchange since 1930 to elevate the standards of customers' men were outlined yesterday by Maurice L. Farrell, chairman of the Exchange's committee on public relations, at the November luncheon meeting of the New York Financial Advertisers Association at the Lawyers Club.
PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 18. -- If the P.G.A. championship lives to be a thousand years old it may never produce as many upsets as occurred today at Pinehurst.

A jury in Long Island City pronounced Frank X. Donnelly, former police sergeant, guilty last night of first degree manslaughter for killing his estranged wife, Marion, in her apartment at 10-60 Grove Street, Far Rockaway, on the morning of July 3, 1935. The verdict was announced at 9:45 o'clock after the jury had deliberated for about four hours.
The finishing touches were put on the Fordham offense yesterday and the Maroon eleven apparently is in top-notch condition for its battle with the sturdy Georgia team at the Polo Grounds tomorrow.

ROME, Nov. 19. -- The Fascist Grand Council, which held the longest session in its history last night, sitting right through from 10 o'clock in the evening until 4 o'clock this morning, placed the seal of its authority on the state of hostility existing between Italy and Russia.

The Irving Trust Company, acting as trustee in bankruptcy for the estate of the late Charles Bancroft Dillingham, theatrical producer, received a bid of $1,100 yesterday for whatever rights the showman held in a list of 112 plays and musical comedies.

Joseph W. Powell was elected president yesterday of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, which opened a two-day convention at the Engineering Societies Building, 39 Wrest Thirty-ninth Street. Mr. Powell, who is president of the United Drydocks Corporation, succeeds Rear Admiral George H. Rock.

LONDON, Nov. 19. -- As King Edward returned to London tonight after a strenuous two-day tour of the once prosperous South Wales mining region, it became more evident than ever that the British Government will soon focus its attention on plans to provide work for the vast army of unemployed living there.

Abe Goldberg, 205, California, used a body hold to pin Ernest von Hefner, 235, Germany, in the feature wrestling match at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of 2,000 watched the Californian triumph in 27:58.

Sweet revenge was enjoyed by the New York Rangers last night when they beat the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden. The margin, though only 1 to 0, pleased the New Yorkers and their supporters no end.

DUBLIN, Irish Free State, Nov. 19. -- James A. Farley had a busy time in Dublin today. Early this morning he called upon President Eamon de Valera and had a long talk with the Free State President on conditions here. His next call was at the Mansion House, where Lord Mayor Alfred Byrne gave him a cordial reception

GLENVVOOD LANDING, L.I., Nov19. -- Mrs. Ida Carhart, 65 years old and an invalid, lay scantily clothed on the street here all last night with the temperature at 12 degrees above zero after collapsing in an effort to summon neighbors to help her older brother who had broken his leg in a fall.

HONOLULU, Nov. 19. -- Characterizing the situation here as acute. Governor Miles Poindexter asked the Interior Department at Washington today to take steps to provide Hawaii with a shipload of staple foods, the supplies of which have been virtually exhausted because of the ship strike.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 19. -- A code of fair competition to prevent price-cutting was adopted unanimously tonight by 200 Essex County members of the Retail Gasoline Dealers of Northern New Jersey, meeting in the Union Labor Center, 280 Washington Street, here.

A plea for strong self-respect by the Jewish people to offset "the demoralizing influences of a world not sufficiently understanding" was made yesterday by Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson, rabbi of Congregation Emanu-El.

Paul Green, who gave the Group Theatre people their first script, has now given them their most original, "Johnny Johnson," which they put on at the Forty-fourth Street last evening. In the program he describes it as "a legend" to distinguish it from the conventional play.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 19. -- The sprawling lowlands of the Mississippi delta, a land where more than three out of five farmers are tenants and most of them are sharecroppers, were viewed for the first time today by Secretary Wallace, who, as chairman of the President's National Farm Tenancy Committee, will formulate a program for a more widespread farm ownership for the country.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 19. -- Harvard finished its preparations today for its biennial invasion of the Yale Bowl with another hard offensive and defensive drill.

The Stony Wold Sanatorium was the beneficiary of the Tintype Tea yesterday in the ballroom of the Savoy-Plaza. A feature of the afternoon was the showing of a motion picture of debutantes in costumes of the "Gay Nineties," as well as several committee members in gowns of bygone days.

Members of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York, the Federated Garden Clubs of Connecticut and the Garden Club of New Jersey competed yesterday in a Thanksgiving show sponsored by the Gardens of the Nations in Horticultural Hall, Rockefeller Center.

Federal tax returns showing an annual income never less than $1,000,000, even during the depression, were introduced in evidence here yesterday in a contest over the estate of the late Colonel Edward H. R. Green, who died last June at Lake Placid, N.Y.
ATLANTA, Nov. 19 (AP). -- Three persons trapped in a top-floor music studio died today in a fire which swept a five-story downtown building. Eighteen others were injured.

Under steady liquidation of December contracts preparatory to the circulation of notices on next Tuesday, prices on the Cotton Exchange eased slightly again yesterday, but a late recovery left the list 3 points higher to a point lower than on Wednesday.

POTTSVILLE, Pa., Nov. 19. -- In the war of attrition that is being waged between the big coal mining corporations of Eastern Pennsylvania and the organized unemployed of that region, once a stronghold of the Molly Maguires, the companies have been losing steadily.
DALLAS, Nov. 19 (AP). -- James J. Braddock hoisted a pair of "brand-new dukes" for inspection tonight and quietly assured his listeners that Madison Square Garden needn't worry.

ALBANY, Nov. 19. -- Segregation of Negro girls in the State Training School for Girls at Hudson "cannot be justified and should not be tolerated," a report of an investigation by a committee of the State Board of Social Welfare just sent to Governor Lehman, declares.

Sugar, hides and copper futures alone were strong on the local commodity futures markets yesterday, while other staples turned erratic or weak in less active trading. On the cash markets, silk, wooltops and rubber made new highs and cotton, tin and butter rose, while all the grains, lard and cocoa declined.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- A practical test of the manoeuvreability of an army division of 13,000 men -- less than half the size of the unwieldy division that operated during the World War -- will be undertaken next Summer.

VATICAN CITY, Nov. 19. -- Osservatore Romano, the official organ of the Holy See, prints a long account of Cardinal Pacelli's visit to America, which is written in the form of an interview, but nevertheless reveals the unmistakable impress of the Cardinal's own pen.

Using as its vehicle Gerhart Hauptmann's fantastic drama "The Sunken Bell," the Deutsche Schauspiel-Buehne started last night on the road which this enterprising aggregation of German-American actors hopes will lead to the re-establishment of a permanent German-language theatre in New York.

Because the directors of Mayflower Associates, Inc., an $18,000,000 investment trust, believe the undistributed profits tax established by the Revenue Act of 1936 will interfere with the corporation's long-term investment policy they have decided to recommend to the shareholders its dissolution and complete liquidation, according to a letter sent to the stockholders.

PARIS, Nov. 19. -- The suicide of Roger Salengro, Minister of the Interior, and the hasty recognition of the Rebel cause in Spain by Germany and Italy, have provoked a new outbreak of feverish nervousness in Paris. Both internal and international complications are feared.

Featured by a split vote rejecting one rule, the effect of which would be to eliminate "P.M.s" or cash allowances to retail sales clerks to push the sale of products, the trade practice hearing of the perfume, cosmetic and toilet goods industry called yesterday at the Hotel Astor by the Federal Trade Commission went on record in approval of all other regulations to be submitted to the commission.

LONDON, Nov. 19. -- In the face of hostile criticism in the House of Commons last night, the government defended its authorization for the employment of American Lockheed aircraft on its subsidized night air mail service between London and Sweden, which is operated by British Airways, Ltd.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19. -- Hope that world prosperity sought through this country's trade restoration program may ease "economic tensions that set the stage for revolution and war" was expressed by Secretary of State Hull in a letter read to 1,000 delegates attending the world trade dinner, held tonight in conjunction with the National Foreign Trade Convention here.

Anticipating that Villanova will direct its attack at the Manhattan flanks at Ebbets Field tomorrow, Coach Chick Meehan concentrated on end plays as the Jasper squad went through its final hard workout at Innisfail Park yesterday for the battle, which concludes the Green's home campaign.

Worcester, Mass., has invited tenders for a new issue of $500,000 of revenue notes, award of which will be made today. The notes will be dated Nov. 23, 1936, and will become payable on June 11, 1937. Bidders are to name the rate of interest.

Omnibus service on the lower East Side, which was interrupted yesterday by a strike of drivers employed by the Avenue B and East Broadway Transit Corporation and the Grand Street Bus Line, will be resumed this morning, it was announced last night at the offices of the companies at 7 Mangin Street.
A turn to warmer weather halted a widespread, record-breaking cold wave yesterday after it had held temperatures below freezing here for twenty-four hours.

Frank Capra, motion picture director, received $208,000 and Ronald Colman, actor. $162,500 as salaries for the fiscal year ended on June 27, the Columbia Pictures Corporation made known yesterday in its annual report to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The North German Lloyd liner Bremen is due today from Bremen and Channel ports, with Captain Adolf Ahrens on the bridge for the first time as regular commander. Among her passengers are Hannes Schneider, founder and head of the Austrian Ski School; Benno Rybicka, Austrian ski champion; Baroness Ethel von Schilling; Dr. Louis Carre, French art expert, and Manuel Rivas Vicuna, Chilean Minister in France. Others on board include:

A seaway from the Great Lakes to this port via Montreal, Lake Champlain and the Hudson River would save $100,000,000 annually in transportation costs, cut rail rates more than 50 per cent, revitalize industry and offer compensating traffic to the railroads, according to proponents of the project.

The discovery of a huge stone calendar in the jungles of Colombia, believed to be the earliest known invention for telling time in this part of the world, was reported here yesterday by Professor Hermann von Walde-Waldegg, curator of the University Museum of Boston College.

Officials of the New York Stock Exchange, after conferences consuming most of the day, announced last night that they had no statement to make regarding the Securities and Exchange Commission's program for segregating the dual functions of floor brokers as agents for the public and dealers for their own accounts.

ONE fight fan said that Jimmy McLarnin would have ten pounds on Lou Ambers in their Garden debate this evening. Another fight fan said that Jimmy would have seven years on Lou and they would weigh heavily on his shoulders after the fifth round.

BERLIN, Nov. 19. -- Trading on the Boerse was mixed today and activity was limited. Foreign stocks were not affected by the official announcement of regulations for their enforced deposit in the Reichsbank's subsidiary, as these regulations already had been made known.

New York University's football team went through its final workout yesterday for the metropolitan battle with City College at the Yankee Stadium tomorrow. No practice will be held by the Violet today.

RHYMNEY, Wales, Nov. 19 (AP). -- King Edward ended a two-day inspection of poverty-stricken South Wales with a "community sing" and returned to London tonight to see "what can be done" for his unfortunate subjects.

The Jackson Heights Squash Club remained on top in Group 1 of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association competition by defeating the New York A. C. team, 4 -- 1, on the losers' courts yesterday. The triumph was the third is an many tests for the Queens squad.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- A message of sympathy and encouragement "to the Bishops, the priests and the faithful in Spain" was sent today by the Catholic Bishops of the United States, assembled here for their annual meeting of the Catholic University.

LONDON, Nov. 19. -- A bitter attack upon Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin by the Conservative Lord Lloyd, former High Commissioner for Egypt and Sudan, characterized today's defense debate in the House of Lords.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 19. -- Hundreds of workers in the Bendix Products Corporation plant here prepared this evening to spend the third night of their self-imprisonment in an attempt to obtain 100 per cent unionization of the factory as company officials and representatives of the Committee for Industrial Organization ended an all-day conference without reaching a settlement.

More than 80,000 persons visited THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair which came to an end at l0 o'clock last night after having been open to the public fifteen days in the International Building, Rockefeller Center.

The Consumers Power Company of Michigan, a subsidiary of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, has been authorized by the Michigan Public Utilities Commission to call in its $70,682,823 of preferred stocks and to sell a new issue of $75,000,000 of $4.50 dividend no-par preferred stock.

The interesting question is no longer whether Tarzan is going to escape from his enemies -- that much we may take for granted -- but whether his enemies will ever be able to escape from Tarzan. It seems very unlikely, too, so long as the handsome pithecanthrope continues to be surrounded by such rich and leisurely productions as Metro has draped about his handsome shoulders in "Tarsan Escapes," at the Capitol.
The names of Mrs. Ernest A. Simpson, friend of King Edward, and her former husband, who received a divorce recently in England, are listed separately in the New York Social Register for 1937.

Representative RANKIN of Mississippi sounded again yesterday "his "slogan 'Let's electrify every "farm-home in America.'" His capital, Tupelo, is a burning and shining light of Yardstick extension. He has described himself as "co-author with Senator NORRIS" of the bill to set up the TVA.

The dictators may have their unpleasant surprise coming when the speed-up in the rearmament program re-establishes Great Britain as a great military Power; but to the English people nothing brings home the ugly realities of present-day Europe so painfully as Lord STANHOPE'S suggestion in the House of Lords' debate on Wednesday that England may be forced to adopt conscription to build up the army.

The Interstate Commerce Commission, as empowered under the Motor Carrier Act, is preparing for the eventuality of having to intervene in the competitive warfare now going on between rail and truck transportation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Following is the text of the address by Secretary of State Cordell Hull at the dinner tendered to him by Dr. Jose Carlos Macedo Soares, the Brazilian Foreign Minister, in Rio de Janeiro tonight, as released by the State Department:

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 19. -- Colonel Harry B. Bissell of Manchester, United States property and disbursing officer for Connecticut and chief of staff of the Forty-third Division of the National Guard, was arrested late this afternoon on a Superior Court bench warrant charging him and his former clerk, Charles G. Higdon, now in a Florida hospital, with conspiracy to defraud and embezzle $10,000 of State government funds.

GRAND VIEW, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- Zoning Commissioner Elmer S. Hader of this village, who headed a committee of local residents protesting the building of the bridge between Nyack and Tarrytown, refused to comment tonight on a report that engineers had found the site impracticable for the purpose.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19. -- Twelve Philadelphia bankers and lawyers have been indicted by a special Federal grand jury on charges of fraud and conspiracy in connection with the collapse of the $132,000,000 Philadelphia Company for Guaranteeing Mortgages.

Jimmy McLarnin will try his knockout punch on Lou Ambers, the lightweight champion of the world, in an over-the-weight match of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. Although there will be no title at stake, the bout promises to attract a sizable crowd, about 10,000 fans being expected to sit in attendance.
AVILA, Spain, Nov. 19. -- News of Germany's and Italy's recognition of the Insurgents provoked the wildest enthusiasm here.

TELLICO PLAINS, Tenn., Nov. 19. -- A middle-aged college professor who had not shot a rifle in fourteen years became the toast of thirty expert marksmen today when he bagged the first wild boar in a hunt staged by the State in the Cherokee National Forest.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 19. -- Prosecution of thirty-five storekeepers, including the managers of several chain grocery branches, on charges of committing fraud or attempted fraud against the town in connection with the handling of relief clients' food orders began in city court this morning before Judge Edward C. Fisher.

IRVINGTON, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- Led by Miss Margaret Bostwick, the Ardsley Country Club women's squash racquets team defeated Apawamis by an uncompromising 5-0 score today and earned the right to represent the Westchester Class A teams in the triangular matches at Plainfield, N.J., next Tuesday.

Twenty yachtsmen who have been associated with the Interclub class of racing sloops on Long Island Sound, or who will be in the new class being constructed in Norway, now are owners of Class B one-design dinghies. A new list of the small craft that are racing this Winter was compiled yesterday and on it are sixty boats.

ALBANY, Nov. 19 (AP). -- Dr. Alexander C. Flick, State Historian, said today at the unveiling of a plaque honoring President Van Buren, that Van Buren was "entitled to the historic credit for creating the Democratic party."

Brash college youngsters determined to do or die for dear old Alma Mater in the Big Game of the season have nothing on the New York Giants these days. Fired with a more flaming spirit than they have had all year, the lads who play for pay are convinced that they are going to take the measure of the ponderous Packers from Green Bay in their game at the Polo Grounds on Sunday.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 19. -- President Roosevelt's formal request that his reception in Buenos Aires on his arrival for the inter-American peace conference be as simple as possible has upset the government's plans for one of the most elaborate celebrations in recent years.

NANKING, China, Friday, Nov. 20. -- Airplanes and tanks belonging to the Central Government have arrived in Suiyuan Province and will assist in the defense of that region against external aggression, a government spokesman announced yesterday.

BERLIN, Nov. 19. -- The long-heralded decree compelling the owners of certain foreign securities to deposit them with the Reichsbank or its designated agent banks, the imminence of which had caused an upheaval in the foreign securities market, was issued today.

The simplest way to gauge the importance of the modern hospital to any community is to try to imagine that community without the facilities of the modern hospital, and to compare its vital service to mankind with that of many other institutions which we have long since come to take for granted.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the week-end, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local, private and public elementary and high schools:

Manager Burleigh Grimes, new boss of the Brooklyn club, made his first official move yesterday to bolster the Dodgers for the 1937 pennant race with the announcement of the purchase of Anthony F. Malinosky, 22-year-old shortstop, from the Pirates.
Several expansion leases in midtown and downtown were among the business rentals reported yesterday, as follows:
AVILA, Spain, Nov. 19. -- The situation on the Madrid front today remained unchanged.

Giving another superb exhibition of the type of squash tennis play that has stamped him as the sport's leading amateur exponent for the past seven years, Harry F. Wolf of the New York Athletic Club yesterday won the Princeton Club's invitation tournament for the second year in a row.

VIENNA, Nov. 19. -- The eve of Archduke Otto's twenty-fourth birthday was marked here by a meeting of the Legitimist party under the chairmanship of Prince Hohenberg, son of the murdered Archduke Franz Ferdinand. About 5,000 leading Monarchists heard the Prince express the hope for the early restoration of the Hapsburg Archduke.
The Mayor of the largest city in the country and the Mayor of one of the smallest agreed yesterday that the job of being Mayor is by no means what it is cracked up to be.

There have been signs lately that Wall Street is becoming inured to the flood of favorable dividend announcements and that new incentives might be needed to move the market upward again. Yesterday several of the stocks on which extra dividends were declared declined on the good news, whereas a week or two ago such tidings usually brought a brisk rise.

In a twenty-minute outdoor ceremony, cut short to protect almost 1,000 cheering children from the biting cold, Mayor La Guardia formally opened the James J. Flanagan Youth Center, 127th Street and Lexington Avenue, yesterday afternoon.

World economic conditions showed further improvement in September and October, with foreign industrial production attaining a new all-time record, according to the monthly review in The Annalist, published today. International trade made further moderate gains, while the downward trend of commodity stocks was checked, but probably only temporarily.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19. -- Liquidation by holders of December wheat and corn contracts had a depressing effect on prices on the Board of Trade today. Rallies were feeble and the close was at practically the low levels of the day, December wheat lost 1 cent a bushel, while May was 3/8 cent lower and July 1/8 cent higher.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. CHESTER, At Sea, Nov. 19 (AP). -- King Neptune sent his emissaries tonight to the cruiser Chester and the cruiser Indianapolis, bearing President Roosevelt to the inter-American peace conference in Buenos Aires.

MOSCOW, Nov. 19. -- Recognition of the Spanish Rebels by Germany and Italy has greatly intensified the danger to general peace in the view of Soviet observers. It has shown, as they see it, that the Fascist countries are ready to go to any lengths without even an attempt at concealment in order to help their proteges in Spain.
PEIPING, China, Nov. 19. -- Reports from Chinese sources in Suiyuan declare the province's defenders Continued on Page Five

Both the artists now exhibiting at the Rehn Gallery -- Charles Burch-field with a group of twelve recent water-colors and Peggy Bacon with an assortment of prints, new and of earlier coinage -- may be said to exemplify in their work certain traits not commonly belonging to work in their particular mediums.

HAVANA, Nov. 19. -- Death sentences were imposed by an urgency court today on Mario del Toro and Ramon Garcia Pujal, convicted of bombing the building of the newspaper Pais last September, when five persons were killed and twenty-six injured.

Rex, the official Dalmatian mascot of the New York Fire Department and, according to gossip, the sire of 75 per cent of firehouse mascots throughout the city, died last night of double pneumonia in the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital for Animals.

Extra, special and other favorable dividends amounting to close to $15,000,000 were voted yesterday by corporations, bringing to more than $100,000,000 the amount of such distributions ordered in the first four days of this week. This is in addition to the regular dividend payments.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 19. -- "Good Morning, Piliescu," by Richard A. Berman and Wells Root, has been purchased by RKO as a starring vehicle for Francis Lederer. It will be Jesse Lasky's second RKO production, his first to be "Radio City Revels." The Czech star's contract with Columbia permits him to make one film a year for Lasky.

Roger Williams, director of safety service of the State Insurance Fund, advocated more participation by industry in social legislative programs in an address yesterday to the National Founders Association, which closed the fortieth annual two-day convention of the organization at the Waldorf-Astoria.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- One of the largest galleries that has witnessed the popular three-day exhibition in the six years of its existence saw the Peekskill horse show off to a successful beginning in the 156th Field Artillery, National Guard, armory' today.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Nov. 19. Scoring his fourth consecutive victory in the fifth round at the Club Ajedrez de San Juan, Isaac I. Kashdan, Empire State titleholder, wrested the lead from Dr. Adolf Seitz of Augsburg in the international chess masters' tournament today.

New York City will open a new and highly organized offensive against major racketeering with the establishment of a local Bureau of Investigation headed by a veteran prosecutor, it was learned yesterday at City Hall.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 19. -- Evidence that there is not and never has been unemployment among the Arabs of Palestine since British occupation was given by E. Mills, Director of Migration and Statistics of the Palestine Government, before the first public session of the Royal Inquiry Commission here yesterday.

The American Safety Razor Corporation reported yesterday for the first nine months of this year a consolidated net profit of $906,525 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges. No provision had been made for the Federal surtax on undistributed earnings.

The demand for high-grade bonds again was reflected yesterday in strong bids for such issues on the New York Stock Exchange. While interest continued unabated in purely investment vehicles, many of the recent speculative favorites in the corporate section were neglected and drifted to moderately lower levels.

MADRID, Nov. 19 (Censored). -- Members of the diplomatic corps have decided to bring to the notice of their respective governments the distress caused in Madrid by repeated Insurgent bombardments. The diplomats expressed themselves as much disturbed at the serious conditions prevailing generally, especially the fact that Madrid is a target for artillery and air bombardments that are devastating large areas.

An increase of $10,000,000 in member-bank excess reserves to a total of $2,270,000,000 was reported for the week ended on Wednesday in the Federal Reserve statement, published yesterday. The gain, while small compared with last week's rise of $120,000,000, lifted the total of excess reserves to a new high level since the 50 per cent increase in reserve requirements on Aug. 15.

Mr. ROOSEVELT is on his way to visit our good neighbors to the south, whom it would be more correct to call our neighbors to the southeast. The geography of the Western Hemisphere has its eccentricities, like geography everywhere else. Chief among these is the circumstance that South America does not lie directly south of North America or anywhere like it, but far off to one side.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 19. -- Princeton University's Autumn social season will reach its grand climax tomorrow night with the annual "Prince-Tiger" dance in the university gymnasium.
LONDON, Nov. 19 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Designed to tighten securities transactions in "in-and-out" trading on Stock Exchanges, the Federal Reserve Board today submitted to Federal Reserve Banks for their consideration a proposed amendment to Regulation T applying to loans by brokers, dealers and members of national securities Exchanges, which would require stock purchasers to post margins immediately instead of taking advantage of a permissible lag of several days under the current regulations.
United States Department Of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission hopes that at least the first of the regulations involved in its broad program for partial segregation of the broker-dealer functions on Exchanges will be effective within from three weeks to a month, and its experts are rushing completion of drafts of such regulations for submission to the New York Stock and Curb Exchanges.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Nov. 19. -- Cordell Hull, United States Secretary of State, declared tonight that if the American republics at their coming conference in Buenos Aires showed their willingness to ratify the pledges of peace between them, "the people of those countries outside this hemisphere will not be heedless of our example."

WARSAW, Poland, Nov. 19. -- An effort to save what remains of the close Gcrmano-Polish cooperation and friendship after Marshal Edward Smigly-Rydz's trip to Paris and Colonel Josef Beck's visit to London was made by the German Ambassador to Warsaw, Hans Adolf von Moltke, in two important conversations he had Tuesday in Berlin with Chancellor Adolf Hitler and on Wednesday here with Colonel Beck.

BERLIN, Nov. 19. -- Formal recognition by Germany of the Franco government as the legitimate regime in Spain does not affect Germany's present position on nonintervention in that country, it was stated at the Foreign Office today The Reich Government intends loyally to adhere to its military neutrality pledges, it was said.
LONDON, Nov. 19. -- Some British aristocrats are debating with gravity the friendship between King Edward and Mrs. Wallis Simpson, an informed peer asserted today.

Among those who entertained guests last night in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador at the first in a series of dinner dances arranged by the Dutton Club for the younger married people was Mrs. Leonard Abbott Jenkins whose party included Count and Countess Nicolai von Keller, Miss Julia Conklin, Count Arthur von Keller and Nelson Hyde.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- As President Roosevelt was sailing toward South America on a peace mission today, the Supreme Court was confronted with a question on neutrality legislation the answer to which may have a profound effect upon this country's future efforts for world peace.

OSSINING, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- The question of a higher license fee for fishing and hunting in this State bobbed up again at a meeting of the Southern New York Fish and Game Association here last evening.

LONDON, Nov. 19. -- Reports concerning King Edward's friendship with Mrs. Wallis Simpson, which hitherto have been confined, so far as this country is concerned, to clubs and fashionable drawing rooms in London, finally are spreading to wider circles, due chiefly to persistent echoes on the matter coming back from America.

James Gould Cozzens is the winner of this year's O. Henry Memorial Award for the best short story, it is announced in "O. Henry Memorial Award Prize Stories of 1936," edited by Harry Hansen and published by Doubleday, Doran today. The $300 prize was given for "Total Stranger," a story by Mr. Cozzens that was published in The Saturday Evening Post last February.

OTTAWA, Nov. 19 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits by the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada increased $3,154,317 in the week ended yesterday, according to the weekly statement of the bank issue today. Deposits by chartered banks rose $10,407,619. The statement follows:

Bishop William T. Manning of the Protestant Episcopal Church urged a reunion of all Christian faiths, both Catholic and Protestant, last night in an address before the American National Committee on World Christian Conferences, at a dinner meeting in the Hotel Biltmore.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission denied without prejudice today the petition of Class I railroads for the modification of freight rates that will expire on Dec. 31, and ordered a public hearing on Jan. 6, 1937, when the roads will get an opportunity to present arguments for the proposed increase.

Dedicated to His Majesty King Edward VIII, a de luxe brochure featuring twelve coronation colors was issued yesterday by the Textile Color Card Association. The colors are crown ruby, crown sapphire, crown pearl, crown amethyst, royal amethyst, royal yellow sapphire, royal turquoise, imperial gold, regal purple, knight's blue, royal crimson and English scarlet.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 19. -- Any worry that ardent followers of the Yale football fortunes may have over the possibility that the squad and its coaches think the season closed last week with the victory over Princeton is easily dispelled by a visit to this elm-studded university city.

Angelo Fabella, 24 years old, of 49-17 108th Street, Corona, Queens, the first truck driver indicted by the New York County grand jury investigating coal bootlegging from Pennsylvania mines, pleaded guilty yesterday to transporting six tons of the stolen coal into this city.

Contending that the new bill offered by Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx requiring city residence as a condition of appointment to city positions is far more drastic than the bill recently defeated, the Citizens Union asked the Board of Estimate yesterday for a public hearing on the new measure.

Developments yesterday in the proposed heavyweight fight between James J. Braddock and Joe Louis indicated that the Madison Square Garden Corporation might participate in the promotion of the battle. Mike Jacobs, who holds the contract to Louis's services, and Herman Taylor, who has offered Braddock a guarantee of $300,000 to meet Louis in Atlantic City in a twelve-round no-decision bout on Feb. 22, made that fact known after a conference yesterday afternoon.

Andre Maurois, here for a three weeks holiday, has completed the manuscript of his history of England, on which he has been working for six years. The book, titled "The Miracle of England," is now being translated by Hamish Miles and will be published by Harper in the Spring.

Ever since I was a kid the word hospital has frightened me. Even as I grew up a hospital seemed to me a passport to a cemetery. However, last year I finally had that operation that I used to talk about on the stage and screen; and so I found myself in a Los Angeles hospital.

This is the night when the members of the Actors Repertory Company go back to work, the occasion being the presentation -- by the ARC in association with Sidney Harmon -- of E.P. Conkle's "200 Were Chosen," at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre.

Frederick Buldrini, a native New York violinist, made his debut at Town Hall yesterday afternoon in a recital given under the auspices of the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation. Mr. Buldrini, who was the only winner of the foundation's prize last season, was sent to Italy when 8 years old to study violin, and when but 14 received the diploma of Licenza Normale in violin and theory.

Federal Judge Mack denied yesterday without prejudice a motion by Dictograph Products Company, Inc., to restrain the Securities and Exchange Commission from alleged unlawful interference with transactions involving its stock.

BERLIN, Nov. 19. -- Holding fast to the initiative which the authoritarian States have taken from the democracies in international affairs, Chancellor Adolf Hitler today conferred for two hours with Dr. Guido Schmidt, Austrian Foreign Minister, regarding "pending political questions."

CHICAGO, Nov. 19. -- Pursuing the corporate-reorganization program begun a year ago, directors of Marshall Field Co. voted today a sweeping recapitalization plan under which accumulated unpaid dividends on the preferred stock will be cleared up and fixed charges substantially reduced.

Pressing their efforts to establish the machinery for administration of the Social Security Act, government officials took additional steps yesterday to obtain the cooperation of employers and employes.

LONDON, Nov. 19. -- The stock market here continued cheerful today, although somewhat less active. Early closing of the subscription lists for the government's new 100,000,000 funding loan was reflected favorably in other government issues.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Law-enforcement agencies will have in the Federal Social Security Act a new and effective weapon even more potent in their war on organized crime than the income tax law has proved itself to be, government officials said today.

The University Club swept into the lead in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class A team competition yesterday by recording a 3-to-2 victory over the Yale Club on the latter's courts. The triumph was the fourth straight.
At the start of the season, before a game had been played, Dick Harlow analyzed the situation in the Harvard football camp as follows:

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 19 (AP). -- George W. Norris, the grocer who was for a time a candidate against Senator George W. Norris in the 1930 Nebraska primary, won a reversal today of his conviction on a charge of perjury in his testimony before a Senate investigating committee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- The Old Colony Investment Trust of Boston, organized in February, 1927, by officers and directors of the Old Colony Trust Company and its subsidiary, the Old Colony Corporation, was under investigation today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

BOWIE. Md., Nov. 19. -- The Porter colt, Aneroid, from Outburst, which was bred by Mrs. Jock Whitney and now races for Edward Bruner, ripped off the fastest six furlongs of the meeting today in taking the Tench Handicap in 1:12 3-5.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 19. -- The Newark College of Engineering will receive the scientific library, numbering more than 15,000 volumes, and the early electrical apparatus of Dr. Edward Weston, electrical pioneer and inventor, according to announcement today in The Technician, the student publication of the college.

The greatest telephone hook-up in history, linking more than 160 cities in the United States and Canada on a 25,000-mile circuit, was set up last night to assist 25,000 members of the Telephone Pioneers of America celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of that organization.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- The Tarrytown-Nyack Bridge Authority abandoned today its plan to erect a bridge across the Hudson River from Tarrytown to Grand View, according to an announcement by Dr. Joseph E. Hughes, a member of the Bridge Authority.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- A few days ago this department ventured upon a personal survey of the remnant of Republican opposition in the next House of Representatives, reducing this to its human factors and concluding that in the members who fell by the wayside on Nov. 3 the party and the country had suffered a greater loss than the statistics indicated.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 19. -- Jack White, flashy halfback who has carried the brunt of the Princeton offensive during the past two seasons, will be out of the Dartmouth contest on Saturday, it was announced today by Dr. Harry R. McPhee, the team physician.

The most difficult football schedule in Columbia's history was announced yesterday by Graduate Manager Reynolds Benson for 1937. The Blue and White will play nine games, eight of which will be against major opponents. Six of the contests will be in New York.

MOSCOW, Nov. 19. -- A German citizen, E.I. Stickling, an engineer in the Kemerovo coal mines of Western Siberia, and eight Russian executives and technicians pleaded guilty today to committing acts of sabotage and causing the deaths of ten miners in order to discredit the Soviet State and infuriate the workers against it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- "Wanted: Outstanding financial and government bond expert worth $25,000 to $100,000 annually willing to work for $10,000 a year as Under-Secretary of the Treasury. Good opportunity for reliable man.

Atlantic Coast seamen, on strike for three weeks in protest against working conditions on American ships and the enforcement of a working contract which they declare is illegal, brought suit yesterday in Supreme Court to have the contract voided.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 (AP). -- The Montreal Maroons, with the veteran Alex Connell playing a fine game in the net, won their first game of the National Hockey League season tonight by shutting out the Chicago Black Hawks, 4 to 0, before 10,000 fans.

WASHINGTON, Nov 19. -- Future policies in Treasury operations, including the Dec. 15 financing, the credit situation as complicated by a rapid inflow of foreign funds, high excess reserves of member banks and plans to meet a possible inflationary boom, were considered by Secretary Morgenthau and Federal Reserve leaders today.

Share prices closed lower yesterday in a slower market, with final quotations at or near the day's lows in many instances. The trading total on the Stock Exchange was 2,441,000 shares, against 2,920,000 on Wednesday. Treasury bonds advanced to new record highs as corporate issues and foreign loans moved irregularly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- The New York Curb Exchange, in oral argument before the Securities and Exchange Commission, today carried on its battle to retain unlisted trading in the stock of the Bower Roller Bearing Company which was withdrawn last Summer from listing on the Detroit Stock Exchange by the company because the commission had refused to treat as confidential certain information filed by the company with the commission.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- A slight advance in wholesale commodity prices during the week ended on Nov. 14 lifted the index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics (based on the 1926 average as 100), to 82, the highest in the last six years, it was announced today by the Federal agency.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19. -- Today's receipts of 34,000 hogs were the largest for a Thursday since Dec. 13, 1934. While demand was fairly active, prices were steady to 10 cents lower, with the extreme top at a loss of 5 cents at $9.75. The average price for the day, $9.45, was a 5-cent decline.

WITH INSURGENTS, Outside Madrid, Nov. 19. -- At 5 o'clock this morning Insurgent armored bombers attacked the whole Manzanares River front area of Madrid, south of Segovia bridge. They paid no attention, as on previous days, to the Montana barracks and the northern sector.

The unsurpassed Boston Symphony Orchestra, with its singularly gifted leader, Serge Koussevitzky, returned to New York last night to give its opening concert of the season in this city in Carnegie Hall.

Social and industrial changes among the girls and women of the United States were singled out yesterday by Mrs. Austin L. Kimball of Buffalo, N.Y., newly elected president of the Young Women's Christian Association, as important factors to be considered by association leaders in planning programs for the coming year.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date. The ratio of reserve for the New York bank also reached a new high figure for the year.
Nine properties in Manhattan were bid in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales held yesterday in the Vesey Street Salesrooms. Tenement houses formed the bulk of the parcels offered.

Architects filed plans in Manhattan yesterday for alterations to a large number of tenement houses on the East and West Sides. Brooklyn construction activity was featured by a set of specifications for a fifty-five-family apartment costing $121,000 for a Remsen Street site.
TORONTO, Nov. 19. -- A pact to halt illegal sales of securities between two Canadian Provinces and the United States was announced here tonight by John M. Godfrey, Ontario Securities Commissioner.

Patrick F. Halloran, 65 years old, of 385 Eleventh Street, Brooklyn, a member of the Examining Board of Plumbers, which was abolished at the request of Mayor La Guardia in 1934 when Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, uncovered grafting in master plumbers' licenses, pleaded guilty to perjury in General Sessions yesterday.

Evidently acting in accord, MUSSOLINI and HITLER have suddenly recognized General FRANCO as the head of the only Government in Spain. It was known that he had a promise of such recognition by them as soon as he captured Madrid. But he has been a month fighting for its possession and has not yet got it completely in his power.

THE book reviewer is, of course, as unfeeling as diamond. Scratch him and he does not bleed; he is more likely to scratch back. He feeds on printed paper rather than potatoes. He wakes among books, walks among books, sleeps among books. The colorful aspect of a shelf of new volumes, so alluring to the average eye, moves him not at all.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- In a message today to the Business Advisory Council of the Department of Commerce President Roosevelt detailed the problems on which he hopes for the cooperation of private enterprise in solving re-employment, betterment of living conditions in low-income groups and improvement of wages and working conditions of industrial employes.

The social, economic and political significance of the recent election was discussed last night by President James Rowland Angell of Yale University and Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of directors of the Chase National Bank, at the 168th annual dinner of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
COLUMBUS, Ohio., Nov. 19 (AP). -- The National Grange late today went on record as opposed to subsidies or special privileges in any form as a permanent program.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 19. -- Like his namesake, the man with the large and sinewy hands whose stock was boosted by Longfellow, Horton Smith today proved himself a mighty man when he came from nowhere to win a place among the eight left for the quarter-final round of the Professional Golfers Association championship.
LONDON, Nov. 19. -- Great Britain gave tacit but unmistakable recognition today of Generalissimo Francisco Franco's right to blockade the coast of Catalonia and bombard Barcelona.

Three collections of widely differing types of pictures were sold last night at three of the city's leading art auction galleries. The highest prices were obtained at Rains Galleries, 12 East Forty-ninth Street, where a collection of paintings by French Modernists was dispersed.

William B. Joyce, former chairman of the old National Surety Company, admitted in a letter to his son, Morton, in November, 1931, that the mortgage losses of the company were due to "poor management, neglect and poor judgment," it was brought out yesterday at the examination of Mr. Joyce preliminary to trial of the $20,000,000 accounting suit entered in behalf of creditors against Mr. Joyce and other former officers and directors of the company.

Large sales and advertising campaigns are successful not on a national front but only through victories achieved in individual marketing areas, Dr. Miller McClintock, auditor of the Audit Traffic Bureau and director of the Bureau for Street Traffic Research, Harvard University, declared yesterday at a luncheon at the Advertising Club of New York.
Real estate activity in the Bronx yesterday was featured by sales of houses and taxpayer buildings.
PARIS, Nov. 19 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- Residents of this city defeated the city manager plan in a referendum to day on giving up the charter as a second-class city and substituting the city manager form of local government.

TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 19. -- Atlantic Coast seamen who have refused to join the West Coast insurgents in their present strike were upheld here today when the convention of the American Federation of Labor voted condemnation of the insurgent movement.

" The Son of Mongolia," a Mongolian language film with superimposed English dialogue, featuring a native cast, will have its American premiere at the Cameo today. . . . "Can This Be Dixie?" with Jane Withers, a travesty on Southern melodramas, will arrive at the Palace. . . .

Bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday were the highest recorded in a single corresponding period since the week ended on Oct. 8, 1931. The total was $7,358,694,000, against $5,576,438,000 in the same week last year, a gain of 32 per cent.

After a search of more than nine months, detectives arrested yesterday a securities salesman who described himself as William M. Singer, 28 years old, of 112 West Seventy-second Street, on a charge of grand larceny.

LONDON, Friday, Nov. 20. -- In connection with Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's indictment of other countries as more to blame than Italy or Germany for sending arms to Spain, The Daily Express says today that its Istanbul correspondent reports that between Oct. 20 and 31 eighteen Russian ships laden with guns, airplanes and munitions passed through the Dardanelles.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 19. -- General revision of realty tax methods to provide for levies on a basis of income value of property was proposed by the National Association of Real Estate Boards today to replace "the false and artificial tax bases now used in the various States."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Joseph E. Davies of Wisconsin, wealthy supporter of President Roosevelt for re-election, was appointed Ambassador to Russia today to fill the vacancy caused by the transfer to Paris as Ambassador of William C. Bullitt after the death of Jesse I. Straus.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 20. -- William D. Plumb, believed to have been the last surviving member of the last crew of the U.S.S. Constitution, died of a heart attack today, just after he had finished reliving his experiences aboard "Old Ironsides," the most famous ship in the annals of the United States Navy.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- Through Lloyd's and other agencies, even without taking official action, the British Government has more than ample means to prevent ships under the British flag from approaching Barcelona. Therefore, the question of the British attitude toward blockade operations by the Spanish Insurgents possesses only academic value.

Norman Thomas, Socialist leader and former candidate for President, urged "the maximum possible amount of joint action against the forces of reaction" but protested against the use of violent revolutionary methods last night before an audience of about 1,000 men and women at a testimonial dinner at the Hotel Edison in honor of his fifty-second birthday and his "twenty years of valiant fighting for social justice."

Bishop Francis J. McConnell, chairman of the North American Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy, 149 Fifth Avenue, announced yesterday that within a week or ten days a Spanish ship would sail from this port with food, clothing and medical supplies "for the victims of Spanish Fascism."

The first offering to the public of common stock of James Talcott, Inc., factors, since the business was established eighty-two years ago, was made yesterday when 100,000 shares of common were placed on the market by F. Eberstadt Co., Inc., at $14 a share.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- The Boston Stock Exchange has filed applications with the Securities and Exchange Commission for unlisted trading privileges in seven securities listed and registered on the New York Stock and other Exchanges, bringing to fifty-six the total of such applications by various Exchanges pending before the commission.

Operations of the Caterpillar Tractor Company in the twelve months ended on Oct. 31 resulted in a net profit of $8,971,420 after expenses, depreciation, interest, provision for Federal taxes and other charges. No provision was made, however, for surtaxes on undistributed income for 1936, as the directors plan to declare a dividend on the common stock payable in preferred stock, sufficient in amount to make full distribution of the year's net profit.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 20. -- An exchange of several players today settled the destinies of two pictures at RKO and Paramount.
