RKO borrowed Alexander Hall to direct and Frances Farmer and Cary Grant to provide the romantic interest in Edward Arnold's "Robber Barons," based on the life of Jim Fisk.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- The Supreme Court took under consideration today the vital question of how much power Congress may give the President in a program to assure American neutrality through embargo of arms to fighting nations.

BERLIN, Nov. 20. -- The first list of the foreign securities that German nationals or foreigners, including foreign corporations, permanently resident in Germany must deposit with the Reichsbank or its designated agent bank in accordance with yesterday's decree was published today.
A 3-to-1 victory by Boys High over Textile, the defending champion, featured the opening of the annual city P.S.A.L. championship hockey tourney at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

POTTSVILLE, Pa., Nov. 20. -- Declaring that the Creator put coal in the mountains of Pennsylvania for all to share, and charging that it was stolen from them originally by "the greedy rich class," the coal bootleggers have banded together in the Independent Anthracite Miners Association to defend their "rights" by "organized strength."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Hedging transactions, or future sales contracts for the purpose of offsetting losses in spot purchases, where non-speculative in character, were held today as "essentially to be regarded as insurance, rather than a dealing in capital assets," in a ruling issued by Herman Oliphant, general counsel for the Treasury Department.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 20. -- Despite the fact that he was eliminated in the opening round of the Professional Golfers Association championship Wednesday, Gene Sarazen remains the only golfer ever to gain the national scoring and match play titles in one year.

With some divisions striking the most rapid pace thus far this year, trade proceeded with marked vigor this week, retail sales being estimated at 3 to 10 per cent higher than in the previous week, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

In her new establishment at 715 Fifth Avenue, which will be formally opened tomorrow evening, Mme. Helena Rubinstein has arranged with her architects and decorators for the display of sculpture, painting and other objects of art from her private collection.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- President Roosevelt would not have needed to do so much experimenting in the last four years, said H.G. Wells tonight, if the vast knowledge of the United States had been intelligently organized beforehand.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 20 (AP). -- A new form of brain surgery which, in a few selected eases, has given noteworthy relief to persons suffering from abnormal worry, apprehension, anxiety, sleeplessness and nervous tension was announced today before the closing session of the Southern Medical Association.

Lord Beaverbrook, publisher and owner of The London Daily Express, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen and sailed again at midnight on the same ship for England. He said he had taken the trip with the intention of flying to Arizona to get rid of an attack of asthma to which he is subject.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Senator Harrison, chairman of the Finance Committee, returned to the capital today with the declaration that there would be no increase in taxes by the next Congress, but that, conversely, there would be no substantial tax reductions since the government planned to retain Federal taxes generally at about the present levels to facilitate its program of "balancing the budget by the fiscal year 1938."

TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 21. -- Rescue work at Osaruzawa, where a dam burst yesterday and released a huge flood upon one of Japan's greatest copper mine areas, was made inhumanly difficult today by the nature of the flood.

ROME, Nov. 20. -- Premier Benito Mussolini, who all his life has been a very keen fencer, today gave a public exhibition of his skill, thus proving that the cares and responsibilities of government have not kept him from keeping up with his favorite sport.

ALBANY, Nov. 20 (AP). -- Virtually complete records of local option elections in New York State in the Nov. 3 election showed today that twenty-niche up-State towns voted wet and ten dry. Towns voting wet were:

Never ones to let a good old American tradition down, particularly when it plays into their hands, the night club and restaurant bonifaces will respect the President's proclamation of Thanksgiving on Thursday by loading up their menus with the usual turkey and trimmings, putting in little entertainment features here and there and generally emulating the Pilgrim Fathers by giving thanks for an excellent season.

The contest for the estate which Colonel E.H.R. Green inherited from his mother, Hetty Green, expanded yesterday to a consideration of the conflicting tax interests of five States and the Federal Government in the dispute over his legal residence.

The music of Johann Sebastian Bach continues to attract capacity audiences at the New School for Social Research. Last night, the fourth in a series of six programs devoted to the orchestral works and concerti of Bach was attended by an overflowing assemblage that indulged in enthusiastic applause.

While listening to Willard MacGregor, the Boston pianist, play Brahms and Schubert at his recital in Town Hall last night, one could not help wondering why works so completely alien to his temperament should occupy half of the program.

The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to acquire the building at Livingston and Schermerhorn Streets in Brooklyn formerly occupied by the Elks Club as the main administrative office for the Board of Education.
The Chase National Bank is prepared to deliver definitive first mortgage bonds 4 per cent series due 1961 of Wisconsin Public Service Corporation in exchange for the temporary bonds.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- The volume of round-lot transactions and that of member trading both increased on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Oct. 24, compared with the previous week, in which there was one less trading day, according to the weekly summary of daily transactions made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The General Electric Company declared yesterday an extra dividend of 50 cents a share and advanced the date for payment of the regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share to Dec. 21 from the customary date in January. The 75-cent distribution will amount to $21,634,445 and will lift the total of dividends paid from 1936 earnings to $43,268,890, the largest annual disbursements to stockholders since 1931.

Passengers leaving today for Europe on the French Line motorship Lafayette include Judge Paul Myron Linebarger, financial adviser to the Chinese Government; Archibald E. Gray, United States Consul at Helsingfors; Mauricio Moch, consul for Paraguay at Havre; Dr. Lewis L. Lorwin, Mr. and Mrs. Jules Bertrand, Miss Yvonne Bertrand, Miss Marie-Louise Fontaine, Vicomtesse Roederer, Marquess Teresa del Monte, Miss Joan Ames, Miss Ann Whitehead, M.B. Daniels and Miss Ruth Reilly.

In a cordial message to the National Foreign Trade Convention, sent on the eve of his departure for Buenos Aires, President ROOSEVELT pictured conditions as increasingly favorable for a revival of our foreign commerce. His optimism seems justified. The improvement of domestic business in many nations has already begun to stimulate the demand for American raw materials and finished goods.
The following table shows the ten most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the past three days:

The Harvard Club's pace-setting Class C squash tennis team continued its winning streak in the Metropolitan League matches last night, scoring its sixth victory in as many starts. The Crimson players swept their engagement with the Yale Club, 5 to 0, at the Harvard courts.

TRENTON, Nov. 20. -- The New Jersey Social Security Commission made public today three alternate plans for unemployment compensation to be considered at a public hearing at the Capitol here on Dec. 2.

MADRID, Nov. 20. -- Government forces retreated late tonight across the Manzanares River from the Casa de Campo section. The Defense Junta asserted that its men had gained ground at the northwestern edge of the city.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 20. -- John A. Riggins of Haddonfield, president of the New Jersey Utilities Association, charged today that the government, through the use of disguised propaganda of the worst sort, was attacking the public utilities in which more than half the people of the country have a direct or indirect interest.

TELLICO PLAINS, Tenn., Nov. 20 (AP). -- A 29-year-old Knoxville housewife and a Chattanooga grocer today followed the example set yesterday by a University of Tennessee professor in killing a wild Prussian boar in a hunt in the Cherokee National Forest near here.

One or two international twelve-meter racers may be built in this country this Winter, it was reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the North American Yacht Racing Union, held in the Yale Club. Also, some forty races in a number of international series may be held in American waters next Summer.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- Anthony Eden, Foreign Secretary, gave the clearest possible warnings today that Great Britain would fight only where her most vital interests were endangered and would stay out of trouble in Spain or elsewhere.

"Come Closer Folks," a glimpse into the Broadway pitchman racket, in which James Dunn, Marian Marsh and Wynne Gibson are the principals, is the Columbia offering at the Globe today. . . . The World Cinema presents a special program for children under 12 from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. today.

As the site for a one-story taxpayer, the vacant plot, 37.6 by 100 feet, at 359-61 West Thirty-fourth Street, near Ninth Avenue, has been elased by the 359 West Thirty-fourth Street Corporation, Benjamin Goffried, president, to the Le Roy Midtown Corporation, controlled by Bricken Brothers, builders.

Among the subjects that will soon engage the attention of the United States Supreme Court are labor relations, utilities and mama dolls. The Supreme Court has been asked to review a New Jersey patent decision in the matter of "mama voices" or "criers."

Manhattan's football forces, riding on the crest of a victory wave, will close their home campaign at Ebbets Field today, facing a powerful Villanova eleven. The largest crowd of the season, 20,000, is expected to witness the clash. The kick-off will be at 2 o'clock.

Now that "Johnny Johnson" is out of the way, the Group Theatre is turning its attention to other matters. On Tuesday of next week it will meet for the first formal reading of Clifford Odets' "The Silent Partner," a date which suggests the Group might bring it along toward the end of next month.

MADRID, by Courier to London (Uncensored), Nov. 16. -- A tragic mask is covering the smiling face of Madrid, where the supreme art of living for the sheer joie de vivre was practiced as a cult. Madrid has seen bad days before, but neither the Dos de Mayo rising, suppressed so ruthlessly by Murat, nor the cholera camp of the Eighties equals the prospect presented today.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 20 (AP). -- Jesse O ens, former Ohio State University track sensation, said today he had definitely turned professional.

The commodity futures markets were generally higher yesterday. The heavy trading in sugar, which for the fourth consecutive session established new high prices for the current move, was a feature. In the cash markets, wheat, corn, rye, oats, cocoa, silk and wool tops were higher, while cotton and tin were lower.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Industry must share new responsibilities with public and private agencies to meet the problems of unemployed workers, according to George P. Berner, regional supervisor, division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Department of Labor.

The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices reflected higher grains and textiles in the last week, rising to 129.4 on Tuesday from 129.3 on the Tuesday previous. Steers and hogs declined under unusually heavy shipments, carrying with them the meats generally.

ROME, Nov. 20. -- Italy's determination to do whatever is necessary to foil what are regarded here as efforts of Russian communism to take firm root in Spain was clearly expressed this evening in an editorial in the Giornale d'Italia by its editor, Virginio Gayda.

One of your correspondents recently wrote that Dean is a better pitcher than Hubbell. I disagree. He also said that Hubbell was aided by a better defense and a better attack than was Dean. I'll prove that he wasn't.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Nov. 20. -- Mrs. Magda Sargas, who is quite a hand with a sword herself, spent today training her husband, Dr. Franz Sargas, for his nine scheduled duels Monday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- After authorizing its officers to carry on a campaign for State laws aimed at the protection of the mine workers, the executive committee of the United Mine Workers of America adopted a resolution today calling upon the officers and executives to join other labor, farm and progressive groups in a demand for a constitutional amendment, if necessary, to protect social and economic progress.

Declaring that corporation directors are "wholly and unqualifiedly trustees," Supreme Court Justice Pecora ruled yesterday that Arthur J. Morris, founder, and four other directors and former directors of the holding company controlling Morris Plan Banks throughout the country, were liable to the stockholders for nearly $400,000.

The recent advice given by the chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission to railroad officials, to the effect that reorganization eventually reducing the fixed charges now outstanding was needed, calls for a review of the status of railroads.

For the better part of a week the convention of the American Federation of Labor has marked time at Tampa while those who want peace within the organized trade union movement have worked for reconciliation between two hostile factions and those who want war have jockeyed for position.

MOSCOW, Nov. 20. -- The trial of one German and eight Russian engineers for counter-revolutionary sabotage in western Siberian coal mines continued today at Novosibirsk while the government press called for destruction of "these Trotskyist murderers and mad dogs," just as when Gregory Zinovieff, Leon Kameneff and their fourteen fellow-defendants went on trial here last Summer in proceedings that ended in their execution.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- The United States Government received indirectly today a warning from General Francisco Franco, commander of the Rebel forces in Spain, to keep all American naval and commercial vessels from Barcelona, but chose to ignore it. In so doing, it recognized in no way the legitimacy of General Franco's declaration of a blockade of that port.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Internal revenue collections for the first four months of the 1937 fiscal year amounted to $1,209,242,231, an increase of $171,552,487, or about 16 1/2 per cent, over the same period of 1935, the Treasury announced today.

PARIS, Nov. 20 (AP). -- Fury over the suicide of Roger Salengro, Minister of the Interior, was intensified today as anarchists slapped up lurid posters throughout the city advocating an "armed struggle if necessary" against fascism.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

At this time of the year much is usually heard in Wall Street of sales of stocks to establish losses for income-tax purposes. Thus far little has been done along this line, aside from sporadic selling of railroad and public-utility stocks by investors who have held them several years.

I was interested to read the letter which appeared in a recent issue of THE TIMES relative to the proposed plan of "living probate," advocated by Harry Kutscher, whereby testators should prove the authenticity of their own wills during lifetime, leaving the documents in the custody of the court until their death unless previously revoked by them.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 20. -- No Sir, first to lower the colors of the champion, Pompoon, will be favored tomorrow in the $2,500 added Endurance Handicap for juveniles. Ten were named overnight and the son of Sortie will have top weight of 121 pounds to handle over the mile and seventy yards.

Mrs. Arthur J. Morgan gave a luncheon yesterday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for her niece, Miss Virginia Ehret, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Ehret. The other guests were the Misses Helen Kronkhite, Lathrop Allen, Hope Stevens, Carla Eakin, Janet Clark, Marion Fountain, Lisa Mabon, Eleanor Young, Catherine Reily, Eleanor Hoguet, Silvia, Gould, Sophie Kilbreth, Joan Long, Glenny Oelsner and Phoebe Steers.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 20. -- Despite the silence of Premier Milan Stoyadinoviteh and the strict censorship of the press it is becoming clear that the Vienna conference dealt a severe blow to Yugoslav hopes for increased economic relations with Italy.

MOSCOW, Nov. 20. -- The Soviet Government, through Ambassador Constantin Yureneff, has informed the Japanese Government that the Japanese explanation of the Tokyo-Berlin agreement for common action against communism, which the Soviet believes masks a secret anti-Soviet military pact, is unsatisfactory and that such an agreement will seriously damage Soviet-Japanese relations.

The International Hydro-Electric System and subsidiaries reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $499,061 for the year ended on Sept. 30 after all deductions, contrasting with $1,176,049 for the preceding year. Gross revenue was $64,135,588, compared to $62,979,918.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20. -- Dr. Harold L. Moulton, head of the Brookings Institution in Washington, said in a speech here today that a recovery in industrial production in the United States in the next five years to the level of 1929 would bring about a labor shortage which would be acute in some lines.

TORONTO, Nov. 20 (Canadian Press). -- The stork derby clause of Charles Vance Millar's will, bequeathing a $500,000 fortune to the Toronto mother bearing the most children in a ten-year period ended Oct. 31, was adjudged valid today by Justice W.E. Middleton in the Toronto Supreme Court.
Several small commercial buildings, various houses and numerous alterations were listed in the building plans filed yesterday, as follows:
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 20. -- A three-judge Federal court held here today that Ohio's minimum wage law for women and children in certain industries did not violate the Federal Constitution.

The New York State Athletic Commission made it clear yesterday that James J. Braddock would be liable to suspension in this State if he signed to fight Joe Louis in a no-decision bout before agreeing to defend his heavyweight championship of the world against Max Schmeling.

In his speech on the lower East Side a few weeks ago President ROOSEVELT declared his belief in a joint effort by private capital and "city, State and Federal governments" to help solve the problem of providing slum-dwellers with decent housing. For the benefit of the Mayors' Conference, Secretary ICKES has now described the Administration's new program in greater detail.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 20 (AP). -- Northwestern will lay down its last barrage in the campaign for national gridiron honors tomorrow.

The strike of drivers on the Avenue B and East Broadway Transit Company's lines on the lower East Side still was unsettled yesterday, although the company operated a few of its buses under police protection. Benjamin Greenberg, president of the concern, drove one of the buses himself.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20. -- The Princeton varsity soccer team clinched the Middle Atlantic States League championship, defeating Pennsylvania 3 -- 2 today while Haverford lost its match to Swarthmore.
After two years of activity in the Brooklyn market, Louis Schleifer, operator, entered the Manhattan field yesterday by purchasing two tall apartment buildings.

BOSTON COLLEGE vs. BOSTON UNIVERSITY -- Papa Vollard came over from Paris to open the Cezanne exhibition at the Bignou Gallery. He wears a beard and a beret, both unnecessary in this climate, One clean-shaven vote for Boston College.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Shipment of supplies to Hawaii and Alaska by government vessels in case of a food shortage resulting from the maritime strike on the Pacific Coast today was under consideration by four of the ten departments.

About 1,000 striking seamen marched yesterday afternoon in an unbroken line about the block in which the offices of the International Seaman's Union are located, demanding that the union hall be thrown open to them for a meeting.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- The recently completed North Transept parclose, or sculptured stone screen, in Washington Cathedral, including two stained-glass windows and the stairway leading to the crypt chapels, was formally dedicated this afternoon as a memorial to William Thomas Hildrip Jr. of Harrisburg, Pa.

PASSAIC, N.J., Nov. 20. -- The uneasy conscience of a material witness to a hit-and-run automobile accident here brought him and the driver of the car into custody today, eleven days after the accident. Police Chief Charles Monks had found virtually no clues to what he called one of the "most brutal hit-and-run cases" that ever occurred in this city.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Employment in industry reached a higher level in the month ending Oct. 15 than at any time since 1930, Secretary Perkins announced today. There was a correspondingly sharp increase in total payrolls.

Pre-Thanksgiving sermons will be preached in the synagogues today and in the churches tomorrow. From many pulpits the Thanksgiving proclamation of President Roosevelt will be read. Donations of food or of money to purchase dinners for the poor of the parishes will be asked.

The volume of new bond financing this week was the largest for such a period in more than a month, amounting to $102,233,000. It represented five major classifications. The amount compared with $47,363,000 offered last week. A year ago this week new bond financing was $177,549,000.

In the belief that more than 40 per cent of the 150,000 who die from cancer every year could be saved if proper treatment were given in time, men and women interested in combating cancer opened a national drive here yesterday to organize a Women's Field Army for "a war to save human life."

A combination of architectural symmetry and structural utility was revealed yesterday as the goal sought by the Port of New York Authority in its design of the spacious approach in Weehawken, N.J., to the Hudson Midtown Tunnel.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 20. -- With all of the tradition and background that the game holds, the football teams of Yale and Harvard come together again tomorrow for the fifty-fifth time in the sixty-one years these universities have been meeting each other on the gridiron.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 20. -- Yale teams triumphed in four out of five contests with Big Three rivals today, but the Blue's greatest victory came when the Eli lightweight football forces turned back Princeton's eleven, 8 -- 0, to carry off the championship of the Eastern Intercollegiate 150-pound League and the Foster Sanford Trophy.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 20. -- The discussions of the relief problem, the major deliberations of the twenty-second annual convention of the New Jersey League of Municipalities which came to a close here today, were climaxed with a warning by Samuel S. Kenworthy, executive secretary of the organization, that this State must be prepared to provide $15,000,000 for relief in 1937 to augment municipal contributions.

Holders of $10,000,000 of five-year 6 per cent secured notes due on Aug. 1, 1937, of the Consolidated Electric and Gas Company, have been asked to approve a proposal for a twenty-year extension of the notes by means of an exchange for the same principal amount of underlying collateral trust 6 per cent series bond due in 1957.

NORWICH, N.Y., Nov. 20 (AP). -- A county court jury today freed Gus Turkett, 36, and Roscoe Coons, 34, of kidnapping charges in connection with the disappearance of Mrs. Ora Wager Morse, 25-year-old Norwich school teacher, early last July.
The air, land and sea forces of the Police Department and the Coast Guard competed yesterday to save a small boy from death, and the air contingent won.

Today is the last day that employers have to return the Social Security forms, SS-4. that will set up their account numbers and indicate the number of application forms each employer will need for his employes, Pastmaster Albert Goldman warned in an address broadcast last night over WMAC.

The new C.T. Loo Galleries opened to the public yesterday at 41 East Fifty-seventh Street (the Fuller Building). In an attractive setting porcelains that belong to many dynasties are shown. Some pieces produced as early as the era between 2852 and 2205 B.C. are in Mr. Loo's possession, though these have not been put in the cases.

Plans for the organization of a national association of race track operators, the first of its kind in American turf history, were started yesterday at a meeting of operators representing twenty-eight associations at the Biltmore Hotel.

MAURICE MASCHKE, Republican boss of Cleveland for sixteen years, immersed in politics for more than a generation, loved the game as well as he loved bridge. He was a quiet and an intelligent representative of what for the moment seems a dying type. Once the Republicans had most of the bosses.

A plot 75 by 83 by 97 by 28 feet on the west side of Rosedale Avenue between Eastern Boulevard and Story Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the estate of Bradish Johnson to Louise Cannavo. Charles Rubinstein was the broker.

MADRID, Nov. 20 (Censored). -- Fighting was renewed this afternoon in University City in a chill, drizzling rain. The medical school and the Casa Velasquez, the French students' residence, were afire.

Victorious in all his twenty-four bouts since embarking on a career as an amateur boxer, Dennis Deegan of the Long Island Moose Club had the impressive string of conquests broken last night at the Hippodrome.

Fordham hopes to make another advance along the road to the Rose Bowl today. The Rams face Georgia at the Polo Grounds, and a crowd of 45,000 is expected to watch Jimmy Crowley's men defend their unbeaten record. The kick-off will be at 2 P.M.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20. -- A hope that regulations would be completed soon covering the pegging of prices of securities during the period of their distribution to the public was voiced today by Ernest Angell of New York, Regional Administrator for the Securities and Exchange Commission, in all address before the Philadelphia Association of Security Salesmen.

Japan abhors war and is doing its best to approach social and economic equilibrium through the expansion of its industry and foreign trade, Hirosi Saito, Japanese Ambassador to the United States, said last night at the annual sales conference dinner of the Pepperell Manufacturing Company in the Hotel Pierre.

Institutional advertising campaigns by industry have been accepted as quite common this year, but the use of them by labor unions is a new development. This week the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America took full-page space in one newspaper here to explain itself to the public, "just for the sake of having the 'other half' understand unionism better," according to one executive.

HENRY COLLINS BROWN, who is the founder of the Museum of the City of New York, and a "human-interest historian," has written another genial book about our metropolis. He calls it "From Alley Pond to Rockefeller Center" (Dutton, $3.50), thus indicating the breadth of his interest. Alley Pond, in case you are as ignorant of it as was I, is in the Little Neck section of Queens County, some twenty miles from Rockefeller Center.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 20. -- Dr. Oswaldo Aranha, Brazilian Ambassador to the United States, will fight the political battle of his life at Bahia tomorrow with the Presidency of Brazil as the possible prize. His conference there with President Getulio Vargas will probably determine whether Dr. Aranha will be the successor to the mantle the President is expected to discard in 1938.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 20. -- A touchdown in the opening minutes of play provided the margin of victory for the Princeton junior varsity football team today as it downed the Penn jayvees, 7 -- 0, on University Field.

A report on experimental studies of the causes of vibration in ships was delivered to the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, meeting in the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street, yesterday, by Professor Frank M. Lewis of Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

A broad down trend was reflected by almost all classes of bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The turnover, too, increased total transactions amounting to $15,328,600, compared with $12,651,100 on Thursday.

A marked drop in pedestrian fatalities due to motor vehicles in the streets of Manhattan, has been noted by the Police Department since the speeding up of the light intervals at intersections, put into effect a month ago.

Jimmy McLarnin beat another champion last night. The baby-faced welterweight from Vancouver, B.C., who has made it a habit during his ring career to register triumphs over reigning titleholders, outpointed Lou Ambers, king of the lightweight division, in a ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden.

BOSTON, Nov. 20. -- My Own Roderic, a red and white cocker spaniel, bred, owned and shown in the ring by Herman E. Mellenthin of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., tonight was named best of winners in the famous $1,000 Big Four Novice Stake at the annual specialty show of the Cocker Spaniel Breeders Club of New England in Horticultural Hall.

ARISTIDE BRIAND at one time cherished a vision of the United States of Europe. Recent events have caused it to recede deeper into the background of dreamland. For at least two years it has seemed impossible to obtain in Europe common support for an international policy.

The proposed seaway from the Great Lakes to New York City by way of Montreal Lake Champlain and the Hudson River would seriously injure railroads and steamship lines serving the Atlantic seaboard area, opponents of the project declared yesterday at a public hearing conducted by the international joint commission considering the advisability of the plan.

BARCELONA, Spain, Nov. 20. -- The Catalan War Ministry has announced the capture of Mount Purburell, a strongly fortified Insurgent position on the Aragon front facing the government line at Bujaralozcaspe, about thirty-six miles from Saragossa. Several trucks and "a military train bringing forces from Saragossa" are reported to have been destroyed.

Hannes Schneider, widely known figure of the skiing world, arrived yesterday on the Bremen of the North German Lloyd Line. Accompanying him were Benno Rybizka and Otto Lang, two of the twenty-five teachers under Schneider's guidance at his Arlberg school in St. Anton, Austria.
NANKING, China, Nov. 20. -- With negotiations for settlement of outstanding Chino-Japanese issues at a virtual standstill, the relations between the two countries seem mounting toward a new crisis.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20. -- Recommendations covering a broad range of current problems in international commerce comprised the final declaration adopted here today at the closing session of the National Foreign Trade Convention. The statement, with its suggestions, will be transmitted to President Roosevelt and members of Congress as the studied opinion of the nation's exporters on questions affecting foreign trade.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 20. -- One of the strongest Dartmouth teams in years invades Palmer Stadium tomorrow to engage a Princeton eleven that has been hard hit in the back field by injuries. This will be the wind-up game of the season for both contestants.

Governor Lehman received 1,803,429 votes in New York City in the recent election to 874,087 cast for his Republican opponent, William F. Bleakley, it was shown in the official canvass of the gubernatorial vote made public yesterday by the Board of Elections.

There is one broad aspect of the Social Security Act that gives it an overwhelming appeal to those who wish to preserve harmony and well-being throughout the nation, those who fear a too-sudden break with the immediate past and those in particular whose skin prickles at the mention of the word communism.

Charles S. Haight, admiralty attorney of the firm of Haight, Griffin, Deming Gardner, expressed disapproval yesterday of the law being put forward in Brazil for the government regulation of freight rates, saying that such fixing of rates would hamper the shipping industry.

Evening up of outstanding accounts in December cotton before notices on Tuesday furnished most of the trading yesterday on the Cotton Exchange. Prices held in a narrow range to end with a gain of 1 to a loss of 6 points. Undoing of a straddle interest in Liverpool caused a decline in the near months there, compared with a slight gain in the distant positions.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- The stock market here was slightly easier today under the influence of dullness in Wall Street. British Government issues were virtually unchanged. Active dealings took place in the new 100,000,000 government funding loan.

The fifty-first season of the Boston Symphony Orchestra in Brooklyn opened last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Dr. Serge Koussevitzky, conductor, opened his program with Mozart's Symphony in A Major, followed by Stravinsky's "The Fairy's Kiss," and Cesar Franck's Symphony in D Minor.

Stockholders of the Standard Cap and Seal Corporation will take action on Dec. 11 on a proposal to re-capitalize the company by changing each of the 211,005 outstanding shares of $5 par value common stock into one-half share of convertible preference stock of $10 par value and one share of common of $1 par value.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 20. -- With indications of a crowd of 30,000 for tomorrow's climax game with Colgate. Syracuse's football squad today ended its practice with a short signal drill.

George Graham Rice, who went to prison in 1928 for defrauding the public of several million dollars "invested" in stock of the Idaho Copper Corporation, was a fugitive from justice yesterday, a warrant having been issued for his arrest as a parole violator.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- The Pacific Finance Corporation of California has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 35,000 shares of $100-par, 5 per cent, cumulative preferred stock, with common stock purchase warrants for 35,000 shares attached, and 35,000 shares of $10-par common to be issued upon exercise of the warrants.

With members convinced that the college athletic situation today is "more reprehensible than ever before," the trustees' executive committee of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching has been charged with the duty of deciding whether the foundation will undertake another exposure of professionalism and kindred ills in the operating of the athletic systems in the colleges of the country.

New York University's heavily favored eleven will meet City College this afternoon on the turf of the Yankee Stadium. It will be the eighth contest of the season for the Violet while for the Beavers it closes the campaign. The opening kick-off is listed for 2 P.M.

Stanford's Tiny Thornhill, the man who prefers coaching psychology to a good pass defense, is bringing his Indians East to meet Columbia Nov. 28 and I am wondering if we can help the invaders from the Coast with a little manufactured weather.

There were no upsets in the first knockout round for the contract bridge tournament for the Vanderbilt Cup last night at the Hotel Commodore. It was expected that the Four Aces would win comfortably, though not by quite so impressive a score as they made.

The first public meeting to inform members of Protestant churches of the crisis confronting several thousand German refugees of the Christian faith will be held tomorrow at 3:30 P.M. in the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area continued notably active during the week. An average increase of about 15 to 18 per cent over the comparative 1935 period was estimated for department stores. Gains in apparel volume were again outstanding, with some stores noting increases ranging up to 25 per cent or more.

TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 20. -- In its first formal convention move against the Committee for Industrial Organization the American Federation of Labor voted today a boycott of the union label of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, an affiliate of the Committee for Industrial Organization.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Bert Acosta, one of this country's leading racing pilots, and four other fliers from fields in the Newark district have arrived at Valencia, Spain, where they will go through a hurried course in military flying before taking the air against the Rebels, it was revealed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP). -- The cotton spinning industry was reported today by the Census Bureau to have operated during October at 123.3 per cent of capacity, compared with 125.8 per cent during September this year and 103.8 per cent during October last year.

The stock market reflected confused opinion yesterday regarding the probable trend of prices in the immediate future and moved indecisively most of the day. More than ever, each issue appeared to be "on its own"; group movements were never very pronounced.
WINDSOR, Conn., Nov. 20. -- The Loomis football team, handicapped by the injuries to several of its best players, succumbed today to a powerful Deerfield eleven, 26 to 0, on its home field.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- After hearing the present British divorce system ridiculed as "archaic" and the institution of the King's Proctor as "a farce," the House of Commons today gave a second reading to a private member's bill making sweeping reforms in the divorce laws.

An investigation into the legal status of the Communist party as a national organization automatically entitled to a place on the ballot in a national election will be started soon by the Daughters of the American Revolution, it was announced yesterday.

DUBLIN, Nov. 20. -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's visit to the Irish Free State with the United States and British air chiefs has been surrounded by government authorities with the utmost secrecy. This is attributed merely to the flier's distaste for publicity.

Five Manhattan properties sold at foreclosure auctions yesterday included the fifteen-story Downing Building, surrounding the southeast corner of Fulton and Dutch Streets. A four-story house at 116 East Seventy-sixth Street went to the plaintiff, an estate, and two defendants holding a mortgage.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20. -- Conducting his final Friday afternoon concert until next Spring, Leopold Stokowski led the Philadelphia orchestra today in the American premiere of a three-movement symphony by Tikhon Chrennikoff, young Soviet composer.

The following sentence wound up a story in THE TIMES by James Abbe, a photographer in Spain: "And yet they all appeared to have had some idea of the personal risks they ran in undertaking a proletarian revolution when the world proletariat is, after all, a minority group."

Christmas bonuses for some 35,000 employes of Stock Exchange firms will be substantially larger than last year, despite the recent decline in the price of Stock Exchange memberships, a survey in Wall Street indicated yesterday. In some cases bonuses will be twice as large as last year, and the total distribution will be the largest of any year since the depression.

Edward Ryan, who is 30 years old and already has served two prison terms, did an odd thing early yesterday morning. Living at 654 East 233d Street, the Bronx, he went over to a tavern at 613, on the same street, and stayed quite a long time. The proprietor, George Mayer, finally had to hint that it was closing time, before Ryan left.

Two powerful looking, well-dressed men, apparently unarmed and indifferent to the thousands of persons in the neighborhood, last night attacked the ticket seller in the East Forty-second Street offices of the Transcontinental and Western Airways, opposite Grand Central Terminal, and escaped with $1,200.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- The opera "Pickwick," by Albert Coates, which had its premiere world performance at Covent Garden tonight, proved a dismal failure. It is neither light, grand nor comic. There are three acts and twelve scenes.
John Alexander's letter in last Saturday's TIMES on college football as played forty years ago carried me back to my own college days, which were of that time.

New State and municipal financing, scheduled for next week, amounts to only $8,179,836, for forty-one municipalities. This compares with the revised total for this week of $40,580,000. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date is $27,378,947.

Justices Bayes, Hackenburg and Salomon in Special Sessions yesterday, on the recommendation of James J. Wilson, Assistant District Attorney, dismissed an "information" against the Davega-City Radio, Inc., and two of its officials, Abram Davega and Herman H. Stein.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 20. -- On the strength of reports from various parts of the country, showing a rising demand for small homes and farms, members of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, in convention here, laid plans today to handle what they believe will be a vast market for these types of properties during the coming year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- The renewed drive of private business to absorb the remaining unemployed, and thus to join President Roosevelt in solving the greatest continuing problem of his administration, was given still further impetus today by three developments in Washington.
ALBANY, Nov. 20. -- Acting Governor M. William Bray issued a Thanksgiving proclamation tonight in the absence of Governor Lehman, who is spending a vacation in California.

BERLIN, Nov. 20. -- The Boerse was paralyzed today, showing only a tendency to weakness. Fears of expropriation in connection with the foreign security deposit regulations had not disappeared. The leading financial paper refers to the new deposits in the Reichsbank's subsidiary as "valuable foreign exchange reserves."

BOSTON, Nov. 20 (AP). -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The wool market has been more or less excited during the past week and prices have tended steadily upward, so that best fine domestic wools have crossed the dollar mark, clean basis, quite easily.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio., Nov 20 (AP). -- Frank Purnell, president of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, announced today improvements costing about $10,000,000 at the Campbell, Brier Hill and Chicago plants.

WITH INSURGENT ARMY, Near Madrid, Nov. 20. -It is now known that more than sixty heavy projectiles were dropped in yesterday's devastating air raid on Madrid. Every detail of the action, which commenced early in the morning, could be followed from the Insurgent lines.
The Charity Organization Society celebrated yesterday its fifty-fourth anniversary with a Town Hall mass meeting at which contributions totaling $53,500 were announced toward the family service fund.

The National Industrial Traffic League, as representative of the nation's principal shippers, went on record yesterday at the final session of its annual convention, held in the Hotel Pennsylvania, as opposing legislative moves which would subject Interstate Commerce Commission decisions to court review.

Magistrate Louis B. Brodsky looked down from his bench in Jefferson Market Court yesterday morning on the hopeful faces of the three principals in the case against Mrs. Serena Alves, Negro "mammy," whose custody of little Lucy Peluso, a 5-year-old white child, was under question, and said, "Case dismissed."

To judge from the interest displayed in the National Automobile Show and the supplementary exhibitions of 1937 cars in New York's hotels during the past week, there can be little question of a banner year for the automobile industry. By its courage in the face of depression, and by the real improvements for safety, comfort and ease of driving which it has incorporated in its products, that industry has earned the gratitude of the nation.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 20. -- The government announced tonight that President Roosevelt would land at Mar del Plata Nov. 30 when he comes here to address the opening session of the inter-American peace conference, and gave out the definite program form his three-day sojourn.

Herman L. Berger, treasurer of the Deputy Fish and Game Wardens Association of Hudson Couney, N.J., tells us that a fellow who isn't afraid of risking a mild case of chilblains can grab a mess of wall-eyed pike these days by taking a spin up to the Delaware River. Odd the way these fishing fanatics refuse to give up the ghost.

J.B. Priestley is completing a book on America. It is called "Midnight on the Desert" and tells of a Winter spent in the Far West and in New York. Harpers will publish this book in the Spring. The publishers say that, according to reports from England, Mr. Priestley's "They Walk in the City" has been the best selling novel in England this year.

Holders of common stock of the Halle Brothers Company of Cleveland have been called to act on Nov. 30 on a plan of exchange and financing in connection with a new issue of convertible preferred stock. The present 6 per cent bond issues are to be replaced by a new issue of $2,750,000 of bonds bearing lower interest rates, to be sold to an insurance company and a bank.

In the verbal economic battles of recent years few figures have been more often quoted than the statistics of family income as compiled by the Brookings Institution. In recent years we have had a perfect barrage of figures to show how low the income of this or that percentage of the population really is.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20. -- Prices of hogs generally showed little change today although some sales of lights were regarded as 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight higher than yesterday. Demand was fairly active. The day's top was steady at $9.75 and the average was unchanged at $9.45.

MANILA, Nov. 20 (AP). -- Advices from Jolo tonight reported the sudden death of the newly installed Sultan of Sulu and returned to the limelight his powerful rival, Princess Dayang Dayang, who contested his right to the throne.

PEIPING, China, Nov. 20. -- Japan is "vitally interested" in the present hostilities in Suiyuan Province but they are still China's internal problem, a Japanese spokesman in Peiping said today, adding his belief that the conflict was a result of disagreements between the Chinese and Mongols over the exact status of the Mongol Autonomous Council.

PLUM BAYOU, Ark., Nov. 20. -- "A promised land" where tenants and share-croppers may one day own the farms they now cultivate for others was held out today to the "underprivileged" farmers of the nation by Secretary Wallace and Under-Secretary of Agriculture Rexford G. Tugwell in speeches dedicating the Resettlement Administration's Wright Plantation Project here.

Today's program of approximately fifty games in the metropolitan district will accelerate considerably the exodus from the current scholastic football arena. For the past two weeks major prep schools have been winding up their schedules and this afternoon their lead will be followed by numerous high school elevens.

Stanley Baldwin, Prime Minister of Great Britain, was right when he said last Spring that women don't tell. Happily, though tardily, a soprano chorus was lifted yesterday in the Woman's Forum at the Hotel Roosevelt in acclamation of the assertion of the statesman that women have no monopoly on tongues that hang loosely and wag unwarily about important secrets.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 20. -- With six straight victories to his credit as the result of play in tonight's session of the International Chess Masters Tournament at the Club Ajedrez de San Juan, Isaac 1. Kashdan, champion of New York State, needs only to draw his last remaining game to make sure of first prize.
The brothers Styka, Tade and Adam, are having a joint exhibition at the John Levy Galleries, 1 East Fifty-seventh Street. The show opened yesterday and will continue until Dec. 12.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Nov. 20. -- After a long round of official entertainments yesterday, which extended far into the night, Secretary of State Cordell Hull and the other members of the United States delegation to the inter-American peace conference in Buenos Aires resumed their journey to the Argentine capital on the liner American Legion at 6 P.M. today.
Here is an unpleasant experience that I had at Madison Square Garden on Sunday:

With Mayor La Guardia absent, the Board of Estimate branch of the Municipal Assembly voted yesterday to adopt the bill introduced by Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx making three years' consecutive residence in the city a requirement for appointment to city positions.
Opportunity knocked twice for the Milford School eleven yesterday and the Connecticut youngsters heeded the last call to wrest a 7-0 decision from the Horace Mann School team at the losers' field.

If E.P. Conkle had not chosen an absorbing topic to write about in "200 Were Chosen," which was acted at the Forty-eighth Street last evening, a reviewer's task would be simple. He could damn the play as a hodge-podge of theatre and go home with a restful conscience.

BARCELONA, Spain, Nov. 20. -- General Buenaventura Durruti, anarchist leader of the government forces at Saragossa in the early days of the revolt, has been killed aiding in the defense of Madrid, it was reported here today.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Nov. 20. -- Mrs. Julius Bliss's capable chestnut gelding Tupelo tonight established himself as the outstanding contender for the hunter championship as the second day of the sixth annual Peekskill Horse Show was concluded.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that the steadily increasing number of dividends on listed securities declared or likely to be declared for payment before Dec. 31 had reached such proportions as to tax the facilities of transfer and dividend disbursing agencies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP). -- Arguments on the constitutionality of the Ashurst-Sumners act barring transportation of prison-made products into States which prohibit their sale were presented today to the Supreme Court.
NEW CASTLE, Ky., Nov. 20 (AP). -- Kentucky's picturesque military figure, Brig. Gen. Henry H. Denhardt, was ordered sent to jail today after his examining trial on a charge of murdering his fiancee.

BERLIN, Nov. 20. -- The old, respected German military weekly Militar Wochenblatt carries in its most recent edition an article indicating that the tanks and armored cars used by the United States Army are second rate by European standards.
COLUMBIA, Mo., Nov. 21 (AP). -- The University of Missouri won the State football championship today by defeating Washington University of St. Louis, 17 to 10, before 12,000 spectators.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Nov. 21. -- With six fires in as many days, all of which the police believe were of incendiary origin, the citizens of Sea Cliff are canceling engagements to remain on guard in their homes. Squads of special detectives are helping the village police in their efforts to seize those responsible for the wave of terror which has swept over the village.
Corporate dividends declared yesterday aggregated $7,500,000, lifting the estimated total for the week to $260,000,000, and for the month to $607,500,000.

WHEN Mabel Dodge Luhan announced that she was about to write some intimate memories her friends and former friends must have braced themselves, for when Mrs. Luhan says intimate that is more or less what she means.
CARLISLE, Pa., Nov. 21. -- Muhlenberg rallied late in the final quarter to gain a 13-13 deadlock with Dickinson College on Biddle Field today in the season's finale before more than 3,000 spectators.

There is treason aplenty in the old house on Washington Square which is the scene of the most significant events in this story. Almost everybody in it is engaged in double-crossing somebody else. When Jeffrey Keene blunders into the house and is made an involuntary member of the organization that has its headquarters there, he is puzzled by the contradictory things he learns about the aims of the organization and the actions of its members.

I wonder if you would let me use the columns of THE TIMES to correct what seems to be a prevailing journalistic misapprehension, even though THE TIMES itself has been less guilty in the matter than have other newspapers and magazines.

Examples chosen for this illustrative birdseye view of Greek sculpture constitute a comprehensive, though of course by no means inclusive, collection, ranging all the way from the "geometric" style of the ninth and eighth centuries B.C., to the last, often painfully realistic, accomplishments, which are really Hellenistic rather than Greek in the strict sense.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21. -- The Drexel Tech eleven closed its season by defeating Swarthmore College, 32 -- 0, today. It was Drexel's sixth victory in nine games and Swarthmore's fifth loss in seven.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 21. -- The breath-holding championship of the football season went to 60 per cent of 60,000 fans in the Yale Bowl today.

Now is the season when Federal, State and city authorities are taking their pencils from behind their ears and trying to figure the amount of money they will have to spend next year on unemployment relief. In the columns of the S.C.A.A. News, published by the State Charities Aid Association of this city.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 21. -- Reports by regional vice presidents showing rising real estate activity in nearly all parts of the country were features of the closing sessions of the convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards here today.

Miss Jennie Caputo, 18-year-old gymnast from the National Turners of Newark, performing with all the grace of a veteran, captured the women's national championship when she finished ahead of a select group of competitors at the Twenty-third Street Y.M.C.A. last night.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 21. -- Brown battled its way to a 19-to-6 victory over a fighting Colby eleven today. The accurate passing of Hall, Brown left halfback, led to two of the touchdowns.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 21. -- The destroying Dukes of little Duquesne University crushed unbeaten Marquette into submission, 13 to 0, in a thrill-filled gridiron spectacle staged before 27,000 fans today, the second time this year the Night Riders have shattered the Rose Bowl aspirations of a major opponent.
OWEN SOUND, Ont., Nov. 21 (Canadian Press). -- The motor ship Hibou heeled suddenly and sank in Georgian Bay about 5 o'clook this morning, drowning the captain, the stewardess and five semen.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica. -- Political opponents of General Anastasio Somoza in Nicaragua, General Jorge Ubico in Guatemala and General Tiburcio Carias in Honduras are pointing out that the election of the first and the re-election of the other two to the Presidencies of their countries will create a problem for Washington under the terms of the Washington pact of 1923.

LONDON, Nov. 21. -- Hardly had the kilted and excited audience left the crowded theatre in Edinburgh tonight for gala supper parties when it was announced here that C.B. Cochran had made theatrical history and concluded a record box office deal for the run of "Boy David" here.

The social service committee of the women's board of the Church Charity Foundation will give a tea Tuesday for the benefit of the United Hospital campaign in St. John's Hospital, 480 Herkimer Street, Brooklyn. The Rt. Rev. Ernest M. Stires, Bishop of the Protestant Epicopal Diocese of Long Island, former Supreme Court Justice Stephen Callaghan and Mrs. Tracy Voorhees will be guests of honor.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 21. -- The question of the exact shape of the earth will be the cause of a scientific expedition into the Caribbean Sea in December and early January under conditions as different from those of the trips of Magellan and Columbus, who sought an answer to the same question, as the four centuries which separate the trips, it was revealed here today.

THE first book to appear under the joint imprint of Harper's and the Story Press will be Ignazio Silone's new novel, "Bread and Wine." It will be published in the early Spring. In Switzerland, where a German edition has just come out, it has been hailed as a "masterpiece," and in Paris its realism is compared to the "best chapters in Zola's novels."

PAUL HORGAN, once winner of the Harper's Prize for his novel, "The Fault of Angels," brings together in this new book a group of short stories about New Mexico. As the title implies, and the Argument and Resolution state specifically, the theme of these stories is that in the unequal battle of man against nature lies man's glory and tragedy.

The boycott voted by the American Federation of Labor against clothing bearing the label of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America was condemned by the Amalgamated yesterday as "an act of rash impotency."

WILD ducks may escape gunfire only to die of lead poisoning. They scoop up shot as they dabble for food in marshes. Four or five lead pellets are enough to kill. In the records of the Biological Survey there is an account of one duck that had 288 shot of various sizes in its gizzard.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- Great Britain's $2,000,000,000 rearmament machine rumbled along this week, creaking in many of its joints, while the din of public dissatisfaction grew louder every hour. The Ministers tried to their utmost to be reassuring, but they could not silence the clamor.

Commodity futures generally were stronger during the week ended on Friday, and several were at the best level for the year. The cash markets also were strong, the only declines appearing in cotton, raw sugar and tin. Gains were recorded in all grains, lard, butter, eggs, wooltops, hides, rubber, silk, printcloths, lead, zinc, coffee and cocoa.
THE murder of Sir Edmund Godfrey took place in 1678. Its mystery has never been solved. The history of the affair constitutes, says John Dickson Carr, "a very nearly perfect detective story."

Fordham's Rose Bowl dreams were rudely shattered by the tenacious Georgia Bulldogs at the Polo Grounds yesterday as the oft-beaten Southerners held the undefeated Rams to a 7-7 tie. While a crowd of 35,000, preponderantly Fordham in its allegiance, looked on, the Maroon went into a tailspin and Georgia profited thereby.

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 21. -- Climaxing a season which started with defeat and disappointment and ended in sensational victories, the University of California's Bears defeated their oldest football rivals, Stanford's Indians, 20 to 0, today before a capacity crowd of 82,000 fans.
TOKYO, Nov. 21. -- Nowhere else in the world save in Eastern Asia could a tense situation remain tense for three months and absolutely nothing happen.

NOT all the theatre news is gloomy. The Nobel Prize has been awarded to Eugene O'Neill, and that is an item worth celebrating. What his own countrymen think of him has been confirmed by the savants of Stockholm, who perform their annual office at some distance from our battlefield.

WASHINGTON. Though men outnumber women by more than 20,000 in the army of Federal workers in the District of Columbia, the ratio of women to men is much higher in the capital than it is among Federal employes in the field.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 21 (AP). -- The University of North Carolina Tar Heels defeated South Carolina's stubborn sophomore football team today, 14 to 0, before a home-coming day crowd of 10,000 spectators.

Women representing various faiths and creeds will conduct the annual sale of the handicraft work of the blind to be opened under the general chairmanship of Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman on Nov. 30, continuing through Dec. 24. Fourteen committees of volunteers from as many churches are cooperating.

WITH the publication of the eighty-seventh unit in the sectional aeronautical charts of the Department of Commerce, there now is a chart especially designed for the airman's use for any part of the United States, Eugene L. Vidal, director of Air Commerce, pointed out last week.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Labor and employers in industry are again waging a hot battle over the ever-elastic consumer's dollar.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 21. -- Luther C. Steward, president of the National Federation of Federal Employes, predicted here today that the civil service and merit system would be expanded to include most of the 200,000 civil servants added to the Federal payroll during the New Deal.

A flood of white cards poured into postoffices in the five boroughs last night as the deadline for the return of applications for employer identification numbers under the Federal Social Security Act passed. So great was the volume of response that postal authorities predicted that more than 80 per cent of the 550,000 employer forms distributed here would have been accounted for at the opening of business tomorrow.

THEY will celebrate the first birthday of "Boy Meets Girl" at the Cort Theatre next Friday night with a cake from the Waldorf, a case of Scotch from a firm that gets its name among the credits in the program and with dancing on the stage.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 21. -- A poll taken this week at Wesleyan University reveals that 80 per cent of the student body favors abolition of compulsory chapel attendance.

LAKELAND, Fla., Nov. 20. -- Advocates of the 200-mile ship canal across Florida have won another victory in their persistent campaign to obtain money from Washington for completion of the project, which ostensibly was abandoned two months ago after $5,400,000 had been spent on it.

PROVIDENCE, Nov. 21. -- The success of Brown University's "five-year plan" of teacher preparation is shown by the increasing number of schools which ask the university to supply teachers, and in the high percentage of students trained in education at Brown who now hold responsible positions, Professor C. Emanuel Ekstrom, chairman of the Department of Education, reported today.

Miss Katharine A. Righter will entertain at her home, 42 Monroe Place, Brooklyn, Tuesday afternoon, for members of the Brooklyn Children's Museum Auxiliary sponsoring a benefit program in the Academy of Music on Jan. 15.

EASTPORT, Me., Nov. 21. -- Apparently aware of rumors that operations on the Passamaquoddy tidal power project will be revived within the next few weeks or months. Captain Samuel D. Sturgis Jr., engineer in charge here, made a statement today relative to the increased activity on the project.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP). -- Grain Belt farm sentiment for revision of the administration's soil conservation program to permit expanded plantings of wheat and corn next year was reported today by the AAA.

New York University came through in the second half to turn back a surprising City College eleven at the Yankee Stadium yesterday. The Violet aggregation, after yielding a touchdown in the first period, encountered most stubborn and unlooked-for opposition before tying the count in the second.

LONDON, Nov. 21. -- General Francisco Franco has notified the British Government that the security zone in Madrid that his Insurgents undertake not to bomb or shell has been extended to include the British and American Embassics and those of other countries. But he made no mention of the establishment of a safety zone in Barcelona, about which Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden had made urgent inquiry.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP). -- Five New Deal cases rested tonight in the hands of the Supreme Court, with decisions on all possible by Dec. 7.

HOLLYWOOD HAZARD: The ephemeral nature of fame and fortune in the movies was quantitatively described last week -- from an insurance man's viewpoint -- at the Fall meeting in New York of the Home Office Life Insurance Underwriters Association. "In 1920," said Vice President L.W. Morgan of Pacific Mutual Life, "we insured twenty persons of first magnitude, most of them actors and actresses.

Announcement was made yesterday of a junior committee for the theatre party to be held under the auspices of the Maternity Center Division of the Brooklyn Visiting Nurse Association on Dec. 11 at the presentation of "The Country Wife" at the Henry Miller Theatre, in Manhattan.

I see very little in your letter column concerning Little Theatre activities. It is surprising that there is so little said about a field of artistic effort so widespread and filled with spirit, vigor and potentialities for the best in the growth of the American theatre.

LILLE, France, Nov. 21. -- Sixty-thousand workers and their families, more interested in the benefits brought to them by their late Mayor than in the tales of his deserting the army filed past the bier of Roger Salengro in the City Hall here today.

GENEVA, Nov. 20. -- To many here Germany's scrapping of restrictions in the Versailles treaty which apply to German rivers suggests that Hitler has adopted a policy of a new "farewell tour" through the treaty every season as a propaganda device to heat Germany up for the war which the final denunciation -- that of the territorial clauses -- seems sure to bring about.

The report of official Referee Norman S. Dike in the case of Joseph A. Solovei, an attorney of 215 Montague Street, Brooklyn, charged with unethical conduct by the extraordinary grand jury which investigated the facts connected with the murder of Samuel Drukman, has been filed with the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, in Brooklyn, it was learned yesterday.

JOHN BARAGWANATH belongs, he says, to the generation that was brought up on the writings of Richard Harding Davis. He was brought up on the example of John Hays Hammond, too. And one day when he was 16 an uncle took him for a walk in the country and talked about geology and mineralogy until the lad was fair bemused with the wonders of the underground world still waiting to be explored.

THE "underworld empire" of America is not a bizarre dream or fantastic creation of fiction. Says Melvin Purvis, flatly, "It exists. One out of every forty-two persons in the United States has a prison history or a record of arrest. Crime is a business for profit."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 21. -- Undergraduate discussion at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has been concentrated of late on the rclative merits of a gymnasium or an addition to Walker Memorial, student activity building, as the institute's contribution to the extracurricular life of the students.

A HARD-BITTEN apostle of reality, Jacob Wilk is concerned chiefly with the merchandising of intangibles. He can tell you to a dime the gross of the latest Broadway attraction upon which he is casting covetous eyes, or reel off without apparent effort the sales of "Anthony Adverse" in Patagonia.

AT long last the Federal Dance Theatre of the WPA has got around to announcing the opening date of its first Broadway production. On Nov. 29 "The Eternal Prodigal," directed by Gluok-Sandor and Felicia Sorel, will open at the Ritz Theatre for an engagement of one week.

The surf-fishing lads hereabout still are smarting from the verbal spanking administered by Harry Durant, who in a letter to this department intimated that the Long Island and New Jersey squid slingers were softies compared to the stalwart sons of Florida.

The New York Americans win attempt to regain their winning stride tonight when they skate against the Montreal Maroons at Madison Square Garden. The spangled players sustained their first defeat of the current campaign against the Canadiens in Montreal on Thursday night after having piled up eight points in their first five battles.

Ralph Goldstein, 31 years old, a second-grade detective, attached to the Clymer Street police station, Brooklyn, pleaded not guilty yesterday when arraigned in Kings County Court on an indictment charging him with accepting a bribe to release a prisoner under arrest.

The New York City Tunnel Authority will advertise on Dec. 1 for bids for test borings under the East River between the Battery, Governors Island and Hamilton Avenue, Brooklyn. These borings are the first step for construction of the proposed Battery-Hamilton Avenue vehicular tunnel.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 21 (AP). -- President Franklin D. Roosevelt will become the second Roosevelt to be honored by the Argentine Social Museum Welfare Organization upon his arrival here for the Inter-American Peace Conference, officials announced today.

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 21. -- More Lafayette College students are engaged in extra-curricular activities this Autumn than ever before in the history of the college. A survey shows that of 879 men enrolled 789 have some other interests than their books and laboratories.

AUBURN, Ala., Nov. 21 (AP). -- A devastating Auburn attack rolled up a 44-to-0 victory over Loyola of New Orleans today in the Plainsmen's only home game of the year before a homecoming day crowd of 5,000. Three of the seven touchdowns were scored by reserves.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (AP). -- Americans add to the language in four ways, according to Mitford M. Matthews, assistant editor of the Historical Dictionary of American English, a compilation of words in use in the country before 1900.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 21. -- The fighting Ramblers of Notre Dame brought 'em back alive today.
Sixty-five thousand New Yorkers are asking help in their personal problems concerning work or study or recreation from the Guidance Service of the WPA Education Program.

Crude oil stocks, which for the last ten years have been a serious problem to the industry, have been reduced to a point where they are considered no greater than the industry needs in order to insure an uninterrupted supply to refiners. Because of their steady decline in the last few years, it is estimated that there is now no more than thirty days' supply of crude oil actually available for immediate use.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21. -- Marvin Cox, 12 years old, who lives with his father on a farm near Hampshire in Kane County, is to receive a new rifle for Christmas for his bravery. That was the promise today of his father, Fred.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Nov. 21. -- "The Mount-Holyoke-at-Sea," a mythical floating university organized after the college campus was supposedly inundated in the spring floods of 1936, was the setting for the annual Junior Show given tonight at Mount Holyoke College by the class of 1938.

RYE, N.Y., Nov. 21. -- The Apawamis Club of Rye gave a dinner dance tonight. Among those who attended were Mr. and Mrs. Egbert Lillie, Mr. and Mrs. Warren A. Ransom, Mr. and Mrs. John E. Smith, Mr. and Mrs. Charles P. Collins, Mr. and Mrs. Orlando S. Brewer, Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Carlton Peck, Mr. and Mrs. Victor E. Cooley and Mr. and Mrs. Bayard W. Read.

Detectives of the Missing Persons Bureau are seeking two Jamaica boys who ran away from their homes Thursday morning because, according to their parents, they were afraid to go home because of poor marks on their report cards. They are Edward Titamer, 11 years old, of 166-36 Eighty-eighth Avenue, and Robert Denise, 11, of 168-22 Eighty-eighth Avenue.

Copies of both the second and fourth folio editions of Shakespeare's plays are included in Part II of the library of Mrs. Milton E. Getz of Beverly Hills, Calif., which will be sold Tuesday and Wednesday at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries.

CORVALLIS, Ore., Nov. 21 (AP). -- Oregon State College, led by a fleet halfback, Joe Gray, defeated the University of Oregon, 18 to 0, today for its first victory in the annual classic in four years. A homecoming crowd of 18,000 saw the game.

ERNESTINE SCHUMANN-HEINK, a grand veteran of life and art, if ever there was one, was practically the last of her school and generation of singers. There is no contralto of her qualifications and artistic stature left in the world today.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Nov. 21. -- A series of foreign and historical moving pictures shown on Tuesday and Saturday nights at Smith College are being sponsored by the college to develop in the student a critical appreciation of the motion picture as for other forms of art.

Additional plans leading toward the formation of a national organization of race track operators were made yesterday at a meeting of the committee appointed Friday by representatives of twenty-eight racing associations.

BOSTON, Nov. 20. -- Second in importance only to the liquidation of the Amoskeag Manufacturing Company, in the recent textile history of New England, is the reopening of four of the mills of its vast plant.
A freight and passenger elevator in the eight-story loft and factory building at 24 East Twenty-second Street with ten men on board fell yesterday afternoon from the sixth floor to the basement.

BERLIN, Nov. 21. -- Germany acknowledged today her readiness to act with Japan, partner in a common antagonism to bolshevism, "in given situations," but continued to disclaim knowledge of any pact between the two nations aimed against Russia.

In four nations -- Germany, Italy, Russia and Spain -- last Wednesday was, by virtue of historical or other associations, a notable day. Before Wednesday was over it had made history in its own right: Berlin and Rome recognized the Spanish Insurgents.

BERLIN, Nov. 21. -- Germany does not expect war from the Spanish imbroglio and she is also convinced that her recognition of the Franco government will contribute a desired stabilizing factor in the Spanish situation. Her recognition of the Insurgent forces, it was emphasized at the Foreign Office, squarely conforms with political diplomatic realities and therefore constitutes a logical as well as a legitimate procedure.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 21. -- The symbol most expressive of the advances in education for women at Vassar College is the astronomical observatory, one of the original campus buildings.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Approval of the joint application of the Metropolitan Edison Company and the Northern Pennsylvania Power Company for a merger of the latter with the former has been approved by the Federal Power Commission.

There is neat plot work as well as high adventure in this new book in the series of Monsieur Blackshirt's exploits. With the high color of the restless, roistering days when Henry of Navarre was King or France, the story of the random and foolhardy ventures of a soldier of fortune fall into a prettily planned pattern.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 21. -- More business openings were presented to Yale students last year and more students were placed through the direct efforts of the Department of Personnel Study and Bureau of Appointments than in any previous year in the history of the department, according to Dr. Albert B. Crawford, department director.

Striking twice with devastating force in the first ten minutes, Villanova drove across two touchdowns, which were sufficient to send Manhattan down to a 12-0 defeat in the Jaspers' final home appearance of the season before a crowd of 18,000 at Ebbets Field yesterday.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., Nov. 21. -- Charged with misappropriating $2,200 to his own use over a period of two years while serving as Village Clerk, William C. Schreiber, 40 years old, of Sycamore Avenue, was arraigned before Acting Police Justice Louis G. Hart today and after waiving examination was held for the grand jury in default of $2,500 bail.

RICHMOND, Nov. 21. -- Fifth district wholesalers are sharing in the general business rise and are looking forward to the busiest Winter in six years. The Richmond bank's monthly report shows an average gain of 12 per cent for five lines in October.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Nov. 21. -- The New Zealand Industrial Commission, which has received power to rule the industrial field wherever labor is unionized, carried out the Socialist government's instructions yesterday and established a new principle of industrial relations with the declaration of a basic wage for all adult men and women workers.

LEADING American radio manufacturers engaged in the development of high-definition television have agreed to important standards which permit receivers to operate on standardized telecasts, Albert F. Murray, acting chairman of the Radio Manufacturers Association television committee, reported to the organization during the past week.

As the seamen's strike entered its twenty-third day on the Pacific Coast yesterday civic and business groups appealed for the personal intervention of President Roosevelt to end the commercial paralysis which is costing business men mounting thousands every day.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (AP). -- A pair of young sophomores touched the spark to a smoldering Illini offense today, enabling Illinois to come from behind in a thrill-packed fourth period and defeat Chicago, 18 to 7, before 20,000 roaring spectators.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. CHESTER, at Sea, Nov. 21. -- President Roosevelt and his party sped down South America's east coast tonight for Rio de Janeiro, on their way to the inter-American peace conference at Buenos Aires.

IN the onslaught against the government forces of Spain, the Moors are the backbone of the Rightist army led by General Francisco Franco. For months they have been in the vanguard of every important engagement. Their accuracy as riflemen and their coolness under fire have often turned the tide; the very knowledge of their presence throws fear into the hearts of their opponents.
MONTREAL, Nov. 21. -- The Canadiens, their veterans clicking in superlative fashion, defeated the New York Rangers in overtime tonight, 3 to 1, winning on goals by Toe Blake and Johnny Gagnon.
LYNBROOK, L.I., Nov. 21. -- A brief service in the Rockville Cemetery here today marked the one-hundredth anniversary of the worst sea disaster that the ocean front of Long Island has known.

MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 21. -- Diego Rivera, who parted company with the Rockefellers in a dispute over his satirical murals in Rockefeller Center, New York, ran into the same trouble here today and also a charge that he entered a hotel with five pistols.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 21. -- It was an elated group of Yale players that romped into their dressing room this evening after holding off the Harvard threat. No serious injury marred their happiness. Not even George Wright, the tackle from Bronxville, N.Y., who was carried from the field in the second period, was badly hurt.

ENGAGING as they are, it would be a pity to identify Don Marquis exclusively with Archy and Mehitabel. He can write, when he puts his mind to it, as uproarious a short story as any American humorist. His fiction lacks the pith and sting of Lardner's, is gayer, crazier, more farcical, but he is almost equally alert to the nuances of the popular idiom.
