THE world is full of muddles and China is one of them. China is professedly misunderstood or not understood at all in the West, and it really seems to me that she does not care.
More than 1,500 undergraduates and alumni of New York University's twelve departments will inaugurate Thanksgiving Night the first all-university dance in the institution's history.

Mrs. Fenton B. Turck Jr. heads a women's committee assisting in the sale of Christmas seals in New York. The campaign will open next Thursday and continue until Christmas under the auspices of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Assoiciation.

The Smith College Club of Brooklyn, of which Mrs. Edwin P. Maynard Jr. is president, will hold its fourteenth annual bridge to aid its scholarship fund on Saturday afternoon, Dec. 5, in the Brooklyn Edison Building. Mrs. C. Waldo Morrison and Miss Grace E. Ames are co-chairmen for the party.

The official quincentenary of British beer makes peculiarly appropriate the exhibition of inn signs opened in London the other day. It is a show which GEORGE BORROW and DICKENS and Sir WALTER would have been pleased with. Whatever be the case with wine, good -- and plenty of bad -- ale and bitter beer have needed and were at one time compelled to display their "bush."

PEIPING, Sunday, Nov. 22. -- Except for agreement that there was a lull in the fighting yesterday Chinese and Japanese reports of events and of the situation on the Suiyuan front are diametrically opposite.
PARIS, Nov. 21. -- Franco-British negotiations over the Spanish situation were reviewed today when French Ambassador Charles Corbin, here from London, conferred with Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos.

Reflecting a growing interest in the social service which a woman's club can render a community is the establishment of departments of crime prevention and of social adjustment and problems of industry in the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 21 (Canadian Press). -- The tables were turned on the touring Marylebone Cricket Club team today, second day of the four-day match with an Australian eleven. The English team collapsed, losing the last five first-innings wickets for fourteen runs, and at the end of the day's play, shortened by bad light, the scoreboard showed M.C.C. all out for 288, the Australian eleven 221 for two wickets.

The City College Dramatic Society will present "Squaring the Circle" by Valentine Katayev for their performance of the Fall semester during the Thanksgiving holidays, Nov. 27 and 28 at the Pauline Edwards Theatre in the City College School of Business and Civic Administration, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.

SCRANTON, Nov. 21. -- The Rev. E.E. Shumaker, 70, of Glenburn, Scranton suburb, a retired Congregational minister, was found murdered this afternoon in the office of the Pure Coal Company on the mountain two miles west of Blakely Borough.

A significant and important session in Chicago beginning tomorrow will go far toward deciding the scope and character of outboard racing on American lakes, rivers and waterways during 1937. Commodore Charles F. Chapman of New York and his colleagues on the National Outboard Racing Commission are taking time by the forelock and learning in November instead of January what the hydroplane drivers can expect in the way of motors and racing equipment.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 21 (AP). -- Setting down results of a six-year study of how coal burns, research workers at the Carnegie Institute of Technology have prepared the last of sixty-two reports of their experiments.

AN example of the earliest postmark known to the stampless cover collectors fell under the auctioneer's hammer in London recently. It was a "Bishop mark," dated 1662, imprinted on the envelope of a letter from one Bartholomew Hussey of Dublin to his friend John Morris, at the "Flying Horse" at Cornhill.
TROY, N.Y., Nov. 21. -- Theory and practice go hand-in-hand in the new merchandising courses of the School of Business Education at Russell Sage College.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses and former Governor Alfred E. Smith opposed yesterday morning at a public hearing in the State Building a proposal for the creation of a Palisades Interstate Park Commission to act as an agency similar to the Port Authority.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 21. -- Adrian H. Larkin, Albert Stickney and the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company of Manhattan are allowed a total of $423,650.55 by a decree signed by Surrogate Robert S. Pelletreau of Suffolk County in commissions as temporary administrators of the estate of the late Colonel Henry H. Rogers of Manhattan and Southampton.

TROY, Nov. 21. -- Commander Charles E. Rosendahl, veteran dirigible expert in charge of the Naval Air Station at Lakehurst, N.J., is of the opinion that "the time has come to return some of the anti-airship fire."

IN his first novel, which is subtitled "An American primitive," Harry Kemp ranges himself with that growing school of writers who look back upon a vanishing way of life with wistful regret. Mr. Kemp feels, with Sterling North and Arthur Pound, that life on the farm wasn't so bad after all.

IT is our guess that the idea for this volume originated with the artist, Jacques la Grange, and that consideration of the accompanying text came afterward. Yet, be that as it may, Helen la Grange has done yeoman work in support of the thirty-seven color wood-cuts, and the illuminating pen-and-ink drawings, which are the book's foundation.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 21. -- Yale University faculty members and New Haven residents entertained widely over the week-end in honor of guests here for the Yale-Harvard football game.

MR. PEERS'S book is the first of many that are certain to appear dealing with the immediate events leading up to the present climax of what the author aptly terms the Spanish tragedy. It gives a rather complete account of events in the struggle between the Spanish liberals and conservatives between January, 1930, and the present day, with a glance into the future.

TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 21. -- New York City is headed toward one of the worst housing shortages it has ever had, Langdon Post, Commissioner of Housing, declared here today before the labor institute held under the auspices of the Workers Education Bureau and the American Federation of Labor, adding that the situation would have "tragic consequences."
PARIS, Nov. 21. -- New short gloves of colored suede are embroidered on the backs with tiny bouquets.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20. A HARDY soul is that playwright who essays to put a real person on the stage. If, then, of all real persons in the procession of history, Richard Wagner, archangel of controversy and schism, be elected as the subject of a play, how shall we justly adjective its author's hardihood?
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP). -- A sharp curtailment of Federal renal activities in drought areas was being made today by the two agencies directing aid for more than a million persons in the farm area.
BUDAPEST, Nov. 21 (AP). -- The absence of goulash from the family dinner table -- not the nine duels he intends to fight Monday and Tuesday evenings -- bothered Dr. Franz Sargas tonight.

Spain's republican navy of 1936 -- like Spain's monarchical navy of 1898 -- is inefficient, ill-trained, small and ill-equipped, although a considerable number of its ships are of modern construction.

PARIS, Nov. 21. -- Communists succeeded tonight in turning a huge mass meeting called in honor of Roger Salengro's memory into a demonstration for the Spanish Leftists. When Defense Minister Edouard Daladier took the tribune to deliver a tribute to the dead Interior Minister, he was prevented from speaking for several minutes by cries "Airplanes for Spain!" "Cannon for Spain!" "Down with Fascism!" and "A People's Front newspaper for the army!"

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 21. -- Army finished its home season today, burying Hobart College under a 51-to-7 score, in a game which saw practically every man on the cadet squad engaged in the play. Besides being Hobart's final game it was also the Statesmen's first setback of the season.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 21 (AP). -- Gar H. Davidson, head football coach at the United States Military Academy since 1933, will coach the Cadets again in 1937, Major Gen. William D. Conner announced today.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 20. -- After the flurry over the refusal by some of the employes' representatives to sign the year's contract linking the wage increase offered by the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation with a sliding scale based upon the cost of living, everything passed off smoothly in the industry this week.

JEFFERY FARNOL'S proclivities have ever led him to turn to the pages of the past and stage his romances among its faded glamour and sentiment. He illuminates his scenes, both historical and fictional, not by the glaring are lights of blatant reality but softly, as though by a candle moved hither and thither.

With every important division of the textile industry last week taking on the semblance of a runaway market through sharp price advances, buyers of cottons, woolens, knit goods and floor coverings began to fear the effect of the increased quotations on consumer buying power.

LONDON, Nov. 21. -- Musical receptions and charity balls continue to be the most popular form of entertainment. Mrs. Robert H. Bingham, wife of the United States Ambassador, and Mrs. Ray Atherton, wife of the counselor, attended a reception given by the Polish Ambassador and Countess Raczynska.

A proposal for a Federal civil service amendment to the Federal Constitution, which already has the active support of thirty Senators and eighty-five Representatives, will be introduced in the new Congress when it convenes in January, it was announced yesterday by H. Eliot Kaplan, secretary of the National Civil Service Reform League.

NEXT Thursday much of the nation, moving by bus, train, plane and automobile, will be launched on its annual pursuit of the hapless turkey and the savory mince pie. Thanksgiving Day is second only to Christmas as national home-coming day for Americans the country over.

Rufus D. Smith, proost of New York University, in opening the third annual Foreign Language Conference at New York University's School of Education Auditorium, Washington Square East, yesterday, declared that "through the teaching of foreign languages there may come a breaking down of racial passion and prejudice."

TROY, Nov. 21. -- Termed by President William Otis Hotchkiss a "creed" shaded to the need of the times, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute has adopted a new declaration of its aims and responsibilities.

The art of song interpretation in its highest estate was enjoyed by the large audience which gathered in Town Hall last night for the recital given by Povla Frijsh, the Danish soprano. There was a big ovation for the singer when she first appeared and, had she been so minded, she might have doubled the length of the program, so insistent was the applause after each of her selections.

It is not generally recognized how sharp the rise has been, both since the bottom of the depression and even in recent weeks, in world commodity prices. The index number of wholesale prices in the United States, as compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, shows an advance of 35 per cent from the level of March, 1933 -- mainly owing to the rise in farm products.

Strong recommendations and practical plans for peace to be presented by the American women delegates to the Popular Conference for Peace, opening at Buenos Aires today, indicate that the 10,000,000 women whom they represent are not discouraged by the failure of peace treaties abroad and are fired with new hope of success in an economic approach to the question.

TWO new short stretches of parkway have just been opened on Long Island. One -- Laurelton Parkway -- represents a westward extension of Southern State Parkway. The other connects that parkway to the newly developed Bethpage State Park.

If you know a 10-year-old boy who thinks the waterfront the most exciting place in the world, this is his book. Here is a panorama of New York harbor, where the biggest ships in the world glide in and out majestically, freight boats take on cargo, ferries plod, like beasts of burden, from shore to shore.

The introduction last week of several factors which cannot be accurately evalued at this time resulted in a confusing movement of stock prices. The market moved up on Monday and Tuesday and lost this advantage during the ensuing three days; recovery yesterday enabled the list to show a small average gain on the week.

To the old army salute, the Nazi and Fascist salutes, the clenched fist of the Communists and the three uplifted fingers of the Boy Scouts, there have just been added two new salutes. The new Irish semi-clerical party known as the Christian Front held an anti-Communist demonstration in Dublin a few days ago, at which the "cross salute" made its first appearance.

Members of the alumni committee of City College which investigated the fitness of President Frederick B. Robinson and, in a majority report nearly a year ago found him unfitted for the office, last night received the annual service medals of the Associate Alumni.

SYOSSET, L.I., Nov. 21. -- Leading a field of twelve in a test that was severe both for riders and horses, Gerard S. Smith, up on his Sun Faun, today won the Meadow Brook point to point race and captured the Middleton S. Burrill Cup which went with the victory.

Andy High, an old favorite of the fans at Ebbets Field, was named as one of the coaches of the Dodgers for the 1937 campaign by Manager Burleigh Grimes yesterday. For the last two seasons High has been the player-manager of the Hazleton club of the New York-Penn League.

The annual Irvington House Gift Shop will open tomorrow afternoon at 857 Madison Avenue and will continue there during the next four weeks. A wide variety of useful articles, many of which are the handicraft of child patients at Irvington House, will be offered for sale.

MOSCOW, Nov. 21 (AP). -- A blunt warning to Japan that Soviet Russia will not cooperate further in granting "vital" fishing concessions to Japanese until the reported Japanese-German military pact is cancelled was sent to the Japanese Embassy here tonight.

TWO exhibitions of unusual importance in the field of ceramics have just closed at the Syracuse Museum of Fine Arts: the Fifth National Ceramic Exhibition (the Robineau Memorial), and an exhibition of Contemporary American Ceramics, assembled by the Syracuse Museum upon official invitation from Denmark, Sweden and Finland, to be shown later in Copenhagen, Gothenburg, Stockholm and Helsingfors.

WHY is it that mystery stories in which spinsters play leading roles are almost invariably good? Can it be that there is a natural affinity between spinsters and crime? We pause for a reply. Hearing none, we leave the question to the professors.

AWAY out from his native New England young Tom Wyeth rode into lawless Southwestern Kansas (known to many as "Bloody Kansas" in those days) to find a man he had never seen. It was important that he should find that man -- a crook who had stolen his patrimony.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 21. -- The Nebraska football volcano which fumed harmlessly against Pittsburgh a week ago erupted today to smother the Big Six title dreams of Kansas State. The score was Nebraska 40, Kansas State 0.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Representative Edward A. Kenney, Cliffside Park (N.J.) Democrat, completed today preparation of a bill for introduction in the next Congress to extend the time in which States may adopt unemployment insurance laws and receive payroll tax revenues under the Social Security Act.

WHEN plans were announced for a special series of ten commemorative stamps in honor of the United States Army and the Navy, the Postoffice Department expressed the hope that it would be possible to complete the entire series by Dec. 1, thus making all the stamps available for the Christmas holiday season.

Hunter College will celebrate Alumnae Day on Wednesday by holding open house for all alumnae land providing an extensive program that will include the first general assembly to be called by the college since the fire last February rendered the old building on Park Avenue unfit for use.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Industrial activity has held to a steady pace so far this month, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey. With the exception of the seasonal rise in automobile assemblies and the sharp drop in lumber production resulting from labor difficulties in the West Coast shipping industry, changes in the weekly production series have been small.

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 21. -- Wrecking Wisconsin's hopes for an upset victory with a crushing offensive in the first half, the University of Minnesota's powerful gridiron machine coasted to a 24-0 victory today.

MELBOURNE. -- It has been said with a measure of truth that if Australians knew the identity of the man who introduced the rabbit to their country they would burn him in effigy all over the Commonwealth.

All signs in Central Europe indicate that that part of the world is tending toward a more peaceful epoch, reported Dr. Maria Bentivoglio yesterday at the University Women's Club. Dr. Bentivoglio, who has just returned from a stay of several months in Italy, made an extensive tour through Poland, Jugoslavia and Czechoslovakia in her capacity as an observer of current international affairs.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Nov. 21 (AP). They rained forward passes all over Ross Ade Stadium today as Purdue and Indiana fought to a 20-to-20 tie in as spectacular a football battle as ever took place in the forty-year rivalry between the two State schools.

JOE PRENDERGAST'S two-cylinder Maxwell motor cab, bouncing and rattling along New York's avenues thirty years ago, startled every horse within a half mile. Hansom drivers reined their nags in the Maxwell's gaseous wake and called down on Joe's head the richest in an abundant vocabulary.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- Snow covered the Pocono Mountains during the past week-end and preparations are being rushed for the Winter sports season, expected to start early in December. At present, everything is in readiness for the Thanksgiving week-end and all of the large resorts report heavy bookings for the holiday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Through improvements in communications, President Roosevelt on his 4,800-mile dash to Buenos Aires for the opening session of the Inter-American Peace Conference is being kept in as close touch with the government as though he were seated at his desk in the Executive Offices.

In preparation for an extension of the current sharp business recovery, most national advertisers have approved advertising budgets for 1937 showing an average increase of 15 per cent over the current year, according to reports by agency and company executives yesterday.

STEADILY growing interest in the model airplane hobby is reflected in the inauguration by the Adult Education Council of the Works Progress Administration of a course in model airplane building. Grown-ups as well as younger people have enrolled at Bronx Vocational High School for the course, the first of its kind to be offered by the WPA in the city.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 21 (AP). -- Settlement of the sit-down and lockout strike at the Bendix Products Corporation here was delayed until Monday while negotiators went to the football game between Notre Dame and Northwestern Universities.

ANOTHER PLEA: When Supreme Court Justice Carew took the rearing of Gloria Laura Vanderbilt out of the hands of her mother, Mrs. Gloria Mor gan Vanderbilt, and awarded custody of the young heiress to her aunt, Hrs. Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney, he expressed the hope that within three years Mrs. Vanderbilt might demonstrate "the propriety" of his issuing a new order restoring custody to her. That was two years ago.

Two more retriever trials still are to come to round out the greatest season that has been enjoyed on this side of the water. First will be the meeting of the Brookhaven Game Protective Association, which is scheduled for next Saturday and Sunday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21. -- Raymond E. Prochnow, 39 years old, who became known as the "forgotten man" in debtors' row at the Cook County Jail, where he has served almost three years for contempt in a civil proceeding, was ordered released today in a ruling by Judge Harry M. Fisher in Circuit Court.

EDINBURGH, Nov. 21. -- Before a brilliant audience, many members of which had traveled from distant parts of Europe, Sir James M. Barrie's new play, "The Boy David," his first offering in nearly two decades, opened tonight at the King's Theatre here.
OXFORD, England, Nov. 21. -- Robert W. Bingham, United States Ambassador, received the honorary degree of Doctor of Civil Law at a colorful ceremony at Oxford University today.
Twenty-eight gunners took part in a turkey shoot over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. In all, nineteen birds were won by the Winged Foot contestants.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 21. -- The annual Lord Jeff prom, the highlight of Amherst College's Autumn social season, was held last night in old Pratt Gymnasium. Dancing was from 9:30 P.M. to 12 midnight and from 1 to 3 A.M., amid the colorful blue, gold and white decorations of the bare gymnasium walls.

A CALL to colors sounds with the opening of the Southern season. There is no dimming of high lights; prints are as vivid as the plumage of tropical birds. Themes for designs are found in palmettos, sailing boats and sunny beaches.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Nov. 21. -- Miracle Boy, 6-year-old bay gelding owned by Dr. H.J. Sealey of Dumont, N.J., won the five-gaited saddle horse title at the sixth annual Peekskill Horse Show in the arena of the 156th Field Artillery tonight.

THE British-American Himalayan expedition has just returned here after spending nine weeks in the Central Himalayan Ranges of Garhwal, during which it achieved the first ascent to the 25,660-foot crest of snow-capped Nanda Devi, the highest mountain wholly within the British Empire and the highest summit yet scaled by man.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP). -- Western Maryland uncorked a powerhouse offensive in the third period today to smash over a touchdown and gain a 6-to-0 football victory today over Catholic University.

THE bad news is that the Green Bay Packers are still in town. They refused to leave quietly. They slaughtered the Brooklyn Dodgers last Sunday and they may massacre the Giants at the Polo Grounds today. Very definitely they have it in mind. Where are the gendarmes who are paid to protect this territory? The law is a hollow mockery when the Rough Raiders from Green Bay are allowed to roam loose.

WE of the twentieth century are far too complacently convinced that the Victorians were stuffy and inhibited. How many of us would believe, offhand, that an "ordinary girl" of the Eighteen Eighties would wear bobbed hair, pick up strangers on trains, jump into a river while fully clothed (which meant a good deal in those days) or study psychology?

AT length, in the course of its extended travels about the country, the exhibition of art from Soviet Russia has reached New York. It is installed in the galleries on the thirty-third floor of the Squibb Building and may be visited throughout the week.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Nov. 21. -- Mr. and Mrs. J. Macy Willets, who have been in New York for several weeks, are back at Cassilis Farm, New Marlboro, and will remain for Thanksgiving. They are to be at their apartment, 604 Park Avenue, after Dec. 1.

Four teams remained in the running last night for the contract bridge tournament for the Vanderbilt Cup at the Hotel Commodore. The semi-finals will be played tomorrow afternoon and evening, it was announced by George Rieth, chairman of the Vanderbilt Cup committee, who is in charge of the contest.

SERBIA in the last days of the great war, specifically Belgrade and its adjacent terrain, forms the scene in this absorbing story of a very young Austrian cavalry ensign's martial adventures. Menis, the ensign, many years after, relates these shattering experiences as they befell him in the retreat of the beaten Austro German armies before the advance upon Belgrade of the victorious Allies.

A SQUALID story told in the hard-boiled manner, the strength of this novel lies in its compelling delineation of moronic character in its worst phases, of a brutalized weakling's submersion in evils to which he yields without thought of saving himself from contamination.

BOSTON, Nov. 21. -- The increasing demands of students for the services of the department of student counseling and religious activities at Boston University have caused a wide expansion of its services during the past year, according to the recent report of Professor Warren T. Powell.

Besides Mr. Tolefree and his friend Farrar, we have in this story another interesting character, a professor of moral philosophy named Pye. Like Tolefree and Farrar, Pye is on vacation, which is probably why his words and actions are not what one would expect from a man of his calling.

ATLANTA, Nov. 21. -- Unlimbering its heavy artillery in a display of aerial and ground warfare, Georgia Tech's Engineers routed the fighting Alligators of Florida, 38 to 14, today in the presence of 10,000 spectators.

Beginning with a supper tonight, the Outdoor Cleanliness Association will conduct a "beauty benefit" this week at 715 Fifth Avenue, where a collection of paintings and sculpture, and a private collection of antique miniature period rooms will be on exhibition. Following the special opening tonight, at which a group of patronesses for the benefit will receive the guests, the exhibit will be open to the public.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 21. -- Union College, which started the pioneering movement to bring the college and professional theatre into alliance through the establishment of the Mohawk Drama Festival and Institute of the Theatre in 1935, last night showed itself to be influenced in turn by the professional theatre in presenting its own little theatre productions.
PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, Nov. 21. -- Historic Trinidad, discovered by Christopher Columbus in 1496, ceremoniously welcomed President Roosevelt today on his arrival aboard the cruiser Indianapolis.

IN preparing this edition of the life and works of an early and little known American poet, Dr. Pleadwell has performed a service for literature. To the browser in the rather dim and scanty gardens of American poetry during the first two decades of the nineteenth century.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 21 (AP). -- Ohio State combined power and "razzle-dazzle" today to defeat Michigan's Wolverines, 21 to 0, giving the Bucks a second place tie in the Western conference race, in which they tied for the title with Minnesota a year ago.

MADRID, Nov. 21. -- Madrid militia battered Insurgent troops in the suburbs with short-range artillery fire today and recaptured University City positions. Their offensive was aided by icy rains that prevented an Insurgent aerial attack.

SEA ISLAND, Ga. -- Hunters have gone into the swamps and coastal woodlands at the Sea Island Hunting Preserve to try their luck for that wariest of game birds -- the wild turkey. The hunting season in Georgia opened on Nov. 20 and brought many gunners to this area.

Mr. TUGWELL'S friends resent his being driven from public life. In so doing they only make a mystery of his departure. RAYMOND CLAPPER in The World-Telegram says Mr. TUGWELL was hounded out of Washington because he was not enough of a stuffed shirt.

RECENT paintings by Ogden Pleissner in that artist's current show of oils and watercolors at the Macbeth Gallery (through November) reveal new depth and strength in his work. The clear atmosphere and pleasing color of earlier work are none the less evident but reinforced by a deeper emotional mood.

The present American system of industry, business and government will continue to be operated by the democratic method if the people wholeheartedly accept the concept that government in a democracy depends upon education, declared Professor Harold Rugg of Teachers College, Columbia University, yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 20. -- Events have been moving fast in Near and Middle Eastern politics for the past few months. No sooner were the disturbances ended in Palestine than a coup d'etat took place in Iraq, followed by ratification of the Anglo-Egyptian treaty and the Franco-Lebanese accord and parliamentary elections in Syria, which will be followed in turn by ratification of the Franco-Syrian Treaty.

AGAIN and again in the rewarding Gericault exhibition at the Marie Sterner Gallery we perceive French Classicism in what may be termed a process of change. This change had its genesis in the new forces then at work, which, as they became clarified, led the way into French Romanticism.

THE toys of older days are now collectors' items, as the dolls and doll houses on display at the Museum of the City of New York bear witness. Some antiquarians specialize in toys, others cover the whole field.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 21 (AP). -- There wasn't a sound except the scuffling of cleats on the concrete floor as the vanquished Northwestern Wildcats shuffled into their dressing room, after Notre Dame had mauled them today.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 21 (AP). -- A first-period break and a forward pass gave Michigan State a 7-to-0 victory today over the University of Arizona's hard-fighting Wildcats.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Abraham Lincoln, as a lyceum lecturer in 1860, looked forward to a wind-power age. "Discoveries and Inventions" was the title of a lecture which he was delivering to lyceums around Illinois just before his election to the Presidency.

LONDON, Nov. 21 (Canadian Press). -- Sunderland, last season's champion of the English Football League, drew into a tie with Portsmouth at the top of the first division today. The Roker Park team scored over powerful Stoke City by 3 -- 0, while Portsmouth bowed, 4 -- 0, at Everton.
HOUSTON, Texas, Nov. 21 (AP). -- Sam Baugh passed the Texas Christian Frogs to a 13-to-0 victory over the Rice Owls before 15,000 spectators today.

LONDON, Nov. 6. THE fashion of biographical plays does not slacken. Beethoven is to appear on the stage next week; Becket, in Mr. T.S. Eliot's "Murder in the Cathedral," has come to the West End of London; "Parnell," licensed by the censor a year after its first performance in New York, received this week from press and public a reception unequaled by that given to any other play in recent years.

MR. MILLER has been making notes within a few feet of the world's gallows for twenty-four years. With enough material to fill a five-foot shelf, he has distilled his reminiscences down to one breathless volume, written as though it all had to be sent by cable at a dollar a word, as rapid-paced as front-page news.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- The British Government declares repeatedly, and with almost unanimous public approval, that it will have nothing to do with either fascism or communism. With equal emphasis it rejects a policy of isolation, either armed or unarmed, as impossible.

CHAMBER music concerts, at which the Stradivarius instruments donated to the Library of Congress last December by Mrs. Gertrude Clarke Whittall will be employed, will be given in the auditorium of the library, under the provisions of the Gertrude Clarke Whittall Foundation, Wednesday nights and Friday afternoons during December and January.

Bond prices reflected a decidedly firm undertone yesterday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. United States Government loans showed rallying tendencies from their setback of Friday, while several conspicuous gains were recorded in the market for the more speculative domestic corporate issues.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21. -- The University of Iowa came out of its football slumbers today to crush Temple, 25 to 0, before 18,000 spectators. This was the worst setback of the season for Pop Warner's team.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 21 -- Mr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Brown of Stewart Avenue entertained with a dinner tonight for Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Ripley, Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Koons, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Olena, Mr. and Mrs. John Miller, Mr. and Mrs. George Young, Mr. and Mrs. Walter Matteson, Mr. and Mrs. George Fitter and Paul Ripley.

PARIS, Nov. 21 (AP). -- Mobile Guards awaited emergency duty tonight as 20,000 strikers paralyzed industrial plants and a strike call threatened to affect 17,000 others. Under orders of Premier Leon Blum, the police prefects heavily reinforced guards in the strike areas.

IN these times of social and economic groupings every artist seems to be expected to have undergone a baptism into one or another of the simmering creeds. Wells's utopianism, Shaw's socialism, the late John Galsworthy's humanitarianism, all are cases in point of particular doctrinal colorings with which the work of those great writers is associated.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky, conductor, which has never distinguished itself more signally in its New York visits than during the last week, gave its second concert of the Autumn season yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. The program was unusually interesting.

AS a preface to whatever may develop in these remarks, it should be acknowledged that this corner is but temporarily let to its present tenant. This department's Mr. Nugent, in the quaint manner of the busman who takes to the char-a-bancs for his holiday, has taken himself to Hollywood for a fortnight or so, entrusting these columns of comment to other hands.

ARNOLD GENTHE got his doctor's degree at Jena with a Latin thesis on a tenth-century codex of a minor contemporary of Virgil, and was all ready to teach classical philology in a German university. But the Chinese in San Francisco disliked having their pictures taken, and so he became a world-famous photographer instead.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21. -- The wheat market on the Board of Trade made a firm start and a tame finish today. There was buying early on the strength in Liverpool and continued dry weather in the West and Northwest. July wheat advanced 1 cent at the extreme to a new high level for the season, but toward the end there was fairly general selling, and the upturn was replaced with a loss of 3/8 cent.

"You're the daughter of a steel king, dear -- don't forget that," was Hutchinson Stanton's parting injunction to his pretty daughter Maria when she sailed on her first trip to Europe. Maria was young and innocent and blissfully sentimental over the beauties of historic London.

OPEN price systems represent an attempt to provide a means whereby producers and buyers of commodities that are not handled through the organized commodity Exchanges may become acquainted with the prices that are being asked and offered for such commodities.

For the first time leading scholars in various fields of learning have set down "the four or five most significant facts, ideas or points of view" which their subjects have to offer the modern world. Charles A. Beard has spoken for history; Ales Hrdlicka for anthropology; Raymond Pearl for biology; Robert A. Millikan for physics; and Julius Stieglitz for chemistry.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 21. -- Producers as well as consumers are demanding grades and standards for the products which are offered for sale, Rowena Carpenter, assistant home economist for the Federal Bureau of Home Economics, said today at the afternoon meeting of the seminar for consumers which is being held over the week-end at the New Jersey College for Women.

Traditional family dinners and attendance at religious services will mark the observance of Thanksgiving Day on Thursday in New York City. With the price of Turkey from 6 to 8 cents less a pound than last year, according to the city's Consumers Service, the holiday bird will grace more dining tables this season.

BETH BROWN'S new novel is the story of three generations on the distaff side of the Farrell family. The fortunes of all three heroines are closely bound up with a romantic feeling for the Hudson River, and are linked to the history of Riverside Drive from the early days when the shanty Irish squatted on the land.

America's vast and involved housing problems will be the subject of intensive study by a number of prominent women who will meet on Tuesday at 11 A.M. at the home of Mrs. Eustace Seligman, 126 East Seventy-fourth Street.

BERLIN, Nov. 21. -- Major Gen. Wilhelm Faupel, general staff officer under Marshal Paul von Hindenburg in the World War and known as one of the best German authorities on military instruction, has been appointed Charge d'Affaires accredited to the Franco government at Burgos, Spain, following the Reich's formal recognition of the Insurgents Wednesday.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 21. -- Larry Kelley, Yale's brilliant football captain, wanted to be alone tonight in his greatest hour of triumph.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Portuguese East Africa. -- Portugal is taking stern measures to cope with communism in her colonies. A decree published here institutes a pledge against communism for those who have dealings with the State or are on the payroll of the local administration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- The sale in September of 10,000 shares of General Motors Corporation common stock, with a market value of more than $700,000, by Lawrence P. Fisher of Detroit, an officer of the company, was disclosed in the summary of transactions by officers, directors and principal stockholders in equity securities made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

BOSTON, Nov. 21. -- Plans for a test of the Social Security Act were made today as counsel for George A. Davis, a Republican lawyer, prepared to argue Mr. Davis's objections to the act before Federal Judge George C. Sweeney on Monday.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Nov. 21. -- A tall yarn about the fastest race horse that ever ran on the Saratoga track won Peter Sawyer the presidency of the Niagara Falls Liars Club in the early hours today.

Silence since its adjournment last Spring has meant anything but inaction on the part of the committee directing the movement to establish a World Center for Women's Archives. Revelations as to the progress of the project and the momentum acquired in the interim will be made Tuesday by Mrs. Mary Beard, author and historian, at a tea at the home of Mrs. Edward Norman, 1,160 Park Avenue.

IF the films remain cold to the financing of Broadway shows, and it seems that they do, there are yet other sources of supply. The oil business, for instance. For it now appears that the theatre, whose friends are various, has found a new one: the Petroleum Securities Company, a Western corporation, of which Mrs. Edward L. Doheny is chairman of the board of directors.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 19. -- With Secretary Wallace's announcement that he is "ready to tackle the job," and the statement of Dr. W.W. Alexander, probable resettlement administrator in succession to Rex ford Guy Tugwell, that he heartily favors a supervised land-purchase program, the farm tenancy problem has taken on an added interest in the mid-South, with the prospect that something workable will come out of the next Congress.

STILLWATER, Okla., Nov. 21 (AP). -- Major Lawrence (Biff) Jones called out the last command of a long and colorful gridiron career today and watched the University of Oklahoma eleven score a 35-13 victory over Oklahoma A. and M. before 9,000 fans.

Five firemen, caught in a backdraught while fighting a blaze in the dumbwaiter of a four-story apartment house at 667 Bedford Avenue, near Heyward Street, Brooklyn, at 6:30 o'clock last night were painfully burned on the face and hands before they could be carried away by comrades.

Last year 21,480 were killed in automobile accidents between 6 P.M. and 6 A.M. and 14,620 between 6 A.M. and 6 P.M. Of the night fatalities 24 per cent occurred between midnight and dawn, though the number of cars on the road constituted but 3 per cent of the twenty-four-hour total.

A FAIR contemporary definition of an actor is a man who started life as practically anything but an actor and was suddenly dragged into the theatre by some weird accident. Out tale today is of a lad who was destined for the theatre almost from the moment when he could memorize a couplet for visiting relatives on Sunday.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 21. -- Mrs. John Bosley Jr. 1/8 the woman who developed the unbeaten Chase Me, sprang a stunning surprise before 15,000 persons today when her bay colt Betty's Buddy captured the $3,525 Endurance Handicap at $16.50 for $2.

NOVEMBER is a festive month for the broadcasters. On the threshold of television they are celebrating two anniversaries -- sixteen years of sightless broadcasting and ten years of coast-to-coast network performances.

Early sell-outs, delayed deliveries and actual shortages of many gift items will prevent merchants from obtaining an added potential sales volume in excess of $125,000,000 during the forthcoming Christmas period, owing to the inability of stores to obtain sufficient goods in time, according to estimates made in retail quarters here yesterday.

Aloofness of the Vatican on the civil war in Spain was commended in a resolution adopted last week in Brooklyn at the monthly session of the Commission on International Justice and Good-Will of the Brooklyn Church and Mission Federation.

There was jubilation in the Wigwam in Union Square last week, for 3,000 temporary holiday jobs in the post-office had been awarded to Tammany by Democratic Chairman Farley. It was a reward for the remarkable city plurality given to President Roosevelt on Nov. 3. Since 1933 Tammany and the New Deal had been at odds and plums were scarce for the Manhattan organization.

THE National Automobile Show, which closed here last Wednesday, has gone on the road. In large part its exhibits went across the East River from the Grand Central Palace to the 106th Infantry Armory, where the Brooklyn show opened yesterday.

BACH'S violin concerto in A minor, with John Corigliano as soloist, will be a feature of the second of five concerts for the benefit of the scholarship fund of Bennington College to be given at Town Hall, Monday night, Dec. 7, by the Philharmonic-Symphony Chamber Orchestra, under Hans Lange.

BRUCKNER died forty years ago this October and therefore we have latterly been going through the experience of the Seventh International Bruckner Festival. I am not prepared to say just how "international" this festival is, but I do know it is intensely local.
EAST ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 21. -- The Upsala College Vikings took the lead in their four-year series with the neighboring Panzer College eleven today when they scored a 46-7 victory at Ashland Stadium.

NEW highs are being reached in everything this year: Presidential majorities, dividend payments, exploitation parties for the press. In a season of supererogation, we felt it our duty to go along and report the Lucullan festival, or Critics' Sabbat, which RKO Pictures gave last week on the occasion of the first local preview of "Winterset," the film version of Maxwell Anderson's prize-winning drama.

BOSTON, Nov. 21 (AP). -- With her flag at half-staff for her captain and a Malay seaman, the British freighter Tweedbank of Belfast reached port today after a three-day battle with gales and furious seas.

The Brooklyn Democratic organization, through its treasurer, Christopher C. Mollenhauer, filed yesterday an accounting with Secretary of State Flynn indicating that during the recent campaign it had had contributions of $64,602 and expenditures of $50,842.

APPARENTLY they intend to go a little further than just preaching and teaching safety in Connecticut. It was reported recently that the Governor's Commission on Street and Highway Safety had sent out a letter to more than 1,500 employers asking them to organize safety committees and safety work among their employes.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 21. -- With the flood of bonus payments and wage increases showing small signs of abatement, conditions in the Eighth Federal Reserve District approximate a boom.

May I point out a seemingly small, but actually serious error in Worthington Miner's account of the Actors' Repertory Players which appeared in your columns last Sunday? Mr. Miner asserted that its beginning was hastened when The Theatre Union turned "Let Freedom Ring" out of doors -- the Albert Bein play which we revived for ten weeks after it had closed uptown.

Stimulated by the heavy distribution of all types of seasonable merchandise and the early buying of Christmas goods, which sent retail figures to the highest level of the year in some instances, business moved vigorously ahead on all fronts last week.

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 21. -- Shackled throughout the first two quarters, but capably living up to its reputation as a second-half scoring power, Lehigh University's football team blanked Lafayette, 18 to 0, on Fisher Field today in the seventieth edition of their traditional rivalry.
DETROIT, Nov. 21 (AP). -- By the narrow margin of a blocked conversion, North Dakota's North Central Conference football champions defeated the University of Detroit Titans today 14 to 13.

VALENCIA, Spain, Nov. 21 (AP). -- The republican government of Spain charged tonight that Italian recognition of the Burgos Rebel junta had been spurred by a desire for the Spanish Balearic Islands and that Germany had collaborated with Italy to obtain raw materials "for carrying out her aggressive intentions."

Because of an unfavorable report from Acting Chief Engineer Vernon S. Moon, Borough President Harvey of Queens announced yesterday that he had persuaded the Board of Estimate to refer back to him a property owners' petition seeking to have the north side of Forty-sixth Street from 157th to 160th Street rezoned for apartment houses.

The Little Mothers Aid Association, of which Mrs. Frank Oliver Hall is president, will be the beneficiary of a card party and Christmas sale on the afternoon of Dec. 2 at the Ambassador. The organization, one of the oldest groups devoted to social service in the city, maintains a day nursery at its headquarters, 236 Second Avenue, conducts classes in home-making and has a vacation home in Whitestone, L.I.

The United States liner Washington was in safe hands Wednesday morning as she lay at her North River pier preparing to depart for European ports. Aboard the ship were three men who have commanded her at one time or another since she first entered service, in 1933.
The vexing and perplexing question of bulb quarantines is up for discussion again. The United States Department of Agriculture will hold two hearings in Washington on Dec. 15 and 16.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- To observers disposed at times to view public developments with a humorous eye, the recent activities of organized business recall that sage piece of political advice, "If you can't lick 'em, jine 'em."

Thanksgiving week-end will, as usual, wind up the Fall field hockey season for the United States Association. But in the Northeast section, at least, a departure from the usual procedure will be made. Ordinarily during the next week selected players organized in sectional teams would be competing in the national tournament for the honorary All-America and All-America Reserve team positions.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 21. -- Dartmouth's high hopes for its first victory over Princeton since 1913 were circumvented by a game, injury-ridden Tiger team today as the ancient rivals fought to a 13 -- 13 tie in a fluctuating battle before 45,000 spectators in Palmer Stadium.
Mayor La Guardia escorted Mayor Angelo Rossi of San Francisco on an inspection tour of the Flushing Meadows site for the New York World's Fair of 1939 and 1940 early yesterday afternoon.

THE number of publications attributed directly to the inventor of printing is ever so small. Only one book is ascribed to him with certainty, and that is the celebrated 42-line Bible, or Mazarin Bible (named for the eighteenth-century collector in whose library a copy was "discovered") or, more familiarly, the Gutenberg Bible.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Nov. 21. -- The undefeated Port Chester High School football team today annexed the W.I.A.A. championship by virtue of a 19-to-6 triumph over Mamaroneck High before 3,000 persons on the loser's gridiron. The title is the first for the invaders in eleven seasons of tournament competition.

Mayor La Guardia nodded assent in Washington last Monday when, presiding over the Conference of Mayors, he heard his Police Commissioner, Lewis J. Valentine, give aggressive assurance that major racketeers have been put out of business in New York City.

WITH the depredations of the great El Tigre growing bolder and more frequent, terrorizing and scandalizing the whole border, the old marshal knew that something must be done. He knew also that of his whole staff there was only one man with enough daring and cunning and brains and shooting skill to put on the trail of the Mexican bandit.

THE chief outpost of Hollywood these days, you might as well know, is Colt's Ranch, far up near Santa Cruz. A good ten-hour ride over some 370 miles of burning ochre veldt sprinkled with a half dozen towns and a thousand gas stations.

Any one who had been following the progress of the "good neighbor" policy in the Western Hemisphere could have known that Latin Americans would be jubilant over the re-election of Franklin D. Roosevelt to the Presidency of the United States.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 20. -- Outside of the South, no section of the country should be more concerned over the outcome of the Federal attack on the farm-tenancy problem than the Corn Belt. Tenancy has been growing here at a rate and to a point disturbing alike from the standpoint of good husbandry and its social implications.

THAT all forms of energy on earth, life itself, are derived from the sun is now an axiom of science. Living organisms vary from a simple bit of protoplasm to man. Vegetation thrives on energy from the sun's light and heat. Animals eat vegetation, even fight for it, and this to keep body and soul together.

Much interest is being evidenced in the Sally Port dinner dance under the auspices of the alumnae of St. Mary's School in Peekskill, N.Y., to be held Dec. 5 at Sherry's for the benefit of the organization's scholarship fund. The entertainment will include general dancing, bridge, an amateur hour and varied divertissements.

Performances of current Broadway productions will be given in the near future to augment the funds for philanthropic organizations that carry on extensive relief programs among the needy and underprivileged.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 21. -- One of Cornell University's prized possessions, the first telegraph instrument, on which the classic message "What hath God wrought?" was received on May 24, 1844, was shipped last week to Washington, where it will again function Monday as a part of the centennial celebration of the American Patent System.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 21. -- The Mask and Wig Club held the premiere of its new show, "This Mad Whirl," at the du Pont Playhouse tonight before a brilliant audience. Members of Wilmington's social set and many prominent Philadelphians were present for the forty-ninth Mask and Wig presentation.

TORONTO, Nov. 21 (AP). -- The Boston Bruins, playing without their star defenseman, Eddie Shore, defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs 4 to 3 tonight. The victory moved Boston into third place in the American group, ahead of Chicago, and left the Leafs occupying the International Group cellar.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21. -- Temple University's freshman football team finished its season undefeated by routing Kiski School, 25 -- 0, at Temple Stadium today.

TELLICO PLAINS, Tenn., Nov. (AP). -- A footsore band of hunters tramped out of the Unaka Mountains today with little more than bunions and bruises to show for their tracking of the Prussian wild boars which roam these parts.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 21. -- Harvard tried to follow Yale's example in the game at the Bowl today and just fell short of being a splendid imitator.

In his spirited address at Rio de Janeiro, Secretary HULL emphasized the part which the Western Hemisphere might play in maintaining peace both at home and abroad. He expressed the hope that the Pan-American Congress, soon to open at Buenos Aires, would strike a high note in its resolutions on this subject.

The president and members of the board of directors of the Woman's Roosevelt Memorial Association will give a reception the afternoon of Dec. 7 at Roosevelt House, 28 East Twentieth Street, for officers and trustees of the Roosevelt Memorial Association and their wives.
BRESLAU, Germany, Nov. 21 (AP). -- German Catholicism appealed today to the people to save the rights to free worship within the nation.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 21. -- Election of officers of ten principal clubs on the campus of Georgian Court College, here, include five residents of New York City.
MUNICH, Germany, Nov. 21 (AP). -- Attacks on the "Jewish spirit" in science assumed sharper form in Research Department addresses read here today.

The first benefit performance of Maxwell Anderson's play, "The Wingless Victory," starring Katharine Cornell, at the Empire Theatre, will be held under the auspices of the Sarah Lawrence College Alumnae Club of this city the evening of Dec. 26. Mrs. David Channing Moore heads the committee on arrangements, assisted by Miss Nadine Marble, Miss Dorothy Noyes, Mrs. Richard Perkins, Miss Frances Weir and Mrs. Wilder Ripley.

Gardeners who intend to start seedling plants early in the Spring in a hotbed or coldframe, or indoors in a sunny window, save themselves a lot of time and trouble by storing away, before the advent of Winter, soil for that purpose.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 20. -- Argentina is preparing to give President Roosevelt a tremendous triumphal welcome such as has not been seen here since the visit of the Infanta Isabel of Spain twenty-six years ago.

The discussion in your columns of the pros and cons of a six-year Presidential term brings to mind an incident which I believe has never had publicity and which may be of interest in this connection. If President Harding had lived to the end of his term, it is quite possible that a constitutional amendment adopting the six-year plan would have been submitted.

"A turkey in every pot" might well have been the campaign slogan of either political party this year. For the first time in the history of the nation the domestic flock is large enough to supply nearly all Thanksgiving gatherings.

The "whirlwind rush of business turnover" continues to increase in practically all sections and holiday trade "should surpass anything that has occurred in a decade," according to the survey of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

WHY is the setting sun red? Because dust absorbs much of its light and lets only the red rays through. Professor Joel Stebbins and Albert E. Whitford have applied this fact to seventy-five stars in the Milky Way with results which they presented last week before the National Academy of Sciences.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- With advance bookings for Thanksgiving declared to be at the highest point in the last ten years, city officials and hotel men here are preparing to greet a record-breaking influx of holiday visitors.

Although peonies are among the most reliable of hardy border plants, they sometimes stubbornly refuse to set a bud or open a single blossom. Several possible reasons for this condition are then to be investigated and the method of culture changed.
Associated Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries (Present properties included irrespective of dates of acquisition) -- Year ended Oct. 31:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- In seeking a new basis for cooperation between government and industry, the board of directors of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States has recommended to its members the widest possible study of State compacts as a means for future regulation of industry.

The shattering of a 6-year-old Public Schools Athletic League swimming record by John Leitt of De Witt Clinton High School and a surprise victory by Textile over George Washington's triborough champion team were highlights of the eighth series of dual meets for the league's Manhattan-Bronx-Richmond senior high school title, conducted in the 75-foot Clinton pool yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 21 (AP). -- Osbert Burdett, English writer, died today of a fractured skull suffered when he fell down a subway escalator. He was 51.

The General Education Board, 49 West Forty-ninth Street, founded by John D. Rockefeller in 1902, appropriated $9,489,358.31 for educational projects during the year ended June 30, an increase of $1,995,208.28 over the previous year, it was reported yesterday.

Increases in enrollment in the WPA adult education program of the Board of Education are shown in a report last week listing 42,047 students, an increase of nearly 50 per cent over the Summer registration. There are 1,724 teachers. Records also show rapid progress in the campaign for literacy.

BERLIN, Nov. 21. -- The Boerse weakened at the opening today and then became totally stagnant throughout the list. Foreign stocks declined slightly. Heavy industrials had a small turnover, Vereinigtestahl and Rheinstahl each lost 1/2 point.
Data concerning Meleagris gallopavo, which will grace many of our tables this Thursday:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21. -- The wholesale dry goods houses here continued to do excellent business this week and sales generally were between 30 and 35 per cent ahead of last year. Chain-store buyers have been in the market this week, attempting to augment their Christmas orders with local wholesale houses.

WASHINGTON, Pa., Nov. 21. -- Dom Roselli, Youngstown (Ohio) sophomore quarterback, tossed a pass for 18 yards to Bruce Wilson, end, with only three minutes to play in the final quarter to give Geneva College a 6-to-3 victory over W. and J. today.

Members of the international relations department of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs are actively following up a resolution to discourage the purchase and sale of military toys which was introduced last week by their chairman, Mrs. Raymond H. Keith, and passed by the State executive board.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 21. -- Wesleyan University is admired for its historic College Row, with certain of its more than a century old buildings. The casual visitor, however, seldom inspects the rather unique underground Wesleyan which is rapidly developing under student and faculty encouragement.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- A farewell breakfast to be given here by Mrs. Avery Coonley and official receptions at Havana, Barranquilla, Guayaquil, Africa and Santiago will mark the progress of the members of the Peace Mandate Committee's delegation to the Pan-American conference.

Italy has sent us a new Ambassador, Fulvio Suvich, who has been brought up in the spirit of the Fascist revolution and certainly should be able to interpret to the American public what fascism really is. None of the recent Ambassadors has been able to give us that interpretation because none was really brought up as a Fascist.

PARIS. CERTAIN theatrical productions have a particularly happy influence on the mode, because the type of costume worn coincides with the general fashion trend of the season. At a first night or gala performance of such a play there is an exciting rapport between the costumes worn on the two sides of the footlights.

WELLESLEY, Mass. Nov. 21. -- Wellesley graduates marry college men, marry in their middle twenties, and marry only once, statistics indicate. Students who leave Wellesley before commencement turn to matrimony earlier and in larger numbers, and are less likely to ask for a divorce. Fewer in the latter group find husbands with college degrees.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 21. -- Cheerfully discussing the topics of the day from her bed in the Fitkin-Memorial Hospital here, Miss Annie Emery of 339 West Twentieth Street, New York, who will celebrate her 100th birthday on Friday, chuckled today when asked to comment on the friendship of King Edward and Mrs. Simpson.
Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of New York University, announced yesterday the award of ninety-five scholarships in the School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance for the current academic semester.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- Hundreds of visitors who came to this North Carolina resort for the National Professional Golfers Association tournament are expected to stay on at hotels here through next week-end, and Pinehurst is counting on one of the largest crowds for the Thanksgiving holidays.

TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 20. -- In a few days the fifty-sixth annual convention of the American Federation of Labor, entering its second week, will make a decision on the split that has developed in its ranks -- a decision that will profoundly affect labor's future.

ONE of the important community "good turns" which the Boy Scouts carry on is their work with social welfare agencies. In recent years they have contributed increasing time and effort to the collection of clothing, household furnishings and food for the needy.

WARSAW, Nov. 21. -- Will Danzig be the object of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's next week-end coup, now that he has disposed of all clauses interfering with Germany's internal sovereignty and any further move in denouncing more of the Versailles treaty must be directed outside the Reich's borders?

The two most interesting points about the Italo-German recognition of General Franco's government in Spain are: First, that it took place at the time appointed for it, but not in the circumstances which had been expected; second, that it is a further proof of Italo-German solidarity.

STARKVILLE, Miss., Nov. 21. -- A more conservative program for aiding Southern share-croppers and tenant farmers than that recommended by Rexford G. Tugwell, Under-Secretary of Agriculture, was taking shape tonight in the party of Secretary Wallace and his associates, who are touring the Cotton Belt seeking information to decide the best status of the Resettlement Administration in the Department of Agriculture.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 21. -Federal Judge Guy L. Fake has announced his willingness to hold a special court session to naturalize Miss Jessie F.M. Harrod, superintendent of nurses at the Community Hospital in Montclair, who is critically ill there, and whose desire to become an American citizen has been frustrated by one difficulty or another for twenty years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- The article in the German military Weekly Militar Wochenblatt indicating that the tanks and armored cars of the United States Army are second rate by European standards was refuted today by War Department officers, while some of its assertions were said to be completely in error.

Skiers are beginning to think about their trappings for the snow fields. Soon snow trains, laden with sport seekers, will be starting forth from the city's terminals. Against that time the shops are stocking up on equipment for skiing excursions.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 21 (AP). -- Mickey Miers, left halfback of the Davis-Elkins team, intercepted a pass and ran 90 yards for a touchdown in today's football game with Springfield, but not even this feat could keep Captain Warren Huston and his mates from posting a 20-6 triumph over the West Virginians.
A BELL rings and a voice from the loudspeaker resounds through the waiting room of the Pan American terminal on the shores of San Francisco Bay.

BUS travel is gaining in passenger comfort and convenience and in safety provisions through the cooperation of manufacturers and operators with the authorities. One of the most striking bus improvements is pressure ventilation, the use of which is not even suspected by the general public.
Miss Charlotte E. Carr, executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, reported yesterday that only 15 to 20 per cent of new jobs in this city were going to persons from the home relief rolls.

LONDON, Nov. 18. -- With the most interest centered on the opening this Saturday (Nov. 21) of Sir James M. Barrie's long-awaited "The Boy David" at Edinburgh, the coming week's openings in London, although auspicious, assume the nature of an anti-climax.
The teaching of religion to public school children during time released from their daily schedules was advocated yesterday by Bishop Ernest M. Stires of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island.

I HAVE been a wanderer, and the child of chance, all days; and now only look for the time when I shall enter my last ship and be anchored with a green turf upon my breast; and I care not how soon the command be given."

LEADERS of the automobile industry whose views I have been able to obtain agree unanimously that never before have their new models received a more auspicious introduction than was experienced during the National Automobile Show, which closed in Grand Central Palace last Wednesday.

Four art teachers have sent to THE NEW YORK TIMES a spirited protest against the national exhibition of art work by high school students now on view at the American Museum of Natural History. The objectors are Professor Arthur Young of Teachers College, Columbia University; Ralph M. Pearson of the Design Workshop; Victor D'Amico of the Ethical Culture School, Fieldston, and Florence Cane of the Florence Cane School of Art.

LONDON, Nov. 21. -- With the stock markets here closed, money was plentiful today, with demand small, at one-half of 1 per cent. Discounts were steady at around nine-sixteenths of 1 per cent for fine three-month bills.

IT all depends upon the point of view. For instance, the average visitor sitting spellbound in the vast auditorium of the Center Theatre and watching the elaborate magnificence of "White Horse Inn" unroll upon the stage would do little more than assume -- if he even went so far -- that a certain amount of mechanical contrivance was going into the operation of the show.

A municipal council for children, ministering to the needs of the city's youth, is seen by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, as the final objective in his proposed plan to coordinate the budget requests of all city departments concerned with child welfare.

IN this leisurely written discussion about trees, Dr. Cross has not included any new information, most of the content-matter being familiar to those who, like Dr. Cross, have made a hobby of studying trees. The book contains much material on the care, pruning and spraying of trees, with chapters on definite groups of trees for definite purposes, but it is not always complete nor accurate.

Branch banks, although numbering little more than one-fifth of all banks in the country, employ more than two-fifths of all the bank employes and pay about 45 per cent of the compensation paid to all bank employes, according to a nationwide census of the banking business made by the Department of Commerce, the results of which have just been made public.

READERS who chortled over the escapades of "Those Plummer Children" will remember that among the first to stir up trouble in that active family of Tennessee children was Judy and her co-partner in crime, Chris Ellery. In this book those two scamps take the center of the stage.

ITALY is just now making merry at its annual grape festivals, staged wherever big vineyards yield their tons of wine-giving fruit. Through the Tuscany Valley and in the Abruzzi area, pickers are staggering under baskets overflowing with bunches of grapes.

With the demand for seasonal apparel a feature and with early Christmas shopping on the increase, retail trade in the local area made an excellent showing last week. Average department store volume for the week was estimated as ranging from 15 to 18 per cent larger than in the comparative 1935 period.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Nov. 21. -- A 94-yard return of the opening kick-off for a touchdown by John Patrick, sophomore back, featured Penn State's 14-to-0 Victory over Bucknell today, the first victory scored over the Bisons in ten years.

THE critical panel boxed in the Manchester Opera House of an October night some thirteen months ago to meditate on Noel Coward's one-act plays -- then six in number and because of the bedtime practices of the parishioners collectively identified as "Tonight at Seven-thirty" -- were startled if no whit displeased by "the longest kiss ever seen East of Suez."

Two hundred women, representing civic and social organizations of the city, attended a conference on Spain yesterday afternoon and pledged their aid to the Loyalist Government in a ten-point program that includes the collection of funds, food, clothing and medical supplies to be sent to the troubled areas.

BOSTON, Nov. 21. -- Boston University closed its most successful football season in history today by holding its traditional rival, Boston College, to a scoreless tie in a hard-fought game which held 15,000 spectators spellbound through four periods at Fenway Park.

THE first two-thirds of the nineteenth-century New England was, unquestionably, an exciting period. Just how exciting we did not entirely realize until, of late, the warm genius of Van Wyck Brooks illuminated the spiritual and intellectual flowering of these days.

Dr. Isadore Wengraf, 62 years old, of 1,556 Fiftieth Street, Brooklyn, a Health Department employe, against whom the grand jury filed an information in the Court of Special Sessions charging conspiracy to commit larceny, surrendered yesterday morning to Assistant District Attorney Bernard Botein, in charge of the Accident Fraud Bureau in the District Attorney's office.

MADRID, Nov. 21. -- The merciless bombing and bitter fighting in University City, on the northwestern edge of Madrid, is likely to continue next week, unless wintry weather forces a halt by both sides.

The Rye Country Club, Inc., and its subsidiary, the Whitby Holding Corporation, yesterday petitioned Federal court for permission to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act, asserting they were unable to meet their debts as they matured.
The American Indian was noted for his strict observance of Thanksgiving Days for many centuries before the arrival of the white man in America.

Miss Barbara Hill heads a large group of debutantes who are aiding in the sale of boxes and seats for the recital by Kirsten Flagstad of the Metropolitan Opera to be held the night of Dec. 9 at Carnegie Hall for the benefit of the New York Women's Trade Union League. Already an encouraging subscription has been reported.

Selection of Dean Virginia Gildersleeve of Barnard College as recipient of this year's Achievement Award focuses attention on the million-dollar Fellowship Fund of the American Association of University Women, indicative of the educational interests for which she was cited.

Miss Rosalind Everdell has organized a junior committee to assist the sale of programs at the joint concert to be given at the Hippodrome on the night of Dec. 1 by Paul Whiteman's Orchestra and the Philadelphia Orchestra for the benefit of the Museum of American Music, which Mr. Whiteman has founded at Williams College, and the pension fund of the Philadelphia Orchestra.
Buying of steel by railroads this year probably will reach the largest total for any year since 1930, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 21. -- Desperately fighting against the inevitable, Syracuse's victory-starved eleven possessed neither the power nor the plays to thwart Colgate today and the Red Raiders from the Chenango finished on the winning end of a 13-0 score in the presence of 20,000 chilled spectators at Archbold Stadium.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21. -- Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson handed down today an opinion approving tentatively a plan for reorganization and financial consolidation of the companies constituting the Chicago Surface Lines, which have been in receivership ten years.

Earl Humphrey, head of the Independent Anthracite Miners Association, the organization Which has raised coal bootlegging to the status of a $32,000,000-a-year industry, said yesterday that any effort by the big coal operators or the State to stamp out illicit mining by force, would lead inevitably to bloodshed in the anthracite region of Pennsylvania.
PARIS, Nov. 20 -- Suicide has introduced a new and tragic factor into the French political situation.

Demand for seasonal merchandise in the wholesale markets was stimulated by the cold weather last week, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. Many orders requested immediate delivery, which is difficult to obtain. The report continues:

EASTPORT, Me., Nov. 20 -- Rumors that the Quoddy tidal power project will be revived cannot be downed. This to many is more than a hope. It is something that is expected. President Roosevelt said last Summer that Quoddy would be built and the utmost confidence is felt here that it will.

LONDON. THE bells of St. Bartholomew the Great, one of the oldest and most celebrated of London's churches, ring no more. The ancient priory building was erected in 1123 and stands in Smithfield, where martyrs were once burnt and meat markets now flourish.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 21 (AP). -- "Strictly private" might have been written on the door of a hotel dining room tonight where Mary Pickford and Charles (Buddy) Rogers gave a dinner to make the announcement of their engagement "official."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21. -- Carrying the idea of athletic competition over into the fields of literature and art, President Gates of the University of Pennsylvania announced plans today for "cultural Olympics" to be conducted by the university's School of Education.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 21 (AP). -- Dr. Melvin Newman of Ohio State University disclosed tonight that research in the age-old quest for the cause of cancer had led to composition of numerous chemical substances which produced the disease.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Nov. 21. -- Isaac I. Kashdan of New York, chess champion of New York State, tonight captured first prize in the international chess masters tournament at the Club de Ajedrez de San Juan with a score of 6 1/2 points out of a possible 7.
OMAHA, Nov. 21. -- A dinner will be held here on Dec. 5, honoring Carl R. Gray, president of the Union Pacific, and Mrs. Gray, whose golden wedding anniversary will occur the next day.

IN the current issue of the bi-monthly magazine Prints, Aline Kistler, the editor, launches a Prints of the Moment department, "founded to stimulate interest and arouse observation of current production." Miss Kistler appointed a jury or "reviewing group," the members of which look over all of the prints submitted over a definite period and select those that in their opinion seem most worthy.

IDENTIFYING authors with national groups seems a rather arbitrary business. Lafcadio Hearn, for instance, was born in the Greek Island of Leucadia of a native mother and an Irish father. He was brought up in Dublin and England, and it was not until 1869 that he came to America.

Designs for American Living might well have been the subtitle of this handsome book, unique in juvenile literature. The development of architecture is as intimately interwoven into the fabric of history as election campaigns and battles, and while this is not a history in the formal sense, it is a broad interpretation of Colonial architecture in America, its traditions, its determinant factors, and its place in the great sweep of American expansion.
The powerful and accurate booting of Mickey Rutner enabled Monroe High School to regain its P.S.A.L. soccer championship yesterday at Hawthorne Field, Brooklyn, by defeating Manual Training, 2 -- 0.

A coordinated program of education, research and care of the sick will be carried on by the School of Medicine of Columbia University in conjunction with the hospitals of the metropolitan area, it is disclosed in the annual report of Dean Willard C. Rappleye to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, made public yesterday.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Nov. 21. -- Trees which were native to the region of Connecticut in the pre-glacial period but have been unknown there since that time are being successfully grown in the Connecticut Arboretum at Connecticut College, where it is hoped that ultimately every tree and shrub ever native to the State will be represented.
SHREVEPORT, La., Nov. 21 (AP). -- The Texas Aggies, failing to display their usual strength, bowed to the Centenary jinx again today as a second-period field goal gave the Gentlemen a 3-to-0 victory.

A sharp improvement in the condition of world shipping as reflected in the volume of tonnage in operation, ships under construction, the reduction of idle tonnage and similar factors is noted by Lloyd's Register of Shipping in its annual report, published yesterday.

MANCHESTER, England, Nov. 21. -- Italy's new empire in Ethiopia is at present showing the results of a "muddled policy." according to a staff correspondent of The Manchester Guardian, who has just returned from the African country.

While "Regulations 94," promulgated by the Bureau of Internal Revenue under the Revenue Act of 1936, approved by the Treasury on Nov. 12 and made available for distribution in the past week, deals copiously with the surtax on corporate undistributed profits, many phases of this complex measure remain unclarified.

RADIO showmen are being warned to prepare for television. Demonstrations in New York and London reveal that the research experts are about ready to give them a chance to see what they can do in telecasting entertainment.

A plea that employers give greater consideration to the needs of young people leaving school for jobs in industry and commerce was made before the fourth Metropolitan Conference on Employment and Guidance yesterday by Miss Elizabeth R. Roby, vocational counselor for the Board of Education.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 21. -- It seemed reasonably certain tonight that the feminists' "popular conference in favor of peace" would be able to meet tomorrow as scheduled despite the stubborn refusal of police and municipal authorities to issue a permit on the ground that the organizers are Communists.

ENGLAND is determined to "pump" more power into its short-wave stations so that the British lion may roar around the world, according to representatives of the British Broadcasting Corporation in New York during the past week to participate in the tenth anniversary celebration of the National Broadcasting Company.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 21. -- New Rochelle gained power as the game progressed to defeat the A.B. Davis High School, 20 -- 6, before 9,000 spectators today at Howard Field. The victory enabled New Rochelle to finish in a tie for the W.I.A.A. lead.

Final arrangements are being made this week for the forum to be held under auspices of the National Council of Women in connection with the annual meeting here of its board of directors Dec. 2, 3 and 4. Through discussions outlined, it is hoped to arrive at an evaluation of the influence women have had in development of civilization and to estimate their potentialities for future service.

DETROIT, Nov. 21 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin tonight had the answer of the Catholic Laymen's League to an article in next Monday's issue of Social Justice, in which he says the league has attacked him "more viciously than has any Communist in America."
