TAMPA, Nov. 21. -- The American Federation of Labor's committee on education legislation in a statement tonight charged that the organized employers of the nation were banded together to "throttle" the La Follette committee's investigation of industrial espionage and the use of strike-breakers in industrial disputes.

MADRID, Nov. 21 (Censored). -- The defense junta today directed the orderly evacuation of women, children and old men from this besieged city. The decision to transfer them to Eastern Spain followed the killing of hundreds of non-combatants in Rebel air raids and artillery bombardments in the past several weeks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP). -- An air-conditioned farm, with fields lighted like city streets, would help along the growing of plants, according to the results of recent experiments by scientists at Smithsonian Institution, the Department of Agriculture and Purdue University.

Mayor La Guardia will confer "certificates of distinguished service" upon the nine members of the now defunct Charter Revision Commission in the Board of Estimate Chamber in City Hall at 4 P.M. tomorrow, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- To keep pace with the additional work placed upon it by the current naval building program, the navy's civil service "land navy" has been boosted this year to a strength of nearly 70,000, a gain of about 6,000 over last year.

LONDON, Nov. 21. -- A display of coronation robes is being held in Norfolk House, the London home of the Earl Marshal, the Duke of Norfolk. In the magnificent drawing room overlooking St. James Square two models showed the splendor of the crimson velvet robes that will be worn by peers and peeresses next May.

THE idea of trying to climb Mount Everest did not begin to take definite shape until after the end of the World War. And Sir Francis Younghusband, as president of the Royal Geographical Society, was particularly active in bringing the idea to its first truition.
The epitome of dignity, Charles Evans Hughes, Chief Justice of the United States, leaned across the bench a few days ago to call up a case.

With a field of riders coming from seven different countries New York's sixty-first international six-day bicycle race will start in Madison Square Garden a week from tonight. The entrants are from Belgium, Canada, France, Germany, the Netherlands, Italy and the United States.

The sale of English and French furniture, tapestries, jewelry and other objects of art which the American Art Association Anderson Galleries will conduct next Friday and Saturday afternoons is made up of the property of more than six owners.

VATICAN CITY, Nov. 20. -- Pope Pius now may be considered a very old man. In his eightieth year he suffers infirmities of old age, aggravated by persistent asthma, which has troubled him greatly in the past year. But there is nothing in his general condition to justify any immediate alarm.

CHRISTMAS sailings for those who would spend the festive season in the old country are offered by several steamship lines. The Batory of the Gdynia America Line leaves New York on Dec. 13 for Copenhagen. A special stop will be made at Christiansand for the convenience of persons en route to Norway cities.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21. -- Attorneys for the twelve financiers and lawyers indicted in connection with the reorganization of the bankrupt Philadelphia Company for Guaranteeing Mortgages decided today to work together for the "most efficient defense."

WATNESBURG, Pa., Nov. 21 (AP). -- A 22-yard pass by Fullback Windish and a 45-yard sprint by 210-pound Vince Phillips after catching the toss in the final period gave the West Chester Teachers a touchdown and a 12-to-7 triumph today over Waynesburg.

SINCE Austin Dobson produced his enthusiastic appreciation of William Hogarth, with an exhaustive introduction by Sir Walter Armstrong and a large number of excellent plates, no writer has needed to labor the fact that Hogarth's place in English art is unique. In his own day, which covered more than the first half of the eighteenth century, no one seems to have come near to a fair, critical appraisal of his value.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- The Public Works Administration has become America's leading hospital-builder. Its construction program included more than two-thirds of all hospitals built in the past three years, according to a report to Administrator Ickes.

CHARLES BURCHFIELD is not a prolific painter, but he is a prodigious worker. His exhibitions prove that. About once in two years he brings forward a small group of water-colors. That is all he has to show for the interim between one appearance and the preceding.

An adequate appropriation in the new State budget to provide for making effective the legislation extending the merit system in civil service is being sought from Governor Lehman and Budget Director Abraham Weber by the League of Women Voters.

The performance of "The Flying Dutchman," in which Kirsten Flagstad will make her debut as Senta on Jan. 7 at the Metropolitan Opera has been taken over to raise funds for the Florence Crittenton League. Supporting roles in the performance will be sung by Emanuel List, Frederick Schorr and Charles Kullman.

INCREASING its margin over last year, retail trade last week through the country probably ran 20 per cent larger, according to an average Struck from reports received here. About the only section which did not tell of rising volume was the Pacific Coast, where the shipping strike continues to retard sales.

Miss Jeannette Rankin, first woman elected to Congress, will speak on "The Standard of Civilization" at a joint meeting tomorrow of the Twentieth Century Club of Richmond Hill and the Department of International Relations of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 21. -- Playing before a crowd of 10,000, a fighting, stubborn St. Anselm's eleven held the powerful favorite Holy Cross to a scoreless tie today. The Bobcats, showing a gigantic defense, bottled up Holy Cross's highly touted attack all through the game to record a surprising upset in the final home game for the Crusaders.
RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 21 (AP). -- Herbert G. Claudius of Oakland, Calif., was elected national president of Scabbard and Blade, military fraternity, today.

PERSISTING in her quite understandable search for quiet and contemplative peace off the main concrete highways, Miss Willa Cather gives us a small book of literary essays. In them she cultivates an atmosphere of calm in which the melodies of her special tastes will not be drowned out by the blatant concerto of contemporary criticism.
ARLINGTON, Texas, Nov. 21 (AP). -- Infantry raced the mile and a sixteenth in 1:44 today to take the Fort Worth Handicap and lower the track record at Arlington Downs by four-fifths of a second.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- One out of every six farmers in the United States moves each year, according to a recent Census Bureau study. Share-croppers move most often, the records disclosing that 57 per cent of the men who farm on that basis in the South pull up stakes every two years.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 21. -- Declaring he "loved her too much." Brig. Gen. Henry H. Denhardt today denied from a jail cell that he fired the shot that killed Verna Taylor, his fiancee, the night of Nov. 6.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 21. -- There was no gloom in the Harvard dressing room among the members of the gallant team after their defeat by Yale. Only Vernon Struck was a bit unhappy because he had not succeeded in kicking the point that would have given his team a tie and -- judging from pre-game predictions and betting -- most certainly a moral victory.

WITH an almost total lack of the usual premonitory fanfares, The Friends of Recorded Music has sprung to life, full-fledged. That is to say, the first recording under the auspices of the society is not merely announced as having been tentatively planned and ready to launch -- pending the expenses and a liberal profit being met by advance subscriptions.

THE phenomenal development of skiing last year, unprecedented in the annals of sportdom, will be completely overshadowed this Winter if pre-season activity and bustle can serve as a barometer. All along the Atlantic Coast, from Pennsylvania to the northernmost point of Canada, the stage is set for a season in which only heavy snowfalls are needed to complete the glowing picture.

Brooklyn civic leaders approved yesterday the action of the Board of Estimate permitting the acquisition of the Brooklyn Elks Club Buildings at Livingston and Schermerhorn Streets, Brooklyn, for the main administrative offices of the Board of Education.

LINDEN, N.J., Nov. 21. -- About 700 union craftsmen employed on the construction of the $5,500,000 plant of the General Motors Corporation in Edgar Road walked out in a sympathy strike with a group of laborers yesterday afternoon.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 21. -- One single point, the margin of a knife blade's thickness, separated the teams of Yale and Harvard today at the close of their fifty-fifth game of football. And the figures on the scoreboard at the end, Yale 14, Harvard 13, described tersely what had taken place during the previous two hours on the torn turf of the Yale Bowl.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Eric C. Wendelin, Third Secretary in charge of the United States Embassy in Madrid, has been instructed by the State Department to give immediate consideration to the desirability of closing the embassy and proceeding with his staff and American nationals who wish to leave the city, to a safer place.
AMES, Iowa, Nov. 21 (AP). -- Iowa State routed Drake, 21 to 7, in the thirty-sixth renewal of their traditional football rivalry today before 7,000 fans.
COLLEGE PARK, Md., Nov. 21 (AP). -- A fourth quarter offensive carried the Georgetown University eleven to a 7-6 victory over the University of Maryland today before 12,000 fans.

AMONG choral concerts to be given this season in London are two scheduled by the Philharmonic Choir, which, under Kennedy Scott in the Queen's Hall, will present a miscellaneous program, ranging from Palestrina to Holst and later to Bach's "St. Matthew Passion."
WACO, Texas, Nov. 21 (AP). -- Two touchdown sprints by Quarterback Lloyd Russell, Baylor's campus idol, dazed a Southern Methodist football team that fought back but finally fell, 13 -- 7, today.

A mystery involving the death of a 5-year-old boy who had apparently collapsed in front of his home from some internal ailment was solved last night, the police said, when his playmates reported that he had been wedged against a hydrant by a truck that backed to the curb.

With 26,000,000 persons throughout the nation about to register under the Federal old-age retirement system, attention is focused on the Social Security Act under which this program is being promulgated. Within the year, it is expected, this enactment will come before the United States Supreme Court to face the test of constitutionality, primarily because of its provisions dealing with taxes for old-age annulties and unemployment insurance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- The first fiscal relief agency formed by the Federal Government in its battle against the depression was the RFC, which antedated Mr. Roosevelt's New Deal. The first shield for the currency fabricated by Congress after Mr. Roosevelt took office and laid his embargo on gold, was the Thomas amendment to the AAA Act of 1933, which conferred on the President the power to change the gold content of money.

Gerald Tracy, a young pianist from Salt Lake City, was heard in a recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon, the third he has given in this city. His program consisted of the Bach toccata in D major; Schubert's sonata in D major, Op. 53; the "Variations on a Theme by Handel," of Brahms, and the Ravel suite, "Le Tombeau de Couperin."

THE largest chorus of gobblers ever heard in the land was predicted recently by experts in touch with the poultry growers. A horde of turkeys, over 20,000,000 of them, is ready to meet the demands of housewives and restaurateurs on the hunt for the Thanksgiving dinner and for the other traditional feasts of Winter.

A mystery involving the death of a 5-year-old boy who had apparently collapsed in front of his home from some internal ailment was solved last night, the police said, when his playmates reported that he had been wedged against a hydrant by a truck that backed to the curb.

With 26,000,000 persons throughout the nation about to register under the Federal old-age retirement system, attention is focused on the Social Security Act under which this program is being promulgated. Within the year, it is expected, this enactment will come before the United States Supreme Court to face the test of constitutionality, primarily because of its provisions dealing with taxes for old-age annulties and unemployment insurance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- The first fiscal relief agency formed by the Federal Government in its battle against the depression was the RFC, which antedated Mr. Roosevelt's New Deal. The first shield for the currency fabricated by Congress after Mr. Roosevelt took office and laid his embargo on gold, was the Thomas amendment to the AAA Act of 1933, which conferred on the President the power to change the gold content of money.

With less than two weeks remaining before the annual Beaux-Arts Ball is presented by the Society of Beaux-Arts Architects in the grand ballroom suite of the Astor, the many committees for the event are completing arrangements for the ballroom decorations and pageant sequences.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- The grade and staple report for the Cotton Belt issued today by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics shows that 34 per cent of the cotton classified during the week was white middling or better in grade. Fifty-eight per cent of all cotton classed to date from the 1936 crop has been so described.

Gerald Tracy, a young pianist from Salt Lake City, was heard in a recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon, the third he has given in this city. His program consisted of the Bach toccata in D major; Schubert's sonata in D major, Op. 53; the "Variations on a Theme by Handel," of Brahms, and the Ravel suite, "Le Tombeau de Couperin."

THE largest chorus of gobblers ever heard in the land was predicted recently by experts in touch with the poultry growers. A horde of turkeys, over 20,000,000 of them, is ready to meet the demands of housewives and restaurateurs on the hunt for the Thanksgiving dinner and for the other traditional feasts of Winter.

IN the University of Ohio are Drs. Oram C. Woolpert and N. Paul Hudson wondering about resitsance to disease, and immunity. They have already received some attention in the medical press because of their wondering.

Henry Feil led a strong Erasmus Hall High School football team to a 7-to-0 victory over New Utrecht at Erasmus Field yesterday. The contest was the final of the campaign for the victors, who compiled a record of four triumphs, two ties and one defeat.

AS a correspondent of The Herald Tribune in Geneva and Ethiopia, Mr. Whitaker saw the League of Nations in action during several crises and the army of Mussolini in battle against the doomed people of Emperor Haile Selassie.

THE vice president and general manager of Northwest Airlines, Croil Hunter, has a problem on his hands. His company flies between Chicago and St. Paul, continues westward to Seattle and operates a branch to Winnipeg.

Sea and land routes leading to Argentina began to fill last week with what Secretary of State Hull described as "groups of pilgrim brothers," bound for Buenos Aires, where, on Dec. 1, they will gather at a common table to seek an agreement which will keep the Americas at peace.

A stanza from the Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam is one of the clues in this murder mystery, which opens with a preliminary chapter describing the execution of a murderer and bank robber who dies without revealing where his loot is hidden.

THE outstanding literary events of the week read strangely in juxtaposition; namely, the publication of "More Poems" (Cape), by A.E. Housman, and of "In the Steps of St. Paul" (Rich Cowan), by H.V. Morton.

BAIREUTH. ONE of the most radical steps that Wahnfried has ever taken will he the publication within a short time of the complete and unexpurgated correspondence of Wagner and Ludwig II of Bavaria. It is understood that the letters of the composer and his royal patron will be issued before the end of the year in four volumes and that many hitherto unpublished documents will be brought to light for the first time.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21. -- Moving like the champion he is, Vigow of Romanoff, the cream-colored Russian wolfhound owned by Louis J. Murr of Spring Valley, N.Y., topped a field of 880 dogs in the one-day dog show conducted by the Kennel Club of Philadelphia at Convention Hall tonight.

BABYLON. L.I., Nov. 21. -- Nassau County police marksmen won the annual pistol shooting championship of the Nassau-Suffolk County Association, on the New York State Police range at Wyandanch today, defeating five-man teams from fifteen villages and departments, with a point score of 1,460.

ROME, Nov. 21. -- It is a curious fact that now that the guns are actually booming in Spain and a first-class crisis is seen in the offing between the Fascist and Nazi dictatorships on the one side and Russia on the other, there is very little fear in Italy of a general European conflagration.
STATE COLLEGE, Miss., Nov. 21 (AP). -- Mississippi State College crushed its traditional rival, University of Mississippi, 26 to 6, in their annual football game today before a crowd of 20,000.

Dogmatists are as dangerous as wars, according to Andre Maurois, French biographer, essayist and novelist, who, in an interview last week at the Hotel Ritz Carlton suggested that scientific methods ought to be applied in politics. He is here on a short visit and will return next Wednesday.

More than 1,000 of his friends and associates attended a testimonial luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Astor in honor of Frederick Z. Lewis, teacher member of the Teachers Retirement Board. The luncheon was tendered by the Teachers Assembly District Clubs in recognition of Mr. Lewis's twenty years of service on the Board.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21. -- Plans for a rally of 8,000,000 Methodist Episcopal communicants on Feb. 15 in the individual churches throughout the country were discussed at a business session today of the annual meeting of the Methodist Episcopal Board of Home Missions and Church Extension.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 21. -- La Salle Military Academy, of Oakdale, L.I., became the sixth consecutive victim of Hun School's powerful football team today. The Cadets went down to a 25-7 defeat in a contest in which the Hun regulars performed only half the playing time.

The stock market resisted yesterday the downward trend of the preceding three days, and on the average recovered all of the Friday losses. Gains at the closing ranged from fractions to 2 points. Trading on the Stock Exchange, however, was the smallest since Oct. 31, the day's turnover amounting to 802,000 shares.

An anniversary party has been arranged by a group of women interested in the work of the Lots for Little Shop, of which Miss Agnes Franklin Keyes is president and founder. It will be held Dec. 3 at La Salle du Bois to raise funds for the organization.

The Boys High School eleven conquered Abraham Lincoln High, 33 -- 13, yesterday before a crowd of 7,000 persons at Boys High Field and finished its campaign as the city's sole undefeated and untied aggregation. At the same time Boys sent its record of straight triumphs to fourteen in two seasons.

Often the rock gardener's attention is occupied with the beautiful and showy Western native plants to the exclusion of a knowledge or appreciation of the good plants which originate nearer at hand. Fall is the best time for planting many of these natives of Eastern America, especially the early flowering varieties, but they may also be set out in early Spring.

WACO, Texas, Nov. 21 (AP). -- On the eve of his sixty-seventh birthday, Vice President John Nance Garner donned cap and gown here today and joined Mrs. Garner to receive honorary degrees of Doctor of Laws from Baylor University, the State's oldest educational institution.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20. -- Statements by Mayor S. Davis Wilson and other officials calling for reorganization of the city government are regarded here as fairly good evidence that the next regular session of the Legislature in January will be flooded with bills providing for reforms.

The consumer cooperative movement represents an opportunity to return to the economic ideals of the signers of the Declaration of Independence and is a completely American way of living, is was declared by speakers yesterday at the final session of the Institute on Human Relations at 2 West Sixty-fourth Street.

A THOUSAND leaders in science, invention and industry will gather tomorrow in Washington to commemorate the centennial of our patent system. There will be addresses, exhibitions of inventions, a concert in which factory sounds will mingle with music, motion-picture films of technical processes and a dinner at which foods treated by patented processes will be served.
A drive in the last quarter which netted two touchdowns gave Curtis an 18-to-6 victory over Alexander Hamilton High yesterday at Thompson's Stadium, Staten Island.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 21. -- The unprecedented floods which struck the Finger Lakes Region of Central New York last year and the destructive sleetstorm of March have their repercussions in the annual report of Charles D. Bostwick, controller of Cornell University, for the academic year 1935-36, made public today.
HARTFORD, Nov. 21. -- Playing his last intercollegiate game Captain Mickey Kobrosky today led Trinity to a decisive 33-0 triumph over the University of Vermont eleven.

MOSCOW, Nov. 21. -- Never has the danger of war appeared so acute and so immediate to Moscow eyes as it appears today -- never even in the tensest days of Soviet-Japanese squabbles and of the skirmishes along the Manchurian borders which anywhere else would inevitably have proclaimed war.

The most reliable flowering plant for a garden in the house is undoubtedly still the old-fashioned zonal geranium. When this plant is not satisfactory it is usually for one of two reasons -- the use of Summer-weary stock, or too little sunshine in their Winter quarters.

FIRST consideration today must be given to the memoirs of a distinguished scholar. "Niegeschaute Welten" (S. Fischer, Berlin) is the title of this volume by Jakob Baron von Uexkuell, the noted biologist and deep-sea explorer, who is active in the famous museum of maritime life, which he helped found, in Naples.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Although its administrator, Rexford Guy Tugwell, is retiring to go into the molasses business, the Resettlement Administration gives every indication of marching on. Friends of this agency, studying the events of the past fortnight, are convinced that it will not be allowed to die when its original term of life runs out next June.

Here is another adventure of the Baron von Kaz, the Austrian nobleman who is, by his own admission, a great detective. Whether or not one agrees with the Baron's estimate of himself, one must admit that his is a colorful personality and that the stories about him are rich in entertainment as well as in puzzlement.

KWEISUI, Suiyuan Province, China, Nov. 21 (AP). -- Foreigners, including Japanese, fled this province today because of the threatening Eastern Suiyuan-Chahar border crisis, the result of invasions, allegedly Japanese-sponsored, of the North China area.

MANILA, Nov. 21 (AP). -- Talk of a new rift among the Moros over the Sultanate of Sulu appeared today as Moslems from all over the Sulu archipelago gathered at the Maimbung capital for the funeral of Sultan Mawallil Wasit.

FORTY speakers of national prominence have been invited to participate in the program of the First National Conference on Educational Broadcasting, to be held Dec. 10, 11 and 12, at the Mayflower Hotel in Washington, D.C. The meeting will be conducted in cooperation with the Federal Communications Commission and the United States Office of Education.

Wide interest and extensive bidding by both dealers and private purchasers marked the second day's sale yesterday of the auction of property belonging to Mrs. Herbert Shipman of Newport, R.I., and the River House, this city, at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries.

For once it can be said that America will "definitely" influence the work of a great French designer. That designer is Captain Edward Molyneux, who recently visited New York and is now on his way home to Paris. The main purpose of his visit was to observe the American woman.
AUGUSTA, Ga. -- With the Augusta Open Golf Tournament scheduled to start on Friday, golf and Thanksgiving festivities constitute the principal attractions here for the week.

BERLIN, Nov. 21. -- Having achieved "a gratifying agreement in principle regarding all political, economic and cultural questions pending between Germany and Austria," Dr. Guido Schmidt, Austrian Foreign Minister, left Berlin on a special plane this afternoon, accompanied by Franz yon Papen, who is also returning to his Vienna post.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 21. -- One of the more significant steps taken in recent years by the Christian Association of Pembroke College in Brown University to broaden its activities through contacts with many agencies outside the college campus is that which characterizes the work of the deputations team of the association.

A material increase in the amount of the Christmas Club checks to be mailed to Rockaway residents by banks in the Rockaways for this year as compared with last was revealed in the figures made public by the banks yesterday. The total sum to be sent out will be well in excess of $350,000.

LONDON in 1805, recently reconstructed with due reverence by the producers of "Lloyd's of London," was a flowering garden. True, it was dirty, smoky, unpoliced and noisy, but the ladies and gentlemen of the period, determined to have a last fling at finery before the French Fiend (the First Consul Napoleon Bonaparte) crossed the Channel and enslaved them all, had achieved the ultimate in personal adornment.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the last distributions ordered by the directors follow:

BASED upon the success of the New York Automobile Show, radio manufacturers expect auto-radio sales to show a marked increase, possibly from 20 to 65 per cent, in 1937. It is estimated that more than 2,000,000 auto-radios will be the 1936 total.

The National Executive Council of the Socialist party decided yesterday to start a campaign to end or relax restrictions put on minority parties by the voting laws of various States. Its action was regarded as preparatory to a movement for cohesion among left-wing political organizations in the 1938 and 1940 national elections, possibly under the banner of a Farmer-Labor party.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Nov. 21. -- Members of the United States delegation to the inter-American peace conference arrived at Sao Paulo at 11 o'clock this morning for a one-day stay as guests of the city's American colony. They came from the port of Santos, to which the liner American Legion, which left Rio de Janeiro yesterday evening, had brought them.

The all-star amateur heavyweight boxing tournament to be staged tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden will have a large patronage from men and women of prominence in society, many of whom are interested in or associated with the West Side Hospital, beneficiary of the tourney.

THE recent stabilization accord between the United States, France and Great Britain and the still more recent action of France, Switzerland and Italy in substantially relaxing their restrictions against imports have again directed attention to the pressing necessity for securing economic stability for the world if war is to be averted.

MANY consider Luigi Dalla Piccola (Pola, 1904) one of the most up-and-coming of the younger Italian composers. He has come considerably to the fore of late in Italy's corporative contests and modern music festivals.

WITH the semi-final and final rounds of the current team-of-four tournament for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Trophy extending into this week, some New York players will have hardly finished in this tournament before leaving for Chicago, where the next major tournament of the year will begin next week.

IT is not surprising that Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt should have wished to write her own story of her life, and give to the public at large her own version of the notorious controversy over the guardianship and care of her child. What is surprising is that her book is done so badly.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 21. -- The St. Benedict's Prep School eleven gained a 34 -- 0 victory over the Admiral Farragut Naval Academy of Toms River today and the victors remained as New Jersey's lone combination in the unbeaten, untied and unscored upon class.

The Women's Division of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City reported yesterday that $336,000 of the $400,000 quota set in its charity drive was already collected. Mrs. Arthur Lehman, chairman of the 1936 campaign, issued the announcement.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- With an unusually large number of reservations made for the Thanksgiving week-end at this resort, the coming weeks are expected to see a big influx of visitors.

There are some Christmas stories which retain their freshness and tenderness long after the holly berries have dropped from brittle stems and the Christmas tree is only a spicy memory, stories which seem right at any time of the year, and this little book, only a trifle too large for a bulging stocking, is sure to find its place among them.

IN a scathing attack upon the government Winston Churchill has urged a parliamentary inquiry to find out why rearmament is not proceeding faster than it is. Churchill, who officially is simply one of 615 members of the House of Commons, has greatly gained in authority and prestige during recent months.

SEVENTEEN years ago one of the notable pioneering flights of aviation was in progress. Taking off from Hounslow on Nov. 12, 1919, Captain Ross Smith and Lieutenant K.M. Smith landed at Port Darwin, Australia, on Dec. 10. They had required 27 days 20 hours to make the trip "down under" in their Vickers-Vimy biplane powered with two 350-horsepower Rolls-Royce Eagle engines.

PAUL Whiteman will give his sole New York program of the season Tuesday night, Dec. 1, at the Hippodrome, when he will direct his own players and the Philadelphia Orchestra in a concert of American music for the benefit of the Museum of American Music founded by him at Williams College, and for the pension fund of the Philadelphia Orchestra.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 21 (AP). -- Filling the air with laterals and forwards, Tulane scalped Sewanee's helpless Tigers by 53 to 6 today before a crowd of 10,000.

THE new exhibition, fifteenth in the series held at the temporary galleries of the Municipal Art Committee, provides a pretty well balanced ration for the visitor and quite upholds the standard set by the recent shows. As before, groups formed outside have each been allotted a floor. A score of names already familiar to New York gallery-goers included in the roster.

After yesterday, no tired business woman who attended a special luncheon at the Hotel Biltmore can indulge herself without a qualm in her usual evening coddling of "a good dinner, a soft chair, a game of bridge and a radio program."

ONE of the most important premieres of the season will take place in Los Angeles under the direction of Otto Klemperer. It will be Ernest Bloch's newest work, "Voice in the Desert," for solo 'cellist and orchestra. Mr. Bloch completed the work recently in Switzerland.

A special matinee performance of "Carmen," with Gertrud Wettergren in the title role, will be given at the Metropolitan Opera House on Dec. 30 as the annual benefit for the six American colleges in the Near East. All the boxes have been taken for the performance.

THE earth rotates. Also it revolves around the sun. But the sun and all the other planets are part of the Milky Way, which Professors J.H. Oort of Leyden, J.S. Plaskett of the Dominion Observatory, Victoria, and Harlow Shapley of Harvard tell us is spinning like a huge disk.

BOSTON, Nov. 21. -- Champion Windsweep Ebony Boy, grand black dog owned by Miss Alice A. Dodsworth of the Windsweep Kennels of Sharon, Conn., tonight was awarded the title of best in show in the fifteenth annual specialty exhibition of the Cocker Spaniel Breeders' Club of New England.
FOR scholars to argue with me as Mr. Blank does," Housman once wrote, "is just the way to foster in me that arrogant temper to which I owe my deplorable reputation."

THE main title may read "James Cagney, co-producer, co-director, co-author and star." At no time in recent history has a player taken such a vital interest in his production nor had more at stake. In the midst of "Great Guy," which he is making with Douglas MacLean for Grand National, Cagney is fighting for his professional life.

MOSCOW, Nov. 21. -- A representative of a foreign power, who may easily be identified as the German Consul at Novosibirsk, has been directly involved in alleged sabotage in coal mines in Western Siberia by the testimony of E.I. Stickling, the German engineer who is on trial with eight Russians at Novosibirsk.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21. -- Although toy sales for the holidays are a little slower in developing this year than last, the general volume of retail trade continues to maintain a sharp gain over 1935. Sales increases of the leading department stores this week averaged about 18 per cent, with the gains per individual store ranging from 12 to 25 per cent.

A long-established service for youths of this city will benefit by a supper dance to be held on Dec. 7 in the Sert Room of the Waldorf Astoria. Many persons of prominence are patrons and patronesses for the event, which has been arranged to raise funds for the Big Brother Movement.

EVERY building shown in this aerial photograph of Greenfield Village, product of Henry Ford's hobby of collecting old buildings, has its significance in the history of the older America that passed with the coming of the machine age.
"Overwork and calumny have been too much. Together with grief they have conquered me. Good-bye .... "

Reckless Sunday drivers are responsible for a mortality of 10 per cent in the trees bordering Queens highways, it was asserted yesterday by Mrs. Charles B. Williams, Honorary Deputy Commissioner of Public Works. She gave a statistical report for the benefit of members of the borough tree planting committee, a subsidiary of the Queensboro Chamber of Commerce, at a meeting there yesterday.

FREEPORT, L.I., Nov. 21. -- Streaking through the air with an attack that bewildered the Instituto Politecnica Nacional eleven of Mexico, D.F., the powerful Baldwin High School juggernaut today captured the international gridiron classic at the Municipal Stadium by a score of 32 -- 12.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Nov. 21. -- Five All-Smith blazers were awarded in assembly this morning by Miss Nancy Zinsser, president of the Smith College Athletic Association, to those girls who have been members of three All-Smith teams during their college careers.

ROCHESTER, Nov. 21. -- Members of the First Unitarian Church of Rochester will see to it that in the future an old silver communion service in its possession is neither mislaid or lost. The service was discovered recently in the disused Tower Room of the old gray stone structure at Temple and Cortland Streets.

TOMORROW night at Carnegie Hall the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under the leadership of John Barbirolli, will give a concert for the benefit of its pension fund. A novelty of the program will be the Bach concerto in A minor for four pianos and orchestra, with Mischa Levitzki, Eugene List, Frank Sheridan and Beveridge Webster as soloists.

Although he failed to tally in his final game against Army on Saturday, Fred King, Hobart fullback, held first place in the Eastern college football scoring race. His closest rivals also have completed their seasons, and his record of eleven touchdowns and 9 points after touchdowns, for a total of 75 points, probably will stand as the season's high.

Leaders of the seamen's strike last night looked forward to an extension of the tie-up in Atlantic and Gulf ports today when they expect some 4,000 members of the Masters, Mates and Pilots Association and the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association to respond to strike calls by their organizations.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 22 (AP). -- The chief of Belgium's Fascist Rexists -- like Chancellor Adolf Hitler and Premier Benito Mussolini -- has forsworn humility.
CASA DE CAMPO, Outside Madrid, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Madrid troops lost two tanks in an unsuccessful counter-attack against this Insurgent stronghold, attacking officers said today.

It wasn't the money involved; it was the principle of the thing, explained Louis Hershkowitz yesterday to the ambulance surgeon who patched him up after he had driven an armed bandit from his store at 128 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn. There was less than $10 in the store when the robber entered, Hershkowitz said, adding:

JONESBORO, Ark., Nov. 22 (AP). -- Ed Paul Peacher, planter and Town Marshal of Earle, Ark., will go on trial in Federal court here tomorrow on a slave-holding charge, an accusation of which he professed ignorance.

PARIS, Nov. 22. -- While the funeral of Roger Salengro, Minister of the Interior, was being held at Lille, a monster Left demonstration massed in Paris, first to hear Premier Leon Blum's speech through loudspeakers placed around the Place de la Bastille and then to march in a procession to the Place de la Nation.

TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 22. -- The civil war in Spain will have a decisive effect on the future of the United States, according to Fernando de los Rios, Spanish Ambassador to the United States, who was the guest of a large group of his countrymen here today.

Football took its farewell bow for 1936 in many schools throughout the metropolitan district during the past week-end. Surprises were quite scarce as the favorites, for the most part, achieved further successes.

In the Atlantic and Gulf ports the shipping strike seems to be failing. It has been declared by the American Federation of Labor to be an outlaw strike, because it was against union rules and contracts. On the Pacific Coast, however, the strike appears to be growing more bitter and extensive, threatening as it now does to cut off needed food supplies from the Hawaiian Islands and from Alaska.

Holcombe Ward of New York heads the slate of officers proposed to direct the United States Lawn Tennis Association for 1937. The list of candidates was announced yesterday by the nominating committee, of which Samuel M. Peacock of Philadelphia is chairman.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 22. -- A trade in players between RKO and Warners will permit RKO to use Paul Muni for the lead opposite Miriam Hopkins in "Escadrille," which Anatol Litvak is to make from his Continental success, "L'Equipage." In return, Warners will have Ginger Rogers for a musical. Miss Rogers's screen prominence dates from her appearances for Warners in "Golddiggers of 1933" and "Forty-second Street.

FREEPORT, L.I., Nov. 22. -- One hundred and eight Negro children were marched to safety this morning when a fire broke out in the Bethel African Methodist Episcopal Church, a frame structure at Helen Avenue and Waverly Place. The fire destroyed the building, doing damage estimated at $3,500.

TORONTO, Nov. 22. -- Dividends from Canadian mining companies will amount to more than $80,000,000 for 1936, according to indications now. Declarations for payment thus far this year amount to $72,889,119 and there is a likelihood that $6,170,000 more will follow before the year-end.

Emphasizing the need for better training of teachers, Dean William F. Russell of Teachers College, Columbia University, suggests in his annual report, made public yesterday, the establishment of a national commission to evolve a "charter for teacher training."

German submarines have been reported in Spanish waters recently. The Loyalist fleet has been at Cartagena, on the southeastern coast of Spain, for several weeks for reconditioning. Those gold reserves of the bank of Spain that have not been sent abroad are at Cartagena.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22. -- Receipts of hogs here last week were heavy, but packers and shippers absorbed most of the offerings, with prices moving between $7.65 to $9.80 a hundredweight. The average price for the week of $9.45, was 10 cents below the previous week and unchanged from a year ago.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 22. -- Three field goals by Ken Strong led the New York Yankees to a 15-to-7 triumph over the Cleveland Rams in an American Football League game before 5,000 spectators today.

WASHINGTON, NOV. 22. -- An increase in the production of naphthalene in the United States of approximately 20,000,000 pounds in 1936 is expected as a result of Germany's embargo on exportation of that commodity, the United States Tariff Commission reported today.

Never trailing at any stage of the contest, the Atlantic City Sea Gulls downed the New York Rovers, 3 -- 2, in Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon in the season's initial Eastern Amateur Hockey League game for both. A crowd of 13,000 saw the visitors hold their 1-point advantage throughout the third period and thus move into first place in the league race.

Yeshiva and Yeshiva College were characterized as Jewry's only effective defiance in educational form to a hostile world by Borough President Samuel Levy last night at a dinner, attended by 1,200 persons, at the Hotel Astor, to commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the college.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- As administration banking authorities drew up plans to offset the effect of the influx of foreign capital on domestic credit, Department of Commerce estimates today indicated that foreign holdings in this country are now more than $7,200,000,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 22 (AP). -- Spokesmen of the University of California Medical School and the City Health Department made statements today criticizing the tendency to overstress the addition to products of the concentrated vitamin D, known as the "sunshine vitamin."

After an absence of more than four years from the Broadway stage, Laurette Taylor is expected to return next month in Gilbert Miller's production of "Promise," for which Sir Cedric Hardwicke and Frank Lawton already have been announced.

Christianity justifies itself not by argument but by the power it brings to those who believe, the Rev. Dr. George Arthur Buttrick, pastor of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Madison Avenue at Seventy-third Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

Pearl Bernstein in a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES seeks to defend the misuse of State moneys collected from the motorists in the form of registration fees and gasoline taxes. Miss Bernstein's epistle takes issue with the statements of John W. Worthing in his splendid article published by you on Nov. 11.

The possibility that the Lutheran Church of St. James, Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street, may have to close its doors, due to a debt of $47,000 for a mortgage and current expenses, was mentioned again by the Rev. Dr. Charles Trexler, the pastor, in a talk before his sermon yesterday morning.

VIENNA, Nov. 22. -- It is believed in Austrian political circles that the principal object of the visit to Berlin of Dr. Guido Schmidt, Austrian Foreign Minister, was a discussion of cooperation by the German and Austrian armies, particularly their air forces, in any forthcoming European war.

Drafting of price adjustments on several steel products for the first quarter of next year was nearing completion at the close last week and it is expected that the changes will be announced early this week, according to the magazine Steel. The publication says there was considerable discussion of a $2-a-ton advance on semi-finished steel, $3 a ton on bars, shapes and plates and possibly $4 to $5 a ton on sheets.

In the drive to keep the city's streets clean, the Department of Sanitation finds itself hampered by the unsuitability of a large number of its trucks, Sanitation Commissioner William F. Carey said yesterday.
ROME, Nov. 20. -- Quotations for industrial stocks here are slowly but constantly rising in harmony with the movement of State securities and they reflect the improved conditions of production.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 22. -- Trading in cotton for future delivery was moderate last week. Buying by the trade was fair and price-fixing by mills about served to absorb the moderate volume of hedge sales. There was uncertainty as to the course of government toward control of the next crop and fears of what Congress may attempt to do at the coming session.

LISBON, Portugal, Nov. 22. -- Differences in the Insurgent high command over the best method of taking Madrid are disclosed in a statement attributed to Colonel Juan Yague before he left for Ceuta, Spanish Morocco, on medical advice.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 22. -- Acquisition of the extensive theatrical collection of the late William Seymour, who was actively connected with the American stage as actor and stage manager for seventy years, was announced tonight by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University.

Pitted against the powerful eleven of the Baltimore Soccer Club, which is setting a fast pace in its section of the American Soccer League, the champion New York Americans could do no better than a 1-1 tie at Starlight Park yesterday before a crowd of 2,500.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,459,442,300. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills. The list follows:

ALBANY, Nov. 22 (AP). -- Elmer C. Lawton, Assistant State Commissioner of Highways, looked at New York State's death toll of about 3,700 yearly in automobile accidents today and said "we are driving sixty to seventy miles an hour on twenty to thirty mile an hour highways."
An inter-church mass meeting in behalf of Christian refugees from Germany was held yesterday afternoon in the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 22 (AP). -- First Lieutenant H.E. Vos, aged about 32, and-Private Ray O'Rea of the 359th Observation Squadron, Air Corps Reserve, were kill today and their bodies were burned when an airplane piloted by Lieutenant Vos crashed into a cornfield near the squadron hangars.

MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 22 (AP). -- The government announced today an effort to mediate the projected strike of 16,000 oil workers, which may prove a decisive factor in Mexican labor's fight to socialize industry under newly enacted wealth-distribution legislation.

BOSTON, Nov. 22. -- Completely outplaying their opponents, Boston's Redskins moved into second place in the Eastern division of the National Football League by trouncing the Brooklyn Dodgers, 30 to 6, before 5,000 frozen fans at Fenway Park today.

Buying activity in the wholesale markets here last week was generally good. New offerings of women's cruise and resort wear met with excellent response, and midseason prints for undercoat, afternoon and evening wear sold steadily.

MOSCOW, Nov. 22. -- A foreign citizen was sentenced to death for the first time in an open court trial in Soviet Russia today when E.I. Stickling, a German engineer, was convicted and ordered shot on charges of sabotage in Western Siberian coal mines.

Amateur boxers will hold sway in Madison Square Garden tonight, when Jack Dempsey will promote a tournament for the benefit of the West Side Hospital fund. Dempsey, heading the fund committee, has succeeded in rounding up a number of the best battlers in the metropolitan district and they will oppose representatives of Philadelphia, Pittsburgh, Detroit, Cleveland, Newark and Quincy, Mass.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 22. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 86.1, which compares with 85.3 the week before, 84.7 two weeks before, 84.5 three weeks before and 84 four weeks before.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 22. -- The Rumanian Government has been obliged, somewhat late in the day, to put a check on visits by Nazis from Germany, in the guise of holidaying students, to the Maramures area, which lies between Czechoslovakia and Russia.

The Interborough subway and elevated lines carried 91,205,871 passengers in October, or 1,042,642 fewer than during the same month in 1935, according to a report made public yesterday by Thomas E. Murray Jr., Federal receiver for the company.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 22. -- In a prepared statement issued here today at his home on Library Place Federal Judge William Clark urged the appointment of a commission to study needs of change in the Constitution of the United States.

Borough President LYONS pursues "the carpetbaggers" implacably. His revived bill restricting appointments to city posts to persons who have resided here three years consecutively has been passed again by the Board of Estimate and will no doubt be approved by the wisdom of the Board of Aldermen.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 22 (AP). -- Santa Clara University won a hard-fought victory over Loyola University of Los Angeles, 13 to 6, today, to remain the only major undefeated and untied football team in the nation.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 22. -- A slender 17-year-old novice, David Berman of the New York Sporting Club, today captured the annual 5-mile handicap road run conducted by La Rabida Council, Knights of Columbus, leading 109 runners from four Eastern States.

The Thanksgiving invasion of new screen fare into Manhattan's first-run houses will include, on Wednesday: "Lloyds of London," Fox's glimpse of Georgian England, with Tyrone Power Jr. and Madeleine Carroll, beginning a two-a-day run at the Astor with an evening premiere;

MADRID, Nov. 22 (AP). -- The Leftist government asserted today that the Italo-German recognition of General Francisco Franco's Insurgent regime was in effect a declaration of war against the Spanish Republic.

The novelty of yesterday afternoon's Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra concert at Carnegie Hall was a 121-year-old symphony, Franz Schubert's Second in B flat. Hulda Lashanska was the soloist, singing again with orchestra Handel's arioso, "Dank sei dir, Herr," in Siegfried Ochs's edition, and Wolf's "Verborgenheit" and "Er ist's.

The St. Francis Prep swimming team successfully began its drive for a fourth consecutive C.H.S.A.A. championship by defeating St. Michael's, 57 1/2 -- 16 1/2, as the annual competition got under way in the Columbus Council K. of C. pool yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 22. -- Stenographic accounts of the conferences and meetings of the City Commission from the day the members took office in 1933 to the present are being scrutinized closely by Warren Dixon Jr., Supreme Court Commissioner, who is conducting the Supreme Court investigation into Newark's affairs.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Nov. 22 (AP). -- His wife learned the truth only tonight -- that fiery, honor-loving Dr. Franz Sarga is going to fight nine duels tomorrow morning -- but her tears could not melt the swordsman's determination to have at all nine of his adversaries on the morrow.

Supporters of the Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities attended a dinner last night at the Hotel St. George that netted in excess of $120,000, far more than; the amount subscribed at any similar event since the series began in 1925.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 22. -- The name of the giant-killer was changed from Jack to Denny at Pinehurst today as square-shouldered Densmore (Denny) Shute, 32-year-old professional at the Brae Burn Club in Massachusetts, won the P.G.A. title by defeating slashing Jimmy Thomson, 3 to 2, in the thirty-six-hole final round of the nineteenth championship.
BARCELONA, Nov. 22 (AP). -- Emma Goldman is seeing the dream of her lifetime take shape in Catalonia.
For more than five hours yesterday morning a troupe of patient burglars took over the management and operation of a six-story apartment house on Washington Heights.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Nov. 22 (AP). -- The Youngstown-Cleveland Council of Employe Representatives was formed here last night by 150 employe representatives from steel mills in the Mahoning and Shenango Valleys and other areas.

Shooting for turkeys again held the attention of gunners of the New York Athletic Club at the Travers Island traps of the organization yesterday. In the scratch event, S. Milligan and H. Thoens led the field, each with 92 out of 100 targets.

The first all-Brahms program of the New Friends of Music's concert series was presented at Town Hall yesterday afternoon. At this third event of the new organization added interest was given the proceedings by the appearance of Florence Easton as soloist.

In his address of last Friday before the Royal Institution Mr. H.G. WELLS vented his dissatisfaction with our encyclopedias. They are too discursive. They fail to direct general ideas. They assume that GOD'S in his heaven and that all's well with the world. He wants a "central ganglion, as it were, of the collective human brain," a synthesis of human knowledge to guide us in our social thinking.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 22. -- The first plenary session of the Peoples Conference in Favor of Peace, organized by Argentine feminists, resulted in a Leftist row which consumed the entire three-hour session this afternoon with an argument on one point of order.

BARCELONA, Spain, Nov. 22. -- A crowd estimated at 500,000 men, women and children marched today at the funeral of Buenaventura Durruti, anarcho-syndicalist leader and chief of the Durruti column, who was killed during Friday's fierce fighting outside Madrid.

Grants totaling $625,000 for the adult education program of the Carnegie Corporation of New York for the next five years were announced yesterday by Dr. Frederick P. Keppel, president of the corporation. Of this sum, $225,000 will be used to study the "social significance" of the movement.

BERLIN, Nov.20 -- The de facto, though not, as yet, formal expropriation of all German-owned foreign securities which officially are quoted, or unofficially traded, on Boerses in the Reich was the week's outstanding event of interest in the financial world.

BAINBRIDGE, Ga., Nov. 22 (AP). -- Sheriff W.J. Catledge said tonight the wails of a baby boy led to the discovery of the body of an unidentified young woman in woods just off a rural highway near here today.

As a prelude to various advertising campaigns on the product, the numerous uses of Polaroid, which, when incorporated in glass, eliminates glare and is claimed to mark the final step in the control of light, will be displayed at an exhibit at the Museum of Arts and Sciences, Rockefeller Center, probably the second week in December.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22. -- A point made by close students of the corn situation is that so long as stocks at terminal markets remain small it appears useless to expect a low level of prices, as accumulations are not looked for.

LILLE, France, Nov. 22. -- Roger Salengro, Mayor of this city and the nation's Minister of the Interior, who committed suicide last Tuesday night, was buried here today below a simple white marble slab by the side of his wife, Leonie. Although trouble had been expected, the reality of Mr. Salengro's body passing before their eyes kept Lille's workers from demonstrating.

As the year-end approaches, financial and industrial activities are moving normally. Even the stock market, after its exhibition of enthusiasm over the long list of increased or extra company dividends, has been inclined to halt. Of a "runaway market" there has been little evidence.

PARIS, Nov. 22. -- On that October day twenty-one years ago when he unhooked his haversack and, telling his lieutenant what he intended to do, crawled over the top into No Man's Land, Roger Salengro started that sequence in his life which ended so tragically last Tuesday evening In his four-room apartment in Lille.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 22. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated at 75 per cent of capacity, up 1 point from the rate in the two preceding weeks and 1 point below the recent high rate, the best in point of tonnage since February, 1930.

A 16-year-old high school boy who worked in his spare time as a Western Union messenger was killed by an automobile about 7 o'clock last night as he was riding a bicycle on Union Street, near Bayside Avenue, Flushing, Queens.

BERLIN, Nov. 21. -- After a week of sharp fluctuations in which trading was dominated by uncertainty as to the fate of foreign securities held by Germans, certain stocks closed slightly below the level of the preceding week. The official statement that mark securities are not affected by the impending governmental restrictions led to a substantial temporary recovery in the industrial group.

The Misses Barbara Eastman and Marie Rose Cassard will give a tea this afternoon in the Viennese Suite of the Crillon for debutantes who are aiding in the plans for the Mothers and Daughters Fashion Show to be held the afternoon of Dec. 3 at the same restaurant for the benefit of the Bellevue Hospital Occupation Committee.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 22. -- Special Thanksgiving services were held today in many of the churches of Westchester County in advance of the regular day of celebration.

BIETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 22. -- The trustees of Lehigh University have revised the present scholarship policy so as to provide for distribution of the equivalent of eighty full tuition scholarships and eighty deferred scholarships and for the establishment of ten regional scholarships.

Declaring that Christians should look upon communism sympathetically as a source of valuable lessons rather than with intolerance and fear, the Rev. Dr. John Gass opened yesterday a series of sermons on "Some Present-Day Lessons" at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue at Thirty-fifth Street.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 22. -- Seventeen years after construction work had begun, Lord Cowrie, Governor General of Australia, opened on Friday Hume Reservoir, the eighth largest project of its kind in the world. It is situated near the junction of the Murray and Mitta Mitta Rivers, at a point where the explorers Hume and Hovell crossed the Murray River in 1824.

With scant slackening of pace the exhibition season continues, more than a score of shows being on the calendar for the present week. In the list paintings by old masters and etchings by modern American graphic artists may be found, along with the latest water-colors from Paris.

MONTREAL, Nov. 22. -- Premier Hepburn of Ontario, having defied the power interests of Quebec by his cancellation last year of four power contracts made on behalf of the Ontario Hydroelectric Commission by the preceding Conservative government, today announced his intention of defying any and all court decisions to the contrary.

A disturbance over a finger wave resulted yesterday in the arraignment of Miss Gertrude Mannis, 37 years old, a teacher of Spanish in the Bayside High School, Queens, on charges of malicious mischief and third-degree assault.

Plans were made at a recent meeting at the home of Prince and Princess Kader Guirey, 130 East Ninety-fourth Street, for the annual Caucasian Allaverdy Ball, which will be held Dec. 18 at the Plaza. Alexander Tarsaidze heads the committee in charge of the arrange-ments.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 22. -- Upholding his sponsorship of a Community Forum, a liberal organization, the Rev. L. Hamilton Garner, pastor of the Universalist Church of the Redeemer here, offered today to resign his pastorate as a result of what he termed "a growing feeling against the Forum" on the part of the board of trustees of the church.

The contradictions in the Bible concerning the birth and resurrection of Jesus Christ should not disturb one who is sure of his faith, for the Christian values Jesus gave to the world are important and factual details are not, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman said in a sermon yesterday at Christ Church, Methodist Episcopal, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

LONDON, Nov. 22. -- A difference of opinion between London and Paris tonight threatened to delay the emergence of a common Anglo-French policy toward General Francisco Franco's threatened bombardment and blockade of Barcelona in the Spanish civil war.

With postal authorities prepared to distribute applications for Federal Social Security account numbers to 3,500,000 wage earners in this city tomorrow, officials of the Bureau of Internal Revenue looked ahead yesterday to expansion of their staffs to enforce the tax provisions of the act, effective Jan. 1.

Chain broadcasting stations east of Denver, Col., were isolated from those west of Denver between 4:55 and 5:33 o'clock yesterday afternoon when a short circuit disrupted service on an American Telephone and Telegraph Company trunk line outside of Denver carrying the station-to-station land lines of the National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting Service.

BOSTON, Nov. 22. -- H. Ware Barnum of Canton, vice president and general counsel of the Boston Elevated Railway and a former Assistant Attorney General of Massachusetts, plunged to his death today from a seventh-floor window of the railway offices in the Park Square Building.

A survey conducted by the Big Brother and Big Sister Federation, Inc., among 26,000 school children in twenty-six up-State communities shows that 2.3 per cent are "problem children," according to a report of the survey made public yesterday.

Led by Lieutenant Joe Stancook, 1934 Army captain, the Fort Jay football team overwhelmed Fort Hamilton, 31-0, before a crowd of 2,500 at the loser's field yesterday. Stancook scored one of the touchdowns on a 12-yard run and passed to Edmund Smith and Charles King for other tallies.

TARRYTOWN-ON-THE-HUDSON, N.Y., Nov. 22. -- More than 500 parishioners listened to Bishop William T. Manning at the 11 o'clock service today extol the historic background of Christ Church, on Broadway in this village, as it began celebrating its 100th anniversary.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22. -- Bullish sentiment dominated the world's grain markets last week. Prices advanced to the highest levels of the season, as well as for the year to date, on buying to cover short sales. New investment purchases in almost all markets were sufficient to absorb all profit-taking and general liquidating sales.
TALAVERA DE LA REINA, Spain, Nov. 22. -- Included among the Insurgent forces are numerous leaders in Spanish sports who are applying their skill, courage and stamina in war.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22. -- Nearly 300 persons, most of whom formerly were members of the Central North Broad Street Presbyterian Church, were received into i membership today by the Church of the Open Door, whose pastor, the Rev. Merril T. MacPherson, was formerly pastor of the Central North Broad Street Church.

MANILA, Nov. 22 (AP). -- Prince Esmail Kiram is reported to have been proclaimed Sultan of Sulu as suspicions rise because of the unexpected death of his father, Sultan Mawallil Wasit. Advices from Jolo said the Prince was proclaimed Sultan shortly before the burial of his father at Maimbung yesterday.

Albert Hirst, legal adviser of the American League to Abolish Capital Punishment, was elected chairman of the board of directors of the league to succeed Warden Lewis E. Lawes of Sing Sing, according to an announcement yesterday following a meeting Saturday at the New York offices, 124 Lexington Avenue.

More than 1,000 persons, attending a forum sponsored by the Federal Theatre Project at Daly's Theatre, 22 West Sixty-third Street, voted last night for the establishment of a Federal Department of Fine Arts to perpetuate government aid to needy artists.

Nominating committees of the New York and Larchmont Yacht Clubs yesterday reported tickets for next year's officers and the lists were posted. The New York election will be held on Dec. 17 and the Larchmont one on Dec. 12.

IOWA CITY, Nov. 22. -- The University of Iowa mixed soft lights and sweet music, dancing and eating, in fact all the ingredients but liquor, in opening the university- operated "night club" last night. Sponsors said it was the first club of its kind in the United States.

Business improvement has brought a general increase in child labor, accompanied in some industries, especially in the South, by "appaling conditions" of exploitation, the National Child Labor Committee asserted in its annual report, made public yesterday by Courtenay Dinwiddie, general secretary of the organization.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- Long-range weather prophets are predicting a severe Winter with enough snow and ice to satisfy young America and devotees of Winter sports.

Discussion is likely to continue as to whether the present business recovery represents the traditional upturn in the "economic cycle," or whether it has resulted from remedial measures at Washington. But there will probably be hereafter a good deal of controversy as to why there should have been such a depression.

James P. Richardson in a letter to THE TIMES invites any one who is a conservative, a Republican or a lawyer to give his opinion with regard to Mr. Richardson's proposal of a constitutional convention. Being all three, venture to reply.

Prices of the cotton staple continued to fluctuate irregularly last week, but the net changes in futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were advances of from 5 to 19 points. The movement followed declines in the previous week and advances in the week before that.
Spiritualism is associated with the defects of men, the Rev. Dr. William H. Rogers, pastor of the First Baptist Church, Broadway at Seventy-ninth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- Imports of gold by Great Britain in October amounted to 19,773,000, making the total for the first ten months of this year 248,858,000. Exports of gold in October were 18,936,000, making the ten-month total 57,848,000.

The year 1936 will go down in gridiron history as a good one for Eastern football. In intersectional games with teams from all parts of the country, Eastern teams have given splendid accounts of themselves.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 22. -- The Boston Shamrocks, heirs apparent to the first American League pro championship, ran into an afternoon of headaches and had to depend upon the breaks to give them a thrilling 13-10 triumph over the Rochester Tigers today at Red Wing Stadium before 7,500 fans.

It should be unnecessary to do more in speaking of the American Red Cross Roll-Call than to remind our readers that it is on. The slight annual contribution for membership has become an item in the annual budget of tens of thousands of persons in New York, but there should be ten times as many.

TOPEKA, Nov. 22 (AP). -- Gifford Pinchot, former Governor of Pennsylvania, said today after conferring with Governor Landon that the Republican party would have to rid itself of domination by "concentrated wealth" if it hoped to "come back."
New York gunners will have to forget about pheasants, grouse and deer for another season, but they still may contemplate pleasant days afield in search of the ubiquitous and bounding bunny.

MADRID, Nov. 22. -- Today's Rebel artillery attack began at dawn. Shells falling in Alvarez de Castro Street wounded a number of persons and hastened the "taxicab" evacuation of 300,000 women, children and aged persons to Valencia.

Herbert Quincy O'Steen, 37 years old, of 248 Sullivan Street, who told the police he was a graduate of the University of Georgia, was held without bail in Flushing Court yesterday after he had waived examination on a charge of burglary.

PARIS, Nov. 20. -- The return of the Bank of France, made up on Oct. 13, shows no exceptionally important changes. Bills discounted rose by 242,000,000 francs to which must be added 76,000,000 more advanced to small banks and farmers through wheat control.

Policemen and detectives of the Sheepshead Bay station rescued a Negro yesterday from a mob that threatened to lynch him for criminally attacking an 8-year-old girl and terrorizing two others. The prisoner, Howard White, 28, a laborer, of 1,410 Avenue X, Brooklyn, was locked up for hearing today in Felony Court.

Only 455,000 bales of cotton moved into sight last week, compared with 571,000 in the previous week and 745,000 at the peak three weeks ago, according to the New York Cotton Exchange. In the last four weeks, however, the average weekly into-sight movement has been 602,000 bales, against 580,000 in the corresponding weeks last year.

A luncheon and fashion show will be given on Dec. 8 in the Regency Suite of the Carlyle to aid the Winifred Wheeler Day Nursery. Mrs. Ary J. Lamme Jr., president, and Mrs. Richard W. Hollman, chairman, will be assisted in the arrangements by a large committee.

Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, issued a statement yesterday charging that the motive behind the action of the convention of the American Federation of Labor at Tampa in boycotting the union label of the Amalgamated was punishment for the union's affiliation with the Committee for Industrial Organization.

The New York Americans won another last night. The amazing Dutton Dusters, who have been set back only once in the current National Hockey League race, turned back a fighting Montreal Maroon sextet in a blistering battle at Madison Square Garden, 3 to 2.

Neither religion nor business can be "anybody's private affair," the Rev. Heber Corwyn Benjamin, rector of St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church, Sanford and Wilson Avenues, Flushing, Queens, declared in his morning sermon yesterday.

The 1937 John Fritz Gold Medal for notable scientific or industrial achievement has been awarded to Arthur Newell Talbot, 79-year-old professor emeritus of engineering of the University of Illinois, it was announced yesterday.

MAGAZINE non-fiction has been improving for some time. Reporting is more thorough than it ever has been before, more facts are used, "slants" are sounder and the writing is more colorful. Fiction, sticking to the observance of old taboos and fetishes, has been left behind. But several writers, setting their course for fiction on that taken by non-fiction, are catching up.
BERMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 22 (AP). -- Security of land tenure for tenant farmers was ranked in importance by Secretary of Agriculture Wallace tonight with the security of the working man in his job.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- The limit has about been reached in Germany's remarkable commercial expansion in the Danube region and the Balkans, according to a report issued today by the Foreign Policy Association. The report was prepared by John C. de Wilde of the research staff.

FRANKLIN, Pa., Nov. 22. -- "The record of the American Army in the World War speaks for itself," says General John J. Pershing in answer to the charges made by David Lloyd George that the American forces did not measure up to the expectations of the Allies, and that General Pershing was dogmatic and arbitrary in his contention that they should "fight on their own front."

The shorter time-cycle in Manhattan traffic lights has been accompanied by a drop of one-half to four-fifths in pedestrian fatalities from automobiles. A longer test is necessary to determine how far this is coincidence.

TAMPA, Nov. 22. -- Charles P. Howard, president of the International Typographical Union, arrived here unexpectedly tonight and threw a bombshell into the controversy between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization by declaring that his union would not remain a part of the federation if the executive council persisted in "interfering" in the affairs of affiliated unions.

The New York Giants lost a game and valuable ground in the National Football League pennant race at the Polo Grounds yesterday, but they lost nothing of the esteem of a gathering of 26,000 as they played the feared Green Bay Packers to a standstill before finally capitulating, 26 to 14.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22 (AP). -- The Chicago Bears, coming back from a scoreless first period, pushed over a trio of touchdowns in the second and added another in the final quarter to swamp the Philadelphia Eagles, 28 to 7, in a National Football League game today.

Conferences looking forward to the selection of a Republican State Chairman to succeed Melvin C. Eaton are scheduled to begin this week, it was disclosed yesterday. Mr. Eaton's retirement from the post becomes effective on Dec. 14 unless no successor is picked at the meeting of the State committee here on that date.

BAYONNE, N.J., Nov. 22. -- Lying on a stretcher early today after he had been struck by an automobile at Hudson Boulevard and Forty-sixth Street here, Joseph Paurez, 44 years old, was hit by a second machine and received injuries from which he died in Bayonne Hospital.

Norman Notley, baritone, and David Brynley, tenor, appeared in a program of duets at the Town Hall last night. Not often in the course of a season does a concertgoer have the opportunity to hear so interesting and unhackneyed a body of selections as these British singers presented.

Appointment of a committee of industrialists to aid and encourage the building of low-cost homes for wage-earners as a factor in further national recovery by campaigning for concerted action by the various groups in the housing industry was urged yesterday in report of the National Association of Manufacturers' committee on housing and employment.

Without a common spiritual compact, clashing interests in the United States threaten the success of our democracy, the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, pastor of the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas, said at a Thanksgiving service in which thirty patriotic societies participated yesterday afternoon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Predicting that within twelve months social security "will be a boomerang" and "workers will be rising up to curse it," Norman Thomas struck at the measure last evening in a speech before approximately 900 persons at the Community Forum, 550 West ll0th Street. His topic was: "What Next in the United States?"

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 (AP). -- The Detroit Lions, coming from behind with a fourth-period rush that produced two touchdowns, defeated the Chicago Cardinals, 14 to 7, at Wrigley Field today before 8,000 fans.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- Mature consideration in financial circles here of President Roosevelt's hint that steps might be taken to restrict foreign investments in United States securities has brought a modification of the first impression that this was a new important factor in the investment picture.
SEA CLIFF, L.I., Nov. 22. -- After an all-day questioning 16-year-old Garry Connelly confessed tonight that he had started every one of the nine fires that have broken out here in the last two weeks.

A proposal that the advertising panels on the walls of the Independent Subway be replaced by sculpture, mosaics or murals executed by artists now employed on WPA projects has been received with interest by representatives of the city, it was announced last night by Miss Elizabeth Olds of the Artists Union.

An offering to the public will be made today of an issue of $1,770,000 of first mortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds due in 1966 of the Ohio Associated Telephone Company through a banking group headed by Bonbright Co., Inc., and including Painee, Webber Co. and Mitchum, Tully Co. The bonds will be priced at 103 and accrued interest.

MADRID, Nov. 22(Censored) -- Fighting continues today in University City, on the northwestern outskirts of Madrid, where the tide of battle sways back and forth. The government forces at one time yesterday held the Casa Velasquez there, but apparently they were subsequently driven out of the building.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22. -- Val Hartman's forward pass to Johnny Cole in the second period gave St. Joseph's College a 7-0 victory over La Salle at the Phillies' ball park today before 10,000 spectators. Hartman also place-kicked the extra point.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 (AP). -- Four heroes in Northwestern's march to Western Conference gridiron glory, Don Heap, Fred Vanzo, Steve Reid and John Kovatch, have added the champion's share of places on the 1936 Big Ten all-star team to Wildcat honors for the season.

The calling of several large issues of public utility and industrial bonds featured a sharp increase last week in the volume of bonds called for redemption before maturity. This month's total of called bonds was increased slightly by the addition of some miscellaneous bonds to $126,941,000, compared with $341,801,000 last month, and $217,684,000 in Nov., 1935, for corresponding weeks.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Nov. 22. -- Superior end-game strategy enabled Frank J. Marshall of New York to win his adjourned game with Francisco Benitez, city champion of San Juan, in the final session of the international chess masters tournament at the Club de Ajedrez de San Juan today.
LONDON, Nov. 22. -- Mayfair hostesses are dropping the drawing room for the kitchen -- all because Mrs Wallis Simpson prepared tasty dishes with her own hands "fit for a king" and the King ate them.

Criticizing the "neutral" policy of the United States Government toward the war in Spain, the national executive committee of the Socialist party voted last night to send fraternal greetings and assurance of support and solidarity to the Spanish Loyalists.

A protest against continuing to give exclusive use of two out of the seven traffic lanes on the Queensboro Bridge by street cars was sent to Harold Fowler, First Deputy Police Commissioner, by the First Avenue Association yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- Marvels of science were demonstrated tonight before a group of newspaper men and examiners of the Patent Office in a showing of "Research Parade," featuring laboratory achievements which become the industries of tomorrow.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 22. -- Twenty-three dinghies sailed off the Larchmont Yacht Club today in the weekly regatta, and Arthur Knapp, in his Class B One-Design craft Four Deuces, and Bill Dodge, from Westerly, R.I., with his Class X boat Moth Ball, led the two divisions.

ALBANY, Nov. 22 (AP). -- The International Joint Commission came from New York tonight to continue its hearings on the proposed Montreal-New York waterway, which would come down through Lake Champlain and join the Hudson River here.

PARIS, Nov. 20. -- There has been no lack of disturbing events this week of an unsettling influence on public opinion and the markets. The latest repudiation by Germany of the Versailles Treaty's clauses governing river navigation, and the closer understanding between Berlin and Rome, are not without unfortunate implications from the point of view of future international relations.

A formal and official acknowledgment of the services rendered to the city by the members of the Charter Commission is planned for today. Nothing could be more fitting.
