If ever there should be presented a civic replica of the Congressional Medal for Distinguished Service, it should be in this instance.

DETROIT Nov. 22 (AP). -- The all-star first line of the Detroit Red Wings shot 3 goals in less than two minutes tonight while the Toronto Maple Leafs were a man short and gained a 4-to-2 victory. The triumph put the Wings ahead of the idle Rangers in undisputed leadership of the American Division of the National Hockey League.

It remained for the last full Saturday of football to complete the picture of one of the most amusing seasons in recent years. There may be some giants straddling the gridiron undefeated, untied and all wrapped up in a mythical championship of something just as mythical, but it is difficult to see them with the naked eye.

Due largely to increases in iron, steel and petroleum production and miscellaneous freight car loadings, all of which reached new high levels for the recovery period, industrial activity, on a seasonally adjusted basis, advanced during October, according to the monthly business survey of the National Industrial Conference Board.

I was reading your editorial, "The Enemy," and the idea struck me: Why should we not erect a statue of our own to Felix Mendelssohn? Not in any vindictive manner, for there really is nothing to be angry about. We are, of course, sorry that this has happened, but we should remember that this is not the first time an entire nation has gone haywire.

TALAVERA DE LA REINA, Spain, Nov. 22. -- Fine weather after a rainy spell resulted in the Insurgent attack on Madrid getting under way again today. Only the bombers failed to join the assault, being unable to take off with their heavy death-dealing loads because of the wet grounds.
BERLIN, Nov. 22. -- The Reich Government lost no time today in protesting the death sentence imposed on the German mining engineer, E.I. Stickling, in the Novosibirsk sabotage trial.

A Theatre of Music under the control of the WPA Federal Music Project will be established at the New Yorker Theatre in West Fifty-fourth Street, which was operated for several years as the Casino de Paree, it was announced yesterday by Lee Pattison, New York director of the project.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Nov. 23. -- The present strife in Suiyuan Province is believed in the highest Chinese military circles to be only preliminary to a Japanese attempt to seize all of Shansi Province, southwest of Peiping, for the Japanese army realizes that so long as Shansi remains in possession of forces hostile to Japan's North China program their position in Hopei and Chahar will be insecure.

PEIPING, China, Monday, Nov. 23. -- Japanese sources insist that General Wang Ying's Mongolian-Manchukuoan forces captured Hungkoerhttu, near Taolin, Suiyuan, Nov. 19, after inflicting casualties of more than 1,000 killed and wounded, his own forces losing about 200.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- Deposits in the 15,803 banks of all types operating in the United States on June 30 amounted to $58,339, 815,000, J.F.T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, announced today.

Cosmic optimism, the faith in God and the universe, is the strongest antidote for all the fears that beset a human being, the Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson said in a sermon yesterday morning at Temple Emanu- El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.

ABOARD U.S.S. CHESTER, EN ROUTE WITH PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT, Nov. 22 (AP). -- "Davy Jones," "Neptune's" emissary, tonight charged President Roosevelt with "gross incompetency in failing to carry Maine and Vermont."

ABOARD U.S.S. CHESTER, EN ROUTE WITH PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT, Nov. 22 (AP). -- "Davy Jones," "Neptune's" emissary, tonight charged President Roosevelt with "gross incompetency in failing to carry Maine and Vermont."

McCOOK, Neb., Nov. 22 (AP). -- Edward A. O'Neal of Chicago, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, has informed Senator Norris of Nebraska that he and Secretary Wallace will share the organization's Distinguished Service Medal, awarded annually.

MONTREAL, Nov. 22 (Canadian Press). -- Canada's national income for 1936 will exceed that for 1935 by about $600,000,000, J.L. Ilsley, Minister of National Revenue, said last night in an address at a dinner in connection with the opening of Montreal's new National Revenue Building.

TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 23. -- The budget for next year was provisionally fixed by the Treasury today at 3,040,000,000 yen after the War and Navy Offices had consented yesterday to cut their joint demands by 200,000,000 yen. Of the total, the army and navy receive 1,400,000,000 yen, or 46 per cent.

GENEVA, Nov. 22. -- John G. McNaughton of Montreal, assistant United Press correspondent here, was accidentally killed last evening by a fall of more than 400 yards down the precipitous slopes of the "chimney" in the Roehers de Naye. This peak, which reaches an altitude of 6,000 feet, rises above Montreux and is celebrated for its view of Lake Leman.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- Great Britain's overseas trade results for last month have given rise to conflicting reflections. With imports the largest since November, 1931, and exports similarly at a record since November, 1930, the position appears encouraging, but really it is not so good as the picture, in general, appears.

Goldman, Sachs Co. and associates will offer today to the public a new issue of $27,000,000 of first-mortgage 4 1/4 per cent bonds, due in 1956, of the B.F. Goodrich Company. The bonds will be priced at 101 and accrued interest.

More than 1,000 persons crowded into the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady Queen of Angels, 228 West 113th Street, yesterday for the celebration at 11 A.M. of a solemn pontifical mass in observance of the golden jubilee of the parish. The Most Rev. James E. Walsh, superior general of the Maryknoll Missions, was the celebrant.

The piano recital given by Eugenia Buxton in Town Hall yesterday afternoon showed marked improvement in her work since her debut appearance in the same auditorium last season. The youthful artist from Memphis, who has been studying with Alberto Jonas since 1929, had evidently done all in her power to develop her talents in the interim between the two recitals.

TORONTO, Nov. 23 (Canadian Press). -- Great Britain swept to victory in the international army officers' jumping event at the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show tonight when Lieutenant J.A. Talbot-Ponsonby rode Kineton to a triumph in the $500 military jumping stake.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 23. -- Only three women were appointed today to places on committees of the People's Conference in Favor of Peace, which was organized by Argentine feminists to draw up recommendations for presentation to the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace next week.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. CHESTER, at Sea, Nov. 23 (AP). -- President Roosevelt, appointed "senior pollywog" aboard the cruiser Indianapolis, ordered a watch posted today for Davy Jones, Royal Agent of King Neptune.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Scientists marked the 100th anniversary of the institution of the American patent system here today with a preview of developments in science and engineering just being perfected, including a glass-woven tie a solar oven and foods kept fresh by a kind of "suspended animation."

The complete field of fifteen teams for New York's sixty-first international six-day bicycle race, which starts in Madison Square Garden Sunday night, was announced yesterday. Riders from seven nations, including virtually every outstanding star now in competition, are slated to participate.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 23. -- Referring to the Buenos Aires conference opening Dec. 1, the South Pacific Mail says the different tendencies concerning the organization of peace probably will create a clash.

A total of 7,000 shares of stock of the Hearn Department Stores, Inc., worth almost $110,000 at present market price, will be distributed among 2,300 regular employes of the store as a Christmas gift, it was announced yesterday by Maurice Levin, president.

Your recent comment on a census of the unemployed clarifies some of the problems inherent in that task. Yet to me it seems that the difficulties in taking a comprehensive census show not so much a need for the census as a need for revising our conception of our social aims and purposes.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Nov. 24. -- Although both factions in the Suiyuan Province hostilities are handicapped by the cold of 15 degrees below zero, the invaders and defenders continue assembling addditional forces.
MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 23 (AP). -- Company and labor representatives struggled tonight to avert a threatened general strike in Mexico's great oil industry.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23 (AP). -- Villanova College today accepted an invitation to play Auburn in a post-season game at Havana, Cuba, on New Year's Day.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- Victor A. Hanson today resigned as head football coach at Syracuse University, a position he held since 1930.
New or additional price advances affecting practically all lines of floor coverings were considered certain before the end of the year by buyers who canvassed the wholesale market here yesterday.

Kielman A. Schuddekoff, 34 years old, a building contractor, of 322 West 108th Street, agreed to pay a $500 fine in Special Sessions yesterday rather than serve a six-month workhouse term on his recent conviction in the "kick-back" racket.

A substantial drop in the number of automobile accidents, and in deaths and injuries resulting from them, is shown in figures for the period from Sept. 1 to Nov. 15 this year, compared with the same period in 1935, according to announcement yesterday by Harold L. Fowler, deputy police commissioner.

An army travels on its stomach, a World's Fair on its bond issues. It is not enough that the architects shall draft plans, or that the promoters shall secure exhibits. Without funds even the most harmonious plans will stay on paper, and even the most attractive exhibits will never he displayed.

Offensive records in the National Football League this year are running substantially ahead of the 1935 performances, according to the figures announced yesterday. Detroit, with an average of 304 yards a game; the Bears, with 296; and Green Bay, with 285, all are ahead of the 284 average recorded by the Bears last season.

Traffic leads this evening to Forty-first Street and the National Theatre, where Noel Coward will set up the first third of his nine short plays bearing the collective title of "Tonight at 8:30." Breaking the program down into individual units, there will be "Hands Across the Sea" (comedy), "The Astonished Heart" (serious), and "Red Peppers" (comedy).
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 23. -- Judging from the goal-kicking ability displayed by young Bill Ingram as the Navy prepares for Saturday's game, he will be an outstanding scoring threat against the Army.

BERLIN, Nov. 23. -- Twenty years late the German Government recognized today through Joachim von Ribbentrop, its Ambassador to London, an agreement regarding submarine warfare that might have kept the United States out of the last war and changed the course of Occidental history.

Officials of the New York Curb Exchange, it became known yesterday, plan to apply to the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to admit to unlisted trading privileges only a handful of the many issues which will become eligible for such trading under SEC regulations that become effective on Friday.

ROME, Nov. 23. -- Reports from Madrid that Italian submarines attacked Spanish warships off Cartagena were officially denied in Rome this evening. Italian warships, it was said, are still in Spanish waters, but they are there solely for the protection of Italian citizens and property and have categorical instructions not to interfere with the civil war in any way.

Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., reports for the year ended on Aug. 29, 1936, a net profit of $3,177,313, after all charges and Federal taxes, equal to 75 cents a share on the common stock, after allowing for full dividend requirements for the year on the preferred stock, on which there is an accumulation of unpaid dividends.

New starting regulations and methods of handicapping were discussed yesterday at the annual meeting of the Trotting Horse Club of America at the Prince George Hotel. While no new rules were made, the tendency was definitely toward a change to eliminate starting grievances and also to handicap horses so that the various all-age stakes result in more evenly matched races.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 23. -- Increases of $2 to $4 a ton on steel products were announced today by the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation. The advance had been expected since the wage increases to workers in the mills, which became effective on Nov. 16, were announced.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The Supreme Court's four-to-four verdict today recalled that as far back as 1826 Chief Justice Marshall ruled that when the court was evenly divided a lower court's decision must stand.

Radioing his greeting from the cruiser Indianapolis which is taking him to Argentina, President Roosevelt hailed the New York World's Fair of 1939 as "a challenge to all Americans who believe in the destiny of the nation" in a message read at a dinner at the Hotel Astor last night.

TAMPA, Nov. 23. -- By an overwhelming vote and in the absence of delegates from ten suspended unions with about 1,000,000 members, the delegates of the convention of the American Federation of Labor tonight supported the executive council which suspended the unions affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization on charges of "rebellion" and forming a "dual" or rival organization.

AVILA, Spain, Nov. 23. -- This writer escaped capture by Madrid troops on Saturday when, bed-ridden with influenza, he was unable to join other correspondents in a tour of the Madrid front. Four of the correspondents were captured by the Leftists in the Casade Campo, on the western outskirts of Madrid.
A left followed by a looping right to the head gave Bobby Pacho, Los Angeles welterweight, a knockout victory over Nick Pastore of Williamsburg at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

LONDON, Nov. 23. -- The stock market here opened in a nervous mood this morning, because of fear of "dangerous" incidents in Spanish waters. It has been several weeks since the relatively phlegmatic London market suffered such an attack of the jitters, and it sent prices down in almost all departments.

The undefeated City A.C. and Princeton Club teams scored again in the Metropolitan Class B squash tennis competition yesterday. City beat the Harvard Club, last year's champion, by a 4 -- 1 margin, and Princeton won by default from the Montclair A.C.
BERLIN, Nov. 23. -- A weak tendency caused by the slump in foreign securities here last week again sent today's Boerse to stagnation point.

PARIS, Nov. 23. -- The parliamentary session, which was interrupted two weeks ago to permit local general councils to meet, will be resumed tomorrow morning in an atmosphere made tense by the grave international situation and by the suicide of Interior Minister Roger Salengro.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 23. -- John Beal will go before the test cameras for the role of the boy in RKO's "Escadrille," a part next in importance to those of Paul Muni and Miriam Hopkins.

THERE wasn't even mild surprise in this corner when a recent A.P. story out of Cleveland quoted Jesse Owens to the effect that he didn't expect to run any further as an amateur. He would be foolish to stick to the amateur cinderpath when he had a chance to make himself enough money to keep the wolves of the future away from his front door.

About 250 members of the Retail Cigar Salesmen's Union of Local 906, of the Retail Clerks International Protective Association, an American Federation of Labor affiliate, met at the Hotel Central, 108 West Forty-third Street, last night and voted to call a strike against Schulte Co. at 7 o'clock this morning.
Mal Stevens holds a grievance against the Georgia football team. He told the Football Writers Association about it yesterday at the Hotel Lincoln in the final luncheon meeting of the season.

MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 23. -- Since 8 this morning field guns, machine guns, rifles, cartridges and other war materials have been piled aboard the Spanish steamer Sil at Veracruz. According to private telephone advices to this correspondent, the ship at any moment will sail for a destination designated by the Spanish Government.

The decision yesterday of the Supreme Court of the United States, upholding the constitutionality of the New York State Unemployment Insurance Law, is an important landmark in the history of social security legislation in this country. It does not deal with the power of Congress to enact legislation in this field.

Oris P. Van Sweringen, director of the great Van Sweringen railroad interests, died at 12:10 yesterday afternoon aboard a private railroad car in the Hoboken yards of the Lackawanna Railroad. He was on his way from his Cleveland office to J.P. Morgan Co. here for a conference.
MADRID, Nov. 23 (Censored). -- The battle for Madrid was renewed with great intensity tonight after a day of little fighting.
The Postoffice Department will undertake today the most exacting assignment in its history, the delivery of 26,000,000 applications for employe account numbers under the Federal Social Security Act.

Douglas Beattie, bass baritone, gave his first New York recital last night in Town Hall. He is a young Californian, a graduate of California University, and he studied singing in Italy. He made his operatic debut in 1933 and sang for two years in Italian lyric theatres.

Joseph Wood Krutch, author and dramatic critic, said last night that during the last ten years the American theatre had been one of the most interesting theatres the world had ever known. He spoke at a symposium held by the Decorators Club at the Cosmopolitan Club, 129 East Sixty-fifth Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The Harriman National Bank and Trust Company of New York and Frederick V. Goess, its receiver, lost today in the Supreme Court in their effort to keep from returning to Charles A. Munroe securities they said he had lent in 1932 to Joseph W. Harriman, former president of the bank, to enable the latter to obtain a $380,000 loan from the institution.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- A portent of possible action by the Federal Reserve Board to reduce the enormous volume of excess reserves -- $2,270,000,000 on Nov. 18 -- was discerned today in the announcement by Secretary Morgenthau that, aside from maturing bills, there would be no government financing during January or February.

Alfred Mercurio, unattached, gained premier laurels in the 118-pound class of the semi-monthly metropolitan A.A.U. boxing show at the New York Athletic Club last night. A crowd of 1,000 watched the program of fourteen contests.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 23. -The belief that only twelve men in the world can understand Einstein's theory of relativity is dispelled by Professor Henry De Wolf Smyth, chairman of the Department of Physics at Princeton University, in the current issue of The Princeton Alumni Weekly.

Troubled by his conscience, Frank Forbes, 40-year-old ex-convict, has been arrested twice within a year at his own request by Detective John Sheridan of the Poplar Street station in Brooklyn on burglary charges.
TAMPA, Nov. 23. -- Following is the report of the American Federation of Labor Resolutions Committee on the Committee for Industrial Organization:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23. -- Mr. and Mrs. John Stewart Wurts of Hedgefield, Germantown, gave a tea at their home today to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Dorothy Williams Wurts. The debutante wore a bouffant gown of silver brocaded taffeta and carried varied shades of African daisies.

PORTLAND, Conn., Nov. 23. -- Norman Little and Mike Olesen, a couple of old-time 'coon hunters from New Haven County, were feeling a bit apologetic today. They took three rod and gun editors 'coon hunting and tried their best to put on a show for their guests, but the luck of the chase was against them.

With diphtheria cases continuing to increase last week, Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, yesterday repeated his warning to parents that every child under the age of 6 should be immunized without delay. Twenty-five new cases were reported for the week ending Saturday compared with twenty-one cases the preceding week.

Oris Paxton Van Sweringen was the elder of the two Van Sweringen brothers, who turned a "shoestring" investment in one railroad into control of a vast railroad empire, the assets of which at one time totaled $3,000,000,000.

Because of decisions reached through a series of dictatorial meetings last week, Selznick International Pictures will make a bid for leadership among producers of independent films, it was announced yesterday by John Hay Whitney, chairman of the board. Through a program involving large scale refinancing and expansion, according to Mr. Whitney's statement, Selznick will produce ten to twelve major films next year, four to six of which will be done in Technicolor.

Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott yesterday ordered two officers and three firemen, all of them with long years of service in the department, back to the rookie school for thirty-day periods of retraining. He took this action because of what he characterized as the "atrocious handling of the body" of John Bermudez, 15 years old, who was fatally overcome at a Brooklyn fire.

Wide publicity has been given to the Citizen Budget Commission's comparison of our city government's costs in 1900 and 1936. Before becoming unduly alarmed by the $92 per capita cost for 1936 I remembered that in 1900 we had no subways, few high schools, no Bureau of Child Hygiene, next to no skyscrapers, few of the present facilities that have increased many real estate values far more than city cost has risen.

NEWPORT, R. I., Nov. 23. -- Mrs. Marie Lebel Knight, widow of Edward Collings Knight, formerly of Philadelphia, named the Newport Hospital and the Mercy Home and School here as the eventual beneficiaries of the bulk of her estate, valued at $50,000, in her will, filed for probate today.

BALBOA, Canal Zone, Nov. 23. -- A United States Senate subcommittee on military affairs under the chairmanship of Senator Robert R. Reynolds of North Carolina began hearings here today on the employment of aliens in skilled and semiskilled positions and other posts of strategic importance in the defense of the Panama Canal.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 (AP). -- R.E. Cummer Co. announced today that nine Florida counties and other taxing units in the State have taken steps to adjust their funded indebtedness aggregating approximately $20,000,000 par value.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The Supreme Court today, by the rare division of four to four, upheld the constitutionality of the New York Unemployment Insurance Law. The decision was believed by many to forecast eventual victory for the National Social Security Act when that law is tested before the high court.

An easier tone prevailed in the commodity futures markets yesterday. Trading was active. Coffee futures, excepting the old Rio contract, however, advanced to new seasonal high levels before profit taking erased part of the gains. In the cash market, rye, cocoa, wool tops and hides were higher, while wheat, corn, oats, cotton, silk and tin were lower.

MOSCOW, Nov. 23. -- Count Friedrich Werner von der Schulenberg, German Ambassador, appealed to Nikolai N. Krestinsky, Soviet Vice Foreign Commissar, again this afternoon in a final effort to save the life of Emil I. Stickling, German citizen, who with eight Russians was sentenced to death yesterday on charges of sabotage in Western Siberian coal mines.

The names of three men who are under indictment in connection with the restaurant racket and are alleged to be fugitives were disclosed yesterday at the office of Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets. It also became known that Mr. Dewey had obtained warrants for the arrest of two important witnesses believed to have fled from the State.

A tract of seventy-one and a half acres on the Rahway River at Linden, N.J., has been sold by the estate of Mary B. Child for industrial development. Julius Finkel was the broker. The purchaser was represented by Aaron Kaufman, attorney, of Elizabeth. The Child family had held the property about 200 years. The General Motors Corporation is building a plant opposite.

Neighbors led John Finley, who is blind, down the back stairs of a three-story dwelling at 206 Fifteenth Street, West New York, N.J., to safety yesterday just before they were cut off by smoke from a fire in the house, which trapped the sightless man's five grandchildren and his daughter-in-law on an upper floor.

FORT SILL, Okla., Nov. 23. -- A suicide note signed "The Corpse" and borne into camp by a riderless horse instructed that the body of First Lieutenant William L. Carson, 25, be cremated and the ashes strewn on the grave of a dead sweetheart.

To the average foreigner, the United States is a land of gangsters and flying bullets, flagpole sitters and marathon dancers, interspersed here and there with insufferably rich persons and teeming with badly kept prison camps.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, directed by John Barbirolli and assisted by four pianists -- Mischa Levitzki, Frank Sheridan, Beveridge Webster and Eugene List -- gave a concert for the benefit of its pension fund at Carnegie Hall last night.

The list of the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria, due tonight from Europe, includes G.H. Middleton, British Vice Consul at New York; Mr. and Mrs. Philip Russell, Mr. and Mrs. James M. Kemper, Mrs. E.J. Hanlon, R.C. Graham, Vicky Baum, novelist; R.B. Job, George Ratsey, R.R. Appleby, Mrs. Paul C. Nicholson and Mrs. Frederick B. Read.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23. -- Failure of the Liverpool and leading European wheat markets to place a bullish construction on the unfavorable turn in political conditions in Europe today left North American traders at sea regarding the situation.

In his report of 1844 Commissioner of Patents HENRY L. ELLSWORTH observed that nearly everything of importance seemed to have been invented. If he had only been in Washington yesterday! There inventors, scientists, business men were celebrating the centennial of the present patent system.

Willingness to participate in movements for the establishment of a national Farmer-Labor party was expressed yesterday in a statement adopted by the national executive committee of the Socialist party at a meeting at the home of Norman Thomas, 206 East Eighteenth Street.

Offering to the public of $48,000,000 of first and refunding 3 3/4 per cent bonds due in 1966 of the Montana Power Company will be made today by an underwriting group headed by J. and W. Seligman Co. The bonds are to be priced at 101 and accrued interest.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 23. -- Students at Providence College offered today to forego Thanksgiving at home so their might give their blood to Francis Moriarty of Brooklyn, a fellow-student, who is ill with leukemia.

Adoption of a uniform procedure by all branches of the women's garment industry for defraying the social security taxes will be discussed this afternoon at a meeting of the Apparel Industries' Inter-Trade Bureau at the offices of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., Samuel Klein, executive director of the council, and chairman of the bureau, said last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP). -- Senator Wheeler of Montana said today that he was conferring with labor groups on a proposed constitutional amendment to authorize Federal regulation of wages and hours of labor.

James Sullivan, 17 years old, of 9 Folsom Place, Brooklyn, a Richmond Hill High School pupil, was sentenced yesterday to die in the electric chair for beating to death a storekeeper in a $9 robbery. Judge Brancato in Kings County Court ordered the prisoner to Sing Sing prison, with the execution of the sentence set for the week of Jan. 4.

West Side detectives were puzzled last night by the theft of approximately $20,000 in jewelry from the penthouse of Bernard Gordon, a stock broker, on the twelfth floor of the new Rockefeller Apartments at 24 West Fifty-fifth Street.
Senator Robert F. Wagner, who received word of the Supreme Court's action while he was visiting the regional offices of the Social Security Board, at 45 Broadway, said:

BERLIN, Nov. 23 (AP). -- Germany today admitted she and Japan had agreed on an anti-Bolshevist campaign as charged by Soviet Russia last week. A Foreign Office spokesman made the announcement, the first admission from Germany that the Russian assertions were true.

After deliberating less than a minute a Municipal Court jury returned a verdict for $704 plus interest and costs in favor of the city yesterday in what was said to be the first case establishing the responsibility of a child for relief funds illegally advanced to a parent.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23. -- Police guarded the trucks of five department stores today as they made deliveries in defiance of strike pickets and sympathizers.
One of the pleasant bits of news which Mr. FARLEY may have delivered on his Irish visit is how well the Kelly family is doing over here. Indeed, some of Mr. FARLEY'S very best friends are Kellys.

The Long Island Railroad's rate practices on "short jumps" within the metropolitan area were disputed before Supreme Court Justice Albert Conway in Brooklyn yesterday in a proceeding to punish the railroad for contempt of court. Justice Conway reserved decision.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP). -- The Federal Trade Commission today charged Standard Brands, Inc., of New York, and Anheuser-Busch, Inc., of St. Louis, with violation of the Robinson-Patman Act through price discrimination in the sale of baker's yeast.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 23. -- Argentina expects the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace to be by far the most important of all Pan-American conferences and very probably the most important international assembly of any kind in recent years.

LONDON, Nov. 23. -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told Parliament today that the British Government was not yet ready to accord to the Spanish Insurgents the status of belligerents, which would give them automatically the right to visit and search outside the three-mile limit British ships suspected of carrying contraband cargoes for the Madrid government.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 23. -- Fire in the bakery building of the State prison here tonight brought police and fire-fighting apparatus from all parts of Trenton when two alarms were sounded. The blaze was confined to the bakery and the adjoining storeroom.

ALBANY, Nov. 23. -- William E. Woollard, president of the New York State Waterways Association, declared today at an International Joint Commission hearing on the proposed Montreal-New York seaway that construction of the project would waste $150,000,000 of public money.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP). -- The Progressive Republican Committee for Roosevelt reported today that it had received $7,468 in campaign contributions, including $1,000 from Mrs. Joseph E. Davies of Roslyn, N.Y., wife of the new Ambassador to Russia. Another $1,000 came from George Henry Payne of Islip, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP). -- A move by Eastern trunk-line railroads to reverse an order by the Interstate Commerce Commission ending less-than-cost terminal warehouse services was fought today by warehousemen from the New York Harbor area.

A sentence of two to four years in Sing Sing was imposed by Judge Jonah J. Goldstein in General Sessions yesterday on John J. Hassett, former Tammany chairman and for eighteen years a member of the disbanded Board of Examining Plumbers, on his conviction by a jury Oct. 22 of bribery.

A plan to reorganize the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation, in receivership since 1933, was presented yesterday to Judge Bondy in Federal Court here, providing for continuance of the company under a new capital structure and the distribution of new securities to creditors and stockholders.

The series of articles by our special correspondent, F. RAYMOND DANIELL, on the "bootlegging" of coal in Pennsylvania, throw fresh light on the amazing situation that has grown up there in the last few years. Some 15,000 men and boys are engaged in the actual illegal mining of anthracite from owned by the once-powerful coal companies, while 5,000 or 6,000 others are trucking it.

PARIS, Nov. 23. -- Premier Leon Blum tonight summoned his Cabinet to meet the threat of spreading strikes in which workmen occupied many plants. He called the session for tomorrow, in the face of growing industrial unrest, to clear the Cabinet's desks for quick action in the event that the present strikes spread.

The Gamma Chapter at the City College of the Phi Beta Kappa, national honorary scholastic society, elected forty-one new members last night at a meeting at Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street. There was a talk on "The Economic and Social Aspects of Modern Medicine" by Dr. Henry E. Sigerist, professor of Medical History at Johns Hopkins University.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 23 (AP). -- Morris Humphrey, 30, of New York, testified in Superior Court today that Mrs. Gertrude Greeley Whiting of Holyoke, 60-year-old widow, promised to pay him $100 a week if he would give up night club work and study music.

A proposal that all pupils be fingerprinted on leaving elementary school brought from Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, yesterday the comment that so many parents would object that such a plan would be "impracticable" at this time.

The end of the smoke and fumes nuisance in New York City buses is in sight, the Transit Commission announced yesterday. The commission said that after five years of research it expects to announce the solution to the problem within a few days.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23. -- Two thirds of the Julius Rosenwald Fund, established in 1917, has been expended, Edwin R. Embree, president of the fund, disclosed today. The present holdings, according to Mr. Embree's report, covering the twenty years that the fund has been in existence, have a market value of about $7,000,000.

ABOARD S.S. AMERICAN LEGION, at Sea, Nov. 23. -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull and his colleagues of the United States delegation to the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace held a final meeting today, going over the general program.
SEATTLE, Nov. 23 (AP). -- A recall movement against Mayor John F. Dore, accusing him of inciting acts of violence in a labor dispute, was started today, but Mr. Dore refused to be alarmed.

Tenders will be considered on Dec. 10 by officials of Montgomery County, Ohio, for a new issue of $340,000 of general bonds. The bonds will be dated Dec. 1, 1936, and will mature semi-annually from Dec. 1, 1941, to June 1, 1951. Bidders are to name a rate of interest not exceeding 6 per cent.
VALENCIA, Spain, Tuesday, Nov. 24 (AP). -- The Spanish Government definitely accused Germany and Italy today of aiding the Spanish Fascist fleet, according to the Reuters News Agency.

The Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation has notified the New York Stock Exchange of the sale, on Nov. 6, of 19,180 shares of 150-franc par-value stock of the Societe Worthington-Batignolles, a French company, reducing its holdings to 10,020 shares.

The apparent link between stock market activity and the course of the foreign exchanges was emphasized yesterday when, coincident with the reaction in securities, the principal foreign exchanges rose sharply in terms of the dollar. The pound sterling advanced to $4.91 and closed at $4.90 1/4, up 11-16 cent.

Storm warnings were hoisted for N.Y.U. at Fordham Field yesterday. The Rams were the maddest collection of gridiron warriors in the history of the university as they assembled to begin preparing for Thursday's traditional meeting with the Violet.

Corporation Counsel Paul Windels, asserting that an anti-Tammany ticket could be elected next Fall to carry on the policies of the present city administration, laid groundwork for the campaign yesterday by urging the immediate start of cooperative organization by independent political groups.

Members of the faculty and alumni of Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart, at 133d Street and Convent Avenue, will gather at the partly built new dormitory at 2:30 P.M. today for dedication of the cornerstone.

Featured by further advances of 5 to 10 per cent, trading last week in silk and synthetic griege goods was the most active week in over four years, according to the market report issued yesterday by Nickel, Barrett, Lieberman Quinn, Inc., textile brokers.

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, announced last night that 3,000 persons had been dropped from the WPA rolls in this city, and that a specific but undisclosed number of others would be dropped in con formity with orders from Washington.

VIENNA, Nov. 23. -- Dr. Edmund Glaise-Horstenau, Minister of the Interior, by appearing on a public platform tonight at the formation of an anti-Communist league in Vienna, committed the present regime to cooperation in the "world crusade against communism" inaugurated by Chancellor Adolf Hitler of Germany.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The State Department, acting "solely for the protection of American lives," ordered the closing of the United States Embassy at Madrid today. Eric C. Wendelin, third secretary in charge, was directed to leave Madrid as soon as possible and to take with him the embassy staff and all American citizens willing to leave.
The Empire Trust Company was accused before Justice Peter Schmuck in Supreme Court yesterday of making loans through "dummies" and exacting payment of "bonuses" for the loans.

The full support of the business community to the success of the New York World's Fair of 1939 was pledged last night by Richard F. Whitney, former President of the New York Stock Exchange and chairman of the bond sales committee of the fair, at a dinner at the Hotel Astor.
Business and apartment structures were included in the Brooklyn realty turnover reported yesterday.

MADRID, Nov. 23. -- Six shells struck the heart of the city today. One aerial incendiary bomb fell in the War Ministry courtyard. Several militiamen were wounded and many windows shattered by the explosions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Oral argument before the full Securities and Exchange Commission on the report to be proposed by William Green, trial examiner, on charges of violation of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 made against Michael J. Meehan, New York broker, in connection with alleged manipulation of the stock of the Bellanca Aircraft Company on the New York Curb, was set today for Dec. 8 at 10 A.M. in the commission's office here.

Mr. and Mrs. John Williams Morgan gave a dinner last night at the clubhouse of the New York Junior League for Prince and Princess Rodolfo del Drago and the latter's mother, Mrs. Francis Allen Wallace of Rome, Italy, who are passing the season here at the Ambassador.

MONTREAL, Nov. 23 (Canadian Press). -- Dave (Sweeney) Schriner, the Calgary sharpshooter who led National Hockey League scorers last year, has lost none of that goal-getting ability and tonight he appeared at the top of the league's first issue of statistics along with Bob Gracie of the Montreal Maroons.

Mrs. Eunice Dana Brannan, widow of Dr. John Winters Brannan and daughter of Charles A. Dana, woman suffrage leader who died on Nov. 14, left her estate in trust to her son and daughter. This was learned yesterday when her will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court.

Great Britain's deep concern in the threat of the Spanish Rebels to blockade Barcelona and Alicante is easy to understand. The question is not one merely of immediate commercial gain or loss. The law of blockade needs to be rewritten, and no country in the world is more interested than Great Britain in having the rights of blockaders, and also of neutral ships, clearly established in international law.

Magistrate William F. O'Dwyer served notice in the Brooklyn Homicide Court yesterday that he would not stand for having the court used for the collection of damages, particularly in cases involving the owners of dogs which have been hit by automobiles.

The contract bridge team of Fred D. Kaplan, Phil Abrasion, Harry Fishbein and Irving Epstein, which was almost eliminated in the final knockout round last week, won the right to compete in the finals for the Vanderbilt Cup last night. This team won its semi-final match at the Commodore Hotel with a margin of 4,060 in sixty boards played against the team of Benedict Jarmel, Herman H. Goldberg, Morrie Elis and J.C. Bank.
Park Commissioner Moses in his recent letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES relative to Inwood Hill Park, stated: "We are not reshaping Inwood Hill Park."

The prices of almost all classes of domestic bonds were lowered yesterday by a moderate reaction on the New York Stock Exchange. The movement spread to the higher-grade investments, including United States Government loans, in line with recessions among the more speculative and convertible corporate issues.

Going out to Kansas to breathe the purer air of the Grass Roots, Mr. GIFFORD PINCHOT, a progressive of the 1912 model, was inspired to utter the thoughts that have arisen in him since election day. When he attached himself to Governor LANDON and the Republican party he must have forgotten that the latter was the party of "concentrated wealth."

The continued slaughter of top-ranking football teams, including Northwestern and Marquette, leaves just eight teams in the nation's list of undefeated and untied college squads compiled by The Associated Press.

Andre Maurois, French essayist and novelist, compared last night the governmental system of France with an ocean vessel threatened by storms on the high seas, but firm in the hands of its captain. "Sweeping waves of political emotion throw the ship of state to the right and throw it to the left, but it is well balanced and in the end reaches a safe port," he said.

Heavier demands for Winter sports apparel and reorders on cruise and resort wear, together with hurry calls to spur delayed shipments of gift merchandise, featured the start of the week in the wholesale markets here yesterday. The demand for formal wear and accessories likewise showed a spurt, leading to the belief that many retailers have underestimated their needs on formal social attire.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23. -- "This Mad Whirl," the forty-ninth annual production of the Mask and Wig Club of the University of Pennsylvania, was received enthusiastically by an audience tonight at the Locust Street Theatre, where it opened a week's engagement.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- John G. Winant, chairman of the Social Security Board, and Thomas Eliot, general counsel, hailed the Supreme Court ruling on the New York Unemployment Insurance Law with great satisfaction, saying that despite the lack of a definite pronouncement the justices seemed, in the majority, sympathetic toward such State laws.

For the first time in nearly a month, Columbia's football squad gathered yesterday at Baker Field with all of its members firm of limb. Injuries to such stars as Sid Luckman and Johnny Siegal were gone and forgotten as the Lions settled down to the task of preparing for their game with Stanford at the Polo Grounds on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today the arrangement whereby the Keeshin trucking interests and the Chicago Great Western Railroad Company offer to shippers joint motor-rail-motor freight rates between the East and the Middle West.

BERLIN, Nov. 23. -- The death sentence passed by a Soviet court at Novosibirsk, Siberia, on a German mining engineer, Emil I. Stickling, and eight Russian co-defendants was met by the German press today with a wave of denunciatory protests which exceeds anything heard here even in war propaganda and which, in the case of any other two countries, would strain their diplomatic relations to the breaking point.
The Children's Aid Society, the Hobo Fellowship and the city joined yesterday in announcements of Thanksgiving meals for the homeless young and the homeless old.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 23. -- At a meeting today of twenty-five Yale football players who took part in the games against Harvard and Princeton, Clinton Edward Frank of Evanston, Ill., was unanimously elected captain for next year. The election, held in the Ray Tompkins House, quarters of the Yale Athletic Association, closed with only one ballot.

In at least three branches of the government at Washington officials are preparing material with which to answer questions the President is expected to ask about the capital gains tax upon his return from South America. This activity, plus the fact that several of the President's fiscal advisers are inclining toward modification of that levy, justifies real hope that the proposal will come seriously before Congress this Winter.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 23. - To an even greater degree than anticipated, the prophecy of an exceptionally early season is being fulfilled, with more than half the villas and hotels here now occupied. Opening dates for other hostelries clubs and shops have been advanced weeks ahead of former years.
MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 23 (AP). -- Diego Rivera's satirical frescoes in the new Hotel Reforma have been removed, it was disclosed tonight, because the management considered parts of them "offensive."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Angelo Herndon, Negro Communist, won the right today to a Supreme Court review of his conviction under a Georgia statute passed in Reconstruction days.

A new national football scoring champion appeared in The Associated Press compilation after Norman Schoen, 170-pound halfback from Baldwin-Wallace College in Ohio had tallied 31 points in a 67-0 victory over Louisville Saturday, bringing his total for eight games to 117.

A business plot on the northwest corner of Polk Avenue and Eighty-third Street, Jackson Heights, has been purchased by Sam Minskoff, builder, from the Queensboro Corporation. The plot is 100 by 100 feet. Mr. Minskoff is planning immediate improvement with a commercial structure.

JUNEAU, Alaska, Nov. 23 (AP). -- Flames spread through wrecked buildings beneath a great landslide here tonight and hope faded for at least thirteen missing persons who, rescue crews believed, were trapped under mud, rock and shattered timbers.

Yesterday was a day of adversity for the markets. Stocks had their widest decline since Oct. 26, with many leading issues down 1 to 4 points. Foreign selling of our securities played an important part in the day's proceedings, and, at the same time, the pound, the franc and the guilder rose sharply against the dollar.

PEIPING, China, Tuesday, Nov. 24. -- Following defeats of all attempts to force the Eastern Suiyuan defenses, the invaders are reported to be concentrating at Peilingzao, whence they are expected to launch attacks southward and westward toward Kweisui, the provincial capital, and Paotow, thus forcing the defenders greatly to extend their lines.

Dividends declared yesterday were estimated at $10,000,000, including extra and special disbursements. This brings the total of dividends voted this month to $617,500,000, the largest amount for any full month on record.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23. -- The market for hogs was unsettled today. Weights over 200 pounds were steady to slightly higher than on Saturday, while the lighter kinds ranged from steady to as much as 10 cents a hundredweight lower. Owing to the Thanksgiving holiday, shippers were inclined to go slow, which accounted for most of the weakness in the lighter averages.

The commissioners of the Port of New York Authority will meet today, it was learned yesterday, to discuss the advisability of proceeding at once with the construction of a twin to the Midtown Hudson Tunnel, now within a year of completion.

When Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, announced a payroll rise of 31 per cent and a net profit of $13,636,177, the largest for any quarter period in six years, he showed that the fears expressed by the American Iron and Steel Institute concerning reciprocity were baseless.

Under the sponsorship of Jack Dempsey, some of the leading amateur boxers in the country were brought together last night in fourteen bouts in the Madison Square Garden ring. Five knockouts marked the program, which attracted a crowd of 9,000 persons.

ONCE upon a time -- somewhat over fifteen years ago, to be exact -- a half-grown boy, combing the family bookshelf in search of something to read, hit upon a volume by David Grayson called "The Friendly Road." He took it down, and couldn't understand all of it, but it was a nice, comfortable book about life in the country, and he liked it.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- Army's squad turned out for the short Monday practice today without losing any time. The Cadets will devote every minute of the practice sessions left before the Navy game to a concentrated effort to get back into their early season form.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 23. -- A Chancery Court proceeding to restrain the Republic Steel Corporation from paying a dividend on a new series of cumulative prior preference stock was dismissed here today by Vivian M. Lewis, Vice Chancellor. Both sides in the action consented to the dismissal when the petitioner's lawyer revealed that a stockbroker inadvertently had sold the petitioner's old stock upon which the suit was based.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 23. -- Vincent L. Keating, a member of the State Board of Finance and Control, died at the Bridgeport Hospital late last night from the effects of a fall caused by being tripped by his dog at his home on Friday. He suffered a severe blow on the head and a clot on the brain developed.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 23. -- Dr. Felipe A. Espil, Argentine Ambassador to the United States, has been appointed secretary-general of the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace. He arrived here with Mrs. Espil recently from Europe after having gone to Geneva to confer with Foreign Minister Carlos Saavedra Lamas while the latter was in Europe to preside over the Assembly of the League of Nations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The Kansas Electric Power Company of Lawrence, Kan., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering an issue of $5,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds Series A due on Dec. 1, 1966.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 23. -- The Shandon Farm, owned by the Nash Brothers of Chicago, scored a triple today, the filly My Elsie capturing the feature six-furlong dash. Miss Mary Hirsch, who had the bad luck to be beaten with the favorite in the feature last Saturday, suffered the same fate when Which-print, at 9 to 10, finished out of the money.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 23 (AP). -- As a crowded court room booed questions put by B.F. Sacharow, opposing attorney, Dr. Francis E. Townsend replied calmly today that he "tried not to be a dictator" in his old age pension movement.

Returning from a visit to nine European countries, Raymond Leslie Buell, president of the Foreign Policy Association, declared yesterday that President Roosevelt had it within his power to prevent the outbreak of a new world war.

LITTLETON, N.H., Nov. 23. -- The many thousands of metropolitan Winter sports devotees, who make the Mount Mansfield-Smugglers Notch region of Vermont and the Franconia area of New Hampshire their skiing rendezvous, can anticipate the same adequate facilities of last year in addition to a number of improvements this Winter.

MOULTRIE, Ga., Nov. 23. -- A system of payments in kind to enable worthy tenant farmers to purchase land from the Federal Government after demonstrating their ability to succeed with the guidance of the government was suggested by Secretary Wallace today after a tour of the Red Hill sections of Alabama and Georgia.

Declaring that Gustave Halpern of 110 Riverside Drive, winner of a $300,000 condemnation award for property taken for street widening, had "practiced deception upon the court," Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo ordered the award set aside yesterday.

Members of Mayor La Guardia's Charter Revision Commission, the authors of the new city charter adopted at the last election, received formal recognition for their work yesterday when the Mayor gave them certificates of merit at a ceremony at City Hall.

Joseph A. Solovei, attorney involved in disbarment proceedings as an outgrowth of the Drukman case, has been cleared of four of the five charges against him, and censure or suspension has been recommended on the fifth count, it was said yesterday by Harold Corbin, counsel for Mr. Solovei.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The Netherlands and Switzerland have joined with the United States. Great Britain and France in the tripartite accord of Sept. 25 to promote international monetary equilibrium, Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. announced today.

The Masque, Majestic and Royale-Golden Theatre properties in West Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets, were sold at auction yesterday to the Magoro Corporation for the upset price of $700,000 fixed by court order. The purchaser was represented by William Klein, attorney for the Shubert interests, who declined to identify his clients beyond the corporate name.

HAVANA, Cuba, Nov. 23. -- Sugar producers here are considerably agitated over the proposed tax of 9 cents per bag on Cuban sugar production, which legislators plan to introduce in Congress in a few days.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 23. -- Union strikers by the hundreds marched out of the Bendix Products Corporation plant here this afternoon after having occupied it for slightly more than six days in an attempt to force complete unionization of the company.

Influenced by weakness in the stock market, unsettling foreign news and final liquidation of December contracts in advance of notices this morning, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange lost ground yesterday and ended 10 to 15 points lower than on Saturday.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 23 (AP). -- As a crowded court room booed questions put by B.F. Sacharow, opposing attorney, Dr. Francis E. Townsend replied calmly today that he "tried not to be a dictator" in his old age pension movement.

Returning from a visit to nine European countries, Raymond Leslie Buell, president of the Foreign Policy Association, declared yesterday that President Roosevelt had it within his power to prevent the outbreak of a new world war.

LITTLETON, N.H., Nov. 23. -- The many thousands of metropolitan Winter sports devotees, who make the Mount Mansfield-Smugglers Notch region of Vermont and the Franconia area of New Hampshire their skiing rendezvous, can anticipate the same adequate facilities of last year in addition to a number of improvements this Winter.

MOULTRIE, Ga., Nov. 23. -- A system of payments in kind to enable worthy tenant farmers to purchase land from the Federal Government after demonstrating their ability to succeed with the guidance of the government was suggested by Secretary Wallace today after a tour of the Red Hill sections of Alabama and Georgia.

Declaring that Gustave Halpern of 110 Riverside Drive, winner of a $300,000 condemnation award for property taken for street widening, had "practiced deception upon the court," Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo ordered the award set aside yesterday.

An emergency revolving fund of $1,500,000, provided by New York State to finance foreclosure proceedings and help clear up the certificated mortgage situation, was suggested here yesterday by Wendel P. Barker, chairman of the State Mortgage Commission.

ROME, Nov. 23. -- Rome is preparing to give a royal welcome to Admiral Nicholas Horthy, Regent of Hungary, whose arrival tomorrow afternoon on an official visit is designed to impress on the world the closeness of the ties uniting Italy and Hungary and emphasize Italy's complete espousal of the cause of treaty revision.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The first stamps of the army-navy heroes' series will be put on sale Dec. 15 at the Washington postoffice and on the following day at postoffices throughout the country.

A suit to enjoin the proposed sale by the Carib Syndicate, Ltd., of its 21 per cent interest in the Colombian Petroleum Company, holder of the Barco oil concession, has been started in Supreme Court by Fred Rosenthal, a stockholder, it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad Company today asked permission of the Interstate Commerce Commission to extend for ten years $7,250,000 of the first mortgage bonds of the Lake Erie Western Railroad Company, dated Feb. 21, 1887, and due on Jan. 1, 1937.
The guests seated on the dais at the dinner at the Hotel Astor last night opening the debenture sales campaign of the New York World's Fair of 1939, in the order of seating, were:

A plot 50 by 100 at 29 Mosholu Parkway North has been purchased by a builder from the Lawyers Mortgage Guarantee Company for improvement with a six-story elevator apartment structure. An old two-story bulding is on the property, which is assessed for $27,000. Schimmer, Kerner Feder acted as brokers.

TRENTON, Nov. 23. -- There will be about $10,000,000 of State funds available for diversion to relief financing in 1937, it was estimated today by "economy" advocates in the Legislature after disclosure that Highway Department moneys already spent and committed for road and grade-crossing improvements this year would exceed $24,000,000.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- As a recount of the approximately 250,000 votes cast for Surrogate in Westchester got under way in Yonkers today, moves were made in New Rochelle and White Plains to prevent a recurrence of the widespread discrepancies which formed the legal basis for the county-wide recount ordered by the Supreme Court.

The strength of two organizations of licensed officers was placed behind the strike of Atlantic and Coast seamen yesterday when national officials of the Masters, Mates and Pilots Association and the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association ordered their members ashore.

Asserting that there was not the slightest doubt of the tremendous success of the New York World's Fair of 1939, Mayor La Guardia revealed last night at the dinner opening the sale of debentures for the fair, at the Hotel Astor, that the city would spend $7,000,000 directly and about $10,000,000 indirectly as its contribution to the fair.

Final details of the acquisition of the Toccoa Electric Power Company by the Tennessee Electric Power Company were set forth yesterday in an announcement by the New York Stock Exchange. The Exchange's statement said:
The Thanksgiving Day football classic of them all comes into its own again this week after years of mediocrity and dwindling attendance.

ENSENADA, Lower California, Nov. 23. -- Deportation by Mexican immigration officials of a large group of striking American maritime workers today preceded the successful unloading of 107 passengers from the intercoastal liner Santa Elena at this resort port.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 23 (Canadian Press). -- The touring Marylebone Cricket Club has a sporting chance to avert an innings' defeat in its match with an Australian eleven. Hitting 544 for eight, the home team leads by 256 runs, the Englishmen's first innings netting 288.

Albert Morris Bagby's season of Musical Mornings was inaugurated yesterday. The 389th concert took place in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria and attracted the usual representative gathering of society. Gertrude Kappel and John Charles Thomas of the Metropolitan Opera, and Mischa Elman, violinist, took part in the program.

An accounting suit charging waste, mismanagement and dissipation of the assets of the old United Founders Corporation, now merged with its affiliated companies in the American General Corporation, was disclosed yesterday in Supreme Court when the plaintiffs moved for a bill of particulars on certain acts of the defendants.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- William F. Bleakley, defeated candidate for Governor, by implication here tonight proclaimed himself leader of the Republican party in the State. At the same time he urged a drastic revision of the party's policies and program pending reaction from the New Deal election victory.

While Anna Swift, who insists on being called "doctor" because, as she says, she is a doctor of chiropractic and doctor of osteopathy, was listening to testimony in her Special Sessions trial yesterday, the State Tax Commissioner filed a judgment against her for $47,960.

The rise of $2 to $4 a ton announced by the United States Steel Corporation late yesterday afternoon was regarded as rather small, in view of the recent 10 per cent increase in wages; the steady advance in material costs, and the Social Security levies which will begin on Jan. 1.

A man who should have been committed to the Tombs as a fourth offender without bail, pending grand jury action, was released on parole because the police took two weeks to find his record, it was revealed yesterday when the record was sent to the chief clerk of the Yorkville magistrate's court.

The thud of the auctioneer's hammer today will mark the start of another Old Glory Sale at which the best yearlings and some outstanding older horses of the light harness ranks will change hands. The forty-second annual sale will begin at 10:30 this morning and run through Thursday at the Squadron A Armory.

Sheriff William F. Brunner of Queens, the Democratic candidate for President of the Board of Aldermen in the last election, had a plurality of 892,296 over Alderman A. Newbold Morris, his Republican opponent, according to the official canvass of the vote made public yesterday by the Board of Elections.

A proposal for a voluntary agreement among the merchants of the country on a four-point program covering relations with the consumer, the government, employes and producers has been adopted by the board of directors of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, it was announced yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 28. -- One hundred and forty-nine different athletic events, involving seventeen separate teams, are listed on the Princeton Winter sports schedule published today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics of the university.

A benefit loan exhibition of twenty-four paintings by Georges de la Tour and the three brothers Le Nain -- Antoine, Louis and Mathieu -- opened with a reception and private view yesterday afternoon at Knoedler's, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23. -- The Commonwealth Edison Company and the Public Service Company of Northern Illinois today declared special dividends of $1 each on their common stocks, voted bonuses of 2 1/2 per cent on annual earnings of employes and wage increases of 2 1/2 per cent.

Manhattan's football team, starting preparations to meet Texas A. and M. in the Rose Festival game at Tyler, Texas, a week from Saturday, engaged in a brief drill under the direction of Coach Chick Meehan at Innisfail Park yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Nov. 18 shows a decrease for the week of $46,000,000 in total loans and investments, increases of $20,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $7,000,000 in time deposits, a decrease of $75,000,000 in government deposits, and increases of $63,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks and $65,000,000 in balances with domestic banks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Allocation of $13,555,644, including $12,015,044 in outright grants and sixty-two loans amounting to $1,540,600 for 272 public works projects in thirty-seven States, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, were announced today by Secretary Ickes.

More than 800 property owners of Kew Gardens and Forest Hills, Queens, were told at a mass meeting last night that a petition with 500 signatures had been filed with the Board of Estimate asking for a hearing on proposed assessments in Queens for the Interborough Parkway.
Mary Washington Colonial Chapter, Daughters of the American Revolution, held its annual luncheon at the Plaza yesterday for 150 members and friends.
Jean Pierre Le Mee, 19-year-old French student who was sent here by the French Government to report on the social life of American colleges, found it "very new" and "very astonishing."

Footballs and snowballs filled the air at Ohio Field yesterday as the New York University squad moved into the final practice stage for tomorrow's battle with unbeaten Fordham at the Yankee Stadium. The football tossing was the idea of Mal Stevens and his coaching staff but the snowball part of the aerial display was contributed gratis by the spirited youngsters who think that they'll take the measure of the wrathful and rampaging Ram.

At 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon passers-by at 71 Broadway craned their heads when J.P. Morgan emerged from the offices of the United States Steel Corporation, surrounded by several of his fellow-directors. Wearing his familiar square derby, the former chairman of the board of the Corporation towered above the little group as it walked briskly toward the offices of J.P. Morgan Co., two short blocks away.
The Four Aces contract bridge team, defending champions for the Vanderbilt Cup, was eliminated in the semi-final round completed yesterday at the Hotel Commodore.

More than 200,000 postmen, who are excluded from benefits under the Federal Social Security Act, spent their busiest day yesterday distributing the forms that will enable 26,000,000 wage-earners to share in the government pension program.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 24. -- The Republic Steel Corporation announced today plans to construct continuous cold and hot strip mills here at a cost of about $15,000,000.

TALAVERA DE LA REINA, Spain, Nov. 24. -- There is no romance in the warfare on the Madrid front at present for this correspondent. A cold, damp wind blew all day as airplanes flew in a leaden gray sky over the drab city. There was plenty of shelling and routine small-arms fire, but night fell leaving me cold and regarding Spain as a Summer resort in the Winter.

Different versions were current yesterday of a fist fight that enlivened the Stork Club early yesterday morning and revolved around. Johnny Weissmuller, the screen Tarzan and former swimming champion, and Lieutenant Cameron McRae Winslow Jr., U.S.N., son of the late Rear Admiral Winslow.

Payment of the Dec. 1 coupon of the American portion of the Young Plan bonds (German Government 5 1/2 per cent International Loan of 1930) has been provided in the same way that was followed in meeting the June 1 coupon, it was announced here yesterday by the German Consul General.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 24 (AP). -- Mme. Ernestine Schumann-Heink, in her will filed for probate today, left the bulk of her estate to four children and her music to colleges or institutions to be selected by her executors.

Klara Kwartin, a young soprano heard here in the last two years in recitals which she gave under the auspices of the Music Guild, sang a program consisting entirely of songs by Hugo Wolf last night in Town Hall.

Now that licensed officers have joined the seamen on strike and the admission has been made that the situation is serious, how long will the steamship companies abuse our patience? Do they think that we, the taxpayers, have no concern when our money goes into a generous subsidy to their lines?
Intensive efforts by customs men to corner a diamond-smuggling syndicate resulted yesterday in the arrest of three persons and the confiscation of diamonds valued at $150,000.

A building believed to have been built in 1697 and probably the oldest Dutch structure in New York used originally as a school and church has been found on Staten Island, it was announced last night by Loring McMillen, director of the Staten Island Historical Museum.

The announcement that the Netherlands, Switzerland and Belgium have formally declared their adherence to the tripartite currency agreement which France, Great Britain and the United States reached on Sept. 25 must be welcomed as a cause for further reassurance.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Nov. 24. -- The special prosecutor of the newly created National Security Tribunal, which will try those implicated in the Leftist revolt in November, 1935, filed charges today against the first batch of accused, comprising thirty-five men alleged to have been the leaders.

LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 25. -- There are two passages in an editorial that The Times publishes here today that normally would have passed unnoticed had not King Edward caused some disturbance of mind among his friends and advisers over his open friendship with Mrs. Wallis Simpson, who only recently obtained a divorce from Ernest A. Simpson.

From its great store of material about the theatre, the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, has arranged in its main exhibition room a special display entitled "The English Theatre. 1660-1860."

Michael J. Meehan, who made Wall Street history in 1928 with his coup in R.C.A. stock, a series of deals supposed to have shown profits of $5,000,000 to $15,000,000, has been confined to a private sanitarium since late Summer, it was learned yesterday.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Nov. 24. -- Coming from behind both times, New Jersey defeated New York and Westchester, both by 5 -- 2, to win the first 1936-37 Class A group match of the women's division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association at the Short Hills Club today.

Supreme Court Justice Valente reserved decision yesterday in the suit brought by a stockholder to restrain the Carib Syndicate, Ltd., from selling its 21 per cent interest in the Colombian Petroleum Company but ruled that the stockholders might meet today, as scheduled, to vote approval or disapproval of the proposed sale.

LONDON, Nov. 24. -- Partial recovery from yesterday's sharp decline was made on the stock market here today following reassurance as to the tenor of Foreign Secretary Eden's statement regarding Great Britain's policy toward the war in Spain.

Giving "inadequate representation of retailing" as the reason, the National Retail Dry Goods Association has resigned as a member of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, it was announced here yesterday.

PEIPING, Nov. 24. -- Announcing today the discovery of two additional brain pans of Sinanthropus Pekinensis, Professor Franz Weidenreich of the Peiping Union Medical College, declared the latest discovered anthropological data place the "Peking Man" between Pithecanthropus Erectus and the "Neanderthal Man."
With its contest against Stanford less than four days away, Columbia speeded up its preparation yesterday at Baker Field by having a thorough rehearsal of offensive and defensive tactics.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 24. -- That nothing has been done by the mandatory government to fulfill Article VI of the Palestine Mandate, calling for the facilitation of the settlement of Jews on government lands, and that few Arabs had been ousted from their holding by Jewish land purchasers was revealed in testimony given today before the royal commission of inquiry.
MADRID, Nov. 24. -- Many persons were wounded this afternoon in a bombardment of the central quarters of Madrid by Rebels in the Casa de Campo, on the western edge of the city.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- While no confirmation could be obtained today from officials that direct negotiations had been started for a reopening of the war debt problem, there was a belief in some quarters that the persistent reports from abroad concerning the possibility of steps in that direction by Great Britain, France and Italy might be the forerunner of at least informal inquiries soon.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Nov. 24 (AP). -- Dr. Franz Serge shot one adversary in the arm today in one of his scheduled duels and embraced a second opponent after both duelists had missed.

Marked improvement in sentiment was reflected in bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange as the market shook off the nervousness which had characterized the preceding session. Higher prices prevailed in most of the important groups, including the higher grade loans as well as the more speculative corporate issues.

From Valencia the Spanish Government issues almost daily statements hard to believe. One of the latest charges is that a German submarine had sunk a Spanish man of war in Spanish waters. Other assertions of the kind indicate the desperate state of mind to which Prime Minister LARGO CABALLERO has been reduced by successive misfortunes.

PARIS, Nov. 24. -- The complete parallelism between the policies of the French and the British Governments in the Spanish dispute was emphasized today when the French Cabinet Council met to discuss the latest developments in the international situation resulting from the civil war.

The directors of the Powdrell Alexander Company will meet early in December to consider payment of an extra dividend. The company reported yesterday the largest amount of unfilled orders on its books in its history.

ABSECON, N.J., Nov. 24. -- Encouraged by the rousing send-off from almost 1,000 undergraduates and the university band, before it left the campus, Pennsylvania's varsity football squad went through an hour's workout on the fairway of the Seaview Golf Club today.
The forward passing combination of Arnold Herber and Don Hutson of the powerful Green Bay Packers has shattered three National Football League records, according to statistics announced yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 24. -- President Roosevelt's visit and the Spanish civil war momentarily became matters of secondary interest today as newspapers announced with first-page streamers the award of the 1936 Nobel Peace Prize to Dr. Carlos Saavedra Lamas.

Price movements were mixed on the commodity futures markets yesterday. Rubber, sugar, cocoa and silk were strong in active trading, while coffee and tallow were lower. On the cash markets corn eased but gains were scored by wheat, rye, cotton, cocoa, rubber and tin.

Mrs. August Belmont, chairman of the Metropolitan Opera Guild, yesterday reported that the organization has 1,842 members and that the group has purchased $24,330 worth of subscriptions for the Metropolitan Opera season. Mrs. Belmont made her announcement at the second luncheon meeting of the season at the Hotel Pierre, at which more than 750 persons were present.

The New York City guidebook, about which there has been so much ado and which occupied the energies of 400 WPA writers for more than a year but which the Federal government never seemed disposed to print, is nearing publication under private auspices, it was learned last night.

BERLIN, Nov. 24. -- The Boerse, after several weeks of activity resulting from rumors of devaluation of the mark in connection with France's cheapening of her currency and from disturbances attributable to the Reich at government's campaign against foreign stock holdings, now is apparently returning to its normal state of stagnation.

Suffocating fumes in the hold of a ship unloading a cargo at the Dupont Street (Brooklyn) terminus of the State barge canal were fatal to five men shortly after 7:30 o'clock last night. Three others were overcome but were revived after rescue by policemen who climbed into the hold wearing gas masks.

LONDON, Nov. 24. -- Alterations in the disposition of British warships in Spanish waters are now being made with a view to implementing Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's statement in the House of Commons yesterday that British shipping on the high seas would be protected "against interference by ships of either party engaged in the conflict in Spain."

The Jaysee Realty Corporation will begin work today on a three-story building to be constructed on two adjoining plots assessed at $136,000 at 2,869-73 Hudson Boulevard, at Journal Square, Jersey City. Title passed last Monday. The site adjoins the new three-story China Clipper Building, recently completed by the same company.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 24. -- The first of the big "pep" meetings which herald the approach of the Army game took place at the Naval Academy tonight, with the Middies dancing around a huge bonfire on the parade grounds.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 24. -- T.H. Somerville's Treford took the Bay Shore Handicap by four lengths today. Jack Westrope handled the winner with the ease which has made him a favorite here, and had little to do in the closing yards but sit tight as the others were beaten off behind him.
Citations for the protection of human rights were presented to six leading Americans by New York Lodge No. 1 B'nai B'rith at the B'nai B'rith Club, 36 West Sixty-ninth Street, last night.

The magnificent Philadelphia Orchestra, with Leopold Stokowski, the man responsible for its present status, conducting, gave its second New York concert of the season last night in Carnegie Hall. The program followed a pattern rather familiar when Mr. Stokowski conducts, and always effective.

A crew of dressmakers was planning last evening to work all through the night and today to make a wedding gown (ivory velvet with a five-yard train) and two bridesmaids' dresses for the wedding tomorrow of a "pair of childhood sweethearts."

Judge BLEAKLEY made so good an impression in his campaign for Governor, and fared so well at the polls in view of the hopeless odds against him, that he is fully entitled to regard himself as the Republican leader in New York. It sorely needs one. At Binghamton Monday he stated candidly the causes of the present condition of his party.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,060,950 barrels, compared to 3,040,400 in the previous week, a gain of 20,550, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gains of 15,200 and 6,150 barrels, respectively, in the daily average output of Texas and Oklahoma were the important changes.

MOSCOW, Nov. 24. -- The eighth Congress of Soviets will convene tomorrow evening in the great Kremlin Palace for a session destined to be highly important in history. It will adopt the new "Stalin Constitution" and then go out of existence forever, for under the new Constitution a bicameral body, similar in form to the United States Congress, will replace it as the theoretical repository of the supreme Soviet power.

The first consignment of the holiday film fare reaches Broadway today. "Lloyds of London," Twentieth Century-Fox's treatment of times and manners at the turn of the eighteenth century, featuring Freddie Bartholomew, Tyrone Power Jr., Madeleine Carroll and a host of others, has its premiere at the Astor tonight.
In the homeward movement for Thanksgiving that begins today, railroad reservations indicate that three persons will leave the city for every two who arrive.
Housing under government subsidies "is bound to make record-breaking strides" during the next four years," in the opinion of Evans Clark, economic adviser to the New York City Rousing Authority.

The reminder in the "negative affirmation" of New York's Unemployment Insurance Law by the Supreme Court, that when the justices divide evenly the decision of the lower court stands, recalls the day when Supreme Court minorities used to prevail in judgments.
