CHICAGO, Nov. 24. -- The Inland Steel Company today followed the action of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation in increasing prices of steel products from $2 to $4 a ton, effective Dec. 1, for delivery in the first quarter of 1937.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 24. -- Efforts by Juvenile Court Judge Siegler to induce Mr. and Mrs. Benno Bongart of 123 Watchung Avenue, West Orange, to return their two sons, William, 12 years old, and Robert, 11, to the Washington public school in West Orange failed today when Mrs. Bongart said she wanted to send them back, but "wanted safety for my children."

The Michael Friedsam Gold Medal was awarded yesterday afternoon to Mrs. Ellen Dunlap Hopkins, founder of the New York School of Applied Design for Women. The presentation was made at brief exercises which began at 5 o'clock at the Architectural League of New York, 115 East Fortieth Street.

Thanksgiving services will be held tomorrow in the cathedrals, synagogues and in parish churches of every faith. Most of the services will be at 11 A.M., although some will be earlier. A number of churches will hold pre-Thanksgiving observances this evening.

Led by the United States Steel Corporation, which declared a dividend of $7 a share on account of arrearages on its preferred stock, large corporations continued yesterday to pour undistributed earnings into the hands of stockholders.
MADRID, Nov. 24. -- Fighting continued on the outskirts of Madrid today as Insurgent troops, led by tanks, attempted to force their way toward the city proper under a heavy barrage.

The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that, pursuant to a plan of readjustment of the New York Railways Corporation, a supplemental indenture between that corporation and the New York City Omnibus Corporation and the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company would be executed today.
MADRID, Nov. 24. -- The text of the government communique charging "foreign warships" with attacks on Spanish Government vessels follows:

Various floors and other large units were among the commercial units reported rented yesterday. The Conway Press, Inc., leased the sixteenth floor in the Tower Building, at 227-33 East Forty-fifth Street, through Huberth Huberth. Thomas H. Tang, dealer in Oriental art, leased a floor at 23 West Fifty-sixth Street through Cushman Wakefield and Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc., broker.
MADRID, Nov. 24. -- The German and Italian embassies were seized and locked tonight by armed Spanish militiamen, who arrested several political refugees in the German building.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24. -- Wheat prices on the Board of Trade here fluctuated in a listless manner today within narrow limits, but the undertone was firm. An early dip was followed by a rally of approximately 1 cent a bushel from the low point, with the close at the top.

LONDON, Nov. 24. -- On the floor of the House of Lords today the Earl of Halsbury delivered a stinging rebuke to the government for having fallen into "a sluggard's slough" in remedying Britain's deficiencies in air defense.

ALBANY, Nov. 24. -- An ordinance enacted by the village of Port Chester, which prohibited the selling of newspapers on the streets between the hours of 9 P.M. and 7 A.M., was declared unconstitutional today by the Court of Appeals.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24. -- Directors of Montgomery Ward Co., today raised the quarterly dividend rate on the common stock from 20 cents to 50 cents and voted a special distribution of $2.90 a share. At the same time the company reported the largest profits for the third quarter and the first nine months of the year in its history.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24. -- Unlisted trading on registered securities exchanges is unsound in principle and should be eliminated gradually, the Chicago Stock Exchange argued in a brief filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington in opposition to the application of several exchanges throughout the country to extend unlisted trading privileges.

Stuart M. Crocker, general chairman of the United Hospitals Campaign, announced yesterday that $370,503.75 had been pledged to date toward the annual fund of $2,881,644, required for the operation of eighty-six voluntary hospitals in the city for the current year.
Nearly all the 100 cigar stores of Schulte Co. in this city were closed yesterday when more than 400 clerks and store managers went on strike for more wages and a reduction in hours.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- Ninety-seven underwriters, believed to be the largest number in connection with any single issue registered under the Securities Act of 1933, were named today by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in an amendment to its registration statement for $165,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent debentures due Dec. 1, 1966.

The engagement of $2,052,000 gold abroad for shipment here, $1,896,000 in England and $156,000 in India, was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The bank reported no gold imports here yesterday.

Business failures declined in the retail and wholesale branches of business in the week ended Nov. 19, compared with the previous five business days, but increased in the manufacturing division, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24. -- Heavy hogs were scarce and were in good demand. Prices were steady to 5 cents higher than yesterday. Lighter weights sold slowly until late in the session when leading packers came into the market and some sales were regarded as 15 cents lower.

Plans of two apartment houses for corners on the Grand Concourse in the Bronx were filed yesterday. The estimated costs of the two projects totaled $575,000. Details of filings in the city were as follows:

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 24. -- Alexander W. Weddell, the United States Ambassador, called at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs this morning and informed Foreign Minister Carlos Saavedra Lamas that President Roosevelt had acceded to the Argentine Government's repeated request that he land at Buenos Aires instead of at Mar del Plata when he arrives next Monday for the opening of the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace.

Members of the board of trustees of the Neighborhood Music School gave a reception with music yesterday afternoon at the headquarters of the school, 238 East 105th Street, for the junior committee aiding in the sale of tickets for the performance of the "A" series of Noel Coward's one-act plays. "Tonight at 8:30," the night of Dec. 2 at the National Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the organization.
YESTERDAY we mentioned Willa Cather's essay "The Novel Demeuble" -- and here today, a case in point, is a first novel by Eugene Armfield, "Where the Weak Grow Strong" (Covici, Friede, $2.50).

JONESBORO, Ark., Nov. 24 (AP). -- City Marshal Paul D. Peacher of Earle, Ark., testified today at his trial on charges of violating the Federal anti-slavery law, that his arrests of Negroes who were later sent to his farm in East Arkansas to work out sentences were "official acts" and that the men had "regular trials."

Confusion over the application of the Robinson-Patman Act has been brought about mainly by those who are endeavoring to evade the provisions of the law, Representative Wright Patman said last night to a large group of independent retail druggists at a meeting in the Hotel Astor held under the auspices of McKesson Robbins.

At one Army post, at least, all the football interest this week is not directed toward Philadelphia. Governors Island is a definite exception. The harbor outpost is agog, but about the meeting of its Fort Jay Hawks with the Fort Du Pont Red Devils at Ebbets Field Sunday rather than the big Army-Navy battle at Franklin Field.

The Norfolk Western Railway declared yesterday an extra dividend of $5 a share on its common stock. Of the $7,032,000 disbursement, the Pennsylvania Railroad will receive more than $2,979,000 as a result of its holdings of 44 per cent of the stock.

Nothing very serious happens in the three one-act plays that Noel Coward and Gertrude Lawrence put on at the National last evening, and nothing very dull tarnishes any part of their program. For this is one of the many things they do superlatively well.

Lewis Henry Lapham, financier and one of the founders of the Texas Oil Company, now the Texas Corporation, left an estate of $5,796,357 gross and $5,559,186 net when he died on June 10, 1934, the transfer tax appraisal disclosed yesterday.
During the first extensive snow of the season 1.8 inches fell in the metropolitan area Monday night and early yesterday morning, equaling last year's record for Nov. 24.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 24. -- George and Ira Gershwin have been engaged by S.J. Briskin to score "A Damsel in Distress," the P.G. Wodehouse story, purchased for RKO on Monday by Pandro S. Berman for Fred Astaire. The film will be the first in which the dancer is the sole star.
Jumping into a four-goal lead before the first period was over, the New York Rangers had little difficulty conquering the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden last night.

Phil Furr, Washington welter-weight, made his initial metropolitan appearance a successful one by gaining a ten-round decision over Walter Matis of Carbondale, Pa., in the feature bout at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of 6,000 saw the fast contest.
SYRACUSE, Nov. 24. -- The house of delegates of the State Teachers Association went on record today for the extension of the Tenure Law to the entire State.

The quantity of American record-breakers during the past year dropped more than a hundred from the total of the season before but the quality of the performances showed no appreciable difference, it was indicated yesterday when Secretary-Treasurer Daniel J. Ferris made known the list that the A.A.U. will consider at its convention in Houston, Texas, on Dec. 4, 5 and 6.

The annual exhibition of work accomplished by artists of the Louis Comfort Tiffany Foundation during the season of 1936 opens today at the Grand Central (Vanderbilt Avenue) Galleries, where it will be current until Dec. 5. Fifteen artists are represented by oils, five of these are showing prints and six of the fifteen and two others are represented by water-colors or pastels.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- The Federal Trade Commission has ordered an association and its members, with headquarters at 1 Union Square, New York, to discontinue using the name "A.F. of L. Trade Union Committee for Unemployment Insurance and Relief" or any other name suggesting connection with the American Federation of Labor.

According to a reliable estimate it cost the Republican State Committee approximately $900,000, a new high record, to finance the late State campaign which resulted in crushing defeat for the candidates on the State and national tickets.

Maurice Evans, now starring in "St. Helena," may appear here for Max Gordon in other plays when his current vehicle closes, it was indicated yesterday. Declaring that he wanted to present Mr. Evans in "Richard II" or in repertory, the manager went before the Equity Council, seeking an exception to Equity's rule that an alien actor cannot appear here for six months after concluding a Broadway engagement.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24. -- Samuel H. Williams of the Chamber of Commerce Transportation Bureau said of the Interstate Commerce Commission ruling on the Albany rate case that "probably the commission prescribed the Philadelphia rates as a maximum basis for Albany on the theory that the average distance between the interior points and the two ports are approximately the same."

ABOARD THE U.S.S. CHESTER, At Sea, Nov. 24 (AP). -- President Roosevelt, sailing down to Rio de Janeiro on the cruiser Indianapolis, worked today on his speech to be delivered Friday in the Brazilian capital.

Work in preparation for the complete operation of the State Unemployment Insurance Act beginning January, 1938, will require the State Department of Labor to take on from 300 to 400 new employes within the next three months and to open from thirty to forty district offices within six months, it was learned yesterday.

Exhibitions opening this week but not hitherto announced in this column include a group show at Alfred Stieglitz's An American Place, with paintings by Demuth, Dove, Hartley, Marin, O'Keeffe and Rebecca S. Strand, commencing on Friday.

Soviet Russia aims ultimately at handling all Soviet foreign trade at Moscow, where the heads of export and import trusts have been authorized to deal directly with foreign buyers and sellers, Mark M. Watkins, export manager for the Brown Instrument Company, advised members of the Export Managers Club of New York, Inc., at a luncheon yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

PEIPING, China, Wednesday, Nov. 25. -- Chinese reports from Suiyuan Province state that both sides are massing unprecedented troops and armaments and that a major conflict between the Chinese and Mongols is expected to start Friday or Saturday.

A registration statement will be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, probably on Friday, for a new issue of $25,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent bonds, due in 1966, of the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company, it was disclosed yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 24. -- The first effect of the increase in prices for finished steel is expected to be the driving in of new business as consumers take advantage of the current lower prices. It is not doubted that the big independent companies will follow the advance with announcements of their own.

The New York State Conservation Department has just completed a depressing job -- the annual compilation of deaths and injuries during the general upland game season. Yet, in making public the details of the season's tragedies, the department is performing a helpful service.
Several apartment houses were included in the Bronx trading reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- Albany, as a seaport, was placed by the Interstate Commerce Commission today on a parity in North Atlantic freight rates with Philadelphia when the commission found that present railway rates were preferential to the ports of New York, Boston, Norfolk, Baltimore and Philadelphia.

The Port of New York Authority decided yesterday afternoon to proceed immediately with the construction of the twin, or north, tube of the Midtown Hudson Vehicular Tunnel at an estimated cost of about $33,000,000, bringing the cost of the two tunnels to about $80,000,000.

Prospects for careers, if not exactly glittering, at least tinged with the hope of substantial achievement, were presented to 100 Barnard College undergraduates last night in four occupational round tables by leading alumnae. The four topics, selected in a poll of the students, were social work, statistical and other research work, writing and publishing and medicine and its allied vocations.

John M. Franklin, president of the International Mercantile Marine Company, announced yesterday the appointment of Charles S. Hand, former New York newspaper man and city official, as assistant to the president. Mr. Hand has been associated with the steamship concern for the last two years as counsel in public relations.

LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 25 (AP). -- Armed Spanish Insurgent ships were reported today to have stopped two foreign vessels, one Norwegian and the other Greek, and forced them to go to Insurgent-held ports.

Stanley Galowin, New York University junior, won the Eastern Squash Racquets Association tourney final yesterday at the New York Athletic Club by defeating A.E. Watt of Jackson Heights after a three-game rally.

Minneapolis, Minn., awarded yesterday through the secretary of the Board of Estimate and Taxation, a new issue of $1,030,000 of public relief and permanent improvement bonds to Phelps, Fenn Co., on a bid of 100.162 for 1.70s.

Albert Holroyd, 42 years old, vice president of the Central Elevator Company, 405 West Fortieth Street, had a bullet in his left hip for about nine hours yesterday morning before he discovered the wound. The wound, according to Detectives Patrick Harty and Timothy Hegarty of the West Sixty-eighth Street station, was received in an altercation with a house detective at the Alamac Hotel, Broadway and Seventy-first Street, where he lived.

Reports of a general shortage of newsprint were characterized as "scarehead" yesterday by L.B. Palmer, general manager of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, 370 Lexington Avenue. Mr. Palmer asserted that a survey of both Canadian and United States mills revealed an ample supply for the next eight or ten months.

ROME, Nov. 24. -- Will H. Hays, American motion-picture czar, who has been in Rome for ten days, has spent almost all his time collaborating with William Phillips, the United States Ambassador, in negotiations with Italian authorities to solve a number of difficulties in the distribution of American motion pictures in Italy.
F.E. Miller, formerly general manager of the Ohio division of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, has been appointed manager of the New York City division of Seagram-Distillers.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 24. -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull urged the nations of the two American continents today to "rededicate" themselves to the "cause of peace and economic progress." He proposed that they provide "inspiration and a guide to a world sorely needing leadership and enlightened statesmanship."

No one has any fault to find with any group of people or representatives of various nations who desire to put an end to strife, bloodshed and hatred. That is a worthy objective and all thinking people hope for it. If national energies were directed toward this end as fully as those for waging battle, the problem would seem soon to be solved.

GENEVA, Nov. 24. -- Assurances from the Spanish delegates that they were not waging a religious war against Protestants were demanded by the Central Office for Mutual Aid Among Churches here in a statement issued today.

The number of buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday was less than in the preceding week but showed a substantial gain over the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES. For the week the arrivals totaled 802 as against 872 in the previous week and 683 in the same period last year.

A thirty-day workhouse sentence was suspended in Special Sessions yesterday on Mrs. Marion C. Kail of 140 West Seventieth Street for serving as a trained nurse without being registered by the State Education Department.

The General Realty and Utilities Corporation, an investment company, and its subsidiaries, exclusive of the Lefcourt Realty Corporation, issued yesterday a financial statement for the first nine months of this year, showing a profit of $362,274 after interest, State and Federal taxes other than income taxes, but before depreciation.
Sales of property on York Avenue and Broadway and leases of several buildings for business purposes were included in the Manhattan realty deals reported yesterday.

WITH INSURGENT FORCES OUTSIDE MADRID, Nov. 23 (Delayed in Transmission). -- Insurgent infantrymen captured two Russian tanks today, when Leftist defenders of Madrid attempted an attack on the Insurgent-dominated Casa de Campo Park, on the western edge of the city.

Owners' claims for property taken by the city for improvements in Kings, Queens and Richmond Counties in the twelve months ended Sept. 25 last were pared down by Supreme Court Justice Lockwood in Brooklyn from $17,116,000 to $10,350,000, it was disclosed yesterday.

The technique of modern strike-breaking by means of "missionary" work and "propaganda" conducted by men who call themselves "industrial diplomats" was described yesterday. The description was offered at a hearing before the National Labor Relations Board in an inquiry being conducted by the board into the recent strike of employes of Remington Rand, Inc.

The City Athletic Club remained undefeated and retained first place in Group 2 of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association by invading the Jackson Heights courts last night and defeating its host, 3-2. I. Knopp won the deciding match by defeating G. Gordon Lynn, a substitute for O.D. Ellis, 15-9, 15-11, 15-12.

In your editorial "Disunited Europe" you make no allusion to the share of responsibility that falls to the United States, if indeed through recent events Aristide Briand's cherished vision of a United States of Europe has "receded deeper into the background of dreamland."

The Staten Island women's Class B squash racquets team surprised the Junior League players by defeating them, 3 -- 2, on the league courts yesterday. The deciding match between Mrs. Scott Russell of Staten Island and Mrs. Frank Smith couldn't have been closer, with Mrs. Russell finally clinching the class sectional title for her team after five prolonged games, 12 -- 15, 10 -- 15, 18 -- 16, 17 -- 14, 15 -- 13.

At the close of the State's case yesterday in the Special Sessions trial of "Dr." Anna Swift on a charge she maintained a house of prostitution in her Danish Institute at 8 West Seventieth Street last June, Justices Bayes, Hackenburg and Salomon denied the motion of James D.C. Murray, the defense lawyer, for dismissal of the charge.

A new legend is in the making about President ROOSEVELT and the newspapers. Before the election he was supposed to have 20 per cent of the press. Now in The Nation one of Mr. VILLARD'S readers tells him Mr. ROOSEVELT had only 15 per cent of the press.

East Side apartment leases reported yesterday included a rental of eleven rooms and four baths in 45 East Sixty-sixth Street to Hugh Knowlton of Kuhn, Loeb Co. by Port Burke, Inc. A twelve-room floor in 956 Fifth Avenue was leased to Israel Fridkin by Douglas L. Elliman Co., who also leased eight rooms and four baths at 940 Park Avenue to Walter O. Dunnock.

Notices for about 22,000 bales were issued on the New York and New Orleans Cotton Exchanges yesterday, but they had little effect on the course of prices, which ended unchanged to 3 points higher than on Monday. Instead of being stopped, houses in receipt of notices kept them in circulation, and it was estimated that hedges representing between 50,000 and 100,000 bales in the spot month were covered during the day.

Licensed officers joined striking seamen on picket lines in port cities along the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts yesterday as the strike of their national unions for higher wages and improved working conditions became effective. They carried placards urging fellow-officers to quit their ships and registered at strike offices for other duties.

PARIS, Nov. 24. -- The Bourse rallied today after yesterday's slump. The foreign exchange market was improved by the adherence of Switzerland, the Netherlands and Belgium to the international monetary accord and the political outlook was made brighter by the strong Franco-British stand on the Spanish situation.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 24 (AP). -- In a surprise autopsy, seven physicians attempted to learn whether Oris P. Van Sweringen's death was super-induced by a minor accident to the railroad car in which he was traveling to New York Monday.

ALBANY, Nov. 24. -- The Court of Appeals affirmed an order today granting a new trial in the action of Warren Leslie and others against the City of New York in which the city is contesting an award for Bergen Beach property on Jamaica Bay, desired for wharf purposes.

The markets generally recovered yesterday from their state of nervousness of the day before, in that selling pressure was relaxed and the fair-to-moderate demand was sufficient to bring about a substantial improvement in prices. The stock market, in terms of the stock averages, regained about half of the ground lost on Monday.
The acts of a delinquent employe do not absolve a railroad of responsibility for the misuse of its property resulting in the injury of another, the Appellate Division in Brooklyn ruled yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP). -- The appointment of M.L. Wilson, Montana farm planner, as the successor to Rexford G. Tugwell in the post of Under-Secretary of Agriculture was forecast today in some quarters.

A great horse brought a fine price as Mr. McElwyn, one of the most famous sires of the light harness turf, was sold for $15,500 yesterday in the opening session of what promises to be the most successful Old Glory auction of trotters and pacers in ten years, at the Squadron A Armory.

TAMPA, Nov. 24. -- Charles P. Howard, president of the International Typographical Union and secretary of the rebellious Committee for Industrial Organization, declared today that "those who control the American Federation of Labor, by the action of the convention last night, started the federation on the road to destruction."

An international tangle over the custody of the five-year-old daughter of an Italian banker was put into the hands of Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Callahan here yesterday, after it had wound its way around the world from Italy and France through Russia and China to New York.

The American people faces the threat of a revolution affecting its greatest private enterprise, B.L. Winchell, chairman of the executive committee of Remington-Rand, Inc., said in a statement, issued yesterday, titled "The Imminence of Government Ownership of Railroads."

A warning that WPA workers who refused to admit Federal relief investigators to their homes would automatically lose their relief status and be regarded as non-relief employes, subject to instant dismissal if their services were deemed "non-essential," was the official answer yesterday to a threatened boycott of the home investigations by 16,000 organized relief workers.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 24. -- From the good ship "Cardinal" comes word of penetrating cold, furious gales, mountainous waves and disaster at sea.

Realty owners of the city were warned yesterday by Harold Riegelman, counsel to the Citizens Budget Commission, that in 1938 their taxes "are going to be $24,400,000 greater than in 1937." This increase, he said, would be due to the end of the bankers' agreement on Jan. 1, 1938, and the demands for added budgetary appropriations that are becoming more frequent with the return of prosperity.
Numerous sales of housing and business parcels in Brooklyn were reported yesterday by the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn.

May I draw attention to the recent decision of the Court of Appeals at Albany confirming the conviction of Mrs. Diana Ward and Mrs. Evelyn Preston on a charge of disorderly conduct for picketing the May Department Store in Brooklyn?

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24. -- Officers and directors of N.W. Ayer Son, Inc., with executors of the estate of Wilfred W. Fry, who was president of the advertising agency, sought dismissal in court today of a suit brought by George H. Thornley, former vice president, to obtain control of the company.

The 201 W. 75th St. Corp., Charles 1Vfoore, president, leased to i'r. Moore, individually, the premises at the northwest corner of Amsterdam Av. and 75th St., 102.2x100, from last Jan. 1 to Sept. 13, 1945, for occupation as a garage and stores, at annual rents of $13,500 for the first year, $15,500 for the following two years and $17,500 for the remainder of the term.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- Five of the largest distillery concerns in the country, together with seven liquor trade associations, were cited by the Federal Trade Commission today on charges of unfair trade practices. Twenty days were allowed in each case for the accused to file answers.
Minnesota's Gophers are right back where they started -- at the top of America's collegiate football heap.

As a result of the recent 10 per cent average increase in wages, the current basic wage rate is the highest in the peace-time history of the steel industry and is 19 per cent above the 1929 level, it was announced yesterday by the American Iron Steel Institute.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., Nov. 24. -- Dr. I. David Cohen, principal of the Brooklyn Boys' Vocational School, in an address here today urged that the entire elementary curriculum of public schools be recognized in an effort to give children the type of education they can use in later life.

Joseph Mercadante, in the shipping business at 120 Broadway, testified in the Supreme Court yesterday that in September, 1925, he was asked by Myron J. Brown, vice president of the Empire Trust Company, for a $20,000 fee for obtaining for him a loan of $85,000 from the bank. He said he made the payment.

Grover A. Whalen, president of the New York World's Fair of 1939, signed a contract yesterday with Wallace K. Harrison and J. Andre Fouilhoux, architects, for the design of the Theme Building of the fair, which is intended to be "the most splendid and significant edifice" in the project.

OSLO, Norway, Nov. 24. -- Breaking the tradition of awarding the Nobel Peace Prize on Alfred Nobel's birthday, Dec. 10, the Nobel committee issued today an announcement that the peace prize for 1935 had been awarded to Carl von Ossietzky of Germany and that the prize for 1936 had been given to Dr. Carlos Saavedra Lamas, Argentine Foreign Minister.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 24. -- Army removed two inches of snow from the practice field today in order that the scheduled scrimmage would not be missed.

LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 25. -- The Daily Telegraph's diplomatic correspondent makes the startling assertion today that Ambassador Joachim yon Ribbentrop, before leaving London yesterday for Berlin, informed Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin that Germany would break off diplomatic relations with Russia if the Soviet executed Emil I. Stickling, the German engineer who was sentenced after his recent trial by the Soviet Supreme Court.

The rapid spread among independent drug stores throughout the country of the plan of selling window space to display organizations has begun to worry national advertisers catering to the retail drug field, reports here yesterday indicated.

The French liner Normandie will sail today for Europe with Andre Maurois, French novelist, and Mme. Maurois; Countess Marthe de Fels, French writer; Kenneth McKenzie Clark, director of the National Gallery of London, and Mrs. Clark; Prince and Princess Guy de Polignac, Baroness Raymond de Luze, Major Gen. and Mrs. Ivor Thord-Gray, Ray Atherton, Counselor of the United States Embassy in London, and Mr. and Mrs. Marshall H. Clyde Jr.

The customary schedule of forty-two championship games was announced for the 1936-27 season yesterday by officers of the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League, according to The Associated Press. The chart calls for a round-robin of home-and-home engagements among Yale, Harvard, Princeton, Pennsylvania, Columbia, Cornell and Dartmouth.

They met thirty years ago. He had a job as a train dispatcher and at 47 had a wife, a home on Shelton Avenue, Jamaica, and two fine children. She was an unmarried school teacher of 40. Yesterday they were married and together they started for Florida on their wedding trip.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP). -- Planning the most generous seating accommodations ever provided for such a ceremony, the Capitol architect's office contracted today for 14,000 seats for President Roosevelt's midwinter inauguration.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 24. -- The funeral of O.P. Van Sweringen is scheduled to take place at 2:30 P.M. tomorrow at Daisy Hill Farm in Hunting Valley.

At least 3 per cent of the individuals in any large population are unable through their own efforts to provide for themselves and their offspring because of hereditary conditions, Dr. Marie E. Kopp, recently returned from Europe where she made a study of hereditary diseases, declared in a paper presented last night at the Academy of Medicine.

The first eleven railroads to report earnings for October showed gains of 15.6 per cent in gross revenues and of 16.9 per cent in net operating income. They increased their gross by 18.9 per cent and their net operating income by 27.4 per cent in September.

The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on Oct. 31 a consolidated net income of $12,204,141 after all deductions. This was equivalent, after full preferred dividend requirements, to 9 cents each on the 33,673,328 no-par common shares. In the preceding year the net income was $8,754,885, or $5.84 each, on 1,499,478 preferred shares.

Four former drivers of the New York City Omnibus Corporation and the man accused of selling them "cheap quarters" to pass on to passengers were sent to jail yesterday by Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey. The chauffeurs had pleaded guilty to possession and passing and the coin distributor to aiding and abetting them.

Ernest BeHagen, 47 years old, a native of the Virgin Islands who posed in hotel bars in the Park Avenue district as "Lord Desmond" of England, was sentenced to Sing Sing for two and a half to five years yesterday by Judge Koenig in General Sessions.

ROME, Nov. 24. -- Admiral Nicholas Horthy, the Regent of Hungary, and Mrs. Horthy, accompanied by Premier Koloman Daranyi, Foreign Minister Koloman de Kenya and a considerable retinue, arrived in Rome this afternoon, and a brilliant official reception and an enthusiastic popular one were given to them.

PARIS, Nov. 24. -- Max Dormoy, who has been acting as Under-Secretary of State in Premier Blum's Cabinet, was officially nominated to be Minister of the Interior today, succeeding Roger Salengro, who committed suicide.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- Holding that unified administration of the New York, New Haven Hartford and the Old Colony Railroad Companies should reduce expenses and promote efficient operation, the Interstate Commerce Commission today ordered that Howard S. Palmer, W.M. Daniels and James Lee Loomis continue as trustees for both companies, separately now in process of reorganization under Section 77 of the Bankruptcy Act.

ROME, Nov. 24. -- Admiral Nicholas Horthy, the Regent of Hungary, and Mrs. Horthy, accompanied by Premier Koloman Daranyi, Foreign Minister Koloman de Kenya and a considerable retinue, arrived in Rome this afternoon, and a brilliant official reception and an enthusiastic popular one were given to them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- Holding that unified administration of the New York, New Haven Hartford and the Old Colony Railroad Companies should reduce expenses and promote efficient operation, the Interstate Commerce Commission today ordered that Howard S. Palmer, W.M. Daniels and James Lee Loomis continue as trustees for both companies, separately now in process of reorganization under Section 77 of the Bankruptcy Act.

A friend of the C.O.S. is one who helps to make it possible for this society to be a friend to families that need a friend in this great city where most people do not know their nearest neighbors. For more than a half century this society has been performing this intermediary service.

WITH his overcoat collar turned up and his hat brim turned down, Coach Harry Mehre of the Georgia team was encountered some hours after his team had tied Fordham. The cracker-barrel philosopher from Athens broke out a wide grin and said:

ALBANY, Nov. 24. -- The 1933 Stock Transfer Tax Law, under which all transfers of shares of stock or other corporate certificates are taxed on the actual sale value of the shares, regardless of whether they have par or face value, was held constitutional by the Court of Appeals in a unanimous decision today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 (AP). -- Amelita Galli-Curci returned to grand opera tonight as Mimi in "La Boheme," but not with the impeccable and bewitching voice, critics said, which began her fame on a Saturday afternoon in Autumn twenty years ago.

MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 24. -- Mexico's leading oil companies today informed Genaro Vasquez, Secretary of Labor, that they were compelled to refuse the demand of the oil workers' syndicate for discussion and approval within ten days of a new collective labor contract governing the industry, on pain of a strike in all its branches beginning Sunday.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 24 (AP). -- Nine men were believed entombed in the hatch of the steamship Scantic of the Mooremack Line by a fire which started late today. At least four others were injured.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today made public a list of additional applications for registration as brokers and dealers in the over-the-counter market which contained the following from New York City and vicinity:

Shepard Stone and Hanson W. Baldwin of THE NEW YORK TIMES have signed a contract with Simon Schuster to edit a book of newspaper chronicles written by TIMES correspondents and reporters in all parts of the world. Many of the contributors will tell "the story behind the story" of outstanding news events, and will interpret the background of recent history.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 24. -- Hun School defeated Raymond Riordon of Highland, N.Y., today, 12 -- 6, thereby ending the football season undefeated and untied. It was the seventh straight victory for Coach Bob Lechner's team and also completed the second consecutive season through which Hun has gone unbeaten.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 24. -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull received a warm welcome here today. He revisited the scenes of the Pan-American Conference of three years ago, although he stayed ashore only a few hours.

PORT MORESBY, British New Guinea, Nov. 24. -- So many deaths have been caused by native football in New Guinea that the leading chief has asked the authorities to discuss the situation with the native council.

MADRID, Nov. 24. -- Preparations to evacuate the United States Embassy staff and all United States citizens living in the Embassy who wish to leave Madrid were being advanced today. Eric C. Wendelin. the Charge d'Affaires, plans to move his staff and the other Americans to Valencia on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- Katharine Cornell launched Maxwell Anderson's new play, "The Wingless Victory," before a thunderously enthusiastic audience tonight at the National Theatre. The house was sold out even to standing room, with a gala appearance which little else than Cornell in an Anderson play could produce, and the customers applauded and cheered at the end until the house lights went on and the steel curtain rolled down.

The Court of Appeals in Albany in a decision yesterday, laid down the rules under which deficiency judgments may be obtained in mortgage foreclosure cases. The decision was regarded as of great importance, because the lower courts had construed an earlier decision of the Court of Appeals, upholding the constitutionality of the Mortgage Moratorium Act, as barring deficiency judgments during the depression.

A trend toward better manners among spectators at college football games, less drinking and rowdiness was noted yesterday at a meeting of the board of directors of the Sportsmanship Brotherhood at the Hotel McAlpin.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 24 (Canadian Press). -- Defending stubbornly, the touring Marylebone Cricket Club team today forced a draw in its match with an Australian eleven. The Aussies declared at their overnight total of 544 for eight wickets.

BALBOA, Canal Zone, Nov. 24. -- The inadequacy of the housing for naval personnel here has been brought out in a hearing before the Senate subcommittee on military affairs by Captain Guy Davis, commanding the Third Submarine Squadron and submarine base at Coco Solo.

BERLIN, Nov. 24. -- The award of the Nobel Peace Prize to Carl von Ossietzky, German pacifist, who was sentenced to eighteen months' imprisonment for treason against the State under the republican regime and has been in "protective custody" since Chancellor Adolf Hitler came to power, was first received in German official quarters today with incredulous astonishment and then with boiling rage that percolated from Hitler down.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 24. -- Discovery of matter in interstellar space which is probably ionized gas of the element titanium is reported from the Mount Wilson Observatory to the Harvard Observatory.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- A confident assertion that Representative O'Connor of New York would be elected majority leader of the House in the next Congress came from his supporters today.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 25. -- With Navy engaging in next to the last practice on the home field, the midshipmen practicing stunts they will perform in Philadelphia's Municipal Stadium, and Tecumseh in his full warpaint, signs of the approach of another service school football game are not wanting.

ALBRIGHT VS. MUHLENBERG -- The final march to the polls of a stirring season. Or in other words, the last chance to make a lot of well-meant mistakes. Fumbling on first down, one light vote for Albright.

Two very blond, very startled, but very delighted little boys had their first birthday party yesterday. They were Danny and Davy, 2-year-old twins, for whom the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association is hopeful of finding a permanent home soon.

LONDON, Nov. 25. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin, accompanied by Sir John Davidson, Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, called at Buckingham Palace after today's Cabinet meeting for an audience with King Edward. Sir John is a member of His Majesty's Government, but not of the Cabinet.

MONTREAL, Nov. 25. -- Opposition to the proposed deep-water route from Montreal to New York by way of the Richelieu River and Lake Champlain is contained in a report submitted to the French Canadian Chamber of Commerce in Montreal by its Montreal harbor and transportation committees today.

Covici, Friede report that the book in their display at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair that was most often picked up by visitors was "Technique of Advertising Layout," by Frank Young. The book has had no advertising nor reviews recently, but since the book fair its steady day-by-day sale has almost doubled.

Here and there in the outdoor world: It will be "duck day" instead of "turkey day" for an army of wildfowlers along the coastal bays, rivers and lakes of New Jersey, as the waterfowl hunting season opens this morning in the southern zone. . . .

Year-end cash dividends declared yesterday by corporations amounted to $55,000,000, bringing the total amount of distributions ordered thus far this month to approximately $767,500,000. This exceeds the high record for a full month, established in December, 1930, when dividends of $567,000.000 were voted.

The high-flying Americans and the New York Rangers will meet in their scheduled league hockey game in Madison Square Garden tonight and the holiday provides the opportunity for an afternoon amateur double-header in which the New York Rovers will face the Pittsburgh Yellow Jackets in the feature.

PARIS, Nov. 25. -- News of the announcement by Germany and Japan of their agreement to combat Communist activity, followed by rumors which necessitated the posting of official denials here on the floor of the Bourse today, caused a sharp decline in prices on the Paris stock market.

Lieutenant Cameron McRae Winslow Jr., U.S.N., son of the late Rear Admiral Winslow, issued a statement yesterday concerning the row at the Stork Club on Tuesday morning in which he was punched in the left eye, the fracas involving Johnny Weissmuller, the screen Tarzan.
PARIS, Nov. 25. -- This time Chancelor Adolf Hitler did not wait for the week-end. The middle of the week seemed as good as Saturday for him to shake the world with a new coup.

MADRID, Nov. 25 (AP). -- Four Insurgent bombing planes darted over Madrid today, spat machine-gun bullets on government lines, bombed the model prison and soared away before defending planes had time to give combat.

Frank X. Donnelly, former police sergeant, convicted of first-degree manslaughter for killing his estranged wife, Marion, was sentenced yesterday to serve from five to ten years in Sing Sing prison by County Judge Thomas Downs in Queens County Court, Long Island City.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- The Standard Cap and Seal Corporation, Chicago, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933, covering 108,003 shares of convertible preference stock, par value $10, cumulative dividends $1.60 per annum, and 327,858 shares of $1 par common stock to be offered in connection with a proposed plan of recapitalization.
BERLIN, Nov. 25. -- The text of the Japanese-German agreement on communism, consisting of a preamble, three articles and a supplementary protocol, follows:

Commodity futures generally were higher yesterday. A further advance of 10 to 14 points in crude rubber futures was the feature. In the cash market, wheat, oats, coffee, lard, tin, cotton, silk and rubber were higher, while corn, rye and wool tops were lower.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- The State Department was informed today by Eric C. Wendelin, in charge of the United States Embassy in Madrid, that he expected to leave tomorrow morning for Valencia, accompanied by members of his staff and approximately fifty American nationals who are in the Spanish capital.

MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 25 (AP). -Maritime workers further tangled Mexico's labor situation today with a threat to strike against "invasion of our activities" by the Oil Workers Syndicate -- which seeks a blanket labor contract for the industry -- and has called a strike for this week-end.

MACON, Ga., Nov. 25. -- At the end of a 2,000-mile tour of the Cotton Belt and a fortnight spent in Governors' Mansions and sharecroppers' hovels and in dusty travel over county roads, Secretary Wallace spoke enthusiastically today of the work done by the Resettlement Administration toward solving "one of the greatest social problems of our time."

Eager to end completely the faint hopes still possessed by the New York Giants for the Eastern division crown in the National Football League, the Brooklyn Dodgers will conclude their home campaign today by tackling their interborough rivals at Ebbets Field.

"Reunion," the second of the Dionne quintuplet pictures with Jean Hersholt, Slim Summerville, Dorothy Peterson, Rochelle Hudson, Robert Kent and Helen Vinson, is the new Twentieth Century-Fox offering at the Roxy today. . . . At the Capitol, Clark Gable, Joan Crawford and Franchot Tone usher in the holiday season with MGM's "Love On the Run." . . .

JERUSALEM, Nov. 25. -- Not even at the first session of the royal commission of inquiry was there such rush for the few dozen seats allotted to journalists and visitors as at the morning session today for Dr. Chaim Weizmann's testimony. The commission listened for almost three hours to the president of the World Zionist Organization.
BERLIN, Nov. 18 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Nov. 23 shows the following changes from the preceding week in thousands of marks:

An American premiere and debut marked last evening's dramatic event of the French Theatre of New York at the Hotel Barbizon-Plaza Theatre -- just as they did at the opening of the second season here a fortnight ago. The "Martine" of Jean Jacques Bernard, from the repertoire of the Comedie Francaise, was seen and, as its protagonist. Mlle Daniele Delbruyre, fresh from the Trianon Lyrique of Paris.
The highest mark of The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices for 1936 was reached on Tuesday, the index rising to 129.7 from 129.5 the Tuesday previous, and 129.4 a year ago.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 24. -- Before Argentine-United States relations can be made really satisfactory to both parties it is essential that Argentina abolish her exchange discrimination against United States exporters and that the United States abolish its sanitary discrimination against Argentine meat, according to former Finance Minister Alberto Hueyo in an address at the American Chamber of Commerce luncheon yesterday.

Twenty-two young women made their debut's last night at the thirteenth annual Debutante Ball, held at the Heights Casino, Brooklyn Heights, under the leadership of Mrs. Ira Bertine Downs and the sponsorship of the board of governors of the club.

Additional evidence of methods used by Remington Rand, Inc., to break the recent strike in five of its plants was heard yesterday by Charles A. Wood, trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board.
MADRID, Nov. 25 (AP). -- A heavily guarded motor caravan was being assembled tonight to take the fifty-five Americans scheduled to leave the American Embassy before daybreak tomorrow for Valencia.

Evidence to support the charge that the old National Surety Company had made an illegal purchase of its own stock through a subsidiary was produced yesterday at the continuation of the examination before trial of William B. Joyce, former chairman of the company.

MOUNT WASHINGTON, N.H., Nov. 25. -- A big turkey will be lugged up the gale-swept shoulders of Mount Washington, highest peak in the White Mountain range tomorrow, for a rendezvous with four men at a holiday dinner table.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 25. -- Rutgers will meet Ohio Wesleyan at Neilson Field tomorrow, completing its most disastrous season since 1926. The Scarlet has won only one game this year, its first against Marietta.

Fourteen men on twelve motor trucks alleged to be hauling 140 tons of coal stolen from mines in the anthracite region in Pennsylvania were gathered in last night in a renewal of the campaign of the police and District Attorney Dodge's office against so-called coal bootlegging.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 25. -Colgate rules a heavy favorite to defeat Brown in the twenty-first game of their series, which dates back to 1908, when they meet here tomorrow morning.

Although the market for unlisted bonds maintained a firm undertone, trading, nevertheless, reflected the usual pre-holiday nervousness yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, which gave the market a somewhat mixed tone at the close.

Lieutenant Tom Hamilton is leading pretty much the same squad into the Philadelphia Municipal Stadium on Saturday that was put to rout for eighteen minutes at Franklin Field last year and suffered the worst defeat from Army since 1903.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Wholesale prices in the week ended on Nov. 21 rose to the highest level in six years, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the average for 1926 as 100, rose to 82.4, compared with 82.0 in the preceding week and 80.6 a year before.

The Duchess, one of the most aristocratically bred fillies in the light harness world, topped the sales on the second day of the forty-second Old Glory auction at Squadron A Armory yesterday. This daughter of the renowned Peter Volo and the star of the consignment of the Walnut Hall Farm went to William H. Strang Jr. of Brooklyn for $7,000, the highest price for a yearling at the sale thus far.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP). -- The Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation, Ltd., of New York City, with six alternate proposals ranging from $16,604,000 to $21,312,000, was the sole bidder today on construction of the navy's new floating dry-dock at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, designed to be the world's largest.

MOSCOW, Nov. 25. -- Joseph Stalin, general secretary of the Communist party, presented the new Constitution for the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics at the Congress of Soviets tonight in a calm and deliberate two-hour speech.

Miss Helen Cronkhite and Miss Joan Douglas Filley were introduced to society last night at a dinner dance given at the Pierre by Mr. and Mrs. Walter Cooley Douglas, stepfather and mother of Miss Cronkhite, and Mr. and Mrs. Frank Herbert Filley, parents of Miss Filley.

TORONTO, Nov. 25 (Canadian Press). -- Canada's army team swept to victory at the Winter Fair Horse Show tonight and captured the International Officers' Team Challenge Trophy, donated by G. Howard Ferguson, former Canadian High Commissioner to Great Britain.
Samuel Rappaport, a teacher in Public School 23, the Bronx, was dismissed from service by the Board of Education yesterday following a committee trial on charges of corporal punishment.

Thefts of bonds worth nearly $250,000 were attributed by the police yesterday to Frederick B. MacLaren, 47 years old, described as "another Jimmy Valentine," and to his brother, William C. MacLaren, 39, both of whom were said to be expert electrical engineers.

A stiff northwest wind set a blue pennant snapping on the main truck of the U.S.S. Cummings, a 1,500-ton destroyer, in the New York Navy Yard, Brooklyn, at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, as the fourth fighting ship of its kind to be commissioned there in 1936 received a commander and crew from Rear Admiral Harris Laning, commandant of the Third Naval District.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- In connection with its study of investment trusts and investment companies the Securities and Exchange Commission today issued the form of a short questionnaire for investment counsel, investment management, investment supervisory and investment advisory services which have investment trusts or companies or commingled funds as clients.
Miss Sophie J. Kilbreth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James T. Kilbreth, was introduced to society last night at a large dinner given by her parents in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis.
Columbia worked long and hard yesterday at Baker Field in an effort to strengthen its defense for the game with Stanford at the Polo Grounds on Saturday.

Department store rug buyers here expresed concern yesterday that the rug style show, scheduled to be held at 295 Fifth Avenue for four weeks beginning Jan. 4, would lead to a revival of the practice of "open showrooms," or wholesalers selling at retail, which has affected retail trade.

The injunction sought by fifteen wholesale milk dealers to restrain the State milk-control authorities from interfering with their prices for milk was denied by Supreme Court Justice Kadien in Brooklyn yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25. -- Mary McCormic made her debut in Chicago in 1921. She and Mr. Johannsen met here two years ago through mutual friends in radio work, according to his brother, Alfred, who, with Mr. Johannsen, resides with their parents at 72 East Elm Street.

The final obstacle in the path of early operation of franchised buses in three of the four official zones in Queens was removed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Leander B. Faber, sitting in Special Term in Jamaica. Justice Faber denied the application of John J. Walsh, Jamaica civic worker, for a temporary injunction to restrain Mayor La Guardia from signing two of the three franchises recently voted by the Board of Estimate.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25. -- Led by Co-captains Franny Murray and Lew Elverson, Pennsylvania will close its most successful football season in almost a decade when it meets Cornell on Franklin Field tomorrow before a crowd expected to pass the 50,000 mark if weather conditions are good.

The New York Central Railroad announced yesterday that it was about to buy 100 steam locomotives for about $8,600,000 -- the largest order of its kind since 1929 -while brisk buying of railway-equipment-company stocks sent some of them to the highest levels of the year.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 25. -- President Agustin P. Justo signed a decree today appointing a delegation of eighteen members to the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace. The delegation comprises eight members with plenipotentiary powers, three of whom are Cabinet Ministers and two Ambassadors.

Lucille Malin, widow of Jean Malin, an impersonator of women, pleaded guilty yesterday to a six-count Mann Act indictment accusing her of having caused the transportation in interstate commerce of six women for immoral purposes.

A jury before Federal Judge Inch returned a verdict of guilty yesterday against David J. Goldsmith, a diamond dealer of 1,414 Shakespeare Avenue, the Bronx, on all nine counts of an indictment charging the smuggling of Swiss watch movements and diamonds.

A boyish determination to burn down a row of seven houses erected on a lot where they used to play was revealed last night with the arrest of three boys who were held responsible for starting at least a dozen fires in their Brooklyn neighborhood in the last few months.

With the steady development of orange juice in containers this year, most of the large food packers now including it in their lines, the possibility of an extension of the rivalry between can and bottle manufacturers, which started in the beer field, into this newer industry was seen yesterday.

MOSCOW, Nov. 25. -- The Soviet Government in a terse announcement disclosed today that Emil I. Stickling's sentence had been commuted to ten years' imprisonment after the German Embassy had made repeated protests against his death sentence.

Manhattan's football team completed its week's work yesterday with a brisk two-hour contact session at Innisfail Park. Coach Chick Meehan excused the Green squad after the drill and plans to resume practice for the Texas A. and M. game at Tyler, Texas, Dec. 5 on Monday.

Vina Youssey, 16 years old, who came here from her home in Oklahoma City, Okla., to become a tap dancer, was discharged yesterday by Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio in Felony Court for possessing a .25-caliber pistol when she arrived. The magistrate directed, however, that the girl be detained at the Florence Crittenton Home until tomorrow, when she will leave for her farm home.

LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 26. -The Daily Express appears to be among those British newspapers that, unfamiliar with Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's habits, spent considerable time and money Tuesday night in investigating the "mystery" of his flight from Ireland to England.

Longshoremen at the port of Havre refused yesterday to unload about 500 tons of freight from the United States liner Washington in response to the plea for "solidarity" by American seamen who are on strike in Atlantic ports. Immediately the longshoremen's union here announced that it would refuse to unload French flag ships arriving in American ports.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the weekend, have been endorsed as specially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents in local, private and public elementary and high schools.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Nov. 26. -- Japan having failed in pressing upon China her demands for a joint anti-Communist front and for establishing a special area in North China, and now having met a serious setback with the Chinese capture of Peilingmiao, Tokyo's next move is awaited here with keen anxiety.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Miss Gloria Grosvenor, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gilbert Grosvenor, was presented to society today at a reception given by her parents at Wild Acres, their home at Bethesda, Md.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 25. -"Sink the Navy," is the watchword at Army, as time gets shorter before the meeting of the service schools. A big Navy game rally was held tonight in Washington Hall, with the team present. Coaches and players spoke and told the corps that Navy would know it was playing a real football game Saturday.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 25 (AP). -- A record Thanksgiving throng of 103,000 football fans is expected to jam Memorial Stadium tomorrow to watch Southern California and the University of California at Los Angeles settle a crosstown grudge.

NANKING, China, Thursday, Nov. 26. -- From many parts of the country congratulatory messages are pouring upon General Fu Tso-yi, the young, able Governor of Suiyuan Province, who became a national hero overnight with the capture of Peilingmiao.

LONDON, Nov. 25. -- The British Cabinet examined today the draft of a bill to prohibit British ships from carrying munitions from any foreign port to Spain. Such trade from British ports is already controlled by export licenses.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Despite the reluctance of some business groups to join with Major George L. Berry, Coordinator for Industrial Cooperation, in his plans for a conference called for Dec. 9 and 10, preparations for the gathering are going forward.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 25. -- The former White Plains Daily Press will be published by the International Typographical Union in the near future, it was learned today as representatives of the union visited the plant on Mamaroneck Avenue to start renovations.

Options given by Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., to four executives on 20,000 shares of its common stock at $22 a share and the offering by Stokely Brothers Co. Inc., of 15,000 shares of its common stock at $15 a share to a group of officers and employes were revealed yesterday in listing applications approved by the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange.

A school building program calling for the inclusion of $30,000,000 in the city's capital outlay budget for 1937 was approved unanimously yesterday by the Board of Education. The projects listed were in addition to those approved in the 1936 capital outlay budget.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25. -- The new Pennsylvania Legislature, both houses of which are controlled by the Democrats, was summoned today by Governor Earle to convene in special session Tuesday to enact legislation bringing this Commonwealth into conformity with the unemployment insurance feature of the Federal social-security program
Two shutouts, scored by the pacesetters, the Columbia University Club and the New York Athletic Club, featured last night's Class A squash tennis competition in the Metropolitan League.

SAN PERLITA, Texas, Nov. 25 (AP). -- The strange circumstances under which two hunters vanished a week ago in the fastnesses of the world's largest cattle ranch baffled Texas Rangers and aroused their neighbors tonight.
LONDON, Nov. 25. -- Great Britain will certainly not be one of the powers to accept the invitation of Germany and Japan to join them in the anti-communism pact they signed this afternoon.

Paramount Pictures, Inc., reported yesterday for the third quarter of 1935 a net operating profit of $1,961,789, and in addition, a profit of $51,975 on the purchase of its debentures. This figure was after crediting to operations a reserve of approximately $200,000, which was provided out of 1935 earnings to cover the excess costs of certain pictures.

The text of the Japanese-German pact, published yesterday after it had been signed at the Foreign Office in Berlin, adds little to our understanding of this new diplomatic alignment. Explicitly it provides only for cooperation against the disruptive activities of the Communist International.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 25. -- Friendly informality marked the reception to Secretary of State Cordell Hull, head of the United States delegation to the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace, here today, in decided contrast to the formal, glittering welcome being planned for President Roosevelt.

Back in May, 1933, the weary presses were grinding out sad notes on the end of a beautiful friendship: Lew Brown and Ray Henderson. This morning they may take satisfaction in the resumption of that friendship, for Broadway battles never last four years, and yesterday saw the former partners become partners again, as well as collaborators.

PARIS, Nov. 25. -- While the German-Japanese treaty is being taken seriously enough in Paris, especially in official circles, there is a tendency also to consider it as having some almost comic features.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 25. -- The police had to be called in last night to keep peace in the People's Conference in Favor of Peace after the delegation of American feminists had split and started a lively battle over the question of whether women want protection or equal rights with men.

T.O.M. Sopwith and Sir Ralph Gore will be the helmsmen of the challenger Endeavour II in the America's Cup match off Newport next Summer. Definite word of that was received here yesterday. Frank Murdock, who designed the steel mast and the rigging for the first Endeavour, as well as for the new one, will be in the afterguard. He is building another steel spar for the challenger.

Owen D. Young, general chairman of the roll-call of New York Chapter, American Red Cross, in a Thanskgiving Day appeal made public yesterday, urged the public to support the roll-call through which the chapter is trying to obtain $325,000 for its relief work and other activities during 1937.

Two brothers, aided by the manager of the Park Row branch of the Manufacturers Trust Company, ran a cheese business on funds of the bank, it was alleged yesterday in an eleven-count indictment obtained by John J. Dowling, Assistant United States Attorney.

BOWIE, M., Nov. 25. -- What may be Maryland's banner race crowd of the Fall season is expected tomorrow for the running of the Thanksgiving Handicap, the Marlboro Stakes and the Howard Jackson Handicap, named for Baltimore's Mayor.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25. -- Because higher Federal estate taxes took effect a few hours before the death of Mrs. Anna Wilmarth Ickes, her husband, Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, will receive $17,000 less from her $500,000 estate than if the old schedule had applied.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- The only tied Congressional election in 110 years was studied with keen interest today by House parliamentarians.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Rear Admiral Joseph M. Reeves, chairman of the General Board, and Major General John H. Russell, Commandant of the Marine Corps, who are to retire for age on Dec. 1, were commended by Secretary Swanson today for their services during their long careers.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 25. -- A verdict of guilty was found in the County Court here today against Peter Hellebrand, 55 years old, cattle dealer of Warrenville, N.J., marking the first cattle-rustling conviction in Nassau County in more than thirty-five years.

A white flag with a red, double-barred cross, the international standard in the battle against tuberculosis, was presented last night to Mrs. Marie Chase Cole, executive director of the International Institute of the Y.W.C.A. at 341 East Seventeenth Street. This symbolized the opening by the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association of the thirtieth Christmas Seal Campaign.
The selection of an All-Pacific Coast eleven is a very difficult assignment this year because of the severe schedules played by all teams.
A demand for housing properties on the upper West Side was indicated by sales and leases of dwellings and flats there yesterday.

TALAVERA DE LA REINA, Spain, Nov. 25. -- This Insurgent supply base seventy miles southwest of Madrid has had a surprise attack from government forces. The inhabitants of the city, who thought they were well behind the Insurgent lines, were astonished early yesterday morning when 75-millimeter shells were rained on the northeastern quarter of the city.

A preliminary investigation by District Attorney Geoghan of Brooklyn into the asphyxiation of five men in the hold of the freighter Empire State yesterday evening has failed so far to disclose evidence of criminal negligence, he said yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25. -- Deere Co., Manufacturers of farm equipment, announced today that 10,000 employes at Moline, Ill.; Ottumwa and Waterloo, Iowa; Haricon, Wis., and Syracuse, N.Y., would receive pay increases of 7 per cent on Nov. 30. Employes of at least a year's service will receive a Christmas bonus of $25.

Simplicio Godina, sometimes referred to in the past as Codino, was reported in "favorable condition" last night at the York Hospital, after an operation which severed him surgically late Tuesday night from the body of his brother Lucio, who had just died of rheumatic fever.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Nov. 25. -- F.W. Nyland, traffic manager of the Delaware Hudson Railroad, told the International Joint Commission today that the proposed Montreal New York waterway would have no effect on the movement of anthracite coal into New England.

A month ago we cited on this page some of the remarkable results achieved by Professor RHINE and his associates in Duke University from more than a hundred thousand tests to determine the existence of "telepathy" and "clairvoyance." These results were summarized in the first of two articles in Harpers Magazine.
ROME, Nov. 25. -- The terms of the anti-Communist agreement between Germany and Japan caused no surprise in Italy.

Buying of steel in anticipation of the rise of $1 to $4 a ton in prices, announced on Monday and Tuesday, has resulted in an increase of a half point in steel operations to 74 1/2 per cent of capacity, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by Iron Age.

One of the largest debutante parties of the early season was a supper dance given by Mrs. Emanuel Gerli last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton to introduce her twin daughters, the Misses Diana M. and Muriel M. Gerli. The debutantes were introduced to relatives and older friends of the family at an afternoon reception given by Mrs. Gerli last Sunday at her home, 907 Fifth Avenue.

Lynn Waldorf, head coach of the Northwestern University football team which captured outright its first Big Ten championship this year, was guest of honor at a victory dinner staged by the Northwestern University Club of New York at the Shelton Hotel last night.

Furs, with a sales increase of 50.4 per cent over 1935, led other divisions in local department stores during October, according to the monthly analysis, issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Fur merchandise also made the premier showing for the period from February to October, the bank survey indicated.

Jack Corrigan, 20 years old, a New York University freshmen, was arrested at 3 A.M. yesterday, after, the police charge, he had admitted that he had raised a white flag with red lettering reading: "Arms and Ammunition for Spanish Democracy," to the top of the forty-foot flag pole in Washington Square Park, opposite the downtown center of New York University.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 25. -The eight-day-old strike at the Bendix Products Corporation plant here was settled today when union employes voted unanimously to return to work Friday morning in return for recognition of the union as the bargaining agent of its members.
PARIS, Nov. 25. -- French naval strength will be reinforced by the launching at Brest tomorrow of the destroyer Volta and on Dec. 12 at St. Nazaire of the 26,500-ton battle cruiser Strasbourg.

LISBON, Portugal, Nov. 25. - According to information here, 1,500 Spanish Loyalist troops joined in the surprise attack on Talavera de la Reina yesterday. One shell exploded near the headquarters of the Rebel Military Governor and thirty fell at the airfield.

The Federal Reserve System has begun a survey of the distribution of excess reserves among its member banks with a view to determining the probable effect of a further increase in reserve requirements.

WARSAW, Poland, Nov. 25. -- Police tonight stormed Warsaw University in order to clear the buildings occupied for two days by several hundred Fascist students. Tear gas was used against the students, who threw iron and stone missiles from behind barricades.
Meat trade condttfons and wholesale prices in New YetiS' Clty
ALBANY, Nov. 25 (AP). -- New York State lawyers awaited tonight a ruling by the State's highest tribunal on the constitutionality of the new law banning "heart balm" suits.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Preliminary figures from the Census of Manufacturers, complied by the Bureau of the Census, continued today to show improvement in industry.

The retirement of John. D.M. Hamilton as chairman of the Republican National Committee, and the remolding of the party in State and nation into a "humanized and liberalized" political agency, was demanded by Representative Hamilton Fish of Putnam County in a radio address last night over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Mayor La Guardia's plan to place the Commissioner of the Department of Water Supply and other high officials of that department under civil service met with a distinct set-back yesterday when the Municipal Civil Service Commission was informed that such action would he contrary to the law of the State.

Besides the great majority of New Yorkers who will enjoy their turkey dinners at home or in restaurants, thousands of men, women and children in hospitals, prisons and other institutions will receive free Thanksgiving dinners today. Thousands of others, more fortunate, kept the city's transportation facilities busy yesterday and last night, going to and from New York in record traffic over air, rail, ship and bus lines, as well as by private automobiles.

The high spot of local warfare on the gridiron comes at 1:30 this afternoon, when the teams of Fordham and New York University trot out on the field at the Yankee Stadium for the renewal of their feud.

LONDON, Nov. 25. -- Despite the continuance of favorable earnings statements by corporations, the stock market here reflected renewed uncertainty today over the international political situation. The day's trading was marked by heavy selling and sharp declines in most shares.

ROME, Nov. 25. -- William Phillips, United States Ambassador to Italy, said today that negotiations he had been carrying on with the Italian Government about the distribution of American motion pictures in Italy had been concluded. He said that the agreement reached had been found acceptable by Will H. Hays, American movie czar, who left Rome for Paris this morning.

TAMPA, Nov. 25. -- Conferences designed to prepare the way for renewal of peace proposals by the executive council of the American Federation of Labor to the Committee for Industrial Organization were held here today.
Building plans filed by architects yesterday included projects for erecting a variety of new structures and the making of alterations in existing ones.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25. -- Hogs weighing 200 pounds or more generally sold at steady prices today, but underweights were weak to 10 cents a hundred weight lower than yesterday and some pigs were reported down 25 to 50 cents. Sows sold steady to 10 cents lower.

In your news column today an article captioned "Fingerprinting Held Unlikely in Public Schools" attracted my attention. You state that Superintendent Harold Campbell, for whom I have great respect, vetoes the plan as "impracticable" because of parental objection.

With the two newly elected Republican members of the next Assembly from Suffolk County out in opposition, Speaker Irving M. Ives will lack the necessary votes to win re-election to the Speakership, it became known yesterday.

MADRID, Nov. 25. -- Members of the British Parliamentary commission who left London last Thursday arrived here at 4 o'clock this morning and after a few hours' rest were in the streets acquainting themselves with conditions.

In view of the impending Thanksgiving Day, and its traditional glorification of roast turkey, I would like to warn a great many well-intentioned Americans against what amounts to a gastronomical crime -- namely, serving both wine and cranberry sauce at a turkey dinner.

LONDON, Nov. 25. -- Internal evidence has been accumulating in London for several weeks now to prove that the German-Japanese agreement to create an anti-Communist front is only a cover for more serious contractual obligations.
PEIPING, China, Thursday, Nov. 26. -- China forcefully repelled yesterday the tide of Mongol and Manchukuoan invasion.

Mr. and Mrs. Leon Rhodes Thurlow and Mrs. John Leonard Moon gave a dinner dance last night in the roof garden of the Pierre to introduce their respective daughters, Miss Constance Rhodes Thurlow and Miss Mary Charlotte Moon. Mrs. Thurlow and Mrs. Loon assisted their daughters in receiving.

BERLIN, Nov. 25. -- The ]3oerse failed to establish any definite trend today, opening slightly stronger but later losing the early gains. The market's typical stagnation now has spread to all sections of securities on the list. any business groups that have been represented in trading in the last few weeks now are quiet again and the usual routine has taken hold once more.

With 1,500 persons an hour telephoning the offices of the Federal Social Security Board for information about the Security Act, Mrs. Anna Rosenberg, regional director, paused yesterday afternoon to make public answers to a dozen of the most frequent inquiries.
RYE, N.Y., Nov. 25. -- Stanford's football players proved to be an adaptable squad on the first day of their visit here.

The stock market was characterized yesterday by narrow and irregular movements of prices and by slightly diminished trading. Perhaps this was to be expected on the eve of the holiday, considering the contradictory market trends of the last few days.

MADRID, Nov. 25 (Censored). -- Further details regarding the raid yesterday on the German Embassy by police and militiamen were disclosed today by newspapers following the issuance of an official statement.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 25. -- John J. Gallagher Jr., 18-year-old son of an oil and insurance company executive in Philadelphia, was killed today as his father's automobile skidded into a telephone pole and overturned on the Marlton Pike near here.

Although further deliveries were made on the December position yesterday, notices circulated less freely, and after midday, when selling pressure lifted prices on the Cotton Exchange, rallied to end with gains of 6 to 12 points. Fewer hedges came on the market, which reduced the quantity of contracts available for trade price-fixing requirements.
BOSTON, Nov. 25 (AP). -- A brief defending unemployment insurance provisions of the Social Security Act as proper taxation was filed today in the Federal District Court by government attorneys.
E.E. Loomis denied yesterday published reports that he would resign the presidency and assume the chairmanship of the Lehigh Valley Railroad on Jan. 1.

In the current number of The New Republic Secretary WALLACE attempts to forecast what lies ahead for American agriculture during the second Roosevelt Administration. He notes the great gains made since 1933, particularly in the recovery of prices and the reduction of surplus stocks.

The Vanderbilt Cup, emblematic of the nee plus ultra in contract bridge, was won early this morning by a team composed of Phil Abramsohn, Fred Kaplan, Harry Fishbein and Irving Epstein. Playing the seventy-two hands of the finals at the Crockford Club, 14 East Sixty-second Street, they defeated the team composed of Walter Beinecke, Charles H. Goren, John P. Mattheys and Lee Langdon by 2,030 points.

Miss Yvonne Johnstone gave a luncheon yesterday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for Miss M. Thayer Gibbons. Other guests were Mrs. Ludlow Elliman, the Misses Le Brun Rhinelander, Elizabeth Russell, Barbara West, Mary Schley, Lucy Hutchinson, Anne Halle, Harriet Arthur, Kay Will and Margaret Kelsey.

The habits of Manhattan residents are indicated in the things they send to the dry cleaners, Miss Miriam Cooper, who is conducting a survey for the dry cleaning industry, declared yesterday. Miss Cooper's findings, she said, upset several popular beliefs regarding people who live in various sections of the city.
GARY, Ind., Nov. 25 (AP). -- Three bandits were killed and a fourth was captured tonight as police thwarted a hold-up of sixty patrons in a downtown gambling place.

The Hercules Motor Corporation reported yesterday a net profit for the third quarter of this year amounting to $170,687, after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges, but before provision for surtax on undistributed earnings.
