TAMPA, Nov. 25. -- Charles P. Howard, president of the International Typographical Union, said tonight his organization has purchased the White Plains (N.Y.) Daily Press and would be ready to begin operating it in about three weeks.

SEATTLE, Nov. 25 (AP). -- The biggest football prize on the Pacific Coast -- the Conference championship and the Rose Bowl nomination -- will be at stake tomorrow when the Washington Huskies and the Washington State Cougars clash in their thirty-first annual battle before a sellout crowd of 40,000 fans.

ATLANTA, Nov. 25 (AP). -- Amendments providing for an increase in membership of the Southeastern Conference and new proposals regarding entrance requirements for athletes are scheduled for discussion at the annual meeting in December.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. CHESTER, at Sea, Nov. 25 (AP). -- President Roosevelt, now a "shellback" by virtue of his initiation into King Neptune's court, got his first view of land today since leaving Trinidad last Sunday.

Caput Mundi received today a visiting potentate from beyond the Alps who came, as THE TIMES correspondent in Rome rightfully states, "to impress upon the world the closeness of the ties uniting Italy and Hungary, and emphasize Italy's complete espousal of the cause of treaty revision."

BERLIN, Nov. 25. -- Foreign Minister Constantin von Neurath today instructed the German Minister at Oslo, Dr. Heinrich Sahm, to express to the Norwegian Government the Reich's astonishment and displeasure over award of the Nobel Peace Prize to Carl von Ossietzky, German pacifist.

TRENTON, Nov. 25. -- Governor Hoffman was advised today by Controller Frank J. Murray that the State was in "a very fine fiscal position" and that a surplus of about $1,571,536 at the close of the current fiscal year, June 30, was in prospect.

A newsreel theatre and cocktail lounge to be constructed in Grand Central Terminal has been leased by Grand Central Newsreel Theatre, Inc., from Eastern Offices, Inc., owners of the Graybar Building. The twenty-year lease calls for an aggregate rental of about $586,500.

BERLIN, Nov. 25. -- A German-Japanese entente technically directed against the international activities of the Moscow Comintern, or Communist International, but containing implications, the full scope of which cannot be gaged at this moment, was signed in Berlin today.
A record for speed in the pressing of condemnation cases has been set in the action to acquire land required for the site of the World's Fair, Corporation Counsel Paul Windels announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- The case of Davis v. the Boston Maine Railroad, which is expected to provide the first court test of the Social Security Act, is limited by stipulation to unemployment insurance taxes.

A FIVE hundred word autobiography must be revealing or nothing. There is little room for modesty. The writer must say what he means about himself or pass the pen. Realizing this, Georges Schreiber, portrait maker, persuaded forty authors not only to pose for his pencil, but to talk about themselves in capsule, concentrated form. Many of the writers he so captured are eminent.

Gratitude has been defined as a negative virtue. If we have it, no special merit is implied. But if we have it not, we are disgraced. Certainly it would be a reproach to the American people if they were not, at this time of national thanksgiving, grateful to the Giver of All Good Gifts for having cast the lines of this nation in such pleasant places.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- An additional regulation designed to prevent evasion of the Walsh-Healey act, which sets up wage and working hour standards for firms holding government contracts amounting to more than $10,000, was issued today by Secretary Perkins.

VIENNA, Nov. 25. -- The Austrian press, which is entirely government controlled, fell in line with the German press today in condemning the Nobel peace award. The Weltblatt calls Carl von Ossietzky a "traitor to the German Fatherland condemned for high treason" and emphasizes that it is by such actions that the Nobel prize loses its value.
TOKYO, Nov. 25. -- The Japanese public's opinion of the new pact can scarcely be estimated, as it will not be published here textually until tomorrow.

Traditional Thanksgiving Day contests head today's scholastic football program in the metropolitan district as the current campaign officially comes to a close. Approximately fifty games are booked for fields in this vicinity, with eight of them listed for New York City gridirons.

LONDON, Nov. 25. -- Only a few weeks after his scathing attack on General John J. Pershing, David Lloyd George praises the United States Army in glowing terms in the sixth and final volume of his war memoirs, to be published here tomorrow.
CHICAGO, Nov. 25. -- The death toll in Chicago's elevated railway wreck rose tonight to ten, including seven men and three women, two of whom were sales representatives of New York textile companies.
LONDON, Nov. 25. -- There is a new "Ballad of Maidstone Gaol," according to a prisoner who has just been discharged from this modernized prison for long-termers.

While a movement is under way to rid the great intercollegiate athletic contests of certain objectionable features, it is of special interest to note that steps are being taken by one institution, the University of Pennsylvania, to reintroduce contests such as were held in connection with the ancient Greek games (notably at Olympia) in arts and letters, in music and the crafts, in the drama and other forms of skillful expression.

One of the great hopes lodged in the forthcoming conference of the American republics at Buenos Aires is that a common mood will be formed to discourage war, not only in this hemisphere, but in the other. Peace is the dominant impulse of the conferees, and to fix and dramatize that impulse the greatest peace salesman in the world, the President of the United States, is on his way to Buenos Aires.

JONESBORO, Ark., Nov. 25. -- -- A Federal court jury convicted Paul D. Peacher, planter-peace officer, today on charges of violating an ancient anti-slavery statute. He was sentenced to two years in prison and fined $3,500.

The directors of the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company authorized yesterday the payment to all employes and officers, except officers who are also directors, of a bonus equal to one-half of one month's salary. The bonus, which was designated as extra compensation for 1936, will be paid on Dec. 15.

Although fifteen members of the cast of "This Pretty World" will call at Equity tomorrow and receive checks for two weeks' salary and rehearsal expense money, Johnnie Walker, producer of the show, said last night that rehearsals would continue.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 25. -- The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company today declared a Christmas bonus for its workers. All will receive $5 plus an additional dollar for every year of service.

Five men were killed by carbon dioxide fumes in the hold of a freighter in Brooklyn and three others were overcome but revived. Only two of the men were properly the victims of accident. They were the first two who went down into the hold to be immediately struck down.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 25. -- Business in the Pittsburgh district recorded substantial gains last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The bureau's general index of business activity rose to 103.6 per cent of normal last week from 99.0 in the preceding week.
The strike of 400 employes in about 100 stores of the Schulte Cigar Company in this city was ended yesterday. The men returned to work and the stores were reopened.

St. Francis College opened its basketball season by routing an alumni five, 33 -- 17, last night in the Butler Street gymnasium. Coach Rody Cooney started his second team, but withdrew it in favor of his varsity midway in the first half.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Nov. 25. -- Mrs. Agnes Murphy Mulligan, 71-year-old grandmother, who was the first woman graduate of New York Law School and now is an operator of large real estate holdings, applied here today for a permit to carry a pistol and demonstrated her marksmanship to convince the court she ought to have it.

AS attorney who defended Carl von Ossietzky in the Supreme Court (Reichsgericht) at Leipzig, against the accusation of treason, and as one of the friends and collaborators of Ossietzky speaking with him about his trial, we should like to make the following statement:
Miss Gertrude Levis made her debut last night at a dinner dance given by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Chester C. Levis, in the Neptune Room of the Pierre.

SEATTLE, Nov. 25 (AP). -- Charles B. Lindeman, associate publisher of The Seattle Post-Intelligencer, and Richard Seller, president of the Seattle Chapter of the American Newspaper Guild, announced at 10:22 o'clock tonight that the Guild strike against the newspaper "has been settled."

Connie Smythe, manager of the Toronto Maple Leafs of the National Hockey League, announced yesterday the outright release of the Leafs' veteran goalie, George Hainsworth, The Associated Press reports.

Two paintings from the current exhibition of works by Czanne at the Bignou Gallery have been acquired by American museums. "Les Sables Rouges" goes to the Barnes Foundation of Merion, Pa., to join ninety-eight other paintings by the French master which form part of the collection.

Eva Lynne Booth, pianist, a granddaughter of the late General William Booth, founder of the Salvation Army, gave her first New York recital last night at the Town Hall. The tall, slender pianist studied extensively abroad, first at the Metropolitan Academy of Music, England.

Eleanor Holm Jarrett, swimming star, appeared in Supreme Court yesterday to fight an injunction suit brought against her by Samuel Snyder and Fred Waible, sponsors of the National Professional Swimming Tours. They seek to restrain her from making any professional public appearance after Dec. 1 on the ground that she refused to carry out an oral contract to appear in a series of swimming meets under their direction.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25. -- The wheat market on the Board of Trade here showed a distinctly firm undertone today with strength in Liverpool and the uncertain political outlook in Europe the main influence. While prices held within narrow limits, the old crop months closed 1/4 to 3/8 cent a bushel higher and July 1/4 cent lower.

The allegation of Joseph Mercadante, shipper, that in February 1928, he signed an agreement of indebtedness to the Empire Trust Company as a result of misrepresentation was challenged yesterday in Supreme Court by Max D. Steuer, attorney for the bank.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 25. -- The creation of a State agency to supervise the finances of local governments in New Jersey is recommended by the Princeton local government survey in a report made public here today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 25. -So acute is the shortage of story material here that the studios are negotiating for many ideas. Right now Booth Tarkingson is under option to Universal for an untitled and unwritten story. The terms call for payment of $5,000 for first call on the book, with an additional $45,000 when the sale is completed.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Nov. 25. -- The cruiser Indianapolis, carrying President Roosevelt to Rio de Janeiro and Buenos Aires, and her escort, the cruiser Chester, passed sufficiently close to Pernambuco this morning for the city's inhabitants to see those on board through binoculars.

Retail deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas increased 16 per cent for the week ended Nov. 21, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The rise compares with a gain of 21 per cent for the preceding week, which represented one of the Fall delivery peaks.

All the principal security and commodity markets in the United States will be closed today in observance of Thanksgiving Day. All foreign markets, including Canadian, will be open for business as usual.

CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 25. -- Alphonse Roy, Democrat, and Arthur B. Jenks, Republican, each polled 51,679 votes in the Nov. 3 election for the Manchester district seat in Congress. The tie was disclosed today in a recount of the ballots in the office of the Secretary of State.

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, Works Progress Administrator, directed the heads of the four Federal art projects in the city yesterday to drop 1,923 persons from their rolls as the second step in the WPA curtailment program.

Immediate construction of the second tube of the Midtown Hudson Vehicular Tunnel, to which the Port Authority is now committed, appears to be justified on every count. From an engineering point of view it is to be commended because it will allow one tube to be used for eastbound traffic and the other for westbound traffic, instead of imposing the hazards and inconveniences of two-way traffic on a single tube for an indefinite period.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- With both domestic production and imports surging steadily higher, the largest stocks of liquor in the country's history were on hand today.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 25.One of the largest events of the early season was the dinner dance with which the Club Madrid initiated the season's festivities tonight.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 26 -- Montclair High School tossed a scare into Bloomfield High's eleven today, but its rival turned on the power in the final period to register three times and win, 21 -- 0. For three quarters, Montclair's warriors staved off the Bloomfield thrusts, but weakened in the final period.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 26. -- The President's inaugural ball will be dispensed with at the second inauguration of President Roosevelt, Colonel Edwin A. Halsey of Washington, in charge of arrangements, announced here tonight.

OXFORD, England, Nov. 26. -- The red "tail lights" of nebulae which are seen in far-off space out near the seeing limits of the 100-inch telescope at Mount Wilson, Calif., received a new interpretation today by Dr. Edwin Hubble, the American astronomer.
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 26. -- The United States delegation to the Inter-American Peace Conference enjoyed a quiet day today resting after the excitement of landing and getting settled.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- Prestige, measured alongside the yardstick of an era in history, is an evanescent possession. As Burns wrote of pleasure, it is "like the snow falls in the river, a moment white, then melts forever." It is well, therefore, for public men to use their prestige while they have it, and the President is no exception.

BOSTON, Nov. 26 (AP). -- Waging their second overtime battle in three nights, the Boston Bruins gained a spectacular 3 -- 2 victory over the Montreal Maroons before a holiday crowd of 16,000 at the Boston Garden tonight.

UNIVERSITY, Va., Nov. 26. -- North Carolina's eleven wound up its 1936 gridiron campaign by defeating Virginia today, 59 to 14. The Tarheels registered nine touchdowns, scoring in every quarter, while the Cavaliers had to be content with two, both coming in the second period.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 26. -- Zevson, 4-year-old son of the great Zev, set up a new track record today in capturing the Thanksgiving Handicap at the Fair Grounds.

St. James Lutheran Church, at Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street, has been saved from closing its doors for financial reasons. The Rev. Dr. Charles Trexler, the pastor, and George S. Runk, treasurer of the congregation, made the announcement yesterday morning at the Thanksgiving service.

The latest Supreme Court decision may bring a revival of Mr. Dooley. On every side we meet now his famous observation, omitting the dialect, that the Supreme Court follows the election returns. And this reminds one that the list of 700 books compiled as a home library for the recent TIMES Book Fair regrettably omitted FINLEY PETER DUNNE and GEORGE ADE.

DETROIT, Nov. 26 (AP). -- The Chicago Black Hawks won their first game in eight National Hockey League starts tonight, blanking the champion Detroit Red Wings, 2 to 0, in a tight battle before 10,470.

TALAVERA DE LA REINA, Spain, Nov. 26. -- I have just returned from a visit to the Madrid front in depressing weather and found conditions there little changed from the last few days. There was desultory cannonading from both sides and rifle fire from the Insurgent front lines.

BERLIN, Nov. 26. -- Two of the leading National Socialist journals, the Angriff and the Black Corps, organ of the Hitler Special Guards, carry announcements threatening and deriding the Leipzig municipal authorities for preserving an ordinance requiring orphans under their protection to be reared as Christians.

Miss Genevieve Butler Travers was introduced to society at a reception given yesterday afternoon by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Travers, at their home, 23 East Eighty -- third Street. Autumn foliage and yellow and rust-colored chrysanthemums were used in the decorations.
LONDON, Nov. 26. -- Scores of threatening letters addressed to Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson have caused precautions to be taken to protect King Edward's American friend.

ARLINGTON, Texas, Nov. 26. -- Croon, running as the W.C. Stroube and Corsicana Stable entry, with Pundit as her running mate, took the Thanksgiving handicap today by one and one-half lengths in a field of twelve at Arlington Downs.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26. -- The most successful Pennsylvania football season since 1924 came to a close with a hard earned 14-6 victory over a game, dangerous Cornell team today in the forty-third holding of this Thanksgiving Day fixture before 57,000 spectators at Franklin Field.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 26 (AP). -- John Roosevelt, the "baby" and only man of the President's immediate family at the ancestral home for Thanksgiving, said tonight that the condition of his brother, Franklin, Jr., "is not at all serious."

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 26 (AP). -- The battling Bruins of the University of California at Los Angeles and the favored Trojans of Southern California battled to a 7-7 standstill today before a Thanksgiving crowd of 85,000 football fans.

OTTAWA, Nov. 26 (Canadian Press). -- A large number of applications for seats from which to view the coronation procession in London next May have been received by Vincent Massey, Canadian High Commissioner, and it has been decided to close the subscription list for seats at the high commissioner's disposal on Jan. 1.

His head and arms on one rail and his legs on the other, Buddy Tortore, 19 years old, of 59 Perry Street, lay unconscious where he had fallen on the northbound track of the municipally owned Independent subway line at the West Fourth Street station at Sixth Avenue at 9:30 o'clock last night as a train, out of sight around a curve, was rumbling toward the scene.

I have to thank you for printing that letter in which I suggested that we do a little cosmic pinch-hitting and erect a statue of Felix Mendelssohn and keep it here until our German friends shall be able once more to listen to his charm- ing music without getting the Aryan jitters.
OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 26. -- After scrawling a report of his symptoms over a wall of his office, Dr. Edwin Katskee, 34, died of an overdose of a narcotic this morning.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 26. -- Leading a sustained drive of 43 yards, Elmer Klinsman crossed the Princeton goal line for the only touchdown of the game as the Rutgers 150-pound football team defeated the Tiger lightweights, 7-2, on University Field today.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 26. -- Army's football squad received a rousing send-off today as it departed for Green Hill Farms, near Philadelphia, where the players will remain until shortly before Saturday's game with the Navy at Philadelphia's municipal stadium.

TAMPA, Nov. 26. -- Far-reaching changes that would liberalize and broaden the scope of the Federal Social Security Act were proposed here today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, who indicated that amendments would be suggested to Congress by the executive council.

PARIS, Nov. 26. -- Too great expectations should not be built on the reports from here that the French Government is discussing debt payment to the United States. In the first place, it is not strictly true. In the second place, there is a long road to be covered between discussing payment and raising a new loan on a promise to pay.

The Gydnia-America liner Pilsudski arrived yesterday two days behind her schedule as a result of stormy weather on the Atlantic. Captain Zdenko Knoetgen, relief captain in command of the ship during the absence of Captain Mamert Stankiewicz, said the storm was incessant for six days.

PARIS, Friday, Nov. 27. -- A serious conflict between big business and the government, which may have great internal consequences in France, developed today when the General Confederation of Employers refused to agree to arbitration of industrial disputes and ended all negotiations with the government.

Striking through the air and along the ground with equal effectiveness, the powerful De Witt Clinton football team overwhelmed the High School of Commerce, 44-0, yesterday before more than 13,000 spectators at Randalls Island Stadium.

KWEISUI, Suiyuan Province, China, Nov. 26. -- Chinese military headquarters said today that General Fu Tso-yi, Governor of Suiyuan, had received a strong threat that the Japanese Kwantung Army would be thrown into the Suiyuan conflict as a result of the Chinese capture of Peilingmiao.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- The volume of wholesale business in the United States amounted in 1935 to more than $42,000,000,000, an increase of 41 per cent over the total for 1933. In giving out the figures today, William L. Austin, director of the census, explained that they were based on a preliminary summary of the wholesale census now being made as a part of the census of business.

Mr. and Mrs. Kingdon Gould gave a ball last night at Sherry's to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Silvia Gould, a great-granddaughter of the late Jay Gould and granddaughter of the late George J. Gould and the late Mrs. Edith Kingdon Gould.

Mrs. George Washington Kavanaugh, wife of a retired cotton converter, revealed last night that jewelry, silver and gold valued at $25,000 was missing from her eight-story town house at 10 East Sixty-second Street.

Striking twice within ten seconds early in the final period, the New York Rovers came from behind to down the Pittsburgh Yellow Jackets, 3 to 2, in an Eastern Amateur League hockey contest before a crowd of 3,500 at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

HAMPTON BAYS, L.I., Nov. 26. -- John Hand, 78 years old, and his family of eleven have been removed by the police from the squalor of their four-room shack in the woods here, it was revealed today, after an investigation of alleged immoral conditions in which the family was living.

BURLINGTON, N.J., Nov. 26. -- Struck in the temple by a revolver bullet that ricocheted after it was fired by her husband, Mrs. Lila Wood, 23 years old, of Burlington, was fatally wounded today. She died in the emergency hospital at the Burlington City Hall less than an hour after she was shot.

Miss Mabelle F. Lane, 70 years old, member of a prominent old New York family, was burned to death early yesterday morning while fighting a fire in the bathroom of her two-room apartment at 11 East Fifty-fifth Street, where she had lived for twenty-two years.

The novelty of the concert given by John Barbirolli and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony last night in Carnegie Hall was the orchestral suite arranged from the music that Vaughan Williams composed for a dance pantomime in nine scenes, "Job," the scenario -- after pictures by William Blake -- by Geoffrey Keyens and Gwendolen Raverat.
HONOLULU, Nov. 26 (AP). -- The can-opener played an important role today in preparing Hawaii's Thanksgiving dinner. And chicken, duck and young pig shoved the customary turkey right off the table.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 26. -- Rutgers closed its season with a 7-to-7 tie against Ohio Wesleyan before 4,500 today.

TOKYO, Nov. 26. -- Though the German-Japanese agreement is presented as a fair accompli of national policy, the press displays misgivings lest its international implications outweigh the benefit of the anti-Communist crusade.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 26 (AP). -- Pittsburgh's Panthers snatched a 31-to-14 triumph out of the bleak Thanksgiving air today after a stalwart Carnegie Tech eleven forced them to uncover all their vaunted power.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif. -- Both Columbia and RKO have stories waiting for Herbert Marshall when he returns to Hollywood. Columbia has purchased "Weather or No," by A.H.Z. Carr. The screen adaptation will be made by Ethel Hill and Lynn Starling and shooting is to begin on Dec. 15.
PARIS, Nov. 26. -- Protests against the transference to the United States of the fifteenth century chapel at Chauvirey-le-Chatel have been gaining in volume lately.

MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 26. -- With only three days left before the hour set for a strike of oil workers throughout the country two meetings were held today in an effort to reach an agreement. Representatives of the owners and the syndicate attended the meeting but they were unable to reach an understanding.

Test borings of the East River bottom along the projected route of the Queens Midtown Vehicular Tunnel have thus far disclosed that the project would be difficult but that there would be no unusual obstacles in driving the new tube under the river, A.W. Copp, general manager of the New York City Tunnel Authority, announced yesterday.
WINNIPEG, Man., Nov. 26. -- A brisk demand for wheat from overseas spurred trading on the Winnipeg grain exchange today with the result that futures ended 1/8 to 5/8 cent a bushel higher.

The long and sometimes dismal trail back from Columbus and a 60-to-0 defeat in the first game of the season ended in blazing sunset for the New York University football team yesterday at the Yankee Stadium.

A plan whereby the Banco di Napoli Trust Company would acquire the banking business of the Bank of Sicily Trust Company and its branches, and would assume all liabilities to depositors and banks, and certain other liabilities will be discussed at meetings of the boards of directors of both banks, it was announced yesterday.

John Boettiger, veteran reporter and President Roosevelt's son-in-law, will be publisher of William Randolph Hearst's Seattle Post-Intelligencer, which suspended publication more than three months ago after a strike of its editorial employes called by the Seattle branch of the American Newspaper Guild.

PARIS, Nov. 26. -- Yvon Delbos, Foreign Minister, invited Vladimir Potemkin, Soviet Ambassador to Paris, to the Quai d'Orsay today and told him that France considered European peace was being risked by the continued delivery of arms to the Spanish Loyalists.

LISBON, Portugal, Nov. 26. -- Tuesday's surprise artillery attack by Spanish Government troops on Talavera de la Reina, which most observers had thought was sixty or seventy miles behind the Insurgents' front line, apparently came from San Bartolomeu, about thirteen miles away.
Miss Virginia Ehret was introduced to society last night at a dinner dance given by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Louis John Ehret, in the Perroquet Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.

SEATTLE, Nov. 26. -- Washington smothered the challenge of Washington State, 40 to 0, today, winning undisputed possession of the Pacific Coast Conference football championship and the Western Rose Bowl assignment.

TORONTO, Nov. 26 (Canadian Press). -- Industrial shares declined today on the Toronto Stock Exchange, led by the oils, which lost about a point each, disturbed apparently by news that a new carburetor might reduce gasoline consumption.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26. -- The United States accumulated a "marriage deficit" of nearly 750,000 fewer weddings as a result of the depression, during the six-year period from 1930 to 1935, according to a survey made public today by Samuel Stouffer, Professor of Sociology at the University of Chicago, and Lyle M. Spencer, fellow in sociology.

LIVERPOOL, Nov. 26 (AP) -Wheat futures advanced today to 1 cents a bushel in a steady: market, December closing at $1.20i and March at $1.14. The market' opened slightly dearer than yesterday but gave way moderately, the
LONDON, Nov. 26. -- Postmaster General James A. Farley, addressing The Pilgrims at the Thanksgiving luncheon in his honor today, said:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 26. -- Yale University's enrollment for the present academic year is 5,130, and includes students from every State in the union and from thirty-three foreign countries, according to the official figures issued today by the University.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Nov. 26 (AP). -- Mary's immortal, school-going lamb may become the center of a literary controversy as soon as the New Hampshire Guide, prepared by a WPA Federal writers' project, comes off the press.
WASHINGTON, Nov 26. -- Details ., of the evacuation of Madrid by American nationals were announced tonight by the State Department. The official statement said:

The world's welterweight championship will be at stake tonight when Barney Ross, the titleholder, clashes with Izzy Jannazzo of the East Side in a fifteen-round bout at Madison Square Garden. Although the battle will mark Ross's first appearance in defense of his crown since he won it from Jimmy McLarnin a year ago last May, he is the topheavy choice to defeat the New York warrior.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26. -- Barclay H. Warburton Jr., 38, eldest of the three children of Major and Mrs. Barclay Warburton and a grandson of the late John Wanamaker, was fatally injured in a gunning accident while he was hunting alone this afternoon on his 94-acre farm near Doylestown.
LONDON, Nov. 26 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

LONDON, Nov. 26. -- After repeated proddings by London, Generalissimo Francisco Franco has finally agreed to grive safe anchorage to foreign shipping in ease he carries out his threat to bombard and "if necessary destroy" the port and city of Barcelona.

Willard I. Kimm of Orange, N.J., president of the Columbia University Club of Essex County, N.J., announced yesterday that Frederick William Reimherr, principal of the West Orange Senior High School, had won the 1936 "Columbia Lion" awarded by the club.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP). -- President Roosevelt's South American peace trip has presented new and worrisome problems for Colonel E.W. Starling, his far-traveling and careful planning protector-in-chief.

LONDON, Nov. 26. -- A new trade agreement between the United Kingdom and Argentina is ready for signature, Walter Runciman, President of the Board of Trade, told the House of Commons today, and it will take effect as from Nov. 20.
SEATTLE, Wash., Nov. 26 (AP). -- Alabama's undefeated Crimson Tide tonight appeared the probable opponent of Washington in the New Year's Day football classic in Pasadena's Rose Bowl.

Lord BALFOUR'S judgment, recorded in the biography lately published by his niece, that Lord KFFCHENER was "stupid" has been drawing comment from the tribe of letter-writers to The Times of London. KITCHENER'S "stupidity" came up curiously in BALFOUR'S mind in connection with the former's early expressed opinion, so irritating to the Christmas-in-Berlin school, that the war would be long.
TULSA, Nov. 26 (AP). -- Arkansas defeated Tulsa University today, 23 -- 13, in their thirteenth Thanksgiving football meeting before 16,000 fans.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., Nov. 26 (Canadian Press). -- The little Norwegian freighter Beran lay in the shelter of St. John's Harbor tonight while her crew sought sleep and fresh food after thirty-eight days of storms.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- Net capital movements into the United States for 1935 and the first nine months of 1936 amounted to $2,281,659,000, the Treasury announced today.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 26 (AP). -- Two women evangelists, Aimee Semple McPherson and Rheba Crawford Splivalo, one time "Angel of Broadway," marshaled forces tonight for a million-dollar battle around a charge of slander.
BOSTON, Nov. 26. -- An acute sinus infection confined Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. to a hospital bed today and disrupted the Thanksgiving plans of the Presidential family at their Hyde Park, N.Y., home.

READING, Pa., Nov. 26. -- A1bright defeated Muhlenberg, 70 -- 13, today before more than 7,000 spectators. Dick Riffle scored five of the Lions' eleven touchdowns, furnishing thrills with runs of 92 and 61 yards.

Manhattan's football squad will leave New York Tuesday night for its game with Texas A. and M. at Tyler, Texas, a week from tomorrow. The itinerary of the Jaspers was announced yesterday by Brother Anselm, director of athletics.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 26 (AP). -- A 21-yard rushing and passing drive to a touchdown in the first quarter gave Detroit University a 6-to-0 victory over Creighton University before 10,000 spectators today.

After having been held by the same family since 1845, the property at 739-41 Broadway, running through to 298-300 Mercer Street, has been sold by the Almy Realty! Corporation to B, M. E. Realties, Inc., for cash. The assessed valuation is $110,000.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 26. -- Ray Trail of Mont Pleasant High School, Schenectady, N.Y., carried off the national interscholastic cross-country title for the second successive year in the eleventh annual Thanksgiving Day race over the two-and-one-half mile course in Branch Brook Park today.

Father Diedrieh Knickerbocker lost his head yesterday in the annual Macy parade down Broadway. His glowing nose snagged in the elevated structure at Lincoln Square and the helium hissed from it, and from his neck, his smiling face and his cocked hat.
CHESTER, Pa., Nov. 26. -- Taking advantage of two breaks, each of which gave possession of the ball inside the P.M.C. 20-yard line, Ursinus punched out a 12-6 triumph over the Cadets today.

DETROIT, Nov. 26. -- The slight hope the Detroit Lions have of retaining their National Football League championship was prolonged today when they defeated the Chicago Bears, 13 -- 7, before a capacity crowd of more than 22,000.
PARIS, Nov. 26. -- Physical education between the ages of six and eighteen soon will be required by law in France following Cabinet approval of a bill embodying this principle.

PARIS, Nov. 26. -- Armed men today held up an auto truck carrying the first copies of this week's issue of Gringoire and dumped them into the Seine. Gringoire, a political journal, is blamed by friends of the late Minister of the Interior Roger Salengro for his suicide, which they attribute to its slanderous attacks.

A turkey among a million -- perhaps it might be called a Scheherazade among turkeys, as that happens to be what they call it -- clucked and preened itself yesterday in the animal hospital at the Bronx Zoo.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- George Washington won its first homecoming game of its long football career today when it defeated West Virginia, 7 to 2, in a battle seen by 25,000 fans.
THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Nov. 26. -- Press reports of a German-Japanese secret treaty affecting the Dutch East Indies are received here with mixed feelings, skepticism prevailing.

PARIS, Nov. 26. -- United States Ambassador William C. Bullitt, addressing an American Legion Thanksgiving dinner tonight, said the Americans had come through hard times and were thankful their old liberties had not been impaired.

SOME grim-looking fellows were sighted riding bikes in the suburbs and it was suspected that another six-day race was just around the corner. The suspicion was affirmed later when three Frenchmen dropped into the office for a visit. The tallest of the trio was Vincent Denarie, and it turned out that M'sieu Denarie had two prime virtues; he speaks English and he is not a six-day rider.

The most successful Old Glory sale in recent years and one that revived memories of the boom days of 1928 and 1929 came to a close at Squadron A Armory yesterday leaving a strong feeling of optimism among light-harness followers for a big season next year.

A medical device designed to prolong life caused inadvertently the death of an aged man yesterday in a Brooklyn hospital. The victim was Aaron Handler, 73 years old, a cardiac patient at the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn since last Saturday.

Dr. HAROLD G. CAMPBELL City Superintendent of Schools, has proposed the creation of an official interdepartmental agency for coordinating the budget requests of the departments that have to do with matters relating to children, their health, education, recreation,

Dr. Albert Einstein, proponent of relativity and of the profound elastic uncertainty of the universe, was revealed yesterday as the inventor of a practical device. It will enable any amateur to use a camera successfully without knowing how to time an exposure.
CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (AP). -- Dust storms in the wheat country have inspired fresh fears among grain traders that drought again may threaten farm crops in 1937.

MADRID, Nov. 26 (AP). -- On the University City battlefront in Northwestern Madrid every available member of two international brigades fought to stave off a new Insurgent assault. Four Insurgent planes bombed the model prison, machine-gunned defense barricades and blasted houses.

Collecting all their points within approximately three minutes in the second quarter, the New York Giants remained in the running for the Eastern Division title in the National Football League competition by blanking the Brooklyn Dodgers, 14 to 0, before 18,000 fans at Ebbets Field yesterday.

Maritime labor leaders of France announced yesterday that an international drive against American-flag ships was under way and that freight carried by such ships would not be handled, according to The Associated Press.

There are an infinite number of possible universes. Einstein's original one, now abandoned, was full of matter and static. At the other end was de Sitter's, which was empty. The generally accepted universe of today is the Abbe Lemaitre's, which contains matter (stars) and which is dynamic.

WATERFORD, N.J., Nov. 26. -- The Wildwood Express of the Pennsylvania Seashore Line, speeding sixty miles an hour, plowed into an auto truck at a light-protected crossing here this morning. The truck was demolished, the wreckage strewn along the tracks for nearly half a mile and three men and a boy, riding in the vehicle, borrowed from a WPA project, were killed.

Money market was closed in observance of Thanksgiving Day holiday. Wednesday's final quotations were: For demand loans, 1 per cent; time money, all dates, 1 1/4 per cent, and commercial paper, best names, three-quarters of one per cent.

Offering to the public of an issue of $6,250,000 of Piedmont Northern Railway Company first mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds, series due in 1966, will be made today through a banking group comprising Blyth Co., Inc., R.S. Dickson Co., Inc., and Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc.
BERLIN, Nov. 26. -- National socialism, with the publication of the German-Japanese treaty, definitely launched an effort to divide the world into blocs friendly to and opposed to communism.

The John Adams High School eleven, routed by St. John's Prep two weeks ago, came back to register the biggest surprise of the season in Queens school circles by routing Grover Cleveland High, 30 -- 7, before 8,000 fans at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 26. -- Mrs. Ernest Simpson, the King's friend, for the first time in her long career as a hostess became front-page news in a London newspaper tonight.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 26. -- The undefeated, untied and unscored-upon St. Benedict's Prep football team ended its season today by burying Newark East Side under an avalanche of touchdowns, 59 -- 0, to press its claim to the North Jersey Group IV prep school championship.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 26. -- An animosity, developed through several years' strife over property sharings within the family circle of the three remaining Clark brothers, heirs of the Singer Sewing Machine fortune, has been kindled anew during a recent attempt of the older brother, Robert Sterling Clark, to make final disposition through gifts of his real estate holdings within this locality.

The Noel Coward-Gertrude Lawrence season at the National this evening moves into the second of those three phases known collectively as "Tonight at 8:30." Play by play, the new batch consists of: "We Were Dancing" (comedy), "Fumed Oak" (something bitter about a domestic revolt) and "Shadow Play" (a fantasy with music).

Eleven players and their substitutes were responsible for New York University's thrilling victory over Fordham yesterday, but the name of one was on the lips of every Violet supporter and stamped indelibly in the minds of the assembled experts. He was Howard Dunney, a junior end, whose punting unquestionably was one of the major instruments in the unlooked for result.

Trailing at the half, Curtis High School of Staten Island rallied in the last two quarters to score three touchdowns and defeat a hard-fighting Roosevelt eleven, 20 to 6, before 6,000 spectators yesterday at Thompson's Stadium, Stapleton.

TOLEDO, Spain, Nov. 26. -- The military situation on the Madrid front gives grounds for supposing the Insurgents are changing their original plan of besieging Madrid. Their purpose now seems to be to conquer the capital piecemeal in order to give the government forces a chance to surrender instead of trying to capture the whole city by a single stroke.

MOSCOW, Nov. 26. -- The authoritative newspaper Pravda asserted tonight that Soviet Russia had documentary evidence to support its declaration that Japan and Germany have a military pact against Russia.

CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 26. -- Four American and Canadian automobile manufacturers are considering the possibility of establishing factories in Australia with the aid of a bounty and the tariff, according to Sir Henry Somer Gullett, Minister Without Portfolio, who says that the government has supplied them with copious information that has evoked keen interest.
Columbia and Stanford concluded their heavy practice yesterday in preparation for their meeting tomorrow at the Polo Grounds.

MONTREAL, Nov. 26 (AP). -- Toronto, scoring three goals in an exciting third period, beat the Canadiens, 4 to 2, tonight for their second victory of the National Hockey League season. The decision sent the Maple Leafs into a third-place tie with the Montreal Maroons in the international division while the Canadiens remained in second place.

Fire started by a short circuit in defective electric wiring destroyed last night the Riviera, a popular Summer cabaret atop the Palisades in Fort Lee, one mile north of the New Jersey end of the George Washington Bridge. The police estimated the damage to the large, one-story frame building and its costly interior decorations at $150,000.

A contract signed yesterday by R.H. Cochrane, president of Universal Pictures; J.J. Robbins of the Robbins Music Corporation and Leo Feist, Inc., has made the music catalogues of both companies available for use in Universal pictures. The contract, negotiated over a period of six months with provisions extending over a period of twenty years, is the first of its kind entered into by Universal.

One of the few services done to the nation by the late political campaign was that of presenting the Social Security Act to the critical attention of the general public. Even in the heat of the discussion many of its defenders agreed that the act stood in need of extensive revision.

BOSTON, Nov. 26. -- Professor Walter Barnes of New York University, speaking tonight at the opening of the twenty-fifth anniversary convention of the National Council of Teachers of English, urged considering well the desirability of a "sweet disorder" in speech which would admit the propriety of slang and colloquialisms.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. CHESTER AT SEA, Nov. 26 (AP). -- President Roosevelt had his turkey dinner with all the fixings today and then completed the speech he is to deliver tomorrow before a joint session of the Brazilian Congress.
The readers' forum. . . .

A strong contingent of amateurs from the Irish-American A.C. of Boston took eight quarter-finals in the Eastern division of the All-America boxing tournament last night before 4,000 persons at the Ridgewood Grove Sporting Club, Brooklyn.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Nov. 26. -- In quarters slightly cramped for the celebration, the fifty families who emigrated from New York last July to form Jersey Homesteads, a model Federal resettlement project near here, observed their first Thanksgiving in their new homes today.

WARSAW, Poland, Nov. 26. -- Poland, having recemented her alliance with France, is now seeking to improve her relations with her other ally, Rumania. The visit of Victor Antonescu, the Rumanian Foreign Minister, to Warsaw, is likened to Marshal Edward Smigly-Rydz's recent visit to Paris.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 26. -- Taking advantage of a break in the final minute of play, Barringer High School's eleven put over a touchdown to score a 6-0 triumph over East Orange High School in the fortieth annual game of a series that has been uninterrupted since 1897.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Nov. 26 (AP). -- The paneled salon of the $2,500,000 yacht Alva was garlanded today for a Vanderbilt wedding. Mrs. Earl T. Smith, the former Consuelo Vanderbilt, will be married there tomorrow to Henry Gassaway Davis 3d, grandson of the late West Virginia Senator who was Democratic Vice Presidential nominee in 1904.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 26. -- Westchester County is going to have a new charter, Supervisor Bert C. McCulloch of Mamaroneck, chairman of the Special Committee on Reorganization of County Government, declared today.

MOSCOW, Nov. 26. -- The Congress of Soviets at today's session became the Bolsheviki's deliberate answer to the Nazi party's Nuremberg congress. To the hymns of hate sung by Chancellor Adolf Hitler and his aides Soviet speakers replied in kind.

Prospective purchasers of the 4 per cent debentures to be issued by New York World's Fair 1939 Incorporated to help finance the exposition on the Flushing Meadows site, will receive today a prospectus containing detailed estimates of the expenditures and revenues of the enterprise.
WINNIPEG, Nov. 26 (AP). -- Grain prices on the Winnipeg Exchange follow:

Profiting from a timely break in the last three minutes, after it appeared that the result would be a scoreless tie, Brooklyn Prep downed its borough foe, St. John's Prep, 6 -- 0, in the eighteenth struggle of their football rivalry at Boys High Field yesterday morning.

Thirteen men, adrift in dories after they had abandoned their grounded fishing schooner, were rescued in the Atlantic off Montauk Point by the Coast Guard yesterday morning. The men had drifted aimlessly for hours because they feared to attempt a landing against the smashing breakers.

TORONTO, Nov. 26 (Canadian Press). -- A spectacular story that the long-lost Ambrose Small was murdered seventeen years ago, based on a confession ascribed to his wife, collapsed late today when Justice Nicol Jeffrey dismissed with costs an action to upset the Small wills, involving a $2,000,000 estate.

SEATTLE, Nov. 26. -- The Seattle Chapter of the American Newspaper Guild, its strike against The Post-Intelligencer settled, hailed the appointment today of John Boettiger as publisher as "a change in the direction of genuine liberalism" in the policies of William Randolph Hearst.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 26. -- Sent hack into the game for a point-after-touchdown kick, Harry Mattos made good, giving the Cleveland Rams a 7-6 victory over the Rochester Tigers today in an American Football League game. Some 5,000 Thanksgiving Day fans braved bitter cold weather to see the thrilling contest.
MADRID, Nov. 26. -- Seventy-three Americans in two contingents left Madrid on this cold Thanksgiving Day and fled through the rain to Valencia.

LONDON, Nov. 26. -- An all-round recovery set in today on the stock markets following yesterday's session of nervous selling. Although Wall Street was closed for Thanksgiving, a brisk demand developed for international shares, with tractions, nickels, steels and hydros all stronger.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP). -The calling of a special session of the Pennsylvania Legislature to enactI n unemployment insurance law I was expected by Federal officialsI today to develop a rush by otherI States to get such legislation on the i statute books-by the end of the year.
A reception was given by Mr. and ]rs. Edward Woolsey Freeman yesterday afternoon at their home, Wave Hill, Riverdale-on-I-Iudson, to introduce their daughter, Miss Dor-i othy Freeman, to society.

The agreement between Japan and Germany, representing what has been characterized officially as a defensive instrument against Communist propaganda, and interpreted in other circles as paving the road for a military alliance emphasizes the basic changes that have occurred in Soviet foreign policy designed to protect Soviet Russia in the West in the event of a war in the Far East.

Representative HAMILTON FISH Jr. naturally considers himself a spared monument after the Democratic landslide of Nov. 3. He carried his own Congressional district, in which President ROOSEVELT lives and votes, by an increased majority. This seems to Mr. FISH to entitle him to take the lead in telling the Republican party what it must do to be saved.

Your editorial "Conscripting Youth" deserves applause. But your statement that the CCC is "the nearest American equivalent to the labor brigades and youth services of Europe," it seems to me, is based on an oversight. What about the ROTC?

The following estimates, contained in the prospectus for the World's Fair debenture issue of $27,829,500, show the receipts and expenditures for a two-year duration with a paid attendance of 40,000,000 the first year and 24,000,000 the second year:

I For the first ten months of 1936i I i building contracts m the New York !district totaled $266,502,500, an adi vance off 45 per cent over the same period in 1935, when the total wasI $184,277,800, according to figures I compiled by the F. W. Dodge Cor-I poration.

Simplicio Godina was reported last night by the Academy of Medicine in "extremely favorable condition" nearing the end of the second day after his surgical severance from the body of his dead Siamese twin.

Assuming command one mile before the finish, Murray Rosenstein, 20-year-old novice representing the Ninety-second Street Y.M.H.A., captured the twenty-sixth annual handicap walk from City Hall to Coney Island yesterday. Walking with ease until his winning spurt in the last few miles, the youth covered the ten-and-one-half-mile route in the actual time of 1:36:35.

The thirtieth annual national Christmas Seal Sale, which will continue until Christmas, began yesterday with a radio speech at Hyde Park, N.Y., by Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President. The address was broadcast over a coast-to-coast network of the National Broadcasting Company and was heard here over WJZ.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 26. -- Before 22,000 persons, Maryland's largest crowd of the Fall season, which wagered approximately $500,000, C.V. Whitney's Piccolo won the $3,075 Thanksgiving Handicap today, returning $6.70 for $2. The result was a stunning surprise to admirers of the Man o'War colt, Jean Bart, the odds-on favorite which brought up third in the field of four.

A particularly interesting study in contrast is furnished by two of the exhibitions of the week -- that of canvases by Emma Fordyce MacRae at the Grand Central Galleries in Vanderbilt Avenue and of water-colors by Raoul Dufy at the Carroll Carstairs, 11 East Fifty-seventh Street.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 26. -- Conservative football was cast to the winds today in the high school stadium as the Baldwin eleven from Long Island defeated White Plains, 19 to 13, before nearly 5,000 spectators.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 26. -- A move to organize the large industries and businesses in New Jersey and near-by parts of New York and Connecticut for voluntary, cooperative self-regulation along lines pioneered by the NRA has been started by the State Trade Service Council, which has offices here.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Nov. 26. -- The undefeated Riverhead High eleven ended its season today by downing Southampton, 14 -- 13, before 4,000 persons. The triumph, decided on Walter Hogan's placement in the third quarter, was Riverhead's fifth in six games, one of which ended in a tie.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Nov. 26. -- When President Roosevelt steps ashore from the United States cruiser Indianapolis here tomorrow morning for a one-day visit en route to the inter-American peace conference at Buenos Aires, thousands of secondary school pupils will greet him with the singing of the American and Brazilian national anthems.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- With the Treasury's working balance under the $1,000,000,000 mark for the first time in many months, Secretary Morgenthau took steps today to replenish government cash by announcing $100,000,000 bill issues for Dec. 2, when only $50,000,000 in the same type of securities will mature.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 26. -- Santiago Luis, Cardinal Copello, Primate of Argentina and Archbishop of Buenos Aires, has issued pastoral letter pledging the Catholic Church's closest cooperation with the Inter-American Conference of the Maintenance of Peace.
LONDON, Nov. 26. -- The celebrated publishing firm of John Lane, the Bodley Head, Ltd., has gone into receivership, but it is hoped that the business will be continued without interruption.
BERLIN, Nov. 26. -- The Boerse continued almost wholly stagnant today although some resistance, or at least a tendency to strength was discerned.

Full figures of the Bureau of Labor's employment and payroll index, revised and published this week, gives 96.5 as the employment index for October, against 89.3 in October, 1935, and 66.3 in October, 1932. The present index is the highest since March, 1930.

Cold feet, red noses and chattering teeth meant nothing to some 25,000 youngsters and grown-ups who assembled on the Central Park Mall yesterday morning to view the third annual Thanksgiving Day circus staged by Hearns department store.
Many New York churches had Thanksgiving services yesterday and the topics of sermons preached ranged from national problems to matters of faith.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 26. -- Rallying for two touchdowns in the second half, Alabama drove to a 14-to-6 victory over Vanderbilt today before 25,000 fans to finish the season unbeaten as its partisans waited hopefully for an invitation to the Rose Bowl.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26. -- Before 12,000 chilled spectators Temple and Bucknell battled to a 0 -- 0 tie in their tenth annual game at the Owls Stadium today.

The New York Rangers avenged themselves on their neighbors, the Americans, at Madison Square Garden last night. The Patrickmen defeated the forces led by Red Dutton, 3 to 1, and in so doing squared matters with the Star-Spangled troupe. A little over a week ago the Rang-I ors. making their season bow on their home ice, were humbled bY l the Americans, 2 to 1.

OTTAWA, Nov. 26 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits by the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada in the week ended on Nov. 25 showed a decrease of $4,957,341 compared to the previous week, according to the weekly statement issued by the bank today.

IS it possible, the average reader may ask, for anything more to be said about Napoleon? Has he not been in his grave for more than one hundred years? Has he not been the subject of biographies, histories, memoirs, novels, poems, monographs, essays, articles, sketches, interpretations, tracts, treatises, theses, disquisitions and dissertations apparently without end, filling whole alcoves and departments of libraries and requiring the services of special bibliographers?

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 26 (AP). The perfect placement kick of dependable Jim Porter, senior reserve end, was Tennessee's margin today in a 7-to-6 victory over Kentucky in the thirty-first renewal of their game, played on a snow-covered field before 22,000 spectators.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 26. -- Charles Hooper, who has devoted the greater part of his life to research in order to write letters to newspapers, spent his first Thanksgiving in twenty-three years with his sisters and mother here.
Among the business leases reported by brokers yesterday were several involving changes or expansions by jewelry concerns.

What the public wants in music was discussed last night at the Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street, under the joint auspices of the League for Political Education and the National Broadcasting Studios. Composers, conductors, radio officials, music critics and dance orchestra leaders, in addition to the audience, responded to the question without finding a definite answer.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 26. -- The Spiders of the University of Richmond ended their season today, defeating the William and Mary Indians, ancient rivals, 6 -- 0, before 10,000 enthusiastic fans.
PROVIDENCE, Nov. 26. -- Brown's Thanksgiving Day continues to be lean, for the Bruins lost to the Colgate eleven for the eighth year in succession this morning, 32 to 0.

LANCASTER, Pa., Nov. 26. -- Franklin and Marshall defeated its traditional rival, Gettysburg, in their forty-seventh annual game today, 19 to 0, and also won the Eastern Pennsylvania collegiate conference championship for the second straight year.

Total bank clearings for the twenty-two leading cities in the United States for the week ended on Wednesday, as reported to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., were $6,527,449,000, against $5,472,736,000 a year ago, a gain of 19.3 per cent, it was announced yesterday.
Thanksgiving Day never meant much to New York University in a football sense -- until yesterday.
NANKING, China, Nov. 26. -- The German-Japanese anti-Communist declaration was greeted with a chorus of disapproval in authoritative quarters in China's capital.
PARIS, Nov. 26 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

HUNTINGTON BEACH, Calif., Nov. 26 (AP). -- William H. Papke, Sr., former middleweight boxing champion, and his estranged wife, Mrs. Edna Eloise Papke, were shot and killed tonight in Mrs. Papke's home on Balboa Island.
VALENCIA, Spain, Nov. 26 (AP). -- A motor caravan of weary Americans straggled into Valencia tonight from Madrid, only to find every bed in this city occupied.

The committee of the Norwegian Parliament could not have awarded the Nobel Peace prizes for 1935 and 1936 to two men more contrastingly circumstanced than Mr. CARL VON OSSIETZKY and Dr. CARLOS SAAVEDRA LAMAS: one the militant German pacifist, in a tuberculosis hospital, his health shattered by three years in Nazi concentration camps; the other, the Argentine Foreign Minister, preparing to preside over the Pan-American conference at Buenos Aires next month.

America's millions celebrated Thanksgiving yesterday in a spirit of gratefulness for a year of returning prosperity and of hope for the year to come. Across the broad span of the continent and in far corners of the globe they observed the day after the fashion that has come down from the Pilgrim Fathers.

PEIPING, China, Friday, Nov. 27. -- The government's capture of Peilingmiao, Suiyuan Province, was believed today to have ended threats to the security of Kweisui, the provincial capital, from the north and probably to have taken the power of initiative from the Mongol and Manchukuoan invaders along the whole front unless they receive more open support from Japan.

EDMONTON, Alta., Nov. 26 (Canadian Press). -- The Aberhart government was requested today to lend its venture in stamped scrip. The Chambers of Commerce of Edmonton and Medicine Hat and the Board of Trade of Calgary and Lethbridge addressed a letter to Premier Aberhart, asserting that the experiment was a failure and should be scrapped.

DURHAM, N.C., Nov. 26 (AP). -- Captain Ace Parker of Duke closed his collegiate football career today by returning a punt seventy yards in the fourth quarter to give the Blue Devils a 13-to-0 victory over North Carolina State College.

Holding that it was unconstitutional for the State Civil Service Commission to "cover in" under exemptions the "first incumbents" of a position put under civil service, the Appellate Division ruled yesterday that Robert J. Rooney was entitled to a peremptory mandamus terminating the appointment of Louis Fischer as executive officer and Elsie Waldeck as secretary of the New York City Alcoholic Beverage Control Board.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- A demand by the government that Joseph Weiner, convicted as a poultry racketeer, be returned to prison was made to the Supreme Court today in briefs filed by Stanley Reed, Solicitor General.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 27. -- Rudolph Eisele, formerly a captain in the New York City Fire Department, was found hanging from a beam in the garage of his home at 34 South Randolph Avenue this morning by his wife, Mrs. Caroline Eisele. Dr. Howard P. Carpenter, medical examiner, pronounced him dead and gave a preliminary verdict of suicide.

The Appellate Division, in a unanimous decision yesterday, rebuked General Sessions Judge Cornelius F. Collins for conducting a trial in such a way as to "render impossible anything in the nature of an impartial judicial inquiry." The higher court chided the judge because "in the course of the trial o this simple issue of fact, he asked over 1,600 questions and, in the presence of the jury, made approximately seventy-five statements summarizing the evidence."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- Formal notices that war debt payments will be due on Dec. 15 have been sent by the State Department to thirteen foreign governments, with indications that in the replies France, Italy and possibly some other countries may make suggestions that will lead to a reopening of the debt question.

The Board of Education has no power to oust principals and teachers in the day schools from "double" positions in the evening schools if they previously have received permanent tenure in the evening jobs, the Appellate Division ruled yesterday.

The Republic of Argentina, through Dr. Roberto M. Ortiz, Minister of Finance, announced yesterday that a decree had been signed providing for the application of $37,969,668 of cash resources of the Treasury to the retirement by June 1, 1937, through operation of the sinking fund, of all of the government's external sinking fund 6 per cent bonds of 1925, due June 1, 1959, now outstanding and not previously called for redemption.

Creation of the important new post of "Internal Store Promotion Manager" in department stores is advocated by Thomas Robb, manager of the sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, in a fifty-two-page publication to be issued shortly by the division.

The Columbia Gas and Electric Company and affiliated interests will advertise on Monday throughout Southeastern Pennsylvania a proposal to petition the Governor for permission to incorporate the Pennsylvania Gas Transmission Corporation to supply natural gas in the area.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings, the reserve note circulation and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.

Tomorrow is Advent Sunday and the sermons in the city churches will be on this subject. Three leading Catholic edifices will have a visiting priest to give a course of Advent sermons at the 11 A.M. mass. The Protestant churches will hear plans announced for the four days' National Preaching Missions which will begin Dec. 6.

WASHINGTON, Nov.27. -- Sales by wholesale establishments throughout New York totaled $10,517,203,000 last year, increasing by 34 per cent over those of 1933, according to results of the national business census made public today by the Census Bureau.

DUBLIN, Irish Free State, Nov. 27. -Former President William Cosgrave, the Opposition leader, initiated a full-dress debate in the Dail Eireann today on the Spanish situation when he opposed the motion to adjourn for the Christmas recess until Feb. 3, moving an amendment that the House reassemble Dec. 2 in order to recognize General Francisco Franco's government.

Returns to date indicate that the Class I railroads earned an aggregate net operating revenue of about $90,000,000 in October, a gain of 22 per cent from October, 1935. This would produce a net income of about $48,000,000 in October, a gain of about 55 per cent over the net of $31,200,000 correspondingly in 1935.

OTTAWA, Nov. 27. -- President Roosevelt's implied invitation to Canada in his Rio de Janeiro speech today to participate in a Pan-American movement for peace was the most important foreign news of the month as far as this Dominion is concerned.

In preparation for the National Preaching Missions in this city, which will begin Sunday, Dec. 6, a "Pre-Preaching Mission" will be held for four successive evenings next week, beginning Tuesday, in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Seventy-third Street.
TOKYO, Nov. 27 (AP). -- The Japanese Cabinet approved today a record-breaking budget of 3,041,000,000 yen with almost half of the sum devoted to the Japanese Army and Navy.
The Spelman Fund of New York made grants aggregating $880,974.30 in the field of public administration during 1935, according to its annual report, made public yesterday.
The veteran Walter Kinsella and W.E. (Billy) Coyle, New York State singles champion, made an auspicious entry into the Heights Casino pro-amateur squash racquets doubles tournament last night.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 (AP). -- Willie Hoppe, one-time "boy wonder" of billiards, made an impressive start in defense of his world three-cushion championship tonight by trouncing Tiff Denton, veteran Kansas City star, 50 to 32, in the opening match of the 1936 tournament.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27. -- A revival of an aggressive foreign demand for cash wheat, reports of frost in the southern and western sections of the province of Buenos Aires, Argentina, and pronounced strength in Liverpool combined to bring about a sustained advance in domestic wheat markets today.

PARIS, Nov. 27. -- To Communists within France and to other critics abroad Premier Leon Blum tonight announced that this country has the strongest military force in Europe outside of Russia and that it had nothing to fear from foreign pressure.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27. -- Experiments on plants and animals which shed further light on the hereditary factors involved in the development of cancer were presented here today before the Autumn meeting of the American Philosophical Society, oldest learned society in America, founded by Benjamin Franklin in 1727.
PARIS, Nov. 27. -- The text of the Spanish Government's telegram to the League of Nations, as made public by the Spanish Embassy here, follows:

MADRID, Nov. 27. -- Government defenses at University City were battered tonight by a lone Insurgent bomber. The plane dropped at least ten bombs, repeatedly defying the anti-aircraft defense, and then sped off.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Nov. 27. -- At a press conference here today President Roosevelt said, in response to questions, that no proposal for an American League of Nations would be brought before the inter-American peace conference at Buenos Aires.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 27 (AP). -- A Coroner's jury put a climax on five months of conflict among criminologists today by asserting that Mrs. Eleanor Feely, 30, and her two children were "murdered."

Three persons were injured and more than fifty bruised and shaken in the rush hour at 5:32 o'clock last evening when two trolleys, both Manhattan bound, collided on the Williamsburg Bridge. Traffic on the westbound track was tied up twenty-five minutes.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 27. -- Par figures staggered against a concerted attack of 214 golf campaigners today and when the field of battle was cleared Henry Picard, the lanky star from Hershey, Pa., paced the touring professionals with a fine 69 in the first round of the seventy-two-hole $5,000 Augusta open tournament.
MADRID, Nov. 27. -- Citizens of Madrid dug underground tunnels today to speed their flight from house to house in the bitter siege of the capital by Spanish Fascists.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP). -- This season's cotton crop was reported "longer in staple, on the average," than the 1935 crop by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics today in a grade and staple survey of cotton ginned to Nov. 1.

By taking three places in the finals, Albany won the team honors last night in the Eastern section of the Hearst all-America amateur boxing tournament at the New York Hippodrome. Boston, taking two of the eight finals, was tied with New York for the runner-up honors, while Rochester was fourth with 1 point.

New Jersey wildfowlers who opened the duck hunting season of the southern zone in Barnegat Bay on Thanksgiving Day report that while the shooting did not equal advance predictions it was on the whole quite satisfactory.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 27. -- Harvard's sport program showed a profit of $4,746.59 in the college year that closed last June 30, it was revealed tonight when the annual financial report for the Harvard Athletic Association was made public.
URBANA, Ill., Nov. 27. -The theory that tough beefsteak comes from athletically inclined cattle was upset by experiments of the University of Illinois, Professor Sleeter Bull said today.

Viscountess Astor returned yesterday from Bermuda on the Furness liner Monarch of Bermuda with Viscount Astor, the London publisher. Lady Astor, who has achieved fame in England as one of the most outspoken Members of Parliament, said that the United States was twenty years behind Great Britain in social legislation.

Although prices on the Cotton Exchange improved at one time yesterday in sympathy with strong outside markets, hedging pressure in distant positions developed in the last hour and left the list with a gain of 2 to a loss of 11 points.

LONDON, Nov. 27. -- The country was disturbed today by the spectacle of an emergency meeting of the Cabinet, called apparently with only partial justification and without the slightest official or semi-official hint to explain it.

PARIS, Nov. 27. -- Premier Leon Blum replied today to the notice given him yesterday by the General Federation of Employers that it was unwilling to continue negotiations for application of the Matignon agreements by preparing a bill for the Chamber of Deputies providing obligatory arbitration of all social conflicts.
In the olden days when shipbuilders received an order to build a ship they made a model of the proposed craft, as they did not know the art of drafting it on paper.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The "flying delegation" of the People's Mandate to Governments to End War left today for Miami en route to Buenos Aires to present to the Pan-American Peace Conference petitions signed by millions of men and women demanding peaceful adjustment of international difficulties.

LAMBERTVILLE, N.J., Nov. 27. -- Chancefield Flirt, owned and handled by Frank G. Turner of Asbury Park, captured the silver trophy in the members' all-age English springer spaniel stake, as the first field-trial meeting of the Valley Forge English Springer Spaniel Club opened today on the estate of Colonel A. Foran.

GENEVA, Nov. 27. -- The Spanish Government telegraphed a note to the League of Nations today invoking Article XI -- the preventive and conciliatory part -- of the covenant and asking the Council to "proceed as soon as possible to examine the situation" in Spain.
Despite the annual hullabaloo to change the intercollegiate football rules, W.S. Langford, secretary of the rules committee, said yesterday he "doubts if any major changes win be made."

OTTAWA, Nov. 27 (Canadian Press). -- The speech of President Roosevelt at Rio de Janeiro in which he urged maintenance of peace in the Americas was described tonight by Prime Minister Mackenzie King as of "striking and momentous chaarcter."

BERLIN, Nov. 27. -- Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Propaganda Minister, announced today that in future all criticism of the drama, films, literature, painting, sculpture and other art works would be prohibited. The ruling applies primarily to published criticism but evidently it applies also to the radio and the platform.

MONTREAL, Nov. 27. -- Definite objection to the proposed deep draught waterway to link Montreal and New York as "inopportune at this time" and as "a potential threat to its business" was registered at today's final local session of the International Joint Commission studying the project by the Canadian Pacific and Canadian National Railways and the Montreal Board of Trade.

Many improvements are possible in the Social Security Act, but the various amendments suggested by WILLIAM GREEN, president of the American Federation of Labor, appear to be based on some misconceptions of the nature of the law and are not, for the most part, well considered.

LONDON, Nov. 27. -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden today again gave Belgium assurance of Great Britain's military support in the event of attack and he coupled that promise with an unmistakable warning to Germany not to repeat her blunder of 1914 in thinking that Britain would not fight.

TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 27. -- The convention of the American Federation of Labor, as it closed two weeks of sessions here today, voted a demand for a Federal law providing a thirty-hour week. It refused to ask amendment of the Federal Constitution to permit labor and social welfare legislation and to curb the Supreme Court.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27. -- Hogs sold steady to 15 cents a hundred pounds higher here today, with most light and underweights up 10 to 15 cents, while most other weights were 5 to 10 cents higher. Sows were mostly steady. The price of pigs was unsettled, offerings comprising a fair percentage of the total receipts.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today a summary of seventeen additional registration statements filed recently under the Securities Act of 1933 as follows:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- To reimburse its treasury for the payment of about $10,000,000 in dividends that were declared to avoid penalties of the Federal undistributed profits tax of 1936, and to add to working capital, Montgomery Ward Co., Chicago marl order house, filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering the issuance of 652,143 shares of no-par common stock, and 4,565,004 stock-purchase warrants.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 27. -- Current efforts to discard established business principles and to seek a new economic Utopia make the immediate future of marketing "confused and uncertain" and may result in the "negation of all market education and training'' members of the American Marketing Society, in annual conI vention at the Hotel Claridge here, i were warlaed today by two of their past presidents.

A national campaign for an amendment of the Federal Constitution clearing the way for State minimum wage laws was recommended yesterday by the minimum wage conference organized by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner.

The judge, jury and prosecutor in the Drukman conspiracy trial last Summer were charged yesterday with misconduct by Henry G. Singer, former Assistant United States Attorney, who was one of the three defendants convicted of conspiracy to obstruct justice in the murder.

ROME, Nov. 27. -- A small Italian column under Colonel Malta yesterday morning marched into Gore, in Western Ethiopia, which Premier Benito Mussolini once called the seat of the Negus's phantom government, and occupied the town in the name of the King of Italy and Emperor of Ethiopia.

Barney Ross weighed 143 1/4 pounds, two less than Izzy Jannazzo, for their world welterweight championship fight at ladison Square Garden last night. The referee was Johnny McAvoy and the judges Charles Lynch and Marty Munro.

SAN PERLITA, Texas, Nov. 27. -Little hope that the bodies of Luther Blanton and his son would ever be found on the King ranch was held out today by the family when they were notified by officers that the two men arrested earlier in the week had been released.
MADRID, Nov. 27. -- An overcast sky again today brought respite from Insurgent air raids. The lull in military operations around Madrid is giving time for government plans to mature elsewhere.

Judging by the ever-increasing attendance at football games this season and the consequent substantial gate receipts, Alma Mater, far from being a nourishing mother to her children, is feeding quite lustily upon them.

LONDON, Nov. 27. -- The strength of the British pacifist movement was again demonstrated tonight at a huge mass meeting in Albert Hall held under the auspices of the Peace Pledge Union, headed by Dick Sheppard, otherwise the Rev. H.R. Sheppard, Church of England clergyman, who is well known here as a pacifist.

Most futures in the commodity markets were higher yesterday. Cocoa, rubber, hides, coffee and cottonseed oil were strong. Sugar futures eased and other staples were mixed. On the cash markets wheat, cotton, lard, rubber, flour and cocoa advanced, while corn, oats, eggs, silk and standard tin declined.

BERLIN, Nov. 27 (AP). -- Carl von Ossietzky, Nobel Peace Prize winner, who for more than three years was a concentration camp prisoner, said today he hoped to testify anew to his pacifist faith in a speech accepting the Nobel award at Oslo.

Contracts covering wages and working conditions for officers and seamen on two American flag lines operating in the coastwise service were signed yesterday by representatives of four unions, three of which are on strike in the Atlantic and Gulf ports.

Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey signed an order yesterday requiring the All American Bus Lines, Inc., an operating company, and twenty-one other defendants who acted as ticket agents to show cause on Dec. 11 why they should not be enjoined from selling tickets of the corporation at less than the tariff rate posted with the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Testimony to refute the allegation of Joseph Mercadante, shipper, that he was unaware until February, 1928, of the financial relationship of the Empire Trust Company and the individuals from whom he borrowed money and to whom he contends he paid bonuses and excessive interest was offered yesterday in the Supreme Court.

You close the editorial "Motor Cars and the Roads" by observing: "* * * through an extension and modernization of American highways which are still, to far too great an extent, thirtymile-an-hour roads for eighty-mile-an-hour cars and twenty-mile-an-hour drivers."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- There was a substantial increase in trad-
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Nov. 27. -- Democracy and smiles caught the fancy of the press here this afternoon.

The Appellate Division, by a three-to-two vote, denied yesterday the unusual application of District Attorney Dodge for a writ prohibiting Supreme Court Justice Steuer from signing an order in an ambulance-chasing case developed by Bernard Botein, Assistant District Attorney in charge of the new Accident Fraud Bureau.

The stock market benefited considerably yesterday from the generally encouraging news over the Thanksgiving recess. The closing was strong, with the leaders up 1 to 4 points, a few doing even better than that. Total transactions on the Stock Exchange reached 2,280,000 shares, the largest turnover since Nov. 19.
