SHANGHAI, Saturday, Nov. 28. -- Mrs. William H. Harkness Jr. of New York spent hours late last night and early this morning in the customs detention office of Shanghai's Bund caring for and bottle-feeding a 5-week-old giant panda after customs officials had prevented her sailing for America on a technical charge of attempting to remove the animal without a shipping permit.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 27. -- Under a new contract with Paramount, signed this week, Carole Lombard is to make three pictures a year at $150,000 each. The first will be "Show Business," which Fannie Hurst will write. The cast will include Bing Crosby and Randolph Scott.

The Treasury yesterday estimated $2,281,659,000 as the excess during 1935 and nine months of 1936 of foreign capital sent during the period to this country over American capital invested abroad. But that does not measure, as is sometimes imagined, purchases on our Stock Exchanges.

Being tired of the plays they presented on Tuesday, Noel Coward and Gertrude Lawrence put on three more at the National last evening, expecting to keep interested in them until Monday, when the third bill is scheduled to go on. Although this column had few scholarly objections to the opening bill, the current one is eminently superior in the compactness, variety and versatility of Mr. Coward's scribbling.

The Dunbar Apartments at Seventh Avenue and 149th Street, one of the largest housing projects for Negroes in the world, were taken over at auction yesterday by John D. Rockefeller Jr. on a bid of $1,857,000.

BOSTON, Nov. 27 (AP). -- The New England Council in a survey released on Thanksgiving Day, said "the business outlook for the immediate future is good." Business in the region covered during October was approximately 10 per cent above the same month a year ago and higher than in any October since 1929, the council found.
MONTE CARLO, Nov. 27. -- Sir Basil Zaharoff, Europe's mysterious armament salesman, whose name has been linked with major wars and Latin-American revolts, died today at 86.

ROME, Nov. 27. -- The American woman, seen through the eyes of an Italian woman, is a creature apart from her Europeann sister, but admirable nevertheless. Such is the conclusion of Miss Daisy di Carpenetto, Italian novelist, based on her observations during an American tour.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

MOSCOW, Nov. 27. -- Readiness of the Soviet in the Far East, which Joseph Stalin has described as "one of the hearths of war," was proclaimed by G.N. Krutoff, president of the executive committee for the Far Eastern region, at today's session of the Congress of Soviets, meeting in the Kremlin Palace.

An alignment of religious, educational, health, business and real estate interests with the liquor industry with a view to "preserving intelligent liquor control and of arousing articulate, informed public opinion" on the liquor question was announced here yesterday by Colonel Ralph C. Tobin, president of the Retail Wine and Liquor Guild, Inc., who said it marked the first time such groups had cooperated with the liquor industry on its problems.

As practically anybody might have foreseen, the eminently successful "Stage Door," in which G.S. Kaufman and Miss Edna Ferber extol the simple satisfactions of life in the legitimate as opposed to the lucrative humdrum of Hollywood, has been bought for the screen.

The importance of defending academic freedom and intellectual liberty against Fascist oppression the world over will be discussed at a dinner to be given next Monday evening by 150 leading American liberals, together with the exiled German and Italian scholars of the Graduate Faculty of Political and Social Science of the New School for Social Research in honor of Dr. Fernando de los Rios.
From the morning of Thanksgiving Day until yesterday afternoon the local postoffice reported that more than 250,000 Social Security forms, SS-5, signed by employes, had been returned.

A plan to organize city, State and Federal civil service employes in the city into a Cooperative Housing Association to foster the construction of cooperatively owned apartment houses to rent for $11 a room was outlined to department heads and representatives yesterday at a meeting in the State Building.

ARNOLD GENTHE, the distinguished photographer, is one of the latest of our contemporaries to write down stories from his life. The book is called "As I Remember" (John Day: Reynal Hitchcock, $5) and is sumptuously illustrated with more than 100 of his pictures. The pictures will delight any one who has ever handled a camera.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- Lessons in sales technique, with special instructions for women prospects, were expounded today before the Securities and Exchange Commission as it studied the Independence Fund of North America, Inc., of New York, pioneer investment trust selling on the installment plan.

The American Foreign Power Company, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the twelve months to Sept. 30 operating revenues of $55,445,630, compared to $54,951,325 for the previous twelve months, and net revenues from operation of $22,610,896, compared to $22,550,547.

BERLIN, Nov. 27. -- The Boerse was still inactive today, bringing out little material. Heavy industrials and foreign stocks were affected by profit-taking, but Vereinigtesthal, Siemens Halske and Deutsche Eisenhandel gained one-half point each.

Convicted on Wednesday of smuggling watch movements and diamonds, David J. Goldsmith, a member of the Diamond Dealers Club of New York, was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Robert A. Inch to serve four years in a penitentiary and to pay a $5,000 fine.

To the accompaniment of the hum of machinery, described as "the music of American prosperity," leaders of industry participated yesterday in a nation-wide broadcast in which they revealed evidence of recovery throughout the land.

Rumors current yesterday in the financial community that an advance of 15 cents a barrel in the price of crude oil in the Mid-Continent fields would be announced within a day or two were considered premature. Although an advance is believed to be in the offing, the amount and the time when it will be made are considered as unpredictable as the coming of the Spring rains.

The letter from George Fester Peabody takes exception to your recent editorial on the subject of Chairman Mahaffie's speech in Atlantic City on the present status of the railroad problems; it also takes exception to his suggestion that the interest charges on prior lien bonds be reduced.

The members of the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company seem to like it here, just as Broadway appears to favor their version of Gilbert and Sullivan. Those things being so, the Martin Beck yesterday announced that its visitors, instead of going home in the middle of December, will remain for three more weeks, departing only after the performance of Jan. 2.

New bond financing this week totaled $93,510,000 and represented five general classifications. This is compared to $102,233,000 in new bonds marketed last week and with $58,531,900 a year ago this week.

Cass Canfield, president of Harper Bros., newly, returned from his annual trip abroad, brings news of authors working in England and France. Rose Macaulay is working hard on a new novel, "I Would Be Private," which she hopes to complete in time for publication this Spring.

The Chicago Pneumatic Tool Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the quarter ended on Sept. 30 a net profit of $307,195, including profits of approximately $35,000 earned in foreign countries having restrictions on exchange and after deducting Federal income taxes, depreciation, interest and discount charges.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 27. -- A very bad impression has been created in government circles by private reports from Vienna concerning the meeting there Tuesday for the formation of an Austrian anti-Communist league.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Nov. 28.-- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, China's dictator, and Governor Yen Hsi-shan of Shansi Province, jointly issued today a remarkable appeal addressed to the Mongol and Manchukuoan forces that have been attacking Suiyuan Province.

LONDON, Nov. 27. -- Germany and Italy again found themselves isolated from the rest of Europe today when the main subcommittee of the international non-intervention group considered ways and means of controlling traffic in war material across the frontiers of Spain.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- All ranks of official and resident society were represented, and debutantes from many parts of the country were in the receiving line at tonight's annual Black and White Ball at the Mayflower Hotel.

LONDON, Nov. 27. -- Stocks here again were cheerful today, with substantial gains in most departments. British Government issues advanced fractionally. Renewed demand sprang up for iron and steel shares which had slumped heavily in the past fortnight.

It is not wholly pleasant to think of one important election treading hard on the heels of another, yet it is not too soon to begin preparing for the choice of a Mayor of New York next year. A few months ago the outlook for the municipal campaign of 1937 seemed discouraging.

A record for speedy erection of skyscraper steel was claimed by the Rockefeller Center interests yesterday when the last beams were riveted into place on the framework of the thirty-six-story office building which will be the eleventh unit in the midtown commercial and amusement center.

With the pace of Christmas holiday shopping moving distinctly faster yesterday, and with heavy sales volume expected today, retail trade here this week has been rolling up gains over last year in keeping with expectations. Department store executives estimated volume for the week at 15 per cent or more above the sales for the comparative 1935 week.

Triumphing on their home courts over the Bayside Tennis Club, 4 to 1. the City A.C. representatives moved into a first-place tie with the Harvard Club in the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League Class C team competition last night.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $8,426,380, representing ninety-eight municipalities. This compares with $8,179,836 awarded this week. The weekly average of offerings for the year to date now is $26,978,966.

Now that Thanksgiving has passed and nothing of sensational import looms on the immediate nocturnal horizon, eyes are turning hopefully toward Christmas and what it may hold. So here is a star entry for the date books: the new revue at the French Casino, which will be called the "Folios Bergeres of 1937," will have its tinseled premiere on Christmas night, after the theatre.

The excess of member-bank reserves over requirements fell $60,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $2,210,000,000, according to the weekly Federal Reserve reports, published yesterday. The decline was principally due to the large withdrawals of currency from the banks preceding the Thanksgiving Day holiday.

William A. Brady, theatrical producer, announced last night that he would continue to oppose the plan of reorganization for the Baldwin Locomotive Works and currently before the courts. He maintained there had been a general misinterpretation on the part of the press as to the effect of a special master's report on acceptances to the plan.

In expectation of continued improvement in general business, the Great Northern Railway will spend $30,000,000 for improvements and maintenance in 1937, according to St. Paul advices quoting W.P. Kenney, president. Mr. Kenney described as "very bright" the chances for enactment by Congress of a law to repeal the clause in the Interstate Commerce Law which prevents railroads from charging more for haulage between two points than the sum of charges between the points.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27. -- Army and Navy meet here for the thirty-seventh time tomorrow and the largest crowd ever to witness a football game east of Chicago will pay close to $500,000 to see the unrivaled spectacle of the gridiron. The kick-off is set for 1:30 and will be preceded at 12:15 by the parade of the 1,600 West Point Cadets and the Navy regiment of 2,300 Midshipmen.

Stockholders of Sears, Roebuck Co. approved yesterday an increase in authorized capital stock from 5,200,000 to 6,000,000 shares. They held a special meeting in the company's offices at 360 West Thirty-first Street. There are 4,876,593 shares outstanding.

With a cargo of toys and trinkets to be traded for facts and friendship in Dutch New Guinea, the schooner-rigged yacht Chiva sailed yesterday from her East River pier in command of Captain Frederick E. Crockett, Harvard graduate and former dog-team driver in the Antarctic with Admiral Byrd.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 27. -- The Northeast Field Hockey Association tournament and umpires' conference began this morning at Vassar College. Fourteen games were listed for the school's field, and between luncheons and meetings the association umpires will attend instruction conferences at Kenyon Hall.

The responsibility for abolishing the "Hell Week" of fraternity "horseplay and hazing" was placed upon local college authorities in a resolution adopted unanimously yesterday by the National Interfraternity Conference at its twenty-eighth annual session in the Hotel Commodore.

Pledges of cooperation in restricting consumers in access to showrooms maintained by wholesalers and manufacturers of rugs have been obtained from jobbers and mill executives, Philip Bermont, executive secretary of the Associated Metropolitan Retail Floor Covering Dealers, announced yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 27. -American high school education is softening and degenerating, Dr. John L. Tildsley, Assistant Superintendent of New York City Schools, told the fiftieth annual convention of the Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools at Chalfonte-Haddon Hall here today.

Engagements of $7,010,000 of gold abroad for shipment here were reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank. Of the total, $2,386,000 was engaged in Canada, $1,813,000 in England and $2,811,000 in India. The gold obtained in London, which actually was bought on Thursday, brought to $127,000,000 the total of gold taken in that market for United States account since the suspension of the gold standard by France on Sept. 26.

In selecting a Rose Bowl opponent for the Pacific Coast entrant, the committee makes every effort to pick the outstanding team east of the Mississippi. Why does not the committee exercise the same diligence in choosing the Pacific Coast representative?

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The volume of all transactions and of member trading declined on the New York Stock Exchange in the pre-election week ended Oct. 31 compared with the previous week, according to the report of daily transactions published today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 27. -- Assistant Secretary of State Sumner Welles reported to the other United States delegates today that a long interview he had with Dr. Carlos Saavedra Lamas, the Argentine Foreign Minister, last night had brought out the unity of purpose and viewpoint of the Nobel Peace Prize winner and Secretary of State Cordell Hull regarding the objectives and methods of the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace, opening here Tuesday.

WILLIAM F. CAREY, Sanitation Commissioner, has modestly promised to do a "fairly good job" of snow removal this Winter. He would be able to do a better job if he had more up-to-date equipment. While he is waiting for that equipment -- and even after he gets it -- property owners can do a great deal to help him with his task by assuming their legitimate share of the burden.

Extra. special, regular and other dividends declared yesterday amounted to approximately $14,000,000. This estimate lifted the total for the month to date to $781,500,000, which is a larger amount than for any full month on record.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 27. -- The Eastern racing season will come to an end tomorrow with a program featured by the $5,000 added Bryan and O'Hara Memorial Handicap, in which Roman Soldier is scheduled to run. This fellow is the handicap star of the Maryland season, having won the most important race for older horses at each of the previous three local meetings this Fall.

A goal by Paul Grabarino in the last thirty-eight seconds enabled New Utrecht High to gain a 3-3 tie with the strong Jamaica sextet in the feature match of the second of a series of weekly city P.S.A.L. hockey games at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

Marked improvement in sentiment was reflected in bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Speculative interest assumed the leadership, however, as the advance among the second-grade rails, convertible industrial issues and better grade utility bonds was resumed on a broad scale.

Anita Dorfmann, a Russian pianist who studied in early years with Leschetizky and later with Phillippe, and who has given concerts and appeared with various orchestras, in Europe, made her debut last night in the Town Hall. She opened her program with a delightful sonata of Galuppi which constituted a fortunate departure from the average cut-and-dried arrangement of music for a piano recital.

SEATTLE, Nov. 27. -- The University of Washington received "the best news we've had for a long time" -- official notification that its Huskies would represent the West in the Rose Bowl -- today and turned to consideration of an opponent for the football classic.

David B. Costuma, Republican member of the Board of Elections, advanced evidence yesterday which he says shows that the trip to Ohio which his fellow board members plan for Monday to study at first hand the workings of proportional representation in Cincinnati and Toledo is nothing but a "junket."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- Public testimony by the country's leading railroad men and private bankers concerning railroad financing, reorganization and the relation of eighteen of the nation's largest roads with leading private banks was presaged today by an announcement by Senator Wheeler that his subcommittee of the Interstate Commerce Committee, which has investigated these matters for a year and a half, would start hearings on Dec. 7.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 27. -- Lee Parsons Davis, Supreme Court justice-elect, and his family were "embarrassed," he said at his law office here today, on their recent European trip to find themselves unable to answer questions by Europeans about New York.

President ROOSEVELT'S address yesterday in Rio de Janeiro, before the joint session of the two houses of the Brazilian Congress, was a felicitous response to the enthusiastic welcome of a country and a people with whom the United States has an unbroken record of friendship of more than a century.

A small but interesting exhibition of paintings, including one of the last works by the late Charles Demuth, never before exhibited, opened yesterday at An American Place, to continue through December. For the occasion Alfred Stieglitz selected canvases by Marsden Hartley and Georgia O'Keeffe, wafor-colors by John Marin, an abstract design on metal by Arthur Dove, and some small recent decorative paintings on glass by Rei becca Strand, wife of Paul Strand, photographer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The volume of American industrial output increased seasonally in October, with steel production larger than in any other month since 1929, and there was a substantial rise in employment and payrolls, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

In a unanimous ruling yesterday, the Appellate Division reversed a decision of Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman and reinstated two suits for more than $11,500,000 brought by the trustees of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company against Edward N. Brown, chairman of the board of the railway; six partners in Speyer Co. and eight partners in J. W. Seligman Co.

The welterweight crown rests just as securely on Barney Ross's brow this morning as it ever did. The black-haired champion from Chicago risked his title in a fifteen-round bout with Izzy Jannazzo at Madison Square Garden last night and experienced no trouble whatever in protecting it from the bid made by the New York fighter.

The Bank of Montreal reported yesterday for the year ended on Oct. 31 total profits of $3,181,501, after appropriations to contingent fund, compared with $3,005,212 in the preceding year. This year's profits were equal to 4.18 per cent on the bank's capital, surplus and undivided profits.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 27 (AP). -- Firemen, answering four alarms, fought tonight to protect two large gas tanks from a spectacular fire which destroyed the factory formerly occupied by the Candee Rubber Company in the downtown industrial district.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 27. -- A move to void the indictment of Ellis H. Parker, chief of Burlington County detectives, and his son, Ellis H. Parker Jr., charging them with conspiracy in the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel, former Trenton lawyer, was made in Federal court today as they were scheduled to plead to the indictments.

The Hudson Trust Company resold to the 480 Palisade Avenue Corporation two five-story, thirty-family brick apartment houses known as the Victory and the Stevens, with a group of one-car garages in the rear, at 480-86 Palisade Avenue, northeast corner of Nineth Street, West New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- A report approving the evacuation of Madrid by the United States Embassy staff was received by the State Department today from Eric C. Wendelin, third secretary in charge of the embassy, as the department sent him a message of commendation for his "excellent work."

While several hundred protesting members of the WPA Teachers Union picketed WPA headquarters at Columbus Avenue and Sixty-second street and later the headquarters of the United States Chamber of Commerce, 420 Lexington Avenue, the Works Progress Administration went ahead with its plan to lay off 19 per cent of the workers on the local Federal Art Projects.

Columbia and Stanford, Rose Bowl opponents in 1934, but now far removed from that status both geographically and athletically, will clash at the Polo Grounds this afternoon at 1:30, with a crowd of 50,000 expected to watch the renewal of the rivalry. It should be a spectacular game.

Perhaps the nicest thing about the middleaged gentleman who has written 70,000 letters to the newspapers since he left college is that he found time on the side to write to his mother. Filial devotion does not always go hand in hand with public service.

The Will Rogers Memorial Fund is being incorporated in this State to assist needy theatrical, variety and motion-picture people. This was learned yesterday when a certificate of incorporation was submitted to the State Department of Social Welfare for its approval.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 27. -The text of President Roosevelt's address today to the Brazilian Congress follows:

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Nov. 27. -- Receiving an enthusiastic welcome from 300,000 Brazilians who lined the capital's streets despite an unpleasant rain, President Roosevelt today pledged the United States against any invasion of its sister republics to the south in an address before a joint session of the Brazilian Congress.
Jacob D. Goodman has bought for occupancy a four-story dwelling at 151 West Eighty-second Street from the St. Agnes Hospital for Crippled Children of White Plains. Pease Elliman were the brokers.

The recently opened Decorators Picture Gallery, Inc., 554 Madison Avenue (entrance on Fifty-fifth Street) is directed by Mrs. Ward Cheney and Mrs. Artemus L. Gates, The directors have arranged for their opening exhibition, which will continue until Jan. 16, four rooms, each of them designed to provide appropriate settings for groups of selected canvases -- work by a single artist chosen, in every instance, to furnish the keynote.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27. -- Restoration of Valley Forge to make it appear to twentieth century visitors just as it did while Washington and his army were encamped there during the Winter of 1777-78 is to be undertaken by the Valley Forge Park Commission.

BOSTON, Nov. 27. -- More than 40,000 are expected at Fenway Park tomorrow for the annual game between the Boston College Eagles and the Holy Cross Crusaders. The Worcester team has the better record this season, having beaten Colgate and held Temple to a field goal.

PARIS, Nov. 27. -- Rear Admiral Cary T. Grayson of the United States was re-elected today for another four-year term as president of the League of Red Cross Societies by the board of governors at the close of its sixteenth session here.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard construction of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday made a move toward setting a date for the world heavyweight championship bout between James J. Braddock and Max Schmeling. The board served notice to the Twentieth Century Sporting Club and the Aadison Square Garden Corporation, associated in the promotion of the bout, to name a date for the show within two weeks.

BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 28. -- Louisiana State University won the Southeastern Conference title for the second straight year and bolstered its Rose Bowl hopes by stampeding through Tulane in today's renewal of their 43-year-old football rivalry, 33 to 0, before a crowd of 48,000, that smashed the Southern gridiron attendance record.

GIJON, Spain, Nov. 28. -- The government announced today in a communique that an offensive, in which dynamiting by Asturian miners played a major role, had been launched on the northern city of Oviedo in Asturias Province.

THIS story, in one form or another, has practically become a yearly fixture of these pages on this particular Sabbath in the calendar. For it is the annual journalistic salute to the birthday of that hardy dramatic perennial, that dean of Broadway attractions, that unflagging theatrical surprise, the one and only "Tobacco Road."

Dr. Angell bids us yield some rights, but it is not a question of yielding rights so much as it is a question of interpreting responsibilities. The essence of American democracy is embodied in the principle that a citizen cannot be arbitrarily prevented by superior force from performing a responsibility or duty, and then charged in a court of law with the failure to perform that duty or responsibility.

DURING late Fall and Winter, when Mexico's tourist season is at its height, visitors who take the orchid route can view a vast variety of the delicate flowers. Most of these plants bloom from October to February over a wide area which leads not only through Mexico, but into Central and South America as well.

WARSAW, Poland, Nov. 28. -- Poland cannot take part in any agreement between Germany and Japan, Colonel Nieczenaky, vice president of the Sejm and close friend of Foreign Minister Josef Beck, declared today in the semi-official Gazeta Polska.

SOUTH AMERICA, host of President Roosevelt and the Inter - American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace, which opens in Buenos Aires next Tuesday, will he the objective this Winter of an increasing number of tourists.

IT took but two or three years for this extremely popular volume to reach these shores from Germany via England. In the migration it changed from "Du und die Natur" to "You and the Universe" and now it is merely "The World Around Us."

WHEN the George Washington Memorial, the Blue Ridge, and the Natchez Trace Parkways are completed in the South, the motoring vacationist will have more than 1,000 miles of hard roads on the three danger-lessened scenic routes.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 28. -- Double B., brown gelding, triumphed today in the six-furlong sixth race at the Fair Grounds. Bachelor Dinner, which led most of the way, finished second, with Compensatory third.

SO much has been written regarding Elizabethan literature in general, and concerning every noteworthy Elizabethan author in particular, that it would seem difficult, if not impossible, to add anything of value at this late date. Yet Esther Cloudman Dunn has given us a volume which presents an interesting if not entirely novel point of view and which adds many percipient individual comments to the library of Elizabethan criticism.

HERE is another story the scene of which is laid in "Wessex," the Dorsetshire first made familiar by Thomas Hardy and since exploited by John Cowper Powys through a series of novels of which this is the latest. "Wolf Solent," "A Glastonbury Romance" and "Maiden Castle" do not, however, form a sequence.

COLOR is undergoing a test at Selznick International that will determine to a marked extent its immediate future. While this altitude has been quite generally expressed with each new venture, until recently color has been experimental and has reflected such imperfections that no acute industry or public interest resulted.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- This resort has been enjoying good weather for golf, tennis, riding, quail shooting and field trials. Each day has seen devotees of these outdoor sports taking part in their particular pastime.
NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Nov. 28. Charles S. Ashley of New Bedford is the man who would be Mayor, and was.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Nov. 28. -- Through a reciprocal arrangement among Bryn Mawr College, the University of Pennsylvania and Haverford College, graduate students in each of these institutions are taking work at the others this year. Swarthmore College also is a party to the agreement.
The luxury market these days is a boom market. Estelle Hamburger, vice president of Jay Thorpe, Inc., so averred the other day at a luncheon for fashion experts, adducing as evidence:

UNDETERRED (or perhaps incited) by the abstraction shows of last season and the deluge of recent exhibitions with a distinctly modernist French tendency, four painters whose names are well known to New York gallery-goers are showing this week at the Delphic Studios.

THE reader will be disappointed if he comes to this book in the belief that it is really a discussion of liberty -- of liberty, that is, in, the traditional sense of the term. For the whole purpose of the volume, as I understand it, is to prove that under capitalism liberty is impossible, and that under socialism it will follow as a matter of course.

Books about prehistoric life have a strong attraction for young readers. Too often the characters in these stories seem to be modern human beings masquerading in the wolfskins and armed with the weapons of their early ancestors, but in "In the Stone Age" the author, a student of anthropology, consistently draws the persons of his tale as inhabitants of the Paleolithic Age of which he writes.

PARIS. THE Paris concert calendar for the coming season, although foreshadowing a probable decrease in the number of concerts by individual soloists, gives promise, none the less, of many varied and interesting programs.

Leading by only three points with three minutes to play, the St. John's University five was forced to the limit to defeat a strong alumni aggregation, 40 to 32, in its opening game of the season before 500 in the De Gray Gymnasium, Brooklyn, last night.

BERLIN, Nov. 28. -- The unemployment problem in the United States will soon be a thing of the past, according to a study of American economic conditions issued here by the government-controlled Reich Credit Association. This bank, which enjoys a European reputation for its statistical studies, paints a rosy picture of the present condition and the immediate future of American business.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 27. -- The sudden death of Oris P. Van Sweringen this week has not caused the so-called Van Sweringen rail "empire" to slide toward disintegration. On the contrary, the passing of the second and more forthright of the Cleveland real estate brothers who had a dream of a Midwestern railroad and industrial baronage served chiefly to call attention to a previous change in ownership of the empire.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Nov. 28. -- Announcing that the reorganization of the welfare relief administration under county supervision had virtually been completed, Welfare Commissioner Irving Williams said today that a cut in the office clerical staff, effective on Tuesday, would result in an annual saving of $30,000.

Except for the Battle of the Marne in 1914 there have been few more surprising rallies in history than the sudden spurt of resistance shown by the government forces in Spain against General Franco. Franco's troops had driven the Loyalists right back to the gates of Madrid.

THE TIMES printed news item from Washington, headed "Age of Wind Power Forecast by Lincoln," which states that Lincoln was delivering his lecture on "Discoveries and Inventions" to lyceums around Illinois "just before his election to the Presidency," giving the impression it was during the Summer of 1860.

VIENNA, Nov. 28. -- Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg's speech in Carinthia Thursday night has aroused much anger among the Nazis and extreme Nationalists in Austria. He declared one of the three great enemies against whom Austria must fight was the Austrian Nazi movement.
With this agreement, our Fuehrer and His Majesty the Emperor of Japan have accomplished a historic deed, which only future generations will appreciate in its full significance.

Bonds continued to move upward yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange under the leadership of the second grade and convertible issues. The trading pace was fairly brisk, sales amounting to $8,885,000, compared with $7,122,000 on the preceding Saturday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 28. -- Eight colleges from seven different States are represented on Rutgers University's 1937 football schedule announced today by George E. Little, director of physical education.

Mr. and Mrs. George F. Baker gave a dance last night at their home, 75 East Ninety-third Street, for Miss Priscilla St. George, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George B. St. George of Tuxedo Park, who will be married to Angier Biddle Duke on Jan. 2.

Scholarships in New York University's Graduate Department of Fine Arts for the first term, 1936-37, have been awarded to eighty teachers of art and staff members of museums in the New York area by the trustees of the Carnegie Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of New York University.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 28 -- The "two-way trade fair" to be held next May in the Port Authority Building in New York City concurrently with the observance of foreign trade week in the United States was approved in principle by the membership of the Association of Secretaries of Foreign Chambers of Commerce at an informal discussion today on the Steamship

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 28. -- Notable in a collection of New Haven magazines and newspapers of the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, now being exhibited at the Sterling Library of Yale University, is an example of the youthful enterprise of Samuel Woodworth, author of "The Old Oaken Bucket."

A radio patrol car speeding in response to a call about 10 o'clock last night struck a car in Jamaica Avenue near 110th Street, Richmond Hill, Queens, then crashed into a parked taxicab. The car struck first by the police automobile careened about the road and then crashed through the doors of a near-by real estate office.

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 28 (AP) -- The first skirmish between the Federal Government and twenty-three of the nation's major oil companies over an indictment charging conspiracy to fix gasoline prices will be fought here Tuesday in the court room of Judge Patrick T. Stone.
MANCHESTER, England, Nov. 28. -- A. Boazman's Newtown Ford today won the Manchester November Handicap, with C.W. Gordon's Sea Bequest, second, and A.E. McKinlay's Latoi, third.

The Fascist generalissimo in Spain, Francisco Franco, has declared his intention of enforcing a blockade against the Loyalist seaboard along the Mediterranean. In so doing he assumes the rights of a belligerent to cut off access of ships carrying contraband of war to hundreds of miles of coast and the great Catalonian seaport of Barcelona.

PARIS, Nov. 27. -- Smart and comfortable travel gloves are composed of alternating vertical strips of leather and hand-knitted mercerized cotton or wool, in same tone. These strips are about finger-width.

KALGAN, China, Sunday, Nov. 29 (AP). -- Chinese reports trickling in here from the snow-buried fastness to the northwest today said Manchukuoan and Mongol legions were massing for a counter-drive against Suiyuan's victorious defenders.
In the heart of Columbia County, N.Y., near the village of Ghent, is a 200-acre farm where there are no horses -- but three elephants.

LONDON, Nov. 28 (Canadian Press). -- Thirty football teams await the draw for the second round of the English cup competition after successfully hurdling obstacles today in the first round proper of the race that ends at Wembley early in May. Eight clubs figured in draw games and replays will be held during the week.

Funeral services were held yesterday for four of the five Brooklyn men who died from carbon monoxide fumes Tuesday night in the hold of the motorship Empire State at the foot of Dupont Street, Brooklyn. The fifth man, William Faise, 39 years old, of 115 State Street, will be buried on Monday in Mount Olivet Cemetery, Maspeth, Queens, following services at 2:30 P.M. at the Cronin funeral parlors at 115 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn.

Advocating the establishment of an industrial research division in the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, Dr. Alexander V. Dye, bureau director, said yesterday that such an agency could render invaluable service through intensive research into the fundamental problems of business.

The tempering of the political party system with the town meeting idea was urged by George V. Denny Jr., manager of the Town Hall and associate director of the League for Political Education, in a foreword to the annual report of those institutions, made public yesterday.

The annual Groton School-St. Mark's School holiday dance In behalf of the Summer camps maintained by the two schools for underprivileged city boys will be held on Jan. 1 in the ballroom of the Pierre. Mrs. James B. Baldwin heads the executive committee for the benefit and Miss Camilla Moss is in charge of the sale of tickets.

As a civilian with no military experience, it might be held presumptuous to address myself to the problem that follows from the article, "German Expert Finds United States Tanks Would Not Stand Test of War." But as one who has a fairly extensive background in the literature of warfare, that apparent deficiency becomes less important.

THE artists who will join the Metropolitan Opera this season are beginning to arrive. Vina Bovy, the Belgian lyric and colorature soprano, reached New York last week and has taken an apartment for the Winter. She will be on hand for the entire fourteen-week season. She may make her debut during the first week.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- It was a bitterly disappointed group of boys who fought their way through the crowd today and made their way to the Army dressing room. They seemed still dazed by the sudden turn of fortune which had upset them after their great fight.

MOSCOW, Nov. 27. -- The German-Japanese anti-Communist treaty which the Soviet insists masks a secret military alliance against U.S.S.R., has intensified the already bitter feeling with which Germans is regarded in this country, and has revived the resentment against Japan which for a long time had been quiescent.

The return of fraternity house management to active student officers was recommended yesterday by A. Blair Knapp, director of the council on men's affairs at Syracuse University, at the closing session of the National Interfraternity Conference in the Hotel Commodore.

MONTREAL, Nov. 28. -- Little Roy Worters allowed a harmless-looking slide shot to ease past his stick tonight, giving the Montreal Maroons their margin in a 3-2 National Hockey League victory over the New York Americans.

THOSE who speak on the radio are drifting "toward an alarming state of affairs," according to Professor T.H. Pear of London, who reports in "The Listener," journal of the British Broadcasting Corporation, that under the glare of television's lights "talkers will have to talk."

A FOUR-DOOR car-locking device was demonstrated here last week, which is now made available to automobile manufacturers by the Houdaille-Hershey Corporation, one of the large makers of automotive products. The simple movement of the control handle on the right front door insures a quick, positive locking of all doors.

CANDY kettles are boiling at top speed and the multitude of stores that sell sweets are preparing tempting displays for holiday buyers. America has always been credited with a sweet tooth; indeed, the statistics show that the per capita consumption of candy each year is about fourteen pounds.

DETROIT, Nov. 28 (AP). -- The 1,200 men on a "sit-down" strike in the Midland Steel Products Company plant here laid in food supplies today for the week-end. Their leaders may ask for a conference Monday with company officials on wage demands.

LONDON. In the western world the people of Great Britain continue to be the greatest of tea-drinkers. Official statisticians recently found that the inhabitants of the United Kingdom consumed 441,500,000 pounds of tea in 1935, or 9.42 pounds per person -- eclipsing all previous British records.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP). -- Preparations for another Congressional battle over the New Deal's reciprocal tariff-reduction treaties are being made at the State Department.

Santa Claus comes back to Russia this year. Moscow's mail-order house has lately begun using the old bourgeois idol in its advertisements of children's toys and Christmas tree decorations. It was only last year that Christmas trees received their first official approval, although as "a New Year's decoration" and without reference to Christmas.

CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 28. -- Sir Henry Somer Gullett, Minister without portfolio, introduced a bill ratifying the trade treaty completed yesterday with France. Australia will grant to France most-favored-nation treatment and will apply an intermediate tariff on ninety-six items such as fancy goods, perfumes, chemicals, soaps, textiles, apparel and other manufactures while reducing duties on seventy-two items.

The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, has received as a gift from Walter P. Chrysler Jr. two collections of Surrealist books, material and memorabilia -- the Paul Eluard collection and the Dr. Camille Dausse collection.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- Provision for rolling up food reserves that would keep Britain supplied for a year in case of war were put under way today when the new Food Defense Plans Department was formed. At the head of it was put Henry Leon French, one of the most experienced of British experts in this field.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- Retail sales in local department stores were substantially affected by the strike against five of the leading Market Street stores, which ended Tuesday night, but were still approximately 10 per cent ahead of the corresponding week of last year.

EDDIE CANTOR, confident that television is not so far away, plans to cast aside the radio script next season and memorize his lines, as the first step toward preparation for radio-sight. In New York on a visit from the West Coast, the comedian warns that the entertainer who does not "keep an eye on television will be left in the lurch."

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- Wild turkey, pheasant and grouse are the chief game hunted in the mountains about Hot Springs just now, since the season for them closes tomorrow. Quail may be shot up to Dec. 15 and bear, rabbit and squirrel throughout December.

Out in the Milky Way blaze countless stars against a black canopy. Astronomers have detected a faint, pearly glow in the blackness. Dust is the interpretation. There is more in the sky than the stars.

The foreign exchanges continued yesterday to strengthen in terms of the dollar, and no further engagements of gold abroad for shipment here were reported to the Federal Reserve Bank. The Netherlands guilder rose 2 points more to 54.31 cents, the highest price in about two months, but forward quotations, which had been rising with the spot rate, weakened, the discount on ninety-day futures being increased from 17 to 23 points.

Directors of the Radio Corporation of America declared yesterday a dividend of 87 1/2 cents a share on the $3.50 cumulative convertible first preferred stock, payable on Dec. 26, making a total of $1.75 to be paid on this stock this year.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 28. -- Accepting a challenge to justify the existence of fraternities as social units on the modern university campus, 350 delegates from Greek letter organizations at twenty-five Eastern colleges and universities will join in an interfraternity convocation at Syracuse University from Thursday to Sunday next week.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 28 (AP). -- Branch Rickey, vice president and general manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, indicated today that Pitcher Dizzy Dean might be traded within the next two weeks.

An important Autumn Job often overlooked is that of cleaning up and putting away garden tools. Neglect of this simple chore means not only tool replacement at a much earlier date than would otherwise be necessary but also loss of time, and more laborious and less satisfactory work when one uses them again in the Spring.

More and more Westchester and New Jersey women are finding that the game of paddle tennis, a comparatively recent development in sports, provides just the exercise they want during the Winter months. They can play it outdoors -- snow can be swept easily from the 60x30 wooden platform and rain dries quickly -- and they can have plenty of fun plus lots of exercise while still novices at it.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 28. -- Retail sales in the Eighth Federal Reserve District have soared and reports from department stores indicate increases in excess of 30 per cent over last year, with a strong demand for higher-priced goods. Highly optimistic predictions are being made on Christmas trade.

COMMODIOUS Pullmans of the air, cruising at 225 miles an hour, with luxurious overnight accommodations for twenty passengers, are possible in the near future, according to Dr. Jerome C. Hunsaker, in charge of mechanical and aeronautical engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and George J. Mead, vice president and chief engineer of the United Aircraft Corporation.

EARLY any morning, between the middle of December and April, the American passenger on the Arlberg express, which has just pulled into the little Tyrolese mountain station of St. Anton on its way to Paris, may see a sight both unexpected and interesting.

SALAMANCA, Spain, Nov. 28. -General Francisco Franco will give orders for a decisive effort to take Madrid as soon as the rain ceases, according to officers close to the Insurgent high command. It is reported General Franco is not disposed, for military reasons to grant the enemy any respite beyond that imposed by the weather.

Mrs. Lester Kissel heads a group of members of the New York Junior League who will act as ushers at the dinner to be given by the Students International Union on Wednesday at the Plaza. The dinner has been arranged as a tribute to three Americans who have made the greatest contribution to world cooperation during the last year, and their names will be announced at the event.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28. -- Holiday trade moved sharply ahead after Thanksgiving under the stimulus of several heavily advertised special sales by large department stores. The crowds made the main floor aisles at times almost impassable. Buying was heaviest in toys, men's furnishings, gift novelties and apparel accessories, with home equipment lines and more expensive women's apparel running nearer normal volume.

SAINT-JEAN-DE-LUZ, France, Nov. 28 (AP). -- Severe fighting on the northern Spanish front was reported today, with government armies claiming successes that endangered Insurgent strongholds in the Bay of Biscay sector.
THE by-product of twelve years as a cattleman in Argentina, Brazil and Paraguay, mostly Paraguay, is here made into a keenly readable account of a roving Englishman's life on the range.

IN this autobiographical volume, it may be said at the start. Joseph Freeman seems to have told, well and honestly, how a certain type of young American passes through the rebel and romantic stage into that of the Communist discipline.

Representatives from Norway, Sweden, Austria, Germany, Canada and Switzerland will form the cast of one of the most spectacular indoor shows ever attempted when the Madison Square Garden's Winter Sports Show and International Ski Meet is held Dec. 9-12.

The plight of 1,227 families forced to move from properties to which the city has taken title for the westerly approach to the Triborough Bridge in the Bronx has been complicated by a sharp rise in rents in the surrounding area, an Emergency Relief Bureau survey showed yesterday.

THE NEW YORK TIMES referred this morning to an excellent statement by Professor Henry De Wolf Smyth of Princeton regarding the intellectual and material contributions of pure science. This subject was also discussed in a letter to the editor by Professor E.U. Condon of the same university.

THE Cadek Choral Society, under the direction of J. Oscar Miller, will open its season in Chattanooga on Tuesday evening, Dec. 8. The program will consist of Rossini's "Stabat Mater" and Grieg's "Olaf Trygvasson." The soloists will be Ora Witte, soprano; Pauline Pierce, contralto; Arthur Bailey, tenor, and Gean Greenwell, bass-baritone.

Grand Central Parkway Extension from Horace Harding Boulevard to the Long Island Railroad, a link in the new World's Fair traffic artery from Grand Central Parkway at Kew Gardens to the Triborough Bridge, must be lowered to conform to the level of the surrounding World's Fair site in Flushing Meadows, Queens, it was disclosed yesterday.

THE Gilbertian definition of the subtle art of "piping," as the newspaper folk call it, was something about "adding verisimilitude to an otherwise bald land unadorned narrative." "Piping" a story, filling in with flights of pipe-dream fancy the stretches where the facts are meager, or perhaps uninteresting, is a precarious occupation, one that should be practiced by none but wise and experienced heads.
Displaying a closely knit man-to-man defense, the Brooklyn College varsity five turned back a strong alumni combination, 33 -- 18, at the Lawrence gymnasium last night.

The annual junior dinner dance under the direction of Miss Adeline King Robinson will take place on Dec. 23 in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria. In the absence of Miss Robinson, Mrs. Huntington Tappin will represent her at the dance.

SEATTLE, Nov. 28 (AP). -- The University of Washington's opponent for the Rose Bowl football classic at Pasadena New Year's Day will be announced next week, Ray Eckmann, director of athletics, said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP). -- Seeking to obtain wider observance of labor standards like those embodied in the defunct NRA, officials here are considering asking Congress to expand the scope of the Walsh-Healey act.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 28 (AP). -- Newton D. Baker, who directed the nation's greatest military effort, approaches his sixty-fifth birthday without political ambition and believing that he is "more useful" as a private citizen.

The foreign political news last week was no less disturbing than in the week before, and the European markets continued to be dominated by this influence, but our own markets were mainly concerned with domestic affairs. With respect to the share market, opposing factors, whether the topics be credit control or inflation, were about a standoff.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Nov. 28. -- Alaska sourdoughs, who once took fifty-five-day musher trails over frozen tundra, relax in airplanes now and cover the distance in a few hours.

The Winter sports season in transatlantic travel was begun yesterday when the Gdynia America liner Pilsudski departed with a group of passengers bound for the ski and hockey centers at St. Moritz, Zakopane and other continental resorts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The 688 guards who patrol government buildings in Washington, with their officers, are being turned into practical fire-fighters in order to protect in every way possible the valuable property of the Federal establishment.

Readers using public libraries in America's largest cities are apparently growing more serious-minded. During the past five years their borrowing of non-fiction books has increased more than 21 per cent, while their borrowing of fiction has gone up only 1 per cent.

ISLIP, L.I., Nov. 28. -- Carl B. Danielson, 47 years old, chauffeur for Mrs. Morgan Belmont of 434 East Fifty-seventh Street, New York City, was killed at about 5 P.M. today. The Belmont car was struck by a west-bound Montauk-Jamaica express train at the Islip Avenue crossing of the Long Island Railroad.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 28. -- The fact that "scientific" polls of public opinion made the best record for forecasting the Presidential election is a tribute to marketing research, Archibald M. Crossley, head of Crossley, Inc., said today to members of the American Marketing Society and National Association of Marketing Teachers at the concluding session of their joint convention in the Hotel Claridge.

The fear that if war comes in Europe the Atlantic may not be a barrier adequate to protect the Americas unless they draw closer together, and the gratitude for the "good neighbor" policy have created an atmosphere which for the first time in many decades gives real basis for hope that large steps may he taken toward making Pan-Americanism a potent force for cooperation in this hemisphere and for peace in the world.

With Winter in the offing, the home-owner's thoughts turn to the protection of his lawn -- which perhaps he has struggled all Summer to get into good condition -- against possible injury during the coming cold months. Yet, contrary to general belief, lawn grasses have no need for coatings of manure or mulches of leaf mold, peatmoss or humus.

AS study of a currently insoluble problem Dr. Raper's book is part of the ephemera of our social evolution, but it is not on that account to be ignored, for with fresh approach and in eminently readable form it casts light on our knowledge to date.

While much depends on the form in which he submits his plan, the announcement of Representative Patman that he will sponsor a measure in the next session of Congress to eliminate "loss leaders" is likely to evoke little resistance from the rank and file of retailers, according to views expressed yesterday.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 28 (AP). -- The engagement of Rosa Ponselle, Metropolitan Opera soprano, to Carle A. Jackson, son of Mayor and Mrs. Howard W. Jackson, was announced here tonight.

THE most elaborate and comprehensive highway safety program ever devised for Pennsylvania was inaugurated last week by the Governor's Highway Safety Council under the direction of Secretary of Revenue John B. Kelly, who is executive vice chairman.

THE creation of an American zone of sanity in a mad world -- that is the sizable task confronting the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace, which opens next Tuesday at Buenos Aires. The prestige and promise of the meeting are enhanced by the presence of President Roosevelt: the conference was called at his suggestion, and with the cordial accord of the twenty Latin-American Presidents.

The college basketball season, which was opened last night, steps off in fuller stride this week with twelve local games scheduled. None of them ranks as being particularly important, merely regular early-season games, with the favorites firmly established in advance.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Nov. 29. -- Unless unforeseen complications arise, Mrs. William H. Harkness Jr. of New York will sail for Seattle on Wednesday aboard the liner President McKinley with her baby giant panda. Shortly before noon yesterday the woman explorer was permitted to take the rare animal to a hotel, where proper nursing was possible, but only after friends had assisted her in posting a heavy cash bond at the custom house.

Possibility of a repercussion in this country from the tumult in Buenos Aires last week among delegates to the People's Conference in Favor of Peace appeared remote yesterday, in the composite opinion of leaders of large organizations of women here.

Heavy mail orders last week called for rush shipments of merchandise, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. Retailers anticipated substantial volume gains for the month of November, with dress, coat, house furnishings and main floor departments all showing excellent activity. cellent activity.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The national automobile racing championship for 1936 was awarded to Mauri Rose of Indianapolis tonight by the contest board of the American Automobile Association, governing body of the sport.

The first sixty-two railroads to report earnings for October showed an aggregate gain of 17.1 per cent in net operating income. Gross revenues and net operating income of these companies, compared with the totals in October of 1935 and 1924, with percentage gains, three ciphers being omitted, are shown in the following table:

Meet Red Lacy, private detective. He is the chap who is too tough to die, as those who oppose him learn to their sorrow. He runs a one-man detective agency, and he makes it pay so well that every now and then he seriously contemplates taking a trip to Bermuda and points south with a blonde, and each time it is a different blonde.

BROWNSVILLE, Texas, Nov. 28. -- The authorities were making plans today to reach into the little city of Villa Juarez, Mexico, to bring Guadalupe Salinas Garza back to this country in the hope that he might give information that would help solve the mysterious disappearance of four men in the huge King ranch in Willacy County.

IN the course of its thirty-fourth annual convention, just concluded, the American Automobile Association adopted a bill of rights for the motorist with the avowed object of assuring full and free use of the automobile with the maximum of safety and the maximum of economy.

Retail trade in the local area continued to forge ahead notably last week as the stores entered the most active period of Christmas shopping. Department store trade here was estimated by executives as averaging 15 per cent or better than in the comparative 1935 week.

Professor DeWitt Clinton Poole of the School of Public and International Affairs of Princeton University will be the principal speaker Wednesday at a luncheon conference on "Trade Developments at Home and Abroad" to be held by the New Jersey State League of Women Voters at the L. Bamberger store, Newark.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 28. -- The Masquers, Amherst College dramatic organization, will open its 1936-37 season in College Hall Dec. 10-11 with a production of "Green Grow the Lilacs," by Lynn Riggs, rehearsals for which are now going on under the direction of Professor Curtis Canfield, with Ralph C. McGoun as technical adviser.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- The plan of the Valley Forge Park Commission to restore the 1777-78 Winter camping ground of Washington and his army was attacked as "unhistorical" today by Dr. Ellis Paxson Oberholtzer, historian and former member of the commission.

I am glad this matter came up and I accept this as I would a challenge, because I feel this is one time where the customer is not always right. When Mrs. Weatherbee asked to purchase two seats she was offered two in the fourteenth row, the best we had in the box office at that time.

Assemblyman Homer Zink, member of the New Jersey Relief Commission, and Samuel S. Kenworthy, secretary of the State League of Municipalities, will discuss the relief situation in New Jersey at a meeting on Friday of the civics and legislation committees of the Contemporary of Newark.

COLUMBUS, Nov. 28 (AP). -- A test of how far the government can go in compelling States to adhere to its standards for social welfare workers may develop in a suit which has blocked the Ohio Civil Service Commission from selecting social workers.

EAST ISLIP, L.I., Nov. 28. -- Okanagan Sandy, Labrador retriever dog, owned by Jay F. Carlisle of the Wingan Kennels of East Islip, and handled by David D. Elliot, late today was awarded first place in the non-winners stake, opening event of the annual retriever field trial meeting of the Brookhaven Game Protective Association.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 (AP). -- The Navy took the Army today, but tonight both took Philadelphia.

PRETORIA, South Africa. -- The reduction of the public debt of the Union of South Africa by $115,000,000 in a single year has been announced by the Treasury. The annual report of the Public Debt Commissioners for last year shows that the period was one of large-scale financing, involving the raising of over $110,000,000 in loans and the repayment of old debts of more than $225,000,000.

Angelo Trulio, New York A.C. four-wall ace, has drawn first place in the metropolitan handball rankings for the third successive season, according to the 1936 list announced yesterday by Arthur M. Wehrmann, chairman of the national A.A.U. handball committee.

THREE generations of imbeciles is enough," remarked the late Justice Holmes in an oft-quoted decision of the Supreme Court which upheld the constitutionality of Virginia's sterilization law. If the eugenic issue were always as plain as it was in the case on which he had to write, there would have been no need of these carefully weighed findings of a distinguished committee.

ALBANY, Nov. 27. -- The four-year-old Port of Albany is now on a parity with Baltimore and Philadelphia in the North Atlantic freight structure. The Interstate Commerce Commission directed the railroads, which heretofore had practically denied the existence of the port so far as rates were concerned, to reduce their rates on export, import and coastwise shipments to the Philadelphia level.

ON the day that the 16-year-old Phil Dunning hung over the side of the Middletown boat a long time ago, waving farewell to his parents who had driven him over from Meriden, Conn., it is likely his head was in the clouds.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 28 (AP). -- The Joint Legislative Committee to investigate mineral waters of the State prepared today to review its two years' work at a New York City meeting on Dec. 15 after receiving a report offering the White Sulphur Company of Sharon Springs for State development at a "reasonable" price of $1,250,000.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28. -- The technique of disintegrating the nucleus of the atom with high-speed, electrically charged particles and the effects of this process occupied the attention of 250 scientists at the closing session today of the American Physical Society.

LAMBERTVILLE, N.J., Nov. 28. -- In a competition which was pronounced one of the keenest of the year by the judges, Trex of Chancefield, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Squires of Norwood, Mass., scored a brilliant victory today in the $75 open all-age English springer spaniel stake.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- With the stock markets closed today, money conditions were quiet and with them was small demand for credit at one-half of 1 per cent. Bill rates also were steady, with three-month funds quoted at nine-sixteenths of 1 per cent.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Nov. 28. -- A revolt of the Calderon Artillery Regiment and an attack on the presidential palace in Quito with the support of a few civilians was reported in extra editions of Guayaquil newspapers tonight.

Remembering tales of enforced goat riding by "victims" of another year, new members to be inducted at a luncheon meeting of the Organized Women Legislators of New Jersey at Essex House in Newark on Saturday have little hope that they will fare better.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 28. -- In a game played in a driving snowstorm, Yale today outscored the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, 6 to 1, at soccer. The players were unable to hold their feet and repeatedly slid in attempting kicks and defensive play.

A.L. Burns was the major winner in the shoot over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. He led with 91 out of 100 targets in the contest for the high scratch cup at sixteen yards. The score was excellent, as high winds made the conditions exceedingly difficult.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 28 -- A 9-year-old boy who was playing on newly formed ice at lower Barbour's Pond, on New Street in West Paterson Borough, was drowned about 4 o'clock this afternoon, together with a passer-by who attempted a rescue.

FEW men have so consistently reported the news from China as accurately as Hallett Abend, The New York Times correspondent. He has at times been denounced as anti-Chinese, as pro-Japanese, as pro-Chinese and anti-Japanese.

Hugh Redwood, author of the book, "God in the Slums," and religious editor of The New Chronicle of London, addressed an open-air meeting conducted by the Salvation Army last night at Broadway and Forty-eighth Street. It was his first public appearance in this city.

THE Yiddish theatre, which has been reported dying so often that its oldest critics yawn at the mention of a new prostration, is showing more life this year than one of its youngest critics can remember. When, before the season opened, he was told that there would be three Yiddish companies on Broadway -- a record number -- he was a bit doubtful that they would materialize.
BELGRADE, Nov. 28. -- University students' organizations here today sent to Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch a strong protest against a rapprochement with Italy.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Nov. 28 (AP). -- A wage increase for more than 1,000 employes of the local plant of the J.K. Mosser Leather Corporation was announced today. Similar increases for workers in all other Pennsylvania plants of the company will bring the total rise to more than $100,000 a year.

Puccini's "La Boheme," the second in a series of operas by that composer, was presented yesterday afternoon at the Hippodrome Theatre by Alfredo Salmaggi and his company before an audience of 3,000. In the evening 5,000 filled the old Sixth Avenue house for the revival of "Samson and Delilah."

Cecil B. De Mille, producer and more recently a master of ceremonies in radio programs in which motion-picture stars are heard, declared yesterday that in his opinion there never had been any good reason for the feud between the radio and movie industries over the appearance of screen celebrities before the microphone.

On the estate of W. Averell Harriman at Sands Point next Saturday and Sunday will be held the annual meeting of the Long Island Retriever Field Trial Club. This will be the concluding competition of the year for retrievers of all breeds, including Chesapeake Bays, Labradors, flat, curly-coated and golden retrievers and Irish water spaniels.

When the Supreme Court last week, by a 4-to-4 decision, declined to overturn the New York State Unemployment Insurance Law, proponents of New Deal social-security measures took new hope that the constitutionality of such laws would be sustained in further court tests.

JONATHAN SWIFT stood at the threshold of the modern era. That he denied the prospect was no less his tragedy than that the crumbling Augustan age refused him comfort and honor. He loved the virtues of courtliness, yet hated the feudalism from which they sprang and the Papist Stuarts who had safeguarded them in England. He admired the aristocracy, yet labored for the political advancement of the merchant class.

STUBBORN, serene and sure, he lived his life solitary among his fellows, forever outside the world of men. He never saw men, his daughter says, "except 'as trees walking.'" He never really knew the children he had begotten.

Mayor La Guardia yesterday called upon the Municipal Civil Service Commission to act favorably on his plan to place the Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity on a civil service status, a proposal which has been termed contrary to the law of the State.

Mrs. Henry Ford and Mrs. Truman H. Newberry of Detroit and Mrs. John D. Rockefeller Jr. are among delegates who will attend the annual meeting tomorrow of the World Service Council of the Y.W.C.A. -- an event which shares interest at headquarters with the luncheon to be given on Tuesday in honor of Miss Lucy P. Carner, who is resigning after sixteen years with the national board.

The promotion and appointment of 119 students enrolled in the basic courses in the Department of Military Science and Tactics in the City College was announced by Colonel Oliver Prescott Robinson, chairman of the department and officer in charge of the college unit of the Reserve Officers Training Corps.

THIS substantial volume adds finis to the Laurentian canon. It contains seventy pieces collected from magazines, reviews and introductions to books, sometimes in a different form. There are also two long pieces -- one on Hardy and one on popular education -- and twenty-five short pieces that have not hitherto been published.

More than half of the $4,054,000 distributed among the ninety-one agencies affiliated with the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City to meet their functional budget for 1936 goes for the care of children, it was pointed out yesterday by Mrs. Sidney C. Borg, chairman of the women's division of the federation.

Manhattan's football team will bring to a close its most successful campaign when it meets the powerful eleven of Texas A. and M. in Tyler, Texas, on Saturday. This game, which marks the opening of a home-and-home relationship, will take the Jaspers further afield than ever before.

Rulers of modern countries that seem to thrive on the persecution of minorities face the fate of the Romanoffs and the Hapsburgs, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday afternoon to the 20,000 delegates attending the convention of the National Labor Committee for the Jewish Workers in Palestine, held at the Manhattan Opera House.

The New York Rovers defeated the Baltimore Orioles yesterday afternoon in an Eastern League hockey game in Madison Square Garden, 4 -- 2. It was one of the most exciting games seen in the amateur ranks in several seasons.

ATLANTIC flying will make its debut between here and the United States shortly, according to W.J. Howard Trott, M.P., chairman of the airport committee, who has supervised the erection of a complete seaplane base on an island in the Great Sound, just outside Hamilton Harbor.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Nov. 28. -- Thirty-nine students have won membership in the Glee Club of Briarcliff Junior College, here, it was announced today by Miss Sally Heedy, the chairman. They were chosen at voice trials held by a student committee under the supervision of W.A. Haesener, director of the Westchester Little Opera Company, who is coaching the club this year.

IT is Raymond Massey who will produce that "And Now Goodbye," which, until just a fortnight ago, was held with great expectation by Elsinore's Mr. Howard. The London branch of the Curtis Brown office, agents for Philip Howard -- he made the dramatization from one of James Hilton's books -- cabled in considerable excitement last week that probably the play would be done in that metropolis during the early Spring.

Forced to sleep on an open porch, despite the freezing temperatures, or face a tumbler bombardment, John Reichel, 46 years old, a tailor of 3,566 Bronx Boulevard, the Bronx, haled his wife, Matilda, 36, into magistrate's court yesterday on a charge of cruelty to husbands.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Nov. 28. -- A three-man expedition arranged by the Fogg Museum of Harvard University has returned to this country with photographs of rare Buddhist and Hindu frescoes found in Afghanistan, India and Ceylon. The expedition, which returned to New York on Nov. 17, consisted of Dr. Benjamin Rowland, Professor of Oriental Art at Harvard; Bailey Vanderhoef of Greenwich, Conn., professional photographer, and Townshend Johnson, 21-year-old Harvard senior.

The Lafayette Guild of the Maternity Center Association will be the beneficiary of a bridge party, tea and fashion show to be held on Dec. 7 at the Waldorf-Astoria. Miss Ruth Boyd heads the debutante committee, whose members are the Misses Patricia Schepps, Mirium Harriet Brown, Mary Johnston and Dorothy Gerster.

ONE of the most important and monumental Greek sculptures of the second half of the fifth century B.C. ever to come to this country has been acquired by the Worcester Art Museum through the Brummer Gallery. It is a funeral stele in Pantellic marble, decorated in high relief with the life-size figure of a Greek warrior.

Standing in the foyer of a bedroom on the second floor of her home, Antoinette Lombardo, 18 years old, of 1,559 West Tenth Street, Brooklyn, between Avenues O and P, was shot in the back and wounded critically at 6 o'clock last night by a rifle bullet that had come through a window.

POSTMAN'S HOLIDAY: Postmaster General James A. Farley went to Ireland to rest from the political campaign, but didn't stop meeting political figures. In one day last week he accepted a gift (a copy of the Farley family coat-of-arms) from former President Cosgrave and a banquet from Mr. Cosgrave's arch-political rival, President de Valera of the Irish Free State.

BENNINGTON, Vt., Nov. 28. -- With snow already covering the Bennington College campus, and predictions of more to come, the Bennington Ski Club announced today tentative plans for the season's activities. Members will participate in Winter sports events in Lake Placid, Brattleboro, Vt., Tuckerman's Ravine in the White Mountains, and other ski centers in Vermont, New Hampshire and New York.

TESTS of a new two-way police radio system in Boston have led the engineers of the General Electric Company, who installed the equipment, to announce, "Boston is now the major city in which it is most difficult for criminals to operate."

AT the Walker Galleries, 108 East Fifty-seventh Street, a first anniversary exhibition is now in progress. It opened on Tuesday and will be current until Dec. 15. Paintings by twenty-one artists have been placed on view.

GENEVA, Nov. 28. -- Both the British and the French Governments are very embarrassed and annoyed by the Spanish Government's appeal to the Council of the League of Nations invoking action against "the armed intervention of Germany and Italy" in the civil war, according to the impression received in the Secretariat.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Nov. 28. -- In an attempt to promote stimulating discussions between faculty members and students outside of classroom work, The Colgate Maroon, university newspaper, is sponsoring a series of informal lecture forums at two-week intervals for the remainder of the college year.

Fifteen men, fourteen of whom were charged with disorderly conduct and the other with bookmaking, were arrested yesterday afternoon when the police raided a store on the ground floor of a tenement at 401 East Seventieth Street, at First Avenue.

As the first month of the national seamen's strike reached its end yesterday without apparent possibility of immediate settlement, the New York Board of Trade appealed to Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins to recognize the existence of a national emergency.

First results of the Federal survey of consumers' purchases, now being conducted by white-collar workers taken from the relief rolls by the Works Progress Administration, are expected to be announced about Dec. 15, according to information received here yesterday.

Announcements last week of bonds called for redemption before maturity were not as numerous as in the preceding week, due possibly to the Thanksgiving Day holiday. However, some of the individual calls were for substantial amounts of bonds.

DUBLIN, Irish Free State, Nov. 27. -- One of the most significant indications in the changed and more accommodating relations developing between the Irish Free State and Great Britain is the marked change in the personal attitude of Eamon de Valera, President of the Free State's Executive Council, toward the latter country.

With the cutting away of the late blooming plants in the final Fall clean-up of the garden the beds look bare indeed. The pruning back or the removal of such sprawling plants as chrysanthemums and petunias leaves empty spaces that will be a problem during the Spring and early Summer next season.

MADRID, Nov. 28. -- British members of Parliament visiting Spain to observe war conditions issued a communique today urging immediate large-scale action by neutral powers to succor the inhabitants of Madrid.

For the gardener who has a moist location, suitable for a bog or swamp garden, many native plants are available. Such plants may be obtained from their natural haunts, but most of them are sold by nurseries. Among these plants are arrowhead, pickerel weed, golden-club, calamus, cattail, bur-reed, marsh marigold, water arum, and pitcher plant.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- Thirteen government agencies awarded 19ihty-one contracts, valued at $3,929,217, under the Walsh-Healy Public Contracts Act during the last week, the Labor Department reported today. Those from New York, unless otherwise designated, were as follows:

CANBERRA. THE great gray pile of masonry which will be Australia's memorial to her dead in the World War is now fast rising on the tree-covered slopes of Mount Ainslie at Canberra, the national capital.

BERLIN, Nov. 27. -- Good or bad, the high command of the Third Reich insists on doing things on a big scale. The proportions and intensity of the hate-the-Soviets campaign which has been going on here since Alfred Rosenberg, Joseph Goebbels and Chancellor Hitler led the brilliantly staged anti-Soviet outbreaks at the Nuremburg party congress cannot well be imagined by any one who is not living here.

Chapter X of the new Soviet Constitution guarantees to every citizen a job at fair pay. But it does seem at times that along with the right to work in Soviet Russia there goes the right to be shot for sabotage.

TRADITIONAL is a term that, in the opinion of John Taylor Arms, applies much more aptly than does the term conservative to work sponsored by the Society of American Etchers, Inc., of which he is president. Those who visit the twenty-first annual show put on by this group, current at the National Arts Club through Christmas Day, may well be disposed, to agree with Mr. Arms on that point.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Alaska, which for decades tolerated gambling as an essential part of the gaudy era, has turned at last against the professional gamester.

LONDON, Nov. 28 (Canadian Press). -- The Archbishops of Canterbury and York reject the doctrine of full pacifism. In a statement issued today from Lambreth Palace, they condemn wars of aggression but in their opinion "circumstances might arise in which participation in war would not be inconsistent with their duty as Christians."
