NINE years ago this month Pascal Covici, then a Chicago publisher, brought out "The Golden Book," a history of printing and book-making, by Douglas C. McMurtrie. About a year and a half ago Mr. McMurtrie decided to revise this book which had gone through many editions.

IN the latter part of the nineteenth century a group of picturesque and scholarly adventurers lived in England. These knights of the itching heel -- with an unflurried calm and pertinacious purpose -- sought danger and suffered hardships in the four cornets of the earth, and returned to write of their experiences with great distinction.

The average college student graduates ignorant of everything except textbooks and finishes his college course illiterate, according to E.C. Kyte, librarian of Queens University, Kingston, Ontario. Speaking yesterday at the twenty-fourth annual conference of Eastern College Librarians at Columbia University, Mr. kyte suggested that the college librarian must add to his other duties the work of guiding the alumnus in reading because that alumnus fails to take advantage of reading opportunities in his undergraduate days.

REFERRING to a recent suggestion that sculpture be permitted to play a larger role in the scheme of life, Doris Krazis, chairman of the public use committee of the Artists Union, writes us the following letter:

LONG drawn out and artlessly unfolded, there are recounted here the adventures of British Secret Service agents hunting down the leaders of a powerful international drug syndicate, the prevailing scene of action Port Said, for the conclusion shifted to Istanbul.

Paintings by old masters, nineteenth century European and contemporary American artists, will be sold at auction at the American Art Association -- Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Thursday evening. Paintings from the collection of John McCormack, singer, will be sold, together with property from the residence of the late Mabel Gerry Drury and of F. Saxham Drury, from the estate of Carll H. DeSilver and from other owners and estates.

Modern college girls are taking their keynote from the present social, political and economic crises and interesting themselves in national and international problems, according to a survey at Hunter College of eight extracurricular organizations devoting time to the discussion of world affairs.
SEATTLE, Nov. 28 (AP). . -- The whipping post, with lashes for women as well as men, became an issue in Washington State today.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 28 (AP). -- Spurred by the scheduled early closing of the barge canal, salvage operations on four barges sunk or damaged along the waterway were speeded up today.

Into the highways and byways of the Empire State emissaries of the Committee on the Education of War Orphans of the American Legion Auxiliary will penetrate with the hope of filling the quota of scholarships, provided for by the New York Legislature at its most recent session, by the time enrollment for the 1937-38 college year begins.

AT this time of the year the Boy Scouts step into one of their most important roles -- that of assistants to Santa Claus. After school and over week-ends they are busy repairing and repainting toys that will be given to thousands of poor children.

Last Wednesday evening two memorable events occurred in Moscow. (1) The Eighth Congress of Soviets met to adopt Russia's new Constitution, considered one of the most important moves since the Bolsheviki seized power nineteen years ago. (2) Joseph Stalin made a speech, said to be the second of his career as dictator.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 28. -- Baltimore's first and second field hockey elevens lost to crack Philadelphia squads, 8 to 0 and 9 to 0, respectively, in two of the four games of the southeast intercity tournament at the Bryn Mawr School today. Teams from these two cities, Washington, Harrisburg, Pa., and the States of Virginia and New Jersey competed.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 28. -- Registering the strongest interest in the social sciences recorded in recent years by the dean's office, nearly 40 per cent of Harvard's upper-class men this Fall are majoring in the study of history, government or economics, it was revealed today.

BOSTON, Nov. 27. -- Sentiments which a decade ago might have been repudiated as surely socialistic and almost revolutionary were vigorously applauded by a representative assembly of about 1,000 New England business and industrial leaders in this city a few days since.

GEORGE DIXON SNELL is the author of "The Great Adam," published by the Caxton Printers out in Idaho two years ago. That was a striking and unusual first novel, notable particularly for the hard, accurate, unsympathetic etchings that were its characters and for the realistic picture it presented of a Rocky Mountain town of some thirty years ago.

BRUNSWICK, Ga., Nov. 28 (AP). -- Bound from Halifax to Vancouver in a twenty-three-foot sailboat with a dog for companion, Captain W.A. (Bill) Crowell of Nova Scotia headed for Cuba today after spinning a tale here of lonely suffering at sea.

Convinced that the new Congress will be more favorably disposed toward importers than those of any previous Congress in more than a generation, the traders in January will seek changes in marking, valuation and other administrative features of the 1930 Tariff Act.

Criticizing "our antiquated criminal laws," Justice Frederick L. Hackenburg of the Court of Special Sessions prophesied yesterday that the court of the future would concern itself less with the value of stolen property than with the reason for the theft.

The toll of accidents that always punctuates the shooting season and mars the mellow pleasures of Thanksgiving Day points once more the sad moral that loaded guns have a fatal tendency to go off unexpectedly in the hands of the most expert shots. That is why the ordinary citizen has a healthy fear of firearm.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 28. -- Illustrations made for Edgar Allan Poe's "The Raven" by James Boggs Beale have been lent to Goucher College by a local art dealer to help students of American literature and art when they turn their attention next week to the poet's work and that of Beale and his fellow Philadelphia artist, Thomas Eakins.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The rapidly drying Spring wheat region was said by the Weather Bureau today to be in grave danger of falling within the choking grasp of the Great Plains "dust bowl."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP). -- Senator George McGill, Democrat, of Kansas, said today that it was "wholly impracticable" for each State to set up its own farm-control program, and predicted that the next Congress would amend the Soil Conservation Act to continue Federal control.

MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 24. -- The new provisions of the Mexican business law detail the requirements that a foreign concern must meet before it can incorporate as a Mexican concern. The text of the amendments to the General Law of Mercantile Societies, covering the procedure for nationalization of such concerns, follows:

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 28. -- An old war horse who blazed his way to victory in the national open championship, stocky Tony Manero of Greensboro, N.C., put on another spectacular exhibition of shotmaking today to lead the field in the $5,000 Augusta Open Golf Tournament.

Dora Macy has written rapid-fire romances about heroines in various professions -- an "Ex-Mistress," a "Night Nurse" and a chorus girl who was rated as "Public Sweetheart No. 1." In "Riding High" she deals with the love and professional perils of a girl rodeo rider, Patsy Wyde, who with her brother Dusty competed in big-time rodeos for the single purpose of winning prize money to take the mortgage off the old home ranch in Montana.

CHRISTMAS shopping got off to a flying start in the week, with gains over last year running as much as 30 per cent in some centers. The rush of customers in Chicago, for instance, was described as near the usual peak proportion that crowds streets and jams up store aisles.

THE brilliant figure, "a beautiful and ineffectual angel beating in the void his luminous wings in vain," has so long been the accepted characterization of Shelley that it is refreshing to encounter a study of the poet which disagrees with this view.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 28 (AP). -- G.A. Tomlinson said today that he would confer on Monday with George A. Ball of Muncie, Ind., on a successor to the late O.P. Van Sweringen as head of the railway and real estate properties controlled by the Midamerica Corporation.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Nov. 28. -- Rumors that a bloc is being formed to back the creation of a League of American Nations, molded after the Geneva organization, have been widely discussed here. At the collective press conference yesterday President Roosevelt was asked his view and he indicated he did not approve the idea.

PARIS, Nov. 18. -- The presence of a new United States Ambassador in Paris adds a certain zest to the social activities that concern especially the resident Americans. In accordance with custom, William C. Bullitt, who reached Paris a few weeks ago, has sent around cards to the best known of his compatriots here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP). -- Senate investigators announced today that they planned to have three major inquiries, involving scores of industrial and financial leaders, under full speed within the next few weeks.

In recent months your columns have carried an increasing number of quotations from sermons of ministers containing attacks on communism. Many of us interested in public education have remarked with growing concern that most of these ministers use the label of communism indiscriminately.

Because a sweet, fresh wind blows in from the pampas, the founders of Argentina's capital named it Buenos Aires, which is good air. In modern, spacious Buenos Aires last week delegates from twenty-one American nations awaited President Franklin D. Roosevelt, who on Tuesday will open a conference designed to insure for the New World a good atmosphere unpolluted by the hatreds and suspicions of the Old.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- No football game in recent years has had quite the setting of the Army-Navy struggle today; at least not l in the East.

A restatement and classification of the needs of New York City children as these needs have manifested themselves to teachers and supervisors in the public schools will be made within the next few weeks.

THE Inter-American Conference, with President Roosevelt in attendance, opens on Tuesday at Buenos Aires, and the eyes of both Americas are turned to this Queen City of the Southern Hemisphere. Located at the eastern terminus of the spectacular air route over the Andes from the West Coast, and the logical objective of cruises by ship down the East Coast, Buenos Aires is certain this season to attract a record host of visitors.
SEATTLE, Wash., Nov. 27. -- A showdown at the polls between Seattle business interests and organized labor loomed as possible this week, when recall petitions were filed against Mayor John F. Dore.

THE Philatelic Agency of the Postoffice Department will celebrate its fifteenth birthday on Tuesday. Established in 1921, under the administration of Postmaster General Hays, the agency in the early years of its operations reported comparatively small sales.

TO the not entirely casual eye, Hollywood and its sisters (Culver City, Burbank, Westwood et al.) suggest a Pelham or New Rochelle Main Street in the throes of a department store anniversary week. There is bunting, gay window dressing and a search-light or two wherever a fruit and vegetable market happens to be opening.

NEWSPAPERS gave some publicity last week to the report that a Princeton student had held a bridge hand containing all thirteen cards of one suit. Such reports find their way into the papers every few weeks, and always they give rise to some discussion of the mathematical odds against holding such a combination.

IF you saw it in The Sun it was so -- whether it was a literal fact or not. Gossip does not have to be gospel truth in order to be a part of history -- a part as vital as no end of lumbering matters that clutter up the serious history books.

TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 28. -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor has the power to lift the suspensions of the ten unions affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization, but it will not do so prior to a joint conference of committees from both organizations, it was announced here tonight by William Green, federation president.

Emphasizing the State rather than the Federal angle, a new and more direct approach to solution of labor relations and fair trade questions in the field of distribution was seen in the program suggested a few days ago by the board of directors of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 28. -- The William and Mary Players will present the second in a series of four plays when "Death Takes a Holiday" will be given on Wednesday and Thursday evenings in Phi Beta Kappa Hall. Miss Althea Hunt, head of the dramatic department, will direct the show.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 28 (AP). -- A thrilling game between the Atlantic City Sea Gulls and the Hershey B'ars in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League tonight wound up in a tie at 1-all.

ON both sides of the Atlantic the television research experts assert "television is still experimental; it is also expensive." But The London Times foresees that "in five years' time we shall smile at the recollection of what we now admire."

Baseball, having remained as quiet as might reasonably be expected since the last out of the world series, will burst forth this week with the first of its series of Winter activities, designed to keep the public mindful of its national pastime until the pennant races are launched next April.

A TALENTED actress, who is a cultured woman as well, Mme. Dussane, gives us a novelized life of Moliere: "Un Comedien Nomme Moliere" (Plon, 284 pp., 15 fr.). It has a rare quality of visualized life -- truth and presentness. Moliere's vocation burst out in the placid household of his father, the King's upholsterer, with amazing peremptoriness.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 27. -- Its expectation of a record-breaking Christmas trade all but destroyed and its economic life all ready suffering a direct loss of $3,000,000 a day, San Francisco groups are organizing into a community drive to bring the utmost possible pressure on ship owners and maritime workers for a prompt settlement of the strike paralyzing coast shipping.

International complications and an ever-recurring battle among labor unions for the right to act as spokesmen of their branch of the shipping industry added last week to the muddle of the seamen's strike. With French longshoremen refusing service to American ships identified as unfriendly to the strikers' cause, a fourth "front" was added to those already created on the Atlantic, Pacific and Gulf coasts.

Much interest is being evidenced in the annual bazaar arranged by members of the Pen and Brush Club in behalf of their charitable enterprises, to be held on Dee. 10, 11 and 12 at the clubhouse, 16 East Tenth Street. In a colorful setting there will be offered for sale various useful and artistic articles, many of them made by members of the club and suitable for holiday gifts.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 28. -- Police Recorder Albert Vreeland, at the request of the Children's Aid and Protective Society, today ordered Mrs. Lorrie Laudermilk, Negro follower of Father Divine, to permit a physician to set the broken right arm of her 14-year-old son, Russell, but at a late hour tonight the compound fracture had not been put in splints.

The fifty-eighth annual meeting of the Music Teachers National Association will be held in conjunction with the annual meeting of the National Association of Schools of Music, Dec. 28, 29 and 30, in Chicago. The program includes discussions on American music, musicology, piano, voice, orchestra and choral music.

MEDFORD, Mass., Nov. 28. -- Pen, Paint and Pretzels, the Tufts College dramatic society, is operating under a new system this year designed to increase its value to the student body and the college community. Each student is required to pay a small annual fee, which entitles him to a ticket for each production presented by the society.
The American Academy in Rome has announced its annual competitions for fellowships in architecture, landscape architecture, painting, sculpture, musical composition and classical studies.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- One of the largest Saturday-night audiences to hear a Philadelphia Orchestra concert this season refused to budge tonight after Paul Whiteman had led the orchestra and members of his own band in a symphonic-jazz program nearly two and one-half hours long.

Chairmanship of the national membership campaign through which it is hoped to enroll an additional 5,000 members in the National Council of Jewish Women before Feb. 3 has been accepted by Mrs. Rebekah Kohut, one of the founders of the council.

GOSLAR, Germany, Nov. 28. -- Col. Gen. Hermann Goering's Deputy Commissar for Food Control under the four-year plan, State Secretary Herbert Backe, informed Germans today that they were still eating far too much fat for the Fatherland's good, and indicated measures were to be taken to limit their diet.

The special agents of the Department of Justice, commonly known as G men are tempting material for the writer of crime thrillers. Their work, in some of its phases, is so well known that the public is quite ready to swallow anything that is written about them.

CONSIDERING the suave blending of sight and sound that makes up such recent films as "Fury," "Bullets or Ballots" and "Mr. Deeds Goes to Town," it seems strange that the microphone should ever have been regarded as a menace to the integrity of the motion picture.

FRANCE has issued two stamps commemorating the recent 100th postal flight of French aviators across the South Atlantic. A 1 franc 50 centime blue stamp pictures a monoplane in flight above a caravel of Columbus's time which rides majestically on the crest of a wave.

The Long Island University freshmen basketball team captured its second straight game by defeating the Brooklyn Central Y.M.C.A. quintet, 33 -- 25, on the losers' court yesterday. The victors were ahead, 18 -- 7, at the half. Bill King led the collegians with eight points, while Howard Stegeman tallied eight for the Y.M.C.A.

Your article in the Sunday TIMES of Nov. 15 on those box office boys and particularly those in attendance at the theatre where "Stage Door" is playing was read with much interest by me. At the same time I raised a skeptical eyebrow at the statement that good seats could be bought if asked for far enough in advance.

THE Emperor Charles V. ruler -- by virtue of a strange concentration of inheritances -- of the Netherlands, Burgundy, Spain, Austria, part of Germany, part of Italy and nearly all of the Americas, looms so large in the history of his age that anything about him has automatically a kind of importance.

DR. EDWIN P. HUBBLE, one of Mount Wilson's famous staff of astronomers, delivered at Oxford on Thursday the last of three Rhodes Memorial Lectures. His topic was the "Observational Approach to Cosmology." Less grandly expressed, this means: What are the size and structure of the universe?

New York's glamorous festival of the fine arts, the annual Beaux-Arts Ball, will take place on Friday night at the Astor amid its traditional luxurious trappings and general atmosphere of gayety, color and fantasy. After having been quartered at the Waldorf-Astoria for the last few years, the ball is moving back to its original locale, where, until 1932, it had been held since its inception more than two decades ago.

FIFTY years ago an idea was planted in the lower East Side of New York. A young man in lodgings and six neighborhood boys formed the Lily Pleasure Club, little knowing that they were starting a movement which would take hold of the imaginations of many men and women and spread swiftly through the country.

THE COLOPHON is a quarterly all right, that is, four issues are certain to appear within the approximate space of a year. Once the first installment is published subscribers may have no fear of not receiving the remaining three.

MONTREAL, Nov. 28. -- After three years of receivership in which a series of reorganization plans has been submitted but refused by one or other of the interests concerned, the $25,000,000 pulp and paper concern Price Brothers Co., Ltd., has evolved a plan which it is thought will be approved.

ON Sept. 30, 1926, Wilfred H. Osgood, Louis Agassiz Fuertes, Suydam Cutting, Alfred M. Bailey, representing the Field Museum, and James E. Bailey of The Chicago Daily News sailed from Marseilles bound for Ethiopia to collect, paint, photograph and observe its birds and mammals.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Nov. 28. -- A reception and tea will be given on Thursday at the home of Mrs. R. Clifford Black of Pelham Manor, for Mrs. August Belmont, president of the Metropolitan Opera Guild; Mrs. Herbert Witherspoon, secretary, and members of the Eastern Westchester committee.

THE solid achievements of American aviation in the field of fundamental scientific research -- the field which, when all is said and done, has played the major part in putting the United States in a pre-eminent position in the air -- will be stressed at the dinner next Friday to be given by the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences to Dr. George W. Lewis, director of research of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics.

BERLIN, Nov. 28. -- The government decree suppressing criticism of the arts received a new interpretation today by Ministerial Director Alfred-Ingemar Berndt, the Reich's associate press chief, who told the Reich Cultural Chamber:

PARIS, Nov. 27. -- Most people in France consider fascism and Hitlerism greater menaces both to world peace and to social welfare than communism. They are not blind to the perils of the Communist doctrine as preached and propagandaed by the Comintern.

The first of the three Knickerbocker Assemblies for this season took place last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. The dances are arranged each year for debutantes of the past two or three years. Included in the list of subscribers to the Knickerbockers are several young matrons who have been married since accepting their invitations to subscribe.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 28. -- Two sustained drives in the first half gave Auburn a 13-0 Southeastern Conference triumph over the University of Florida before 6,000 fans today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 28. -- Accusations brought against General Luis Cabrera, Minister of the Interior, for the alleged unjust imprisonment of 100 Nazi leaders are being pushed in the Senate by the party.

AMERICA'S supply of games for Winter evenings is large and varied. During the depression the field was enriched by revivals or revised versions of half-forgotten games; moreover, new games were invented, many of which were distributed nationally.
Ninety-one undergraduates of the Washington Square Center of New York University have been pledged to seven fraternities for the coming year, it was announced at the university yesterday.

A luncheon and fashion revue will take place on Tuesday in the new Buttery of the Hotel Weylin as a special celebration to open the rendezvous for the Winter. Net proceeds from the occasion will be donated to the Yorkville Speedwell Unit, a health service for infants in the Yorkville district.

BOSTON, Nov. 28 (AP). -- The thirty-six-year-old battle between the three men and three women directors for control of the $3,000,000 patent medicine business founded by Lydia Pinkham went to Superior Court tonight with a master's declaration that the women have tried to force out the men.

SALAMANCA, Spain, Nov. 28. -- The Spanish Insurgent press continues to be very friendly toward the Fascist nations while criticizing France, Mexico and Peru and observing a wait-and-see attitude toward the powers that are still considered on the fence in what the Insurgents term the worldwide conflict of nationalism versus communism.

Miss Agnes Franklin Kayes head the executive committee in charge of arrangements for the annual sale for the benefit of the Cenacle of St. Regis to be held Tuesday in the main ballroom of the Plaza. A feature of the sale, which opens at noon and continues until 10 P.A., will be the tea room where luncheon, tea and dinner will be served.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 28 (AP). -- Four-year-old Emmie Wilson, who "can't stop talking," carried on his childish prattle today, growing weaker from a strange malady which baffled his doctors.

MADRID, Nov. 28 (AP). -- Artillery shells dropped near the British Embassy today and sent residents of this capital scurrying for cover as clearing skies brought a renewal of the battle for possession of the city.

MELROURNE, Australia. VISITORS to Australia are generally startled to find that railroad tracks in the various States are not of uniform width. This causes inconvenience to rail travelers because, when they reach a State line, they must change trains -- which is often in the middle of the night.

The eyes of the metropolitan skiing world will be focused upon two important meetings scheduled for next week-end. The National Ski Association, ruling body of the sport in this country, will convene next Saturday and Sunday at the Morrison Hotel in Chicago while a State-wide conference on skiing will be held at the State Office Building in Albany on Saturday.
ATHENS, Ga., Nov. 28. -- Georgia's football team, hopeless in October, capped its comeback march today by defeating Georgia Tech, 16 -- 6, before 23,000 excited fans.

A last story by the author of "Karl the Elephant," "Jungle Beasts and Men," "Gay Neck" and other distinguished books for children. Save in Kipling's "Jungle Books" the magic of the Indian jungle is nowhere made so real and vivid as it is in the stories of Dhan Gopal Mukerji.

Gardeners who read with interest last Spring that the New York Botanical Garden had sent a seed-collecting expedition to the Rocky Mountains will have the opportunity to hear a first-hand report of the results achieved at a lecture at the museum building next Saturday afternoon at 2:30 by T.H. Everett, who headed the expedition.

OMAHA, Nov. 27. -- During the first week of January Nebraska's novel experiment with a small, compact Legislature of a single house will begin its trial. Its forty-three members will replace a House of 100 and a Senate of 33.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 28 (AP). -- Members of the Amalgamated Meat Cutters Union, Local 248, went on strike today at the Plankinton Packing Company, a subsidiary of Swift Co. of Chicago. Picketing started at the company's South Side plant.

THE indications are becoming increasingly emphatic that before long the dance recital as a form will be as quaint and old-fashioned as the custom of declaiming "Curfew Shall Not Ring Tonight" for company in the parlor.

To revive and stimulate interest in entertainment in private homes the Studio Guild will present artists of the National Music League in a benefit program tomorrow night at the home of Mrs. John Henry Hammond, 9 East Ninety-first Street. The program will include Vandy Cape in her original singing satires, the Frances Blaisdell Trio, Mary Rodes, Dorothy Orton, sopranos; Benjamin de Loache, Thomas L. Thomas, baritones, and the Ionian Male Quartet.

A comparatively new combination to squash racquets, Stanley Galowin and Joseph Wiener, representing 42 Broadway Inc., was one of four teams to advance as the quarter-finals of the second annual amateur-pro invitation competition were completed at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn last night.

ALREADY a landmark for tourists in the Northwest, old Fort Snelling -- established in 1821 as a headquarters for Indian fighters -- soon will gain new interest. A national cemetery will be created at this historic spot at the confluence of the Mississippi and Minnesota Rivers near St. Paul and Minneapolis.

Beginning tomorrow, the annual Christmas sale sponsored by the occupational therapy committee of the New York Junior League will be held this week at the league clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street. Mrs. George De Wolf Wever is chairman of the committee, her assistants including Mrs. Reginald Pressprich Jr., Mrs. H.H. Reed, the Misses Katherine Marsters, Marilee Becker and Louise Lutkins.

MR. BELLOC appears here in a wee and unaccustomed role and bereft of most of his thunder. "Certainly the range, if not the variety, of his subjects is wide," Mr. Dineen admits, "although within that wide range he plays favorites, three in particular: inns. hills and the sea."

The Columbia-Stanford game set a couple of records yesterday. It was the first time that the Indians had ever played in a snowstorm, and with the thermometer dipping to 18 degrees, it was undoubtedly the coldest day on which the Californians had ever participated in a football game.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 28. -- With all the well-known American liners operating to the Orient and the South Seas idle because of the labor disputes, a number of foreign vessels are entering and leaving this port with capacity cargoes and capacity passenger lists.

AS an experiment in regional planning, the Tennessee Valley Authority, created by Congress in May, 1933, upon the recommendation of President Roosevelt, is charged with the comprehensive development of the Tennessee Valley, a region of 40,000 square miles with much depleted land and many impoverished communities.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 (AP). -- A jury today directed De Paul University to pay $2,000 on a salary contract to John Bernard Fuller, who was dismissed from a teaching post when it was learned that he was a former Catholic cleric who had abrogated his vows.

Most of the accidents of all sorts in New York City occur in the midtown area, it appears from an analysis of accident and emergency cases handled by voluntary hospitals of the city in the last year and made public yesterday by the United Hospital Committee.

Attacks on the private ownership of railroads are imminent from several directions, Harry A. Wheeler, president of the Railway Business Association and chairman of the Transportation Conference, asserted in a statement issued yesterday.

TAMPA, Nov. 27. -- Will it be peace or war in organized labor's ranks? That question, on the lips of the delegates to the fifty-sixth annual convention when they came here a fortnight ago, remained as they concluded their deliberations tonight.

The machine age has at last impinged on the voting system in the House of Representatives. The House has been equipped with a new device, a modified adding machine, which ought to save considerable and perhaps valuable time in tabulating, the vote for the Congressional Record.

Miss Marion Decker Fountain will give a tea next Thursday at her home, 1,000 Park Avenue, for a group of debutantes whose aid she has enlisted in the sale of tickets for the performance of "You Can't Take It With You," the new comedy by George S. Kaufman and Moss Hart, the night of Dec. 16 at the Booth Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the United Neighborhood Houses.

The elimination of race prejudice and religious intolerance was advocated yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, speaking as guest preacher at the Sabbath service of Central Synagogue, Fifty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue, which opened the ninetieth anniversary celebration of the congregation.

HOUSTON, Texas, Nov. 28 (AP). -- The Baylor Bears scored ten points in the final period today to defeat the Rice Owls, 10 to 7, and deadlock Texas A. and M. for third place in the Southwest football conference.

An exhibition of Dutch seventeenth century paintings, including several by Hobbema, Franz Hals, Rembrandt and Pieter de Hooch, will open on Tuesday at the Schaeffer Galleries, 61 East Fifty-seventh Street, and continue there throughout the month for the benefit of the Judson Health Center.

The signing of the Japanese-German agreement against communism directs attention again to the Communist or Third International, abbreviated as Comintern. The Berlin-Tokyo pact accuses the Comintern of interference with the internal affairs of nations and of threatening world peace.

BOSTON, Nov. 28. -- Ninety per cent of high school students read "pulp" magazines and the material contained in them constitutes a menace to the pupil's morals, his English and his mind, said Miss Anita P. Forbes of Hartford, in an address today before the National Council of Teachers of English.

THE Council on Foreign Relations has here republished an article, originally prepared by request and published in its magazine Foreign Affairs, in which Mr. Baker undertook to review, in the light of all available evidence, the course of events which led to the declaration of war by the United States in April. 1917.

With the adoption last week of a $300,000,000 school building program for 1937, the Board of Education will go forward with plans for a survey by architectural experts to determine what economies and improvements might be made in structural design.

The magnitude of international movements of capital during the recent period of monetary disorder was revealed for the first time last Friday when the United States Treasury made public a record of the flow of foreign money into this country since the beginning of 1935.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 28. -- Twenty-two alley cats were displayed today at the fourth annual championship show of the Westchester Cat Club. Many juvenile exhibitors objected to the term "alley cats," contending that their pets were equal to cats with pedigrees, but the show committee did not relent and kept the non-pedigreed animals in a row by themselves.

Babe Ruth, baseball's retired home run king, admitted yesterday that he has been considering an offer to manage the Albany Senators of the International League, but that after an hour's conference with Joe Cambria, owner of the up-State club, nothing definite had been decided.
THE "American Hour" from 2RO at Rome is back on 9.635 megacycles for the Winter. This broadcast is at 6 P.M., Eastern standard time, on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays.

TO many who feel that the complexities of our modern era are heralding the death of that era, it may be comforting to turn back to some of those complexities which ushered it into being. In 1492, when Lorenzo the Magnificent died and with him that wave of Renaissance art and humanism which stemmed from the Middle Ages, a new world was opening.

The New York Rangers and the Boston Bruins battled to a 2-2 deadlock at Madison Square Garden last night. Early in the overtime victory seemed certain for the Rangers when Alex Shibicky put them ahead with a sensational solo goal.

The Family Thrift Shop, a new permanent rummage shop for the benefit of the New York Kindergarten Association's nursery schools and kindergarten projects, will be opened formally on Wednesday at 631 Eighth Avenue.

The football year of 1936 was unusual for the abundance of fine linemen it produced. In the past, your All-America jury has had to scratch around, dig into files and cross-question scouts to get a fair line on the ends, guards, tackles and centers operating outside the members' own immediate sectors.

All knowledge of interstellar space for some time to come must proceed from further exploration of the secret of the cosmic ray, said Dr. Carl D. Anderson, discoverer of the positron, who arrived here by air yesterday on his way to collect his share of this year's Nobel prize in physics.
TOKYO, Sunday, Nov. 29. -- Virtual completion of an agreement between Japan and Italy, following the Japanese-German accord, has been made known here.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- A dwarf magnet which produces a more powerful magnetic field than any of the giant magnets now in use for the smashing of atoms was described here today before the closing sessions of the Autumn meeting of the American Philosophical Society, founded in 1727 by Benjamin Franklin "for the promotion of useful knowledge."

CARLISLE, Pa., Nov. 26. -- Although in 1786 the eleven founders of the Belles Lettres Society at Dickinson College feared that "the organization would soon sink into the greatest degeneracy and licentiousness," the organization has lived to celebrate this year its sesquicentennial of literary activity.

Whistles on craft in the lower reaches of the East River will be tied down at 9:45 o'clock tomorrow morning when, to accompaniment of cheers of the crowds ashore and the unfurling of flags, the U.S.S. Brooklyn is launched. Admiral William H. Standley, ranking officer of the navy, is scheduled to attend the ceremony in the New York Navy Yard in Brooklyn.

BERLIN, Nov. 28. -- Trading on the Boerse was quiet today. Heavy industrials were inactive, Vereinigtestahl losing 1 point and Rheinstahl 3/8. Potashes were quiet. Salzdetfurth lost 1/4 point. Machines were mixed in a small turnover; Berliner Maschinen declined 3/4 point and Orenstein Koppel 1.
The first step toward punitive action against employers failing to comply with the registration requirement of the Federal Social Security Act was taken yesterday.

ACTION by the Senate and House of Representatives in passing in the last month of the recent session a bill to establish in Washington a memorial to Thomas Jefferson not to exceed $3,000,000 in cost means that at last a suitable memorial to the author of the Declaration of Independence is to take its place in the Capital city among those which honor the memory of other great men who helped to build the nation.

Because he ignored the command of the leader of five young hold-up men to walk with other customers and the proprietor to the rear of a cigar store at 922 Brook Avenue, near 162d Street, the Bronx, early yesterday afternoon, William Edgerton, 66-year-old Municipal Court clerk, received two bullet wounds in the shoulder.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 28. -- Retail business as affected by Thanksgiving Day was said to be excellent in all sections of the Pacific Coast. Strike conditions prevail, however, and many items, particularly in luxury lines, were not moving.

BARCELONA, Spain, Nov. 28. -- The United States cruiser Raleigh, with Rear Admiral Arthur P. Fairfield aboard, and the destroyer Hatfield left Barcelona today after having taken on fifty American refugees en route to Marseilles or Nice, France.

A book of beautiful full-page photographs, showing the Indians of the Southwest engaged in their occupations expert makers of pottery and jewelry, or in such daily tasks as washing wheat, grinding corn and baking bread in adobe ovens.

ARLINGTON, Texas, Nov. 8. -- A.A. Baroni's Star Shadow took the Au Revoir Handicap, the feature at Arlington Downs today. The big 4-year-old son of Man o' War displayed a great burst of speed in the stretch and won by two lengths in a field of ten.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 28. -- A powerful Nebraska football team defeated the Oregon State Beavers, 32 to 14, in a spectacular, wide open game today before 15,000 fans. It was the Cornhuskers' fifth victory in as many games between the schools.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- With three minutes left to go in a deadlocked struggle of wasted scoring opportunities, the greatest crowd ever to see a football game in the East was thrown into an uproar in the Municipal Stadium today as Navy profited by a penalty for interference with a pass and carried the ball over from the 2-yard line to defeat Army, 7 -- 0.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 18. -- The Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace, which is to open here on Dec. 1, is expected to be the most momentous reunion in the history of the American republics. Its program has been cleared of the usual academic questions and confined to projects of immediate and vital importance to the subject in hand -- the advancement of the cause of permanent peace in the Western Hemisphere.

BUDAPEST, Nov. 27. -- "Nobody who is in Hungarian social life can avoid dueling without danger of becoming an outcast," said Dr. Franz Sarga's whose duels are causing amused curiosity abroad. While dueling is extinct in most countries, Dr. Sarga's statement is undoubtedly valid in Hungary.

PARIS, Nov. 28. -- Gold ingots and coins concealed in loaves of bread are being smuggled across the Spanish border into France, according to French customs officers in Perthus, on the Catalonian border.

THE Book Exhibition organized by The Sunday Times with the cooperation of the National Book Council is now four years old, and is evidently developing into a sturdy child. The display staged this week and next at the Dorland Hall is both bigger and better than last year's.

Up to now the scope and personnel of the feminine forum on "A 1937 Forecast for Better Living," scheduled for Wednesday and Thursday at the Hotel Astor, identified the event as probably the most important of the season on the calendar of such organizations.

ALBANY, Nov. 28 (AP). -- Seneca Indians' candidates of the "Independent Ticket," defeated by only three votes in their tribal election Nov. 3, appealed today to the white men's government to settle the issue.

Activity in the six-meter racing class of yachts already has started with the number of international events in that division, including the Seawanhaka Cup, Scandinavian Gold Cup and Scandinavian team match, scheduled for Long Island Sound next Summer.

ONE of the world's minor miracies of energy -- minor, that is compared with Niagara Falls or the Gulf Stream -- Eleanor Powell, has lately had to suffer the restraint of being ordered by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to get rid of her sports roadster and to acquire a sensible coupe with an all-steel non-crushable top.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- Miss Uytendale Emily Wayne Caner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison K. Caner Jr., of this city, was introduced to society this afternoon at a tea given by her parents at the Barclay.

WILDWOOD, N.J., Nov. 28. -- Shooting close to par golf, Jack Buchanan, Overbrook Golf Club star and Philadelphia amateur champion, won his first two matches in the fourteenth annual Wildwood Thanksgiving golf tournament today.

The Very Rev. Robert I. Gannon, S.J., president of Fordham University, will be the guest of honor at a tea and reception this afternoon in the jade room of the Waldorf-Astoria given by the Italo-American Professional Women.

Miss Pamela Brinton heads a group of debutantes aiding in plans for the Christmas sale in behalf of the Art Workers Club for Women which will e held on Dec. 8 at the Pierre. A wide variety of useful and decorative articles suitable for gifts will be offered for sale, including pictures, books, holiday cards, novelties, smocks and aprons, neckwear, early American glass, as well as homemade cookies, preserves and pickles.

To the Editor of The New York Times:Last Sunday more than 1,000 people went to Daly's Theatre to participate in a forum on the question: "Shall the Artist Survive?" On the following day the WPA in Washington answered the question with an emphatic "no."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 28. -- Ground has been broken in the Radcliffe College dormitory quadrangle for a new residence hall to be ready for occupancy next Fall. The building, fronting on Walker Street, will house seventy-two students in single rooms and will be attached to Whitman Hall by means of joint serving quarters.

PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 28 (AP) -- A two-way radio telephone with new improvements keeps scientists at the California Institute of Technology in close touch with the top of Palomar Mountain, 93 miles away in San Diego County, where the institute's astrophysical observatory is under construction.

When up-State New Yorkers start getting excited about a project of motor boating, they go the whole distance. Charles F. Chapman of New York, America's quasi "czar" of speed-boat racing because of his position as leading referee and member of the National Outboard Racing Commission, was wide-eyed with astonishment yesterday in telling about the results of a meeting in Syracuse during the week.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP). -- With the opening of Congress only six weeks away, a score of Congressional leaders are setting up the framework for a heavy legislative program.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The social security tax on workers' wages, under fire in labor and some other quarters, was defended by an administration official today as an effective control against excessive pension demands in the future.

Four young thugs assaulted a motorist in West Forty-sixth Street last night and beat him severely because he refused to pay one of their number more than a dime for "watching your car" while he and a young woman friend were at dinner.

A CONCERTO by Max Trapp will be given its premiere in Chicago by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, under Frederick Stock, this week, at that organization's eighth pair of Thursday-Friday concerts of the season. The novelty is the third work of this composer to be played by the orchestra.

LONDON, Nov. 26. -- The full significance of the German-Japanese treaty against communism signed this week in Berlin lies in the fact that Italy, although not yet a signatory, applauds the agreement, which is virtually identical with Premier Mussolini's own arrangement with Germany.

President Roosevelt said in the final speech of his campaign that in his second term he would continue fighting for higher wages, minimum hours and the elimination of child labor and of unfair competitive practices in business. But he did not say how; for example, he said nothing specific about revival of the NRA -- the means by which his first administration had attempted to accomplish those objectives.

George H. Gardiner, who was a member of the law firm of Davis, Polk, Wardell, Gardiner Reed, 15 Broad Street, left an estate of "more than $10,000 personal," it was learned yesterday when his will was filed for probate in the Kings County Surrogate's Court.

FOUR exhibitions of the Autumn season come in for attention in the November issue of Parnassus. Margaret Bruening, former art editor of The New York Post, discusses the Carnegie International both in its larger aspects and in detail.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 28. -- The curtain came down on the Eastern racing season before 12,000 persons today with the black colt, Roman Soldier, attaining a distinction never before gained by any thoroughbred when he completed a sweep of the four big Fall handicaps at Maryland's major tracks for the first time in history.

How to keep a job after 50 and how to become a more judicious buyer will be answered for members of the American Woman's Association by two events to be held this week at the clubhouse, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street.

PARIS. THE private client is frequently conceded to have a powerful influence on midseason fashions. Many couturiers compose the major part of their collections at this season for the smart woman rather than for the commercial buyer.

May I ask the courtesy of your column, to correct a misstatement, concerning my poetry made in THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review? Edna Lou Walton attributes to me the phrase "thunderous kiss," which she declares is "a little absurd" as indeed it is, since she, coined it herself.

THE scene is a lonely old house on the Eastern Shore of Maryland. Three men are so terrified at the sight of a child's rag doll that one of them wires to a New York detective agency for a man "shrewd enough to deal with the very devil himself, if need be."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The authorized airport construction and improvement program of the Works Progress Administration, extending to 616 projects at 446 airport sites, is now half complete, according to an estimate by Harry L. Hopkins, PWA Administrator, who presented a quarterly report today on that subject.
With the opening of the Pan-American conference there is new interest in the nature and composition of the New World.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the last distributions ordered by the directors follow:

ROME, Nov. 28. -- The Spanish Leftist government's appeal to the League of Nations yesterday is understood to have been the subject of conversations that the Italian Ambassadors in London and Paris have been carrying on with the governments to which they are accredited.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27. -- The latest order from Mayor S. Davis Wilson directing Philadelphia police to "conduct a more active campaign against vice and crime" comes at a time when several factors have combined to attract public attention to police activities.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 (AP). -- Johnny Layton of Sedalia, Mo., playing one of the greatest games in his long career, defeated Kinrey Matsuyama of Japan, 50 to 20, in twenty-eight innings today in an opening-round match of the world's title three-cushion billiard tournament.

With the surge of holiday buying gathering momentum as shoppers thronged retail stores, distribution reached peak levels in many trading areas throughout the country last week. Reflecting the upturn, orders in the wholesale markets continued to mount as retailers sent in hurried calls for immediate shipments of all types of seasonable goods and gift items and also began to prepare for post-holiday activities.

Miss Cornelia Van Wyck Kellogg, daughter of Mrs. Frederic Rogers Kellogg of Morristown, N.J., and Dark Harbor, Me., was introduced to society last night at a dinner dance given by her mother in the roof garden of the Pierre.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Nov. 28. -- A "transition house," built partly of steel and partly of older and more conventional materials, is being erected under the direction of scientists in the University of Pittsburgh's Mellon Institute of Industrial Research.

THE story of that figure of legend, the Alpine chamois, is told by Waldemar Schmidtman in this unusual book. Mr. Schmidtman spent much of his boyhood on an estate in the Salzburg Mountains, where game is guarded in large preserves and hunted according to a traditional code of sportsmanship which safeguards it against extermination.

A crowd of 15,000 is expected to see the benefit football game at Ebbets Field this afternoon that will bring together the Fort Jay Hawks and the Fort Du Pont Engineers for the Eastern army gridiron championship and the George V. Cooper Trophy.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 28. -- Plans for an extensive fourteen-concert schedule which will take the Williams College Glee Club to New York, Boston, Hartford, Buffalo and Bermuda were announced today by Arthur H. Tibbitts Jr., undergraduate manager of the musical clubs.

AS Britain prepares, with high regard for tradition, for the coronation of Edward VIII, a stronger light beats upon Buckingham Palace, where the scarlet, blue and gold of the royal standard flies against the gray skies of London. For this ancient building draws together all of the multifarious activities which radiate from the King's study and the royal household.

Despite the efforts of a fire-patrol crew to save them by using tarpaulins as smoke barriers, 300 canaries, finches, cardinals, parrots and other birds were killed last night as the result of a fire at 105 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, the owner of the pets estimated after the flames had been brought under control at about midnight.

Dr. Casey Wood, the 80-year-old scientist and associate in ornithology of the Smithsonian Institution, is to sail for Italy next week on the steamship Vulcania to complete the first English translation of a famous treatise on falconry by Frederick II, who ruled as Holy Roman Emperor during the first half of the thirteenth century.

An Alumni Association "to acquire a knowledge and appreciation of the culture and the life of all peoples for the furtherance of goodwill between nations and races" has been organized by the members of International House, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Marise Butler, secretary.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 27. -- Conviction yesterday of Paul D. Peacher, city marshal of Earl, on a charge of slavery arose out of an investigation made by "G" men from Washington who spent some weeks in Arkansas after farm tenancy disturbances in Crittenden County last Spring.

IN the early nineteenth century, when railways were still in the experimental stage, there were a few builders who used rails of stone. Examples of their handiwork are now rare, but at Haytor, Dartmoor, in England, there is a stone track which still remains largely in place.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 28 (AP). -- The American police radio system has reached the change-of-voice stage as its tenth birthday nears.

As a graphic demonstration of its keen interest in peace and detestation of war, the National Federation of Business and Professional Women will make every effort to have its representation at the 1937 Conference on the Cause and Cure of War in Chicago total 100 delegates and 100 alternates, it was announced yesterday by Miss Charl Williams of Washington, D.C., national president.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Nov. 28. -- "Holiday," by Philip Barry, will be produced jointly next Friday and Saturday by the Bryn Mawr College Varsity Players and Cap and Bells, the undergraduate dramatic club at Haverford College. The performances, starting at 8 P.M., will be given in Goodhart Hall at Bryn Mawr College.

THE interruption came just in time. The stout Harry Mendel, who aids and abets the venerable John Chapman in the promotion of six-day bike races, was pumping up a tire and his breath was coming short. It was evident that Mr. Mendel was about to burst, although the tire showed no signs of tension whatsoever. The cease-and-desist order by the intruder was eagerly welcomed by the stout pumper.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- No happier crowd of youngsters ever tore into a dressing room after a game than the Navy boys today. Happiest in the lot was their young-looking coach, Lieutenant Tom Hamilton, who, in that memorable day in 1926, kicked the goal after touchdown to tie the Army, 21 to 21, out on Soldier Field in Chicago.

PROBABLY the theatre is always middle-aged, and probably the young are always beating their way in from the bleak outside. But after the prolonged dullness of the Autumn it is particularly gratifying to realize that the young have not lost heart and that somehow they manage to do the rash things that are stimulating.

The New York World's Fair of 1939 is described as "one of the greatest community enterprises ever undertaken" in a pamphlet to be distributed today by the fair's bond sales committee. Affecting "virtually every citizen of New York," and destined, if successful, to bring the city at least $1,000,000,000 in new business and greater prestige as a world cultural center, "the fair needs the support of every one," the pamphlet declares.

LONDON-, Nov. 13. THOUGH, when this article appears, others will already have written at length of Eugene O'Neill, it would be wrong not to say, however briefly, that we in England were made glad by yesterday's news that the Nobel Prize has been awarded to him.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 28. -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today that preliminary conversations with most of the heads of the delegations to the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace have convinced him that at this stage it was evident there was a most sincere desire on all sides to cooperate toward realization of the objectives of the gathering that President Roosevelt will open Tuesday.

PARIS, Nov. 28. -- Some change in the form of the response that will be made on Dec. 15 to Washington's reminder that a war-debt payment is due was indicated as likely today by Yvon Delbos, the Foreign Minister, in reply to a question by a member of the Foreign Affairs Commission of the Chamber of Deputies.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Nov. 28. -- A section of the Ecuadorean Army revolted today and battled loyal troops in the streets of Quito, the capital. President Federico Paez declared tonight the uprising had been crushed.

Fashions in flowers will be the central theme of the December Ball to be given on Thursday at the Ritz-Carlton in behalf of the Grosvenor Neighborhood House. Leading New York florists will originate corsages, bouquets, hair ornaments and other floral appurtenances for a flower fashion show, in which many debutantes will participate.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 28. -- The possibility that President Roosevelt will fly home from the inter-American peace conference here was disclosed tonight by an announcement by Pan American-Grace Airways that it had been requested to keep the giant flying boat Pan American Clipper at the President's disposition ready to depart for the United States on the shortest notice.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 28. -Introduction of the divisional program of humanistic studies at Princeton University this Fall is termed "the most significant modification of the Princeton plan of study made during the past year" by Professor Robert K. Root, dean of the faculty, in his annual report to Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university.

ROME, Nov. 27. -- Central Europe always has been the fulcrum of Premier Benito Mussolini's foreign policy, with the exception of a very brief experiment of collaboration with France, between January, 1935, and the beginning of the acute stage of the Italo-Ethiopian crisis.

Reading, 'riting and 'rithmetic have no appeal for gypsy children of school age. They would rather learn to peddle needles or to tell fortunes. That is why truant officers assigned to duty in New York City's gypsy settlements are having their troubles at this season.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Nov. 28. -- A "new deal" in buying has come to Smith College in the organizing of a Cooperative Consumers Club, in line with similar groups promoted by the American Student Union over the country.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 28 (AP). -- Donald Comer, president of the American Cotton Manufacturers Association, expressed confidence today that the visit of American textile leaders to Japan would help find "a fair solution" to the rising shipment of Japanese cotton goods to this country.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP). -- Styles change with the sweep of seasons, but never the mind of the American woman on the subject of telling the government her age.

TWO subjects of current interest -- radio personalities and neurotics -- provide plot complications for Miss Widdemer's latest romance. She uses her crisply modern material in a deft, light way and employs her blithest manner to make "This Isn't the End" a pleasantly readable and intelligent bit of light fiction.

LAKE GEORGE. -- The Winter Sports Club of Lake George is now preparing a program which is expected to be one of the most outstanding in the Adirondack Mountain region. All of the activities will center around skiing, because at this time it is held to be the most popular Winter sport in the country.

A lusty era -- that of the early 1890's in the old Bowery -- will be symbolized by the settings which will decorate the drill hall of the Seventh Regiment armory for the annual Fall Military Ball to be given there Saturday night by the members of the regiment.

Jan Smeterlin, the Polish pianist, whose many appearances in this city in the last half dozen years have familiarized local concertgoers with his art, played an all-Chopin program before a large and approving audience at Town Hall yesterday afternoon.

THE broadcasters are planning extension of their "long lines" to South America, where the Pan-American Peace Conference at Buenos Aires will be the centre of international broadcasting during the first half of December.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP). -- A survey of Agricultural Adjustment Administration expenditures showed today that more than half of the $80,850,000 government benefit payments for sugar-crop control has gone to cane growers in the Philippines, Hawaii and Puerto Rico.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 28. -- Mr. and Mrs. Phil H. Clarke were hosts today for cocktails to Mr. and Mrs. Luther A. Wait, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Appleton, Prince and Princess Balthazar Odescalchi, Mr. and Mrs. George Angue Dobyne, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Hughes, Mr. and Mrs. George Stevenson Fenton, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Johnson and Mr. and Mrs. Edward U. Roddy Jr.

For the first time in its existence, the New York Women's Symphony Orchestra will include ten male musicians when the orchestra gives its first concert of the season on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall under the direction of Antonia Brico, its conductor and founder.

A nation-wide survey of the portfolios of insurance companies, making possible an analysis of investment trends in this field, will be a feature of the thirtieth annual convention of the Association of Life Insurance Presidents, which will be held on Thursday and Friday in the Waldorf-Astoria.

Influenced by the December delivery and strength of the stock market, prices on the Cotton Exchange improved yesterday and ended with gains of 2 to 9 points. Hopes of an early settlement of the shipping strike, which would clear cotton now at ports, and indications of a big holiday trade stimulated support.

While Mr. ROOSEVELT visits South America, the Budget Bureau in Washington is at work on the estimates which will necessarily be the first major question to receive his attention when he returns. The budget is traditionally submitted to Congress as soon as it convenes.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Nov. 28. -- The second annual Christmas Bargain Shop sponsored by the Westchester County Children's Association will open in White Plains on Thursday afternoon and will continue through Dec. 12. Mrs. Richard Blum of Purchase is chairman of the committee in charge.

The six-day bicycle race will take over Madison Square Garden this week. Tonight at 9 o'clock, Jimmy Durante will fire the gun that will send the riders off on their dizzy whirl. Fifteen teams will set out in the competition, that will continue without interruption until 11 o'clock on Saturday night.

Declaring that preparedness in medicine is far more important than the building of war machines to destroy life, Saal Van Zwanenberg, chairman of the board of directors of Zwanenberg Factories, Ltd., of Holland, the largest packing industry in Europe, arrived here last week with the aim of prevailing upon American scientists to speed up the development of medicines to save and preserve life.

AUGUSTA, Ga. -- With the nation's top flight golfers battling through the thirty-six-hole finals of the $5,000 Augusta Open Golf Tournament today, the interest of Winter visitors and residents is centered on golf.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 28. -- The Princeton basketball team will open its Winter season next Saturday against Dickinson College with only one of three returning lettermen available and few more experienced candidates around whom the first quintet can be built.

MOSCOW Nov. 28. -- The Soviet Government knows positively that Italy is negotiating an anti-Communist agreement with Japan similar to the recently announced Japanese -German agreement. Foreign Commissar Maxim Litvinoff declared tonight in a speech before the All-Union Congress of Soviets.

Average weekly working hours in the manufacturing industry have increased somewhat since the invalidation of the NRA but are still lower than the average of forty hours a week set up under the NRA to spread employment, it is shown by a survey just made public by the National Industrial Conference Board.

TORONTO, Nov. 28 (AP). -- Toronto scored three goals in thirty-three seconds while their opponents were two men short in the third period tonight and came up with their second straight 4-2 victory over the Canadiens. The result left the Leafs tied with the Maroons for third place in the International Section of the National Hockey League.

IN the course of their experiments Radio City television engineers often focus their cameras and glaring lights upon a painting of a girl whom they describe as the "perfect television type." The secret of her charms is the shade of brown in her make-up, which registers so perfectly on the television screen as to make living models at times unnecessary.

Driving back to London from Cornwall, Miss Jo Garrett found herself at nightfall in a country lane with a car that refused to budge another inch and the rain coming down in torrents. At 3 in the morning a handsome stranger rescued her and escorted her over a mile of rocky road to his home.

BOSTON, Nov. 28. -- In a driving snowstorm and with a roaring crowd of 25,000 looking on, the Boston College Eagles today came through gloriously for Gil Dobie against the Holy Cross Crusaders, who were better than 2 to 1 favorites before the game.
The second and final session of the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries' week-end sale brought $41,400 yesterday afternoon, bringing the total for the sale, which opened Friday, to $73,957.

The National A.A.U. cross-country championship will be held today in Branch Brook Park in Newark, starting at 2:30. Don Lash of Indiana, world record holder for two miles, will defend his title and seek to lead his team-mates to the team crown as well.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- An amazing wealth of creative talent has been discovered among American musicians as a result of the activities of the Federal Music Project of the Works Progress Administration, Dr. Nikolai Sokoloff, project director, announced today in revealing that compositions of 1,351 American musicians have been heard in public performances by WPA units since October, 1935.

ALTHOUGH the Knoedler Galleries (see above) led off with last week re-enforcements for our local "French season," the process of garnishing by no means stopped there. Three other thus related events remain to be recorded.

A CITY trying to solve its traffic difficulties, as New York is currently doing by extending its one-side parking regulations, faces a serious dilemma. On one hand it seeks to clear the traffic arteries of all but moving vehicles, and on the other it must recognize the need of providing for at least temporary stops.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 28 (AP). -- Scattered fogs, a higher humidity and low temperatures proved of material aid today in checking flames which were still crackling over thousands of acres in the Northwest.

Fifty-two years ago a small band of women ventured into the New York League of Girls' Clubs, eager to attend the recently opened classes in dressmaking and millinery. They had served long hours behind store counters and in factory rooms, but this new opportunity for improved earning capacity was not to be overlooked.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Nov. 28. -- The opening dance of the season took place at the Sulgrave Club tonight, when Miss Margot Garrett was introduced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. George Angus Garrett. Mr. and Mrs. Garrett and Miss Garrett received their guests in a setting of green and silver, combined with towering white palms and other tropical foliage.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 28. -- Mrs. Celestin A. Durand of Cathedral Avenue has announced the names of those who will serve with her on the St. Joseph's Church benefit card party and dance in the Garden City Hotel next Friday.

Mrs. Eleanor Holm Jarrett, the bathing beauty who rocked the American Olympic boat last Summer, isn't going to Houston, Texas, next week but she would like the administration's forces to know what she thinks about the situation before they lock horns with prospective opposition in the 1936 convention of the Amateur Athletic Union, with Avery Brundage wielding the gavel.

I WAS sitting in a club car of the Santa Fe Chief, bound for New York on one of my annual trips. A stout man, wearing pince-nez glasses, whom I might have cast in one of my films as a prosperous steel manufacturer, apparently recognized me and leaned over to open a conversation in the casual manner of co-passengers on a train.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- With the holiday season approaching, business activity is at the highest level of the recovery period, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey report.

LONDON. IN 1920 Richard Strauss said to me he wanted to write not a comic but a grotesque opera. As hero he had chosen a classical personage: Peregrinus Proteus. This Asiatic Greek was not only a comic figure (like Offenbach's), but a grotesque one -- because of the strangely terrible circumstances of his death.

RECENTLY a representative of this department encountered a member of that very active and productive organization for the propagation of modern music, the League of Composers. A new work by a young American, Robert McBride, a work commissioned by the League, will be performed on Dec. 7 in Town Hall at the concert for the benefit of Bennington College scholarship fund.

About 15,000 Communists paraded from Union Square down Fourth Avenue, Lafayette Street and Broadway yesterday morning at 10 o'clock and left at the German Consulate, 17 Battery Place, a resolution adopted by the Communist party denouncing Nazi assistance to the Rebels in Spain.

THE tale begins with Elizabeth Marlowe, otherwise known as Beppy, waking on a January morning in the London of 1715. In its course the story takes her from her home to Charles Town in the Carolinas, where she finds, somewhat to her surprise, a gracious way of living that is like the England she ha left.

NANKING, China, Sunday, Nov. 29. -- The Chinese Government has warned Japan in effect that any interference with China's punitive campaign against the Mongol and Manchukuoan invaders in Suiyuan Province might mean war on a national scale.

A man living in Hannibal, Mo., Mark Twain's old home town, is this year's winner of the annual prize awarded by the Mark Twain Association for the best quotations selected from the writings of the classic American humorist, Mrs. Ida Benfey Judd, founder and president of the association, announced last night.

CRUISE ships are off again, earlier this year than ever. Steamship lines and travel agents report the biggest program in their history, with bookings pouring in. There are cruises of six days or two weeks or half a year; quick runs to Bermuda and Nassau and back, longer trips to Caribbean ports, South American cruises, Mediterranean cruises, leisurely sailings to the South Seas.
PARIS, Nov. 28 (AP). -- French Communists challenged Premier Leon Blum and Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos tonight to debate "before the masses" the Spanish civil war question.

In a generally admirable review of Professor Paxson's "Pre-War Years" in your issue of Oct. 18 the reviewer, Nathan G. Goodman, falls short. I think on a point or two. He seems quite unaware, for instance, that President Wilson had ever declared himself in favor of war with Germany before 1917.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 28. -- After fighting flames in the five-story factory of the Candee Rubber Company in East Street, formerly a branch of the United States Rubber Company, the Fire Department today subdued a blaze which caused a loss of more than $250,000 and stopped employment for 1,600 employees of sixteen business and manufacturing companies in the building.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 28. -- National fraternities as well as college officials have a responsibility in curbing excessive fraternity hazing during "hell week," Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, said today of the resolution passed by the National Interfraternity Conference yesterday placing such responsibility upon local college authorities.

KWEISUI, Sulyuan Province, Sunday, Nov. 29 (AP). -- Military headquarters of General Fu Tso-yi declared today that alleged Japanese threats of retaliation for his capture of Peilingmiao were merely "bluff."

Creation of a State "municipal finance commission" to control expenditures of heavily indebted municipalities with a view to gradual reduction of tax and debt burdens on property will be sought early in the coming session of the Legislature, it was revealed yesterday at the close of a two-day meeting off the New York State Commission for the Revision of the Tax Laws.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- A personal friend of Mrs. Ernest Simpson, friend of King Edward, who saw her this evening and was authorized to speak as her agent, gave the following information on a purported interview with her published in a New York newspaper this morning:

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- Thanksgiving brought warmth and color into a week of the worst type of London weather. The annual dinner and ball of the American Society of London was held at the Dorchester Hotel. The honorary chairman, Ambassador Bingham, presided over the gathering of well-known Americans.

JAPAN is encouraging every form of colonization near her shores, as a partial solution of the problem of a surplus population. She has 10,000,000 already born for whom work must be found before 1950. Her continental ambitions lend interest to her experiments in Formosa, which she took from China in 1895.

DALLAS, Nov. 28. -- Two mud-caked kicking artists, "Slingin' Sam" Baugh of Texas Christian and Bob Finley, bulky Southern Methodist fullback, slammed a soggy football back and forth in a scoreless thriller before 18,000 drenched fans today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 27. -- Decision of the directors of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at their meeting in New York on Tuesday to submit a voluntary NRA agreement to their members at the annual convention in January recalls the successful experiment begun by San Francisco retailers that provided inspiration for the proposal.

Trading in the stock market yesterday was the heaviest for a Saturday since Oct. 3. The turnover on the Stock Exchange reached 1,632,000 shares, compared with 802,000 on the Saturday before. Stocks opened higher, with heavy buying of steel shares a feature, and continued upward in the first hour.

Gains were the rule in fairly active trading on local commodity futures markets in the week ended on Friday, but sugar lost most of its earlier improvement. Cocoa and rubber futures were the strong features.

Japan, in explaining her new vows with Nazi Germany, has protested against cynical suggestions that they might be aimed in reality not at the Communist propaganda machine, the Third International, but at the Soviet Union. How genuine are these protestations?

AFTER her Roman Spring, Mrs. Winthrop Chanler is centering the Autumn of her agreeably eventful life in an American valley. For thirty years she has made her home in the Genesee Valley of New York. But if these years have been truly centered in her American country place, they have by no means been wholly spent there.

WITH their customary halo'd generosity the movies have cast the pure white light of investigation on almost all of man's vocations -- with one notable exception. They have been deafeningly silent about those wunderkinder of the world who are blessed with the benign afflatus to figure a piece of clean stretched canvas with shapely pigment.

On the eve of sailing for France, after a brief visit to this country, M. ANDRE MAUROIS was asked by the reporters to state his opinion of President ROOSEVELT. He declined on the ground that he must wait four years more before forming a final judgment. It is true, he said, that Mr. ROOSEVELT has been a great President in adversity.

" What is the reason for the pronounced shortage this year of upland game birds in the coverts of the various States, especially in the North-Central and Northeastern parts of the country?" asks Game Breeder and Sportsman in an editorial in its current issue.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- A task requiring an estimated two and one-half or three years and involving the compilation of a volume on wholesale prices in Philadelphia between 1861 and 1896, is about to be undertaken by the industrial research department of the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce at the University of Pennsylvania.

BARCELONA, Spain, Nov. 28. -- Notwithstanding General Francisco Franco's threats to blockade Barcelona, no blockade exists. Merchant ships from France and other nations freely entered the port this week, although they were probably observed by unidentified and apparently hostile craft some distance off shore.

CURT E. ENGELBRECHT is a news photographer. And for him John D. Rockefeller "loomed as a kind of professional quarry. He was news." In November 1925, Mr. Engelbrecht went to Florida. After waiting around in Ormond for nearly a month he succeeded in getting a photograph of Mr. Rockefeller as he was coming out of church -- he not knowing, of course, that his picture was being taken.

Detective Edward J. McLoughlin, 31 years old, of 237 East 163d Street, and a Negro who bad been stopped with two others for questioning, were seriously injured last night in an exchange of shots at about 1 A.M. in a hallway at 242 West 122d Street, near Seventh Avenue.

The tenth anniversary of the charter grant to Long Island University will be celebrated on Dec. 9, 10 and 11, according to plans announced yesterday by Dean Tristram Walker Metcalfe of the university.

It is quite apparent to those of us who are actively working in the Little Theatre field that E.R. Welsh thinks he knows a great deal more than he actually does. He is apparently one of those who sit back and wait for the revolution but is not going to do anything personally to help it one way or another.

CAR manufacturers have done the best export business this year since 1929 and are confidently predicting that further gains will be made during 1937. The chief reason for marked improvement in sales overseas is the favorable currency situation, coupled with industrial recovery.

City College's basketball team opened its season with an impressive 36-23 victory over St. Francis last night at the winners' home gymnasium. Except for a few minutes at the start of the contest, the visitors were never a serious threat as the Lavender, warming up after a slow beginning, held a ten-point lead at the half and the Terriers never were able to cut into that margin.

BERLIN, Nov. 28. -- The chief of the Reich Labor Service, Konstantin Hierl, speaking at Potsdam today, warned that compulsory labor service for all German girls would be introduced eventually. He was addressing students at the Central School for Women Labor Service directors.

Announcement was made yesterday of a number of additional patronesses for the theatre party benefit of the Maternity Center Division of the Brooklyn Visiting Nurse Association, to be held Dec. 11, at the Henry Miller Theatre, where the performance of "The Country Wife" has been taken over by the association.

The recent hearing before the Federal Communications Commission requesting more radio educational programs should remind us that not only is there not enough radio education, but there is also far too much radio misinstruction.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27. -- The underworld of labor and political intrigue broke through the surface of Chicago's life last Monday night with the three shots that scattered twenty-nine leaden slugs through the bulky frame of Michael Galvin.

DETROIT, Nov. 28 (AP). -- Five alleged members of the Black Legion charged with the "thrill killing" of a Negro World War veteran were convicted of first degree murder tonight by a jury in recorder's court.

Although no show is expected today, the Weather Bureau predicted last night a continuation of the cold spell, with brisk and chilling winds sweeping over the city this afternoon and tonight. The lowest temperature yesterday was 21 degrees at 5:10 A.M.
