MANY decorators have preferred not to use pictures in a room because they were so frequently out of harmony with the furnishings. Now pictures are coming back into favor. But they are chosen to agree with the general decorative effect, or else the whole room is built around some important example of the painter's art.

IT would be hard to imagine a release more fitting to the moment than Victor album M-325, in which Fritz Kreisler and the London Philharmonic, with John Barbirolli conducting, play the Beethoven violin concerto -- in D. Opus 61.
PARIS, Nov. 15. EDOUARD BOURDET and Paul Raynal are certainly among the first half dozen French dramatists; and a new play by either of them is a theatrical event. This week we have plays by both.

TORONTO, Nov. 28. -- Belief that the Province of Quebec would become one of the richest mining areas in Canada in the next ten or fifteen years was expressed this week by T.A. Crerar, Federal Minister of Mines.

With the New York Giants mere spectators for a change, the National League football race continues apace today as three important contests hold the spotlight. The Pittsburgh Pirates face an opportunity to clinch the Eastern championship in a game with the Boston Redskins at Boston, with defeat eliminating them entirely from the title chase.

BOTH as history and as biography Professor Nevins's imposing life of Hamilton Fish constitutes one of the half-dozen most important works by American scholars in the post-war years. Thanks to the wealth of new material at his disposal, he has flooded with light the dark corners of the Grant administration and made possible a far more accurate and just estimate of political events in those unhappy years.

Toy shops are already swarming with youngsters eager to try out the season's new playthings, some of the children shouting with delight at things they like in hopes that Santa Claus will overhear, others -- with a more experienced technique -- boldly putting in a bid for this or that.

The rural New Yorkers of the Dyckman Street section of Manhattan were aroused last night by reports that Joe Benedeto, iceman, parking-lot proprietor and quondam vegetable farmer, whom some sentimentalists have dubbed the island's "last agrarian," was to be evicted to make way for an automobile trailer camp.

RIO DE JANIERO, Nov. 25. -- Some idea of the scope of the issues to be raised at Buenos Aires has been gathered from discussions here and from exchanges of opinions among the Foreign Offices of the twenty-one nations that will take part in the conference.

MILAN. ITALY'S Fall opera season, as far as noteworthy modern native works are concerned, was opened with Ludovico Rocca's "In Terra di Leggenda" (first stage production) at the Teatro Donizetti of Bergamo. In the field of contemporary Italian opera, Rocca is gaining recognition faster than any other composer of his generation.

The chefs of New York -- most of them, of course, French -- took the evening off after completing their culinary duties last night to attend their annual supper and dance in the grand ballroom of the Hotel New Yorker.

MR. MENCKEN notes in his "The American Language" that "the first American Colonists had perforce to invent Americanism if only to describe the unfamiliar landscape and weather, flora and fauna confronting them."

" Wage Earner," in a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, supposes that at 36 years of age he earns $2,200 a year and assumes that his earnings will remain the same figure until he reaches the age of 65. He further states, incorrectly, that his total contributions to the old-age pension fund during these twenty-nine years will be about $1,800.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- Sixteen States and the District of Columbia have now passed laws that will enable them to meet the requirements of the Federal Social Security Act, it was announced today, with unconcealed satisfaction, by the board in charge of the government's great social experiment.

AN air of freshness invests the Georges de la Tour and Brothers Le Nain exhibition at Knoedler's, which, held for the benefit of Les Amis du Musse de Blerancourt and the Lycee Francais of New York, will be current until Dec. 12.

THE countryman's year is full of "adventures in contentment." But no one is more candid than David Grayson (Ray Stannard Baker) in the comment that it takes more than merely moving to the country to bring content. If people are to find contentment, "here or there," he says, "they must first have the capacity for it in their own souls."

FROM his retirement on the farm at Lake Simcoe after nearly fifty years of teaching -- the last thirty-five at McGill -- Professor Leacock sends this latest collection of random sketches. Fragmentary, discursive writing and much of it personal (as when he depicts the "Senility Gang," a baker's dozen, including the author, who, we learn, terrorized McGill for years until the governors ejected them ), not every piece will be deemed funny.

IF you really want to read "all about" New York society, here is your book. There may be some details of that subject which Miss Worden -- an experienced society editor -- has left untouched, but if so they are beyond the imagination of the present reviewer.

In the by-election Thursday in the Scottish burgh of Greenock to choose a member of Parliament as successor to the late Sir GODFREY COLLINS, National Liberal and Secretary of State for Scotland, Mr. GIBSON, the Labor candidate, a distinguished lawyer, won by a majority of 2,600 votes.

LONDON, Nov. 25. -- London theatregoers are promised three important openings in the coming week. Perhaps the most heralded of these is "O Mistress Mine," a new play by Ben Travers, which offers Yvonne Printemps as the queen of a Balkan country who flees from a revolution.

THE New York World's Fair is still two and a half years away; yet large numbers of people are already busy on the project. Some 300 men and women are working over plans and details on four floors of the Empire State Building, while hundreds more are rushing day and night to prepare the ground for the exposition on Flushing Meadows.

In the first fourteen seconds of play, Columbia fashioned the touchdown that defeated Stanford, 7 to 0, at the Polo Grounds yesterday and the remainder of a bitter battle between these old Rose Bowl rivals in an arctic setting was one of frustration and futility.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- Army vs. Navy or Navy vs. Army -- depending on which branch of long-legged Uncle Samuel's two fighting arms comes first in your affections.

CUMBERLAND, Md., Nov. 28 (AP). -- Renewed outbreaks of rioting at the strike-closed celanese plant here left at least six persons injured today, more than a score of strikers under arrest, and brought a warning of "drastic action" from Governor Harry W. Nice.

FOLLOWING two good years, the O. Henry collection has slipped backward a peg. Although it has not reverted to its sponsorship of the slick popular tale, the 1936 volume is a somewhat lackluster affair. The prizewinning stories are adequate but not brilliant; there is a distressing abundance of mannered and pretentious writing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- Detailed plans for President Roosevelt's visit to Buenos Aires, covering the period from the time the American Chief Executive lands at the dock of the Darsena Norte next Monday afternoon, until he sails away from the same dock at 2 P.M. Wednesday, were announced by the State Department tonight.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 28. -- Out of seven freshmen in the average American college only two graduate, Dr. Robert J. Trevorrow, president of the Centenary Collegiate College, Hackettstown, N.J., told eductors gathered here at the convention of the Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28. -- Bullish sentiment in the wheat market was further stimulated today by an advance of 1 1/2 to 1 3/4 cents a bushel in Liverpool, a continuation of the aggressive demand for cash wheat from importing countries and an announcement that the British Government would create a food-defense plan.

So far New York City has appropriated $7,000,000 directly for the 1939 fair, most of it for the acquisition of land; about $1,000,000 will remain to put up a city exhibit building. Additional large sums -- Mayor La Guardia's estimate is $10,000,000 -- will be spent by the city for sewers and other improvements around the grounds.

Handsome, dignified and with the unassuming manner of the truly serious devotee of her art, Alice Tully, an American soprano new to these parts on the concert platform, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. An audience of good size was on hand to hear her and followed her efforts with attentive interest.

THIS story of a Kansas homestead is a story of heroism. Amazing heroism. The kind of heroism that went on day by day for twenty years, constantly meeting new perils, shouldering new burdens, surmounting new bewilderments, and reaching a victory not merely material, in the end. It was the greatest triumph

That vines are among the more popular house plants is evidenced by the number of housewives who buy new pots of English ivy (Hedera helix) every Winter. But there are other vines, and other ivies, and they offer fewer difficulties in the work of keeping them in health.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 28 (AP). -- Staying up all night to pile kitchen matches on the mouth of a beer bottle, Dr. Thomas H. Staggers, a mechano-therapist, convinced himself that he had steady nerves.

OUT of Spain's civil war has sprung an ominous threat to international peace. Half of Europe has taken sides, however much the dictators may protest their intention not to intervene. Berlin and Rome have openly recognized General Francisco Franco's government. Moscow is helping Barcelona and Madrid all that it can -- although perhaps much less than is alleged.
CHICAGO, Nov. 28. -- The American Society of Agricultural Engineers will open a five-day meeting Monday to discuss methods of farm improvements through the application of scientific engineering.

THE Spirit of '76 was built up largely by Samuel Adams. Passionately devoted to the cause of American liberty, he sacrificed personal comforts and pleasures and fought until the goal was reached. He used foul means as well as fair to attain his end, and his racy, vitriolic pen served him well in his exertions.

Snow flurries, falling temperatures and brisk winds stimulate the appetite and encourage the marketmen. Heavy foods are the order of the day, with the result that meat dishes are assuming a new importance on the menu.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Nov. 28. -- Activities of the two chief musical organizations at Wellesley College show a marked increase in scope and intensity under the inspiration of their two young directors, Edward Barry Greene, director of the choir, and Malcolm H. Holmes, conductor of the orchestra. Both are Harvard men.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- State Governments in 1935 collected $1,655,000,000 in tax levies from eight sources of which six also are taxed by the Federal Government, according to a report by the Treasury Department on "double taxation," covering the 1930-35 period.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29. -- Bobby Wilson and Ralph Kercheval furnished the thrills as the Brooklyn Dodgers defeated the Philadelphia Eagles in the latter's closing National Football League game of the season at the Municipal Stadium today, 13 to 7, while 5,000 frost-bitten spectators looked on.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP). -- After pouring billions into industry, business and agriculture during the depression, government lending agencies now are tightening their purse strings.

Warren B. Ashmead, Republican leader of Queens County, declared yesterday against further alliances by the Republican organization with independent parties, referring particularly to next year's city election, and asserted that the life of the Republican party depended upon it becoming more strongly Republican than ever.

Scott R. Dunlap, identified with motion picture production since 1912, has been appointed production chief of the newly formed Sterling pictures by W. Ray Johnston, president. His first activity was the purchase of "The Belled Palm," a current magazine story by Allan Vaughan Elston.

Last week the Appellate Division handed down a decision defeating an attempt to get around the Civil Service Laws of this State. It is a question of only two public employes, but their case is on all fours with many others. They had held exempt positions, and had been "covered" into the general service without any examination or other test of merit and efficiency.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- Enforcement of the Federal kidnapping statute, known as the "Lindbergh law," from June 22, 1932, its date of effect, to the present, has resulted in the conviction of 171 persons who received prison terms aggregating 2,229 years.

The Citizens Budget Commission made public yesterday an interchange of letters with James E. Finegan, chairman of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, in which the budget group proposed seven reforms in the city's civil service and Mr. Finegan placed the blame for current evils on "ill-balanced administrative practices rather than ill-balanced rules."

A further increase in reserve requirements of member banks of the Federal Reserve System would not disturb present money market conditions in the slightest, in the opinion of Colonel Allan M. Pope, president of the First Boston Corporation.

Manhattan's football team, whose activities were curtailed last week because of the holiday, will resume preparations today for Saturday's battle with Texas A. and M. at Tyler, Texas. As the Jaspers are scheduled to depart on their 1,800-mile journey tomorrow night, Coach Chick Meehan plans to accomplish as much as possible in the last two practices at Innisfail Park.

MOSCOW, Nov. 29. -- The Soviet Red Army now has more than 7,000 airplanes, and in size, quality and equipment and in skill and spirit of pilots it is the most powerful air fleet in the world, General V. Khripin, assistant chief of the Red Army air force, told cheering delegates of the All-Union Congress of Soviets today.

New efforts by Federal officials to settle the maritime strike on the Pacific Coast were begun yesterday, while steamship owners continued to move ships in New York and insisted that no emergency existed in Atlantic and Gulf ports.

That zealous young organization, the New Friends of Music, which believes that the chamber works of Beethoven and Brahms are their own excuse for being, devoted to the former its program at the Town Hall late yesterday afternoon. The Kolisch Quartet played the C sharp minor quartet, Op. 131.

VALENCIA, Spain, Nov. 29 (AP). -- The Spanish civil war will last "at least through the Winter," War Minister Indalecio Prieto declared today, and will pass through "a far more intensive stage" than the present battle for Madrid.
In your issue of Nov. 25 I find an article about the necessity of public housing and about the "duty of government to provide low-priced dwellings, as private business" has failed to do so.

So far as business and fluctuations in the foreign exchanges went, last week's market dovetailed closely with that of preceding sessions -- a light demand for bills, coupled with a limited range in values.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 29. -- Philadelphia's first and second women's field hockey teams rolled up thirty-five goals in their undefeated and unscored on sweep through the inter-city tournament which finished today at the Bryn Mawr School.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,459,442,300. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interesthearing discount bills. The list follows:

Sweeping the match in straight games, W.E. (Billy) Coyle and his veteran partner, Walter Kinsella, won the second annual Heights Casino invitation amateur-pro squash racquets tournament yesterday by turning back Stanley Galowin and Joseph Wiener in the final at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn.

LONDON, Nov. 27. -- The stock markets here have experienced the most trying and unprofitable week in a long time. At one period the nerves of the city looked like being badly shaken by fears of another European upheaval. Spanish affairs again came prominently and unpleasantly into the news at first, to be succeeded by the signing of the German-Japanese anti-Russian pact and the threatened execution of a German subject in Russia.

A.L. Burns triumphed for the second day in a row at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday, taking the high-over-all cup with 98 out of 100 targets. He prevailed in Saturday's competition when he returned a card of 91.

Extension of the Federal Social Security Act at the next session of Congress to include millions of farm workers and domestic servants, not now protected, was predicted yesterday by John G. Winant, chairman of the Social Security Board.

The entire personnel of the Seventh District Magistrate's Court, 25 Snyder Avenue, Brooklyn, will be transferred to other magistrates' courts today, it was announced yesterday by Chief City Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. The Seventh District Court will open this morning with an entirely new staff of clerks, assistant clerks and court attendants.

Numerous mail orders were received in the wholesale market last week, although fewer buyers were here. Fair demand was noted for daytime dresses, the bulk of the orders being for the new midseason prints and pastels. Evening gowns and wraps sold steadily.

Proposals to revive the NRA, to establish a thirty-hour week and to extend the back-door NRA represented by the Walsh-Healey Government Contracts Act, combine to make particularly timely the study of changes in wages, hours and employment since NRA, compiled by the National Industrial Conference Board.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 (AP). -- Chicago's surprising Cardinals, who had lost eight of ten National Football League games this season, wrecked the title hopes of the Chicago Bears with a 14-to-7 upset victory before 13,704 fans at Wrigley Field today.

PORT WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- Allan Clark, sailing Penguin, won the only two races that the local Frostbite Dinghy fleet managed to finish in the teeth of a strong northwest wind today, and thereby clinched his title to the November championship series for Class D.

PARIS, Nov. 28. -- The foreign exchange market was quiet this week, and the equalization fund was able to maintain the franc rates with ease. The pound sterling and the dollar even showed a tendency to decline.

Dr. Carlos Saavedra Lamas, Argentine Foreign Minister and president of the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace, was heard from Buenos Aires last night in a short talk over National Broadcasting Company networks on "The Significance of the Nobel Peace Prize."

The curtain was lowered in the East Saturday on football's most prosperous season since pre-depression days with the unprecedented turnout of 102,000 spectators at the Army-Navy game in Philadelphia's Municipal Stadium.

Tuberculosis, which has been known and dreaded in many parts of the earth and under various names, is itself no respecter of names or persons. The greatest and the humblest have been its victims. It is authoritatively stated that it was the cause of the deaths of ROBERT LOUIS STEVENSON, KEATS, BYRON, MOLIERE, BALZAC, DOSTOIEVSKY, GORKI, KANT, SCHILLER, CHOPIN, SPINOZA, CHRISTY MATHEWSON, TRUDEAU and RING LARDNER.
TORONTO, Nov. 29 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian women were urged by Lady Astor, in an address here yesterday, to use their influence to further civilization by crusading on Christian standards.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 29. -- With their characteristic nose for news-inspired screen stories, Warner Brothers will start screen writters to work tomorrow on "Uncrowned Emperor," based on the life of the late Basil Zaharoff. Paul Muni may be cast in the lead part.

John Barbirolli resumed the good work of resuscitating rarely heard compositions at the concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. Mozart's symphony in B flat (K. 319), written when the composer was 23, was presented for the first time in the history of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society.
BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 29 (AP). -- Discovery of an additional factor in blood clotting mechanism was reported today by the University of California Biochemistry Division.

BERLIN, Nov. 28. -- The chief business interest here this week was the official policy toward foreign trade. A decline early in the week in the stocks of certain manufacturing corporations which can earn profits only on domestic sales gave color to the story that Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics, is considering a new campaign to foster exports.

Remarking that the progress toward business recovery has left the country with economic questions still unanswered, the Guaranty Trust Company says in the current issue of its publication, the Guaranty Survey, that a "clear and urgent need exists for true cooperation between government and business."

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 27. -- Holland's joining of the tripartite currency agreement is contrary to the action of Belgium and Switzerland in so far as it means only adherence in principle to the declarations of Sept. 25 and Oct. 13. Until technical details in cooperation with Washington, London and Paris are worked out, Dutch adherence is only of theoretical value.
James W. Lee 2d, a partner in the firm of Ivy Lee T. J. Ross, public relations counsel, will address members of the Princeton dvertising Club at the Princeton Club on Thursday night, Dec. 10.

Democratic procedure in America would be dispensed with forty-eight hours after we entered the next war, the Rev. Dr. Harry F. Ward, Professor of Christian Ethics at Union Theological Seminary, declared in a sermon there yesterday morning.

The Fourth Church of Christ, Scientist, dedicated its building at Fort Washington Avenue and 185th Street yesterday morning. The service marked the full payment of debts incurred in erecting the structure. The cost, including the land, was about $385,000.

Mr. and Mrs. 0. Frank Woodward gave a tea dance yesterday in the roof garden of the Pierre for Aiss Mary A. Royall, dbutante daughter of Mrs. M. Buckner Royall of Fieldston Old House, Riverdale-onHudson. Smilax concealed the walls of the roof garden and multicolored Spring flowers and white chrysanthemums were used in the decorations.

Ridicule of another's conception of heaven was denounced yesterday by the Rev. Leonard Feeney at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Father Feeney, who is associate editor of America, Catholic weekly, preached the first of a series of Advent sermons that will be completed on Christmas Day.

BELLEVILLE, Ill., Nov. 29. -- Police will apply tomorrow for a warrant charging murder against Charles Koehr, 64 years old, who "confessed" to Chicago police last night that thirty-five years ago he killed his younger brother, Henry, 14 years old, because the lad had taken a job as roustabout in a saloon.

STERLING, Ill., Nov. 29 (AP). -- The entire community and out-of-town guests have been invited to a party tomorrow night celebrating the ninetieth birthday anniversary of Nicholas George Van Sant, Civil War veteran.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 29. -- Streaking down the stretch in a Garrison finish, Ralph Guldahl of St. Louis overtook the field today to win first money in the $5,000 Augusta open golf tournament with a seventy-two-hole score of 283.

Fear and despair that cause suicides will be banished from our lives if we live in accordance with "God's plan," Bishop Herbert E. Welch, retired, declared yesterday morning at the eighty-seventh anniversary of the Centenary Methodist Episcopal Church, Washington Avenue and East 166th Street, the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP). -- With seven educational camps already functioning for unemployed young women, the National Youth Administration today said that the establishment of eight other "women's CCC camps" had been authorized.

Champion Elyria Easter Parade won his fifteenth best in show for 1936 last night when he was judged above all others in the sixth annual specialty show of the Brooklyn Boston Terrier Club at Odd Fellows Memorial Hall.

After leading for most of the season, Fred King, Hobart halfback, was toppled from his position as the leading scorer in Eastern college football when Dick Riffle, Albright college halfback, went on a scoring spree on Saturday. Riffle tallied five touchdowns in his team's victory over Muhlenberg to give him fourteen for a total of 84 points, 9 more points than King.

PORT ARTHUR, Ont., Nov. 29 (Canadian Press). -- Their bows and cabin sides coated with two inches of ice, the Canada steamships lines freighter Calgarian and the S.S. Noronic docked here today to discharge heavy loads of package freight preparatory to making their last trip down the lakes this season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- The decision of Australia to have her own envoys abroad is expected to mean the designation of a Minister to the United States and the appointment of an American Minister to that Commonwealth.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 29. -- An expanded program for birth-control education was unanimously recommended here today by 500 members of the convention of the Western New York Baptist Young People.

Notice will be issued today by the bondholders' protective committee of an extension to Dec. 31 of the time in which holders of Vertientes Sugar Company first mortgage 7 per cent bonds due on Dec. 1, 1942, and of Camaguey Sugar Company first mortgage 7s due on Oct. 15, 1942, may deposit their bonds in assent to the respective plans of reorganization for these corporations.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29. -- Prices of oats for future delivery had last week a range of 1/8 to 1 3/8 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade, the latter for July, which closed at 41 1/2 cents, a net loss of 7/8 cent from the previous week. December closed at 45 3/4 cents, a net gain of 1/2 cent, while May finished at 41 1/2 cents, a net advance of 3/4 cent.

State Senator Thomas C. Desmond of Orange County has announced his candidacy for minority leader of the State Senate in letters to his colleagues, asking for their support. State Senator George R. Fearon of Syracuse, present minority leader, was not a candidate for re-election.

Some years ago, when JOHN J. CARTY was making it possible for the President's voice to be heard across the continent by multitudes through the tying together of wires into a network -- the antecedents of the wireless -- some one spoke of the United States as "Carty's Hall."

Carl Quade, 15 years old, in his last term at Public School 217, Newkirk and Coney Island Avenues, Brooklyn, was killed by gas early yesterday morning in his home at 725 Foster Avenue while warming milk for a stray cat.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 (AP). -- The Montreal Canadiens, scoring twice in the second period, tightened their hold on second place in the National Hockey League's International Division tonight by defeating the Chicago Black Hawks, 2 to 1, before 12,000 spectators.

The Engineers Public Service Company and subsidiaries will report today a consolidated balance of $2,973,373 for the twelve months ended on Oct. 31 after all deductions, against a balance of $1,213,571 in the preceding year. The parent company's annual preferred dividend requirements are $2,323,537.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 29. -- After twice coming from behind to tie the score, the New York Rovers were beaten, 4 -- 3, in overtime by the Pittsburgh Yellow Jackets in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game today. The victory, the Jackets' first of the season, was cheered by 2,500 fans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- Expenditures in this Fall's Presidential campaign reached $13,000,000, a record total, Robert L. Jefferys, secretary of the special Senate committee investigating campaign spending, declared today in discussing plans of the committee for legislation to restrict outlays.

During the nine weeks since the second French currency devaluation in September, gold exports from Paris to New York have ceased. Most of the French bank's weekly reports have shown no change whatever in its gold reserve; but this means that at Paris, as at London, gold import or export no longer moves automatically, as it used to do, into or out of the central bank.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 29. -- Goal-post fighters, looking forward to a good season next year, when experts predict Harvard will have a winning football team, were gleeful today upon learning that the old-fashioned wooden goal posts will still be the vogue on Soldiers Field.

To the Editor of The New York Times:It is a difficult thing to report so long a discussion as I led last night at the Community Forum in a condensed statement with adequate and correct emphasis. It happens that the particular discussion concerned issues on which I am most anxious not to be misunderstood. Hence my desire to correct the impression of my position at certain points.

DETROIT, Nov. 29 (AP). -- The Green Bay Packers clinched the Western Division title in the National Football League by defeating the Detroit Lions, 1935 league champions, before 22,000 chilled spectators today. The score was 26 to 17.

A list of recommendations for December by the Cardinal's Literature Committee is published in the Cathedral Bulletin, which was issued yesterday. The list contains current books in fiction, biography, literature, poetry, religion and philosophy, with an appended brief list of juveniles.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- New residential construction in October increased over October, 1935, by 63.9 per cent, measured in the number of permits issued, and 66.2 per cent in estimated cost, the Labor Department announced today in its monthly report.

Eva Gauthier, song interpreter, will give three "retrospective" programs the nights of Dec. 8, Jan. 13 and Feb. 10 in the ballroom of the Gotham Hotel. The first will be devoted to Spanish numbers, the second to songs stemming from Central Europe and the third to French compositions.

The world is learning from the dictators. It is discovering that by their very nature dictatorships must be a disturbing force. Quite apart from the good or evil they work in their own countries, the international system is too sensitive, too closely integrated, to stand the shattering shocks of dictatorial methods.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Nov. 29 (AP). -- Hundreds of Budapest housewives have quit cooking. They purchase the family meals in milk pails nowadays from messengers on bicycles.

KALGAN, Chahar Province, China, Monday, Nov. 30. -- Refugee Mongols -- men, women and children driven from their nomad homes in Western Chahar and Eastern Suiyuan by the threat of war -- streamed into this frontier town today within the lee of China's Great Wall.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 29. -- Rosa Ponselle, vivid star of grand opera, waited ten years for her Prince Charming to come along.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29. -- Eighteen thousand persons, representing about 1,000 Protestant churches in Philadelphia and vicinity, overflowed the Municipal Auditorium today to welcome the National Preaching Mission to this city and hear the Rev. Dr. E. Stanley Jones, Methodist missionary to India, plead for a "return of the kingdom of God on earth."

Because of the superior manner in which Webster Aitken, the California pianist had performed Beethoven's "Diabelli" variations and Ravel's "Gaspard de la Nuit" here last season, there was good reason to expect he might soon stand at the top of the ladder among the younger generation of American keyboard artists.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 29. -- Headed by mighty Don Lash, who led a field of fifty-seven with astonishing ease, Indiana University placed five runners among the first six decisively to capture the national senior cross-country team title at Branch Brook Park today.

A four-pound, nine-inch bomb, containing three sticks of standard 40 per cent dynamite was found in the rear hallway of the building at 849 First Avenue at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Michael Blaury, 14 years old, a florist's delivery boy, who lives upstairs in the building, found the bomb.

The great lesson which the depression has taught us is that God is vitally interested in the material as well as the spiritual welfare of mankind, the Rev. Dr. John Gass, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

Variety again sets the key for the exhibitions of the week, with between twenty and thirty new attractions on the calendar of the local galleries. The diversity of times and subject-matter is unusually wide, ranging from old Dutch masters to surrealism and from English landscape to contemporary Bulgarian paintings.

An offering to the public of 70,000 shares of $20-par cumulative convertible preferred stock of the Atlas Plywood Corporation, producer of plywood packing cases, will be made today by Van Alstyne, Noel Co., Inc., by means of a prospectus.

Moriz Rosenthal, one of the few remaining pupils of Franz Liszt and one of the greatest names among the pianists of the last fifty years, returned after an absence of some seasons to New York and gave last night at the age of 74 his first American recital of the present season in Town Hall.

SEATTLE, Nov. 29 (AP). -- Presses of The Seattle Post-Intelligencer rolled today for the first time since the night of Aug. 13, when a strike of American Newspaper Guild members, supported by the Seattle Labor Council, forced suspension of publication. The strike was settled Nov. 25.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- Substantial gains in sales of goods by manufacturers and wholesalers during October, compared with the same month a year ago, were reported today in a joint survey by the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce and the National Association of Credit Men.
Due to my absence from the office, your editorial of Aug. 28, "International Wage Pacts," has just come to my attention.

With the parole system a subject of lively debate throughout the country, the digest of indeterminate sentence and parole laws prepared by ROBERTS J. WRIGHT and published by the Prison Association of New York as part of its annual report is exceptionally timely.

IRABAT, French Morocco, Nov. I 29. -- The Spanish Rebel leaders of_ [ ficially deny the execution of a son I of Premier Francisco Largo Caballero, which was reported in B[adrid on Friday. The denial was broadcast by the Rebel radio station at i Seville, Spain,

TAMPA, Nov. 29. -As the executive council of the American Federation of Labor completed its postconvention session today it became apparent that its members were divided on how peace might be obtained in connection with the internal controversy which has split the labor movement.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Nov. 29. -- Yesterday's revolt in Quito, which began at 1:30 P.M., was ended by 8:30 P.M., and an hour later the dictator, President Federico Paez, was broadcasting a statement reassuring the people.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 29. -- The gay holiday excitement and intense public emotion attending the preparations for the spectacular official and popular reception to President Roosevelt tomorrow have momentarily eclipsed the tremendous historical significance of his visit.

MARSEILLES, France, Nov. 29. -- The U.S.S. Raleigh, Admiral Arthur F. Fairfield's flagship, commanded by Captain Edward J. Foy, together with the destroyer Hatfield, brought 103 American refugees from Spain to this port this morning, including forty-four who embarked at Valencia Thursday and Friday and twenty-six who embarked yesterday at Barcelona.

Old and new legislators of New York State, both at Washington and at Albany, will be interrogated by the State League of Women Voters on their stand on measures of particular interest to the league members. Instructions for the questioning will be mailed today by Mrs. Douglas Moffat, State chairman, to county chairmen, together with literature on the legislation involved.

George M. Cohan and Sam H. Harris, whose banner -- "Cohan Harris present" -- flew over many a successful show from 1904 to 1919, will reunite in January for the production of a new play starring Mr. Cohan. The play will be "Fulton of Oak Falls," a comedy by Parker Fennelly, but extensively rewritten by Mr. Cohan, and Broadway already is preparing for as sentimental an event as it has seen in years.

A hope that the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace would prove successful was expressed in the following cable sent yesterday by the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, representing twenty-three communions, to Secretary of State Cordell Hull at Buenos Aires:

Senator John J. McNaboe, as chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee to Investigate Communism and Subversive Activities in the Public Schools and Colleges of the State of New York, charged yesterday that Cornell University at Ithaca was a "center of revolutionary communistic propaganda."

MONTREAL, Nov. 29. -- Although the government has British textile makers primarily in view, American exporters may also expect to benefit from an inquiry just completed into the relation between high protection and high textile profits in Canada.

More than one-third of the special fund sought by the Charity Organization Society has been raised, it was announced yesterday by Lindsay Bradford, chairman of the family service fund committee. A week of campaigning has yielded gifts of $100,451 against a quota of $278,000, Mr. Bradford said.

LONDON, Nov. 27. -- Retail trade sales in October were 7.4 per cent above October, 1935, when the increase over the same month in 1934 also was 7.4 per cent. In September the increase was 4.5 per cent and in August the expansion was the same as for last month.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 29. -- The feature of the concluding day's exhibition of the fourth annual champion show of the Westchester County Cat Club at the County Center today was the awarding of a first prize to a blue bob-tail Manx alley cat belonging to a thirteen-year-old boy.

Harry W. Alexander, who has resigned as vice president in charge of sales of the American Type Founders sales Corporation, Elizabeth, N. J., will announce his new connection on Feb. 1. In the meantime he will spend a vacation in assau.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 29. -- The Army-conquering Navy football squad came home tonight to an uproarious reception.

Few will deny that the Budapest gentleman who fights duels wholesale makes a finer picture than the dictators and minor heads of State by whom he is surrounded in Central Europe. The political supermen are busy organizing alliances against this one and understandings against that one, and are being met with counter-agreements and ententes.

RIDGEFIELD, N.J., Nov. 29. -- Paul Harley, lessor of the Ridgefield Chateau, a three and one-half story hotel on Broad Avenue here, was rescued by a policeman in a fire that destroyed the structure at 1 o'clock this morning after he had gone back into the hotel to get some clothes for his family and save their pet cat, Lulu Belle.

MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 29 (AP). -- Princess Concetta Leone de Nigeratze, unaware that her husband was dead, was under arrest tonight charged with having killed him as he left the home of the Finnish Vice Consul.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood on Nov. 25 at 76.3 against 75.5 a fortnight before, 74.6 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

An approach of the Socialist party of New York State for affiliation with the American Labor party, which supported President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman in the recent election, has been rebuffed by the American Labor party leaders, it was learned last night.

Police Inspector John J. de Martino was injured in an automobile accident just before 3 A.M. yesterday while on his way to Harlem Hospital to visit Detective Edward McLoughlin, who had been shot by a Negro suspect two hours earlier.

BERLIN, Nov. 28. -- The volume of trading in the stock market this week was the smallest for a week in many months. Owing to the need for cash to cover losses on foreign securities, selling predominated at first, but the middle of the week brought a noticeable recovery and, despite another slight weakening today, gains on the whole were maintained.

THE TIMES editorial "High Cost of Funerals" begins by referring to a bulletin issued by the State Department of Health. Only some of the facts stated in the editorial are taken from the bulletin, however. You will not find therein any statement as to the costal of funerals in New York State or as to the number of undertakers in 1900 or in 1920.

Tales of Shanghai Pierce, a Paul Bunyan of the Eastern Seaboard, whose voice could be heard two miles and whose wit tickled the housewives of early New England, have been uncovered by Professor George Hibbitt of Columbia University in the town of Little Compton, near Newport, R.I.

LONDON, Nov. 27. -- Although regarded as still promising, the business outlook in the United States is not untinged with doubt, according to views expressed here. There are symptoms, as in Great Britain, of some unrest over the rising cost of living, but more importance is attached to the influence on labor of expanding company earnings, and the big dividends being distributed among stockholders.

ALBANY, Nov. 29 (AP). -- New York State's public employment offices placed 143,616 persons in private industry in the first ten months of this year, 20,000 more than for the entire year of 1935, Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, reported tonight.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- Large, general and "recurring wage increases throughout all industry" is the goal set by the American Federation of Labor in its monthly survey of business.
As the clock struck 9 last night Jimmy Durante raised a pistol, fired into the air, and the sixty-first New York six-day bicycle race started at Madison Square Garden.

TENAFLY, N.J., Nov. 29. -- Reports that the Erie Railroad, in order to reduce its burden of local assessment taxes, plans to install single track operation over its line between this point and Sparkill in Rockland County, N.Y., were confirmed here today by George W. Conklin, Tenafly station master.

A policeman rescued a 10-year-old boy from afire that drove about twenty-five men, women and children to the street about 3 o'clock yesterday morning at 186-01 Jamaican Avenue, Hollis, Queens. Fire damage was confined to an empty drug store which was being made ready for opening on the first floor of a two-story building.

EAST NORTHFIELD, Mass., Nov. 29. -- Plans for the centenary celebration of the birth of Dwight L. Moody, opening Feb. 5, were completed today in a committee session headed by the Rev. Dr. John McDowell, former moderator of the Presbyterian church.

Not only retail trade, but wholesale trade as well, enters the closing month of 1936 at a high level of activity -- in many respects the highest for a year-end in seven years. This is true also of railway freight, the latest weekly report for which showed last week that car-loadings, for the first time even in 1936, had gone above any corresponding week since 1929.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29. -- Buying of hogs by local and outside packers made a strong market last week. The top price was $9.90 a hundred-weight, the highest in five weeks, against $9.75 in the preceding week and $9.95 a year ago. Most sales were between $9.10 and $9.85.

Statistically outclassed, but able to capitalize swiftly on three good opportunities, the Fort Du Pont Engineers vanquished the Fort Jay Hawks, 20 to 14, before 15,000 fans at Ebbets Field yesterday, thereby winning the Eastern Army football championship and ending their season with twelve victories in as many starts.

BOSTON, Nov. 29. -- The Boston Redskins crushed the Pittsburgh Pirates and the Pirates' Eastern championship hopes in one motion on the snow-fringed Fenway Park gridiron today with a smashing 30-0 victory that kept alive the title chances of the New York Giants.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 29. -- President Roosevelt approached the shores of Argentina tonight under an escort of picked units of the Argentine Navy with prospects for the most impressive reception of his career. No effort has been spared here to arrange what is apparently a sincere tribute by the entire Argentine people to the man who stands in their eyes as the champion of fair play in the Western Hemisphere.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 29 (AP). -- What may prove to be a major development in science, discovery of a skeleton-like structure in the proteins, which compose the principal part of the living human body, is reported in Nature, British Journal of Science.

MADRID, Nov. 29. -- Following up a warning contained in leaflets dropped yesterday that a general attack was imminent and that noncombatants should stay in cellars, the Insurgents tonight staged an air raid here. Earlier in the day the capital was bombarded, shells dropping in the vicinity of the North Station.
DANZIG, Nov. 29. -- An extraordinary session of the Danzig Diet will be held soon to appoint a new Senate President. It will be the first meeting since the dissolution of the Socialist party.

EAST ISLIP, L.I., Nov. 29. -- Dilwyne Montauk Pilot -- "good old Pilot" to his admirers -- today won first place in the open all-age stake of the annual retriever meeting of the Brookhaven Game Protective Association.
President Roosevelt, it is said, will follow the precedent set by George Washington and will not be a candidate for election to a third term.

SAN PERLITA, Texas, Nov. 29. -- Citizens of this little South Texas community have taken a solemn oath that they will never abandon the search for Luther and John Blanton and for the persons who killed them if the two hunters have met with foul play.

PEARL S. BUCK has written an account of a missionary who was conscious of the world for an agonized ten minutes when he was 7 years old, and after that shut actuality away and lived in himself, happily believing that he lived in God. For half a century he preached in China, absently moved through rebellion and the crash of empire, was kicked, beaten, robbed and spat upon, but never fully emerged from his dream.

Item 2 of the Theatre Guild's season, "Prelude to Exile," by William J. McNally, will be revealed officially at 8:25 o'clock tonight in the Fifty-second Street headquarters. A drama of Richard Wagner during that period when he was writing "Tristan," it brings Wilfrid Lawson as the composer, Eva Le Gallienne as Mathilde Wesendonck, Lucile Watson as the Countess Marie D'Agoult, Evelyn Varden as Minna, Miriam Battista as Cosima, Leo G. Carroll as Otto Wesendonck.
CHICAGO, Nov. 29 (AP). -- Earl Lookabaugh of Chicago defeated Art Thurnblad of Chicago, 50 to 30, in forty-one innings tonight in the world championship three-cushion billiard tournament.

Building employes in the downtown area will help the Sanitation Department removing snow this Winter, under an arrangement worked out by William F. Carey, Sanitation Commissioner, and the management division of the Real Estate Board of New York, it was announced yesterday.

GENEVA, Nov. 29. - - A proposal to establish a fortyhour week in the printing trades, made By the International Trade Convention, will be considered by an International Labor Organization committee meeting here tomorrow.

A very ancient philosopher observed that a changing and complex problem may in time point its own solution if we are able to discern it. The world today presents a problem of war and peace, of fascism, communism and democracy, that is constantly changing and becoming increasingly complex.

SAINT JOHN, N.B., Nov. 29 (Canadian Press). -- Her starboard lifeboat stove in and her superstructure damaged by mountainous seas, the little Norwegian collier Fanefjeld crept into harbor last night after bucking the North Atlantic for twenty-seven days from Swansea, Wales.

In a decision he declared to be without precedent and which was based upon the social trend of recent legislation and legal opinion, Justice Jacob Panken in Domestic Relations Court ruled Tuesday that an illegitimate son is required to support his mother.

SEGOVIA, Spain, Nov. 29. -- Hinting that enemy propaganda behind the lines, designed to create a rift between the Carlists and the Fascists, is working, Colonel Juan Yague has appealed to local Fascists for concord. He suggested that the two parties merge and adopt one uniform, retaining the red beret of thin Carlists and the blue shirt of the Phalanxists.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29. -- Although corn was active on the Board of Trade here last week, it failed to reach the volume of trading that had been conspicuous for several weeks. Trade sentiment is more mixed and the general situation is so difficult to understand that, although many large operators express themselves as bullish, they are not so confident, as the price advances to much higher levels, as they were a few weeks ago.

DETROIT, Nov. 29 (AP). -- Pickets prevented removal today of several thousand finished automobile frames as the "stay-in" strike of 1,200 employes of the Midland Steel Products Company plant entered its third day.

The British Royal Commission now in Jerusalem inquiring into the administration of the Palestine mandate of the League of Nations was asked yesterday to embody in its findings the policies of the Balfour Declaration of 1917, which pledged Great Britain to facilitate the establishment of a Jewish national home in Palestine.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 29. -- Although Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, dismissed the subject tonight with the terse comment that he "had not heard of it," his name has been added to the list of those being mentioned for the Republican nomination for Governor next year.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 29. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 75 per cent of capacity, unchanged from the preceding week and 1 point under the recent high level, when tonnage output was the largest since early in 1930.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29. -- American motorists are speeding toward a new record of about 37,500 traffic accident fatalities this year, according to figures issued today by the National Safety Council. The total of such deaths during 1935 reached 37,000.

Five hundred Hungarian-Americans and members of the clergy attended the thirtieth anniversary celebration of the First Magyar Presbyterian Church, 223 East 116th Street, yesterday. The Rev. Ladislaus Harsanyi, pastor of the congregation since 1908, presided at the ceremonies which included a Hungarian dinner in the parish house following the morning jubilee service.

Addressing an audience of more than 2,200 at Carnegie Hall, Emil Ludwig, the writer, declared yesterday morning that the United States would find it difficult to remain aloof from an inevitable war in Europe. Dr. Ludwig spoke under the sponsorship of the Free Synagogue.
TOKYO, Nov. 29. -- Japan made known today her desire to build quickly an army equal to any Soviet Russia could put in the Far East in a war.

The judges of the American composers' contest conducted by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra have decided not to award a first prize in the competition for a short orchestral work but to give an honorable mention to Philip James for his overture, "Bret Harte."

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 29. -- Trading in the cotton market here last week was of moderate proportions with liquidation of the December position and evening up for the Thanksgiving holiday absorbing most of the attention of traders. Lack of speculative interest was attributed to fear of an increased estimate of the crop by the government in early December, which will be the last estimate of the season.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29. -- Bullish enthusiasm in the world's wheat markets carried prices sharply higher here last week and the upturn of yesterday following that of Friday made prices the highest since December, 1933. There were many recessions from every price upturn, but they induced new buying of greater volume which absorbed the offerings of traders who had favored higher price levels a long time and who were disposed to take profits.

PARIS, Nov. 28. -- There are evident reasons why industrial recovery, which already has taken shape in France, should continue and broaden on a large scale, as is happening in most other countries. Such recovery is hampered, however, by social agitation.

One has never found a plea for "a moratorium on preaching" in any year book of the Brick Presbyterian Church, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, declared yesterday morning in that edifice, at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 28. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 86, which compares with 86.1 the week before, 85.3 two weeks before, 84.7 three weeks before and 84.5 four weeks before.

VIENNA, Austria, Nov. 29. -- Admiral Nicholas Horthy, Regent of Hungary and his wife, coming from Rome, arrived in Vienna today for two-day visit. They were accompanied by Premier Koloman Daranyi, Foreign Minister Koloman de Kanya and a large staff.
CROYDON, England, Nov. 29 (AP). -- Captain James A. Mollison, before taking off for Cape Town today in the airplane Dorothy, said:
Cotton prices moved irregularly last week. On the New York Cotton Exchange their net changes ranged from an advance of 13 points on the maturing December delivery to a decline of 12 points on July.

Deceit is the characteristic trait of communism, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the faculty of Catholic University, pointed out in a sermon yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament, Seventy-first Street, east of Broad-way.

DETROIT, Nov. 29. -- The New York Americans, led by the high-scoring Dave (Sweeney) Schriner, handed Detroit's champion Red Wings their second successive shutout defeat tonight. The score was 2 -- 0, with Schriner scoring both goals.

BY this time Lieutenant Gar Davidson of the Army must be pretty well fed up with Penalty 2 under Article 4 of Rule 7 in the football rule book. That's the section that cut Army down to a tie with Notre Dame last year and cost it the Navy game the other day in Philadelphia.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 29. -- Just about blasted on their way by a shaky, puffy northwest wind, twenty-one sailing dinghies participated today in the regatta off the Larchmont Yacht Club. Three of them were blown over beyond their beam ends to capsize and cast their occupants in the frigid water.

GENEVA, Nov. 29. -- The dates of Dec. 7 or 14 for the League of Nations Council to meet on the Spanish appeal have been proposed to the Council members by their Acting President, Augustin Edwards, Chilean Ambassador to London, according to a good source.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman and leading educators from all parts of the country will participate in a series of meetings designed to "honor and evaluate scholarship in the fields of religion and Hebraic learning" under the auspices of the Semi-Centennial Committee of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, it was announced yesterday.

BOSTON, Nov. 29 (AP). -- The Marine Hospital here radioed instructions tonight for treatment of a "violently insane" man aboard the transatlantic freighter Independence Hall, ninety-five miles east of Nantucket.
GOSLAR, Germany, Nov. 29. -- Air Minister Hermann Goering, speaking here today at the Peasants Congress, declared that Germany was now a stronger military power than she was in 1914.

A curtailed hunting season on small upland game has just come to a close in Pennsylvania. The results were far from encouraging to the State Board of Game Commissioners. In fact, the board states that "unless we take care of what is left, it may be necessary to close certain seasons next year," and it urges sportsmen to exert special efforts to feed wild life during the severe weather ahead.
MOSCOW, Nov. 29. -- Andrei A. Zhdanoff, Leningrad Communist party leader, in an address at the All-Union Congress of Soviets today warned Baltic countries to avoid Fascist intrigues against Russia.
TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 30. -- Questions of consular status in Manchukuo, which the American and other governments have carefully avoided touching, are raised by the forthcoming Italo-Japanese agreement.

A syndicate consisting of Wall Street men who are investing their money in real estate has acquired a large midtown property, according to an announcement made over the week-end. The property involved is the eighteen-story and penthouse professional building at the northeast corner of Fifty-seventh Street and Sixth Avenue.
MONTREAL, Nov. 30 (Canadian Press). -- Dave (Sweeney) Schriner of the New York Americans leads National Hockey League scorers with a point total of 11, official statistics showed tonight.

Brooklyn employers, 26,000 of whom failed to file Social Security registration forms within the legal time limit, responded in such numbers yesterday that Postmaster Francis J. Sinnott abandoned his plan to draw up a list of delinquents for transmission to the Federal Social Security Board.

Officials of the city of Buffalo, N.Y., have invited bankers to submit tenders on Dec. 8 on a new issue of $1,900,000 of tax-anticipation certificates of indebtedness. The certificates will be dated Dec. 15, 1936, and will be due on June 15, 1937.

A seal featuring a "popping champagne cork" will be used as a quality insignia in the cooperative campaign to promote American wines, it was announced last night at a dinner held under the auspices of the American Champagne Guild in the Hotel Lexington to mark the start of the campaign.
ROME, Nov. 30. -- When the 393 members of Italy's Chamber of Deputies assembled today it was for one of the last parliamentary sessions of the legislative body.

LONDON, Nov. 30. -- The argument over the cost of passport visas, which has been going on spasmodically between the United States and British Governments ever since the World War, is about to be settled by a reduction of the visa fee from $10 to $2.
Heralding the approach of Christmas, Acting Captain Walter Rustis, in charge of the police headquarters pickpocket squad, issued a list of warnings to shoppers yesterday.

GENEVA, Nov. 30. -- The Permanent Central Opium Board of the League of Nations, in its report for 1935, adopted today, called the Council's attention to seventy-three tons of raw opium that Iran was reported to have exported to the Straits Settlements and that later was said to have been shipped to Manchukuo.

The air fleet of the Spanish Loyalists consists of fast and powerful airplanes that look like craft of American manufacture but are supposed to be of Russian origin, Arthur Menken, son of Mr. and Mrs. S. Stanwood Menken, said yesterday on his return from the Spanish battle zone.

The United States Treasury varied its recent policy yesterday, when it doubled its offering of discount bills. For a long time this has amounted to $50,000,000 weekly -- just enough to retire earlier issues of discount bills, maturing from one week to another. Yesterday the amount was raised to $100,000,000.

Supervisory workers on the four WPA Federal art projects were warned yesterday that their threatened refusal to designate subordinates to be dropped from relief jobs might lead to their own dismissal for "insubordination."

NEWARK, N. J., Nov. 30. -- A plan of reorganization for the Botany Consolidated Mills, Inc., of Passaic, submitted last April, was approved today by Federal Judge Guy L. Fake. The court approved also a slate of fifteen directors for the reorganized company.

ATLANTA, Nov. 30 (AP). -- The Citadel and the Middle Tennessee Teachers completed their Southern Intercollegiate Athletic Association gridiron campaign with four victories for the best records in the league. Miami University, with three triumphs; Centenary and Centre, each with two victories, and Howard with two triumphs and one tie also were unbeaten within the S.I.A.A. ranks.
A fifty-one-inch bronze head of Mark Twain was unveiled last night at a dinner at the Ritz-Carlton marking the humorist's 101st birthday.
LONDON, Nov. 30. -- The stock market here was cheerful today, although business was on a small scale. The British Government issues recovered after a dull start.

Our brave new world reverberates with brave new words. Frontiers between nations remain as exclusive as spite fences, but at least one medium of exchange knows no curb. No visa, tariff quota, currency restriction or prohibitory law hinders the free flow of loud language from one country to another.

New housing projects in Brooklyn and Queens featured the building plans filed yesterday. In the former borough the proposals included a $150,000 multi-family structure for East Eighteenth Street and a $52,500 group of dwellings for Eighty-first Street.

Plans for organizing apartment house superintendents and janitors into snow-fighting crews on a block-by-block basis were agreed upon yesterday at a conference between officials of the Sanitation Department and representatives of civic organizations, including the New York Real Estate Board.

The Don Cossack Chorus, directed by Serge Jaroff, gave its only New York recital of the season last night as the second event of the seventh annual Town Hall endowment series. This was the third time that the ensemble has appeared in these institutional programs; no other individual or group has had more than two concerts.

ROME, Nov. 30. -- Foreign Minister Count Galeazzo Ciano today received the new Chilean Ambassador, who delivered to him a copy of his credentials addressed to Victor Emmanuel III both as King of Italy and Emperor of Ethiopia.

Bonds called for payment in November before maturity aggregated $126,941,000, the smallest total for a month since May, 1935. The amount compared with $341,801,000 in the preceding month and with $219,529,000 in November, 1935.

The five members of New York City's Police Department who entered New York University's Washington Square College to study for a Bachelor of Arts degree in preparation for Law School are far better than average students, Dean Milton E. Loomis said yesterday in an interview in the presence of the five.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 30. -- Lieutenant Thomas J. Hamilton, head coach of the Navy team which defeated Army Saturday, said today that was the "best Navy team I've ever seen" and one to which "no one has given due credit."

The complete personnel of the tennis cast which will surround Fred Perry of Great Britain when he makes his professional debut at Madison Square Garden the night of Jan. 6 was announced yesterday by the promoters, Francis T. Hunter and S. Howard Voshell.

That miniature women's symphony orchestra which rejoices in the title of Orchestrette Classique, and is conducted by Frederique Petrides -- not the only one of her sex to swing the baton hereabout -- gave one of its excellent and original programs last night in Carnegie Chamber-Music Hall.

In her recent letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES Pearl Bernstein advocates the diversion of revenues from motor vehicle taxes from their proper use on the highways, in order to pay for traffic policemen, traffic lights, snow removal, support of hospitals, playgrounds and park areas.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30. -- Mayor S. Davis Wilson abolished today his special police raiding squad which has been crusading since mid-Summer against organized gambling rackets and vice. Lieutenant John T. Murphy, head of the squad, was promoted to be acting captain of detectives and the other members were detailed to street duty.

VIENNA, Nov. 30. -- The city's garrison paraded today before Admiral Nicholas Horthy, Regent of Hungary, 15,000 men in their new equipment and with modern armament lining the Ringstrasse. The Regent offered his congratulations on the troops' bearing.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- More than forty striking seamen from Baltimore paraded in front of the German Embassy here today in protest against Germany's policy in Spain.

The General Investment Corporation, an investment trust controlled by the International Equities Corporation, has sold its holdings of obligations of the Buenos Aires Central Railroad and Terminal Company to Buenos Aires interests, it was announced yesterday by Ernest B. Warriner, president of General Investment.

Bobby Pacho of Los Angeles took the decision over Ray Napolitano of Williamsburgh at the end of a hard-fought eight-round bout before 2,500 fans at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. Pacho weighed 146 1/2 and Napolitano 146 1/4.

Under the lead of December which advanced above 12 cents a pound for the first time since Oct. 19, prices on the Cotton Exchange continued to strengthen and closed with a gain of 9 to a loss of 3 points yesterday. As the spot month was the strongest on the list, so October of the next crop was weakest.
The thirteen teams remaining in the six-day bicycle race at Madison Square Garden continued to ride their weary way 'round and 'round the huge pine saucer last night.
A plan for renting oil paintings by the month has been put in operation here by the East River Gallery, opened recently at 358 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Money rates were unchanged in November for the sixth consecutive month. Absence of any appreciable change in brokers' loans, as might be expected from greater stock market activity, was a contributing factor to the steadiness of quotations.

A total of $75,000 has been contributed to the United Hospital Campaign by three large companies, it was announced yesterday. They were J.P. Morgan Co., $30,000; the United States Steel Corporation, $25,000, and Kuhn, Loeb Co., $20,000.

GENEVA, Nov. 30. -- The probability of a League of Nations Council meeting on the Spanish appeal before Dec. 7 was virtually ended today when replies to the council president's inquiries showed wide divergencies on the date. Three main trends were shown by the first three replies received.

Dr. Richard Archbold, who returned Sunday from an expedition far into the hinterland of Southern New Guinea, was back at his desk yesterday in the mammalogy section of the American Museum of Natural History and gave details of his experiences.

ROME, Nov. 30. -- Italy, in common with all other League of Nations members, has received an invitation to attend the special Council session convoked to consider the Spanish Government's appeal. Whether or not the Italian Government will participate depends on the result of conversations the Italian Ambassadors in London and Paris are carrying on.

Joseph Mercadante, shipper, testified in the Supreme Court yesterday that in March, 1918, the United States Shipping Board requisitioned three of his ships and paid him $7,000,000 less than the board received from the Italian Government for their use.
RUTLAND, Vt., Nov. 30. -- Vermont's Governor, Charles M. Smith, president of the Rutland Marble Savings Bank, was arrested today, charged with concealing alleged thefts from the bank he headed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- A charge that the American International Corporation had used "window dressing" in its reports to its stockohlders for 1927 and 1930 and that this practice had resulted in a profit-and-loss statement which made the company show a profit at the end of 1930 despite the decline in the value of securties, was made today at hearings in connection with the investigation of investment trusts by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

BERLIN, Nov. 30. -- Sentences of one and one-half to two and one-half years, passed in Kattowicz, Poland, on nineteen German boys charged with belonging to the secret German Youth Organization were protested today in certain Berlin newspapers, notably the Angriff.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Nov. 30. -- The Claim of an 81-year-old retired railroad switchman of Sacramento, Calif., for part of the estate of Mrs. Ellen Jane Ackerman of Westwood, who died Nov. 20, 1935, was declared valid today by James D. Moore, Inheritance Tax Supervisor of Bergen County, who is also administrator of the estate.

The University of Pittsburgh's football team, beaten once and tied once this season, was named the outstanding college eleven in the East by the board of judges for the new August V. Lambert Memorial Trophy, it was announced yesterday.
CHICAGO, Nov. 30. -- An increase of more than $5,500,000 in the payroll of the International Harvester Company in the United States and Canada was announced today.

Steadily increasing interest in the covering of staple and semi-staple needs for post-holiday selling was reflected in the mail orders received in the market here yesterday. With the wholesale markets bare of any substantial quantities of off-price merchandise of the traditional January white-goods type, the communications from retailers began to take on a more anxious note with respect to covering commitments of this type.

The tax of 3 per cent imposed by the city against public service corporations as a means of providing revenue to relieve the unemployed is constitutional, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals held yesterday, dismissing a suit filed by the Southern Boulevard Railroad Company.

Because of objections of Negro leaders that a figure of a Negro eating a piece of watermelon in a scene depicting Abraham Lincoln is undignified and "belittling" to the Negro race, the figure will be painted out and another substituted in the murals decorating the rotunda of the County Court House, it was decided yesterday.

A new type of railroad dwarf locomotive, much smaller than the modern ones but with capacities of 2,000 to 10,000 horsepower, was described last night before the fifty-seventh annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

ALBANY, Nov. 30. -- In the presence of lawyers and civic leaders, a portrait of the late Chief Justice Cuthbert W. Pound of the Court of Appeals was presented to the court today by Presiding Justice Charles B. Sears of the Appellate Division, Fourth Department.

BERLIN, Nov. 30. -- Trading on the Boerse was quiet again today. [ Heavy industrials at the close showed some strength in a small turnover, Vereinigestahl gaining 5 point and /fannesmann 1. Potashes were largely inactive; Salzdetfurth lost 2A point.

The charge of Senator John J. McNaboe, chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee to Investigate Communism and Subversive Activities in the Public Schools and Colleges, that Cornell University was a "center of revolutionary communistic propaganda" exposed the Senator yesterday to a flood of criticism, including some from within the committee itself.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 30 (AP). -- Gene Sarazen, the Connecticut farmer-golfer, thinks the professionals should give the game a new act, and suggested today that the pros delete the present medal play events.

In honor of the loves and tantrums of Richard Wagner the Theatre Guild has produced for its second play of the season "Prelude to Exile," which was staged at the Guild Theatre last evening. It is so vast an improvement upon the first play of the season that patient subscribers may now logically look forward to a third play that will be not only respectable but exciting.

While the number of new diphtheria cases reported for the week ended Saturday declined to 19, the new tuberculosis cases rose to 178, the highest total in any seven-day period since Oct. 10, Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, announced yesterday.

While the leading issues were sagging yesterday, several low-priced stocks advanced in active trading. Of the twelve most active issues on the Stock Exchange, no fewer than eight were in a price range between $1 and $9 a share. Not one motor, steel or public utility stock was in the list of the dozen most active stocks.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 30. -- Mrs. Lorenzo F. Woodhouse, chairman of the board of directors of the Society of the Four Arts, will preside at the group's opening tea on Saturday. She arrived today from Easthampton, L.I., to open Quinta Marina.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 1. -- Japanese officials are displeased by what they term magnified versions of the Italo-Japanese negotiations, which, it is broadly hinted, originate in Rome's desire to give the accord greater importance than it possesses.

The winning novel in the international novel competition for a $20,000 award will be published on Jan. 4 by Farrar Rinehart. The title is "The Street of the Fishing Cat," and the author is Jolan Foldes. "Steps Going Down," by John T. McIntyre, won the American prize in this competition.

It is not strange that the Mayor and the Police Commissioner were a good deal disturbed by the incident which occurred in Forty-sixth Street the other evening. A citizen having parked his car while he was eating dinner was approached by three men who demanded that he give them a quarter for having "watched" it.
Dean Detton, one of the many claimants to the world heavyweight wrestling championship, conquered Big Chief Sanooke, giant 325-pound Indian, before 3,000 at the New York Hippodrome last night.

Members of the Tenth District of the Advertising Federation of America, representing six clubs in Texas, and the Oklahoma City Advertising Club, have started a movement to guard advertising against adverse tax legislation. A special committee will be appointed from the district to work with the existing committee of the Texas Press Association in "fighting legislation levying discriminatory taxation on advertising," according to Will F. Grant, retiring governor of the district.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 30. -- It took a photo to decide the winner of the Shreveport Purse, mile race that topped the Fair Grounds program today.

A steady to firm undertone was reflected by almost all classes of bonds in trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. High-grade underlying obligations were firm to slightly better in light trading, while several of the recently favored convertible industrial loans extended their advance on good volume.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Greater public interest in America's foreign policy and support of it are urged in a publication issued today by the National League of Women Voters. In it the Pan-American Conference in Buenos Aires and the civil war in Spain are contrasted as current events emphasizing the need of understanding action by people everywhere to maintain peace.

Having spent a week with Coward comedy, the theatre tonight reaches back to the Restoration for Wycherley's "The Country Wife." Ruth Gordon has the title role -- she had it in earlier variations at Westport in 1935 and at London's Old Vic more recently -- and others helping out are Irene Browne, Percy Waram, Louis Hector, Roger Livesey, Anthony Quayle, George Carr and Helena Pickard.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 30 (AP). -- B.H. Markham of New York, director of the American Petroleum Industries Committee, speaking here tonight told more than 1,000 delegates to the convention of the Independent Petroleum Association of America that "gasoline is cheap, only the tax is high."

Rumors of a shake-up in the Long Island University basketball team, which has won thirty-three straight, were substantiated somewhat yesterday as Coach Clair F. Bee named two sophomores to start tonight in the Blackbirds' opener against Princeton Seminary at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium.

Mr. and Mrs. George Arents Jr. were hosts at a dinner last night in their home, 6 East Seventy-seventh Street, for his mother, Mrs. George Arents, to celebrate her birthday. Later they took their guests to a theatre and after that to supper in the Persian Room of the Plaza.

Exhibits to show that the New York, New Haven Hartford incurred losses of $298,384,000, including charges for interest and for depreciation of capital, between July 1, 1913, and Oct. 23, 1935, from unprofitable investments were introduced by counsel for the Interstate Commerce Commission at a hearing in the Pennsylvania Hotel yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- The government's plans for industrial mobilization of the nation's resources in the event of war contemplate no thought of control or management of industrial establishments by army personnel, Secretary Woodring said tonight.

Describing what he considered essential in new legislation changing the present Federal statute on pure foods and drugs, Senator Royal S. Copleland yesterday told delegates to the twenty-eighth annual convention of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America that a new law must protect consumers, must not weaken the existing law and must be so constructed as to permit legitimate industry to live without continual annoyance from the government.

Looking ahead with anticipation to the balmy climes they will meet on their way to Tyler, Texas, for their game with Texas A. and M. Saturday, Manhattan's football players shivered through a brisk ninety-minute drill in sub-freezing weather at Innisfail Park yesterday.
VALENCIA, Nov. 30. -- This city, which is bigger and busier today than ever before in its history, will witness tomorrow its first sitting of the Spanish Legislature.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 30. -- Mrs. Louise Geist Burns, who played an important part in the investigation into the murders of the Rev. Edward Wheeler Hall and his choir leader, Mrs. James Mills, died late Saturday night in Middlesex General Hospital of pneumonia a week after the birth of a daughter.

LONDON, Nov. 30. -- Lord Nuffield, wealthy motor manufacturer and philanthropist, announced today the formation of a 2,125,000 trust fund composed of common stock of Morris Motors Ltd., the proceeds of which will be distributed to wage-earning employes.

GENEVA, Nov. 30. -- The British Government and British employers were accused by the United States workers' delegate of blocking the proposed forty-hour convention in the printing industry when an International Labor Organization committee was considering the project at a meeting today.
MADRID, Nov. 30. -- A strong Insurgent attack on the strategic town of Pozuelo de Alarcon, about seven miles northwest of Madrid, was reported crushed tonight in a Spanish Government bulletin.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 30. -- The Pan-American Peace Conference, which President Franklin D. Roosevelt suggested last January, will open here tomorrow afternoon under the official name of the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace.

For the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a net profit of $9,142,654 after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges. After dividends on the series A 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock, the net profit is equivalent to $3.28 each on 1,932,497 shares of $10-par common stock.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Vice President and Mrs. Garner, weeks ahead of their planned schedule but "obeying orders from the President," returned to Washington this evening.

Hand-woven woolens, beaten copper ornaments, tiny toy dolls and household utensils of every description, representing the efforts of 1,400 blind persons throughout New York State, were offered to the public at reasonable prices yesterday at the opening of the fourteenth annual Christmas Sale for the Blind.
