To aid owners of multiple residential properties in New York and other large cities, Stewart McDonald, national administrator of the FHA, will ask Congress to extend mortgage activities to dwellings of more than four families and to dwellings that include store properties.

MONTREAL, Nov. 30 (AP). -- The International Baseball League today opened its two-day meeting prior to the annual gathering of the National Association of Professional Baseball Clubs by holding two brief sessions at which various minor matters were cleared up.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Announcement that the New York Central Railroad Company had discharged all its obligations to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, including $6,969,000 collateral notes purchased by the RFC from the Public Works Administration, and had wiped its slate clean with a final payment of $16,858,951, was made today.

BERLIN, Nov. 30. -- The Reich Minister of the Interior, Dr. Wilhelm Frick, today ordered civil servants to abandon the terms Christian, Protestant and Catholic in documents indicating a citizen's religion. New categories for this purpose place members of Nordic-Pagan associations and Christian churches under one heading, "members of a religious society or ideological society."

The stock market held irregularly lower during most of yesterday, resisting rather well considerable selling pressure. In the final hour, some sections of the list rallied substantially, so that the tone at the closing was steady to firm. Transactions on the Stock Exchange totaled 2,142,000 shares, against 2,276,000 on Friday.

Due somewhat to the holiday, but mainly to inability on the part of the mills to secure sufficient yarns for the business offered, trading in synthetic and silk griege goods last week was reduced in comparison with the preceding two weeks, according to the market report of Nickel, Barrett, Lieberman Quinn, textile brokers.

BOSTON, Nov. 30. -- The first test case in the country of the Social Security Act was argued before Judge George C. Sweeney in the Federal District Court here today. Judge Sweeney took the case under advisement.

The United States Department of Labor, through Sylvester Pindyck, special assistant to Attorney General Homer Cummings, started actions yesterday in the Brooklyn Federal Court to cancel the citizenship of sixty-three Brooklyn and Queens residents.
The Board of Alderman adopted the 1937 tax levy budget at a total of $554,998,917.10 yesterday without exercising its privilege of reducing any of the budget items.
Eight Manhattan parcels and seven Bronx properties were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales yesterday.
Two British ships will leave this week with 75,000 pounds of yellow New York State onions, the first shipment of onions from this country to England since the World War.

The Johns Manville Corporation announced yesterday that each employe in its service longer than a year would receive a bonus of about a week's pay, while those in its service more than six months, but less than a year, would receive about a half week's pay.

GENEVA, Nov. 30. -- The world's admitted arms traffic in 1935 totaled $43,600,000 (old standard), or nearly $72,000,000 on the present United States gold basis, according to the League of Nations arms trade year book, issued today. This was the same total as the previous year's.
The Green Bay Packers, the Chicago Bears and the Boston Redskins are staging a close fight for statistical laurels in the National Football League, according to the team figures announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30. -- A warning that the military air power of the United States was falling behind in the world race for air supremacy was given today at the first working conference of the National Aeronautical Association.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 30. -- A special session of the Legislature will be held starting Dec. 21 for enactment of an unemployment compensation law, as required under the Federal social security program. Should the State fail to act by Dec. 31 it would stand to forfeit a 90 per cent rebate of payroll taxes, estimated at about $12,000,000.
MADRID, Nov. 26 (Delayed). -- It is now three weeks since the government departed, and still Madrid holds out.

ALBANY, Nov. 30. -- Governors of all the States have been invited by Governor Lehman to participate in the World's Fair in New York beginning April 30, 1939, which will celebrate the 150th anniversary of the inauguration of George Washington and the establishment of the Federal Government in New York City.

The codfish is a dullard. He is logy, lazy and a coward. On the end of a line he submits passively to his fate, gives no more argument than an old boot. There is no fight in him. You just draw him up.

The Broadway Tabernacle Society will receive $846,537 from the $1,106,950 net estate of Mrs. Harriet M. Richardson, widow of Frank H. Richardson and head of the Richardson Manufacturing Company, makers of jewelry. This was disclosed yesterday with the filing of the transfer-tax appraisal on her estate.

The Young Women's Christian Association served more than 3,000,000 women and girls in the United States in 1935, Miss Katherine Lambert, chairman of the organization's World Service Council, said yesterday at the council's annual meeting, held at the home of Mrs. Ray P. Stevens, 834 Fifth Avenue.

The extent of overlapping taxation imposed by the Federal and the forty-eight State Governments is summarized in a report just issued by the Treasury Department. In 1935 the Federal Government received $2,271,400,000 from six tax sources, and the various States also received a total of $1,049,900,000 from these same tax sources -- estates and inheritances, individual incomes, corporation incomes, gasoline, liquor and tobacco.

Price changes were mixed on local commodity futures markets yesterday, with silk, cottonseed oil and the breakfast-table commodities stronger and other staples generally weaker for the day. On the cash markets, new highs were set by wheat, rye, lard and cocoa, and cotton, corn, flour and silk gained. Declines developed in butter, oats, tin and rubber.

For the second time within a year John L. Lotsch, Brooklyn attorney, who once was president of the Flatbush Republican Club, was cleared yesterday of the charge that he had asked $500 and had received $200 in connection with patent litigation in which he had been designated to sit as a special master.

An Italian exhibition will open to the public today at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East Thirty-sixth Street. From the marvelously rich archives of this collection have been selected original drawings, illuminated manuscripts, autograph manuscripts and letters, together with artists' sketch books, printed books and examples of bookbinding.

Charges that Spanish Catholic priests "with bombs and bayonets in their hands" were participating on the Rebel side in the "assault against the liberties of the Spanish people" were made last night by Dr. Fernando de los Rios, Spanish Ambassador to the United States.
The Police Department, the Board of Aldermen and the West Side Association of Commerce decided yesterday to put an end to the petty hoodlum racket of "car watching" in the theatrical district.

READING, Pa., Nov. 30. -- Resisting tear gas and sub-freezing temperatures, a living carpet of hosiery strike pickets lay on the pavement today before the Berkshire Knitting Mills in suburban Wyomissing, where a walkout began ten weeks ago.

LONDON, Nov. 30. -- Engulfed in a roaring sheet of flames, which towered so high into the night sky that it could be seen almost from the English Channel, the world-famous Crystal Palace, architectural pride of the Victorian era, crashed to the earth tonight a raging inferno of twisted girders and molten glass.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 30. -- The Argentine capital welcomed President Roosevelt today with a reception that was in every way the largest and most jubilant this country has ever extended to anyone.

With the statement that proportional representation was a complex matter that could not be handled "like a mail-order proposition," S. Howard Cohen, president of the Board of Elections, and three of his colleagues left yesterday to study the election machinery in Cincinnati, where proportional representation is used.
CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (AP). -- Vernon Washington, St. Paul outfielder, finally has caught up with the American Association batting championship -- with the help of a league ruling.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 30. -- Moshe Shertok, head of the political department of the Jewish agency, testifying today before the Royal Commission on questions of Jewish immigration, especially of laborers, indicated that far from overcrowding the labor market the latest group of immigrants, accompanied as it was by new Jewish capital for investment, also increased opportunities for Arab laborers.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30. -- Willie Hoppe of New York, the defending champion, won his second match in the world's three-cushion billiard title tournament tonight, defeating Allen Hall of Chicago, 50 to 37, in 45 innings.

Curtailment by the New York State Legislature of all State spending is recommended in a report, made public yesterday, by the committee on taxation and public revenue of the Merchants Association of New York. The association announced that it would distribute this week to commercial and civic groups, State and city officials and members of the Legislature a pamphlet containing two reports, the results of a tax-load study.
Several apartment house coveyances by banks were included in the New Jersey realty transfers reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30. -- Hog prices advanced 5 to 15 cents today to the highest level in six weeks despite receipts of 41,000, the largest for Monday since December, 1934. Some late sales of lights were regarded as 25 cents a hundredweight above Friday's market.

Dr. COFFIN paid a high tribute to the Brick Church in praising its recent pastors, for congregations "are known by the ministers they choose." The noble succession includes HENRY VAN DYKE, MALTBIE D. BABCOCK, WILLIAM R. RICHARDS and WILLIAM P. MERRILL, to go no further back than the memory of most of the living.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- The Public Service Company of New Hampshire, a subsidiary of New England Public Service Company, a registered holding company, filed today application with the Securities and Exchange Commission for exemption from the requirements for filing a declaration under the Public Utility Act of 1935 with respect to $1,400,000 of bonds, 11,500 shares of preferred stock and 10,000 common shares.

" SHE is certainly not handsome," the groom-to-be admitted, "nor would she be quite called plain, I think. She is 28 years old. She knows her own mind uncommon well. She does not talk very American. Her manners are quiet. She reads German -- also Latin -- also, I fear, a little Greek, but very little. She talks garrulously, but on the whole pretty sensibly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- The Treasury will borrow $300,000,000 in "new money" on Dec. 15, pay $400,000,000 of maturing bills in cash and refund about $758,000,000 in notes falling due on that date and on Feb. 15, Secretary Morgenthau announced today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30. -- Opening guns were fired today in what is expected to be a protracted legal battle between Harley L. Clarke of Chicago, recently deposed as president of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, and Floyd B. Odlum of New York, president of the Atlas Corporation, the investment trust that in 1935 gained control of the utilities company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- When President Roosevelt returns from South America one of his first official acts, according to information in high naval quarters, will be to use the discretion voted him at the last session of Congress to begin construction of two battleships whenever such construction is undertaken by other signatories to the London Naval Treaty of 1930.

Two of the eight former officers and directors of the defunct National Title Guaranty Company on trial before Federal Judge Harlan W. Rippey in Brooklyn will be acquitted by direction of the court, it was indicated yesterday as their attorneys began summing up in their trial on conspiracy and mail fraud charges.

Rapid recovery in the market value of two large certificated mortgage series of the New York Title Company was reported yesterday at the Bar Association before a joint investigating committee presided over by Senator Lazarus Joseph of the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- The function of the handful of Republicans in the next House of Representatives is to provide a reliable and dispassionate source of information on bills, said Representative Bacon today in suggesting establishment of a "fact-coordinating" bureau in the Republican Congressional Committee.

Savings of $114,000 annually to consumers in Freeport and Rockville Centre are contained in revised electric rate schedules submitted to the Public Service Commission by the municipal power plants in those two villages. The commission announced yesterday the new rates would go into effect this month.
Paced by Pitt's powerful Panthers, eight teams are represented on The Associated Press Eastern football team announced yesterday.

The sustained interest in real estate in the midtown district close to Rockefeller Center was demonstrated again yesterday with announcement of the sale of the block front on the west side of Sixth Avenue from Fiftieth to Fifty-first Street.

LONDON, Nov. 30. -- Another thinly veiled warning to King Edward -- the third within a week -- appeared in The Times of London this morning, tucked away at the very end of an otherwise innocuous leading editorial.

Imports of gold here in November amounted to $66,705,400, the smallest total for a month since August. They compared with $182,284,800 in October 1936, and $205,090,700 in November, 1935. Last month was the eighth consecutive one in which there were no exports of the metal.

PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 30 (AP). -- The Tournament of Roses football committee was "just as puzzled as the fans" tonight over who will play the University of Washington in the Rosa Bowl New Year's day.

Three special trains will leave the city this afternoon with more than 400 delegates and their wives from New England and the New York metropolitan area aboard, on the way to the twenty-fifth annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America, which will convene tomorrow morning in Augusta, Ga.

Supreme Court Justice Timothy A. Leary signed an order yesterday reopening the two-year-old fight between Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt and Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney over the custody of Mrs. Vanderbilt's daughter. Gloria Laura Morgan Vanderbilt.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30. -- "You Can't Take It With You," the new comedy by Moss Hart and George S. Kaufman, had its metropolitan premiere at the Chestnut Street Opera House here tonight before a responsive audience that laughed hilariously at times over the activities of an eccentric New York family, the Sycamores.
ROME, Nov. 30. -- The Chamber of Deputies reopened today and its first sitting was marked by a great, enthusiastic demonstration to Premier Mussolini and the State's armed forces.

Martin (Buggsy) Goldstein, self-styled "Public Enemy No. 6," and his bodyguard, Seymour Magoon, were sentenced yesterday to serve indefinite terms in the penitentiary by, Special Sessions Justices Kozicke, Perlman and Brady in Jamaica, Queens.

Some Columbia pundits have done a public service by discovering Little Compton, one of the most meritorious towns in the United States. Seven miles away from Newport, it is fortunately several centuries away in most other respects. It is old Rhode Island. It has flocked by itself and remained original.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

New securities offered here in November amounted to $275,322,000, and consisted of $250,903,000 in fifty-one bond issues and $24,419,000 in thirteen stock issues. Offerings in October totaled $392,291,000, with $330,412,000 for forty-five bond issues and $61,879,000 for sixteen stock issues.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 30. -- In the first balloon weather observation flight ever attempted in darkness in this country, Harvard University sent a balloon up to a height of about 50,000 feet early this morning. It sent back a radio signal indicating a temperature of 77 degrees below zero and then floated southward to land off Cape Cod.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -Railroad normally accounting for more than 98 per cent of operating revenues of all Class I roads had a combined net railway operating income in October of $88,477,459, compared to $74,043,157 for the corresponding month last year, an increase of 19.4 per cent, The Association of American Railroads announced today.

Stressing the importance of cooperation and education in safety work, the Associated Advisory Committee of the Greater New York Safety Council held a luncheon yesterday under the chairmanship of Arthur Williams, president of the council, at the Hotel Commodore.

Walter Mills, American baritone, who has not been heard here in several seasons, appeared in recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. His program began with Beethoven's "Die Ehre Gottes in der Natur," sung in English; an aria from Verdi's "Simon Boccanegra" and Peri's "Invocazione di Orfeo."

The International Catholic Truth Society is undertaking to organize 500 young women to collect funds throughout the city for medical supplies to be sent to the Fascist forces in Spain, the Rev. Dr. Edward Lodge Curran, president of the society, announced last night.

A large audience attended Albert Morris Bagby's 390th musical morning yesterday in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The artists were Miss Maria Mueller, Emanuel List of the Metropolitan Opera and Alberto Salvi, harpist. At the piano was Fritz Kitzinger.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 30. -- Bids for purchase of the 167-foot Absecon Lighthouse, which was built on the shore here in 1854 but which now stands far back in a residential district, will be received by the Treasury Department Dec. 15, according to word reaching here today from Washington.

Another arrest was made shortly after 6 o'clock last night in an investigation by Bernard Botein, Assistant District Attorney in charge of the new Accident Fraud Bureau, of an alleged extensive accident ring in which, he charged, about 500 bogus claims, running from $50 to $250, had been paid by insurance companies in the last nine years.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 30. -- The Rev. Dr. Howard Sargent Wilkinson, canon of the Protestant Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation here, said tonight he had been appointed rector of St. Thomas's Episcopal Church at Eighteenth and Church Streets, Washington, D.C., of which President Roosevelt and his family are communicants.

ALBANY, Nov. 30. -- Reports of damage to vessels by ice in the State barge canal system coincided today with the announcement that shippers were working feverishly to clear more than one hundred vessels before Winter forces the waterway to close.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Nov. 25 shows a decrease for the week of $41,000,000 in total loans and investments, an increase of $65,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and decreases of $72,000,000 in government deposits, $69,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks, $30,000,000 in balances with domestic banks and $40,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

Sale of Hampshire House, unfinished thirty-four story apartment hotel at 150 Central Park South, for not less than $1,000,000, all cash, was recommended yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler by Frank L. Weil, speaking for trustees of the $24,419,857 Series C-2 guaranteed mortgage certificate issue of the New York Title and Mortgage Company.

LONDON, Nov. 30. -- The government's expectation of being able to rush the new shipping bill for prevention of carrying arms to Spain through all its parliamentary stages tomorrow without opposition is now frustrated by the unforeseen antagonism from both the Labor and Liberal groups in the House of Commons.

Minnesota's Gophers hold their place as America's No. 1 college football team by a decisive margin over Louisiana State, champion of the deep South, in the final national ranking poll conducted by The Associated Press for 1936.

Because of present world conditions, Christianity is facing what is perhaps its greatest crisis in all history, Bishop William T. Manning declared yesterday morning before fifty members of the Baptist Ministers Association at their weekly conference at the Madison Avenue Baptist Church, 30 East Thirty-first Street.
BERLIN, Nov. 30. -- Did Germany in winning Japan finally alienate Britain and therewith destroy one of the pillars of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's own foreign policy?

CHICAGO, Nov. 30. -- The world's wheat markets continued on the upgrade today with all deliveries on the Board of Trade here and the March and May futures at Liverpool selling at new high prices for the season. Prices here were up as much as 1 cent a bushel at the extreme, with the December selling at $1.20 7/8, the highest level at which any future has sold since July in 1933.

Hearings before the Public Service Commission on the proposed merger of the Consolidated Edison Company, the Bronx Gas and Electric Company and the New York Edison Company, Inc., came to an end yesterday, with testimony by Floyd L. Carlisle, head of the Consolidated system.
J. Howard Sindberg is with the Hetfield Company as manager of the bond-trading department.
The Princeton Club and the City A.C. teams remained undefeated in the Metropolitan League Class B squash tennis tournament as a result of matches played yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Further gains in farmers' cash income were shown today in a Department of Agriculture report that October receipts from sales of farm commodities totaled $886,000,000, as compared with $752,000,000 in September, and $802,000,000 in October, 1935.

BERLIN, Nov. 30. -- Following in King Edward's footsteps, a special correspondents for the German news agency has been sent to the stricken coal areas of South Wales in an attempt to contrast the blessings of Nazi rule in Germany with misery in other countries.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- The State Department gave out today details of a reciprocal trade agreement between the United States and Costa Rica which was signed Saturday. It is the fifteenth completed under the Trade Agreements Act passed in 1934 and the eighth signed with a Latin American nation.

IN the thick of the recent bleak football scrimmages there came that entrancing tale about a fair exchange between the St. Louis Cardinals and the Pittsburgh Pirates. Possibly Branch the non-alcoholic Rickey is aiming at the Nobel Prize for Literature. Certainly he turned out one of the best short stories of the week.

Whipped by a freezing offshore wind that set taut her dress flags from jackstaff to ensign and made 12,000 spectators shiver, the U.S.S. Brooklyn glided into the waters of Wallahout Basin off the Navy Yard in Brooklyn, at 9:43 o'clock yesterday morning, to add a 10,000-ton light cruiser to the strength of the United States Fleet.

The most novel feature of the program played by Albert Spalding, the violinist, last night in Carnegie Hall was the work in the form of a suite, or sonata if you like, of Joaquin Turina, "El poema de una Sanluquena." The composition was not played for the first time hereabouts, as advance notices had inferred, but was perhaps heard for the first time by a Carnegie Hall audience.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30. -- Harvey J. Harman, head football coach at the University of Pennsylvania, who announced before the start of the season, "I am ready to take all the blame or some of the credit for whatever happens this year," was reappointed today for a term of three years.

I am quite in accord with your verdict that Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. really did not get anywhere in his radio address on the need for Republican reorganization. As a matter of fact, it is quite impossible for men to sit in conference and deliberately fabricate a political issue.

State Senator McNABOE says that Cornell University is a center of revolutionary communistic propaganda. Can it be that Mr. McNABOE has seen in the press frequent references to the Big Red Team from Ithaca and has jumped to conclusions?

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 30. -Purchase of the plot about which the 1937 "Goldwyn Follies" will revolve was announced today at the Goldwyn offices. The original story, written by a New York newspaper man under the nom de plume of Harry Selby, concerns a metropolitan theatre critic who becomes a producer.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month, with only twenty-two sessions, was the heaviest of any month since last February and the largest for a November since 1929, with the exception of last year.

Dick Weisgerber, an Eastern boy who went West to make good in a big way on intercollegiate football fields, made a great bid to snatch the national scoring leadership from Norman Schoen of Baldwin-Wallace during the past week, but fell 19 points short of his mark, according to The Associated Press compilation.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 30. -- Arthur M. Brown, Republican candidate for Governor of Connecticut, and J. Kenneth Bradley, Re publican floor leader of the State Senate, united in urging a revitalization of the Republican party in the State today.

Thousands of city employes are being defrauded of amounts up to 10 per cent of their salaries through a well-organized garnishee racket, an investigation by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., revealed yesterday, has disclosed.

Two more maritime unions, with a combined membership of about 9,500 men, voted yesterday to join the strike which is being staged in Atlantic and Gulf ports by insurgent members of the International Seamen's Union and the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association and the Master Mates and Pilots Association.

Max Schmeling cabled the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday that he will arrive in this country in time to be present at the meeting of the commission on Dec. 11, at which time it is hoped articles will be signed for the proposed championship fight between the German challenger and James J. Braddock, titleholder.

Although night baseball, inaugurated in the National League last Summer by the Cincinnati Reds, is slated to make its debut in the American League in 1937 with the Browns acting as sponsors in St. Louis, New York will continue to remain cold toward playing under floodlights.

The estate of Otto Sartorius has sold to James A. Graham the six-story elevator apartment house, on a plot 120 by 110 feet, at 1,290 Ocean Avenue, northeast corner of Avenue H, Brooklyn. There are fifty-nine apartments in the building, which was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $318,000. Thomas M. Graham Co. were the brokers.

The estate of Otto Sartorius has sold to James A. Graham the six-story elevator apartment house, on a plot 120 by 110 feet, at 1,290 Ocean Avenue, northeast corner of Avenue H, Brooklyn. There are fifty-nine apartments in the building, which was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $318,000. Thomas M. Graham Co. were the brokers.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 30. -- The Princeton football lettermen today elected Charles Hansen Toll Jr. of Amherst, Mass., regular tackle on the 1936 Tiger varsity who is frequently being mentioned for All-America honors, as captain of next Fall's Nassau eleven.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 30. -- Legislation by Congress, comparable to the NRA, either under the Richberg proposal barring a Supreme Court review or by constitutional amendment, was recommended tonight by Mgr. John A. Ryan, Professor of Moral Theology and Industrial Ethics in the Catholic University of Washington, D.C., to the Catholic conference on industrial problems.

Stockholders last month participated in the largest aggregate of dividend payments in any month on record. The distributions included regular and extra declarations, resumptions and increases. Payments voted against accumulated dividend arrearages and initial disbursements were more numerous than in any other month since June.

A new era in college hockey in the United States and Canada will be ushered in at Toronto on Dec. 17 when Princeton and Toronto meet in the first contest of the forty-game schedule drawn up for the International Intercollegiate Hockey League.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30. -- Harvey J. Harman, head football coach at the University of Pennsylvania, who announced before the start of the season, "I am ready to take all the blame or some of the credit for whatever happens this year," was reappointed today for a term of three years.

DALLAS, Texas, Dec. 1. -- Out of an unpredictable conference scramble that made "goats" of heroes and heroes of "goats," arose seven seniors and four juniors today to take their places on the 1936 Associated Press All-Southwest Conference Football Team.

Orders for two lightweight, streamlined trains driven by oil-electric motors, designed to be the largest and most powerful of any in service, were announced jointly yesterday by the Southern Pacific, the Chicago North Western and the Union Pacific Railroads.

The per capita cost of New York City's government in 1934, exclusive of capital expenditures, was nearly 50 per cent higher than the average of twelve other cities of more than 500,000 population each, the Merchants Association of New York reported yesterday in the second part of its study of the tax load of New York citizens.

Father Bernard R. Hubbard, geologist of Santa Clara University, known as "the glacier priest" because of his adventures in Alaska during the last fifteen years, in a statement issued here yesterday defended colonists in Matanuska Valley in Alaska against recent allegations by Senator Thomas Oklahoma, chairman of the Senate Indian Affairs Committee.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 1. -- Representatives of the Parliaments of the Little Entente countries -- Czechoslovakia, Yugoslavia and Rumania -- held a joint session in the Rumanian Parliament today on the eighteenth anniversary of the union of the Transylvanian Rumanians with the Rumanians of the old kingdom.

Various reasons have been given in Wall Street for the market's decline since Nov. 10, when it reached its highest level of the year to date. Among them are the increasing number of labor disturbances, with attendant dislocation of production; worry over the international situation, and the approach of the convening of the new Congress next month.

Mr. ROOSEVELT'S instincts and sentiments led him aright to Buenos Aires. His presence at the opening of the Pan-American Congress at once elevated it from a merely regional gathering into a world event. It gave him a sounding-board for his voice better suited for his purposes than any he could command at Washington or elsewhere.

In the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton last night the first of the Yorkville Dinner Dances for this season was given for the benefit of the Yorkville Community Association, which provides vocational and recreational privileges for families living in the Yorkville district.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 1. -- A temporary injunction restraining N. B. Early, Virginia Collector of Internal Revenue, from collecting the "windfall taxes" was granted here today to the Rapidan Milling Company and the Mine Run Roller Mills by Judge Robert N. Pollard in the Federal District Court.

QUINCY, Mass., Dec. 1. -- The destroyer Gridley was launched at the Fore River Ship Yards here today. Named for the late Captain Charles V. Gridley, who commanded Admiral Dewey's flagship Olympia in the Spanish-American War, it was christened by his daughter, Mrs. Lewis Buddy 3d of East Orange, N.J.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Hurd entertained at a dinner party last night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria in honor of the officers of the British Military Jumping team, who competed here in the National Horse Show. Members of the team and their wives will sail for England today on the Queen Mary.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 1. -- Both sides rested today in the trial of the complaint against Mr. and Mrs. Benno Bongart of West Orange before Juvenile Court Judge Joseph Siegler on charges of failure to send their two sons to school. The parents testified concerning the educational facilities available at their home and their qualifications as teachers.

Play in Groups 1 and 2 of the New York Division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets League was launched yesterday, with the Squash Club getting off to a fine start in defense of its championship by turning back the Union League team, 4 to 1, in a Group 1 encounter on the victor's courts.

A letter that Henry VIII wrote to Anne Boleyn, evidently in an early stage of their romance, will be included in a sale of rare books and autograph letters at Christie's auction rooms in London on Dec. 7. The letter ends: "Written with the hand off hys that longyth to be yours Henry."

SEATTLE, Dec. 1 (AP). -- University of Washington football players began to get excited over their Rose Bowl opponent today when reports reached the campus that Yale and Navy might be considered along with Alabama, Louisiana State and Pittsburgh.

Mayor La Guardia, speaking yesterday morning at the opening of the new Queens Felony Court, Chaffee Street and Catalpa Avenue, Ridgewood, issued what he termed his "Christmas greetings" to gangsters and racketeers.

Angered by the refusal of WPA guards to allow a mass delegation to see Philip W. Barber, regional director of the WPA Federal Theatre Project, 500 workers attempted yesterday to force their way from the main floor of 701 Eighth Avenue to Mr. Barber's office on the third floor.

Distribution of more than $5,000,000 of the New York World's Fair debentures has been tentatively assured by representatives of five of the city's largest businesses, it was announced yesterday by Harvey D. Gibson, chairman of the fair's finance committee.

" Rembrandt," the Alexander Korda screen transcription of the great Dutch painter's life, delineated by Charles Laughton, who is assisted by Gertrude Lawrence, Elsa Lanchester (Mrs. Laughton), John Bryning, Sam Livesey and Abraham Sofaer, will have its American premiere this morning at the Rivoli.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, directed by John Barbirolli, will give the first performance of the Overture, "Bret Harte," by Philip James on Sunday afternoon, Dec. 20. "Bret Harte" received honorable mention in the American composers' contest for a short orchestral composition conducted by the Philharmonic-Symphony Society.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Vice President Garner, summoned to be here while President Roosevelt is in South America, came out today for Representative Rayburn of Texas for Democratic floor leader of the House. He was promptly attacked for interfering in House affairs by Representatives Dingell of Michigan and Nichols of Oklahoma, supporters of Representative O'Connor of New York, who is Mr. Rayburn's principal opponent for the post.

Uniform State legislation to check the practice of "loss leader" selling in grocery merchandising was advocated in a report submitted yesterday by the National Food and Grocery Committee to the annual convention of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Five manufacturers of men's felt and derby hats were arrested yesterday on charges that they violated the penal law by selling hats under the pretense they were products of the John B. Stetson Company.

A two-hour conference yesterday on the returned goods problem between representatives of the Apparel Industries Inter-Trade Bureau and members of the vendors' relations committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association resulted in an agreement to form a joint working committee of ten members to undertake a factual study of returns.

Salaries of the principal executives of four companies whose securities are listed on the New York Stock Exchange were disclosed yesterday in annual reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The companies and the compensation they reported were as follows:

Testimony to show that some directors of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad made large purchases of its common stock a little before dividends on this stock were resumed was offered yesterday by counsel for the Interstate Commerce Commission at a hearing before Charles D. Mahaffie, chairman of the commission, in the Pennsylvania Hotel.
Apartment and business buildings and lots were among properties in Queens reported sold yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Diplomatic feelers by the French Government looking toward a possible settlement of its war debts to the United States raised hope today that this long-standing source of ill-will between nations might be removed.

With Jack Ahearn starring with 10 points, the St. John's University freshman quintet turned back Richmond Hill High School, 31 -- 25, for its second victory of the season at the De Gray gymnasium yesterday after leading by 15 -- 8 at the half.

TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 1 (AP). -- Dizzy Dean, loquacious Cardinal pitching ace, said tonight he would "welcome a move to the Cincinnati Reds," adding: "You can say for me that if I go to Cincinnati we will finish ahead of the St. Louis Cardinals in 1937."

The opening meeting in a series designed to enlist civic organizations and property owners in the movement for a State limitation on realty taxes was held yesterday in the Hotel Commodore. It was called by Edward F. Hosinger, president of the Long Island Real Estate Board and Queens County chairman of the State Tax Limitation Committee.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- France has expressed a desire to arrange a settlement of her debts to the United States, Acting Secretary of State R. Walton Moore said today.

In three generations American newspapers have evolved from mere house organs of political parties to impartial mediums for conveying political news, and in the transition they have lost none of their influence with the public, Frederick E. Murphy, publisher of The Minneapolis Tribune, told the annual convention of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP). -- Four women who played together for the first time last year to win the American Bridge League's women's team of four championship repeated their victory at the league's tenth annual championships tonight.

The second group of twelve reproductions of paintings by Americans, in the program of Living American Art, Inc., was placed on view yesterday at the F.A.R. Gallery, 19 East Sixty-first Street, before the showing later this month in about 260 cities throughout the country.

The markets presented a study in contrasts yesterday. Most leading stocks were heavy in tone and closed generally lower; the lower-priced issues, including many infrequently traded stocks, together with various specialty issues and preferreds, gained ground. Trading on the Stock Exchange was more active than on Monday -- 2,234,000 shares against 2,141,000. Bonds moved irregularly in increased dealings. Leading foreign currencies showed minor net changes on the day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP). -- Puerto Rican nationalists plan to use the Inter-American Peace Conference at Buenos Aires to help their independence demands. Several followers of Pedro Albizu Campos, imprisoned nationalist leader, have gone to Argentina, it was reported here, to attack "Yankee imperialism."

Holders of common stock of the Associated Rayon Corporation will meet in Baltimore on Dec. 21 to vote on a plan of liquidation for the corporation proposed by the Algemeene Kunstzijde Unie N.V., a Dutch corporation, which holds 88 per cent of the stock.

Twenty-five rookies from the Police Department Training School, wearing civilian attire, were sent into the theatre zone yesterday with orders to make wholesale arrests, if necessary, to end the "car-watching racket."

LISBON, Portugal, Dec. 1 -- As a result of yesterday's offensive on a seven-mile front outside of Madrid, Spanish Insurgent sources reported today, their troops established a line from the Casa de Campo, west of the city, through Humera and Pozuleo de Alarcon to a point of the Corunna road three miles from the capital.
Laurence M. Marks Co. announced yesterday that the subscription books had been closed on the $900,000 of 3 1/2 per cent serial equipment trust certificates of the Birmingham Southern Railroad.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Indications that corporations are seeking to obtain larger sums in new money to replenish working capital and for other purposes were reflected in the registration statements that became effective in October under the Securities Act of 1933 when the total for such purposes aggregated $75,194,875, or 17.8 per cent of the month's net cash proceeds, according to a summary issued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

BROKEN HILL, Northern Rhodesia, Dec. 1 (Canadian Press). -- Captain James A. Mollison and his co-pilot, Captain Edouard Corniglion-Molinier, landed at Broken Hill at 5 P.M. today (10 A.M. Eastern standard time) in the course of their attempt to break the speed record from London to Cape Town.

Republican campaign fiction was a worst seller. Representative BACON'S suggestion that the Republican remnant in the House be furnished with "facts" collected from trustworthy nonpartisan sources and collated or "coordinated" by a bureau set up by the Republican Congressional Committee, of which he is vice chairman, is excellent in intention.

I want to relieve the mind of Mr. de la Ruffiniere of that painful picture of the Pilgrims and Puritans sipping water with their Thanksgiving turkey. I am quite in accord with him as to the conflict between red wine and cranberry sauce. The fact is that the first colonists brought with them from England the conviction that water did not qualify as a beverage.

A plea for organized effort throughout the country to promote the economic security of orphaned and needy children was made yesterday by President Roosevelt in a message to the Child Welfare League of America.

SAN MATEO, Calif., Dec. 1. -- Distribute, 4-1 shot owned and trained by E.E. Presnell, captured the mile and a sixteenth event that featured the card at Bay Meadows today. With Jockey Schultz up, the gelded son of Display led home a field of five.
IT appears from a communication at hand that the mouse-trap play in football was first put out in the guise of early Fall fiction. The following is offered in evidence:

DETROIT, Dec. 1 (AP). -- Negotiators reported progress tonight toward settlement of a "sit-down" strike which has kept 1,900 employes of the Midland Steel Products Company idle for five days and has halted assembly lines in some automobile plants.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 1. -- After her team had been two matches behind, Mrs. Lawrence Gilman of the Elizabeth Town and Country Club rallied to win the decisive point for her team in defeating the Plainfield Country Club in a women's New Jersey Squash Racquets Association Class B match today, 3 -- 2.

Don Bridge has been named chairman of a finance committee to develop a plan for raising the $400,000 yearly for a period of three years, which will be used to underwrite the "United Front" plan for promoting newspapers as an advertising medium, Frank E. Tripp, general manager of the Gannett Company, announced yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 1. -- As President Roosevelt was opening his address at the first session of the Pan-American Peace Conference in the hall of the Argentine Chamber of Deputies today a young man seated in the first row of the brilliant audience shouted out, in Spanish, "Down with imperialism!"

Following is a translation by Ambassador Spruille Braden of the United States of a speech broadcast last night from Buenos Aires by Foreign Minister Carlos Saavedra Lamas of Argentina and recorded here by the National Broadcasting Company:

HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 1. -- Pennsylvania's new Legislature, with both houses controlled by the Democrats for the first time in ninety-one years, assembled in special session today to hear Governor Earle appeal for speedy enactment of an unemployment insurance law to bring the Commonwealth in line with provisions of the Federal social security program.

Eighteen Manhattan parcels and one Bronx property were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales yesterday. Among the Manhattan items were an eighteen-story apartment house at the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and Ninety-sixth Street, four five-story flats at 205-11 West 107th Street, the eight-story Dunsbro Building at 120-22 East Thirty-first Street and a parking plot in West Thirty-seventh Street, near Ninth Avenue.
New York was the winner yesterday in two team matches of the Class A group of the Women's Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association competition.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 1. -- Charles R. Allen of Greenfield, Mass., the guard who kicked the tying point against Princeton, was elected captain of the 1937 Harvard football team today at a meeting of lettermen in the Dillon field house.

BERLIN, Dec. 1. -- Suppression of art critics by Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Minister of Propaganda, is now to be followed, it is understood, by the general disappearance from editors' chairs of such leading figures of pre-Hitler journalism as are still active here.

GENEVA, Dec. 1. -- The League of Nations Secretariat announced today that the League Council would meet here Dec. 10 in response to the Spanish Government's appeal that it examine the danger to peace caused by the German and Italian "armed intervention" and recognition of General Francisco Franco, Rebel chief.

Adolph Wharftig, 35 years old, of 449 West 123d Street, who weighs about 112 pounds and is about five feet tall, chased three bandits, two of whom were armed, from his jewelry store at 948 Lexington Avenue, near Sixty-ninth Street, yesterday morning at about 10:30 o'clock.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 1 (AP). -- Moving into the lead at the half-way stage, A. Kayfetz's Icy Wind, a 4-year-old filly, today annexed the seven-furlong $500 Hampshire Purse, beating Mrs. B.F. Christmas's Headin Home by a length. Two lengths separated Headin Home and C. Feltner's Silvery Cloud in the race for 3-year-olds and up.

While the first of the evening sprints was going on in the six-day bicycle race at Madison Square Garden last night the hard-driving German rider Adolf Schon set out to steal a lap. And his attempt proved the spark that set off cycling fireworks which lasted throughout the greater part of the night, as the rugged pedal athletes swung into their third shift of 24 hours around the shining pine saucer.

HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 1. -- The long-rumored merger of Gaumont British Picture Corporation and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation is once again being negotiated, it was indicated today in a statement issued jointly by Joseph M. Schenck and Sidney R. Kent, chairman of the board and president of the American organization.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1. -- New high prices for the season were established by December and May wheat and all deliveries of corn and rye on the Board of Trade here today as the result of a wave of general buying which swept aside all opposition.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 1. -- At today's session of the royal commission of inquiry on Palestine, Moshe Shertok, head of the political department of the Jewish Agency, told of the work being done in European countries to prepare prospective immigrants for pioneer tasks in Palestine.

Every one who knows the President knew the big, mild-mannered, good-natured secret service man who was his faithful bodyguard for the past eight years. His name was AUGUST ADOLPH GENNERICH, native of Yorkville, but every one called him "GUS." He was the shadow of Mr. ROOSEVELT, always at his elbow or within call, and his strapping figure, his unfailing smile, broad and characteristic as the President's own, were in the background of every Presidential picture.

It is our considered opinion, after watching the Rialto's "Rose Bowl" contest, that the Carnegie Foundation, in its threatened new scrutiny of football conditions, should inquire into the overemphasis on pigskin puppy love at Dear Old Hollywood.

Highly significant is the movement among Federal, State and city civil service employes living in New York to form an association to foster the construction of cooperatively owned apartment houses. Here is a natural group of families with broad common interests, brought together by a desire to obtain improved housing at comparatively low rentals.
MONTREAL, Dec. 1. -- Unless his bosses think he's worth considerably more than a fifth of a million dollars, Dizzy Dean is through pitching for the St. Louis Cardinals.
NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 1 -- The New Jersey Sponsoring Group of the Regional Plan of New York and Its Environs was organized today at a luncheon of business and professional men at the Essex Club, here.

The Eastern intercollegiate football show, starring Jack Sutherland's Pitt Panthers, Navy's novelty troupe and Jimmy Crowley's receding Fordham Rams, this year took the intersectional spotlight away from the Midwest and Southwest.

Most commodity futures were lower in active trading on the local exchanges yesterday. Sugar and coffee advanced slightly. On the cash markets, however, all the grains were at new high levels, raw sugar was 20 points higher at 3.85 cents a pound for duty-frees, and cotton, lard, pork and flour were strong.

Bonds were irregularly higher in more active trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. High-grade issues were firm but relatively quiet; second-grade rail and sugar issues advanced fractions to 2 points. United States Government bonds were irregular, although seven issues established new highs for the year.
A "racket" involving waiters and taxicab drivers was believed uncovered yesterday with the arrest of three men charged with extorting money from William Harmon Beers, well-known architect.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 1. -- Officials of the New York City Board of Elections studied for two hours today Cincinnati's proportional representation method of electing city Councilmen, and confessed confusion and doubt whether it could be adopted in New York.

With the cheers of several hundred students ringing in their ears, Manhattan's football men entrained from Pennsylvania Station last night on the first leg of a 2,000-mile journey which will take them to Tyler, Texas, to meet Texas A. and M. Saturday.

A record of a long career of theft confronted Mrs. Louise Stadler, 42 years old, of 330 West 108th Street, Manhattan, once a successful music teacher, when she appeared in Brooklyn Felony Court yesterday. For several years, it was brought out, she has made a specialty of looting homes of money and jewelry while posing as a servant.

As attorney for the Independent Miners and Truckers Association of Pennsylvania in the prosecution of the so-called coal "bootleggers" in New York State, I have noted with considerable interest the series of articles written by your special correspondent, F. Raymond Daniell, and your editorial of Nov. 24, incident thereto.
PARIS, Dec. 1. -- Frenchmen considered tonight the possibility of wiping out France's war debt to the United States by paying roughly one-eighth of what she owes.
LONDON, Dec. 1. -- The House of Lords tonight voted down proposed legislation to permit medical men to kill patients suffering from agonizing incurable diseases.
BILBAO, Spain, Dec. 1 (AP). -Spanish Government forces, their own capital of Madrid under siege for nearly a month, pushed offensives against the Rebel capital of Burgos today.
New restrictions on the sale of goods at public auction are contained in a proposed city ordinance made public at City Hall yesterday by Alderman Morton Moses of Manhattan, its sponsor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Purchases and sales made in October by officers, directors and principal stockholders of equity securities of corporations were reported today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 these statements to the SEC must be made monthly.

Happy to leave the cold and predicted snow behind, a group of men and women delegates to the annual convention of the Amateur Athletic Union departed yesterday for Houston, Texas, where they expect both climate and words to be warm.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Telephonic communication with Paris over a new direct radio circuit 3,600 miles in length was opened today by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company with ceremonies conducted in this country from the office of the Federal Communications Commission.

If a tale of literary bawdry must be told in seventeenth-century finery, it is plain that Ruth Gordon has the knack of it. After an Autumn engagement in London she is now back in New York as Mrs. Pinchwife in Wycherley's "The Country Wife," which was acted at Henry Miller's last evening.
HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 1. -- Plenty of explosive material for the A.A.U. convention was in prospect today as the Gulf Association prepared for the national meeting Friday, Saturday and Sunday.

The mercury dropped to 12 degrees yesterday at 5:30 A.M., reaching a low for the season, according to the United States Weather Bureau. The highest temperature, 33 degrees, was recorded at 6:30 P.M. The average was 22 and the normal 39.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Three members of the du Pont family were the largest contributors to the Republican campaign fund, according to a list of contributors made public today by the Senate committee investigating campaign expenditures.

BARCELONA, Spain, Dec. 1. -- Mariano Vasquez, new National Secretary of the powerful anarcho-syndicalist organization Confederacion Nacional de Trabajo [C.N.T.], said today that the Spanish Government was determined to respect foreign property and debts.

Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, bought from the Louis Isaacs Realty Corporation, Anna Glaser, treasurer, a five-story, fifty-family house at 2,285 Davidson Avenue, southwest corner of Evelyn Place. The plot is 100 feet square. The seller acquired the parcel ten years ago through C.J.C. Muller, broker in the present deal.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 1. -- Frank H. Moser, cartoonist, of Hastings-on-Hudson, charged in Supreme Court today that Paul H. Terry, Larchmont cartoonist, and several of the latter's business associates, had conspired to defraud him of a 50 per cent interest in the Terry cartoon business.
PARIS, Dec. 1. -- President Roosevelt's address at the Buenos Aires peace conference was displayed with great prominence in the French press today, and received enthusiastic approval in editorials.

The familiar voice of President Roosevelt, interrupted by tumultuous applause from his hearers in the Chamber of Deputies at Buenos Aires as the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace opened yesterday, came to listeners in the United States with unusual clarity by way of short waves from Argentina.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP). -- Business volume in many industries is equal to the high levels of 1929, according to a report by Dr. V. D. Reed, assistant director of the Census Bureau, citing field reports of the 1935 business census just completed.
CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP). -- The Julius Rosenwald Fund has set aside $75,000 a year, later to be increased to $100,000, in two programs to establish annual fellowships for young people in the South.

The Soviet Government has called for redemption as of yesterday the entire issue of 10 per cent Soviet Union gold bonds due in 1942, its first issue sold in this country, according to cabled advices received yesterday from the Bank for Foreign Trade of the U.S.S.R. by the Soviet Securities Corporation here.

Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck reserved decision yesterday on a motion to dismiss a complaint against the Empire Trust Company in the suit brought by Joseph Mercadante, shipper, of 120 Broadway, who seeks the rescission of an agreement of indebtedness and the cancellation of two mortgages held by the bank amounting to $251,000.

BERLIN, Dec. 1. -- Prices on the Boerse today were mixed and failed to develop any significant tendency. Heavy industrial stocks showed some strength at the opening of the session, Mansfeld gaining 1 1/2 points and Vereinigtestahl 3/4 of a point. Lignite issues were weaker.

New life must be instilled into the missionary movement in this country, the Right Rev. Henry Wise Hobson, Bishop of Southern Ohio, declared yesterday in asking members of the Episcopal Church to "supplant ignorant enthusiasm with a devotion based on knowledge."

PARIS, Dec. 1. -- Persistent rumors that the Communists would vote against Premier Leon Blum's government Friday on the issue of intervention in Spain or would at best abstain and so break the Popular Front, were current all day today in the lobbies of Parliament.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1. -- Six smiling young people from the agricultural areas, all outspoken exponents of regular eating and sleeping and plenty of exercise, were named the healthiest 4-H Club members today.

Collective bargaining agreements between labor unions and trade associations are immune from the provisions of the State Anti-Monopoly Law, Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman ruled yesterday. His decision, in a case involving the fur industry in New York City, was the first ruling on the question in the State courts since the law was amended in 1933 to exempt "bona fide labor unions."

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 1. -- A two-hour stoppage of work in the Essex County District was called by members of the Federal Writers Project yesterday, following an announcement that 8,000 of the 80,634 project workers on the WPA rolls in New Jersey would be dismissed soon.

VALENCIA, Spain, Dec. 1. -- The Spanish Government is convinced the bombardment of Alicante on Saturday night was carried out by collusion of German planes and probably the German warship Emden, and it is now felt here that international interference in the Spanish civil war has reached a point where active reply will be called for.

RUTLAND, Vt., Dec. 1 (AP). -- Governor Charles M. Smith, 68-year-old president of the Rutland Marble Savings Bank, won freedom late today from a charge of concealing a bookkeeper's alleged thefts from the bank.

The Musicians Emergency Fund, started in 1931 to aid destitute musicians, celebrated the fifth anniversary of its inception yesterday afternoon with a meeting at Steinway Hall. The assemblage was addressed by speakers who were responsible for its founding.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 1. -- Several official openings, from two to four weeks ahead of former seasons, marked today's program here.

Mr. and Mrs. John Sloane will give a reception this afternoon at their home, 48 East Ninety-second Street, to introduce their daughter, Miss Grace Elsie Sloane, and their nieces, the Misses Alma Nicoll and Elizabeth Nicoll Lawrence.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Reflecting a gain of 20 per cent over the preceding month, export trade of the United States in October reached a value of $264,708,000, the highest with one exception for any month since December, 1930, when foreign shipments were valued at $275,000,000.

American Trade Commissioner Basil D. Dahl, who recently returned from his post in Stockholm, will be in New York during the period of Dec. 9 to 10 for the purpose of conferring with business men interested in Swedish economic conditions, it was announced yesterday at the office here of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, Custom House.

STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 1. -- Dr. William T. Hornaday, veteran defender of American wild life and for thirty years director of the New York Zoological Society, celebrated his eighty-second birthday today in his home here. Dr. W. Reid Blair, director of the society, and others who visited him found him bedridden but "in good fighting condition" for his campaign on behalf of the country's game.

Jennie Fantle, 54 years old, of 853 Tiffany Street, the Bronx, was fatally injured yesterday afternoon when she was struck and dragged seventy-five feet by an automobile into which had crashed a Southern Boulevard surface car. The accident occurred at Southern Boulevard and Tiffany Street, the Bronx.
PARIS, Dec. 1. -- Charges of fraud today interrupted the sale of art from the collection of the late Francois Coty, noted perfumer and publisher.

A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers bought privately yesterday a new issue of $1,087,000 of refunding bonds of Jersey City, N.J. The issue, bearing an interest rate of 2 3/4 per cent, is dated July 15, 1936, and will mature from July 15, 1938 to 1943.

Robert O. Braunsdorf, the Brooklyn home-relief investigator whose acceptance of a $5 gratuity aroused the ire of Mayor La Guardia recently, was permitted by County Judge George W. Martin in Brooklyn yesterday to plead guilty to a reduced charge.

The New York Women's Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Antonia Brico, opened its third season with a well-arranged program at Carnegie Hall last night and was heartily received by an audience of good size. Miss Brico had announced a few days ago that to fill vacancies in the orchestra's ranks she had engaged the services of ten men.

R.H. BRUCE LOCKHAT'S "Return to Malaya" (Putnam, S3) is an item for both Jack Sprat and his wife. That is to say, it is at once romantic travelogue and study of conditions in the Far East. It treats profound matters rather superficially, and light matters with not a little profundity. It is adventure story, personal history and foreign affairs notebook rolled into one.
BERLIN, Dec. 1. -- The German Cabinet and Colonel-General Hermann Goering as Commissar for the Four-year Plan issued decrees today as follows:

PARIS, Wednesday, Dec. 2. -- President Roosevelt's address to the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace in Buenos Aires yesterday was interpreted in French political circles as brightening the outlook for closer cooperation between democratic countries which France hopes to line up against possible aggression by other nations.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 1. -- Jockey Joe Cowley monopolized the limelight at the Fair Grounds today, winning three races aboard Mr. Marvel, Shatterproof, and Hit and Run. The last two named captured the best races on the card and in both instances Cowley put up fine rides.

A toy show, which, it is planned, will be the first of an annual series, opened yesterday in Rockefeller Center, on the eleventh floor of the R.C.A. Building, adjoining Horticultural Hall, and earned itself the distinction of being an exhibit really planned for children, with a nurse in attendance and a glorified playroom where children may use the nursery equipment, learn to operate the toys, read books and draw as well as "watch things work."
Cash dividend declarations yesterday approximated $25,000,000, bringing the amount ordered since Nov. 1 to $908,200,000. Last month's total, the largest for any month on record, was $883,200,000.
LONDON, Dec. 1. -- The danger of a general European war growing out of the Spanish civil conflict seemed greater tonight than at any time since the beginning of the Franco rebellion.

The seventieth annual exhibition of the American Water Color Society will be held in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, from Jan. 6 to Jan. 21, inclusive. Works to be submitted will be received at 210 West Fifty-eighth Street on Dec. 28.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 1. -- The Perfection Stove Company's 1,800 workers at Cleveland, their 1929 pay already restored, will receive a 7 1/2 per cent increase, affecting all employes on piece rate, hourly pay or salary, effective Dec. 15. The company did not announce the total amount represented.

An offering of $140,000,000 of American Telephone and Telegraph Company thirty-year 3 1/4 per cent debentures will be made today by a nation-wide investment banking syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc. The price is to be 102 and accrued interest, to yield 3.13 per cent to the time the debentures will be callable at par.

LONDON, Dec. 1. -- Except for a flurry in shares that might be affected by last night's destruction of the Crystal Palace by fire, the stock market here was quiet today and had no regular tendency. The rise in exhibition shares was reflected in advances in issues of Olympia, Earls Court and Madame Tussaud's.

Linking leprosy with tuberculosis in its effect upon public health, Dr. Ernest Muir, general and medical secretary of the British Empire Leprosy Relief Association, said here yesterday that treatment for both diseases "should consist largely in improving the general health."
Business and housing properties were included in the Manhattan realty trading reported yesterday.

Larry Kelley, captain and end of the 1936 Yale football team, had another honor bestowed upon him yesterday when it was announced that he was the winner of the Heisman Memorial Trophy, awarded annually to the outstanding college gridiron athlete of the country by the Downtown Athletic Club.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1. -- Willie Hoppe of New York, defending champion, won his third straight game in the world three-cushion billiard tournament tonight, defeating Earl Lookabaugh of Chicago, 50 to 31 in thirty-seven innings. Hoppe had a high run of 10, one short of the current tourney record, compared with Lookabaugh's high of 5.

President James Rowland Angell of Yale told a large group attending the Winter meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers at the Engineering Societies Building last night that the last election has "confirmed rather definitely" in this country the "certain trend in the modern world to regard all important effects of commercial and industrial methods on large groups of our human brothers as properly and inevitably the subject of general social and political consideration."

Twenty minutes after the close of testimony in Special Sessions yesterday Anna Swift was convicted by Justices Bayes, Hackenburg and Salomon of conducting a house of prostitution in her Danish Institute at 8 West Seventieth Street. The decision was handed down at 5:12 P.M., exactly eight minutes after her lawyer, James D.C. Murray, had finished a plea for dismissal of the charge, which was opposed by Louis J. Capozzoli, Assistant District Attorney.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- A sense of gloom seemed to envelop the whole White House staff today when word came from Buenos Aires of the death of August A. (Gus) Gennerich, President Roosevelt's faithful personal bodyguard and aide.

A meeting under League of Nations auspices to cope with the problem of integrating German-Jewish refugees into the social and economic life of other nations probably will be held within a few months, it was made known here yesterday.
The Long Island University five, making its 1936-37 debut at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy last night, took up where it left off in the last campaign and routed the Princeton Seminary, 61 to 27.

RICHMOND, Dec. 1 (AP). -- Secretary Ickes, determined that the "show must go on," "thumbed" a ride to Richmond to take part in a dedicatory ceremony today after his automobile had been in a collision en route.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 1. -- Argentine reporters had their sample of President Roosevelt's press conferences at the United States Embassy today. The President, although saddened by the death of August Adolph (Gus) Gennerich, his personal bodyguard, conducted the meeting with the frankness and camaraderie that characterize Washington semiweekly gatherings when he is in the capital.
WARSAW, Poland, Dec. 1. -- A small surplus was foreseen in the budget for the fiscal year beginning April 1, submitted to the Sejm today at the opening of the new Parliamentary session.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 1. -- The Alabama-born parents of Jesse Owens, Negro Olympic star, today received a share of the $50,000 the sprinter has earned since his return from Germany.

There were two orchestras, a college glee club, a baritone, a harpist, two choral conductors, living program notes, four kilted bagpipers, and Paul Whiteman on the stage of the New York Hippodrome last night. They added up to Mr. Whiteman's perennial obeisance to art.

According to the report of a correspondent of The (London) Observer in Budapest, a new order of the Home Minister prohibiting begging in that city and in the health resorts has resulted in a strike by the beggars. Though they have prospect of receiving the legal dole, they find this poor compensation for giving up their "stanches" at church doors and busy street corners, which were considered "safe capital" and commanded high prices.

While Mrs. William H. Harkness Jr. is en route to America with the first baby giant panda ever to make the trip, two full-grown specimens of the rare species stand sleek and stuffed under cellophane at the American Museum of Natural History.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

A proposed city ordinance regulating the sale of coal and aimed at the elimination of "bootleg coal" was discussed at a public hearing yesterday before the general welfare committee of the Board of Aldermen.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Secretary Morgenthau bought today for $1, on behalf of the government, the patented formulas for three powerful new narcotics, thereby virtually eliminating the possibility of their passing into illicit channels and making for narcotic addiction.
TORONTO, Dec. 1 (AP). -- While Ontario remained gripped in near-zero weather tonight the threat of a shipping tie-up at Sault Ste. Marie where seventeen vessels were ice-locked had passed.

Registration of visiting buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday was well below the preceding week but showed an increase over the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES. The arrivals for the week were 509, as against 802 in the previous week and 400 in the same period last year.

LONDON, Dec. 1. -- A trade agreement between Britain and Yugoslavia has been added to the growing list of such transactions completed by this government under a principle similar to that prompting commercial treaties negotiated by Secretary Hull for the United States.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 1. -- The wave of popular enthusiasm for President Roosevelt's good-will mission that followed his trip down the South American coast came to its climax as he reached the Congressional Palace in this city today to open the inter-American conference.

There is a distinct feeling in Republican quarters that the meeting of the Republican State Committee, called for Dec. 14 to elect a new State chairman to succeed Melvin C. Eaton, who has resigned, may prove an epochal party gathering. There is a prospect, too, that the meeting will be anything but harmonious.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 1. -- Social security registration card No. 1, evidencing the government's promise of retirement at 65 on a maximum pension of $85 a month, was allotted today to John David Sweeney Jr., Princeton man, shipping clerk, Republican.

Marcel Grandjany, French harpist, appeared last night in a recital at the Town Hall which was wholly a delightful music experience. The list consisted of compositions adapted to the instrument by Mr. Grandjany, his own works and compositions seldom heard on the harp.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 1. -- While most studios are concerned with the military aspects of the Spanish revolution. Paramount has purchased a romantic-adventure story, "The Last Train for Madrid," by Paul Hervey Fox. The screen play will be written by Louis Stevens and Marguerite Roberts, with Cary Grant in mind as the star.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,010,650 barrels, compared to 3,060,950 in the preceding week, a drop of 50,300, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Declines of 26,800 and 25,350 barrels, respectively, in the daily average outputs of California and Oklahoma were the important changes.

Two hundred and nineteen men and women were forcibly ejected by the police last night from the quarters of the WPA Federal Art Project on the eight floor of 6 East Thirty-ninth Street, after a two-hour "stay-in" strike against impending dismissals from the work relief rolls.

Trying out in Philadelphia, "You Can't Take It With You" is undergoing changes -- new first-act material goes in this afternoon, the third act was touched up last night. Just where the show will take up residence on Broadway is any one's guess.

The communication entitled "Restraining Free Speech," by Frederick L. Redefer, executive secretary of the Progressive Education Association, interests me for several reasons. In the first place it confirms a suspicion long held by me regarding the real objectives of "Progressive" (spelled with a capital "P," of course) education.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 1. -- The text of the address of President Aguatin P. Justo of Argentina this afternoon at the opening session of the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace follows:

MOSCOW, Dec. 1. -- The new Soviet Constitution moved toward final adoption tonight. The Congress of Soviets, meeting in the Kremlin Palace, adopted the proposed draft in its entirety as the basis of a new Constitution.

The Brooklyn lodge of B'nai B'rith, largest Jewish fraternal organization in the United States, presented an award last night to The Brooklyn Daily Eagle as the metropolitan New York City newspaper that had done most this year to promote "inter-racial amity and comity as well as good-will among the people of the United States."

The American Water Works and Electrio Company, Inc., reported yesterday for the year to Oct. 31 a consolidated net income of $4,877,598 after all deductions. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.72 a share on 2,142,662 average no-par common shares.

Judge and Mrs. Edward Ridley Finch of New York and Sunswick, Westhampton Beach, will give a supper dance Saturday at their home, 21 East Eighty-fourth Street, to introduce to society their younger daughter, Miss Anne Crewe Delafield Finch.

Individual honors in the National Football League as well as the Eastern division championship will be at stake when the New York Giants battle the Boston Redskins at the Polo Grounds Sunday. For Tuffy Leemans, sensational Giant recruit, and Cliff Battles, Boston's ace ball carrier, both will be seeking to add to their laurels in ground-gaining ability.

ALBANY, Dec. 1 (AP). -- Harvey O. Schermerhorn, State Commissioner of Canals, said tonight that a checkup indicated that at least 385 vessels were trapped in the ice-locked barge canal and might be forced to Winter there "unless a week of warm weather saves the day."

BERLIN, Dec. 1. -- German comment on President Roosevelt's voyage to South America and the opening of the Pan-American Conference at Buenos Aires is chiefly remarkable for its scarcity. It is significant, however, that there is a wholly friendly attitude, devoid of any evidence of commercial jealousy or fears that German business interests may be harmed if the two American continents draw closer together.

LONDON, Dec. 1. -- Whatever lingering doubts may have existed regarding the knowledge of King Edward's friendship with Mrs. Wallis Simpson among the rank and file of the British people can now definitely be laid to rest.

Education in American universities provides much learning but little wisdom, and observation of student behavior indicates that there has been "a distinct decadence in our manners," Dr. Dexter S. Kimball, dean emeritus of engineering at Cornell University, told the Women's Auxiliary to the American Society of Mechanical Engineers at a luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Commodore.

The financial statement of the Diamond Match Company and subsidiaries for the first nine months of this year, issued yesterday, showed a net income of $1,520,531 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges. After nine months' regular dividend requirements on the 6 per cent preferred stock, the income is equivalent to $1.21 each on 700,000 no-par shares of common stock.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1. -- Prices of hogs were generally steady for a short time in the early trading here today, but later the market weakened and final prices were regarded as around 10 cents a hundredweight lower than the average on Monday. Receipts were 44,000 head, the largest since December, 1934.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The text of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's speech to the Inter-American Peace Conference at Buenos Aires, as given out by the State Department, is as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- A new high record for steel ingot production for a month was established in Great Britain in October when the output reached 1,060,500 tons, according to a report to the Department of Commerce today from Homer S. Fox, assistant commercial attache at London.

The forms to be used by employers in this State in keeping the employment and payroll records which will determine a worker's eligibility to share in unemployment insurance benefits were issued yesterday by Glenn A. Bowers, executive director of the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Department of Labor.

A Coast Guard surfboat from the Little Egg Station on the New Jersey Coast went several miles to sea yesterday to take a sick fireman off the American freighter Howard for treatment in an Atlantic City hospital. The seaman, William Macklin of 1,920 Christian Street, Philadelphia, was apparently suffering from acute appendicitis and required immediate attention.

Popularly known as a "television pipe," the coaxial cable installed by the Bell Telephone Laboratories between New York and Philadelphia had its first talking test yesterday. Dr. Frank A. Jewett, president of the laboratories, talked with members of the press over the circuit, looped within itself to cover 3,800 miles, although in reality the cable spans less than 100 miles.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Moves to broaden its market by obtaining unlisted trading privileges in six securities were made today by the Boston Stock Exchange under provisions of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. In two instances continuance of unlisted trading was sought on the ground that the securities are substantially the same as those that previously had that privilege on the Exchange.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 1. -- For the first time in its twenty-year history the John Prentiss Poe Cup, awarded annually to that member of the Princeton varsity football team who shows the greatest proficiency and sportsmanship, has been given jointly to two players.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Any foreign service officer of the United States who hereafter marries an alien without the approval of the Secretary of State will be held guilty of insubordination and will be subject to immediate dismissal.
New York architecture, which has attained notice in the city's skyline, soon will get further public attention in a special gallery which will be devoted to it in the Museum of the City of New York.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 1. -Following is the text of a speech broadcast tonight by Cordell Hull, United States Secretary of State:
