BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 1. -- President Roosevelt in a stirring speech this afternoon at the opening of the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace called upon the nations of the New World to unite to help the Old World avert its impending catastrophe of war.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 1. -- President Roosevelt's activities today were overshadowed by the shock of the sudden death late last night of his personal bodyguard, comrade and friend, August Adolph Gennerich. He cancelled all possible engagements for the day and arranged a funeral service at the embassy for tomorrow.

While business failures in the retail group in the five business days ended Nov. 26 showed an increase of five over the total for the previous week, the number was thirty-two below the average for the first forty-seven weeks of this year and under last year's figures, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Many seats have been purchased for the performance of the "A" Series of Noel Coward's one-act plays tonight at the National Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Neighborhood Music School. Many of the patrons and patronesses of the benefit will give supper parties later in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria, where a percentage of the proceeds will be donated to the school.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 1. -- Japanese semi-official sources in Shanghai announced late last night that Foreign Minister Chang Chun of China and Shigeru Kawagoe, Japanese Ambassador to China, would probably discontinue their negotiations after their next meeting, which is expected late this week.

ALBANY, Dec. 1. -- The death sentence imposed upon John Fiorenza for the slaying of Mrs. Nancy Evans Titterton in New York City was affirmed by the Court of Appeals today. Before it recesses Friday the court will fix a date for the execution of sentence, probably about the middle of January.

Shareholders of the Bank of the Manhattan Company at their 138th annual meeting, held at noon yesterday at the bank's head office, 40 Wall Street, received from J. Stewart Baker, chairman of the board of directors, a report for this year showing increased business, improved earnings and a higher average rate of return on loans and securities.

MONTREAL, Dec. 1 (AP). -- Harvey Jackson broke into the goal-making column for the first time this season tonight and accounted for both scores as the Toronto Maple Leafs downed the Montreal Maroons, 2 to 1, in a National Hockey League battle.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Dec. 1. -- Rescued unconscious from his burning home by T. McFergus Cooper, neighbor and fellow-artist, Charles Leslie Thrasher, 47 years old, painter of magazine covers, is in an oxygen tent tonight at the Mather Memorial Hospital here, under treatment for pneumonia resulting from exposure and the smoke he inhaled.

The New York district council of the International Longshoremen's Association, representing about 25,000 pier workers, voted at a special meeting last night to refuse to service the French liner Champlain when she arrives in this port this morning.

Under the strength in the December option, which advanced steadily as mills fixed prices on raw material, quotations on the Cotton Exchange continued to improve and closed at the top with gains of 8 to 16 points yesterday. The record domestic cotton goods business brought active calling by consumers, coincident with a marked decrease in hedging operations.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP). -- Mrs. Helen Coyimzoglu, saying Samuel Insull "owes his life to me," declared tonight she would sue him for $40,000 worth of jewelry he "promised" her and $22,000 in cash unless a settlement is made with her attorney "immediately."
A new feature marks the exhibition that will be opened to the public today at the temporary galleries of the Municipal Art Committee, 62 West Fifty-third Street.
PARIS, Dec. 1. -- The imminent retirement of General Henri Gouraud, "the Lion of Champagne," as Military Governor of Paris was announced today.

PARIS, Dec. 1. -- There is some fire behind all this smoke that is filling the air about the intention of the Blum government to try to get a new debt deal with the United States if it is still in office two weeks hence. But up to the present there has been more smoke than fire.
MADRID, Dec. 1 (AP). -- The Spanish Government suddenly changed its civil war plan tonight from dogged resistance to fierce attack.

GENEVA, Dec. 1. -- The forty-hour week for printers was defended today on the International Labor Organization committee, which is considering its general establishment by treaty, by Harold Winchester, United States employer delegate, against an attack from other employer delegates.

Contracts for several million dollars' worth of artillery fire-control instruments for the use of foreign governments have been rejected by the Bausch Lomb Optical Company of Rochester, N.Y. The United States and Germany produce 95 per cent of the fine optical instruments used for military purposes, the United States at the Bausch Lomb plant and Germany at the Zeiss plant at Jena.

A scholastic basketball program stretching over a period of six weeks will get under way at Madison Square Garden on Saturday, Dec. 19, according to the schedule of games announced by Ned Irish, director of Garden basketball, at a luncheon tended coaches and sports writers of the metropolitan area at the Hotel Lincoln yesterday.

Obviously it is not a private fight that is going on in unhappy Spain. Everybody is joining in -- French, Russians, Germans, Italians, Irish, Americans, even Chinese; for Nanking has just fired its Minister to Poland because he has been running arms into Spain.

The women's campaign committee of the United Hospital Campaign has raised thus far this year $266,345, against $226,716 at the same time last year, it was announced yesterday at a report meeting at the Hotel Biltmore. Mrs. William Woodward is chairman of the committee.
After holding public hearings yesterday on seventeen local bills, Mayor La Guardia signed five of the batch and laid the others over for further consideration.

ALBANY. Dec. 1. -- Ninety banks, trust companies and investment houses share in the allocation of $60,000,000 of short-term notes to be issued as of tomorrow by Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller. As usual the demand was greater than the supply.

Joseph A. Huisking of Charles L. Huisking Co. was elected president of the Drug, Chemical and Allied Trades Section of the New York Board of Trade, Inc., at a meeting of the executive committee at the Drug and Chemical Club yesterday. Other officers named were August A. Wasserscheid of the Mallinckrodt Chemical Works, vice chairman; S. Barksdale Penick of S.B. Penick Co., treasurer, and Ray Schlotter, secretary.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today received bids on security issues of forty-seven municipal and other districts throughout the country which it had purchased from the Public Works Administration for resale in the private market.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, now in the final weeks of its long investigation of investment trusts and investment companies, inquired today into the operations of the Adams Express Company, which was converted into an investment trust in 1927 by a group described before the commission as "speculators."

Officers of the honorary professional educational fraternities at New York University's School of Education for the current academic year were announced yesterday by Dean John W. Withers of the School of Education. The following were elected:

Passengers sailing today for Southampton via Cherbourg on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary include Dr. Carl Anderson, winner of the Nobel Prize for physics; John Cudahy, United States Ambassador to Poland; Lord and Lady Astor, Lady Furness, Lord Fairfaux of Cameron, Prince Radolfo del Drago, Viscount Cobham, Count Andre and Countess de Limur and Aiiss Ethel de Limur.

Saverio Turiello, Italian welterweight, forced the issue from start to finish to get the decision over Johnny Clinton of the West Side in eight rounds at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of 6,200 attended.

The recent appointment of I.T. Bode as senior scientist of the extension service of the United States Department of Agriculture is hailed by the American Wildlife Institute as a step of major importance to wild life and a milestone in conservation progress.

BERLIN, Dec. 1. -- Lawrence B. Simpson, the American seaman sentenced last Sept. 29 to three years in the penitentiary after conviction on a charge of sedition, will be released five days before Christmas.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $1,512,320,670 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. The average price of all listed stocks on Dec. 1 was $44.26 a share, compared to $43.36 at the beginning of November.

LONDON, Dec. 2. -- The International Non-Intervention Committee, with the Portuguese representative abstaining from voting, decided today to submit to both sides in Spain a plan for the supervision of imports at the principal ports in that country, both by land and by sea, to keep out munitions.
Seventy-six Columbia athletes who competed in varsity and freshman sports this Fall will receive their insignia, it was announced yesterday by Graduate Manager Reynolds Benson.

Coming from behind twice in the last half with drives of eleven and eight points, the Pratt Institute basketball team turned back the Lafayette College quintet of Easton, Pa., 55 -- 50, in the opening encounter for both squads on the winner's court last night.
Joseph Bernard Tucker celebrated yesterday fifty years of service to the jewelry house founded almost sixty years ago by August V. Lambert.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 2. -- O.P. Van Sweringen, the railroad operator whose financial exploits dazzled the business world and piled up a fortune in excess of $100,000,000, left an estate valued at $700,000, according to an estimate filed in Probate Court today by John D. Fackler.

LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 3. -- Commenting on President Roosevelt's speech in Buenos Aires, The Daily Telegraph ventures the hope his suggestions for breaking down trade barriers in the Western Hemisphere may extend to Europe as well.

ALBANY, Dec. 2 (AP). -- Working under the added handicap of steadily falling snow, canal officials strove today to release nearly 400 boats in the ice-choked Barge Canal system bearing cargoes estimated to be worth between $5,000,000 and $10,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The Democratic members of the New York delegation in the House will vote as a unit for the election of Representative John J. O'Connor as majority leader in the next Congress, it was stated today by Representative John J. Boylan of New York after he had polled the twenty-nine Democratic members of the delegation.

HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 2 (AP). -- An eight-year automobile trip of 15,000 miles yielded a stirring account today from three weary travelers of jungle, desert, wild animal, hunger, desolation -- of months without once seeing other human beings.

ALBANY, Dec. 2 (AP). -- Seeking a cross-section of opinion before convocation of the 1937 Legislature, Peter G. Ten Eyck, State Agriculture Commissioner, asked dairy industry representatives today to go on record as to "continuance, discontinuance or amendment" of the State Milk Control Law.

Approval of the lease of space formerly occupied by the retail division of the Bronx Terminal Market to the Sunshine Farms, Inc., for a milk pasteurization plant was voted yesterday in City Hall by the Sinking Fund Commission.

Both major book clubs will distribute Farrar Rinehart books next month. The Literary Guild choice for January is "The Street of the Fishing Cat," by Jolan Foldes, winner of the All Nations Prize Novel Competition. "Shining Scabbard," by R.C. Hutchinson, will be the Book-of-the-Month Club choice.
MONTREAL, Dec. 2 (AP). -- The International Baseball League ended its sessions today with the assurance that Toronto would retain its franchise under a probable compromise reorganization.
LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 3. -- Following are the texts of editorials on the King and Mrs. Simpson appearing in London newspapers today: ...

NEWMARKET, England, Dec. 2 (AP). -- Miss Dorothy Paget's famous steeplechaser, Golden Miller, will run in next year's Grand National Steeplechase, according to an announcement made by Trainer Owen Anthony after the Miller had negotiated the Aintree course and finished second to Royal Mail in the recent Beecher Steeplechase, over 2 1/4 miles.

OTTAWA, Ill., Dec. 2. -- Acting in sympathy with 6,000 employes of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company, who have been on strike for five weeks, 1,300 workers in the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company plant here began a "sit-down" strike today determined to stop the company from turning out a $4,000,000 glass order said to be for the Chrysler Motor Company, placed originally with the Pittsburgh concern.

Although they favored the basic purpose of the Robinson-Patman anti-price discrimination law, members of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., at their annual convention in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday, adopted a resolution stating that they could not approve "the apparent substantial and formal defects of the act."

A jury of "typical readers" will pick prize-winners at the second annual exhibition of photographs sponsored by the Press Photographers Association of New York. The show will be opened to the public on Saturday, following a preview tomorrow, in the mezzanine galleries of the RCA Building, Rockefeller Center.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP). -- Acknowledging that he had worked for a private investment service while he was an official of NRA, Albert J. Hettinger of New York denied today before the Securities and Exchange Commission that reports he made to the service were based on the NRA's files.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Social Security Act has resulted in the enactment by many States of unemployment insurance plans. Those of New York have passed through the proving ground of the Supreme Court, and their faults may now be improved without fear of having all the work go to waste.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The American Federation of Labor seeks recurring wage increases in industry.

VIENNA, Dee. 2. -- To the considerable number of American musicians who have made Viennese debuts this season was added tonight the young violinist, Oscar Shumsky, who gave a successful recital in the Konzerthaus small hall.
Major Patrick J. Walsh, candidate for the presidency of the Amateur Athletic Union, left last night with other members of the metropolitan division for the A.A.U. convention in Houston.

After nearly eleven months of preparation, the WPA Federal Dance Theatre finally got around to showing its first production on Broadway last night when "The Eternal Prodigal" opened for a ten-day season at the Ritz Theatre. The work is a dance drama based loosely on the biblical parable of the Prodigal Son, with scenario and choreography by Gluck-Sandor, music by Herbert Kingsley and scenery and costumes by Nat karson.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2. -- The world's wheat markets continued to advance today with a further broadening in the general speculative interest. All deliveries of futures sold at the highest prices in several years, except the July, on the Board of Trade, which equalled its previous high mark.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "De la Braila," in a letter to THE TIMES, hopes that America may "make it emphatic that another war cannot be tolerated." More particularly he is interested in rallying supporters of the territorial integrity of three European States -- Czechoslovakia, Rumania and Yugoslavia.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 2. -- The undergraduate newspapers at Columbia, Cornell, Dartmouth, Harvard, Pennsylvania, Princeton and Yale tomorrow will run an identical editorial advocating concrete formation of an "Ivy League" among the football teams of the seven institutions, it was announced tonight.

VIENNA, Dec. 2. -- It is reliably reported in diplomatic circles that Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg is seriously perturbed by the evident danger that the Austro-German agreement of July 11 is going to give the Nazis, through peaceful penetration, everything, including finally control of Austria in all but name, that they failed to obtain by their long campaign of violence.
AMSTERDAM, Dec. 2. -- The Bank of the Netherlands today reduced the discount rate from 2 1/2 to 2 per cent, effective tomorrow.

READING, Pa., Dec. 2 (AP). -- Strike pickets for the third successive day lay flat in slush and snow at the main entrance of the Berkshire Knitting Mills today, and police took thirty-two of them to the already-crowded county jail.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Sponsors of the Social Security Act seem to have given little or no thought to what might be the fate of men and women beyond the half-century mark. At best there could be but a small pension or cash surrender.

A blunt warning to lawyers that unless they see to it that poor men are enabled to get justice the bar's monopoly will be broken by some kind of socialization of the practice of law was advanced last night by Harrison Tweed, the new president of the Legal Aid Society, at a testimonial dinner to the retiring president, Allen Wardwell, at the Biltmore Hotel.

W.I. Myers, governor of the Farm Credit Administration, predicted in Washington yesterday that a steady increase in farm purchases during the last eighteen months would continue during the remainder of this year and all of next.

ALBANY, Dec. 2. -- The total vote in New York State for President Roosevelt and Vice President Garner was 3,293,222, while Governor Landon and Colonel Knox, the Republican candidates, got 2,180,670, making the Democratic plurality 1,112,552.
Purchases of housing properties in Manhattan extended yesterday over a wide area from the lower East Side to Washington Heights. Many of the buildings were bought by investors for modernizing.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 2. -- Manhattan's Texas-bound football squad staged a hurried workout under floodlights at Georgia Tech's field tonight before departing for New Orleans on the second leg of its journey to Tyler, where it will close its 1936 campaign against Texas A. and M. on Saturday.

BERLIN, Dec. 2. -- With the Spanish civil war rapidly turning into a great rehearsal for a new world war -- a rehearsal in which the arms and men of the potential chief opponents are being tested for more serious business -- Germany is expected to rush a new proposal before the Non-Intervention Committee in London asking for the prohibition of shipments to Spain.
The Guaranty Trust Company has been appointed registrar for 500,000 shares of $1 par preferred stock of the Patchogue-Plymouth Mills Corporation.

LONDON, Dec. 2. -- The reign of King Edward VIII came perilously close to the breaking point tonight after a day of such fantastic happenings as the proud old British monarchy has not had to experience for hundreds of years.

Robert Elmore, young American organist, gave his first recital in Carnegie Hall last night. Despite the miserable weather, an audience of good size turned out to hear him play and remained to receive him warmly. Since Mr. Elmore is comparatively unknown to the average recital public, it was suggested that the popular prices, ranging from $1.10 to 55 cents, had attracted part of the audience.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The Houston Lighting and Power Company of Houston, Texas, an operating unit of the Electric Bond and

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Leading all the way, Mrs. K. Basehore's 6-year-old Flower Time today captured the Barbour Purse for 3-year-olds and up at one and one-sixteenth miles, feature of the program at the Charles Town track.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2. -- The Rev. Dr. E. Stanley Jones of India in an address tonight urged formation of "The Church of Christ in America," comprising all denominations.

The California Fruit Growers Exchange will break a newspaper campaign today on behalf of navel oranges, with copy running in forty-eight newspapers in thirty-four Central and Eastern markets. More markets and more newspapers will be added to the advertising list after the holidays.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., and Bonbright Co., Inc., will offer today an issue of $12,000,000 of first mortgage 3 1/4 per cent bonds, due in 1966, of the Consumers Power Company at 102 1/2 and accrued interest. The yield will be 3.11 per cent to the first date at which theI bonds will be callable at par.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2. -- Charles F. Edwards and Arthur S. Tobias of New York, investment brokers filed suit today in the Circuit Court here against John Dewitt, an investment banker at 208 South La Salle Street, asking $750,000, which they allege is due them as profits under a partnership agreement.

A formal report and opinion of the committee on professional ethics of the American Bar Association has criticized the conduct of lawyers, judges and ex-judges who participate in such broadcasts as the Good-Will Court program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- James W. Gerard, former Ambassador of the United States to Germany, has been selected by President Roosevelt to represent this country at the coronation next May of King Edward VIII of Britain, it was learned today.

The New York Trust Company, as executor, sold to an investing client of Joseph Howard Katz, attorney, the five-story apartment house at 1,987-1,989 Washington Avenue, the Bronx. Assessed at $58,000, the building was sold for cash over a $45,000 mortgage at 4 per cent for five years.
MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 2. -- El Nacional, the organ of the National Revolutionary party, which may be accepted as voicing official sentiment, will declare in an editorial tomorrow morning:
LONDON, Dec. 2. -- The Manchester Guardian said in an editorial today:

GENEVA, Dec. 2. -- President Roosevelt's Buenos Aires speech has made a very deep and favorable impression in the highest League of Nations quarters. They seem surprised at the strength of his speech, particularly the veiled allusions to Germany, Japan and Italy, whom they believe have been embarrassed by them.

Yesterday's rain caused a temporary halt in the plans of the New York Giants, who at the moment are deeply concerned with Sunday's crucial meeting with the Boston Redskins at the Polo Grounds. Preparations for the forthcoming battle, the outcome of which will determine the Eastern Division championship of the National Football League, called for a long workout yesterday, but that, of course, was out of the question.
KANSAS CITY, Dec. 2. -- The class of the Big Six conference is the senior class -- and the champion Nebraska football team which didn't even let its five rivals score against it.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 2. -- Argentine newspapers are unanimous in enthusiastically acclaiming President Roosevelt's speech before the Inter-American Peace Conference yesterday as an epoch-making declaration of American foreign policy.

An offering of two new issues aggregating $44,500,000 of Oklahoma Gas and Electric Company first mortgage bonds and debentures will be made today by an underwriting syndicate headed by H.M. Byllesby Co., Inc., Schroder Rockefeller Co., Inc., and the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation.

A "Musical World Tour" will be the theme of the six Saturday-morning Concerts for Young People which the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Ernest Schelling, will give at Carnegie Hall, starting on Dec. 19.

Personnel directors and employment experts, in conference yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania, concluded generally that the cost of living was one of the most important factors to be considered in determining wage rates.
Despite the general impression that the offense has advanced ahead of the defense in college football, an Associated Press survey revealed yesterday that scoring fell off slightly in 1936.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2. -- Arthur Thurnblad of Chicago provided another stunning upset in the world three-cushion billiards championship tournament today by defeating Otto Reiselt of Philadelphia, 50 to 31, in 48 innings. It was the Easterner's first defeat in three matches.

November, 1936, is likely long to be remembered for the aggregate to which declaration of company dividends rose. As stated at the month-end, announcements of such dividends -- "regular," "special," "extra," or in payment of "accumulated arrears" -- foot up $883,000,000.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 2. -- William F. Rafferty, 37 years old, division sales manager for the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association of New York, was drowned early this morning when his automobile was accidentally driven off a dock at the foot of Hudson Street here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The Agricultural Adjustment Administration today virtually limited any crop-insurance program to wheat for 1937 when Secretary Wallace let it be known that the special committee, of which he is chairman, would report such a recommendation to President Roosevelt in December.

MONTREAL, Dec. 2. -- Determined to find out whether the Cardinals were fighting or fooling in their oft-repeated threats to trade Dizzy Dean, Horace Stoneham, youthful president of the Giants, plunged fearlessly into the bidding today for the loquacious St. Louis pitching ace.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas showed an increase over last year of 13 per cent for the week ended Nov. 28, it was announced yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The figure shows a slightly smaller increase than that noted for the previous week, when the rise was 16 per cent.

Many parties were given last night in conjunction with the performance of the "A" series of "Tonight at 8:30," Noel Coward's group of one-act plays, at the National Theatre for the benefit of the Neighborhood Music School.
The New York Athletic Club team went into a deadlock for first place in the Class A group of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League last night.

LONDON, Dec. 2. -- The Stock Exchange, England's traditional barometer, was rife with discussion of the Bishop of Bradford's speech of yesterday, in which he said: "Some of us wish he [the King] gave more positive signs of his awareness of his need of God's grace."

CHICAGO, Dec. 2. -- Hogs were in active demand at 10 to 15 cents advance in prices, with some sales reported as 25 cents higher, compared with the low point of Tuesday. The extreme top of $10.10 was 10 cents higher and at the best level since Oct. 19.
REEDSVILLE, W. Va., Dec. 2 (AP). -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt made a swift inspection tour of the Arthurdale homestead today after visiting friends near Fairmont and a high school at Morgantown.

The city's $600,000 worth of new snow-removal equipment, delivery of which has been delayed by labor trouble in the manufacturing plant, will be available some time in January, Sanitation Commissioner William F. Carey revealed yesterday. The equipment, ordered from the J.I. Case Company of Racine, Wis., consists of 300 small crosswalk plows, used to keep crossings and curbs clear of snow.

Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, in a report filed yesterday with Mayor La Guardia, charged eight Brooklyn contractors employed by the Board of Education with violation of their contract agreements to pay prevailing wage rates to their employes.
TRENTON, Dec. 2. -- The New Jersey Social Security Commission will submit to the Legislature two proposals for unemployment compensation.

The City Bank Farmers Trust Company, a successor trustee, announced yesterday that $17,000 of Kansas City Gas Company first mortgage gold bonds, 5 per cent series due in 1946, had been drawn for redemption for the sinking fund on Feb. 1, 1937, at 102.

The first of the monthly index numbers, published yesterday by Dun's Review, shows an advance during November of 4 5/8 per cent in the commodity price average. This was the largest percentage gain of any month since July, 1933, and was the sixth successive increase of the present year.

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, left for Washington yesterday morning, presumably to confer with WPA authorities on the demonstration that led to the forcible ejection of 219 persons at the offices of the Federal Art Project on Tuesday night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- Opposition to scaling down the French debt and insistence on legislation for Federal incorporation of industries were high points in an interview Senator Borah gave today upon his return to begin his seventh term in the United States Senate, of which he is the dean.

The humble concertina, usually considered not much more than a toy, came into its own last night under the magic fingers of Raphael, who gave his first American recital at the Town Hail. Raphael was first brought to this country as one of the artists of the "Continental Varieties," which enjoyed a run at the Little Theatre, two years ago.

The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad will emerge from bankruptcy on a conservatively reorganized basis, Howard S. Palmer, president, announced yesterday after a hearing conducted by the Interstate Commerce Commission in the Pennsylvania Hotel as part of its investigation of the New Haven's finances.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 2. -- Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation, and one of the original sponsors of the coal research laboratory at the Carnegie Institute of Technology, will be the guest of honor at a dinner to be given tomorrow evening by Dr. Thomas S. Baker, president emeritus of Carnegie Tech and founder of the coal laboratory.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 2. -- Mexico today pledged her fullest cooperation in supporting President Roosevelt in his effort to establish a practical, workable Pan Americanism.
TALLAHASEE, Fla., Dec. 2 (AP). -- Governor Landon came into this Democratic stronghold for "some serious fishing" today and received a warm welcome.

In opening its doors yesterday to an appeal by Alfred E. Smith on behalf of the United Hospitals Fund, the Stock Exchange let in a wintry blast of criticism when it suspended its nation-wide quotation ticker service for the duration of Mr. Smith's address. Inquiries and protests from newspapers and brokers came in swiftly by telephone and telegraph.
PARIS, Dec. 2 (AP). -- France announced tonight plans for a huge naval building program as an answer to increased warship construction by Germany and Italy.
Gerard Debaets set out last night to show that he is far from through, even though he is the oldest rider in the current six-day bicycle race at Madison Square Garden.

Plate-glass windows in twenty-two stores and restaurants in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens were broken or shattered by small metal pellets and one young woman was injured by glass yesterday as a strike of glaziers extended to the whole building industry.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Dec. 2. -- The newspaper Diario de Costa Rica says that President Roosevelt's speech at Buenos Aires was obviously directed against the tendency in recent years to establish autocratic regimes in Latin America, imitating the Old World, whereas the New World is fundamentally democratic.
Engineering construction in this country last month totaled $162, 743,000, a 5 per cent gain over the $154,973,000 for November, 1935, The Engineering News-Record reported yesterday.

TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 3. -- The Foreign Office announcement of the Italo-Japanese agreement occupies barely four lines in Japanese. It merely states that the legation at Addis Ababa is becoming a consulate general and that Italy has agreed to give specially favorable consideration to Japan's commercial and other interests in Ethiopia.

LONDON, Dec. 2. -- Harold S. Vanderbilt's drastic proposals for revision of the sailing rules relating to the right-of-way which have been brought to the notice of the permanent committee of the International Yacht Racing Union by members of the North American Y.R.U. now are being rigorously canvassed among British yachtsmen but no decision of an authoritative nature is likely to be reached until next year.

If King Edward of Britain should leave his country in the present crisis without abdicating he might create a situation somewhat similar, from the legal point of view, to the flight of James II from England in 1688.

The unusually high percentage of Negro criminals could be lowered greatly if living and recreational conditions were improved in the areas where members of this race are centered, according to Warden Lewis E. Lawes of Sing Sing, who spoke last night at the dedication of a new recreation center opened by the Boys Athletic League at 235 West 113th Street.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 2. -- Hal Horne, former chief of the United Artists advertising forces in New York and a producer for RKO Radio since last July, has joined Walter Wanger's unit as a production executive. His first assignment will be "Vogues of 1937." He will take over the new office on Monday.

PARIS, Dec. 2. -- France attaches so much importance to President Roosevelt's Buenos Aires speech that the most important passages were rebroadcast over the government radio this evening with a foreword of commendation. At the same time the press comment reflects the public sentiment that noble words and ideological sentiments in themselves are not a sufficient contribution from the Americas to assure world peace.

Smith, Smith, Smith and still another Smith, all with the first name of Fred, got together yesterday afternoon to lay the groundwork for the founding of the Benevolent and Protective and Completely Universal Order of Fred Smiths.
MADRID, Dec. 2 (AP). -- Hundreds of men, women and children were believed killed today in three Insurgent air raids opening a fierce assault on hunger-ridden, besieged Madrid.

Three of the top-notch women skiers in the world were added to the imposing list of competitors who will participate in the International Ski Meet and Winter Sports Show to be held at Madison Square Garden from Wednesday to Saturday next week.

BERLIN, Thursday, Dec. 3. -- Germany, with few exceptions, continues to regard the Buenos Aires conference and President Roosevelt's trip to South America with complete indifference. A considerable part of the press today contains not a reference to the events in Argentina, or at the most only short and colorless reports.

The old National Surety Company acquired 150,000 shares of the Insurance Securities Company, Inc., an insurance-company holding company, in 1929 without informing the State Insurance Department of the transaction until after the contract had been made, it was brought out yesterday at the examination before trial of William B. Joyce, former chairman of National Surety.

England's North Country It used to be said that what Lancashire thinks today, meaning thereby by England's industrial North, England will think tomorrow. On the subject of King EDWARD'S big domestic problem today Lancashire and Yorkshire newspapers are saying out loud what the rest of England has been only thinking or alluding to in carefully veiled language.

Most commodity futures were higher yesterday in fairly active trading. Coffee futures sold at new high levels for the current move. Santos contracts sold above 10 cents a pound for the first time since January, 1935. In the cash markets, wheat, rye, cocoa, cotton, wool tops and rubber were higher, while corn, oats, lard, tin and silk were lower.

OTTAWA, Dec. 2. -- A new trade agreement between Great Britain and Canada has been concluded and its details, it is understood, will be disclosed within a few days. The pact probably will become operative at the beginning of the new year, twelve months after the Canadian treaty with the United States became effective.

The jury that heard evidence in Brooklyn Federal court in the trial of former officers of the National Title Guaranty Company on charges of conspiracy and use of the mails to defraud, was locked up last midnight.

A large number of persons have continued to hope and believe that the responsibilities of power would finally sober the Nazis and lead to a more moderate course. All such hopes have been shattered once more by the new decrees, one forcing all boys and girls to join the Nazi youth organizations, the other ordering the death penalty for Germans who smuggle money and other property abroad.

True to her promise, Juliana Morgan, who withdrew "All Editions" for repairs after its recent tryout in Baltimore, now plans to open it on Dec. 22 at the Longacre -- which, barring changes of plan, means a conflict with "Aged 26." The repairs to the Charles Washburn-Clyde North comedy include these cast changes: Walter N. Greaza for Regis Toomey, Nancy Evans for Martha Hedge, Richard Taber for Tom Fadden, Gladys Griswold for Berilla Kerr.

BERLIN, Dec. 2. -- The public learned further details today of the new exchange law empowering the Exchange Control Service to seize and administer the fortune and property of any citizens suspected of an intention to go abroad permanently.

Wide increases in the use of Diesel power, as the herald of a new power age, were forecast yesterday in railroad operation, highway and sea transportation, agriculture, and aviation at a luncheon at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria in honor of the fortieth anniversary of the introduction of Diesel power in the United States and in memory of the late Rudolf Diesel, who designed the first practical compression-ignition engine.

Statistics fail to support the popular conception of women drivers as the cause of most automobile accidents, Professor William Junkin Cox of Yale informed an audience yesterday at the Hotel Astor, at a conference on "A 1937 Forecast for Better Living." Only 6 per cent of the highway accidents involve women drivers, he said.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP). -- A possible 33 per cent reduction in Federal relief costs next year was suggested today by Works Progress Administration plans to trim relief rolls to about 2,000,000 cases by January, as compared with about 3,000,000 the first of this year.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 2. -- According to information filtering in from Athens, Greece, today, the Metaxas military dictatorship last night carried out a coup d'etat against its critics who were said to be concerned in a plot against the government.

Luigi Antonini, State Chairman of the American Labor party, emphatically denied last night a published report that the party was being torn by dissension and that a group of "conservatives," with an intent of monopolizing Federal patronage which may be allotted to the party, was edging out a group of young "idealists" who had been instrumental in starting the organization.

TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 2. -- One of the outstanding literary finds of recent years has been made here with the opening of an old trunk brought from Norway this Fall by a 16-year-old lad named Hjalmar Hjorth Boyesen 3d.

Three New York executives of major oil companies, indicted with many others in Madison, Wis., for violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act, were arraigned yesterday before United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter in removal proceedings and held in $2,500 bail each for hearings on Jan. 7.

Trading in bonds was more active on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday but price movements were contradictory, with United States Government securities uniformly lower, high-grade issues generally firmer and second-grade rails strong.

The screen transcription of the 1935 prize play, "Winterset," comes to the Music Hall today with three; members of the Broadway cast, Margo, Burgess Meredith and Eduardo Ciannelli, interpreting their original roles for the screen. Other important players are Edward Ellis, John Carradine, Paul Guilfoyle, Maurice Moscovitch and Stanley Ridges.

For the first time in thirty-five years the Metropolitan Opera Association will open its season on Monday evening, Dec. 21, with a major Wagnerian work, "Die Walkuere," it was announced yesterday by Edward Johnson, general manager.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:
PARIS, Dec. 2. -- Talk of war debt settlement between France and the United States received a temporary check today when the Foreign Affairs Commission decided to defer discussion of the problem.

Featured by the announcement that the New York State Council of Retail Merchants will affiliate with the American Retail Federation and by the emphasis of speakers that a "vital need" exists for coordinated State-wide action to combat "selfish" legislation detrimental to retailers and consumers, a testimonial dinner was tendered last night by leading local merchants to John C. Watson, president of the council.

City Hall, one of the finest examples of Colonial architecture in this country, will have its interior restored to its original appearance through an appropriation of $12,000 approved yesterday by members of the Aldermanic committee on public letting.

Colonel Bill Terry, believed to have been delayed somewhere in transit between Memphis and Montreal, was discovered snug and dry in the Giants offices on West Forty-second Street yesterday, full of good health and spirits as well as denials that Hank Leiber is a Giant chattel definitely to be disposed of.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the admission on Aug. of C. Russell MacGregor as a special partner in Auchincloss, Parker Redpath and the proposed admission on Jan. 2 of Robert A. Leisher to Weingarten Co. The interest of the estate of Lawrence Strassburger in Strassburger Co. will cease on Dec. 31 and Newton Henry Neustadter Jr. will be admitted to the firm on Jan. 1.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 2. -- Woodlander, star distance-running gelding owned by Norman Hernandez of New Orleans. defeated a field of sprinters in the West End Handicap at the Fair Grounds today.

ROME, Dec. 2. -- President Roosevelt's speech at the opening of the Buenos Aires conference yesterday created a good impression in Italy. Favorable comment was made on the speech excepting parts which have irritated the Italians.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 2. -- Mrs. Margaret Emerson entertained with a dinner tonight at her home on Banyan Road. Mr. and Mrs. Douglas W. Paige, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick M. Alger Jr. and Mr. and Mrs. Askel C.P. Wickfeld are visiting her.
A steady rise in temperature yesterday saved this city, and most of the Eastern Atlantic States, from a heavy snowstorm. It rained instead, and the total was more than an inch.

H.L. Allen Co. obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of refunding bonds of Rutherford, N.J., on a bid of 100.837 for 2s. The bonds are being reoffered today at prices to yield from .50 to 2 per cent for the various mounts to maturity and are dated Dec. 1, 1936, and will mature from Dec. 1, 1937 to 1946.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- Drafts of regulations covering some of the I features of the broad program of the Securities and Exchange Commission which would result ultimately in at least a partial segregation of the broker-dealer functions on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange probably will be ready early next week, it was indicated today.

In its way, the speech of President JUSTO at Buenos Aires was hardly less noteworthy than that of Mr. ROOSEVELT. The Argentine President was both courteous and cordial in recognizing the significance of the presence of the President of the United States, and of the speech delivered by him.

In many respects the action of the stock market yesterday was a repetition of the performance on the day before. Leading issues continued lower, although there were no signs of what might be rightly termed aggressive selling; bargain-hunting resulted in small to moderate gains in many low-priced issues, and some preferred stocks made headway.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 2. -- Paced by a twenty-piece band, a jostling line of 3,000 merchants and clerks marched on Alabama's historic State House today in protest against a proposed 1 1/2 per cent gross receipts tax on retail sales and amusements.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 2. -- Herbert T. Borden, vice president of the New Jersey Farm Bureau, told the New Jersey Grange here today that farmers in this State own and control twenty-five cooperative buying and selling organizations involving a turnover of about $35,000,000 a year.

LONDON, Dec. 2. -- The loan exhibition of thirty-six paintings and drawings by Franz Xavier Winterhalter at Knoedler's today is particularly significant and timely, coming as it does while the ruins of the Crystal Palace are still smouldering.

The first attempt by protectionist interests to obtain a court ruling on the constitutionality of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act failed yesterday when the third division, United States Customs Court, dismissed a test case there.

The "windfall tax," designed by the government to recover money collected by manufacturers for processing taxes and not paid into the Treasury, was described yesterday at a conference of the American Management Association as a measure to punish those who sought the defeat in the Supreme Court of the AAA.

BERLIN, Dec. 2. -- The Boerse was almost totally paralyzed today although securities did not come, of course, under the Reich's price-freezing decree issued yesterday. Throughout the market there was a tendency toward weakness on a very small turnover, and an atmosphere of watchful and somewhat anxious waiting prevailed.

For more than four weeks shipping services in this area have been severely handicapped by a seamen's strike which has caused large losses and great inconvenience. What was already a serious domestic problem now threatens to have international complications. A few days ago longshoremen at the port of Havre, acting in response to pleas from this side for "solidarity," refused to unload freight from an American liner.

LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 3. -Harold Laski, Professor of Political Science at the University of London, reviewing the constitutional position of the King in the British system, declares the King must act on the advice of his Ministers.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the week-end, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and of pupils in local private and public elementary and high schools.

PARIS, Dec. 2. -- Revolt by the Communists, the Left wing of Premier Leon Blum's majority, on the issue of intervention in Spain is announced for Friday and there is much nervous speculation over the outcome. Last night when the Communists, after protesting the government's Spanish policy in the Foreign Affairs Commission, finally voted the appropriations asked it was believed a settlement had been reached.

Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente dismissed yesterday the suit brought by Fred Rosenthal, a stockholder of Carib Syndicate, Ltd., to restrain Carib's sale for $2,000,000 of its 21 per cent interest in the Colombian Petroleum Company, holder of the Barco oil concession in Colombia.

If the Republican party is to win back the favor of the voters in this State, it must have a new and militant chairman for its State committee and liberal party leadership in both branches of the Legislature which can be depended upon to carry out a reasoned party program, former Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley told members of the Republican County Committee last night.

LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 3. -- Following a day in which securities sagged as a result of anxiety over the monarchical situation, the usual routine of business preparatory to the opening of the Stock Exchange was being conducted at 9:30 A. M. today.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull was one of three "distinguished Americans" honored by the annual awards for "outstanding contributions toward world cooperation during the past year" at the twelfth anniversary dinner meeting of the Students International Union at the Hotel Plaza last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The text of President Roosevelt's remarks at the luncheon he tendered to President Agustin P. Justo of Argentina at Buenos Aires today, as given out by the State Department, is as follows:

Philip J. Roosevelt, president of the North American Yacht Racing Union, announced yesterday that an invitation has been received from Admiral G. Pietro Lodolo, president of the Royal Italian Yacht Club in Genoa for all owners of American six-meter class and eight-meter class yachts to compete in the international races which will be held next Feb. 22 to March 7.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 2. -- Thousands stood for hours in a pouring rain to throw flowers at President Roosevelt as he departed for home today.

Leroy W. Baldwin, president of the Empire Trust Company, testified in Supreme Court yesterday that the bank had accepted the information given to it by Joseph Mercadante, a shipper, as the basis of an agreement the latter signed Feb. 3, 1928, showing his indebtedness to the bank.

GENEVA, Dec. 2. -- Employer delegates of the International Labor Organization, preparatory to a meeting for the forty-hour-week convention for printers, informed it today that with the single exception of their American. colleague, Harold Winchester, their group refused to take part further in its work.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Dec. 2. -- Discovery of two ninety-year-old stamps issued by the postmaster at Brattleboro before American stamps were made was reported today by Paul A. Dorn of Redlands.

Winston Guest and Arthur Borden remain at the top of the handicap list as a new season of indoor polo gets under way in the various rings of the country, leading up to the national championships of the late Spring, which are expected to be held in New York City again.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- Approving a preliminary report of the Business Advisory Council made to Secretary Roper in July, a special subcommittee today urged that the Commerce Department cooperate with the Maritime Commission in order that the principles of the Maritime Act of 1936 may be applied to airships.
SEATTLE, Dec. 2. -- A sixteen-ton Boeing bomber, described by its makers as the fastest and longest ranged aircraft of its type in the world, made a successful test flight here today.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 2. -- Premier Paul van Zeeland won an important victory today when the Belgian Chamber of Deputies approved the Army Bill by a vote of 145 to 40, with 89 abstentions.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 2. -- Formal rupture of Chino-Japanese diplomatic relations is expected this week, surprisingly not because of China's continued refusal to agree to Japanese demands, but because the Nanking government is unwilling to resume negotiations while the military threat to Suiyuan Province continues.

Former President Hoover, in an address last night at the Hotel Astor before a large group of distinguished fellow engineers, warned that the United States is headed for a debacle like that of 1929, "unless we can bring the intelligence and courage of the engineer into industrial statesmanship."

A mortgage-liquidation plan, intended to salvage the investment of mortgage certificate holders in properties that are worth less than the face value of the mortgages, was presented yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler by trustees of the $10,000,000 Series Q issue of the New York Title and Mortgage Company.

Mrs. Mary G. Echols Stafford Moore, thrice-married showgirl from Texas, who graced the Winter Garden here fifteen years ago, took the witness stand yesterday against the widow of Colonel Edward H.R. Green.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 2 (AP). -- Rose Bowl officials promised today to announce within twenty-four hours the name of the University of Washington's opponent for the New Year's Day football classic.

PLEASANTVILLE, N. J., Dec. 2. -- A band of indignant and determined women, armed with knitting needles, darning spools and embroidery hoops, was in possession of City Hall tonight, vowing to lift the siege only if and when they got work again.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 2. -- The twenty-fifth annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America opened in the Bon Air Hotel here this morning with more than 900 members in attendance. This is the second largest attendance at a convention in the history of the association, having been surpassed only at the meeting in Quebec in 1929.

The 1937 edition of the British "Who's Who," published today, prominently features the royal section as that of a coronation year. The King is listed at the front of the book simply as "His Majesty King Edward VIII."

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 2. -- Thousands stood for two hours in a heavy downpour of rain this afternoon so that they might for two or three seconds throw flowers at President Roosevelt's automobile as he passed them on his way to the port to board the cruiser Indianapolis and sail for Montevideo.
PARIS, Dec. 2. -- A Separatist-Fascist plot involving the assassination of some if not all the members of the Catalan government has just been frustrated in Barcelona.

Under the broadest and most active trading in several months, prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced again yesterday. December touched 12.32 cents a pound, the highest price since the season started on Aug. 1, and four of the five active 1936 crop deliveries were above 12 cents at one time.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 29 Miss Anita P. Forbes is quoted as stating that the material found in "pulp" magazines constitutes a menace to high school pupils' morals, English and minds.

BERLIN, Dec. 2. -- The Reich Youth Administration confirmed reports today that Catholic Youth organizations would be allowed to exist despite the enforced enrollment of all German youth in the Hitler Youth organization.

The fourteen-month reorganization proceedings of the Warner-Quinlan Company, producers, refiners and distributors of asphalt and oil, which have been marked by considerable wrangling, appeared to be drawing to a satisfactory close yesterday.

Forecasting the styles in men's apparel for next Spring and Summer, the Merchant Tailor Designers Association of New York, at their annual fashion exhibit at the Hotel Commodore last night, indicated that there will be a decided trend toward loose-fitting clothes, showing the British influence and "refined" athletic effects.

Julius Brittlebank has seen so much of the world over and over again that he is not quite certain which part of it he likes the best, but there is never a doubt that his passion for travel waxes with the years.

Gunnar Barlund, heavyweight champion of Finland, scored his third successive victory since coming to this country by knocking out Frankie Connelly of Boston in the ninth round of their scheduled ten-round bout at the Hippodrome last night.

A series of long-drawn-out battles marked the opening of the season last night for the Class C teams in Groups 1 and 2 of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association. The Princeton, Harvard, Yale and University clubs were the winners in the first group, while Brown, Columbia and the Downtown A.C. triumphed in the second section.
MANILA, Dec. 3 (Thursday) (AP). -- A typhoon, waning in violence as it moved northward, brought torrential rains and high winds to Manila today, but no casualties were reported.

The General Motors Corporation has adopted a uniform arrangement for overtime compensation for its 220,000 employes, under which payment will be made at the rate of one and one-half times the normal rate for all work in excess of forty hours a week, it was learned yesterday. Hitherto, the corporation has paid at the same overtime rate for all work in excess of forty-eight hours a week.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Dec. 2. -- Editorial writers here call President Roosevelt's speech yesterday at the Inter-American Peace Conference sensational and declare that, together with the address he delivered to the Brazilian Congress last Friday it will form a strong foundation for establishing peace in the Americas.
BERLIN, Dec. 2 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Dec. 1 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

WANAKENA, N.Y., Dec. 2. -- New York Forestry College experts told today of a "frost pocket" deep in the Adirondack woods of St. Lawrence County where the temperature drops below freezing at least once in every month, including July and August.

With textile prices advancing on a broad range yesterday, shoe leaders predicted that after the first of the year their industry would be compelled to follow the examples of the woolen and cotton field and move up prices 15 per cent.

A plea by former Governor Alfred E. Smith for contributions to the United Hospital Fund, made on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, caused confusion in the financial circles of the nation. The plea was made just as the stock market closed to about 3,500 brokers and their employes on the floor.

With textile prices advancing on a broad range yesterday, shoe leaders predicted that after the first of the year their industry would be compelled to follow the examples of the woolen and cotton field and move up prices 15 per cent.

A plea by former Governor Alfred E. Smith for contributions to the United Hospital Fund, made on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, caused confusion in the financial circles of the nation. The plea was made just as the stock market closed to about 3,500 brokers and their employes on the floor.

The Rev. Dr. Arthur J. Brown, chairman of the American Committee on Religious Rights and Minorities since its formation in 1920, was the guest of honor at a dinner given last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania under the joint auspices of the committee and the Church Peace Union in celebration of his eightieth birthday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The government completed the first five months of the fiscal year on Nov. 30 with a deficit of $1,244,597,991, which was $447,884,668, or more than 26 per cent, smaller than of a year before, it was announced today.

With steel ingot production at 76 per cent of capacity and probably heading for higher levels, indications are that 1936 ingot production will approach 47,000,000 tons; some steel interests are confident that next year's total will be fully 50,000,000 tons, barring unforeseen developments, Iron Age said yesterday in its weekly summary.

LONDON, Dec. 2. -- A general tendency downward marked the movement on the Stock Exchange here today, with an all-round shrinkage in trading. The only section which withstood the almost uniform dullness was tobacco, and these shares spurted on the heels of an announcement by the Carreras Company showing that consumption of tobacco had set new high records in recent months.

Reform in property assessment methods, reduction in taxes on real estate and larger State aid for education and highways were listed as the objectives of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York at a meeting of the board of directors yesterday in the Hotel Astor to map the program of the organization for its thirty-third year.

LONDON, Dec. 2. -- The Lord Chamberlain, who also exercises jurisdiction as a censor, has been authorized by King Edward to announce that plays dealing with the life of Queen Victoria can now be considered for production after June 20, 1937, the date being the centenary of Victoria's accession to the throne.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- Reductions amounting to $12,000,000 annually in the interstate long-distance rates of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company will become effective on or before Jan. 15, 1937, bringing to $22,000,000 the rate reductions ordered this year.

Production of coke pig iron in November, according to The Iron Age, totaled 2,993,434 gross tons, compared with 2,991,887 tons in October. Last month's daily rate was 99,781 tons, or 3.3 per cent above the 96,512 tons in October. There were 164 furnaces in blast on Dec. 1, a gain of three since Nov. 1.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2. -- A conference of President Roosevelt and representative clergymen to discuss methods of "insuring this country's future" was suggested today by the Right Rev. James E. Freeman, bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Washington.
BERLIN, Dec. 2. -- Karl Robson, correspondent of The London Morning Post, was informed by the police today that he must leave Germany within three days.

BOSTON, Dec. 2. -- Gilmour Dobie, football coach at Boston College, and Frank Murdock, freshman coach, were seriously injured today when Mr. Dobie's car crashed into a railroad abutment on Beacon Street near Kenmore Square.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 2. -- With President Roosevelt's short but triumphal visit at an end, the various delegations began active preparations today for the work of the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace which the President came all the way to Buenos Aires to open.

BUCHAREST, Dec. 2. -- The trade methods of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, German Minister of Economics and president of the Reichsbank, were exemplified again today, in the opinions of Rumanians, when the German Minister here officially called on the Minister of Commerce to announce that the Third Reich was unable to fulfill its obligations under the Germano-Rumanian trade agreement.

The engagement of $2,136,000 gold abroad for shipment here, $1,953,000 in England and $183,000 in India, was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Of the gold taken in England, $700,000 was secured yesterday and the remainder on some previous day.

Cash dividends declared yesterday amounted to $35,000,000, an increase of $10,000,000 from the disbursements ordered on Tuesday. The total for the first two days of the month approximated $60,000,000. Last month cash dividends declared amounted to $883,200,000, the largest amount for any month on record.

The French liner Champlain lay last night at her pier in the North River, at Forty-eighth Street, her hold filled with 525 tons of Christmas perfumes, wine and other cargo which were there when she docked early yesterday afternoon and seem doomed to return to her home port of Havre when she sails this noon.

Turn out the guard! Officer of the day Or maybe there should be a call for a general court-martial. It's General Hugh Johnson who has gone and done it again. Once before he carried a football a long way in the wrong direction, but this tops it. This is one for the legendary book.

Cash dividends declared yesterday amounted to $35,000,000, an increase of $10,000,000 from the disbursements ordered on Tuesday. The total for the first two days of the month approximated $60,000,000. Last month cash dividends declared amounted to $883,200,000, the largest amount for any month on record.

The French liner Champlain lay last night at her pier in the North River, at Forty-eighth Street, her hold filled with 525 tons of Christmas perfumes, wine and other cargo which were there when she docked early yesterday afternoon and seem doomed to return to her home port of Havre when she sails this noon.

Turn out the guard! Officer of the day Or maybe there should be a call for a general court-martial. It's General Hugh Johnson who has gone and done it again. Once before he carried a football a long way in the wrong direction, but this tops it. This is one for the legendary book.
Threescore and seventeen years have left Harry Hessler with a calm, philosophic outlook on life, but have not weakened his arms.

Santa Claus, in the form of New York City policemen, will stand guard over shipments of Christmas trees this year to make sure that no racketeers prey upon receivers or shippers, Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday.

Three domestic items and a German importation comprise today's schedule of new films. At the Capitol will be Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "Born to Dance," starring Eleanor Powell, with music by Cole Porter. The Roxy will show "The Luckiest Girl in the World," from the Universal studios, played by Jane Wyatt, Louis Hayward, Nat Pendleton, Eugene Pallette and Catherine Doucet.
Effective Jan. 1, the name of Weill Hartmann will be changed to Arkwright, Inc. The buying office will be operated on a semicooperative basis.

Bank clearings of the principal cities throughout the nation for the five days ended on Wednesday aggregated $6,153,176,000, against $5,442,041,000 last year, according to an announcement yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The 13.1 per cent gain was attributed in part to certain of the heavy settlements incident to the first of the month and which are included in the current figure.

MONTREAL, Dec. 3. -- Following a day of intensive bartering, during which, however, little was accomplished, it remained for the Dodgers and Cardinals to show themselves the only major league clubs represented at the minor league convention which are not afraid to give up something on the chance of getting something better in return.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 3. -- Supreme Court Justice-elect Lee Parsons Davis said today at his law office here that his family's "rubbernecking" tour of New York, planned after they had returned from a trip to Europe and realized how little they knew of their own country, was definitely canceled.

PARIS, Dec. 3. -- France is following with keen interest the drama in the British dynasty -- and with a feeling that great issues for Europe as well as the British Empire are dependent on a rapid and final settlement of the question.
LONDON, Nov. 3. -- In view of the grave constitutional crisis, the tendency of the stock market today was to mark time.

Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation and a trustee of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, received the gold medal of the American Arbitration Association yesterday at a luncheon given by that organization in the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 3 (AP). -- Running the six-and-one-half furlongs over a heavy track in 1:25 1-5, Mrs. G. Hutchins's 4-year-old Credulous, ridden by Jockey L. Machado, won the fourth race today, paying $7.20 for a $2 mutuel ticket.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP). -- Registration by employers under the Social Security Act was running so far behind expectations tonight that the government instituted a check-up of delinquents.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- J.B. Lovelace, president of the Investment Company of America, testifying before the Securities and Exchange Commission today, urged rigid Federal regulation of investment trusts. Mr. Lovelace said new tax legislation in so far as investment trusts were concerned should be undertaken by Congress.
BERLIN, Dec. 3. -- Every German household is to be put this Winter on government-enforced rations of butter, oleomargarine, lard and other fats.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 3 (AP). -- A St. Louis cancer expert and a Cleveland physicist received tonight from the Radiological Society of North America its 1936 achievement awards for their eleven years of successful effort to obtain a standard "yardstick" for the measurement of X-ray "dosage."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- The text of President Roosevelt's response to the speech of welcome by President Terra of Uruguay at Montevideo today, as given out by the state Department, is as follows:

American business must cure its structural flaws, mend its mistakes and face its responsibilities in a changing economic, political and social world, or face inevitable loss of its economic freedom because of increased governmental control, James O. McKinsey, chairman of Marshall Field Co., declared yesterday at a luncheon of the American Management Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Commodity prices advanced in the last week on a wide front and The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices rose 1.7 points to 131.7 on Tuesday, the highest since June 3, 1930
LONDON, Dec. 3 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- Mrs. Doris Duke Cromwell of Somerville, N.J., one of the wealthiest women in the United States, contributed $50,000 to the last Democratic campaign, according to a list of contributions made public today by the Senate Committee on Campaign Expenditures.

Were Emerson living today he would find recent world events grist for his philosophy of tough-mindedness. The World War and its aftermath have demonstrated that soft-mindedness, wishful thinking and the path of least resistance lead to inner decay and destruction, exposing individuals, institutions, and even mighty nations to the aggression of ruthless and unprincipled men.

There is something damnably ungrateful about an artist wanting to provide decent food, clothing and shelter for his family. If he must be an artist, why doesn't he live in a garret and forget about his belly? If he behaved in the good old way and if he became recognized as great in fifty years he would be honored.

The discovery that under certain given conditions there exist "cosmic lenses" in the spaces around stars, which act as magnifying glasses for two stars in a direct line of vision, is reported by Dr. Albert Einstein, author of the relativity theory, in the current isssue of Science, official organ of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 3. -- Old Field, owned by Mrs. E.J. Chambers, came from behind under a rousing ride by Joe O'Malley to win the mile and seventy yard Biloxi Purse by half a length today at the Fair Grounds. Mrs. H.O. Simmons's Donnahona nosed out the Swingland Stable's Boiling Point for second place.

LONDON, Dec. 3. -- Winston Churchill and Sir Walter Citrine, General Secretary of the Trades Union Congress, appeared on the same platform in Albert Hall tonight when an "all-party pledge" in "defense of freedom and peace" was obtained from 8,000 persons.

BERLIN, Dec. 3. -- Thomas Mann, winner of the Nobel Prize for literature in 1929 and generally regarded as the greatest living German author, was deprived of his German citizenship tonight by Dr. Wilhelm Frick, Minister of the Interior, acting in conjunction with Baron Constantin von Neurath, Foreign Minister.

The law committee of the Stock Exchange, it was learned yesterday, has submitted to the Federal Reserve Board its criticism of the board's proposed amendments to Regulation T, to eliminate "free rides" in unmargined securities. Partners in several large commission houses feel that, in seeking to obviate the so-called three-day "free ride," the board goes too far in requiring the deposit of margin before an order is executed.

Mrs. Vladimir Behr entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Countess Alfonso P. Villa, Mrs. Leland Eggleston Cofer, Mrs. Finley Thomas, Mrs. Donald C.T. Atkinson and Mrs. Francis L.V. Hoppin.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 3. -- A project for joint American action against any outside aggression, suggested by President Roosevelt, was laid before the Inter-American Peace Conference tonight as it began actual work.
CAPE TOWN, South Africa, Dec. 3 (AP). -- Captain James A. Mollison and his French co-pilot, Edouard Corniglion-Molinier, were found safe today after they had vanished within 100 miles of here.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 3. -- Manhattan's football squad left here tonight on the last leg of its 1,700-mile journey to Tyler, Texas, where Texas A. and M. will be met in the final game of the Green's season Saturday. The Jaspers had a busy day cramming in a two-hour practice session and ten hours of sightseeing during their stop-over.

HARRISBURG, Dec. 3. -- The Republican State Committee spent $657,207 in its unsuccessful fight to prevent President Roosevelt and the Democrats from sweeping Pennsylvania in November, according to a statement filed today with the State Elections Bureau.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 3. -- Nelson A. Applebach, 67-year-old retired banker, and his wife. Elizabeth, 65, were found dead in their apartment at 110 Lincoln Place here this evening, apparently of poisonous fumigating gas seeping from an adjoining apartment.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 3 (AP). -- Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne tonight appealed to New York State sportsmen to build up a strong, representative association which could make its wishes listened to "with respect" by high State officials.

Most commodity futures were irregularly lower on local exchanges yesterday. Hides and cocoa, however, advanced to record high levels. On the cash markets, wheat, rye and cocoa sold at new high prices and flour, cotton and silk advanced. Corn, eggs, tin and rubber declined.

Leading stocks improved irregularly yesterday after two days of pronounced heaviness, and the "public" demand for low-priced issues continued active, so that the market averages showed their best gains, however small, in exactly one week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- Representative Rayburn moved into the lead in the race for the floor leadership of the House today when Democratic members from Pennsylvania caucused and voted 18 to 6 to support the Texan as a unit. The vote later was made unanimous.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding in the week ended on Dec. 2, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,465,000,000, a decrease of $2,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $10,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 3 (AP). -- Don Harrison, director of athletics at the University of Pittsburgh, said tonight the Panthers would accept the Rose Bowl bid.

MADRID, Dec. 3. -- Two quick air raids early this morning and some fairly heavy shelling, all of which did little more damage to the already battered northwestern corner of this city, were the sum total of today's military action on the Madrid front.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3. -- A new major oil company to be known as the Richfield Oil Corporation, the result of judicial approval of the merger of the Richfield Oil Company and the Rio Grande Oil Company, was launched here today in the United States District Court.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 3. -- Gay, smiling Uruguayans made a carnival today of President Roosevelt's final triumphal appearance of his South American tour.

English history offers a parallel in the reign of King Richard II in the fourteenth century for the present impasse between Edward VIII and his government. Richard was forced to submit to a parliamentary Council of State, a precedent which The London Times has hinted could be invoked in the current situation.
Increased activity in Queens properties was reported yesterday.

Supreme Court Justice Timothy A. Leary heard argument for nearly an hour yesterday in a preliminary hearing on the application of Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt for modification of the order of Justice John F. Carew, which gave principal custody of her daughter, Gloria, to the girl's aunt, Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney.

The New York Mudhens -- better known as the Giants -- sloughed through the Polo Grounds mud in a curtailed practice yesterday for their forthcoming Eastern championship football game with the Boston Redskins there on Sunday and found out afterward that the Hub eleven had had a highly satisfactory session on the dryer tablelands of the Westchester Country Club.
SHANGHAI, Friday, Dec. 4. -- The Japanese action in landing marine units at Tsingtao proved the proverbial last straw in breaking China's patience.

Bond prices variously were steady or firmer yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange on a moderate turnover. High-grade issues were virtually unchanged, and United States Government securities registered advances of 1-32 to 7-32 point for the day, with a few of the loans rising to record levels during the session.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 3 (AP) -- Over the bunkers and around the doglegs the golfing profession wended sub-par ways in practice today, indicating the members who collect Colonel Henry L. Doherty's $10,000 in the Mami Biltmore open starting tomorrow will earn it.
BERLIN, Dec. 3 (AP). -- Max Schmeling left on his way to the United States today confident that no fight between Joe Louis and Jim Braddock would "chisel" him out of his heavyweight title chances.

That great booking crisis in Forty-fifth Street has been settled. On Dec. 14, the scheduled date, the Booth will get "You Can't Take It With You," at the same time yielding its current tenant, "Swing Your Lady!" to the Golden.

After holding the liner Champlain at her North River pier beyond her scheduled hour of departure in the hope that French and American longshoremen would settle their differences and make possible the unloading of her freight, the French Line sent the ship away at midnight last night, still carrying most of the cargo that was in her hold when she docked Wednesday.
Testimony in the Empire Trust Company suit in equity before Justice Peter Schmuck in Supreme Court was ended yesterday.
The Manufacturers Trust Company is registrar for 394,937 1/2 shares of $1 par common stock of Bath Iron Works Corporation.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3. -- A young Professor of History will attempt to make history in the Western Conference tomorrow by pleading for adoption of a modified type of subsidy that would award scholarships to football players and other athletes on the basis of $400 a year.

Weekly magazine circulation is at present closer to that of 1930 than is that of women's publications and general monthly magazines, according to the sixth edition of the annual "Analysis of Net Paid Circulation and Subscription Production," released yesterday by the Association of National Advertisers.

Reaching the second highest weekly volume of the year, engineering construction awards reported this week total $74,328,000, according to The Engineering News-Record, which attributes the large volume to $38,517,000 in private wards, this classification reaching the highest point for any week in more than four years.

DETROIT, Dec. 3. -- In a smashing come-back after two shut-out defeats, the champion Red Wings used a revamped line-up tonight to blank the New York Rangers, leaders of the American division of the National Hockey League, 2 to 0.

Four amendments to the new Traffic Code now pending in the Board of Aldermen were added yesterday with the specific objective of eliminating petty racketeering in the watching, parking and cleaning of automobiles.
MONTREAL, Dec. 3. -- The American Association and International League today patched up their differences and agreed to play the little world series in 1937 after all.

Dedicated to the interests of the woman consumer, the second annual American Women's Association Consumer Mart opened yesterday at the A.W.A. ballroom, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street, with a varied program of speeches and exhibits under the direction of Rita Otway, president of the Advertising Women of New York, Inc.
TORONTO, Ont., Dec. 3. -- Representative Canadian subjects of King Edward VIII refused, in interviews today, to accept the contention that the monarch's life was his own.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.J. Dec. 3. -- Determined to be dragged from the council hall here rather than waver in their fight for restoration of their jobs as WPA seamstresses, eighty-eight tired women startled this town of almost 10,000 population today with an unprecedented picketing attack on gambling which they described as open and politically protected.
BERLIN, Dec. 3. -- The Boerse was weak and listless today.
