WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- An additional list of holding companies which have filed on the complete form for registration under the Public Utility Act of 1935 was made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. All the companies were among the sixty-five that had filed on the preliminary form.

While the question is extremely unsettled, a study of English law, church and state, would seem to indicate that King Edward would have little difficulty in marrying Mrs. Wallis Simpson within the Church of England if he so chose.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- Mortgages authorized for foreclosure in October by the Home Owners Loan Corporation numbered 6,265, a decrease of 1,014 from September and 1,938 from August. The rate was the lowest since May, the corporation said today.

Bill Sledge of Houston, Texas, threw Ernest Von Hefner, German grappler, in 22:11 of their scheduled feature finish bout at the New York Coliseum last night. Sledge weighed 215 and Von Hefner 235. A crowd of 1,500 saw Sledge pin his rival with a flying tackle and double leg lock.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 3. -- Pittsburgh was selected today to play the University of Washington in the Rose Bowl football classic New Year's Day.

The jury that retired on Wednesday afternoon to weigh the evidence against the six remaining defendants in the trial of eight former officers of the National Title Guaranty Company on charges of conspiracy and the use of the mails to defraud, returned a verdict of guilty of conspiracy yesterday afternoon against four of the defendants.
A dark-horse team, one that was accorded little chance at the start, made matters interesting during last night's session of the six-day bicycle race at Madison Square Garden.

WOODBURY, N.J., Dec. 3. -- Linford Castor, 42 years old, of Paulsboro, was sentenced today by Judge Woods in Special Sessions Court here to serve three months in the county jail for manslaughter by automobile, but he will be permitted to leave the jail daily to go to work.

Following a lower opening yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered all the early loss and closed with changes ranging from a net gain of 2 to a loss of 3 points. While trading fell short of Wednesday's unusually large volume, liberal mill buying continued to stiffen the spot month, and from 12.11 cents a pound the December moved up 17 points at one time. Steadier outside markets influenced sentiment.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 3. -- Dorothy McNulty, a member of the Broadway company of "Follow Thru," signed a Metro contract today and was assigned immediately a prominent role in "They Gave Him a Gun." This, because of the reception she received last night at a preview showing of "After the Thin Man."
BOSTON, Dec. 3. -- The opening of the six-day horse show sponsored by the ll0th Cavalry drew nearly a capacity attendance at the Commonwealth Armory tonight.

The need for cleaning up New York City in preparation for the World's Fair to be held here in 1939, with particular reference to the rivers and harbor, was stressed yesterday by Lawrence B. Elliman, real estate man, at the monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, held at 62 Liberty Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- In a rare procedure, Dr. Francis E. Townsend, author of the $200-a-month old-age pension plan, and two aides, were indicted on contempt charges by a Federal grand jury today for flouting the authority of the House of Representatives.

Clouds of dust rose yesterday afternoon in the once glamorous Manhattan Opera House as rows of red plush opera chairs were removed to be given away to friends and well-wishers of the late Oscar Hammerstein, who rose from cigar-making in a downtown side street to design his own theatre and develop a singing organization with which he hoped to rival the Metropolitan.
PARIS, Dec. 3. -- Fervent words of gratitude for President Roosevelt's stand for international peace were spoken today by Deputy Francois de Tessan, addressing the American Club here.

A resolution, protesting the dismissals on WPA music projects and reminding President Roosevelt of his promise to "provide useful work for the needy unemployed," was adopted last night at a meeting of about 300 WPA musicians held under the auspices of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians.

Intercollegiate football from the Atlantic to the Pacific is being commercialized, with the result that a spirit of professionalism is insidiously creeping into it, Dr. Livingston Farrand, who will retire in June as president of Cornell University after sixteen years' service, said last night at a dinner in his honor at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Although only three liniments are recognized by the United States Pharmacopeia, 492,547,635 can be made available in any drug store, Dr. Lawrence H. Mayers, Professor of Medicine at Northwestern University, said last night in an address denouncing the rise of patent medication for arthritis.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3 (AP). -- The Most Rev. John Joseph Cantwell, "inspirer" of the Legion of Decency, became the nation's sixteenth Archbishop of the catholic Church today, climaxing a three-hour ceremony which elevated Los Angeles to a Metropolitan See of the faith.

One of the largest apartment house transactions of the current realty market was announced yesterday when the Coya Realty Corporation, Percy Uris, president, sold to an investor the twelve-story and penthouse building at 17 East Eighty-ninth Street, northwest corner of Madison Avenue.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Dec. 3. -This l:h-ovince of Canada, with a large number of British-born residents, has been hoping against hope that American press reports of strained relations between King Edward and his Cabinet were at least exaggerated.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 3. -- Floyd T. Smith, explorer and big game hunter and a partner of William H. Harkness Jr., who died in Shanghai in February of this year, in a published statement charges that Mrs. Harkness did not capture the baby panda with which she sailed for America yesterday.

ALBANY, Dec. 3. -- Within an hour of his arrival in Albany today after a three-week vacation in California, Governor Lehman summoned department heads to his office for a conference. He was warmly greeted by members of his staff and department representatives.

The Franklin K. Lane quintet opened its drive in Division I of the Brooklyn P.S.A.L. tournament with a 28-to-18 triumph over Bushwick High on the Central Methodist Episcopal Church court yesterday. Sid Trifon, with 10 points, paced the victors, who were in front by 12 -- 10 at the half.

Several hundred engineers have celebrated the fortieth anniversary of the Diesel engine's introduction and gloried in the fact that it now drives the fastest trains in the world at the lowest cost, generates electricity in many a central station, takes the place of horses on the farm and crowds out steam on the high seas.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP). -- Nearing the half-way point of its five-year program of modernization, the army tonight shaped plans for acquiring about 250 new tanks during the next three years.

An attempt by the police to "starve out" WPA "stay-in" strikers in the new offices of the Federal Writers Project on the seventh floor of 10 East Thirty-ninth Street, between Fifth and Madison Avenues, failed at 12:30 o'clock this morning, after three women among the strikers had fainted, when food was smuggled in from the outside.

The more one thinks about the new Nazi decree on art criticism the more it appeals to the imagination. German critics must henceforth abstain from passing judgment and restrict themselves to straight description.

Reference is made in THE TIMES to the trip of Colonel Starling to South America to make plans for guarding President Roosevelt. The report observes that the President traveled thousands of miles during the recent campaign under the watchful eyes of his protectors without an untoward circumstance.

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 4. -- King Edward sped away to an early morning rendezvous with Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson today to tell her whether he had triumphed over the forces that, during the night, demanded he choose between her and the British throne.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and the reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date. The ratio of reserve at the New York bank also reached a new high figure for the year.

The directors of the Public National Bank and Trust Company have approved plans for increasing the capital and surplus of the bank to $7,000,000 each, compared with $5,775,000 and $6,225,000 respectively, at the present time, through the issuance of a 20 per cent stock dividend and the sale of 4,000 shares at auction, it was announced yesterday by E. Chester Gersten, president.
Detroit will issue today an invitation to bankers to bid on $25,333,000 of non-callable refunding bonds, to be sold on Dec. 14. The securities will mature from 1938 to 1963.

MANILA, P.I., Dec. 3 (AP). -- Typhoon-shattered communication lines hampered rescue workers tonight in the wake of a violent island storm which whipped across the Philippines south of here yesterday, leaving at least one person dead and thirty-two missing.

OTTAWA, Dec. 3 (Canadian Press). -- The Dominion Government's deposits with the Bank of Canada increased $5,727,724 in the week ended yesterday, the weekly statement of the bank showed today. Deposits by chartered banks decreased $6,817,541.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 3 (AP). -- New York's Rovers gained a 6-5 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight in a rough-and-tumble match in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League, and took over the lead in the circuit.
A portrait of Sir Henry Raeburn of "Master George John Fraser," owned by John McCormack, singer, brought $10,000 at auction last night at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc.

Putnam Bradlee Strong, 67 years old, son of the late Mayor William L. Strong, denied yesterday afternoon at a hearing before Referee Jeremiah F. Connor that he had a son during his marriage to May Yohe, former actress, now Mrs. John Smuts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP). -- Hugh Walpole, British author, said today that the storm over Mrs. Wallis Simpson, King Edward's American friend, might destroy the power of the crown and threaten the empire.

John Smiukse, athletic young Latvian whose admiration for President Roosevelt impelled him to destroy a painting satirizing the President at an exhibition two years ago, returned to this country from exile last night, a candidate to become a citizen of the United States.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 3 (AP). -- The Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company refused tonight to accede to union demands for a conference here "to present further spreading" of a strike which already involves one of their plants and 6,000 Pittsburgh Plate Glass workers.

The Hamburg-American liner New York is due today from Hamburg and channel ports. Her passengers include Mr. and Mrs. Fred Kolb, Miss Anne G. Darlington, Count Robert de Calry, Louis Beeh, Professor Werner Jaeger, Mr. and Mrs. Carl Kroll, Hans A. Breitag, Mrs. Winifred de Beck and Mr. and Mrs. Wallace McCamant.

What we of the Federal Theatre Project feared most is now a reality. One-fifth of us are, as the administration so naively puts it, to "go" by Dec. 15. The administration neglects to state definitely where we are to go, but the implication is there, and the place as we all know is torrid.
Various housing and business properties were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

THERE will now be a little test of "the power of the press" in intercollegiate circles since the student editors at Harvard, Yale, Princeton, Cornell, Columbia, Dartmouth and Penn are coming out in a group for the formation of an Ivy League in football.

Dr. ARTHUR J. BROWN at the dinner Wednesday night in celebration of his eightieth birthday presented as a formula for long life the identification of one's self with a good cause. He has himself given days and years to several causes that have to do with the welfare of humanity, chief of which has been that of religious freedom.

The consolidated statement of Armour Co. of Delaware, controlled by Armour Co. of Illinois, and which was issued yesterday, showed, for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31 a net income of $7,458,331 after all charges and provision for Federal income taxes.

By vote of the board of directors, a bonus totaling approximately $500,000 will be distributed by R.H. Macy Co., Inc., to the employes of its New York store and affiliated corporations, it was announced yesterday by Percy S. Straus, president.

LONDON, Dec. 3. -- When the history of this strange political crisis over King Edward's proposed marriage comes to be written, it may be found that the great democratic dominions played a decisive role in defeating their democratic King.

TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 4. -- When Foreign Mister Hachiro Arita invited foreign correspondents to hear him deny that Japan was joining the Fascist bloc he was giving utterance to some anxious second thoughts evoked by the unfavorable reaction that the German-Japanese agreement met everywhere except in Germany and Italy.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 3. -- An exhibition of 250 paintings, drawings, sculpture and artifacts by WPA artists on Federal projects in Nassau, Westchester, Rockland, Orange and Dutchess Counties, and also in Oneonta, Rochester, Buffalo, Johnson City and Woodstock, was opened at the Westchester County Center here tonight with a preview for WPA officials and other guests.

Consumption of ice cream during the first six months of this year rose approximately 33 per cent, Peter G. Ten Eyck, State Commissioner of Agriculture, told members of the Association of Ice Cream Manufacturers of New York State at their twenty-ninth annual convention in the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.
By a unanimous vote of the lettermen yesterday, Johnny Druze, star right end, was elected captain of the 1937 Fordham University football team.

King EDWARD seems to have got into a deadlock with his Government, his Parliament and the public opinion of his country which lies behind both Parliament and Government. The breaking point is over his rights as an individual contrasted with his duties as a monarch.

Certain plumbing arrangements common in factories, hospitals, offices and other large buildings are responsible for perils to the public health, Lewis V. Carpenter, Professor of Sanitary Engineering at New York University, told members of the Public Health Association at the first meeting of the new organization yesterday afternoon at the George Washington Hotel.

A program involving Federal regulation of the bituminous coal industry probably will be placed before Congress next month by the industry itself, it was indicated here yesterday at a conference of eighty coal operators representing Eastern bituminous producers.

PEIPING, China, Dec. 3. -- Yin Ju-keng's Japanese-sponsored East Hopei Autonomous Administration now threatens to join the Manchukuoan oil monopoly in restricting the markets of American and British oil companies.

HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 3. -- Despite attempts to administer soothing syrup to belligerently minded delegates by Avery Brundage of Chicago and Jeremiah T. Mahoney of New York, leaders of the two factions which split over Olympic issues, indications tonight pointed to a wide open struggle for control of the Amateur Athletic Union, chief sports-governing body in the United States.

Reports of definite shortages of gift items at retail were heard in the wholesale markets here yesterday. It is unusual for shortages to appear so early in holiday shopping, but it is now evident that more than a few stores underestimated their advance requirements.

The city must continue to provide an adequate reserve against uncollected real-estate taxes in its annual budget despite the fact that the Bankers' Agreement, which calls for such a reserve, ends at the end of next year, Controller Frank J. Taylor said yesterday.
A broadcast from a speeding ambulance and a microphone tour of a city hospital, said to be the first radio program of its kind, was given yesterday afternoon by Station WOR.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3. -- Willie Hoppe of New York, the defending champion, suffered his first defeat of the world three-cushion billiards tournament tonight, being soundly beaten by Kinrey Matsuyama of Japan, 50 to 28, in forty-three innings.

With affectionate but anxious eyes one watches the reorganization, revival, rejuvenation, "revitalization," as the Connecticut phrase is, of the Republican party in this State. At present, and as usual, the cardinal question is: Who shall be chairman of the State committee?

RUTLAND, Vt., Dec. 3 (AP). -- A day of swift developments in the Marble Savings Bank case saw the State rearrest Vermont's Governor, Charles M. Smith, president of the bank, and a weeping judge sentence an old friend and neighbor, Lathrop H. Baldwin, the bank's treasurer.
A decision upholding a bondholder in a suit to compel the Banco de Colombia to pay accrued interest on a $2,000,000 bond issue was handed down yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Kadien in Brooklyn.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 3. -- Mrs. Eugene Meyer, chairman of the Westchester County Recreation Commission, asked in a letter to the Board of Supervisors today that all salary cuts for county employes be fully restored.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Friday, Dec. 4. -- The vast majority of Australians, excluding the readers of American publications, were not aware until Monday of the situation involving King Edward and Mrs. Wallis Simpson, owing to the silence of the press.

During his long service with the Marine Corps, Major Gen. RUSSELL, who has just retired as Commandant, saw a great heightening of its repute. This advance in prestige he not only witnessed but helped to bring about. The marines, as tradition and slang phrases testify, used to be rather looked down upon as if they were a superfluous branch of our national defense.

Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets, turned his guns yesterday on the second-hand brick racket, which is alleged to have brought in a gross revenue of $3,000,000 a year to a ring that had established a monopoly in the field by intimidation.

The order for the reduction of workers on the four arts projects, which followed the election with the most indecent haste, has created a mood of bitter disillusionment in the personnel. That President Roosevelt has let them down badly is the impression an outsider gets from talking to various workers.
Brooklyn College's pony quintet crushed Panzer College, 46 -- 21, at Union Temple last night to score its second victory of the young season and remain in the unbeaten ranks.
Purchase of a Concourse corner for an apartment house and scattered sales of housing properties comprised realty activity in the Bronx yesterday.

The side of the Good-Will Court radio program in the case of legal ethics, filed recently in the Appellate Division for an opinion governing the appearances of judges as legal advisers on such commercial broadcasts, was learned here yesterday from a brief prepared by Charles H. Turtle, former United States Attorney, representing the program's sponsor and advertising agency, and Louis Nizer, attorney for A.L. Alexander, who conducts the broadcasts.

George Meany, president of the State Federation of Labor, said on his return from Europe yesterday that the United States led most of the countries in Europe today in advanced labor standards and recognition of labor problems.

President Roosevelt and State Governors were urged yesterday by the National Council of Women to give "special consideration" to the appointment of women to the Cabinet and other positions of prestige and responsibility in the Federal and State Governments.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3 (AP). -- Superior Judge Henry M. Willis ruled today in favor of State Insurance Commissioner Samuel Carpenter's plan for internal reorganization of the Pacific Mutual Life Insurance Company, $220,000,000 concern doing business in forty-two States.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 3. -- A spirited fight to bar the introduction of any extraneous matter into the deliberations of the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace took place this morning at the first meeting of the steering committee.

BOSTON, Dec. 3. -- A warning against permitting snobbery or pride of purse in the college fraternity was given at the fiftieth anniversary dinner of Tufts Chapter of Delta Upsilon tonight by Wilson L. Fairbanks of the class of '87, telegraph editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Victories by the University Club and the Harvard Club, enabling both to remain undefeated, featured last night's play in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class A team competition. The University players triumphed on their home courts, downing the Princeton Club, 4 to 1, while Harvard won by the same score from the Yale Club on the latter's courts.

NANKING, China, Friday, Dec. 4. -- An unexpected meeting of Foreign Minister Chang Chun and Ambassador Shigeru Kawagoe of Japan last evening, held at Mr. Chang's initiative, opened with the Foreign Minister making the most vigorous protest against the landing of Japanese naval forces in Tsingtao in connection with a strike in Japanese textile mills.
PARIS, Dec. 3 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:
CAPE TOWN, South Africa, Dec. 3. -- The Cape Times says editorially today:

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 3. -- Specially qualified students from preparatory schools which do not point for college board examinations will in the future be admitted to Princeton University on the basis of their scholastic records, it was announced today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university.

In the account of the proceedings of the royal commission of inquiry on Palestine, as published in THE NEW YORK TIMES Nov. 26, there appeared an erroneous quotation attributed to Dr. Chaim Weizmann, who gave evidence.

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 4. -- In parliamentary circles the next move is held to be the King's in the crisis that has arisen between him and his Ministers over the refusal to approve his marriage to Mrs. Wallis Simpson.

LONDON, Dec. 3. -- Roaring at top speed, the great presses of London's daily newspapers were unable today to supply the demand for news about King Edward, his American-born friend, Mrs. Wallis Simpson, and his Prime Minister, Stanley Baldwin.

BETHPAGE, L.I., Dec. 3. -- The bright silver top of a refrigerator truck that contained the body of a man who had committed suicide by inhaling carbon-monoxide gas was sighted from the air this afternoon in the dense woods just north of this village by a searching party in the Nassau County police plane.

Flying squadrons of striking glaziers, who began a sabotage campaign last Tuesday by smashing plate-glasss window on lower Broadway, smashed fifty-four more windows between 3 P.M. Wednesday and 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- A warning against the spreading of propaganda abroad was given by Fulvio Suvich, the new Italian Ambassador, in an address on fascism before the National Press Club today. He coupled with it a plea for political tolerance in international affairs and emphasized that his government was not engaging in propaganda in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- Seventeen of the larger automobile companies, including General Motors, Chrysler. Ford and Packard, and four of the leading automobile financing companies, were charged in eight complaints today by the Federal Trade Commission with false and misleading representations as to the amount of interest charged purchasers of automobiles under deferred payment plans.

District Attorney William C. Dodge, at a luncheon yesterday of the Associated Motion Picture Advertisers, Inc., urged that producers outlaw the outlaws of the screen, such as gangster heroes. Such sinister characters, he said, too frequently become the idols of children.

Mme. Else Schiaparelli, noted Parisian couturiere, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa to spend four weeks indulging herself in a shopping spree in American stores. As fashion arbiter for many women in metropolitan cities all over the world, Mme. Schiaparelli has wearied of buying everything from her own shop on the Place Vendome in Paris and decided to do most of her Christmas shopping in New York.

An alleged confession by Dr. Jacques P. Alper, New York physician now serving a penitentiary term for vice ring activities, resulted yesterday in grand jury indictments against a Manhattan dentist and a taxicab driver who are charged with extortion.

The study of economics and of labor relations should be as fundamental in management training for engineers as knowledge of their own particular science, in the opinion of Joseph W. Roe, Professor of Industrial Engineering at New York University.

Cash dividends declared yesterday totaled $35,000,000, lifting the total for this month to $95,000,000. On Wednesday dividend declarations likewise totaled $35,000,000. Last month the total was $883,000,000 the largest amount for any month on record.

The predominant and extremely exciting feature of the Philharmonic-Symphony concert last night in Carnegie Hall was Jascha Heifetz's performance of the Sibelius violin concerto. This concerto has been long in coming into its own, but little by little it advances to its proper position.

The Mayors of eleven large cities, our own included, are protesting in Washington against a reduction of the Federal work-relief program. It is not difficult to understand their attitude. They know that a large volume of unemployment still persists in the urban centers, and they want as much help as they can get in taking care of it.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3. -- Prices of wheat futures dipped sharply in the early trading on the Board of Trade here today in sympathy with Liverpool, which was affected by the unexpected announcement that the Argentine Government would not guarantee a minimum price for this year's harvest.

Continuing the seasonal expansion that got under way in the previous week, the total of money in circulation rose $37,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $6,466,000,000, according to the Federal Reserve reports issued yesterday.

The New York School of Industrial Art announces that a new series of classes in life drawing will open next week at the Public Library, 224 East 125th Street, near Third Avenue. "All who wish to study the figure and to advance themselves in the art of drawing and painting" are eligible.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 3. -- Endorsement of the entire principles of the Rochdale plan of consumer cooperatives was voted tonight by the New Jersey Grange at the closing of its sixty-fourth annual convention here.
For the first time an Eastern football league is in sight.

Lester Hofheimer, trustee of Mount Sinai Hospital and late president of the Nathan Hofheimer Foundation, which was named for his father, directed in his will, filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court, that 5 per cent of his net estate after the payment of debts, taxes and administration be used for charitable purposes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- Wholesale prices rose for the fifth consecutive time in the report for the week ended on Nov. 28, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The index, based on the 1926 average of 100, was 82.6, the highest level since October, 1930. The preceding week it was 82.4, and on Nov. 30, 1935, it was 80.8.
Attendance and gate receipts at college football games jumped approximately 15 per cent this season over last, an Associated Press survey yesterday revealed.
In the first of a series of women's versus men's squash racquets matches at the Junior League, the men won yesterday by a margin of 6 to 1.
Attendance and gate receipts at college football games jumped approximately 15 per cent this season over last, an Associated Press survey yesterday revealed.
In the first of a series of women's versus men's squash racquets matches at the Junior League, the men won yesterday by a margin of 6 to 1.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 3. -- The surtax on undistributed profits passed in the last session of Congress presents a new problem to investment bankers, one calling for study and analysis in connection with provision for adequate sinking funds, according to the report of the industrial securities committee of the Investment Bankers Association which was made public today.

A floral display transformed the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton into a garden setting last night for the December Ball and Flower Carnival, presented for the benefit of the Grosvenor Neighborhood House in East Forty-ninth Street.

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 4. -- King Edward VIII and the Duke of York, the brother who may succeed Edward on the throne at almost any hour, met last night in Buckingham Palace for the first time since the conflict of wills between the Crown and the Cabinet entered an acute stage.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 3 (AP). -- The Standard Oil Company of Ohio today declared a dividend of $1.50 a share on its common stock, payable on Dec. 21, 1936, to stockholders of record of Dec. 10, 1936. Twenty-five cents a share of the dividend was voted in anticipation of the regular Jan. 15 quarterly dividend, and the balance of $1.25 is a special dividend.

The annual Fall scratch squash tennis tournament, opening at the City Athletic Club last night, saw one seeded player eliminated. Frank A. Sieverman 3d, young Winged Foot star, seeded No. 8, had the difficult assignment of facing Frederick B. Ryan Jr., playing under the Yale Club banner, and could not quite fulfill it.

Late reorders from wholesale importers, direct purchases by department and chain stores from European sources and special orders of monogrammed fancy linens, lingerie and other products constitute the type of Christmas goods affected by the delays incident to the present shipping strike, importers said yesterday.

MADRID, Dec. 3 -- Insurgent airplanes bombed Madrid twice today while opposing infantry forces were locked in battles for possession of the city' western suburbs. The raiders loosed a score of explosive bombs in the Rosales area and in Retiro Park, hard by the government artillery emplacements.
ALABANY, Dec. 3 (AP). -- Up-State New Yorkers dug their way out of the season's heaviest snowfall today, while transportation facilities slowly returned to normal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- Mayors and representatives of eleven industrial cities, constituting the executive committee of the United States Conference of Mayors and meeting here today on call of Mayor La Guardia of New York, cabled an appeal to President Roosevelt in South America to countermand orders for a reduction in relief recently issued by the Works Progress Administration.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 3 (AP). -- The Alleghany Corporation, a Van Sweringen holding company, reported today a net loss of $20,754 for the third quarter of this year and a net loss of $99,957 for the first three quarters. Net losses in the corresponding periods of 1935 were $20,885 and $164,124.
OTTAWA, Dec. 3. -- In the first editorial commentary on the London situation published by the press of Canada. The Toronto Evening Telegram observes in part:

With mills continuing to issue new price lists based on higher raw material and labor costs, trading in wool goods markets quieted down this week, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service. Unfilled orders for men's wear fabrics are estimated at 40,000,000 yards, which are sufficient to keep mills busily employed for twelve to fifteen weeks, and producers are making no attempt to force business.

LONDON, Dec. 3. -- The British public discovered today what a "constitutional crisis" looked like when skillfully photographed fresh from the hairdresser and carefully transmuted into two and three column portraits in the London evening papers.

OCTAVE AUBRY, the eminent French historian, has produced an altogether admirable work in "St. Helena" (Lippincott, $5). As translated by Arthur Livingston, the book seems to be nothing short of a masterpiece. Just a week ago, in connection with the Caulaincourt memoirs, we raised the question of whether there could be anything more to say about Napoleon.

A conference of religious leaders arranged by the National Committee on Welfare and Religious Recovery, embracing the Catholic, Protestant and Jewish faiths, to determine a means of raising contributions, yesterday was advised to change its methods of approach and to beware lest its efforts cause the Federal Government to ask "embarrassing questions."

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 4. -- In a flood of editorial comment this morning, the public is advised to rest content for the moment with Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin's assurance that "no constitutional difficulty" at present exists in regard to King Edward's marriage plans.

JEAN PIERRE LE MEE, the 19-year-old French student sent by the French Government to report on the social life in American colleges, was bowled over by the good times enjoyed by students here in contrast to the hard-working, serious, solitary lot of students in France.

Two ringleaders of a gang accused of having smuggled huge quantities of narcotics into this country on transatlantic liners in the past year were found guilty last night by a jury before Federal Judge Murray Hulbert.

Five hundred life insurance presidents in convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, representing 64,000,000 policy-holders and $104,000,000,000 of insurance, were requested at their opening session yesterday to "make their opposition known and felt against the announced intention of labor executives to put special pressure behind the six-hour-day bill in the approaching Congress."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- A seven-point list of demands, including most of the farm relief schemes proposed to or undertaken by the government in the last decade and part of what already has been outlawed by the Supreme Court, was laid before Secretary Wallace today in resolutions adopted at the close of a two-day meeting of wheat farmers from the Great Plains area.

PARIS, Dec. 3. -- France's great naval replacement and extension program, expected to cost more than 12,000,000,000 francs over a period of six years, will be submitted to the Superior Naval Council tomorrow by Alphonse Gasnier-Duparc, Minister of Marine.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 3. -- The Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace will hold a special recess session at noon tomorrow to receive a pacifist petition, containing several million names, which will be presented by a delegation of American women who flew from Washington to represent the People's Mandate to End War Committee.

GENEVA, Dec. 3. -- The idea of trying to solve the Spanish war problem by a plebiscite roughly similar to the League of Nations' Saar plebiscite has been cautiously and informally put forward by the French Government, it is understood here, for airing among League Council members.

Conveyance of sixty-eight Manhattan properties by the executors of the will of Ella V. von E. Wendel to the Wendel Foundation of 175 Broadway was recorded yesterday. Various institutions joined with the executors in the conveyance, as of last Aug. 1, in order to make a partial distribution in kind of the residuary estate.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3. -- More than 700 civic leaders and social workers at a general conference on public assistance here today adopted a resolution asserting that interruption of WPA social, recreational and educational projects in this city would "seriously interfere with the work which is essential to the welfare and morale of the neighborhoods in which it is conducted.''

Luigi Antonini, State Chairman of the American Labor party, declared yesterday that there was a general expectation among labor leaders that Mayor La Guardia would run in next year's campaign as the standard bearer of a group of which their party would form the nucleus.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 3. -- The official translation of the text of President Gabriel Terra's toast to President Roosevelt at the official luncheon here today follows:

A threat by Brooklyn builders to tie up $20,000,000 worth of building contracts yesterday started a new rackets inquiry into the relations between subcontractors and union leaders in forty-two building trades in that borough.

Thomas E. Brady and Melville C. Rosch, president and secretary, respectively, of the Southern New York Fish and Game Association, left yesterday for Syracuse to attend the annual convention of the New York State Conservation Council.

A new season of indoor polo comes to the city tomorrow night, when two games will be played at the famous armory of Squadron A, Ninety-fourth Street and Madison Avenue. The matches, the first starting at 8:30 o'clock, will open the weeks of play extending through March and concluding with the national championships, which are to be brought back to New York this season.

Postmaster Albert Goldman called attention to tomorrow midnight as the closing time for the return of employes' application forms under the Social Security Act in an announcement yesterday at his office in the Postoffice Building.

Brisk gains in active trading featured local commodity futures trading yesterday as the markets reacted from the previous day's hesitation, and several staples went to new high levels for the movement. In the cash markets Santos coffee and rubber reached new high levels and flour and corn rose, while wheat, rye, butter, tin and silk eased.

The Department of Parks announced yesterday that it would open today a new playground, two redesigned and reconstructed playgrounds, another section of a new playground previously opened in part and two reconstructed park areas in different sections of the city.
LONDON, Dec. 4. -- King Edward wrestled alone today and tonight with the most critical decision of his life -- whether to renounce his throne or renounce the woman he had set his heart on marrying.

The letter from J.A. Connolly in last Saturday's TIMES provoked me beyond all measure. He contended that because some designers are now, in preparation for the next America's Cup defense, testing their models in the towing tank at Stevens Institute, they are therefore "guessing -- they do not know."

President Roosevelt has endorsed the observance of annual Universal Bible Sunday, which is tomorrow. The American Bible Society, Park Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, made public yesterday a letter it received from the President.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Corporations may be penalized for income tax purposes on unreasonably high salaries paid to officials or employes, officials of the Internal Revenue Bureau said today when it was announced that inquiries had been received recently in relation to the application of a provision of the revenue laws enacted in 1919 and continued since that time.

DETROIT, Dec. 4. -- The strike at the Midland Steel Products Company plant here ended late today when workers voted to accept a peace proposal which union leaders called a "90 per cent victory" for employes.

The first of the Junior Assemblies for this season was held last night at the Ritz-Carlton in a Winter setting of green, white and pink. On arriving the 125 debutantes and their escorts passed through masses of Boston ferns and Southern smilax that banked the stairway and twined the balustrade to the foyer, where were snow-covered cedar trees and standards of pink poinsettias.

The city's shifting population, resulting in classroom congestion, has been virtually the controlling factor in determining public school policies, according to a report made public yesterday by a joint committee on problems of school maladjustment, headed by James Marshall, vice president of the Board of Education.

VALENCIA, Spain, Dec. 4 (By Air Mail to London). -- A "unified military command and discipline" is being demanded by the Anarcho-Syndicalist members of the Cabinet, who openly state that if the present situation continues it will have disastrous effects for the government.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard construction of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

The Continental Oil Company announced yesterday through its office here that on Jan. 4 next it would add 17 cents a barrel to the price of crude oil in the areas in which it is a large purchaser. With the exception of some minor adjustments, the belief in the trade is that the other large crude-oil purchasing companies not only will meet the advance but also will make it general east of the Rocky Mountains.

For the nine months ended on Oct. 31 the City Stores Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a net profit of $372,348 after depreciation, interest, normal Federal income taxes and minority interest and other charges, exclusive of any provision for surtax on undistributed income.

Mayor La Guardia conferred yesterday in City Hall with Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine on the car-watching racket, and received Mr. Valentine's assurance that the racket would be cleaned up speedily.

Herbert Wilcox has just announced from London that the film production, "Victoria the Great," will be released on June 21, 1937. A few days ago it was announced that the King had authorized the lifting of the man on plays about Victoria, the ban to be lifted on June 20, 1937.

GENEVA, Dec. 4. -- The International Labor Organization's preparatory committee for a forty-hour week for printers concluded its work tonight by adopting a report defining the printing industry in terms that would have made Gutenberg rub his eyes.

THE reigning heavyweight champion was deep in an easy chair, protecting himself against the heckling of an intruder by putting up a heavy smoke screen fomented by an opulent cigar. James J. Braddock is in the money now and he can well afford those large cigars.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 4. -- The National Symphony Orchestra of Washington, D.C., conducted by its founder, Hans Kindler, in its first appearance in the metropolitan area, tonight played here to an audience of more than 2,000 persons at the County Center.

Pioneers in settlement work in thin country and abroad were commended by political, educational and civic leaders yesterday at exercises marking the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of University Settlement in this city and of the settlement movement in the United States.

PONTIAC, Mich., Dec. 4 (AP) -- Fire Captain William H. Bradburn shot and killed a fellow-fireman and committed suicide today. He acted in resentment at taunts about his alleged membership in the Black Legion, according to Frank Nelson, acting Chief of Police.

After the Nazi triumvirate, a triangle the bases of which are held together only because both depend on the apex, the most ubiquitous figure in the Third Reich is BALDUR VON SCHIRACH. This pale, stout, moon-faced young man is a constant apparition on the screen. His monotonous voice is heard regularly over the radio.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4. -- Weary and repentant, John Dougherty went to the House of Correction today to begin serving a six months' term for vagrancy, to try to atone for "framing" an innocent man in a court room seventeen years ago.

Last week the receiver of the Interborough made public his report for the last six months, showing a loss of about one million fares. The report attributes this loss to the competition by the city-owned subways.
MADRID, Dec. 4. -- Bomb-scarred Madrid reverberated under the fiercest aerial onslaught of the siege today as thirty Insurgent warplanes, droning high over the city, unleashed death from the skies.

Steady growth in his art has marked the successive appearances here of Erno Valasek, the highly talented young violinist from Cleveland, who gave a recital in the Town Hall last night. When heard here last season he was still in knickers, and his playing retained that unearthly sort of purity bound to vanish with the years.

It is generally believed that Mussolini's, like Hitler's, coup and the Spanish rebellion were financed by the great munition makers and by the landholders, who feared socialistic appropriation of the land.
MONTREAL, Dec. 4. -- For the first time since he became commissioner of organized baseball, Kenesaw Mountain Landis was beaten on the convention floor of the minor leagues today.

BERLIN, Dec. 4. -- Students in the German gymnasia, or preparatory schools, have been informed that their education will be cut short by one year. The final class, known as "ober prima" will be dropped, and examinations and diplomas will be granted a year earlier.

PARIS, Dec. 4. -- Without seeking any dramatic effect in the midst of a long speech on French foreign policy, Yvon Delbos, Foreign Minister in the Cabinet of Leon Blum, announced this evening that France would use all her forces on land, at sea and in the air "spontaneously and immediately" for the defense of Great Britain and Belgium against any unprovoked aggression.

The 1,408 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $45,025,928,137 par value as of Dec. 1, had a total market value of $43,679,640,206, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of Nov. 1, there were 1,405 issues, aggregating $45,018,484,420 par value, which had a total market value of $43,179,898,054.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Representative Vinson of Kentucky, manager of Representative Rayburn's campaign for majority leader, charged today that Representative O'Connor was seeking support of Senators in his campaign and asking them to use their influence in his behalf.

French longshoremen were ordered yesterday to abandon their boycott of American-flag ships docking at French ports and the immediate prospect of the resumption of Franco-American commerce last night depended upon their willingness to respond.
BERLIN, Dec. 4. -- Former Kaiser Wilhelm's stepdaughter, the Princess Carmo zu Schoenaich-Carolath, is to marry a commoner, it was announced today.

An ordinance passed by the Board of Aldermen last month to prevent fake fire and bankruptcy sales on the part of a class of storekeepers who are out to "do" a gullible public is a great stride in the right direction, but does not cover the growing need of a harassed business community and a very much wronged buying public.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 4 (AP). -- Dr. Franz Sarga, Hungary's "me against nine" duelist, tonight crossed sabers with his third opponent and gashed his adversary's head before police ended the encounter.

BRISBANE, Australia, Saturday, Dec. 5. -- England's batsmen completed their first innings against Australia in their opening cricket test match today with a total of 358 runs. Warm, sunny weather attracted a throng of 20,000 spectators to the first of five test matches for "The Ashes."

NANKING, China, Saturday, Dec. 5. -- Ambassador Shigeru Kawagoe of Japan, who came to Nanking nearly three months ago with an imposing list of demands, left for Shanghai this morning for what was described as a long period of rest.

The problem of worry was fully discussed by six speakers ranging from a radio personality to an obstretrician and a philosopher yesterday afternoon at a luncheon of the League for Political Education at Town Hall Club.

"The Follies" won't be moving about town after all. Instead of going to another theatre for the holidays, it will end its New York run at the Winter Garden on Dec. 19 and then will take to the road. It will reopen -- perhaps in Chicago -- on Christmas night, and will go on from there.
LONDON, Dec. 4. -- The possibility of the abdication of King Edward VIII and his retirement to private life has given rise to speculation concerning the amount of private means at his disposal.

MOSCOW, Dec. 4. -- The new Stalin Constitution of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics will be formally adopted, with a few changes from the original draft, at tomorrow's closing session of the Congress of Soviets, which will then go out of existence forever.

Because he broke his promise to the late Judge Max S. Levine that he would make gradual restitution of $35,000 he had stolen from a woman client, Michael Seinfeld, 47 years old, a disbarred lawyer, of 150 Morton Place, the Bronx, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Owen W. Bohan in General Sessions to fifteen months to two and one-half years in Sing Sing.

The Jamaica and Brooklyn Tech hockey teams, scoring their second victories of the season last night at the Brooklyn Ice Palace, remained tied for the lead in the P.S.A.L. hockey tournament. Jamaica beat Boys High, 5 -- 1, while Brooklyn Tech shut out Textile, 4 -- 0.
DETROIT, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Five Black Legion members convicted of killing a 42-year-old Negro for "target practice" received life sentences here today.
LONDON, Dec. 4. -- The text of Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin's statement today to the House of Commons in regard to the King follows:

A photograph snapped of the late Mayor Gaynor just after he had been shot and seriously wounded on board the North German Lloyd liner Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse at Hoboken in 1910, won first prize yesterday in the spot news division of the Press Photographers Exhibition in the mezzanine galleries of the RCA Building, Rockefeller Center.

The maintenance of business stability and prosperity is dependent upon higher wages, lower prices and a continuing system of profit sharing, according to Ordway Tead, editor of economic books of Harper Brothers and president of the Society for the Advancement of Management.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 4. -- The address of James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, to the Investment Bankers Association today follows:
LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 5. -- While London newspapers still express strong sympathy for King Edward in his present controversy, editorials appear to be preparing the public for his abdication.

The wide spread of better times among the 64,000,000 holders of life insurance policies throughout the country was indicated in a practical way by a formal report yesterday at the closing session of the thirtieth annual convention of the Association of Life Insurance Presidents in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

LONDON, Dec. 4. -- The Evening Standard tonight publishes an article, "Parliament, Cabinet and Crown," by Colonel Josiah Wedgwood, now one of the senior Laborite Members of Parliament. The article is arousing wide discussion.

The James Monroe and Thomas Jefferson High School fives, coholders of the city P.S.A.L. title, launched their league campaigns yesterday with triumphs on their home courts. Monroe conquered Roosevelt, 33 -- 11, in an Upper Manhattan-Bronx Division test, while Jefferson turned back Hamilton, 31 -- 24, in a Brooklyn engagement.
The 1936 football season has been a notable one and, happily, few injuries have appeared among the well-trained teams.

ATLANTA, Dec. 4 (AP). -- Southern sports editors today called the selection of Pittsburgh for Washington's opponent in the Rose Bowl a "slight" on Southern football, setting the stage for a national championship game in the Sugar Bowl at New Orleans.
An allotment of $60,503,797 for the Hospital Department in the city's capital outlay budget for 1937 was submitted yesterday to Budget Director Leo J. McDermott by Commissioner S.S. Goldwater.

The announcement of an increase in the price of crude oil by the Continental Oil Company yesterday was taken as a recognition of the improved statistical position of the industry and the cooperation of the producers in keeping output within consumptive demands.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 4. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission will submit to the Stock Exchanges of the country next week recommendations and suggestions on broker and dealer segregation, James M. Landis, chairman of the commission, disclosed today in an address before the Investment Bankers Association of America, in convention here.

The New York Giants and the Boston Redskins will end their preparations today for their titular engagement which takes place tomorrow at the Polo Grounds. The Redskins will go through their paces at the Westchester Country Club, while the Giants will have a brief workout at their ball park.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 4. -- Two of the nation's three undefeated major football teams -- Louisiana State University and Santa Clara -- will clash New Year's Day in the third annual Sugar Bowl game.
Cash dividends declared yesterday totaled $15,000,000, swelling the total for this month to $110,000,000. On Thursday dividend declarations amounted to $35,000,000.

Count Ludwig Salm yon Hoogstraeten lost yesterday in the Appellate Division his suit to have his former wife, Mrs. Millicent Rogers Salm Balcom, removed as co-guardian of the property of their son, Peter Salm. The court decided unanimously in favor of Mrs. Balcom, daughter of the late Henry H. Rogers, and upheld a ruling by Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins.

HOUSTON, Tex., Dec. 4 (AP). -- Four of America's Olympic champions in track and field sports dominate the "ten most worthy" candidates for the 1936 Sullivan Memorial Trophy award, made annually by the Amateur Athletic Union to the athlete contributing most to the cause of amateurism, sportsmanship and achievement. Two women stars are included.

After gaining moderately in the forenoon, the stock market drifted irregularly lower in the late trading. Petroleum shares, as a group, did well, responsive to the news that one important producer had lifted the price of crude oil, effective Jan. 4.

Sanitation Commissioner William F. Carey took issue yesterday with the statement made by Lawrence B. Elliman that something must be done to end the danger of contagion that has arisen "as a result of the cesspool that the East River has become."

The three-room apartment of Mrs. George Monro, on the second floor of 210 East Sixty-eighth Street, was ransacked Thursday evening and jewelry valued at $4,000 was taken from a jewel box in her bedroom. The theft was reported yesterday although in leaving the burglar had set off an alarm that sounded in the lobby of the seventeen-story apartment house and in the office of the Holmes Electric Protective Company.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 4. -- Mary Garden in her report to Metro on her scouting activities announced that on her tour of Europe she interviewed 1,000 young singers from whom she selected six whose voices are to be trained in Paris for a year, after which they will come to Hollywood.

When the leader of the Labor party asked Prime Minister BALDWIN if a constitutional crisis had arisen, the answer was that it had not yet. This can mean only one thing. It is that King EDWARD has not completely and finally refused to follow the advice of his Ministers in the matter of a proposed marriage which they have decided to be of the highest imperial concern.

The National Preaching Mission, which began Sept. 13 and which has been conducted in twenty-five of the largest cities in the United States, will close next week with series of services in the metropolitan area. The mission has been conducted by the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4. -- Prices of wheat forged ahead in the early trading today to new high levels for the season in all the leading markets, only to react sharply on a wave of profit-taking.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4. -- The first junior dinner dance of the season was given tonight in the main ballroom of the Bellevue-Stratford. These dances are traditional events of a Philadelphia season and began as the Monday evening dancing class.
SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 4 (AP). -- Axes flew and saws sang today in answer to the demand for more than $5,000,000 worth of Christmas trees.

In your editorial of Nov. 17 "The Capital Gains Tax and the Market" you state correctly that capital gains are taxed at the same rates as ordinary income. You continue by mentioning that if the stock has been held for more than a year, only 80 per cent of the gain would be taxed, and if held for more than two years, only 60 per cent thereof.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Dec. 4. -- Educational preparation and scientific guidance for marriage were advocated today at the closing sessions of the Wesleyan University Conference on Marriage, which also heard discussions of the sociological and ethical aspects of the problem.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.J., Dec. 4. -- Atlantic County detectives, ordered by Prosecutor Joseph Altman in Atlantic City to "go and get" gambling-law violators here, reported three suspected places "closed" this afternoon and left the former WPA seamstresses whose picketing called attention to the "joints" claiming a moral victory.

Although actual output in various manufacturing industries has reached or even surpassed the 1929 level, per capita production in general is still approximately 19 per cent below that in 1929, according to a study comparing figures for 1929, 1933 and 1936, which the National Industrial Conference Board announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP). -- A rush by workers to register under the Social Security Act was reported from one end of the country to the other today as officials expressed confidence that the registrations would be practically complete.

The Preaching Mission which has been "touring" America for weeks comes now to New York; but on no such errand as that of the ancient missioner who was sent to preach "against" a certain city. Rather have they looked to the culminating services in New York, beginning tomorrow, as giving supreme support to this nationwide movement with world-wide implications.

Picking this year's all-America football eleven, with a supporting cast sufficient to equip the mythical team with material three-deep in each position, proved scarcely less nerve-racking than trying to fix the relative merits of leading collegiate units.
BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 4 (AP). -- Coach Bernie Moore of Louisiana State University took the selection of Pittsburgh's football team for the Rose Bowl game with a grin today.

LONDON, Dec. 4. -- The Archbishop of Canterbury's first public incursion into the clash between King Edward and the Cabinet came tonight in the form of a plea to the leaders of the Anglican Church in the following terms:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 4. -- Henry Rosenfeld, 42 years old, of 84 Smith Street, this city, treasurer of the Steidinger Press, Inc., of New York, was killed instantly early this morning in an automobile crash that caused another death and injured five more persons.

Let by Jimmy Gorman and George Palmer, the St. John's University five came back after an unimpressive start to defeat Seth Low Junior College, 48 -- 24, in the De Gray Gymnasium in Brooklyn last night.

After fluctuating within narrowest limits of the week, prices on the Cotton Exchange ended yesterday with a gain of 2 to a loss of 8 points. Although a smaller volume of business was reported in wholesale cotton goods, consumers continued to fix prices. The decision to grant an Exchange holiday on Dec. 26 brought final trading in the spot month to Dec. 15, a day earlier than the usual date.
LONDON, Dec. 4. -- The stock market took a philosophical view of the constitutional crisis today, and the undertone remained firm, although the volume of business was small.
BERLIN, Dec. 4. -- A mixed showing characterized the Boerse's opening today, although there were some signs of firmness near the close.

Four of the new Norwegian-built sloops of a group of twenty-five that are to be raced as a class on Long Island next Summer, were on the decks of the Norwegian America liner Stavangerfjord, which arrived yesterday afternoon from Oslo.

The Board of Governors of the New York Young Republican Club, according to announcement yesterday, met on Thursday and endorsed Senator Thomas C. Desmond of Orange County for the Republican leadership of the State Senate.

Public support of volunteer service institutions such as hospitals is support of the principle of private responsibility instead of government ownership and activity, which "is not the best way," Arthur A. Ballantine, former Under-Secretary of the Treasury, declared yesterday.

It is high time that somebody should speak out, as Commissioner BLANSHARD did the other day, about the thinly veiled efforts of Tammany and its allies to block the reorganization of county government in this city. The enabling constitutional amendment was adopted over a year ago.

Frederick Ely Williamson, president of the New York Central Railroad, has won the Yale Bowl, annual honorary award of the Montclair (N.J.) Yale Club to the Yale alumnus "who has made his 'Y' in life," it was announced here yesterday by Nicholas Roberts and Paul H. Crane, chairman of the board and president of the club, respectively.

Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the General Motors Corporation, issued a statement yesterday regarding complaints brought by the Federal Trade Commission against the 6 per cent time-payment plan of twenty-one automobile and financing companies.

Activity increased yesterday in the bond section of the New York Stock Exchange and prices of the speculative rails and equity issues were advanced sharply. United States Government securities, while not particularly active, were strong, and four loans rose to their best prices since issuance.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (AP). -- Stern faculty representatives of the Western Conference tonight listened to a plea for modified subsidization of athletes and withheld comment after polite discussion of the drastic proposal.
The six-day bicycle race resolved itself into one of the closest struggles in years as the eleven teams remaining swept into their final 24-hour shift at Madison Square Garden last night.

Disclosing that President Roosevelt had characterized him as "an unreconstructed rebel," Senator Carter Glass of Virginia made it clear last night that, despite his support of the President at the recent election, he still was a believer in the old Democratic doctrine of States' rights and opposed to many of the policies of the New Deal.

The validity of the city's pension system was questioned during a Board of Estimate meeting yesterday by Borough Presidents Samuel Levy of Manhattan and George U. Harvey of Queens, when the board considered the pension application of Julian Wood, dismissed Deputy Tax Commissioner in the Bronx.
PEIPING, China, Saturday, Dec. 5. -- Chinese telegrams from Suiyuan Province report that the attacking Mongol and Manchukuoan forces were sharply repulsed for the second time at Pailingmiao.

HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 4. -- Despite indications of a last-ditch fight for the presidency between two New York lawyers, Jeremiah T. Mahoney and Major Patrick J. Walsh, the forty-eighth annual convention of the Amateur Athletic Union opened today with factional forces concentrating on a harmonious adjustment of differences, which at one time threatened to rip the organization apart.

Mrs. Seaman Schepps gave a luncheon yesterday at Theodore's at which she introduced her daughter, Miss Cora Patricia Schepps, to society. Receiving with Miss Schepps were her sister, Mrs. Kenneth Price Dillon of Boston, and Miss Ruth O'Day Boyd of New York.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4. -- Johnny Layton of Sedalia, Mo., went into first place in the world's three-cushion billiard tournament tonight by defeating Otto Reiselt of Philadelphia, 50 to 30, in forty-nine innings. Layton, whose record now is four victories and one loss, had a high run of six to three for Reiselt.

New York State will have the "most expensive and most complicated" unemployment insurance administration of the nation unless the present forms of records and reports required from employers under the new law are not drastically modified.

TYLER, Texas, Dec. 4. -- Carrying the banner of the East in intersectional football strife, Manhattan reached the end of its 1,700-mile journey from New York today and stood ready for its battle with powerful Texas A. and M. at Lion Stadium tomorrow.
The Beaux-Arts Ball last night was preceded by many dinner parties, at most of which the hosts and hostesses and their guests wore the costumes in which they attended the ball.

New bond financing this week amounted to $203,061,000, the largest sum for such a period since the week ended on June 12, when new issues for $204,466,600 were marketed. The total last week was $93,510,000. A year ago this week it was $26,299,000.

NEWARK, Dec. 4. -- Miss Jane Illingsworth Veghte was presented to society today at a large tea given by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Debow Veghte, at their home in this city. The debutante received with her mother and her grandmother, Mrs. Robert Illingworth of Newark and Denville.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 4. -- While it was no surprise when Harvard's eight-game football schedule for 1938 was announced today to include a game with the University of Chicago at Cambridge Nov. 5, it made known for the first time that Cornell has been placed on the list two years hence.

BALDOCK, Hertfordshire, England, Dec. 4 (AP). -- Russell K. Boadwee Jr., an American business man whose father's address was given as 453 De Kalb Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y., was killed today in an automobile accident.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Saturday, Dec. 5 (Canadian Press). -- The clash between the King and the British Cabinet evoked further comment in Australian newspapers today.

Patrons of the theatre and the films have been moving in very distinguished company of late. Only the other day Napoleon of St. Helena was in town. We still have with us Queen Victoria and Richard Wagner, and, on the screen, Rembrandt.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Dec. 5. -- Shgeru Kawagoe, the Japanese Ambassador, left Nanking at 8:20 this morning for Shanghai, declaring, "The negotiations are neither terminated nor suspended. I do not intend to return to Tokyo to report on the situation but expect soon to return to Nanking to continue efforts for a gradual settlement of all outstanding issues between our two countries."

A note of optimism and plans for the most intensive campaign in its history were contributed by the speakers, among them Mayor F. H. La Guardia, at a luncheon at the Biltmore Hotel yesterday opening the thirtieth annual Christmas seal sale under the auspices of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association.

PARIS, Dec. 4. -- Mrs. Wallis Simpson found refuge tonight at the Hotel de France in Blois. In the medieval city in Central France she is resting from a trip across the Channel and a day's automobile journey from Dieppe through Rouen, skirting Paris.
BERLIN, Dec. 4. -- Alone in the world, the German press continued today to ignore the storm that has broken over Britain as a result of the King's marriage plans.

Juan T. Trippe, president of Pan American Airways, returned yesterday from a 36,466-mile business trip around the world, all by air, announcing the completion of negotiations with the Chinese Government which will permit American air-borne commerce to enter the Orient for the first time by way of Hongkong.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 4. -- Storm signals were hoisted over Pasadena's famed Rose Bowl tonight as verbal winds blew hot and cold over the selection of Pittsburgh to oppose Washington in the annual New Year's Day football classic.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 4. -- Ralph Eccard, apprentice rider of Chewsville, Md., had the first mount of his career in the fifth race at the Fair Grounds today, finishing last on Saint, but he came back in the featured Audubon Purse, next on the card, and steered D.L. Ogle's Infidox, home an easy winner over a band of fast sprinters.

During these weeks in which attention has been centered on the situation that has risen out of the relations between King Edward and Mrs. Simpson, thousands of persons must have been struck with the wonderful relevance of some familiar lines in "Hamlet" to that situation; and yet, so far as I have observed, no allusion has anywhere been made to those lines.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- John Hamilton issued a call today for a meeting of the Republican National Committee in Chicago, Dec. 17, when he will offer his resignation and retire as chairman of the committee, unless it gives him a vote of confidence and approves a plan of reorganization drawn up by him and the executive committee.

Predictions as to the immediate future of aviation were made by eight leaders in various fields of aeronautics at a round-table discussion at the Engineering Societies Auditorium yesterday afternoon on "The Next Five Years in Aviation."

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 4 (AP). -- Dr. C. A. Ives, Dean of the Teach-I ers College of Louisiana State Uni-I versity, was elected president of [ the Southern Association of Col-I leges and Secondary Schools at theI close of the forty-first annual ses-I sion of the organization here today. I

Vigorous protests against the adoption of a proposed ordinance which would vest control over the slaughtering of kosher poultry exclusively in the Kashruth association of orthodox rabbis were expressed yesterday when the ordinance came before the general welfare committee of the Board of Aldermen for a public hearing.
With the football campaign practically over, except for the various "Bowl" games, the season is now open on all-America selections.

The appointment of commissioners in various cities who will question labor leaders in connection with the cases against the fourteen men accused by Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey of operating a restaurant "shakedown" racket which netted $2,000,000 a year was completed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook.

Today marks the third anniversary of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, but so rapidly do perspectives change and so crowded with unusual events have these years been, that to many people it doubtless seems that a much longer time has passed since the December day in 1933 when Utah cast the final vote that put an end to national prohibition.

New municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $10,264,622, representing fifty-two municipalities. This compares with $9,418,380 awarded this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date is $26,260,586.

While the local nocturnal resorts buzz with imperial gossip quite as absorbing as any formal entertainment, it seems rather proper that this column should intrude this morning no more than to report the occurrence of only two scheduled events of moment during the coming week.

VATICAN CITY, Saturday, Dec. 5. -- Pope Pius was stricken this morning with what reliable sources declared was paralysis of his left leg. The paralysis was attributed by the attending physicians to inflamation of the heart.

MONTREAL, Dec. 4. -- Burleigh Grimes began in earnest today his task of rehabilitating the Dodgers for 1937. By engineering two deals he succeeded in bringing four new players to the Brooklyn roster in exchange for two.

Stanley Gallowin of the City A.C., seeded No. 1 in the draw for the Long Island championship of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association which started yesterday, was the victim of an upset in the initial round. Facing G.W. Fraker Jr., a member of the Downtown A.C., on the latter's home courts, Gallowin bowed after a hard battle, 15 -- 13, 15 -- 18, 15 -- 13, 16 -- 14.

BLOIS, France, Saturday, Dec. 5. -- Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson, who came to France from England Thursday night, left here hurriedly and unexpectedly early today. She was accompanied by her entire party. After asking earlier that she be called at 7 A.M., Mrs. Simpson rose at 3 A.M. and continued her voyage south.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:...

A rift developed at yesterday's Board of Estimate meeting between Mayor La Guardia and other members over whether the board should adhere strictly to a policy of keeping land adjacent to the new Queens parkways as restricted as possible, to protect them against unsightly roadside developments.

Governor Lehman, commenting on today's third anniversary of the repeal of prohibition, declared that the most important gain since the sale of liquor was legalized was the better attitude of the public toward law observance and the establishment of an effective system of liquor control for the State.

Students, faculty members, alumnae and friends of Barnard College joined forces yesterday in a campus carnival illustrative of the scholastic and social activities of the college community. The proceeds of the affair, continuing today with a more elaborate program, will go to the Fiftieth Anniversary Fund Committee, which is raising funds for the construction of a college building at 119th Street and Riverside Drive.

Mrs. Emma B. Kaufman Brunner, widow of Arnold W. Brunner, architect, left her residuary estate of undetermined value to ten architectural and educational institutions here and abroad. This was learned yesterday when her will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court.

Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook peered anxiously over the edge of his judicial bench yesterday, his eyes following closely the movements of a large, black ant in the center of a dish placed on the witness stand. The court room clock ticked loudly, while attorneys, witnesses and scores of spectators gazed at the lamp whose rays were beating down upon the unfortunate insect.

Charles E. Robinson, a distinguished looking, 64-year-old Englishman, handsomely turned out in Bond Street clothes, spats, a walking stick, a monocle and a long cigarette holder, with an expensive automobile at his disposal, was arrested yesterday in Tenafly, N.J., on a charge of being a fugitive from justice under the Federal Stolen Property Act.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 4. -- Malcolm Farmer, chairman of athletics at Yale, tonight issued a statement with regard to the proposed "Ivy Football League" in which he emphasized its disadvantages rather than its advantages and left little doubt that Yale is opposed to entering such an organization.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Substantial increases in the net railway operating income of Class I railroads in all districts both in October and the first ten months this year, and compared with last year's corresponding periods was shown today by data released simultaneously by the Interstate Commerce Commission and the Association of American Railroads.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 4. -- Pan-American neutrality in case war breaks out anywhere in the world, which Secretary of State Cordell Hull is expected to propose in his first speech tomorrow before the Conference on Maintenance of Peace, promised to become the most controversial issue the gathering would discuss as the delegates settled into preliminary manoeuvring today.

The Daniel Guggenheim Medal, given for notable contributions in the advancement of aeronautics, was presented last night at a dinner at the Hotel Biltmore to Dr. George W. Lewis, director of research of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics, "for outstanding success in the direction of aeronautical research and for the development of original equipment and methods."
DUBLIN, Irish Free State, Dec. 4. -- The constitutional crisis in Britain has aroused intense interest throughout the Free State.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4. -- Hogs were in active demand today, but sales generally were steady to 10 cents lower compared with Thursday's average. In some instances, business was put through which appeared to be as much as 25 cents lower than the high point of the preceding day.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 4. -- Miss Elizabeth Gildersleeve Parke of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Hulick Parke of New Haven, Conn., was married here this afternoon to Richard Stotesbury Jessup, son of Mrs. William H. Jessup of New York and the late Mr. Jessup, at the Hitchcock Memorial Church.

Building projects filed for in the city yesterday included plans for two tenement houses and three dwellings in the Bronx. In Brooklyn plans were submitted for a hospital to cost $280,000 and several dwellings.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 4. -- The Alumnae Association of Rosemary Hall, school for girls in Greenwich, has organized a fund to buy the school from Miss Caroline Ruutz-Rees, founder and headmistress, Mrs. Atwood Violett, alumnae president, announced today.

BOSTON, Dec. 4 (AP). -- Lost for a century, a symphony by the famous Italian pianist, Muzio Clementi, received its first hearing in the United States today at the hands of the Boston Symphony Orchestra. The performance, conducted by Serge Koussevitzky, received warm applause.

MOSCOW, Dec. 4. -- The taboo that the Soviet keeps against public discussion of private lives was suspended today for fairly extensive reporting of the controversy in Great Britain regarding King Edward's possible plans about Mrs. Wallis Simpson.
J. Heyward Peck, Great Neck, L.I. -- As a novice of four years' standing in surf fishing, I feel compelled to answer Mr. Robinson's letter in your column criticizing the surf fishing at Jones Beach.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 4. -- Horton Smith, ambling golfer from the Ozarks, made it difficult today for 200 colleagues trying to take his Miami Biltmore open title and the $2,500 that goes with it.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey has agreed to grant wage increases of 5 per cent to its 7,000 employes in New Jersey, it was learned in Bayonne yesterday. In addition, the company has agreed to continue permanently a 5 per cent increase granted last June as a temporary step to adjust wages to the cost of living.

A conference of trust officers and other executives of up-State banks engaged in the trust business will be held on next Wednesday in Rochester under the auspices of the committee on trust functions of the New York State Bankers Association, according to an announcement made yesterday by the association.
The annual "Universal Bible Sunday" will be observed tomorrow by pastors preaching sermons pleading for a more general use of the Holy Scriptures.

Manchester Central High, one of New Hampshire's schoolboy football powers for more than a decade, will combat Curtis High at Thompson's Stadium, Stapleton, Staten Island, this afternoon in New York City's scholastic gridiron finale for 1936. The contest is to start at 2 o'clock.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 4. -- Mrs. Caroline O'Day, New York's Representative at Large, entered the field of international politics today by presenting an appeal for word peace to the conference gathered here to seek means to accomplish that end for the Americas at least.

With Christmas trade steadily increasing, retail trade in the metropolitan area again made a notably good showing this week, particularly in volume of evening shopping. Gift buying swelled the demand for seasonal merchandise experienced in most store sections and volume for the week was estimated as ranging around 15 per cent ahead of the comparative 1935 period.

A conference of trust officers and other executives of up-State banks engaged in the trust business will be held on next Wednesday in Rochester under the auspices of the committee on trust functions of the New York State Bankers Association, according to an announcement made yesterday by the association.
The annual "Universal Bible Sunday" will be observed tomorrow by pastors preaching sermons pleading for a more general use of the Holy Scriptures.
