Manchester Central High, one of New Hampshire's schoolboy football powers for more than a decade, will combat Curtis High at Thompson's Stadium, Stapleton, Staten Island, this afternoon in New York City's scholastic gridiron finale for 1936. The contest is to start at 2 o'clock.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Saturday, Dec. 5 (AP). -- A man who identified himself as Lawrence Doyle, 31-year-old fugitive Lynbrook, L.I., policeman, wanted on charges of forgery and suspected murder, was held here today. He walked into city police headquarters last night and surrendered.

OTTAWA, Ont., Dec. 4. -- Prime Minister Mackenzie King issued a statement today making clear what had generally been inferred -- that the Canadian Government had taken no initiative in the matter of King Edward and Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 4. -- Mrs. Caroline O'Day, New York's Representative at Large, entered the field of international politics today by presenting an appeal for word peace to the conference gathered here to seek means to accomplish that end for the Americas at least.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Saturday, Dec. 5 (AP). -- A man who identified himself as Lawrence Doyle, 31-year-old fugitive Lynbrook, L.I., policeman, wanted on charges of forgery and suspected murder, was held here today. He walked into city police headquarters last night and surrendered.

OTTAWA, Ont., Dec. 4. -- Prime Minister Mackenzie King issued a statement today making clear what had generally been inferred -- that the Canadian Government had taken no initiative in the matter of King Edward and Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson.

SYDNEY, New South Wales. -- Four young nurses of Sydney are now on their way to Spain, where they will place their services at the disposal of the Spanish Government. The four women who have volunteered to go to the front are Sisters Mary Lowson, Una Wilson, May Macfarlane and Edith Johnson.

Mayor La Guardia denounced as "gratuitous, inaccurate and premature" last night a statement earlier in the day by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local WPA Administrator, that WPA funds for New York City would be cut $4,000,000 a month and that beginning Jan. 1 the city would be expected to bear approximately 20 per cent of the cost of the projects.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 4. -- The text of the address today by Dr. Carlos Saavedra Lamas, Argentine Foreign Minister, accepting the permanent presidency of the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace and welcoming the delegates to the conference, follows:
Housing and industrial parcels were among the New Jersey conveyances reported yesterday.

Bank exchanges in 164 clearing houses throughout the country in November amounted to $26,949,913,089. This was a decrease of 5.4 per cent from the total in the preceding month, but 10.4 per cent in excess of the turnover in November, 1935.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 4 (AP). -- The little University of Miami football team used a field goal and an aerial attack to upset Georgetown of Washington, 10 to 6, before a crowd of 7,500 tonight.

LONDON, 11 A.M., Saturday, Dec. 5. -- A special Cabinet meeting, summoned at 10 Downing Street to hear Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin's account of his telephone discussions with King Edward yesterday over their conflict regarding the King's desire to marry Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson and his visit to His Majesty at Fort Belvedere, the King's country home, assembled a few minutes after 10 o'clock this morning.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 4. -- President Roosevelt's visit here was described as a godsend to democracy and he was called an apostle of peace in the speech with which Foreign Minister Carlos Saavedra Lamas of Argentina welcomed the delegates to the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace at its first plenary session this morning.

LONDON, Dec. 4. -- The views of the dominion governments, according to authoritative information, are dead against the marriage of King Edward and Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson, morganatically or otherwise. Their opposition is not based on the fact that she is a commoner and an American.

It is gratifying to note that a major American city, Philadelphia, has determined to try the experiment of supplying some of its police officers in outlying districts with trained dog assistants. The Mayor has instructed the Superintendent of Police to purchase eight such dogs, rightly commenting that if a patrolman who was murdered in a lonely suburb while on night patrol had had such a companion he might have been warned and his life spared.

The Harvard Club Class C squash tennis team blanked the City Athletic Club in Metropolitan League play yesterday and gained undisputed possession of first place, while driving City into a tie with the New York A.C. for runner-up honors.

HARRISBURG, Saturday, Dec. 5. -- The Pennsylvania Legislature passed the Earle administration's Unemployment Insurance Bill early this morning, several hours after Governor George H. Earle, in a conference with Democratic Legislators, had forced the restoration of most of the civil service provisions which had been eliminated by a Senate committee.

CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 4. -- The Australian public, having recovered from the staggering surprise of King Edward's clash with his Cabinet, is beginning to articulate in almost one voice the fervent desire that the empire shall not be deprived of the services of a King who is a very real personality to the people of all walks of life in Australia.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4 (AP). -- Southern California fans made merry at their annual homecoming celebration tonight before sending the Trojans into tomorrow's football game against Notre Dame. Coach Elmer Layden led his Ramblers into town tonight and hurried to the dinner as honor guest.

We publish elsewhere on this page the letter of a correspondent criticizing our supposed "calculation," in an editorial article of Nov. 17, of the amount by which a holder would have to expect a stock he owned to break under the present capital gains tax before it would be worth his while to sell it.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4. -- Belief that future low-rent housing projects "should, in general, be undertaken by local housing authorities on a loan and grant basis" was voiced here today by Edward H. Foley, director of the legal division of the Public Works Administration, in an address at the annual meeting of the National Association of Housing Officials.
Herbert Fitzpatrick, vice president and general counsel of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company for many years, was selected last night as the new head of the vast Van Sweringen railroad empire.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 5 (AP). -- James Norman Hall, co-author with Charles Nordhoff of "Mutiny on the Bounty," is yearning for Tahiti, his home for seventeen years, and bemoaning the approaching "collapse of our present civilization."

Dr. Samuel Lambert, chairman of the doctors' committee of the United Hospital Campaign, announced last night that the membership of his group included the presidents of the five county medical societies as well as more than forty other prominent physicians and surgeons.

BERLIN, Dec. 5. -- Trading on the Boerse was quiet today. Heavy industrials showed some slight strength at the close, Mannesmann gaining 5/8 point and Hoesch 1/2. Potashes were quiet; Westeregeln gained 1 1/2 points. Chemicals were mixed, I.G. Farben gaining 1/4 point.

Cash dividend payments by the companies of the Standard Oil group of 1936 are estimated at $239,000,627, compared with $170,113,682 in 1935, an increase of roughly 40 per cent, according to Carl H. Pforzheimer Co. This will be the largest amount for any year since 1930 when the record of $286,526,728 was distributed.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 5. -- At the risk of losing its $1,188,000 State appropriation and being forced virtually to become a privately endowed institution, the University of Pittsburgh was definitely on record today that it would not change its policies to accede to the demands of Governor Earle.

A MOVIE camera opening its eye from a point on the Ninth Avenue L and looking westward toward the river" discovers, on a feverish midsummer night, a long line of tenements before which the shadows of vacationless humanity stir in the slight cool of dusk.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 5 (AP). -- The football machine of Western Maryland College rolled down from the hills today, flattened the University of Maryland by a score of 12 to 0 and surged into the State championship in a game that had 15,000 fans in a continual uproar.

I have read the letters in today's Drama Mail Bag concerning the purchasing of theatre tickets. I wish to agree with Miss Weatherbee's letter. There are, unfortunately, in this metropolis, a number of people who can afford to pay only a certain amount of money for their tickets.
LONDON, Dec. 5. -- Among the floods of opinion on King Edward's future course, no expression has been more surprising than that of "The Tablet," one of the leading Roman Catholic weeklies in London.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 5. -- Inaugurating its second season, the Society of the Four Arts today gave a tea and preview of an exhibition of American art, the first of a series of similar events planned for the Winter at its galleries here. The collection, including one painting from each State, was chosen from that shown at Rockefeller Center last Summer.

Three seeded players advanced in first-round play in the Long Island championship of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association on the Jackson Heights Squash Club's courts yesterday. Second-round competition will be started at 11 o'clock this morning at the club.

If you are a reader of the outdoor magazines and a votary of wildfowling, you doubtless are familiar with the name of Fred Kimble. Few stories dealing with the history of duck shooting in this country fail to mention the prowess of Fred Kimble with a shotgun.

The Abraham Lincoln High School track and field team began the scholastic season last night with a fine victory in the carnival staged by the Second Masonic District Association of Manhattan at the 102d Engineers Armory before a turnout of more than 2,000 persons.

An exhibition of dolls made at the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled will open tomorrow at 10 West Fifty-seventh Street and continue there through the Christmas holidays. Founded in 1917, the institute teaches those who are disabled and crippled to be self-supporting.

LONDON, Dec. 2. -- Save for the feverish preparations attendant on the annual season of pantomime productions, the London theatre has entered its pre-holiday doldrums. The only offering of wide general interest scheduled for the coming week is Kurt Robitschek's new revue, "Laughter Over London," starring Lou Holtz, George Robey and Billy Bennet.
SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- The season's round of sports and socials here is getting under way early, with hunting attracting wide attention among visiting sportsmen.
In THE TIMES editorial "Einstein on Competition" you state: "Nietzsche developed Darwinism to the full and preached a doctrine of brutality: the doctrine that the world belongs to the strong."

LONDON, Dec. 4. -- Immersed in what is known as a constitutional crisis at home, most Britons have momentarily forgotten the far graver crisis in foreign affairs. Perhaps they are glad to forget it for a while, for the official leaders of the country have long since ceased to clothe their apprehensions in the optimistic phrases that were formerly customary.
WHEN inventive minds first "toyed" with the radiophone one of the first programs they aimed to broadcast as a "natural" was the Metropolitan Opera.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 5 (AP). -- An attempt to extort $5,000 from dancing Ginger Rogers of the films led a 20-year-old sailor into a Department of Justice trap today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The Social Security Board announced tonight a ten-day extension of time for the filing of employes' application forms under the old-age pension provisions of the Social Security Act.

TOKYO, Sunday, Dec. 6 (AP). -- The Ministers of War, Navy and Foreign Affairs were reported today to have reached a decision for the removal of Japanese subjects, in event of future trouble, from points in the interior of China to cities where they could be under protection of Japanese arms.

Members of the Riverside Association of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York have arranged a luncheon and card party in behalf of the institute for Dec. 14 at the Hotel Peter Stuyvesant. Mrs. Charles L. Craig is director of the Riverside Association, one of several groups within the Port of New York working actively as members of the Central Council of Associations.

MADRID, Dec. 5 (AP). -- An Insurgent aerial bomb wrecked an occupied house near the United States Embassy today in a raid apparently aimed at razing the entire Arguilles section of Madrid less than half a mile from the embassy. At least a score of persons were killed.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 5. -- An eight-point program to make peace so alive and so forceful that it would be strong enough to prevent war was presented to the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace by Secretary of State Cordell Hull of the United States this afternoon in a speech before its second plenary session.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- With a yield of 2,000,000 pounds of tung oil in sight this year from domestic tung trees, a good start has been made toward the establishment of a new American industry. Heretofore China has been the main producer of tung oil and during the first eight months of this year she exported 107,000,000 pounds to this country.

As a result of the strides being made in national recovery, the fifteen thousand students enrolled in the University Extension division at Columbia are turning again to cultural studies, Director James C. Egbert declared in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, which was made public yesterday.

THERE is always room for a systematic survey of classic writers, and in the present case there was perhaps a downright need. If the great English novelists must from time to time be realigned in terms of the growth of the English novel, even more imperatively must they be reinterpreted in terms of a given age.

A MAXIMUM speed limit of fifty miles an hour on certain sections of all State trunk line highways has been established by Connecticut, according to the Connecticut Safety Bulletin published by the Governor's Commission on Street and Highway Safety.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5. -- Miss Maria Bullitt, 18 years old, of Chestnut Hill, debutante cousin of Ambassador Bullitt, was sentenced today to keep out of automobiles for sixty days.

THE police of Georgia are still searching diligently for the silver plates of the Great Seal of the State which disappeared during a political campaign last August. Meantime new plates, cast soon after the theft, are being used to stamp official documents requiring the use of the seal.

Magistrate Jeanette G. Brill will speak at a luncheon of the Junior Child Guidance League of Brooklyn, of which she is honorary president, on Saturday at Essex House, 160 Central Park South. Magistrate Brill will talk from her experience in court cases involving mentally handicapped children, and will make recommendations for their disposition.

BRISBANE, Australia, Dec. 5. -- A grim struggle for victory appeared likely today, with England and Australia preparing to resume play on Monday in the first of their five cricket test matches. In the match started yesterday, England made 358 runs in its first turn at the wickets, the home players replying with 151 for two today.

THIS is a book of man's achievement, and it fairly teems with superlatives. It begins with a description of the two Pacific Coast bridges which now "hold a majority of the world's 'big bridge' records." And it ends with an explanation of experiments in the use of aluminum alloy, on the note of possibly vaster superlatives yet to come.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 5. -- The Mississippi Rebels halted Tennessee's great come-back campaign today by fighting the Vols to a scoreless tie before 16,000 fans.

AT the Opera-Comique a complete overhauling of the entire repertory of fifty-five operas and ballets has been undertaken by the new management. While Mr. Jacques Rouche retains the office of directeur general, new appointments have brought Mr. Antoine Mariotte to the post of administrateur general, and Mr. Febvre-Longeray to that of secretaire general.

THOSE who, in the simplicity of their hearts, really imagined that the Staatsoper had learned a thing or two about "Die Meistersinger" from Toscanini, Herbert Graf and their associates in Salzburg last Summer found out in proper season that even a State opera, led to the source of wisdom, cannot be made to drink.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP). -- Senate investigators announced today that they were giving "careful study" to a proposed law drafted by Professor James K. Pollock of the University of Michigan to control "irresponsible and indiscriminate" political spending.

THE unprecedentedly large attendances at this year's Book Exhibition have started an uneasy feeling in the minds of some thoughtful people. Is there not a danger of the tail wagging the dog? To put it more precisely, are not the sideshows threatening to eclipse the exhibition proper?

IN the month between the closing of the Marin Retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art and the opening of the next exhibition of recent work by Marin, Alfred Stieglitz has put on at An American Place a group show of selected paintings by Marin, O'Keeffe, Dove and Hartley.

Rowland Caldwell Sheldon, executive director of the National Crime Prevention Institute, committed suicide at 8:45 A.M. yesterday by leaping from a bedroom window of his eleventh-floor apartment at 440 Riverside Drive into the rear courtyard, on 116th Street.

The "Pageant of Living Dolls," to be presented during luncheon tomorrow in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre, will benefit a unique philanthropic service that has brought happiness to many underprivileged children of the city. A portion of the proceeds from the luncheon and its pageant feature will be donated to Toyery, Inc., an organization which established free lending collections of toys for the entertainment of children of needy parents.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Dec. 5 (AP). -- A shorthand account of the last hours of President Lincoln, transmitted to a friend two days after the President's death by a War Department clerk who was at his bedside, came into the possession of the University of Michigan today.
The program question is not new; indeed, it is old and stale and tiresome, but I cannot refrain from raising it once more and asking you to discuss it candidly and calmly.

In Spain last week the civil war continued on its bloody course, with no abatement of the threat that it might bring in its wake a general European struggle. At Geneva preparations were being made for a meeting of the nations at which the question of life or death for the League was likely to be answered.

SAYRESVILLE, N.J., Dec. 5. -- Police throughout Middlesex County were searching today for hit-and-run drivers responsible for the deaths of two persons in separate accidents here and at Morgan last night.

Due to the increasing importance of Mexico in art work in the last few years, Columbia University held its first art class in Mexico this Summer. The twenty members of the class, artists in their own right, who are doing graduate work at Teachers College, Columbia, are now returning to the several cities of the United States where they are employed as teachers.

CANNES, France, Sunday, Dec. 6. -- Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson was driven at great speed through the gates of the villa belonging to her intimate friends, Mr. and Mrs. Herman Livingston Rogers of New York, on her arrival late last night.

HERE is an anthology which is quite literally described by its title -- and one need only look at the title to realize that it is, therefore, different from most other anthologies in its basis of choice. For fifteen years Hazel Felleman has been editor of the Queries and Answers page of THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review.

Experts of the Department of Agriculture at Washington have just made a forecast of the nation's Winter food supply. Their predictions indicate that there will be quantities of meat and poultry for the American pantry, a possible shortage of eggs, and butter at higher prices, possibly the highest since 1930.

The supper dance to be given tomorrow in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria in behalf of the Big Brother Movement will be featured by a novel dancing contest in which members of the junior committee for the benefit will take part.

LONDON. EDIFICES that have seen two or three centuries of political history are to be swept from Whitehall by the construction of an immense block of government buildings, plans for which have recently been made public.

Between 1926 and 1931 the American Telephone and Telegraph Company put into effect a series of reductions in long-distance telephone rates calculated to result in substantial savings to subscribers. Last January it instituted a further cut of $4,000,000, largely in night and week-end rates.

The staff of Hunter College will have a chance to demonstrate its histrionic ability this week when the faculty-student social relations committee presents the third annual faculty play "The Question Is * * *" at the Little Theatre of the Bronx buildings of the college.

GENEVA, Dec. 4. -- Many dilemmas are presented to the League of Nations by the Spanish Government's appeal to the Council, which meets next Thursday, to examine under Article XI of the League Covenant, the danger to peace in the "armed intervention" by Germany and Italy and their recognition of the government of the Rebel generalissimo, Francisco Franco.

IN the hope of raising the standards of educational programs now on the air, representatives of eighteen organizations are to meet this week in Washington, D.C., for the first national conference on educational broadcasting.

Unanimous agreement on the fact that the depression is over so far as the rug industry is concerned is found among executives of rug departments in leading stores all over the country, A. Funduklian, sales manager of A. M. Karagheusian, asserted yesterday on his return from an extensive trip to retail centers in the East and Mid-west.

OLD problems are stalking Ireland again on this, the fifteenth anniversary of the creation of the Free State. They are intensified by an economic war and the Free State's growing national ambitions. It was thought, back in 1921, that the Irish question had been solved by a treaty which gave the South dominion status and allowed Northern Ireland to keep its close union with the empire.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.J., Dec. 5. -- With enough canned goods and cash on hand to assure continuation of their "siege" of the Council Hall here for another week at least, the ousted WPA seamstresses under Mrs. Anna McArdle and Miss Isabelle O'Connor resumed their antigambling drive today.

The criticism of the Kamerny Theatre and its director, Alexander Tairov, by the Moscow newspaper Izvestia, and the possibility of its disbandment, recently caused a stir in the theatrical circles of America and Europe. In Moscow, however, this criticism was not unexpected.

THE Supreme Court of the United States the other day listened to arguments on the question of the President's proclamation last year, in which Congress concurred, calling for a drastic embargo on the shipment of munitions to warring countries.

THIS is an educator's answer to the oft-repeated question, What is the matter with American education? It is an educator's answer, too, to the corollary, What can be done about it? It is an answer which is comprehensive, positive, emphatic, and highly controversial.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn affirmed yesterday the conviction of two officers and two members of District Council 18 of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paper Hangers of Brooklyn, who on Jan. 6 were found guilty of extortion.

A VERY much chastened Bette Davis is awaiting the ring of the telephone to summon her to the pursuit of art at the Warner Studio. Writers are hastening with the script of "Marked Woman" and it is possible that cameras will turn within the coming week.

Should King Edward VIII abdicate as a result of the present crisis, his brother, the Duke of York, would succeed him in accordance with a statute, the Act of Settlement, enacted by Parliament in 1701. The terms of this law are simple -- that the royal heirs of the Electress Sophia of Hanover, a granddaughter of King James I, should receive the British Crown.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 5. -- A concert will be presented by the Greenwich Choral Society at the Greenwich Academy on Monday evening, under the direction of Lowell P. Beveridge, conductor of the Columbia University Glee Club and Barnard Choir.

Roman Soldier, winner of all the big handicaps during the Fall season in Maryland, is one of the seventy-nine nominees for the $50,000 added Widener Challenge Cup March 6, at Hialeah Park, Miami, Fla., according to an announcement yesterday from the Miami Jockey Club.

"KEY TO CIVILIZATION": Crusades are no novelty in the career of Lady Astor, born a Virginian and first woman member to sit in the British House of Commons. She has described herself as a "teetotaler, non-smoker early riser and mother."

BOSTON, Dec. 2. IN this Winter of Shakespearean rivalries, Walter Huston has chosen a path of his own with a fresh mounting of that production of "Othello" which he first tried three Summers ago. But if he avoids the risks of comparison, it seemed at the Opera House here this week he also misses the benefits of competition.

LONDON, Dec. 5. -- If Mrs. Wallis Simpson were a member of the English aristocracy, the government's present attitude would be different, Sir Stafford Cripps, Left Wing Laborite and one of the best legal minds in the Labor party, declared in a statement today.

BOSTON, Dec. 5. -- Trade and industrial conditions throughout New England continue highly satisfactory. Textile mills in this section have more orders on hand than at any time in recent years, and pictures are beginning to appear in the newspapers of night activity at some of the large centers in the Merrimack Valley and at other points.

New York University will open a series of Christmas concerts on Saturday night when the Glee Club of 110 voices presents its annual Town Hall concert at 8:30 o'clock, under the direction of Professor Alfred M. Greenfield.

LONDON, Dec. 5. -- While the personal wealth of King Edward VIII is unknown, he is not generally regarded as among the wealthiest sovereigns of Europe. Wills of reigning kings are not published in England and no means exists of ascertaining the fortune he inherited.

Sergei Rachmaninoff's recital yesterday in Carnegie Hall was a return to the sort of spectacle which has not often been witnessed by audiences since the depression; a crowded hall, a gathering in festive mood, and, at the end, a stampede to the stage for the encores.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP). -- Five disputes involving New Deal legislation, a record number for any one time, may be decided Monday by the Supreme Court.

Judge and Mrs. Edward Ridley Finch gave a supper dance last night at their home, 21 East Eighty-fourth Street, to introduce to society their younger daughter, Miss Anne Crewe Delafield Finch. Smilax, ferns and Autumn flowers were used in the decorations.

Because Queen Marie of Yugoslavia admired particularly two of the books in the Biblioteca Femina at the International Council of Women in Dubrovnik in October, the collection was started yesterday on its way back to the Deering Library at Northwestern University in Evanston, Ill., with substitutions and apologies.

HERR GOEBBELS having forbidden the drama critics to criticize the drama in Germany, I am not sure how far his jurisdiction extends, and I hardly dare sit down to work this morning lest the Storm Troopers and other civilizing forces drop around for a constructive chat tomorrow.

THE original of this hut, on the same site, near Morristown, N.J., housed officers of the Pennsylvania Division of the Continental Army during the Winter of 1779-80, when the weather was the severest in many years and the ill-equipped Continentals suffered much hardship and privation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- But for the maritime ship strike, business news of the week ended on Nov. 28 was almost uniformly favorable, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey.

Members of the executive committee for the fifth annual Miami Biltmore Fashion Show and Ball to be held on Friday at the Waldorf-Astoria gave a tea dance yesterday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for the young women who comprise the junior and debutante committee for the event.

With holiday trade moving rapidly toward its peak, business throughout the country last week registered some of the best gains in years. Retail trade generally exceeded earlier estimates, as buying power increased as the result of wage advances, bonuses and dividend disbursements.

IN West Forty-eighth Street a few nights ago they had those figurative flags unfurled before the Cort Theatre and its one-year-old tenant, "Boy Meets Girl," for all the world as if it were news that George Francis Abbott had a hit.

Most American gardeners have appreciated the year-round comeliness of native evergreen shrubs, but there is besides a wealth of native deciduous shrubs, not so well known, which are highly decorative. Many of these have the added interest of attracting fruit-eating and seed-eating birds.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 5. -- Coming from behind a see-saw second half to take the lead for the first time with but six minutes left to play, Princeton's basketball team defeated the Dickinson quintet, 33 -- 31, in the season's opener in the university gymnasium tonight.

BERLIN, Dec. 4. -- Most Germans, however inured to political surprises, shuddered at their breakfast tables one day this week, when they picked up the morning newspaper, to read the big, black headline: "Death penalty for economic sabotage."

LONDON, Dec. 5. -- Information received tonight from Fort Belvedere, King Edward's country home, indicated that he apparently had reached his great decision to step down from the throne so that he could marry the woman he loved.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- By the will of Lucy Maynard Salmon, who died Feb. 14, 1927, $30,200 has been bequeathed to Vassar College for a librarian's fund, the annual income to be used at the discretion of the librarian.

Special courts for offenders 16 to 21 years old were urged yesterday by George Z. Medalie, former United States Attorney, in a report on the activity of the Jewish Board of Guardians, which he heads. The report included a plea for support of the drive of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, of which the board is a unit.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Dec. 5 (AP). -- New discoveries concerning the workings of the "scavenger" cells of the human body which are highly important to life were announced today by the Carnegie Institution of Washington.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 5. -- Granville, William Woodward's fine colt which won a half dozen big stakes last Summer after tossing his rider in the Kentucky Derby, was named today as the best race horse of the 1936 season by the nation's turf writers.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 5. -- Still unable to walk but cheerful, Mrs. Hilda Ellenstein, wife of Mayor Meyer Ellenstein, was brought back to Newark tonight from a hospital in Uniontown, Pa., where she has been a patient since the crash April 7 of the transport plane Sunracer.

SANDS POINT, L.I., Dec. 5. -- Nine dogs were selected today to start tomorrow morning in the third series of the open all-age stake of the second annual meeting of the Long Island Retriever Field Trial Club in the covers of the estates of W. Averill Harriman and Mrs. Aimee C. Guggenheim in this village.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 5. -- The first phase of Rutgers University's newly instituted deferred rushing period for fraternities ended this week, sixty-five freshmen being pledged during a three-week restricted period, Dean Fraser Metzger announced today.

MADRID, Dec. 4. -- The battle for the possession of Madrid, which began last Sunday on the capital's north and northwest fronts and is still raging, may, before it is over, prove the fiercest of the whole civil war in Spain.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 5. -- The Matson and American-Hawaiian lines have been accepting January bookings, but the American-Hawaiian for freight only. Officials of both lines explained, however, that acceptances are subject to changes in schedule, meaning settlement of the maritime strike.

The service staffs from homes of many prominent persons in this city and surrounding country places are looking forward to the fourth annual Butlers Ball, which will take place on the night of Jan. 13 in the grand ballroom of the Commodore.

SHANGHAI -- In spite of the fact that the early harvests in China this year were exceptionally bountiful, the price of all grains has increased so enormously that seven provinces have declared embargoes and prohibited grain shipments outside their own borders.

TURNING away from the peasant plays it has featured so long, the Abbey Theatre of Dublin is going back to poetic dramas of the type it produced when William B. Yeats, Lady Gregory and others of their school organized the theatre in the early days of the present century.

Marked gains were scored in active trading by most of the commodity futures on local Exchanges during the week ended on Friday. Silk and certain of the metals were exceptions to the trend, and failed to better their prices.
PARIS, Nov. 26. -- Paris, like London, foresees an unprecedented influx of tourists, especially Americans, next Spring and Summer.

Encouraged by the Democratic sweep in the recent election, friends of Postmaster General James A. Farley have considered the possibility of putting him forward for the nomination for Governor in 1938, it was learned yesterday. These friends express belief that little stands in the way of either Mr. Farley's nomination or election.

IF an effect of elegance is desired in a room -- and elegance is the note in many city apartments and certain types of suburban homes -- it is important to choose accessories correctly. Perhaps a room will need a Dresden porcelain, a wall hanging, or an unusual chair to give the final successful touch.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5, -- Speculative interest in the wheat market today was limited and fluctuations were confined to 1 cent a bushel, with the close unchanged to 3/8 cent lower, the latter on the July delivery. An early upturn was quickly lost on profit-taking, led by houses with Eastern connections, and on reports of light precipitation in parts of Oklahoma, Kansas and Nebraska.

THE three years which Stephen Foster spent as a bookkeeper in Cincinnati were extremely important both in the shaping of his career and in the actual beginnings of his work. His father had sent him to a position in his brother's shipping office in the hope that attention to prosaic business would drive his "strange talent" for music from his mind and heart.

In England this book was published under the title "Physician Heal Thyself," a much more appropriate title than has been given the American edition. "The Anniversary Murder" suggests a detective story, which it is not. It is highly probable that the author never intended it to be taken as anything but a study of the mind of a murderer.

IMPRESARIO of many modern European artists for more than a decade, J.B. Neumann is now showing for the first time at his "New Art Circle" a group of paintings by Mark Chagall. Mostly gouaches, with occasional use of oil and pastel, these decorative fantasies obviously have been influenced by Russian ikons.

Permission to hold a WPA protest meeting in Stuyvesant High School tomorrow night was denied to the City Projects Council yesterday by William J. McAuliffe, acting director of the Bureau of Extension Activities of the Board of Education. The meeting was called to set a date for a stoppage of the work on the four WPA Federal art projects, in protest against impending cuts in their personnel.

The third annual conference on guidance conducted by the Department of Psychology at Fordham University's Graduate School, 233 Broadway, will take place Thursday and Friday, it was announced yesterday by the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, S.J., president of the university.

THIS is the season in Washington when you are likely to find the nation's foremost bureaucrats in little rooms full of angry voices, huddled over interminable rows of figures. It is Federal budget-making time -- a season rich in neuroses, thick with doubts and miscalculation, dark with tempers and by no means unclouded with intrigues and subtle lobbying.

LONDON, Dec. 4. -- At a moment of growing peril in international affairs the people of Great Britain and the dominions have found themselves this week in the grip of an internal crisis that has shaken them emotionally and politically more than any event since the World War.

IN addition to being valuable additions to their respective catalogues, the number of instrumental records recently released -- particularly those featuring the piano, harpsichord and harp, solo -- offer an opportunity to note improvements in recording these instruments and consider some of the difficulties of reproduction that are the direct outcome of this progress.

Of 2,515,827 persons who were on the payrolls of the Works Progress Administration Oct. 15 officials hoped by the end of December to transfer 250,000 drought sufferers to the Resettlement Administration, to drop 5,000 administrative employes and 20,000 other non-relief workers and to eliminate another 150,000 cases by a general "combing-out" process.

More than 500 persons, including thirty-five boys and girls seated in the special section for minors, heeded a warning that there was nothing to worry about, and remained in their seats for nearly an hour yesterday afternoon as firemen extinguished a small blaze in a storage room behind the projection booth of the Momart Theatre at 590 Fulton Street, near Lafayette Avenue, in the downtown section of Brooklyn.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 5. -- The continuance of the Mongol-Manchukuoan attack on Suiyuan Province, coupled with Foreign Minister Hachiro Arita's abrupt rejection of China's protest against the landing of Japanese marines at Tsingtao has increased the tension between the two countries.

MARACAIB0, Venezuela. -- Investigation by the Venezuelan Government to ascertain what happened to the enormous royalties paid by foreign oil companies to the late Gomez government has revealed some curious details.

The swimmers of Evander Childs High School registered a startling upset yesterday, defeating De Witt Clinton High School, leader in the tourney for the Manhattan-Bronx-Richmond senior high school championship of the Public School Athletic League, at the ninth series of dual meets for the triborough title in the latters' seventy-five-foot pool.

Proud of its status as an experimental college despite the fact that it has made a solid place for itself in the field of higher education for women, Sarah Lawrence College at Bronxville, N.Y., will celebrate on Wednesday the tenth anniversary of the granting of its provisional charter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Following is the text of the opening address of Secretary of State Cordell Hull as chairman of the American delegation to the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace at Buenos Aires:

Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, outstanding as a leader of the peace movement in this country, has announced that she has "a special message" to convey to members of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs at a five-borough meeting of the organization on Tuesday at the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- A large number of constitutional amendments, most of them designed to keep America out of war or to broaden Federal control over agriculture and industry, will be introduced in the new Congress convening Jan. 5.

OMAHA, Dec. 4. -- On orders from Washington the Corn Belt farm States are attempting to taper off on WPA and exhibiting a good deal of distress over the effort. That distress is chiefly, if not altogether, a hangover from the drought, which not only imposes its own special problem of relief, but acts also as a brake on re-employment.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 5. -- A definite plan for merging, after graduation, the classes of Yale College, or the academic department, and the Sheffield Scientific School and the School of Engineering, the undergraduate departments of the university, has made headway, and predictions are made that as alumni the three class organizations will soon be one unit.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 5. -- Fourteen hundred guests, ranging in rank from presidents of the nation's great railroad lines to towermen, honored Carl R. Gray, president of the Union Pacific, and Mrs. Gray on the fiftieth anniversary of their marriage tonight.
BERLIN, Dec. 5. -- The whole Cabinet, National Socialist party notables and business and finance leaders were out in the streets today gathering pfennigs for the relief of the poor.

JOHN KESSLER'S "Introduction and Fugue" will receive its premiere at this week's concerts of the St. Louis Symphony Friday afternoon and Saturday night, under the direction of Vladimir Golschmann. The composer of the new work, which was finished last year, is a native of St. Louis, and has had several other of his works performed by the same forces.

THE Anne Brown Alumnae Free Nursery School will be the beneficiary of a card party to be held Friday afternoon in the Astor Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. The organization, located in the New York Kindergarten Association Building, 524 West Forty-second Street, provides all-day care for fifty children of pre-school age, giving them necessities, medical attention and instruction.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5. -- Johnny Layton of Sedalia, Mo., tightened his grip on first place in the world's three-cushion billiards tournament tonight by defeating Allen Hall of Chicago, 50 to 44, in a slow, forty-seven-inning duel. The victory gave Layton a record of five victories against one defeat.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- A total of 110,186,311 taxable gallons of liquor was released for consumption during the fiscal year 1936, an increase of 33.5 per cent over 1935, and during the first four months of the current fiscal year consumption continued at a slightly accelerated rate, the Internal Revenue Bureau announced today.

Increased attention on the manner in which stores are handling the carrying of installment accounts developed in the retail field yesterday as the result of the complaints issued by the Federal Trade Commission against leading automobile manufacturers with respect to the advertising of credit terms on car purchases.

VATICAN CITY, Dec. 5. -- For the first time in the fourteen years of his Pontificate Pope Pius XI, who entered his eightieth year on May 31, was obliged by illness to take to his bed, causing alarm to spread throughout Rome and the Catholic world despite the reassuring official statements put out by the Vatican.

AT 43 Brand Whitlock had lived a life rich, varied and useful, and he was ready to retire. He had worked with Altgeld, and had prepared that passionate protest against the judicial murder of the Chicago anarchists that cost Altgeld his popularity.

Announcement of the payment of a bonus to all employes of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., amounting to 2 per cent of each person's basic salary and aggregating $300,000, was made yesterday by Bernard F. Gimbel, president of the organization.

MR. STEVENS has always been a poet for whom the precise tone of an idea or a feeling was all-important, a poet for whom words had a life of their own. He is not a dramatic poet and not in the usual sense, a lyric poet pouring out his feeling in song.

AMONG the numbers to be played by Joseph Szigeti, violinist, in his "Outline of Three Centuries of Violin Literature," in Town Hall, Saturday afternoons, Jan. 16, 23 and 30, will be three short sonatas by Debussy, Ravel and Hindemith, presented as outstanding examples of the modern compositions in the form.

With Christmas trade advancing toward an early peak of holiday shopping, retail trade here moved forward on all fronts last week. Gains over a year ago of 15 per cent or more were estimated for department stores here over the comparative 1935 period.

Penny-wise Christmas shoppers who carefully budget their gift list are finding many attractive and inexpensive objects in the shops this season. A tour of city stores reveals many gifts suitable for the house and for the family's feminine relations at $5 or less.

Patrons and patronesses for the tenth annual "Colony House Capers" to be presented by the senior and junior guilds of Colony House, 297 Dean Street, Brooklyn, on Jan. 22 and 23 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, have been announced by Mrs. John R. Garnaus, chairman of the patroness committee, and Mrs. Donald B. Knight, co-chairman.

Presently home interiors will be garlanded with Christmas greens. To be sure that they will stay fresh and lustrous until Twelfth Night, it is of course necessary that the right material shall be chosen. Plants most often used are clubmoss and groundpine, both lycopodiums.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Dec. 5. -- A comprehensive program of "Sports Education" for men has been in operation at Swarthmore College for the past semester and will be enlarged during the Winter sports season, which has just begun.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- "If New York State is to regain its position of leadership in Winter sports, it is essential that more adequate ski trails be constructed under the supervision of the Conservation Department and that a definite, permanent policy for such development be formulated," Frederick T. Kelsey, president of the Adirondack Mountain Club, declared today at the State conference on skiing.

Except for a few dissenting voices from Indiana territory, the metropolitan district annually has turned out the best college basketball teams in the country. This coming season should prove no exception. When the quintets from all sections of the land invade New York for intersectional games, local court followers will need prepare no alibis.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 4. -- President Roosevelt's triumphal (there is no other word to describe it) tour of South American capitals on the Atlantic Coast has tended to obscure the initial work of the Conference for the Maintenance of Peace scheduled to meet here for some three weeks longer.

To add to the sorrows of Europe, the wine crop has failed. Most of the Bordeaux vineyards were nipped by frost early in October. Hailstorms last Spring played havoc with the Burgundy wines. The Moselle and Rhine areas had so bad a Summer that some growers left the grapes on the vines in hope of a better Autumn.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Dec. 5. -- Arthur Barnes, 12-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur S. Barnes of Locust Drive, Roslyn Heights, L.I. is in a critical condition tonight in North Country Community Hospital here from a bullet wound accidentally inflicted by his playmate, William Bissell, also 12, son of Mr. and Mrs. Karl Bissell of Wheatley Hills, L.I.

The stock market has completed another week in which movements of prices were indecisive. Favorable and unfavorable factors were almost in balance, with the scales tipping slightly in favor of the latter group. THE NEW YORK TIMES index of fifty issues declined 2.66 points on the week, against 0.31 point the week before.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Replying to protests of "white collar" members of the Workers Alliance of America, about twenty of whom came here today to insist that no workers be dropped from relief rolls, Aubrey Williams, Acting WPA Administrator, told them that lack of funds made it necessary to drop about 175,000 by Dec. 15, and that, in addition, another 250,000 would be transferred from drought relief to the Resettlement Administration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP). -- Widespread training of men and women for jobs in industry to prevent a future shortage of skilled workers was proposed today by W. Frank Persons, director of the United States Employment Service.

The new indoor polo season started with a double victory for two squadron teams at Squadron A Armory last night. Against Governors Island, the squadron with Joel Macy, Jay Secor and Major F.A. Vietor scored on the flat, 11 1/2 to 5.
CHICAGO, Dec. 5. -- The proposal to give financial aid to athletes of the Western Conference fell on deaf ears today.

BOSTON, Dec. 5. -- The Art Guild of Simmons College will sponsor an exhibition of modern French and American painting in color reproduction by the German "lichdruck" method from Dec. 6, to 20 as one of its first ventures in collaboration with student activities in the fine and applied arts.

Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, announced yesterday that Flushing Meadow Park would be the Central Park of Queens at the completion of the basic permanent improvements for the site of the World's Fair of 1939.

Seven early American silver tankards were sold for $14,950 yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries. They formed part of the collection of Mrs. Miles White Jr. of Baltimore, which the galleries auctioned Thursday, Friday and yesterday for $59,466.

THE editors first selected the year 1934; next searched newspapers for interesting events of the year; finally asked writers to compose brief sketches, one for each day, using the newspaper stories as their source of inspiration.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 5. -- A spirited attack upon the Federal surtax on undistributed income was the highlight in the report of the Federal taxation committee of the Investment Bankers Association of America, which was presented today. The committee is headed by T. Stockton Matthews of Robert Garrett Sons, Baltimore.

Two ski runs and a ski tow will be Winter sports features this season in the Bear Mountain section of Palisades Interstate Park of New York and New Jersey, the commissioners of the park announced yesterday. The facilities will be ready for use by Christmas with the first good snow.
TO those who cannot content themselves without a thorougn understanding of music this book will become required reading.

These essays by the famous Spanish modernist of the Ecole de Paris were first published over here in, respectively. The Arts for May, 1923, and Creative Art for June, 1930. Picasso's aphoristic enunciation of his credo can often prove arresting, but not when the meat reappears as hash.

BELGIANS are to continue indefinitely the poetic custom of sounding at evening a bugle call to the tens of thousands of British soldiers without known graves who fell fighting in the Ypres salient during the World War.

The court of last resort in the controversy between King Edward and the government and the Church of England must be the people of the British Isles and the dominions, Lady Rhondda told an American radio audience yesterday in a broadcast over WEAF and the Red Network of the National Broadcasting System.
LONDON, Dec. 5. -- Lord Dawson of Penn, the royal physician, said today that King Edward was in "excellent health."
Those long, grueling hours of Christmas shopping, during which the mind and body -- and especially the feet -- grow weary, are here again, but there is a ray of hope.
The annual dance of the Junior Guild of Yonkers on Dec. 29 at the Hudson River Country Club will benefit St. Johns Riverside Hospital.

FOR the pre-holiday sales the main center of interest in the auction rooms will be Sotheby's of London. Two unusually large and well-documented catalogues have been issued, describing collections of major importance, the Napoleon Library of Mr. Emile Brouwet and the Ant. W.M. Mensing Library of fine bindings, illuminated manuscripts and early printed books.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Though Congress delegated to the General Land Office in 1812 the job of surveying the United States, progress has been so slow under the appropriations available, that there are still 182,000,000 acres of land that have never been surveyed, the Department of Interior recently revealed.

LONDON, NOV. 20. YOUNG MADAME CONTI," by Bruno Frank, adapted by Hubert Griffith and Benn Levy, is a play which stands on the border-line between plain melodrama and serious analysis of human suffering in circumstances of extreme violence.
MOSCOW, Dec. 4. -- Events are impressively vindicating the Soviet Union's military strategy and the terrific speed with which it has armed itself.

THIS work is devoid of any attempted popularization or any summary of the background of the Freudian psychoanalytic theory. Assuming that his reader is acquainted with the structure and terminology of psychoanalysis, Freud immediately begins his discussion of the problem of anxiety as it stands in relation to symptom formation, the general nature of inhibitions and certain modifications of his views concerning the functions of the ego and the id.

An amendment to the Social Security Act to bring within its provisions more than 174,000 employes of member banks of the Federal Reserve System who now are excluded in desired by a majority of the bankers of the country, according to bankers here who recently have been discussing the question.

EASTVILLE, Va., Dec. 5 (AP). -- Russell F. Randolph, retired New Jersey banker, who had been missing for more than two months, informed his family of his whereabouts today. He said he might leave for home "tonight" or might decide to remain in Eastville "another month" or perhaps "a year."

The rise in freight and passenger traffic has resulted in purchases of rolling stock by the railroads which will make the total for 1936 the largest since the depression. This year's buying, moreover, will compare favorably with some of the figures for years before the depression.

Ch. Dewet Von Der Starrenburg, handsome German shepherd dog owned by the Giralda Farm of Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge, was judged best in show last night as the twenty-second annual Bronx County Kennel Club exhibition came to an end at the 105th Field Artillery Armory.

WITH not a gray hair to her head, and not so much as an incipient case of crow's-feet or what the beauty parlors nastily designate as "crepey neck," Edith Fellows is the veteran of over a hundred pictures.

Members of society both here and in Europe will be among the guests at the annual Christmas party to be held Tuesday afternoon at the British Empire Exhibition's Salon on the top floor of the British Building, 620 Fifth Avenue. A feature of the party will be the "Wassail Bowl," one of the oldest English customs at the holiday season.

PRAGUE, Dec. 4. -- The power of dictatorship to threaten the peace of the world by confusing with propaganda the minds of millions even beyond its own frontiers is shown in the reiterated German assertions that Czechoslovakia is an outpost of bolshevism.

Advice on how the "women's field army" of the American Society for the Control Of Cancer might best "dislodge the five-key psychological logs at the center of the general dam that blocks efforts to control cancer through education" is being sought, the society announced yesterday.

KATHERINE KINGSTON did not murder her husband; that goes without saying. But if this were real life, instead of a detective story, she would not stand a ghost of a chance of escaping conviction. Before Inspector McKee appears on the scene the District Attorney has a clear-cut case against Katherine.

More than 200 personalities in the world of music attended a dinner last night at the headquarters of the Beethoven Association, 30 West Fifty-sixth Street, in celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the American debut of Efrem Zimbalist, the violinist, who was the guest of honor.

The holders of low numbered or distinctive automobile license plates renewed the registrations on their vehicles and were enabled to keep the special plates another year, it was disclosed yesterday at the Bureau of Motor Vehicles, 80 Center Street.

The collection of arms and armor, tapestries and paintings belonging to Frank Gair Macomber of Boston will be sold at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Thursday, Friday and Saturday afternoons.

Those frequent visitors, the New England Singers, had a pleasing novelty to offer on their program at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. For the first time here they presented a group of lute songs. These were given with lute accompaniment, and included examples of all the vocal combinations employed in connection with that instrument in the days when the lute was in its heydey of popularity.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Dec. 5. -- Beekman Pool of New York, former national squash racquets champion and defending trophy holder, was eliminated from the gold racquet tournament in the opening round today at the Rockaway Hunting Club.

THE most remarkable thing about Mr. O'Sullivan book is that it has been praised by Bernard Shaw as being "the first sane and credible description" of Wilde and a necessary publication to "clean up the superfluous mud that has been heaped on the story of Oscar Wilde's last days in Paris."

The constitutional crisis which arose in London last week affects directly the whole British Empire. The King, as the only symbol to which the entire realm owes allegiance, is the link that binds together the strange and vast alliance of communities which make up the empire.

MONTREAL, Dec. 5 (AP). -- The Montreal Canadiens came from behind in a brilliant third-period rally to defeat the Boston Bruins, 4 -- 3, tonight and go into the lead in the International Group of the National Hockey League. The victory put the Flying Frenchmen a point ahead of the New York Americans, idle until tonight.

FEVERISH activity has returned to Geneva. In the spacious corridors of the new League palace, whose lofty windows frame Mount Blanc, there is life again. Diplomats, League officials and journalists are talking and speculating on one question: What will be the effect on Geneva of the Spanish controversy which has suddenly burst over the League?

PHILATELIC exchanges, designed to provide a clearing house for postage stamps for collectors, dealers and speculators indulging in large-scale operations, are the outgrowth of the recent broad trading in this field and of the rapid changes in the prices of many issues.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 5. -- Permission to produce two proposed musical comedies, "Yale on Bail" and "Lily Guilder's," has been refused to an undergraduate student organization by Deans Clarence W. Mendell and Charles H. Warren of the academic department and the Sheffield Scientific School.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. CHESTER, at Sea, Dec. 5 (AP). -- President Roosevelt, en route to the United States aboard the Cruiser Indianapolis, feasted tonight on fish chowder after a turn in his luck as a fisherman.

The partnership which made zoography and paleontology matters of beauty and interest as well as science has combined again to produce a sort of geographical directory of the world's reptiles. The number of species, as described by Dr. Ditmars in his preface, which is a brief characterization of the reptiles and their scientific groupings, is staggering, but out of this embarrassment of numbers he brings a clear-cut order.

JOHN STUART MILL has a message for the twentieth century, and particularly for the United States. The late Dr. S. Parkes Cadman aptly stated Mill's position: "His influence on his generation was enormous and if advocates of democracy, political economy and moralists of today see further than their fathers, it is because they stand on the shoulders of John Stuart Mill."

Medical education in the United States is entering a wholly new phase, Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, dean of the Columbia University School of Medicine, announces in his annual report to be issued this week.

IT has become a Christmas Eve custom, since the days of Calvin Coolidge, for the broadcasters to place their microphones around the community Christmas Tree in Lafayette Square, Washington, and from that ceremony radio to the nation the President's Yuletide greetings.

Under a combination of profit-taking and hedging operations coincident with less aggressive mill calling, prices on the Cotton Exchange eased 3 to 8 points yesterday. After the active trading earlier in the week, the market quieted materially but disclosed scale-buying limits on slight recessions.

Following a brisk start yesterday when active buying of petroleum shares influenced slightly higher prices generally throughout the list, the stock market quieted down and moved irregularly thereafter. The closing was mixed, with the oil stocks finishing strong.

The Huntington Family Association, descendants of Simon Huntington of Norwich, England, who went to Dorchester, Mass., in 1632, gave a luncheon yesterday in the Regency Room of the Weylin. The last reunion of the association, which has been in existence almost seventy-five years, was held in 1927 in Norwich, Conn.

The Municipal Art Committee of the City of New York, appointed by Mayor La Guardia to further art activities, is extending its work far beyond the bounds of the city, according to Mrs. Henry Breckinridge, chairman.

High-school girls who count their hours in the office of the school paper among the best of their school life, whose envisioned futures invariably include a typewriter and desk in some hazily pictured city room, will revel in this story of the making of a girl reporter.

AMHERST, Mass., Dec. 5. -- An advanced course in extemporaneous public speaking is being taught in a new way at Massachusetts State College this year. It is organized without a single formal lecture. The course draws its students from nearly every division of the college.
Frank Darvall, British lecturer, told in a broadcast over the Columbia Broadcasting System last night of the quiet he had found in London.

THE 85,000 Americans who are annual visitors to the United Kingdom will be saved $8 apiece on passport visas after April 1, when the present $10 fee will be cut to $2. Of course, if they continue their travels to the Continent, they must pay the additional tariffs charged by many of the countries there, but these are seldom excessive.

The general tenor of your four recent editorials about Japan is critical of Japanese action in Manchuria and North China. You give an excellent summary of Japanese actions on the Asiatic mainland, from the twenty-one demands on China during the World War to Japan's present activities in Inner Mongolia.

James R. Garfield and George B. Cortelyou, both of whom served in the Cabinet of the late President Theodore Roosevelt, will assist Mrs. John Henry Hammond, president of the Woman's Roosevelt Memorial Association, in receiving at the first in a series of receptions for this season of that organization tomorrow afternoon at Roosevelt House, 28 East Twentieth Street.

LONDON, Dec. 5. -- Apart from the merits of the constitutional crisis which has arisen between the King and his governments throughout the empire, the fact that the crisis has arisen is a tribute to the honesty and straight-forwardness of King Edward's character.

Former Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley, Republican nominee for Governor who was defeated by Governor Lehman in the recent election, replied last night to reports that he was a contender for the State chairmanship of his party with the declaration: "I will not be the State chairman and will not select him."

PLOWSHARES ONLY: Carl Hallaur, vice president of the Bausch Lomb Optical Company of Rochester, N.Y., revealed last week that the firm had rejected millions of dollars' worth of contracts to make artillery fire-control instruments for foreign armies.

Like a singing tea kettle, the aftermath of last September's unfortunate collision at Washington in the President's Cup Race recurrently boils up and then simmers down every few weeks. There is beginning to be a suspicion that the George Reis-Herbert Mendelsohn case, started when the two famous Gold Cup craft, El Lagarto and Notre Dame, came together in a crack-up, sinking the former, may be a cause celebre for weeks and months to come.

A SECTION of the old Cincinnati-Pittsburgh stage-coach trail has been restored as a nature trail by the Civilian Conservation Corps, which is working in the John Bryan State Park of Ohio. The restored portion runs through the park near Yellow Springs in Clark County.

Miss Caroline Faison is chairman of entertainment for the supper dance to be given by the Junior League of Brooklyn on Dec. 19 at the Towers, Brooklyn. During the supper hour there will be an entertainment by professionals.

Agitation over high taxes remains active as is indicated in the announcement by the women's division of the New York State Economic Council that it plans a drive to enlist all women of any political persuasion who are interested in the theme.

The bicycle breakfast established here last Winter as a wheel version of the traditional hunt breakfast will have its first anniversary today when a large group of young members of society will cycle down Fifth Avenue to Le Coq Rouge in East Fifty-sixth Street for a late breakfast, or "brunch," followed by a program of bicycle races and a special entertainment.

A bit of old New York -- specifically a section of the Bowery in its heyday a few decades ago -- was revived and transplanted last night to the immense drill hall of the Seventh Regiment Armory to form the setting for the annual Fall military ball given by members of the regiment.

EMERSON would doubtless have described Mr. Bragdon as "the man of the world as mystic," or by some similar phrase; and that would be a wholly suitable description even today. For if the present man of the world needs anything (and he needs much) it is a touch of those spiritual forces and interests roughly grouped under the term of mysticism.
ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 5 (AP). -- The first man to read the best-selling novel, "Gone With the Wind," finds himself in an enviable position. He can say "I told you so," and his wife has no defense.

BARNARD COLLEGE, now beginning preparations for the celebration of its fiftieth anniversary, offers to its 1,014 students a wealth of varied supplements to academic courses. To an important degree America's largest city, with great institutions of government, finance, industry, science and art, constitutes a laboratory to reinforce campus facilities.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 5. -- One of the first steps in the program of segregation of the functions of broker and dealer on Stock Exchanges will be a tightening by Federal authorities of the credit restrictions on trading by members of organized security markets, it was made known here today by James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 5. -- Disputes today over technical questions jammed the machinery of the inter-American conference's committee on organization of peace, the most important subdivision of the parley, and the committee on intellectual cooperation.

HELIGOLAND, celebrated fortress-isle of the World War, has come into a new fame of late. Europeans fun Central and Northern Africa have reported during recent months the capture of migrating birds bearing small metal leg rings inscribed "Vogelwarte, Heligoland."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Cotton of white middling or better in grade formed 36 per cent of the cotton classified in the week ended on Dec. 3, the last weekly grade and staple report of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics for this crop season showed today.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 5. -- Lieutenant Luke Christopher, veteran marine and Coast Guard pilot, was killed today and two others aboard his seaplane were injured seriously when the craft, which was carrying an injured seaman, crashed into Chincoteague Inlet, off the Virginia East Coast.
Still in the warm-up process and far from a finished product, the Long Island University Blackbirds made the University of Newark quintet their thirty-fifth straight victim, 56 -- 13, last night.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5. -- Striking at the heart of the automobile accident problem at least eighteen States are now, or soon will be, waging definite campaigns for the passage of standard drivers' license laws or to bring existing laws up to standard.

Production of gold in the United States in October amounted to 450,000 fine ounces, compared with 407,000 in September and 369,000 in October, 1935, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics. For the first ten months of the year it was 3,549,000 ounces, almost equaling the output for all of 1935, which was 3,619,000 ounces.

AN expert recently predicted that 8,000 new books would be published in the United States during 1936. Three-quarters of them, he says, will disappear almost stillborn, so there remains not more than a scant quarter that can achieve the service stripe of a reprinting.
ROCHESTER, Dec. 5. -- The State committee of the Socialist party voted today support of three industrial strikes and adopted a ten-point program for protection of farmers and workers.

ONE HUNDRED THOUSAND people packed the Grand Palais for the first Sunday of the fifteenth Exposition International de l'Aeronatique. In the morning they stood hundreds deep waiting for the doors to open -- they pushed and fought for a chance to put down five francs for a ticket -- they stood for hours all afternoon in queues that reached into the Champs-Elysees in one direction and to the Pont Alexandre III in the other.

OUT of the Hollywood of romantic sugar plums, squirrel-cage melodrama and problem plays with pulled punches, there has come at last, in the "Winterset" of Pandro S. Berman and Alfred Santell, a mature, purposeful drama, frankly outspoken in its argument, courageous in its conclusions and zealously played by a superbly chosen cast.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 5. -- The luck of the Irish deserted Notre Dame today and University of Southern California's Trojans scored once on a 65-yard sprint and again on a 100-yard dash to tie the famed Green of South Bend, 13 to 13.

THE scene of this steep tale is the village of St. Bruno, on the northeast shore of the Bay of Fundy, its fantastic heroine Armande, beauteous present-day descendant of Norman nobles, called by the superstitious local peasantry, because of her weird ways, the "Moon Witch." One storm-racked Autumn night there is tossed up by the raging waters of the Bay, and salvaged by Armande, a shipwrecked, unconscious American seaman.

HUGH WALPOLE, English novelist, may have more to say on these matters when he opens his lecture tour here at the Lyceum Theatre next Sunday, but right now he feels that American critics of the British cinema are correct when they point out that two common faults of English films are lack of action in the stories and a deficiency in technical skill in the production.

Even at this early date the women squash racquets players have everything pretty well lined up for a big season. Locally the group team matches and metropolitan club team championship will be out of the way by the Christmas holidays, and all will be in readiness for the various State events and the national championship after the new year.

VIENNA, Dec. 5. -- Objections raised against the reappearance in Vienna of Gertrude Ruenger, German soprano engaged by the Metropolitan Opera Company for the coming season, will bar her participation as scheduled in Bruno Walter's new production of Verdi's "Don Carlos" on Dec. 16.

Mrs. Charles Edward Tracy gave the first of two teas for her grandniece, Miss Joan Ellett, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Ellett of 164 East Seventy-second Street, yesterday at her home, 170 East Seventy-ninth Street. The second will be given today.

OHIO'S buckeye tree, from which the State derives its nickname, is still flourishing. This may seem strange to those who visit Ohio towns and villages and find buckeyes pointed out as rarities, but the State Forester reports that in Central Ohio, where there are many well-watered ravines, young buckeyes grow abundantly.

WITH more resilience than we had believed possible, Hollywood already has recovered from, and probably forgotten, its recent gala premiere at the Carthay Circle. It was the opening of the Twentieth Century-Fox picture "Lloyds of London," and it was an event so refulgent that a comparison-seeker would have to describe it in terms of a Windsor coronation, a Delhi Durbar or the circus's first night at Madison Square Garden.

VIENNA, Dec. 5. -- Ferdinand Kurt Hahn, illegitimate son of the Archduke Francis Ferdinand, the Austro-Hungarian Crown Prince murdered at Sarajevo in 1914, is suing his father's legitimate son and heir, Prince Max Hohenberg, in a local court for a monthly allowance of $200.

HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 5. -- The Amateur Athletic Union's forty-eighth convention, which is expected to see a complete shake-up of administration before it closes tomorrow, battled today through a broken field of arguments that brought into the open for the first time echoes of the stormy 1935 split on Olympic issues.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- European nations now owe the United States $12,168,255,970.79 on the World War debts, exclusive of $155,093,973.74 which will be due on Dec. 15. Whether there is a reasonable chance of reaching agreements which would result in resumption of payments by nations in default is a question pondered here.

CUSTOM underscores for us the fact that our local art seasons are strongly inclined to be epidemic rather than episodic. The French phase is still at flood tide, augmented by a few fresh entries, reported elsewhere today. But now another "run" has established itself.
FOR the Hundred Neediest Cases of New York City the twenty-fifth annual appeal is made by THE NEW YORK TIMES today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The President has lost the only man who called him "pal" to his face. Others -- Secretaries Early and McIntyre -- greet the nation's head as "chief," but to the former New York policeman, who served as guard, nurse, masseur and gay companion, the head of the world's most powerful nation was "pal."

PARIS, Dec. 5. -- All those experienced men in France, from Edouard Herriot downward, who believed four years ago that it was an immense mistake for France to suspend war debt payments to the United States are at work trying to get payment restarted.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- Larry Kelley, Yale's spectacular end; Carl (Mutt) Ray, Dartmouth's 200-pound center, and John Handrahan, 185-pound line-smashing fullback for Dartmouth, today accepted invitations to play with the All-East eleven against the All-West team on the Coast, Coach Andy Kerr of Colgate announced.

Freezing weather, which has temporarily at least put an end to the planting of bulbs out of doors, in no way interferes with their preparation for Winter bloom indoors. Many varieties excellent for "forcing" are still to be had, and thrifty gardeners take advantage of end-of-the-season sales of tulips, daffodils and many of the smaller bulbs which are always held at this season of the year.

A well-known Paris dressmaker now in town says that a woman's wardrobe should display quality rather than quantity. Her words will be widely quoted in millions of domestic sales talks, for the glad holiday season is at hand.

THE TIMES makes today its twenty-fifth annual appeal for the Neediest Cases in this city, and as evidence that a generous response is urgently required asks consideration of the statement made to it by the directors of the public relief agencies in New York and published in this issue. That statement explains a point which may trouble some of our readers.

Brooklyn Tech's No. 1 team, P.S. A.L. champions and unbeaten in schoolboy competition this season, captured both the individual and team laurels yesterday in the first annual City College invitation interscholastic rifle tournament.

PEIPING. -- No appreciation of the Japanese position in China can be correct which regards Japan's policy there as being unified or under a single control. It is therefore essential to a true understanding to analyze the various policies that are being followed, to trace out the areas in which they are being put into effect and to note who is behind them.

ONION-GROWERS, seeking to make their pungent, aromatic product more popular, have aroused scientific and culinary circles. The scientists, in a well-meaning effort to give the onion new sales appeal, have offered to develop a scentless onion.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 5. -- Fifty Baltimore girls and a score of out-of-town girls, mostly from New York and Philadelphia, will make their debuts at the Bachelors' Cotillon here on Monday night.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 5. -- Alumnae of Radcliffe College are to share in completing the new undergraduate dormitory, construction of which is now well under way on Walker Street. The building, which is to be ready for occupancy in the Fall of 1937, will be a unit housing seventy-two students, and will be attached to Whitman Hall by means of joint serving quarters.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 5. -- Charles E. Robinson, the suave, dapper Englishman who is accused of swindling Frederick C. Tuttle, vice president of the Peters Cartridge Company of Cincinnati, out of $30,000, lost some of his aplomb today when United States Commissioner Joseph F. Holland fixed bail at $25,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4. -- For the second time this Fall the suggestion has been made publicly that Governor George H. Earle be impeached for his "hands-off" policy in Pennsylvania's bootleg coal mining situation.

While a more-than-seasonal slowing up of retail trade may feature the early months of next year, merchandising executives do not believe the reaction will be prolonged or that it will reverse the upward trend in sales so strongly manifest during the present year.

Curtis High School of Staten Island closed its season successfully yesterday afternoon, defeating Manchester Central High of New Hampshire by the score of 13 to 0, in its second intersectional test of the year. The White warriors bowed 13 -- 12 to Marblehead High of Massachusetts earlier this season.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 5. -- How designs for articles common to every household, from towels to liquor bottles, are first conceived and later developed into the finished product will be shown in an exhibit opening Monday in the School of Architecture of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

TIRELESS engineers continue to hurdle or to bore beneath the broad moats that for years had kept Manhattan Island a towering fortress nearly impregnable to traffic. A few days ago the Port of New York Authority announced that work would begin soon on the long-projected second tube of the Midtown Hudson Tunnel, the first tube of which has been under construction for eighteen months.

STANISLAVSKI stands by nature and truth. He has a great nature sense and out of that springs truth that is fire. This exciting fact, which was so evident in his beautiful and masterfully searching "My Life in Art," is more apparent than ever in his long-awaited book on the training of actors.
