WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Coincident with the increasing political and military uncertainties in the Far East and the negotiations of the German-Japanese accord, purchases of airplanes from the United States by nations situated in or interested in the Orient took a sharp upward bound during November, according to the monthly report of the exports of arms, ammunition and implements of war just issued by the State Department.

Lord Marley, chief Opposition "whip" in the British House of Lords, said yesterday at a luncheon of the Foreign Policy Association at the Hotel Astor that he "would support the King in any matter touching upon his right to marry." His statement was greeted by laughter and applause.

Mrs. Cleveland E. Dodge, Mrs. John H. Finley and Mrs. Harvey N. Davis head a group of women in New York and the Metropolitan district who are sponsoring the annual bazaar and sale of handicraft made by Near Eastern refugees, which will open tomorrow at the headquarters of the Near East Foundation and will continue there throughout the week.

An art exhibit of seventy-five paintings by clubwomen will be opened Thursday at the Montclair Art Museum. It comprises an innovation in the program of the New Jersey Federation of Women's Clubs, and is expected to draw an excellent attendance before the closing of the show on Dec. 27.

A group of sixty men, fifty-one of whom were seized in a single raid on an alleged Harlem disorderly house early yesterday morning, were subjected to examinations by Health Department doctors yesterday prior to their arraignment in Harlem Court before Magistrate Anna M. Kross, who called in the doctors. Nine of the men were taken in other raids.

It was a gracious gesture on the part of John Barbirolli, thus early in his career in this country, to add an American work to the repertoire of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, as he did at last night's student concert of that organization.

TWO anniversary concerts of unusual interest will be given this week in New York. One of these will be the violin recital of Efrem Zimbalist, celebrating the twenty-fifth anniversary of his American debut. That event occurred when he played the Glazunoff concerto with the Boston Symphony Orchestra in Boston, Oct. 27, 1911.

The annual Christmas song festival and dance of the People's Chorus of New York will take place on the night of Dec. 18 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Plans for the entertainment have just been announced by Mrs. John Henry Hammond, chairman of the organization, and her first vice chairmen, Mrs. Walter Ewing Hope, Mrs. Dunlevy Milbank, Mrs. Arthur Poillon and Mrs. Marshall Prentiss.

HOLIDAY trade moved up to boom proportions in the week and from reports received here the business probably averaged about 18 per cent over a year ago. The Pacific Coast was the only section to lag, due to continuation of the maritime strike.

The elimination of Franklin V. Brodil of the Columbia University Club, seeded sixth, and the narrow escape from defeat of F. Barry Ryan Jr., top-ranking entrant of Short Hills, featured the day's play in the Fall scratch tournament of the National Squash Tennis Association at the City A.C. yesterday.

AT frequent intervals during the last year or two a young, unknown actress has been skipping onto the world stage and stealing the spotlight from her elders. Most of the other players knew her only by name. Most of the audience knew her not at all. But whoever she might be, one thing was clear. She was nobody's understudy.

IN order that our community may be successful in establishing a definite program for the avoidance of highway accidents, and the promotion of traffic safety, we must have interest and cooperation from many sources.

Orchids were for years considered the rarest plants in cultivation. The sources of supply for rare types were sections of tropical America and Asia. Plant collectors from many countries gathered with difficulty specimens from their native habitats and at great expense shipped them to sections where they were grown in greenhouses and conservatories.

BOSTON, Dec. 4. -- The Police Department of Boston is in turmoil and the citizens are seriously disturbed over the possibility that many policemen who went on strike seventeen years ago will be reinstated by the new head of that department.

THESE lines, quoted by Mr. Ukers from Antoinette Rotan Peterson's poem "The Old Tea Master of Kyoto," to which he refers as "the best English interpretation of the Japanese Tea Ceremony in terms of poetic imagery might well have stood at the head of the opening chapter of this truly delightful history of the tea plant's 1,600 years of beneficent ministry to man's comfort and esthetic pleasure.

JUST in case there is any dispute over footprints at the Polo Grounds today where the Boston Redskins will be wrestling with the Giants for Eastern play-off honors in the National Football League, George, the Well-Dressed Marshall Man, has sent word that he is prepared to furnish his own evidence this time. He is bringing a wide assortment of favorable footprints with him.

NOVEMBER'S air was ideal for long distance short-wave reception and December is equaling the results. During the past week the peace-and-good-will broadcasts from South America have been quite in contrast with the short-wave news flashes from European centers that told of war and preparations for war.

CHICOUTIMI, Que., Dec. 5. -- Seven children and their convalescing mother, who died in a vain effort to rescue her family, were burned to death last night when flames from a gasoline explosion swept their little farm home in the isolated village of St. Ambroise, twenty miles north of here on the Saguenay River.

Under the auspices of a joint committee of the Judson Health Center and the Smith College alumnae a special day at the exhibition of seventeenth-century Dutch art now in progress at the Schaeffer Gallery, 61 East Fifty-seventh Street, has been planned for next Friday.
Keating Hall, a new Graduate School building of Fordham University, will be dedicated today at services at which Cardinal Hayes, Archbishop of the Diocese of New York, will officiate.

Artists, high school principals, art teachers and students who have benefited by its scholarships yesterday praised the School Art League at its twenty-seventh annual meeting at Sherry's, 300 Park Avenue.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 5. -- The Princeton hockey team opened its season today by defeating the M.I.T. Sextet, 7 -- 3, in Baker Rink, handing the Engineers their second straight defeat of the 1936-37 schedule.

THAT The Saturday Review is the only purely literary journal in these parts to have survived the depression is a tribute to Mr. Canby's prudent and generous editing. As he gives way to Mr. De Voto, he may look back with satisfaction on the records his paper has presented contemporary literature fairly and squarely, with a nice balance between the professor and the public, an absence of blurb and an assured presence of mind.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 5. -- Horton Smith, Chicago professional, retained the lead in the $10,000 Miami Biltmore open golf tournament today with a 36-hole score of 137.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP). -- An indictment charging two residents of New York and a lawyer here with making a false registration statement for securities was thrown out today by Justice Peyton Gordon of the Federal District Court on the ground that it was not sufficiently specific.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Dec. 4. -- Vermonters saw with mixed emotions this week the Governor of their State, Charles M. Smith of Rutland, arrested in connection with the alleged embezzlement by a bank bookkeeper of funds from the Marble Savings Bank, Rutland, of which the Governor is president.

THE sweeping movement of Winter sports activities, which during the past five years has assumed vast proportions, seems likely to reach its greatest height this season. A full program for competitions and recreation has already been arranged for the thousands who soon will be seeking their favorite places for skiing, skating, ice-boating, skate-sailing, tobogganing and bob-sledding.

Four bequests, provided for by friends of the Fund who wished their contributions to the Hundred Neediest Cases to continue after they themselves had passed on, have been added in the last twelve months to the increasingly lengthening roster of such gifts.

THE Metropolitan Opera will open its season with one of the great music-dramas -- Richard Wagner's "Die Walkuere." The last time Wagner was thus honored at the Metropolitan was in 1901, when Maurice Grau launched the season with "Tristan und Isolde."

JUST before the turn of the century, when New York was enjoying one of its gayest eras, when, as Jimmie Walker recently remarked, there was neighborhood spirit, there were a few women in the firmament who helped to make the city intimate and romantic. Youths went to see them in the theatre and lost their hearts, just as completely as any moonstruck maiden ever lost hers to James K. Hackett.

Miss Kate Larned will give a tea tomorrow at the Montparnasse for a group of debutantes who will display carriage costumes of bygone eras at the fashion showing to be held in conjunction with a luncheon at the same restaurant next Sunday under the auspices of the Cooperative Committee of the Big Sisters as a part of the drive for funds to carry on its work.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- Hundreds of deer hunters are in the Berkshires for the start of the open season on deer tomorrow morning. Camps and taverns in the small towns have been opened, wood piled high around the fireplaces and huge stores of provisions laid in, for the deer chasers are a hungry crew.

With actual and projected legislation destined to "freeze" such a large portion of the competitive element in business, marketing and advertising will play a more important role in the coming few years than ever before, according to authorities in the field here yesterday.

THE results of the American Bridge League tournament in Chicago last week should put to rest for a while the talk about "standardization" of bidding systems. It is not hard to remember the time, a few years ago, when one could visit a dozen tables of bridge and see as many different systems in use.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 4. -- The first women's secret vigilance committee ever formed in the Southwest has been organized as "The Women's Investigating Committee of 500."

THE new Wodehouse book is one of the best. It has a fine fresh tang because it has a new angle. Its bright slant goes off at a tangent that touches familiar situations with new implications. A typical Wodehouse pip-pip character in Hollywood is warranted to produce good comedy and Wodehouse has used that combination.

The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, will open to the public on Wednesday morning an "Exhibition of Fantastic Art, Dada and Surrealism." The show is to remain on view through Jan. 27, except on Christmas Day and New Year's Day, when the museum will be closed.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Dec. 5. -- The United Chapters of Phi Beta Kappa and the Alpha of Virginia chapter celebrated today at the College of William and Mary, scene of the society's founding, the 160th anniversary of the famous scholarship organization.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Dec. 5. -- Undergraduate students of sociology at Smith College are receiving an unusual opportunity this year to apply sociological theory to practical research in the community. From among the class of seventy-five studying social disorganization, cooperative research squads have been organized under the direction of Professor Howard Becker of the department of sociology.
READING, Pa., Dec. 5 (AP). -- Sheriff Cook and his deputies escorted sixty-three prisoners today from the overcrowded Berks County jail to new quarters in neighboring counties.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The problem of re-employment of middle-aged and older workers has become increasingly pertinent, as broadening industrial revival has brought steady gains in general employment. President Roosevelt recently urged business to give its attention to these groups, it being believed that they may not be sharing in the work upswing.

The Charity Organization Society, 20 Exchange Place, gave assistance last year to 21,000 persons, of whom more than one-third were children under 16 years old, according to a pamphlet issued yesterday by the Family Service Fund Committee of the society in connection with its campaign for $603,000.

As the first step in a movement to encourage and aid American schools and colleges to include a brief study of the civil service merit system in their curricula, the Committee on Education in the Merit System of the National Civil Service Reform League yesterday made public an outline of the status of civil service and a definite program for merit system expansion.
The annual Winter Gambol, dinner and ball of The Lambs, veteran theatrical club, was held last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria with some 1,200 members and guests present.
TORONTO, Dec. 5 (AP). -- The Toronto Telegram today reviewed the background of Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson and said:

Next Saturday and Sunday the final field trial meeting of the year for English springer spaniels will be contested over the preserves of the Ingham Hill Game Farm at Saybrook, Conn. The prize will be the Walton Ferguson Jr. Perpetual Memorial Trophy, which has just been offered by many friends of the late sportsman.

High praise for the efficiency and organization of American hospitals and medical centers was expressed by Dr. Ramon Palacio Posse who sailed early yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Clara, having completed a three-month survey of American medical methods for the Argentine Government.

THIS is, I hope, one of those occasions on which a reviewer may assume the first person with greater ease both to himself and his readers. I have both an advantage and a disadvantage in trying to write about Fremont Older, and about a book dealing with Fremont Older.

LONDON, Dec. 5 (Canadian Press). -- Sunderland is back at the top of the English Football League. Deposed a week ago by Portsmouth, the Roker Park team returned as pace-setter by virtue of a smashing 5-1 victory over the strong Grimsby Town squad today.

THE era of highway construction in this country began scarcely two decades ago. During this period the amounts spent for roads and streets have increased until they approximate $2,000,000,000 each year. But, even with the expenditure of these enormous sums, only a small beginning has been made in the task of constructing adequate roads.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 5. -- Rose Bowl football officials opened the day's mail and sighed with relief. Bombarded for twenty-four hours by a cross-fire of criticism over the selection of Pittsburgh as the Eastern opponent in the annual New Year's Day game, they had reason to welcome the mail.
The earliest fixed date in history is 4236 B.C., the late Dr. James H. Breasted, noted Egyptologist, re ported in "Time and Its Mysteries," which the New York University Press published yesterday.

SUFFERN, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- Mrs. Marjorie Anderson McConnell, wife of David H. McConnell Jr., perfume manufacturer, was found dead in the McConnell garage this morning, wedged betwen the rear of her car and the garage door. Dr. John C. Dingman of Spring Valley, Rockland County Coroner, said tonight that while his investigation had not been completed he was convinced that death was accidental.

MUCH is expected of the new State Choir in Moscow, which consists of some 130 voices, under the direction of A.V. Svenchnikoff. In addition to the chief choral works of Bach and Handel, the organization intends to present "a cappella" music, such as the madrigals of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries.

With peace negotiations in the thirty-seven-day-old maritime strike on the West Coast apparently in a bog of hopelessness, Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins intimated in an interview in Lincoln, Neb., yesterday that the efforts of Federal mediators had borne fruit, and declared the strike would come to "an early close."

The proposed merger of the New York and Queens Electric Light and Power Company and the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., has been threatened, if not halted, by a decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn which is considered of vital importance to all kinds of minority stockholders.

Some of the difficulties encountered by the modern student who would reconstruct the picture of Sumerian culture are hinted at by Dr. Woolley in his foreword. It seems that a kind of schematic outline was drawn up by Sumerian scribes about 2000 B.C.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 5 (AP). -- Dwight Sloan, slim University of Arkansas junior, drove his passing Porkers to their first undisputed Southwest Conference championship and a 6-to-0 victory over the University of Texas today on a field reduced to a morass by a cold-driving rain.

ON the cover of his lovely red and blue catalogue prepared by Pierre Matisse, the Spanish surrealist Joan Miro gives us the black hand. But while elements of black magic may seem to obtrude now and then in the exhibition at Mr. Matisse's gallery, there is nothing very sinister or terrifying here.

Breaking 96 out of a possible 100 targets, H. Thoens captured the High-Over-All Cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. It was the best score in a field of twenty-four gunners divided into two classes.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP). -- Sentiment for revival of the great plains shelterbelt project was reported today by the Forest Service.

INSTEAD of the usual comments during the Chicago Opera broadcasts WJZ now presents Aleo Templeton, 26-year-old blind pianist-composer, who tells what the opera means to him as a listener. Mr. Templeton, assisted by an orchestra, broadcasts during each major intermission.

A field tour of good and bad housing on Tuesday morning will conclude the intensive study of slum clearance conducted by the Vomen's Committee of the National Public Housing Conference for the past three weeks.

Since the events narrated in this book take place in a large department store, and on Bargain Day at that, the author generously gives us six murders for the price of one. The narrator is Miss Ethel Thomas, an elderly spinster who is a large stockholder in the store.

Mobilization of a vast feminine army -- the General Federation of Women's Clubs -- for a mass attack on underlying causes of the dismayingly high maternal mortality rate of the United States was announced yesterday by Mrs. Clarence Fraim of Wilmington, Del.

Mrs. Edward Cox Brewster and Mrs. Stephen A. Koshland head a group of young matrons and debutantes of recent seasons who will be in charge of the Christmas sale at the Lighthouse Craft Shop, which opens tomorrow at 115 East Fifty-ninth Street and will continue there throughout this week.

AN English wood is a little thing -- a lovesome thing, like an English garden, for all the untrammeled natural wildness that is a part of its very loveliness. The English wood "never dominates, never assumes the dark dictatorship of forests"; beyond the ancient oaks and tall beeches one will come soon to harvest fields, or upland reaches, or perhaps the sea.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5. -- After a somewhat sluggish opening, holiday shopping came on with a rush, the crowds in the department stores in the last half of the week rivaling boom days. The sales average for the week showed an approximate gain of 18 per cent over 1935 with Loop and outlying stores.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The executive order of President Roosevelt forbidding the marriage of Foreign Service career officers to aliens without permission of the State Department struck the service like a bombshell. Yet the regulation had long been contemplated.

Expressing what he termed the "Spanish intellectuals'" viewpoint of the chaotic situation in Spain, Professor Homero Seris, former general secretary of the Center of Historical Studies of Madrid, declared that the "money, manpower and ideals" of the government forces would bring them rapid victory if foreign powers would cease their intervention.

Returning to the city yesterday with the mile-long baseball caravan that had wended its way through the snow fields of Canada, the Giants immediately set to work clearing the decks for more action in the trading mart.
MADRID, Dec. 4 (Delayed). -- The western sector of Madrid toward the Model Prison was bombed heavily at 2 o'clock this afternoon.

Articles brought from abroad by Miss Anne Morgan and donated to the committee in charge will be among the merchandise offered for sale at the annual bazaar of Pen and Brush at its clubhouse. 16 East Tenth Street, this week. Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt and Mrs. Daniel Guggenheim are other patronesses who have sent generous donations to the club for the opening on Thursday.

BERLIN, Dec. 5. -- The official economic spokesman for the National Socialist Party, Bernhard Koehler, declared in an address last night that Germany was finished forever with the capitalist system of economy. Mr. Koehler bears the title of chairman of the Economic Commission of the National Socialist party.

LAST April the leaders of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints launched from its Salt Lake City headquarters an ambitious church security program designed to remove all Mormons from direct relief rolls of governmental agencies.

An encouraging subscription has been reported for the performance of "The Flying Dutchman," in which Kirsten Flagstad will make her debut as Senta, on Jan. 7 at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Florence Crittenton League.

CANNES, France, Sunday, Dec. 6. -- Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson arrived here three minutes before midnight last night after a two-day motor flight across France and is now staying with her friends Mr. and Mrs. Herman Livingston Rogers of New York at their Villa Lou Viel.

Dr. Joseph Jastrow, former president of the American Psychological Association, for twenty-nine years the University of Wisconsin's Professor of Psychology and author of numerous books, has given to The Associated Press an interview on the psychology of King Edward VIII.

Thousands of the city's underprivileged children will receive help with their homework and facilities for supervised games and crafts after school hours in the next few months through a new system of youth centers maintained by the city's Juvenile Aid Bureau in cooperation with the WPA and the Board of Education.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4. FOR something like two and two-thirds acts of "You Can't Take It With You," which was disclosed last Monday night at the Chestnut Street Opera House, the Messrs. Moss Hart and George S. Kaufman devote themselves diligently to a glittering and gorgeous glorification of goofiness.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The Illinois Freight Association asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to reopen proceedings as to the authority of the railroads to offer store-door pick-up and delivery service, to postpone the effective date of its order setting rates for this service at 45 cents a 100 pounds and to broaden the scope of the proceedings so as to apply the same rate to competing truck lines.

AS its second attraction the recently established Schaeffer Gallery at 61 East Fifty-seventh Street is holding, for the benefit of the Judson Health Center, a show composed of paintings by a group of Dutch masters, several of them very famous masters and some of them but slenderly known to the American public.

Confounding the critics who perennially denounce the political inertia of the electorate, the vigorous drive for the new charter recently concluded by the League of Women Voters of the city is to be followed on Tuesday by another step in its campaign on specific legislation.

TYLER, Texas, Dec. 5. -- A brilliant third-period dash of 76 yards by Dick Todd provided the difference between Manhattan and Texas A. and M. in their intersectional battle today and enabled the Aggie eleven to repel the invasion of the New Yorkers by a 13-to-6 score.

Starting slowly, increasing its pace midway in the first session and reaching the high point of its powerful drive in the second half, City College's basketball team won its second game of the season last night at the Lavender gymnasium, routing Brooklyn College, 35 -- 11, before an overflow crowd of 1,200.

New York City, which boasts the tallest bufidingsL the largest population, the gayest White Way and many other superlatives, has also, it is asserted, the costliest of muicipa[ governments. Just how costly, in comparison with twelve American cities of 500,000 or more population, was disclosed last week by the Merchants Association.

South America is by no means the only area where the grand word "peace" is on men's lips today, and President Roosevelt is by no means the only statesman to carry the great message to men's hearts far and wide across the earth. Let us rejoice that this is so.
NORTH BAY, Ont., Dec. 5. -- A little girl has written to Santa Claus asking for the Dionne quintuplets as a Christmas present.
Catholic women were praised by Cardinal Hayes yesterday morning for the assistance their organizations gave the church and were urged as individuals to give in greater service even if at a sacrifice.
BRUNSWICK, Me., Dec. 5. -- Few college dramatic societies undertake as ambitious a program as has been outlined for Masque and Gown of Bowdoin College by its director and coach, George Quinby.
Mr. and Mrs. Haliburton Fales gave a tea dance yesterday at the Pierre for their debutante daughter, Miss Angelica Van Rensselaer Fales.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 5 (AP). -- Harvard astronomers unfolded today a story of drama in the heavens, potentially capable of dazzling the world.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- A forest in each of the forty-eight States, planted, cared for and owned cooperatively by club women and the United States Forest Service, is the goal set by the General Federation of Women's Clubs through its Division of Conservation of Natural Resources, of which Mrs. H.G. Bogert of Akron, Col., is the chairman.

THE American advance which forms the subject of this book is quite literal: the book is the story of transportation, by railroad, automobile, airplane and ship, and of communication by telegraph and telephone.

DESPITE the vast public relief program the work of the private charitable agencies is needed more than ever. Public relief grew out of the emergency needs of a great national catastrophe. Its agencies have met successfully the cry for bread and shelter; they have taken over, in large degree, this burden once carried by private philanthropy.

ADD still another name, that of W. Ray Johnston, to the list of small-town boys who have made good in the big city. At 44 he is marking his twenty-second year in the motion-picture industry by organizing a new independent producing and distributing company to take the place of his Monogram Pictures, which passed into limbo in 1935 when Mr. Johnston formed and assumed the presidency of Republic Pictures.

China's sacred bean was the subject of an article by Duncan Aikman in THE TIMES recently. Although China has known the ta-teon or "big pea" for centuries and has adapted it in as many ways for human welfare as we have the products of the long leaf pine, it remained for Japan to vastly extend the use of the soy bean and to introduce it to the world.

MOSCOW, Dec. 5. -- The Soviet Union reinforced its military alliance with France by an unexpected amendment in the final draft of its new Constitution this afternoon as the Congress of Soviets tumultuously adopted that charter as the basic law of the land.

BERLIN, Dec. 5. -- Indifference is professed here toward the mutual pledges of military assistance exchanged between France and Great Britain, which, added to the Franco-Soviet pact and the refurbished French alliances with Poland and the Little Entente, would seem to complete Germany's encirclement, at least on paper.

A reception celebrating the 100th anniversary of the founding of the Colored Orphan Asylum was held at the institution's home overlooking the river at Riverdale-on-Hudson yesterday afternoon, attended by several hundred "graduates," friends and members of its board of trustees.

DALLAS, Dec. 5. -- Retail distribution of merchandise in the Eleventh Federal Reserve District continued its steady advance, given increased impetus by extensive holiday buying. A shortage of merchandise in many stores and a tendency toward increasing prices did not check the rush of holiday shoppers, who thronged stores in all parts of the district and registered a new volume for retail trade since 1929.

Celebrations are planned by Columbia University and by chemical, civil and industrial groups to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the birth of Professor Charles Frederick Chandler, for sixty-one years a member of the faculty of Columbia, the father of the American Chemical Society, and one of America's first great industrial chemists.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 5. -- St. Mary's Gaels capped an indifferent football season in brilliant fashion today with a 13-to-7 intersectional victory over the veteran Glenn (Pop) Warner's light but tricky Temple University Owls.

The engineer, broadly trained in the social as well as technical sciences, will be the key man to whom society will turn for the next century or two for solution of the gravest series of problems the world has faced in 2,000 years, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, predicted last night at a dinner of the Society for the Promotion of Engineering Education.
This is the story of King Edward VIII, of Wallis Warfield Simpson -- and of the British Empire.

It was in the Summer of 1636 that a small band of emigrants from Cambridge followed Thomas Hooker through the green wilderness of New England to settle in the tiny village of Newtown, which was later to become the great city of Hartford.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 5 (AP). -- Judge M.A. Musmanno declared today he had adopted a policy of giving women defendants sentences only two-thirds as heavy as those given men for similar offenses.

Bond prices were generally firm, with oils and sugars outstanding in the domestic corporation group in yesterday's trading in the bond section of the New York Stock Exchange. United States Government issues were mixed, with advances of 1/32 to 3/32 point interspersed with declines of equal size.

IN the Soviet Union all manifestations of policy, however diverse and even contradictory they may appear, eventually are found to be parts of a coherent, deliberate pattern. For here nothing is left to chance or whim. All major decisions of policy are made in the last analysis by one mind alone -- Stalin's -- and a very determined and logical mind it is.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 5. -- Biography, owned by Norman Hernandez of New Orleans, made every post a winning one to take the mile-and-a-sixteenth handicap that topped today's Fair Grounds program.

Divergent opinions as to the proper approach in teaching engineering subjects were heard here last week from an educator on one hand and a practicing engineer on the other, both of whom attended the annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.
The British Board of Trade has issued the following recommendations to ship owners in respect to cargo ships going on Winter voyages and particularly crossing the North Atlantic.

LONDON, Sunday, Dec. 6. -- That King Edward VIII will vacate his throne as the penalty for not abandoning his romance with Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson is now a virtual certainty. That he will surrender his crown without a fight and quietly abdicate tomorrow is counted almost as inevitable by members of the British Cabinet.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 5. -- Two professional exterminators were arrested here tonight in connection with the death of Nelson A. Applebach, 69 years old, retired Milford, Pa., banker, and his wife, Elizabeth, 68.

TELEVISION experts in New York are aiming at countless lights in neighborhoods for miles around. At least that is the way it seems to those who go up into the lofty realm of research atop the Empire State Building, the dome of which holds the telecasting aerial rods 1,250 feet above the sidewalks.

MAYOR LA GUARDIA is determined to drive the racketeer out of New York. The Dewey investigation and the Police Department already have achieved some results, but the Mayor feels it is possible to eradicate racketeering entirely. To accomplish this, hard and persistent work will be necessary, work requiring the services of skilled men who will devote all their time to this particular phase of crime.

NEW YEAR'S EVE is three weeks from next Thursday night, and don't think the showmen don't know it. Hospitable fellows all, they count on entertaining large hordes of Times Square celebrants -- more of them, it is expected, than any New Year's Eve since the good old days.

A permanent "clearing house" for the interchange of information and joint action in connection with unfair returns and "chronic returners" is being established by the Apparel Industries Inter-Trade Bureau, comprising the executive heads of the various garment trade associations, it was announced yesterday by Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- The recount of the totals on the voting machines in Westchester County was completed tonight, with the representatives of the two major candidates for Surrogate agreeing that the plurality of Surrogate George A. Slater, Republican incumbent, over his Democratic opponent, William J. Sheils, was approximately 108 votes.

A NEW geometry," said the writer of Topics of the Times the other day, "which succeeds in measuring the horn angle that has baffled mathematicians for 2,500 years was described at Harvard University. Failure to understand this new triumph of the human mind should induce a feeling of humility rather than humiliation.

President Roosevelt's phrase, My Friends -- recently translated into the Spanish Mis Amigos for Latin-American audiences -- gained popular currency through the President's frequent use of it in his radio fireside talks soon after his inauguration. Mr. Roosevelt had been sprinkling it fairly liberally through his speeches as far back as 1920, when he was Democratic nominee for Vice President.

HOUSTON, Tex., Dec. 5. -- Sudden outbreaks by fiery reserves brought a 9-0 victory for Southern Methodist's Mustangs over a battered Rice Owl in the season's football final here today as 10,000 rooters looked on.

A series of entertainments planned for the purpose of creating a fund for the establishment of an Alexander Pushkin Literary Scholarship at Columbia University will be inaugurated with a Pushkin dinner to be held in the Russian Eagle of the Sherry-Netherland on Dec. 15.

NEW ROCHELLE; N.Y., Dec. 5. -- The New Rochelle League for Service will present the Don Cossacks in a concert at the Senior High School of New Rochelle on Dec. 19 for the benefit of the New Rochelle Hospital.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 5. -- One of the most important social events of the season in Englewood will be the nine-league presentation of "The Wizard of Oz" in the Plaza Theatre here on Thursday evening.

The lecturers for the course on "Artistic Arrangement of Flowers," to be conducted by the Federated Garden Clubs of New York in the Astor Gallery of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Jan. 11 to 14, have been announced by Mrs. James H.S. Ellis Jr., chairman of the committee in charge of this project.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5. -- Rallying near the close of its thirteenth meeting with Lafayette, the University of Pennsylvania five came through with a 28-22 decision tonight. About 4,500 fans were in Penn's Palestra to witness the fray.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 5 (AP). -- Town Superintendents of Highways opening the final session of their State convention today considered a prediction of Speaker Irving M. Ives of the Assembly that diversion of gasoline taxes and county government reform would be dominating issues before the 1937 Legislature.

Secretary HULL'S address yesterday at the Inter-American Conference in Buenos Aires was moving and idealistic, yet it presented a definite and practical program of action for consideration by the American countries. He pleaded for cooperation and a return to international order based on respect for the pledged word of nations.
The Manhattan College basketball team opened the season last night as it easily defeated an Alumni five, 57 -- 25, in the Manhattan gymnasium before 700.

HOW great is the need for trailer camps in New York City and this vicinity was emphasized last week by the report that Manhattan's last farm -- bounded by 213th and 214th Streets and Broadway and Tenth Avenue -- might be converted into a haven for yachts of the land.

Engagements of gold abroad for shipment to this country, amounting to $1,570,000, and consisting of $1,500,000 taken in Switzerland and $70,000 in England, were reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Both items were obtained at some previous date.

A tea and meeting in the interests of the Josephine Home will be held on Thursday at the home of Mrs. Russell Cecil, 153 East Sixty-first Street. Mrs. R. Stuyvesant Pierrepont and Commissioner Byrnes MacDonald will speak on the work being accomplished by the organization.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- The annual international debate between the College of New Rochelle and a visiting British team will take place Monday evening, Dec. 14, in the sports building, on the resolution, "That this house prefers peaceful militarism to militant pacificism," the New Rochelle Council of Debate announced yesterday.

Edward Jamison, 39 years old, of 1,425 Sterling Place. Brooklyn, a surgical instrument salesman, was arrested last night at Jamaica Avenue and Sutphin Boulevard, Jamaica, on a petit larceny charge. At the Jamaica police station later Jamison admitted, according to detectives, having stolen eight sets of surgical instruments at various times in recent months.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 5 (AP). -- Karl T. Fredericks of New York City is the new president of the New York State Conservation Council. Inc.

Ogden Reid, publisher of The New York Herald Tribune, was the principal speaker at a dinner of the Delta Kappa Epsilon fraternity, held at the Yale Club last night, which served to honor the memory of James Alexander Hawes, long its friend, field worker and benefactor, and to re-establish the tradition of the national fraternity's annual dinner.

ENGLAND has her Shakespeare, Germany her Goethe, Spain her Cervantes, and Russia -- her Pushkin. Each of these great writers represents not only what is best and most essential of his race, its root quality, so to speak -- call it soul -- but also its aspirations to universality.

OTTAWA, Dec. 5.-- So far as Canada's part was concerned, there were no concrete developments today in the constitutional deadlock that has arisen over King Edward's desire to choose a wife considered unsuitable by the British and Dominion Governments.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP). -- Jose Enrique Colon, Puerto Rico's Interior Secretary, predicted today after a series of conferences here that the island would get several million dollars additional Federal grants and loans next year.

LAST year the first part of these memoirs was published under the title of "With Napoleon in Russia." It concluded with General de Caulaincourt's remarkable account of the journey he made alone with the Emperor across Europe by sled and coach, while the Grande Armee was being massacred as it fought its way through ice and snow out of Russia.

A reception will be held in the lounge of the Henry Miller Theatre on Friday night in conjunction with the annual theatre party of the Maternity Center Division of the Brooklyn Visiting Nurse Association, to see "The Country Wife" at that theatre.

Dr. Martha McChesney Berry, founder of the Berry Schools at Mount Berry, Georgia, was made an honorary member of Kappa Delta Pi, international honor society of the School of Education of New York University, at a dinner at the Hotel Lexington last night.

Here are six murder stories by six different authors, each one of whom describes what is intended to be a perfect crime. Following each story are a few pages of comment and criticism by Ex-Superintendent Cornish, who proves, at least to his own satisfaction, that not one of these crimes is perfect.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 5. -- A roller-skating carnival will be held on Dec. 20 at the Mineola Fair Grounds for the benefit of the Nassau Speedwell Unit, which aids in the care of convalescent children in foster homes.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- The veterans of this village are so anxious for completion of the Spanish War memorial in Summerfield Park that they have caused the ousted WPA sculptor, Karl Illava, to submit another model which appeared to win approval of the village board.

The exhibition of paintings by the seventeenth century French artists, Georges de La Tour and the brothers Le Bain, which opened at the Knoedler Galleries on Nov. 23, and for which there has been an admission fee for the benefit of the Musee de Blerancourt and the Lycee Francais, will be open through the week free to the public.

I hope that your editorial "A Minor Poet" will bring to mind the forgotten works and stories of Thomas Bailey Aldrich. Reading them over last Summer was to me like a breath of fresh air, or finding again in the woods the trailing arbutus and red checker berries. There is something precious about them to us of the old stock.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 5. -- The recent charge that the average college graduate gains his degree from a desultory and uncoordinated study of text books centered attention here this week on a part of the annual report of President Harold Willis Dodds of Princeton University in which he praises the independent research done by Nassau seniors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Narcotic addiction in the United States is decreasing, but the official report of H.J. Anslinger, Commissioner of Narcotics, transmitted to the International Drug Convention through the Secretary of State and made public today, disclosed, nevertheless, that in this country there still is close to one addict to each thousand of the population of about 126,000,000.
OTTAWA, Ill., Dec. 5. -- Officials of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Company expressed confidence today that the strike of 1,300 employes at their glass-making plant here would end soon.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- "Westchester on Parade," the combined Christmas pageant, style show and ball sponsored by all the Episcopal churches in the county, will be presented at the County Center here on Friday. Funds raised by the sale of subscriptions will provide Christmas food baskets in parishes where they are requested for needy families.

IN another week four imaginary candles will be lighted on a theoretical cake, which now is browning in an unseen oven to honor the fourth consecutive birthday of the Stage Relief Fund. That is the emergency theatrical organization which resulted from a mass meeting called by Rachel Crothers and John Golden at the Golden Theatre on the afternoon of Dec. 13, 1932.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4. -- Stirred by the frequency of crimes in which parolees from the State penitentiary are reported as participants, Cook County members of the State Legislature are drafting bills for introduction at the January session which propose drastic amendments to the Parole Law.

LONDON. -- Plans and devices to combat gas attacks from the air were explained to Londoners recently. At a meeting of the Public Health Congress various machines for defense of this kind were demonstrated and a representative of the Home Office told of the work done by his department.

In one of the wildest finishes seen in Madison Square Garden since the present structure was built, the all-American team of Jimmy Walthour and Al Crossley flashed to victory in the sixty-first New York six-day bicycle race, which ended shortly after 11 o'clock last night.

Mr. and Mrs. Stephen D. Hurlbut gave a dinner with dancing last night at the Pierre to introduce to society Mrs. Hurlbut's daughter, Miss Diana Kissel. Miss Kissel was presented to the older friends of the family at a reception given by Mr. and Mrs. Hurlbut on Nov. 24 at their home, 10 Gracie Square.

The New York Historical Society, which for 133 years has been collecting records of American history and genealogy, soon will undertake a building-expansion program which will give the organization three times its present space, it was learned yesterday.

Speaking at a dinner held last night by the Women's Moderation Union at the Circle Club, 1,819 Broadway, Frank Miller, president of the Westchester County Restaurant Liquor Dealers Association, predicted the return of prohibition within three years unless the liquor interests organized to regulate their business.

AS an aftermath of the spectacular rise in the value of special sheets of stamps issued for the International Philatelic Exhibition "Tipex" held in New York last May, interest has been increased in the special exhibition issues of other countries.

Carrying out their announced determination to end the racket of car watching, taxi "jockeying" and juvenile sidewalk entertainers in the Times Square theatre zone, the police arrested thirty-nine children last night near midtown hotels and playhouses in the first phase of a drive staged by fifty plainclothes patrolmen.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 4. -- New York City election officials who were here last week to study the operation of the proportional representation system used in Cincinnati since 1925 left town well primed with information that they expect will be of service to them when their metropolis undertakes a similar system under its new charter.

BLAIRMORE, Alta., Dec. 5 (Canadian Press). -- Mayor William Knight, who since 1933 has been Chief Magistrate of Blairmore, with its Left-Wing Council and School Board, will not seek re-election at the civic election in February.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 5. -- Student understanding of modern American art and its European background is being taught at Brown University this year under methods unusual in approach and valuable in covering such a broad field intensively in a year's time, Professor Will S. Taylor, chairman of the Department of Art, reports.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The first of the "Three Dances," sponsored by Mrs. Joseph Leiter, Mr. and Mrs. John F. Wilkins and Mr. and Mrs. Henry Bennings Spencer took place tonight at the Sulgrave Club. These dances, long a feature of the Washington season, are a definite part of the residential life, only a few of the diplomats or officials being asked as guests each year.

LONDON, Dec. 5. -- Sterling continued weak today, as it has been since the constitutional crisis began. Official control is believed, however, to have been at work and the rate moved only slightly from yesterday's $4.90 1-16 to the pound to $4.89 3/4. The French franc remained virtually pegged at 105 5-32.

VATICAN CITY, Sunday Dec. 6. -- Pope Pius XI slept uneasily early today, pain from a blood clot on his left leg occasionally arousing him. Vatican attendants kept a vigil through the hours of darkness in a dimly lighted room adjoining the Pontiff's bedchamber.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 5. -- Yale opened its hockey season tonight before 1,100 spectators in the New Haven arena by winning its annual game with the St. Nicholas Club of New York City, 6 -- 5, in an overtime battle.

ALBANY, Dec. 5 (AP). -- Balked in their final attempts to clear a passage through the ice-choked Barge Canal, State officials today concentrated their efforts on finding safe moorings for more than 300 vessels, loaded with millions of dollars of cargo, which face the virtual certainty of wintering in the canal.

Walter J. Gutterson, convicted of a similar offense fourteen years ago, was arraigned yesterday before United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter on a charge of using the mails to defraud. Federal authorities declared that he was one of a group that had obtained more than $500,000 through spurious stock promotions.

A fascinating and thrilling program of popular outdoor Winter sports events on real ice and snow, combined with a panorama of colorful exhibits illustrating the swift progress of the Winter sports industry, will be shown at Madison Square Garden, beginning Wednesday night and concluding on Saturday, when the first annual International Ski Meet and Winter Sports Show will be staged at the famous Eighth Avenue arena.

To aid a project that will provide a more adequate health service for hundreds of children who are taken to the clinics of Greenwich House, the first matinee performance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera -- "Hansel und Gretel" on Dec. 24 -- has been taken over as a benefit for the Children's Health Service of the settlement.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- To provide an apprenticeship in citizenship for the college student is the aim of a new program introduced this year at Skidmore College. Under the direction of the Sociology Club, the college will administer a college-community center intended to introduce college students to life in the community and to develop in them a feeling of civic responsibility.

CAGE bird fanciers and hobbyists of the metropolitan area will center their attention next Saturday and Sunday on the annual grand national exhibit of the Empire Cage Bird Association, to be held at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

GENEVA, Dec. 5. -- The number of women non-manual workers greatly increased after the war in industrial countries, especially the United States, according to statistics just issued by the International Labor Office here.

THE ghost ship, rustling ominously, outlined in ghastly light against the dark, was a sight to make the good people of the little Norwegian fishing village quail in terror as it would sail head-on up the fjord and then disappear as mysteriously as it had come.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Major George L. Berry called today for "a great, human crusade to end unemployment and raise the American standard of living."

Interest in Britain's "constitutional crisis" has established a new week's record for the transatlantic photoradio service of the Radio Corporation of America. The previous record, made during the Olympic Games in Berlin last August, was surpassed yesterday when the King Edward-Mrs. Simpson photographs fluttering across the Atlantic exceeded fifty pictures for the week.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5. -- An international poll to determine who are the seventy greatest living Jews will be undertaken by the Ivrim, Chicago honor society for Jewish young men, according to Ben Aronin, sponsor for the society.

In the following years the occupation was confirmel by a lease, and Tsingtao developed into a thriving, modern port. Five thousand miles of "superhighways" designed to permit automobiles to travel in comparative safety at a speed of 112 miles an hour, are being built in Germany, the Regional Plan Association reported yesterday in a survey emphasizing European progress in road construction.
MONTREAL, Dec. 4. -- Whatever may happen to its social credit policy, the Alberta government's preliminary experiment with taxable "prosperity certificates" is an admitted failure.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- New warnings to Greek letter societies to mend their ways were voiced today during the final sessions of the interfraternity conference which has been held at Syracuse University.
SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Dec. 5. -- In the next two weeks Professor William Churchill Hammond will lead the Mount Holyoke College Glee Club of 125 members in his farewell annual carol concert tour.
GAINESVILLE, Fla., Dec. 5 (AP). -- Mississippi State lashed out with one brilliant touchdown thrust today and ended a successful season by defeating a fighting Florida team, 7 to 0.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Major George L. Berry called today for "a great, human crusade to end unemployment and raise the American standard of living."

IN spite of the firm conviction of a sizable corps of doubters that the ructions which have kept the WPA Federal Dance Theatre Project in a turmoil ever since its inception would result in its being abandoned before it could manage to get a production together for Broadway, last Wednesday night saw the first performance of "The Eternal Prodigal" at the Ritz Theatre, and a highly creditable and workmanlike production it proved to be.

Mrs. Irene Halloran, 41 years old, a widow and the mother of three children, living at 89-47 215th Place, Queens Village, Queens, was arrested last night at the Garden Theatre, Farmers Boulevard and 141st Avenue, Springfield.
Conde Nast gave a dance last night at his home, 1,040 Park Avenue, for Miss Barbara Field, debutante daughter of Mrs. E. Marshall Field and of Marshall Field.

LONDON, Dec. 5. -- Prince Paul, senior regent of Yugoslavia, and Princess Olga, sister of the Duchess of Kent, who have been in London for several weeks, were guests of Lady Cunard at a supper party given in the Savoy Grill this week.

ROME, Dec. 4. -- President Roosevelt's opening speech at the Pan-American Conference made a deeper impression on Italy than official quarters are willing to admit. In particular, the antithesis he drew between America and Europe, wherein he condemned Europe as a whole, produced a strong reaction in Italy.
MILLSFIELD, N.H., Dec. 5 (AP). -- Eighty-six-year-old Quincy Davis, life-long Republican, prized a letter from Governor Landon, today recent Republican Presidential candidate.

TO us in America, England beckons in its visual scene which we must go abroad to visit, in its history with which we are all more or less familiar, and in its literature which is our common heritage; not often do we find these three important factors brought to our arm-chair attention within the covers of one book.

CHRISTMAS is at hand. It is the time for choosing gifts. Displays in the shops dazzle the eyes, so much is there of sparkle and brilliance. Jewels, perhaps because of the return of prosperity and the piling up of dividends, are in the front row.

Two million women in the United States, working long hours for relatively small wages, did not file applications for registration under the administration of the Federal Social Security Act. They are the household employes, who are specifically excluded, and for whose benefit concerted action will probably be taken under the aegis of the National Board of the Young Women's Christian Association.

WHEN the scientific events of the year are recalled it must be admitted that none outranks in importance the recent discovery of titanium gas in space by Dr. Walter S. Adams and Dr. Theodore Dunham Jr. of Mount Wilson Observatory.

Experiments looking to the practical adaptation of the "electric eye" to vehicular traffic control are being made by the New York Police Department, Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine said yesterday in his appearance at the seasonal forum, "New York Advancing," being held at the Rand School, East Fifteenth Street.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- Cornell University will receive more than $100,000 for athletic scholarships, and the music and medical schools of the University of Rochester will share a like sum for scholarships, preferably for entering students with athletic ability, under the terms of the will of Mrs. Merry M. Dennis, 72-year-old widow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Attorney General Cummings called upon the lawyers of the nation tonight to reflect upon their duty "to those innumerable, unnamed, unknown and sometimes forgotten clients -- the people of America."

BERLIN, Dec. 5. -- An announcement from the War Ministry, which receives prominence in the press today, puts aside all subterfuge and makes it quite clear that the final year of preparatory schooling for German boys has been dropped in order to obtain young officers for the military services.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5. -- Department stores were back to normal activity this week, following the strike of warehouse employes, and business was approximately 20 per cent ahead of the corresponding period last year. Activity was general in all lines, especially Christmas gift items.

Certain news items indicate a tendency to lean too far to New England and the Puritans as founders of our country. At a recent patriotic service at St. John's Cathedral the chosen speaker eulogized those who had observed the first American Thanksgiving. A night or two later at the Sons of the Revolution meeting I heard again the same note.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 5. -- Applauding President Roosevelt's affirmation at Buenos Aires of faith in democracy as a force for peace, Professor De Witt Clinton Poole, director of the School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University, urged here closer cooperation among the democratic nations to restrain war makers.

A handwritten letter in German by Queen Victoria, mourning the death of Prince Albert, her consort, was acquired a few days ago by David M. Neuberger, a lawyer, with offices at 154 Nassau Street. Dated June 4, 1863, the nine-page letter is written on the Queen's personal stationery.

A noteworthy step in the training of music teachers is being taken in the Crane Department of Music at the State Normal School, Potsdam, N.Y. For the first time in the history of teacher training in the United States, a normal school is offering a semester's work in the various centers of Europe.

Lord BRYCE, in his book on "Written and Unwritten Constitutions," discussed the advantages and disadvantages of each with his usual philosophic breadth. Among the claims of superiority for the unwritten British Constitution which he mentioned was its flexibility. It represents, to be sure, a body of ancient law and precedent, but it can be made quickly to conform to new conditions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Since the first row of cotton was plowed under in 1938 it has always been a proud boast of the Roosevelt administration that its agricultural policy and the programs promulgated under it have been a real lesson in economic democracy.

Much has been said and written about the legality and propriety of the Spanish Rebels' position and nearly always it has been in condemnation of the Rebels. The contention, in the main, is that the Madrid government is constitutional and the Opposition should have resorted to ballots and not bullets.

Mr. and Mrs. John T. Terry Jr. entertained with a dinner last night in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre for Miss Elizabeth Terry Savage and Cornelius W. Wickersham Jr., whose marriage will take place on Saturday in the Brick Presbyterian Church.

PARIS, Dec. 3. -- The Spring millinery field is divided into two factions, one favoring headgear of the Rubens period, the other that worn at the time of the American Civil War. Agnes and Louise Bourbon are both on the side of Rubens.

Taking five of the six high school events on the program, the Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School track team, holder of the Catholic Schools indoor and outdoor championships, yesterday won the first athletic meet of the Parish Club of Our Lady of Perpetual Help at the Second Naval Battalion in Brooklyn.

OMAHA, Dec. 5. -- Senator Edward R. Burke said today that he would introduce at the next session of Congress a constitutional amendment to give the President of the United States a six-year term, without the privilege of re-election.

THE TIMES printed the news that the President had approved an executive order forbidding American citizens in the foreign service to marry any woman not an American without permission of the government. This strikes at the heart of our personal liberties. It sets a precedent which may easily be followed by a like law affecting all persons in any branch of the government service.
In the clash between King and Cabinet in Great Britain the British Constitution is playing an important part. Both King Edward and Prime Minister Baldwin are taking their stand on its provisions.

NEW YORK TIMES reporters and correspondents in all parts of the world will contribute to a volume of newspaper chronicles which Simon Schuster will publish in the Fall of 1937. Shepard Stone and Hanson W. Baldwin, both of THE NEW YORK TIMES, will edit the volume.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- Women of the University of Rochester are busily preparing to present the old legend of "The Tumbler of Our Lady" at chapel services Dec. 16.

MUNICH, Germany, Dec. 5. -- The dormant church struggle flamed up here again last night in a peculiar form. Without any announcement except by secret word of mouth, the congregation gathered this evening at the largest Protestant church, St. Matthew's, to hear an anonymous Franconian pastor report on attacks that both Protestantism and Catholicism allegedly were suffering from National Socialist party representatives and limitations the government is placing on religious teaching and exercise.
In the clash between King and Cabinet in Great Britain the British Constitution is playing an important part. Both King Edward and Prime Minister Baldwin are taking their stand on its provisions.

NEW YORK TIMES reporters and correspondents in all parts of the world will contribute to a volume of newspaper chronicles which Simon Schuster will publish in the Fall of 1937. Shepard Stone and Hanson W. Baldwin, both of THE NEW YORK TIMES, will edit the volume.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- Women of the University of Rochester are busily preparing to present the old legend of "The Tumbler of Our Lady" at chapel services Dec. 16.

MUNICH, Germany, Dec. 5. -- The dormant church struggle flamed up here again last night in a peculiar form. Without any announcement except by secret word of mouth, the congregation gathered this evening at the largest Protestant church, St. Matthew's, to hear an anonymous Franconian pastor report on attacks that both Protestantism and Catholicism allegedly were suffering from National Socialist party representatives and limitations the government is placing on religious teaching and exercise.

THE fifth volume of Mr. Lloyd George's war memoirs covers the earlier months of the critical year 1918. The last great German offen sive broke the British line on the western front. There was an appeal to the United States for immediate reinforcements.

Mr. and Mrs. John T. Terry Jr. entertained with a dinner last night in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre for Miss Elizabeth Terry Savage and Cornelius W. Wickersham Jr., whose marriage will take place on Saturday in the Brick Presbyterian Church.

PARIS, Dec. 3. -- The Spring millinery field is divided into two factions, one favoring headgear of the Rubens period, the other that worn at the time of the American Civil War. Agnes and Louise Bourbon are both on the side of Rubens.

Taking five of the six high school events on the program, the Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School track team, holder of the Catholic Schools indoor and outdoor championships, yesterday won the first athletic meet of the Parish Club of Our Lady of Perpetual Help at the Second Naval Battalion in Brooklyn.

OMAHA, Dec. 5. -- Senator Edward R. Burke said today that he would introduce at the next session of Congress a constitutional amendment to give the President of the United States a six-year term, without the privilege of re-election.

THE TIMES printed the news that the President had approved an executive order forbidding American citizens in the foreign service to marry any woman not an American without permission of the government. This strikes at the heart of our personal liberties. It sets a precedent which may easily be followed by a like law affecting all persons in any branch of the government service.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 5. -- Left Wing papers are bitterly criticizing the government's efforts to lower the cost of farm products for domestic consumption. The plan is called impractical.

LONDON, Sunday, Dec. 6. -- Britain's King early today studied "certain documents" handed him in secluded Fort Belvedere by Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin. What the documents were or what they portended was not revealed, but authoritative sources said they might be:

Mail orders for gift items received in the wholesale market last week were heavy, according to a special report prepared for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. Apparel departments, however, were rather inactive. The report continues:

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5. -- "The cruel, hard way of a housing shortage" was described today by Langdon Post, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority and Tenement Housing Commissioner, as the only way to achieve a housing program in this country.

The future composer of symphonies will consult the scientist in his laboratory instead of the violinmaker in his garret, Edgar Varese, composer, director and one of music's ultra-modernists, predicted yesterday in an interview. He has just returned from Sante Fe, N.M., where he worked for six months on a composition that he feels will suggest some of the possibilities of the symphony of tomorrow.
The Sleepy Hollow Country Club and the Ardsley Country Club triumphed yesterday as the Westchester Division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association opened its season.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6. -- A i group of about 100 stockholders and i employes of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company designated today a committee headed by Frank W. Borden and George W. Arnold to represent it in the present reorganization proceedings of the company. Mayor S. Davis V/ilson and Albert M. Greenfield, real estate broker, who suggested a plan of reorganization last Spring, were sharply criticized at the meeting.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- On the basis of an exhaustive report by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Labor Department on the relationship between indirect and direct labor, the Public Works Administration announced today that it creates two and one-half times more work in private industries supplying building materials than it does in the building trades constructing its projects.

TORONTO, Dec. 6. -- Ontario's forty-five producing gold mines recorded an output of $66,213,602 in the ten months ended on Oct. 31, compared with $61,178,172 in the same period of 1935, or a gain of more than $5,000,000, the Ontario Department of Mines reported this week.

The contemporary relevance of the Bible's advice, solace and inspiration was stressed by the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray in his sermon yesterday morning at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration, 1 East Twenty-ninth Street.

The waiters' New Year's Eve brought 1,200 guests last night to Mecca Temple Casino at 135 West Fifty-fifth Street; gayer, happier waiters gladdened by the steady rise in tipping, increasing patronage of night clubs, restaurants and hotels.

On Saturday Mr. WINSTON CHURCHILL made a statement which implied, almost directly asserted, that support for King EDWARD against the Cabinet will be insignificant in Parliament. There is no likelihood of the formation in the Commons of a party of the "King's Friends," reminiscent of GEORGE III.
No one, so far as I know, has yet touched on vitally important by-products of the Social Security Act which transcend in value the money benefits to be enjoyed by the aged.

Mayor La Guardia will carry to Washington today a statistical review of relief expenditures which he hopes will convince the heads of the Works Progress Administration that "local Federal employes" are willfully misrepresenting the WPA situation here.

Again the South is in the saddle. It has the Vice Presidency, will have the Speakership once more and chairmanships of the great committees. This state of things is now viewed with alarm by supporters of the Northern Democratic candidate for majority leader of the House. A few years ago New England was hogging everything, to the sorrow of Western Republican altruists.

The leading real estate transaction reported in Manhattan over the week-end was the sale of the twelve-story apartment house on a plot 60 by 106 feet at 120 West Eighty-sixth Street. The building, recently altered into suites of three and four rooms, was sold by the Bowery Savings Bank to a client of William C. Crane, attorney.

Mankind, by first wondering and then discovering, has come to worship God and will not be deprived of that right, the Rev. Thomas F. Burke declared in a sermon yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Columbus Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

LONDON, Dec. 6. -- Although most Britons continue to give the appearance of not taking sides in the dispute between King Edward and his Ministers, definite signs of the emergence of a "King's party" became evident in two demonstrations in London tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- In holding out to the domestic wine industry the prospect of near-complete recovery of an export trade amounting normally to around $500,000 annually, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce listed the following as the eighteen "most promising foreign markets" for American vintners:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The sugar quotas of Cuba, the Philippines, Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands and Hawaii for 1936 have been almost filled in eleven months, according to the sugar section of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

LONDON, Dec. 4. -- The expansion in the Bank of England's circulation, which always occurs in December and usually reaches its peak at Christmas time, has now begun. Last week's rise of 6,020,000 was nearly 2,000,000 larger than that in the corresponding week of 1935, and, because of the active state of trade, there is no doubt that a new high record will be established by Christmas.

The immigrant population of the country has begun to decline and the number of persons leaving for permanent residence elsewhere about equals the number coming in, according to a report yesterday by the National League for American Citizenship, 405 Lexington Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- A huge artificial ice pack, which cost $30.000, halted a landslide that threatened to delay construction work on the east wing of the Grand Coulee Dam on the Columbia River and saved more than $100,000 in construction costs, the Interior Department revealed today.

In an eerie setting of fog, rain and the stickiest, clammiest mud imaginable, the Boston Redskins defeated the New York Giants. 14 to 0, in the season's finale at the Polo Grounds yesterday, won the Eastern championship of the National Football League and gained the right to meet the Green Bay Packers next Sunday for the professional title.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 6. -- Memorial services on the fiftieth anniversary of the birth of Joyce Kilmer, soldier-poet who was killed in action in France, were held here today in two churches in the city of his birth under sponsorship of Joyce Kilmer Post 25, American Legion, of New Brunswick.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 6. -- Placing the responsibility for the continued ease in money rates which has carried bond prices to abnormally high levels this year directly on the shoulders of the Federal Government, Dr. Lionel D. Edie, president of Edie-Davidson, Inc., addressed members of the Investment Bankers Association at the final session of its convention here today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6. -- Packers and shippers competed for hogs in the market here at the middle of last week and paid as high as $10.25 a hundredweight, the highest price since Oct. 17. However, the top price on Friday was $10, an advance of 10 cents over the previous week and the same as a year ago. The week's average was $9.70, compared with $9.45 the previous week and $9.80 a year ago.
MOSCOW, Dec. 6. -- The Commissariat of Foreign Trade reported today the stopping or attempted stopping of seven Russian ships in the last nine days by Spanish Insurgents.

Soaked but undismayed for the second straight year, about four-score cycling tyros wabbled down rainy Fifth Avenue yesterday to the now annual "bike breakfast" for the benefit of the Children's Welfare Federation.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6. -- Corn prices in all futures advanced to new high levels here last week, bringing out profit-taking by recent buyers. Consumption on farms is estimated as on a normal basis and terminal market stocks are not heavy, while demand is spotty.

A.L. Burns did some excellent shooting at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. He was the high-over-all scratch gunner with 96 out of a possible 100 and also won the scratch and the handicap legs in the shoot at 155 targets on a card of 144 -- 0 -- 144.

Great Britain was sharply criticized by Senator Royal S. Copeland last night for failing to suppress Arab demonstrations against Jews in Palestine. He spoke at a dinner in the Hotel Astor marking the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Mizrachi Organization of America.
Surrounded by Catholic church and educational leaders, Cardinal Hayes blessed and dedicated the new $1,200,000 Graduate School building, Keating Hall of Fordham University, yesterday afternoon.

The Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Knubel, president of the United Lutheran Church in America, preached the fortieth anniversary sermon yesterday morning at the Lutheran Church of Our Savior's Atonement, Bennett Avenue at 189th Street.

Religion is more than a quest for God; it is, for those who find Him, an arrival, an entering in and a possession of God, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the seminary, Broadway at 120th Street.

William Belier, young American pianist, who is a member of the faculty of the Bronx Music School, appeared in recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. He is a pianist of parts. At a time when the woods are full of competent keyboard artists, it is not unusual to find pianists who emerge as soundly equipped as Mr. Beller.

SANDS POINT, L.I., Dec. 6. -- Nothing less than an astonishing debacle was the abrupt finish today of the second annual field trial meeting of the Long Island Retriever Field Trial Club, which opened yesterday morning in the covers of the estates of W. Averell Harriman and Mrs. Aimee S. Guggenheim.

Help for the Neediest Cases in New York has never failed during all the twenty-five years of appeals for them through THE NEW YORK TIMES. This year there is every reason to expect that aid for them will be provided generously. On every side there are indications that, with improving business, there is a great deal more money in the hands of the people.

" The King and the Imperial Crown: The Power and Duties of His Majesty," is the title of a book brought out by Longmans Green. It is the work of A. Berriedal Keith and discusses the relation between the Sovereign and his subjects, describes the ceremonial of the royal accession and coronation, and deals with the part played in government by the King personally.

Excessive "monkeying" with the rules governing the selection of the winner of the Pulitzer Prize for the year's best drama has "drastically undermined its prestige so that now it is taken serious by no one either in or out of the theatre," Clayton Hamilton, dramatic critic and author, told 100 members of the American Woman's Association last night at a "theatre dinner" at the club, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street.

As the site for two six-story apartment houses a plot of fourteen lots on the north side of Eighty-second Road, 140 feet west of the corner of Queens Boulevard, Kew Gardens, L.I., has been bought by Benjamin Kobre of Manhattan from Samuel Margolis.

A plan whereby families of firemen and officers killed in the line of duty will receive cash benefits through voluntary subscriptions from members of the uniformed force was announced yesterday by Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The upward trend in production in the domestic paint, varnish and allied industries has caused an increase in the consumption of industrial drying oils in the last few years and especially in 1936, according to the Tung Oil Blue Book made public by the Department of Commerce.

Carmen Reuben, mezzo-soprano, gave a program at Town Hall last night consisting entirely of songs by Brahms. The singer, who has appeared here on several occasions, was born of English parents in the island of Jamaica, and lived for many years in Europe before coming to this country.

With a galaxy of international stars, including Jose R. Capablanca, Samuel Reshevsky and Edward Lasker among the spectators, the fifth round of the annual tournament for the championship of the Manhattan Chess Club was contested at the Hotel Alamac yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 6. -- Public hearings in the Supreme Court investigation of Newark's government will open Tuesday at 10 A.M. in the Essex County Court House, it was announced today by Warren Dixon Jr., Supreme Court Commissioner, who is in charge of the inquiry. Mr. Dixon declined to reveal what matters the investigating committee will take up first.

The parents of the ten children who were arrested and listed as "chronic offenders" in the police drive on juvenile taxi "jockeys," shoe shine and newspaper boys and sidewalk entertainers in the theatrical district Saturday night will be arraigned in the Children's Court this morning on charges of neglect.
Branch Rickey, the king of the Cardinal chain, checked into town late yesterday afternoon and announced almost immediately that the Cardinals would win the pennant.

BERLIN, Dec. 6. -- Sufficient hints as to Germany's real naval building program up to 1942 have now become available to justify the assertion that the Reich has at present no intention of breaking its 35-120 treaty with Britain but intends to build a fleet "formidable enough to keep the Russians bottled up in Leningrad for the duration of any war."

Owners and managers of buildings in the entire downtown section below Chambers Street have been organized to cooperate with the Department of Sanitation in the speedy removal of snow from sidewalks and streets, Commissioner William F. Carey announced yesterday.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.J., Dec. 6. -- The eighty-eight WPA seamstresses, who seized the city's council chamber last Tuesday because the city had abandoned two sewing projects for want of funds, were holding grimly to the seige today and planning further picketing of alleged gambling places here.

The word "settlement" has long been in the dictionaries of the English language -- and with certain technical meanings in the books of law. But within the last half century it has been given a new application or definition. In one of its earlier senses it suggests the occupation of frontier lands by a group of "settlers."

LONDON, Dec. 6. -- Amusedly tolerated "spellbinders" in their Hyde Park forum today proposed everything from a British republic to the formation of a Royalist party to bring Edward back to the throne if he should leave it.
The Hundred Neediest Cases Fund opened its twenty-fifth year yesterday with seventy-eight contributions, totaling $18,320.75, in hand.

Miss Ellen C. Wilkinson, Laborite Member of Parliament, representing the Jarrow district, England's most depressed area, declared yesterday in a broadcast from London to the WABC-Columbia network that in her district, where the King's popularity is particularly high because of his visits to study its labor problems, the women are nearly unanimous in their feeling against his marriage to Mrs. Simpson.
