CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP). -- Betty Jaynes, 15-year-old schoolgirl soprano, won the benedictions of critics and the willing plaudits of a capacity house tonight in her operatic debut as Mimi in "La Boheme."

OTTAWA, Ont., Dec. 6. -- King Edward's case was the major topic in all Canada today. In many churches prayers were asked for a satisfactory outcome of the crisis. In most cases the invocation contained a marked note of friendliness to the King.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Dec. 6. -- High Time Sensation, a cocker spaniel owned by Ferrier Martin, lived up to his name today by performing sensationally to capture two stakes in the Gun Dog Field Trial Association meeting held on the Ivor estate of Charles Gould.
MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 6. -- Two persons, one the victim of a hit-and-run driver, were killed by automobiles in Nassau County at almost the same time early this morning.
Overcast weather yesterday disrupted regular air passenger service throughout the East and forced an army bomber bound for Mitchel Field, L.I., to find a haven in Boston.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 6. -- Mrs. Ruth Mansfield, 34 years old, weighing only 98 pounds, told the police today that her husband, Alfred Mansfield, 39, compelled her to eat a cup of salt, hold heavy books at arm's length while he burned her fingers with matches, beat her with a heavy razor strap and subjected her to other cruelties.

More than a score of exhibitions are on the calendar for the present week, with modernism and even ultra-modernism to the fore. After several weeks in which old masters and contemporary French painters have vied for attention, a generous admixture of work from the extreme left of the modern movement is about to claim the spotlight.

VALENCIA, Spain, Dec. 6. -- A story of suffering in a Rebel camp at Las Palmas, in the Canary Islands, was told here by an American citizen, James G. Smith, who has just arrived after having been liberated through the intervention of the United States Consul at Las Palmas. Almost his first act here was to join the anti-Fascist militia.

A reception will be given by Prince and Princess Simon C. Sidamon-Eristoff today at the Caucasian Eagle for committee members and patrons of the Caucasian Allaverdy Ball which will be held at the Plaza on Dec. 18.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 6. -- Horton Smith of Chicago was far off his sharp-shooting form today, and turned in a poor 77, enabling Ralph Guldahl of St. Louis to take the lead in the $10,000 Miami-Biltmore open golf tournament with a fifty-four-hole card of 207.

Last week's irregular decline on the Stock Exchange is readily enough explained by the fact that, with the ending of December and the passing of the deadline for imposition of the new corporation surplus tax on 1936, the abnormally large outpour of company dividends will end.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- As a result of the use of the "aski" mark system of compensation trading, Germany has supplanted the United States in Brazilian markets and now occupies first place in the imports of that largest of South American republics, it was made known today by the Pan American Union.

BERLIN, Dec. 4. -- The banks' forecasts of business in the United States predict increasing private activity will relieve President Roosevelt of need to intervene creatively. Indeed they even imply that the application of official brakes soon will be required.

More important today than better roads, better schools, better politicians, are better men and women, the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, pastor, of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eight Street, pointed out in his sermon yesterday morning.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Dec. 7. -- The situation at Tsingtao, where Japanese armed forces have been landed because of strikes in Japanese textile mills, became definitely worse yesterday when four formal demands were submitted to the Chinese authorities.
LONDON, Dec. 6. -- Although demonstrations for King Edward flared up in London streets today, the press of the entire country showed no relenting in its opposition to his proposed marriage.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Conservation and development of the nation's natural and human resources will continue to be the major objectives of the Department of the Interior, Secretary Ickes told President Roosevelt in his annual report for the fiscal year 1936 submitted today.

HAVANA, Dec. 4. -- Commenting on efforts of recent provisional governments of Cuba to better social conditions, United States Ambassador Jefferson Caffery today asserted that the position of labor in 1936 was stronger than at any previous time in the history of the republic.

The National Preaching Mission opened a three-day spiritual campaign in this city yesterday afternoon with a "Metropolitan Youth Meeting" in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street. There were about 1,600 young people present representing many congregations.

BERLIN, Dec. 6. -- President Roosevelt is pursuing a super-Machiavellian policy of calculated altruism and military might, timed to insure American dominance over the world generally and over Europe particularly, says the Koelnische Zeitung in an analysis of the objectives of the Inter-American Conference for Maintenance of Peace at Buenos Aires.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6. -- Scoring in the second and third periods, the New York Rangers withstood a furious last period Chicago attack to defeat the Black Hawks, 2 to 1, tonight in a National Hockey League battle before 14,000 roaring fans.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 6. -- Yale undergraduates formed a society in 1815 for the express purpose of praying for a religious revival at Harvard, according to a letter written by a Princeton student of that period.

MOSCOW, Dec. 6 (AP). -- Maxim Litvinoff, the Foreign Commissar, rebuffed today a new German move to permit German officials to see thirty-five Germans held in jails in Moscow and provincial cities in connection with an alleged international plot.

BERLIN, Dec. 4. -- In general, the new balances of payments show a tendency toward improvement. Thus, 1935's total payments for imports and interest services, except for 102,000,000 marks were covered by receipts, whereas, in 1934, this account showed a deficit of 534,000,000 marks.

Reduction of civil servants' salaries as a means of cutting budgets was deplored yesterday by former Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley in an address at the Hotel Astor before 500 members of the Catholic Social Workers in Civil Service Guild at their second annual communion breakfast.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,509,533,300. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills. The list follows:

CANNES, Dec. 6. -- The captain and full crew boarded the yacht Sister Anne in Monte Carlo Harbor tonight after reports that King Edward, if he abdicated, would fly to meet Mrs. Simpson aboard the vessel.

Public school authorities will be asked to facilitate Catholic efforts to bring religious instruction to public school children of that faith by making available the names of the children, permitting announcement of religious classes to be made and allowing Catholic teachers to accompany Catholic children to the classes, the Rev. Francis X. Fitzgibbon, director of the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine for the Diocese of Brooklyn, announced yesterday.

Steel operations have risen 1 point to 76 1/2 per cent of capacity and show no sign of slackening, the magazine Steel says in its weekly review. Heavy buying has put backlogs at the highest level since 1929, according to the magazine.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Dec. 6. -- Defeating two former national squash racquets champions in succession, Germain Glidden of the Harvard Club of New York today added his name to the distinguished roster of winners of the gold racquet at the Rockaway Hunting Club.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The texts of the Convention Coordinating the Existing Treaties Between the American States and Extending them in Certain Respects, and of the Convention for the Promotion of Cultural Relations, both of which Secretary Hull proposed today to the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace, at Buenos Aires, and which were given out by the State Department here tonight, are as follows:
The Very Rev. Milo H. Gates, dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, pleaded for an unmutilated Bible in his sermon at the cathedral yesterday morning. He said:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Scanning postal revenues for the fiscal year 1936, the Postoffice Department officials saw little likelihood today that the department would recommend return to two cents postage when the Three-Cent Law expires next Summer.

While R.J. Baker, president of the Steamship Owners Association, declared last night that all ships scheduled to leave New York over the week-end had departed, the maritime strike situation on the Pacific Coast remained unchanged.

Rapid transit, bus and street railway lines operating within the city limits carried 3,040,800,000 passengers during the fiscal year fended June 30, 1936, according to a report made public yesterday by the Transit Commission. This traffic represented a gain of 128,400,000 riders, or 4.4 per cent, over the previous fiscal year.
LONDON, Dec. 6. -- Churches throughout Great Britain were crowded today with worshipers offering prayers for King Edward VIII and his Ministers.

As a result of the business upturn, advertisers are now more willing to buy advertising space further in advance than at any time since the depression started, according to comment here yesterday. Another reason for the trend has been the advancing rate structure, with advertisers anxious to have contracts closed before higher rates go into effect.
LONDON, Dec. 6. -- In the mass of confusion which has arisen in this crisis it is essential for us, if we are to act wisely, to keep a firm grip of the central issue involved.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP). -- The Chicago Cardinals, stopping the offense which carried Green Bay to the Western Division championship of the National Football League, battled the Packers to a scoreless tie in the final pro game of the local season today.

The steady rise in the demand for holiday gift items and all lines of staple merchandise was reflected in the wholesale markets here last week. Orders for all types of formal and party dresses, as well as evening wraps, were received in large volume.

BOSTON, Dec. 6. -- A roving, runaway boy salesman of 16, Hubert L. Lewis of 152 West Sixty-fourth Street, New York, is being held by the police here for investigation after his narration of a business travel tale that is out of the ordinary.
MOSCOW, Dec. 6. -- Moscow appealed to the workers of capitalist countries today to accept the new Soviet Constitution as a beacon on their own path toward emancipation.

Only one serious uncertainty confronts the home-building industry in this country, and that pertains to labor, according to the current issue of The American Builder, which estimates that construction activity at present is forging ahead to a total of 260,000 new home units in 1936 and a further increase of 65 per cent predicted for 1937.

PARIS, Dec. 5. -- The Bank of France's return dated Nov. 27 shows a trace of ordinary end-of-the-month credit expansion market requirements. Bills discounted rose 904,000,000 francs; loans to farmers' cooperative societies and popular banks also rose, being higher by 134,000,000 francs.
Prayers for the recovery of Pope Pius XI were offered in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

TEANECK, N.J., Dec. 6. -- Miss Barbara W. Morgan, 22-year-old daughter of Mrs. Helen Morgan of New York and Suffern, was fatally injured today and her brother and two other persons were seriously hurt in an automobile collision at Route 4 and Teaneck Road.
MADRID, Dec. 6. -- All Madrid is steeling itself for a great Rebel attack, which is expected within a few days.
DETROIT, Dec. 6. -- The Detroit Lions today defeated the Brooklyn Dodgers, 14 -- 6, before 11,000 fans here to close their National Football League season.

Tchaikovsky's opera "Mazeppa" was performed by the Ukrainian Art Theatre last night in Carnegie Hall. The same direction produced this work in New York on Feb. 4, 1933, that performance being erroneously described as the first in America.

What of our leaders of industry and finance? If they are to remain leaders they must not skulk behind the skirts of the New Deal. They must lead and be worthy to lead. They must recognize that true leadership is always prepared for change. They must be ready to make concessions which necessary changes may demand.

Nine men and nine women, arrested in raids on two disorderly houses on Saturday night, were arraigned yesterday morning, the men before Magistrate Anna M. Kross in Harlem Court, where they were held in $10 bail each for examination by the Department of Health. The women appeared in Women's Court before Magistrate Samuel M. Iatz, who held them in $500 bail each. Hearing was set for tomorrow for both men and women.

BERLIN, Dec. 4. -- A political demonstration rather than a preventive or punitive measure was the Berlin market's description of law decreeing the death penalty for the illicit transfer of capital abroad. But smuggling of the aggravated character described in the law hardly ever occurs.

At special ceremonies prior to the annual service for friends of the Cathederal of St. John the Divine yesterday afternoon, Bishop William Manning formally accepted the latest addition to the cathedral, a gift of the granite steps leading to the magnificent north portal on the Amsterdam Avenue front of the edifice.

PARIS, Dec. 6. -- All semblance of democratic forms and usages of government has disappeared in Spain, and the first sensation of a newspaper correspondent on arriving in France after covering the civil war for four and one-half months is one of profound relief from strain -- relaxation from fettering restrictions, as though a great burden of prohibitions had been lifted from his shoulders.

PITTSBURGH. Dec. 6. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 77 per cent of capacity, up 2 points from the rate of the two preceding weeks. The percentage was the highest since April, 1930, but the daily tonnage rate was the highest since September, 1929, as the nation's capacity has been increased.

A.F. Marquardt, president of the National Paper Trade Association of the United States, Inc., announced yesterday that the executive committee has authorized A.H. Chamberlain, executive secretary, and J.K. Javits, counsel, to attend as observers the conference called by Major George L. Berry, Coordinator of Industrial Cooperation, to be held in Washington on Dec. 10 and 11.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 6. -- A protest against the "neutral policy of the United States in the Spanish situation" was made today by the State committee of the Socialist party. The committee declared the policy unfair in putting the Rebels on a par with the government in munitions shipments.

LONDON, Dec. 4. -- The grave constitutional problem which has so suddenly confronted Great Britain has completely dominated the financial markets in the last few days. To say that the markets have been unsettled is describing their position mildly.

The Rev. Dr. James M. Farr, vice moderator of the New York Presbytery, officiated yesterday morning at the dedication of a new chancel and a new wing at the Riverdale Presbyterian Church, Riverdale Avenue and 247th Street. The church, built by William Dodge in the 1860's, had grown so rapidly in the last few years that more pews were needed.

A reduction in premium rates for taxicab insurance in New York City, the first reduction in five years, will become effective on Jan. 1, Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, announced yesterday.
CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP). -- Allen Hall of Chicago defeated Earl Lookabaugh, also of Chicago, by 50 to 19 in 41 innings tonight in the world championship three-cushion billiard tournament.
The British dominions have no legal right to play any part in the Simpson case, Lord Marley, a Deputy Speaker of the House of Lords, contended yesterday afternoon at a lecture engagement in Brooklyn.

THOSE were mostly minor operations the baseball moguls performed in their Montreal gathering. Some run-of-the-mill athletes were shifted about, but nothing was done to cause the bleacherites of distant cities to raise a roaring off-season cheer for an acquired diamond idol or deliver a December barrage of brisk booing over a lost star.

ALBANY, Dec. 6. -- Up to Dec. 1, 17,056 new stock companies had been formed in the State this year, Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn reported today. The total was 110 more than during the first eleven months of 1935.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Awards of government contracts under the Walsh-Healy Public Contracts Act in the week ended on Dec. 3 amounted to $5,320,526, the Labor Department announced today.

Trading in the foreign exchange market last week was uneventful in the matter of volume and rate variations. The demand which was small and came chiefly from commercial interests made for a firm undertone.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The text of the Treasury announcements on December financing operations, issued today, follows:

The Whitney Museum of American Art announced yesterday that it had bought eight of the 128 pictures included in its third biennial exhibition of contemporary American painting. The show will close Thursday.

HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 6. -- The bitterest fight in more than a decade for the presidency of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States ended today with a decisive victory for Jeremiah Titus Mahoney, former New York Supreme Court justice and 1935 chief executive of the A.A.U., over his metropolitan antagonist and the administration's standard-bearer.

Still worried lest people find nothing to do on the Sabbath, Catharine A. Bamman last evening launched her "Sunday Nights at Nine" on its fifth season at the little Barbizon-Plaza Theatre. Properly grateful, a friendly audience came in out of the rain to see and hear little sketches, songs and dances that Miss Bamman assembles into a program with which to kill an evening while more formal matters rest in Times Square.

The crippled Red Wings from Detroit prevented the Americans from taking exclusive possession of first place in the international division of the National Hockey League last night. The visiting skaters, forced to trail for the greater part of the encounter at Madison Square Garden, came through with a last-period tally that tied the count and in the overtime session held off the New Yorkers sturdily enough to earn a 3-3 deadlock.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 6. -- The "sidewalk fire chief," captious cousin of the "grandstand quarterback," "back seat automobile driver" and "bleacher baseball manager," will have the opportunity of seeing the error of some of his views graphically demonstrated as soon as Fire Commissioner John A. Bowman completes a motion picture he is working on.

MOUNTAIN LAKES, N.J., Dec. 6. -- George W. Jacobs, one of the few remaining advocates of the most sportsmanlike and one of the most ancient of all weapons -- the bow and arrow -- tossed aside his text-books today and indulged in a little preliminary target practice in his back yard at 93 Ball Road, preparatory to his bow and arrow hunt for deer next week.

LONDON, Dec. 6. -- On this critical day in the life of the British royal family, Queen Mary decided to go back to the scenes of her childhood and to pay a visit of consolation to another Queen even more sorrowful than she.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 10. -- A sleek, almost entirely white pointer bitch, sired by the famous Ch. Nancolleth Markable, which went best in show in the Westminster exhibition at Madison Square Garden a few years ago, tonight captured the premier award in the Newark Kennel Club's twenty-fourth annual all-breed event at the Centre Market Building.

The faith of the world is not a faith in personal reward and personal immortality, but in immortality and reward through the immortality and ultimate triumph of the ideals of truth, justice, freedom and love for which man lives, struggles and dies, the Rev. Dr. Stephen S. Wise, rabbi of the Free Synagogue, declared yesterday morning in his sermon at the services of that congregation in Carnegie Hall.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP). -- In revising the Treasury's borrowing procedure Secretary Morgenthau hopes to eliminate "chiselers," whom he accuses of "trying to beat their own government."

PARIS, Dec. 6. -- Every effort is likely to be made during the next few days to patch up the rift between the Communist members of the Popular Front and Premier Leon Blum's government. The Communists abstained yesterday when the Chamber of Deputies, by a vote of 350 to 171, expressed confidence in the government's foreign policy.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 6. -- Golf honors were well distributed throughout the membership of the Investment Bankers Association at its convention here last week, with Louis S. Lebenthal of Lebenthal Co., New York, capturing the Robert Christie Jr. Memorial Tournament.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6. -- Miss Priscilla Taylor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Taylor of Highclere, Villanova, and Miss Margaret Winifred Dorrance, daughter of Mrs. John T. Dorrance, have been chosen to receive at the second Piccadilly Dance on Saturday at the Bellevue-Stratford.

EASTVILLE, Va., Dec. 6 (AP). -- No longer a "missing person," Russell F. Randolph, retired banker who disappeared three months ago from his home in Bernardsville, N.J., said today that he would not return home for Christmas.
Complete satisfaction with the rules as interpreted last season was expressed by the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League at a meeting yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

LONDON, Monday, Dec. 7. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin viii not be enabled to make his expected announcement in Parliament today that King Edward has abdicated, for the simple reason that no such official, irrevocable decision has yet been reached by the monarch.

NEWARK, N. J., Dec. 6. -- Five hundred Catholics who are deaf or hard of hearing, attended tonight the opening services of a three-day mission being given in St. Patrick's Cathedral. The Rev. Stephen J. Landherr of Esopus, N. Y., a member of the ledemptorist Order. preached the sermon at tonight's services and also will preach at services tomorrow night and Tuesday night.
MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 6. -- Mexico will grant to Leon Trotsky the right of asylum as soon as it is formally requested, Foreign Secretary Eduardo Hay officially announced tonight.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 6. -- That the Investment Bankers Association should continue to be in a position, frankly and independently, to express its views and recommendations on problems of Federal regulation, was voiced as essential by Edward B. Hall of Harris, Hall Co., Chicago, newly elected president of the association.

Veiled references to the possibility of King Edward's marriage to Mrs. Wallis Simpson were made in several churches here yesterday. In several Episcopal churches prayers were offered for King Edward and the British Empire. References in the sermons were mostly indirect.
VATICAN CITY, Dec. 6. -- A distinctly more hopeful atmosphere prevailed in the Vatican today concerning Pope Pius's health. He had spent a good night and awakened greatly refreshed in body and mind.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Dec. 6 (AP). -- Tornadic winds ripped through sections of three South Central States today, injuring twenty-four persons, killing livestock and damaging a dozen homes and business buildings.

Veiled references to the possibility of King Edward's marriage to Mrs. Wallis Simpson were made in several churches here yesterday. In several Episcopal churches prayers were offered for King Edward and the British Empire. References in the sermons were mostly indirect.
VATICAN CITY, Dec. 6. -- A distinctly more hopeful atmosphere prevailed in the Vatican today concerning Pope Pius's health. He had spent a good night and awakened greatly refreshed in body and mind.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Farmers' cooperative purchasing of supplies reached the highest levels on record in the 1935-36 marketing season, amounting to $309,000,000, or an increase of almost one-fourth over 1934-35, according to an announcement today by the Cooperative Division of the Farm Credit Administration.

Under the influence of buying by the cotton trade, prices of cotton advanced appreciably last week on the New York Cotton Exchange, net increases ranging from 29 points in December contracts to 23 in the July and the new crop October.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 5. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 86.7, which compares with 86 the week before, 86.1 two weeks before, 85.3 three weeks before and 84.7 four weeks before.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Dec. 6 (AP). -- Tornadic winds ripped through sections of three South Central States today, injuring twenty-four persons, killing livestock and damaging a dozen homes and business buildings.
Favorites advanced as the Long Island championship play of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association reached the third round at the Jackson Heights Squash Club yesterday.
CANNES, France, Dec. 6. -- Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson, who was extremely tired after her journey from London, remained all day in the Lou Viei villa with her hosts, Mr. and Mrs. Herman L. Rogers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 6. -- Gloria Swanson is reported on her way to Broadway to discuss with Theron Bamberger the possibility of her appearing in his Gladys Hurlbut's "Lovers' Meeting." John Wildberg, representing Bamberger, had conducted preliminary negotiations with Miss Swanson about the play.

Your correspondent, Thomas H. Greene, in his interesting letter suggests "a tough-minded foreign policy" for the United States. With this point of view I am in hearty agreement. Nevertheless, I wonder whether a policy of neutrality at any cost is as "tough-minded" as Mr. Greene thinks it is.

BILBAO, Spain, Dec. 6. -- The importance of the government's operations in the north became evident over the week-end, for it is now seen that the Insurgent capital of Burgos is being menaced by two armies -- a Basque army operating from Bilbao and one advancing from Santander, which has reached a point near Sedano, within twenty-five miles of Burgos.

BUENOS AIRES, Dee. 6. -- A draft neutrality convention was formally presented to the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace here today as the principal United States contribution to the effort to preserve peace in this hemisphere and to the attempt to isolate the Americas from war in other parts of the world.

Mrs. Elisha Walker and Mrs. Ernest Guy Stevens gave a reception yesterday afternoon at Mrs. Walker's home, 33 East Sixty-ninth Street, for Mrs. Stevens's debutante daughter, Miss Hope Stevens. Miss Stevens will be introduced formally to society at a dinner dance to be given by her aunt, Mrs. Walker, on Dec. 30 at her home.

Paving the way for the resumption of an international series started in 1922, the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association yesterday unanimously voted to accept Great Britain's invitation to play there next Summer. Little time was lost in setting up a committee which was empowered to complete negotiations with the North of England Lacrosse Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Quoting the lowest long-term interest rate of any public bond offering made by the government in its history, with the exception of three special issues, the Treasury in announcing today a financing operation totaling $1,486,651,900 put a curb on the big subscriber who hitherto has gained an advantage meant for the "little fellow."

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 6. -- The Montclair Athletic Club, last season's B champion, and the Englewood Field Club, holder of the C title, scored in the opening matches today in the New Jersey division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association, in which both B and C players compete during this campaign.

St. Francis Prep and Bishop Loughlin Memorial High accounted for their second consecutive triumphs and remained in a tie for first place as competition in the annual Catholic High Schools Athletic Association swimming championships was resumed in the Columbus Council, K. of C., pool in Brooklyn yesterday.

Infantile paralysis sufferers will be aided again by a nation-wide series of balls, to be held on the occasion of President Roosevelt's fifty-fifth birthday on Jan. 30, according to an announcement made yesterday by Colonel Henry L. Doherty, who will once more act as national chairman of the Birthday Ball of the President.

" It is to the engineer that we must look for guidance," remarked Dr. NICHOLAS MURRAY BUTLER, in his discussion of our perplexed times before the Society for the Promotion of Engineering Education. If our problems are not all technological, at least they demand the kind of analysis that we associate with science.

The Atlantic City Sea Gulls beat the New York Rovers yesterday afternoon, strengthened their lead in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League and left little doubt that they are enjoying their position at the head of the pack and mean to stay there.

Opening of headquarters of the Progressive City Committee in the Hotel Roosevelt for the purpose of taking an active part in the coming city campaign was announced yesterday by Maurice P. Davidson, its chairman. For the present the committee will avoid commitment to any candidate and will center its efforts on the study of civic problems by committees.

The Max Gordon Plays and Pictures Corporation, which would offer legitimate attractions here and then make them into films in Hollywood, will swing into action with Mr. Gordon's next production, "The Women." Broadway, which has heard of such projects before but has never seen them materialize, is wondering if this is not one way out of the Broadway-Hollywood impasse.
HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 6. -- The Dartmouth College athletic council today announced the complete hockey schedule for this coming season.

Mrs. Mary Flanagan of Montrose, W. Va., who has been balked repeatedly in her efforts to "collect" the first prize for her essay on "Why President Roosevelt Must be Re-elected," is again unable to avail herself of the honor, it was disclosed yesterday.

The management of the American Car and Foundry Company is considering the resumption of dividends for the first time since 1932, it was announced yesterday in a statement by Charles J. Hardy, president.

The Green Bay Packers, who will engage the Boston Redskins on Sunday for the National Football League championship, wound up their regular schedule by garnering team honors in scoring and forward passing, according to the final figures released yesterday.

CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 7. -- Australia passed another tense day. The Cabinet met this morning, after which Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons said the Ministers were awaiting a communication from Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin informing the government of the position regarding King Edward that he would disclose in the House of Commons.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Dec. 7. -- David R. Longenecker of the Rockville Country Club was elected president of the Long Island Golf Association tonight at the annual dinner and meeting of the association in the Garden City Hotel.

A joint legislative committee under Senator Lazarus Joseph of the Bronx, investigating the possible need for remedial enactments at the forthcoming session in Albany, yesterday began questioning bank and insurance company officials with whom mortgages were lodged as corporate trustees when issues of mortgage certificates were floated.

Kirsten Flagstad returned to New York yesterday from her transcontinental tour. She will appear in recital at Carnegie Hall tomorrow night, and at once begin rehearsals for the Metropolitan Opera season.

Four men charged with first-degree murder went on trial in Kings County Court yesterday for the fatal shooting of Isaac Shain who on the first visit in his life to a bar-room interrupted a hold-up last month in the mistaken belief that the robbers were only practical jokesters.

The Treasury's offer of $1,486,651,900 seventeen-year bonds with 2 1/2 per cent interest is something of a landmark in these days. Out of the total offering, $786,651,900 is to be exchanged for maturing short-term loans bearing 2 3/4 and 3 per cent; for the remaining $700,000,000, cash subscriptions are invited.

Commodity futures markets generally were sharply lower yesterday. Cocoa prices had their sharpest break in months in heavy trading. In the cash market, wheat, corn, rye, oats, lard, pork, cotton, tin and wool tops were higher, while cocoa, silk and rubber were lower.
Numerous arguments offered regarding the so-called constitutional crisis in England appear to be based on a misunderstanding of the significance of the affair.
DAKAR, Senegal, Dec. 7 (AP). -- Fears for the safety of Jean Mermoz, famous French pilot and World War ace, mounted tonight as a searching plane returned without a clue.

There have been allusions to the Church of England which tend to represent it as being subservient to the Crown in spiritual matters, with particular reference to its teaching and discipline in the matter of marriage. There is no such subservience; nor could any priest of the Anglican communion be compelled to officiate at the union of the King to a woman who has a husband still living.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The text of the Supreme Court's opinion upholding the constitutionality of the Illinois Fair Trade Practice Law was as follows:
George W. Jacobs, a science instructor at the Mountain Lakes School, wants the New Jersey Fish and Game Commission to set aside a few days as a special deer hunting season for archers exclusively.

Mr. and Mrs. Herman Livingston Rogers, now acting as host and hostess to Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson at their villa, Lou Viei, at Cannes, France, are friends of long standing of King Edward VIII and Mrs. Simpson.

HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 7. -- Outlining a six-point program for far-reaching development of American athletics, Jeremiah Titus Mahoney of New York, newly-elected president of the Amateur Athletic Union, followed up his decisive victory over the forces led by Chicago's Avery Brundage with a strong attack today upon "athletic nationalism."

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Dec. 7. -- A new shipping service inking New Zealand and Canada is proposed in a report of the Imperial Shipping Committee, released here following London conferences of empire countries.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 7. -- The European armament race weighed down hope tonight of approval of an American arms limitation agreement at the Inter-American Peace Conference.

The extraordinary term of Special Sessions to hear misdemeanor charges developed since last May against thirty-six persons in the new Accident Fraud Bureau under Bernard Botein, Assistant District Attorney, held its first session yesterday.

With interest in financial circles yesterday centered on details of the Federal financing of Dec. 15, the listed bond market was relatively neglected. Most of the loans traded on the New York Stock Exchange moved within a comparatively narrow range on a sharply restricted turnover.

Unsettled securities values following the approach of the crisis in King Edward's affairs raise anew the question whether such fortuitous events have any great influence on the trend of the stock market. By "fortuitous" is meant such occurrences as for the most part cannot be discounted in advance and are often non-economic in nature.

Demetrius Sicilianos, Greek Minister to the United States, formally opened the annual bazaar of refugee handicrafts at the headquarters of the Near East Foundation, 2 West Forty-sixth Street, yesterday afternoon. The foundation will continue the bazaar throughout the week.

The National Preaching Mission, which has been carried on successively in twenty-seven of the largest cities of this country since Sept. 13, was climaxed last night with a mass meeting in Madison Square Garden. With the crowd estimated at 18,000 it was the largest for the Protestant churches of all faiths ever held in the city, it was said.

Jacob A. Livingston, who has been a member of the Board of Elections since 1911, was recommended for reappointment for another two-year term last night at a special meeting of the Kings County Republican Committee in the Tenth Assembly District Republican Club, 175 South Oxford Street.
SYDNEY, Australia (Canadian Press via Reuters). -- Speaking of the issue between King Edward and the British Cabinet, B.S.B. Stevens, Premier of New South Wales, said today:

Two exhibitions made up of material relating directly to the theatre are on the boards this week. At the Museum of French Art, French Institute in the United States, 22 East Sixtieth Street, a large exhibition called Decorative Arts in the French Theatre will open with a reception at 10 o'clock this evening and to the public tomorrow.

LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 8. -- A statement that Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin made in the House of Commons yesterday declaring that King Edward had not yet made up his mind concerning his ultimate choice between the throne and Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson was seen and approved by the King before the Prime Minister gave it to the Commons.
After-theatre crowds on Broadway near Fiftieth Street saw two traffic policemen, with revolvers drawn, halt a taxicab and capture two hold-up men about 11:30 o'clock last night.

A contribution of $50,000 has been made to the United Hospital Campaign by the Consolidated Edison Company, it was announced last night by Edward R. Stettinius, chairman of the commerce and industry committee of the campaign, at a dinner meeting at the Union Club.

MONTREAL, Dec. 7 (Canadian Press). -- Six National Hockey League marksmen are crowding Dave (Sweeney) Schriner, star wing of the New York Americans, for league scoring honors, official statistics issued tonight revealed.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 7. -- Columbia University will return to the Yale Bowl in 1938, according to the football schedule announced tonight by the Yale Athletic Association. The Lions opened the season here in 1934 and again will raise the curtain. The game will be played Oct. 1.

BRISBANE, Australia, Tuesday, Dec. 8 (Canadian Press). -- The tea-time score of the first of five cricket matches of England's test series with Australia showed the English batsmen had compiled 211 runs for eight wickets today in their second innings. The English eleven scored 358 in their first turn at bat, the Aussies replying with 234.

VATICAN CITY, Dec. 7. -- The slight but unmistakable improvement that set in yesterday in Pope Pius's condition continued today. Again the Pontiff enjoyed a quiet, restful night and awakened refreshed physically and mentally.

Workmen who have bored through solid rock 150 feet under water for more than a year will hole through the mile-long tunnel connecting the Bronx and the $28,000,000 Wards Island sewage disposal plant at 4 P.M. today, Sanitation Commissioner William F. Carey announced yesterday.

John Sage, retired assistant cashier of the Bank of America in New York, who died at Glen Rock, N.J., on Oct. 11, bequeathed his residuary estate of undetermined value to the Lord Provost of Glasgow, Scotland, to aid wounded British soldiers and sailors, and $10,000 to the New York Skin and Cancer Hospital.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7. -- The wheat market on the Board of Trade today had a strong undertone, being influenced by relative strength in Liverpool, a sustained demand for cash wheat from Italy and a decidedly bullish estimate on the new Argentine crop.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 7. -- So long as Japan and certain European powers continue their preparations for war, Nicaragua will oppose any move for Pan-American disarmament, on the ground that it might put the United States at a disadvantage.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 7. -- The 1937 Preakness Stakes at Pimlico will carry an added money value of $50,000, it was announced today at a meeting of the directors of the Maryland Jockey Club.

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- When thousands of Londoners living in the northern section of the city awoke this morning to find hundreds of walls, fences and sides of buildings bearing the chalked words, "Stand by the King!" it was abundantly apparent that the British Fascist party had seized upon the impasse between King Edward VIII and his Ministers as a weapon to further their own ends.
Will H. Hays, Motion Pictures Coordinator, returned yesterday on the French liner Normandie after visiting a month in Europe, chiefly in Italy.
ITS the top man who is the shining target. As the dizzy world spins on there is accumulating evidence that the old Bard of Avon had it right when he fingered his goose-quill and wrote:

Mrs. Morris Aron, who has helped thousands of crippled children to obtain medical treatment, schooling, jobs and a new outlook on life, was guest of honor yesterday at a luncheon tendered her by 100 past and present board members of Crippled Children's After Care, Inc., an organization she headed for fifteen years.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Dec. 7. -- Minnesota's mighty eleven was ranked today as the nation's most powerful college football team by Professor Frank G. Dickinson of the University of Illinois, originator of the rating system bearing his name.

Wearing ten-gallon cowboy hats and heavily laden with souvenirs of their trip to Texas, Manhattan's football players returned to New York yesterday after their game with Texas A. and M. at Tyler Saturday. Despite their one-touchdown defeat, the Jaspers were greeted vociferously by the college band and several hundred students.

Eight boys and a little girl, ranging in age from 9 to 15 years, who were among the thirty-nine children picked up by the police on Saturday night for seeking alms in the theatre district under the pretense of giving trifling services, were arraigned before Justice Herbert A. O'Brien yesterday in Children's Court.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

The shrewdest of all judges of football talent are the coaches and scouts of professional football teams -- the men who study and appraise college stars from a strictly practical point of view, unswayed by headlines or tradition, weighing the candidates by every possible standard of football measurement, paying attention to nothing but solid worth and ability.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- Justice Jennings Bailey ordered in the District of Columbia Supreme Court today that a certificate of American citizenship be issued to Winston Guest, polo player.

The Boston Redskins and the Green Bay Packers will play off for the championship of the National Football League on the neutral battlefield of New York's Polo Grounds on Sunday, it was announced yesterday by Joe F. Carr, president of the professional football circuit.

The New York Rangers will be hosts to the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League encounter at Madison Square Garden tonight. The sextets met in Chicago on Sunday night, with the Patrickmen scoring a 2-to-1 victory.
Investment purchases of several apartment buildings were reported yesterday in various sections of New Jersey.
Dean Detton of Salt Lake City threw Bill Sledge of Houston, Texas, last night in the feature bout of a wrestling show at the New York Hippodrome before 3,500 spectators.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Dec. 2 shows increases for the week of $58,000,000 in total loans and investments, $53,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks and $37,000,000 in balances with domestic banks, and a decrease of $60,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- Sluggishness in the stock market continued today to reflect the uncertainty in the constitutional issue between the King and the Cabinet. The only outstanding advance was in rubber company shares, which responded sharply to a rise in spot rubber to 9 5-16d a pound.

Employment figures today are greater than ever before in the United States and yet there are more than 8,000,000 employables out of work, Roger Babson told several hundred Babson clients at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday afternoon.

The number of new cases of diphtheria in the city in the week ended last Saturday reached the highest total of any week since July 11, twenty-seven new cases having been reported, Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, announced yesterday.

We of the United States offer our felicitations to Finland on the sixteenth anniversary of her independence, and with special ardor for that she pays her debts when they are due. We read reports of her physical resources, cultural achievements (a symphony of SIBELIUS being still in our ears) and her tourismic attractions.

PEIPING, China, Tuesday, Dec. 8. -- An unidentified airplane circled over Peiping yesterday dropping thousands of handbills signed by General Wang Ying, commander of the Mongols seeking to invade Suiyuan Province.

The Kansas City Public Service Company has made public a reorganization plan dated Dec. 1, approved by voting trustees for its preferred and common stocks, under which holders of $14,887,200 of first mortgage bonds will receive an equal principal amount of new first mortgage 4 per cent bonds.

Fourteenth Street vehicular traffic was tied up for nearly a half hour after 6:30 o'clock last night when Madeline Edwert, 18 years old, a nursemaid, of 218 East Thirty-fourth Street, was struck by bus as she ran across Fourth Avenue near Fourteenth Street.

With some 650 exhibitors displaying their Spring and Summer lines in what is claimed to be the largest showing of shoes under one roof ever held, members of the National Volume Shoe Manufacturers Association yesterday started booking orders from some 2,500 buyers at the Hotel New Yorker.

Preparations for the International Ski Meet and Winter Sports Show that will start tomorrow night and continue through Saturday at Madison Square Garden were speeded yesterday with the construction of the inrun for the towering slide that will reach the ceiling of the Ninth Avenue end.

Kid Chocolate's comeback hopes received a rude jolt last night at the St. Nicholas Palace, when he dropped a ten-round decision to Phil (Matra) Baker of Norwalk, Conn., before a near-capacity crowd of 4,500 persons.

The Walter Huston "Othello," due at the New Amsterdam Dec. 28, apparently is going to be along a little later than that; it opens on Christmas night at the Forrest, Philadelphia, where, obviously, it would stay more than two days. It will be idle Dec. 21-24, following its week in Washington. . . .

Acting in sympathy with striking employes of the mechanical department of the paper, ten members of the editorial staff of The North Shore Daily Journal, with publication offices at Northern Boulevard and Union Street, Flushing, Queens, refused yesterday to walk through picket lines in front of the building and did not report for work.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 7. -- Before it can consider passing an unemployment insurance law when it reconvenes tomorrow, the Ohio Legislature must assume the role of magician and crowd 140 days into about two hours.

SUNNINGDALE, England, Dec. 7. -- Almost simultaneously with the announcement from Cannes that Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson was ready to give up King Edward, guards outside the gates of Fort Belvedere, the King's retreat, sprang to attention and a large automobile carrying the Duke of York swept into the silent grounds.

Trading in silk and synthetic gray goods last week was again very active and covered a wide range of fabrics, according to the market report issued yesterday by Nickel, Barrett, Lieberman Quinn, textile brokers. The buying was described as "strong," in that spot deliveries, which represented over 50 per cent of the total volume, were going into consumption at once.

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- Winston Churchill's hopes of returning to office have been shattered almost beyond repair, it was generally felt in political circles tonight, as a result of his self-appointed advocacy of the King's cause during the present crisis.

James R. Garfield and Hermann Hagedorn received bronze medals of honor yesterday afternoon at a reception for officers and trustees of the Roosevelt Memorial Association and their wives, given by the Women's Roosevelt Memorial Association at Roosevelt House, 28 East Twentieth Street, the birthplace of President Theodore Roosevelt.

The De Witt Clinton High School quintet gained its second straight success in the Bronx division of the P.S.A.L. and took first place by downing Morris High, 41 -- 13, on the winners' floor yesterday. The game was one of five staged in the metropolitan area.

An amended complaint in the suit for $850,000 brought by 217 home owners in the Sunnyside Gardens community of Queens against officers of the City Housing Corporation and its subsidiaries was served yesterday on attorneys for twenty-two defendants, according to Walter Fairchild, attorney for the home owners.

CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE N.J., Dec. 7. -- A legal battle for control of the New Jersey Senate opened here today in Circuit Court before Judge Wilfred H. Jayne, with Democrats charging that their candidate for the State Senate was defeated fraudulently.

OTTAWA, Dec. 7. -- Prime Minister William L. Mackenzie King tonight maintained his refusal to disclose the position of the Government of Canada in respect to the British constitutional controversy over the King's marriage plans.

Passengers arriving today from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria include General Robert E. Wood, president of Sears, Roebuck Co.; Lieut. Comm. and Mrs. Edward St. John Edmondstone, William Brownlow, Capt. and Mrs. John W. McGrath, Mr. and Mrs. Allison Dodd, W.F. Philips, C.H. Wilcox, Mr. and Mrs. F.J. Burd and Mrs. William Yarrow.

Just as it is preparing to launch an extensive test campaign on the use of lemons with bicarbonate of soda as a substitute for laxatives, the California Fruit Growers Exchange has run into a snag on its competitive advertising for Sunkist navel oranges.
Two 105-yard runs, a successful 66-yard forward pass, and a flurry of 80-yard punts were the spectacular highlights of the 1936 college football season, an Associated Press survey revealed yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 7. -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors, acting in its capacity as a county board of canvassers, officially canvassed this afternoon the vote for State Senate in the Twenty-sixth Senatorial District, showing James A. Garrity, Democrat, won the election by 175 votes.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7. -- Hog prices advanced 15 to 30 cents today to the highest level in eight weeks as the result of sharply curtailed receipts incident to the subzero temperatures throughout the West. The top advanced 30 cents to $10.30 a hundredweight, the highest December price in ten years.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7. -- Jay Bozeman of Detroit defeated Johnny Layton of Sedalia, Mo., 50 to 27, in sixty innings in the world championship three-cushion billiard tournament tonight. The setback dropped Layton into a tie for first place with Kinrey Matsuyama, Japanese star, each with five victories and two losses.

Karl Ditters von Dittersdorf, Bach and Mozart of the eighteenth century, and Deems Taylor and Robert McBride of our day and country mingled amiably last night in the second concert of the five that Hans Lange and the Philharmonic-Symphony Chamber Orchestra are presenting at the Town Hall for the benefit of the scholarship fund of Bennington College.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 7. -- Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, State Democratic leader, and United States Senator A. Harry Moore are seeking a conference with Harry L. Hopkins, national head of the Works Progress Administration, in an effort to have the layoffs of project workers, already under way, delayed until after the Christmas holidays, it was announced today by William H.J. Ely, State Administrator.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The Supreme Court in making seventeen decisions today refused to go into an attack upon the Commodity Exchange Act by a Chicago commodities trader and a group of members of the Chicago Board of Trade. The law amended the Grain Futures Act under which grain markets have operated for fourteen years and subjected to government regulation the exchanges dealing in grains, butter, eggs and Irish potatoes.

Fully 500,000 persons, of whom only a small proportion died in battle, are estimated to have been killed in Spain since the start of the revolution, Rear Admiral Cary T. Grayson, chairman of the American National Red Cross, said yesterday.

The indecisive movements of prices of last week were repeated yesterday in the stock market. Cautious buying lowered the resistance points slightly with respect to leading issues, whereas many low-priced stocks and customarily inactive issues gained ground.

One alleged burglar was caught, a woman was injured by glass shattered by ricocheting bullets and the lives of a detective and dozens of residents in the apartment house at 68 West 107th Street were endangered last night by gunfire as the police made a spectacular effort to capture burglars held responsible for 100 thefts in the neighborhood.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 7 (AP). -- A plan of reorganization for the St. Louis-Southwestern (Cotton Belt) Railway, which petitioned a year ago for reorganization under the amended Bankruptcy Act, was filed today with the Federal court here and the Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The "original cost" provisions of the Federal Communications Commission's order for a uniform system of accounting by telephone companies were unanimously upheld by the Supreme Court today in an opinion presented by Justice Cardozo.
MADRID, Dec. 7. -- Madrid's defense officials completed preparations tonight for a Rebel onslaught that they expected to follow an artillery bombardment that razed huge blocks of apartment buildings.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 7. -- Apprentice Ralph Eccard, who rode the first winner of his career several days ago when under colors the second time in his life, piloted D.L. Ogle's Patchpocket to a stirring victory in the six-furlong dash that topped today's program at the Fair Grounds.

Lucrezia Bori, who retired last Spring after more than twenty years with the Metropolitan Opera Company, will sing at the Metropolitan Opera House again. Next Sunday evening she will be heard at the party of the Metropolitan Opera Guild.

Three pleasantly spoken young men with pistols deftly robbed Mrs. Jeanne E. Kerbs of $40,000 worth of jewelry after they had kidnapped her and her first cousin, Lester Meyer, from in front of her home at 983 Park Avenue, near Eighty-third Street, at 4 o'clock yesterday morning.

The Hundred Neediest Cases enters this week upon its twenty-fifth year and with a record of nearly 25,000 individuals assisted by well toward 200,000 givers in an amount approaching $5,000,000. It would be a happy consummation of this year's appeal if the quarter century could carry these totals to the full measure of these "approached" round numbers.

BERLIN, Dec. 7. -- Trading on he Boerse today was listless and weak throughout the list. Heavy industrials fell, with average losses ,,A to , point, but Bruderus lost 1 points. Potashes were soft at the opening. ]Vrachines weakened, ]uag losing point.

A jury was chosen in two and one-half hours in General Sessions yesterday for the trial of A. Henry Ross, a lawyer, of 185 Montague Street, Brooklyn, and Max D. Krone, a private detective, of 255 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, as members of an extortion ring.

Section 901 of the Social Security Act imposed on every employer of eight or more persons a tax of 1 per cent a year on his total payroll for the calendar year beginning Jan. 1, 1936; a tax of 2 per cent for 1937, and a tax of 3 per cent for 1938 and succeeding years.

.-ore than 1,500 persons, including dignitaries of church and State, attended funeral services yesterday morning for .Mgr. Mallick J. Fitzpatrick, treasurer and director in charge of the Mission of the Immaculate Virgin for the Protection of Homeless and Destitute Chil-] dren, Inc., at SS. Joachim and Ann I Catholic Church at Mount Loretto, I Pleasant Plains, S.I.
SEATTLE, Dec. 7. -- Nosing over in landing at Boeing Field after a test flight, the Boeing bomber YB-17 crumpled its nose in the earth today. Damage was not expected to exceed $5,000.

Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Works Progress Administrator, informed Mayor La Guardia yesterday that he would take no step toward curtailing WPA funds for this city until he had conferred with the Mayor late this week.

Ivy Lee Jr. of the University Club, seeded third, was the only favorite to be eliminated as play started in the annual Class B invitation squash racquets tourney at the Squash Club yesterday. Lee was beaten in four games by the home club representative, Dr. R.E. Church, 8 -- 15, 15 -- 5, 15 -- 6, 15 -- 12.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 7. -- Rugged Ralph Guldahl of St. Louis walked off with the $2,500 top check in the Miami Biltmore's seventh annual open golf tournament today.

In an editorial published Dec. 3 you pointed out the complexity involved in counting the votes under proportional representation, minimizing, however the difficulties that also arise for the voter. When there are ten or more preferential choices to be made the voter, unless he has made considerable study and goes to the booth with a written memorandum, might have difficulty in getting his ballot marked within the allotted time.

The Tariff Act of 1930 that prohibits the importation of contraceptives does not apply to articles received here for use under the direction of physicians for the purpose of preserving health, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company, Inc., of New York City, had today before the Federal Communications Commission a rehearing on its application, which was denied last Summer, to add Oslo, Norway, as a point of communication to its radio circuit.

A sentence of twenty to forty years in Sing Sing was imposed yesterday by Judge Jonah J. Goldstein in General Sessions on David Feinberg, convicted of criminally receiving $2,880 in wigs, the proceeds of a burglary.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 7. -- The Baltimore Bachelors' Cotillion was held tonight, and for the first time in the history of the event the thirty-seven debutantes from New York, Philadelphia, New England and the South equaled the number from Maryland.

With Commissioner K.M. Landis slated to unveil his long-deferred decision on the celebrated Bob Feller case and such hardy perennials as radio, the lively ball and night baseball certain to provide ample protection against any possible lulls in conversation, the sixteen club owners of the two major leagues open their annual Winter conclave today.

With Christmas shopping surging forward, reorders on gift merchandise continued to reach the wholesale markets here in volume yesterday. Owing to the tight delivery situation on lines ranging from toys to lingerie and handbags, many more buyers than is usually the case at this time were in the markets to try to speed up delayed shipments.
The latest dilemma which confronts England and the British dominions is indeed a serious one and calls for that calm and fair-minded consideration for which the English people are renowned.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- Conde Nast Publications, Inc., publisher of Vogue Magazine, was ordered today by the Federal Trade Commission to discontinue "certain unfair competitive practices" in promoting the sale of women's garments through the medium of the magazine in a manner violative of the Federal Trade Commission Act.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP). -- Led by fleet-footed Harry Newman, the New York Yankees tonight defeated the Boston Shamrocks, 20 to 13, in the final game of the American Football League season.

Awards to seventy-eight City College athletes who were members of the 1936 varsity and junior varsity football squads and the varsity cross country team were announced yesterday by Professor Walter Williamson, college manager of athletics.

James G. Blaine, president of the Marine Midland Trust Company of New York, presiding last night at a dinner of the Bankers Forum, New York Chapter of the American Institute of Banking, in the Hotel Roosevelt, delivered a plea for private banking interests and the Federal Government to get together in the interests of recovery.

Two plans for retrenchment in the Federal relief program seem to be receiving consideration. One is a proposal to eliminate from the payrolls of WPA the very considerable number of relief-workers (estimated in Washington at 150,000) who have other sources of income.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The company union plan of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, will come under the scrutiny of the National Labor Relations Board Dec. 17 as the result of a complaint issued today by the board, which alleged that the corporations dominated and financially supported the plan of employe representation established three years ago.

Members of the Eastern and Gulf Sailors Association at meetings in fourteen port cities ranging from Boston to Galveston last night ejected their national officers and placed control of union affairs in the hands of local agents pending a general election.

A critical shortage of skilled workers for industrial production and the necessity for training apprentices was called to the attention of the National Industrial Council here yesterday by Warner Seely, secretary of the Warner Swasey Company of Cleveland.

Eddie Cantor, comedian of stage, motion picture and radio, took the role of a serious spectator in Supreme Court yesterday while his former radio "gag man," David Freedman, testified in the latter's suit for 10 per cent of the comedian's gross radio receipts.

CANNES, France, Dec. 7. -- A brief prepared statement by Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson, expressing readiness to "withdraw from a situation that has been rendered both unhappy and untenable," was given to the press tonight in her behalf by Lord Brownlow, private secretary to King Edward VIII, who accompanied her on her hurried trip here from England.

GENEVA, Dec. 7. -- Two points in the American neutrality pact proposed at Buenos Aires seem to draw the most attention in League of Nations circles. One is the neutrality feature, which does not make a good impression; the other is the suggested establishment of a consultative commission to implement the treaty, which commands interest particularly because of its permanence, and even more because of its power to define aggression.

A railroad is not compelled to provide a coach train seat for a passenger, it was ruled yesterday by Municipal Court Justice Joseph Raimo in dismissing an action brought by Philip Davis, an attorney, of 535 Fifth Avenue, against the New York Central Railroad.

" The untutored Mr. Chips" of Case 10, Annie B. of Case 86, who wanted only "a little bit for bread and tea," and the young mother of Case 38 are no longer included in the legion of New York's Neediest Cases.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 8. -- Manchukuo will go to the assistance of the Inner Mongolians now fighting in Suiyuan Province, China, Premier Chang Ching-hui announced today at Hsinking.

DECEMBER is usually set aside by the publishers for a breathing spell. Any potential best-seller, any book likely to be thought of as a suitable Christmas gift, is timed to appear somewhere between September and November, so that when the holiday shopping period is in full blast, its reputation and sales will already have acquired a certain momentum.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 7. -- Mrs. Margaret Emerson gave a dinner tonight for eighteen including her house guests, Mr. and Mrs. Aksel Wichfeld, Mr. and Mrs. Douglas W. Paige and Mr. and Mrs. Frederick M. Alger Jr.

The Spanish civil war issues were brought into New York waters yesterday when the Spanish owners of the 5,000-ton freighter Navemar, anchored off Red Hook flats, Brooklyn, charged in the Brooklyn Federal court that a committee of the crew had forcibly seized the vessel in a South American port, brought it to New York and were now refusing to relinquish it.

Jacques Jolas, pianist, played a well arranged program, one that was not too long and that presented unhackneyed material in an unhackneyed way, yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. The immediate impression of his performance was the gratifying one of a musician of indubitable gifts, whose playing, first and foremost, had conviction, profile and life.

If Jerome Herman Dean is dizzy, the owners and managers of other National League clubs who would like to have him, not to mention the scribes who try to follow the devious trail of Branch Rickey, are apt to be much dizzier before the 1937 affiliation of the ace Cardinal pitcher is decided upon.

OSLO, Norway, Dec. 7 (AP). -- Premier Johann Nygaardsvold indicated tonight that Leon Trotsky, offered a haven in Mexico, would be ousted from Norway if he did not leave of his own will when his permit to stay expired Dec. 18.

The announcement of the terms of the Treasury's December financing, coming, as it did, almost simultaneously with the attack on the government's easy money policy by Lionel D. Edie at the Investment Bankers Association convention in Augusta, Ga., on Sunday, brought the question of the possible aftermaths of this policy to the front as a topic of discussion in banking circles yesterday.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Dec. 7. -- A suggestion that the fraternities at the Peddie School here disband because there is "no place for them" in the school life is contained in an editorial in the current issue of The Peddie News, undergraduate newspaper.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The pursuit of liberal legislative policies and the practice of extreme liberality as to party status were set forth here yesterday as the aims of the Republican side of the Senate in the coming session by a group of regulars, whose discussion of the party situation was revealed today.

LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 8. -- The proposal for a morganatic marriage between King Edward VIII and Mrs. Simpson, which the newspapers voicing the opinion of the King's party have been presenting with added force, was countered this morning with equal vehemence by the "government press."

Melvin C. Eaton, chairman of the Republican State Committee, is preparing to enter a vigorous denial of statements by former Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley, recent Republican nominee for Governor. Mr. Bleakley has been quoted as saying that he failed to receive proper support from the committee under Mr. Eaton's leadership.

The Princeton Club gained undisputed possession of first place in the Metropolitan League Class B squash tennis tournament with a 4-1 victory over City A.C. yesterday on its home courts. It was the first defeat of the season for City.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 7. -- A faded little stamp of British Guiana, dated 1856 and pretty generally labeled as the "world's most valuable," excited delegates to the American Philatelic Congress today, although it was not to be found among the thousands of items on display.

In editorials you join with Prime Minister Baldwin in giving to King Edward "advice" that he abdicate rather than "plunge Great Britain into a new general election"; and imply that, should he precipitate the horrors of such an election, the British people would no longer remain a true democracy.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 7. -- Warner Brothers have abandoned plans for "Joan of Arc," which was to have starred Claudette Colbert under Anatol Litvaks direction. As a result, Miss Colbert, in fulfillment of her one-picture commitment with the studio, will have the lead in "Tovarich."

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 7. -- Governor Hoffman late today granted California's requisition for extradition of Mrs. Maryon Cooper Hewitt on a charge of conspiracy to commit mayhem. Her daughter Ann accuses her of responsibility for a sterilization operation allegedly designed to end the line of heirs to the Cooper Hewitt fortune.

About 200 guests, most of whom were obviously thankful for the warmth of the reception room, attended a farewell party in honor of Mrs. Joseph E. Davies, who will leave shortly for Moscow, where her husband will assume his duties as American Ambassador to the Soviet Union.

Many parties were given last night in connection with the supper dance in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria, from which the Big Brother Movement, received a percentage of the proceeds. Among those who entertained with dinners in their homes and later took their guests to the dance were Mrs. M. Lawrence Keene of 1,111 Park Avenue.

Routine daily mill operations as consumers fixed prices on raw material absorbed an unusually small quantity of offerings on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. Fluctuations were limited to a 10-point range, reaching low levels early and recovering to close with a gain of 5 to a loss of 3 points.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- Despite the record low interest rate of 2 1/2 per cent on long-term government securities, the Treasury's Dec. 15 cash offering of $700,000,000 in 13-17 year bonds was oversubscribed more than four times when Secretary Morgenthau closed the books tonight.

Guarded without their knowledge by a detail of special agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, about 100 men and women of the WPA Federal Theatre Project began a "sit-down" strike on the second floor of the project's headquarters at 701 Eighth Avenue, at the northwest corner of Forty-fourth Street, at 4 P.M. yesterday that was to continue until tomorrow.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 7. -- At an exclusive, quiet and unheralded meeting Secretary of State Cordell Hull, Jose Carlos de Macedo Soares, Brazilian Minister of Foreign Affairs, and Carlos Saavedra Lamas, president of the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace, wrestled until nearly midnight tonight with fundamental differences threatening the success of the conference, which had reached an initial stage.

Your analysis of the present complications in Great Britain, with its conclusion that the question is what are the rights of the Crown, strikes me as hitting the crux of the controversy. It seems to be a matter of the seat and limitations of power as much as was the little quarrel between the nobles and King John a few centuries ago which resulted in the compromise, or treaty, we read about as Magna Charta.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- George A. Ball, glass jar manufacturer of Muncie, Ind., was the first witness called by the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce at the start today of its investigation of American railroad financing. He gave the committee the story of how he had acquired control of more than 23,000 miles of railroads for about $274,000.

Although New York City is spending millions on traffic lights, bridges and tunnels to ease vehicular congestion, its most urgent need is six or seven crosstown express highways to complement the West Side highway and the East River Drive now under construction, Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine declared yesterday.

Steel ingot production last month amounted to 4,337,412 gross tons, the largest for any November in the history of the steel industry, it was announced yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

BERLIN, Dec. 7. -- It was officially announced today that the public oversubscription of the latest government loan of 500,000,000 marks was so large that the government had decided to increase the loan's total to 600,000,000 to "satisfy all subscribers, especially the little ones."

Orlando, Fla., will receive tenders on Dec. 14 on a new issue of $3,221,000 of refunding bonds, the proceeds of which will be used to retire a similar amount of bonds called for redemption on Feb. 1, 1937. The new issue will be dated Feb. 1, 1937, and will mature from Feb. 1, 1938 to 1962.

Among the Christmas shoppers who visited the Christmas Sale for the Blind yesterday afternoon at 475 Fifth Avenue were Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the President; Mrs. James Roosevelt, the President's mother, and Mrs. F.H. La Guardia, wife of the Mayor.

BOSTON, Dec. 7. -- Federal Judge George C. Sweeney upheld the right of Congress today to levy a pay-roll tax on employers for the unemployment compensation system set up under the Federal Social Security Act. An application for an injunction to prevent the Boston Maine Railroad from paying the tax was denied.
Apartment house deals featured the Manhattan realty trading reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The Supreme Court today upheld a finding of lower courts that Algernon S. Schafer, Edward Schafer and Leonard Schafer, partners in the brokerage firm of Schafer Brothers at 120 Broadway, New York City, were not dealers in securities so far as securities purchased in 1923 for the firms' own account are concerned and therefore could not inventory these securities and claim deductions on income taxes from their depreciation.
LONDON, Dec. 7. -- Lord Rothermere predicted today in his Evening News that British Parliaments would pass a bill to legalize a morganatic marriage by King Edward "by a huge majority."

The decision of the Federal Supreme Court in the California and Illinois "fair trade" cases, according to the opinions of authorities here yesterday, sets a precedent which will have "tremendous repercussion" throughout the retail field and exert a major influence upon the relations between manufacturers and retail distributors.

MANILA, Tuesday, Dec. 8. -- Thousands were missing in Northeast Luzon Island today and many of them were feared drowned in what authorities said might prove the most disastrous flood in the history of the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- State "fair trade" laws prohibiting the sale of standard trade-marked and labeled products at prices below those fixed by the producers were held constitutional by the Supreme Court today in cases involving the California and Illinois acts.

I wish to protest your editorial of Dec. 5 in which you state that King Edward's marriage to Mrs. Simpson would mean the defeat of English democracy -- basing this conclusion on the fact that the Cabinet as the executive committee of the House of Commons is opposed to the King's intention to marry Mrs. Simpson.

Dr. John Howard Northrop of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research will receive the Charles Frederick Chandler Medal of Columbia University for 1936, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, following action by the board of trustees.

Playing at top form, F. Barry Ryan Jr. of Short Hills conquered his team-mate, Albert H. Marckwald Jr., 15 -- 4, 15 -- 12, to lead the field into the semi-final round of the Fall scratch tournament of the National Squash Tennis Association at the City A.C. yesterday.

Lord Ponsonby, former leader of the Opposition in the House of Lords, in a broadcast from London yesterday said the "very worst solution" to the difficulty arising over King Edward's desire to marry Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson would be his abdication.

The refunding program of the Consolidated Gas and Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore twill be carried forward another step today with the offering to the public of $23,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent first refunding mortgage bonds, Series N, due in 1971, by a banking group headed by White, Weld Co. The bonds will be priced at 104 and accrued interest.

The undisputed reign over the hearts of children and other circus fans hereabouts that the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus has wielded each Spring is to be challenged next March by a rival organization, owned and operated by former employes of what Dexter Fellows fondly describes as "the greatest show on earth."

BERLIN, Dec. 7 (AP). -- The once-mighty Hohenzollerns, erstwhile ruling family of Germany and cousins of Great Britain's Windsors, followed the storm around the British throne today with intense interest.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 7. -- Miss Katherine Browning Thurber, elder daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred E. Thurber of Gracemere, Tarrytown, was married here this afternoon to Edwards Cobleigh O'Boyle, son or Mrs. E.C. Brenner of New York and the late Charles O'Boyle.

Each day's developments make clearer the thoroughness with which the United States has prepared for the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace. An astute evaluation of what is practicable and a fine regard for the sensibilities of the Latin-American people are evident throughout the texts of the two draft treaties presented yesterday in Buenos Aires by Secretary HULL.
LONDON, Dec. 7. -- The history of far-off days leaped back to life in the House of Commons today as Parliament men and King's men clashed again for the first time in almost 300 years.

" To protect realistically our economic structure against the dangers of extreme liberalism or radicalism," wage scales must be increased and hours shortened, C.W. Young, president of the Young Management Corporation, investment counselors, told members of the Sales Executive Club of New York yesterday at their weekly luncheon meeting at the Hotel Roosevelt.
TOKYO, Dec. 8 -- A Japanese Cabinet crisis, arising over the newly signed Japanese-German agreement, was reported today by the newspaper Miyako.
A Theatre project for West Seventy-second Street and several deals by operators featured the Manhattan realty activity reported yesterday.

Plans to introduce revised "fair trade" legislation at Albany, when the Legislature convenes next month, together with moves to bring about a review by the State Court of Appeals of its adverse decision in the Doubleday, Doran case were among the developments here yesterday resulting from the Supreme Court's validation of the fair trade laws of California and Illinois, permitting agreements to maintain retail prices.

I was amazed to note the order of the Police Commissioner that policemen should not attempt to eject trespassers from private property, but instruct householders to do so. Most amazing of all was the fact that the Mayor took the responsibility for these orders.

For the second time in five days a jury before Federal Judge Murray Hulbert convicted Morris Schatz, reputed head of a ring that smuggled narcotics here on transatlantic liners, for illegal importation of raw opium. Schatz faces two more trials on similar charges.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 9. -- Dissatisfaction with the government's foreign policy is being expressed with an openness not seen since before the army, in 1931, began exerting a dominating influence.

The Federal Trade Commission has served notice on several automobile manufacturers and finance companies to show cause why an order to "cease and desist" should not be entered against them in connection with their advertisements of the so-called "6 per cent plan."

The State Commission for the Revision of the Tax Laws, headed by ex-Senator MASTICK, intends to do its best to persuade the Legislature to set up a "municipal finance commission" to exercise a measure of control over swollen local debts and budgets. The new agency would be called upon to approve any local bond issue creating a net city debt in excess of 8 per cent of assessed valuations.
