A shortage of low rental housing in the Lower East Side is resulting from the decision of banks to board up tenement properties under their control rather than comply with the fire retarding and sanitary requirements of the Multiple Dwelling Law, Mrs. Anne L. Goldstein, neighborhood worker of Madison House told members of the Women's Committee of 100 of the National Public Housing Conference yesterday.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt appealed to consumers last night to use their spending power toward improving the standards of living throughout the country. She told 1,000 men and women, meeting at the Ethical Culture Society Auditorium, Central Park West and Sixty-fourth Street, that public opinion was a paramount force in curbing abuses.

Commercial leasing was reported active yesterday as a variety of enterprises sought space. The Financial Observer, weekly publication scheduled to appear Feb. 5, under the editorship of Reginald Wright Kauffman and with Ralph West Robey as financial editor, leased three floors in 55 William Street, northwest corner of Pine Street.

MANILA, Wednesday, Dec. 9 (AP). -- Military airplanes sped medical supplies and relief-survey representatives today to the flood-ravaged Cagayan Valley, where thousands of residents were reported dead or missing in what army authorities said was the Philippines greatest disaster.

The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company sold the Ivanhoe Apartments, at 83-84 116th Street, Kew Gardens, to Ivanhoe Apartments, Inc., for cash above a purchase-money mortgage of $233,500. Coleman Perlstein represented the seller and Arthur M. Chinman was the broker.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- Business improvement, sales taxes, heavy dividend and bonus payments and other factors were regarded today by experts of the Treasury Department as responsible for a substantial increase in circulation of money, which at the end of November amounted to $6,465,726,394, a high record for normal times and exceeded only by the $7,200,000,000 of the early days of March, 1933, when cash was hoarded.

The Quaker State Oil Refining Corporation has notified the Exchange that, as of Dec. 1, two of its subsidiaries, the Sterling Oil Company of Pennsylvania and the Quaker State Oil Refining Company, were dissolved and their assets assumed by the parent company.

Building plans filed yesterday included a $110,000 apartment house for East Eighty-second Street, near Third Avenue, and a $350,000 house for ninety-four families in Flushing, Queens. Details of the projects were as follows:

"His Jewish Girl," which was produced in Brooklyn half a dozen years ago, was brought to the Public Theatre last night for midweek performance. Though the play wears a tragic mask, since it deals with the difficulties in the way of a mixed marriage in the old country, it looks for every opportunity to drop the hampering false-face.

CANNES, France, Wednesday, Dec. 9. -- Dr. W. Douglas Kirkwood, English physician, and Theodore Goddard, personal attorney of Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson, arrived here at 11 P.M. last night after an airplane and taxicab dash from London.

The success of rebuilding wildlife depends on close cooperation between landowners and conservation agencies. So says Dr. Ira N. Gabrielson, chief of the United States Bureau of Biological Survey, in his annual report to the Secretary of Agriculture, made public yesterday.

Efforts to settle the strike of mechanical employes of The North Shore Daily Journal, Queens, were started yesterday at a conference initiated by Max Abramson, Flushing department store owner and one of the paper's largest advertisers. The strike began more than a fortnight ago.

CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 8. -- After days and nights of conferences the Australian Cabinet dispersed tonight to obtain much needed sleep, hoping for a happy issue of the British constitutional crisis.
The Guaranty Trust Company has been appointed transfer agent for 300,000 of $1 par common shares of the Solar Manufacturing Corporation.

An audience of more than 300 Protestant church officers, including John D. Rockefeller Jr., adopted last night a resolution calling upon the Greater New York Federation of Churches to organize a council through which Protestant churches could act unitedly.

JOHN STRACHEY of Eton and Oxford seems to have won, at the age of 35, the intellectual leadership of all English-speaking Communists. There is no other British or American Marxist of comparable gifts. He has a better economic training than almost any of them. He has not only read Marx, but a few of the wicked "capitalist" economists.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8. -- Details of a third plan for reorganization of Philadelphia's transit system were made public today by Mayor S. Davis Wilson, who said the plan would be filed in the Federal district court this week by the directors of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company.

ALBANY, Dec. 8. -- A warning that "overproduction" is running ahead of buying power was sounded today by Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, in a talk before the executive council of the State Federation of Labor.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

LONDON, Dec. 8. -- For 3,000 years Helen of Troy was unsurpassed. We all know the story of that Greek beauty who upset the life of her country because a boyish Prince, Paris, fell a victim to her charms.
UTICA, N.Y., Dec. 8. -- Lower taxes on real estate and sharp curbs on liquor selling were urged by Raymond Cooper, State Master, at the convention of the New York State Grange here today.

An accounting suit for $34,286,710 damages against Atlas Comporation, the Chatham Phenix Corporation, the Securities-Allied Corporation and fifty of their officers and directors was disclosed yesterday in Supreme Court when Justice William Harman Black denied a motion to vacate the summons served on Securities-Allied Corporation.
SYLVAN BEACH, N.Y., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Five motorships churned the waters of Oneida Lake tonight, fighting for freedom against ice which threatens to freeze in the craft and their cargo for the Winter.

Morris Nadel, a lawyer who had offices at 152 West Forty-second Street and 1,665 Weeks Avenue, the Bronx, was acquitted yesterday in the Extraordinary Special Sessions Court in the Supreme Court Building on a misdemeanor charge of attempting to mislead a court through an alleged incorrect bill of particulars in a negligence case.

If the British constitutional crisis is not soon over, it at least ought to be. During the last two days efforts have been made to reduce the tension. First there was the public statement issued by Mrs. SIMPSON, declaring her readiness to put an end to a position which had become "unhappy and untenable."

LONDON, Dec. 8 (AP). -- The British Press Association, commenting on the arrival of Theodore Goddard, attorney, and Dr. W. Douglas Kirkwood in Cannes tonight, said it understood "Goddard had not previously flown, and it was his request that his personal friend and medical adviser, Dr. Kirkwood, accompany him."

Business opinion has long been divided concerning the desirability of so-called "fair trade" acts which prohibit the sale of standard trade-marked products at prices less than those fixed by the producer. This was shown during the controversy in this State over the Feld-Crawford act.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP). -- Edward Santry, general auditor of the Bell Telephone Laboratories, Inc., told the Federal Communications Commission today that "we never underestimate" depreciation costs of property and equipment in figuring amounts to be set aside for replacements.

The Board of Elections was charged yesterday by David B. Costuma, one of its own members, with "wanton waste of public funds" in ordering 1,550 more copies of lists of enrolled voters for 1937 than were purchased for 1936.
Out of the cross-currents of the major league baseball meeting trade winds the Giants emerged yesterday with a third baseman, one of Colonel Bill Terry's crying needs for 1937.

A 40-year-old woman, the mother of four children, who was found wandering at the scene of a fire believed to have been incendiary was held responsible by the police last night for twenty-five or more recent fires in Brooklyn during which robberies occurred.

The number of visiting buyers recorded in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a substantial gain over the preceding week and the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES. The arrivals for the week were 683, as against 509 in the previous week and 544 in the same period last year.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Dec. 8. -- Miss Elizabeth Giltner, 25-year-old daughter of a college dean, was shot to death late today, State police said, by a former classmate who had been helping her to address invitations to her wedding.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8. -- The hog market opened weak today and the demand was slow until a decline of 10 to 15 cents had been established. The early top of $10.25 was off 5 cents from Monday's high price, but it was hard to obtain more than $10.05 a hundredweight at the last.

To celebrate her thirty years on the concert stage, Eva Gauthier presented the first of three retrospective programs last night at the Hotel Gotham. The first recital was devoted to classic and contemporary composers of Spain. Most of this music Miss Gauthier introduced to New York.
Mayor La Guardia aroused the resentment of some members of the Board of Aldermen yesterday when he delivered an exposition of the law governing legislation handled by the Municipal Assembly.

ANSONIA, Conn., Dec. 8. -- Nicola Lanzi, a laborer in the plant of the American Brass Company here, was arrested at his work late this afternoon on the charge of throwing sulphuric acid at a dozen persons, in the past few weeks. Under rigid examination he confessed in four cases, the police said.

Republican bewilderment could hardly be expressed more comically than by the plan attributed to four Eastern Republican Senators. The bars are to be let down and all the stray sheep coaxed back to the old fold. Mr. NORRIS, lately Republican, now an Independent, Progressive Mr. LA FOLLETTE, the two Minnesota Farmer-Laborites are to be invited to the Republican caucus.

Dr. James Rowland Angell, president of Yale University, speaking last night in the Hotel Roosevelt at the fifty-fifth annual dinner of the New York Association of the Alumni of the Phillips Exeter Academy, commended the Harkness plan at Exeter as "a new departure in American secondary education, which promises to have a great effect on education in this country."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- Plans for dry docking and re-examining all except four of the 197 vessels in the old Shipping Board's reserve fleet, with a view to determining their value for commercial purposes or naval auxiliaries, were announced today by Rear Admiral H.A. Wiley, chairman of the Maritime Commission, who said negotiations to dry dock the vessels in navy yards were now under way.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 8. -- Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein and City Commissioners Michael P. Duffy and Reginald Parnell were called as witnesses at the opening today of public hearings in the Supreme Court investigation of Newark municipal affairs.

A large company attended the Christmas party held yesterday afternoon at the British Empire Exhibition at the British Empire Building, 620 Fifth Avenue. A feature of the afternoon was the observance of the old English Yuletide custom of the "Wassail Bowl," around which had been placed Christmas gifts.

The five-story apartment house at 546 Midwood Street, corner of Kingston Avenue, Brooklyn, has been purchased by the Arley Holding Corporation, represented by Joseph Howard Katz, from Albemarle Apartments, Inc. The house, which is on a plot 100 by 100 feet, accommodates forty-one families and is assessed at $90,000.

Three new members of the National Council of the Episcopal Church were formally introduced to that body yesterday at the opening session of its quarterly meeting in the Church Missions House, 281 Fourth Avenue. They were elected by provincial Synods of the Episcopal Church, of which there are eight in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- Representative B.H. Snell of New York, minority House leader, defined himself today as a "middle-of-the-roader," neither a conservative nor a progressive. In an informal discussion of political trends upon his return to the capital, Mr. Snell insisted that the Republican party was not "dead," and that it would be restored to confidence in due time as new issues arise, and the administration "fails to adopt business-like methods."

Four Assemblymen and a State Senator from Manhattan heard yesterday a critical discussion of legislation passed or proposed in the State from members of the Manhattan League of Women Voters and learned how the women expected them to vote on specific measures in the next session of the Legislature at Albany.

Recovery in the United States rests on somewhat "jittery foundations," General Hugh S. Johnson declared last night at a dinner of the Economic Club in honor of Henry L. Stimson, former Secretary of State, at the Hotel Astor.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 8. -- Backstage discussions between leading delegates continued today in an effort to smooth out differences threatening the future course of the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace.

Three rules for companies trying to break into the New York market were outlined last night by Frank R. Coutant, director of research, Pedlar Ryan, and president of the American Marketing Association, at a meeting of the New York Management Council at Rockefeller Center.

BRISBANE, Australia, Wednesday, Dec. 9 (Canadian Press). -- Australia collapsed sensationally before England's fast bowlers today and the mother country gained an overwhelming victory in the first cricket test match by a margin of 322 runs.

The transfer of stock of the Dictograph Products Company, Inc., held by Pirnie, Simons Co., Inc., the A.M. Andrews Investment Corporation and more than fifty other banks and investment concerns was restrained yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Valente pending a determination of the true ownership of 31,000 shares of Dictograph stock.

Samuel Antek, American violinist, appeared in a recital at the Town Hall last night. Although he is a young man Mr. Antek has had a varied career. His past and present jobs have included membership in the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra, concertmaster of the New Jersey Orchestra, conductor of the Glen Ridge String Orchestra and head of the violin department of the Orange School of Music.

The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday that its sales last month to consumers in the United States numbered 155,552 units, compared with 136,859 in the same month last year and 44,274 in October, 1936. For the first eleven months of 1936 sales numbered 1,546,741, compared with 1,156,798 for the corresponding period of last year.

CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE, N.J., Dec. 8. -- Trial of charges by Democrats that William C. Hunt, Republican, was elected State Senator from Cape May County last Nov. 3 by fraud was halted this afternoon at Mr. Hunt's request for time to seek a Supreme Court order transferring the case from the Circuit Court to the higher bench.

LONDON, Dec. 8. -- King Edward, flanked by two of his royal brothers and Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin, the man who says he cannot as King wed the American-born Mrs. Wallis Simpson, threshed out the issue vital to an empire across the dinner table tonight at Fort Belvedere.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- The 1936 cotton crop was estimated at 12,407,000 bales today in the final report of the Crop Reporting Board of the Department of Agriculture. This was 7,000 bales more than was indicated in the November report and compared with 10,638,000 bales last year, 9,636,000 bales in 1934 and an average of 14,667,000 bales for the five years 1928-32.

The exhibition called "Fantastic Art, Dada, Surrealism" opened last night at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street. There was a preview reception at 10 o'clock held by the trustees for members of the museum and their friends.

Judge Koenig of General Sessions yesterday sentenced Harry Saks Hechheimer, 63 years old, a former lawyer, to two to four years in Sing Sing on his conviction last Aug. 17 of participation in the extortion of $2,000, in December, 1933, from Harry Bannister, former husband of _Ann Harding, the motion picture actress.

James Anderson Murray, 43-year-old painter, who believes that the Federal social security program is "the greatest thing that ever happened to this country," became yesterday the 1,000,001st person to receive a social security account card from the New York Postoffice.

A banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and including Bancamerica-Blair Corporation and Ladenburg, Thalman Co., won the award yesterday of a new issue of $1,900,000 of tax anticipation certificates of indebtedness of Buffalo, N.Y., on an interest rate basis of 0.50 per cent plus a premium of $195.

After more than half a million years of progress based on trial and error, man has accumulated sufficient knowledge in the last few years to enable him to control his own destiny by participating "in the process of his own creation," Dr. Oscar Riddle, internationally known authority on heredity and evolution, declared last night at a meeting of the American Institute of the City of New York.

CANNES, France, Dec. 8. -- "Why smile?" asked Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson with a distressed expression and a tone of vexation today in a response to a request from a photographer who was admitted to Villa Lou Viei to make one picture to be distributed for publication by all newspapers represented in the crowd of reporters congregated here.
Six properties in Manhattan and twelve in the Bronx were taken over yesterday by the plaintiffs at auction sales. Houses formed the bulk of the improvements foreclosed.

Efrem Zimbalist gave a violin recital last night in Carnegie Hall which celebrated his twenty-fifth year in America, where he came as a young man of 22 in 1911. He was accompanied by Samuel Chotzinoff, who played with Mr. Zimbalist on the occasion of his New York debut in Carnegie Hall, Nov. 10, a quarter of a century ago.

BERLIN, Dec. 8. -- The group of conciliatory bishops and pastors whom the government installed to administer the Protestant Church in Germany has now rebelled publicly against the regime's toleration and support of anti-Christian propaganda.
The list of the French liner Normandie, leaving today for Southampton and Havre, includes several diplomatic representatives of the United States and of European nations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- The government's concern lest the Congressional gold-clause joint resolution of 1933 be disturbed by a decision of the United States Supreme Court was illustrated when Attorney General Cummings filed today a brief as a "friend of the court" in a case to be argued in a few days.

LONDON, Dec. 8. -- One hundred eighty letters of Napoleon brought 1,750 at a sale which opened at Sotheby's auction rooms today. They formed part of the third portion of Emile Brouwst's collection, which he began to break up in 1934.

BOSTON, Dec. 8. -- The first proceedings in the country under the Robinson-Patman act, aimed at outlawing discriminatory trade prices were transferred to Chicago tonight after a two-day hearing here. Further hearings will be held here later, it was said.

Mrs. Sarah Wyman, Miami widow, who last May won a judgment of $175,012.80 when Edgar L. Newhouse Jr., New York industrialist, did not appear in a Florida court to contest her action for breach of promise, failed yesterday to obtain an order in Federal court directing him to pay that amount.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 8. -- American feminists have brought to the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace their longstanding fight over the question of whether women should have equal standing with men or receive special "protective" consideration.

History is repeating itself in Spain after a century and a quarter. Foreign troops are once more contending for mastery, as they did in the great five-year duel between WELLINGTON and NAPOLEON after 1808.

LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 9. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin dined with King Edward last night at Fort Belvedere and remained there until after 10 o'clock. He had arrived at 5 with Walter T. Monckton, Attorney General of the Duchy of Cornwall. The Dukes of York and Kent, brothers of the King, were also there.
In the years of unemployment for millions among the most heavily handicapped have been those who like blind Ajax in blind HOMER'S Iliad asked but to see:

Directors of Loew's, Inc., have voted a Christmas bonus of two weeks' salary to be distributed among more than 11,000 employes whose weekly salaries are $50 or less. Announcement of the distribution was made at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday at the offices of the company, 1,540 Broadway.

MADRID, Dec. 8. -- Your correspondent was just sitting down to send a dispatch saying that scarcely a shot had been fired on the Madrid front today when the rumble of exploding bombs was heard outside his window. Six bombers were passing over Madrid from the northwest to the southeast, dropping their murderous loads while anti-aircraft guns rattled away harmlessly.

Pre-season Winter sports activity in the metropolitan area will reach its climax tonight when the first annual International Ski Meet and Winter Sport Show starts a four-day run at the Madison Square Garden arena. A two-and-one-half-hour program that will show practically every sport having to do with the snowy months, such as skiing, figure skating, snow shoeing and dog sledging, has been arranged.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8. -- A deal long rumored materialized today when A.J. Mount, president of the Central Bank of Oakland, announced the approval on the part of himself and associates of a price of $400 a share for the transfer of control of the bank to Kernan Robson, acting for the Transamerica Corporation.

PARIS, Dec. 8. -- The first steps to patch up the crack in the Popular Front that resulted from the Communist abstention in the Chamber of Deputies over the government's Spanish policy were taken today by several groups.

GENEVA, Dec. 8. -- Strong support for the forty-hour-week in the chemical industry was offered today by Professor Theodore Krets, United States Government delegate, at a meeting of the International Labor Organization's preparatory committee.

Continued assumption of the social service burden by the government in the future will make it increasingly difficult for private agencies to get financial support from individuals, the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, minister of the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, said yesterday.

BOSTON, Dec. 8 (AP). -- After spotting the crippled Detroit Red Wings three goals during thirty-five minutes of sloppy play, the Boston Bruins tied the count and then lost out by a 4-3 margin after waging a gallant battle for the deciding counter tonight before a crowd of 15,000 at the Boston Garden.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 8. -- A report submitted to the government by the Automobile Trade Industry Association contends that within four or five years motor traffic in Chile will be almost paralyzed as a result of the severe restrictions imposed by the Exchange Control Commission on imports of automobiles, trucks and parts.

This is to be Sherlock Holmes Night up at the Masque Theatre on Forty-fifth Street, for behind "The Holmeses of Baker Street" dwell Sherlock, Dr. Watson and all the rest. The play is English, having been written by Bash Mitchell, with an American adaptation contributed by William Jourdan Rapp and Leonardo Bercovici.

Miguel de Unamuno, rector of the University of Salamanca and noted philosopher, in a letter addressed to President Nicholas Murray Butler of Columbia University and made public late yesterday by officials of the university, referred to the Spanish Civil War as a defense of "Western and Christian civilization" against "an Eastern fantastic scheme."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- A pledge that "no person who needs relief will be dropped" was made today by Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, who repeated the declaration over and over during a fifty-minute conference with two-score newspaper reporters.

ROME, Dec. 8. -- On the night before she left the American Embassy in Madrid, Virginia McKay of Colorado Springs, Col., reported today to the American Embassy here, she was approached by Marion Greenspan, Madrid correspondent of The Daily Worker of New York, with a request that she convey to France a heavy valise and forward it to New York.

Miss Helen McGraw, pianist, playing yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, indicated that she is a modernist as well as a young woman who has attentively studied the classics. After Bach, Mozart, Brahms of the great E-flat Rhapsodie and Beethoven of the sonata, Opus 110, she played three preludes of Debussy, Gieseking's transcription of Richard Strauss's song, "Serenade," Stravinsky's Fourth Etude and the Scriabine "Sonata Fantasia," Opus 19.

Officials of the Metropolitan Indoor Polo League yesterday announced the complete schedule for this season's play, which opens on Saturday, Dec. 19, with games at the armories of Squadron A in Manhattan and Squadron C in Brooklyn.

The government called two witnesses yesterday in its suit in the Federal court in Brooklyn to collect $450,000 from Frank Bornn and his Bornn Distilling Company, of 18 Center Street, Brooklyn. The government contends this amount should have been paid in internal revenue taxes for industrial alcohol diverted into bootleg channels during the years 1922 to 1926, inclusive.

Exports and imports from and into the United States by classified groups in October have been announced by the Department of Commerce; they are here compared with those of the preceding month and with October, 1935. Exports as given in the tables that follow cover only domestic exports, not foreign goods re-exported.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of $1.50 a share on its common stock, payable on Dec. 24 to holders of record of Dec. 17. This is the first dividend on the common stock since February, 1932.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 8. -- Superseding previous announcements, Paramount today named "I Met Him in Paris" as the next vehicle for Claudette Colbert and Ray Milland as her probable leading man. The story is a comedy drama of Continental life, by Helen Meinhardi.

The plant of the Keystone Leather Company in Camden, N.J., comprising five and one-half acres on Admiral Wilson Boulevard at Sixteenth Street, has been sold to the Camden Boulevard Corporation for use of the R.M. Hollingshead Corporation, manufacturer of automotive chemicals.

An increase in Pullman travel following the reduction of rates for that class of travel to 3 cents a mile on June 1 was reflected in the report of the Pullman Company, car-operating subsidiary of Pullman, Inc., for October and the ten months.

Mayor La Guardia asked twenty-six of the city's most influential business men at a City Hall conference yesterday to help meet the relief problem by arranging for the speedy absorption into industry of persons now receiving Federal and city aid.

John C. Flynn, president of the George W. Helme Company, received in 1935 salary of $56,706, while nine directors were paid $194,311, it was disclosed yesterday in the company's annual report to the Securities and Exchange Commission. C.W. Bumstead, vice president, received $45,103 and L.A. Bengert, vice president, $41,603, the report showed.

BERLIN, Dec. 8. -- The launching of the battleship Gneisenau before Chancellor Adolf Hitler and military and Nazi notables at Kiel today was marred when the 26,000-ton vessel went down the ways so fast that she crashed into the opposite wall of the bay.

Letters in the scrawled penmanship of children or in the wavering characters of the very old, and letters typewritten on business stationery and postmarked all over the metropolitan area brought 337 contributions totaling $9,071.20 to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday in the second day's response to the twenty-fifth annual appeal.

The Regional Plan Association has been doing some figuring to show that gross or even per capita figures are not always the planner's surest guide. Everybody knows that the United States has vastly more automobiles, and many more automobiles in proportion to population, than any other nation in the world.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 8. -- Baroness Johann von Leidersdorff of Sterling Ridge, Harrison, who declared in an affidavit she could not afford to pay a court judgment although she paid $750 a month rent, was held in contempt of court today by Supreme Court Justice Graham Witschief.

Bing Crosby returns to the screen of the Paramount today in "Pennies From Heaven," a comedy with music from the Columbia workshop. Madge Evans, Edith Fellows, Donald Meek, John Gallaudet and Louis Armstrong form the advance guard of the supporting cast.

Federal Referee Peter B. Olney Jr. accepted considerable amendments yesterday to the proposed plan of reorganization of the Consolidated Textile Corporation, announcing that without the changes the original plan would not receive his approval.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8. -- Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Chase National Bank of New York, said tonight in an address before the Illinois Manufacturers Association that steps should be taken now to forestall an excessive expansion in credit.

A. George Townsend of the home club upset Orton Hicks of the Dartmouth Club, eighth-rated performer, in the third round of the Long Island championship of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association at the Jackson Heights Squash Club yesterday. The contest was decided at 15 -- 12, 15 -- 7, 14 -- 18, 18 -- 13.

The Sheffield Farms Company asserts in an advertisement that 48.13 cents of the consumer's milk dollar went to farmers during the nine-month period ended September. It is difficult to find out just how this figure is arrived at. We have data supplied by the Division of Milk Control on the amount paid to farmers, provided the law is obeyed, as well as information on the price paid by consumers.

Indications of a definite rift in the hitherto friendly relations between the major league club owners and Commissioner K.M. Landis were seen yesterday when the National League voted down the so-called Landis "rider" to the Baltimore amendment modifying the major-minor sandlot rule.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- Soon after President Roosevelt returns to Washington next week or before his second inauguration at the latest, he is expected to establish contact with some of the largest industrial employers of the country in an effort to plan a new attack on the omnipresent problem of unemployment.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 8. -- All Forlorn, owned by Miss Mary White, had little trouble leading a field of six sprinters in the Barney Oldfield Purse, six-furlong dash that topped today's Fair Grounds program. Well ridden by Apprentice W. Duffy, who held her in hand the first half mile, All Forlorn had plenty left in the last furlong to move away from the challenge of Odd Blue.

The retirement of Jackson E. Reynolds as president of the First National Bank of New York and the election of Leon Fraser to succeed him, both effective on Jan. 1, were announced yesterday by George F. Baker, chairman of the bank's board.

LONDON, Dec. 8. -- Although the volume of business remained small, the trend of prices on the Stock Exchange here today was distinctly more cheerful and more optimistic. British Government securities led in a general recovery, quotations advancing about one-half point throughout the list.

Samuel S. Stampleman of Boston, president of the Gillette Safety Razor Company, appeared as the complaining witness yesterday at the start of the General Sessions trial of A. Henry Ross, Brooklyn lawyer, and Max D. Krone, a former private detective, on an indictment charging they extorted $5,000 from him in 1933 to stop the suit of a young woman against him.

LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 9. -- The Times indicates editorially this morning that it can find Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson's offer to withdraw from the present situation no solution to the King's problem.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- Increased Federal appropriations for the territorial government to aid in the development of mining and transportation and in the establishment of new colonies in Alaska were recommended by Governor John W. Troy in his annual report to the Secretary of the Interior for the fiscal year ended June 30 last.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation during the period from its establishment on Feb. 2, 1932, to Nov. 30, 1936, made disbursements, exclusive of advances to other government agencies and for direct relief, of $6,308,871,407 in the recovery program, and these eventually will be liquidated without loss to the taxpayer and possibly with a small profit, Jesse H Jones, chairman of the RFC, said today.
Two more seeded players were eliminated as the quarter-final brackets in the third annual Class B invitation squash racquets tournament of the Squash Club were filled yesterday.

THERE was some talk of the Winter Sports Show about to go on at the Garden and Manager James J. Dykes of the Chicago White Sox tapped the ashes from his cigar in an impatient manner. When he heard that Colonel J. Reed Kilpatrick was housing a machine that could and would produce snow in large quantities in a great hurry, Mr. Dykes said:

Industry, more than ever before, is "willing to meet labor half way," it was asserted by Ernest J. Poole, vice chairman of the Employment Relations Committee of the National Association of Manufacturers.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8. -- While heavy profit-taking developed in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today an early upturn carried nearly all deliveries of wheat, corn, oats, rye, barley and soy beans to new high levels for the season. The only exceptions were July wheat and December corn and rye.

The tone of the stock market was slightly improved yesterday, and THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty representative issues just about regained the small loss of the day before. The tension with respect to foreign affairs lessened, and there was little in the domestic news of the day bearing on the market that had not been anticipated generally.

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 8. - Asserting that gambling cannot exist "without the connivance of public officials," Justice Frank T. Lloyd of the State Supreme Court instructed the Camden County grand jury today to investigate gambling activities in Camden City and county "from the bottom up."
BERLIN, Dec. 8. -- Carl von Ossietzky, who should arrive in Oslo, Norway, Friday to receive the Nobel Peace Prize, probably will not go.

There was music in Grand Central Terminal today. I don't know who supplied it or for what purpose. It was soft and slow. It had an astonishing effect upon the throngs in their mad scramble to get to their destinations. Taut faces relaxed and gave way to smiles.

BERLIN, Dec. 8. -- The German press, led by Chancellor Adolf Hitler's own Voelkischer Beobachter, has started a violent campaign technically directed "against world Jewry and against bolshevism," but obviously designed to exert pressure on the judges at Chur, Switzerland, who begin tomorrow the trial of David Frankfurter in the killing last February of Wilhelm Gustloff, Swiss Nazi leader at Davos, Switzerland.

Prices of commodity futures were mixed on the local markets yesterday, with rubber and hides moderately higher. On the cash markets oats and coffee sold at new high prices and rubber, cotton and tin advanced. Wheat, corn, rye and silk declined.

Sir Josiah Stamp, chairman of the London, Midland Scottish Railway and a director of the Bank of England, was heard in the United States over a National Broadcasting Company network last night in a short talk on the British situation.
The bond market on the New York Stock Exchange was irregular yesterday and price changes were mostly small. Total transactions were $13,504,100, compared with $11,946,200 on Monday.
The Continental Paper and Bag Corporation has sold its operating paper and bag properties to the Southern Kraft Corporation. Both are subsidiaries of International Paper and Power Company.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 8 (AP). -- The odds-on favorite, Bubbling Spring, 4-year-old filly racing in the colors of Mrs. W. Davis, proved best in the running of the featured five-furlong dash for 3-year-olds and upward at the Charles Town track today.

Several large apartments were reported leased yesterday. One was a fifteen-room unit at 885 Park Avenue, leased to George Dixon for Walter Richard through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., and Hickernell-Romeyn, Inc. Other leases included the following:

MOSCOW, Dec. 8. -- Soviet Russia's first act under her new Constitution was to increase today her preparations for war. Acting without delay, the Central Executive Committee announced the creation of the newly authorized Commissariat for Munitions Industries, which Joseph Stalin told the recent Congress of Soviets, "had become necessary."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- A $500,000,000 soil-conservation program which in one important respect marks a return to the production control that the Supreme Court held unconstitutional in invalidating the old AAA programs was proclaimed by Secretary Wallace today for application to next year's crops.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,000,200 barrels, compared with 3,010,650 in the preceding week, a decrease of 10,450, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decrease of 39,000 barrels in the daily average output of Oklahoma and a gain of 19,150 in Texas were the important changes.

A sharp difference of opinion developed yesterday between national officers and members of the unions of mates and marine engineers, threatening to delay settlement of the strike the unions are waging against Atlantic and Gulf ship lines.
Stuart M. Crocker, chairman of the United Hospital Campaign, made public last night an additional list of contributions, including a $5,000 gift from Harry Payne Bingham, the banker.

BILBAO, Spain, Dec. 8. -- The Basque army is consolidating its front on a line running through Respaldia, Amurrio and Orduna, north of Vitoria and commanding the railway to Burgos, the Rebel capital, and Logrono.

BERLIN, Dec. 8. -- A more or less official explanation of why the German press is forbidden to say anything about the British constitutional crisis resulting from King Edward's desire to marry was broadcast today over government radio stations.

A compromise settlement in the new action over the custody of 12-year-old Gloria Laura Morgan Vanderbilt has been agreed upon by the parties, subject to the approval of the Supreme Court, it was learned last night. The settlement, reached yesterday at a conference of attorneys, will be presented this morning to Supreme Court Justice Timothy A. Leary, it was said.

The Rangers were held to a scoreless tie by the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden last night. Try as hard as it might, and try it did, the New York sextet was forced to skate off the ice at the end of the overtime session with nothing to show for its efforts against a team that was committed to defensive hockey and which refused, except at rare intervals, to take any chances whatever.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8. -- Kinrey Matsuyama, diminutive Japanese star, shot into undisputed possession of first place in the world's three-cushion billiards tournament tonight by defeating Otto Reiselt of Philadelphia, 50 to 33, in 38 innings. Matsuyama now has won six games and lost two.

Commemorating his sixty years in the Society of Jesus, the Rev. John J. Wynne, author, educator and scholar, was feted by more than 600 persons, many of them distinguished in the church, State and city, at a dinner last night at the Hotel Biltmore.

The Weston Electrical Instrument Corporation and its domestic subsidiary reported yesterday for the first nine months of 1936 a net profit of $161,885 after depreciation and Federal income taxes. After dividend requirements on the $2 cumulative participating Class A stock, the profit was equivalent to 73 cents each on 160,583 no-par shares of common stock.

November set a new record for motor vehicles shipped from the factories, the Automobile Manufacturers Association disclosed yesterday in a preliminary report on the business of the month. Not including the figures of the Ford Motor Company, the major quantity producer outside of the association, factory shipments for the month were 337,446 cars and trucks.

Twenty-three major letters in football and eight minor letters in cross-country will be awarded to Fordham athletes, it was announced yesterday by Graduate Manager John F. Coffey. The most successful eleven in history at Fordham won five games, tied two and lost one.

"Bassa Moona," an African drama by Momodu Johnson and Norman Coker, had its first performance last night at Harlem's Lafayette Theatre under the auspices of the Manhattan and Bronx Unit of the WPA Federal Theatre. Though it is officially styled drama, this is a purely technical designation, for its interest centers entirely in its dancing and the accompanying music.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Dec. 8. -- After coming from behind to conquer New Jersey by 4 -- 3 in the morning, Westchester lost, 5 -- 2, to a strong New York squash racquets squad in a women's Class A team match at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club this afternoon.

Business failures declined in the' 'manufacturing, wholesaling and re-i tailing division in the week endedI IDoc. 3, compared with the preced-] ing business period according to i the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Retail failures, according to the report, have comprised 63 per cent of the failures toi date, The detailed report is as follows:

JERUSALEM, Dec. 8. -- Eliahu Epstein continued today his testimony before the British inquiry commission regarding illicit Arab immigration, stressing that this caused an economic grievance, because unskilled Arab immigrants worked for 35 to 50 cents a day and spent only 15 cents daily.

Mayor La Guardia, who has been studying midtown traffic congestion, announced yesterday that he has called a conference of midtown business men, policemen and members of the Aldermanic Traffic Code committee for next week to consider steps for relieving the situation.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 8. -- Mr. and Mrs. Jay O'Brien were dinner hosts at Villa del Sarmiento tonight. Those present were Mr. and Mrs. William Rhinelander Stewart, the Misses Mary and Frances Munn, Charles A. Munn and the Duke of Sutherland.

With Irving E. Cantor defeating Ralph Marson, 5 to 3, in the deciding bout, the Fencers Club trio turned back the New York Athletic Club team on the latter's strips last night, 5 to 4, to win the national junior foils team crown. The victors, Cantor, Joseph Ullman and Henry B. Wesselman, received the Sanford Saltus Gold Medals and the New York University Cup.

The question of a "Pax Anglo-American" has arisen on numerous occasions in the past. Each time the arguments in its favor have been conclusively refuted. Nevertheless the idea persists, as evidenced by recent letters in your columns.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 8. -- The Metropolitan Opera Association of New York will present a season of grand opera in this city the week of April 12, it was announced tonight by Senator Robert J. Bulkley, chairman of the Northern Ohio Opera Association, which again will act as sponsor.
VATICAN CITY, Dec. 8. -- A decided improvement in Pope Pius's condition, which the Vatican had anxiously been awaiting since he was taken ill Friday, occurred during the night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- The Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce heard evidence today that when the Van Sweringen brothers lost control of their $3,000,000,000 network of railroads in 1935 they regained control within a few days without putting up "a nickel."

There were two articles in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 6 which might well have been printed side by side. In one the Regional Plan Association complained that we are far behind Germany in highway construction and, although apparently disclaiming advocacy of any plan to build highways mainly for high speeds, held up these 112-mile-an-hour military roads in Germany as an example for us to follow.

Ed Rosenthal of Boys High's undefeated football team, continued in a starring role as the Red and Black upset Thomas Jefferson, 32 -- 19, in a Section 1 test of the Brooklyn P.S.A.L. basketball championship at the Jefferson court yesterday.

The Boston Redskins, in splendid shape despite their mud battle with the Giants on Sunday when they annexed the Eastern Division championship, today planned to engage in their first workout at the Westchester Country Club, Rye, in preparation for the National Football League title clash against the powerful Green Bay Packers at the Polo Grounds Sunday.
BERLIN, Dec. 8. -- The Boerse was almost completely stagnant today, but the mrket is showing signs of weakness. Borrowing by the government apparently is exhausting the capital market entirely.

Although the Crop Reporting Board added 7,000 bales to last month's cotton estimate of 12,400,000, prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced into new high ground for the movement yesterday. All of the 1936 drop deliveries, except July, rose above the 12-cent level while December made the best quotation since the latter part of July.

Sensational marksmanship by Jim McNally, slim veteran guard, enabled Manhattan's basketball team to turn back the challenge of a scrappy Seton Hall College quintet, 40 to 25, before a crowd of 1,000 at the Jasper gymnasium last night.

Appealing to 800 prominent citizens and Queens business men attending the annual dinner of the Queensboro Chamber of Commerce at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria last night for support of the World's Fair of 1939, Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation, cited the success of expositions in Chicago, Cleveland and San Diego as proof of benefits expected for New York.

Maxie Berger, promising Montreal lightweight, stopped Lew Massey, veteran Philadelphian, in the fourth session of the feature eight-round bout at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx last night before 6,000 spectators. Berger weighed 137, Massey 138.

CHUR, Switzerland, Dec. 8 (AP). -- Hundreds of Nazis and anti-Nazis thronged this little town tonight on the eve of the trial for murder of David Frankfurter, 27-year-old Jewish medical student, in the killing of Wilhelm Gustloff. Many members of the German Legation at Berne have arrived here.

The Brooklyn blue ribbon jury sitting in the trial of the four men accused of killing Isaac Shain in a bar last month will see the alleged murder weapon discharged in the court room today, and will be permitted to examine the spent bullet under a microscope.

The James Monroe High School five, co-holder of the city P.S. A.L. championship, advanced to a tie for first place with Evander Childs and DeWitt Clinton in the Upper Manhattan-Bronx Division as the result of games played yesterday.

He gives twice who gives quickly. That saying is particularly applicable to this year's gifts for the Neediest Cases. The reason is that the period during which contributions are sought is shorter than usual. As always, the appeal begins on the first Sunday in December and closes with Christmas Day.

Maxie Berger, promising Montreal lightweight, stopped Lew Massey, veteran Philadelphian, in the fourth session of the feature eight-round bout at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx last night before 6,000 spectators. Berger weighed 137, Massey 138.

CHUR, Switzerland, Dec. 8 (AP). -- Hundreds of Nazis and anti-Nazis thronged this little town tonight on the eve of the trial for murder of David Frankfurter, 27-year-old Jewish medical student, in the killing of Wilhelm Gustloff. Many members of the German Legation at Berne have arrived here.

Members of the board of managers of the Women's Auxiliary of Union Settlement will give a reception this afternoon at the headquarters, 237 East 104th Street. Guests will have the opportunity of inspecting children's activities. Members of the settlement's staff will act as guides.

LONDON, Dec. 8. -- Tons of timber for the erection of stands along the route of the planned coronation of King Edward next May have been delivered despite the excitement of the past few days, coronation advertisements have returned to the newspapers and London insists on its calm.

Ernst Silberstein, who gave his first New York recital at the Town Hall last night, belongs in the growing company of musicians who have been forced out of Nazi Germany. For ten years he was solo 'cellist of the Staedtische Opera in Berlin and at the same time he was a member of the Klingler Quartet, an internationally known string ensemble.

BERLIN, Dec. 9. -- Prices on the Boerse fell steadily today. Heavy industrial stocks, however, were so completely stagnant that not even a tendency toward weakness had any concrete results. Potash shares softened, Salzdetfurth losing 1 point.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Conditional approval by the Interstate Commerce Commission of plans of the Keeshin trucking interests to bring six operating subsidiaries under the management of a single corporation, the Keeshin Motor Express Company, Inc., was recommended today to the commission in a proposed report by J. Edward Davey, chief of finance of the I.C.C.'s Bureau of Motor Carriers.

BUENOS AIRES. Dec. 9. -- The current deadlock hampering the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace seemed to hinge today on a reported Brazilian plan to offer an American security pact as a supplement to the various neutrality measures now officially pending.

LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 10. -- A series of swift, behind-the-scenes moves led the British Empire to fear last night that its sovereign had decided to abdicate his throne to marry Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson.

To digress and relieve the tension, "The Frogs" of ARISTOPHANES, produced in the original at the University of Cambridge last Spring, was repeated at the Chiswick Empire Theatre the other afternoon, to the delight of a highbrow audience. The Provost of King's College "explained how useful "'The Frogs' might be to us at present."

A rarely used law was invoked yesterday for the arrest of a jeweler who is accused of concealing a man indicted for grand larceny in a $5,000 "shake-down" of one of the members of the Nicholas (Nick) Montana vice ring.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP). -- The navy was in the market tonight for 2,600,000 pounds of copper but could find nobody willing to sell.

Scoring on three successive stop thrusts after trailing by 4 -- 2 in her last match with Miss Elizabeth Bruskin of Brooklyn College, Miss Carol King of the Salle Santelli topped a field of thirty-three entrants to annex the gold medal in the Manrique novice foils tournament held under the auspices of the Amateur Fencers League of America at the Fencers Club last night.

The new picture on today's schedule is "More Than a Secretary," played by Jean Arthur, George Brent, Lionel Stander, Ruth Donnelly, Reginald Denny and Dorothea Kent. The film was produced by Columbia and will be on view at the Radio City Music Hall.

The Dictionary of American Biography -- a biographical history of the United States -- is completed by the publication of the twentieth and last volume under the auspices of the American Council of Learned Societies. For twenty years following the publication in England of the British Dictionary of National Biography the thought of such a work for America possessed the minds of some of our leading scholars in the humanities.

German newspapers have thus far not been allowed to say anything about the constitutional crisis in Great Britain, but have enjoyed a certain freedom in commenting upon President ROOSEVELT'S speech at Buenos Aires. To the Nazi mind it appears not to mean what it says. The whole plan of a peace treaty for all the Americas seems to be highly suspect to the Nazi press.

SUNNINGDALE, England, Dec. 9. -- With all the royal servants told to keep out of sight and out of earshot, King Edward at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon met his broken-hearted mother. Queen Mary, in the Duke of York's study at the Royal Lodge in Windsor Park.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine announced yesterday that he would promote thirty-nine men on Saturday night at the graduation exercises of the current class of 198 rookies in the 165th Regiment Armory. Mayor La Guardia will attend.

Dr. OSCAR RIDDLE of the Carnegie Institution of Washington's staff of biologists will raise no objection if we call him a "eutelegeneticist," a term coined to designate one who would apply genetics to control human evolution and give us a type something better than a Buddha, Newton, Goethe and Lincoln rolled into one. For Dr. RIDDLE tells the American Institute that the time has come for man to direct his own biological destiny.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 9. -- A hook-up between the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace and the Chaco Peace Conference was effected today when a session of the latter was attended by the chiefs of the delegations of the six American States that are acting as mediators in the Chaco negotiations.

Many supper parties were given in conjunction with the Babies Costume Supper Dance for the benefit of the Madison Square Boys Club last night in the Caprice Room of the Weylin. The guests had been requested to wear juvenile costumes.

The Cunard White Star liner Berengaria sailed for Cherbourg and Southampton yesterday with one of the ship's seamen held in irons in connection with the slaying of a fellow-seaman on the night of Dec. 2 as the liner was steaming out of Cherbourg harbor for New York.

The Works Progress Administration, under pressure from Mayor La Guardia and relief workers, abandoned yesterday its announced intention of cutting a specific number of persons from the Federal rolls in this city.
United State Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

The four teams that won last week again scored victories yesterday in the Metropolitan Class C, Group 1, squash racquets tournament. The Princeton Club easily conquered Rockaway, 4 to 1, while the Harvard Club blanked the Heights Casino in five matches.

Miss Elsa Maxwell gave a dinner last night in the Perroquet suite of the Waldorf-Astoria for Mr. and Mrs. Emile Mathis, followed by a surprise supper for Gertrude Lawrence and Noel Coward. Varied divertissements were given during the evening.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP). -- A sharp drop in gold imports during November was reported today by the Department of Commerce. The administration has contended that the inflow has passed its peak. Imports for the month were $75,769,-661, compared to $218,928,514 in October, $171,866,183 in September and $210,809,729 in November, 1935.

With only one regular from last season's squad available, Fordham's varsity basketball team launched its 1936-37 campaign last night on its home floor and triumphed over a strong alumni quintet, 33 to 21.
The undefeated Union Temple five recorded its fourth victory of the season at the expense of the Prudential Insurance A.A., 43 -- 29, on the Temple floor last night.

While a large majority of the newspapers in the United States supported the Republicans in the Presidential campaign of 1936, radio was no more effective in influencing public opinion, according to statistics obtained yesterday from the major networks.

Scoring in three straight games, W.J. McQueeney of the home club eliminated the second seeded player when he defeated B.B. Adams of the University Club in the Squash Club's invitation Class B squash racquets tourney yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9. -- Daniel C. Green, president of the Middle West Corporation, presented today his final report as trustee of the Middle West Utilities Company, predecessor company reorganized under the Federal Bankruptcy Laws on Nov. 27, 1935.

SARASOTA, Fla., Dec. 9 (AP). -- The Sarasota Herald said today that it had learned from reliable sources the late John Ringling bequeathed the Ringling Art Museum here to Florida. The art works are said to have been valued as high as $20,000,000.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the week-end, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local private and public elementary and high schools:
VATICAN CITY, Dec. 9 (AP). -- Physicians attending 79-year-old Pope Pius XI kept a careful check on his heartbeats tonight to determine whether he would be able to sit up in a chair tomorrow.

With a final blast that rumbled through the full mile of its length, the tunnel connecting the Bronx with Wards Island was holed through yesterday morning at 9:40 o'clock. The tunnel, fifteen feet in diameter now, will be lined with concrete to be ten feet six inches wide.
LONDON, Dec. 9 (AP). -- The European "hands-off Spain" committee tonight agreed to prohibit indirect intervention in the Spanish civil war.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 9. -- Honoring Sir Bede E.H. Clifford, Governor of the Bahamas, who arrived today to be his overnight guest before attending the all-American air meet beginning tomorrow in Miami, Charles A. Munn entertained tonight with a dinner at Amado.

BRISBANE, Australia, Dec. 9 (Canadian Press). -- England's touring cricketers have every reason to feel proud today. Victors by the big margin of 322 runs over Australia's best in the first of five test matches, they are enthusiastic over their chances of returning to England with "the ashes," mythical emblem of world cricket honors.
One of the most glamorous spectacles ever presented indoors was unfolded at Madison Square Garden last night as the first annual Winter Sports Show and International Ski Meet began a four-day run.

James S. Becker of the Yale Club provided a highlight in the weekly Class A team matches of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League yesterday by giving Harry F. Wolf, national champion, a real scrap for one game. The match was the No. 1 test in the New York A.C.-Yale Club meeting on the Eli courts, which the Winged Foot won to remain unbeaten in seven starts.
OTTAWA, Dec. 9. -- Refunding of all Canadian governmental borrowings was discussed this afternoon at a Dominion provincial conference presided over by Charles Dunning, Federal Minister of Finance.
Purchase of a Washington Heights block front for improvement with a taxpayer and apartment house was included in Manhattan deals announced yesterday.

With all the deals, rumored, proposed or actually completed, that engaged major league owners and managers during the second day of the major league meetings, the one involving the disposition of Jerome Herman (Dizzy) Dean, great pitcher and showman of the Cardinals, stubbornly stayed in the spotlight yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Gravely concerned over the promotion by the Federal Government of Federal savings and loan associations to compete with established institutions and the danger of promiscuous chartering of banks in the recovery era, the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks is determined to seek appropriate legislation and administrative rulings, Luther A. Harr, Secretary of Banking for Pennsylvania and chairman of the association's executive committee, said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Misunderstandings regarding the relief policies of the Works Progress Administration were cleared away today at a conference between Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator and Mayor La Guardia, acting as president of the United States Conference of Mayors.

Monday, Jan. 4, is the latest in the long series of opening dates set for "The Eternal Road," at the Manhattan Opera House. The postponement from the week of Dec. 28 will add $25,000 to the already huge production cost, in addition to the loss of holiday business, the management says.

The commodity futures markets generally were higher yesterday in comparatively quiet trading. However, crude rubber futures, which have been under pressure for several days, suffered another sharp setback. In the cash market grains, flour, cocoa, lard, cotton, tin, wool tops and silk were higher, while eggs, printcloth and rubber were lower.

Although Sherlock Holmes professes to have retired in "The Holmeses of Baker Street," which was acted at the Masque last evening, he still keeps a finger on crime and his daughter is smart for a girl her age. She is a good shot at eight paces in her father's study; and, if it is not breaking faith to say so, she can capture a band of thugs single-handed.

Green Bay's Packers arrived in New York yesterday and immediately repaired to the Polo Grounds, where they engaged in a two-hour workout in preparation for Sunday's play-off battle with the Boston Redskins for the National Football League championship.

KINGSTON, R.I., Dec. 9. -- Harvard opened its basketball campaign tonight as Rhode Island State drove the Crimson to a 53-48 defeat. It was only through their driving game that the Rams wore down the invaders, who led by a comfortable margin midway in each half.
CANNES, France, Dec. 9. -- Theodore Goddard, London solicitor, and Dr. W. Douglas Kirkwood, London gynecologist, left Cannes today without clearing up the mystery of their visit.

CHUR, Switzerland, Dec. 9 (AP). -- David Frankfurter, on trial for the killing of the German Nazi leader in Switzerland, testified tonight that he had decided not to assassinate Chancellor Adolf Hitler and the German Propaganda Minister, Joseph Goebbels, "because it would cause too great suffering among the Jews in Germany."

Rolling up one of the biggest scores ever made in the DeGray Gymnasium, the St. John's University quintet scored a 46-to-24 triumph over Wagner College last night. The Redmen led throughout and were in front at the end of the first half, 36 to 7.

OWL'S HEAD, N.Y., Dec. 9. -- Scientists who offered proof today that this Adirondack Mountain hamlet is not, as it contended, the "icebox of the East," paid tribute at the same time to the enterprise of its citizens in making this village famous on the weather map.

Lindsay Bradford, chairman of the Family Service Fund of the Charity Organization Society's campaign for $278,000, announced yesterday at a luncheon for committee members in the Bankers Club that more than half of this amount -- $144,355 -- has been raised.

LONDON, Dec. 9. -- Fourteen lives were lost and three other persons were seriously injured today when a twin-motored Douglas plane of the Royal Dutch Air Line bound for Amsterdam crashed and burst into flames in a London suburb less than a quarter of a mile from Croydon Airdrome where it had taken off a few seconds before.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 9 (AP). -- An average of less than 72 strokes for 65 rounds gave Ralph Guldahl of St. Louis the Radix Cup for the best medal play along the 1936 golf tournament stretch. Robert E. Harlow, tournament manager for the Professional Golfers Association, today announced Guldahl the winner with an average of 71.63, the lowest ever recorded.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Secretary Wallace told members oil the American Farm Bureau Federation today that the farmer must be willing in the cause of peace "to accept small increases in the imports of certain agricultural products."

A "siege" by WPA workers of the supervisor's office of the project of the Mayor's Committee on City Planning at 242 Fourth Avenue ended last night after the official in charge of the project, F.D. McHugh, had promised to meet this morning with higher officials to reconsider the cases of eleven men and women dismissed from the project

Writing "gags" or jokes for radio comedians is on the way to become Big Business. It goes beyond the radio star who hires some one to do his funny lines. The gag purveyor in turn runs a factory. He has a filing system which covers all the jokes in history and he employs a staff of writers.

BERLIN, Dec. 9. -- A new demand for colonies, coupled with a warning that unless the growing German people obtained more room and the world ceased to attempt to shrink them through external pressure there would be an explosion that would shake the peace of Europe and the world, was voiced today by Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics and President of the Reichsbank.

Plans to limit next year's production of cotton along the lines of the last season, as announced yesterday by the Department of Agriculture, had an immediate influence on cotton prices. With no change in the 35 per cent reduction from the base acreage allowable to growers participating in the soil-conservation program, fears of an unrestricted acreage were removed and trading on the Cotton Exchange broadened at advancing prices.

Thomas A. Buckner, president of the New York Life Insurance Company for five years, was elevated yesterday to the position of chairman of the board and Alfred L. Aiken, a vice president for the same length of time, was made president.

Reports have it that persons asking for alms are more numerous in the streets than for some time past. If this is true it may be partly explained as one of the usual incidents of the Christmas season. It is a source of perplexity to the charitably minded. Shall they refuse to give to one whom they fear to be an impostor, though he may be a worthy individual?

When the I.C.C. ordered that railroad fares for coach travel henceforth should not exceed 2 cents a mile, the carriers rushed into court to prevent the order becoming effective. That was instinct, not judgment. The roads' increase in gross income testifies to the wisdom of the I.C.C. order.

Testimony was given at a hearing before Judge Galston, in the Federal court in Brooklyn, that the seizure of the Spanish steamer Navemar by a "committee" consisting of some of its officers and members of its crew took place in New York Harbor after it had been learned that the Spanish Government had given notice of confiscation of the vessel.
The governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange approved yesterday the listing of securities of five companies. The applicants and their issues were:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 9. -- Profits of limited price variety chains declined slightly in 1935, according to a report issued today by the Harvard Business School through its Bureau of Business Research. Thirty chains controlling somewhat more than 90 per cent of the trade in this country last year earned net merchandising profits (after interest on net worth) of more than $33,000,000, or 4.5 per cent, on sales amounting to $742,000,000.

CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE, N.J., Dec. 9. -- A 22-year-old Philadelphia girl testified here today that she voted five times on Nov. 3 in Wildwood, N.J. She was a witness when a hearing was resumed before Circuit Court Judge Wilfred H. Jayne on the allegedly fraudulent election of William C. Hunt, Republican, as State Senator from Cape May County.
Apartment houses and dwellings were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.
Is not the Merchants Association table of per capita costs for this city's government which you print seriously misleading?

TOKYO, Dec. 9. -- Japanese Privy Council members today assailed the foreign policies of the Premier and his Foreign Minister, indicating, some observers felt, that their resignations might be demanded.

The Brooklyn Daily Eagle will take over The Brooklyn Times-Union about Jan, 1 and continue it as a separate publication, according to an announcement yesterday by M. Preston Goodfellow, president of The Eagle, and Fremont C. Peck. owner of The Times-Union.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9. -- In the hog market here today sows were unchanged in price, but most other grades were 10 cents a hundred-weight lower. There was a larger percentage of weights under 170 pounds than of late and some sales were regarded as 15 cents or more lower than on Tuesday.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Dec. 9 (AP). -- The mental quirk that led 25-year-old Hope Morgan, fearful of losing her sanity, to kill her college chum and confidante came under scrutiny of a court-appointed sanity commission tonight.

The conference of business and labor groups so long and so hopefully planned by Major BERRY is to meet in Washington today, and its opening program calls for an all-day forum at which ideas and opinions are to be exchanged. Committee meetings will follow later, provided the conference is able to proceed in peace and no difficulties are encountered similar to those which appeared at another meeting of this kind, held just a year ago.

Kirsten Flagstad came upon the stage of Carnegie Hall last night, before an immense audience, with the dignity and simplicity of bearing which is hers by nature, and quickly revealed a new phase in her development as a singer of lieder.

Accounting for two seeded players in as many days, A. George Townsend of the home club upset Lieutenant David P. Laubach of Mitchel Field, fourth rated player, in the quarter-final round of the Long Island championship of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association yesterday at the Jackson Heights Squash Club.
Deals by operators continued to mark the activity in Queens real estate yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9. -- Willie Hoppe, veteran cue expert, came from behind tonight to defeat Welker Cochran, San Francisco star, 50 to 43, in forty-five innings in the world's three-cushion title billiard tournament. Hoppe had a high run of five and Cochran's best cluster was six.

i Postmaster General James A. ari ley returns today from a vacation trip to Europe on the steamship I Washington of the United States Lines accompanied by Ambrose O'Connell and Edward L. Rodden. Others coming on the ship from !Hamburg, Havre, Southampton and i Oueenstown include:

MANILA, Dec. 9 (AP). -- President Manuel Quezon proclaimed "a state of calamity" tonight in the flood-swept Cagayan River valley, while varying reports of the water's toll came out of the stricken area. Government agencies rushed relief preparations.

HAZLEHURST, Ga., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Lawrence Ward, 51-year-old itinerant repairman accused of "stomping'' his 14-year-old stepdaughter to death because she had a date, was convicted of murder today and sentenced to die.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 9. -- Dr. Henry Noble MacCracken, president of Vassar College, retired this afternoon as chairman of the board of trustees of Sarah Lawrence College, thus ending the official tie that has bound the two institutions since Sarah Lawrence received its provisional charter ten years ago.

Discussing the position of the United States in the threatening world situation, Henry I. Harriman, former president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, praised the initiative of President Roosevelt last night in seeking to unite the two Americas in a compact for peace.

A set of twenty-one rare proof engravings by the English mystic William Blake, poet and artist, were sold for $5,000 last night at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., at an auction of rare books and autographs. The sale included property of Francis K. Swartley of Philadelphia, Richard Greene Holbrook of Larchmont, Alfred L. Bernheim of this city and Irving S. Underhill of Buffalo.

R. Hoe Co., Inc., in their report for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday, showed a consolidated profit of $391,858 before interest charges. After interest charges of $264,459 on the company's 6 1/2 per cent bonds and 7 per cent notes there was a consolidated net profit of $127,398 before income tax.
CHICAGO, Dec. 9 (AP). -- Wagering on horse racing in Illinois in 1936 totaled $32,133,764, a decrease of approximately $2,000,000 compared with 1935.

It will cost-the city $8.03 for each of the 11,075 copies of lists of enrolled voters which the Board of Elections has obligated itself to buy in the coming year, it was learned yesterday. And, it was explained, after it buys the books the city sells them for from $2 to $3 each.

Dr. Harlan H. Horner, assistant State Commissioner of Higher Education, told the faculty, officers, trustees and students of Long Island University in Brooklyn last night that their college "has proved its right to a future in the field of higher education."

READING, Pa., Dec. 9 (AP). -- Union leaders' appeals for a mandate to close the Berkshire Knitting Mills and to release thirteen strikers held in solitary confinement in the Berks County Prison met today with refusal by Governor Earle and a reserved decision by the Berks County Prison Board.

Commissioner Lithgow Osborne of the New York State Conservation Department gathered the outdor columnists of the metropolitan area around a luncheon table at the Harvard Club yesterday and recounted some of the woes that make a fish and game official age prematurely.

Robert Sinagra of 38-12 Astoria Boulevard, Astoria, was arrested yesterday on a charge of burglary because of a few dog hairs on the back seat of his new sedan. The dog which provided the clue belongs to Edward Kissell, who has a tavern at 2921 Newtown Avenue, Astoria.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 9. -- Women's organizations and feminist leaders of twelve Latin-American countries today added their voice to the demand of United States women that the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace go on record as favoring votes for women as a measure in furtherance of peace.

TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 10. -- Foreign Minister Hachiro Arita, who has consulted the fighting services at every step in his foreign policy, yesterday admitted to the Privy Council that difficulties had arisen over the German pact and over the Nanking negotiations with China.

Work on the 10,000-ton cruiser Helena at the New York Navy Yard, Brooklyn, moved outdoors yesterday when Rear Admiral Harris Laning, Commandant of the Third Naval District, witnessed the riveting of a keel section. The ceremony was the last of many at the navy yard this year, including an unparalleled number of peacetime launchings and commissionings.

The persistent strength in New York City bonds that has carried most of those issues to record high levels and placed the 4 1/4s of 1981, a representative issue, close to a 3 per cent yield basis, was cause for renewed discussion in municipal bond circles yesterday of the pending city financing.
BERLIN, Dec. 9 (AP). -- The Reichsbanks statement as of Dec. 7 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

Bidding $10,000 over mortgages aggregating $2,300,000, the New York Life Insurance Company yesterday took over the vacant block front on the east side of Madison Avenue, Thirty-eighth to Thirty-ninth Streets, at a foreclosure sale in 18 Vesey Street.

"The Frantic Physician," a two-act comic operetta, was presented by the opera department of the Juilliard School of Music in the Juilliard Concert Hall last night. This operetta, as it was correctly designated on the printed program, was a metamorphosis of Gounod's comic opera in three acts, "Le Medecin Maralgre Lui," founded on Moliere's play.
LONDON, Dec. 9. -- The remaining items of Emile Brouwet's Napoleonic collection, which were auctioned at Sotheby's today, netted u2,399, bringing the total for the two days' sale to more than u4,000.

LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 10. -- The Times reveals today the contents of its mail bag in an editorial which traces, so the editor declares, "the progressive trend" of public opinion from "sentimental" in the first days of the crisis in the definite direction of reminding the King of the services and the sacrifices made, particularly in wartime, by the people in the name of their King.

A temporary injunction restraining the Television Corporation of America, its president Oliver C. Harriman, and six other defendants from any transactions in the corporation's stock was signed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo on application of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr.

Eight firemen were overcome by smoke while fighting a fire in the subcellar of the twenty-one-story apartment building at 25 Prospect Place, Tudor City, yesterday morning. Firemen went through the building arousing nearly 1,000 tenants, who were forced to walk down unlighted stairs in the 5:30 A.M. gloom because the fire put the electric service out of commission, shutting off lights and elevator service.

The revival of "Samson et Dalila," which has been absent from the Metropolitan's repertoire for eleven years, will take place the first Saturday afternoon of the season. Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association, yesterday announced the full list of operas for the opening week, revealing that there will be many debuts during that time.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 9. -- Princeton's basketball team routed a fighting Lafayette five, 41 -- 24, tonight in the University Gymnasium. It was the second victory in as many games for the Tigers and the third stright setback for the Leopards.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP). -- Final returns from the Presidential election, official in every State save one, showed today that the record-breaking vote amounted to 45,812,155. President Roosevelt's plurality, also a record, was 11,069,699.

BERLIN, Dec. 9. -- Baldur von Schirach, Reich youth leader, in a broadcast this evening which 6,000,000 Hitler Youth members were ordered to hear either at home or at special assemblies, undertook to reassure Christian parents. He declared that in the future there would be no Hitler Youth exercises Sunday mornings or any other time calculated to interfere with attendance at religious ceremonies.

Art chairmen of New York's forty-five high schools will meet this evening at 7:30 o'clock in the design laboratory of the W.P.A. Federal Art Project, 10 East Thirty-ninth Street, to discuss methods of teaching design to young people. The program for the evening includes a demonstration tour of the school in the effort to develop a closer relationship in art education between modern manufacturing methods and the theory of design.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The $12,000,000 telephone-rate reductions recently ordered by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, to become effective on Jan. 15, have been detailed to the Federal Communications Commission, which made them public today in a statement in which the new schedule was praised as "an important forward step in the science of telephone rate-making."

An underwriting group headed by A.G. Becker Co., Inc., and including Cassatt Co., Inc., and Singer, Deane Scribner will offer today at $19 a share, 100,000 shares of common capital stock of $1 par value of the Universal-Cyclops Steel Corporation.

ROME, Dec. 9. -- Miss Virginia McKay, American refugee from Madrid, has just visited this correspondent and has given him a terrific talking to about everything that has happened here since she accepted my more or less innocent breakfast invitation on the train from Ventimiglia.

Samuel Marcus, for the last thirty-three years general counsel of the New York Society for the Prevention of Crime, has resigned, it was disclosed yesterday by Dr. George Drew Egbert, pastor of the First Congregational Church of Flushing and president of the society.
