While two priests gave him the last rites of the Roman Catholic Church and physicians worked frantically over him, a fireman died last night from the effects of smoke at a two-alarm fire in the 245th Coast Artillery Regiment -- the old Thirteenth -- at 347 Sumner Avenue, Brooklyn.
The New York University basketball team opened its seventeen-game schedule last night with a 45-to-19 victory over an alumni combination at the University Heights gymnasium.
Sales of apartment houses by savings banks featured realty trading in the Bronx yesterday.

CANNES, France, Dec. 9. -- Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson's offer to withdraw from the life of Edward VIII "if it will solve the problem" still holds good, her spokesman, Lord Brownlow, Lord-in-Waiting to King Edward, said tonight.

Stockholders of the Freeport Texas Company voted yesterday in Wilmington, Del., to change the name of the company to Freeport Sulphur Company, the name of its principal subsidiary. This subsidiary will be liquidated, and after Jan. 1 the parent company, operating under its new name, will engage directly in the production and marketing of sulphur, Langbourne M. Williams Jr., president, said.

Recent resumption of "finger job" jewel robberies inspired Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine yesterday to order Assistant Chief Inspector John A. Lyons to form a new detective squad to get the "finger workers."

Andre Geraud, French political writer known as Pertinax, told the Congress of American Industry at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday that "a possibility of war will exist" some time next year or early in 1938 as a result of German rearmament under the Hitler regime.

PARIS, Dec. 9. -- The French need to borrow and the reported abundance of unwanted foreign capital in the United States have given rise to persistent rumors on the Bourse and in the Chamber of Deputies of negotiations in progress for a French loan in the United States, the amount mentioned being 17,000,000,000 francs.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec.' 9. -- Robert W. Johnson, president of Johnson Johnson, manufacturers of surgical supplies, recommended here tonight a "three-code plan for the nation's business and industry to take the place of the multiplicity of restrictive reguations which caused havoc and confusion under the old NRA."

Organization of a textile stabilization commission, to proceed at once upon a fact-finding investigation for the benefit of the industry, was proposed last night at a meeting of the Textile Converters Association by Sylvan Gotshal, attorney for the association.

Hocus-pocus vs. old-fashioned powerhouse -- an argument that has figured prominently ever since wily Bob Zuppke came out of Oak Park, Ill., High School a quarter of a century ago and mystified every one with his flea-flicker and razzle-dazzle stuff -- still supplies a subject for debate among college football leaders.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The case of Dirk De Jonge, a Communist convicted of violating the Oregon Criminal Syndicalism Law, attracted such attention in the Supreme Court today that five of the eight judges sitting asked many questions of Maurice E. Tarshis, State Deputy District Attorney, as he argued in support of the State statute.

With profits higher than at any period in many years, those cotton goods companies that have been consistent national advertisers are expected to increase sharply their budgets for 1937, according to comment here yesterday. In contrast to the total number of mills in the country, some 1,200, they are comparatively few, numbering between fifteen and twenty, according to estimates.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The reappointment by President Roosevelt of Rear Admiral Cary T. Grayson, U.S.N., retired, as chairman of the American Red Cross, was announced today coincident with the annual meetings here of the society's central committee, board of incorporators and chapter delegates.

CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 9. -- Angered by the government's refusal to allow debate, the extremist faction of the Labor opposition today threw the House of Representatives into turmoil at the close of a session lasting twenty minutes.
Anthony Garlaus, an ex-convict, admitted yesterday before a Kings County jury that he had killed Isaac Shain in a Brooklyn hold-up on Nov. 8.

Today for the first time the public will be able to see a complete model of the Rainbow Arch Memorial on which George Grey Barnard, noted American sculptor, has worked eighteen years and which he hopes to erect as a gift to the city.

Expansion of production and not shorter working hours is the cure for unemployment, it was declared yesterday by Dr. Harold G. Moulton, president of the Brookings Institution, before a luncheon meeting of the Congress of American Industry at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

THE men in the corridors of the baseball meet yesterday were throwing them low and inside. About every third fellow encountered gave the come-hither sign, slipped behind a pillar, cupped his hand over one side of his mouth and whispered:

LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 10. -- With King Edward secluded at Fort Belvedere, the nation and empire prepared themselves last night for the first voluntary abdication in all the thousand-odd years' history of the British monarchy.
In the Dec. 5 edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES, Murray J. Lefcourt commented on the rush-hour operation in the Interborough subway and made several suggestions for the improvement of service.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 9. -- Making the first start of his career, Zippy, 4-year-old gelding owned by R. Kearns, captured the Fayette Purse at the Charles Town track today, to return $52 for a $2 ticket.
The Barat Settlement will be the beneficiary of a Christmas sale to be held today in the small ballroom of the Plaza. A feature will be the tea room under the direction of members of the auxiliary.

GENEVA, Dec. 9. -- Turkey appealed to the League of Nations today under Article XI of the covenant to take protective measures during the special Council session opening tomorrow on Spain "to insure the safety of the Turkish people [of Alexandretta, Syria], whose lives and liberties are endangered."

A broad advance in South American dollar bonds, a belated recognition of the effect of the Buenos Aires Peace Conference featured the trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. New high prices were recorded for many Latin-American issues, regardless of their position in respect to partial or total interest default.

John Spargo, former Socialist, urged yesterday that there be no truce in criticism of the Roosevelt and Lehman administrations at a luncheon meeting of the women's division of the New York State Economic Council in the Hotel Biltmore.

Juan de la Cierva, who was killed yesterday, was regarded as one of the outstanding engineers of modern aeronautics. His autogiro, a revolutionary aircraft, was considered one of the most promising experiments in modern design.

Melvin C. Eaton, retiring chairman of the Republican State committee, made public last night a detailed denial of charges by William F. Bleakley, recent Republican nominee for Governor, that the party organization failed to give him proper support during the campaign.
The Shippers Conference of Greater New York voted yesterday to oppose the proposal of the railroads to increase rates on transcontinental shipments and class ratings on carload freight.

ALBANY, Dec. 9 (AP). -- A State NRA bill fashioned on the lines of similar legislation in California was recommended for legislative action in 1937 by the executive committee of the New York State Federation of Labor at its closing session today.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 9. -- Yale defeated Boston University, 9 to 3, tonight before 600 spectators in the New Haven Arena, Captain Bill Moore and Andy Gagarin featuring the attack. Gagarin tallied four times.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9. -- Holding the lead most of the way in a nip-and-tuck struggle, the Penn basketball team defeated La Salle, 26 to 25, in the Palestra tonight before 3,000 fans.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Dec. 9. -- Alabama is ready to drop the prosecution of four of the nine Negroes in the Scottsboro case because of lack of evidence, the Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers, chairman of the Scottsboro Defense Committee, said here tonight in an address at a dinner of the Department of Race Relations of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America.

The twentieth and final volume of the Dictionary of American Biography, marking the completion of one of the most ambitious ventures in cooperative scholarship ever undertaken in America, is being issued today, under the auspices of the American Council of Learned Societies, by Charles Scribner's Sons. Eight years passed between the publication of the first volume, Abbe to Barrymore, on Nov. 8, 1928, and that of the final volume, Werden to Zunser.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The Townsend old-age pension plan is pronounced "economically unsound" by the majority of the select House committee which investigated the financial operations of the founder, Dr. Francis E. Townsend, and analyzed his program.
The Long Island University basketball team scored a 73-35 victory over the Montclair State Teachers before an overflow crowd at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium last night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The Securties and Exchange Commission made public today a list and summary of registration statements filed recently under the Securities Act of 1933. The list follows:

LONDON, Dec. 9. -- After a fairly cheerful opening this morning, the stock market here developed dullness this afternoon, most quotations falling to the overnight levels or below. British Government securities failed to hold their early improvement and moved lower than yesterday's close.

HARTFORD, Dec. 9. -- Bridgeport got its much desired Housing Authority Bill from the Legislature today, but only after hours of jockeying, during which the House defeated a Senate bill and complicated a rules situation by refusing to reconsider that action.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 9. -- First Entry, 4-year-old gelding, owned by G. Laflesh, annexed the Opelousas Parse, mile and a sixteenth claiming race, which topped today's program at the Fair Grounds. Given a heady ride by Jockey F. Maschek First Entry closed strongly to overhaul the Swingland Stable's Boiling Point and Mrs. H.O. Simmons's Heart Break in the stretch.

A powerful second-half attack enabled Columbia to defeat Brooklyn Polytech, 35 -- 21, last night in the Lion's gymnasium. Leading by only 14 -- 12 at the intermission, Coach Paul Mooney's outfit, which was opening its campaign, rolled along in high early in the second and assumed a commanding lead, which never was threatened.

Complaints have been received by the New York Stock Exchange of the growing tendency of listed corporations to take dividend action after the close of the market and, in many cases, after the daily suspension of service by the financial news tickers.

Captain George Fried of the Steamboat Inspection Service and United States Shipping Commissioner John Daly were accused last night by the striking seamen of acting in concert with the American Shipowners Association in "vicious attempts" to break the strike.

Cash dividends declared yesterday totaled $30,000,000, bringing the figure for this month to $210,000,000. Since the beginning of November dividend declarations have amounted to $1,093,200,000, of which $883,200,000 was declared last month.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Dec. 9. -- A three-cornered link between clubwomen, newspaper women and the public in presenting the views and aims of clubwomen through newspapers was seen here today at a luncheon at which newspaper women of New York and Westchester County were guests of the Manor Club at the Pelham Manor Club house.

Joseph T. Higgins, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Third New York District, informed employers last night of the elements that will have to go into their payroll records in compliance with the old-age benefit provisions of the Federal Social Security Act.

The fistic world has no new bantamweight champion today only because Sixto Escobar, Puerto Rican holder of the title, did not place his crown in jeopardy last night when he fought Harry Jeffra, Baltimore boxer, in the feature bout of ten rounds before 5,000 excited fans in the Hippodrome.

In moving irregularly higher yesterday, the share market ignored the lower trends of stock prices in London and Paris. The leadership here was better than it had been for several days, in that many representative railway issues gained from fractions to 1 point or more and issues of the metal group, along with various specialty stocks, improved.

MADRID, Dec. 9. -- Another trip to the front today -- this time to Guadalajara -- and talks with members of the international column who have just come back from the lines have again served to emphasize what an apparently hopeless task General Francisco Franco has trying to occupy Madrid.

Lieut. Gov. Thomas E. Knight Jr., special prosecutor in the Scottsboro case, said last night at Montgomery, Ala., that there has been no agreement by the prosecution to drop any of the indictments against the nine defendants in the case.

Public offering of a new issue of $12,000,000 of ten-year 3 per cent debentures, due in 1946, of the Associates Investment Company of South Bend, Ind., will be made today by a banking group headed by F.S. Moseley Co. The debentures will be priced at par and interest. The company is engaged in financing the purchase of motor vehicles at wholesale and retail.

Led by Art Fitzgerald, who scored nine points, the Brooklyn Cathedral Prep basketball team defeated New York Cathedral Prep, 34 -- 15, on the former's court yesterday. The victors led, 19 -- 10, at the intermission.

Two hundred and nineteen persons -- college students, professional men and women, laborers, the very young and the very old -- added $6,819.19 yesterday to the fund in the third day's response to the "silver anniversary" appeal for the Neediest Cases of New York.

Frank W. Taylor, 63-year-old actor, was killed last night when an explosion wrecked his apartment at 25 West Sixty-fourth Street as he sat quietly in a chair waiting for death from the fumes which caused the explosion.

Examination of William B. Joyce, former chairman of the old National Surety Company, in preparation for trial of a $20,000,000 accounting suit against former officers and directors of the company, was concluded for the present at a hearing yesterday afternoon at the offices of Hays, Wolf, Kaufman Schwabacher, 30 Broad Street.

PARIS, Dec. 9. -- Britain and France have called on other leading powers, it was revealed today, to join in an effort to mediate the war in Spain by a plan that would include a plebiscite by the Spanish people on the form of government they prefer.

Various store, office and loft rentals in larger numbers were reported yesterday. Among the lessees was the Finnish Travel Information Bureau, which took space in the International Building, Rockefeller Center. In Brooklyn a glove manufacturer and a bank were among the outstanding tenants.
If Gilbert and Sullivan had not long ago gone to their deserved reward, something could surely be done to put the epic of the Chilean plants into imperishable song and verse.

VIENNA, Dec. 9. -- It was learned today that Nazi discontent with the Austro-German agreement is steadily increasing and that Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg is alarmed by the rapid growth of Nazi influence, particularly in the provinces. Austro-German negotiations for a commercial treaty again were postponed until Dec. 14.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9. -- The Chicago Title and Trust Company announced today that it would give a bonus of two weeks' pay to employes in its service a year or longer and one of a week's pay to those employed less than a year.

The 1936 public school building program, authorized in the city's capital outlay budget, was advanced a step yesterday afternoon when the Board of Education voted approval of several calendar items at a meeting at its offices, Park Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 9. -- Discussions with Adele Astaire (Lady Cavendish) anent the possibility of a screen career have been revived by R.-K.-O., it was learned today. Lady Cavendish has been offered the leading feminine role opposite her brother, Fred Astaire, in "A Damsel in Distress" and the word from London is that she may not be averse to the proposal.

From the rise of the curtain on Maurice Rostand's "L'Homme que j'ai Tue" at the Barbizon-Plaza Theatre last evening, the audience realized they were in the presence of a masterpiece, which was not only a drama but a homily. This was made manifest by a synchronized silence that was church-like and by applause that was deliberate, thoughtful.
LONDON, Dec. 9 (AP). -- In uproarious fashion the first favorable political demonstration in King Ed-[ ward's favor from the dominions! came today from the Labor benches i of Australia's Parliament.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Department store sales in November were 8 per cent higher than for the same month last year, and for the first eleven months of the year exceeded the similar period of 1935 by 11 per cent, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

Professor George B. Pegram, eminent physicist, has been appointed to succeed the late Professor Howard Lee McBain as graduate dean of Columbia University, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, following action by the board of trustees.

Practically the entire collection of jewels of the late Mrs. Emma T. Gary, widow of Judge Elbert H. Gary, former head of United States Steel Company, has been sold to Harry Winston, a dealer in gems, who confirmed yesterday reports of his purchase.

The New York City four-day sessions of the National Preaching Mission ended yesterday, with seventeen meetings in Brooklyn and one in Queens. The four-day attendance was about 100,000. The nation-wide tour, which started on Sept. 13, has already reached twenty-five leading cities of the United States.
In THE NEW YORK TIMES last Sunday I read with keen interest the story on "Crop Insurance Plans" by the Secretary of Agriculture, Henry A. Wallace, from which I cull three striking assertions:

JERUSALEM, Dec. 9. -- Today's session of the royal commission of inquiry on Palestine proved that its members are well acquainted with the Arab complaints against the Jewish national home despite the fact that the Arabs are boycotting the commission.

Leading industrialists who have been severe critics of the New Deal called for a constructive program by industry to cooperate in solving unemployment and other social problems growing out of the depression and in seeking means to prevent or alleviate future crises at the opening sessions yesterday of the Congress of American Industry, the forty-first annual convention of the National Association of Manufacturers, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 9. -- A tax appeal "racket," in which persons solicit the handling of tax reductions from door to door on a contingent fee basis, has developed in Newark, Frank A. Boettner, Corporation Counsel, declared today on the stand in the Supreme Court investigation into Newark's municipal affairs.

LONDON, Dec. 9. -- While the King last night was suffering the torments of indecision in his private apartments at Fort Belvedere many persons prominent in London society, who had been regarded as his associates if not close friends, were attending a party given by Lady Cunard, at which, according to The Evening Standard's society paragrapher, "Women wore their smartest frocks."

Briefs assailing the proposed merger of the New York Edison Company, Inc., into the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., were filed yesterday with the Public Service Commission by the city and the Socialist Party, Local New York. The merger, both briefs declared, would be contrary to the public interest and would benefit the companies involved.

PARIS, Dec. 9. -- King Edward's abdication is reported tonight in Paris as definitely fixed for tomorrow unless the King, who is said to be in a completely unstrung, nervous state, should at the last minute withdraw his signature to the abdication document.

The concert given by John Barbirolli and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall was also the occasion of the American debut of the Spanish 'cellist Gaspar Gassado. He is a remarkably gifted artist, as the audience was quick to discover.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10. -- The charity ball tonight at the Bellevue-Stratford was held as a "Coronation Carnival." The beneficiaries were the Jefferson Hospital, represented in the pageant by Mrs. William Potter Wear, Mrs. Robert E. Hare and Mrs. J. Kent Willing; the Pennsylvania S.P.C.C., represented by Mrs. Philip Price, Mrs. Walter L. Ross Jr. and Mrs. John Wintersteen; the University of Pennsylvania Hospital and the Children's Hospital.

Following is the text of the Declaration of Principles for American Industry, adopted yesterday afternoon at the closing session of the Congress of American Industry, the forty-first annual convention of the National Association of Manufacturers, at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria:
LONDON, Dec. 10 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:
From the standpoint of personality, at least, there is a distinct parallelism between the relationship of King George VI of Britain to Edward VIII and that of George V to Edward VII.
LONDON, Dec. 10 (AP). -- King Edward renounced his throne "not because of his intention to marry Mrs. Simpson but simply because he hates his job," George Bernard Shaw asserted tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Cash subscriptions for the Treasury's offering of $700,000,000 2 1/2 per cent thirteen-seventeen-year bonds amounted to $5,100,000,000, or more than seven times the amount advertised, Secretary Morgenthau announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- The Ohio Edison Company, Akron, Ohio, filed today a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $26,834,000 of first-mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds, series of 1937, due in 1972, proceeds from the sale of which, together with funds in the treasury, will be used for the redemption on Feb. 1, at 105, of $26,834,500 of the company's outstanding 5 per cent bonds, series due in 1960.

A plan for merging the Briggs Manufacturing Company and the Motor Products Corporation, two concerns in Detroit which manufacture automobile parts and accessories, is being considered by the directors, it was announced yesterday.
Bessie Wallis Warfield was brought up in the way of an average American girl to a life of uneventful gentility, but destined to more fateful things.

The Warner-Quinlan Company's reorganization proceeding again was adjourned yesterday by Federal Judge Murray Hulbert, the next hearing being set for Monday morning. The court must consider whether it has authority to permit sale of the company's gasoline stations before a plan of reorganization has been formally approved.

The upward trend of prices continued last week. The Annalist reports, and its weekly index of wholesale commodity prices rose to 132.0 on Tuesday, the highest mark in six years, from 131.6 (revised) the Tuesday before. The gains were greatest in hogs, wheat and rye.

Directors of Paramount Pictures, Inc., declared yesterday an initial dividend of $12 a share on its first preferred stock, clearing up all arrears that had accumulated on this 6 per cent issue. The reorganization of the company was completed more than a year ago.

Two defendants in the third of a series of smugglers' trials were found guilty last night by a jury before Federal Judge Murray Hulbert on four counts of an indictment charging them with illegally importing and concealing 115 pounds of crude opium.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- The United States threw its moral support today behind the new Franco-British proposal to Germany, Italy, Russia and Portugal for mediation in Spain to terminate the civil war, but declined to join in the movement because of its policy of non-interference in the affairs of other countries.

" Dr." Anna Swift, middle-aged owner of the Danish Institute at 8 West Seventieth Street, which was raided by the police last June, was sentenced yesterday in Special Sessions to a three-month workhouse term by Justices Bayes, Hackenburg and Salomon on her conviction of maintaining a house of prostitution.
Despite the decline in bank clearings from the aggregate in the five days preceding, they continue to gain over the corresponding period last year.

With the familiar call of "track" echoing through the crisp Winter air as skiers go whizzing down snow-packed hills, the biggest year in the history of skiing, truly the king of Winter sports, is on its way. Once again, the ever-increasing army of modern Vikings is descending on favorable snow spots, eager to take up where they left off last year.

Postmaster General James A. Farley returned from Europe yesterday on the United States liner Washington accompanied by two campaign aides, Ambrose O'Connell and Edward L. Rodden, who went to Ireland with him to seek out the place where the Postmaster General's ancestors were born.
ROME, Dec. 10. -- King Edward's abdication, though expected here, did not fail to create an enormously deep impression on the Italian public.

As the exodus of the baseball folk began early yesterday afternoon and continued far into the night, no owner or manager made his exit carrying the conviction that any of his player deals had come close to rocking the foundations of his league.

That was a heartening meeting of the Salt Water Anglers of America at the Hotel Gramercy Park on Wednesday evening. You had a feeling that after three years of talk the sport and commercial interests were ready to get down to brass tacks.

Captain George Fried, supervising inspector of the Federal Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation, said yesterday that Federal regulations governing the employment of able-bodied seamen and men qualified as lifeboat crews on American ships leaving this port had been rigidly enforced during the seamen's strike.

Plans for altering the four-story apartment house at 471 West End Avenue were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the property by the Fifth Avenue Bank to the Esjol Realty Corporation, represented by William Seligson, attorney.

DURHAM, N.H., Dec. 10. -- Dr. Fred Engelhardt, head of the Department of Educational Administration at the University of Minnesota, was elected president of the University of New Hampshire today by the trustees at a special session here.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Dec. 10. -- The Rev. Dr. Edgar De Witt Jones of Detroit was elected president of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America for the coming two years at the biennial session of the council here this afternoon. The Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo of New York was elected vice president.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve reserve banks showed the reserve note circulation and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.

Four new films, two from Hollywood and two from abroad, form today's schedule. The domestic contributions are Twentieth Century Fox's "Banjo on My Knee," featuring Barbara Stanwyck and Joel McCrea, at the Roxy, and Universal's "Make Way for a Lady," with Anne Shirley, Herbert Marshall and Gertrude Michael, at the Palace.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. CHESTER, at sea, Dec. 10 (AP). -- The cruiser Indianapolis, bearing President Roosevelt homeward from Latin America, slowed tonight to nineteen knots as it neared Trinidad, where the President is to spend four hours ashore tomorrow.

Advertising was called a potent agent in putting the unemployed back to work and restoring the purchasing power of the nation by E.H. McReynolds, director of publicity for the Missouri-Pacific Railroad and president of the Advertising Federation of America, speaking yesterday at a luncheon of the Advertising Club of New York.

Your recent editorial, "Housing Public Employes," raises a vital question concerning the relation between the operations of cooperative housing societies and the general policy of governmental subsidies.

BERLIN, Dec. 10. -- King Edward's abdication broke through the news embargo Chancellor Adolf Hitler imposed on the German press and radio and an astonished and bewildered German people learned of the world-shaking event for the first time tonight when extra editions of the newspapers and the government radio at last were forced to make an announcement.

DUBLIN, Irish Free State, Dec. 10. -- For the first time in the years since he became President of the Council of the Irish Free State, Eamon de Valera today made the significant admission that the Free State was a member of the British Commonwealth of Nations.

The pre-Christmas rise of money in circulation was carried further this week, according to the Federal Reserve reports published yesterday. The amount in circulation on Wednesday, the report showed, was $6,497,000,000, an increase of $31,000,000 in the week and a total rise of $122,000,000 in three weeks.

The petition to close the Stock Exchange on Saturday, Dec. 26, received eighty-one additional signatures yesterday, bringing the total to 333. Final decision in the matter, however, rests with the governing committee of the Exchange, which often has turned down requests signed by a majority of the 800 active members.

All things considered, King Edward's abdication will probably serve the best interests of the monarchy, the empire and Parliament, Hugh Walpole, English novelist, said yesterday a few minutes after the news of the abdication reached New York.

ALBANY, Dec. 10. -- The State Traffic Commission will ask the next Legislature to authorize the Department of Public Works to use highway money for the construction of sidewalks on rural roads, it announced today.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 10. -- According to dates requested by the four major race tracks of Maryland, the Spring season will open April 1 at Bowie and close May 15 at Pimlico. In the Fall the season will begin Sept. 17 and close Nov. 30.
For the first time since 1929, a match for the world's open racquets championship will be held next year in New York and London.

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 11. -- "Both the monarchy and the empire have been sadly shaken, but they can and will be restored." This statement appearing in The Times today seems to epitomize the feeling of London's press, which is inclined to blame King Edward's friends rather than the King himself for the present tragedy, although, as The London Times remarks "there must have been something lacking in Edward himself."

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 10. -- Cars owned privately by three city officials, and used by them both on city business and privately, are serviced by the City Bureau of Motors, according to testimony given by two of the officials today before Warren Dixon Jr., Supreme Court Commissioner, in the investigation of Newark's municipal affairs.

For the second successive session prices on the Cotton Exchange opened yesterday with an advance, improved during the day and closed at the top. All of the 1936 crop deliveries rose above the 12-cent level, while October of the next crop gained $1 a bale.

GENEVA, Dec. 10. -- The special session of the League of Nations Council called by the Spanish Leftist government to examine the danger to peace resulting from Germany's and Italy's "armed intervention," and recognition of General Francisco Franco and the resulting naval situation, opened today with a brief private meeting confined to formalities.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Dec. 10. -- The arrest of William Keck, president of the Progressive Miners of America, in connection with the Federal investigation of railroad bombings in Illinois, was announced today by Paul E. Ruppel, Federal Marshal.

Key men in the Republican State organization will meet tonight at dinner with William F. Bleakley, titular State leader, in an effort to arrive at a harmonious decision on a successor to Melvin C. Eaton as chairman of the State committee.

Down the improvised hill in Madison Square Garden last night shot ski jumpers of international repute, while 12,000 cheered the performers in the first annual Winter Sports Show and International Ski Meet.

Following a new trend of mass recreation for the blind, 43.885 tickets for lectures, concerts and other entertainment were distributed to sightless persons in New York City from Nov. 1, 1935, through Oct. 31, 1936, it was reported yesterday afternoon at the annual meeting of the New York Association for the Blind.

After a four-hour public hearing in City Hall yesterday on Alderman Max Bollt's ordinance giving the Kashruth Association of rabbis exclusive jurisdiction over kosher food, members of the Aldermanic General Welfare Committee could reach no decision on the merits of the measure.
A team of men players was credited with a 4 to 3 victory over a selected group of metropolitan women in a mixed squash racquets team match on the courts of the Junior League Club yesterday.

Columbia's wrestling team will open its season next Thursday, Dec. 17, it was announced yesterday by Graduate Manager Reynolds Benson. The Lion grapplers will compete in eight meets this season, seven of which will be at home.

Miss Helen Conboy, 26 years old, a stenographer, of 3,395 Fort Independence Street, the Bronx, continued her testimony in General Sessions yesterday at the trial of A. Henry Ross, a Brooklyn lawyer, and Max D. Krone, a former private detective, for the alleged extortion of $5,000 in 1933 from Samuel C. Stampleman, president of the Gillette Safety Razor Company.

An 18-year-old girl was burned to death and eleven other persons were painfully burned shortly before 6 A.M. yesterday, when the last of four presumably incendiary fires swept a five-story tenement at 3,108 Third Avenue, near 158th Street, the Bronx.

STOCKHOLM, Dec. 10 (AP). -- King Gustav of Sweden presented today the Nobel Literary and Peace Prizes, won by Eugene O'Neill, American dramatist; Carlos Saavedra Lamas, Argentine Foreign Minister, and Carl von Ossietzky, German pacifist.
LONDON, Dec. 10. -- The blue and white flag of the Duchy of Cornwall fluttered slowly to the foot of its mast at 10 o'clock this morning on the high turret over Fort Belvedere.

Two men declared by the prosecution to be "notorious free-lance ambulance chasers" were convicted under the Ambulance-Chasing Law yesterday by Special Sessions Justices Frederic Kernochan, William R. Bayes and Max Salomon. The men are Maxwell J. Korbin, 47 years old, and Charles McCue, 55, of 803 West 180th Street.

The demand for supervision of industry was viewed as an "irresistible force" while the Supreme Court's opposition to it was termed an "immovable object" last night by General Hugh S. Johnson in a speech to the New York County Lawyers Association at the Hotel Waldorf Astoria.

CHARLES TOWN, W.Va., Dec. 10. -- Backed into odds-on favoritism, Buck Langhorne, 4-year-old gelding racing in the colors of Mrs. K.N. Gilpin, captured the featured Wetzel Purse, a sprint of six and one-half furlongs at the Charles Town track today. He covered the distance over a muddy track in 1:24 4-5.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 10. -- Biography, owned by Norman Hernandez of New Orleans, won the Morgan City Purse, six-furlong dash that topped an excellent program at the Fair Grounds today. It was Ladies' Day and in spite of the in-element weather a large gathering turned out.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- "Constitution Day" anniversaries were celebrated here today by the diplo matic representatives of Siam and the Union of Soviet Socialist Reipublics.

Heralding the Paris International Exposition of 1937, a special window display of pictures and models was opened yesterday morning near the Fifth Avenue entrance to the Empire State Building by Count Charles de Ferry de Fontnouvelle, French Consul General in New York, and Grover A. Whalen, president of the World's Fair Corporation.

LONDON, Nov. 10. -- The effect on the stock market of King Edward's abdication is as yet unknown as Prime Minister Baldwin's statement to the Commons was delivered after the market had closed for the day.
LONDON, Dec. 10. -- Ernest Aldrich Simpson, divorced husband of King Edward's companion, was disclosed tonight to have made a poignant last-minute attempt to stave off abdication of his sovereign.

MOSCOW, Dec. 10. -- The Soviet government's acceptance in principle of the proposal of Britain and France to join in mediation efforts to end the conflict in Spain was expressed in a reply handed to the British and French Ambassadors here yesterday by Maxim Litvinoff, Foreign Commissar, on the eve of his departure for Geneva, where he is expected to take a strong stand in behalf of the Spanish Government.
Anticipating a continuance of last year's tremendous boom in "snow trains," the various railroads in the East have arranged comprehensive schedules for the approaching Winter sports season.

ROME, Dec. 10. -- Luigi Pirandello realized during his illness that his death was approaching and expressed only the regTet that he would be unable to finish his latest manuscript, reported to be an autobiographical work entitled "Memories of My Involuntary Sojourn on Earth."
BERLIN, Dec. 10 (AP). -- Princess Carmo Schoenaich-Carolath, stepdaughter of former Kaiser Wilhelm of Germany, and Hugo Hartung were married today by the clerk of the Borough of Wilmersdorf.

The Henry Hudson Parkway will be opened tomorrow as the newest link in a great express highway and parkway system that city planners hope eventually will extend from the south shore of Brooklyn to the northern boundary of the city in the Bronx.

CANNES, France, Dec. 10. -- With tears streaming down her face, Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson, for whose sake Edward VIII has abdicated as King and Emperor of the greatest empire the world has ever known, listened today as did all the rest of the world to the news over the radio from the scene in the British Parliament.

Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, announced yesterday another move in the campaign for safe operation of automobiles. He said the Motor Vehicle Bureau had installed a new filling system with which to keep more accurate and up-to-the minute records of motorists convicted for traffic violations.

LONDON, Dec. 10. -- The momentous session of Parliament that received today King Edward's message of abdication was best described by Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin himself when he said near the close of his narrative of the crisis:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- The Republican party "must reorganize or liberalize or die," Representative Hamilton Fish of New York, asserted in a letter addressed today to members of the Republican National Committee, in which he urged the displacement of John D.M. Hamilton as chairman.
VAN METER, Iowa, Dec. 10. -Bob Feller, the major league's 18-year-old "problem child" pitcher, lost $100,000 today with a "that's fine by me."

A dinner dance will be given tonight at the Ambassador by the "Gay Thirties" Committee to raise money for the support of the clubhouses of the Boys Club of New York. The club assists in developing the character of its young members by interesting them in sports, games, crafts and other activities.

Miss Idi Papez and Karl Zwack, Austrian figure skaters, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen to begin their professional careers. Ten exhibitions have been arranged for the skaters, who won the European pairs championship in 1933.

A total of 1,022 homeless children were cared for during the last fiscal year by the child placing and adoption committee of the State Charities Aid Association, it was reported yesterday by Mrs. Charles Dana Gibson, chairman, at a meeting of the committee at 105 East Twenty-second Street.
MOSCOW, Dec. 10. -- The first charges of violating the new Constitution were brought at Kazan today in connection with the arrests of eleven persons there by the militia on its own initiative.

A declare on of principles for American industry, calling for an era of good feeling both at home and abroad, pledging cooperation with the government in the national interest and embracing, at least in principle, some of the most important social reforms of the New Deal, was adopted yesterday afternoon at the final session of the forty-first annual convention of the National Association of Manufacturers, held in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

" In the Bag." scheduled to relight the Belmont tomorrow night, will refrain from doing so until next Thursday evening. The postponement was caused, according to the management, by the illness of Dudley Clements, a leading member of the cast.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10. -- George H. Thornley, former vice president of N.W. Ayer Son, Inc., advertising agency, testified today that he had given notice to company officials that he was ready and able to buy 234,000 shares of the corporation's stock involved in a contest for control.

An article in The Reader's Digest describes the organized business of begging by mail that flourishes at this season. "Dear Sir: I am the mother of "seven children * * * husband has been "ill and out of work for two years " * * * baby starving * * * please help "me * * * cash * * * GOD bless you."

Deputy Chief Inspector Patrick McCarthy, regarded by many as the greatest police authority on motor traffic, retired at midnight last night under the Police Department age limit at a pension of $3,150.

Mayor La Guardia moved yesterday to aid 1,565 employes of the New York, Brooklyn and Queens Public Libraries who are without pension systems of any kind and whose futures are not provided for under the recently adopted National Social Security Act.

DETROIT, Dec. 10 (AP). -- The champion Red Wings, their patched-up defense ably supporting the deadly attack of a brilliant first line, defeated the Canadiens of Montreal, 2 to 1, tonight to climb past the Rangers into leadership of the American Division of the National Hockey League.

Retail prices in November were at their highest level since July 1, 1931, according to the Fairchild Index, issued yesterday. Quotations last month gained nine-tenths of 1 per cent compared with those in October and 3.2 per cent in comparison with November, 1935.

Bob Feller, 18-year-old pitching sensation of Van Meter, Iowa, who was discovered last Summer by the Cleveland Indians, remains officially the property of that club and a crisis which threatened to give the old foundation of America's national pastime a sizable rocking has slipped peacefully by without causing so much as the slightest tremor.

Shipments of finished steel products by the United States Steel Corporation last month totaled 882,643 tons, a decrease of 124,774 tons as compared with October's shipments of 1,007,417 tons, and an increase of 200,823 tons, compared with the 681,820 in November, 1935.

PARIS, Dec. 10. -- Today's statement by the Bank of France for the week ended on Dec. 4 shows a loss of 4,000,000,000 francs taken from the gold stock. This amount is explained in a note published by the Ministry of Finance as being used for repayment of the loan of 40,000,000 which was contracted for by the French Treasury in London last February.

LONDON, Dec. 10 (AP). -- Viscount Halifax, Lord Privy Seal, moving the reply to the King's message in the House of Lords, read correspondence that passed between the Cabinet and King Edward vainly seeking to change his "irrevocable" decision.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 10. -James H. R. Cromwell gave a small swimming party and luncheon today at Malmaison for Frank Mur-! phy, Governor-elect of Michigan who, with his brother, George Murphy, is at Brazilian Court.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 10. -- A Christmas pageant, fashion show and ball, entitled "Westchester on Parade" will be held tomorrow night at the County Center here for the benefit of the Episcopalian churches of Westchester County.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission has called on the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee, now investigating the financing of the vast network of railroads and other properties included in the so-called Van Sweringen System, for a completed transcript of the evidence disclosed before the committee.

LONDON, Dec. 10. -- The question naturally arises what effect King Edward's abdication will have on Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin, who is a character only second in importance in the drama played out today. The new King is hardly in the picture yet.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 9:
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Judge Alfred C. Baldwin filed a decision in Superior Court today denying Mrs. Ruth Shann Kilpatrick's divorce petition.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Wholesale prices again rose in the week ended on Dec. 5, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. This is the sixth consecutive weekly advance, and lifts the bureau's index, based on the 1926 average as 100, to 83, compared with 82.6 the preceding week, and 80.9 a year ago.

LONDON, Dec. 10. -- Some time Saturday morning, perhaps even as soon as tomorrow night, Edward VIII will cease to be a King and Emperor. He has made his choice between a woman and a throne and the woman has won.

The national championships of the United States Figure Skating Association will not be held in the East this Winter for the first time since the formation of the organization. At the meeting of the executive committee it was voted to hold the national events for seniors, juniors and novices in the new Chicago Arena under the auspices of the Figure Skating Club of Chicago on Feb. 12-13.

Having completed free courses in Braille transcribing, home hygiene, hospital service or staff assistance service, 161 women and two men yesterday afternoon received certificates from the New York chapter of the American Red Cross in the chapter's headquarters at 315 Lexington Avenue.

MADRID, Dec. 10. -- The atmosphere in Madrid is growing very tense as General Francisco Franco's expected attack presumably draws near. It has been postponed again and again; but everybody knows that sooner or later it must come, and Spaniards are not patient people.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Dec. 10 (AP). -- Daytona Beach had a woman Mayor and a woman City Commissioner tonight -- wives of two officials who resigned today under what they termed a threat of removal by Governor Dave Sholtz.

Following an inspection yesterday of the eighty-six-year-old Raymond Street Jail in Brooklyn, Mayor La Guardia said the building was a disgrace to the city and asked the Correction Department to prepare plans for a new prison to replace it.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10. -- Heavy realing sales in wheat futures caused a sharp reaction on the Board of Trade today following an early advance which lifted prices in the world's leading markets to new high levels for the season. Closing trades were 3/8 cent higher to l/4 cent a bushel lower, the former on December, which was inclined to act tight throughout the day.

The election of John J. Daly of Belleville, N.J., to the captaincy of Manhattan College's 1937 varsity football team was announced yesterday by Brother Anselm, director of athletics. He succeeds Harry Wheeler of Queens Village. L.I., and James F. Whalen of Cambridge, Mass., co-captains of this season's Green eleven.

As a result of the Supreme Court decision validating the California and Illinois "fair trade" acts permitting agreements to maintain retail prices on branded merchandise, efforts to enact such legislation in the thirty-three States now without such laws "will probably be successful in 1937,"

LONDON, Dec. 10. -- As the news of King Edward's abdication sped to the far corners of the empire this afternoon Britain received confirmation of her worst fear with mixed emotions, sadness at losing so popular and beloved a sovereign and relief that the gnawing suspense of the last week at last had drawn to an end.

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, Works Progress Administrator, announced last night that he was reconsidering his dismissal of eleven WPA employes of the Mayor's Committee on City Planning, who had been discharged for participating in the "sit-down" strike Monday night at 330 Broadway.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10. -- Most hogs were sold here today at steady prices, compared with yesterday's average. The demand generally was not brisk. The top was down 5 cents a hundredweight from yesterday's mark, at $10.05, with the day's average unchanged at $9.80.
Contributions of $422,201.55 received by the Women's Campaign Committee of the United Hospital Fund were announced last night by Mrs. William Woodward, chairman of the committee.

A head-on collision between two automobiles last night on the Harlem River Drive at 166th Street caused injuries to ten persons, four of whom are in a serious condition. One of the cars, a taxicab, took fire after the accident.

The New York stock market was thrown into a feverish activity on the receipt of the news of King Edward's abdication shortly before 11 A.M. yesterday. Active buying ensued and prices mounted rapidly. From 11 o'clock until 11:17 the stock ticker ran two to three minutes late in reporting transactions.

THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review contains a review of Messrs. Abend and Billingham's new book, "Can China Survive?" by George E. Sokolsky. In their book the two writers say: "It is curious that today China seems to expect every other nation to do its duty, while making no concrete plans to do anything for itself until after Japan becomes embroiled with some other power."
Sales of housing properties in the Bronx yesterday included a deal for two walk-up houses containing 184 rooms and four stores at 1,025 and 1,029 Boston Post Road.

John Barbirolli, 37-year-old British conductor, has been engaged to lead the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra for the next three seasons, it was announced yesterday by the board of directors. Mr. Barbirolli, besides becoming the first full-time permanent conductor that the Philharmonic has had in sixteen years, will be the music director.

PARIS, Dec. 10 (AP). -- The repayment by the Bank of France of 4,000,000,000 francs of the 40,000,000 credit obtained by the government in London last February cuts the bank's gold reserves to approximately 60,000,000,000 francs (about $2,967,000,000 at the arbitrary rate of 4.96 cents to the franc adopted by the bank in valuing its gold holdings).
The flow of investment money into real estate mortgage loans was indicated yesterday by announcements of new financing of properties in the metropolitan area.
Collier's 1936 All-America football team was announced yesterday through The Associated Press, as follows:

TOKYO, Dec. 10. -- Withdrawal of all the Japanese demands regarding North China autonomy and of that for cooperation against communism was implied in a statement issued to the press today by Eiji Amau, Foreign Office spokesman.
LONDON, Dec. 10. -- The text of Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin's message to the House of Commons today follows:

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 10. -- A counter-seasonal increase in the operating rate of the steel industry and a substantial gain in trade boosted the index of business in the Pittsburgh district to a new high level last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

LONDON, Dec. 10. -- Following is the text of the abdication letter of King Edward VIII as read to the House of Commons by the Speaker, Captain Edward Algernon Fitzroy, after Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin had announced he had "a message from His Majesty the King, signed by his own hand":
Apartment houses and dwellings were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

Undismayed by their failure for six years to recapture the Class A ice boat title of the Shrewsbury and Navesink Rivers, which has come to be called the North American championship, the Winter sailors of the Long Branch Ice Boat and Yacht Club have challenged again for it.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.J., Dec. 10. -- Cutting off food and light and other restrictions imposed by Mayor Thomas Crawford reduced to ten tonight the number of WPA seamstresses who have been engaged in a "sit-down" strike in the council chamber of the municipal building here since their project was ended Dec. 1 for lack of appropriations.
The new Queen Elizabeth, who celebrated her thirty-sixth birthday on Aug. 4, was a commoner until 1923, when she was created a royal Princess following her betrothal to the Duke of York.

The Marine Midland Trust Company delivered yesterday to the Kreutoll Realization Company, Ltd., the securities bought by the latter at the recent auction of collateral for the 5 per cent secured debentures of the Kreuger Toll Company, for which Marine Midland was trustee.
VATICAN CITY, Dec. 10. -- Pope Pius XI left his bed today for the first time in his six-day illness, but attendants almost carried him and he remained up only a short time.
INTERLAKEN, N.Y., Dec. 10 (AP). -- Judge Leon S. Church of Seneca County today recommended a jail sentence for every person convicted of driving an automobile while intoxicated.

Three of the four men on trial in the Kings County Court for the murder of Isaac Shain in a barrom hold-up last month admitted on the witness stand yesterday that they had been at the scene of the crime.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Plans for a great industrial mobilization machine, directed by the President and a War Resources Administration, will be laid before the new Congress by the War Department. Although the plan will be presented by the War Department, it was worked out in cooperation with the Navy Department.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Welcomed by Secretary Ickes and assured by Anning S. Prall, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, of his interest and that of the commission in the success of their endeavors, 500 delegates of eighteen organizations opened here today a three-day session on educational broadcasting.

A banking syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers won the award yesterday of a new issue of $3,000,000 of general refunding bonds of the city of Camden, N.J., on a bid of 95.003 for the securities as 3 1/4s and 3 1/2s. The interest cost basis afforded to the city on the sale was 3.640 per cent.

Seven major sessions, each stressing an outstanding phase of the general objective, "Solving 1937 Problems of Retailing in the Public Interest," are planned for the annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association from Jan. 18 to 22 at the Hotel Pennsylvania, Channing E. Sweitzer, managing director, announced yesterday.

Under police protection, a copy of the first edition of Adolf Hitler's "Mein Kampf" was sold at auction for $250 yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc. This was said to be the first copy of the two-volume first edition of the book to be offered at auction either in this country or in Europe.

Max Schmeling arrived in New York yesterday for a short visit, during which he hopes to gain definite assurance that he will be the first fighter to meet James J. Braddock for the heavyweight championship of the world.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- The Maritime Commission notified the Lykes Brothers Ripley Steamship Company, Inc., of New Orleans today that it was prepared to make delivery of the remaining nine ships of the fifty-two which were sold to the company by the government under an agreement dated Feb. 17, 1933.

Abdicating after a reign of less than a year, King Edward VIII gave up not only his throne but his ambition to go down in history as a "poor man's King," for the sake of his love for the American-born Mrs. Wallis Simpson.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES today F. Lavis erroneously describes the Regional Plan Association as citing the type of highways being built in Germany and designed to make driving safe at a speed of 112 miles an hour as a model for road-building in this country, though in the recently published statement to which he refers we took pains to avoid giving that impression.

A delegation of six French advertising leaders will arrive here on Jan. 6 to invite American advertising people to the Advertising Congress under the auspices of the Continental Advertising Association, in conjunction with the International Exposition in Paris in July, it was made known yesterday at the meeting of the board of directors of the Advertising Federation of America at the Advertising Club of New York.

Rise in the price of wheat has quite invariably been an important incident of recovery from world depression, and the fact that wheat at Chicago has this week touched practically the highest price since 1929 proved that, in this respect, the present world recovery has been running true to form.

LONDON, Dec. 10. -- One of the first statements to come from the Duke of York when he becomes King probably will be an announcement that he will be crowned May 12, the date on which the coronation of his brother was to have taken place.

A bright outlook for the railroads was outlined in views presented at a dinner held to celebrate the sixty-fourth anniversary of the New York Railroad Club in the Hotel Commodore last night. Representatives of railroad management and labor, of equipment manufacturers and of savings bankers were included in the symposium.

The Thomas Jefferson High School basketball team won its second game in Division 1 of the Brooklyn P.S.A.L. yesterday by defeating Brooklyn Tech, 35 to 23, on the Central M.E. Church court. Jefferson came from behind after trailing 13 -- 10 at the half.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- That man in public life, whether or not a citizen of the empire, who could look instantly to the consequences of the great drama of the British palace without pausing for melancholy thought of the human tragedies involved, would write himself down unfeeling or an official automaton.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 10. -- In Earl Peel's opinion the Jewish Agency should have pressed its claim for State domains to which it is entitled according to the mandate.

The annual "Who's Who" issue of The American Hebrew, published today, lists 299 Jews and six non-Jews for citation because of notable achievements during the year. Some won distinction in their professions, others by their contributions to government, industry, literature, international relief and other phases of welfare.

OTTAWA, Canada, Dee. 10. -- An hour after the abdication of King Edward VIII was announced today in the British Commons, the Canadian Government passed an order-in-council approving the change in succession and requesting the British Parliament to give effect to Canada's wishes by applying to this country the new legislation that it will enact tomorrow to that end.

Gains again were the rule on local commodity futures markets yesterday, with trading generally active. On the cash markets, cotton, lard, corn, rye, flour, rubber and tin advanced, while wheat, oats, silk and raw sugar declined.

BERLIN, Dec. 10. -- The German Government, having been approached on a mediation effort by Great Britain and France seeking to forbid the enrollment of volunteers for service in the Spanish conflict, replied today with a suggestion that the non-intervention agreement be widened still further.

ALBANY, Dec. 10. -- The Public Service Commission announced today its approval of the merger of the New York Central Electric Corporation into the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation under certain specified conditions and its consent to reclassification of the capital stock of the New York Central Company.
Death ended the suffering and distress of one of New York's Neediest Cases yesterday before the help he so much needed could be given to him.

Concentration of its efforts upon the problem of relieving congestion on east and west streets in Manhattan as the first and most vital step in a general traffic relief program will be urged upon Mayor La Guardia's traffic conference when it meets next week, it was indicated yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 10. -- After a quiet night and early morning in which no vehicles left or arrived at Fort Belvedere, King Edward's country estate, except speeding dispatch riders, the King's three brothers came in dramatic succession for a final conference.

LONDON, Dec. 10. -- The texts of the statements in the House of Commons today on the King's abdication by Mr. Attlee, leader of the Labor Opposition; Sir Archibald Sinclair, leader of the Liberal Parliamentary party, and Mr. Churchill, who attempted to form a King's party, follow:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP). -- While the State Department refrained tonight from any comment on King Edward's abdication, the view that it was no concern of this country was expressed widely in other government quarters.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 10 (AP). -- Judge Mell G. Underwood in Federal Court today sentenced Reese Bailey, 30-year-old desperado caught by government agents, to twenty years in prison.

By defeating the Princeton Club team, 4 to 1, last night the Harvard Club advanced into a tie for the Class A lead in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association, but the move was not so easily accomplished as the score would indicate.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 10. -- A taxpayer's injunction threatened today to upset an elaborate scheme whereby members of the House of Representatives hoped to collect $21,507 in mileage to and from the capital during a 140-day recess when they actually never made any trips.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Dec. 9, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,478,000,000, an increase of $13,000,000, compared with the preceding week and a decrease of $2,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

Tony Desmarais of the New York Rovers is leading the Eastern Amateur Hockey League in scoring with a total of 10 points, according to figures released by officials yesterday. The fast-skating New York recruit has tallied five goals and has made five assists.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 10. -- Jean Hersholt's contract with Metro has been purchased by Twentieth Century-Fox, thus ending a rivalry for the actor's services between the two lots dating from Hersholt's success in "The Country Doctor." As soon as negotiations were completed, Fox announced the player for the role of Father Chevillon in "Seventh Heaven," replacing Brian Donlevy, who will assume the romantic lead in "Midnight Taxi."

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 10. -- The deadlock which had been holding up the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace for a week was solved today by an agreement among the leaders and the conference finally got under way.
INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 10. -- The validity of the government's "windfall" tax on processors was upheld today in a decision by Judge Robert C. Baltzell in the Federal court.

LONDON, Dec. 10. -- Cheering crowds greeted Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin today as he arrived at the House of Commons to deliver what was expected to be a final explanation of the controversy between King and Cabinet over Mrs. Wallis Simpson.

The list of the Hamburg-American liner Hamburg due today from the Channel ports, includes Randolph T. Ode, Miss Doreen E. Tanner, Mr. and Mrs. William Vievering, Franz Frisch. F.A. Howard, Mrs. Tessy Meyer, Mrs. Elsa Berger, Walker D. Braly and Gustav Fuld.

Frederick Barry Ryan Jr. of Short Hills and Frank A. Sieverman 3d of the New York A.C. gained the final round in the Fall scratch tournament of the National Squash Tennis Association at the City Athletic Club yesterday and will meet tomorrow afternoon for the laurels left undefended by Harry F. Wolf, the Winged Foot club's national champion, who won the tournament the last two years.

To the extent that Britain's royal controversy contributed to the recent unsettlement in the New York stock market, that uncertainty is now removed. News of the abdication of King Edward VIII came toward the close of the first hour of trading here and the market turned active and strong forthwith, helped to some extent by foreign buying, inasmuch as the European markets had closed by that time.

ALBANY, Dec. 10. -- An increase of 0.1 per cent in employment and 0.2 per cent in payrolls in factories in the State from October to November was reported today by Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, who said that in fourteen of the last twenty-two years October had marked the Fall peak in volume of employment.

Members of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York, meeting at 40 Worth Street yesterday, adopted and recommended for the use of the industry a clause for contracts on future cloth deliveries which calls for the adjustment of prices in the event of legislation affecting sellers' costs.

A double tragedy, apparently a murder and suicide, was discovered about 5:30 o'clock last night when the police broke into a third-floor apartment at 149 East Thirty-seventh Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues.

" Don't talk to me about fiction," said a French Prime Minister. "I have "too often seen truth much more incredible"." Something of that feeling has been in the mind of the whole world during the past week. Events seemed to be piling one unbelievable thing upon another.

Three men, posing as messengers for a florist service, entered the home of Mrs. Vera F. Brand at 133 East Seventy-fourth Street at 8 A.M. yesterday, bound Mrs. Brand and two maids and got away with $125 in cash and a vanity case worth $20.
LONDON, Dec. 10. -- Thousands of Londoners shouted a welcome tonight to a shy and awkward young man who was ready to step into the dazzling light of the greatest throne on earth.
MADRID, Dec. 10. -- Insurgents struck again at Madrid today from the west, but the government declared tonight the attackers had been driven off in a bitter three-hour struggle.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 10. -- Scoring three times in the final five minutes of a wild third period, the Princeton hockey team defeated the St. Nicks, 3 -- 1, before 200 persons in Baker rink tonight.

It rained yesterday morning and was clear in the afternoon, but the Green Bay Packers apparently prefer to do things the hard way. So they practiced for Sunday's National League championship playoff at the Polo Grounds in the morning amid unceasing showers and in gumbo-like mud at Central Park.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Deposits of $45,188,000,000 in 14,085 of the 14,092 commercial banks affiliated with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation were 43 per cent insured as of May 13 last, Leo T. Crowley, chairman, announced today.
LONDON, Dec. 10. -- The text of the abdication bill which was filed in the House of Commons tonight follows:

OTTAWA, Dec. 10 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits by the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada showed an increase of $5,423,231 in the week ended on Dec. 9, compared with the previous week, according to the weekly statement of the bank issued today.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Nine players advanced past the first round of the Fall Class B and C squash tennis championships at the Columbia University Club yesterday, four by victories and five by defaults. None of the seeded players was included in the first round. They will get their first chance in the tourney tomorrow.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 10. -- Although the Eastern seaboard was blanketed with "ceiling zero" today, from Maine to Florida and westward to Kansas, "the show went on" for the ninth annual Miami All-American Air Manoeuvres.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10. -Willie Hoppe of New York dealt a severe blow to Johnny Layton's chances of winning the world three-cushion billiard championship by defeating the Sedalia (Mo.) expert, 50 to 33, in forty-seven innings tonight. It was Layton's third defeat against five victories.
LONDON, Dec. 10. -- Edward VIII is still King and will remain so until he gives his assent to a bill giving effect to his declaration of abdication.

A small exhibition of sculpture and drawings by Herbert Haseltine opened yesterday at the Carroll Carstairs Gallery, 11 East Fifty-seventh Street, to remain until Dec. 19. In subject matter it relates for the most part to the Rodeo. While the Rodeo was at the Madison Square Garden Mr. Haseltine had his modeling stand set up beside the arena and spent much time there sketching his impressions both with pencil and in clay and plaster.

The movement toward currency stability was furthered yesterday when it became known here that the Argentine official exchange control had reduced the spread between its buying and selling rates for sterling, and the quotation for the free inland peso advanced 1.15 cents to 30.15 cents, a new high for the year.

J.S. Bache Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that it would pay on Dec. 19 a bonus of two weeks' salary and that as soon as practicable after Jan. 1 would distribute to employes a sum equivalent to 15 per cent of the firm's net profits for 1936.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 10 (AP). -- Chester C. Davis, a governor of the Federal Reserve System, gave warning today that if bulging reservoirs of money and credit flow into speculative investment channels "we are in for trouble."

CANBERRA, Australia, Friday, Dec. 11. -- Australia received the long-awaited news of King Edward's abdication at 1:45 this morning, at which hour, it had been previously announced over the radio, Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons would broadcast a statement over a nation-wide hook-up.

The fifth annual fashion show and ball for the benefit of the Goddard Neighborhood Center will be held tonight at the Waldorf-Astoria. A feature of the program will be an historical pageant. "Brides of Two Centuries." in which members of the junior committee will act as manikins.

Lady Astor, American-born member of the British Parliament, last night declared that it was the "previous history" of Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson and the necessity of keeping the empire united that caused the opposition of the government to her marriage to King Edward.
VATICAN CITY, Dec. 10. -- Pope Pius left his bed today after an illness that caused fears to be expressed for his life since being taken ill Friday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- The Resettlement Administration is prepared to ask Congress for an appropriation of "at least $100,000,000" to enable it to carry on its relief and rehabilitation activities after Feb. 1, it was indicated today by officials of the agency after W. W. Alexander, acting RA head, disclosed that uncommitted funds for all purposes would be exhausted by that date.

Plans for the construction and rebuilding of passenger, freight and motor-power equipment of the Southern Pacific Company at a cost of more than $16,000,000 were announced yesterday by A.D. McDonald, president. It was said that this would bring the company's total appropriations for new and modernized cars and locomotives in the last twelve months to more than $41,000,000.

Continued strength in South American dollar obligations and a cautious attitude in the market for United States Government loans, pending official announcement of allotments on the new Treasury 2 1/2s, characterized bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

Railroads yesterday launched their advertising drive for "snow trains" with large copy breaking in newspapers here and in other metropolitan areas. The coming season, which opens around Jan. 1, is expected to be a boom one for this type of railroad service and advertising budgets have been expanded considerably over a year ago, when the vogue for skiing received its first real impetus.

Britain's troubles evicted at least one news item from an otherwise assured place on the front page. It was the story announcing the appointment of JOHN BARBIROLLI as sole and permanent conductor of the Philharmonic Orchestra, the initial term being three years.

An intimate word picture of Britain's new King and Queen -- of whom he said, "No couple ever was more popular in England, even before this happened" -- was painted yesterday by the artist who has done both their portraits in oil.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. ll. -- A code of prices and fair trade practices was adopted today by 600 retail gasoline dealers from all parts of New Jersey, who met from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. in the auditorium of the Lawyers Building at 880 Bergen Avenue, here.

LONDON, Dec. ll. -- The boys and girls of Britain were told tonight that the Empire's objection to Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson as the wife of Edward VIII was "simply that she had two husbands living."

David Rosenthal, 25 years old, son of the proprietor of a clothing store at 128 Park Row, turned the tables on two thieves yesterday morning by chasing them out of the store and bringing down one suspect with a well-aimed shot.
LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 12. -- Later editions of the London newspapers this morning show marked sympathy for former King Edward following his farewell broadcast last night.

Frequent mention has recently appeared in the American press of the German Academy in New York, an offspring of the American League for German Cultural Freedom; it has also been stated that I have joined this fully organized body. May I state briefly the reasons for the sympathy with which I have welcomed this idea and which have moved me to collaborate in its realization?
NANKING, Dec. 11. -- "A lasting readjustment of Chino-Japanese relations is out of the question until the policies of the Japanese Foreign Office and the Japanese Army are coordinated."

That the metropolis is rapidly becoming Winter-sports minded was vividly demonstrated last night in Madison Square Garden at the first annual International Ski Meet and Winter Sports Show. Despite the downpour, a capacity throng of 12,000 -- the third full house in three nights -- packed the arena to witness another thrilling program.

The recent ruling of the Supreme Court upholding the Illinois and California "fair trade" laws involves five major phases of importance to stores, according to an analysis issued yesterday by Irving C. Fox, counsel for the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

ALBANY, Dec. 11. -- The Harbor State Bank of New York has been authorized by the State Banking Department to increase its capital stock from $450,000 to $600,000, the department's bulletin today announced. The bank also has been permitted to change its branch office from 52 William Street to 45 Fourth Avenue and its principal office to 52 William Street.

SAN MATEO, Calif., Dec. ll. -- Faithful Maud, a 5-1 shot, stepped a fast six furlongs in 1:11 flat down the chute at Bay Meadows today to capture the feature race from the favored Red Wagon. The Pelican finished third.

The Harvard Club held its lead in the Class C standings of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League by scoring a 5-0 sweep over the visiting Columbia University players last night, while the New York A.C. and City A.C. teams maintained their runner-up tie by victories over Elizabeth and Crescent, respectively.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. ll. -- The British Empire has emerged from the "constitutional crisis" over former King Edward's love affair "stronger than before," according to James G. McDonald, of the editorial staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES, who addressed 300 women here tonight on the "European Scene."

A portrait of the late Marcella Sembrich, for twenty-five years a leading member of the Metropolitan Opera company, and a bust of Giulio Gatti-Casazza, who retired two years ago as general manager of the Metropolitan after a reign of twenty-seven years, were unveiled yesterday afternoon in the lounge of the Metropolitan Opera House.

Members of the general welfare committee of the Board of Aldermen clashed yesterday with spokesmen for the larger auctioneers in the city after the speakers had opposed a proposed ordinance regulating the conditions under which auction sales are conducted.

Broadway is entering next week upon a customarily slack interlude -- the pre-Christmas holiday period -- so it is not remarkable that the night clubs intend just to coast along through it. No events of any spectacular importance are listed, with the exception of a celebration tomorrow evening at the Cotton Club commemorating Bill Robinson's anniversary of fifty years on the stage.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 11. -- A Rochester woman held in jail at Bath for five months on forgery charges was freed today by chagrined investigators who admitted that she was arrested by mistake.

Following the active covering of December obligations at the highest quotations of the season in the early trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, prices developed a reactionary tendency and ended with losses of 8 to 15 points. Partly in sympathy with outside markets and in part to an increase in the supply of contracts from both commission house quarters and producing' sections, an easier tone prevailed in most of the session.

A suit to recover $855,703 from the National City Bank and the former National City Company for investment losses alleged to have been caused by the company's misrepresentations was begun yesterday in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn.
Building projects filed for yesterday included plans for a Manhattan apartment house to cost $850,000 and a $750,000 school building in Brooklyn.

The plea for an annulment of marriage by Mrs. Marjorie Jean Contento Ryan, who declared that she was under the influence of liquor when she wed Jerome Anthony Ryan, was refused yesterday by Justice Burt Jay Humphrey in Supreme Court in Jamaica, Queens.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 11. -- The Southern Conference, after hearing the resignation of the University of Virginia, abolished by unanimous vote the Graham plan tonight and substituted another more liberal system for the elimination of athletic subsidies.

Setting a fast pace in the second half the Springfield College basketball team turned back Pratt Institute last night, 50 to 30, on the latter's floor. The game was close for the first half, with the invaders leading, 21 to 18.

The Federal Maritime Commission yesterday notified nine American flag ship lines holding mail contracts on ten routes whose schedules have been disrupted by the strike of Atlantic and Gulf seamen that they must immediately revise their ocean mail sailings subject to the commission's approval.
Carlisle Rountree, New York cotton broker, and his brother, Louis Underwood Rountree, of Houston, Texas, were convicted last night by a Federal court jury on a thirteen-count mail fraud indictment.

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 11. -- The first of the series of Winter dances to be given by the officers in Newport took place at the Naval Training Station Auditorium tonight. It served as a farewell party for Rear Admiral and Mrs. Kalbfus, who are about to leave for the West Coast.

Preferring to perfect the team's running attack rather than give the squad another taste of action amid rain and mud, Coach Curley Lambeau sent the Green Bay Packers through an indoor drill in the All Hallows Institute gymnasium yesterday in preparation for tomorrow's National Football League championship play-off at the Polo Grounds.

CHESTER, Pa., Dec. 11. -- Workmen seeking to enter the plant of the Sun Shipbuilding and Drydock Company clashed with strikers today in two brief but furious engagements. Four men were hurt critically and more than 100 received less serious injuries.
