CHICAGO, Dec. 11. -- A sharp falling off in hog receipts here and in the West, local arrivals being the smallest since Oct. 30, brought all classes of buyers into the market today and prices advanced 15 to 25 cents, with most sales equal to the highest level of the Winter.

There was a large attendance at the fifth annual Miami Biltmore fashion show and ball last night at the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Goddard Neighborhood Center. During the evening a historical pageant, "Brides of Two Centuries," was presented with members of the Junior committee and debutantes acting as manikins.

Overriding an opinion of Corporation Counsel Paul Windels, the Board of Estimate voted a pension of about $2,000 a year yesterday to Julian Wood, a former Deputy Tax Commissioner dismissed for holding a full-time private job at the same time that he drew full pay from the city.
Several sales by banks and deals by operators were among the Manhattan realty transactions reported yesterday.

Public-utility borrowing again led the new bond financing this week, accounting for $30,250,000 of the $92,309,500 of issues placed on the market. Last week's total was $203,061,000. A year ago this week $205,536,000 of bonds was marketed.
Harlem's community Christmas celebration, long dominated by a pallid Santa Claus imported from down-town, will have a Negro Kris Kringle for the first time this year.

MANHASSET, L.I., Dec. 11. -- Leading court tennis players of the country, headed by Ogden Phipps, the national champion, will gather here tomorrow for the annual Payne Whitney Memorial doubles tournament.

GENEVA, Dec. 11. -- The Council of the League of Nations, after hearing Julio Alvarez del Vayo, Foreign Minister of the Spanish Government, accept international supervision of non-intervention in the civil war and ask nothing concrete from the League, is strongly headed after its first day's discussion of the Spanish war danger toward a resolution confined to virtually blessing the Anglo-French peace move.

MADRID, Dec. 11. -- All remains quiet on the Madrid front. There was some shelling of houses in the center of the city about 4 o'clock this afternoon. Two shells struck a building a few blocks from the Telephone Building.
The Textile High School quintet turned back New Utrecht High, 22 -- 19, in a contest on the losers court yesterday. Textile held a 12-9 margin at the half.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The Committee for Industrial Organization today requested Governor Earle of Pennsylvania to protect the right of picketing at Chester. Its telegram, signed by John Brophy, director, was as follows:

As Prince Edward, former King of Great Britain spoke his farewell message into a microphone at Windsor Castle last night, a short-wave radio hook-up carried his message throughout the empire, the United States and other countries in a broadcast that was globe-encircling.

As an expression of its intention further to cooperate with the Federal administration in carrying out provisions of the Public Utility Act and also to facilitate the refunding of more than $100,000,000 of indebtedness, the Northern States Power Company of Minnesota and the Minneapolis General Electric Company, through action of the respective boards of directors, have elected to register under the act, it was announced yesterday by Robert F. Pack, president of Northern States Power.

WASHINGTON, Dec. ll. -- An application by the Nevada California Electric Corporation, which had registered as a holding company, for an order declaring it no longer to be a holding company under the provisions of the Public Utility Act of 1935 has been granted by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

James A. Farley, Postmaster General, returned yesterday to his desk at Democratic national headquar ters in the Biltmore Hotel and started at once to sign letters of congratulation to every Democratic candidate for Congressional, State, legislative, judicial and county offices successful at the recent election.

ZIS for Zoning, which stands pretty well down toward the bottom of the list of subjects which lend themselves readily to popular treatment. In his latest book, "Zoning: The Laws, Administration and Court Decisions During the First Twenty Years" (Russell Sage Foundation, $3), Edward M. Bassett, although godfather of a movement which has swept this country, makes no attempt to write a best-seller.

DUBLIN, Irish Free State, Dec. 11. -- President Eamon de Valera sprang one of the biggest political surprises of his career on the Dail Eireann and the country today when he introduced two bills calling for fundamental changes in the King's relations to the Free State.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Authority from the Interstate Commerce Commission to issue $10,000,000 of 4 per cent refunding mortgage bonds was sought today by the Long Island Railroad. The Pennsylvania Railroad asked authority to assume liability for the issue.

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 11. -- President Lazardo Cardenas, despite numerous petitions protesting his decision of last Sunday that Leon Trotsky be admitted to asylum in Mexico, has reiterated his resolution that Mexico, as a free country, would give hospitality to the man described here as "a wandering Jew" if and when he requested it.
LONDON, Dec. 11 -- Following is the text of a message to the British people from the Queen Mother:
In THE NEW YORK TIMES for Nov. 23 and Dec. 6 there appeared statements by California health officials on the alleged danger of overdosing of children with vitamin D.

The Cunard White Star liner Scythia will sail today for Galway, Cobh and Liverpool, carrying a group of 380 excursionists bound for Ireland for the holidays. Among the passengers are Mr. and Mrs. George Ferrier, D.B. Kendall-Cook, Mrs. G.P. Armstrong, Walter Biggar, Mr. and Mrs. A.J. Field, Mrs. W.E. Newberry, Miss Mary O'Donoghue, S.W. Gomm, Major and Mrs. B. Day, F.C. Godfrey, William Montgomery and Major H.E.F. Shackleton.

After trailing through most of the first half, the St. John's University quintet came back with a rally in the second period to turn back Seton Hall, 26 to 20, for its fourth straight triumph of the season before a large crowd in the DeGray Gymnasium last night.

An appeal was made yesterday by Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott to the heads of large department stores throughout Manhattan to enlist their stores in a "no smoking" campaign to minimize "in so far as humanly possible the ever-present danger of fire and panic."

Yesterday's trading in securities continued to reflect a relatively large volume of speculative demand. This was shown by the heavy trading in low-priced shares. The ten most active issues were all in a price range below $28 a share and did not include one of the so called "market leaders."

Corporations whose earnings and surpluses have warranted their declaring extra dividends and giving bonuses were urged yesterday by Stuart M. Crocker, general chairman of the United Hospital Campaign, to contribute to the drive in the interest of the welfare of their employes and the "maintenance of a sound and healthy community."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 11. -- Having embarked upon a policy of immortalizing the unsung heroes of American history, Cecil B. De Mille has set "The Buccaneer" as his next picture, preceding the scheduled "Samson and Delilah." The story bears no relation to the Maxwell Anderson play of the same name based on the exploits of Sir Henry Morgan, a property which Paramount owns, but will deal with the life of Jean Lafitte.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11. -- The Philadelphia Record announced tonight its resignation from the American Newspaper Publishers Association in protest against what it called "the unfair attitude of that organization toward the American Newspaper Guild." The association's directors, in a resolution adopted recently, urged its members not to bargain with representatives of the guild.

Lady Lister Kaye of London entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for Mrs. Hamilton McK. Twombly, Countess Gregorini. Mrs. Joseph Kuznick, Mrs. J. Sergeant Cram, Mrs Mary Roberts Rhinehart, Mrs. Whitney Warren, Mrs. Joseph E. Willard and Miss Angelica L. Gerry.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday for the first ten months of 1936 a net income of $5,796,737 after all deductions. This was equal to $5.54 a share on 1.045,279 shares of capital stock. It is compared to $4,131,399, or $3.95 a share, for the same period of 1935.

An axis deer one of a handsome and extremely shy breed of which the Bronx Zoo has twenty-three, was found dead on a range in the park yesterday morning by two keepers, who soon afterward discovered that another of the herd was trotting about with a length of rope about its neck.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman has accepted membership on the Sponsors Committee for the American Christian Conference on Palestine to be held in the Hotel Astor Tuesday from 1:30 to 5 P. M. This gathering, which will begin with a luncheon, is under the auspices of the Pro-Palestine Federation of America, the headquarters of which are at 307 Fifth Avenue.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11. -- A continuation of the profit-taking movement in wheat that developed yesterday was largely responsible today for a further decline in prices. Closing prices on the Board of Trade, while somewhat above the inside figures, showed net losses of 1/4 to 1 cent a bushel, the latter on the December, which was affected to some extent by the delivery of 15,000 bushels of cash grain on contracts, the first this month.

Commissioner MOSES is modest about his part in the reclamation of the Hudson and Harlem River waterfronts, a new phase of which is signalized today by the opening of the Henry Hudson Bridge and Parkway. There is nothing new in New York, he insists, in the field of physical public improvements; he has simply fallen heir to plans devised long ago, but only now matured.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 11. -- Mr. and Mrs. Guernsey Curran Jr. gave a dinner tonight at their home, later taking their guests to Club Madrid for dancing

ST. JOHN N.B., Dec. 11. -- The heroic action of Hans Hansen, a seaman, who plunged into the ice-strewn waters of the Bay of Fundy and carried a life-line to shore, brought safety today to thirty-six shipmates of the stranded Norwegian vessel Kings County.

Many pastors will discuss in their sermons tomorrow the abdication of Edward VIII and the accession of the Duke of York as King of Great Britain. In the sermons of Protestant ministers there will be echoes of the Madison Square Garden meeting last Monday evening, at which there were 18,000 present, closing the National Preaching Mission and ways suggested of perpetuating its influence will be set forth.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP). -- A survey by four government farm agencies recommended today a reduction in harvested crop lands of 15,000,000 to 50,000,000 acres below the 1928-32 average.

A group of some twenty-five outstanding leaders in the Republican State organization met last night at the National Republican Club in East Fortieth Street to discuss candidates for chairman of the Republican State Committee to succeed Melvin C. Eaton of Chenango, whose resignation has been pending since election.

VATICAN CITY, Dec. 11 (AP). -- Pope Pius displayed new strength today in his fight against partial leg paralysis, but his physician prescribed stimulants to correct the irregularity of his heart action.

Louis Beitcher, 46 years old, who collected the "dues" from owners in the operation of the $2,000,000 restaurant shake-down racket which Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer organized in 1932, was arrested yesterday and held in bail of $150,000.

Paintings by fifteen American artists, chiefly water-colors, together with twoscore pieces of ceramics by Carl Walters, were placed on view yesterday as a special Christmas exhibition at the Downtown Gallery.

CANNES, France, Dec. 11. -- Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson and her hostess, Mrs. Herman L. Rogers, seeking distraction, motored this afternoon to Grasse to visit the big establishments of the French perfume industry there.

Any WPA worker who has been dismissed as "unessential non-relief personnel" may be reinstated immediately if certified as needy by the Emergency Relief Bureau, it was announced yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local WPA Administrator.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 11. -- Flying a high-wing monoplane over the 25-mile distance, Dewane L. Wallace of Wichita took first place, $350 in cash and the $2,000 Argentine Trophy in the feature event of the second day of the Miami All-American air manoeuvres here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. ll. -- A further drop of 93,770 employes between Nov. 28 and Dec. 5 brought the total of Works Progress Administration projects workers released from relief rolls from Nov. 7 to Dec. 5 to 198,350, according to a new survey made public tonight by Harry L. Hopkins, administrator.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 11 (AP). -- Three lengths off the pace at the halfway stage. J.Y. Christmas's 4-year-old chestnut filly Rough Party roared down the stretch today to win the fifth race, a six-furlong and forty-yard sprint. The victor was a 1-2 favorite.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 11. -- Sixty delegates from eight up-State New York colleges and universities convened at Syracuse University today in the Fall session of the Central New York Model Council of the "League of Nations" to weigh problems of international conflict based upon the war clouds hovering over Europe and the Orient.

CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 11. -- A resolution approving the United Kingdom legislation ratifying the abdication and excluding Edward's issue from succession and transferring the throne to the Duke of York passed both houses today.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 11 (AP). -- Half-back Jack Lyon's long punt return in the third quarter gave the University of South Carolina a 6-3 victory over the Miami Hurricanes before a crowd of 7,500 tonight.

Burleigh Grimes, who is to be responsible for the Dodger destinies in 1937, was the last major league manager to leave town and, appropriately, had the last word before heading for his farm at New Haven, Mo., late yesterday afternoon.

Mary Felts, a young pianist from Kansas City, made her New York debut in a recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon. Miss Felts, after studying music in her childhood, later turned her attention to medicine. After a pre-medical course at the University of Wisconsin, she decided to take up a musical career, and re-entcring the field, was graduated with honors from. Park College and the Kansas City Conservatory.

Charles Walzer, operator, has bought a five-story, fifty-family house at 2,805 University Avenue, southwest corner of 197th Street, assessed at $150,000. The plot is 100 feet square. Schack Schack, attorneys, represented the buyer. R. Gross was the broker.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 11. -- A unanimous agreement on a formula to determine the course of the united Americas in view of the existing world conditions was reached here today by the representatives of twenty-one republics at the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace.

A committee consisting of Controller Taylor, Borough President Ingersoll of Brooklyn and himself was appointed yesterday by Mayor La Guardia to confer with representatives of the trustees of the New York, Brooklyn and Queens Borough Public Libraries on the proposal to create a pension system for the library employes.
The four robbers accused of killing Isaac Shain when he stumbled into a hold-up in a Brooklyn bar a month ago were convicted of first-degree murder in the Kings County Court last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Reduced receipts of pig iron were mainly responsible for the decline recorded in the 45,977 gross tons of finished and semi-finished iron and steel products valued at $2,220,997 that were imported into the United States in October, according to the Department of Commerce.

A coupe took fire after overturning on Grand Central Parkway Extension in Corona, Queens, yesterday afternoon and its driver, Miss Harriet E. Bruen, 24 years old, of 91-16 116th Street, Richmond Hill, was burned to death, imprisoned in the wreckage.

Price changes were mixed yesterday in the local commodity futures markets, with declines in rubber, hides and cocoa and gains in sugar, tallow and most of the metals. In the cash markets new high records were set by coffee, lead and zinc, and silk advanced, while losses occurred in wheat, corn, oats, cotton, eggs, rubber and tin.

PLEASANTVILLE, N. J., Dec. ll. -- The WPA seamstresses relinquished their hold on the City Council chamber at 6 o'clock tonight after remaining there in shifts continuously for the last eleven days in protest over the l abandoning of a sewing project.

The President recently appealed to employers to give jobs to those over 40 years of age. Is anything going to be done about it? I wonder, because I am familiar with the experience of some friends who have had to face stupid employers who look at age and not at ability.
Seth Low College defeated Brooklyn Poly, 27-17, at the Columbia court last night. The victors, held to 12-9 at half-time, increased their margin in the second half until substitutes entered the game.

LONDON. Dec. 11. -- Although buying still was on a moderate scale, the Stock Exchange today reflected relief from tension which has kept securities in check for a week. As a result of improved sentiment prices rose in almost all sections of the market.

Pupils of the elementary and high schools of the city, both public and parochial, received cash awards and certificates of honor yesterday in the annual essay contest conducted by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York and the Board of Education.

WASHINGTON, Dec. ll. -- Demands of labor, religion, the arts and other special groups for more and better time on the air were presented today by their delegates to the National Conference on Educational Broadcasting.

The last vestige of the influence recently exerted on the stock market by Britain's constitutional controversy disappeared yesterday. Trading in stocks relapsed into the familiar state of a few days ago, in that speculative activity in low-priced issues was prominent while many of the best-rated stocks made little or no headway.

New municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $55,130,088, representing seventy-eight municipalities. This compares with a revised total of only $14,538,192 of new municipal financing this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date is $26,378,938.
The latest edition of the Manhattan Telephone Directory rolled off the presses yesterday in a new cover on which art and convenience replace the geography and figures of the old book.

"Kind Lady," the first production this year of Wigs and Cues, Barnard College's dramatic organization, was given last night at Brinckerhoff Theatre in Milbank Hall. The play was the first modern melodrama to be presented at Barnard.
LONDON, Dec. 11. -- The first dinner given by King George VI and Queen Elizabeth was one unparalleled in the history of the British Empire.

LATE tonight, squads of workmen will swarm over Madison Square Garden and proceed about their routine business. This is the changing of weather. If Mark Twain can look down from whatever part of Olympus he is at present he can find man doing something to change his remark about the weather. No longer is it true that "Everybody complains about the weather, but nobody does anything about it."

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Dec. 11. -- Indications that the Southeastern Conference will affiliate with the New Orleans Midwinter Sports Association in sponsoring the annual Sugar Bowl football classic developed today in the annual meeting of the deep South athletic organization.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Senator Norris, author of the "lame duck" amendment, and Representative Clarence Lea of California are preparing to urge action on a resolution to amend the Constitution so as to abolish the Electoral College and provide for election of the President and Vice President by popular vote.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11 (AP). -- The colorful Texas Christian Horned Frogs and Santa Clara Broncos clash here tomorrow in a game 40,000 football rans will view as a "battle of the bowls."

The Long Island University basketball team has won thirty-seven games in succession to date and is just getting its second wind. I've searched through the record book, but I find no winning streak that approaches the L.I.U. mark.

The first of the Friday Assemblies of this season was held last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. The dances were inaugurated in the 1927-28 season for young members of society who had subscribed to the Junior and Knickerbocker Assemblies in former years.

Philip J. Roosevelt, president of the North American Yacht Racing Union, received a cable from London yesterday outlining the changes governing the sails of the six-meter sloops which were adopted by the International Yacht Racing Union.

Merry Anny Ondra (in private life Frau Max Schmeling) is back on the Yorkville screen after a prolonged absence, doing her usual happy-go-lucky, largely slapstick stuff to the amusement of film patrons able to understand the wisecracks with which the dialogue is filled.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 11. -- Awarding of the Montclair Yale Bowl to Frederick Ely Williamson, president of the New York Central Railroad, and the honoring of Captain Larry Kelley and Captain-elect Clint Frank, all-America stars at Yale, will feature the revival of the famous Yale barn parties tomorrow night at Nick Roberts's Old Yale Barn at 87 High Street.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses announced yesterday two bids were received earlier in the day by the State Department of Public Works in Albany for the construction of a bridge to carry Northern Boulevard over the East Service Road of the Grand Central Parkway Extension in Flushing Meadow Park.
Two members of the Squash Club gained the final of the club's annual invitation Class B squash racquets tourney yesterday.

Fate so willed it that JUAN DE LA CIERVA should have met his end in an airplane -- a means of transportation which he never wearied of attacking, yet one which, he admitted, had its place. With an inventor's natural enthusiasm for his own brain-child, he predicted a future which belonged to autogiros.

De Witt Clinton's strong quintet broke a three-way deadlock for first place in the Upper Manhattan-Bronx division of the P.S.A.L. championship and took undisputed possession of the lead by routing[ Evander Childs High, 44-22, on Clinton's floor yesterday.

TSINGTAO, China, Dec. 11. -- A temporary agreement in principle is the only result of the days and nights of negotiations between Admiral Shen Hung-lieh, Mayor of Tsingtao, and Consul General Nichi of Japan.

The engagement of $1,766,000 gold abroad for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, $1,450,000 of the amount being taken in India and $316,000 in England. The Reserve Bank reported the receipt here of $912,100 gold from India and announced that $1,125,200 gold had been released from earmark.

Paced by Captain Bill Hartog, who accounted for 13 points, the Trinity School quintet vanquished the Dwight School five, 36 to 16, on the former's court yesterday. The victory marked the second in as many games for the winners.

The State Street Investment Trust has declared a special dividend of $20 a share on the common stock, payable on Dec. 19 to stock of record of Dec. 15. The regular quarterly dividend of 75 cents, payable on Jan. 15 to stock of record of Dec. 15 also was voted.

LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 12. -- No longer King, but only Prince Edward and a subject of George VI, the man who had been Edward VIII until yesterday afternoon made a swift and lonely journey by automobile from Windsor to Portsmouth, where early today he boarded the Admiralty yacht Enchantress and left England for voluntary exile.
BERLIN, Dec. 11. -- The Boerse was weaker today on a small turnover throughout the session.

An 84-year-old man was burned to death and four persons rescued during a two-alarm fire early yesterday in a three-story frame dwelling at 96 Linden Street in the Bushwick district of Brooklyn. The rescued persons included two women and a 7-year-old child.

The city does not have power to fix the pay of employes of the Independent Subway System under the Board of Transportation, the Appellate Division ruled yesterday. The court held that the legislative intention to give the board the greatest possible freedom from interference on the part of the city would be "subverted" if the board did not have complete-control over the salaries of its employes.
rsten Flagstad, Metropolitan sop. no, and Henri Deering, pianist, will appear this afternoon in a joint concert at the Waldorf-Astoria, the second Rafaelo Diaz musicale of the season.

LONDON, Dec.11. -- The British Government has been heartened by news that President Roosevelt is concerting with Dr. Carlos Saavedra Lamas, Foreign Minister of Argentina, with the object of proposing that the Pan-American conference give some effective backing to Anglo-French mediation between the warring factions in Spain.
The Fordham swimming team captured the relay event by two yards to defeat City College, 41 to 30, at the Beavers' pool last night.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- Both houses of the British Parliament gave a memorable demonstration today that when the need arose they could act quickly and concurrently to end the dangerous situation which had seemed to menace the foundations of the country's constitutional throne.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard construction of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by I the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.
ALBANY, Dec. 11. -- The game of bingo has been banned as gambling in the parishes and organizations of the Catholic Church in Albany by the Right Rev. Edmund F. Gibbons.

"I always regret so my inability to do more," wrote one of the old contributors to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday. "But I have a great many I help privately myself and I am a cripple and an invalid. * * *"
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 11. -- Concerning rumors that Rumania is desirous of breaking relations with the Soviet Union, Foreign Minister Victor Antonescu declared in Parliament tonight:

The embryo basketball season will take a step in a new direction tonight when the New York Hippodrome stages the first of nine college double-headers, not only the opening show of the year for the Mike Jacobs arena but the first collegiate twin bill ever scheduled there.

President Nicholas Murray Butler, Dean Herbert E. Hawkes and Associate Dean Nicholas McD. McKnight head a group of faculty patrons who are sponsoring the Columbia College Dean's Drag, a charity dance to be held tonight in John Jay Hall, Columbia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Great Britain defaulted today on its war debt payments due the United States next Tuesday, but in less categorical terms than it has previously employed by implying indirectly that possibly less valid reasons for default might now exist than heretofore.
MOSCOW, Dec. 11. -- The Soviet public, like the rest of the world, is interested in the abdication of Edward, though to a far less extent than elsewhere.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Dec. 11 (AP). -- Federal agents investigating a series of railroad bombings invaded Southern Illinois coal fields today and seized nine men, one of them the Sheriff of Saline County.

The arthritic condition that prevented James J. Braddock from defending his world heavyweight title last September against Max Schmeling developed into a big pain in the neck for everybody concerned at yesterday's meeting of the State Athletic Commission.

PARIS, Dec. 11. -- All comment in the French press today on the manner in which Edward's abdication has been conducted expressed profound respect and even admiration for the British Prime Minister, Stanley Baldwin, and the British people.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. ll. -- "The Hungarians feel they have passed through a personal tragedy through Edward's abdication, and Hungary has lost a very close friend," a representative Hungarian told the writer today. "No other ruler ever captured the Hungarians' imagination as Edward and no other ruler is ever likely to do so."

Bond prices, in general, yesterday moved irregularly higher in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The total turnover, however, was less than on Thursday, the figures being, respectively, $13,041,600 and $16,262,600.

It is not probable that Prime Minister BALDWIN'S speech in the House of Commons tells the whole story of King EDWARD'S abdication. That may not be known for some time to come. There are personal friends and confidants of the former King who doubtless will have their own versions to give, sooner or later.
PHILADELPHIA. Dec. 11. -- The Assembly, oldest and most exclusive dance in the history of Philadelphia society, took place tonight in the ballroom of the Bellevue Stratford.

A suit by the Metropolitan Museum of Art for exemption from the city sales tax as a "semi-public institution" was disclosed yesterday in Supreme Court when the city asked the court to dismiss the suit on the ground that the complaint did not state a sufficient cause of action and that the court had no jurisdiction.
CANNES, France, Dec. ll. -- The voice of former King Edward VIII spoke out of a radio tonight in the Villa Lou Viei, where the woman for whom he renounced his throne listened.

The Treasury has reason to be gratified by the reception given its most recent offer of securities. A few days ago it invited cash subscriptions to $700,000,000 of bonds bearing interest at only 2 1/2 per cent -- the lowest rate ever placed on a new long-term issue of the United States, with the exception of several pre-war issues which bore the "circulation privilege."

Retail trade in the metropolitan i area proved somewhat disappointling during the week. While the week as a whole will probably show some increase over last year, trade volume on one or two days dipped under last year. For the first half of the month the indications are that department store sales will run about 5 per cent ahead of last year.
IOWA CITY, Dec. 11 (AP). -- "Fingerprinting" of human brains accurately by electricity was reported today by Lee Edward Travis and Abraham Gottlober of the University of Iowa.

Refinancing of outstanding bonds and notes of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company cannot be negotiated while the issue of the company's right to disaffirm its 999-year lease of the Manhattan Railway elevated lines remains in doubt, Federal Judge Julian W. Mack was told yesterday by Carl M. Owen, counsel for Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver for the company.

BERLIN, Dec. ll. -- The German press and other organs of official publicity began today a delicate but unanimous campaign to win the favor of the new British King. This has been done presumably to bridge the estrangement that found expression in the Franco-British entente and the German-Japanese entente, contrary to the fundamental tenets of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's foreign policy.
LONDON, Dec. 11. -- Following is the text of the farewell broadcast of former King Edward, who was introduced to the radio audience as "His Royal Highness Prince Edward":

Gleefully admitting an obvious prejudice, I yet cannot pretend to understand the various unofficial rankings that almost invariably rate Yale and Penn above Dartmouth. I suppose it's no use objecting that Dartmouth did beat Yale and that Yale, although outplayed, did beat Penn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Former President Hoover returned to Washington today for the first time since he left the White House in 1933. He came to attend the annual meeting of the board of the Carnegie Institution, and he declined to discuss political questions or give an interview.

Because of pyramiding of taxes under the Social Security Act, price increases for some products under the maximum tax rates may be as much as 4 per cent, Thomas E. Shearer, editor-in-chief of the Prentice-Hall Labor and Unemployment Insurance Service, told the concluding session yesterday of the twentieth anniversary convention of the Toy Manufacturers of the United States og America at the Park Central Hotel.

Milder weather and rain hampered distribution in some sections of the country this week, the rise in sales volume from the week preceding being held down to 4 to 8 per cent, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

CHICAGO, Dec. ll. -- Welker Cochran of San Francisco forced a playoff for the world three-cushion billiard championship tonight by defeating Kinrey Matsuyama of Japan, 50 to 26, in thirty-two innings. Cochran's victory leaves himself, Matsuyama and Tiff Denton of Kansas City deadlocked for first place, each having won six games and lost three.

Headed by Mayor La Guardia and Park Commissioner Robert Moses, a party of more than fifty city and Park Department officials braved a steady rain and thick fog yesterday afternoon to inspect the new Henry Hudson Parkway and bridge over Spuyten Duyvil that will be opened to the public today.

PARIS, Dec. 11. -- France's reply to the habitual reminder from Washington that she has not paid her war debts will be couched, it is believed, in slightly different language from those in the past. But the French Government has not yet definitely decided what policy to follow in the matter of debts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Trading in stocks by members for their own account as represented by combined purchases and sales in round lots on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Nov. 14, in which there were five trading days, aggregated 5,115,513 shares or 18.93 per cent of the total volume, according to a summary made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Detectives of the forgery squad last night arrested Mrs. Jean Wolf, 45 years old, said to be the wife of an attorney, at the Hotel Oliver Cromwell, 12 West Seventy-second Street, on a charge of having accepted $7,500 to prevent a government witness from testifying against Jacob J. Lesser, one-time aspirant for a Federal judgeship, and thirteen others indicted in a bankruptcy fraud.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- A three-point program for industry, calling for a revised NRA favorable to the "little man" amendments to make the anti-trust laws more effective, and a system of government-guaranteed loans to small businesses similar to those extended to home owners under Title I of the Federal Housing Act, was evolved by the Council for Industrial Progress, which ended its sessions here today.

From the time of his first appearances in this country four seasons ago Emanuel Feuermann showed himself to be a 'cellist of consummate technical equipment and of solid musical understanding to boot. But last night in Carnegie Hall he was more than a singularly efficient performer.
OTTAWA, Dec. 11. -- A meeting of the Dominion Cabinet was adjourned at 5 o'clock this afternoon to allow Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King and his ministers to hear Edward's farewell to his empire.

The approximate status ,of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

While the Brooklyn Tech and Jamaica hockey teams were engaged in a scoreless battle, the New Utrecht combination defeated Textile, 4 to 0, at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night to move into a triple tie for first place in the P.S.A.L. tournament.

OTTAWA, Canada, Dec. 11. -- Stamp dealers yesterday tried to buy up the only outstanding stamp issue bearing a portrait of either of the two principals in Britain's empire-shaking change of monarchs, but they were balked by the Post Office Department's policy of protecting the interests of small collectors.
As a student of Fordham I feel that it is only right that I should answer William Kurl's letter in which he unfairly attacked the sports reporters for "giving too much praise to the Ram eleven."

About 200 Brooklyn property owners won new consideration from the Board of Estimate yesterday for their plea that they should pay little or nothing toward the cost of acquiring land needed for part of the Sunrise Highway project, the road that gives Brooklyn one of its chief connections with the new Queens-Long Island parkway systems.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- "Baby" bonds may to a degree be replacing gold pieces as Christmas presents.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad. Dec. 11 (AP). -- President Roosevelt started the last lap of his return from a Latin-American peace mission today, leaving Port of Spain for Charleston, S.C., where he will arrive Tuesday.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 11 (AP). -- The American Farm Bureau Federation resolved tonight to use every effort found necessary to maintain price levels of farm products in line with the American standard of wages and living, to assure to agriculture its "rightful share of national income."

New "peep-holes" enabling scientists to obtain behind-the-scenes glimpses of the activities of living matter and of the chemical factories within the cells, the building bricks of all plant and animal life, were described and demonstrated last night at a symposium at Washington Square College, New York University.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- In reply to questions in the Commons this afternoon, the Attorney General, Sir Donald Somervell, told the House that all revenues from the civil list and from the Duchies of Cornwall and Lancaster which had come to Edward VIII would be transferred automatically to the new King.

The New York State Conservation Department, in a bulletin released yesterday, proposes a four-point program "to bring the pheasant population back to relative abundancce in the shortest time and with the least expenditure of funds and effort."
ROME, Dec. 11. -- King Edward's abdication continues to receive great prominence in the Italian press.

WASHINGTON. Dec. 11. -- The Justices of the United States Supreme Court were asked today to decide whether the Congressional resolution of June, 1933, abrogating payments in gold extended so far that rental contracts based on payment in gold bullion or its equivalent can now be settled with devalued dollars.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Dec. 11. -Asserting that the churches "cannot and will not give their moral consent" to the United States expenditures on its military and naval establishments, the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, at the closing session of its biennial meeting here, approved today a nine-point program for America's contribution to peace.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today that it had sold to the Controller of the State of New York $3,358,000 of Buffalo Sewer Authority 4 per cent bonds at 105 and accrued interest and $2,141,000 Rip Van Winkle 4 1/2 per cent bridge bonds at 113 and accrued interest, representing respectively premiums of $167,000 and $278,330.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 11. -- High Diver, owned by O.H. Reed, chalked up his second straight victory when he captured the Golden Rod Purse, mile and sixteenth feature of the Fair Grounds program today, by a head. High Diver showed a good effort, but the judgment of Joe Cowley aided greatly in his victory.

The permanent benefits of football as a social factor rather than a mere instrument of temporary elation or depression were toasted last night as the Touchdown Club held its fourth annual post-season dinner at the Hotel Martinique, with 200 former college gridiron lettermen and a number of distinguished guests present.

LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 12. -- Edward VIII ceased to be King and Emperor at 1:52 P.M. yesterday and his brother, Albert Frederick Arthur George, who has been until now the Duke of York, reigns in his stead over Great Britain and the Empire as George VI.

VIENNA, Dec. ll. -- Former King Edward's vast popularity here has provoked a great wave of personal sympathy for him, with most Austrians regarding his abdication as a great loss to the empire and to the world generally. Sympathy for Edward, however, is mingled with sympathy for the British people.

In THE TIMES of Nov. 14, wherein my letter relating to odds was printed, an editorial note was appended stating that there still remained the problem of picking the right horse, or team. My intention in writing that article was not to show which horse to pick, but to explain a horse's probability of winning.

HARRISBURG, Dec. 11. -- Governor Earle, starting Dec. 21, will spend three days in a personal investigation of anthracite coal bootlegging, visiting Schuylkill, Northumberland, Carbon and Coumbia Counties. With him will be State officials, representatives of the operators and of the United Mine Workers, and possibly a representative of the Federal Labor Department.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday heard argument and reserved decision on the first case to reach it involving the constitutionality of the so-called market-rigging provisions of the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934 as amended.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 11. -- Establishment of a rediscount back for mortgages was urged today by Walter W. Rose of Orlando, Fla. president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards in a speech to delegates at the twentieth annual convention of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards in the Ritz-Carlton Hotel here.

This piety is curiously served just now. Last week Governor BRANN made a number of appointments. There was no question about their fitness. Many of the appointees were Republicans. The Council in its wisdom rejected all the nominations. The only reason given was that "it is so near the end of the year."

Lena R. Waters director of the department of social service at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia, was the guest speaker at the annual meeting of the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness, 50 West Fiftieth Street, yesterday afternoon at the Russell Sage Foundation, 130 East Twenty-second Street.

LAWRENCE, L.I., Dec. 11. -- A few minutes after silverware, furs and wearing apparel, valued at $6,800, had been stolen from the home of Mr. and Mrs. Garson Studley at 20 Margaret Avenue here, the loot was recovered at 8:15 o'clock last night in an automobile which a policeman had chased for a minor traffic violation.

The Seaboard Trust Company sold to Patrick J. Dunn of Hoboken the old Columbian Brewery, a three-story brick structure on a plot 275 by 100 feet at 225-45 Bartholdi Avenue, with twelve lots in the rear on Winfield Avenue, Jersey City.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- Thoughts of the coronation continue to be uppermost in the minds of thousands of British people who have a direct monetary stake in it. The big question has been answered. York is King, the empire goes on and London looks the same.
PARIS, Dec. ll. -- At a moment when all hope for Jean Mermoz, noted flier, and his companions had been abandoned, a telegram was received from Brazil tonight reviving hope of their rescue.

Mrs. Margaret Gislar, 73 years old, was found dead last night in the rear yard of her home, 69-28 Sixty-fourth Street, Middle Village, Queens, and her husband George, 72, was found in the cellar of the house with a slashed throat, after what the police described as a family argument.

Interscholastic basketball made its debut at the Hippodrome yesterday afternoon and the crowd of 2,000 which attended saw two hard-fought games. In the opening contest Power Memorial defeated All Hallows by 18 -- 13 for its fifth straight victory, while De La Salle staged a stirring rally to conquer St. Nicholas of Tolentine, 32 -- 28, in the second.

E.P. Field of the Princeton club, seeded No. 1 in the annual Fall squash tennis championship for Class B and C players, swung into action yesterday and won his opening match handily. He defeated C. Andrews of the Yale club, 15 -- 3 and 15 -- 5, on the Columbia University club courts.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Shall the United States retain its frontier line of defense in the Philippines or withdraw it to some such line as that stretching from Alaska to Hawaii and thence to Panama?

The Treasury last Monday offered for cash $700,000,000 of 2 1/2 per cent seventeen-year bonds. That evening Secretary Morgenthau closed the subscription books, more than $5,000,000,000 of tenders having already been received. If any one had predicted such an event three, or even two years ago, he would have been laughed at in Wall Street.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 12. -- The fact that, under the Palestine land laws, a title deed to property is not sufficient guarantee of ownership and that trespassers can remain in occupation while holders of the legal title are obliged to take costly proceedings against them, was revealed by Solomon Horowitz, a prominent Palestine lawyer, before The British Royal Commission of Inquiry yesterday.

VATICAN CITY, Dec. 11. -- The Vatican is one of the very few absolute governments left in the world. The Pope rules the church personally without intermediary or legislative bodies, and although much of his authority is exercised through the medium of the Roman Congregations, which correspond to the Ministries or Departments of State in civil governments, these are directly responsible to him and him alone.

We always did suspect that these archer-huntsmen took their sport seriously. A communication from George Webster Jacobs, the bow-and-arrow man from Mountain Lakes, N.J., leaves no room for doubt. Mr. Jacobs writes of archery in the manner of a rifle expert discussing ballistics.

OMAHA, Dec. 11. -- While the farm program for 1937, announced this week, makes many detailed changes with which the farmer will have to become familiar, the feature of primary interest to this area is the inclusion of a corn acreage limitation as a condition to qualification for the maximum benefit earnable.
Chiang Kai-shek, the generalissimo, and Chang Hsuch-liang, the "young marshal," have been the two outstanding figures in Chinese military affairs during the last decade and more.

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 12. -- The lifelong habit of James Sullivan of rubbing his ear with a pencil or anything he chanced to have in his hand caused him to scratch his ear with a pistol and kill himself when the weapon was discharged, it was disclosed today.

LONG before the first snow falls the ski fanatics of Europe practice skiing in their bedrooms. Turnhalls and gymnasiums are filled with professional and business men and women who do "dry ski exercises" to take the creaks out of their joints and to achieve the proper physical condition for their ventures in the "white art."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- With a final exchange of views, but no conclusions concerning the problems presented, the delegates to the First National Conference on Educational Broadcasting adjourned today a three-day session held in cooperation with the Federal Communications Commission and the United States Office of Education.

State-wide organizations of women have been asked by the Merchants Association of New York to make an immediate study of the cost of taxes to the family in New York City, in order that "a demonstration of popular interest may induce the next New York State Legislature to effect needed reforms."

Cooperation of more than twenty-eight national business groups in a movement by industry to have so-called "hold harmless" clauses stripped from sales contracts was announced here yesterday by John G. Goetz, secretary and treasurer of the Risk Research Bureau, Inc., a national organization of insurance buyers and self-insurers.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dee. 12. -- The traditional Nativity play was presented at the Edgewood school this evening, before a large audience under the direction of Miss Lucine Finch, who arranged the sequences from the Bible story. It was given in pantomime, with the piano accompaniment played by Miss Clare Hamilton.

GENEVA, Dec. 12. -- The Spanish crisis as it comes before the Council of the League of Nations looks from Geneva like one of those puzzles that have been well polished by futile fingering. It is hard to find any one who is hopeful of its being solved soon.

Chain store sales in November did not maintain the pace set in recent months, for the first time in seven months having failed to increase more than 15 per cent over the like month of 1935, according to the monthly compilation of Childs, Jeffries Thorndike, Inc., and Hammons Co., Inc.

Christmas vacation will not be all cakes and ale for some college students. Several hundred of them from all parts of the country are to spend the last week in December in discussion of youth problems in two national conventions, one in Chicago and one in New York City.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 12 (AP). -- Men of science, clipping a leaf from the history of earthquake recording, advanced a simplified seismograph today as a means of preventing deaths in the coal mines.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- Though there has been as yet no official decision, it is generally assumed that the coronation will be held next May, as long planned, the only difference being, aside from one of personality, that now it will be a King and a Queen who will be crowned instead of a King alone.

CANNES, France, Dec. 12. -- The staff at Villa Lou Viei asserted today that Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson had remained in her room today until well in the afternoon and that her whole day was "very quiet."
AS ski frenzy mounts, ski makers are searching for lumber to replenish stocks of seasoned hickory and ash, and of such cheaper woods as yellow pine, maple and birch, used in making skis.
ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 12. -- Radical changes in the tax system in this State were demanded by the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards in annual convention today at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.

SALAMANCA, Spain, Dec. 12. -- Baron Carl von Haartman, "the Hollywood general," now an Insurgent captain, has been wounded in action in a Leftist counter-attack near Espinosa de los Monteros, roughly thirty-five miles south-southeast of Santander.

The city markets are marking time in anticipation of the Christmas rush. Housewives have postponed their heavy buying until Christmas week, and are turning their attention to such accoutrements as puddings and cakes, figs, dates and nuts.

The library of Thomas L. Malone of this city, author's manuscripts and first editions, and other lots will be sold at auction at the Rains Galleries on Thursday and Friday evenings. The first seventy-two numbers on the catalogue constitute a group of author's manuscripts and first editions consigned by the author.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12. -- Marking the attainment of an objective of many years, the library of the University of Pennsylvania has just installed a "founder's room" for the permanent segregation and display of nearly 1,000 volumes which formed the nucleus of its collections during the university's early days.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- A demand for "bigger and better abdications" in the leadership of the Republican party came today from Representative Fish of New York in a statement in which he said that the party must either liberalize its policies or commit suicide.

LONDON, Dec. 12. -- In the person of the new King and Queen the British monarchy returns to the tradition which enabled it to retain the affection of its world-wide empire and the respect of all foreign nations -- that Spartan devotion to duty which won for George V the impressive tributes of his silver jubilee.

Miss Nancy Wemple Bissell was presented to society yesterday afternoon at a reception given by her parents, President Justice and Mrs. Pelham St. George Bissell, at their, home, 270 Park Avenue. Receiving with the debutante and her mother in the drawing room, which was decorated with palm and Autumn flowers, were her two sisters, Mrs. Charles Hecker Stout and Miss Mary Sackett Bissell; and her sister-in-law, Mrs. Pelham St. George Bissell 3d.

The student council of Fordham University, composed of thirteen heads of campus organizations, will in the future control all major campus elections as well as the campus dances, according to a new council constitution adopted yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12. -- Led by the greatest passer this football-conscious section ever has seen -- cool and courageous Sammy Baugh -- Texas Christian beat the University of Santa Clara today, 9 to 0. Forty thousand cheering fans watched the last undefeated and untied major team in the United States crumble before Baugh's deadly effective aerials.

Greyhound I, a trim fishing trawler destined to serve on the stormy Grand Banks off Newfound-land, tasted salt water yesterday afternoon for the first time in as gentle a launching as ever held in Erie Basin. The vessel was lifted clear of its keel blocks on shore and swung by a derrick over the bulkhead line to be lowered into the lapping waves.

In keeping with the trend toward training for leisure as well as to enrich the general vocational and cultural aspect of a college education, Hunter College has added to its curriculum this semester a course in practical photography.

THERE have been no more passionate quests in the history of exploration than that of Robert E. Peary for the North Pole. He had at times a detachment of purpose which makes one feel that the man sought the Grail rather than a geographical point upon a map.
WITH PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT AT SEA, Dec. 12. -- President Roosevelt found a rich fishing spot today, close to tiny Bird Island in the Caribbean, about 350 miles north of Trinidad.

The twelve-year reign of Public School 9 in elementary school indoor track was brought to an end yesterday when the representatives of Public School 3 captured the team title in the annual city P.S.A.L. championships at the 245th Coast Defense Armory in Brooklyn.

LONDON, Dec. 12. -- The British people noticed for the first time today that something important and immensely encouraging had happened across the Irish Sea while they were immersed in their crisis over the monarchy.

BOMBAY. -- By a stroke of the pen on his twenty-fifth birthday the young Maharajah of Travancore has set at naught the custom of centuries and in his State abolished untouchability, root and branch. He has signed a proclamation giving to 2,000,000 of his untouchable subjects the right of entering and worshiping in public temples.

In European figure skating circles the passing of Miss Sonja Henie into the professional ranks not only leaves important championships for a new titleholder but signifies the rise of a new generation of women competitors.

ANOTHER fox-hunting season has opened in England, and the gentlemen with the old school ties are stall discussing prospects. If there is any substance in the old saying that a good harvest means a good foxhunting season, prospects have to be put down as pretty bad, for the harvest was late and long But perhaps this saying only means that a good harvest puts the farmers in a good humor.

Patsy Boggia, 7 years old, of 4,454 Hill Avenue, the Bronx, awakened yesterday morning by the fumes of coal gas which permeated the apartment, saved the lives of the other nine members of the family who already were overcome or partly affected by the gas.

Completion of the State organization of the Woman's Field Army, through which the American Society for the Control of Cancer plans an accelerated drive against the disease throughout the nation, will be effected tomorrow at the Town Hall Club.

Grant was a Neediest Case then -- deserted and ill at the age of 6. His mother had abandoned him, and then his father -- a heavy drinker -- left the boy alone in the world. He had acute appendicitis and it was weeks before they were sure he would live.

"A school in every army post" is the slogan of New York WPA and Board of Education executives who, with army officers of the Second Corps Area, embracing New York, New Jersey, Delaware and the eastern half of Pennsylvania, have seen an experiment in adult education for soldiers achieve what they regard as unusual success.

The annual Christmas sale of dolls and other articles suitable for gifts will open tomorrow at the Bargain Box, a thrift shop on Third Avenue at Sixty-eighth Street, and continue through Wednesday. On Dec. 23, Santa Claus will be at the shop to distribute gifts to children for a moderate sum.
Mounting tension between Germany and Russia has brought into prominence the role of the buffer States that lie between them.

PARIS, Dec. 12. -- While his brother was being proclaimed King-Emperor in London with all the time-honored ceremony with which he himself succeeded to the throne less than a year ago, the Duke of Windsor, formerly Edward VIII, landed in France this afternoon to begin his self-imposed exile.

S.S. Smith (the pseudonym of a well-known writer of novels), chooses as backgrounds for his mystery stories for boys and girls only places and ways of life that he knows from personal investigation. "The Falcon Mystery" has for its setting the great plain of Hungary, where herders graze their half-wild horses.
PARK CITY, Utah, Dec. 12 (AP). -- Fist-swinging strikers, battling while women cheered, repulsed today about 100 miners who were seeking work in silver mines closed down by a strike.

NOT so many years ago the coming of Winter meant the closing of most of our great scenic national parks to travel. Wrapped in snow as in cotton-batting, they were virtually put on the travel shelf until the Summer sun unwrapped and again placed them on display.

THE way of a fish with a line has thousands of Florida's Winter visitors strenuously at play along nearly 4,000 miles of coast and in many of the 30,000 fresh-water lakes. They have rigged up tackle and gone forth to indulge in a major diversion that holds moments of excitement for novice and veteran alike.

NOW tell me all about yourself in a few words. That, in effect, was what the artist, Georges Schreiber, formidably said to each of the forty modern celebrities, mostly literary, whose portraits he had drawn.

While the superpopular chapter headings, and ever-so-intimate presentation of this subject-matter will attract many lay readers, they will not only ruffle the dignity of the more academic members of the medical profession, but will quite likely arouse their suspicion of this being either an unserious or an unaccurate document.
Renewal of a pledge to shun all motion pictures which "offend good morals and good taste," will be asked of the Roman Catholic laity of the United States today.

A NEW travel season has opened with clear indications that the Winter vacation is becoming a democratic institution. In increasing numbers Mr. Average Citizen is accompanying those perennial vacationers, the idle and near-idle rich, to the Southland's languid climes and to the more vigorous playgrounds of the North.

"Interesting Arrangements of Common Material" will be the subject of a lecture by Mrs. Milton Freudenheim at Monday's meeting of the Women's Guild of the Jewish Community Center of White Plains. The lecture, which will be given at the Jewish Community Center at 10:30 A.M., is open to members of outside garden clubs.

The Seward Park quintet strengthened its hold on first place in the Lower Manhattan Division of the P.S.A.L. tournament by recording its third victory in as many starts in halting Stuyvesant, 29 -- 27, on the latter's court yesterday.

Mistletoe is not much to look at. Its small leaves are thick and yellowish, its berries whitish and sticky. By any other name it would not seem attractive; persons unacquainted with its appearance would disdainfully pass it by. But on hearing it called the magic word "mistletoe," sentiment is instantly aroused.

LAKE PLACID. -- Already the Winter trek to Lake Placid and Winter sports has set in, although the regular program does not open until next Saturday. Early bookings indicate the best season since the Olympic Winter games were staged here in 1932.
An engagement party planned for Rosa Ponselle, the opera singer, and Carle A. Jackson of Baltimore will be a wedding reception today.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 12. -- The Legislature's action in passing a slum-clearance bill enabling thirty-two cities and towns to set up housing authorities will, for the present, mostly concern Bridgeport because this is the only Connecticut city now contemplating slum clearance and housing with Federal aid and local financing combined.

Christmas cards are now on the counters of shops all over the country and in New York scores of little stores have been opened merely for the purpose of selling gay paper greetings to the city's seven millions. The old Christmas themes that reappear with traditional regularity are placed beside the newer and more imaginative cards designed by artists of reputation.

RICHMOND, Dec. 12. -- In comparison with the whirlwind start made by the pre-holiday trade, there was a slackening up in volume this week in the Fifth Federal Reserve District, but not enough to change the optimistic forecasts made generally by retailers.
MADRID, Dec. 11. -- A few days ago this correspondent went into the Rosales district of Madrid about ten minutes after a heavy bombing by thirty Italian Caproni planes of the Insurgent air force.

In order to arrive at unanimity of opinion among "key" women of eleven organizations comprising the National Committee on the Cause and Cure of War, propositions based on a study of the relation between war and economic life will be submitted to them this week by a special committee, entrusted last January with preparation of this work.
MANILA. Dec. 12 (AP). -- Health authorities, relief workers and soldiers swarmed into the flood-swept Cagayan Valley tonight to fight against threats of famine and disease.

Some classes of businesses are required to employ inventories in determining profits and losses for income-tax purposes, and yet others are forbidden the use of them. Merchants and manufacturers generally cannot determine net income from business operations without the use of inventories, whereas in the case of security transactions the employment of inventories is permitted only to those coming within the prescribed definition of "dealers in securities."

Declaring that a capital goods inflation can develop quicker than is generally realized, Dr. Joseph J. Goodbar, president of the Society for Stability in Money and Banking, yesterday urged that a statistical study of durable goods construction be made so that "its true normal level can be recognized and held when that point is reached."

AS its subtitle states, this book is a "popular introduction to the story of the universe and man's place on earth." And one is first struck, on picking up the volume, by the wide range of the material and by the skill of the author in assembling the differing branches of his subject into one well-knit whole.

Price changes were erratic in the local commodity futures markets throughout the week ended on Friday, and gains and losses appeared about even at the close, with wool tops, cocoa, coffee, rubber and silk lower while sugar, cottonseed oil, hides and metals gained.

CALYPSO, N.C., Dec. 11. -- Confronted by a pressing local problem which is funny to some, but not to Calypso, Town Clerk George Albritton has resorted to newspaper advertising in his search for "two used jail cells. State price."

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 12. -- Alumni of the University of Pittsburgh, almost 25,000 strong, have completed preliminary plans for the celebration on Feb. 25 of the 150th anniversary of the university's founding. The actual founding date was Feb. 28.

BARCELONA, Spain, Dec. 12 (AP). -- Premier Jose Tarradellas of autonomous Catalonia announced today the break-up of his government because of its inability to control anarchist and labor syndicate groups. He said that his Cabinet, loyal to the Valencia regime, would hold its last meeting Monday and that he refused to accept further responsibility for "the action of irresponsible, uncontrolled groups."

LONDON, Dec. 12. -- Under a gray sky and amid a mild drizzle characteristic of London in mid-December, a new regime, which is in a measure nothing more than a return to the old order of things, began in Great Britain today with the proclamation of George VI as King and Emperor.
Range of call loans on the New York Stock Exchange in this week for a series of years:

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Dec. 12. -- The roundup of persons indicted by a grand jury for railroad bombings and other terrorism in the Illinois coal fields was continued by Federal agents today when many of those already seized were freed on bail.

Six remarkably spry Civil War veterans, out of a total membership of fifteen, came a long way from their homes yesterday to attend the seventieth annual meeting of the Memorial and Executive Committee of the Kings County Grand Army of the Republic.

Beginning Jan. 1, employers' contributions for State unemployment insurance will be at the rate of $5,000,000 a month, Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews said yesterday afternoon in a radio address from station WABC.

KINGS and great noblemen in days of old had their food tasters and food testers. These men were kept to protect the delicate taste of their masters from off-flavors. They were also kept to protect royalty from being poisoned.

Graduates of women's colleges in New York City are organizing to help their younger sisters find jobs. In the last few weeks alumnae of Smith, Vassar and Bernard have taken decisive action, and the New York City branch of the American Association of University Women is following their activities and aiding in coordinating them.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 12. -- The West Point officers' team proved its jumping superiority for the second straight year tonight in the thirteenth annual Military Horse Show of Troop F of the 102d Cavalry, staged before 3,000 persons at the Essex Troop Armory.

PASSENGER traffic managers for railways, for bus lines and for airways are busy men these days as the Winter travel season gets under way. Plans have been completed to care for the largest band of travelers in Winter holiday history, and these plans include features which are new even to a land where travel, whether for a week or a week-end, has never been an affair of hardship and discomfort.

With the election of Edwin F. Jaeckle as Republican State Chairman tomorrow seemingly assured, the conservative wing of the party produced last evening a new candidate for the chairmanship in William S. Murray of Utica, Oneida County Chairman.

BROTHER RAT" comes into the Biltmore on Wednesday as George Abbott's first comedy contribution of the season. Deceptive as it may sound, the title is a term of endearment, much like Al Woods's "sweetheart," and is used as a friendly salute among the cadets of the Virginia Military Institute. As for the authors, one would never suspect that they were the bad boys of the V.M.I.; further, one would never suspect them of being playwrights.

Artists' models, members of the Models Union whose weekly earnings average about $8, are conducting a campaign to raise their stipend to about $12, and to place their calling on a more business-like basis. The union hopes for a wage of a dollar an hour for posing, as against 75 cents now paid by art schools and many artists.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 12. -- By unanimous vote the Central New York Model Council of the League of Nations, representing eight colleges and universities, today authorized Miss Holley Redington, secretary-general, to forward the council's expression of "hearty cooperation" to the Pan-American Conference at Buenos Aires.
OTTAWA, Dec. 12. -- Canada, which yesterday heard her second King say farewell to his empire, joined today with that empire to proclaim allegiance to her third King, George VI.
Frederick Barry Ryan Jr. yesterday won the final of the annual Fall scratch squash tennis tourney at the City Athletic Club, defeating Frank A. Sieverman 3d of the New York A.C.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP). -- J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that Federal agents had learned the whereabouts of Francesco (Cheech) Guarna, alleged artichoke rackeeter under indictment in New York.
Columbia University has received $45,416.75 in gifts, according to an announcement made yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

A church choir festival by ensembles of Greater New York is planned, to take place between April 19 and 27, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. George B. French, who has accepted the appointment as chairman of the choir music festival of the Municipal Committee.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12. -- Wheat made an easy start and a strong finish today with the July future on the Boards of Trade here and in Kansas City, and all deliveries in Winnipeg and Buenos Aires selling at new high prices for the season. Closing trades were at the top with net gains of 1 1/8 to 2 3/4 cents a bushel locally, while Kansas City was 1 1/3 to 3 1/8 cents higher.

The woman who goes shopping for presents for men in stores now jammed with peak crowds does well to arm herself with a gift list in advance. This reduces wear and tear on feet and temper. In making up her Christmas list for 1936 she must choose among wares offered in a market well provided with all the old stand-bys as well as with a number of new departures.
DUTCH windmills seem to be safe for many a year to come. In most countries these medieval centers of community life survive as museum pieces, serving the cause of the picturesque and the antique.

MR. BISHOP has decided that a life of Pascal, if it is to be written at all, must be written thoroughly and in its entirety. This biography is not a casual and superficial impression of a great celebrity. It is a solid, comprehensive and valuable addition to the library.

WILL JAMES is writing here about a bad horse. And he doesn't try to make a good horse of him. There was nothing kind or loving or tender-hearted or touchingly grateful about Scorpion. The Roman-nosed chestnut of this story was "good" only in the sense that his most outrageous misbehavior seemed uncannily timed to produce good ends, albeit somewhat painfully for whoever was trying to ride him.

UNDER date of Sunday, Nov. 8, 1789, George Washington dutifully confided to his diary the unexciting occurrences of his sojourn in the town of Ashford, Conn. It was not one of his lucky days. He had fallen victim to the famed blue laws and local prejudice against traveling on the Sabbath.

The stock market failed to retain all of its early advantage yesterday and closed irregular. The better-rated issues led the list higher in the first hour of trading but gave up most of their gains in the second hour when the demand favored the more speculative of the low-priced stocks.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- Winter sports are in full swing in the Poconos and -- since conditions for skiing and skating were favorable during the past week -- many guests are on hand this week-end for the cold-weather activities. Also, sportsmen who came here for the deer-hunting season, which closed yesterday, are remaining over the week-end.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Dec. 12. -- The annual artists' course series at Pennsylvania State College was oversubscribed this week to the point where it became necessary to hang out a "standing room only" sign and to discourage applications from out-of-towners.

KING EDWARD VIII broadcast his first message to the Britist Empire on March 1, 1936. It marked his seventy-sixth broadcast, his other radio appearances being as the Prince of Wales. Since his first brief broadcast as monarch he was not on the air until his farewell.

A reception and tea were given yesterday afternoon by Mr. and Mrs. Hanford Mead Twitchell at their home, 166 East Seventy-first Street, to introduce to friends in this city their debutante niece, Miss Prudence Cleveland Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Watson Hall Smith of Providence, R.I.

Fanciers the country over will enter this week on the annual Winter vacation season which will continue for four full weeks. Not an all-breed exhibition; not even a minor specialty event is on the calendar during the rest of December and the first week of January.

Once more, A.L. Burns was the winner of the major prizes in the weekly shoot of the New York Athletic Club. Yesterday, at the Travers Island traps of the organization, he captured the high scratch cup by breaking 94 out of a possible 100, then won a leg on both the scratch and handicap trophies at 155 targets, with a card of 142-0-142.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- A notable improvement in the economic situation in the Philippines has been reported to the Department of Commerce by J. Bartlett Richards, trade commissioner. Internal revenues, provincial and municipal collections, he said, have shown substantial gains over 1935, while gold production has increased from month to month.

AGAIN the American Artists Group, Inc., has brought out a large and attractive assortment of Christmas cards, each containing a reproduced subject in oil, water-color or in one of the several graphic mediums by an artist affiliated with the group.

SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 28. ON a white sandy sea floor, above multi-colored ridges of growing coral, move black and gaudy objects. Their motion is so slow that you must watch them intently for minutes to see them in action.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 12. -- William Ong of Kansas City carried away two trophies and top prize money as he won the two feature races at the closing day of the ninth annual Miami All-American air manoeuvres today.

WITH the first sharp chill of Winter and with colder days ahead, New York's public fishing fleet is starting in upon a bang-up cold-weather cod-fishing season. For almost a month now a smattering of fresh-run cod have been coming in over the rails, but it will be another week or two before the heavy runs of the year will start.

PARIS, Dec. 2. -- Several lines of activity in which Americans in Paris are interested recall something of the animation of a decade ago. Two big sales of pictures and other art objects have been attracting, during the last few days, distinguished cosmopolitan buyers who are notables of Parisian society.

GREAT SOUTH BAY on the ocean side of Long Island has just been assigned a new special-duty Coast Guard boat. She is the AA-25, an all-oak, heavily built craft sixty-two feet long and carrying a crew of ten men.

LONDON, Dec 9. -- With seats sold out weeks ahead and frantic theatrophiles advertising in the agony columns of London's newspapers for tickets, Sir James M. Barrie's "The Boy David," which opens at His Majesty's on Monday evening, promises to provide a very merry Christmas for the ticket scalpers.

VALETTA, Malta, Dec. 12. -- Eight deckhands, including the boatswain, of the British steamer Thurston, charged with disobeying orders of Captain Benjamin Allen to proceed to Cartagena, were acquitted today in a magistrate's finding that they were justified in their refusal.
CHICAGO, Sunday, Dec. 13. -- Welker Cochran of San Francisco won the world three-cushion billiards championship early today, defeating Kinrey Matsuyama of Japan, 50 to 37, in fifty-three innings.

PEIPING, Dec. 12. -- Another dangerous anti-Japanese student demonstration occurred in Peiping this afternoon when 2,000 students, including 300 girls, seized control of part of Peihai Park formerly part of the "Forbidden City."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP). -- A new drive for legislation to exempt private pension systems from the Federal pension program under the Social Security Act was announced today by Chairman King of the joint Congressional committee which has been studying the proposal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Promotion of eight naval captains to be rear admirals and thirty-one commanders to be captains was approved by President Roosevelt today on the cruiser Indianapolis in accepting the recommendations of a selection board, headed by Admiral Arthur J. Hepburn, commander-in-chief of the fleet.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP). -- The Treasury sought a purchaser today for Cedar Island and its 67-year-old nine-room house and lighthouse tower, a half mile off Cedar Point, L.I.

A varied program well calculated to hold the attention of its listeners was offered at Carnegie Hall last night by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under John Barbirolli's direction, with Gasper Cassado, the Spanish 'cellist, as the soloist.

THE Heinrichshofen Verlag of Magdeburg has recently issued a work which can hardly fail to make a certain sentimental appeal to music lovers, besides embodying a tonal curiosity of the first order. This work is a sonata for violin and piano, written in 1853 and boasting no less than three authors -- Schumann, Brahms and a friend of these masters, Albert Dietrich.

At Albany about noon tomorrow the New York State Electoral College will open for its quadrennial one-day session with forty-seven prominent citizens in attendance. The college used to convene on the first Monday in January, but Senator Norris's "lame-duck" amendment has advanced the great day.

THE radio industry in 1936 has shattered many of the records of the past, and the year will go into history as a twelve months' boom period for all branches of the radio business, according to Bond Geddes, vice president of the Radio Manufacturers Association.

PARIS, Dec. 11. -- Moygashel linens are being launched in interesting novelties for Spring and Summer. Transparent effects are being featured in these linens; chenille stripes are shown on a linen chiffon or a voile ground.

DETROIT is making what is believed to be the first organized attempt to find and eliminate the unsafe driver. After a ear of preliminary research the city has put into operation a clinic devoted exclusively to examining motor car drivers psychologically and physically.

WHEN good newspaper men die they go to towns that are always booming, where the big money is setting fancy and action free, turning beads, making news. The spirit of Dana is probably down in Washington, and Greeley is there, too Pulitzer, Bennett, Raymond, hover over New York.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 12. -- Yale, with victories over Boston University and St. Nicks to its credit, lost, 3 to 0, to the Boston Olympics tonight before 1,000 spectators in the New Haven Arena.

American education will be reminded this week of the contributions which religion has made and is still making to its advancement when the Jewish Theological Seminary of America starts its semi-centennial celebration Dec. 17.

Continuance of democracy as a militant faith to offset the rise of dictatorship in Europe, construed as a challenge to America, was urged last night by Dr. John Dewey, philosopher and educator, who spoke from Station WJZ on a program commemorating the ninetieth anniversary of the Central Synagogue of New York.

Christmas activities at Barnard College will center around the program of Christmas carols which will be broadcast from the college on Tuesday from 1:15 to 1:45 P.M. from station WEAF. During the second part of the program Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve will extend Christmas greetings to the undergraduates assembled in the auditorium and to alumnae and friends listening in.

Executives of social agencies and of women's clubs cooperating in the work of the Magistrates' Courts Social Service Bureau will be guests of honor at the first annual tea to be given by the group tomorrow at the Hotel Plaza. Mrs. Adeleine Adler Victorsen, chairman, will preside.
