SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 12. -- The Terrace Council, the senior honorary society at Union College, tonight sponsored the third Union College-Skidmore College freshman informal party of the year. This was the second to take place on the Union campus.

Though this is a second edition of a work that appeared in 1931, extensive revisions have been made throughout, and the fourth chapter, "Psychogenic Factors in Organic Diseases," has been replaced by two new chapters entitled "Psychic Influences on Body Functions" and "Recognition of Psychic Influences in Modern Medicine."

Obtaining delivery on reorders of gift merchandise is one of the most difficult problems confronting the retailer, according to a special report prepared for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. Manufacturers are unable to assure deliveries on reorders, as, in many cases, they are still working on original shipments.

Members of the Junior League Players are abandoning their usual custom of presenting their Christmas plays at the clubhouse of the New York Junior League and at the Heckscher Theatre, to give them at the various settlement houses in the city and at hospitals.
Squadron A defeated Governors Island, 10 to 4 1/2, in an exhibition polo game at the Squadron A Armory last night.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 12. -- When the New York State Water Power and Control Commission ruled a year ago that the City of New York could not tap the surface water supplies of Nassau and Suffolk Counties it may have averted a crisis similar to that which confronts Westchester County today.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12 (AP). -- Top Row, 1936 winner of the $100,000 Santa Anita Handicap, drew top weight of 127 pounds today for the third running of the classic, scheduled for Feb. 27.

An encouraging subscription has been reported for the performance of "You Can't Take It With You" Thursday night at the Booth Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Child Study Association.

A luncheon and fashion show, followed by a tea dance, will be held this afternoon at the Montparnasse under the auspices of the cooperative committee of the Big Sisters in connection with the organization's appeal for funds to continue the aid which for the last thirty-three years has been given to underprivileged girls.

SAJO AND THE BEAVER PEOPLE," written by an author who is half Scotch and Ojibway Indian, has the friendly convincing quality of a tale told by word of mouth. "Grey Owl" has done much for the preservation of the beaver, and is in charge of beaver life in a Canadian national park.
HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 12. -- About one-fourth of the students at Trinity College here are indebted to the National Youth Administration for a means to continue their course of study.

LONDON, Dec. 12. -- Now that a "safe" King is on the British throne, upholders of old-fashioned tradition in morals and society, in religion and politics are preening themselves on what they regard as a great and lasting triumph.

LONDON, Dec. 12. -- It is seldom that the royal family denies statements appearing in the newspapers, but the departure of Edward, Duke of Windsor, has been quickly followed by a disclaimer on the part of the Queen Mother concerning Mrs. Simpson.

With weather conditions somewhat of a retarding factor, Christmas trade in the local area did not quite measure up to expectations last week. On at least one day during the period department store sales here fell behind 1935 volume, and store executives said yesterday the indications are that trade for the first half of the month will average about 5 per cent ahead of last year.

A sustained burst of scoring near the end of the first half gave Fordham a sufficient margin to ward off a late attack by Yale and the Rams won their second basketball game of the season last night at their home gymnasium, defeating the Elis, 36 -- 33.

The book follows in time those classics, "The Oxford Book of Verse" and "The Oxford Book of Victorian Verse." edited by Sir Arthur Quiller-Couch. But it does not follow them in method (except that it is chronological ) or temper.
ROME, Dec. 12 (AP). -- Accords between Germany and Italy to split up business in the Danubian States and to exchange goods rather than money were announced today.

James J. Braddock, world heavyweight champion, and his German challenger, Max Schmeling, former holder of the title, yesterday signed articles before a special meeting of the State Athletic Commission to fight for the title in the Madison Square Garden Bowl, Long Island City, the night of June 3 next, ending a muddled situation, with concessions made on all sides.

The united group of the New York University Faculty, Alumni and Varsity Glee Clubs, numbering a hundred choristers under the direction of Alfred M. Greenfield, gave its tenth annual concert last night at the Town Hall.

MANHASSET, L.I., Dec. 12. -- Led by Ogden Phipps, the national champion, and George H. (Pete) Bostwick, polo player and steeplechase rider of international fame, New York qualified with Boston for the final round of the eighth annual court tennis doubles tournament for the Payne Whitney Memorial Trophy today.

IT is almost certain that the Metropolitan Opera Association's tour next Spring will be longer than it has been in a number of years. With Cleveland asking for a full week of performances, Boston sure to have at least ten days and Baltimore half a week, the total tour should be at least three weeks.
Is world agriculture on the upgrade? This inquiry naturally suggests itself to all of us associated in the work of the International Institute of Agriculture.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12. -- Retail trade broadened its gains over last year in the week just ended. Sales of the larger department stores averaged better than 20 per cent over the like 1935 period. Executives said the buying movement was remarkable for its breadth and that practically all departments shared in the upturn.

ALTHOUGH we happen to regard "Winterset" and "Rembrandt" as two of the finest pictures produced this year, it is only fair to warn you that Hollywood has serious doubts about their success. One eminently practical producer, who had seen both, conceded they would be "critics' pictures" and smiled commiseratingly as he said it.
SEA ISLAND, Ga. -- With many improvements nearing completion, added impetus is given the sports and social programs at this coastal resort.

NANKING. -- A carefully selected group of sons and daughters of high chiefs in the border provinces of China are now undergoing training at a school in Nanking. Many of them are princes and princesses of Mongolia.

THIS is the first regular edition of the intimate journals written by Gauguin in the South Seas and dated, at the end, Atuana, Marquessas, January-February, 1903, the year in which the artist died. Some years ago a small limited edition for subscribers only was brought out under the imprint of Liveright.

BERLIN, Dec. 12. -- Trading on the Boerse was quiet and weak today. Heavy industrials showed some signs of strength at the close, Hoesch gaining 1/2 point and Mansfeld 1. Chemicals were mixed, I.G. Farben gained 1 point. Electricals showed weakness in a small turnover.
PINEHURST, N.C. -- Field trial events of the Pointer Club of America close with this week-end.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12. -- Horace C. Coleman, Norristown banker, manufacturer and philanthropist, gave $7,022,875 to relatives and charity under three deeds of trust before his death Aug. 11, according to first accountings filed in the Orphans Court of Montgomery County today by Aaron S. Swartz, Norristown attorney, the trustee.

A charming little book in which the author constructs out of treasured memories a picture of Southern Ireland that is vivid and full of interest. His home was on a farm in Tramore in Munster. Tramore Bay, with its long stretch of golden sand, was one of his earliest recollection.

MR. DUTTS examination of world politics since 1918 leads him to certain conclusions which begin to emerge early in his book and become increasingly prominent as his exposition proceeds. If the present imperialist order, inseparably bound up with capitalism, continues, another war is inevitable, for the basic policy of both capitalism and imperialism is war.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 12. -- A protest against a reported attempt to remove Dr. Glenn Frank from the University of Wisconsin presidency was made tonight by Zona Gale Breese, author and alumna, of Portage, Wis. In a statement sent from New York she said: ...

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. l2. -- The Christmas festivities at the College of New Rochelle will come to a climax here next Thursday evening with the traditional formal dinner in Maura Hall, followed by a party for the seniors in Chidwick Auditorium and a series of tableaux presented by Props and Paint, the college dramatic society, it was announced yesterday.

DR. KUNKEL considers that the question "What does it mean to grow up?" is, from the perspective of character study, analyzable into two complementary questions which are framed in more fundamental terms: "How can I learn the art of swallowing bitter medicine?" and "How am I to prevent myself from forsaking an objective attitude for an egocentric one in my efforts to cope with the difficulties of life?"

Unless the majority of New York's 7,000,000 "villagers" overcome the deficiencies of their "small-town minds" and develop a more sophisticated, universal outlook, New York, together with other large cities, will eventually dwindle in size, Professor Joseph K. Hart of Teachers College declared in a survey, entitled "City Dwellers With Small-Town Minds," made public yesterday.
TORONTO, Dec. 12. -- Lester Patrick's young New York Rangers batted out their second victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight, winning by 5 -- 3.

THIS time of year, when inland streams in the Northern United States are frozen or on the verge of freezing, the Sea Scouts are busy with their indoor program. Their winter meetings ashore are as interesting and instructive as their Summer activities afloat.

WASHINGTON, in 1880, was discussing with avidity the authorship of that anonymous novel "Democracy," which exposed with such shrewd understanding and such malicious cruelty the corruption of American politics and the vapidity of official society.

Columbia and Springfield battled through forty minutes of fast, rough and thrilling basketball last night in the Morningside Heights gymnasium and at the final gun, the Massachusetts five had the game, 35 -- 34.

A RATHER unattractive, faded and rubbed bit of stamped paper which wealthy philatelists and even kings have sought to own, because it is presumed to be the only one of its kind in the world, may find a permanent place on exhibition in Washington.

A New York conception of Dionysia, the Athenian festivals in honor of the Greek god of wine, will be presented on Saturday at the Ritz-Carlton when a Champagne Tasting Night will be given under the auspices of the Women's Committee of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association.
TO those of you who do not believe in "miracles" there are commended today the stories of Helen and Laura, two of the Hundred Neediest Cases of 1935 --

WELLESLEY, Mass., Dec 12. -- The Wellesley College Art Museum has just received a mosaic pavement taken from a fifteen-century-old villa recently discovered near Antioch, Syria. The trustees of the college have authorized its restoration by a group of mosaic experts and it will be laid in one of the museum galleries, to take its place with other art treasures belonging to the college.

THE beavers are most consistently the heroes of this book of wilderness experience and woodland lore: Jelly Roll, the Queen Beaver, "jovial, wayward and full of whims;" Rawhide, her consort, "calm, silent and inscrutable;" their children and an occasional "aboriginal" that strays in from the wild and becomes an inmate of the beaver colony.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Dec. 12. -- Painter Hall at Middlebury College, oldest college building in Vermont, will be reoccupied by fifty undergraduate men next week when the reconstruction of the building will be completed. The ground floor will also provide office suites for the deans of both men's and women's colleges, the director of admissions for women, the registrar, the Spanish Department, editor and the superintendent of real estate and grounds.

MADRID, Dec. 12. -- The present session of the Council of the League of Nations at Geneva and the Anglo-French effort to mediate the Spanish conflict have stirred very definite reactions here, but they are all unfavorable. There is certainly a great desire for peace, but only for peace with victory.

The Hapag Lloyd liner Hamburg found her way up the bay into Hudson River and to her pier in the thick fog Friday afternoon when other ships were held at Quarantine. The explanation was that Captain William Drechsel, marine superintendent of the line, had practiced a role as official guide of fog-bound ships for several years and found his talents valuable in Friday's weather.

Mayor La Guardia yesterday renewed his campaign for lower liability insurance rates for New York City auto owners. He warned insurance companies that these reductions, if and when granted, must not be as "insignificant" as those recently granted to taxicab owners.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 12. -- Taking his barriers in faultless style, Ivanhoe, 9-year-old roan gelding owned by Mrs. Robert Gussenhoven of White Plains, had the championship rosette pinned to his bridle as he triumphed in the jumper sweepstakes at the seventh annual Boulder Brook Club's horse show in the club's spacious indoor arena tonight.

This book differs from the ordinary run of "Psychiatric Primers Simplified for the Tired and Neurotic Business Man and His Wife" in several important respects First of all, the author stresses the vital distinction between "bringing up" a child and letting him "grow up."

HOT SPRINGS, Ark. -- With hotels declaring that advance reservations for the Winter are the largest in ten years, and with new highs already reached in the number of baths given at the government-controlled spa institutions, preparations are under way for a record tourist season here.

Following Friday's profit-taking movement, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered yesterday and the December touched 12.70 cents a pound, the highest figure of the week. January moved upward sharply and gained almost $1 a bale, while the list ended with a net improvement of 7 to 18 points.

For the first time in American history. Labor party electors will cast their ballots for a successful Presidential candidate when six electors representing the American Labor party go to Albany tomorrow for the meeting in the Senate chambers at which New York's forty-seven Electoral College votes will be cast for President Roosevelt.

WESTMINSTER ABBEY is to have a new organ, the latest in a long series. There is presumptive evidence that organs were used in King Edward the Confessor's great church, which was begun in 1050 and consecrated in 1065, the year before the Battle of Hastings.

THE Fiji Islands, China, Japan and Australia are vieing for the attention of American radio audiences these cold December mornings. The signals often are so loud it is next to impossible to overlook them on the all-wave dial.

ALTHOUGH Wycherley does not exactly reign today, "The Country Wife" is back on the boards, 263 years after the original production, and Ruth Gordon is giving a brilliant performance as Meg Pinchwife. For men are still false and women vain, and money is still a sore decayer of your confounded virtue; and, although Evelyn does not specifically make the point, conversation among the wits is still ribald.

I write to you with regard to the review of my book on Metternich, published by the Yale University Press, and reviewed by Shepard Stone in your paper on Oct. 4. The review is most flattering and has given me the greatest pleasure, but I feel that I must make quite clear the point which, as stated by Mr. Stone, seems to me to lead to a misapprehension.

The interest of Eastern turf followers turns again to the Florida Winter racing season, which begins tomorrow at Tropical Park, Miami. This session, which annually leads the way for the sport in the peninsular State, will last for twenty-six days.
SHANGHAI, Sunday, Dec. 13. -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek has been seized by General Chang Hsueh-liang in Shensi Province in an effort to force the Nanking Government to declare war against Japan.

BERLIN, Dec. 11. -- Somewhere a phonograph is playing "Silent Night, Holy Night" -- at least the music is that of the old Christian hymn; the words, on the contrary, are a new creation of the Ludendorff pagans. Christmas decorations are already up in the window of a shop on one of the chief streets of Berlin devoted to the sale of the various Nazi uniforms.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The first test of the constitutionality of the Robinson-Patman Act, approved on June 19 last and conferring upon the Federal Government broader powers than it ever before possessed to prevent price discrimination and trade practices held to be unfair, may arise from a formal hearing by the Federal Trade Commission that began this week in Boston and then was shifted to Chicago.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 12. -- Princeton University's basketball team chalked up its third straight victory and handed Rider College its first defeat tonight, 22 -- 15. Nearly 3,000 fans packed the Central High court to watch the benefit contest.

AS all cinema observers knew, it was time for a cycle to come along. Another is here -- the Deep South cycle, you might call it. Producers and writers alike have turned their attention to the aspects of Dixie, and there's scarcely a studio in Hollywood that hasn't a story of the South in production.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12. -- Retail sales in local department stores surged forward this week and averaged 25 per cent higher than in the corresponding period last year. Virtually everything was in demand, with emphasis on Christmas gift merchandise.
DALLAS, Dec. 12 (AP). -- Open subsidizing of athletes for the Southwest Conference was proposed before the seven-man governing body today.

KNOWING the life and works of Eddie Dowling, you must have guessed that sooner or later he would be thinking about a musical show again. He is, and it has gone as far as this: For the last fifteen days or so, he and James Montgomery have been at work on a libretto, Joseph McCarthy on the lyrics and James Hanley on the score.
Montauk Junior High of Brooklyn and Junior High School 40 of Queens gained the final round of the junior high school city championship basketball tournament yesterday.

Members of the junior committee of the People's Chorus of New York, working toward the success of the organization's annual Christmas song festival and dance to be held Friday night in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, have arranged a dinner party for members of the committee and friends at Le Mirage before the festival.

TELEVISION broadcasts from atop the Empire State Building have been discontinued to facilitate changes in the apparatus. It is expected that shortly after the first of the year image broadcasts will be resumed, but later another shut-down will be ordered to afford the engineers opportunity to adjust the equipment to handle 441-line pictures.

A recent editorial in THE TIMES discusses the lack of cooperation among those engaged in cancer research. It is noted that brilliant individualists are working independently in place of coordinating their efforts, and an appeal is made for teamwork. In the list of workers no mention is made of clinicians.

WARSAW, Poland, Dec. 12. -- Polish nationals participating in the Spanish Civil War will lose their citizenship, the official Monitor Polski has announced, at the same time recalling that the provisions of the Polish Citizenship Act stipulate this consequence of service in a foreign armed force without the government's sanction.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Public welfare officials who are faced with the problem of giving effect to the Social Security Act in their home States and cities, met here today and discussed the questions of raising money to cooperate with the Social Security program, choosing personnel and other problems raised by the law.

Starting their purchases three to four months earlier than usual, buyers of important textile lines have placed the largest volume of advance Fall business since the war, manufacturers and selling houses reported here yesterday. The result of this active demand, created by rising prices and fear of a scarcity, has been a sold-up condition for numerous mills for the greater part of next year.

Three New York University music organizations will present Christmas concerts during the next two weeks. The Music Education Chorus of 210 voices, under the direction of Professor Luther Goodhart, will give its program next Friday morning at 11 A.M. in the University Auditorium, Washington Square, East.

VIENNA, Dec. 12. -- The Duke of Windsor appears unlikely to find in Austria the seclusion he seeks. The mere indication that he might come to Austria sent a score of newspaper men scurrying to the Tyrol.

IT is not unusual for the tourist to see, in Guatemala and Salvador, the great crown of a palm protruding from the bowl of a wild fig tree. Literally speaking, the fig tree has enveloped and absorbed the palm.

HAVANA. -- The spirit of good-will generated by the Pan-American Conference at Buenos Aires has given hope to American business men in Cuba and American exporters that some revision will be made in the reciprocity treaty between Cuba and the United States.

VASLAV NIJINSKY was the greatest dancer in living memory. It may well be that those enthusiasts were right who hailed him as the greatest dancer who ever lived. For a few years his star shone with almost incredible brilliance throughout the Western World, and then it faded swiftly into darkness. For nearly two decades he has been insane.

IN these sophisticated days, appreciation of fine workmanship is increasing Decorators need, to give the final touch to a room, objects which are so excellent that one does not easily tire of them. A pair of metal book ends for a desk, a glazed bowl for flowers, or candlesticks for a festive board these are trifles, perhaps, but when they are valid expressions of modern art and craftsmanship they become important.

The annual nation-wide birthday ball for the President will be held on Jan. 30 in celebration of President Roosevelt's fifty-fifth birthday, it has been announced by Colonel Henry L. Doherty, national chairman of the committee in charge.

Bonds maintained a firm undertone yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, with the turnover less than Saturday the week before. Activity continued mostly along speculative lines, with attention again devoted to selected South American dollar loans and a few of the convertible industrial issues.

WINGING its way swiftly southward the great twin-motored Douglas passenger plane begins to lose altitude for its landing at Nanking. The huge silver-colored ship is en route from Chungking. head of navigation on the Yangtse River, to Shanghai, the great foreign-controlled city on the China coast, and its schedule permits only a two-minute pause at the capital of China.

GREENSBORO, N.C., Dec. 12. -- The sophomore class at the Woman's College of the University of North Carolina will present "Divinity," a pageant of the Holy Nativity, as arranged by Leonard Young and Daniel Williams, next Wednesday evening in Aycock auditorium.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The Polish Ambassador and Countess George Potocka will entertain at the first of their official dinners at the embassy on Jan. 6. Additional guests from the official, residential and diplomatic sets are asked later for a musicale.

WINTER or Summer, Americans can find in their own land a comfortable beach resort. But while, in one latitude or another, vacationists have all-season facilities for bathing and playing at the seashore, it requires constant oversight to insure that our popular beaches are kept intact.

EASTON, Pa., Dec. 12. -- The Lafayette College "Decade of Progress" fund for $500,000, signalizing ten years of the administration of Dr. William Mather Lewis as president, has already reached the $50,000 mark, according to officials of the drive today.
SARASOTA, Fla., Dec. 12. (AP). -- The will of John Ringling, filed for probate today, left his $1,000,000 home and the Ringling Museum of Art, valued as high as $20,000,000, to the State of Florida.

THE Brookings Institution in Washington is as important in the world of economic research as the Pasteur Institute is in the world of medicine. Its findings on studies connected with costs of production with labor earnings with employer-employe economic relationships are accepted throughout the world with the respect given to precise formulae worked out in laboratories of science.

ONE of the most frequent laments of the theatrical Jeremiahs during the recent lean years of depression was that which they generously wailed for the passing of an old friend, the Road. Gone forever, they bemoaned, were the good old days when a show could leave New York on a tour and make more money away from Broadway than it had on.

CASS CANFIELD, president of Harper Brothers, returned recently from his annual trip to Europe, bringing with him a budget of news about Harper authors. He reports that Rose Macaulay is working hard on a new novel, "I Would Be Private," which he hopes will be ready for publication in the Spring.

One of the most comprehensive plans ever developed to link retailers effectively with the housing movement will be launched with the holding of a housing forum and show under the sponsorship of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at its annual convention hers from Jan. 18 to 22.

NANKING, Dec. 12. -- Prince Teh, the most influential Mongol dignitary in Inner Mongolia and the nominal leader of the Mongol armies defending Suiyuan and Chahar Provinces, has sent a telegram to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek reiterating his loyalty to Nanking and declaring that his differences are only with the Suiyuan provincial officials, according to information from official sources here.

LONDON, Dec. 12. -- By virtue of having been the official instrument, if not the moving spirit, in the transfer of the British crown from the head of a recalcitrant King to that of his more amenable brother, Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin has achieved toward the end of his political career a position of authority which few would have believed possible.

MOSCOW, Dec. 12. -- The official estimate of Soviet gold production this year exceeds last year's production by 46 per cent and caused new speculation among foreign observers here as to the Soviet's actual annual gold output.
FROM England have come the most dramatic broadcasts of the week; in fact, of the year. "The King Abdicates" was one of the most historic flashes radio has ever carried.

EXTENSION of television research and increased power for broadcasting stations are provided for in the Japan Broadcasting Corporation's plans for 1937, according to a report from the United States Trade Commissioner at Tokyo to the Department of Commerce.

German cities have lately paraded their old war horses and have presented each of them with a little sack of oats and an enamal label with the word Kriegskamerad on it, so that anybody who meets one of these horses on the road will know it is a survivor of the great war.

Professional football's world series will be staged on the Polo Grounds gridiron today, starting at 2 P.M., when the ponderous Packers from Green Bay, Wis., Western champions of the National Football League, clash with the resurgent Boston Redskins, the Eastern titleholders, for the world crown of the lads who play for pay.

DANSVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 12 (AP). -- With the public schools in this village barred to unvaccinated students, Dansville and the near-by city of Hornell today continued stringent measures to combat the spread of an epidemic of mild smallpox.

Five hundred and eighty-two high schools and academies in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut enrolled to date reported yesterday through their respective school contest managers that approximately 71,500 students are now entered in THE NEW YORK TIMES Constitution Essay Contest, which will have its formal opening on Feb. 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- A total of $772,874.39 for public aid to needy aged in New Mexico, Texas and Hawaii was announced by the Social Security Board today. To New Mexico was awarded $27,423.97; Texas, $735,000, and Hawaii, $10,450.42.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP). -- An Agricultural Department expert said today that a plan for Federal crop insurance, which was being prepared by a commission under Secretary Wallace, would guarantee farmers 50 to 75 per cent of their average yields.

TIME was when people who wrote about the future almost always pictured it in terms which would be highly satisfactory to their readers. That is to say, they thought of a new environment which would gratify desires established under an old environment which it did not closely resemble.

APPLICATIONS are being received for the third MacDowell Club amateur chamber music competition. Auditions will be held in March. The object of the competition is to stimulate and encourage non-professional musicians to form chamber music groups.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Senator Carter Glass of Virginia faced a choice today between two powerful legislative posts and his decision is expected to have much bearing on the course of major legislation in the incoming Congress.

Announcement last week of bonds called for redemption before maturity were not as numerous as in the preceding week and, with few exceptions, were for smaller amounts of issues. In size, the largest were in the industrial and public utility categories, while most of the others were in the municipal, foreign and institutional groups.

GENEVA, Dec. 12. -- The Council of the League of Nations adopted unanimously tonight a resolution closing at least temporarily its discussion of the Spanish war danger by formally recognizing its existence, referring it for all practical purposes to the London non-intervention committee and blessing the recent Anglo-French mediation proposal.

The latest thing in strikes is the "sit-down." It is also called the "sit-in," "slay-in," the "folded-arm," or the "occupation" strike. Instead of walking out of their factory, store or office, the strikers simply remain at their machines, benches or desks, but stop work.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 12 (AP). -- Leading all the way, Vacillate, 9-year-old mare owned by A.C. Compton, barely lasted to gain a head decision over the favored Buck Langhorne in the running of the Mingo Purse, a sprint of about four and a half furlongs for all ages, feature of the closing day program at the Charles Town track today. Sun Sweep was third.

1. Edward the Eighth, of Great Britain, Ireland, and the British Dominions beyond the Seas. King, Emperor of India, do hereby declare My irrevocable determination to renounce the Throne for Myself and for My descendants * * *.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 11. -- Rheba Crawford, once the "Angel of (New York's) Broadway," sues Aimee Semple McPherson for a million-odd dollars, alleging slander and defamation of character.

The Composers Forum-Laboratory sessions will be discontinued during the holiday season. Because of the death of Jacob Schaefer, who was scheduled to appear at the meeting on Wednesday evening in the direction of his own oratorio, "Biro Bidjan," this forum has been postponed.

DURLIN, Irish Free State. Dec. 12. -- The Irish Free State acknowledged the accession of George VI to the throne of the British Commonwealth today after declaring his power In Irish affairs was limited to representing Ireland abroad.

Gardenia veitchi, commonly called the Cape Jessamine, and usually thought of as a greenhouse plant, is coming into favor as a choice specimen for the window gardens of amateurs. Although the gardenia is by nature not at home under ordinary house conditions, this exceptionally beautiful plant can be grown successfully by those who are willing to take pains to approximate the careful regulation of humidity, temperature and ventilation possible in the conservatory.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 11. -- Further development of Dutchess County as a suburban community for the New York City metropolitan area was forecast this week with a movement to make the activities of the Poughkeepsie Chamber of Commerce country-wide.

Perhaps the inspiration came from the fact that some of the latest women's hats look as if they. had been rescued, slightly crumpled, from an ashcan. Whatever its source, the fact is that New York has recently been flooded by feminine headgear known in the trade as "ashcan hats."

LIGHTHOUSES abandoned by the government have attracted landsmen as residences. When situated on a point of land on a coast in a resort region these towers are sought for Summer use, because generally they are remote from neighbors and overlook picturesque waters.

The American Steamship Owners Association refused to supply a spokesman to address the League for Industrial Democracy at a luncheon symposium on "Safety at Sea" yesterday at the American Women's Association, 361 West Fifty-seventh Street.

The Women's Field Army of the American Society for the Control of Cancer will hold a day's conference to launch the New York State division of the army tomorrow at the Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third :Street.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 12 (AP). -- A.M. Anderson, receiver for the National Bank of Kentucky of Louisville, filed suit today against 305 stockholders of the Bancokentucky Company asking recovery of double liability on the bank's stock. The bank failed on Nov. 17, 1930, and the Controller of the Currency ordered the stockholders to pay double liability of $4,000,000.

With the deadline for the filing of applications for Social Security account numbers seventy-two hours away, postal authorities announced last night that 85 per cent of the employe cards from this city had been returned but that returns from up-State were lagging far behind.

TOKYO, Sunday, Dec. 13. -- The seizing of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek by anti-Japanese rebels in China is considered here to have thrown the whole Far Eastern situation into confusion, the outcome of which it is impossible to foresee. Official quarters said the Japanese Government was most gravely concerned about immediate developments and possible future consequences of General Chang Hsueh-liang's rebellion. Official comment, however, was withheld until the situation becomes clearer.

THE names for Ireland are legion, and they stand as a sign and symbol for much of her history. Early legend has it that when the Milesians came to Ireland they found the country ruled by three kings of the Tuatha De Danann, whose queens were Eire, Fodla and Banba, and each of these queens has given Ireland a poetic name.

The air corps of the United States Army is now sixth in relative rank in aviation today, Major Gen. Oscar Westover, chief of the Air Corps, told members of the Balloon Officers of the World War at the annual reunion dinner last night at the Hotel Montclair.

A large group of young women headed by Miss Muriel Langmore are aiding in the sale of boxes and seats for the performance of "Tristan und Isolde" with Kirsten Flagstad and Lauritz Melchior in the leading roles the afternoon of Jan. 20 at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over to raise funds for Sir Wilfred Grenfell's Mission in Labrador and Newfoundland.

MONTCLALR, N.J., Dec. 12. -- Larry Kelley, captain of the 1936 Yale football team, arrived late for the annual Yale Barn Party staged at Nick Roberts's tonight. But he had a good excuse. The famous Eli end made a flying trip from New York, where he starred in the Yale-Fordham basketball game.

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- Social interest here this week will center around the annual Cruise Ball to be held next Saturday evening at the George Vanderbilt Hotel. Sponsored by the Asheville Junior League, this dance is considered one of the most outstanding held during the Christmas holidays.

QUITE unprecedented is the influx of new galleries established here this season. Last week two more were opened -- the Findlay Galleries, at 8 East Fifty-seventh Street, and the French Art Galleries, in the Fuller Building.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12. -- Co-captain Franny Murray, making his first basketball appearance of the season, helped Pennsylvania defeat Harvard in the opening of the Eastern Intercollegiate League competition at the Palestra tonight, 34 -- 31. It was the third straight victory for the Red and Blue.

The volume of retail trade in all five boroughs of New York in 1935 was $2,847,332,000, an increase of more than 20 per cent over 1933, but still more than 25 per cent below 1929, according to the final report of the business census for last year conducted by the Bureau of Census of the Department of Commerce, public yesterday. made day.

Underprivileged children aided by the various health stations maintained in many sections of the city by the New York Diet Kitchen Association will be the beneficiaries of the performance of "The Tales of Hoffman," with Grace Moore and Lawrence Tibbett in the leading roles, the night of Jan. 14 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

MOVED by the threatened extinction of the koala, the native Australian bear, Commonwealth dwellers are organizing to protect native animals. It is planned to approach the Federal Government for aid in a concerted move by the States to halt the serious fall in the numbers of native beasts and birds.

Dean Charles C. Williamson, in his annual report to President Nicholas Murray Butler, made public yesterday, announced that the Columbia University School of Library Service would inaugurate a new plan of administering achievement tests next year.

SEASON'S debuts by two of the leading figures in the American dance field have been scheduled for next Sunday evening, with a third performance by a dancer from Ecuador thrown in to further complicate the occasion.

THE one Hollywood prerogative of which Adolph Zukor avails himself is going about hatless. Iron-masters, shipping magnates and other iron-jawed Bashaws of industry wear derbies that appear riveted on. Voice goes that when Zukor is in New York he is bonneted with equal firmness.

SYDNEY, Australia. REMOTELY menacing in the cattle country of Western Queensland is the Cooper. known eloquently to the stockmen as "Tragedy Creek." There is tragedy in plenty surrounding the place, but "creek" is no word for it, for in the rainy season it stretches thirty miles across the hard clay surface of the land, forming vast lagoons which leave, as they recede, treacherous areas of seemingly firm land which are death-traps for cattle.

The Detroit Institute of Arts has received as a gift from Edsel Ford and the Founders Society an important painting believed to be the work of either Leonardo da Vinci or his teacher, Andrea Verrocchio.

A loud-speaker system by which firms placing orders with floor brokers on the New York Stock Exchange receive latest sales, quotations and other news from the trading floor faster than they are transmitted by the ticker has been developed and put into operation by Weicker Co.

All signs in the metropolitan area led to the snow setting in Madison Square Garden last night as another highly enthusiastic gathering of almost 13,000 jammed the Eighth Avenue plant to witness the finale of the first annual International Ski Meet and Winter Sports Show.

Charged with being a fugitive from justice from France, whence he escaped in 1924 after being sentenced to be guillotined for the murder of two men, a 42-year-old longshoreman was arrested yesterday afternoon as he sat in his parked automobile in front of the Supreme Court Building in Foley Square.
Final returns were tabulated last week showing the full extent of the New Deal victory:

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- The leading towns of the Berkshire Hills are ready for the expected invasion of the Winter sports crowd during the holidays and after the first of the year, when the railroads start the weekly operation of snow trains.

The educational campaign which the State Liquor Authority is waging and developments in the three years since repeal of the prohibition law will be reported by Mrs. John S. Sheppard, the only woman member of the board, before the Woman's Forum, meeting Friday at 11 A.M. in the Hotel Roosevelt.

TOKYO, Dec. 11. -- Damned with faint praise by the Japanese press, received abroad with cynical suspicions and answered by Russia and China with sharply hostile reactions, the German-Japanese pact aimed at Moscow and Nanking has come back on Tokyo like a boomerang.

Commodore Rudolf J. Schaefer was re-elected to head the Larchmont Yacht Club at the annual meeting of that organization last night. Two other new flag officers were chosen. They were Robert N. Bavier, as vice commodore, and Thomas L. Burton, rear commodore.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 12. -- Progress of the three educational institutions comprising Yale-in-China through thirty years was acclaimed here tonight at a celebration of the anniversary of the founding of the movement.

OUT of nihilism came Dada. Nihilism is almost as old as the human race, but Dada, its twentieth century bundle of neurasthenic chills and fever, uttered the first tentative yell of protest against every thing on earth in the Cabaret Voltaire in Zurich about two years after the World War started.

A three-alarm fire that swept an unoccupied five-story tenement house at 64 East 116th Street and destroyed the second floor of the adjacent tenement at No. 66 early last night caused four persons to be overcome by smoke and two firemen to be injured.

How shall society protect the legal rights of poor persons accused of crime -- presumably innocent, but unable to retain competent counsel, or to cope with the powerful machinery of prosecution? How shall the community deal with all accused persons -- rich or poor, innocent or guilty, gangster or falsely accused -- in so far as defense counsel is concerned?

WISE, Va., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Medical testimony concerning the cause of Trigg Maxwell's death became contradictory today as defense counsel for Edith Maxwell began the presentation of her case in the second trial of the 22-year-old school teacher.

WARRENTON, Va. -- The most elaborate social event of the holiday season here will be the ball at North Wales on Dec. 23, to which Mr. and Mrs. Arthur White of Chilton Farm, Middleburg, Va., have sent out invitations. The occasion will be the presentation to society of Miss Bettina Belmont, daughter of Mrs. White and late Raymond Belmont of Middleburg and New York.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 12. -- Retail trade continues to hold at a high level in the Eighth Federal Reserve district and many establishments state that it is only equalled in volume by 1929. Department stores report sales around 22 per cent ahead of last year.

Many parties will be given in advance of the first of the Dolphin Dances for the season on Saturday at the Pierre. Among the hosts and hostesses will be Mr. and Mrs. Henry Austin Clark, who will give a dinner for their daughter, Miss Elizabeth D. Clark, and Mrs. N. Johnson Van Vleck, who will entertain for her daughter, Miss Nancy Van Vleck.

A NEW hobby has appeared in which sea shells play a leading part. There has always been certain amount of interest in amateur conchology, which probably is the basis of this fad. Once the shells were sedately placed in cabinets or ensconced on the Mid-Victorian walnut "what-nots" and open corner cabinets.

While "the principle of diminishing returns has undoubtedly begun to operate to a minor degree," considerable opportunity for further expansion of chain variety stores is indicated in a comprehensive analysis of variety store merchandising, issued yesterday by Fiduciary Counsel, Inc.

NEVER before as in the past weeks has the symbolic nature of the British sovereignty been revealed with so blinding a light. Around the sovereign there have been breaking emotions that will roar their way through history for many a long year to come. There is, of course, intense interest in the man, but the reasons for that interest are found in what the man represents.

MADRID, Dec. 12. -- Fascist Insurgents have abandoned efforts to smash their way through Madrid's defenses and have resorted to an encircling "siege of starvation," the city's military leaders believed tonight.

Grand Street Settlement will be the beneficiary of a midwinter festival and dance the night of Jan. 15 at the Waldorf-Astoria. Proceeds will further the recreational and educational programs of the settlement among the under-privileged in a crowded district of the city.

Because a Sunday school teacher got the idea twenty years ago that she wanted to help the "shut-ins" of children's homes during the Christmas season, about 3,000 dolls and other toys will be given away this Christmas in thirty-seven of the city's child shelters.

BERLIN, Dec. 12. -- All Storm Troop companies received orders to stage a National Socialist Christmas of their own on the night of Dec. 21. The occasion is the ancient Germanic festival of Winter solstice. The same event is the occasion for one of the main annual festivals of the various Nordic pagan societies.

The committee of judges in the Philharmonic-Symphony Society's competition for short orchestral works -- the prize was $500 -- could not find any composition among the 132 submitted worthy of the prize. One honorable mention was awarded -- to Philip James for his "Bret Harte" overture, which will be performed and directed by Mr. Barbirolli shortly.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 12. -- The development of a program of athletics for all Princeton undergraduates, in which 88 per cent of the students now participate regularly, has been the great achievement of the first twenty-five years of the Department of Health and Physical Education of the university, Dr. Joseph E. Raycroft, organizer and retiring chairman of the department, said today in his final report.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 12. -- A new conception of university library science is evident in the efforts of the Syracuse University library to fit its activities to the needs of the students rather than to the demands of custom.

WHILE Christmas shopping continued to forge ahead in some sections, the increases over last year in several important areas fell below expectations and gave a spotty appearance to retail trade last week. The Middle West, New England and the Coast sections reported a high level of holiday sales.

"Santa Claus fever" already has gripped e juvenile set of New York and the General Postoffice at Thirty-third Street and Eighth Avenue is getting its share of letters to "Dear Santa." The address, of course, is the North Pole.

Two employes of Pechter's Baking Company, 469 Cherry Street, were held up and robbed of checks totaling $20,000, more than half of which were negotiable, and $200 in cash at East Broadway and Montgomery Street by an armed thug at noon yesterday. The thief escaped in a waiting automobile.

Competition in the Private Schools Hockey League got under way at the Brooklyn Ice Palace yesterday with the Brooklyn Prep sextet turning back St. John's Prep, 3 to 1. St. Francis Prep, scheduled to face Poly Prep in the second test, encountered Brooklyn Tech's jayvees in a non-league contest instead and played to a scoreless tie.

Mrs. Frank E. Simmons of 160 Henry Street, Brooklyn, will give a luncheon at her home on Friday for members of the committee for the motion picture entertainment Jan. 15 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music to benefit the Brooklyn Children's Museum.

IN his latest work Professor Adams offers both a precise and a concise analysis of our national economic system. It is particularly effective in answering the why and the wherefore of our bothersome business problems. To begin with, the author gives an excellent survey of the economic development of the United States.

Radio telephones are to be used in tuning up the challenger Endeavour II for her attempt to win the America's Cup next Summer. In line with his leaving no stone unturned in his effort to capture the cup, T.O.M. Sopwith has ordered radio systems installed on both the challenger and the first Endeavour, which will come to this country with her for their races off Newport to prepare the newer yacht for the international match.

A bronze bust done from memory by one of his former students will be presented to the New York Medical College and Flower Hospital Tuesday by the class of 1937 in honor of the late Dr. William Francis Honan, for forty years Professor of Surgery there.

Lucrezia Bori, for many years a prominent member of the Metropolitan Opera Company, will be the guest of honor at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria on Jan. 3, in recognition of her contribution to the cause of music in New York. Plans for the dinner were made at a meeting at the home of Mrs. Vincent Astor.

LONDON, Dec. 12 (Caadian Press). -- Downfall of Sunderland, Portsmouth and Brentford, leading contenders for the English Football League championship, and assumption by Charlton Athletic, fast-stepping London club, of the role of pace-setter gave soccer enthusiasts cause for speculation today.

The annual tea for the Cinderella Dance committee will be held next Sunday at the home of Mrs. Russell V. Cruikshank, 15 Monroe Place, Brooklyn. The Cinderella Dance was founded twenty-seven years ago by Mrs. James Guthrie Shaw of Manhattan, formerly of Brooklyn, for girls who have not yet made their debuts and their escorts.

Guiomar Novaes, the Brazilian pianist who long since won a large following in this city, gave a recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. She is a pianist of certain exceptional qualities, including a facile and brilliant technic and a femininity of approach which is to be valued as one of her distinctive attributes.

In "To and Again," now nearly ten years old, Mr. Brooks told an amusing and spirited tale of a group of farm animals who decided to migrate to Florida to escape the cold weather. His next two stories, however, failed to recapture the spontaneity of the first one: in "More To and Again" and "Freddy the Detective," the adventures tended to melodrama and the dialogue to cheapness.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Awards of engineering contracts totaling $3,929,251.87 were announced by the War Department today as follows:

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 12. -- The Starlight Terrace of Essex House here will be the scene on Wednesday of a dance being arranged by members of the Newark Junior League to follow the presentation of "Take It Away" by the Princeton Triangle Club at the Mosque Theatre.

LONDON -- There is no doubt that prosperity has returned to Britain if statistics just issued by the Post Office may be taken as criteria. The figures are part of a review of the work of the department during the last fiscal year and reveal transactions with the public amounting to more than four and a half billion dollars.

THE country-wide craze for cardboard picture puzzles which nearly unhinged the national mind three years ago has run its course, but the pastime of piecing together the more expensive jigsaw puzzles carries on quietly in many homes.

CONSTRUCTION of an extensive system of "freeways" in in the vicinity of New York, as the best permanent solution of the traffic problem on main highways, is advocated in a plan made public today by the Regional Plan Association.

Mr. ABBOTT LAWRENCE LOWELL comes to eighty years today in the soundest physical and intellectual health. He has not only shown his fitness to run an automobile but he is spry on his legs. Almost daily he proves, if sometimes to the anxiety of his friends, his ability to survive amid the innumerable herds of chariots of danger.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of Aug. 30 there is an illustrated article, "The English Village Speaks," about the town of Uttoxeter (pronounced Ux-eter). I know the place well. The article is good and so are the pictures, but one curious fact, which I should think would be of special interest to Americans, seems to have escaped notice.

Period furniture, Chinese porcelains, Georgian and early American silver, tapestries, and rugs from the estate of Malcolm Sumner, the collection of the late Carll H. DeSilver, and other sources, will be sold at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries on next Wednesday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday afternoons.

Guests at the Woman's Club of Upper Montclair, N.J., tomorrow afternoon will be taken back through the years to glimpse an old English Christmas party. The club lounge, redecorated to represent the drawing room of an English manor, will provide a background for a program of carols and Christmas readings.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- Tourist hotels are opening weeks earlier this vacation season as an unprecedented number of Winter visitors is pouring into St. Petersburg. The Soreno and Vinoy Park Hotels opened their doors yesterday, while the formal opening of the Jungle Hotel and Country Club will occur on Jan. 3, although guests are being received prior to that date.

PARIS, Nov. 28. AFTER the long success of his last play, "La femme en fleur," Denys Amiel has now given us another, of which the subject is essentially the same -- that subject being the attitude toward life and love of a modern upper middle-class French girl, who enjoys to the full the liberty, physical activity and independence which for middle-class French girls are so recent an acquisition.

TWO more "teleferiques," or cableways are being rushed to completion for this Winter's ski season in the neighboring Mont Blanc region. They were begun in anticipation of heavier traffic even before prospects of an inrush of American skiers soared with the announcement that "snow boat" service from New York would be opened this Winter.

Photographs of a number of famous American women, taken in the last forty years by Dr. Arnold Genthe, will go on exhibit for the first time in an exhibit to be opened Tuesday evening by the Panhellenic House Association, of which Mrs. A. Barton Hepburn is president.

THE six rural boys and girls acclaimed in Chicago this month as the healthiest of the year in 4-H Clubs in the United States had given that pledge, as have more than 5,000,000 other young Americans of the farm lands and the villages in the last two decades.
PARIS, Dec. 11. -- Late last Saturday evening Premier Leon Blum's Popular Front government encountered its first internal storm, and it has survived.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 12 (AP). -- A rare collection of Eugene Field relics will be on display when the birthplace of "the children's poet," restored to the period of his birth, in 1850, is opened Friday as a museum.

BOSTON, Dec. 12. -- New England business unquestionably is better than it has been at any time since the Autumn of 1929. From nearly all centers reports are heard of an excellent demand for goods at retail and sustained industrial operations.

LONDON, Dec. 12. -- With the Stock Exchange closed, money over the week-end was in moderate demand at one-half to three-quarters of 1 per cent. The discount market was firm, the three-month bill rate going as high as 11-16 per cent. The price of gold was 1/2d higher than yesterday, at 141s 10d a fine ounce, with only 196,000 of the metal sold in the open market.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12. -- Amid growing public demands for an end to the shipping tie-up, strikers and employers moved a little closer to the peace table today and the unions took another step toward relief for isolated Hawaii.

Carl von Ossietzky, German pacifist and editor recently released from a Nazi concentration camp, was hailed last night for his courageous sacrifices for the cause of peace by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University; Mayor La Guardia and others at a mass meeting in Cooper Union honoring the winner of the Nobel Peace Award.

WITH the rains over and Mexico's Winter tourist season just starting, Mexico, D.F., squats in the sunshine of her peak-girdled plateau and awaits the arrival of what promises to be a record number of American visitors, many driving through from the North in their own cars.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Through its Hydrographic Office the Navy Department has become a large-scale publisher. In addition to printing 480,593 nautical charts, the Hydrographic Office has distributed during the year more than 1,357,000 of its periodicals.

Speaking at a dinner of the Hudson County Bar Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night, General Hugh S. Johnson, former administrator of the NRA, asserted that the Sherman Anti-Trust Laws were outmoded and futile.

THE Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra will open its fourteenth year of Concerts for Young People, conducted by Ernest Schelling. The concerts this season will take the form of a "Musical World Tour," the first program being devoted to England and the Christmas season.

WHEN the talkative radiophone emerged from the World War as a practical instrumentality it appeared to have more possibilities than for point-to-point conversation, although many took it for granted such was to he its role in communication, probably because of the way wireless was used.

LONDON. Nov. 27. ALL the leading representatives of Scottish life were in the audience which welcomed the production in Edinburgh last Saturday night of "The Boy David" -- the first full-length play written by Sir James Barrie in the course of the last sixteen years.

SALAMANCA, Spain, Dec. 12. -- With early morning temperatures below freezing, the Moroccan troops, who might have been expected to suffer most, do not seem to mind. The fact is that Moroccan Winter temperatures often are lower, so the Moors are stoical and accustomed to the cold.

THE department more Santa Claus. so he admit, is feeling a bit anachronistic this Christmas season. Garbed in his conventional red, with white beard and rouged cheeks, he stanos a lone survivor of the reindeer age in a toy world of airplanes and Hollywood dolls.

THE Russian school of composers, one of the most recent in its flourishing and still continued by a vigorous youthful growth, has received much attention from biographers and critics since its rise to prominence. Its better known names of the last century are beginning to lose a little of their luster, even before the music signed by them had been thoroughly explored.

The sailing of the Italian liner Rex from Pier 59, North River, yesterday with 1,753 passengers, who will spend the holidays in Europe, was delayed one hour when a crowd of 5,000 visitors broke down fences and gates and stormed the gangways to the ship.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 12. -- A sustained belief that Southern New England cannot prosper unless the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad is successful has focused the public eye upon the efforts of that system to rescue itself from the depression plight which sent it into a reorganization status nearly a year ago.

THE Carnegie Institution of Washington maintains one of the great research organizations of the world. It conceives it to be one of the functions not only to increase the store of human knowledge but to tell the technically informed multitude what it has done.

MILAN. SEVERAL local novelties have marked the early offerings of the Milan concert season. The Scala Orchestra did Renzo Bossi's descriptive "symphonic picture" of "Il Palio di Siena"; Zandonai's "Colombina," an overture on the theme of the familiar "Carnevale Veneziano"; Busoni's "Rondo Arlecchinesco" and Reger's "Island of the Dead" (the third of his four poems inspired in the Boecklin canvases).

A record performance by Peter Kurlak of Stuyvesant and the defeat of the Evander Childs team, which had been tied for the lead in the Manhattan-Bronx-Richmond senior high school P.S.A.L. swimming championship, were highlights of the tenth series of dual meets conducted yesterday in the seventy-five-foot pool of De Witt Clinton.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 12. -- Mr. and Mrs. Horace Taylor Cook of Princeton were hosts at a large tea and reception at their home today to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Mary Taylor Cook.

The public utility companies that come under the regulatory authority of the Federal Power Commission, either as licensees under the old Federal Water Power Act of 1920 or as interstate companies under Title II of the Public Utility Act of 1936, are preparing now to introduce the new unified system of accounts that the commission has ordered for adoption by Jan. 1.
ALBANY, Dec. 12. -- New York State's Electoral College will convene here Monday at noon to cast the forty-seven electoral votes for President Roosevelt and Vice President Garner.

Although I spend the better part of my spare time studiously avoiding listening to the radio, I cannot, in the very nature of things, avoid hearing some portion of the material that is incessantly being fired at us over the air waves.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Since the Supreme Court began its new term two months ago and, more particularly, since the election, the court's every order and decision have been scanned to detect any indication that the Justices have had a change of heart toward the New Deal or have been influenced by the election returns.

BIOGRAPHIES of more than a thousand British authors fill this thick volume which covers so great a century in English literature. Most of the sketches are short, but there has been a general effort both to make a really lifelike presentation of these writers and to offer a sound, though brief, critical judgment of their work. The book is thus genuinely interesting.

Members of the Mask and Wig Club of the University of Pennsylvania will present performances of their annual production, "This Mad Whirl," a satirical revue, the afternoon and night of Jan. 9 at the New York Hippodrome.

NOW is the time when many Northern sportsmen who enjoy yachting, hunting and fishing in an unusual tropical background start for the Bahamas. The yachting season begins about the first of the year, for during January, February, March and April there is little likelihood of the sailor's encountering the hurricanes which occasionally sweep across the Caribbean.

The response to the appeal for The Hundred Neediest has been such that the first hundred "cases" have been provided for. But the Fund has never since 1914 stopped at the hundred mark. The "Hundred Neediest" became the "gathering word" for other hundreds whose need made each in turn the neediest.

LONDON. ONE of London's oldest inns, The Bricklayers' Arms, which has had a distinguished place in English history is to be renovated and modernized. There will be new furnishings and a much-needed alteration of the interior, although the building's familiar facade will not be changed.

Champion canaries and other feathered aristocracy from twelve States basked under the admiring gaze of hundreds of bird lovers and fanciers yesterday as they competed for prizes at the opening of the Empire Cage Bird Association's grand national two-day show at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 12 (AP). -- "Looks like it may be a battle of punchers," drawled stoical Joe Louis, Detroit bomber, as he worked out lightly today for his ten-round bout with Eddie Simms, Cleveland heavyweight, Monday night on The Cleveland News Christmas Fund show.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The enrollment in the Works Progress Administration educational system, totaling 1,324,144 persons who require 34,440 teachers, is larger than the enrollment of all the colleges and universities in the country, said Harry L. Hopkins today in making public a survey of the WPA educational program.

THE observances of the fiftieth anniversary of Liszt's death in 1886 have been in this country very few. In New York, where the Philharmonic-Symphony and the visiting orchestras are concerned, they have been negligible.

Mrs. Grace Morrison Poole, past president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, now dean of Stoneleigh College, and Mrs. Walter S. Comly and Mrs. William H. Purdy, past presidents of the New York Federation, will serve on an advisory board to the American home department of the State Federation, according to an announcement by its chairman, Mrs. Bert W. Hendrickson.

VALENCIA, Spain, Dec. 12. -- The Ministry of Marine of the Leftist government issued a communique tonight saying that its submarine C-3 had been torpedoed and sunk. The C-3, the Ministry asserted, was torpedoed by another submarine, "evidently foreign."

IF, with the astonishing speed at which changes occur in sports seasons, the football campaign of 1936 is already back down long and echoing corridors, buried in the dim recesses of time in any follower of football's mind, this is in slight error. There remains a detail to be finished up before the sideline markers can be laid aside and the locker room boy can check up on the missing shoulder pads.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- A draft of proposed legislation which would embody the three-point program for industry as adopted yesterday by the Council for Industrial Progress will be started within the next week, according to George L. Berry, the President's Coordinator for Industrial Cooperation.

Engagements of $2,731,000 of gold abroad for shipment here were reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. They consisted of $1,683,000 taken in Switzerland, $627,000 in England and $421,000 in India.

LOWELL, Mass., Dec. 12 (AP). -- Locks and canal officials reported today that the Merrimack River was rushing through here at a rate of 15,000 cubic feet a second, an increase of 7,000 cubic feet in twenty-four hours.

TOKYO, Dec. 12. -- The newspaper Jiji Shimpo predicts Foreign Minister Hachiro Arita will have to resign before the Diet debates begin in January if the Soviet Union still refuses to ratify the fisheries treaty. Failure of the fisheries treaty will give such a weapon to the government's enemies that the Cabinet will have the greatest difficulty in surviving the session unless Moscow relents.

While trade in many sections of the country last week was the heaviest in comparison with any corresponding period since 1929, as the surge of holiday buying continued to gain momentum, unfavorable weather conditions served to temporarily retard business in some districts.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11. -- Mayor S. Davis Wilson's renewal of his earlier drive against vice and crime, marked by threats of police shake-ups, by orders to arrest gamblers and by enlistment of a commission of clergymen to investigate and make recommendations, is, in a sense, history repeating itself.

Despite his position as a commentator on Nietzsche, Oscar Levy is clearly wrong in taking issue with your statement that "Nietzsche developed Darwinism to the full and preached a doctrine of brutality: the doctrine that the world belongs to the strong."

The wall-garden, with its great mats of white, yellow and lavender blossoms in early Spring, need not lose its beauty when the height of the flowering is past. If well planned, the wall-garden will show some color all Summer, and even in Winter will display foliage and trailers that are brightly green against patches of snow.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Dec. 12. -- Christmas parties and other pre-holiday events, always a regular feature of college life at Bryn Mawr at this time of year, will be increased in number this year as a result of the activities of new undergraduate clubs.

There is no welcome quite so intense as that of a stockholder claiming a lost dividend check. He is the ghost of Hamlet's father, seeking revenge. He is a pirate, he is to be viewed with suspicion, he is probably obtaining money under false pretenses. All this is a case that came under my notice recently.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 12. -- The executive board of the New Jersey Federation of Labor went on record tonight in opposition to Labor's Nonpartisan League of New Jersey, thus seriously damaging prospects for the creation of an independent labor party at the league's first convention, Jan. 10.

ALL the truth that any guide to Chinatown can tell you, you can see -- and smell -- for yourself," remarks the Chinese journalist and civic reformer who now shows us "Chinatown Inside Out." And Chinese vice is not at all strange and glamorous, he adds, but, like most vice, quite commonplace.

LOUISVILLE, Dec. 11. -- Golden burley tobacco leaf has been pouring into forty markets in Kentucky all week and 100,000 farmers have been riding their "jolt wagons" home with golden returns. The price of Kentucky's chief money crop is the highest since 1928, and in some cases since the post-war high market of 1919, when an all-time record was established.

LONDON, Dec. 12. -- A small group of strongly pro-American members of the House of Commons is going to have a private, informal dinner on Tuesday to form a committee for the study of Anglo-American relations with a view to furthering every effort to improve them.

NEW varieties of tropical fish, new marine plants and new types of aquarium equipment are creating unusual interest in New York's colony of indoor fishermen, as collectors turn from outdoor hobbies to the annual tank cleaning, sure harbinger of the tropical fish season.

WRITING from Beaufort Farms, Cecil, Md., J. Stanley Fraser takes issue with recent statements concerning the application of Diesel power to aircraft in a resume of an article by Jerome C. Hunsacker and George J. Meade on "Around the Corner in Aviation." He says in part:

PARIS, Dec. 12. -- Britain and France today started to prepare the second step in their plan for mediation of the Spanish conflict. Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos, conferring with Sir George Russell the British Ambassador, Clerk, over the replies now at hand from all the nations consulted, decided that there was sufficient unity of views to push the action further.
LONDON, Dec. 11. -- As the storm aroused by the fascination of Simpson subsides two questions of moment are left prominent in the wake.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 12. -- The Princeton hockey team scored its third consecutive victory of the season in recording a one-sided 5 -- 1 triumph over the Boston University skaters today before 600 persons in the Hobey Baker Memorial rink.

WASHINGTON. -- Seventy-eight schools for the blind will receive 45,000 Braille maps made under WPA auspices at the Perkins Institution for the blind at Watertown, Mass. The maps are expected to fill a long existing need.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- This island, accustomed for the past two years to a four-and-a half-months' season and previously to one much shorter, has donned the habiliments of hostess unusually early and made all arrangements to entertain its colonists for six months.

It was the International Composers' Guild, founded in 1921 by the composer Edgar Varese, that presented the American premiere of Schoenberg's "Pierrot Lunaire" on Feb. 4, 1923, at the Klaw Theatre, New York.

With Captain Milton Schulman setting the pace in a second-half rally, the N.Y.U. varsity basketball team defeated a smooth-working St. Francis College quintet, 29 to 23, last night before a crowd of 1,000 at the University Heights Gymnasium.

Mr. and Mrs. George William Gordon of Ardsley-on-Hudson, N.Y. gave a tea dance and reception here yesterday afternoon at the Cosmopolitan Club to introduce to society their youngest daughter, Miss Stella Walker Gordon. Receiving with the debutante were her sisters, Mrs. Albert Bristol Turner, the former Miss Virginia Gordon, and Miss Alice Neale Gordon, who made her debut at the Cosmopolitan Club two years ago.

CRIES of "Achtung! Achtung!" may be heard in Manhattan's busiest shopping centers these days, despite the fact that Fifth Avenue and Broadway are both a long way from snowy mountainsides. Borax-covered slides, effective substitutes for snow-laden slopes, have been set up in several department stores and sporting-goods shops, and large numbers of eager tyros are learning the fine points of skiing right in the heart of the city.

CHESTER, Pa., Dec. 12. -- With the assurance of Governor Earle that picketing would be permitted as long as the activities of pickets were peaceful, striking employes of the Sun Shipbuilding and Drydock Company re-formed their lines today outside the company's plant here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Though the WPA is being drastically cut it is not likely to be completely demobilized until the bulk of the unemployed have found private jobs. This is the assurance that comes from WPA Administrator Harry L. Hopkins's office after a week or more of conflicting reports as to what the Federal Government's next step in relief would be.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 12. -- Judge M.A. Masmanno haled from jail into church today seventy-seven convicted liquor-drinking automobile drivers and preached a funeral sermon over the body of a penniless victim.

Market Commissioner William Fellowes Morgan Jr. charges that "political opposition" in the Board of Aldermen is holding up action on his plans to take the pushcarts off the Manhattan streets and house the peddlers in inclosed markets like that recently opened on upper Park Avenue.

THERE was comment in this column recently on how great are the chances against ever holding an entire thirteen-card suit, even if you play bridge every day of your life. The most inveterate bridge player will hardly play more than 100,000 hands during his lifetime, and the chance of holding a thirteen-card suit is only one in 158,000,000.

LONDON, Dec. 12. -- Strube in a cartoon in The Daily Express today depicts a crowd outside Buckingham Palace singing "God Save the King." Amid the forms of everyday people gazing hatless and open-mouthed at the palace is the figure of Edward, clad like the crowd and singing lustily with the rest.

Arthur E. Barton of Brooklyn, former president of the Waterway League of America and now one of the A.P.B.A. directors of the New York region, is impatient, as are most power yachtsmen, over the delays in obtaining public boat basins for New York City.

SOME day a statistician will compute how much money the travel industry owes to Napoleon Bonaparte. He will find that commissions on the tourist business, due to the glamour of the Emperor of the French since that tragic day of Waterloo, would run into astronomical figures.

SANTA CLAUS halts his panting reindeer for their final southern stop in the United States at Key West, Fla. He mops his brow with a red handkerchief and digs into his pack for an armload of firecrackers. He knows that hundreds of stockings are hanging on bedposts for him, for there are no fireplaces.

Borough President Samuel Levy's plan for a $28,000,000 crosstown tunnel under Thirty-seventh Street, linking the Queens-Midtown and Midtown-Hudson vehicular tubes, was approved in principle yesterday by the Merchants Association.
SAYBROOK, Conn., Dec. 12. -- Five dogs were called back tonight to run tomorrow in the second series for the Walton Ferguson Jr. Memorial Trophy for English springer spaniels in the field.

The Broadway record this season seems to be no hits, no runs and many errors. And yet, in the crop of plays that have died a quick death there have been many of appreciable value. The enemy within the gates is the newspaper critic, who by a few taps of his typewriter keys is able to mow down with machine-gun accuracy the sincere efforts of a worthy playwright.

MR. EKINS holds the present record for swift circumnavigation of the globe. He won the race -- if race it can be called -- of two months ago. And he flew all the way by means of the commercial air lines. Embarking on the Hindenburg on Sept 30, he covered 25,794 miles in 18 days 10 hours and 26 minutes, and his average flying speed was 127 miles an hour.

The Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace passed last week, as one delegate expressed it, "out of the kissing stage and into the fighting stage," but before the week had ended it was well on the way toward final amity again, with an announcement by Secretary Hull that all twenty-one American nations had agreed on a peace formula.

LOOKING as though they had been dipped to their heels in barrels of concentrated suntan, 104 young ladies of the ensemble were being adjured to precision by a frenzied voice coming through a loud-speaker from a point some sixty feet above the black-enameled floor.

GENEVA, Dec. 12. (AP).-- A serious dispute between Turkey and France over Turko-Syrian border clashes became known today as the League of Nations Council correspondence between the Turkish and French Governments was published at the instigation of Turkey.

HOW TO GET VENISON: The Fish and Game Commission of New Jersey was petitioned last week to be "progressive." The plea came from George W. Jacobs, science instructor at Mountain Lakes School by profession, and fancier of the bow and arrow by avocation. Mr. Jacobs, like the Indians who once hunted the deer in the Ramapos, makes his own equipment, and once in Maine brought down a 250-pound bear.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 12. -- In an emotional, excited atmosphere reminiscent of a really inspired religious revival meeting, the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace took today its first important step toward trying to assure the Western Hemisphere against any threats of war from within or without.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP). -- Increased sugar quotas for 1937 for continental beet and cane-sugar areas, offshore areas and other foreign sources were announced today by the sugar section of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

Club owners and coaches of the National Football League, meeting at the Hotel Lincoln yesterday, decided that if the Green Bay Packers and Boston Redskins tie in the league championship game at the Polo Grounds today they should clash again for the title.

With the advent of colder weather, the resultant increase in a degree of heat required indoors, and with short, dark days cutting down the amount of direct sunshine, the window gardener needs to be watchful of the health of her plants.

Upon payment of $318,000 in back taxes and waiving of a claim of a perpetual street car franchise, Mayor La Guardia signed at City Hall yesterday a ten-year franchise authorizing the Manhattan and Queens Traction Company to operate buses on Queens Boulevard from Manhattan over the Fifty-ninth Street bridge through Long Island City to Jamaica.

POTTERY and hieroglyphics recently discovered in the mining country east of Lake Winnipeg in Manitoba axe believed by their finder, the Rev. Charles Leo Abbott, to indicate the presence there 20,000 years ago of a race that may have been related to the Egyptians.

TOKYO, Dec. 12 (AP). -- Three out of four prominent Japanese women declared today they were unable to understand how former King Edward could place his personal life ahead of his country and kingly duty. They said:

HOT SPRINGS. Va. -- The Homestead will be the scene of many family reunions over the Christmas holidays. A huge Christmas tree with its gay trappings in front of the "scenic window" and Yule logs crackling on the two large hearths in the great hall will indicate the arrival of the festive season.
