Need exists for wider education of youth in the basic principles of aeronautics, Mayor La Guardia told 6,000 boys and girls yesterday morning at a rally of the New York Wing of the Junior Birdmen of America at Radio City Music Hall.

DETROIT, Dec. 12 (AP). -- One hundred sit-down strikers withstood a barrage of tear gas early today and then left the Gordon. Baking plant peacefully after a truce was called in this week-old controversy. Another Detroit strike was also suspended, but a third continued.

CALIFORNIA and the Far West in general have had their share of success stories, with a formula almost as unvarying as that of "Boy Meets Girl." Adventurous youth finds undeveloped natural resources, adventurous youth grabs undeveloped natural resource, adventurous youth blossoms out as admirable citizen, gives part of fortune to university, observatory or library and dies amid plaudits of fellow-grabbers and of late-comers who never grabbed anything -- such is the familiar yarn.

THIS is a first book by the latest of New England voices in poetry. Only in the past several months has the name of Robert Francis entered the consciousness of readers of poetry in the best periodicals. The intimation of authentic quality which those occasional appearances had is here confirmed in a slender but impressive collection of leas than a hundred poems.
A midnight shake-up of commanding officers in the Police Department became known early today, following ceremonies at which forty promotions were announced.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- The crowds that surged around the Houses of Parliament on a chilly, foggy afternoon awaiting King Edward's abdication were neither noisy nor agitated and seemed oddly undemonstrative. The few policemen who were there had nothing more to do than gently suggest that the throngs keep moving, which they obediently did.
Arrangements have been completed for the benefit dinner dance of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York on Wednesday in the Guard Room of the Park Lane.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 12. -- The South American censorships were described today as making it impossible for newspapers to carry out their natural mission of creating international public opinion in favor of peace in the Americas.

AMY LOVEMAN, associate editor of The Saturday Review of Literature, conducts therein a department to which readers bring their quests and their questions when they are looking for a book on any imaginable subject.

BERLIN, Dec. 12. -- Germany has returned a friendly answer to the Anglo-French proposal regarding extension of the non-intervention embargo to volunteers in the Spanish war. This is all that is ascertainable officially on the subject.

One of the most colorful entertainments -- the Caucasian Allaverdy Ball -- reminiscent of fetes in Czarist Russia, will take place on Friday in the grand ballroom of the Plaza, when old Caucasian customs will be revived for one night by Russian exiled nobility.

PARIS. JEAN PATOU'S "Riviera week-end wardrobe," which was one of the midseason's biggest successes, adds something new to the technique of individual dressing. Most of the style leaders have adopted a personal color gamut that runs through all their wardrobes, varying in quality and key with the changing seasons.

OTTAWA, Dec. 11. -- The St. Lawrence waterway, that giant project for joint use of the river as an oceanic shipping route and as a source of hydro-electric power, which has been falling in and out of political favor on both sides of the Canadian-American border since it was signed in 1932, is again to the fore.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Dec. 12. -- The third annual Christmas Ball, which will be given by President John Stewart Bryan to the students and faculty of the College of William and Mary, will be held Friday evening in Phi Beta Kappa Memorial Hall.
Indoor polo made its Brooklyn debut of the 1936-37 season at Squadron C Armory last night as the New York A.C. and First Division teams rode to victories in two interesting exhibition encounters.

With no prolonged period of warm weather to be feared, gardeners are now tucking their flower beds and borders in for the long Winter's rest. Mulching materials of several different types having been collected for the purpose; these are used according to the growth habits of the plants to which they are to be applied.

SAN FRANCISCO. -- California, and particularly the area around San Francisco, for many years has placed a taboo on any open discussion of that section's being susceptible to destructive visitations from nature. Sons and daughters of the Golden West never spoke of the "San Francisco earthquake" but the "San Francisco fire," and there existed a distinct prejudice when it came to broadcasting any news of tremors.

IN current fiction one of the successes of the new season is Sally Salminen's "Katrina," going rapidly from edition to edition and soon appearing in English and other translations. By confining her story to the Aaland Islands in the Baltic, the author provides a setting from these isles of the northern seas that will be new to most of her readers outside Scandinavia or Finland.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12. -- The Chicago Board of Trade reported today that twenty of the eighty-seven applicants admitted to membership this year were less than 30 years old but that the average age of the new group was 40. The youngest was John C. Watson of this city, who was elected when he was only a few days past 21 years 6 months.

LOOKING ahead, Kirby Page sees the prospect of "terrific social conflict," out of which no lasting tranquility will come for a long, long time. A Christian Socialist, he is utterly opposed to the violence of communism and all the tyranny of fascism, but he is convinced that unless the challenge of injustice in present life is courageously met, a frightful struggle between those two forces, and the victory of one of them, is inevitable.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Whether the second inaugural of President Roosevelt on Jan. 20 shall be the simplest in many years or one of the most elaborate and colorful in history must be decided by the President soon after he returns next Tuesday from his South American voyage.

Your editorial "State Job Insurance" misses the essential point. The object of Sections 901 and 902 of the Social Security Act was to persuade States to move promptly in the development and enactment of unemployment compensation laws.

NAZI Germany has decreed that "Alcazar" is a "sacred" name because of the Fascist defense of the historic building in Toledo during the Spanish civil war. Thus the Reich recognizes the latest heroic episode in the story of this celebrated fortress, which now lies wrecked by guns and dynamite.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 12. -- The Junior promenade of the College of New Rochelle will be held Friday evening in the Sports Building before the departure of the students for the Christmas holidays. Miss Elizabeth O'Dea of Brooklyn is general chairman.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Dec. 12. -- Smith College's annual crop of picturesque Winter headgear has come to full bloom. Even those young ladies who sturdily ignore the weather, and wear no hat, appear on particularly cold mornings in brightly colored ear-muffs.
Two of the three Irish boxers who were making their American debuts were victorious at the Ridgewood Grove last night before a gathering of 3,000.

A significant trend in the operation of the city's public schools has been a reduction over a period of years in the number of supervisory positions while pupil registration was increasing and school problems were becoming more complicated.

THIRTY-FIVE years ago today Guglielmo Marconi, a young man of 27 years, was in Newfoundland, harboring a secret unknown to the world outside. On the day before, Dec. 12, 1901, he had picked up the first transatlantic signal, the letter "S" broadcast from Poldhu, on the southwest tip of England.

This year's "Little All-America," selected by Associated Press survey from the small-college footballers who romp the gridirons from coast to coast, presents an aggregation of talent that belies its designation.
ABOARD ZURICH EXPRESS, France, Dec. 12 (AP). -- The Duke of Windsor sped across France tonight in quest of private life.

COSTA RICA will open its first national fair two days after Christmas, in San Jose, the country's capital. With its mountainous background and immediate semi-tropical setting, San Jose offers picturesque surroundings for a display of Costa Rican wares and products.

THE United States will have another transcontinental radio network at the beginning of 1937, for the Mutual Broadcasting System is scheduled to extend its facilities on Dec. 29. Nine new stations will become affiliated with Mutual on that date, bringing the total membership hook-up to thirty-two.
To gaze at the stars is to ask questions. How did sun and planets come into being? Is every one of the thousand million suns revealed by photography the center of a solar system?

TROY, N.Y., Dec. 12. -- The traditional Christmas Carol Candlelight Service of Russell Sage College, presented in alternate years by the combined choir and glee club of Russell Sage College, will be given tomorrow evening at St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

The weeks just ahead will determine in large measure whether evergreens in the lawn and garden are to go through the Winter successfully. In many respects, this is the most trying time of the year for both conifers and the broad-leaved types.

Twenty-four undergraduate student clubs at City College elected 106 student leaders as officers for the current semester, according to an announcement by Dr. John R. Turner, Dean of Men. They will hold office until the Fall term closes in February.

PAUL LAURENCE DUNBAR died in 1906 at the age of 34. Brand Whitlock telegraphed to the young writer's mother, "America has lost a poet." And The Boston Transcript commented editorially, "He was not, perhaps, a great poet, but he was a real one."

Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, Chancellor of New York University, announced yesterday that the Civil War residence on the University Heights campus occupied for twenty-five years by the late Henry Mitchell MacCracken would be named "MacCracken Hall" as a mark of respect to the sixth chancellor of the university.

The American Art Association Anderson Galleries completed yesterday afternoon their sale of more than 700 lots from the collection of Frank Gair Macomber, Boston art collector and an honorary vice president of the American Bureau of Shipping.

PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 11. -- One result of last Summer's drought is a refugee problem of growing seriousness to the Far Northwest. The State of Washington estimates that 12,000 persons on its relief rolls come from the dust-bowl areas; in Idaho and Oregon a similar situation has been found.

Gross revenues of the Seaboard Air Line Railway this year will be about $37,800,000, against $33,941, 811 in 1935, according to R.P. Jones, the carrier's chief finance and accounting officer. He predicted that gross income available for interest would be $3,400,000, against $1,825,706. The indicated results for this year would be the best since 1930.
The Benjamin Franklin High School naturalization campaign was ended last week with alien mothers and fathers representing twenty-three different nationalities seeking citizienship aid.

IT is just ten years since Mrs. Parker first made plain that the world is safe enough for girls who wear glasses, but reasonably precarious for most others. It is ten years or thereabouts since people began to repeat at dinner tables those bright sayings of hers which could not always have been repeated in print.

Fourteen of the original twenty-nine founders of the Columbia University Club, including Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, will participate in the celebration of the thirty-fifth anniversary of its founding at a dinner at the club's quarters, 4 West Forty-third Street, Wednesday night.

The crowning of Luke Appling as the American League's batting champion for 1936, and official acceptance of a wholesale smashing of records by the mighty Yankees, provide the highlights of the official averages released by the Will Harridge circuit for publication today.

Rojankovsky's illustrations have both radiance and drama. Plouf is an engaging little duck, whose story is told with such clarity in the pictures that it is hardly necessary to refer to the text, while Pompom, the little red squirrel and his family fairly seem to whisk up and down the trees and across the green meadow.

IN the apparently eternal stream of record releases, the single ten-inch disk, carrying two or more songs, has, hitherto, borne a rather forlorn air. While the particular monthly list to which it belonged was current, it blossomed, only to be lost all too soon in the intricate mazes of the back catalogues.
LONDON, Dec. 12. -- Edward's new title in private life will be the "Duke of Windsor." King George told the members of the Accession Council today.

Final election returns invariably lag well behind the event itself, and it was not until last week that figures were published revealing the total votes received by the various minor party candidates on Nov. 3. The showing made by them turns out to have been fully as bad as seemed likely to be the case, on the basis of early and incomplete returns.

BERLIN, Dec. 12. -- The intimation from the government of South Africa that it plans legislation to halt National Socialist activities in the mandated territory of Southwest Africa aroused resentment and protests in Germany.

To the diversified program developing for the New York League of Business and Professional Women under direction of its president, Mrs. Katherine Bleecker Meigs, was added this week another activity which will engross its civic consciousness committee.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11. -- Pacific Coast business is taking staggering losses as a result of the maritime strike, now entering its seventh week. Cost of the strike to San Francisco alone is estimated at $3,000,000 a day for each of the forty-two days, by the Shipping Merchants Association, and at $7,000,000 a day for the Pacific Coast.

MEN of many nations walk the corridors of the Legislative Palace in Buenos Aires where the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace is being held. Among them is James Monroe. The things said, the things done, take us back 113 years to those days in 1823, when James Monroe, the fifth President of the United States, made the declarations which have since borne his name.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12. -- Problems confronting college athletics will not be solved by legislation but by "the education of the public and good faith among the colleges." President Clothier of Rutgers University asserted at the annual meeting of the Middle Atlantic States Collegiate Conference here today.

Final plans for the supper dance to be given by the Junior League of Brooklyn on Saturday at The Towers. Brooklyn, has been announced by the chairman, Miss Jane Paffard. Mrs. Frank A. Sherer is in charge of tickets. Miss Mary Thayer heads the patroness committee.
HAVRE, France, Dec. 12 (AP). -- The stay-aboard strike, initiated by the crew of the French liner Champlain this morning, spread to an other French ship, the San Francisco, tonight.

PELHAM, N.Y., Dec. 12. -- The Pelham Service League will hold a dinner dance next Saturday for the benefit of the milk fund of the Pelhams, at the Pelham Country Club. Miss Ruth Leonard, general chairman, is being assisted by the Misses Peggy Austin, Susan Sicard and Carman Hart.

At the peak of form yesterday afternoon, Fritz Kreisler enthralled his vast audience in Carnegie Hall with a series of superb violin performances which invariably remained at the exalted level of excellence reached during the opening moments of the recital.

Unsheathing an 18-inch sword from an apparently harmless malacca cane which he carried, Kurt Schultz, 15 years old, described by the police as "a tough kid from the West Side," ordered an East Side haberdasher to "stick 'em up" about 10 o'clock last night.

Speaking last night at the closing session of the Fifth Annual Scouters Conference and the twenty-first annual meeting of the Queens Council, Boy Scouts of America, held in the auditorium of Jamaica High School, Warden Lewis E. Lawes of Sing Sing took for the text of his talk the theme of the whole conference, "Making Scouting Available to More Boys."

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (AP). -- The National Semi-Professional Baseball Congress announced today the forty-eight cities which next Summer will hold State semi-pro baseball tournaments, with each State title winner eligible to compete in the national finals at Wichita, Kan., Aug. 13-15.

In choosing to be known as another GEORGE. the new King seems to wish to give the British Empire to understand that, in spirit, in aims, and in conduct, he intends to follow in the footsteps of GEORGE V. Something of that sort is plainly called for, following the shock of King EDWARD'S abdication.

IT is just ten years since Mrs. Parker first made plain that the world is safe enough for girls who wear glasses, but reasonably precarious for most others. It is ten years or thereabouts since people began to repeat at dinner tables those bright sayings of hers which could not always have been repeated in print.

Fourteen of the original twenty-nine founders of the Columbia University Club, including Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, will participate in the celebration of the thirty-fifth anniversary of its founding at a dinner at the club's quarters, 4 West Forty-third Street, Wednesday night.

The crowning of Luke Appling as the American League's batting champion for 1936, and official acceptance of a wholesale smashing of records by the mighty Yankees, provide the highlights of the official averages released by the Will Harridge circuit for publication today.

Rojankovsky's illustrations have both radiance and drama. Plouf is an engaging little duck, whose story is told with such clarity in the pictures that it is hardly necessary to refer to the text, while Pompom, the little red squirrel and his family fairly seem to whisk up and down the trees and across the green meadow.

Final plans for the supper dance to be given by the Junior League of Brooklyn on Saturday at The Towers. Brooklyn, has been announced by the chairman, Miss Jane Paffard. Mrs. Frank A. Sherer is in charge of tickets. Miss Mary Thayer heads the patroness committee.
HAVRE, France, Dec. 12 (AP). -- The stay-aboard strike, initiated by the crew of the French liner Champlain this morning, spread to an other French ship, the San Francisco, tonight.

PELHAM, N.Y., Dec. 12. -- The Pelham Service League will hold a dinner dance next Saturday for the benefit of the milk fund of the Pelhams, at the Pelham Country Club. Miss Ruth Leonard, general chairman, is being assisted by the Misses Peggy Austin, Susan Sicard and Carman Hart.

At the peak of form yesterday afternoon, Fritz Kreisler enthralled his vast audience in Carnegie Hall with a series of superb violin performances which invariably remained at the exalted level of excellence reached during the opening moments of the recital.

Unsheathing an 18-inch sword from an apparently harmless malacca cane which he carried, Kurt Schultz, 15 years old, described by the police as "a tough kid from the West Side," ordered an East Side haberdasher to "stick 'em up" about 10 o'clock last night.

What the prologue is to the performance, a dinner at the Hotel Roosevelt Tuesday night will be to a concentrated drive for an adequate, long-term Federal program to relieve the housing headaches of the nation, State and city. Dignitaries who will represent and speak for each, as guests of the Woman's Committee of One Hundred, will be United States Senator Robert F. Wagner, Governor Herbert H. Lehman and Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Dec. 12. -- The Boston Shamrocks defeated the New York Yankees, 12 to 6, today in an exhibition contest between the two American League football teams.

Although the eighty member hospitals of the United Hospital Fund received a larger income from patients the first six months of this year as compared with the same period in 1935, expenditures have wiped out the increase.

Alphabet Soup, whatever the joke-smiths say about it, has become a standard item of the political and commercial diet of the world. All nations use words coined from initials and strange to the dictionary. In these days of multiplied corporation and government activities it saves the public lots of breath, though it may shock the lexicographers.

THE portraits of Moses Levy and his second wife, Grace Meers, have recently been bequeathed to the Museum of the City of New York by a descendant of the sitters, Alphonse H. Kursheedt. They were painted by an unknown artist, probably of the New York Dutch school and presumably between 1720 and 1728.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Chairman O'Connor of the House Rules Committee, a contender for the post of House leader, insisted tonight that efforts to get him out of the race "have been a complete flop."

EASTVIEW, N.Y., Dec. 12. -- The story of a forger just released from prison with a "psychological paralysis'' which deprives him of the use of his right or "forging" hand, was made public today by Warden Paul Brown of Eastview Penitentiary.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 12. -- The 1936-37 production of the Princeton University Triangle Club, a musical comedy titled "Take It Away" with scenes laid in both Princeton and Hollywood, will open here in McCarter Theatre at 8:30 tomorrow evening.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 12. -- The Rutgers University Choir will present. "A Mystery for Christmas" tomorrow night. It was written in 1928 by Professor Howard D. McKinney, director of music at the university.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Determination of the most distant star of the universe, swinging two quintillion (2,000,000,000,000,000,000) miles away in space, was reported today by the Carnegie Institution of Washington.

WE do not usually look to the press of the various churches for the most helpful guidance on literary matters, but the unexpected sometimes happens. In the current issue of The Methodist Recorder is an article by Dr. George Jackson which deserves the attention not only of literary novices but of many writers whose long experience in the production of books has failed to teach them certain things that even a beginner ought to know.

CONSIDERING its current pre-occupation with such sensitive versifiers as Shakespeare and Maxwell Anderson, Hollywood is by way of becoming the world's leading retailer of dactyls and trochees. Yet, despite its yeoman endeavors to establish poesy as a staple commodity, the movies never relinquish their husky pragmatism.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 12. -- College athletes, under a regulation adopted by the Southern Conference today, must maintain a higher scholastic standing than the minimum required of students to remain in the various schools.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 12. -- The peace and security project approved in committee today provides:

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12. -- The outcome of the first day's squash racquets play in the twelfth annual renewal of the Lockett Cup series at the Penn A.C. was of a surprising nature. New York, the defending team, after leading by 3 matches to 2, was defeated by Boston, 4 -- 3.

THE white quilt that December brings has covered the Western hills. Each year the coming of snow, shrouding timbered slopes and barren uplands, heralds to the Pacific seaboard the thrills of the ski run, the toboggan slide, the skating rink, and the snowshoe and dog-sledge trail.

LIFE flows on in Hollywood, great stars wax and wane on the sky-signs, but the name of Spencer Tracy -- who was never one of your flashy, first magnitude luminaries -- continues to burn quietly along the boulevards with a lasting glow born of sincerity and hard work and more to be desired, perhaps, than the neon splendor of top billing.

AN early and delightful phase of the art of Maurice Prendergast is revealed by the current exhibition (through December) at the Kraushaar Galleries. The artist's reputation as a colorist, whose oils and water-colors have been familiar for a generation, is assuredly enhanced by these delicate monotypes, possessing as they do a certain delicate Old World charm combined with a flavor of the Oriental.

The appointment of C. Higbie Young as head of machine design and engineering drawing in the Cooper Union Schools of Engineering, with the rank of full professor, was announced yesterday by Gano Dunn, president of the Union. He succeeds the late Professor Carl Rossmassler.

CANNES, France, Dec. 12. -- Lord Brownlow, gentleman-in-waiting to Edward VIII as King, hastily left Villa Lou Viei tonight and boarded the 8:45 train for Geneva. He declined to make any statement of the purpose of his trip or whether he would return here.

Members of the Fordham University Council of Debate will speak on political and social problems this Winter before outside organizations such as Newman Clubs, Holy Name Societies and Knights of Columbus Clubs, it was announced yesterday.

NOW that skiing is rapidly becoming the most popular of Winter sports, many beginners and many more who would like to begin to glide down snow-covered hills with the greatest of ease are, no doubt, looking for advice and guidance.
LONDON, Dec. 12. -- The texts of the Accession Council's proclamation today declaring George VI King and of his initial declaration follow:

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 12. -- An effort to force the dismissal of Dr. Glenn Frank from the presidency of the University of Wisconsin has been renewed by the Wisconsin Progressive party, headed by Governor Philip F. La Follette.
HUDSON, N.Y., Dec 12. -- Charles H. Benedict, still hale and hearty, observed his 102d birthday today at his home at Columbiaville, north of Hudson.

With sharp controversy following in its wake, but with agreement that it is likely to have "far-reaching" effects upon the consumer and retail merchandising in this country, the precedent-establishing decision of the United States Supreme Court a few days ago in the California and Illinois "fair trade" cases was being carefully weighed by retailers and manufacturers at the week-end.

The Board of Education is striving to raise the morale of the public school system by eliminating politics from the appointment and advancement of teachers, by not persecuting teachers for their beliefs and by encouraging them to think independently, James Marshall, member of the board, declared yesterday.

ALTHOUGH Henry Albert Phillips is quick to see the "white elephants" of the West Indies, this book about all those islands bears the subtitle of a "magic journey." And the foreword's first sentence -- verbless, exclamatory and emphatic, is "The sheer romance of the West Indies!"

CLOSING today at the Corcoran Gallery of Art there is an exhibition including preliminary mural studies, completed murals, sculpture models, completed sculpture, architectural models of rooms, easel paintings and drawings representing the work of some 350 painters and sculptors.

Britain's new King is called GEORGE and the new Queen is called ELIZABETH. If we accept the authority of W.S. GILBERT, then the new reign could not have conceivably started out under more favorable auspices. The earnest student of "Iolanthe" need hardly be reminded that Britain won her proudest bays in good Queen BESS'S glorious days.
One man was killed and three others were injured when a coupe collided with a delivery truck, turning the truck over, at Claremont Parkway and Washington Avenue, the Bronx, yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Following is the text of the broadcast address delivered at Buenos Aires by Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, over the network of the Columbia System, as made public by the State Department:

SAN MATEO, Calif., Dec. 12 (AP). -- Seabiscuit, 11-10 favorite owned by Mrs. C.S. Howard of San Francisco, made a runaway of the $10,000 added World's Fair Handicap at Bay Meadows today, leading all the way to win by five lengths.

AS the wearer of the best-known monocle in the House of Commons. Sir Austen Chamberlain seems to have more followers today than he has had for many years past. More than a score of M.P.'s now wear the single eyeglass.

Carrying placards displaying the above sentiment in front of the offices of Lieut. Col. B.B. Somervell, New York City Administrator of the WPA, 2,000 WPA white-collar workers, some of whom displayed pink dismissal slips in their hatbands, protested last week against the announced program of retrenching on relief work.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 12. -- Silas, 3-year-old son of Crucifixion, the property of Mrs. B. Franzheim, captured the Jefferson Park Handicap, one-mile race that topped an excellent program today at the Fair Grounds.

Aside from the short-lived rally in stock prices on Thursday on the news of the passing of Britain's constitutional crisis, last week's stock market moved indecisively. On the week, THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks was off 0.81 point after fluctuating within a range of but 3 points.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Endorsements of the candidacy of Representative O'Connor of New York for majority leader in the next House came today from Representatives Harlan of Ohio and Hancock of North Carolina, both members of important delegations.

JOHANNESBURG, Union of South Africa. -- The high cost of living, particularly the prohibitive prices at which bread, butter and milk are selling in the Union of South Africa, is resulting in widespread malnutrition, if speakers at the annual congress of the Chambers of Commerce of South Africa may be believed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today approval of an application by the Central Railroad Company of New Jersey and the Reading Company for permission to make adjustments in the calculation of passenger fares for points within a radius of forty miles of New York, compared with points beyond that area.

WIDELY at variance in theme and treatment are two drawing shows that became current last week. At the Frank K.M. Rehn Galleries we find what is presented as the first comprehensive exhibition of drawings by Henry Lee McFee, and at the Valentine Gallery (where canvases by Henri Matisse may still be seen) a group of drawings by Man Ray, the American modernist who has spent so much of his time in Paris.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 12. -- Henry Picard took a four-stroke lead today in the $4,000 Nassau open golf tournament with a 63 that was 5 under par.

Miss Innes Griffith James was introduced to society yesterday at a reception given by her grandmother, Mrs. Walter Graeme Eliot, and her mother, Mrs. Eliot James, at their home, 520 East Eighty-seventh Street.

Mrs. Lionel Sutro, chairman of the Manhattan division of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, is expected to arrive today or tomorrow by airplane from Buenos Aires, and will be the principal speaker on Wednesday at the midwinter meeting of the division, at luncheon in the home of Mrs. Gerard Swope, 1,040 Park Avenue.

ROME, Dec. 12. -- Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Foreign Minister, today sent to the British Ambassador and the French Charge d'Affaires the Italian Government's reply to the proposal recently submitted to it concerning non-intervention in Spain and mediation between the two parties in the conflict there.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 12. -- With holiday buying in full swing, retailers report that merchandise shortages are rapidly developing in several lines. While dollar sales are still under those of 1930, price differences account for much of the discrepancy, and it is estimated that volume sales will more closely approach the figures for 1929.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 12. -- In a significant modification of Harvard's policy of providing an equal amount of tutorial instruction for all students, regardless of their scholastic ambitions or abilities, the Department of History has adopted a plan for giving juniors and seniors a definite choice in the amount of tutorial attention they are to receive.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., Dec. 12 -- The dogs of Amityville are learning to steer clear of 42 Bennett Place, the home of Harlan Major and his whistling wildcat. Big dogs and little dogs, brave dogs and timid, want no part of the Major place.

The fulsome praise that has been bestowed on City College and Manhattan basketball teams in this new season has been deservedly given. The Beavers and Jaspers demonstrated their prowess in the New York Hippodrome's opening college court double-header last night before a near-capacity crowd of 5,100, the Lavender defeating Providence College, 44 to 28, and the Green downing its transpontine rival, Brooklyn College, 31 to 22.

THE vast army of skiers, who will soon move from the cities to snow-covered slopes and picturesque trails, will find improvements in practically every place they visit. Old downhill and cross-country runs have been widened; abandoned bridle paths, growth-covered hills and pastures have been cleared of brush.
PARIS, Dec. 12. -- Owing to the sudden "holdup" strike of seamen and engineroom workers the French Line passenger ship Champlain did not sail from Havre as scheduled today.

TOKYO, Dec. 12. -- A public demonstration in support of the German-Japanese pact this afternoon gave Foreign Minister Hachiro Arita another opportunity to reaffirm that Japan was not joining a Fascist bloc.

IN an unusual and somewhat drastic move to battle the major lots with their imposing contract lists and heavy production schedules, three independent producers for United Artists are uniting on a plan for block booking of talent and for expanded programs which should materially affect screen product within the next few months.

GREAT BRITAIN has set up the blocks for the keel of another super-liner. She will be built in the same berth in John Brown Co.'s yard in Clydebank in which the great hull of the Queen Mary went from keel-laying to launching in the course of three years and nine months.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 12 (AP). -- The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation has begun an expanded apprentice program to train men for specialized work in its mills.
Three thousand WPA workers massed outside the offices of Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, Works Progess Administrator, yesterday morning to protest curtailment of the Federal rolls in this city.

THE destiny of Germany and the fate of National Socialism rest today in the hands of one man -- Hermann Wilhelm Goering, the "Minister-President" of the Third Reich, whom Adolf Hitler has appointed as his plenipotentiary commissar in charge of his second Four-Year Plan.

WHEN Vice President Garner recently cut short the period allotted to contemplation of his beloved pecan groves and entrained for Washington, he threw an unaccustomed spotlight on the important but relatively obscure office he holds. For according to common report he returned when he did at the direct request of President Roosevelt, who had entered a foreign jurisdiction thousands of miles away.

MOSCOW, Dec. 11. -- The new Constitution adopted Dec. 5 is still the chief topic of the Soviet press and popular conversation. Talks with individual Soviet citizens show the attitude toward the Constitution falls roughly into three categories.

A BRIGHTER day is dawning for the farmer's hired man. Uncle Sam's agricultural experts have found that his pay is rising and predict that it will continue to rise, if both agriculture and industry show increasing prosperity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP). -- Contributions of $51,000 to the Democratic National Committee and the Good Neighbor League were reported to the Senate Campaign Funds Investigating Committee today by James W. Gerard of New York, former Ambassador to Germany.

A discussion of the best methods of securing a minimum wage law will feature the thirty-seventh annual luncheon of the National Consumers League on Tuesday at the Hotel Commodore. Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins and Miss Mary Anderson, director of the Women's Bureau, United States Department of Labor, will be guests of honor.

VALENCIA, Spain, Dec. 12. -- The Anglo-French suggestion of an armistice and plebiscite to bring about peace in Spain has not had an enthusiastic reception at this seat of the Leftist government, but it has set more serious minds to thinking about the future.

A parade of striking seamen, estimated by police at 3,000, was held yesterday afternoon "to demonstrate there is a strike." The marchers proceeded up Broadway from the Battery, the starting point, to Union Square, where a brief meeting was held.

An offering to the public of $13,900,000 of 4 per cent equipment-trust certificates, Series Q, of the Illinois Central Railroad Company will be made today by Salomon Bros. Hutzler and Stroud Co., Inc. The certificates are non-callable and will mature semiannually from Aug. 1, 1937 to Feb. 1. 1944.

MANILA, Dec. 13 (AP). -- Relief workers, moving in by ship and army trucks rushed aid tonight to 80,000 homeless persons. The official death list in the flood-stricken mounted to 116, Cagayan Valley with reports of the missing ranging up to 1,000.

The Rev. Elmore McNeill McKee, rector of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, urged upon a congregation of more than 700 persons yesterday a new quarter-century of parishional expansion and continued service. He preached at a morning service that marked the 125th anniversary of the church.

Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens denied last night published reports that the city was negotiating to bring about substitution of buses for the last of the two trolley lines crossing Queensboro Bridge.

LONDON, Dec. 13. -- Answers to the Franco-British proposals for mediation in Spain were received without comment in London today. In unofficial quarters the opinion was expressed that while both the notes are not flat negatives to the peace invitation that is about all that can be said for them.

President ROOSEVELT and Administrator HOPKINS are again insisting, and doubtless will continue to do so, upon the necessity of the slack in employment being taken up by private enterprise. It has been shown that the Government can neither afford nor effect this.
A series of four mysterious shootings early yesterday resulted in the death of a Negro, gunshot wounds to two other Negroes and the wounding of a white man.

NANKING, Monday, Dec. 14. -- Over nearly all the railways of North and Central China troops of the national government are converging on Shensi Province to fight rebellious soldiers commanded by General Chang Hsueh-liang.
The majority of views expressed from pulpits of all denominations throughout the city yesterday was that King Edward VIII should have chosen the throne rather than Mrs. Simpson.

CHESTER, Pa., Dec. 13. -- Striking employes of the Sun Shipbuilding and Drydock Company were weighing today letters from John G. Pew, president of the company, asking them to return to work over the Christmas season and promising conferences after New Year's Day.

The Metropolitan Opera Guild held its second annual "at home" at the Opera House last night. About 2,000 members saw and heard a program that ranged from serious music-making to a hilarious extravaganza in three scenes called "Opera As You Like It," an impression of what the lyric stage might look and sound like in the year 2000.
OMAHA, Dec. 13. -- Born without the glands which provide the body's thermostatic control, John Ferguson, 14, is a prey to atmospheric conditions.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- For those who like a good, safe bet, tomorrow's Presidential election offers opportunity.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,559,572,300. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills. The list follows:

The ninth anniversary of the Church Army in the United States, the only lay organization in the Protestant Episcopal Church giving full time to mission service, was marked yesterday in a sermon by the Right Rev. Dr. Benjamin M. Washburn, Bishop of Newark, at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue at Fifty-first Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- As long as there are young men eager to work, but idle through no fault of their own, the Civilian Conservation Corps can continue to be "an effective part of our national policy," Robert Fechner, director of the CCC program, stated in his annual report to President Roosevelt, made public today.

German Day, an anti-Nazi observance arranged by the German-American League for Culture, was held for the second time yesterday with a mass meeting of 3,500 German-Americans in the Hunts Point Palace. Southern Boulevard and 163d Street, the Bronx.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Dec. 13. -- O.H. Chalkley's Popover and V.A. Romagna's Jenny were the winning dinghies in today's frostbite regatta held by the Manhasset Bay dinghy fleet. Popover scored in Class B by a large margin and Jenny triumphed by a single point in Class D.

Distributors Group, Inc., will make today an initial public offering of 20,000 shares of $1.50 cumulative convertible preferred stock, and 15,000 shares of Class A common stock of the Automobile Banking Corporation. The preferred stock, of $25 par value, will be priced at $26.50 a share, and the common stock at $7 a share.

TSINAN, China, Dec. 13. -- A few hours after General Chiang Kaishek had been made a victim of the coup at Sian but before the news of General Chang Hsuehliang's revolt had reached Tsinan, General Han Fu-chu, the Governor of Shantung Province, revealed that he had permitted Central Government troops to enter the southern part of the province.
In an American Soccer League game at Celtic Oval in Brooklyn yesterday, the St. Mary's Celtics and the Scots Americans played a 3-3 tie. All of the goals were scored in the second half.

The supremacy enjoyed by the St. Francis Prep natators over rivals in the C.H.S.A.A. swimming tournament during the past three years came an abrupt to termination yesterday. The Franciscans, victorious in twenty-one consecutive meets, sustained a 44-31 setback at the hands of Bishop Loughlin Memorial High in the competition at the Columbus Council pool in Brooklyn.
Everything that the hockey fan wants to see in a game was on view at Madison Square Garden last night -- that is everything but a victory for the home team.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The texts of the two economic resolutions introduced by the American delegation to the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace at Buenos Aires, providing for equality of treatment in international trade and for reduction of excessive trade barriers, were given out by the State Department tonight as follows:

Stephen Leacock will do a "Canadian Journey" that Dodd, Mead will publish. He writes that he intends to make a thorough survey of Western Canada and to report on the country and its people. The title will be "My Western Excursion, A Study of the East and West in Canada."

THE last of this year's popular novels is one of the panoramic sort, reproducing with endless industry the plainer forms and more obvious colors of recent history, and having a Mr. America for a hero. The title is "Rich Man Poor Man" (Houghton Mifflin, $2.50). Janet Ayer Fairbank is the author.

A service in memory of the Right Rev. Arthur Selden Lloyd, for fifteen years the senior Suffragan Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New York, was held yesterday afternoon in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. It was under the auspices of the diocese.

The upward trend in cotton prices continued last week and trading in the futures market was active on several days. On the New York Cotton Exchange, the price of active futures made net advances of 33 to 49 points, following gains of 3 to 29 points the week previous and establishing new high marks for the season.

William Robyn, tenor, gave his annual musicale at the Mansfield Theatre last night before a highly enthusiastic audience. Henrietta Schumann, pianist and Tosha Samaroff, violinist, were the assisting artists.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- A considerable increase in the activities of the Federal Trade Commission following the Supreme Court's decision holding the National Industrial Recovery Act unconstitutional was shown in the commission's annual report for the fiscal year ended on June 30, 1936.

Five hundred delegates from twenty-five States voted yesterday to increase the 1937 quota of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee to a figure "much higher" than the $3,500,000 set as the goal of the campaign ending this month.

LONDON, Dec. 13. -- After Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin's address in Parliament on Friday, which was eloquent in its expression of sincere sympathy, sorrow and affection for a King who had abdicated, and after Queen Mary's own moving appeal to the public on the same day in behalf of "my dear son," the Archbishop of Canterbury and some other churchmen today rebuked the departed King.
LONDON, Dec. 13. -- Following is the text of the broadcast address delivered tonight by the Archbishop of Canterbury on the change of rulers in Britain and the empire:

WYCKOFF, N.J., Dec. 13. -- Ellis Willett's effort to give his hens and roosters a place to enjoy the more abundant life, a duplex chicken "apartment" the like of which this village has never seen, unfortunately for Mr. Willett, has become so entangled in official red tape that neither Mr. Willett nor any of the officials know where they stand.

Some years ago Dr. PHILIP ZENNER of Cincinnati established a small loan fund at the Ohio Penitentiary to aid paroled persons to rehabilitate themselves. As The Cincinnati Enquirer pointed out recently, when it became known that the fund had been exhausted, the months following a man's release from prison are perilous both for him and the community in which he lives.
NANKING, China, Monday, Dec. 14. -- Nanking's streets are crowded with marching men in the mobilization to crush the forces of General Chang Hsueh-liang.

One child was killed, two persons were critically injured and nine others were slightly hurt last night in a five-car collision on Interboro Parkway in Glendale, Queens, between Myrtle and Cypress Hills Avenue. Traffic on this main artery connecting Long Island and Brooklyn was tied up two hours before the police could get the wreckage removed.

PARIS, Dec. 12. -- The return of the Bank of France dated Dec. 4 shows a decrease of 900,000,000 francs of bills discounted by reason of collection of end-of-the-month maturities, whereas loans against securities and bonds rose only 300,000,000 francs.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13. -- Oats prices advanced here last week to new high levels, with December bought by shorts and processors, while the selling was largely by speculative hedging interests. December oats reached 49 7/8 cents a bushel and finished at 49 1/4, a net advance of 2 3/8 cents for the week.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (AP). -- Ill fortune dogged the victory-starved Black Hawks tonight, the Chicago National Hockey League team taking a 2-to-1 beating from the Red Wings on an overtime goal which qualified as one of the most freakish scored here in several seasons.

FLINT, Mich., Dec. 13 (AP). -- Striking operators of Flint trolley coaches refused today, by a vote of 103 to 3, to accept proposals that they resume operation tomorrow, pending arbitration, of transportation facilities here.

BERLIN, Dec. 12. -- This week's stock market was inert and, although selling never attained considerable dimensions, quotations in nearly all groups of securities weakened. Declines among the leading industrial issues seldom exceeded 1 or 2 points but certain potash, brewery and non-ferrous metal shares lost considerably more, while Reichsbank issues fell sharply.

A wise man of long experience was once asked to give advice to two friends of his contemplating marriage. It was a marriage which, as both knew, would mean the complete changing and perhaps wrecking of the opening and promising career of the husband. The counselor first went to the woman.

" This so-called new freedom has the world by the throat," according to the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, in his sermon yesterday morning at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue at Forty-eighth Street.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- The period of suspense in the last few days, the like of which had not been experienced in the financial markets here since the fateful days preceding the outbreak of the Great War, has been ended by the abdication of King Edward.

HAVANA, Dec. 13. -- Roy S. Evans of Miami Beach, Fla., piloted his monocoupe 90 to victory in the Miami-Key West Havana handicap race today, flying the 110 over-water miles from Key West in 50 minutes 10 seconds.

PARK CITY, Utah, Dec. 13 (AP). -- Governor Henry H. Blood tonight pleaded for peace in this strike-ridden North Central Utah silver camp, scene of bloody rioting yesterday climaxing a two-month metal mines tie-up.

Martin Berger and Harvey Berger, 16-year-old twins, of 1,160 Hoe Avenue, the Bronx, were charged with grand larceny yesterday after policemen were unable to decide which one actually stole the automobile belonging to Fred Engel, 1,442 Minford Place, the Bronx.

Those of us who are interested in following the proceedings of the Inter-American Peace Conference at Buenos Aires are indebted to THE NEW YORK TIMES for the articles regarding it and, in particular, for publishing the full text of the two conventions proposed by the United States delegation.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 13 (AP). -- Federal Government will convene a new grand jury Tuesday in what officials described as an effort to forestall further delay in the trial of oil conspiracy cases involving twenty-three companies, fifty-eight individuals and three trade journals.

Though nothing official has been said about it, it is known that Cornell athletic authorities are thinking seriously of moving their plans to the point where sports are not dependent on gate receipts for their success. There is a strong feeling that it is wrong to have the entire athletic program -- and this means intramural and recreational activities -- dependent on gate receipts for existence and on the size of those receipts for scope.

Proceeds of the fifteenth annual Christmas sale to be held tomorrow at Everybody's Thrift Shop, 112 East Fifty-ninth Street, will be divided among six charitable organizations. They are the Association to Promote Proper Housing for Girls, the Bryson Day Nursery, the Maternity Center Association, the Union Settlement, the Vanderbilt Clinic Auxiliary and the Wayside Day Nursery.

The Treasury's monthly statement of the amount and kinds of money in this country has its interest as showing that the total sum in actual circulation, outside of holdings by the Treasury and the Federal Reserve, is the largest ever reached under normal conditions. The $6,465,726,000 reported as of Nov. 30 compares with $5,846,463,000 a year ago and with $4,929,421,000 at the same date in 1929, the highest of that period.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13. -- Active buying of all grains in leading markets of the world assumed last week a volume that had not been known for a long time. Sentiment was extremely bullish and many leading operators expressed the opinion that the world's trend of grain prices was toward higher levels.

A long lost painting by Winslow Homer has been found, according to announcement by the Macbeth Gallery, 11 East Fifty-seventh Street, where the painting will be shown in an exhibition of Homer's work opening tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- A marked improvement in business was reflected in the final report by the Census Bureau today in its biennial tabulation of retail sales throughout the country, which showed them as being 67.5 per cent of the 1929 level, whereas in 1933 they showed a drop of 49 per cent from 1929.

Preparations for staging the horse show at the Riding and Polo Club on Dec. 29 and 30 are nearing completion. With many persons staying in New York during the Christmas holidays before departing for the South, a prominent list of exhibitors is anticipated.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 13 -- The sturdy, well-groomed veteran sable and white Champion Honeybrook Big Parade, owned by W.R. Van Dyke of Upper Darby, Pa., repeated his victory of last year by taking the best in show award tonight at the Collie Club of America specialty exhibition in the Westchester County Center.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Dec. 14. -- A vast military movement is under way to rescue General Chiang Kaishek, the virtual dictator of China. from imprisonment at the headquarters of General Chang Hsuehliang, leader of the rebel troops at Sian, the capital of Shensi Province.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 12. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 86.6, which compares with 86.7 the week before, 86 two weeks before, 86.1 three weeks before and 85.3 four weeks before.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 13. -- A number of society folk of Westchester County who are lovers of dogs were among 500 folk who attended the Golden Anniversary Specialty Show of the Collie Club of America this afternoon at the County Center and saw Robert G. Wills of Shaker Heights, Ohio, win the futurity championship with his collie, Astolat Peerless.

Random gleanings from a week's activities: A report was submitted at the meeting of the Salt Water Anglers of America that deserved more attention than it received, for it is of interest to thousands of anglers who fish in Great South Bay.
LONDON, Dec. 13. -- The new Queen Elizabeth, it was unofficially announced tonight, is suffering from a "mild attack of influenza."

A liberal legislative program for the Republican party, including ratification of the Federal Constitutional amendment prohibiting child labor, was urged yesterday by the Legislative Advisory Committee of the New York Republican County Committee.

Charges that J. Edgar Hoover's G-men and United States marshals had been brought into Cape May County, N.J., by the Democrats in an attempt to "steal" the State Senate seat won on the face of the returns in the November election by William C. Hunt, Wildwood publisher, were made yesterday by Andrew O. Wittreich, Hudson County chairman and chief counsel for Mr. Hunt.

Arriving from Hollywood yesterday afternoon to whip "The Eternal Road" into shape before its Jan. 4 premiere, Max Reinhardt paused to observe that "America is fast becoming the sole refuge for the free spirits of humanity" and to detect in Eugene O'Neill's winning of the Nobel Prize "the proof that Europe is revising its attitude and views toward the American stage."
CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (AP). -- For the third time in four years the world's three cushion billiard championship belonged today to Welker Cochran of San Francisco.

Messmore Kendall, president general of the Sons of the American Revolution, met with a "question from the floor" at an open forum discussion last night that was probably unprecedented in the numerous public gatherings at which he has been a principal speaker. The question was put to him by his wife.

ROME, Dec. 13. -- Warm applause this afternoon greeted the world premiere of the "Symphony in One Movement," by Samuel Barber of Westchester, Pa., performed here in the Adriano Theatre. The young American composer was called several times to the stage after Bernardino Molinari's excellent interpretative performance.
Real estate activity in this city over the week-end was featured by sales of apartment houses in Yorkville and the Bronx.

Dean Detton will risk his claim to the world's heavyweight wrestling title tonight when he opposes Man Mountain Dean in the feature finish contest at the New York Hippodrome. Detton will be outweighed by about 100 pounds, but he is expected to topple his giant challenger.

Christmas week in the Broadway showshops -- in some years overcrowded with theatrical openings -- will disclose next week only a half-dozen premieres. As usual during the holidays, the range -- on and off Broadway -- will be wide and diverse, including D'Oyly Carte revivals, several Federal Theatre Project items, a Yiddish offering in Times Square and the usual quota of puppet entertainments.

For the week preceding the beginning of the holidays the number of exhibitions on the calendar in local galleries exceeds twenty new openings, together with a dozen more shows which came in over the week-end. Several of these are of outstanding interest in the long perspective of the season and others are particularly timely.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13. -- The Lockett Cup returned to Philadelphia's possession at the Penn A.C. today when Neil Sullivan defeated E. Rotan Sargent of Boston in the deciding match of the squash racquets series to give Philadelphia a 4-3 victory.

The Sleepy Hollow Country Club strengthened its hold on the lead in the Westchester Division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association inter-club tournament by defeating Ardsley Country Club, 5 to 2, on the victor's courts yesterday.

While the story of "Ein Lied, ein Kuss, ein Maedel" (A Song, a Kiss, a Girl), the latest attraction at the Eighty-sixth Street Casino Theatre, is old stuff, and the film probably was turned out as a sort of "pot boiler" for Martha Eggerth and Gustav Froehlich while waiting for better assignments, it is decidedly enjoyable.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The texts of the draft conventions for maintenance, preservation and reestablishment of peace, for nonintervention, and for coordinating and extending the existing treaties between the American States, which have been unanimously agreed to by the delegations at the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace, at Buenos Aires, were given out by the State Department today, as follows:
VIENNA, Dec. 13. -- On the train from Innsbruck to Salzburg today, the Duke of Windsor called for Austrian dishes, for which he developed a taste during his vacation last Summer.

Baron Eugene de Rothschild, at whose castle the Duke of Windsor will stay for a time, is the third son of the late Albert Baron Rothschild, head of the great Vienna banking house. He is reputed to be one of the wealthiest men in Central Europe.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 13. -- The first assignment under the talent pool which will include Samuel Goldwyn, Selznick International, Walter Wanger and perhaps Alexander Korda is the drafting by Selznick of H.C. Potter of the Goldwyn staff to direct the long-delayed "Tom Sawyer," now scheduled for April production.

DUBLIN, Irish Free State, Dec. 13. -- A party of 693 young Irishmen sailed from Galway today to join General Owen O'Duffy's Irish brigade in Spain. Already 200 of General O'Duffy's volunteers are in training there preparatory to going into action with General Francisco Franco's forces.

BERLIN, Dec. 13. -- Reports that National Socialist leaders, major and minor, are leaving the Christian churches continue to come in. The latest is to the effect that Joachim von Ribbentrop, the Ambassador to Britain, and his wife have both given up membership in the established Protestant church and have now come under the new census category of "unbelievers" without affiliation to any organized Christian communion.

Republican leaders opposed to the election of Edwin F. Jaeckle, Erie County chairman, as Republican State Chairman to succeed Melvin C. Eaton at today's meeting, suddenly came to life last night. They formed a strong combination which they believe will result in the election of William S. Murray of Utica, who is Oneida County chairman.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 13. -- The Princeton Department of Art and Archaeology will hold a special exhibition of twenty-seven works of modern French artists in the Antioch Court of McCormick Hall during the coming week, it was announced today by Professor C. Rufus Morey, chairman of the department.
Barely two years after he first started competition as a novice, Irving Horowitz annexed his fourth and most important title by winning the national 15,000-meter walking championship yesterday.

MADRID, Dec. 13. -- Newspapers were again full of warnings today to be prepared for General Francisco Franco's attack, but the sixth Sunday since the siege of Madrid started passed quietly without any sign that the Insurgent leader was ready.
Seventeen basketball games and six wrestling engagements have been scheduled for Gettysburg College athletes this season, according to an announcement by C.E. Bilheimer, director of athletics.

LARCMONT, N.Y., Dec. 13. -- Despite a slightly sub-freezing temperature, with the added chill rising from the sea water, nineteen sailing dinghies measured speed today in the regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club.

CANNES, France, Dec. 13 (AP). -- Because of a flood of "crank notes" sent Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson since Edward VIII gave up his throne for her, French police said today they would continue guard over the villa of Mr. and Mrs. Herman L. Rogers in which Mrs. Simpson took refuge.
MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 13. -- A project of law affecting rents was presented to the Senate today by General Candido Aguila. It is backed by the National Chamber of Labor.

VIENNA, Dec. 13. -- Concluding another stage of his journey into voluntary exile, the Duke of Windsor arrived here tonight to be the guest of Baron Eugene de Rothschild at Enzesfeld Castle, about twenty-five miles almost due south of Vienna.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Dec. 13. -- The Montclair Athletic Club and the Englewood Field Club triumphed in the New Jersey division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association today to take joint possession of first place. Montclair defeated the Racquets Club here, 7 -- 0, while Englewood also recorded a sweep over the Essex Club of Newark at Englewood.

Supreme Court Justice Edward J. Byrne signed an order on Saturday temporarily enjoining from selling securities, two investment-trust corporations, an investment holding company, two firms and ten individuals, John J. Bennett Jr., State Attorney General, announced yesterday.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 13. -- Joe Louis, Detroit's famed Brown Bomber, will undertake his first local ring battle tomorrow night in Public Auditorium and will seek his twenty-seventh knockout triumph.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 13 (AP). -- Florida's ninety-six-day horse racing season will open at Tropical Park tomorrow with new devices installed to aid both turf followers and riders.

General Feng Yu-hsiang, once known as the "Christian General," has regained power in Nanking as vice chairman of the National Military Council, of which General Chiang Kai-shek was chairman until his imprisonment.

The executive committee of the Welfare Council of New York, in a statement issued yesterday, attacked the Lyons Residence Bill as unsound in principle and the embodiment of a narrow and primitive view of public administration.

LONDON, Dec. 13. -- This week will be officially devoted in Great Britain to clearing up the left-overs of last week's crisis and to consolidating the new situation that has come into being. It will not be so easy a task as the simplicity of this statement might indicate.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- Confirmation of the view that the recent large influx of gold to London from France was due to repayment of the credit extended to France is contained in the Bank of France's latest return, which shows a decline of approximately 40,000,000 in its gold holdings.

LONDON, Dec. 13. -- Britain's new King, accompanied by his mother, Queen Mary, and his daughters, Princesses Elizabeth and Margaret Rose, attended church services today at Marlborough House. The services were held in the Danish Chapel in which Queen Alexandra often worshiped during her last years.

LONDON, Dec. 13. -- Social reforms are necessary, but communism is a remedy worse than the evil, according to a joint pastoral letter from the hierarchy of England and Wales that was read in all Roman Catholic churches here today.

THERE is, as is almost inevitably the case at a change in the seasons of the year with its consequent lull in major activities, some viewing with alarm by the more articulate of the followers of the various sports. There are also some voluntary suggestions for improvement here and there. One correspondent writes:

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 13. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 81 per cent of capacity, compared with the average of 79.05 per cent for November which the American Iron and Steel Institute reported. The daily tonnage output in November was the largest for any month since September, 1929, and was exceeded only in that month and the seven which preceded it.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13. -- Receipts of hogs on Friday, at 16,000 head, were the smallest since Oct. 30, and brought active buying by packers, advancing prices 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight, with an average of $10, equal to the highest price in thirteen weeks.

A century's growth of the St. Vincent de Paul Society from a small group of Parisian students to a world-wide movement for charitable cooperation among Catholic laity, was reviewed yesterday by Mgr. Robert F. Keegan, in a sermon in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Augustine, 167th Street and Fulton Avenue, the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- A huge nomadic population, wandering in trailers from coast to coast and from the Great Lakes to the Gulf of Mexico, was foreseen with some apprehension here today by public welfare officials attending the round-table conference of the American Public Welfare Association.

Robert A. Low, national inter-scholastic titleholder, and Isadore Bellis of Philadelphia, boys' American indoor champion, are among the contestants who will vie for the national indoor junior tennis singles crown when play in the twenty-second annual championship starts at the Seventh Regiment Tennis Club on Dec. 26.

Notable changes appear in the list of boxholders of the Metropolitan Opera for the 1936-37 season, made public yesterday. The parterre boxes, popularly known as "the Golden Horseshoe," will lose some familiar figures but will see the return of others who were missing last season.

More than 1,000 members of the Consolidated Brooklyn Retail Pharmacists, Inc., closed their stores for four hours yesterday afternoon, picketed seventy-five stores whose proprietors refused to close and met at the Hotel Bossert to take action against unfair trade practices.

BERLIN, Dec. 13. -- All German radio stations rebroadcast today the speech that Colonel General Hermann Goering, Commissar for the Four-Year Plan, delivered to the peasant congress at Goslar two weeks ago. In this address he forcefully impressed on peasants their duty to deliver fixed amounts of bread grains as ordered, and especially denounced as a "traitor" every peasant who used bread grain as feed for hogs or cattle.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13. -- Stocks of lard on Dec. 1 were around the largest on record, with well up in the millions of pounds in cold storage. Prices declined early last week, but at the last buying accredited to Eastern account absorbed the offerings and brought about a sharp advance, with futures making net gains of 55 to 75 cents a hundredweight.
A contribution of $30,000 to the United Hospital campaign from the Davison Fund, established by John D. Rockefeller Jr., was announced last night by Stuart M. Crocker, chairman of the campaign.

TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 14. -- Japan will avoid any measures likely to increase the present unrest in China and if precautions for the protection of Japanese are taken they will be directed solely toward insuring local peace.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 13 (AP). -- Smoke lifting from the Southern Conference battlefield today revealed that despite the compromise substitute for the "Graham Plan," the subsidization issues of the fifteen-member athletic group were apparently far from settled.

Plans for new buildings and alterations to old ones filed in Brooklyn during 1935 exceeded in construction costs those of any other borough, according to a report of progress made public yesterday by Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll. The report in condensed form was for 1934 and 1935 although it also included some of the principal statistics for 1933.
CHICAGO, Dec. 13. -- Five feet of snake, when the reptile is already eighteen feet long, would not make much difference to the average man, but it does to the Lincoln Park Zoo.

Following the advice of expensive professional commentators and prophets instead of using our own intelligence, was decried by the Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming in his sermon yesterday morning at Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway at the head of Wall Street.

Brooklyn has "once more given a prophet to the world," said the Rev. Dr. Howard Chandler Robbins of the faculty of General Episcopal Theological Seminary, speaking of the Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman in a memorial address yesterday morning at Central Congregational Church, Hancock Street near Franklin Avenue, Brooklyn.

Production of motor cars and trucks by the General Motors Corporation this year will total more than 2,000,000 units, aside from a large volume of other products, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president, said in a letter sent yesterday to shareholders, accompanying the year-end dividend of $1.50 a share on the common stock voted by the directors on Nov. 9.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 13. -- One hundred and ninety undergraduates at Harvard have been awarded sports insignia with the approval of the Committee on the Regulation of Athletics, it was announced today.

Insurance totaling $85,244,750 has been written on the five interstate vehicular crossing under its jurisdiction, the Port Authority announced yesterday. The five-year contract was described as covering "the largest amount of insurance of its kind ever placed under one policy."

Activity in the wholesale markets here last week was marked by a strong demand for fill-in items in holiday lines. Rush calls were received for accessories, lingerie and lounging apparel, novelty linens, men's and boys' wear and other goods for pre-Christmas selling.

Dictators fail to realize the real nature of human unity, according to Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the faculty of the Catholic University in a sermon yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament, Seventy-first Street, east of Broadway.

BERLIN, Dec. 12. -- Current official pronouncements are in such vein as to indicate insistence in high places that exports must be pushed. Significant in this light is the fact that November's steel export total reached a high record figure since the depression, the net export being twice the monthly average of 1934.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Dec. 14. -- The Shanghai Stock and Bond Exchange did not open on time this morning at 10 o'clock, finding a large majority of members voting in favor of suspension because of the national crisis. The government, however, believing the fiscal position secure, advised experimental opening, saying that if bond prices dropped more than 4 points the Exchange could then close as a protective measure.
To the Editor of The New York Times:Two editorials in your issue of Dec. 7 seem to me to have a related interest if, as is most important, the subject of taxes is gone into a bit more deeply.

The WPA art project will hold a National Exhibition of Graphic Art at the International Art Center, 310 Riverside Drive, from Jan. 4-31. Three hundred prints by artists from all parts of the country will be shown.

Although the basketball season is merely in its opening stages, only six of the leading college teams in the metropolitan area still have unbeaten records. Long Island University, C.C.N.Y., St. John's, Fordham, Manhattan and N.Y.U. are the teams thus listed, while Brooklyn College, St. Francis and Columbia have already tasted defeat.

Like others curious about human affairs, I have heard about those who were right about stocks in 1929. Without questioning that there may have been such people, two things are obvious: If there had been more of them, there wouldn't have been any '29 except from the point of view of the calendar, and they must have been terribly lonely.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Dec. 13 (AP). -- Delegates to the New York State Conference of the American Student Union at Colgate University here this afternoon denounced the McNaboe investigation of so-called "radical" activities in a resolution which also supported the Cornell University Chapter of the A.S.U.

Rain pattered dismally against the panes and formed luminous black puddles in the yard late Friday night as Howard S. McGrath and his wife, Adelaide, sat in their parlor at 1.917 Morris Avenue, the Bronx.

This afternoon will see what has for some years been the cardinal issue and event for the Republican party of New York, election of the chairman of the State committee. To get that functionary in, wrangle with and rage against him ferociously, choose a successor to be treated in the same way, has been the regular course.

That the approaching year-end will, from the viewpoint of business activities, present the most cheerful picture of any corresponding period since 1928, is now evident. Some industrial weather signs have been rather unexpectedly impressive.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Dec. 13. -- Walter Gorton, the chronic forger who is suffering from acute paralysis of his right arm, the one he used in imitating signatures, will receive massage treatments in Orange County jail on orders from Sheriff Henry Clark, who has received verification of the diagnosis that Gorton has a "psychological paralysis'' induced by a stricken conscience.

BERLIN, Dec. 12. -- This week's international and domestic developments were in no wise conducive to optimism, and stocks here have declined steadily. The market regarded the Spanish situation as distinctly aggravated and the mystery that surrounded the London crisis because of press censorship aroused needless fears of a prolonged constitutional struggle in Great Britain.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 13. -- New Jersey's Young Republicans served notice today on their elders that they must be given a greater voice in party affairs and that unless this is done their organization may have a candidate of its own for Governor next year.

The body of Ralph Lacock, 45 years old, of 508 South Huron Street, Wheeling, W. Va., a student at a school for salesmen maintained by the E.R. Squibb Drug Company of 745 Fifth Avenue, was found hanging from the framework of the door between the bedroom and bathroom of his suite at the Hotel Barbizon Plaza, 101 West Fifty-eighth Street, at 10 A.M. yesterday. Detective James Sheehey said he was "apparently a suicide."

LONDON, Dec. 12. -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood on Dec. 9 at 77.8, against 76.3 a fortnight before, 75.5 a month before and 60.4 on Sept.
NANKING. Dec. 13. -- Japanese officials blame the Nanking leaders for their plight since the imprisonment of General Chiang Kai-shek by General Chang Hsueh-liang Saturday in Shensi.

CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE, N.J., Dec. 13. -- The body of a woman between 30 and 35 years old was found enclosed in two burlap bags today in the woods forty-five feet east of State Highway S-49 near Goshen, six miles north of here. Because of the circumstances, she was believed to have been murdered.

PARIS, Dec. 13 (AP). -- Germany's reply to the Anglo-French appeal for an international effort to mediate the Spanish civil war was stated in unofficial circles to be favorable in that it leaves the way open for further negotiations.

Every Horatian student has inevitably his own HORACE; "and I have mine," says MICHAEL ROSTOVTZEFF in his article on the great lyric poet which appears in The Yale Review. Looking back two thousand years, Professor ROSTOVTZEFF sees HORACE, not as a great poet pure and simple, but as a human being in the midst of an economic and social order which produced a crisis as grave as that which exists in our own time.
MADRID, Dec. 13. -- Madrid housewives chopped up dining room tables today as bitter cold swept the city and the food and fuel shortage increased.
With Winter coming on and the consequent need for the proper food to resist its rigors, the Gourmet Society turned yesterday to New England for the dishes for its December dinner.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 13. -- Willie Macfarlane of Hollywood, Fla., forged ahead at the three-quarter mark in the $4,000 Nassau open golf tournament with rounds of 68 and 64 today for a fifty-four-hole total of 200, four under par. He shot even par 68 in the first round.

As the second week of the appeal for New York's Neediest Cases opened yesterday, contributions to the Fund dropped to $2,587.45, the smallest amount received on any one day since the first Hundred Cases of those in deepest distress in the city were published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Dec. 6.

BERLIN, Dec. 13. -- The text of Germany's reply to the Anglo-French memorandum respecting measures to stop enlistment of foreigners in the civil war in Spain and bring about a plebiscite to end the war, was made public tonight following its delivery to the British and French Ambassadors yesterday.

Addressing the convention of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards at the Hotel Ritz-Carlton. Atlantic City, at the week-end, Leonard Dreyfuss, president of the United Advertising Corporation, Newark, urged an extensive campaign to advertise and publicize New Jersey.

SAYBROOK, Conn., Dec. 13. -- One of the most remarkable coincidences in field trial history in this or any other country was reached today when the judges in the first annual stake of the English Springer Spaniel Amateur Field Trial Association decided that they could not conscientiously make any awards.

Gunners who seldom break into the limelight captured the majority of the prizes at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. In the contest for the high scratch cup, O. Agathon, who competes in Class B, and J. Mercadante, a Class A contender, tied, each with 93 out of a possible 100 targets.

SALAMANCA, Spain, Dec. 13. -- The Spanish civil war was in its twenty-second week today, with the military situation virtually the same as when the Insurgents went into University City, on the outskirts of Madrid, a month ago.
New York University has received $105,754 in gifts and bequests since the beginning of the fiscal year, July 1, it was announced yesterday by Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase.

Taking time by the ear rather than by the forelock, the friends of Governor PAUL MCNUTT, "Indiana's retiring Chief Executive," gave him a "testimonial banquet" in Indianapolis the other night Governor-elect TOWNSEND, Governor EHRINGHAUS Of North Carolina, Governor ALLIED of Texas, celebrated the retiring Executive's future even more than his past.

Among police transfers regarded in the department as an effort to increase efficiency in strategic areas Captain John Golden was named yesterday by Commissioner Valentine to succeed to the command of the West Forty-seventh Street Station.

Because she had her husband arrested on a charge of disorderly conduct, Mrs. Catherine Higgins of 4-42 Astoria Boulevard, Astoria, Queens, must ask the Department of Correction today for his release to enable him to give a blood transfusion to the couple's 7-year-old daughter.
VATICAN CITY, Dec. 13 (AP). -- Pope Pius XI continued very gradual recovery today from the illness that struck him down a week ago Saturday.
