The sixth concert of the New Friends of Music given at Town Hall late yesterday afternoon was devoted to chamber works of Brahms. Unlike the previous events of the series, this one did not bring forward any long-neglected compositions.

The old military axiom that fortune is on the side of the army with the heaviest artillery was proved in a football way at the Polo Grounds yesterday, when the ponderous Green Bay Packers crushed the Boston Redskins in the National Football League championship playoff, 21 to 6, gained their fourth professional title and demonstrated conclusively that they are quite a gridiron team.

Trouble, as one of the most valuable opportunities ever entrusted to man, was expounded as a rich occasion of happiness by the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick in his sermon yesterday morning at Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, under the title, "Six Paradoxes Concerning Trouble."

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13. -- Harry Lundeberg, secretary of the Sailors Union of the Pacific, came from a maritime strike conference with shipowners' representatives tonight to declare: "We are closer to actual agreement than we have ever been since the strike started."
MANHASSET, L.I., Dec. 13. -- For the first successive time, New York won the Payne Whitney Memorial court tennis doubles tournament today in the Whitney court at Greentree.

A committee made up of seven of the country's leading painters and Alfred Stieglitz, photographer and art patron, has launched a campaign to win for American artists one of the rights already won by American writers -- the right to royalties from all sales of reproductions of their work.

TORONTO, Dec. 13. -- A development record unequaled at any previous time in the Dominion is credited to the mining industry in Ontario in a report published this week by the Hydro-Electric Power Commission of Ontario.

The youth from the university or college sets the style and pace in ballroom dancing, members of the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., were told yesterday at their December meeting in the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- A review of the international and domestic financial situation, which was interpreted in certain official quarters as further intimation that action would be taken after the year-end to increase the reserve requirements of member banks, was presented today by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System in its December bulletin.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 13 (AP). -- The Rhode Island Reds overwhelmed the Pittsburgh Hornets, 6 to 1, tonight in an International American Hockey League game.

A special German service was held yesterday morning at Christ Lutheran Church, 406 East Nineteenth Street, commemorating the seventieth birthday of the Rev. Dr. Henry W. Voight, assistant pastor of the church until his retirement in 1934.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The gross public debt on Dec. 15, after the completion of all aspects of the December financing program, will be $34,232,200,000, the Treasury estimated today in making public a summary of Treasury financing operations since Dec. 1, 1933.

TORONTO, Dec. 13 (Canadian Press). -- Clergymen in Toronto pulpits today paid tribute to the statesmanship of British leaders and the soundness of the British mentality in the constitutional crisis climaxed by the abdication of King Edward VIII.

We have to be grateful this season, among other things, for the return to this city and country of the English Singers. They performed yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, and more than ever was one impressed with their value as an element of musical civilization.

General Ho Ying-chin, who is now acting commander-in-chief of the Nationalist armies of China in the absence of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, is regarded as one of the ablest men in the republic. He has given proof of exceptional ability as an administrator during the last six years as Minister of War.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- At 458,852,044, the Bank of England's circulation has reached a new high record, although a fortnight has yet to pass before the Christmas peak is reached. The present total exceeds the record of Aug. 6, last, by 4,445,647.

Patrolman Michael Darienzo, Motorcycle Squad 1, was stripped of his shield and service revolver yesterday and held prisoner for two hours in the detention pen of Washington Heights Court, on order of Magistrate W. Overton Harris, for disturbing the Sabbath calm with Old 238.

Encountering the stiffest sort of opposition in his self-imposed task of conducting three consultation games against some of New York's best chess talent at the Manhattan Chess Club, Jose R. Capablanca, Cuban master and former champion of the world, finished last night with a minus score after playing for seven hours without a break.

MOSCOW, Dec. 13. -- The Seventh International Congress on Genetics, which was to have been held here next August with a thousand of the world's leading scientists in this field participating, has been canceled by order of the Soviet Government, it is learned unofficially.
Scoring once in each of the first three periods, the Bay Parkways conquered the New Rochelle Bulldogs, 18 -- 0, before 10,000 persons at Erasmus Field, Brooklyn, yesterday.

ALBANY, Dec. 13. -- The up-State death rate for October of 11.3 per 1,000 population was the lowest of any October in the records of the State Department of Health, it was reported today by Dr. J.V. De Porte, director of the Division of Vital Statistics.

DETROIT, Dec. 13 (AP). -- Several members of Michigan's delegation in Congress said yesterday that they would seek amendment of the Social Security Act to prevent the Federal Government from using an estimated $20,000,000 of the payroll taxes to be paid by Michigan employers, for general purposes.

The foreign exchange market, at least as far as it revolved around the principal currency the pound sterling -- moved irregularly last week. This was linked to the varying tides of opinion over the consequences of the constitutional crisis in Great Britain growing out of King Edward's abdication of the throne.
LONDON, Dec. 13. -- Commenting editorially on the swiftness as well as the intensity of the crisis of abdication, The Times will say tomorrow:
The City Bank Farmers Trust Company is prepared to issue Bangor Hydro-Electric Company first-mortgage bonds, 3 3/4 per cent series, due in 1966, in definitive form in exchange for temporary bonds.

PARIS, Dec. 12. -- After some weak sessions earlier in the week, the Bourse rose sharply in accordance with the tendency in foreign markets. The anxiety caused by the prospect of the abdication of King Edward disappeared when it became a certainty.

The New York Rovers balanced the scales in the won and lost columns yesterday afternoon as they skated to a well-earned 4-3 decision over the last-place Hershey team in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League tussle at Madison Square Garden.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- Wheat prices continue to rise steadily with little likelihood of a set-back with Italian purchases still in evidence. This buying is in larger volume than heretofore reported. Last week it was reported to have been 1,000,000 quarters.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Thirty-three individuals in the United States had taxable incomes of more than $1,000,000 in 1934, the Internal Revenue Bureau disclosed today in giving out final statistics of income for that year.

More than 1,000 members or guests of the Jewish Education Association attended the fifteenth annual Chanukah dinner held last night at the Hotel Astor, and heard Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman urge a "rebirth of interest" in Jewish religious education.

Unqualified praise of the Baldwin government for its stand in the crisis that resulted in the abdication of King Edward VIII was voiced yesterday by the Right Rev. William T. Manning, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, in an address in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Members of the recently organized junior committee for the annual theatre party benefit of the New York Kindergarten Association on Jan. 6 were guests at a tea given yesterday by Mrs. William Carter Dickerman, president of the association, at her home, 6 East Seventy-ninth Street.

William F. Carey, Sanitation Commissioner, said yesterday that the city's snow-fighting forces now were equipped to handle a severe snow storm, with the cooperation of building owners who have pledged their support in clearing small side streets by pushing snow into the sewers.

ENZESFELD, Austria, Dec. 14. -- Gray-uniformed gendarmes with bayoneted rifles guarded all approaches to Enzesfeld Castle today, and nothing was seen of the Duke of Windsor, who arrived there last night.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 14. -- Simultaneous with the filing in Camden of a petition to reorganize under Section 77b of Federal Bankruptcy Act, officials of the Leeds Lippincott Company, operators of the Hotel Chalfonte-Haddon Hall, today issued a statement here explaining their action.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 14. -- Many luncheons at the clubhouse preceded the opening of the racing season here today, and box parties helped to swell the crowd of 15,000 gathered for the event.

The close race between the New York Rangers and the Detroit Red Wings for the lead in the American Division of the National Hockey League will be resumed tonight on two fronts. In New York the Rangers will be host to the Montreal Maroons in Madison Square Garden, starting at 8:45 o'clock.

LONDON, Dec. 14. -- The most fashionable circles in the British capital turned out tonight to witness the London opening of Sir James Barrie's "The Boy David," with Elisabeth Bergner in the title role.

Due to the large number of foreclosures on vacant land holdings, which make it possible for speculative builders to pick up parcels at bargain prices, there is now a revival of the building of large apartments in the Bronx and Brooklyn. In the latter borough a great many private houses are also being torn down to give way to six-story apartments on narrow residential streets.

OSLO, Norway, Dec. 14. -- The twenty-fifth anniversary of Roald Amundsen's discovery of the South Pole was marked today by a meeting in the polar museum aboard Dr. Fridtjof Nansen's vessel Fram, in which tablets were unveiled in memory of Nansen and Captain Otto Sverdrop by Knud Ringnes, chairman of the Fram committee, and in memory of Amundsen by Knut Domaas.

Uncommon entertainment was provided the audience which gathered at the Beethoven Association's second concert of the season last night in Town Hall. The concert began with a concerto played by four solo violinists, with accompaniment of an ensemble of strings and a "continuo" part played on the piano by Carlos Salzedo.
The Irving Trust Company is prepared to deliver definitive first mortgage bonds 3 1/4 per cent series due in 1966, of the Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company, in exchange for temporary bonds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- While France will again be forced to default on its war-debt installment, due tomorrow, and can make no proposals at this time looking toward a settlement, a note from that nation tonight expressed hope that improved conditions would permit the opening of negotiations with a view to an acceptable arrangement.

Kings in exile remind one that the world today must be fuller of exiles and refugees than ever in its history. A world war and its sequels have scattered them over the face of the world in the millions. In the vast majority they know, with the poet DANTE, how salty is the taste of another's bread and how hard it is to walk up and down a stranger's stairs.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Dec. 14 (AP). -- With almost complete lack of ceremony, President Roosevelt will arrive in Charleston early tomorrow on his return from South America. Debarking from the cruiser Indianapolis, he will hasten two blocks to his train and speed back to Washington.

Deaths from pneumonia and influenza increased last week, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, reported yesterday. The deaths from pneumonia were 126, an increase of 31 over the week before. Influenza caused seven deaths, four more than the previous week.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 14. -- Proph, chestnut son of High Time and Mary Belle, flaunting the silks of J.W. Parrish of Midway, Ky., dashed to a hard-earned victory in the featured Bougainvillea Purse today as Florida's longest racing season, scheduled for ninety-six days, got off to a colorful and successful start.

CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 14 (AP). -- The nation's first Congressional tie vote in 110 years, between Alphonse Roy, Democrat, and Arthur B. Jenks, Republican, a tie apparently once broken, bounced back tonight to become the storm center of a bitter dispute.
LONDON, Dec. 14. -- The new account opened cheerfully on the Stock Exchange here today. British Government securities were steady in quiet trading.

CANNES, France, Dec. 14. -- To set at rest persistent reports reaching New York and London that she had left Cannes. Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson this afternoon consented to be seen by the vigilant band of newspaper men who had been keeping a day and night watch over Villa Lou Vlei ever since she arrived there.

Jose R. Capablanca of Havana, former world chess champion, gave a brilliant exhibition of simultaneous play before a large crowd last night at the Marshall Chess Club. Against thirty-three rivals at thirty-two tables the Cuban master won twenty-eight games, lost one and drew three.

THE visitor was deceptive. He was a medium-sized individual with slightly curly black hair and quiet appearing black eyes. There was no warning of his amazing persistency, though there was a slight threat in the direct way in which he went into action without any preliminary moves.

Driven by fire from his apartment hideout, Harry Brunette, 25-year-old bank robber, wanted for the kidnapping of a New Jersey State trooper, stood off twenty-five G-men under the personal command of J. Edgar Hoover, their chief, and 100 patrolmen and detectives surrounding the flat at 304 West 102d Street early this morning.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 14. -- Richard T. Potts, one of the conservators of the Jersey Mortgage and Title Guaranty Company of Elizabeth, which has been in the hands of Carl K. Withers, State Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, since April 5 last, filed today with Vice Chancellor Malcolm G. Buchanan here a report on his investigation of the manner in which the company was operated.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 14. -- Students rallied today behind Dr. Glenn Frank, president of the University of Wisconsin, as a majority of the board of regents, governing body of the university, prepared to force his dismissal at a special meeting Wednesday.

A resolution protesting against reported "political interference" in the administration of the University of Wisconsin was being prepared yesterday for introduction late this afternoon at a meeting of the New York Alumni of the University of Wisconsin.

Hannes Schneider, internationally famous Austrian skiing instructor from St. Anton, whose Arlberg technique is the adopted system all over the globe, was the guest of honor at two farewell functions yesterday.
Resales of flats in West New York and Union City featured the New Jersey realty conveyances reported yesterday.

Net profit of the Patterson-Sargent Company for the year ended on Oct. 31 amounted to $423,939 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges. After dividend requirements on the $4 preferred stock, the profit is equivalent to $2.02 each on 200,000 no-par shares of common stock.

A new program for slum clearance and model housing for families of low income in New York City has been worked out by the legislative advisory committee of the New York County Republican Committee, which has presented it to Governor Lehman and other State officials for study, it was learned yesterday.

Moss Hart and George S. Kaufman have written their most thoroughly ingratiating comedy, "You Can't Take It With You," which was put on at the Booth last evening. It is a study in vertigo about a lovable family of hobby-horse riders, funny without being shrill, sensible without being earnest.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- The question of whether private ownership or control of ocean beaches should be curtailed or limited was brought before the American Shore and Beach Preservation Association here today at its tenth anniversary meeting.

New York savings, building and loan associations reported that 70 per cent of their home mortgages accepted for insurance by the Federal Housing Administration on Nov. 1 were for construction of new homes, George E. Palmer, special assistant to the administrator and director of savings, building and loan activities, said yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 14. -- Expanding his activities beyond supervision of Paramount's music department, Boris Morros announced. today he would produce a film based upon Pushkin's poem, "The queen of Spades," an effort which the studio regards as an important cultural venture.
If you notice flocks of normally wary wild ducks and geese wandering up "Main Street" this season don't imagine you are seeing things. They're probably looking for the town "duckport."
What police described as a lovers' quarrel between two deaf mutes resulted in the death last night of Alberta Castello, 26 years old, of 711 East 230th Street in the Wakefield section of the Bronx.

BERLIN, Dec. 14. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler has issued a warning from Berchtesgaden to assembled district leaders of the National Socialist party from the whole Reich and to Hitler Youth leaders to cease their attacks on Christianity.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14. -- Increased receipts of hogs were reflected in a decline of 10 cents in prices today following a steady opening. Some late bids showed a loss of 15 to 20 cents compared to Friday. The top was unchanged at $10.25 a hundredweight, but it would have been hard to obtain more than $10.10 at the close.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 14. -- "Take It Away!" was the title, but the audience which packed McCarter Theatre tonight for the opening of the forty-eighth annual production of the Princeton University Triangle Club wanted to "take it with them" at the conclusion of two and a half hours of delightful entertainment.

TOKYO, Dec. 14 (AP). -- Japan consulted Germany today on reports that the Communist International was behind the amazing seizure of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in China. Tokyo acted under the "anti-Communist" accord recently signed by Japan and Germany.

ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 14. -- A panic on a crowded passenger bus was averted and the passengers saved from injury last night by Martin Wohlegemuth, 26 years old, of West Orange, the driver, who subdued a large, stray, shepherd dog that jumped on the vehicle here and snapped at the occupants.

CANNES, France, Dec. 14. -- Chauffeur George Ladbrook, a beret perched atop his large head, started back to England tonight to confront a crisis of his own created by the abdication of King Edward VIII.

Women interested in the work of the Boys Club of New York will assist at the exhibition and sale of handicraft made by the members of the club, in connection with Metropolitan Junior Achievement, which will be held throughout the week at 582 Madison Avenue.

LONDON, Dec. 14. -- Anthony Eden, Foreign Secretary, expressed tonight his government's gratitude to the United States for having encouraged the recent Anglo-French attempt to mediate in the Spanish civil war.
CHICAGO, Dec. 14. -- Grain prices reached the highest points in seven years on the Chicago Board of Trade today by the biggest one-day rise since the wild "inflation" market in July, 1933.
The Fund for New York's Neediest Cases dropped back again yesterday as compared with a year ago. For the day there were 294 contributors who added $7,796.88 to the year's total.

On the surface, the Chinese crisis is a sensational conflict of personalities. CHIANG KAI-SHEK, generalissimo of all the Chinese armies and dictatorial head of the Chinese Government, is held prisoner by CHANG HSUEH-LIANG, Deputy Commander-in-Chief of Northwest Bandit Suppression and "little brother" to his chief.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced into new high ground yesterday, with trading the heaviest of the season. Strength in the December upturn in the early trading, with a sharp rise in stocks, grains and rubber, attracted commission house interest, particularly in deliveries recently selling at unusual discounts.

A speeding automobile with a drunken driver at the wheel swerved into a safety zone at Broadway and Eighty-second Street at 10:10 A.M. yesterday and struck and seriously injured two women waiting for a southbound trolley car.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary arrived yesterday from Southampton via Cherbourg seven hours late because of three leaking tubes in the after condensers. Commodore Reginald V. Peel had to shut off two engines on Friday night and reduce speed to 15 knots to locate the trouble.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 14. -- Angular Willie Macfarlane tended strictly to his game of golf today and was rewarded by winning the Nassau open's top prize of $800.

Each year the National Orchestral Association, under the direction of Leon Barzin, devotes one of its concerts to young soloists, and last night five were presented at Carnegie Hall. Kalman Bloch, 23, was heard in Debussy's Rhapsody for clarinet and orchestra.

The doctrine of noblesse oblige -- the one surviving heritage of feudalism, says WILLIAM ALLEN WHITE in all editorial in The Emporia Gazette -- is still the "footing stone of a permanent democracy" -- political, social or economic. Our peril is in demanding "inalienable rights" without stressing "inexorable obligations."

The popping of Motorcycle Patrolman Michael Darienzo's service machine, which led Magistrate W. Overton Harris to strip the patrolman of his revolver and shield on Sunday for violation of the anti-noise ordinance, threatened yesterday to become a localized version of the shot heard 'round the world.

Cash dividends declared yesterday totaled $20,000,000, lifting the total for this month to $279,000,000. Since the beginning of November, cash disbursements, both voted or paid, have amounted to $1,162,200,000.

MOSCOW, Dec. 14. -- Increasing irritation is being shown here at the continued interception and searching of Soviet cargo ships by the Spanish Insurgents. Seventeen vessels have been so treated, according to reports here, which state no arms whatsoever have been discovered, despite continued declarations by the Insurgents and the Italian and German press and radio that the Soviet is shipping huge supplies of contraband to the Madrid Leftists.

Those who are now attacking the United States Supreme Court in the name of the New Deal are misinterpreting the mandate of the voters in the November election. During the campaign the Democrats were silent regarding the court.

New life insurance written in November increased 1.9 per cent over the same month last year, totaling $709,051,000 against $696,974,000, according to reports received by the Association of Life Insurance Presidents from forty companies that have 83 per cent of the total life insurance outstanding in all United States legal reserve companies.

City College's varsity baseball team will play nineteen games during the Spring season of 1937, according to the schedule released yesterday by Professor Walter Williamson, college manager of athletics. There are four more games than in the 1936 campaign.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Unless the utterances of clerics produce retorts in similar vein from friends of the Duke of Windsor, the most dramatic event of recent times will soon and surely take on long perspective so far as the newspaper public is concerned. But to diplomats and international politicians, as represented in Washington, the important phase is just beginning as reports from behind the scenes make their way into this capital.

The cash income of dairy farmers in this Country will show an increase of about $100,000,000 this year over the total for last year, it was estimated yesterday by Thomas H. McInnerney, president of the National Dairy Products Corporation.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 14. -- Frank W. Rounds Jr. of Winchester, Mass., has been elected chairman of the 1938 board of The Daily Princetonian, undergraduate newspaper of Princeton University, it was announced today by Penn T. Kimball, '37, of New Britain, Conn., the present chairman.

The property at 1,726-30 Lexington Avenue, southwest corner of 108th Street, has been sold by Marie S. Gibbs to Harris and Maurice Mandelbaum, Inc., in a cash deal, which marks the return of Maurice Mandelbaum to realty operations in a district where he formerly was active.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- President Roosevelt probably will open his eyes Christmas morning on six bulging stockings dangling from his bedroom mantel. Outside the door in all likelihood will be four small grandchildren waiting to burst in on him and the stack of gifts by his fireplace.

Many dinners were given before the first in the series of coffee dances for this season, which took place last night at the Cosmopolitan Club. The hosts and hostesses took their guests later to the club for coffee and dancing.

Roark Bradford has sent to Harpers the manuscript of his new novel in which he turns from his Negro characters, made famous in "Green Pastures," to write of the white people who settled in Phinizy County, Tenn. The novel is scheduled for Spring publication.

ALBANY, Dec. 14 (AP). -- The New York State Conservation Advisory Council went on record today as favoring so-called "split licenses" for hunting, fishing and trapping, with a fee of $2.25 for each license.

Brisk gains in virtually all public utility stocks yesterday followed a United States Supreme Court decision ordering a retrial of the "Buzzard's Roost" power development case, in which the Duke Power Company contested the right of the PWA to make loans and grants to competing publicly owned power projects.

Gains were the rule yesterday in local commodity futures markets in active trading. In the cash markets, new high levels were attained by all the grains, flour, lard, copper, lead and zinc, and gains were scored by cotton, printcloths, rubber and cocoa. Silk and tin declined.

A field goal by Alfred Simonpetri in the last ten seconds gave Dwight School a 16-15 victory over the Brooklyn Academy basketball team at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory yesterday. The losers held a one-point margin at half time, 8 -- 7.

BOGOTA, N.J., Dec. 14. -- Joseph Mundorf, 22-year-old son of Patrolman John Mundorf of Bogota, has been arrested by his father on charges of stealing $410 from the office of the Mayor here last Nov. 23, it was disclosed today. The young man is in the Bergen County Jail at Hackensack awaiting arraignment on a complaint of grand larceny.

Mayor La Guardia's proposal to build a city power plant in Brooklyn College was voted down yesterday by the Committee of the Whole of the Board of Estimate after Controller Frank J. Taylor had reported against the plan.

The August Kings County grand jury was charged with "snooping and stepping beyond their province" by Magistrate David L. Malbin in Coney Island Court yesterday, during the arraignment of 108 persons charged with violating the Sanitary Code. All received suspended, sentences.

Tonight they will be opening up the new Lillian Hellman show at the Vanderbilt, the old Lillian Hellman show being "The Children's Hour" and the new one "Days to Come." Reports have it that the evening will consider a small town during a strike of mill workers.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 14. -- In honor of Herbert Hoover, Mark Sullivan, William C. Antwerp of San Francisco and Lawrence Richey, Wiley R. Reynolds gave a dinner followed by cards tonight at his villa here.

The United States Horse Show team, which will compete in Chile next month, will be honored at a luncheon tendered by the Chile-American Association on Dec. 23 at the India House, it was announced yesterday.

Francis H. Hoge Jr. gave a dinner last night in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre for his sister, Miss Barbara Hoge. Others in the party were the Misses Edith Beale, Dorothy S. Siems, Mary Elizabeth Humphrey and Margery Banks; Roland Irving, Ralph Birdsall, Cecil Hoge and Henry Wing.

NANKING, China, Tuesday, Dec. 15. -- The government commanders engaged in attempting to encircle Sian, where Chiang Kai-shek is held, report virtually no resistance and expect, unless resistance stiffens, to be within striking distance on all sides by Thursday night or Friday.

HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 14. -- William H. McCarter, '19, has been appointed director of athletics at Dartmouth College, it was announced today by the Athletic Council. The appointment will take effect Jan. 1.

One hundred and fifty members of the New York Power Squadron, one of the units of the United States Power Squadrons, elected Bertrand H. Perry to the commandership for 1937 at the annual meeting last night at the Hotel Woodstock.

LONDON, Dec. 14 (AP). -- The following are foreign trade figures by the Board of Trade for November: Total imports, 78,670,000; exports of British products, 38,440,000; re-exports, 4,340,000; total exports, 42,780,000; excess of imports, 35,890,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Consolidation of the properties of the Western Pacific and the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroads in the interests of the roads, their creditors and the public, has been recommended to the Interstate Commerce Commission by Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. At present

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- A rehearing and reargument of the case involving the New York Unemployment Insurance law before a full bench of nine justices was asked of the Supreme Court today. The plea was made by the New York employers who lost three weeks ago when a four-to-four division automatically sustained a lower court decision upholding the statute.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 14 (AP). -- Dorothy B., a four-year-old daughter of Diavolo, chalked up her first victory of the year today at the Fair Grounds but she paid only $3.80 for $2 after running the six furlongs in 1:12 4-5.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- The text of the statement made this morning by William C. Potter, chairman of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, before the Senate special committee to investigate railroad financing, of which Senator Wheeler is chairman, follows:

Christmas trade throughout the country showed an average increase of 10 per cent over a year ago for the first ten shopping days of this month, according to the results of a telegraphic survey of member stores announced yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

The fairness of a reorganization of more than $3.000,000 of mortgages guaranteed by the Metropolitan Casualty Company was questioned yesterday, at the Bar Association, by a State legislative committee under Senator Lazarus Joseph of the Bronx investigating the real estate mortgage certificate situation.

The testimonial dinner for the Charter Revision Commission at the Waldorf-Astoria last night, became the setting for presenting the plans for a fusion campaign in 1937, to perpetuate "nonpartisan city government."

LYNCHBURG, Va., Dec. 14 (AP). -- Captain Norton Pritchett, director of athletics at the University of Virginia, said tonight that the university will cease denying outside financial aid to athletes in what he termed a move for "honesty in athletics."

The trustees for the Series C2 New York Title and Mortgage Company guaranteed first-mortgage participation certificates have announced an income distribution of 1 per cent, payable on Dec. 30 to holders of record of Dec. 18. An income distribution of 1 per cent and a principal distribution of 1 1/2 per cent were made in October.

BERLIN, Dec. 14. -- The German press announces in connection with the verdict handed down in the trial of David Frankfurter at Chur, Switzerland, that Germany will now undertake its own investigation of the case.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- By an order issued today, the Supreme Court refused to review the sentence of two years' imprisonment, and a $10,000 fine imposed upon Joseph (Socks) Lanza on charges of violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Law through a "racket" in the fresh fish industry.

All the leading copper producers advanced yesterday the price of the metal in the domestic market a half cent a pound to 11 cents, the highest level since July, 1930. The important fabricating copper companies also announced a similar increase in the prices of their products.

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, announced last night that 1,000 persons dropped from the Federal rolls as "non-essential non-relief workers" would be reinstated as a result of the Emergency Relief Bureau's certification that the workers did have relief status at the time they received their WPA jobs.

CHARLES M. ANDREWS, one-time president of the American Historical Association and Professor of History at Yale for more than twenty years, was awarded the Pulitzer Prize in 1935 for the first volume of "The Colonial Period of American History." It was by no means his first book on that particular subject. As long ago as 1889 he wrote a volume on the river towns of Connecticut.

The trustees of Series C-2 of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, one of the largest guaranteed mortgage certificate issues, announced yesterday an interest distribution of 1 per cent to be paid on Dec. 31 to the 7,500 certificate holders of the issue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- On the ground that The Associated Press had failed to show damage of more than $3,000, the minimum amount that must be in controversy if a Federal court is to assume jurisdiction, the Supreme Court today ordered the lower courts to dismiss the press association's complaint that its news was "pirated" by KVOS, a radio station at Bellingham, Wash.

Mayor La Guardia was informed yesterday in a letter from V. Clement Jenkins, President of the Sixth Avenue Association, that the present loading zone plan for parking in the midtown side streets does not work, and that some alternative must be devised.

None of the boroughs that comprise the City of New York has ever had a more useful public servant than RAYMOND V. INGERSOLL, President of the Borough of Brooklyn. He is familiar with both the social and the economic aspects of city government. He is a wise counselor.

Efforts to unite the chief European Powers for the purpose of offering to mediate in the Spanish civil war are continuing, but are still hardly out of the diplomatic stage. The question is confessedly difficult. There are no modern European precedents to guide the nations interested.

The United States Government in the person of two deputy United States marshals from Brooklyn ran afoul of a local phase of the Spanish civil war yesterday afternoon in the bay off Red Hook flats, Brooklyn.

Harry Bridges, president of the San Francisco division of the International Longshoremen's Association, arrived here yesterday morning by airplane from the Pacific Coast, to discuss the issues of the maritime strike before audiences in Atlantic Coast ports, and to use his influence with longshore leaders in obtaining support of the strike on the Atlantic and the Gulf.

LONDON, Dec. 14. -- George VI sent his first message to Parliament today. Unlike the usual addresses from the throne, it was not intended to reflect the policies of the King's Ministers or indicate their legislative program, because all that had been attended to in the last message of Edward VIII at the state opening of the present session.

Cancer's death toll in the United States in 1935 mounted to 153,000, second only to that caused by heart diseases, Dr. Frank E. Adair, secretary of the American Society for the Control of Cancer, announced yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 14. -- The Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace took a strong stand today in favor of a moral disarmament as one of the most important conditions for preserving peace. The conference gave its support to several intellectual and cultural matters that it considered to be measures tending toward moral disarmament by creating an atmosphere of good-will and understanding among the American nations.

CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE, N.J., Dec. 14. -- How a plan was manipulated to transport members of a CCC camp to Wildwood to vote in the general election on behalf of the Republican State Senatorial nominee, was described today at the resumption of a hearing being conducted by Circuit Court Judge Wilfred H. Jayne.

ROME, Dec. 14. -- Italy's reply to the Anglo-French proposals to strengthen non-intervention in Spain and to effect a reconciliation between the parties in conflict there was delivered Saturday but was published only today. It is, as expected, an acceptance in principle.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 14. -- Harvard and the University of Pennsylvania will resume football relations in 1939, it was announced tonight by the Harvard Athletic Association.

HAVANA, Dec. 14. -- The new Cuban Constitution received the final approval of Congress tonight when the Senate passed the amendments and modifications introduced by the lower house at its recent session. This legislation had been greatly delayed and the period provided by the Constitution for approval of the new charter ends tomorrow.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 14. -- The Argentine delegation today again upset the equilibrium of the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace by withdrawing the approval it was understood previously to have given to the neutrality convention coordinating existing peace machinery of the Americas.

Lively exhibitions marked the opening wrestling show of the 1936-37 season at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory last night as Danno O'Mahoney of Ireland, former world's titleholder, triumphed in the feature scheduled finish affair before a crowd of 3,500.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 14. -- Commissioner Carl K. Withers of the State Department of Banking and Insurance charged Judge William Clark of the United States District Court today with bias and prejudice against the department.

MONTREAL, Dec. 14 (Canadian Press). -- Larry Aurie of the Detroit Red Wings forged into the scoring leadership of the National Hockey League with a gain of five points during the past week, official statistics showed tonight.

The flight of time has turned into a tailspin at the Museum of the City of New York and has come to rest at about the year 1900. This period of the pompadour and parasol has come back to life in an elaborately detailed exhibition which the museum will open to the public tomorrow, following a private view for members this afternoon.

BERLIN, Dec. 14. -- Prices on the Boerse were slightly stronger at the opening today. Heavy industrials had a considerable turnover and Vereinigtestahl gained I point and Rheinstahl :. Potashes were not particularly active and Aschesleben lost 1'._. points. Machines were quiet; Rheinmetall gained 1% points and Schubert Salzer ,s. Chemicals were mixed; I. G. Farben gained 7, point.

Congoleum-Nairn, Inc., yesterday announced a special distribution, payable Dec. 22, to all employes receiving $2,000 a year or less, graduated according to length of service. The maximum bonus will be two weeks' pay, which will be given to all those who have been with the company five years or more.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Dec. 15. -- Mrs. Chiang Kai-shek, the dictator's wife, last night received a telegram from Sian signed by the generalissimo assuring her of his personal safety, advising her that his health was good, urging her not to worry and acknowledging receipt of her telegram dispatched Sunday.

Further reductions in the equity of the Chesapeake Corporation in the control of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway were disclosed in statements issued yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. The Chesapeake Corporation is a holding unit through which the Midamerica Corporation controls the railway.
GENEVA, Dec. 14. -- The League of Nations Committee of Twenty-Eight on "application of covenant principles" met today, but could find no one willing to talk on the question of reform of the League.

On the first page of your issue of Dec. 10 there was a story of a fire in the armory of the 245th Coast Artillery Regiment at 347 Sumner Avenue, Brooklyn, which caused the death of Fireman William Neville and the disablement of other members of Be Fire Department.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 14. -- An appeal to bar and bench to purge themselves of "unethical lawyers and venal judges" in a drive to curb criminal activity was made by Governor Earle today in addressing 200 judges, lawyers, criminologists and penalogists at the opening of a three-day State crime conference.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 14. -- It took just one punch and exactly twenty-six seconds in elapsed time for Joe Louis, Detroit's paralyzing Brown Bomber, to knock out stout-hearted and husky Eddie Simms, home town product, tonight, in what was scheduled as a ten-round feature bout at the Cleveland News Christmas Fund show.

PARIS, Dec. 14. -- While the French Government's reply to Washington's reminder that another debt installment is due is couched in different terms from those of recent years, it is regarded here as only tending to suggest that the French Government is willing on its side to get the situation out of its long deadlock if it can get any cooperation from its creditor.

Yale has new reason to be congratulated and envied by her sister universities. By a recent bequest she has added to her treasures 322 books printed by JOHN BASKERVILLE of Birmingham, one of the greatest English printers. WILLIAM CASLON'S name and his are most memorable in the history of British type-founding.

Guilty pleas in bogus-accident indemnity conspiracies were entered yesterday by Jacob Hurwitz, 31 years old, pseudo-insurance broker, of 235 East 198th Street, the Bronx, and Samuel Bornstein, 43, of 58 Fort Greene Place. Brooklyn, leaders of separate rings that had defrauded many companies, it was alleged, of nearly $1,000,000 in the last ten years.
The National Collegiate A.A. will stage its thirty-first annual convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania on Dec. 27, 28 and 29, it was announced yesterday.
WOODSTOCK, Ill., Dec. 14. -- The golden voice of Mickey, the Singing Mouse, was stilled today because he got his feet wet.

Representatives of two leading liquor houses expressed the opinion yesterday that the Supreme Court decision upholding the Illinois Fair Trade Act would have little effect on liquor advertising or merchandising policies.

Mae West, motion picture actress, won from Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Callahan yesterday a ruling bringing to an end the attempt of Frank Wallace, vaudeville actor, to have the New York State courts declare him to be Miss West's legal husband.

A general upward trend in both freight and passenger traffic by the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway has marked the current year, according to the annual review of S.T. Bledsoe, president of the company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Presidential electors met in the forty-eight States today to certify the re-election of President Roosevelt and Vice President Garner, but the candidates will not be "officially" elected until the afternoon of Jan. 6, when the Senate and House meet in joint session for that special purpose.

Dean Detton of Salt Lake City, one of the leading claimants of the world's heavyweight wrestling championship, threw Man Mountain Dean of Georgia last night in a scheduled finish bout at the New York Hippodrome before 4,000 spectators.
Building plans filed yesterday included two Bronx apartment projects. as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP). -- Cotton consumed during November was reported by the Census Bureau today to have totaled 626,695 bales of lint and 63,767 of linters, compared with 646,499 and 72,546 during October this year and 512,312 and 59,373 during November last year.

MOSCOW, Dec. 14. -- The Soviet sees in the revolt of General Chang Hsueh-liang in China and his capture of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek not an anti-Japanese and pro-Soviet movement, as it was at first represented to be, but another Japanese manoeuvre designed to weaken and disorganize China at a moment when she is at last beginning to assert herself against Japanese aggression.

A total of $10,000 has been raised by the Women's Commerce Division in the United Hospital Campaign, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Sidney Borg, chairman of the unit. Contributions reported by the individual chairmen for the nine sections of the division, together with the names of the chairmen, follow:

There will be widespread approval of the recommendation, submitted to the President by the director of the Civilian Conservation Corps, that this organization be removed from the list of "emergency" bureaus and be made a permanent agency of the Government. CCC has been one of the most deservedly popular of all Mr. ROOSEVELT'S innovations.

Winslow Homer, one of the greatest artists this country has produced, was born in 1836. In the present centennial year several exhibitions have been organized by way of honoring an artist of the first rank and also of bringing the public into closer contact with his work.
MADRID, Dec. 14. -- Government troops repulsed a sharp attack early this morning when the Insurgents tried to break through their lines at University City.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- With the admonition that "delusive interests of haste" should not interfere with the orderly processes of law, the Supreme Court today sent the Duke Power case back to the lower courts for trial without expressing an opinion on the right of the government to finance publicly owned hydroelectric plants in competition with private enterprise.

The Green Bay Packers, newly crowned champions, led the National Football League in passing for the second successive year, according to the final figures for 1936 announced yesterday. The aerial-minded Wisconsin eleven, paced by Arnold Herber, gained a total of 1,629 yards with forwards.

A new issue of $5,000,000 of fifteen-year 3 per-cent debentures, due on Dec. 1. 1951, of the Dow Chemical Company will be offered today by Edward B. Smith Co. at par and accrued interest. The return on this investment was said yesterday to be the lowest averaged for an industrial issue of comparable maturity in the present period of low-cost financing and to rank with the lowest cost in the history of industrial financing.

Seventeen officers and employes of four corporations were discharged yesterday in Special Sessions on charges of violating the State trade-mark law in the manufacture of allegedly counterfeit automobile parts. The corporations themselves entered guilty pleas, and Justices McInerney, Farrell and Kozicki suspended sentences with the consent of lawyers for the complainant.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday reversed several clauses and amended others of a ten-point cease and desist order issued by the Federal Trade Commission against the Standard Education Society, permitting the society to advertise an offering of a "free" encyclopedia on condition that its customers subscribe for a ten-year "extension service."

A Spanish Youth Front delegation of four, two girls and two young men, arrived on the Queen Mary yesterday and will make a tour of this country in an effort to stimulate a greater interest in and sympathy toward the cause of Spanish democracy.

Charging that Emergency Relief Bureau employes were collecting a $100,000 "slush fund" to block a competitive civil service examination for 3,000 social investigators on Dec. 30, Alderman Joseph E. Kinsley asked spokesmen for the employes yesterday to explain the purpose of the fund.

Ways and means of penetrating the zone defense, which is rapidly becoming popular due to the virtual elimination of the pivot play because of the three-second rule, were demonstrated by Coach Clair Bee of unbeaten Long Island University at the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association luncheon yesterday in the Lincoln Hotel.

Led by the steel, copper, automotive and utility issues, the stock market moved generally higher yesterday. Trading on the Stock Exchange aggregated 2,876,000 shares, the largest turnover since Nov. 18. On the Curb, the volume of slightly less than 1,000,000 shares was the greatest since Feb. 27.

A banking syndicate headed by the Bankers Trust Company and including thirty investment houses won yesterday the award of a new issue of $25,333,000 of general refunding bonds of the city of Detroit on a bid of 100.0005 for the securities as 2 3/4s and 3 1/2s.

WASHINGTON. Dec. 14. -- A total of $254.676,000 was subscribed for two series of Treasury bills aggregating approximately $100,000.000. bids for which were opened today at Federal Reserve Banks. Secretary Morgenthau announced. Of the amount offered, $100,230,000 was accepted.

Joseph Fishbach, De Witt Clinton High School star who is fifth in the national boys' ranking, reached the quarter-final round in the second annual metropolitan junior indoor tennis championships at the 102d Engineers Armory yesterday.
Yesterday. Friday. For the best names . . . . . . 3/4% 3/4% The quotations are for four-six months' paper.
Bobby Pacho, Mexican welterweight, knocked out Pete Mascia of Greenpoint last night in the feature attraction at the St. Nicholas Palace before 4,000 persons.

ALBANY, Dec. 14. -- New York State's forty-seven electoral votes for President Franklin D. Roosevelt and Vice President John N. Garner are on their way to Washington. The electors met here today, the day being the 100th anniversary of the election of Martin Van Buren, the first President from New York State.

BERLIN, Dec. 14. -- With inspired unanimity all German organs of official publicity today represent Moscow generally and the Comintern particularly as the direct instigators of the new upheaval in China.

Led by the steel, copper, automotive and utility issues, the stock market moved generally higher yesterday. Trading on the Stock Exchange aggregated 2,876,000 shares, the largest turnover since Nov. 18. On the Curb, the volume of slightly less than 1,000,000 shares was the greatest since Feb. 27.

A banking syndicate headed by the Bankers Trust Company and including thirty investment houses won yesterday the award of a new issue of $25,333,000 of general refunding bonds of the city of Detroit on a bid of 100.0005 for the securities as 2 3/4s and 3 1/2s.

WASHINGTON. Dec. 14. -- A total of $254.676,000 was subscribed for two series of Treasury bills aggregating approximately $100,000.000. bids for which were opened today at Federal Reserve Banks. Secretary Morgenthau announced. Of the amount offered, $100,230,000 was accepted.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission gave notice today to under-writers of public-utility securities that it would not hesitate to assert its jurisdiction over their charging of commissions for distributing such issues.

The Princeton Club, undefeated leader of the Metropolitan League Class B squash tennis tournament, continued to move along smoothly yesterday in its quest for the title captured last year by the Harvard Club.

OTTAWA, Ont., Dec. 14 (AP). -- Cecil Duncan, president of the Canadian Amateur Hockey Association, announced tonight the severance of "articles of alliance" between the association and the Amateur Athletic Union of Canada. The break goes into effect Jan. 15.

As one of those "inordinately proud" sons of Maine, may I say that I find myself moderately resenting the editorial "A Balky Council" in THE TIMES, not so much because of what it says as because of the identity of the speaker.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Steps designed to meet a complicated situation involving the taxability of distributions of stock to shareholders by corporations were announced to day by Guy T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue.

Meyer Luckman and his nephew, Harry Luckman, who are serving sentences in Sing Sing of from twenty years to life imprisonment for the murder of Samuel Drukman, have decided not to press their appeals from their convictions for second-degree murder, it was announced yesterday.

Mrs. Reeve Schley heads the committee organized to sell programs at the twenty-third annual hockey game between St. Paul's School, Concord, N.H., and the freshman team of Princeton University at Madison Square Garden on Thursday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 . -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Dec. 9 shows increases for the week of $135,000,000 in total loans and investments, $24,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, $13,000,000 in time deposits and $35,000,000 in vault cash, and decreases of $54,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve banks, $55,000,000 in balances with domestic banks and $63,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

Although shorn of their league and world championship laurels during 1936, the Detroit Tigers concluded the campaign still retaining one honor, for by turning in a mark of .975 Mickey Cochrane's men again carried off the team fielding crown in the American League, according to the official averages, announced yesterday.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 14. -- Tournament of Roses football authorities announced triumphantly today that the teams of Washington and Pittsburgh would play before a capacity throng of around 85,000 in the annual Rose Bowl classic New Year's Day.

William Brownlow, young English baritone, who gave his first New York recital at the Town Hall yesterday, is a singer who employs his modest endowments with consistent resourcefulness. His voice is limited in scope, but he was able to establish a wide dynamic range because of a delicate use of various gradations of half voice.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 14. -- The theft from Federal court records of eighteen pages of names of stock and bondholders in the Francisco Sugar Company was disclosed today when an investigation by Federal authorities was ordered. The theft was suspected to be linked to the spectacular rise in bonds of the company following the ending of its receivership last week.

William S. Murray of Utica, a chemical engineer who for the last three years has been chairman of the Oneida County Republican Committee, was elected chairman of the Republican State Committee at a meeting of that body at the National Republican Club yesterday afternoon.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices In New York City:

Jesse Owens's habit of setting the pace makes it no surprise that the Tan Thunderbolt was voted the outstanding athlete, amateur or professional, of 1936 in the sixth annual poll conducted by The Associated Press.

William S. Murray of Utica, a chemical engineer who for the last three years has been chairman of the Oneida County Republican Committee, was elected chairman of the Republican State Committee at a meeting of that body at the National Republican Club yesterday afternoon.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices In New York City:

A large audience attended Albert Morris Bagby's Musical Morning yesterday in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The artists were Enid Szantho, contralto; Richard Crooks, tenor of the Metropolitan Opera, and Emanuel Feuermann, 'cellist.

Superb defensive work which permitted only five points in the second half helped the New York University basketball team to rout the Upsala College five, 46 -- 15, last night on the University Heights court. It was the third straight victory of the season for N.Y.U. and the thirty-sixth consecutive triumph on its home court.

While domestic bonds were stronger in fairly active trading, United States Government series were irregular and foreign bonds were weak on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Transactions amounted to $13,503,800, compared with $13,041,600 on Friday.

WITH PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT AT SEA, Dec. 14 (AP). -- President Roosevelt's flotilla hummed with activity tonight as members of the Presidential party packed and said their farewells in preparation for landing early tomorrow in Charleston, S.C.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 (AP). -- The traditional Army-Navy football game will be played in 1937, 1938 and 1939 in the Municipal Stadium where two weeks ago it was staged before 105,000 persons.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Seeking to collect inheritance taxes of $10,000,000 to $15,000,000 on the $50,000,000 to $80,000,000 estate of Colonel Edward H.R. Green, Texas, through Attorney General William McGraw, asked the Supreme Court today to decide whether Texas, New York, Massachusetts or Florida was entitled to these levies.

A fire of suspicious origin burned through three floors of Public School 127, on Seventh Avenue, from Seventy-eighth to Seventy-ninth Streets, in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn a little before 10 o'clock last night after a prowler, apparently a child, had ransacked the desks of the principal and several teachers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Forty-one persons had million-dollar incomes in 1935, according to a preliminary report for that year issued by the Internal Revenue Bureau today. This compares with thirty-three who had such incomes the previous year.

BERLIN, Dec. 15. -- The Boerse was firmer again today on a small turnover. Heavy industrial stocks had some strength, Nereinigtestahl gaing 1 points and Mannesmann 1% points. Chemical shares were mixed throughout the session. Machine issues had moderate strength; Orenstein climbed 1% points.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- The garden tulip, "on trial" here today with a list of other bulbs at a conference called by Dr. Lee A. Strong, chief of the Bureau of Entomology and Plant Quarantine, was acquitted, so far as the evidence of both entomological experts and commercial growers went, of being a "carrier" for the narcissus nematode or eelworm.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- Deeply tanned and well refreshed by his twenty-eight-day cruise, President Roosevelt returned to the capital tonight expressing high hope for gratifying results from the Pan-American peace conference which he opened at Buenos Aires on Dec. 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- The Treasury Department issued for cash and in exchange for maturing notes $1,509,444,650 of the new 2 1/2 per cent thirteen to seventeen-year bonds and the 1 1/4 per cent five-year notes, Secretary Morgenthau announced today in making public allotment figures on the Dec. 15 financing.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 15. -- Alabama's Unemployment Insurance law, enacted in 1935, was declared violative of State and national Constitutions in a decree issued here today by a three-judge Federal court enjoining its enforcement against the Southern Coal and Coke Company and the Gulf States Paper Company, foreign corporations.
CANNES, France, Dec. 15 (AP). -- Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson received a big bouquet of flowers from the Mayor today in apology for the crowds that gathered about her during a shopping tour.

Burglars who were unusually particular about selecting their loot broke into the office of the New Netherlands Coin Company at 95 Fifth Avenue late Monday night or early yesterday and, after jimmying a large safe, escaped with a quantity of rare and special coins, some dating back to 1690 and others 1,800 years old.

ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 15. -- Raymond Curtaia, 50 years old, a shoemaker, was held up yesterday in his shop at 126 South Essex Avenue, here, by two gunmen, who accompanied him to a bank and forced him to withdraw his life savings of $1,050 and give it to them, it was disclosed by the police today.

William S. Murray, newly elected chairman of the Republican State Committee, was told yesterday by W. Kingsland Macy, former Republican State Chairman and now leader of the Republican forces in Suffolk County, that the two Republican Assemblymen-elect from Suffolk, Edward R. Lupton and Elisha Barrett, would not support Speaker Irving M. Ives for re-election when the 1937 Legislature meets to organize on the first Wednesday in January.

Four men, convicted last Friday of killing Isaac Shain in a Brooklyn bar and grill on the night of Nov. 8, were sentenced yesterday to death in the electric chair by Kings County Judge Algernon I. Nova. Their execution at Sing Sing was set for the week of Jan. 25, but it will be postponed automatically because the first-degree convictions must be reviewed by the Court of Appeals.

Gold to the value of $2,490,000, additional for Monday, was reported yesterday as engaged in England for shipment here. The amount previously reported as engaged there on Monday for American account was $7,910,000. Actual receipts of the metal here yesterday were reported by the Federal Reserve Bank as $1,215,400, all from England.

HANLEY, Staffordshire, England, Dec. 15. -- So keen are collectors to obtain the more expensive coronation commemoration pottery bearing the portrait of former King Edward that some firms have sold out stocks that they had at first believed would be a complete loss and have resumed their manufacture.

Trailing by 13 -- 7 at the close of the first half and 18 -- 15 at the end of the third quarter, the James Monroe High School quintet rallied to beat Stuyvesant High, 25 -- 21, at Monroe in an outstanding non-league basketball struggle yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 15. -- The Argentine customs has finally cleared the packages containing 2,000,000 signatures to the "People's Mandate for World Peace," ten days too late for their presentation to the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace.

MOSCOW, Dec. 15. -- The Soviet Union has launched a general campaign for observance of the guarantees of individual rights in the new "Stalin Constitution." Minor officials have been warned, and in at least one case have been summarily removed for discriminating against persons because of class origin.

Putnam Co. and Chas. W. Scranton Co., heading the group that yesterday offered $16,000,000 of Connecticut Light and Power Company first and refunding mortgage 3 1/4 per cent bonds, announced that subscription books on the issue had been closed, the entire amount having been sold.

PARIS, Dec. 15. -- Although the economic and business situation in France has improved considerably in the last few months, the financial position of the government is weighing heavily upon the market, and transactions have dropped again to a very low ebb.

The Pro-Palestine Federation of America, a Christian organization, criticized British policy there in a resolution adopted yesterday at a luncheon conference on "the Jewish problem" at the Hotel Astor.

MOSCOW, Dec. 15. -- Christmas shopping is in full swing in Soviet Russia and Christmas trees, gay with tinsel and colored lights, adorn many homes. Effigies of Santa Claus, complete with red overcoat and white whiskers, beam from store windows.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Dec. 16. -- Martial law was declared throughout China today by the Central Government authorities in Nanking because of the rebellion in Shensi, where General Chang Hsueh-liang's forces had seized Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and allied themselves with the Communists to demand war against Japan.

NANKING, China, Wednesday, Dec. 16. -- As a result of W.H. Donald's report from Loyang, it is believed here that Chang Hsueh-liang is still in complete control of the Shensi revolt, aimed to force a declaration of war on Japan. This fact brings relief that the Communists have not gained ascendancy in the reported alliance.

Offering will be made today of a new issue of $300,000 of Jacksonville, Fla., 2.60 per cent bonds, due Jan. 1, 1957, by a group headed by William R. Compton Co., Inc., and including Morse Brothers Co., Inc., and the Wells-Dickey Company.

Industrial production throughout the world continued to advance during October, according to the monthly survey of the National Industrial Conference Board. Increases in output in Canada, the Netherlands, France, Germany, Norway and the leading South American countries were sufficient to more than offset isolated declines in a few minor countries.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 15. -- The neutrality convention was finally agreed upon today for introduction in the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace, with the unanimous backing of the twenty-one delegations taking part. Thus untroubled passage of this convention, like the collective security and non-intervention agreements, is assured at tomorrow's plenary session.

Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra opened their concert last night in Carnegie Hall with Prokofieff's "Classical Symphony." The performance by the wonderful orchestra was considerably inferior from the interpretive standpoint to the quality of the composition.
MOSCOW, Dec. 15 (AP). -- The Russian press renewed today charges that "Japanese imperialists" were behind the capture of General Kai-Shek by General Chang Hsueh-Liang.

CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE, N. J., Dec. 15. -- Testimony that more than seventy "floaters" were sent out from headquarters in a Wildwood tavern to cast 200 or more fraudulent votes for William C. Hunt, Republican candidate for State Senator, last Nov. 3 was put into the record today at the hearing before Judge Jayne in Circuit Court here on charges of illegal balloting.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- Retail establishments in New York City, numbering 204,511, did in 1935 a gross business of $4,749,708,000, the total exceeding sales in 1933 by 27 per cent, according to final figures made public today by the Census Bureau in its American business survey.

Sale of four properties, all assets of companies in rehabilitation or liquidation, was announced yesterday by the Title and Mortgage Rehabilitation and Liquidation Bureau of the State Insurance Department. The Franklin Apartments at 721 Franklin Avenue, Garden City, were sold to Sadie Radman for cash above a $285,000 mortgage for five years.

Scoring seventeen consecutive points in a whirlwind finish, Columbia vanquished Fordham, 36 to 28, at the Morningside Heights gymnasium last night. The Lions clicked with startling suddenness in the final eight minutes. In that short span they registered almost as many points as they had in the previous thirty-two and walked off with the basketball game.

MONTREAL, Dec. 15 (AP). -- The Montreal Canadiens, leaders of the National Hockey League's international division, halted the Detroit Red Wings' winning streak tonight by taking a fast game, 4 to 3. The winners increased their lead in the international group, while the losers now are tied with the New York Rangers for first in the American group.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,119,500 barrels, a new high level, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The previous high was established in the week ended Oct. 24 when the daily average was 3,083,050 barrels.
A New York chapter of the National Association of Real Estate Boards was organized yesterday at a meeting of about a score of Manhattan members of the organization in the Hotel Biltmore.
Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, expressed "concern" yesterday over the recent increasingly heavy trading in low-priced shares.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 15 -- The 1938 Princeton University football schedule, announced tonight by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics, will bring a renewal of football relations between Army and the Nassau team after a lapse of thirty years.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 15. -- Heated exchanges between Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein, as a witness in the Supreme Court investigation of Newark municipal affairs, and Andrew J. Steelman, one of the investigators, marked the hearing today. The inquiry, after a week devoted to generalities, turned to the deals involving the acquisition by this city of land in the Port of Newark area.

Five seeded players were among the six who scored third-round victories yesterday to enter the quarter-finals of the annual Fall Class B and C squash tennis championship tourney in progress at the Columbia University Club.

PELHAM, N.Y., Dee. 15. -- A spelling bee between teams of the Men's Club of Pelham and the Manor Club of Pelham Manor, a women's organization, was declared a draw at 10:30 tonight because of the lateness of the hour and lack of suitable words.

Operations of the Florsheim Shoe Company in its fiscal year ended on Oct. 31 resulted in a net profit of $1,041,330 after provision for depreciation, reserves for all doubtful accounts and for Federal income and all other taxes, it was announced yesterday.

Although some of Monday's buying enthusiasm carried over into the early trading in stocks yesterday, many leading issues appeared to be in fairly good supply so that in the afternoon the market moved irregularly. At the closing, declines outnumbered advances about four to three.

For the two weeks or more of the strain at home, the voice of Great Britain is scarcely heard in matters of general European concern. One sign that the British now consider their own crisis to be entirely surmounted is the fact that their Foreign Minister, Captain EDEN, felt free to make on Monday a speech directly addressed to other nations.

Encouraged by domestic producers increasing their price to 11 cents a pound on Monday, export copper prices yesterday advanced to 11.125 cents a pound c.i.f. the European base ports. This is the highest price since August, 1930, and compares with 10.85 to 10.90 cents on Monday.

Lefty Bob Grove, lean and dour left-hander of the Red Sox, who only a little more than two years ago appeared to have reached the l end of a brilliant career, brought a successful climax to his come-back climb by winning the American League's major pitching honors for 1936, according to the official averages, released for publication today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- The investigation of railroad financing by the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce today proved to be one of the most exciting staged by a Senate committee since the days of the Teapot Dome and Daugherty inquiries.

Formation of the National Lawyers Guild, which will seek to be a "progressive force in the life of the nation," was announced yesterday by Frank P. Walsh, a leading advocate of the New Deal, chairman of the National Public Service Commission and president of the guild.

LONDON, Dec. 15. -- There were gains in most sections of the stock market here today, the outstanding features being a sharp rise in Argentine railroad shares and further buying of oil issues on the belief that there will be a general increase in American crude oil prices next month.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 15. -- Paradisical, 4-year-old filly carrying the I.J. Collins silks, turned in a game performance to capture the Coconut Grove Purse before a good-sized crowd today at Tropical Park. The bay daughter of In Memoriam, a Churchill Downs handicap winner in her most recent endeavor, needed one of George Seabo's most powerful rides to squeeze home by a nose.

The second series of Class B team matches in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association, played last night, saw the Harvard and Squash Clubs move into a first-place tie in Group 1, with two victories and no defeats. In Group 2 the Downtown A.C. went into the lead alone.

" Thy need is greater than mine," said Sir PHILIP SIDNEY, and his words have long been a sort of measure of charitable feeling and action. Individual needs may be graded down by fine degrees. The obligation to help a fellow-being in extreme distress rests upon everybody only a little better off than he is.

Secretary WALLACE is far and away the best of the Government pamphleteers, and his annual report for 1936, which is published today, shows the same careful preparation and refreshing candor which have marked his earlier reports. The present document is primarily an account of the changes (mostly for the better) which American agriculture has experienced during the past year.

GENEVA, Dec. 15. -- French and Turkish delegates tonight reached an agreement in principle on measures for the maintenance of order in Alexandretta. French troops have been sent to the port because of agitation for its return to Turkey.

Although the New York Giants failed to carry off the football title, the Maramen received some measure of recognition when it was announced yesterday that Alphonse (Tuffy) Leemans, sensational rookie, had won the individual ground-gaining honors of the National League with a total of 830 yards in 206 attempts.

The pension roll of the Church Pension Fund of the Protestant Episcopal Church is now about $1,300,000 a year, according to a report by William Fellowes Morgan, president, to the trustees at their annual meeting yesterday noon at 20 Exchange Place, offices of the fund.

Another exhibition of unusual interest was added yesterday to the already considerable number of attractions current for lovers of prints. This is the tenth anniversary exhibition of the American Print Makers, whose annual show has for years been held at the Downtown Gallery but is this year being held at the Midtown Galleries, 605 Madison Avenue.

Continued strength in some South American dollar loans and secondary domestic corporate issues again characterized trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The trading pace was stepped up considerably, transactions amounting to $17,299,900, compared to $13,503,800 on Monday.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 15. -- With the climax in Governor La Follette's efforts to oust President Glenn Frank of the University of Wisconsin set for tomorrow, when the Board of Regents of the institution meets, opposition among the 10,000 students here and among educators throughout the country continued to grow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP). -- Operators in the soft coal industry notified the United Mine Workers tonight that they would be asked to increase their work week to forty hours from thirty-five after March 31, with no increase in wages.

A gift of $20,000 from Edward S. Harkness to the United Hospital Campaign fund was announced yesterday by Stuart M. Crocker, general chairman of the fund, in making public a list of forty-two other donors who made gifts ranging from $100 to $1,000.

By the finesse, shown almost at the last moment, of some of the most astute members of the Republican committee, Mr. WILLIAM S. MURRAY, chairman of the Oneida County Republican Committee, was chosen chairman of the State committee. The choice was unanimous.

Spotting their rivals a 2-goal lead, the New York Rangers fought back vigorously against the Montreal Maroons at Madison Square Garden last night to get back this brace of counters and earn a 2-2 deadlock with the sharp-shooting sextet from Canada.

GENEVA, Dec. 15. -- The Committee on League of Nations Reform decided today to divide the score of proposals before it into two categories, the first to be treated as somewhat urgent and the second to be taken up later.

The turnover of more than one billion dollars yesterday in connection with the government's Dec. 15 financing resulted in little change in the reserve position of the nation's banks, as a whole, according to opinions expressed in banking circles.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Dec. 16. -- A report was circulated here today that General Chang Hsuehliang, captor of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, had broadcast from Sian, Shensi, an announcement that the dictator and several of his aides had been put to death.

LONDON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The International Rubber Regulation Committee today fixed permissible exports of the commodity from producing areas for the first quarter of 1937 at 75 per cent of basic quotas and for the second quarter at 80 per cent.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Dec. 15. -- The seventy-fifth birthday of President Pehr Evind Svinhufvud, who by popular consent is hailed as the father of Finland, was celebrated today throughout the country with great enthusiasm. He was acclaimed as the man whose protracted fight for the country's constitutional rights against czarist Russian oppression and whose subsequent hard struggle for Finland's political independence had earned for him his people's everlasting gratitude.

Harry Balsamo will seek to redeem himself tonight. The hard-hitting Harlem middleweight, who had been hailed as the "second Stanley Ketchell" until he was soundly beaten by Babe Risko two months ago, will return to action against Solly Krieger of Brooklyn in the main bout of ten rounds at the New York Hippodrome.
LONDON, Dec. 15. -- Joachim von Ribbentrop, Germany's Ambassador to London, declared tonight that Germany was determined to scrap "the discriminating part of the Versailles treaty." Emphasizing...

Lincoln Ellsworth was the guest of honor last night at a dinner at the New York Athletic Club attended by more than 1,000 members. While all those present stood and cheered the explorer returned to the club for its trophy room the red and white winged foot emblem which he had carried with him on his flight last year across the Antarctic Continent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- Secretary Wallace insisted today that production control must have a place with soil conservation and consumer protection in any permanent agricultural policy. In his annual report to the President Mr. Wallace warned that the present soil conservation program was inadequate to prevent the accumulation of excessive surpluses, and that one year of normal weather might recreate the overproduction of 1933.

Four organizations of WPA workers agreed yesterday to abandon sit-down strikes as a means of airing grievances against the WPA. In return for this agreement, the groups obtained from Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, a pledge that ninety-six persons dismissed for participation in two such demonstrations would be reinstated this morning.

Over the objection of the two defense lawyers, Miss Catherine Pavlick, 26 years old, of 25-25 Steinway Avenue, Astoria, Queens, gave evidence for the State yesterday in the General Sessions trial of A. Henry Ross, a young Brooklyn lawyer, and Max D. Krone, a former private detective, on an extortion indictment.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Dec. 15. -- The Special National Tribunal, created under the state of war proclaimed after the Leftist revolt of November, 1935, has indicted 156 persons as participants in the rebellion. They will be brought to trial very soon.

Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, bought from Interurban Apartments, Inc., Gerald B. Weldon, vice president, the two-and-a-half-story dwelling for two families at 2,629 Grand Avenue, between 192d Street and Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx. George J. Kearns was the broker in the sale of the property, which is 50 by 106 feet and runs back to the Croton Aqueduct.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 15. -- Mrs. James H. Kennedy gave a luncheon and contract for twelve today at Kenlewinai. At Casa del Pastor John Shepard Jr. entertained with luncheon and cards for men, and Oheka was the setting for a small dinner which Mr. and Mrs. John Barry Ryan gave tonight for their guests, Lady Isobel Guinness and Loel Guinness.

With linage for the current month running between 18 and 20 per cent ahead of 1935, magazines in general will wind up this year with gains of approximately 15 per cent over last year, according to comment here yesterday. Linage for this year will come close to the 29,000,000 mark, as against a figure somewhat in excess of 25,000,000 lines for last year.
