ENZESFELD, Austria, Dec. 15 -- Former King Edward had a headache, ear trouble and an "emotional letdown" today and retired to his rooms after a half-hearted bit of practice-putting on the golf links, but plans were made for him to "step out" next week.

MADRID, Dec. 15. -- The new Insurgent attack yesterday and today in the northwest sector of the Madrid front running out to Escorial would seem to indicate that Generalissimo Francisco Franco has at last begun his great offensive against the city.

Coming from behind, the St. John's University basketball team staged a rally in the second half to defeat St. Peter's College, 34 to 26, for its fifth straight victory of the season before a small crowd in the DeGray Gymnasium last night. The defeat was the first St. Peter's has suffered in four games.

ALBANY, Dec. 15. -- To meet increased automobile traffic, Colonel Frederick Stuart Greene proposes to ask the Legislature in 1937 for an appropriation of $150,000,000 for building of four-lane highways on important State routes and to renew his demand that gasoline tax money be used exclusively for roads.

TRENTON, Dec. 15. -- Judge Phillip Forman in the United States District Court here ruled today that railroad companies operating in New Jersey must pay their 1932 and 1933 tax bills in full. The sum in dispute amounts to $10,628,497. It is expected the case will be carried to the Supreme Court.

Governor Lehman predicted that local communities if aided by Federal funds could wipe out the slums of the United States within ten years in an address last night before the National Public Housing Conference at a dinner in the Hotel Roosevelt.

The coming year will bring further expansion in production and in sales but companies expecting to benefit by the improved conditions must be prepared to furnish consumers with quality goods, accurately labeled and reasonably priced, marketing authorities warned yesterday at the first semi-annual meeting of the National Federation of Sales Executives, at the Hotel Commodore.

Now the Navy Department is said to be planning a ban on foreign marriages, after the example of the State Department. The same reason operates. Your married diplomat may blab stats secrets to a foreign wife, and your married navy man may give away even more important military information.

The August Grand Jury, which has been investigating the complaint that Brooklyn is the dirtiest borough in the city, heard Kings County Judge Franklin Taylor charge, yesterday afternoon, that a magistrate who deliberately flaunts the law by handing out wholesale suspended sentences for sanitary violations encouraged violations and was indictable for a misdemeanor or possible removal proceedings before the Appellate Division.
The National Consumers League announced yesterday its advocacy of "an appropriate constitutional amendment to permit without question effective Federal and State labor and social legislation."

A chance to regain the world's heavyweight title now held by James J. Braddock having been assured him, Max Schmeling, former holder of the crown, sailed early this morning on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen for his native Germany.

Play in the second annual metropolitan junior tennis championship was brought down to the semi-finals yesterday, with the four favored entrants coming through to straight-set victories on the Hamilton indoor courts at the 102d Engineers Armory.

A boom in capital goods and construction industries, as part of the general process of recovery, was foreseen yesterday by Malcolm Muir, president of the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company, and a director of the National Association of Manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- That Michael J. Meehan of New York, stock broker, manipulated the market in Bellanca Aircraft stocks so as to give a false impression as to their value, is charged in a report on findings of fact made today to the Securities and Exchange Commission by William Green, one of its trial examiners.

Unexpected repercussions followed yesterday upon the machine gun and tear gas siege of 304 West 102d Street, where Federal agents led by their chief, J. Edgar Hoover, captured Harry Brunette, bank robber and kidnapper, in such melodramatic fashion that Mayor La Guardia demanded to know what all the shooting was about.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 15. -- A bonus clause may be dangled before Bob Feller to get the sensational 18-year-old rookie pitcher to sign his 1937 contract, C.C. Slapnicka, general manager of the Indians, said today.

With the city confronted by a shortage of low-cost housing resulting from enforcement of the Multiple Dwelling Law, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday at a City Hall conference on housing that immediate steps must be taken to meet the emergency situation.
LONDON, Dec. 15. -- The Archbishop of Canterbury's radio speech Sunday criticizing former King Edward has aroused considerable controversy.

The City A.C. strengthened its hold on first place in the Eastern Squash Racquets Association tournament as competition in Group 2 passed the half-way mark last night. The leaders accounted for their fifth victory in a row, turning back the New York A.C., 4 to 1.

LONDON, Dec. 15. -- The royal racing colors of King George VI will be carried tomorrow for the first time when Marconi, the King's entry in the Windsor Steeplechase, enters the race as the favorite. The horse will draw the good wishes of thousands of British turf enthusiasts and others.

While policemen and firemen stood by almost helpless, a 67-year-old retired business man carelessly trod along an eight-inch wide sloping ledge atop the Hotel Pennsylvania for more than an hour yesterday, resisting "an unexplainable impulse to jump."

Many parties were given in conjunction with the Pushkin dinner, the first in a series of entertainments planned for the benefit of the Alexander Pushkin Foundation at Columbia University, which took place last night at the Russian Eagle at the Sherry-Netherland.
Nine days before Christmas and the Neediest wait!

New low-cost records in financing operations of the Port of New York Authority were established yesterday in the award to a banking group headed by Blyth Co., Inc. of a new issue of $10,000,000 of 3 per cent general and refunding bonds, due in 1976, of the Authority, on a bid of 103.8599.

Members of the Musicians Emergency Fund yesterday gathered at the Hotel St. Regis at a luncheon in honor of the wives of prominent artists who in the past have supported the fund's activities. Mrs. Vincent Astor, president of the organization, presided.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- High administrative sources disclosed today that Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, was favored for a new Cabinet post to be known as Secretary of Public Welfare.

BOSTON, Dec. 15. -- Two rapid-fire goals in the overtime enabled the Boston Bruins to turn back the New York Americans for the second time in three nights in an exciting National Hockey League game before a partisan crowd of 15,000 at the Boston Garden tonight.
TOKYO, Dec. 15 (AP). -- The Foreign Office continued today to study evidence of Communist instigation of Marshal Chang Hsuehliang's revolt in China.

Delegates to the American Kennel Club yesterday held their quarterly meeting at headquarters in this city. All of the proposed changes in the rules that had been advertised for the prescribed number of times were adopted. For the most part these comprised minor alterations and clarification of existing regulations.

After two years of strained relations Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, broke definitely yesterday with Harry Bridges, president of the association's San Francisco local and acknowledged leader of Pacific Coast maritime workers.

WARSAW, Poland, Dec. 15. -- Polish-Rumanian military cooperation, which was never interrupted even during the period when the alliance between the two countries seemed to be breaking down, will be extended and improved as a result of the five-day visit here of the Rumanian chief of the general staff, General Nicolae Samsonovici, who returned to Bucharest tonight.

Under the supervision of the American Foundation for the Blind, 15 West Sixteenth Street, 10,000 talking-book machines have been produced this year, with Federal funds totaling $422,000, for the use of needy blind persons, it was reported yesterday by M.C. Migel, president of the foundation.
May I congratulate THE NEW YORK TIMES on its splendid and illuminating article by its foreign correspondent William P. Carney on the situation in Spain.

The board of trustees of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company created yesterday the office of chairman of the board and elected George McAneny to fill the post. Mr. McAneny has been president of the institution three years. Harold Wardwell Hoyt, who has been vice president and general manager for president before moving up to vice president.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 15 (AP). -- Colonel Leonard P. Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company said today that "general business will be better in 1937 than it has been in 1936, in spite of unrest that prevails in much of the world, labor difficulties which may develop here and new legislation that Congress may enact."

Although showing improvement, "the railroads' path to recovery is strewn with difficulties," E.E. Loomis, president of the Lehigh Valley Railroad, said yesterday in his annual review of conditions in this field.

More than eighty members of the New York City Alumni Association of the University of Wisconsin, meeting last night, passed a resolution urging that the university Board of Regents take no action to dismiss Dr. Frank, "before the alumni and the public are apprised of all the facts involved."

Miss Helen Stephens, the Fulton, Mo., flash who streaked down the Olympic 100-meter stretch in 11.4 seconds and broke all records for the metric century, was acclaimed the year's No. 1 woman athlete in the sixth annual poll conducted by The Associated Press.

The Empire Properties Corporation. Howe E. Landers, president, of 10 Park Place, Newark, N.J., acquired yesterday on a bid of $871 over a mortgage of $298,250 and interest the six-story Sherman Hall Apartments at 165-75 Sherman Av., near 204th Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- Speaker Bankhead, who will be re-elected by the House without opposition, returned to Washington today. The chief legislative measures to be acted upon at this session, he indicated, will be the Farm Tenancy Bill and neutrality extension, aside from budgetary measures.

F Sales of Van Wyck Brooks's "The Flowering of New England" have been averaging 2,000 copies daily for the last week, John Macrae Jr, of E. P. Dutton Co. said yesterday. The Dutton book on Mrs, Simpson, "Her Name Was Wallis Warfield." also is averaging 2.000 copies daily, he said.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 15 (AP). -- Robert E. Harlow, notified that the Professional Golfers Association had dismissed him as its tournament manager, indicated today he would attempt to form an organization of his own if the P.G.A. refused to reinstate him.
HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 15. -- The romance of former King Edward and Mrs. Wallis Simpson is not to be done for the screen. The Hays office has officially banned it.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

TOLEDO, Ohio, Wednesday, Dec. 15 (AP). -- Employes of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company plants here, numbering 4,300, staged a sit-down strike early today. Simultaneously, said Glen W. McCabe, president of the Federation of Flat Glass Workers.

CANNES, France, Dec. 15. -- Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson has asked her Aunt Bessie, Mrs. D. Buchanan Merryman of Washington, to join her in Cannes. Mrs. Merryman has previously acted as a chaperone and counselor of Mrs. Simpson and her coming visit has aroused various rumors.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 15. -- El Mundo, in a long leading editorial attack on censorship, calls upon all South American governments to heed the speech of John W. White, chief South American correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, made at the reception given to newspaper men Saturday by Dr. Carlos Saavedra Lamas, Foreign Minister of Argentina, and to assist newspapers in the creation of international good-will by abolishing censorship.

LONDON, Dec. 15. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin, leader of the Conservative party, and Clement R. Attlee, leader of the Labor Opposition in the House of Commons, toasted the United States tonight at an informal private dinner held to form a committee of Members of Parliament to consider ways to foster good will in Anglo-American relations.

A suit for $250,000 damages against J. Sterling Rockefeller, Jere H. Wheelwright and the Garrison Engineering Corporation was disclosed yesterday in Supreme Court when the two individual defendants moved for dismissal of the action on the ground that New York State courts had no jurisdiction.
Larry Kelley, Yale football star, will he honored at the Downtown Athletic Club today when he is presented with the Heisman Trophy by the club as being the most valuable player of the year.

Soon after Judge Cornelius F. Collins in General Sessions yesterday ordered the third New York County grand jury to start a vigorous investigation of the garnishee racket, especially among city employes, the first six witnesses were questioned before the jurors by Harold W. Hastings, Assistant District Attorney.

Mrs. Charles J. Welch entertained at luncheon yesterday in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre for Mrs. Clarence C. Chapman. Other guests were Mrs. Edward Gould, Mrs. Philip A.S. Franklin, Mrs. Julian S.L. Humphrys, Mrs. James B. Lowell, Mrs. Arthur Ryle, Mrs. C. Carroll Carpenter, Mrs. Leonard P. Morgan, Mrs. J. William Kilbreth, Mrs. Ernest Flagg, Mrs. Henry O. Tallmadge, Mrs. Robert B. Minis, Mrs. William Willis Reese, Mrs. Edwards Spencer and Mrs. Drexel Dahlgren.
The petition to close the New York Stock Exchange on Dec. 26 has been signed by 473 members, it was announced yesterday by the Exchange.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 15. -- Local 301 of the United Electrical and Radio Workers of America, affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization headed by John L. Lewis, was chosen today as the collective bargaining agency of employes of the General Electric Company's plants here.

BERLIN, Dec. 15. -- Although Europe's politics have largely slipped from the hands of Foreign Ministers and professional diplomats and are being conducted in the main by the realistic gentlemen dealing in rival propaganda and surreptitious shipments of arms and "volunteers," there are signs that the various foreign offices are trying to recapture command to avert a catastrophe.

The Neediest Cases Fund passed the $100,000 mark yesterday as 504 contributors -- the largest number on any one day since the 1936 appeal opened -- gave $11,940.48 to those in greatest distress in New York City.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 15. -- In hopes of catching a glimpse of man in the making, seven American scientists will make their home for the next nine months with the anthropoid apes in the jungles of Siam, Borneo and Sumatra to make close observations of the life, habits and behavior of the subhuman species in their natural environment, it was announced here today by Harvard University.

Pointing to the small increase in brokers' loans accompanying the current advance in prices of securities, the monthly Bulletin of the New York Stock Exchange asserts that "this is eminently a cash market, and as such is relatively devoid of that major characteristic of speculative inflation the use of borrowed money."

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Dec. 15. -- A Western Air Express liner with four passengers and a crew of three was missing tonight and planes, automobiles and persons on foot hunted over a treacherous terrain in Central Utah, where some feared the ship had fallen.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 15. -- Thirty persons were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of using the mails to perpetrate an alleged fraud involving millions of dollars in connection with the celebrated "Baker estate."

The leadership of the Republican party will be formed, when formation becomes possible, by those party members elected to Congress who supported Governor Landon and by the State chairmen in the Commonwealths where the bulk of Mr. Landon's national vote was polled.

LANSING, Mich., Dec. 15. -- Miss Hope Morgan, young social worker, who shot and killed her best friend a week ago, hanged herself in the county jail early today. The body was found by sheriff's officers dangling from a water pipe. She had made a rope out of silk pajamas and stockings.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP). -- Charges of industrial coercion of voters in the recent election campaign were dismissed in wholesale fashion today by the Senate campaign investigating committee, but inquiries into a batch of new complaints were ordered.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 15. -- Consideration of proposals for the establishment of an inter-American court of justice was postponed until the Pan-American conference to be held at Lima, Peru, in 1938. This was a result of a resolution adopted today by the first standing committee of the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace.

Miss Hellman is in her somberest mood in "Days to Come," which was acted at the Vanderbilt last evening. Having finished with the tragic consequences of malicious gossip in "The Children's Hour," she is now investigating the tragic consequences of strikebreaking in a small Middle Western community.

LONDON, Dec. 15. -- Leaders of London's monetary market were heartened this afternoon by an announcement by Chancellor of the Exchequer Neville Chamberlain that out of 65,000,000 in gold unexpectedly purchased today by the Bank of England's issue department 60,000,000 would be employed to reduce the Bank's fiduciary note issue and 5,000,000 to increase the basis of credit.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 15 (AP). -- An increase in the number of persons employed and increased wages were given as major factors for rises in collections and credit sales during November for cities reporting to the research division of the National Retail Credit Association. Of forty-two cities reporting today, thirty-three showed collection gains and forty reported credit sales increases.
VATICAN CITY, Dec. 15. -- Pope Pius's breath came with difficulty tonight after he had suffered a relapse from the ailments that have kept him in bed for eleven days, Vatican sources said.

The engagement of JOHN BARBIROLLI as sole conductor for the next three seasons of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra has much to commend it. It marks the end of the star-conductor system and the policy of divided leadership under which the Philharmonic has functioned, with various results, through the last fifteen seasons.

The third of the season's plays about military school life -- though this is the first comedy on that subject -- will come along to the Biltmore tonight under the title of "Brother Rat." John Monks Jr. and Fred F. Finklehoffe wrote it, from observations of their own academic surroundings at V.M.I., and Frank Albertson of the movies is one of the leading players.
Three more police captains retired from the force yesterday, making way for the promotion of three lieutenants from the captains' list, which will expire at midnight Saturday.

MADRID, Dec. 15. -- Defense officers asserted tonight that they had observed German troops in the front lines of the Rebels attacking Boadilla del Monte. The drive involving the Germans, they said, was "duly checked."

James E. Bennet, lawyer, of 38 Park Row, was brought to trial yesterday before a church commission on a charge of "defiance of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, and acts contrary to the Word of God and to the rules and regulations of this church, founded thereupon."

Registration of visiting buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday was less than in the preceding week. However, the total was well above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES. The arrivals for the week numbered 531, as against 683 in the previous week and 429 in the same period last year.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 15. -- Argentina, El Salvador and Colombia made reservations today to the revised draft neutrality convention agreed upon by the delegates to the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace. The consensus was that these reservations would not hamper the consultative machinery on neutrality.

Two thousand pints of pasteurized cream, frozen by the Birdseye process, have been shipped to Moscow for Joseph E. Davies, the new United States Ambassador to Soviet Russia, who will proceed there shortly with Mrs. Davies.

THE NEW YORK TIMES Hundred Neediest Cases Fund and nine charitable institutions were named among the legatees in the will of Miss Cora Fielding, daughter of Michael B. and Mary A. Fielding, who died on Dec. 3. This was learned yesterday when her will was filed for probate in Surrogates' Court.

Creation of a reserve of $350,000 for depreciation of securities, charging the sum to paid-in surplus, was reported yesterday by the United Corporation to the Securities and Exchange Commission in an amended annual report.

The Duke of Sutherland, Lady Geddes, Sir Harry and Lady McGowan, Princess S.A. Poniatowski, Lady Keith Fraser and Henri Morin de Linclays, director of the French Line in the United States, are among the 1,200 passengers sailing today for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- Requests for immediate action on three motions for dismissal made by respondents in connection with the complaint brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission against C.C. Wright of New York and others, for alleged manipulative activities in the stock of the Kinner Airplane and Motor Corporation on the Los Angeles Stock Exchange, have been denied by the commission.

A Christmas bonus of about $125,000 will be distributed among employes of the Collins Aikman Corporation, it was announced yesterday by W.G. McCullough, president. Approximately 5,000 employes in Rhode Island, Pennsylvania, North Carolina, New York City and Canada will receive $25 each.
Sales of housing and business properties in scattered sections of Manhattan were reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- A detailed study of the administration's lending agencies. to determine the need of extending some which soon expire. was started today by Secretary Morgenthau, acting as chairman of the Interdepartmental Committee for Coordinating the Various Credit Units.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15. -- Continued heavy receipts of hogs were reflected today in a decline of 5 to 25 cents compared to the best prices on Monday. The extreme top of $10.05 a hundredweight showed a loss of 20 cents and was the lowest in ten days.

GENEVA, Dec. 15. -- The China committee of the League of Nations Council met here today and, undeterred by events in the Far East, adopted its program for Chinese reconstruction during the coming year. The program consists of two parts -- the sending of foreign experts to advise Nanking and the bringing of Chinese experts to the West to study.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 15. -- The newspaper Nacion, which is supposed to have close access to the views of Foreign Minister Carlos Saavedra Lamas of Argentina, devoted its leading editorial to praise of the inter-American collective security and non-intervention agreement.

A number of expansions and full-floor leases were reported by brokers yesterday. The Schenley Products Company took five additional floors in the Terminal Warehouse Company structure bounded by Twenty-seventh and Twenty-eighth Streets and Eleventh Ave-and overlooking the North River, through the Cross Brown Company.
After months of surveys and investigations, the Board of Aldermen voted unanimously yesterday to adopt a new comprehensive Traffic Code replacing the old system created by individual ordinances.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 15 (AP). -- The Albany Evening News id today that Joe Cambria has expressed his willingness to sell for $60,000 to unnamed Albany men his International League baseball franchise.

Declaring that imports of Japanese cotton cloths into this country will reach a new high record in the early part of next year, Dr. Claudius T. Murchison, president of the Cotton Textile Institute, said yesterday that the volume "will constitute a genuine menace for the entire domestic industry before the passage of another year."

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Dec. 15. -- The Short Hills Club's 4-1 victory over the Elizabeth Town and Country Club today brought the two teams into a second-place tie in Class B of the Women's New Jersey Squash Racquets Association.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 15. -- As a Federal grand jury began an investigation here today of alleged frauds in the Nov. 3 election. Judge Albert L. Reeves disclosed that he was threatened by an anonymous telephone caller last night a few hours after he ordered the inquiry.
This is the story of four exuberant boys who dragged a weary man from slippered ease and the cozy depths of a living-room chair to roam the wide open spaces of Westchester.

A plan for the mutualization and consolidation of the National Investors Corporation and its affiliated investment companies, the Second, Third and Fourth National Investors Corporations, was announced yesterday by Fred Y. Presley, president of each of the companies.

The Blackbirds of Long Island University recorded their thirty-eighth consecutive basketball victory by downing the Panzer College quintet, 61 -- 29, before a capacity crowd at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- John D.M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, returned here today from a Southern vacation and left immediately for Chicago, where he will submit his resignation at a meeting of the committee on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- The rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission covering unlisted trading have been amended so as to make it plain that any National Securities Exchange may suspend or terminate unlisted trading privileges in any security in accordance with the rules of the exchange, subject to the requirement that it shall promptly notify the commission of any such action, the effective date and the reasons.

The directors of Sears, Roebuck Co. yesterday voted an extra dividend of $2.50 a share, payable Jan. 7 to stockholders of record Dec. 26. This is the balance of the extra dividends forecast by the board last October, when an extra of $1.75 a share was declared.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 15. -- Zionist worries over one of the two dangers confronting the future development of the Jewish national home -- the proposed law restricting Jewish land purchases, a danger equal only to the suggested curtailment of Jewish immigration in Palestine -- loomed large at today's session of the British Royal Commission.

Declaring that the sixty-one divisions already organized to solicit subscriptions to the $27,829,000 of New York World's Fair, 1939, Inc., 4 per cent debentures, which were formally offered last week, have accepted their quotas in excess of $28,000,000, Richard Whitney, chairman of the bond sales committee, expressed confidence at the committee's headquarters yesterday, that the issue would be oversubscribed.

THE NEW YORK TIMES published a dispatch from Berlin by Otto D. Tolischus about a speech by Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics and president of the Reichsbank, in which he demands colonies for Germany.

The Brooklyn Prep quintet advanced to a tie for first place with St. Augustine's in the Brooklyn C.H.S.A.A. tournament by virtue of a 24-11 triumph over Holy Trinity on the latter's court yesterday. Each of the leaders has scored two victories in as many starts.

The Spanish Government, through its embassy in Washington, decided last night to intervene in the international situation involving the Spanish freighter Navemar, which is alleged by its Spanish owners to have been seized by the crew in behalf of the Loyalist government.

Business failures in the week ended Dec. 10 in the retail division dropped to eighty-eight, compared with ninety-two in the previous week, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Declines were also reported in the manufacturing, wholesale and commercial service branches. The detailed report is as follows:

HOBOKEN, N.J., Dec. 15. -- Confessions of participation in the casting of 150 illegal Republican votes in Cape May County were submitted to United States Commissioner Stanton here today when three men were arraigned on charges of violating the Federal election laws by voting in Wildwood, N.J., last Nov. 3.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- The Social Security Act reached the Supreme Court today when George P. Davis, a stockholder in the Boston Maine Railroad, asked for a constitutional test of the law.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 15. -- The delicacy of the situation in the English royal household has caused Harold Lloyd to discard the script upon which his writers have been working for several months and seek a new story for his next Paramount film.
The city's capital outlay budget for 1937 in its preliminary form carries departmental requests for a total of $429,488,161, according to schedules listed yesterday in The City Record.

LONDON, Dec. 15. -- An assertion that Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson's social set had been all too friendly with a foreign power was made by Ellen Wilkinson, Member of Parliament, who before the crisis broke had made many attempts to drag Mrs. Simpson's romance with Edward into the limelight of parliamentary debate.

LONDON, Dec. 15. -- Germany's campaign to regain her lost colonies was launched on British soil tonight by Ambassador Joachim von Ribbentrop in his first speech to a British audience since his appointment to the Court of St. James.

Athletic leaders from seven Eastern colleges, bound by tradition into what has come to be called the "Ivy League." are meeting this week at the Georgia plantation of Jim Lynah, Cornell's athletic director, to do a little hunting and fishing.

Internal Revenue officials have been using income tax records to draw up their own lists of potential taxpayers under the unemployment insurance and old-age benefit titles of the Federal Social Security Act, it was learned yesterday.

PARIS, Dec. 15 (AP). -- The government has decided to try to halt the smuggling of gold out of France by issuing bonds for gold holders under which they would make a profit from the recent devaluation of the franc, officials said tonight.

BOSTON, Dec. 15. -- The great playing of Captain George Ford and his first line carried Harvard to an 8-0 triumph over the Massachusetts Institute of Technology six at the Boston Arena tonight as a crowd of about 1,000 watched the Crimson in its debut.

With metals, rubber, hides and silk buoyant in active trading, other commodity futures were erratic on local Exchanges yesterday. On the cash markets rubber rose 68 points to a new high record, hides and zinc made new highs and tin also advanced. Cotton, Rio coffee, lard, cocoa, silk and all the grains declined.

In twelve minutes yesterday a jury in Judge William Allen's part of General Sessions returned a verdict of guilty of assault in the second degree against Philip Travis, 22 years old, for a brutal attack on a textile manufacturer last September when his shop was being picketed in a strike.

Three Emergency Relief Bureau investigators and two Bowery clothing merchants were arrested and held for trial in Special Sessions yesterday on charges of violating the Public Welfare Law by conspiring to defraud homeless men of part of their clothing vouchers.

Before the huge fireplace in the foyer of Washington Irving High School students and faculty members had their annual pre-Christmas thrill yesterday morning when they filled 400 big red stockings with toys, candies, books and other gifts for needy children.

With the December position off the board at noon yesterday, trading on the Cotton Exchange quieted and prices ended unchanged to 6 points lower than on Tuesday. While commission house, mill and foreign buying continued substantial, an increase in hedging operations furnished the market with more contracts, while urgent covering in the spot month ceased.

A one-yard plunge over the goal line early in the second period by Frank Saniuk enabled the Danbury Trojans to defeat the New Rochelle Bulldogs, 7 to 0, before a crowd of 1,500 at the 105th Field Artillery Armory last night. Saniuk's scoring effort climaxed a 64-yard sustained march by the Trojan eleven.
A short time ago, when her story was submitted for the Neediest Cases Fund appeal, she was "a sick mother in despair."

A contest for domination of the management of the Kansas City Southern Railway which the veteran L.F. Loree had waged since 1931 ended yesterday with the severance of his connections with the company. He was succeeded as chairman of the board by Kenneth D. Steere, a partner in Paine, Webber Co., formerly brokers for the Van Sweringen interests.

After several labor organizations had protested the award of a $126,795-order for business machines by the city to Remington Rand, Inc., because of that company's labor policies, Mayor La Guardia vetoed yesterday an ordinance which would have permitted the purchase.

Selected South American dollar obligations stood out as the only major group to exhibit underlying strength in bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Domestic loans, including both the higher grade investments as well as the secondary issues, were subjected to varying degrees of selling pressure and drifted irregularly to moderately lower levels.

Owners of Queens properties provided the bulk of plans filed yesterday for new construction in this city. The proposed improvements in that borough included numerous small dwellings and large apartment houses in Kew Gardens and Jamaica.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Going to his office this morning for the first time since he departed on Nov. 17 for a 13,000-mile journey to Buenos Aires, President Roosevelt approved plans for a "simple but colorful" inauguration ceremony on Jan. 20 to mark the beginning of his second term.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16. -- George A. McKinlock was a retired utility executive, manufacturer, philanthropist, prominent member of Chicago society and donor of the McKinlock Downtown Campus of Northwestern University.

The Chase National Bank will pay employes with saIaries of less than $5,000 a year bonuses amounting to 4 per cent of their salary this year, or about one-half of one month's salary, Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman, announced last night at the annual meeting of the Chase Bank Club in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel

Margaret Kennedy, author of "The Constant Nymph," has signed a contract with Random House for the publication here of her new novel, "Together and Apart." The novel is the current English Book Club selection. It will be published here in March.

Passengers due to arrive today from Gothenburg on the Swedish-American motorship Kungsholm include Mme. Kerstin Thorberg, Swedish opera singer, and her husband, Gustaf Bergman; Sigurd Steckmest, Norwegian Consul in San Francisco; Captain and Mrs. Hugh Murril, Mrs. Hanna Pierson, Mr. and Mrs. William Pittson and Mrs. Elly Coonley.
Nelson S. Dearmont was elected yesterday a vice president of the New York Trust Company. Gustave B. Widoff was appointed auditor.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 16. -- To the accompaniment of cheers from students Dr. Glenn Frank, at a stormy session of the Board of Regents, today, defied the forces seeking to unseat him as president of the University of Wisconsin.

Michael Pecoraro, alias Joseph Briano, who pleaded guilty to an indictment charging that he fraudulently obtained nineteen Federal housing loans from two banks, was sentenced by Federal Judge William Bondy yesterday to eighteen months in the penitentiary.

The enactment of laws requiring the sterilization of those suffering from dementia praecox and manic depressive types of insanity "would eliminate some of the world's most brilliant minds and would result in a world populated largely by Babbitts," Dr. Foster Kennedy, internationally known authority on nervous and mental diseases, declared yesterday in a symposium held by the division of psychiatry, New York City Department of Hospitals, in the recently completed Psychiatry Building of Bellevue Hospital.
Roy W. Wright has resigned from the McCall Corporation to join the Blaker Advertising Agency as account executive for the American Radiator Company.

Two prime favorites of the Metropolitan, Elisabeth Rethberg, soprano, and Ezio Pinta, basso, were heard in a joint recital at the Town Hall last night, given for the benefit of the endowment fund of that institution. Despite the unfavorable weather a large audience was present which waxed so enthusiastic that both artists were forced to add many encores in the course of the evening.

A report on the balloted decision of General Electric Company employes in Schenectady, N.Y., to have Local 301 of the United Electrical and Radio Workers of America represent them in collective bargaining was sent to Washington yesterday by Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, director of the National Relations Board.

Several aspects of the administration's studies and observations on the methods to be used for modifying and keeping under control a possible boom seem to be worthy of comment. The very fact that official attention is being directed to the problem is strikingly different from the attitude adopted in the Twenties.

CANNES, France, Dec. 16 (AP). -- A French taxpayer's protest brought a hasty assurance from Mayor Pierre Nouveau tonight that he had not dug into the public coffers of Cannes to pay for flowers for Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson.

An auction sale of the eighteen-story apartment house at the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street, scheduled for yesterday, was stayed by order of the Appellate Division. The action was brought by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, trustee, against the New York Deaconess Association of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 16 (AP). -- Nationally known figures of civil and military aviation will send greetings or appear personally here tomorrow to shake the hand of Orville Wright, who with his brother Wilbur made history just thirty-three years ago on the dunes of Kitty Hawk, N.C.

Ten officials of the city of Los Angeles were in this city yesterday conferring with municipal bankers on plans to market $47,000,000 of bonds of the Department of Water and Power of the city of Los Angeles. Among them were E.C. Scattergood, director of the department and Clyde Ehret, controller of the board.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Arguments on the constitutionality of the Washington State Minimum Wage law for women began today before the Supreme Court, which last June ruled invalid a New York State Minimum Wage law by a five-to-four vote, and a little more than ten weeks ago refused to grant a rehearing on that statute.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 6 (AP). -- The Argentine Statistical Department tonight announced a preliminary estimate of the 1936-37 wheat crop of 6,800,000 metric tons. This estimate, the largest since 1933-34, is 655,560 tons over the average for the last five years and 502,330 tons over the average for the last ten years.

A sentence of eight to sixteen years in Sing Sing was imposed by Judge Morris Koenig in General Sessions yesterday on Edward Bradley, 27 years old, a suspended patrolman, in the shooting and killing of two men last May 11 in a drunken fight beside a taxicab at Fort Washington Avenue and 193d Street.

It is said that President ROOSEVELT is planning to fill and give away half a dozen Christmas stockings to as many grandchildren. Will the stockings be streamlined and have an inner coating of cellophane? Mention of such a type of hosiery occurs in the holiday literature and is conducive to wonder.

Eddie Driggs, famed Princeton gridiron star who, following his graduation, took up golf and approached stardom, will be inducted into office as president of the Metropolitan Golf Association tonight when that organization holds its annual meeting at the Commodore Hotel.

Public offering will be made today, by means of a prospectus, of a new issue of $2,500,000 of first-mortgage 4 1/2 per cent convertible bonds of the Mengel Company by James C. Willson Co. of this city and the Metropolitan St. Louis Company of St. Louis.
TRENTON, Dec. 16. -- It appeared probable tonight that the Legislature in special session next week would enact an unemployment compensation law similar to the New York statute.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Miss Nina Tamburo, 19, of 328 Stockton Street, Brooklyn, a stenographer and lawyers' assistant, and Henry C. Jordon, 48, of 393-A Putnam Avenue, Brooklyn, an insurance company investigator, were held in $5,000 bail each yesterday by Magistrate Gustav Wieboldt in Queens Felony Court on charges of forgery and grand larceny.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 16. -- Cardinal Copello, Archbishop of Buenos Aires, in a radio address to the United States tonight praised the work of the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace, saying it has the undivided sympathy and support of the church.

At least half of the retail store positions now held by men could be handled as well or better by women, Kenneth Collins, vice president of Gimbel Brothers, said yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Fashion Group at the Hotel Biltmore.

Despite a "nominal saving in taxes" it is "not advisable" for corporations to change their form and become partnerships because of the Revenue Act of 1936, according to a detailed study made by credit men who are members of the Uptown Credit Group of the Textile Industry and the National Federation of Textiles, Inc.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 16. -- Many dinner and supper parties marked the opening tonight of the Patio for its fourth season. Flower-decorated tables filled the loggias surrounding the dance floor. Colored lights added to the festive air.

The Radio City Music Hall will usher in today its Christmas show, "Rainbow on the River," starring Bobby Breen, the boy singer, with May Robson, Charles Butterworth, Louise Beavers, Alan Mowbray and Benita Hume, and a Yuletide stage presentation, "Christmas Greetings."

Fortunately the authors of "Brother Rat," which was acted at the Biltmore last evening, have taken the frivolous point of view towards military schools, and George Abbott sees eye to eye with them. They are John Monks Jr. and Fred F. Finklehoffe, late privates in dubious standing at Virginia Military Institute, and apparently they had a good time at school.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 16. -- Pitt's husky Panthers headed West tonight for their fourth attempt to capture a Rose Bowl football game -- a grim-looking bunch of youngsters.

The New York Americans will return to action at Madison Square Garden tonight when they skate against the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League engagement starting at 8:45 o'clock. It will be the second time this season the two clubs have met, the local skaters having won the first contest.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 16. -- Cornell's tall, rangy basketball team defeated a veteran University of Rochester quintet before 1,400 tonight, 49 -- 32. Walt Foertsch, only sophomore in the Red line-up, tallied 23 points, only one of them from the foul line.

Efforts to increase the output of steel ingots from the present level, 79 per cent of capacity, will be hindered by shortages of coke and pig iron, the magazine Iron Age reports in its weekly review, issued yesterday.
BARCELONA, Spain, Dec. 16. -- Three issues vitally affecting the proletarian revolutionary cause in Spain are raised by the Catalan government crisis which has been in progress since Saturday night.
LONDON, Dec. 16. -- Despite the growing number of Italian "volunteers" in Spain, the long-delayed Anglo-Italian agreement over the Mediterranean was reported today to be almost ready for signature.

Formal offering to the public of 490,000 shares of capital stock of the Transwestern Oil Company will be made today at $13.75 a share by an underwriting group headed by Riter Co. and including Reynolds Co. and Vallance Co. This will be the first public financing for Transwestern Oil, which was organized recently to take over the oil and gas properties of the Slick-Urschel interests in the Southwest.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Dec. 17 (AP). -- The newspapers of China united today in an emotional appeal to the people, asking unqualified support of the government in the crisis created by the seizure of General Chiang Kai-shek.

Seven Catholic charities or educational institutions are named among the beneficiaries in the will of Mgr. Mallick J. Fitzpatrick, late rector of the Mission of the Immaculate Virgin for the Protection of Homeless Children, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday.
ALBANY, Dec. 16. -- Invitations to the inauguration of Governor Lehman Jan. 1 are being mailed, and the Assembly Chamber is being transformed for the ceremony.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 16. -- The Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace set up today vast machinery in the Americas for making peace a strong and vital weapon with which to combat war.

ROME, Dec. 16. -- William Phillips, United States Ambassador, and Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano signed at the Palazzo Chigi today an agreement reciprocally denouncing the old Italo-American commercial treaty which had regulated trade between the two countries since 1871.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP). -Golfdom's turf experts have outwitted nature, turning the rusty brown grass of Fall into a bright green carpet.

The Princeton freshmen and St. Paul's School of Concord, N.H. -- principals in one of the oldest hockey rivalries in the United States -- will clash in their twenty-third annual meeting this afternoon in Madison Square Garden.
Jack Brosnan tallied at the start of a three-minute overtime period to give the unbeaten St. Augustine's High School quintet a 16-14 triumph over Adelphi Academy at the loser's court yesterday.

NANKING, China, Thursday, Dec. 17 -- Government troops in considerable force and a Communist army were engaged today in a race toward Sian, Shensi Province, where Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, China's dictator, is held captive by General Chang Hsueh-liang.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The charges of the Securities and Exchange Commission's investigators that Michael J. Meehan manipulated the stock of the Bellanca Aircraft Corporation on the New York Curb Exchange in violation of the provisions of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 were asserted to be built on "inference on inference" and to be unsusceptible of proof by Monroe Goldwater, counsel for Mr. Meehan, in arguments before the full commission today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Fully aware of the difficulties which the large party majorities in both houses of Congress may create, the Democratic leadership started today a series of conferences with President Roosevelt to chart a general course of legislation for the coming session.

ARMONK, N.Y., Dec. 16. -- John M. Crowley, Town Clerk of North Castle, which includes this village, gave notice today he would not issue marriage licenses to couples after 10 P.M. from now on without previous reservation, and then only for extraordinary reasons.

SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 16. -- Two women and five men, missing in a giant skyliner, were given up for dead tonight just as one searcher came upon what might be "tracks" of the plane and a new storm broke over the snow -- encrusted mountains where the hunt was centered.

Don Hutson, star end of the champion Green Bay Packers, established new marks in pass receiving and in yardage gained as the result of forward passes in finishing at the top of the National League standing, according to the final statistics.

BERLIN, Dec. 16. -- The Catholic bishopric of Berlin, through its diocesan journal, protests openly today against the libeling of the Church and its clergy by the Angriff, the official National Socialist party newspaper, which Dr. Joseph Goebbels, the Minister of Propaganda, founded.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Holiday merchandising this year is being featured by the buying of costly gifts in greater volume than has been true of Christmas trade during the last few years, Secretary Roper reported today, on the basis of reports received from district offices of the Commerce Department.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 16. -- "The Prisoner of Zenda" was announced today by Selznick International as Ronald Colman's next picture. Production will start in February, with Colman playing the dual role of the King and of Rupert Rassendyll, the pretender.

PARIS, Dec. 16. -- The Rumanian Foreign Minister, Victor Antonescu, who arrived here after visits to Belgrade, Prague and Warsaw, began a series of talks with French statesmen today looking toward reaffirming and strengthening the mutual pledges between France and the Little Entente.

Amelita Galli-Curci, who has not visited New York in several years, arrived here yesterday for a brief stay, and discussed her recent return to the concert stage, the art of singing and her future plans. On the subject of her own voice, the singer was most emphatic on one point.

Police Commissioner Valentine and Fire Commissioner McElligott "cracked down" yesterday on J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, as a hunter of headlines as well as of fugitive criminals.

LONDON, Dec. 16 (AP). -- Former King Edward's finances, which, informed persons said, need never worry him. were believed to have been the subject of a talk today between his brother, King George VI, and the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Neville Chamberlain.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the weekend have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Pictures Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local private and public elementary and high schools:

Brokers' reactions to the apprehension expressed yesterday by Charles R. Gay, president of the Stock Exchange, over the increased trading activity in "penny stocks" were mixed. Many brokers, on the floor and in the offices of member firms, were said to be in thorough accord with Mr. Gay.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16. -- Mayor S. Davis Wilson announced settlement tonight of a truck drivers' strike which had threatened the loss of $1,000,000 worth of perishable goods on railroad sidings in Philadelphia.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban area for the week ended Dec. 12 showed a gain of 3 per cent over the comparative 1935 period, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The increase is well under expectations, the small rise being accounted for by adverse weather and fewer night openings of department stores here last week.

The engagement of $1,738,000 gold in England for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This amount, of which $756,000 was taken yesterday and the remainder on a previous date, brought to $154,000,000 the amount of gold taken in England for shipment here since the currency devaluations by the gold-bloc nations on Sept. 26.

Operating revenues of the Union Pacific Railroad last month were about 15 per cent more than the $12.040,397 earned in November, 1935, according to Carl R. Gray, president. He said that, because of adjustments made at this time of year, it would be difficult to estimate net operating income for last month, but that it would be ahead of the $2,539,467 earned in November, 1935.
VATICAN CITY, Dec. 16. -- Pope Pius is said to have benefited by his day of absolute rest and to have a good chance of passing a relatively comfortable night.

Caroline Whitney writes in your paper very encouragingly concerning the activities of the Milk Consumers Protective Committee. It may be that something helpful to us milk producers may come as a result of their efforts. We seem unable to do anything for ourselves.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16. -- Prices of hogs were steady to generally 10 cents a hundredweight higher here today, although some early sales were regarded as showing as much as 20 cents above the low point of yesterday. While packers balked at paying the full advance, there was only a small carry-over.

Stuart M. Crocker, chairman of the United Hospital Fund Campaign, announced last night large donations by business houses. Mr. Crocker revealed that thirty-eight corporations that have made gifts of $1,000 or more have given 25 per cent more this year than last.
TOKYO, Dec. 16. -- Suggestions from abroad that either Tokyo or Moscow is behind the seizure of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in China are allowed to cancel each other by informed opinion here.

Save for a slight improvement in tone in the late trading, the stock market moved in uncertain fashion yesterday and prices generally fluctuated within narrow limits. The closing was irregular, slightly lower on the average than on Tuesday. The day's business on the Stock Exchange was 1,945,000 shares, compared with 2,481,000 the day before and with 2,876,000 on Monday.

Urging community support in financing the New York World's Fair, Douglas L. Elliman, chairman of the realty division of the Fair Bond Sales Committee, predicted yesterday that a sharp upward surge in realty values would result from the fair.

The estate of Mrs. Josephine E. McFadden, lawyer and a director of the Crowell Publishing Company, who died on July 3, 1932, increased in value more than 200 per cent from May 1, 1935, to last Oct. 31, when it was worth $3,500,000. The increase was caused by appreciation in value of securities held by the estate.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 16 (AP). -- Rose Bowl ticket officials looked up today from their pleasant task of counting receipts and announced Washington University's Huskies and Pittsburgh's Panthers probably will play before the second richest gate in the history of the New Year's Day classic.

Backed by the Corporation Counsel's office, Motorcycle Patrolman Michael Darienzo will appear in Washington Heights Court before Magistrate W. Overton Harris today to answer a summons charging him with violation last Sunday morning of the Anti-Noise Law.
Manhattan realty activity was marked yesterday by housing deals on St. Nicholas Avenue and sales and leases of buildings in other sections of the borough.

The President returns from his cruise to the South Temperate Zone breathing peace for the Americas. His sublime obsession gives hope to a group which is among those most eagerly awaiting an audience. These are the newest devotees of peace -- representatives of big business and finance in the United States -- though the peace they are immediately interested in concerns their personal affairs.
The Harvard Club's Class C squash racquets team registered its third consecutive triumph in the Metropolitan League Group 1 matches last night.

An amendment to the by-laws governing the three city colleges was introduced last night at a special meeting of the Board of Higher Education at the City College School of Business, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue, by Mrs. Marion Reckford Mack to curtail the period of maternity leave for teachers from two years to one year, with the remaining year optional.

WITH THE SPANISH TROOPS OUTSIDE MADRID, Dec. 16 (AP). -- Insurgent bombers flew through the fog today in an attack on the Madrid front as ground troops pushed their advance against a Leftist counter-attack.
Sites for apartment construction were among the properties figuring in real estate transactions reported in the Bronx yesterday.

Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, accepted yesterday the honorary chairmanship of a campaign to raise $500,000 for the Bethune-Cookman College, an institution for Negroes at Daytona Beach, Fla., in which she has been interested for several years.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16. -- Wheat markets fluctuated in an erratic manner today with trading somewhat restricted as many operators took a position on the sidelines awaiting Argentine's official crop estimate which was to be issued late in the day.

Granville, acknowledged 3-year-old champion of this year and greatest money winner as well, will race no more. He had been expected to be one of the most important factors in the handicap division next year.

The responsibility of the world's great educational centers was greater than that of any other human agency in the molding of the future, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler declared last night. He addressed more than 200 alumni at a dinner marking the thirty-fifth anniversary of the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street.

A fat Christmas is just around the corner. Looking back to the lean years, weren't we too pathetic about ourselves? Didn't we overdo the grumbling and whining? If we poor victims of depression look into the dark places of suffering undeserved we shall understand better what suffering is.

Andrew Barberi, stellar guard, was elected captain of the New York University football team for the 1937 campaign, it was announced at a dinner tendered to members of the football squad by the N.Y.U. Athletic Association at the New York Athletic Club last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The new treaty between Italy and the United States is expected to eliminate complications incident to the extension of unconditional most-favored-nation treatment, especially in connection with a reciprocal trade agreement, and to remove any question, in so far as it may concern Italy, of the treaty right of the United States to impose neutrality measures in time of war.

BERLIN, Dec. 16. -- Prices on the Boerse closed weak today. Heavy industrial stocks showed some losses, Harpener falling a half point. Machine issues were mixed and unstable. In this group Metallgesellschaft gained 2 points. There was little activity in the chemical section.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP). -- The War Department's board of engineers was told there was "a public demand" for completion of the Florida Ship Canal at a public hearing today on a special board report which held the proposed $162,000,000 Gulf-Atlantic waterway was feasible.

Harry Bridges, leader of Pacific Coast longshoremen told an audience at Madison Square Garden last night that the maritime strike in the West was won but that he expected its leaders would refuse to settle with the ship lines unless the demands of striking seamen in the Atlantic and Gulf also were granted.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 16. -- James A. McAlvanah, 25 years old, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. McAlvanah of 956 Arlington Avenue, this city, will become one of the youngest members of the New York Stock Exchange, it was learned today. Mr. McAlvanah purchased a seat on the Exchange yesterday for $104,000.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 16 (AP). -- B. Hernandez's highly regarded combination of Biography and Woodlander finished second and third, respectively, behind the fast traveling Reelon in the mile and seventy-yard feature at the Fair Grounds.

Since the recent decision of the United States Supreme Court upholding the validity of the California and Illinois Fair Trade Acts, numerous statements have been made which indicate that the inevitable effect of fair trade legislation is to increase prices to the consumer.
VIENNA, Dec. 16. -- As police guards watched all approaches to Enzesfeld Castle today, the Duke of Windsor passed his time quietly bowling and playing golf.

Federal Judge John C. Knox, a New Deal supporter, said yesterday that the rights of the average American citizen would be best protected by the continued freedom of the United States Supreme Court, whereas "those who would assume the place the court now occupies" could not be trusted "over the years."

While telephone call interruptions from field agents dramatically punctuated his discussion, Theodore Toole, director of merchandising ou the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company, told members of the Anthracite Club of New York of the difficulties in obtaining evidence in the stolen-coal racket at the Hotel McAlpin last night.

The St. Francis College five routed the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy team, 38 -- 18, on the Butler Street court last night. Pat Gleason and Lynch each tallied 9 points for the victors. At the end of the first half St. Francis led, 22 -- 10.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the dissolution on last Monday of Marshall Marshall and prospective changes in several other firms holding membership in the Exchange. Ralph Lowell retired from Lee, Higginson Co. and the interest of the estate of Frank M. Dick in E.F. Hutton Co. ceased, both on Monday.

Two DeWitt Clinton High School stars, Marvin Kantrowitz and Joseph Fishbach, top ranked entries, defeated two Scarborough school representatives, Donald Buffington and William Gillespie, in semi-final matches in the second annual metropolitan indoor junior tennis championships at the 102d Engineers Armory yesterday.

Five careworn Carmelite nuns who escaped from Spain late in November after their convent at Burriana, Province of Castilla, had been burned by the Loyalist forces, arrived yesterday afternoon on the Dollar liner President Adams. Dressed in the makeshift civilian clothing which they wore to escape across the Spanish border into France, the nuns said through an interpreter that they were going to a convent in Grand Rapids, Mich.

Commodity futures markets were mixed yesterday in comparatively active trading. Crude rubber futures again were in heavy demand, reflecting the strength in the primary markets, and final quotations here were at the best level since October, 1929.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 16. -- The State's three-day crime conference closed today with the adoption of an eleven-point program to curb criminal activity, which was forwarded to a legislative committee for study and correlation.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 16. -- Empty Bottle, fleet bay 3-year-old in the Ohio-owned colors of Mrs. E.B. Carpenter, scored a surprise victory in the five and a half furlong Matecumbe Handicap, for all ages, at Tropical Park today. Earl Porter, winning rider in the opening-day feature, had the son of Jock well in hand while scoring by a length and a half over the three-time Maryland winner, Grand Duke, representing Mrs. Emil Denemark.

Contributions of more than $430,000 to the women's division of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies were announced yesterday in a campaign report following a workers' rally at the Hotel Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- All but ten of this country's fifty principal foreign markets purchased in October more goods made in the United States than in the corresponding month last year and shipments were larger to all the seven so-called grand divisions, the Department of Commerce reported today in its analysis of trade by countries.

In a decision handed down yesterday, Judge Robert A. Inch in the Federal court in Brooklyn ordered the payment of $998,800 of interest in arrears to holders of Bush Terminal 5 per cent consolidated mortgage bonds maturing in 1955. Under the order $150 will be paid on each $1,000 bond.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP). -- Experts in the Department of Agriculture said today that the high quality of this year's crop of burley tobacco, a small yield and reduction of reserve stocks to normal proportions accounted for prices 50 to 75 per cent above those of last year.
SWARTHMORE, Pa., Dec. 16. -- The University of Pennsylvania five overcame a stubborn Swarthmore team in a second-half rally to win, 35-32, tonight. The score at the half was tied at 22-all.
Stockholders of the Frank Presbrey Company have voted to annul the office of chairman of the board, which was held by the late Frank Presbrey. Charles Presbrey continues as president.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 16. -- The neutrality convention that has kept the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace nervous. for the past three days was approved today by the standing committee with only perfunctory legal quibbles.
A statement by Mayor La Guardia in support of the Christmas seal sale was made public yesterday by the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association. The Mayor said:

Speaker BANKHEAD has arrived in Washington, and as it is taken for granted that he will be elected Speaker of the next Congress without opposition, it was natural that he should be asked what he thought the legislative program would be. Mr. BANKHEAD replied that he could not, of course, make a definite statement on that subject until he had consulted with the President.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Dec. 17. -- The declaration of a punitive expedition against Chang Hsueh-liang and reluctant abandonment of all efforts to settle the revolt by negotiation and compromise gravely imperils the safety of Chiang Kai-shek.
While the New York Yankees did it with their bats, experts, using ballots, selected the world baseball champions as the No. 1 team of 1936 in the sixth annual Associated Press sports poll.

Queens home owners and business men were urged to improve the appearance of their property in preparation for the World's Fair in a talk last night by Borough President Harvey at the first general meeting of the Queens World's Fair Committee in the Queens County Court House, Long Island City.

Apprehension expressed by the Transportation Conference and other organizations interested in the railroads that the industry was faced with the threat of a six-hour day was minimized yesterday by Daniel Willard, president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, in a discussion of the outlook.

Canada Dry Ginger Ale, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 a net income of $182,400 after interest, depreciation and income taxes of the United States and the Dominion of Canada. In the preceding twelve months the company earned $240,422 after similar deductions.

Paced by Captain Jack McGuirk, who tallied 10 points in as many minutes of the second half, Manhattan's undefeated basketball team coasted to a 27-to-19 triumph over Cooper Union at the Manhattan gymnasium last night.

The deadlock that has endured from the start of the season between the Class A squash tennis teams of the Columbia University Club and the New York A.C. was finally broken last night when the wearers of the Winged Foot defeated their rival on the former's courts, 3 to 2, to take the lead in the Metropolitan League.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Income tax collections from Dec. 1 to 15 amounted to $254,421,651, a gain of 15 per cent over the like period a year ago, when they were $216,425,761, according to telegraphic reports from Internal Revenue Collectors to the Treasury.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The Union Oil Company of California has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $10,000,000 of fifteen-year 3 1/2 per cent debentures, due Jan. 1, 1952, and 300,000 shares of capital stock, $25 par value.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 16. -- Following is the text of the measure on tariffs as unanimously approved by the Committee on Economic Problems for submission at the next plenary session of the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace:

CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE, N.J., Dec. 16. -- Six more "floaters" testified before Judge Jayne in Circuit Court here today that they voted repeatedly for William C. Hunt, Republican, whose election Nov. 3 as State Senator from Cape May County the Democrats are contesting on the grounds of fraud.

Four 13-year-old schoolboys, led by their gang "boss," who is 14, were held responsible last night for. twenty-two recent robberies in Brooklyn. They will be arraigned as juvenile delinquents in Brooklyn Children's Court this morning.

BOSTON, Dec. 16. -- Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. faced death from a throat infection last week, it was disclosed tonight by his personal physician, Dr. George Loring Tobey Jr., at the Phillips House of the Massachusetts General Hospital, where young Roosevelt is a patient.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP). -- Campaign contributions from a member of the du Pont family to anti-New Deal causes and from Cabinet members to the Democratic chest were included today in reports to the Senate Campaign Funds Committee.

More than 300 persons attended the third annual World-Telegram football dinner at the Downtown Athletic Club last night in honor of the scholastic gridiron athletes who distinguished themselves during the 1936 campaign. Among the speakers was Larry Kelley, brilliant end and captain of the 1936 Yale eleven.

Establishing a new low record cost for long-term telephone financing, a banking group headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., will offer today a new issue of $25,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent refunding mortgage bonds of the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company.

PARIS, Dec. 16. -- Offering a 140 per cent redemption price and 3 1/2 per cent interest, Vincent Auriol, Minister of Finance, appealed today to all gold hoarders of France to subscribe to the new bond issue which will be available tomorrow.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 16 (AP). -- Lanky Horton Smith stands first among golfdom's money winners of 1936, with a total of $7,884.75.

Frank A. Bellucci, president of the Queens County Bar Association, wrote yesterday to Mayor La Guardia charging that chaotic conditions prevailed in the Court of Special Sessions of Queens. He asked the Mayor to take action to install new methods of procedure in the court.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he would defer until after the first of the year his contemplated general conference on ways and means of relieving traffic congestion in Manhattan and key points in other boroughs.

There can be no peace in Europe without settlement of the German colonial problem and the opening to Germany of sources of raw materials from which she is now excluded, declares Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, German Minister of Economics, in an article in the January issue of Foreign Affairs, published today.

MADRID, Dec. 16. -- For the third day in succession fighting is going on at Boadilla del Monte, with Generalissimo Francisco Franco's Insurgent forces still trying to break through the northwestern sector of Madrid and pave the way for encircling the city.

Emile Baume, French pianist, appeared in his first New York recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon, preceded by impressive European achievements. He was graduated from the Paris Conservatoire at the age of 17 with first prize in piano, and other honors were first prize in harmony, the Fernand-Halphen award in composition in 1924 and the Diemer Prize in 1927.

CHIANG KAI-SHEK imprisoned, as when heading his troops, still dominates the Chinese scene. The consternation felt throughout the world at the report on Tuesday that the head of the Nanking Government had been killed by his captor, the rebellious General CHANG HSUEH-LIANG, was a spontaneous tribute to CHIANG'S unique strength.

HAVANA, Dec. 16 (AP). -- Army headquarters tonight asked all members of the House of Representatives to meet with military leaders tomorrow as a controversy between civil and military authorities over an army-sponsored sugar tax bill threatened to create a government crisis.

Support of social welfare legislation was pledged yesterday by delegates to the annual meeting of the Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations, Inc., in the Community House of Temple Emanu-El, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street. Representatives of 260 member organizations approved a report of the committee's activities in this field.

Latin-American nations, with few exceptions, are emerging from the exchange difficulties which have handicapped their foreign trade for several years and 1937 should bring a substantial expansion in orders from that continent, export credit men agreed yesterday.

Fraudulent voting of the crudest type shocked the "better element," but failed last night to interfere with the result of an "election" of City Councilmen under proportional representation, at the forum meeting of the Fifteenth Assembly District Republican Club, 122 East Eighty-third Street.

Larry Kelley of Yale, opportunist extraordinary, received the Heisman Memorial Trophy, presented by the Downtown Athletic Club to football's outstanding player of the year, at a luncheon there yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- In an effort to stimulate a dwindling trade with the United States, Germany has reopened negotiations with the Treasury Department for certain commercial relations in which "blocked" marks are employed.

TOLEDO, Dec. 16 (AP). -- The nation's major flat glass plants, feeders of the busy automotive industry, were closed by strikes tonight, but no immediate effect on automobile production was apparent or expected.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in both the First and Second Judicial Departments announced yesterday a new rule for lawyers intended to prohibit them from taking part in "good-will courts" broadcast over the air. The ruling followed protests by bar associations against the practice.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16. -- All indications point to the re-election here tomorrow of John D. M. Hamilton as chairman of the Republican National Committee. He has stated that he will resign unless he receives a vote of confidence from the national committee.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 16. -- Staving off a final Princeton rally, a smooth-passing Georgetown quintet tonight scored its second victory of the season by subduing the Tigers, 25 -- 22, before 500 persons in the university gymnasium.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- There were indications today that the Bower Roller Bearing Company would soon again register its common stock on a national securities Exchange. The Securities and Exchange Commission has initiated proceedings to determine whether the stock should be stricken from unlisted trading on the New York Curb Exchange because it was withdrawn by the company last Summer from registration on the Detroit Stock Exchange."

HENDAYE, France, Dec. 16. -- It is learned from Pamplona, Spain, that a Basque delegation from Bilbao has reached an agreement in San Sebastian with the Insurgent military authorities there for the exchange of 8,000 political prisoners.

Some of the best horses in the country, including Granville, champion 3-year-old of the year; Bold Venture, winner of the Kentucky Derby and Brevity, which took the Florida Derby, are among the entries for stakes to be run at Belmont Park and Saratoga in 1937, 1938 and 1939.

A mistrial was declared by Judge Owen W. Bohan in General Sessions late yesterday afternoon in the eight-day trial of A. Henry Ross, a young Brooklyn lawyer, and Max D. Krone, a former private detective, on the indictment charging they extorted $5,000 in 1933 from Samuel C. Stempleman of Boston, president of the Gillette Safety Razor Company.

The bruising, punishing experience of a knockout overtook the sensational Harry Balsamo of Harlem last night in the ring of the Hippodrome, where, before a crowd of about 4,000, Solly Krieger, hard-hitting Brooklyn middleweight, polished off the ex-brakeman in seven rounds of what was to have been a ten-round encounter to a decision.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Large annual appropriations and vigorous programs for ridding America of its farm tenancy problem along lines already embodied in administration-sponsored legislation were opposed today by Secretary Wallace in an opening address to the President's special committee on tenancy, of which he is chairman.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16. -- N.W. Ayer Son, Inc., advertising agency, which has been involved in a court fight for control, issued tonight the following statement:

Leading all the way, the New York Athletic Club's 300-yard medley relay team captured the New York State A.A.U. title in the opening swimming meet of the season at the Winged Foot clubhouse last night in the good time of 3:03.7.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Exports of industrial machinery from the United States in October were 36 per cent higher than in October, last year, and those for the first ten months of this year were $18,622,079 higher in value than those in all 1935, a report by the Department of Commerce showed today.

LONDON, Dec. 16. -- The principal feature of trading on the stock market here today was a sharp rise in the rubber group to the highest level since October, 1929. Shares of rubber-producing companies received strong support as the price of the commodity rose from 9 3/8d to 9 13-16d a pound. Later in the day quotations for the commodity eased to 9 23-32d for spot and 9 11-16d for forward delivery.

Magistrate David L. Malbin suspended sentence yesterday in twenty-two more cases of persons charged with sanitary violations and told newspaper men he thought his method brought "results." He declined to enter into any controversy regarding the criticism voiced by County Judge Franklin Taylor on Tuesday of suspended sentences in such cases.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The proposed sterilization, or "cooking," of all flower bulbs grown in the United States as a prerequisite to their being permitted in interstate shipment was held to be unnecessary and impossible of enforcement by representatives of many horticultural organizations, trade associations and State Departments of Agriculture at a hearing here today called by Secretary Wallace.
The issue of cooperation between unions of various crafts in seeking to enforce union conditions in an industry was raised again yesterday.

New Jersey's season on small upland game came to a close on Tuesday. Judging from comments of veteran gunners, the shooting was little better than that experienced in other sections of the Northeast. Good bags were made for a week or so following the opening on Nov. 10, but after that it was hard going.
Dealers snapped up every bottle of perfume offered yesterday at the public auction of seized and abandoned goods in the United States Customs Seizure Room, at 201 Varick Street.

GENEVA, Dec. 16. -- A veiled plea to the Committee on League of Nations Reform that it do nothing while the Buenos Aires conference is in session, was made by Augustin Edwards of Chile today. He said the coincidence of the two meetings perturbed his government because the Buenos Aires conference was to express views on a number of questions before the committee.

DALLAS, Dec. 16 (AP). -- The Washington government filed an application in the Federal District Court today to enjoin Interstate Circuit, Inc., and fourteen other exhibitors and distributors of motion picture films from carrying out contracts alleged to be in violation of antitrust laws of 1890.

One of the important questions before the Roosevelt Administration -- a question which the Treasury is now considering -- is the future of the various credit agencies which have made the Government the biggest banker in the country. There are more than thirty of these agencies in Washington -- a few antedating Mr. ROOSEVELT, but most of them the work of his Administration.

" Days to Come," the Lillian Hellman drama which opened on Tuesday night at the Vanderbilt, is expected to be withdrawn by Herman Shumlin next Tuesday evening after nine performances. It is the second produced play by Miss Hellman, author of the sensationally successful "The Children's Hour."
