WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 16. -- Enlivened by a controversy which resulted in the barring of a painting of a nude, the annual exhibition of the Westchester Arts and Crafts Guild and the Westchester Workshop opened tonight fat the County Center.

Government "competition" under the old-age benefit title of the Federal Social Security Act has stimulated, rather than hurt, the group annuity business of private insurance companies, officials of two major companies reported yesterday.

ALBANY, Dec. 16. -- A saving of $7,000,000 a year by users of electricity in New York City was announced by the Public Service Commission tonight in making public a schedule of reductions in rates submitted by the Consolidated Edison System and approved by the commission.

LONDON, Dec. 16. -- The dust raised by the British constitutional crisis has served to hide from the world the outstanding fact that the Anglo-French Entente has now become something more than a mere unwritten agreement to cooperate.

ALBANY, Dec. 17 (AP). -- Assurance that the Republican party will support a complete social security program similar to that sponsored by the Roosevelt administration in Washington at the next session of the Legislature was expressed today in high party councils.
LONDON, Dec. 17 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Officials of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation charged before the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee investigating railroad financing today that in a little less than four months in the early part of 1932, relying upon balance sheets, which subsequently were proved to be false, the RFC lent to the Missouri Pacific Railroad, then under Van Sweringen control, $17,l00,000.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 17. -- Earl Peel, chairman of the royal commission of inquiry in Palestine, and other members of the commission expressed doubt at yesterday's session that anything could be done to improve the adverse trade balance of Palestine.

The total expenditure by the petroleum industry for newspaper advertising in cities of 10,000 population or over amounted to $4,679,685.55 for the first six months of this year, according to a study "Going for Gallons" released yesterday by the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP). -- In a report on a survey of wheat prices, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics of the Department of Agriculture said today:

CLINTON, N.Y., Dec. 17. -- Including in its membership several undergraduates who gained valuable experience in snow sports with preparatory school and other teams before entering college, the Hamilton Outing Club ski team is making extensive plans to participate in the college invitation tournament held annually at Lake Placid, N.Y., during the Christmas vacation.

The Atlas Corporation, a $100,000,000 investment company, has made application to the New York Stock Exchange for the listing of its common and preferred stocks. For several years its securities were traded on the New York Curb Exchange on an unlisted basis.

United States Government obligations underwent yesterday the sharpest reaction on the New York Stock Exchange since before the December quarterly financing. In the heaviest trading since Nov. 20 -- transactions reached $2,612,600 -- the Federal loans declined from 2/32 to 11/32 point.

Edward P. Field Jr. of the Princeton Club, displaying sparkling form with his southpaw strokes, advanced a step nearer the annual Fall metropolitan Class B and C squash tennis championship by conquering Joseph N. De Raismes, veteran Elizabeth Town and Country Club representative, in a quarter-final at the Columbia University Club last night.

Kerstin Thorborg, the new Swedish contralto of the Metropolitan Opera Association, arrived yesterday on the Swedish-American liner Kungsholm accompanied by her husband, Gustaf Bergamm, director of the Gothenburg Opera. Mme. Thorborg will make her first appearance before an American audience in the season's opening presentation, "Die Walkuere."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17. -- Frederick M. Dunn Jr., member of a socially prominent family from which he had been separated, was found burned to death today in a bare, fourth-floor room of an Arch Street lodging house.

A LONG about this time of year, when sports goes through its annual period of transition from the great outdoors to what is commonly called the "indoor season," there is invariably a bit of a lull. Pleasant enough, perhaps, for the surfeited fan, seeking momentary rest. Not so pleasant for one assigned to do a column with the urgent request that it be "lively, entertaining and even enlightening," if possible.

The survey of the first four years of President Roosevelt's administration has been written by the editors of The Economist, London financial journal, and will be published by Alfred A. Knopf on Jan. 2 under the title "The New Deal: An Analysis and Appraisal."

Ray Impellittiere, young giant from Cold Spring, N.Y., will make his bid for major heavyweight recognition tonight when he tackles Bob Pastor, former New York University football player, at Madison Square Garden. The rival boxers are slated to travel over the ten-round route, and the victor will be recognized as heavyweight champion of New York State, a title recently created by the Athletic Commission.

TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 17 (AP). -- A man whom Deputy Sheriff Kennedy Yeazell identified as Thomas Fortune Ryan 2d, 38, of New York, began a thirty-day jail sentence here today for failure to pay wages alleged to be due to three Tucson nurses.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP). -- A prediction by Chairman Marriner S. Eccles of the Federal Reserve Board that "there will be very little more borrowing by the Federal Government" was made public today.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 17. -- Deadly hydrogen sulphide fumes struck down Fred Thamann, 38, today in a laboratory where he conducted a dangerous search for a means to eliminate one of the hazards of industry, lead poisoning.
VATICAN CITY, Dec. 17. -- Pope Pius XI relapsed again into a period of weakness tonight, the result, worried physicians said, of undue exertion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP). -- Sweeping aside all requests for delay, the National Labor Relations Board started today its battle to dissolve the employe representation plan of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, largest subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation.

Upholding the contention that the State courts should follow rulings of the Federal courts rather than the higher State courts in eases involving construction of a Federal statute, Supreme Court Justice James E. Norton yesterday awarded judgment for $8,327 in favor of Mrs. Benveneda B. Davis in a suit against the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company and the Harriman Securities Corporation.

The present midtown congestion is slight compared to what it will become as continuing prosperity brings added visitors to Manhattan. The property owners will have to join with the city authorities in finding a solution, or they may find their tenants slipping away to other places where it will he easier to do business.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 17. -- Hun School's football team, adjudged scholastic "champion of champions" of New Jersey during the past season, was feted at a dinner in the school tonight. Gold footballs were awarded to eleven men.

Commodity futures markets were generally lower yesterday in quiet trading. A further advance in crude rubber futures to the highest level since 1929 brought in heavy profit-taking, and final prices were lower on the day. Cocoa futures also dropped sharply on increased selling pressure from Europe.
SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 17 (AP). -- Searchers failed tonight to develop their only "clue" in the hunt for an airliner lost with seven persons, all feared dead, and wearily moved to "begin all over."

The experts who wouldn't concede him a chance have hailed Max Schmeling's twelve-round knockout of Joe Louis as the year's crowning comeback achievement in the sixth annual Associated Press sports poll.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 17. -- A bronze medal, symbol of distinguished achievement in one of the branches of journalism, was awarded tonight to Frederic W. Goudy of Marlboro, N.Y., called the foremost living type designer, by the Syracuse University School of Journalism.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 17. -- The Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace devoted its principal efforts today to providing for a vast interchange of intellectual and cultural values among the American nations as a foundation on which to build permanent peace.

DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 17 (AP). -- Orville Wright, who looked down on the sands of Kitty Hawk, N.C., thirty-three years ago in man's first flight in a heavier-than-air machine, looked up today at a shiny, twenty-one-passenger airliner dipping in salute to "those crazy Wright boys," co-inventors of the airplane.

The Irish Theatre Players threw off their wraps last evening and at Labor Stage -- this is the old Princess Theatre -- gave the first American presentation of "Mr. Jiggins of Jigginstown." Sixth Avenue sages were saying that Lady Longford's play was shown originally three years back at the Gate in Dublin, where it was perhaps more at home than currently in Manhattan.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17. -- A gangland execution squad of three gunmen herded fourteen men into the stuffy rear room of a grimy pool hall at 1,032 West Grand Avenue tonight, motioned one of the fourteen to one side, and shot him dead.

Helmer, who "had never really played," and whose trial by pain and hardship has been almost too much for his five years, found a friend yesterday who contributed $395 -- the amount needed for case 142 -- and thus removed Helmer from the list of the Neediest Cases.
Cash dividends declared yesterday totaled $12,000,000, lifting the total for this month to $341,000,000, and the total since Nov. 1 to $1,224,200, 000.

George Roberts of Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam Roberts, counsel for Edward S. Greenbaum, American trustee in bankruptcy of the Kreuger Toll Company, made application yesterday to Harold P. Coffin, referee, for payment of a first dividend of 3 per cent on the American estate.
BERLIN, Dec. 17 (AP). -- Carl von Ossietzky, recent Nobel Peace Prize winner, has been moved from Berlin's West End Hospital to "a little private sanitarium," a friend said today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17. -- By a vote of 74 to 2 the Republican National Committee declined today to accept the resignation of John D.M. Hamilton as its chairman, expressed confidence in his leadership and considered far-reaching steps to put the party abreast of economic and social advances.

LONDON, Dec. 17. -- With the approval of the American and Japanese Governments Britain is going to keep five old cruisers which were due to be scrapped at the end of this month under the expiring London Naval Treaty of 1930.

Aviation officials, civic organizations with interests in aeronautics and members of aeronautic societies throughout the city joined yesterday in the celebration of Aviation Day, the thirty-third anniversary of the first flight of the Wright brothers in 1903 on the sand dunes near Kitty Hawk, N.C.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported yesterday for the first nine months of this year a consolidated net income of $2,442,140, which was equal to 38 cents each on 6,399,002 capital shares. This compared with $969,754, or 15 cents a share, correspondingly in 1935.

Edmund H. Driggs Jr., one-time Princeton back-field ace, last night was elected president of the Metropolitan Golf Association, succeeding Jess W. Sweetser, Yale graduate, who has held the reins for the past season.

Princeton's freshman skaters had too much speed and teamwork yesterday afternoon for their old hockey rivals from St. Paul's School, and had little difficulty in triumphing at Madison Square Garden to retain possession of the historic Hobey Baker stick that goes each year to the winner of this annual game.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 17 (AP). -- Mrs. Emily Milliken Lambert received a divorce today, with gross alimony of $1,600,000 and custody of her two minor children, in a suit against J.D. Wooster Lambert, former secretary and treasurer of the Lambert Pharmacal Company.
ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 17. -- National aviation day and the thirty-third anniversary of the Wright brothers' first flight at Kitty Hawk, N.C., were marked here today with a luncheon.

The Board of Estimate, when it meets today in City Hall, will consider a request that the site now occupied by the Claremont Inn on Riverside Drive be used by the city for an official residence for the Mayor and his family. Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx first suggested the idea, which has yet to arouse any visible enthusiasm in Mayor La Guardia.

GARDEN CITY L.I., Dec. 17. -- The Princeton Triangle Club, under the auspices of the Princeton Club of Nassau County, presented "Take It Away" tonight at the Rivoli Theatre. A tea dance and supper preceded the entertainment at the Cherry Valley Club. The hostesses were Mrs. Thomas Gurney, Mrs. W.W. Hewitt, Mrs. William Whitney and Mrs. Caswell Stoddard.

To meet the requirements of holiday spending the public drew $55,000,000 more coin and currency into circulation in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the Federal Reserve statement published yesterday. This brought the total rise of money in circulation in four weeks to $177,000,000 and lifted the volume in use to $6,552,000,000, a new high record, save for a few days in the bank holiday of 1933.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Dec. 18. -- Telegrams from Hongkong saying that Kwangsi leaders have declared martial law caused some concern here, because hitherto martial law in Kwangsi has always accompanied mobilization of the provincial militia, which last June numbered 300,000 effectives.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 17 (AP). -- Warren C. Giles, general manager of the Reds, announced today that he has scheduled twenty-nine Spring exhibition games for the club during the 1937 training season.

"AT the very moment when the praise of industrialism was loudest and most confident," wrote Lewis Mumford in his "Technics and Civilization," published in 1934, "the environment of the machine was regarded as inherently ugly: so ugly that it mattered not how much additional ugliness was created by litter, refuse, slag-piles, scrap metal or removable dirt."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Wholesale prices moved upward again in the week ended on Dec. 12, continuing the trend begun late in October, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average as 100, now stands at 83.4, compared with 83 the preceding week and 82.6 a year before.
SHANGHAI, Friday, Dec. 18. -- Government circles here viewed the Sian situation more hopefully today, as the seventh day of the crisis arrived.

Predictions that the New York World's Fair of 1939 would establish closer diplomatic and trade relationships between the United States and countries in Europe were made yesterday at a luncheon in the Metropolitan Club.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Uncle Sam dug into his jeans for about $10,500,000 of Emergency Relief funds during the last eighteen months to build and improve golf courses. This sum was spent by the Works Progress Administration.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and the reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date. The ratio of reserve for the New York bank also reached a new high figure for the year.

HAVANA, Dec. 17. -- The friction between President Miguel Mariano Gomez and Colonel Fulgencio Batista, Chief of Staff of the Cuban Army -- which has been growing since the Gomez administration took office last May -- has reached a point where it is causing considerable anxiety.

BARCELONA, Spain, Dec. 17. -- The Catalan Government crisis was settled today by the formation of a bourgeois-proletarian Ministry and the elimination of the P.O.U.M., or Workers' Party for Marxist Unity.

Although New Yorkers are said to be the hardest persons in the world to sell something to, this contention was not upheld during the recent International Ski Meet and Winter Sports Show that enjoyed a highly successful four-day run at Madison Square Garden.

The Jackson Heights Squash Club strengthened its hold on the lead in the Eastern Squash Racquets Association Group 1 tourney yesterday by defeating the Bayside Tennis Club, 4 to 1, on the victors' courts. It was the fourth triumph in as many starts for Jackson Heights.

CAPE MAY COURTHOUSE, N.J., Dee. 17. -- Testimony that election board officials participated in alleged vote frauds that elected William C. Hunt a State Senator on the Republican ticket by 437 votes last Nov. 3 was given before Judge Jayne in Circuit Court here today by a Democratic election inspector.
A good demand for apartment properties in Manhattan was indicated in transactions reported yesterday. Activity covered a wide area, ranging from downtown to the Dyckman Street district.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 17. -- The Public Opinion Quarterly, said to be the first journal in this country devoted exclusively to scientific examination of public opinion, appeared here today as a new publication of the Princeton University School of Public and International Affairs.
EDMONTON, Alberta, Dec. 17. -- Development of a drought-resisting wheat, hardy enough to withstand permanent wilting during a severe heat wave, was announced today by the University of Alberta.

Building code violations have been permitted in Queens by Frank C. Keller, the borough Building Commissioner, which "may render him liable to criminal action," Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, said in a report made public yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.

Last month Drs. PERRIN H. LONG and ELEANOR A. BLISS of Johns Hopkins told the Southern Medical Association of their success with prontosil and prontylin in treating dangerous streptococcus infections that destroy red blood-cells. They were merely clinical verifiers of a discovery made by Professor G. DOMAGK, a chemotherapist in the employ of the Interessengemeinschaft.

Ordinarily the quality of leadership supplied by steel shares is sufficient in itself to impart some degree of strength to other sections of the stock list, but this was not the case yesterday. A few of the steel issues attained new highs for the year in the early trading on the Stock Exchange while the market as a whole continued to move indecisively.

A dismal picture of the living conditions of the more than 2,000,000 persons in the city who dwell in "old-law" slum tenements was painted yesterday before the city Housing Authority, as the La Guardia administration opened a drive to obtain State or Federal aid for widespread slum demolition.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 17. -- "Prolonging the lives of the weak and even physically unfit is, in a very real sense, undermining the physical well-being of future generations," says a report prepared for President Roosevelt and made public tonight by a special faculty committee of the Georgia School of Technology.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17. -- Old crop wheat futures rallied sharply today on the Board of Trade here after scattered liquidation had caused a moderate recession in the early trading and closed at practically the top with net gains of 5/8 to 1 cent a bushel.

A few days ago Commissioner HODSON of the Department of Public Welfare of New York City issued several "don'ts" for the season of giving. They may be summarized in the single sentence of advice against giving without knowing the "validity of the appeal.''

For the second consecutive day, the much criticized low-price shares on the Stock Exchange were relatively inactive yesterday. Ever since Charles R. Gay, president of the Exchange, questioned the soundness of "penny stocks" as investments, there has been a failing off in trading in those shares that are selling for less than $10 a share on the Exchange.

Arrangements have been made for the sale of a membership in the New York Stock Exchange for $115,000, an increase of $10,000 from the previous transaction, it was announced yesterday. Within the last three weeks the price of Stock Exchange memberships has advanced from $89,000, a gain of $26,000.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 17. -- Mr. and Mrs. Harry Oakes gave a cocktail party today at Seven Oaks in farewell to their friends. They will leave on Sunday to pass the Winter at their home in Nassau, B.W.I.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 17. -- A reduction in electric rates aggregating "not less than $1,500,000" a year has been agreed to by the Public Service Electric and Gas Company in negotiations with the New Jersey Hoard of Public Utility Commissioners, it was announced today by Harry Bacharach, president of the board.

MONTREAL, Dec. 17 (AP). -- The Boston Bruins handed the crippled Montreal Maroons their first white-washing of the National Hockey League season and their first defeat in five games tonight, 5 -- 0. The victory put the Bruins only a point behind the New York Rangers and Detroit Red Wings, tied for the American group lead, and left the Maroons deadlocked with the New York Americans for third in the International group.

Broadway will see only one new film today, Shirley Temple's "Stowaway," at the Roxy. The film, which features Alice Faye, Robert Young, Eugene Pallette, Helen Westley and Arthur Treacher, will remain at the Roxy during the Christmas holidays. . . .

After a motion had been rushed through endorsing the stand, in opposition to the seamen's strike as an "outlaw walkout," taken by Joseph P. Ryan and the International Longshoremen's Union which he heads, the Central Trades and Labor Council was thrown into bedlam last night with scuffling and disorder among the 300 delegates at l Beethoven Hall, 210 Fifth Street.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 17 (AP). -- Sale of 1,100 shares of Milwaukee Journal stock at $3,500 a share was approved today by County Judge D.E. McDonald. The stock, owned by the estate of the late Lucius W. Nieman, founder and editor of The Journal, was sold to the Journal Company and Miss Faye McBeath, a niece of Mr. Nieman.

No need of wasting any time on this column this morning, folks. Although Don Carle Gillette's "In the Bag" was put on at the Belmont last evening, life will still go on in the highways and byways of this great metropolis. Young people will still fall in love and the old people, with silver in their hair, will still hold hands as they sit at home by the radio.

Only about 7 per cent or 15,000 of the more than 200,000 persons now on WPA payrolls in this city will be dropped as a result of the retrenchment policy announced from Washington, it was indicated yesterday at WPA headquarters. No one in actual need will be dismissed.
Bank clearings in the week ended on Wednesday for the third time this year rose above $7,000,000,000. With these exceptions, so high a point had not been reached since October, 1931.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 17. -- Skillful defensive play allowed Colby College, for four years the Maine State college champion, to hold Yale to a 4-0 hockey score before 600 spectators in the New Haven Arena tonight. Lacking reserves, the visiting regulars played most of the game.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 17 (AP). -- Dr. Giuseppe Motta was elected President of the Swiss Confederation today for his fifth term. He succeeded Dr. Albert Meyer. A stipulation in Swiss law prevents the re-election of a President except after an interval of one term, a year.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Improvement in nearly every leading industry and a market gain in freight shipments, after adjustment for seasonal variation, is reflected in a sharp rise in The Annalist index of business activity to 107.6 (preliminary) for November from 103.1 for October.
BERLIN, Dec. 17 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Dec. 15 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Some of the lines of the administration's legislative program for the new Congress began to appear today out of a series of conferences held by President Roosevelt with Congressional leaders and administrative officials.

In a letter to THE TIMES Miss Helen Alfred, secretary of National Public Housing Conference, opposed your advocacy of tax exemption for cooperative housing projects for civil service employes in the moderate income class, contending that subsidized housing for this group is indefensible.
SYRACUSE, Dec. 17. -- Using three teams, Syracuse handed Dartmouth its first defeat of the basketball season tonight, 42 to 29, before 2,000 spectators.

Carlos Hevia, former President of Cuba and now New York representative of the Cuban Revolutionary party, asserted yesterday that Colonel Fulgencio Batista, chief of staff of the Cuban Army, was trying deliberately to bring about a showdown with President Miguel Mariano Gomez for the purpose of forcing him out of office.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dee. 17. -- Mrs. Emil Denemark's Uneasy, a juvenile that threatened on numerous occasions in Maryland competition, triumphed at Tropical Park today when he drove first home by a neck in the Winter Haven Purse, a dash of five and a half furlongs that held the honored spot on the card.

MADRID, Dec. 17. -- Interest in the struggle for Madrid centered today on the Guadalajara sector, where Generalissimo Francisco France's troops are gradually approaching the government lines. There has not been much actual fighting there yet, but for the first time a government communique mentioned an artillery duel at the town of Taracena, just outside Guadalajara.

The women's committee in the United Hospital Campaign has raised $521,657 in contributions, it was reported yesterday by Mrs. William Woodward, chairman of the women's committee, at a meeting attended by 450 women at the Hotel Biltmore.

That feeler put out by the organ of the New York Republican State Committee must have been received more favorably than some Republican comments would indicate. It is reported that Republicans in the Legislature of 1937 will accept Governor LEHMAN'S Social Security Bill, reserving only a benevolent and helpful criticism.

The Guaranty Trust Company has been appointed co-registrar for 30,000 shares of $3 convertible cumulative preference stock, 30,000 shares of Class A stock and 200,000 shares of common stock of the National City Lines, Inc.

Marked activity in the Building Departments of the city was evident yesterday, when architects continued the rush of plans for new construction and alterations that has kept the municipal bureaus busy during the closing weeks of the year.

The sliding New York Americans dropped another one last night. Facing the speedy Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden, Red Dutton's erstwhile Dusters were battered by a 5-1 score, their third straight defeat since Sunday night.

A roaring fire, fed by light wood, was discovered at 8 o'clock last night in a six-story brick building occupied by a box manufacturing concern at 11 to 13 Hubert Street on the lower West Side, a block west of the New York Central Railroad freight depot.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the following changes reported by listed companies in their holdings of reacquired stock:

Miguel de Capriles of the University Fencers Club, the national outdoor epee champion, showed his versatility by annexing the gold medal in the individual senior saber invitation meet held under the auspices of the Amateur Fencers League of America at the Salle d'Armes Vince last night.

The text of a radio address made in Nanking, China, yesterday by Dr. H. H. Kung, Minister of Finance and brother-in-law of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, as transcribed by the National Broadcasting Company in New York, follows:

After encountering a little difficulty in the first few minutes, the New York University basketball team defeated Cathedral College, 63 to 26, last night in the victors' gymnasium. It was the fourth triumph of the year for the Violet.
WISE, Va., Dec. 17 (AP). -- A Wise County jury today convicted Edith Maxwell for the second time of slaying her miner-blacksmith father. Her punishment was fixed at twenty years' imprisonment.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 17. -- Dr. Glenn Frank sat for four hours today across the table from the chief figure in the move to remove him as president of the University of Wisconsin, Governor Philip F. La Follette, but neither mentioned the proposed ouster.

The Canadian sportsman, Harry B. Greening of Hamilton, Ont., was renamed chairman of the American Power Boat Association's racing commission by the association's council last night at the Hotel Lexington. More than 100 appointments of officers and committeemen were announced by George W. Sutton Jr., president.

In connection with the conviction of Michael Pecoraro, alias Joseph Briano, of fraud in obtaining nineteen housing loans totaling more than $15,000 from two New York banks, Thomas G. Grace. State Director of the Federal Housing Administration, pointed out yesterday the loans involved were "modernization credit" loans and had no bearing on the regular FHA home-mortgage loan insurance plan.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 17. -- The Most Rev. Maurice F. McAuliffe, Bishop of Hartford, notified Catholic pastors of the city today that Pope Pius XI has excommunicated the Rev. Orestes P. Chornock, pastor of St. John's Greek Catholic Church here since 1911, and five other priests of the Carpatho-Ruthenian Greek rite, which is in communion with Rome.

Importers who paid thousands of dollars in compensating taxes under the defunct AAA are entitled to repayment of the money and can sue for such refunds in the United States Customs Court, that tribunal ruled yesterday.

In keeping with the return of more prosperous times to Wall Street, the community Christmas tree to be set up today in Broad Street, opposite the Stock Exchange, will be nearly twice as large as those of previous years, it was announced yesterday.

Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman, wife of the Governor, visited the Christmas sale for the blind at 475 Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon, purchased several articles made by the blind of New York State and said she was "thrilled" at the financial report.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- The National Conference for Legalizing Lotteries, Inc., of which Mrs. Oliver Harriman of New York is the head, failed to obtain an injunction in Federal District Court here today restraining Postmaster General Farley from impounding mail addressed to the organization and from returning some of it to the sender bearing the mark "fraudulent."
One week to Christmas -- and the Neediest wait!

Undismayed by the entrance of three customers, one the wife of a policeman, three armed men stole jewelry valued at $30,000 and $2,000 in cash yesterday morning from a pawn shop at 32 Fifth Avenue, two blocks from Brooklyn police headquarters.

TORONTO, Dec. 17. -- The University of Toronto handed Princeton a 10-to-0 setback tonight in the first game of the International Intercollegiate Hockey League. The Tiger defense was shattered by the fast-skating Canadians in the final period and the winners scored seven goals.

Ill winds blew from three directions yesterday upon Magistrate W. Overton Harris, who ordered the arrest last Sunday morning of Michael Darienzo, motor cycle policeman, whose machine disturbed him as he presided in Washington Heights Court.

The Collins Aikman Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the nine months to Nov. 28 a net income of $3,940,599 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges. After allowing dividend requirements on the 7 per cent preferred stock the income is equivalent to $6.44 each on 562,800 shares of common stock.

The ofttimes confusing f.o.b., or factory prices, heretofore quoted for automobiles are to be changed immediately in newspaper and national advertising to "delivered" prices at the point of manufacture, Alvan Macauley, president of the Automobile Manufacturers Association, announced here yesterday.
Marvin Kantrowitz, top-seeded player, won the metropolitan indoor junior tennis championship yesterday at the 102d Engineers Armory by defeating Joseph Fishbach, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Details of how David M. Milton, son-in-law of John D. Rockefeller Jr., acquired control of Equity Corporation, a $218,000,000 investment trust, last Dec. 31 through an original investment of $13,000 and 6,300 shares of an inactive insurance company stock were laid before the Securities Commission today.

Freight traffic on the Pennsylvania Railroad is above usual seasonal levels, according to Washington advices quoting I.W. Clement, president. He declined to estimate what the company's net income this year would be, but he said the line had spent between $26,000,000 and $27,000,000 more on maintenance this year than last, and that it had returned 21,000 employes to work.

Engineering construction awards dropped back during the past week to $39,853.000, according to The Engineering News-Record. The figure compares with $59,244,000 the week before and $86,817,000 a year ago. Private awards accounted for $22,767,000; public awards for $17,086,O00, and of the latter, $1,466,000 was for Federal and $15,620,000 for State and municipal projects.

CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 17. -- The Lieutenant Governor of Papua, Sir Hubert Murray, reporting to Prime Minister Joseph A, Lyons on native wedding customs, says girls in some communities of the hinterland will not accept a suitor unless he has killed a man.

Even a former King has a right to privacy. After EDWARD VIII's abdication and broadcast of farewell to the Empire, he naturally disappeared, doubtless much to his own relief, from the front page and the big headlines. Yet in his self-imposed exile he has been infested by a battalion of spies, eavesdroppers and inventors of fantastic and impossible tales about him.

Hundreds of persons packed the lobby and lines formed on Broadway yesterday morning when the Metropolitan Opera House began the individual seat sale for the opening week's performances. Within a half hour after the box office was opened all the seats that had not been sold by subscription or mail order for the inaugural on Monday night were gone.

Although Hal Trosky, slugging first baseman of the Indians, carried off individual honors for runs batted in during the 1936 American League campaign, the Yankees, led by their redoubtable Lou Gehrig, contributed most to a record-smashing season, according to the official figures announced yesterday.

Detectives were baffled last night by a mysterious fire that burned the mattresses of two Colonial beds in the historic Jumel Mansion on a bluff overlooking the Harlem River at Edgecombe Avenue between 160th and 162d Streets.
PARIS, Dec. 17 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

L. F. Livingston, manager of the agricultural extension department of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., said in an address yesterday at the monthly dinner of the Commodity Club, New York, held at Oscar's Restaurant, William and Beaver Streets, that "industry depends upon a prosperous agriculture as a market for manufactured goods and agriculture depends likewise upon a market created by industry and the millions of workers which it employs.
The text of the conditions which will govern the America's Cup races next Summer and which were agreed upon by the Royal Yacht Squadron and the New York Yacht Club follows:

The Laicremore Realty Company sold two apartment houses in Montclair, N.J., one at 30 Gates Avenue and the other at 47 Union Street, to an investing syndicate headed by Abraham Weinstein, it was announced yesterday by R.L. Greene, broker.

At the close of evidence by both sides last evening in General Sessions in the five-week trial of three former officials of the defunct Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company for an alleged false statement on its finances in 1932, Judge James G. Wallace took under consideration a motion by the defense lawyers for a directed verdict of acquittal.

Marks, Laser Co., members ofI the New York Stock Exchange, will I pay a bonus equivalent to twoI weeks' salary to employee who have been with the firm more than two years and lesser amounts to i others.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 17. -- Clifford Odets's desire to write a documentary play for the screen will be satisfied after a fashion in 'Castles in Spain," with Lewis Milestone directing. Odets has arrived at the Walter Wanger plant with the preliminary scenario on which the two have worked.
A new champion was crowned in Class A of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets League last night when the University Club defeated the Harvard Club on the former's courts, 3 to 2.

Frank C. Whitmore, dean of the School of Chemistry and Physics of Pennsylvania State College, has been elected president of the American Chemical Society for 1938, according to an announcement yesterday by Dr. Charles L. Parsons, secretary of the society.

PARIS, Dec. 17. -- Both in the Chamber of Deputies and in the Senate today the government gave evidence of its intention to pursue a moderate financial and social policy and so reassure capital and the employers of labor.

Samuel Untermyer, president of the Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League to Champion Human Rights, has telegraphed to Henry Ford, the league announced yesterday, asking a disavowal of an anti-Semitic book published in Germany last year under the title of "The International Jew," with a cover implying that the book was written by Mr. Ford.

Big business as a whole has failed to understand the real aims and purposes of the New Deal and has been too prone to criticize its entire program, W. Forbes Morgan, treasurer of the Democratic National Committee, declared last night at a dinner given in his honor in the Hotel Biltmore.

A very minor item in the news of the last few days insists on tying up with one of the biggest things in the morning paper. The big story is about unhappy Spain and the Anglo-French effort at mediation and peace. The unimportant story is about two neighbor families here at home who have been playing bridge over a great many years.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday, through Milo R. Maltbie, chairman, its approval of the merger of the New York Edison Company, Inc., the Bronx Gas and Electric Company and the Brush Electric Illuminating Company into the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc.
The New Jersey Fish and Game Commission yesterday issued its annual report for the fiscal year, July 1, 1935, to June 30, 1936.

Organization of a foundation in memory of Miss Margaret B. Holz, former head of the Department of Modern Languages at the New Jersey State Teachers College in Montclair, N.J., was announced yesterday by a committee of five former students who are members of the Foreign Exchange League of the college.

Harry Brunette, 25-year-old bank robber and kidnapper, was sentenced to life imprisonment in a Federal penitentiary by Federal Judge Phillip Forman in Trenton late yesterday afternoon. The youthful desperado had pleaded guilty to violation of the Lindbergh Law and indicated his eagerness to get the court proceedings over with as speedily as possible.
LONDON, Dec. 17. -- With the usual account day routine occupying attention, the stock market generally was quiet today.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Police in suburban Duquesne arrested a 70-year-old fellow policeman tonight after a series of revolver shots killed five persons, three of them women.

A banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., Lehman Brothers, the First Boston Corporation and the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $6,600,000 of Chicago 3 per cent refunding bonds on a bid of 104.037 and of art issue of $3,000,000 of Chicago Board of Education 3 per cent refunding bonds on a bid of 103.245.

With $278,000 in special contributions as its goal to augment its Family Service Fund, the Charity Organization Society of New York reported yesterday at a luncheon meeting at India House, 1 Hanover Square, that it had raised $204,000 to aid the city's needy families next year.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 17. -- The economic aspirations of the United States delegation to the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace were completely fulfilled today when the conference's standing committee adopted a favorable report on its suggestion regarding equality of treatment in international trade.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 17. -- The standing committee on intellectual cooperation recommended to the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace today the passage of a resolution urging all the American republics as a peace measure to accord "the rights and duties of citizenship" to women.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Public-debt transactions for Dec. 15 amounted to $2,618,546,813, increasing the national debt to $34,229,084,171, compared to $30,555,791,967 a year earlier, the Treasury announced today.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 17 (AP). -- Executives of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company, in a statement issued today, said that union leaders "seem to be trying to mislead our employes and the public" in a strike which has suspended operations in nine plants and crippled the industry nationally.
The current exhibition of paintings by artist members of the Lotos Club, being held at that institution, has been extended through Jan. 4.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Great Britain's decision to retain five over-age cruisers came as no surprise here and will occasion no objection. Formal notification of the move will receive only an acknowledgment.

HAROLD RIEGELMAN'S proposal for a $100,000,000 State bond issue to stimulate slum clearance requires a historical setting. The State first intervened effectively in the effort to bring about improved housing conditions for slum-dwellers when the Legislature passed the Tenement House Act of 1901.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today three important decisions reflecting some of the principles which it feels are applicable in dealing with the question of unlisted trading in securities on securities exchanges and trading in over-the-counter markets.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- The Consumers Power Company of Jackson, Mich., today filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 547,788 shares of no-par $4.50 dividend cumulative preferred stock.

Until January, 1939, and possibly until January, 1941, more than three-fourths of the States of the Union will have Democratic Governors. Next month there will be thirty-eight of these -- a development of the recent election which was hailed so heartily as a partisan victory that its significance in any move to amend the Constitution has been overlooked.
The Continental Paper and Bag Corporation, a subsidiary of the International Paper and Power Company, filed yesterday a petition in bankruptcy in the Federal District Court here.

Fordham's swimming team won its second dual meet of the season yesterday, defeating the St. Francis College natators of Brooklyn, 36 to 35, in the Maroon pool. The Rams captured four of the eight events.

For ten minutes last night the Clarkson Tech quintet seemed to be on its way to stopping Long Island University's prolonged winning streak, but for the remaining half hour of play the Blackbirds put on the pressure and triumphed, 49 -- 24, at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy for their thirty-ninth consecutive victory.

Thomas V. Judge, '37, of New York City has been elected captain of Manhattan's varsity crew for next Spring, it was announced yesterday by Brother Anselm, director of athletics. Judge, a scholastic honor man, is 20 years old, 6 feet 3 inches tall and weighs 175 pounds.

Earl (Dutch) Clark, versatile back field ace of the Detroit Lions, topped the individual scorers of the National Football League during the past season, according to the final statistics released yesterday. The former Colorado All-America quarterback registered 73 points.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP). -- An attack by railroads on the proposed Gulf-Atlantic canal across Florida was heard today by the Army Board of Engineers.
LONDON, Dec. 17 (AP). -- Mention of the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin of Detroit was injected into the House of Commons' debate on the affairs of the British Broadcasting Corporation tonight.

NANKING, China, Friday, Dec. 18. -- Optimism in official circles over possible early deliverance of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek communicated itself to the general public here when tens of thousands of newspaper extras were sold announcing the arrival this morning of General Chiang Ting-wen from Sian, Shensi Province, with an autographed letter from the dictator.

Wednesday, Dec. 30, is the new date for "Promise," whose postponement from next Thursday night had already been announced. The name of Laurette Taylor is omitted in the latest bulletin from the Gilbert Miller office, and that of Irene Browne added, indicating a replacement.

The Grace liner Santa Barbara will sail tonight for the West Coast of South America via the Panama Canal. Among the passengers will be Artura Lamarca, M.D. Munn, John T. McGrath, Nathan Sharp, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lane, Mr. and Mrs. G.H.S. Bushnell, Mr. and Mrs. W.M. Adelson, Dr. and Mrs. Charles N. Gelber, Mr. and Mrs. Harold Landeryou, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Kaylor, Benjamin B. Green-Field and Mr. and Mrs. Carl H. Hoper.

Father Divine, Negro cult leader of Harlem, must show cause in Supreme Court on Monday why he should not be punished for contempt of court for willfully and knowingly testifying "falsely" concerning his knowledge of the financial affairs of his "heavens."

CHICAGO, Dec. 17. -- Prices of hogs advanced 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight today as the result of relatively light receipts. The top at $10.30 equaled the highest of the Winter, and was 10 cents above yesterday's best price. The upturn was in the face of further recessions in fresh pork loins in some markets which carried them down to the lowest level of the year.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17. -- Disregarding critics of the story of Betsy Ross and the first American flag, Mayor S. Davis Wilson sent to the City Council today an ordinance which, if passed, would wipe out thirty years of delinquent taxes on the property at 239 Arch Street, known as the "Betsy Ross house."

CORINTH, Miss., Dec. 17 (AP). -- The sudden disappearance of Larry Glass, 26 years old, remained a mystery tonight while his wealthy New York uncle expressed fear the young man had met with foul play."

Setting the pace throughout, the Alexander Hamilton High School basketball team overwhelmed Bushwick High, 33 -- 13, yesterday in a Section 1, Brooklyn P.S.A.L. contest at the Central Methodist Episcopal Church court in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Dec. 16, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,496,000,000, an increase of $18,000,000, compared with the preceding week and a decrease of $2,000,000, compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

OTTAWA, Dec. 17 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits of the Dominion government with the Bank of Canada decreased $5,758,035 in the week ended yesterday, according to the bank's weekly statement, issued today. Deposits of chartered banks dropped $3,867,420.

AUGUSTA, Me., Dec. 17. -- The Maine House of Representatives passed an order today amid laughter and applause inviting Vermont to join Maine "in perpetuation of the Declaration of Independence, the preservation of our Constitution, and a return to the United States of our forefathers."

Mrs. Philip G. McFadden entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre for her niece, Miss F. Pamela Brinton, debutante daughter of Mrs. Laurence Eyre. Other guests, all debutantes, included the Misses Barbara Wall, Alma Nicoll, Elizabeth N. Lawrence, Mallory Mixsell, Angelica Fales, Rachel M. Parker, Ellenor B. Colgate, Andrea Dowd, Anne C.D. Fitch, Marie Rose Cassard and Barbara Eastman.

Following the lull in the wake of the most recent price advances, the demand for wool goods expanded this week, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service. Buyers continued to test the new prices on all types of suitings and coatings, but were not successful in their efforts to force prices down from the high levels to which they were advanced in the last month, it is stated.

ROME, Dec. 17. -- A decisive step toward occupation of the whole of Ethiopia has been taken by three Italian columns operating in the vast region southwest of Addis Ababa. They have broken the back of the Ethiopian resistance in that sector by forcing Ras Emerou, only chieftain remaining in the field against the Italians with an organized, well-armed army, to surrender with all his men.

Pastors and other leaders of the Lutheran Church throughout the United States have been asked by five synods of the American Lutheran Conference to take a firm stand against anti-Semitism in this country, according to an announcement yesterday by the National Conference of Jews and Christians.

It was interesting to observe that the popular success of the concert given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra. John Barbirolli, conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall, was Sibelius's First symphony. It is true that this work might not have overbalanced in its effect the Brahms D minor concerto, superbly played by Rudolph Serkin, if the concerto had come before the symphony, instead of vice versa.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Recurring reports that there would be a "shake-up" in the Cabinet at the beginning of President Roosevelt's second term were minimized today by persons who have the President's confidence. The denial of such reports was prompted by their growing prevalence.
GLENDALE, Calif., Dec. 17 (AP). -- Miss Mildred (Babe) Didrikson finished her first eighteen holes of tournament golf against male competition today, tossed her club to her caddy and exclaimed:
BERLIN, Dec. 17. -- Trading today on the Boerse was quiet and prices were mixed, failing to establish any tendency.

Mrs. Cecil Huntington Trowbridge of Milford, Conn., won a silver loving cup yesterday afternoon for her decoration of a Christmas midday dinner table. Her's was considered the most outstanding exhibit in a tri-State Christmas show in Horticultural Hall, Rockefeller Center.
TOMS RIVER, N.J., Dec. 17. -- One man was killed and two were injured by gunshot today as hundreds of deer hunters invaded the New Jersey woods at the opening of the four-day State season.

War, economic distress and intolerance are the three great problems of contemporary civilization and can only be solved by the application to them of the spirit of religion, Governor Lehman declared last night in opening the semi-centennial celebration of the Jewish Theological Seminary, at Broadway and 122d Street.
VIENNA, Dec. 17. -- The Duke of Windsor for the fourth day remained secluded behind the ring of bayonets surrounding Enzesfeld Castle day and night. He is markedly shunning publicity.

The Bureau of Internal Revenue has just published a preliminary report which shows that about 4,500,000 individual income tax returns have been filed in 1936. Of this number, however, more than half are returns in which net incomes are exceeded by allowable credits and deductions.

The three-story and basement dwelling at 228 East Sixty-second Street has been sold for cash for the estate of Vincent A. Clark. The purchaser plans alterations and will occupy the house. Fox Wintner were attorneys for the seller, and Davis, Polk, Wardwell, Gardiner Reed for the buyer.

MADRID, Dec. 17 (AP). -- The Leftist government at Valencia, in a new note to Great Britain and France today, charged that Germany, Italy and Portugal were continuing to "send planes and gasses with which to murder women and children in Madrid."

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 17 (AP). -- William H. Neblett, law partner of Senator William G. McAdoo, filed suit in Federal Court here today to overthrow the $187,000,000 merger of the Associated Oil Company, the Tide Water Oil Company and the Tide Water-Associated into the Tide Water-Associated Oil Company.

No check in the upward trend of world economic conditions was apparent last month, according to the monthly review of foreign economic conditions in The Annalist, out today. While the expansion of industry continued unchecked, international trade declined a little, but the drop appeared to lack significance, The Annalist states.
With Christmas coming a week from today, preparations for the holiday season increased yesterday. Announcements of celebrations came from government and private agencies.
A wave of selling swept over the Cotton Exchange yesterday, dropping prices about $2 a bale before a sharp recovery set in. Final quotations showed losses of 4 to 17 points on the day.

Bob Pastor, Washington Heights heavyweight, last night knocked out the giant Ray Impellittiere of Cold Springs, N.Y., in the seventh round of their scheduled ten-round bout before a gathering of 4,000 fight fans in Madison Square Garden and transformed a desultory heavyweight battle into a highly exciting one.
VIENNA, Dec. 18. -- The Duke of Windsor received today newspaper photographers for precisely one minute at the Enzesfeld castle of Baron Eugene de Rothschild.
Services over the week-end in the city's temples and synagogues will include the following:
PARIS, Dec. 18. -- Premier Leon Blum today suffered his first major legislative setback in the Senate when it revamped the Labor Arbitration Bill beyond recognition.
HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 18. -- Divorce is more than four times as prevalent in Hollywood, among the movie people, as it is throughout the nation generally, figures showed today.

The Thomas Publishing Company, publishers of Thomas's Register and Industrial Equipment News, announced yesterday the distribution to its office staff of additional compensation averaging fifteen weeks' salary for each employe.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 18. -- Harry Brunette, kidnapper of Trooper William A. Turnbull, of the New Jersey State Police, was transferred from the Mercer County jail here today to the Northwestern Federal penitentiary at Lewisburg, Pa. Brunette was sentenced by Federal Judge Phillip Forman yesterday to life imprisonment under the "Lindbergh law," but may be eligible for parole after 15 years.

Featuring two of Sweden's favorite comedians, Gideon Wahlberg and Edvard Person, the amusing little piece at the Cinema de Paris, which house has gone Scandinavian again for a brief period, is bound to please persons familiar with its language and even some others who enjoy fine views and a certain amount of slapstick work, regardless of just what it means.
BERLIN, Dec. 18. -- The Boerse was extremely quiet today with occasional signs of weakness. Inactive for many weeks, the market apparently is lapsing into a state of holiday stagnation.

Only six days more remain before Christmas during which appeals for the Neediest Cases will be printed in THE TIMES. Contributions received later will be, of course, gratefully acknowledged. The opportunity for giving has been shorter this year because of the first Sunday in December falling on the 6th, so that the daily average of receipts must be high if last year's total is to be reached or passed.
BERLIN, Dec. 18. -- Large red placards appeared on billboards and kiosks today warning the inhabitants that they must register for butter, oleomargarine, lard and other fat rations by Monday.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Lorenzo Camilieri and his People's Chorus of New York -- numbering approximately 600 voices -- gave its ninth annual Christmas Song Festival last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. A large audience enthusiastically greeted the program and later took part in the dance.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 18 (AP). -- Branch Rickey, general manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, said today Dizzy Dean. ace pitcher, probably would not be traded.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The suit of John D. Montgomery of Philadelphia, "citizen and taxpayer," to enjoin the Federal Reserve Board from issuing bank notes, was dismissed finally today by Justice Joseph W. Cox in United States District Court.

LONDON, Dec. 18. -- Although Edward left his throne only a week ago he is being gradually thrust out of British consciousness. The voluntary censorship of the days before the crisis is at work again to make the British public forget the whole episode. This time apparently it is truly voluntary, for no discoverable pressure has been brought to bear on newspaper editors by any official or semi-official body.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Dec. 19. -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, Thursday morning at Sian, in the presence of his captor, General Chang Hsueh-liang, sent a verbal message to War Minister Ho Ying-chin that he expected to return to Nanking unharmed by tonight (Saturday).

In St. Peter's Episcopal Church, 344 West Twentieth Street, near Ninth Avenue, a "Chelsea Stone" will be dedicated tomorrow at the annual Dr. Clement C. Moore memorial service. Dr. Moore, who wrote the immortal children's poem, "'Twas the Night Before Christmas," was long a vestryman and active supporter of St. Peter's.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 18 (AP). -- Direct efforts by the Toledo Industrial Peace Board were made today to intervene in the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company strike.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Dec. 18. -- Harper Sibley, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, arrived here yesterday from Buenos Aires, Argentina, and Sao Paulo, Brazil. He said there was a great potential market for the United States in Brazil that "we cannot let slip through our fingers."

Leading by 14 -- 3 at the intermission, St. Augustine's High School routed St. Francis Prep, 33 -- 15, at the victor's court last night to take undisputed possession of first place in the Brooklyn C.H.S.A.A. basketball tournament. The victory was the third in as many league starts for the pace-setters.
SARASOTA, Fla., Dec. 18. -- George Jacobus, president of the Professional Golfers Association, announced tonight the appointment of Fred Corcoran of Boston as manager of the tournament bureau.
NANKING, China, Dec. 18. -Yakichiro Suma, Japanese Consul General here, conveyed to Foreign Minister Chang Chun today Japan's sympathy over the Sian revolt.
Probably the happiest hunter in New Jersey yesterday was 35-year-old George Baylor of Stewartsville.
The Caucasian Allaverdy Ball, sixth in the series of annual entertainments given by the Societe Caucasienne-Allaverdy took place last night at the Plaza.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $9,831,575, representing two States and thirty-nine municipalities. This compares with a revised total of $56,105,088 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date is $26,961,804.
SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Dec. 18. -- Miss Janet Milne, 17, said today she hoped to win the women's North American speed skating championship by climbing mountains.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The Social Security Board announced today that 21,338,120 applications for social security accounts had been received up to noon of Dec. 16, covering more than 82 per cent of the 26,000,000 workers originally estimated as eligible to come under the Federal old-age benefits plan.

POTTSVILLE, Pa., Dec. 18. -- Joseph J. Bruno, former Schuylkill County detective, serving a life sentence in prison for his connection with the Kelayres massacre on election eve in 1934, escaped from a guard in the central business district here this morning.

" Days to Come," Lillian Hellman's new play, will go away from the Vanderbilt this evening after a staccato run of seven performances. For a time they had considered keeping it going through next Tuesday, for the benefit of prearranged theatre parties, but yesterday concluded it was simpler to return the advance sale and have the whole thing done.

Joe Louis, who was the experts' best friend a year ago because he never let them down, was set down yesterday by those same individuals as being the party of the second part in the greatest sports upset of 1936.
DOWN from the mountains came Rip Van Winkle and as he landed right in the middle of Broadway and Forty-second Street his first question easily was logical and understandable enough.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcioths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Motorists received a "preview" yesterday of the city's new methods of snow removal. The Police Department and the Department of Sanitation shut off a city block at Seventh Avenue and Forty-fourth Street to demonstrate that the removal of snow can be achieved in half the usual time without impeding traffic seriously.

With the world champion Yankees blazing the trail, the American League during the 1936 campaign witnessed the greatest record-smashing season in its history, an official check-up, released for publication today, reveals.

PARIS, Dec. 18. -- At the conclusion of three days of official conversations during the visit of Foreign Minister Victor Antonescu of Rumania here, a communique was issued tonight declaring that the French and Rumanian Governments had reached "a complete identity of views."
LONDON, Dec. 18. -- Home Secretary Sir John Simon today exhorted financial leaders to take precautions against air raids, and city police were fitted with new masks.

Polo internationalists, including the only ten-goal man in the country except Thomas Hitchcock Jr., will go into action in the indoor game at the Squadron A Armory, Ninety-fourth Street and Madison Avenue, tonight in a special match arranged to feature the opening of the Metropolitan League season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today a summary of registration statements recently filed under the Securities Act of 1933, including one by Financial Independence Founders, Inc., of New York City, covering $4,000,000 of trust certificates as follows: $2,160,000 of Series D; $1,440,000 of Series DN, and $400,000 of Series DP.

The surging tide of Christmas shopping, "which has had no parallel to its proportions since 1929," pushed the estimated volume of retail sales throughout the country this week 15 to 30 per cent ahead of the figures for the corresponding period last year, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Distribution was larger in all districts and showed gains over the previous week ranging from 5 to 15 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- Plans for the construction of one or two new battleships were discussed by President Roosevelt and his Cabinet today as a major topic of consideration at the first meeting of the Cabinet since the President's return from his twenty-eight-day trip to South America.

Next year will see new records set for the manufacturing and distribution of electrical appliances, A.E. Allen, vice president in charge of all merchandising activities for the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, said yesterday at a press preview of the company's 1937 appliance lines at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Commodity futures were mixed in trend yesterday, with rubber, copper, cocoa, coffee and cottonseed oil slightly firmer on the day and sugar and hides showing small declines. On the cash markets all the grains, flour, hides and rubber made new highs. Cotton, lard and cocoa advanced, while silk and tin declined.

WARSAW, Poland, Dec. 18. -- The policy of keeping an even balance between Poland's two powerful neighbors, Russia and Germany, found expression in passages of equal length in a speech Foreign Minister Josef Beck delivered today to the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Senate.
BERLIN, Dec. 18. -- The effects of the recent devaluation wave on German exports became visible when the figures on Germany's foreign trade for November were issued.

The determined drive of the government to obliterate the international narcotics smuggling ring operating here and in Boston under Morris Schatz of Brooklyn came to a climax in a packed courtroom yesterday when Federal Judge Murray Hulbert imposed record penalties on seven members of the Schatz combination en masse.
Let me cite some inaccuracies in the letter of Judge O'Brien on "The Situation in Spain":

The investment market this week was supplied with the most diversified list of new issues in several months, six classifications of borrowers being represented in the $138,477,000 of new bonds. Last week $92,309,500 of bonds was placed on the market and a year ago this week bonds for $68,480,000 were marketed.

The Mount Holyoke College Glee Club, under the direction of Dr. William C. Hammond, made its twelfth annual appearance last night at the Town Hall in a program devoted to Christmas carols of many countries and of many centuries.

Federal Judge John C. Knox announced yesterday that he would refer to a special master a motion made on behalf of Jascha Heifetz, the violinist, and other bondholders to inspect the books and minutes of the Theatre Guild.

With the extra flourish of all competing teams still being unbeaten, the big-time intercollegiate basketball season will open at Madison Square Garden at 8:15 o'clock tonight, Indiana meeting Manhattan in the feature and City College and St. Joseph's clashing in the preliminary. It is a singularly attractive offering

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 18. -- The Peoples' Mandate today presented their petitions, bearing more than a million signatures, to outlaw war to Dr. Carlos Saavedra Lamas in an impressive ceremony in his office in the Anchorena Palace. Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, attended and directed Edward L. Reed to interpret when Dr. Saavedra Lamas made his response, since the leading women in the delegation were Americans.

For twelve years I have used the White Plains Road line of the I.R.T. subway and have been so disgusted with the service that even the impulse to write a letter has been deadened. The recent communication in THE TIMES from Leon G. Godley, acting chairman of the Transit Commission, however, comes as a last straw.

It is a pleasure to see that new interest is being stirred up for the formation of an Ivy League in football. With many others. I have long felt that such a group was even more desirable than are the existing leagues in basketball and baseball, due to the greater prominence of football.

PALM BEACH. Fla., Dec. 18. -- Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. Cheek were hosts tonight at a dinner at their home, taking their guests later to Club Madrid. They included Mr. and Mrs. George Stevenson Fenton, Mr. and Mrs. Guernsey Curran Jr., Mr. and Mrs. A. Parker Bryant, Mr. and Mrs. Blaine Webb and Mr. and Mrs. Edward U. Roddy Jr.

After a fierce fight on a fire-escape outside her second-floor apartment window, Mrs. Louise Marsh of 461 West Forty-fourth Street captured a young woman whom she said she had surprised in her apartment shortly before 8 o'clock last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The shortest supplies of farm products of any recent year except 1934, selling at the highest average prices since 1929, have combined this year to carry gross farm income to its highest point in six years, a total of $9,530,000,000, it was announced today by the government Crop Reporting Board in its final summary of 1936 production.

TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 18 (AP). -- A Federal grand jury closed the government's investigation of the June Robles kidnapping today, leaving the case as much a mystery as it was two years ago when the 6-year-old child vanished for nineteen days.
In the quiet of my room I have just finished my usual weekly occupation of reading the Sunday issue of your paper. Extreme age has its moments of pleasure; mine comes to me through that paper.

A revision of the criminal laws of the nation to place the emphasis on discipline and protection instead of punishment and vengeance was urged last night by Sanford Bates, director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons.

Christmas trade picked up sharply here during the week, but the percentage increase ran below earlier expectations. For the month to date, local department stores are estimated to be running about 5 per cent ahead of 1935. Including the last-minute spurt in Yuletide shopping and making allowance for the extra business day this year before Christmas, it is believed that the gain over 1935 will climb to about 10 per cent.

Many of the newspaper correspondents in China report a growing desire or determination not only to resist Japan but quickly to declare war upon her. This feeling has undoubtedly had something to do with the kidnapping of CHIANG KAI-SHEK, and with the negotiations which have followed with the impetuous CHANG HSUEH-LIANG who seized him and his aides.
X-ray photographs of a mummy nearly 4,000 years old have revealed that the Metropolitan Museum of Art owns a hitherto unsuspected collection of Egyptian jewelry of 2,000 B.C.

Substantial Increases in advertising appropriations for 1937 were outlined yesterday by several companies holdings sales conventions here. The merchandising division of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company will increase its advertising budget 50 per cent for 1937, Sidney D. Mahan, merchandising and advertising manager, announced yesterday at a preview of new lines at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
The Blackbirds of Long Island University downed Hampden-Sydney's basketball team, 63 -- 41. at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium last night.

BERLIN, Dec. 18. -- Before 300 leaders of German business and industry called together in a secret session in Berlin Chancellor Adolf Hitler and Colonel General Hermann Goering delivered yesterday afternoon what were officially described as "comprehensive and fundamental lectures on the tasks facing German economy in the execution of the Four-Year Plan."

Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens called on Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, yesterday to present to the District Attorney any direct evidence of improper or unsafe building construction in Queens.

The list of the Cunard White Star liner Lacoma, sailing today for Liverpool via Glasgow and Belfast, includes Captain and Mrs. John Devim, Miss Anna Condon, N.B. Smith, Dr. H. Warren Crowe, Miss V.F. Crowe. Miss D.A.A. Harcourt and K.H. Walden.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Pledges and cash contributions totaling $1,611,562 have been received thus far by the United Hospital Campaign Committee in its drive for $2,881,644, it was announced yesterday at a luncheon held by the committee in the Biltmore Hotel.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 18. -- An insane man attempted to set fire to the Swedish American liner Gripsholm while the vessel was at sea, it was learned today when the ship arrived at Gothenburg carrying Christmas travelers from New York to Sweden and Denmark.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 (AP). -- Directors of Armour Co. (Illinois) today voted the disbursement of $1,062,000 to pay all accumulated dividends on the 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock, of which there are about 33,000 shares outstanding. The back dividends amount to $31.50 a share.

The Brooklyn College basketball team defeated Seth Low. 38 -- 23. at the Columbia gymnasium last night. The winners led. 10 -- 6. at half time. Wally Levine, lanky Seth Low center, led in scoring with 13 points.
PARIS, Dec. 18. -- Prices sagged on the Bourse today, reflecting a general uneasiness caused by recent debates on the budget in the Chamber of Deputies.

Representatives of tenants' organizations presented a united front yesterday against any delay in enforcing the provisions of the Multiple Dwelling Law amendments requiring fire-retarding and other improvements in old-law tenements. They made their position clear at the second hearing on the housing problem held by the New York City Housing Authority at its offices at 10 East Fortieth Street.

Ten large manufacturers of electrical equipment filed a joint suit yesterday in Federal court seeking to recover alleged damages of $1,350,000 under the triple-penalty provisions of the anti-trust laws from Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical workers and from nine of its officers and agents.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 18. -- Peter Harry Van Horn, 43-year-old New York business man and former president of the American Federation of Textiles, Inc., was killed about 4 o'clock this morning when his automobile crashed into the concrete wall of the Bath and Tennis Club on South Ocean Boulevard.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- President Roosevelt said at a press conference today that he never had and never would take a direct or indirect part in choosing the officials of the House. He was replying to a question as to whether he favored a particular candidate for majority leader.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18. -- New high price levels for wheat and rye were established today on the Board of Trade here and on the Winnipeg Grain Exchange. The prices for both grains were in new ground for the last seven years.

Directors of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation and those of the Mohawk Hudson Power Corporation, one of the two principal intermediate holding companies in the Niagara Hudson system, voted yesterday at separate meetings to recommend to their stockholders a plan eliminating Mohawk Hudson Power.

A strike of 635 drivers of the Brooklyn Bus Corporation, a subsidiary of the Brooklyn Manhattan Transit Company, voted during the day by the drivers, was ratified late last night by an executive committee of the union locals of the State.

The runaway of two horses hitched to a soda water delivery wagon threw First Avenue in the lower Seventies into a turmoil at 3 P.M. yesterday, and ended with the death of one of the horses. Many pedestrians narrowly escaped injury.

New York City cannot exact rent from Swift Co., packers, for a freight loading platform maintained by the company on the East River waterfront between East Forty-fourth and East Forty-fifth Streets, Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Lauer ruled yesterday.

Most of the factors needed to guarantee the success of New York's World Fair in 1939 are definitely assured. The site is admirably chosen. The direction of the project is in capable hands. The cooperation of municipal, State and Federal Governments has been effected. Twenty-seven foreign nations have already accepted invitations to participate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- Total volume of round-lot trading and member trading showed substantial increases on the New York Stock and Curb Exchanges in the week ended on Nov. 21, compared with the previous week, according to summaries made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 18. -- Definite peace in the Chaco has become the new goal of the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace, in session here. Secret negotiations have been progressing all this week in an attempt to persuade Bolivia and Paraguay to renew diplomatic relations and begin conversations toward a settlement of the frontier problem that underlies the entire Chaco problem.

KINGSTON, Ont., Dec. 18. -- Queen's University gave the invading Princeton hockey team its second defeat in two nights of International Intercollegiate League competition tonight, winning 6 to 1. The Tigers lost, 10--0, to Toronto last night.

The appointment of three vice presidents, two of whom began their banking careers as office and messenger boys, was announced yesterday by the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company. The three are H. J. Osborne, Frank Wolfe and A. McD. McLean.

With visions of sugar-plums dancing in their heads, the local night club bonifaces are putting on their best bibs and tuckers, bringing out their finest entertainers and preparing for the rush of holiday reveling which is expected to begin next week.
LONDON, Dec. 18. -- With the approach of the Christmas holidays, business on the Stock Exchange has contracted and in a number of groups the current tendency is toward dullness.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP). -- A number of contributions to the Republicans during the last campaign were reported today to the Senate Investigating Committee, headed by a gift of $25,000 from Frazier Jelke of New York and Newport.

When the conditions to govern the America's Cup were digested yesterday by yachtsmen the general opinion was that T.O.M. Sopwith has an outstanding chance to capture the old trophy in the series that is to be held off Newport next Summer.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18. -- Plans to obtain a Federal appropriation to permit the enrollment of 38,000 men in citizens military training camps next year, 7,000 more than were in camps this Summer, were discussed today at the annual meeting of the governing committee of the Military Training Camps Association and representatives of the War Department.
The removal of superfluous hair by electrolysis treatments in beauty parlors by any one other than licensed physicians was forbidden yesterday in a decision by the Bronx Court of Special Sessions.

Jersey City will become the first club in the proposed New York Giant farm system, and Travis Jackson will be the manager of that International League team, according to strong intimations by Horace Stoneham, youthful president of the Giants.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 18. -- Brown scored its first victory over Yale in hockey in more than thirty years with a 3-to-2 triumph in an overtime game tonight. After trailing until the final half-minute of the regular play, Davis tied the score at 2-all at 19:30 of the third period.

MADRID, Dec. 18 (AP). -- After six weeks of siege, the Madrid defenders massed their forces today to meet a new Insurgent drive, following the loss of Boadilla del Monte, seven miles west of the city, in one of the most bitter engagements of the war.
There could be no better illustration of the deep distress and terrible plight of New York's Neediest Cases than the sad news that came to the Fund yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- Using the files of J.P. Morgan Co., the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee investigating railroad financing disclosed today that in January, 1933, that New York banking house became aware that Van Sweringen bookkeeping was not entirely accurate in so far as obligations of the Missouri Pacific Railroad, a Van Sweringen-controlled system to Terminal Shares, Inc., a wholly owned Van Sweringen holding company, were concerned.

United States Government obligations continued to soften yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, but the turnover of these issues was decidedly smaller -- $916,000, compared with $2,612,600 on Thursday. Declines ranged from 1-32 to 11-32 point.

BOSTON, Dec. 18 (AP). -- Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. today underwent a sinus operation which attending physicians said should permit him to spend Christmas at the White House with his family. Tonight he was reported as resting "very comfortably."
