De Witt Clinton moved into the forefront of the race for city P.S.A.L. basketball honors by crushing James Monroe, co-holder of the city crown with Thomas Jefferson, 33 -- 13, at the Monroe court in one of the outstanding league games played yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The new 2,000-ton United States gunboat Erie was fired on yesterday at Musel, the port of Gijon, Spain, by a Spanish warship, believed to be the Rebel warship Espana, but was not hit, according to a report from Commander Edward W. Hanson, commander of the gunboat.

The Standard Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $3,796,361 for the twelve months ended on Oct. 31, after all deductions. This compared to $2,241,716 for the preceding year. For the ten months to Oct. 31, net income was $2,491,134, against $1,239,411 a year before.

Virtually the last of the trolleys in Queens County were doomed yesterday when the Board of Estimate voted a franchise to the New York Queens Transit Corporation to motorize its existing street railways. The buses will be operated by Queens-Nassau Transit Lines, Inc., subsidiary of the trolley company.

GENEVA, Dec. 18. -- The League of Nations reform committee adjourned indefinitely yesterday after naming eleven rapporteurs to prepare the next stage of its work on the proposals it has decided to treat first. Chairman M. Bourquin, authorized to convoke it when he believed a meeting necessary, is expected to call a session in several weeks.

For the third time a Federal District Court upheld the Revenue Act of 1936 as constitutional when Judge Mandelbaum yesterday dismissed three suits by tobacco processors seeking refunds of AAA taxes. The court held that it was without jurisdiction because the statute was valid and that therefore the refunds must be in conformity with the new act.
TOKYO, Dec. 18 (AP). -- Japan's Ambassador to Nanking, Shigeru Kawagoe, today urged that his country extend moral support to the sorely pressed Chinese Government, at least in the field of finance.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Dec. 18. -- Pittsburgh's football squad, heading for the War of Roses in Pasadena New Year's Day, when it hopes to atone for three unsuccessful invasions, broke its transcontinental trip today with a hard, secret workout on the mile-high University of New Mexico gridiron.

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 18. -- Over the signature of Mgr. Leopoldo Ruiz y Flores, Archbishop of the State of Morelia and Papal Delegate to Mexico, now in exile in Texas, and thirty-four other Mexican prelates, a pastoral letter has been issued urging Catholic parents to fight to the last by passive resistance the socialistic educational plan evolved by the Cardenas government.

Brooklyn College will move into its new $5,500,000 buildings next September. The 43-acre site is located in one of the best sections of Flatbush and the college, with an enrollment of almost 11,000 students, is the largest arts and science college in the country and ranks tenth among the country's institutions of higher education in total enrollment.
The names of seventy-nine men who will serve on the national committee for the 1937 birthday ball for the President were announced yesterday by Colonel Henry L. Doherty, chairman of the celebration.
Two victories by Waiter Kasper gave the City College swimming team a 37-to-32 victory over St. Francis College last night in the C.C.N.Y. pool.

Any one who has been in China recently and is in touch with Chinese public sentiment, knows that Chang Hsueh-liang lost face completely with all patriotic Chinese when he failed to offer the resistance he was capable of in September, 1931. The existence of Manchukuo is a constant reminder to the people of Chang's failure.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18. -- Demand for hogs today was less active than yesterday, and the refusal of packers to take hold freely resulted in a decline of 10 to 25 cents in prices of stock over 220 pounds, while other weights were steady to 10 cents lower, with pigs showing the most strength.

A gain of 18.5 per cent in passenger revenue for 144 Class I railroads in October was reported yesterday by the Interstate Commerce Commission. This brought the increase in this revenue for the first ten months of the year to 15.4 per cent. Reduced passenger fares took effect on June 1.
In your issue of Dec. 16 is a letter signed by Herbert A. O'Brien, which is headed "The Situation in Spain."

A 13-year-old boy inmate of the New York State Training School for Boys at Warwick, N.Y., broke down last night after two days of questioning by psychiatrists and told of murdering a 10-year-old chum three months ago in a quarrel over the division of stolen lead pipe and of hiding the body of his victim in a closet in an abandoned lower East Side tenement.

LONDON. Dec. 18. -- On adjournment of Parliament today for a month's holiday, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told members of the House of Commons not to spoil their Christmas recess by being "in a mood of inspissated gloom about the international situation."

The St. John's University five displayed a fine brand of basketball in routing Clarkson Tech, 44 to 24, in the DeGray gymnasium last night for its sixth straight victory. The winners led at the half, 23 -- 9.

VATICAN CITY, Saturday, Dec. 19 (AP). -- Vatican prelates said early today that Cardinal Pacelli, Papal Secretary of State, had taken over the administration of ecclesiastical affairs at the Vatican during Pope Pius's illness. They added, however, that there had been no indication the Cardinal would continue to do so if the 79-year-old Pontiff recovered.
Holiday travel by rail, bus and train began in earnest yesterday.

BOSTON, Dec. 18. -- Thomas E. (Tommy) Qualters of the Massachusetts State Police has been selected from thousands of honor men in the public safety service throughout the nation to replace the late August A. (Gus) Gennerich as personal bodyguard to President Roosevelt, it was reported here tonight, and will be sworn in at Washington Monday.

A special statutory court made up of Judges Thomas W. Swan, William Bondy and Vincent Leibell declined yesterday to issue an interlocutory injunction restraining the Interstate Commerce Commission from enforcing tariff schedules which provide for free pick-up and delivery service for shippers and receivers.

Holding the opposition in check throughout, the Horace Mann basketball team inaugurated its drive by repulsing the Fanwood School quintet, 39 -- 16, on the former's court yesterday. Bill Crozier and Lou Duesing, with nine and eight points, respectively, paced the home forces, who held a 19 -- 6 advantage at the conclusion of the first half.

The Knickerbocker Greys, a junior military organization composed of young boys from leading New York families, held their annual Christmas drill yesterday afternoon before several hundred guests in the armory of the Seventh Regiment, the 107th Infantry of the National Guard, at Sixty-sixth Street and Park Avenue.

Salaries of the principal executives of three companies whose securities are listed on the New York Stock Exchange were disclosed yesterday in annual reports to the Securities and Exchange Commission. The concerns and their officers were:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- How David M. Milton, president of the Equity Corporation, injected himself into a complete deadlock in the affairs of the Atlantic and Pacific International Corporation and, without any expenditure, got $1,145,000 for Arthur J. Morris, founder and head of the Morris Plan, was outlined today in the investigation of investment trusts by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 18. -- The Compania de Petroleos de Mexico (Petromex) has applied to the Ministry of National Economy for a concession to construct and operate a natural gas pipeline 240 kilometers in length from Poza Rica in the State of Vera Cruz to this capital. The line will be the longest in the world.

Reflecting the effect of adverse weather upon early Christmas trade here which resulted in a smaller gain than was expected, sales of department stores showed an average increase for the metropolitan area of 4.1 per cent during the first twelve shopping days of December, against the same period last year, according to figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

You can pass by the stories of the Neediest Cases. You can find refuge in the thought that others will provide. Your absence will not be noted. No one will know you have turned a deaf ear to the cry for help. But will your heart and your conscience permit you to ignore these fellow-men in distress?

EVANSTON, Ill., Dec. 18. -- Larry Kelley, Yale's nimble-tongued all- America end, hadn't been on the field five minutes for the first meeting of the Eastern all-star football squad today before he lost an argument.

A careless smoker who fell asleep and dropped a cigarette which caused a fire that resulted in the death of four adults and a baby in a rooming house at 273 West Seventy-third Street early yesterday morning was later charged with second-degree manslaughter.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Dec. 18. -- The Colgate basketball team won its third straight game tonight, coming from behind in the second half to subdue a battling Dartmouth five, 44 -- 33 with a rally in which Pick Turevon, guard, made seven baskets.

SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 18. -- A second missing transport plane was sought by air and land today as a new clue in the wide search for the big airliner lost Tuesday indicated that the ship and its seven occupants might have come down in Southern Nevada.

Although the report of the Department of Agriculture giving the estimated production of the main grain crops in the United States this year was about in line with its recent monthly reports, a comparison with the yields of former years emphasizes the low level to which grain production in the United States has declined.

By defeating Princeton, 4 to 1, the Harvard Club maintained its lead among the Class C teams in the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League last night. The victory over the Tigers left the Harvard Club quintet one game ahead of the New York A.C. team, its most dangerous rival.

About 2,000 persons, many of whom had to stand throughout a three-hour meeting, filled the auditorium of the Center Hotel, 108 West Forty-third Street, last night to urge the right of a Mexican asylum for Trotsky, exiled Russian leader.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- Changing his mind overnight, Justice Daniel W. O'Donoghue in the United States District Court today granted a temporary injunction to Mrs. Oliver Harriman in her suit to restrain the Postmaster General from impounding mail of the National Conference for Legalizing Lotteries, Inc., until the Court of Appeals hearing.

To the Globe tonight comes Columbia's latest excursion into melodrama, "Lady From Nowhere," featuring Mary Astor, Charles Quigley, a newcomer, and Thurston Hall. . . . A program of film cartoons and comedies for children will be offered this morning at the Symphony Theatre, Broadway and Ninety-fifth Street. . . .

This is a continuation of my letter of last week on "How to Pick the Right Horse." I pointed out that the entire secret of beating the races is to wager only on horses whose odds are greater than their probability of winning and that the bookmaker himself shows when a horse is overlaid through his opening odds.

Charles Dillingham, league-leading scorer, tallied both of his team's points as Jamaica blanked Textile, 2 -- 0, at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night to remain tied with New Utrecht for first place in the P.S.A.L. hockey race. Each has won three tests and tied two in five starts.

SYDNEY, Australia, Saturday, Dec. 19 (Canadian Press). -- Wally Hammond, England's sensational batsman, had run his score to 226, not out, at the tea time adjournment of the second cricket test match with Australia today. The score of the tourists totaled 418 runs for five wickets at that point.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 18. -- A saga of the Hudson Bay Company depicting the feuds between the French Canadian trappers and the English was announced today by Paramount. Of heroic proportions, "The Long Traverse" (a phrase, incidentally, from the language of Northeast Canada), will be peopled by most of the stars on the Paramount roster.

BERLIN, Dec. 18. -- Not satisfied with shortening German preparatory schooling by three years, the Reich Ministry of Education, according to the German Educators' Journal, intends to shorten the university course.

In order that there might not be any delay in arrangements for the 1939 World's Fair, the Board of Estimate yesterday authorized Borough President Harvey of Queens to accept the low bid for construction of the new municipal asphalt plant near the World's Fair site, even though it was $172,811 above the engineers' advance estimate.

Conceding that his arrest of a motorcycle patrolman last Sunday as a noise violator might have been "bad judgment or bad taste" on his part, Magistrate W. Overton Harris denied in a statement yesterday that his action had exposed the magistrates' courts to ridicule or contempt.
DETROIT, Dec. 18. -- An official Ford statement tonight said:
H.E. Listman, a director of the Yellow Truck and Coach Manufacturing Company, has been elected vice president of the concern.

DETROIT, Dec. 18. -- Production at the Ford plant was seriously curtailed today because of shortage of parts. Labor troubles in some of the industries that supply materials were expected to affect several branches next week. Some factories will be forced to suspend operations completely and remain closed until supplies are available.

John Cummins, 69 years old and unemployed, was arrested early yesterday in connection with the fires which slightly damaged two historically valuable beds in the Jumel Mansion at about 11 P.M. Thursday. The mansion, at 160th Street and Edgecombe Avenue, is maintained as a museum under the Park Department.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 18 (AP). -- While her brother, the "Pinney" of the poet's whimsey, looked on, "Sister Girl," inspiration of Eugene Field's "Little Mistress Sans-Merci," turned a big key in the brass lock.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt distributed gifts yesterday to the children of needy trade unionists at the eleventh annual Christmas party in the Women's Trade Union League headquarters, 247 Lexington Avenue, Manhattan.

Discussions for an early recapitalization plan for the International Paper and Power Company and its subsidiary, the International Paper Company, are taking definitive shape, according to information in financial circles yesterday. It is expected now that a program will be ready for action by the respective boards of directors within a few days.
HAVANA, Saturday, Dec. 19. -- The bill levying a 9 cents tax on raw sugar was approved last night in the House of Representatives by a vote of 106 to 43.

Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission, struck back yesterday at city officials who have belittled the $7,000,000 reduction in electric rates recently approved by the commission. He declared that their criticism, as well as their denunciation of the commission's approval of mergers of electric and gas companies into the Consolidated Edison Company, were founded on "ignorance of the facts."

Maine's Legislature is playing with fire. In a skylarking mood the lower house at Augusta formally invited Vermont to join the Pine Tree State in reaffirming American principles against forty-six recreant Commonwealths. The latter are accused of selling their birthright for a mess of pottage.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, complained yesterday to Police Commissioner Valentine that members of his union reporting for duty on piers within the port, had been attacked by striking seamen.

Indictment of at least twelve men by the Federal grand jury in Trenton on charges of smuggling beverage alcohol into this country from Belgium was revealed yesterday in Newark by Federal agents, following the arrest in Brooklyn of Frederick Walter Watson, 60-year-old shipping broker, who is one of the persons indicted.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18. -- John D.M. Hamilton agreed to give his entire time to the chairmanship of the Republican National Committee and the executive committee today fixed his salary at $15,000 a year with an allowance of $10,000 for "base expenses."

Moving toward acquisition of an official city residence for the Mayor, the Board of Estimate authorized Controller Frank J. Taylor yesterday to investigate an offer of the $4,000,000 mansion of Charles M. Schwab at Seventy-third Street and Riverside Drive, and to survey other properties which might be used for the same purpose.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 18. -- Mrs. Emil Denemark of Chicago, whose colors were so prominent here last Winter, continues to set a fast pace for rival owners at the Tropical Park course. Her popular canary and blue banner again was borne to victory today when Chief Cherokee, making his first appearance of the local season, defeated A.C. Morris's Patriotic by a head in the featured Homestead Purse.

MARIETTA, Ohio, Dec. 18. -- A three-mile race on the Ohio River in which the country's outstanding college crews will be invited to participate was scheduled today for June, 1938, as a feature of the Northwest Territory celebration.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- Navy orders for steel went begging today when bids were opened on an esti mated 8,784 tons of construction and stock material.

ROME, Dec. 18. -- An important reference to the Anglo-Italian situation brought about by the part Great Britain played in the ItaloEthiopian controversy and sanctions was made by Premier Benito Mussolini today in a speech in Littoria, in the heart of the reclaimed Pontine marshes, where he inaugurated several important public works.

Dr. Joseph E. Goodbar, economist and president of the Society for Stability in Money and Banking, Inc., urged bankers to work together for progressive stabilization of prosperity last night in an address at the dinner session of the National Economic Forum in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The Good Will Court broadcasts have been withdrawn from the radio, effective tomorrow night, following Wednesday's ruling by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of New York forbidding lawyers to give advice "in connection with a publicity medium of any kind."

Back from a tour of the Orient with Elisworth Vines, William Tilden, former world's tennis champion, flatly predicted yesterday that the tall Californian would defeat Fred Perry of Great Britain when they meet in Madison Square Garden the night of Jan. 6.

An official statement that conditions surrounding the release of government cotton had not been determined finally served yesterday to restore more normal trading on the Cotton Exchange and a further recovery left the list with gains of 1 to 7 points.

The Progressive Arts Association, a group of young artists, many of whom have studied at the Art Students League, has opened a gallery at 428 West Fifty-seventh Street. The opening exhibition includes paintings by Morris Kantor, sculpture by William Zorach, and oils, water-colors, prints and drawings by members of the group.

Christmas will be celebrated tomorrow in most of the denominational churches. In Roman Catholic, Protestant Episcopal and Lutheran churches the commemoration will be on Christmas Eve and Christmas Day, Friday. Tomorrow there will be sermons on "The Birth of the Christ Child" in the morning, and in the late afternoon and evening there will be Christmas oratorios, pageants and nativity plays, candlelight and carol services.

J.P. Morgan gave a dinner dance last night at his home here, 231 Madison Avenue. for two of his granddaughters, who are among this season's debutantes -- namely, Miss Virginia Morgan Pennoyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul G. Pennoyer of New York and Locust Valley, and Miss Jane N. Nichols, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Nichols of this city and Cold Spring Harbor.

BERLIN, Dec. 18. -- The Olympic Games cost the municipal government of Berlin 16,500,000 marks. This sum was spent exclusively for decorations and traffic accommodations, such as bridges and other approaches to the Olympic Field. The municipality invested nothing in Olympic equipment proper, which was constructed solely by the Reich Government.

MILFORD, Conn., Dec. 18. -- Walter Perry, 16, formerly of Milford, who travels by bus to the scene of his thefts, loads up two suitcases with loot and returns to his New York home by bus, was locked up in Stratford police headquarters, under a $10,000 bond, after his capture by Policeman John Koch in a Walnut Beach roof garden early today.

It is ill jesting with a wounded heart. Otherwise some details of the meeting of the Republican National Committee might give pleasure to the thoughtless. Liberator FISH of Alaska, for instance, trying to "liberalize" such old stagers as Tireless JOE TOLBERT of South Carolina, PERRY HOWARD of Mississippi and Mr. R.B. CREAGER of Texas.

Coordination of the Federal and New York State laws to solve the problem that will arise in 1938 when member banks of the Federal Reserve System no longer will be permitted to pay the interest that State officials are required by law to collect on public funds or on uninvested trust funds was recommended yesterday by William R. White, New York State Superintendent of Banks.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 18. -- The solidarity of the Americas was more positively affirmed today than the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace had previously felt moved to express the sentiment that had been the basis of its deliberations.

Engagements of $2,051,000 of gold in England for shipment here were reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Of this amount, $1,232,000 was obtained yesterday and the remainder on Thursday. The total of gold engaged in England for shipments here since Sept. 26 is now $156,600,000.
Alfredo Salmaggi and his company resumed operatic productions at popular prices last night at the Hippodrome. Verdi's "Rigoletto" was received enthusiastically by an audience of 2,500 persons.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18. -- One of the biggest financial undertakings in years was set in motion late today when officials of the Commonwealth Edison Company and its affiliated utility concerns announced a sweeping program of changes in capitalization which would give Commonwealth Edison complete
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- Pursuing his campaign to unionize mass-production industries. John L. Lewis moved today to come to grips with the General Motors Company.

Sporadic flurries of selling kept the stock market heavy in tone during most of yesterday's session. The recent support levels for many stocks were lowered, although the pressure of offerings appeared to be no greater than on many days recently.

GLENDALE, Calif., Dec. 18 (AP). -- Turning in his second sub-par round, George Von Elm of Hollywood, former national amateur golf champion, took a two-stroke lead over Olin Dutra, former United States open king, at the close of the second round of the $1,500 Southern California open today.

BERLIN, Dec. 19. -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's speech in the House of Commons yesterday, accusing Germany, Russia and Italy of shipping arms to Spain in violation of the non-intervention agreement provoked bitter comments in the German press, finding a climax in the flat charge in the Boersen Zeitung that Mr. Eden misrepresented the situation "against his better knowledge and at the expense of the truth."

THE Borzoi Reader" (Alfred A Knopf, $3.50) contains over a thousand pages of some of the most satisfying writing done in the last two decades -- a generous balanced ration for the sophisticated. Carl Van Doren edited it and limited his choice to contemporary material published by Alfred A. Knopf in the twenty-one years of the existence of that film.

A supper dance has been arranged for the night of Jan. 11 in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria as a benefit for Christodora House. A feature of the entertainment will be a rhumba contest in which members of the junior committee will participate.

JOHN STRACHEY needs no introduction to the American public. His enthusiasm for communism, his sincerity, his undoubted literary abilities, his very name which evokes a great literary tradition, and also perhaps his aristocratic family affiliations, have firmly established him as a favorite of the radically minded reader.

Victor S. Yarros is unfair in his denunciation of Mr. Barbirolli. His programs are much superior to those of Toscanini, and while he has regrettably listed music like the "Siege of Corinth," he has delighted us with Arnold Bax's "The Tale the Pine Trees Knew," Schubert's Second symphony and Charles Martin Loeffler's "In a Russian Village."
JOHN LILLIE'S show at the Ferargil (until Dec. 30) should reinforce this Vermonter's reputation. It contains some surprises, along with the logical making-good on a basis of earlier promise.

" This year I have had the gift of great happiness bestowed upon me," wrote a contributor to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday, who gave "In Memory of Three," "and want more than ever to pass on a little cheer to those less fortunate. 'Freely ye have received, freely give.'"
What is Europe thinking about at this Christmas of 1936? One way of discovering is to look into the Christmas numbers of the magazines.

GRANT'S reputation as a soldier is forever overshadowed by the man he defeated. Lee is the hero of the Civil War, Grant merely the winner. Guedalla said of Wellington's victory over Napoleon that there is an odd tendency to choose almost any explanation except the possibility that the abler fighter won.

The first of the Dolphin Dances for this season took place last night in the ballroom of the Pierre. The entertainment brought together many young women who will be introduced to society within the next few years, and their young men friends, the majority of the subscribers being young people at home from schools or colleges for the holidays.

LONDON, Dec. 19. -- The coronation of King George and Queen Elizabeth on May 12 was proclaimed today at four points of London. Thus twice within a year Londoners have witnessed this ancient ceremony ordinarily occurring only once in a generation.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Dec. 19. -- The third annual Christmas ball given by President John Stewart Bryan to the students and faculty of the College of William and Mary was held last evening in Phi Beta Kappa Hall. The party was even more successful than that of last year, with more than 1,000 persons in attendance at a reproduction of a typical eighteenth-century Christmas party in a lord's manor during the holiday season.
ONE still meets Americans occasionally who say, "Yes, I flew across the Channel several times in 1929, but I never fly in the United States. Those Europeans seem to know better what it is all about."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- From his home in Arkansas, Senator Robinson, leader of the Senate, telegraphed today to Representative Rayburn of Texas denying published reports that he had endorsed Representative O'Connor of New York for House majority leader.

Not one day's delinquency in payment of rent by any tenant in the first full year of operation of First Homes, the New York City Housing Authority's low-rent housing project at Avenue A and Third Street, was reported yesterday by Langdon W. Post, Authority chairman.

OF all the figures that embody the Christmas legend, the most appealing is that gentle woman who was the Mother of Christ. As symbol and as woman she has caught at the imagination of men since the earliest days, and her progress throughout Christian art mirrors the changing world through which she moves.
LAKE PLACID. -- This Adirondack Mountains resort has been putting its facilities for skiing into Winter readiness and is this week-end opening its regular program of scheduled events.

BEGINNING next week-end and for ten days thereafter, New York City's gates will be swinging like a weathervane before the eager push of travelers seeking yuletide cheer either within the city or outside of it.

The paradox of Motor Cycle Patrolman Michael Darienzo's arrest last week by Magistrate W. Overton Harris as a violator of the very anti-noise ordinance he is supposed to enforce drew renewed attention to Mayor La Guardia's drive in the last fourteen months to make New York a quieter community.

BAYONNE, N.J., Dec. 19. -- Commissioner Horace K. Roberson, who represented the Bayonne City Commission in the negotiations looking toward construction of a ship-to-rail terminal in New York Bay, said tonight he expects the city authorities to consider a new contract for the project "very shortly."

Tenement House Commissioner Langdon W. Post, speaking yesterday afternoon at the Rand School, 7 East Fifteenth Street, declared that nearly 1,000 old-law tenements had been closed by his department during the year for failure to comply with housing regulations.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 18. -- This community, which likes to be called the "Athens of the Midwest," is pretty hard-boiled about investigations, particularly when they concern the University of Wisconsin.
BERLIN, Dec. 19 (AP). -- Leaders of the Third Reich balanced empty butter plates with submarines today and turned the German eye toward "breadlines in America."

AMHERST, Dec. 19. -- The announcement that the trustees of Amherst College have voted to keep the Stearns Church open and heated this Winter, for such religious purposes as may be determined upon by the administration and the Christian Association, has revived interest in one of the most puzzling problems facing the college authorities.

Indiana sharpshooters, deadly, from up close and from long range, brought about the downfall of Manhattan's unbeaten hosts last night as the intercollegiate basketball program of Madison Square Garden got off to a flying start before a gathering of 11,000.
Miss Louise Brion, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Brion of Roslyn, L.I., was introduced to society last night at a dance given by her parents in the Viennese roof garden of the St. Regis.

The number of women in this country who know the thrills of down-mountain ski racing and slalom contests is very small compared to the thousands of women who enjoy the less strenuous pleasures of casual week-end skiing and "snow-train" excursions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP). -- The National Boxing Association today ranked Max Schmeling, German heavyweight, behind Champion James J. Braddock and in front of Joe Louis, the Negro sensation, in its ratings for the last quarter of 1936.

SHANGHAI, China, Nov. 27. -- The Bronx Zoo in New York will soon come into possession of the only specimen of the giant panda ever to be brought to America alive. And all because a young New York woman would not accept discouragement nor defeat where many men had failed.
The ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton was the setting yesterday afternoon for a tea dance given by Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Peters Jr. of Glen Head. L.I., to introduce their daughter, Miss Helene Louise Peters.
BOSTON, Dec. 19. -- The Boston Olympics tallied in every period tonight to conquer the Dartmouth hockey team, 5 -- 1, in the Boston Garden.

PARIS. MILLINERS are finding material for thought and notions for hats in the current Paris exhibition of paintings by Peter Paul Rubens. The master's famous self portrait, and the well-known canvas portraying Helene Fourment and her children, seem to have attracted great number of modistes.

PROBLEMS, somehow, are always with us. And perhaps next to the one on what to do with ex-Presidents not the least of an absorbing interest concerns the question: What are we to do about our old ball players?

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Government awards under the Public Contracts Act in the week ended on Thursday amounted to $1,986,995, with forty-seven contracts awarded, the Department of Labor announced today.

SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., Dec. 19 (AP). -- The University of Pittsburgh football team, as solemn a pack of gridiron warriors as ever journeyed West, roiled into San Bernardino today to prepare for the New Year's Day clash with the Washington Huskies in the Pasadena Rose Bowl.

LONDON, Dec. 19. -- A wave of prosperity, checked temporarily by last week's constitutional crisis, burst with such fury on London's shopping districts today that two of the largest stores had to close their doors to customers.

Members of the Democratic Junior League of New York will hold their annual supper dance in behalf of their philanthropic fund on Jan. 16 in the Roof Garden of the Pierre. Miss Marie Helen Olvany is president of the league and Miss Grace E. Manning heads the benefit committee.

THE Emperor Napoleon passed twenty-five years on St. Helena. For twenty of those years he lay dead in his tomb. Months before he was laid there he had really ceased to live. "Bed has become a place of delight.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art will place on exhibition this morning for the first time selections from the bequest of arms and armor made by George C. Stone, internationally known metallurgist, inventor and collector.

In pronouncing Chinese names the only important thing to remember is that all vowels in the ordinary spellings have their Latin values and not their English values, that is, a, e, i, o, u are prononced ah, eigh, ee, oa, oo. There is a u with two dots on top (German umlaut), but that never gets printed in newspapers, being spelled like ordinary u, which is of course confusing to the reader.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Dec. 19. -- A blind freshman at Colgate University here is proving that it is possible to enjoy life, be a good student and participate in student affairs despite the handicap of lack of sight. He is Michael Supa of Binghamton, N.Y., a cheerful, medium-sized youth, who mixes in all campus affairs, always accompanied by his faithful "seeing eye," his police dog Taffy.

NANKING, China, Dec. 19 (AP). -- The Nanking government's order for an attack on General Chang Hsueh-liang was taken here to indicate new difficulties had arisen in the negotiations for settlement of the Sian revolt.

CHRISTMAS programs of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra will bring Josef Hofmann here in his first appearance of the season as soloist Thursday, Friday and next Sunday. He will be heard in Beethoven's "Emperor" concerto Christmas Eve and Christmas Day, and will play the Chopin Concerto No. 2, in F minor, next Sunday.

Danny and Davy, 2-year-old orphaned "Thanksgiving twins," will spend this Christmas and many more to come in their own home in the suburbs, with a new mother and father to look after them and a back yard -- complete with a big, friendly dog -- in which to frolic.
Five days before Christmas and the Neediest wait!

MEXICO'S Christmas celebration is already under way, for on Dec. 12 it is the custom of the rural people to make an annual pilgrimage to attend the Feast of the Guadalupe Virgin -- the patron saint of Mexico -- at her shrine just outside of Mexico, D.F.

LONDON, Dec. 19 (Canadian Press). -- One of the tightest struggles in years is being waged for the English Football League championship as the teams prepare for the heavy holiday program. Failure of the two leading teams today and victories for their nearest rivals resulted in a shuffling of the standings with only one point separating the first five clubs.

High-goal polo started its indoor season at the Squadron A Armory last night when the Optimists team, which included three of last Summer's international players, turned back the New York Athletic Club, 10 to 7 1/2.

A young servant girl who said she had never been able to earn sufficient money to buy the "nice little things" she wanted told her troubles to Magistrate Matthew J. Troy in Felony Court, Brooklyn, yesterday. She is Marion Snyder, 20 years old, gave her address as 216 East Seventeenth Street, Manhattan, and was held in $1,000 bail for further hearing Dec. 24 on a charge of grand larceny.

VIENNA, Dec. 19. -- The Duke of Windsor went through his daily routine at Enzesfeld Castle today and played golf, despite a thick fog that must have reminded him of London, in the afternoon. He wrote letters in the evening and attended a private cinema show in the castle of Baron Eugene de Rothschild.

PARIS, Dec. 18. -- Agnes is featuring novel forms of trimming in her advanced Summer hats. Large milan, leghorn or baku shapes are trimmed with the type of colored straw braid that usually makes hats. It is either looped into chrysanthemum-like rosettes, placed right at the front of the hat, or is sewn under the brim at the back, where it hangs in loops over the hair.

Henry T. (Dick) Merrill, who has flown more than 2,000,000 miles without injury to himself or a passenger, won wide acclaim for his return-trip flight between the United States and England last September with Harry Richman, Broadway entertainer.
BERLIN, Dec. 19. -- Living in Germany is becoming an art, the successful pursuit of which depends on one's own kitchen staff's diplomatic relations with the butcher, baker, milkman and greengrocer.

Now that the Dictionary of American Biography stands complete on our shelves, I wish to express my professional and personal appreciation of it, and for the part THE NEW YORK TIMES took in backing its compilation.

THE American invasion of the past few weeks is not yet at an end. The procession from across the water was led by Rose Bampton and then followed in quick succession (and in one case even simultaneously) by Shura Cherkassky, Dusolina Giannini, Ray Lev, the Curtis Quartet and the harpsichordist Lucille Wallace.
Employes of the Works Progress Administration and of the Emergency Relief Bureau staged separate protest demonstrations yesterday in the City Hall area, both of them entirely orderly.

With Congress soon to convene, and the President back in the capital, more news is coming out of Washington. Several of last week's dispatches were particularly interesting. Mr. ROOSEVELT discussed taxes with two leading members of Congress, chairmen of the finance committees.

LONDON, Dec. 5. IN the shadow of what is called "The Constitutional Crisis" playgoing during the present week has been a little pale and even a little anxious. It will not easily be believed in America that millions of people in England were, until a few days ago, completely unaware that any such crisis was impending, so careful has been the silence of our newspapers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The problem of police cooperation in Federal Bureau of Investigation raids, aggravated by criticism New York of G-man procedure in the capture of Harry Brunette, confessed kidnappers is one that has given J. Edgar Hoover much concern.

HAPPY days must indeed be here again when a popular novelist ventures a sympathetic treatment of a wealthy banking family. Mrs. Fairbank, remembered particularly by women readers as the author of "The Bright Land" and "The Smiths," continues to write of American family life.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Peacemakers within the American Federation of Labor were said today to have abandoned for the present their effort to end the federation's strife with John L. Lewis. This indicated that the angry conflict, which has split labor into two hostile camps, would rage for most of the Winter, at least.

Bob Pastor's spectacular conquest of the giant Ray Impellittiere Friday night in Madison Square Garden appears to have catapulted him into the limelight, over which the figure of Joe Louis casts the only discouraging shadow. This may be fortunate or otherwise, depending on the point of view, for the scrappy Washington Heights husky who bowled over the 6-feet 7-inch Impellittiere in seven rounds.

Engineers, technicians and medical men, as reported recently in your columns, have referred to the fact that technical science needs supplementing by a study of the social sciences so that increased technical efficiency and productivity shall result in general social welfare.

The eyes of the world turn toward China as she faces the greatest crisis of the past ten years. I believe that unfolding events will prove that China can well stand the gaze of the world. The last four years of China's development, since the Manchurian war, have been a period of steady national consolidation and integration.

" A MERRY CHRISTMAS be yours!" At this holiday season, for the first time since the clouds of depression gathered, New York is a City of Gladness. Peace and cheer dwell again in hearts that have long been anxious; the streets reflect the new hope, the new promise that recovery brings.
Shao Yuan-chung, who was killed by Chinese rebels last week, was a soldier, professor, editor and author. He was born at Shaohsing, Chekiang, in 1889.

ON Christmas Eve, when the lights shine through the holly wreaths in the windows, the carol singers will be around in the crisp or blustery Winter weather, shivering in the snow perhaps, in spite of galoshes and buttoned coats and mufflers tightly wound about the throat.

Celebration of the seventy-sixth birthday of Miss Henrietta Szold by Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization which she founded twenty-five years ago, and the thirteenth annual convention of Junior Hadassah opening on Christmas Day in Washington, D.C., make the coming week memorable for these two groups.
DETROIT, Dec. 19. -- The city of Detroit, said to operate the only psychopathic "traffic clinic" in the United States, has embarked on a new project to reduce automobile accidents.

The relative letting up in the fighting in Spain may or may not mean that the bloodshed is nearing an end. It is probably true that to believe the civil war is about fought out would represent an optimism without justification.

The economic plight of Jews in Poland is growing progressively worse as the immigration of German Jews seeking escape from the Hitler regime continues, Lord Marley, Deputy Speaker of the House of Lords of England, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- By a 9-to-2 decision the Interstate Commerce Commission today denied the plea of Class I railroads that emergency freight charges, which will expire Dec. 31, be continued until sixty days after the commission's decision on the proposed general freight-rate adjustment.

The office of Charles L. Wagner has announced its list of concert attractions for 1937-38 season. The list is headed by Jussi Bjoerling, leading tenor of the Royal Opera, Stockholm. Mr. Bjoerling will come to this country next November for opera and concert engagements.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP). -- The cotton spinning industry was reported today by the Census Bureau to have operated during November at 129.9 per cent of capacity, compared with 123.3 during October this year and 101.1 during December last year.

BENNINGTON, Vt., Dec. 19. -- The students of Bennington College left the campus yesterday for the annual two months' Winter field and reading period, which is a feature of the institution's educational plan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The "alarming increase" in farm tenancy at the expense of ownership since 1910, the plight of the tenant and share-cropper family "averaging" a yearly income of $312, and the future reconstruction of the Cotton Belt through State and Federal legislation, are subjects of an exhaustive study on "landlord and tenant on the cotton plantation," released today by Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator.

THE slanting rays of a southern sun are flooding a large part of California with an almost tropical warmth as the State prepares to welcome the thousands of Eastern visitors who annually go west to escape the snow and ice. Weather forecasters on the Pacific Coast predict a milder Winter than and usual, travel agencies expect a tourist boom.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 19. --Announcement by two large trucking firms of their itention to move out of Jersey City as a result of interference with their business by strikes, brought from Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City today a criticism of the union leadership responsible for the strikes.

The Bank of N.T. Butterfield Son, Ltd., the largest and oldest bank in Bermuda, faced with an opportunity to expand its business by accepting custodian, trust and banking accounts from scores of Americans and Canadians who are seeking to evade various types of taxes in this country, has decided to decline the business, if it does not appear to it to be legitimate, according to Harry D. Butterfield, secretary of the bank.

LUXURIOUS weaves, as handsome as the finest wool, cotton, silk and linen, are now made of synthetic yarns. Gone are the days when "artificial silk," the forerunner of these fabrics made from cellulose and other basic materials, was regarded as a cheap imitation of the silkworm's product.

The practice of presenting amateur gardeners with gifts for Christmas related to their hobby has grown apace in recent years. Seed stores and gift shops have been quick to respond with a long and varied selection of articles designed for this purpose.

New York City is making a double-barreled attack on its internal traffic problem. Last week the Board of Aldermen approved a new traffic code, the first in nearly twenty years. Within a short time, according to word from City Hall, Mayor La Guardia will call a conference of civic organizations and traffic officials to pick up the problem where the Aldermen left off.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19. -- Sales in local department stores this week were approximately 10 per cent ahead of the corresponding period last year. Home furnishings, the higher priced toys and first floor goods were the most active, while ready-to-wear lagged.

THE principal sensation of 1936 in contract bridge tournaments has been the consistent success of a group of young New York players, who have captured three of the major team-of-four titles and have won or placed high in nearly all of the national and sectional pair tournaments in the East.

Christmas shopping here last week reached peak proportions, but the gains in dollar sales over a year ago continued somewhat under expectations. For the month to date, the increase for department stores is estimated at around 5 to 6 per cent, or but slightly better than the gain of 4.1 per cent reported for the first twelve shopping days of the month by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Mickey Mouse is going to do his bit for charity. He will appear with all his friends and the characters of the Silly Symphony films on the screen at Carnegie Hall on Dec. 28 and 29 in an entertainment, called the "Mickey Mouse Carnival," which will be held to aid the anti-tuberculosis committee of the Opportunity Shop, 46 West Forty-seventh Street, a permanent activity of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor.

CARLISLE, Pa., Dec. 19. -- Dickinson College's traditional doll show, held on Friday night in the Alumni Gymnasium, did much more than provide a holiday send-off for rollicking undergraduates; it spread Christmas cheer to people who would otherwise have none -- orphans, poor farm children, tenement dwellers and the families of prisoners.

A broad decline in railroad issues as a result of the Interstate Commerce Commission's decision to terminate the freight surcharges at the end of this year was the outstanding development in trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 19 (AP). -- The last ships on the Great Lakes were heading into this and other ports tonight after a blustery season which took thirty-three lives and five vessels.

MADRID, Dec. 19. -- Communist demands for a "real single command" were supported by a majority of other members of the Popular Front government who held that "ridiculous decentralization schemes such as self-appointed independent juntas" must cease.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 19. -- Organization of the Yale University Alumni Board office with a formal program has just been accomplished after thirty years' effective activity with an alumni secretary or agent and a less firmly crystallized platform.

FOR years I believed solemnly the common canon of criticism that has long been used to deal with the light verse of Mr. Guiterman and Mr. Adams. The canon holds, as you recall, that while both are enormously skillful and resourceful technicians, knowing all there is to know about the perilous and exacting rules of light verse, the verses they produce tend, oftener than any one could wish, to be dismayingly wooden and uninspired.

COMMERCE to Mrs. Hewes is not merely a matter of exports and imports, debits and credits; it is rather the lifeblood of history and the inspiration and result of great adventure. In three earlier books for readers of high-school age she has developed this theme in the Old World and the New, and in "The Codfish Musket" she turns to the early years of American expansion following the Revolution.

While fascism and communism struggle for control of Europe and Asia, with popular government hard put to it to keep a foothold in the Old World, the forces of democracy are waging a battle for survival in the island republic of Cuba, on the threshold of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Reports for the first half of December indicate a continuation of the previous favorable trend in business activity, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey.

SUBLIME is surely the word for the giant grab bag at the Museum of Modem Art (reviewed last week). To it naught could be added, from it naught could be taken away without a pang of excruciating dear distress.

CHARLOTTE. N.C., Dec. 19. -- The glamour of Harlem's "hot spots" and the nostalgia for a cabin in the cotton at hog-killing time are powerful lures at this time of year. And here, at the gateway to the cotton fields, the farm Negro.

NEWMARKET, England, Dec. 19 (AP). -- Although nine of his horses won only nineteen races, Lord Astor topped the list of owners on the English turf during the 1936 flat-racing season, winning 38,131 ($190,655). Rhodes Scholar was the leading money winner of the stable, accounting for 12,466 ($62,330) in two races.

It is the dream of all gardeners, especially of those who live where ground freezes, to decorate the Christmas dinner table with flowers from their own out-of-door gardens. With Christmas-roses available, this need no longer be merely a dream, for at small expense, with a little forehanded preparation in the Spring, exquisite flowers can be raised in protected garden nooks for indoor decoration.

THE Philharmonic-Symphony Society has decided that John Barbirolli is the man and has named him permanent conductor and music director for the next three years. No decision has been made as to whether Mr. Barbirolli will conduct the full twenty-four weeks of the season next year, although it is considered likely that he will wish to rest for a week or a fortnight in mid-season.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Prosperity is returning and bringing with it not only increased dividend checks and bonuses but a grist of strikes and other labor difficulties.
The death of Dr. Henry Moskowitz deprives the community of a leading citizen -- a sincere, broad-gauged, ever-vigilant public servant.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 19. -- In an effort to ascertain the most successful enforcement and engineering methods of the country's automobile traffic agencies, Harvard University has sent sixteen research men on field trips which will take them through seventeen States in the East and Middle West during the Christmas recess.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 18. -- Missourians have reason to believe that the $1,000,000 Algoa Farm, opened in April, 1932, as a prison without walls and the last word in penology, has failed to make the showing as a model that was expected of it.
Getting away to a good lead in the first half, the Cooper Union five turned back the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy team, 41 -- 29, at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy last night.

No second Senator Caraway and not a single woman Governor to carry on the Mrs. Nellie Tayloe Ross and "Ma" Ferguson tradition emerged from the recent national election, yet the status of women as holders of public office is not too discouraging, Miss Charl Williams of Washington insisted yesterday in a national broadcast.
One hundred and sixteen special prizes are offered by the Pekingese Club of America at the thirty-ninth specialty show of that organization at the Hotel Pennsylvania on Monday, Jan. 11.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19. -- November was a record month for the number of revenue passenger miles flown by domestic airlines in the United States, according to figures released today by the Air Transport Association of America. The number of miles flown was 41,161,000, an increase of 130 per cent over November of last year.

FOR the Boy Scouts another season of Winter camping is at hand. As schools close for the Christmas holidays, thousands of boys in all parts of the country will strike out for woodland rendezvous. There is camping in Winter, whether snow lies on the ground or not.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Dec. 18. -- There are increasing purchases of "Menschliche Erblehreund Rassenhygiene" ["Human Hereditary Doctrine and Racial Hygiene"], by Professors Erwin Bauer, Eugene Fischer and Fritz Lenz, published in Munich, because the Netherlanders see a good joke on Chancellor Adolf Hitler in the book's praise of Jews.

Dr. Daniel W. Hering, 86-year-old curator of the James Arthur collection of timepieces at New York University, nominated 1936 as "one of the luckiest years in my life," yesterday after discovering and acquiring his second "pre-pendulum" clock within twelve months.

The Eastern District H.S. basketball team strengthened its hold on first place in the P.S.A.L. Brooklyn Division Section 2 race yesterday by defeating the Franklin K. Lane five, 29 to 15, on the Eastern District court. It was the third league victory for the team in as many games.

THE second program of the Rome symphony series, led by Molinari, included a first Italian hearing of Wolf-Ferrari's typical "Venetian Suite," for small orchestra. The maestro is now at work on a new opera from the Lope de Vega comedy "La Dama Boba" (The Foolish Lady); the book is by Mario Ghisalberti, librettist of the same composer's "Artful Widow" and "Venetian Square."

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 19. -- Holding that the Central Railroad of New Jersey would have exclusive rail facilities on the proposed $5,000,000 ship-to-rail terminal extending from the Bayonne shore into New York Bay, the Supreme Court set aside today a resolution by the Bayonne City Commission authorizing construction of the terminal.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Dec. 19. -- The Misses Dorothy Ayers, Virginia Shaw and Jane Snyder of Garden City gave a dinner tonight before Miss Elsie Livingston Hepburn's junior dance at the Cherry Valley Club.

After a little more than an hour of quiet trading yesterday, the stock market was suddenly plunged into feverish activity on receipt of the news that the Interstate Commerce Commission had declined to extend the emergency railway freight surcharges until the matter of general revision of the freight rate structure could be considered.

Tweeds, woolens, pottery, carved wooden figures and a staggering array of attractive articles made in rural homes over the country are now available in New York shops. Women in mountain villages of the Southern Appalachians, on the little island of Nantucket, in New Hampshire hamlets, as well as in Maine, New Mexico and Southern California, have been stealing time from their household chores to make cloth and gift objects for sale in the cities.

The silver, furniture, rugs and tapestries sold yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries brought $17,947.50. The sale was the fourth and final session of an auction of the goods of several owners including the late Malcolm Sumner, Carll H. DeSilver, Mrs. Louise S. Celestin, Leon F. Ansbacher and the late George W. Wickersham.

The Calvert Distillers Corporation announced yesterday bonuses for its sales staff amounting to 10 per cent of annual salary for those employed more than two years; 7 1/2 per cent for those in service from one to two years, 5 per cent for those employed from six months to one year and one week's salary to others.

A HISTORY of the Sunpapers of Baltimore -- The Sun, The Evening Sun and The Sunday Sun -- written by Gerald W. Johnson, Frank R. Kent, H.L. Mencken and Hamilton Owens, has been completed and is announced by Alfred A. Knopf for publication in May, at which time The Baltimore Sun will celebrate its one hundredth anniversary.

With the advent of the Christmas holidays, the season's gayest period of entertaining for debutantes and their young friends will be under way. Although many of the girls who are making their debuts this season are remaining in town for the Winter, others who are attending school or college will return for the round of parties to be given this week and next in this city.

The last volume of the memoirs of Mr. Lloyd George is so far afield from fact in his comment on General Pershing and the steps taken by him to make American interposition in the World War effective that those who know the facts should by no means remain silent in the face of that assault.

The Seventh Regiment Gazette, official publication of New York's National Guard organization, will mark the completion of fifty years of existence this week with a special "Golden Anniversary" number. President Roosevelt, Governor Lehman, Major Gen. William N. Haskell, commander of the New York National Guard, and other leaders in civil and military life will contribute.

Hundreds of persons trying to get their Christmas parcels in the mail at the General Postoffice, Eighth Avenue and Thirty-third Street, halted for a few minutes yesterday while Postmaster General James A. Farley officially put a festive touch upon a spot which is being rushed as it has not been in years.

A Florida-bound migration, involving somewhere between 1,000,000 and 2,500,000 persons, is well under way. In this annual holiday and sunshine-seeking pilgrimage 90 per cent of all travelers go South by automobile, a large majority of the cars being driven over the highways that parallel the coast from the New York region to the peninsula of palm and pine.

VATICAN CITY, Dec. 19. -- The Vatican represents its anti-Communist campaign as aiming only at opening the eyes of people all over the world to Communist danger and keeping them constantly aware of it. The Pope appeals, with this object in view, not only to Catholics but to all "people of good-will."

A series of free Christmas concerts will be given at Carnegie Hall for the first time in history, it was announced yesterday by M. Murray Weisman, president of Carnegie Hall. WPA Federal Music Project instrumental and choral units will participate.

The New York State law which forbids the transportation into the State of any liquor not consigned to a person holding a liquor license was never intended to apply to persons importing small quantities for their own use. Edward P. Mulrooney, former chairman of the State Liquor Authority, said yesterday.

A large list of patrons has been formed for the benefit performance of Maxwell Anderson's new play. "High Tor," at the Martin Beck Theatre on the night of Jan. 6. The occasion will be the annual benefit for the New York Kindergarten, which provides a comprehensive welfare program for children from 2 to 5 years old.

A special display of Christmas flowering plants is bringing many visitors to the greenhouses at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Groups of gay poinsettias, begonias and cyclamen, set off by the contrasting white and yellow of Paper-White and Soleil d'Or narcissi, form the most colorful part of the show.

The Young People's concert given by Ernest Schelling and the New York Philarmonic Symphony Orchestra yesterday morning in Carnegie Hall, had a strong flavor of the Christmastide, and it attracted a gathering which in later days will probably toil under the designation of "a large and brilliant audience."

THE history of The New York Tribune in the ninety-six years since Horace Greeley began his modest journalistic venture, is rich in lessons for the newspaper man, and filled with interest alike for those in the profession and for all Americans.

HAVING for a long time considered Robert Benchley the Ten Best Actors in America, we felt last week that it would be rather a new and subtle thing to go over and give Mr. Benchley a friendly boost by treating him to a regular fan interview.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Qualifications and reservations appended to bids under the Walsh-Healey Public Contracts Act are inadmissible, Acting Controller General Elliott ruled today, upholding Secretary Perkins in her interpretations of the scope of the act.

The Department of Agriculture takes time out from being crop-control-conscious to urge our people to be less conscious of the word conscious. It thinks the conscious locution in government bulletins and reports has gone too far.
LLOYD GOODRICH, who for some time has been at work upon a definitive book on Winslow Homer, sends along this request:

The refusal of the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday to extend the emergency rail freight surcharges, which expire on Dec. 31, pending its final adjudication of the petition of the railroads asking for permanently higher rates, resulted in heavy selling of securities in the final thirty minutes of trading.

A daring robbery of at least $1,500 worth of diamond engagement rings was engineered by a novel method by four or more thieves who entered the store of the Busch Jewelry Company at 43 Cortlandt Street, directly opposite the Hudson Terminal, at 1:35 P.M. yesterday.

DEAR Santa Claus: I have been a good boy all year, except for those unfortunate three weeks in Hollywood, and I do not ask much. I realize there are some things even you cannot do -- like putting a lump of coal in Robert Taylor's stocking or a few thistles in Mae West's.
LONDON, Dec. 19. -- The King abdicates, Long Live the King! The new King's horse runs in the Windsor steeplechase. All this within a week, and John Bull is himself again.

WHEN the ubiquitous George S. Kaufman took train for Hollywood last Spring to keep a date with Moss Hart, he was planning to write a play with that gentleman which was not in the least like the somewhat fantastic harlequinade which was unveiled last Monday at the Booth under the title of "You Can't Take It With You."

A woman was killed and forty others were injured in automobile accidents throughout the city between 6 and 11:30 o'clock last night. The rain and its accompanying poor visibility was held responsible for the unusual number of accidents.

With the exception of 1919 and 1920, business failures in the United States for 1936 will be the lowest since 1882, according to estimates here yesterday. Chiefly responsible for the excellent showing is the sharp upturn in business activity this year, coming close to the 1929 level in unit volume.

Everybody apparently wants to help the boys of the Civilian Conservation Corps. Garage and factory owners axe offering them apprentice work. Business men are forming committees to find them regular jobs. And a movement, led by President Roosevelt, is on foot to make the CCC a permanent government service.

Stepping a brilliant 4:34.7 mile, Leslie MacMitchell, George Washington High School star, turned in the best performance of the meet as the De La Salle Institute's indoor interscholastic track and field games were revived at the 102d Engineers Armory in Manhattan last night.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn set aside a decision late Friday afternoon of Supreme Court Justice Paul Bonynge, who in turn had set aside a jury verdict of $65,000 in favor of Frank Gulden of Islip, L.I., who sued the Title Guarantee and Trust Company as trustee of the estate of Charles Gulden Jr.

CARRYING the greatest volume of traffic in the world is the highway system of the United States. The three great factors of vehicle, highway, and operator are entirely separated from each other in control. Problems in highway transportation arise therefore from maladjustment between the capacities of the driver, the car and the highway.

Conditions approaching an industrial boom are in the offing in the opinion of editors of trade publications throughout the country. They report the upward surge in business is broadening through all lines from manufacturing to retailing, and from furniture and food to automobiles and shipbuilding.

IN a setting of natural beauty and tropical charm, National Sports Week will be launched in Havana, Cuba, the day after Christmas, to continue until Jan. 2. In that seven-day span a program of sports events has been planned which is expected to delight thousands of tourists who will be on hand throughout the holidays.

A small dinner and dance were given by Mr. and Mrs. Henry Bradley Plant last night at their home, 684 Park Avenue, to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Amy Capron Plant, who is the eldest granddaughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Morton F. Plant.

The volume of bonds called last week for payment before maturity increased over a week ago, with public-utility corporations leading in the amounts called. A feature of the week was the announcement of several redemptions of Federal Land Bank and Joint Stock Land Bank bonds.

SHORT-WAVE broadcasters in foreign lands will feature Christmas programs this week. For example, every day, the British Broadcasting Corporation has scheduled special concerts, plays, poetry and stories. The highlight, as always, will be a reading of Dickens's "Christmas Dinner at Bob Cratchit's" from "A Christmas Carol."

NANKING, Dec. 19 (AP). -- If Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, now a prisoner at Sian, should die in China's current civil crisis his heir probably would be his second son, 20-year-old Chiang Wei-ko, a student in Berlin.
VATICAN CITY, Dec. 19. -- Children all over the world were asked tonight to pray for Pope Pius.

LONDON, Dec. 19. -- That the present crisis in its various aspects, political, economic and social, is fundamentally a world crisis is nowadays recognized by everybody. But that for a world crisis world remedies must be sought is not so generally recognized.

High school courses on the motion picture as a form of art, started experimentally two years ago, are yielding practical results. Students are gaining increased appreciation of the technical problems of the films and greater discrimination as moviegoers, according to reports from various parts of the country.

OLD Ebenezer Scrooge is surely dead by now -- as dead as Marley, his partner. Therefore the "E. Scrooge, London," who came over in the latest seagoing Zeppelin and signed the register at a midtown Manhattan hotel can hardly have been the crusty old codger whom all lovers of Christmas and readers of Dickens know about. A great-grandnephew, perhaps.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Firemen with matches in their hands and lots of burning to do; that is the assignment for the Winter drawn by a hundred CCC men on icebound Isle Royale.

SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 19. -- Similarity in flares set off by searching pilots and those seen several nights ago in the Kavich Mountains of Eastern Nevada spurred officials tonight to renew an aerial hunt for a missing transport plane in that region.

Marking a new phase in its existence which began twenty years ago in rooms on the top floor of the Vanderbilt Hotel, the Women's City Club opens its doors tomorrow on new quarters with a modern setting in the International Building of Rockefeller Center.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Dec, 19. -- Economic measures under discussion at the Buenos Aires conference, especially those referring to tarriff regulations and standardization of customs procedure, would greatly benefit trade, in the opinion of American business men here.
Mrs. Frank Lovett Harrington and Mr. and Mrs. Karl Beckwith Smith gave a tea dance yesterday at Sherry's for their debutante daughters, Miss Mildred Jean Harrington and Miss Edith Canfield Smith.

A SCHOLARLY study of folklore is brought to us here in the form of a most alluring travel book. To follow in the footsteps of this author and illustrator through Portugal would be a novel and entrancing experience.

THE long Winter evenings invariably inspire renewed armchair speculation as to whether deep-sea divers will ever find the by-now Atlantic-soaked treasure chests that went down with the Titanic or whether Captain William Kidd ever really made away with the large hunk of booty which legend attributes to his potent brand of piracy.

Federal Judge Julian W. Mack rejected yesterday without prejudice a motion by the Securities and Exchange Commission for a preliminary injunction to restrain L.S. Saphier Co. from violating the Securities Acts of 1933 and 1934 in General Bronze Corporation and Park Tilford stock transactions.

WITH the growing interest in Winter sports in the vicinity of Bear Mountain Park, the Commissioners of the Palisades Interstate Park have developed new devices for their enjoyment. One reason why this form of sport has grown in favor so rapidly in the Hudson Highlands is the proximity of this playground area to New York City and the greater ease by which it can be reached by automobile.

The body of Mrs. Elizabeth McGoey, about 35 years old, was found shortly after 8 A.M. yesterday in the living room of an apartment at 125 West Sixtieth Street occupied by Andrew Noonan, an automobile mechanic, who has been under treatment for acute alcoholism at Bellevue Hospital since last Thursday.

Test trains are operating on the Queens extension of the city's Independent Subway System, between Roosevelt Avenue, Jackson Heights and Kew Gardens, the local office of the PWA announced yesterday. The official inspection trip will be made on Wednesday, Dec. 30 and the line will be opened to the public at 7 A.M. on Jan. 1.
Four of the most hectic days of the year are ahead for shoppers and salesgirls -- the last store days before Christmas. It is the shopper's last chance to fill the gaps in the Christmas list.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 19. -- While few persons in Westchester regard it as practical or legal to charge tolls on the county's parkways, the Board of Supervisors on two occasions in recent weeks has requested County Attorney William A. Davidson to give an opinion on the legality of such tolls.

THE significance of a number of unusual exhibitions, current or recently closed, comes in for consideration in the December number of the American Magazine of Art. The editor, F.A. Whiting Jr., arrives at some interesting conclusions on American Art as the result of a careful estimate of the annual exhibition at the Art Institute of Chicago and the Whitney's third biennial.
SEA ISLAND, Ga. -- Throughout the holidays at Sea Island, the program of sports and social entertainments offers varied diversion for hotel guests and members of the island colony.

LONDON, Dec. 19. -- Although spot rubber remained at 9 15-16d a pound here today, still higher prices for the near future are expected. Merchants believe that until additional material is released under the new quotas starting on Jan. 1, which will not arrive here until February, there is little likelihood of alleviation of the scarcity.

The anniversary yesterday of the birth of Dr. Karl Wilhelm Scheele, who was the first to isolate glycerine in 1779, was made the occasion of a tribute to his memory by fourteen American scientific, technical and industrial associations.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 19. -- The Inter-American Conference, having concluded agreements on the political items on its agenda, has turned its attention to economic questions, which means discussion of reduction of trade barriers and restoration of equal opportunity in international trade.

AT the Metropolitan Museum of Art the George C. Stone collection of historical swords goes on exhibition today, awakening interest anew in what is probably the oldest hobby in the world. Sword collecting goes back at least as far as Charlemagne, for as King of the Franks in the year 800 he honored his heroes by displaying their weapons on the walls of the royal chambers.

The police and the District Attorney's office were investigating last night what part, if any, a woman "fence" played in the tragedy of congested streets and abandoned tenement houses, revealed by a 13-year-old boy's confession that three months ago he had killed his 10-year-old chum and kept the guilty secret ever since.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Brig. Gen. David L. Brainard, U.S.A., retired, of Washington, the last survivor of General A.W. Greely's Lady Franklin Bay Arctic expedition of 1881-1884, will be honored on Monday by America's polar explorers, most of whom were not yet born at the time of his polar work more than a half century ago.

Approaching the close of the year, many untoward reactions to the corporate undistributed profits tax become observable. Although conclusive proof of inherent subversive tendencies may not manifest itself until after the measure has been in operation for a time, there are already in evidence, nevertheless, many instances of resort to means of avoiding the surtax which do not in themselves constitute good business practice.

Ambrose Day, the young Columbia alumnus of the Larchmont Y.C. who has cruised everywhere in his black-hulled 29-foot Wheeler Deuces Wild, storms or no storms, as if she were an ocean liner, has been appointed flag lieutenant of the New York Power Squadron by Commander-elect Bertrand H. Perry.

ONCE again the Christmas holidays are here, Tiny Tim's big time and also the theatre's. Since early Fall the producers have been looking forward to this week, playing angles and contracts that their children might be around to take part in the general festivities.

The Pan-American Congress at Buenos Aires has nearly completed its work and is expected to adjourn this week. It will go into the historical record as one of the most successful international congresses ever held. This is not alone because of the importance of the subjects discussed or the value of the results attained.

The stir in the horticultural world caused by the recent "hearings" in Washington -- before the Federal Plant Quarantine Board, which had under consideration a proposal to extend the present restrictions on daffodil bulbs to practically all other classes -- lends interest to the origin of the many species of bulbous plants which are used in American gardens.

THE world's oldest Christmas trees stand within her youngest State, the nascent Republic of Lebanon, authorized by a recent Franco-Lebanese treaty. An abrupt 6,000 feet above the Mediterranean, on a shelflike plateau, the impressive little colony of 400 trees stands "next of kin" to the giants whose excellency was extolled by Isaiah.

THIS is a book of true adventure stories, told at the Explorers Club by the men who were the heroes of the exploits, or who saw the exciting events, or had first-hand knowledge of the hair-raising experiences.
SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., Dec. 19. -- Three semi-final round berths were filled today in the Sleepy Hollow Country Club's invitation squash racquets mixed-doubles tournament.

The Budapest University Chorus, an organization dating back to 1702, will arrive here for a concert tour on Jan. 6. The chorus, composed of forty-two male voices, is under the direction of Viktor Vaszy, conductor of the Budapest Philharmonic Orchestra, and is scheduled to give a concert at Carnegie Hall on Jan. 16.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 19. -- Rutgers' high-scoring basketball team earned its fourth straight victory before 2,500 tonight, defeating Princeton, 44 to 35, in a hard-fought game, the result of which was in doubt until the last four minutes.
MADRID, Dec. 19. -- The Insurgents continued today to bring pressure to bear on Madrid from the northeast and northwest.

Industry and trade are now the most active since 1929. Reports of a shortage of skilled labor are being increasingly heard. The rising tide of dividends, inflated it is true by the new tax law, exceeds anything seen in a very long time. We are even on the verge of an old-fashioned boom, according to the talk in some quarters.

The First Division polo team opened its season in the Metropolitan Indoor League by defeating Squadron C at the Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn last night. A small but enthusiastic gathering saw the riders from Fort Hamilton stage a five-goal spurt in the final period to register a 14-to-9 1/2 triumph over the home trio.

" Game Scarcity -- Its Causes and Cures" was the subject of a recent talk before a group of sportsmen by Gardiner Bump, enterprising young superintendent of the Bureau of Game of the New York State Conservation Department.
A REMARKABLE father and son combination are the Braggs. The elder is Sir William Bragg, one of England's foremost scientists. The son is William Lawrence Bragg, who usually signs himself W.L. Bragg.
DETROIT, Dec. 19. -- Strike paralysis halted more auxiliaries of the automobile industry today, leaving about 27,000 workers idle.

the prices of woolen piece goods for the women's wear trade are 10 to 25 per cent higher than they were a year ago, according to a survey conducted among leading fabric houses by the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers and released yesterday.

Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx revealed yesterday that two months ago he suggested that the Charles M. Schwab residence on Riverside Drive be presented to the city by Mr. Schwab as an official residence for the Mayor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Declaring that employment in consumers' goods industries already equals the level of 1919 and that workers engaged in producing durable goods are increasing in number markedly each month, the Chamber of Commerce of the United States concluded in its Washington review, published today, that further expansion in employment "will depend very directly upon finding new employes."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Placements of workers in private employment by the United States Employment Service during November were double the volume made in the corresponding months of 1935 and 1934, while placements on relief projects last month were at the lowest level since June, 1935, Secretary Perkins announced today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Reports of the majority and the minority of the Interstate Commerce Commission relative to the continuation of the emergency freight charges were as follows:

As one of the events celebrating its fiftieth anniversary season, the Rubinstein Club will give a concert tomorrow which will be outstanding in the group's musical history. The program, presenting both guest artists and the club's chorus of women's voices, will be held in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria at 8:30 P.M.

Mrs. Busch Greenough will give a reception tomorrow afternoon for members of the various committees aiding in the sale of boxes and seats for the special performance of "Tristan und Isolde" the afternoon of Jan. 20 at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over to raise funds for Sir Wilfred Grenfell's Mission in Labrador and Newfoundland.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 19. -- Palan, sleek son of Prince Pal, beat fourteen other 2-year-olds in a stirring stretch drive to win the Pass Christian $1,500 added feature handicap at the Fair Grounds today.
