HERE was Hollywood's Herman J. Mankiewicz last week, treading again what he used to call the hot Broadway sands, and with him was a play. To get the matter right to the breakfast table, the play is "The Meal Ticket," and the Messrs.

A duplicate marriage ceremony performed yesterday afternoon in the home of Professor John Dewey of Columbia, 320 East Seventy-second Street, following an unusual "contract marriage" on the previous afternoon in the County Court House before Supreme Court Justice Rosenman, gave the "occasion some social significance to us and to our friends," said Mrs. Rudolph F. Mallina, the bride.

VIENNA, Dec. 19. -- Reports that Richard Strauss, after a long absence from Vienna, might return within the next few months to conduct performances of his works at the State Opera and the Philharmonic, filled the press here this week.

Kid Chocolate, the little Cuban who was world champion a few years ago, pressed his comeback campaign through its second stage last night at the Rockland Palace by outpointing Johnny Erickson, veteran Harlem lightweight.

ERSKINE CALDWELL has had a curious literary career, and the obscure record of his publications will tantalize and delight the collectors, for whom this handsome volume is obviously designed. His early work was privately printed, and his first short stories appeared in such out of the way and now extinct little magazines as Clay, Contact, Contempo.

Alfredo Salmaggi continued his operatic productions yesterday afternoon at the Hippodrome with a performance of Verdi's "La Traviata." The evening production, "Faust," was witnessed by a large and responsive audience.

ENZESFELD, Austria, Dec. 19 (AP). -- Tomorrow is the day for the annual Christmas party for village children, given by the Duke of Windsor's host and hostess. Baron and Baroness Eugene de Rothschild, Edward may go. He may also pose for motion picture photographers, he indicated.

Corporation Counsel Paul Windels issued a second statement yesterday, assailing the Public Service Commission for permitting the merger of gas and electric companies controlled by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York into the parent corporation.

Paul G. Waner, star outfielder of the Pirates for more than a decade, came back as the batting champion in the National League for 1936 with a mark of .373, according to the official averages released for publication today.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Dec. 19. -- President C.C. Williams of Lehigh University sees a "shift of students' interests to the right" as a result of recent extra-curricular trends on the Lehigh campus.

MOSCOW, Dec. 19. -- Marshal Chang's revolt and capture of Chiang Kai-shek are here seen not as the pro-Soviet anti-Japanese manoeuvre they are represented as being, but as new Japanese tricks to weaken China, and as the first fruit of the German-Japanese anti-Communist agreement which everyone here believes masks a military accord against the Soviet.

ITHACA, Dec. 19 (AP). -- Nearly 35,000 New York State farmers will receive payments for cooperation with the national agricultural conservation program in 1936. C.G. Bradt, State executive officer, said today. He added that the payments would be virtually completed before Jan. 1.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Against a pictorial background of palm-bordered avenues, curving beaches and a cobalt sea. Palm Beach will celebrate Christmas with all the time-honored gestures. For family dinners and more formal entertainments, for which numerous plans are now in progress, tables will be placed in patios and gardens bordered with poinsettias and other brilliant tropical blooms.
The kidnapping of Chiang Kai-shek -- dictator over nearly twice as many people as Stalin, Hitler and Mussolini combined -- has provided a new climax for one of the great dramas of history.

Dr. James Weldon Johnson will address the meeting tomorrow night of the Parent-Teachers' Association of Junior High School 136, Manhattan, In the school auditorium, Edgecombe Avenue and 135th Street. Dr. Johnson is giving a course of lectures on the Afro-American as one of the many groups in this country that have had a part in modifying the original English pattern.

BUFFALO, Dec. 19 (AP). -- A 19-year-old youth who, according to Detective George W. Beyers, kept a book account of his collections through a "hex racket" in which he posed as a monastery representative, was held today on a charge of extortion.

AT fall of life, as at fall of day, malignant imps come out from secret lairs to torment the humans. One, imaginatively referred to in popular parlance as le demon du soir (the imp of the dusk), waylays aging men, blows at them its burning breath and drives them mad with belated love.

Resurgent hope for ratification of the Child Labor Amendment by the State Legislature at the forthcoming session at Albany has inspired a merger of women's organizations that have long and consistently pressed for adoption of the measure.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 19. -- Engineers can remember the varied symbols of chemistry and calculus, but they have their difficulties with the English language, according to revelations at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Dec. 19 (AP). -- Illinois's razzle-dazzle basketball offense, paced by sophomores Louis Boudreau and Tom Nesbit, was too much for Notre Dame tonight. Seven thousand fans watched the Ilini achieve a 44-to-29 victory over the Ramblers.

Lost in the storm of mixed rain and snow that covered the Atlantic Seaboard States last night, an Eastern Air Lines plane from Miami, with eleven persons aboard, made a forced landing last night on a mountainside seven miles northwest of Port Jervis, N.Y.

The annual report of Robert Fechner, director of the Civilian Conservation Corps program, urged last week that the program be continued as long as the nation had willing but jobless young men to take care of. There was plenty of conservation work on public lands, he said, to keep busy a permanent enrollment of 300,000.

Hunter College will celebrate the holiday season this week. It was announced yesterday by Janet Mears, president of the Student Self-Government Association, that activities will include parties, plays, a luncheon and a Yule log ceremony.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- Everything is in readiness for Winter sports in the Poconos during the Christmas holidays and preparations have been made for the accommodation of hundreds of visitors. All of the large resorts remaining open during the Winter months have included among their special programs arrangements for children's parties.

The final surge of Christmas buying pushed retail sales figures last week to the highest levels in several years in most districts of the country, although in some sections the volume of buying was under merchants' earlier estimates. In some cities figures rose as high as 35 per cent above the totals for the corresponding period last year.

FLORHAM PARK, N.J., Dec. 19. -- With high hopes and their bows and arrows, George W. Jacobs and Franklin L. Davis led a safari today into the neighboring woods, where once the noble redskin stalked his game. Their immediate aim was the wary deer, but their ultimate objective was to prove a point to the New Jersey Legislature.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 19. -- At ceremonies attended by thousands Morrison Field, Palm Beach County's new airport, constructed by the government at the afternoon.

Twenty-six out of thirty-seven merchandise divisions of local department stores had gains in advertising linage during November, according to the "breakdown" issued yesterday by Media Records. Total department store linage for the month in this city was 3,919,133, against 3,317,803 in November a year ago.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- A varied sports program has been arranged by the Municipal Convention Hall management for the entertainment of visitors here during the Christmas and New Year's Day holidays.

" In a strange land" -- the phrase appears in more than one of the stories of the Hundred Neediest. Typically, a breadwinner has come from another country, leaving his loved ones behind to wait until he can make a home for them here. He gains a foothold, usually through effort and self-denial that only pioneers know, and at last the family is reunited in the new land.
RYE, N. Y., Dec. 19. -- Members of the younger set home from schools and colleges for the Christmas holidays are being feted this week throughout Westchester.

Thirty-seven gunners took part in the annual Christmas turkey shoot over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. The high-over-all victor was C.W. Phellis, who broke 95 out of 100 targets.

MUCH has been said of the futility of liberalism. Hedged in between their rowdy neighbors to the left and to the right the liberals seem to pay for their generous view of both sides by being altogether annihilated.

WINTER-BOUND tennis enthusiasts, irked by the steam-heated atmosphere of indoor courts, are turning to paddle tennis, the speedy outdoor racquet innovation which thrives in subfreezing weather and snow and ice surroundings.

The Thomas Alva Edison Foundation has selected the firm of Massena duPont of Wilmington, Del., to design the $100,000 Edison Memorial Beacon Tower on the site of the inventor's original laboratory at Menlo Park, N.J.
CHICAGO, Dec. 18. -- High school students in Chicago may not write on the question: "Should Chicago Adopt a City Manager Form of Government?"

AUGUSTA, Me., Dec. 19 (AP). -- The Maine Legislature killed late today an appropriation bill financing old-age pensions by a 10 per cent retail liquor sales tax, the House sustaning Governor Brann's veto of the measure.

PLANS to open to the public 7,500 square miles adjoining Boulder Dam are being worked out by the National Park Service in cooperation with the Secretary of the Interior. The program, calling for the utilization of the entire tract, includes road building and the construction of camps, lodges, recreation fields and scenic lookouts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Employe representatives of steel workers in plants from Cleveland to the Atlantic Coast will meet tomorrow in Pittsburgh, with leaders confident of passing resolutions condemning the "company union" plan under which they function and endorsing the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers, an affiliate of the Committee for Industrial Organization.

WARSAW, Dec. 19. -- The omission of mention of Czechoslovakia from Foreign Minister Josef Beck's review of foreign relations yesterday aroused much comment in the press today. Colonel Beck spoke warmly of other neighbors.

A CZAR SPEAKS: Ever since 1922, when he resigned from President Harding's Cabinet to become head of the Motion Picture Producers and Distrib utors of America, Inc., Will H. Hays has been known as the "czar of the movies."

WITH "Return to Malaya" Bruce Lockhart continues to mine with considerable success the same rich vein which he uncovered in "British Agent" and exploited in "Retreat from Glory." Mr. Lockhart has a formula which is entirely his own -- a formula comparable with the judicious mixtures of bitter, strong and mellow that make the perfect pipe tobacco.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 19 (AP). -- America's thirteen leading symphony orchestras, in their first consolidated financial statement, have disclosed an annual combined budget of $4,346,500, an average of $334,346.
NORTHFIELD, Minn., Dec. 19 (AP) -- A visible "appulse" of the moon, a celestial sight that comes only about a dozen times in a century, is predicted for Sunday evening, Dec. 27.

TORONTO, Dec. 19. -- The greatest year in the history of the Canadian mining industry is drawing to a close. The amounts of wealth produced, of dividends earned and distributed and of labor employed have broken all previous records. Expansion, exploration and new development set a pace without precedent in 1936.

Efforts to cut materially the WPA rolls in this city through the elimination of "non-essential, non-relief cases" received another setback yesterday when the Emergency Relief Bureau reported that investigation of the relief status of 4,750 dismissed WPA workers had shown that 3,400, or 71 per cent, were eligible for reinstatement on WPA.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 19. -- The Ryerson House on Ringwood Manor in northern Passaic County, rich in historic background, has been deeded to the State of New Jersey for a historical shrine by Erskine Hewitt, New York City financier and collector of Americana.

DUBLIN, Dec. 19. -- The abdication of King Edward afforded President Eamon de Valera a unique opportunity to get rid of the British Crown in Irish affairs, not by the truculent method of unilateral denunciation, but merely by refusing legislation making the change in the monarchy effective in the Irish Free State.

The mid-December week is usually one of declining security prices, and last week proved to be no exception to the experience of recent years. THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks was off 2.85 points on the week, of which 2.31 points were lost yesterday.

New Jersey schools had the edge over their New York City rivals in the interscholastic basketball program, which opened Madison Square Garden's season yesterday, afternoon, with two victories in the three interstate games played.

A new element of confusion has been introduced into business by the United States Supreme Court's ruling upholding the fair trade practice laws of Illinois and California, Israel B. Oseas, former special assistant to the United States Attorney General in antitrust cases, asserted here yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 19. -- J. Spencer Smith, chairman of the New Jersey State Board of Commerce and Navigation, stated today that the board would soon draw up a statement for the United States Beach Erosion Board to give the reasons why there was a Federal interest in the State's beaches and why Federal funds should be spent to help save them from damage or destruction by erosion.

New York City's system of free colleges, largest in the world, is on the threshold of further development. The establishment of a new college in Queens and major improvements to all three existing municipal institutions are sought by the Board of Higher Education for next year.

The vaunted Green Bay Packers, champions of the National Football League, dominated the all-star team picked by the coaches of the professional circuit Four Packer stars were given first-team recognition, while two others were named for berths on the second mythical eleven.
PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Dec. 19. -- Three Westchester debutantes will be introduced to society next Saturday and another will be presented on Tuesday.

LAKE GEORGE. -- The foundations for the new ski tow which will be built during the next three weeks on the face of Mount Cobble, just outside Lake George Village, are now being laid. This tow will be more than 2,100 feet long and will feature an endless steel cable with T-bars every thirty feet, which will push skiers to the top of the open slope.

THERE is every indication that 1937 will bring new and wider programs in many States for lighting the path of the motorist and the pedestrian at night -- a phase of highway improvement that has lagged far behind other safety efforts.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 19. -- Students of New Jersey College for Women began their Christmas recess today after holding a Yule Log Ceremony. Christmas dinner and formal dances last night. The festivities began with the Log Ceremony in the Elizabeth Rodman Voorhees Chapel, which was followed by outdoor carol singing and the Christmas dinner.

Art-calendar salesmen, who have just held a convention here, talked over what the New Year might hold for them. But the New Year they had in mind was not 1937, toward which the rest of us turn hopeful eyes.

The surprise team of the National Hockey League, the Canadiens of Montreal, will be seen in action at Madison Square Garden tonight. The Habitants, who have been steaming along at the head of the procession in the International Group of the League, will oppose the New York Rangers, occupants of the lead position in the American Division.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP). -- New York State filed today in the Supreme Court a memorandum in opposition to a rehearing of arguments on the State's Unemployment Insurance Law, upheld recently by the court on a 4-to-4 decision.

The grand jury will begin an investigation at 10 o'clock tomorrow morning to determine if the fire in the rooming house at 273 West Seventy-third Street, Friday morning, which resulted in the deaths of four adults and a six-weeks old baby, was due to criminal negligence.

It is a singular thing, putting it mildly, to find nothing about Christmas in an anthology from McGuffey's Readers. One hundred and fifty selections from the famous series, First Reader to Sixth, have been brought together.

Speed limits on all parkways under his jurisdiction will be reduced in an attempt to curtail the number of highway deaths, Park Commissioner Moses announced yesterday in a letter to Borough President Harvey of Queens. He requested patience on the part of city officials and more careful driving by every one using the parkways.

The second oldest night school in the United States, the New York Evening High School, situated at Tenth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, is celebrating its seventieth anniversary. The school was founded on Oct. 1, 1866, to provide opportunity to complete their education for boys returning from the Civil War.

THE opening of the Metropolitan Opera, the most glamorous of first nights, is enhanced this year by the quickening of the nation's economic pulse. For the Metropolitan is not only a citadel of music; it is the stronghold of wealth and position, while its audiences reflect the mood of the people.

The evening Yuletide celebration to be held under the auspices of the Federal Music Project, Thursday night from 6:30 to 8 o'clock, will open with addresses by Mayor La Guardia, Borough President Levy and Nicolai Sokoloff, national director of the project, who will speak from the third-floor balcony of the Hotel Astor during a ten-minute period starting at 7 P.M.

ROME. FIRST salient item of the Rome season: an absolute novelty by Lorenzo Perosi -- a so-called "Gregorian Mass," performed in the Sistine Chapel in the presence of the Pope, and under the composer's direction, at a memorial service for the Cardinals who have passed this year.

UTICA, Dec. 19. -- Central New York is suffering from an invasion of gray foxes, according to sportsmen. At a meeting of the Oneida County Federation of Sportsmen's Clubs a proposal was advanced this week to urge the State to offer a bounty on the foxes to conserve pheasants, ruffed grouse, cotton-tail rabbits and other game.

The Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Company, relying on its strongly intrenched company union, manifested little concern last night as 635 bus drivers pressed plans for a strike which they insisted could be extended to paralyze the entire B.M.T. system.
The striking seamen and their employers took their fifty-one-day disagreement to the American people in their first nation-wide broadcast yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 20. -- Displaying one of the best attacks ever put on by a Crimson five, Harvard's basketball team trounced Cornell 54 to 40 tonight. The victory was the first for the Cambridge team in two starts in the Eastern Intercollegiate League.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 19 -- Mrs. Emil Denemark again was represented by the winner in the feature race at Tropical Park today when her 3-year-old filly Two Bob just got up in time to take a nose decision from Mrs. C.H. Hainsworth's Blackbirder in the Royal Palm Handicap of a mile and a sixteenth.
MADRID, Dec. 19. -- It was five months yesterday since the Spanish civil war began -- months of terror, bloodshed, heroism and cruelty.
Honors continue to pile up for Yale's loquacious Lawrence Morgan Kelley.

Raymond Bernstein's set shot midway in the three-minute overtime period broke a 22-22 deadlock and enabled the Montauk Junior High School of Brooklyn to beat Junior High School 40 of Queens, 24 -- 22, in the final round game for the city P.S.A.L. junior high school basketball championship at the Textile High School court yesterday.

NOW that Maya and Mexican archaeology have made their way into the luridly colored Sunday comic strips and into the gaudy announcements of tobacconists we may expect a great increase of popular interest in this field of historical investigation and, concurrently, we may expect an even greater increase of popular misinformation with regard to the subject.
New York's World Fair of 1939 will be the greatest and most successful if the business Interests of New York "get behind it immediately," former Governor Alfred E. Smith declared yesterday.

The election last week of William S. Murray of Utica, chemical engineer and research man, as chairman of the Republican State Committee has not, broadly speaking, involved any vital change of control in the Republican State organization.

BOSTON, Dec. 19. -- Reports from leading centers in New England, covering not only retail trade but manufacturing activity, indicate the recent high level is being fully maintained. Department store sales in the principal New England cities are running 10 to 15 per cent ahead of a year ago.

RICHARD SMEATON WHITE, proprietor and publisher of The Montreal Gazette, who died last week, inherited and memorably added to a fine tradition. His uncle, THOMAS, and his father, RICHARD, bought The Gazette in 1870. They found it anemic and poor.

CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 19 (AP). -- The New Hampshire State Ballot Law Commission today ordered a second recount of the vote given in the First Congressional District to Arthur B. Jenks, Republican, and Alphonse Roy, Democrat.

Members of the Society for Stability in Money and Banking, Inc., ending a two-day session of the National Economic Forum in the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday, voted in favor of asking Congress to appoint a nonpartisan, expert commission on banking to consolidate and codify existing banking law and to propose new legislation to strengthen the banking system, as well as to close, so far as reasonably possible, all existing channels of inflation.

Steamship agents in New York said yesterday that while about 4,000 third-class passengers had left last week to spend the Christmas holidays in Europe, that was barely a fourth of the number that left this port twenty-five years ago for the holiday season.

With poultry prices down and vegetables and fruits of the season generally not high, the Christmas dinner will cost considerably less than in 1935, the Consumers' Service of the New York Department of Public Markets predicts.

Four members of the women's American Olympic team and several metropolitan titleholders will compete in the first of the series of A.A.U. indoor swimming meets to be staged by the Women's Swimming Association in the home pool this afternoon, while another former Olympic champion, Mrs. Eleanor Holm Jarrett, will be on hand to cheer for her W.S.A. mates.

RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 19. -- Four guests, one of whom was Anna Van Sauter, retired opera singer, were carried down ladders to safety early today when fire destroyed the century-old Globe Hotel, a rambling, three-story landmark on the banks of the Shrewsbury River.

Columbia's basketball team won its third game of the season last night by defeating Williams, 40-28, in the Morningside Heights gymnasium. The Lions were a vastly improved team in the second half and pulled away from the Purple after leading by only 15 to 11 at intermission.

I read Mr. Davis's letter on the "American Background" with considerable interest. If the situation were not so discouragingly pathetic it would be very funny. The Philharmonic has probably played less contemporary music than any major orchestra in the whole history of music.

Mrs. Vincent Astor is chairman and Mrs. Elbridge Gerry Chadwick and Mrs. John Garrett vice chairmen of the group in charge of the arrangements for the dinner to be given on Jan. 3 at the Waldorf-Astoria for Miss Lucrezia Bori, for many years a prominent member of the Metropolitan Opera Company, in recognition of her contributions to the cause of music in New York.

A stench bomb, dropped in the Comedy Theatre in Forty-first Street, east of Broadway, last night just as the curtain was rising on the premiere of "Black Rhythm," a Negro musical comedy, caused the performance to be halted while the theatre was aired.

Contributing a personal check for $50, Lord Marley, Deputy Speaker in the British House of Lords, conducted an appeal for funds at a dinner in his honor last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania that resulted in raising $3,000 for an ambulance to be sent to the Loyalist government in Spain.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Dec. 19. -- Students at the Pennsylvania State College marked this week the close of the first decade of the administration of President Ralph D. Hetzel.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 19. -- College sororities are being weighed in the balance of campus values at the College for Women, University of Rochester, with a view to their possible abolition.

WITH the building up of flying hours, statistics and case histories on the part of transport pilots, the medical profession has added one more to their list of human ills -- aeroneurosis. While the material is still scanty as compared to the knowledge amassed on other ills under the general classification of occupational diseases, enough is known to let physicians reach certain pretty definite conclusions.

The Boston Museum of Fine Arts reports the largest total attendance in its history for a special exhibition, 110,387. This number of visitors was recorded for the exhibition of art treasures from Japan. Although numerically the attendance at the Japanese exhibition was the largest recorded, it tares third place when considered in relation to the total number of days.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 19. -- The Rutgers University Extension Division will offer five courses in social welfare work in Newark during the second semester, Norman C. Miller, director of the division, announced today.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 19. -- With the weather man playing a popular role by sending down a timely snowfall, the pioneer Winter sports region in the heart of the Adirondacks officially launched the 1936-37 season today in a perfect setting.

PARIS, Dec. 19 (AP). -- France's famed headsman, Anatole Deibler, hereditary executioner for the Third Republic, announced his intention today to retire after presiding at the guillotine for half a century.

MONTREAL, Dec. 19. -- The Montreal Canadiens, paced by their veterans, raced to a 4-2 overtime victory tonight against the New York Rangers to take a firm hold on the top spot in the international group of the National Hockey League.

Now that the excitement of the campaign has about subsided, we may consider temperately the weaknesses of political democracy, and some possible remedies. Democracy, being a human institution, is not and never will be perfect, but it is sufficiently better than any of its contemporary rivals to make its supporters anxious to strengthen and preserve it against both internal weaknesses and attacks from without.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 19. -- Indicating to what an extent shipping trade has been throttled by the labor dispute on the Pacific Coast, figures compiled by the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce reveal that only 192 ships arrived at this port in November, compared to 506 in the same period of last year.

Mail orders received in the wholesale market here last week were chiefly fill-in requisitions and lastminute "rush" requests for holidaytype goods, according to a special report prepared for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. The report continues:

LINER'S FUTURE: Since 1934 the Leviathan, formerly the German liner Vaterland, later flagship of the United States Lines, has been idle at Hoboken, N.J., but under the terms of a government mortgage it has been kept in good repair. Once the world's largest passenger ship, it cannot compete with the big liners of today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19. -- An attack upon the "company town," which he called the chief symbol of "economic serfdom," was voiced by Governor George H. Earle in a radio speech tonight as he prepared to leave for the bootleg coal situation.

PARIS. A NEW and glamorous girl will emerge next Spring from her wrappings of fur and velvet. Beruffled and frilled, she will be as fresh as a field flower. Yet, in her flower-like appearance there will be sophistication rather than naivete; the couturier, in the role of fashionable florist, will see to that.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 19. -- Melodies which grew from the colorful life of early America on the plantations of the South, in Yankee villages and towns, and from wartime days in the Colonies have been brought back from the past in a series of fifty old American songs assembled and reproduced from the originals in the Harris collection of American poetry and plays at Brown University.

Positions for college-trained men and women will be more numerous in 1937 than at any time since the boom years of the late Nineteen Twenties, Robert F. Moore, secretary of appointments of Columbia University, declares in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Muray Butler, president of the University. made public yesterday.

EARLY in 1935 Professor G. Domagk, chemotherapist of the German chemical trust, startled the medical world with the announcement that he had discovered a chemical which kept mice alive after they had been inoculated with streptococci -- deadly germs strung in chains.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (AP). -- The Union party, in its first national conference today, reaffirmed its belief in the principles on which it campaigned this year and decided to continue on the same lines until 1940.
HERSHEY, Pa., Dec. 19. -- The new and magnificent Hershey Hockey Arena officially was opened tonight amid ceremonies adequately befitting, with a capacity house looking on.

THE special Christmas books number of The Times Literary Supplement naturally devotes much space to books for boys and girls. It not only reviews scores, if not hundreds, of publications in this class, but makes some interesting generalizations.

An afternoon reception was given by Mr. and Mrs. George Estabrook Brown yesterday at their home, 1,172 Park Avenue, to introduce their daughter. Miss Miriam Harriett Brown, to older friends of the family.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- A summary of reports of transactions effected in October by officers, directors and principal stockholders of corporations with equity securities registered on a national securities exchange showed the common stock holdings of the new Atlas Corporation by its officers and directors.

PARIS, Dec. 19. -- During the last six months and especially since the franc was devalued, there has been steady evidence of economic recovery in France. There has been a considerable increase in the number of loaded freight cars on the railroads, there has been a diminution of unemployment, and there has been a fairly steep increase in wholesale prices.
Plans to clear up the congested calendars of the Courts of Special Sessions throughout the city, which are now from six to twelve months behind, were announced yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Dec. 19 (AP). -- Robert E. Harlow, dismissed tournament manager for the Professional Golfers Association, said today he would ask touring professionals to participate only in those contests arranged by him until he had been given an opportunity to "defend myself" before the P.G.A. executive committee.

Dr. George Kojac, who won the 1928 Olympic backstroke title, last night captured the senior metropolitan A.A.U. 500-yard free style crown in the opening swimming meet of the season at the Brooklyn Central Y.M.C.A.

AMONG the new regulations adopted last week by the New York Board of Aldermen to improve traffic conditions in New York City -- greatest traffic center in the world -- is one that prohibits vehicles from making right-hand turns against red lights except at certain intersections.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 19. -- Judge Walter B. Jones of the Montgomery Circuit Court ruled in effect today that the depression was over.

Scribner's Magazine, which will celebrate its fiftieth anniversary with the forthcoming January issue, anticipated that event a few days with a radio cocktail party yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel at which many of its noted contributors broadcast.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Christmas songs and children's toys will be the contribution of the Works Progress Administration to the holiday season.

Illegal charges of $5,403,520 were made against the United States Government and private ship owners by the Morse Dry Dock and Repair Company of Brooklyn during 1916, 1917 and 1918, it was disclosed yesterday when a decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn became known.

The general science department of New York University's School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance is conducting a series of experiments in an effort to determine whether there is any scientific basis in the belief that extrasensory perception exists.

Brooklyn Prep registered its second victory in as many tournament starts by defeating Poly Prep, 1 to 0, in the first game of the Private Schools Ice Hockey League double-header at the Brooklyn Ice Palace yesterday. By triumphing, the Blue and White skaters are first in the standings.
ADVANCING man must make use of natural resources. He destroys them. He can conserve or restore them if he "wills to do so."

With rising prices and tighter merchandise deliveries expected to bring record arrivals of buyers into the wholesale markets here next month, retail buying budgets for the first three months of 1937 will show an average increase of 10 per cent over the present year. according to estimates yesterday in merchandising circles here.

A number off fine points of customs procedure are to be decided on Tuesday when the French liner Champlain docks here with a cargo she has twice carried to this port. On the first trip the boat was forced to sail without unloading because American longshoremen, resenting the refusal of French dock workers to unload American boats, declined to touch the Champlain's cargo.
SHANGHAI, Dec. 19. -- Nanking officials realize, since Japan's warnings, that they will not be permitted to enter an accord that will make it appear they favor war against Japan.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 19. -- Fewer Princeton University undergraduates applied for student employment aid last year than the year before but the total earnings increased by more than $5,000, the annual report of Richard W. Warfield, '30, director of the bureau of appointments and student employment, revealed today.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Dec. 19. -- The closing session in the semi-annual convention of the New Jersey Building and Loan League was thrown into an uproad tonight by a motion that the 1,000 delegates give a vote of confidence to Carl K. Withers, State Commissioner of Banking and Insurance.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art recently has received official notice that under the designated Project 165-97-6081, the WPA would continue to supply "white-collar" workers for the next twelve months.

After one of the most stubborn contests waged in a long time among the junior riders, Miss Marcia F. Murray of Southampton, L.I., yesterday received the blue ribbon and the medal of the American Horse Show Association in the horsemanship class for the junior members of that organization in the Winter exhibition at the Teevan Riding Academy, Brooklyn.

Casting for the "Colony House Capers" will take place on the night of Dec. 30 at the Hotel Hossert, Brooklyn. Members of the Senior and Junior Guilds of Colony House and their husbands and friends will try out for parts in the revue which will be presented on Jan. 22 and 23 at the ]Rrooklyn I Academy of Music for the benefit! of Colony House, 297 Dean Street, i Brooklyn.

TOKYO, Dec. 19. -- When Chang Hsueh-liang kidnapped Chiang Kai-shek, the dictator of China, last week, he was saving the national Cabinet of Japan. Hopes had sunk so low the night before this coup in Sian became known that an important private gathering in Tokyo had been told that the Cabinet was already going down the rapids. The next morning's headlines changed the whole atmosphere.

MOSCOW, Dec. 19 (AP). -- A renewed Japanese effort to get Russia's signature on a new Russo-Japanese Fisheries Convention was made today without success. Mamoru Shigemitsu, Japanese Ambassador to Russia, called on Maxim M. Litvinoff, Commisar of Foreign Affairs, and declared he was instructed to urge signing of the convention.
The Alumnae Association of St. Joseph's College will hold a supper dance on Dec. 29 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Miss Ann McCormack is honorary chairman.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19. -- Although much depends on the four days before Christmas, it seems probable that holiday trade this year will average 15 per cent above 1935. Some of the large department stores are showing gains of better than 20 per cent, while with others the increase is much lower.

The sailing of the Cunard White Star liner Laconia yesterday for Glasgow, Belfast and Liverpool was delayed four hours through the ship not arriving until late Thursday night and having to discharge 43,000 cases of Scotch whisky, in addition to loading 1,700 tons of freight for Liverpool. She left at 4 P.M.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 19. -- As an interesting development in the march of science in the last half-century, Harvard University today finds that some of its most important advances in astronomy are the independent contributions of women.

ALBANY, Dec. 19. -- In an unprecedented meeting, described as "entirely harmonious," Republican Senators agreed unanimously today upon Senator Perley A. Pitcher of Watertown as their leader in New York's Democratic-controlled Senate for the next two years.

The first intra-university debate in the history of Fordham University will take place tomorrow afternoon in Keating Hall on the Fordham College campus when representatives of Fordham College and Fordham College. Manhattan Division, debate the proposition "Resolved;

THE present season, unusually prolific of interesting exhibitions of work in black-and-white, added another to the list of current attractions last week. This was the tenth annual showing of the American Print Makers, being held this year at the Midtown Galleries (until Christmas).

Anna Falasca, a New York soprano of Italian-American parentage, made her debut in a recital at Town Hall last night. The young newcomer, who received her musical education here, came forward in a difficult and comprehensive list which would have taxed the resources of the most expert conveyors of song.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Dec. 19. -- These additional nominees of candidates for Rhodes Scholarships to Oxford University were reported tonight to the office of Frank Aydelotte, president of Swarthmore College and American secretary to the Rhodes Trustees:

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Dec. 19. -- Economics and sociology students at Mount Holyoke College will make their annual visit to factories, social agencies or institutions and the New York Stock Exchange during the Christmas holidays and will record their observations in papers to be presented to their professors next month.

The establishment of a Department of Research and Service Bureau for Adult Education at New York University was announced yesterday by Dean Ned H. Dearborn of the university's Division of General Education.

LONDON, Dec. 19. -- Although the dates for the royal courts next year have not yet been announced, the Lord Chamberlain will open the list of applications on Feb. 1 and a record number of presentations is expected.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Dec. 20. -- The Nanking Government's attack on the outskirts of Sian is scheduled to be resumed at dawn today by infantry, artillery and airplane bombers, according to a formal order issued at Nanking at 6 P.M. yesterday, when the three-day truce expired without the release of General Chiang Kai-shek by General Chang Hsueh-liang.
William F. Carey, Sanitation Commissioner, and his aides carefully checked their snow removal plans yesterday, confident that they would be able to cope with any storm.

" Boxing Day," as Dec. 26 is known in England, in that country is almost as important as Christmas Day, and is a calendar-marked holiday every year, not just when Christmas comes at a week-end. Its origin antedates Christmas, being traced to the Roman custom of giving and receiving presents during the Saturnalia.

We are rapidly becoming a nation on wheels. Today hundreds of thousands of families have packed their possessions into traveling houses, said goodbye to their friends and taken to the open roads. The auto has made a further raid upon the American home by adding the trailer.

NANKING, Sunday, Dec. 20. -- Although the government officially declares it is determined that the attack against General Chang Hsueh-liang's armies shall be begun this morning, military advisers here reveal that measures have been taken to prolong the truce several days more to avoid embarrassing T.V. Soong, who is expected to fly to Sian from Loyang today.

AS soon as the laughter had subsided at the Booth Theatre on Monday evening and the audience had started to go home in a cheerful frame of mind the neighborhood intellectual began carping. After a droll and hilarious evening he is a dismal fellow to see.

The way to renewal of litigation to recover the full gold value of Austrian Government bonds was opened yesterday through a decision of the Appellate Division of the New York Supreme Court. The court affirmed two lower court orders permitting the filing of an amended complaint against Nelson D. Jay of New York and Paris, one of the three trustees for the Austrian Government guaranteed 1923-43 7 per cent sinking fund gold bonds.
Further Federal legislation to insure greater freedom of the air is recommended in a study of radio censorship published yesterday by the American Civil Liberties Union.

DR. SCHAFER'S carefully documented "The Social History of American Agriculture" is an impressive recital of the contribution of the American farmer to the development of the country. Just as Turner used the history of the frontier as the central theme for a history of American social, economic and political development, so Dr. Schafer almost effects a universal theme in his history of American agriculture.

TORONTO, Dec. 19. -- The Toronto Maple Leafs beat the Americans by 3 -- 1 tonight and went into a tie with the New Yorkers and the Maroons for second place in the international group of the National Hockey League.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Dec. 19. -- Active interest on the part of Smith College students in the study and collection of rare books has led to the formation of the Sette of Odd Volumes Club. The name was taken from the original society founded in London in 1878 under the leadership of Bernard Harwitch.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 (AP). -- Harold Auch of the Shanahan Catholic Club held off the closing challenge of his teammate, Joe Sullivan, to win the Senior Middle Atlantic A.A.U. cross-country championship by a mere 2 seconds over a rain-swept course in Fairmount Park today.
MADRID, Dec. 19. -- It is not only General Francisco Franco and his artillery bombers who are making Madrid suffer these days. Wintry weather arrived this week to pile misery on misery.

DESPITE the heavy gains over a year ago in some sections as the peak of Christmas trade was reached last week, the general retail picture was rendered somewhat spotty by the failure of other major areas to come up to early forecasts.

OUT of the north woods, breathing freshness, smelling of health, come the spruces and balsams and pines, on truck and flatcar. So the city drags in its Yule logs oy the thousands and tens of thousands.
In the three years since an armed uprising forced the resignation and flight of President Machado turbulent Cuba has had four administrations. Last week it appeared headed for a fifth.

HERE is the capstone to a great undertaking. A monumental work of American scholarship is brought to a triumphant conclusion with the publication of this, the twentieth -- and, for the time being, final -- volume of the "Dictionary of American Biography."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Dr. Guillermo Patterson y de Jauregui, the Cuban Ambassador, made an unannounced call on President Roosevelt at the Executive Mansion today, but whether it was in connection with the political crisis in Cuba was not disclosed.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 19. -- Although there may be "no place like home," there is an intangible substitute for it in the spirit which pervades the campus of Cornell University during the holiday season. For two weeks Yuletide festivities have filled the academic atmosphere, making it possible for students to enjoy this season with college friends before leaving to join their family circles.

ONE of the favorite forms of cinema diversion still is lip-reading. In the silent picture days it was something akin to peeping through keyholes or listening to the chirruping of lovers from behind the potted palms. And to the trained eye the chitchat actually indulged in by Sterling Stalwart and Dulcina Droop during their fadeout clasp was often in stark contrast to the honeyed terms credited to this charming couple in the subtitles.

The imprisonment of General Chiang Kai-shek was probably precipitated by the nationalist movement in China rather than by international intrigue, Professor Heng Chih-tao, Chinese educator said yesterday at a luncheon given in his honor at the Pare Vendome, 1344 West Fifty-seventh Street.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19. -- Leaders of the Republican party, giving serious study to its condition, privately agreed today with the statement of Representative Fish of New York that the party "must reorganize and liberalize or die." As a consequence of this opinion, steps will be taken in the next few months to reshape policies and put the State and national organizations on a fighting basis.

I Mrs. Leigh J. Sessions, president of the Hudson Avenue Boys' Club, i ! announced yesterday an initial list' of subscribers for the bridge partyL and sale to be held for the benefit I of the club, the afternoon of Jan. I i 13, at the Towers, Brooklyn.

The annual holiday dance for undergraduates and alumni of the Canterbury School for Boys, which is located in New Milford, Conn., will be held Saturday night at the Pierre. Clarence H. Mackay is president of the school and Henry O. Havemeyer is vice president.

War has made its appearance at Hanover, N.H., this Fall -- not under the elms of Dartmouth College, but just off campus. Not since the undergraduates went about in khaki, drilling and digging trenches in 1917, has there been such an interest in licensed slaughter. For it has become the study of a group of educators, students and citizens in a course recently opened.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 19. -- Dr. Lotus D. Coffman, president of the University of Minnesota, represented this year by the nation's leading football team, denied today that better football teams helped to improve educational work of institutions.

CATALOGUES of book auctions have been assuming a new value lately Apart from the conventional descriptions of literary properties to be sold they have come more and more to include bibliographical and historical matter that is not easily accessible elsewhere.

American manufacturers interested In export have the best opportunity in twenty years to expand foreign markets on a permanent basis, executives returning from selling trips to South America, the Far East, India and parts of South Africa asserted here yesterday.

Claud B. Lancaster, senior purser of the White Star Line, who has made the acquaintance of thousands of American travelers during the thirty-five years he has held that post, will retire at the end of this month in his fifty-ninth year.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 19 (Canadian Press). -- Aided by Wally Hammond's dazzling double-century, England has assumed a commanding position in the second test cricket match against Australia. When rain brought play to an early close shortly after the tea interval today, the mother country had compiled 426 runs for six wickets, the Gloucestershire players being unbeaten with 231.

Claud B. Lancaster, senior purser of the White Star Line, who has made the acquaintance of thousands of American travelers during the thirty-five years he has held that post, will retire at the end of this month in his fifty-ninth year.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 19 (Canadian Press). -- Aided by Wally Hammond's dazzling double-century, England has assumed a commanding position in the second test cricket match against Australia. When rain brought play to an early close shortly after the tea interval today, the mother country had compiled 426 runs for six wickets, the Gloucestershire players being unbeaten with 231.

When 80,000 persons attend a four-day indoor transplantation of an outdoor sport and purchase $100,000 worth of equipment for its enjoyment, that sport may fairly be said to have attained the fad status. But as regards the ski, there are many other signs of immense popularity besides these records set at the recent international meet at Madison Square Garden.

Few things can better serve the custom of Christmas giving than a well-chosen plant. It implies that careful personal thought has been given to the selection; and it will keep fresh and green in the mind of the recipient the memory of the giver.

More than 500 members and guests attended the supper dance given by the Junior League of Brooklyn last night in the ballroom of the Towers, Brooklyn. The room was banked with Christmas trees. Small trees decorated the tables.

A salesgirl, who, with two detectives, had sought a face in the streets since last Monday caused the arrest yesterday of two women and the husband of one of them on charges of grand larceny and acting in concert in connection with the disappearance of a $5,500 mink coat from the retail firm of Ben Cohen Finer Furs, Inc., 6 West Forty-eighth Street.

VATICAN CITY, Dec. 19. -- Renewed alarm for the Pope's health spread through Rome today when it became known he had cancelled his invitation issued yesterday to members of the Sacred College of Cardinals and the diplomatic corps accredited to the Holy See to attend the customary audience on Christmas Eve.

Following your article of Nov. 29 on the "Avant-Garde," a letter which was printed in your paper on Dec. 13 suggests that after three years a society, now defunct, found it difficult "to find new works of enough significance to make up a series of three programs each year."

The swimmers of James Monroe High School yesterday succeeded those of George Washington High School as Manhattan-Bronx-Richmond senior high school team champions of the Public School Athletic League. They easily defeated the Commerce High School team at the concluding series of dual meets for triborough honors in the seventy-five-foot pool of De Witt Clinton High School.

Mrs. Kate Macy Ladd has contributed $20,000 to the United Hospital Fund Campaign, Stuart M. Crocker, general chairman, announced last night. Mrs. Ladd is the founder of the Josiah Macy Jr. Foundation, which also contributed to the fund.

Following your article of Nov. 29 on the "Avant-Garde," a letter which was printed in your paper on Dec. 13 suggests that after three years a society, now defunct, found it difficult "to find new works of enough significance to make up a series of three programs each year."

They easily defeated the Commerce High School team at the concluding series of dual meets for triborough honors in the seventy-five-foot pool of De Witt Clinton High School.

POTTSVILLE, Pa., Dec. 19. -- Four persons were arrested tonight as Charles J. Margiotti, State Attorney General, directed an investigation into the escape yesterday of Joseph J. Bruno, former county detective serving three concurrent life terms for the Kelayres election eve "massacre" in 1934.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- An application filed on June 10, 1931, by Hugh L. Cooper of New York City for a license for construction of a hydroelectric project with a maximum plant installation of 650,000 horsepower at Z Canyon, nine miles north of Metaline Falls, on the Clark Fork of the Columbia River, State of Washington, has been denied by the Federal Power Commission.

He came to my office two days before Christmas, one of our great actors, who had retired "I read in my newspaper this morning," he said, "of your interest in brave old folks, of your wish that every one would think of their loneliness especially at Christmas time I'd like very much to help you, if you will permit me to do it in my own way.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Administrator Robert Fechner's proposal that the CCC be continued as a permanent agency -- a plan in which he says President Roosevelt concurs -- has met with a highly favorable reception in Washington. The CCC -- or Civilian Conservation Corps, to give it its full but rarely used title -- caught the legislative and popular fancy early in the New Deal.

AUGUSTA, Ga. -- Christmas celebrations, which will bring many visitors -- including a number of former Augustans -- here for the holidays, will be the feature of the social and resort activities here this week.

Juniors in society, including girls who will not make their formal debuts until next season and future years, and their young escorts of preparatory school and college age, will attend several subscription dances during the Christmas holidays.

CENTERVILLE, S.D., Dec. 19 (AP). -- Lieut. Gov. Robert Peterson, president of the First National Bank here, was arrested late today after the bank had been closed on orders of the Controller of the Currency. The Controller announced in Washington that shortages of about $170,000 had been found in the institution's accounts.

HAVANA, Dec. 19. -- A secret session of the House of Representatives has been called for 5 o'clock Monday afternoon to formulate accusations against President Miguel Mariano Gomez preliminary to impeachment, according to information obtained from Capitol sources tonight.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 19. -- A number of social events will take place at the clubs during the holiday season, which will be featured by the "Round Hill Round-Up" at the Round Hill Club on New Year's Eve, when members will appear in ranch costumes. The ballroom will be transformed into a ranch scene.
LONDON, Dec. 16. -- "Balalaika," the new play about Russian exiles, by Eric Maschwitz, which was due to open at the Adelphi on Dec. 18, has been postponed until the following Tuesday.

Thousands of holly trees were stripped of their branches to supply the Christmas demand for wreaths and sprays soon to shine their message from the windows of America. Conservationists say that unless the present wasteful method of collecting the branches stops, ultimately the supply will become commercially exhausted.

AN xperiment of extraordinary interest is being conducted by the Brooklyn Museum in the form of a Dance Center, the purpose of which is not only to foster taste and appreciation of the art from the standpoint of the spectator but also to encourage actual participation by laymen on a non-professional basis.

There is a tonic quality in this latest of William Heyliger's stories, a quality which stems from an individualistic young man's determination to make his living in his home town, and from the practical treatment of the business details with which he struggles.

KINGSTON, N.Y. -- Winter sports activities, which received their first impetus last season in Ulster County, have been expanded this year to offer greater variety to enthusiasts. Original facilities have been enlarged and coordinated to care for increased crowds.

Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday the names of the last four captains to be chosen from the present eligible list which expired last midnight. The four brought to seventy-one the total raised to the rank of captain from the 222 originally eligible.

Out of a maze of guarded reference and reluctant admission, emerged yesterday the first factual data concerning a movement among dominant organizations of women to find common ground for action in a field where clashing opinion and ancient antagonisms necessitate a cautious approach.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 19. -- Dartmouth's basketball team lost to Union College's five, 49 to 45, before 1,500 highly excited fans tonight. Union, with a 5-point lead at half-time, exhibited a stalwart defense in the closing session.

NEWARK. N.J., Dec. 10. -- The Fort Hamilton polo team of Brooklyn displayed a crushing offensive to defeat the Essex Troop trio of Newark, 16 to 6, in the feature contest at the Essex Troop armory tonight.

THE twelfth season of Sunday Salon Concerts of the New York Chamber Music Society, founded by Carolyn Beebe, opens Jan. 17, in the ballroom of the Hotel Plaza. Two concerts will be given this Winter, the second, Feb. 14. Soloists will include Frederick Jagel, tenor, and Carlos Salzedo, harpist.

Joseph E. Davies, newly appointed Ambassador to the U.S.S.R., and Mrs. Davies, the former Marjorie Post and one of America's richest women, do not intend to pine for cream in their coffee in Moscow. In advance of their sailing twenty-five refrigerators and 2,000 pints of frozen cream were shipped last week.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 19. -- The Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace, at its third plenary session this afternoon, approved and adopted the following projects:

GOTHIC architecture, says Professor Watkin, was functional. But modern copies of Gothic are, obviously, not functional at all. Church architecture today is in a state of confusion. We need to return, not by any means to an imitation of Gothic line and ornament, but to a re-creation of the clarity and vigor which marked Gothic building, and to that strength and beauty of feeling, in architecture, which this author calls "romance."

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 19. -- The Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace met in a long plenary session this afternoon and laid the third of four foundation stones for its new structure for permanent peace, by adopting a neutrality convention that obligates all the American countries to take a common joint attitude as neutrals in case of an outbreak of hostilities between any two of them.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 19. -- The Steamship Trade Association of Baltimore issued a statement today criticizing Governor Harry W. Nice and Mayor Howard W. Jackson of Baltimore because those officials sent representatives to a meeting called by West Coast labor leaders to persuade Baltimore longshoremen to go on strike.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19. -- An overbought condition was disclosed today in the wheat and rye markets and, although price fluctuations were erratic, the close showed net losses of 1 to 1 3/8 cents a bushel in wheat futures on the Board of Trade here, while rye was off 1 1/2 cents.

THIS new book about Christopher Columbus and the discovery of America is to be recommended for its quality of interest, so strong indeed as to amount to revivification. In spite of the suggestion of controversy in its title, it is not likely to stir up any very acrimonious discussion among historians.

DOMESTIC service anywhere is not among the world's pleasantest occupations. On the screen it is doubly difficult. Robert Greig, Hollywood's fattest butler-valet, was discussing this topic with Arthur Treacher, Hollywood's most famous tall, thin butler-valet, on the set of "Stowaway," the most recent Shirley Temple picture, and they reached the conclusion outlined above.

MOZART'S "The Marriage of Figaro" will be presented by the Cincinnati Symphony, under Eugene Goossens's direction, Jan. 22 and 23, in Cincinnati. The opera will be given in English in a translation largely the work of Mr. Goossens, who went to the original comedy of Beaumarchais for the dialogues.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- On Christmas Day in this resort there will be a fox hunt in the morning and a gymkhana, a skeet shoot and a golf tournament for both men and women scheduled for the afternoon. On Christmas night a dance at the Carolina is scheduled, and greater than usual Yuletide entertainment will be offered at the other hotels, the Holly Inn, the Manor, Pinecrest Inn and Berkshire.
ANDOVER, Mass., Dec. 19 (AP). -- Thomas E. Qualters, 32, athletic State trooper, prepared tonight to leave for Washington to become President Roosevelt's bodyguard.

In the absence of hedges for a supply of contracts to meet the daily requirements of spinners, prices on the Cotton Exchange improved again yesterday, and, despite the break in the stock market, ended with net changes ranging from a gain of 3 to a loss of 2 points.

Appointment of Mrs. Faxon Saunders of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., to succeed Mrs. James M. Farr 3d as editor of the magazine of the Association of Junior Leagues of America, was announced yesterday by Mrs. Peter L. Harvie of Troy. N.Y., president of the organization.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., Dec. 19. -- The Berkshire County Savings Bank of this city has a 143-year-old Bulfinch church on its hands and wants to give it away, but up to this time no taker has been found.

CHIEF interest in automotive circles turned the past week from passenger cars to commercial cars and trucks. Dedication on Friday of the new commercial body plant of the Chevrolet division of General Motors Corporation at Indianapolis was the outstanding event.

CORINTH, Miss., Dec. 19 (AP). -- Chief of Police Joe Daniels expressed the belief today that Larry Glass, 26-year-old nephew of the head of the Weaver Pants Corporation, who has been missing since Sunday night, had left here "of his own free will."

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla. -- Preparations are being made for the celebration here of the fiftieth anniversary of the Hotel Ponce de Leon on Jan. 9. The golf season already has opened. Among those entered in this year's tournaments are Gene Sarazen, Mally Reynolds, Claude Harmon, Tony Manero, Willie Macfarlane and Johnny Farrell.

THE success of "Gone With the Wind" is enough to make every editor sit up and take notice. Why should this first novel of Margaret Mitchell's outstrip the sale of any other volume published since the war?

ONE of the tokens of a Metropolitan season which promises to have unusual distinctions lies in the fact that a superb opera, not selected for mere purposes of show, has been chosen for the opening night. The opera is Richard Wagner's "Walkuere," with a cast which includes a famous new singer.

NO breath of sixteenth-century court scandal is spared to the reader of this latest book about Henry VIII and his marriages. Nor is any blow of violence halted before it falls. The breath of scandal is indeed a gale.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 19. -- Abner B. Brown, Watertown lawyer, long a Protestant Sunday school leader in New York State and a former superintendent of Sunday schools in Maryland, discussed what he viewed as communistic trends in the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America in a talk yesterday before Leray de Chaumont Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution.
ALBANY, Dec. 19. -- Governor Lehman today announced eight commutations of sentences imposed on prisoners in various State prisons.

To bid them bon voyage on the eve of their sailing for South America, members of the United States Army Horse Show team will be the guests of honor on Wednesday at a luncheon tendered by the Chile-American Association in the India House.

THE Winslow Homer centennial year observance winds up with a most satisfactory retrospective exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art, which opened last week and will be on until the middle of January. The work there displayed, covering his career from beginning to end, has been discerningly selected.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18. -- Reorganization and liberalization of the Republican party formed the dominant note sounded by the party leaders this week at the first meeting of the Republican National Committee since the disastrous defeat in the last Presidential election.

BOSTON, Dec. 18. -- The New England railroads are coming out of the depression with a new reputation for energy and enterprise. The managements smile more readily these days than at any other times in the past five years.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19. -- Three large debutante parties, arranged by hostesses in the order of tea dance, dinner dance and ball were given this afternoon and tonight. Invitations to all three went to the same guests.

Ceremonies in connection with the twenty-five Christmas trees that are being put up and decorated in the parks in the five boroughs will take place at 4:45 P.M. tomorrow, the Department of Parks has announced. Special programs will be held at the principal trees in each borough.

AS Christmas Day approaches, the leaves of cookbooks are turned over by those who must plan and prepare the holiday feast, while the men of the family brush up their knowledge of hot and spicy punches.

To bid them bon voyage on the eve of their sailing for South America, members of the United States Army Horse Show team will be the guests of honor on Wednesday at a luncheon tendered by the Chile-American Association in the India House.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he would sign in the near future the new traffic code unanimously adopted last week by the Board of Aldermen. Its provisions, he pointed out, represent the group opinion of traffic experts and on this basis alone it warrants a fair trial by the motorists of the city.

TOKYO, Dec. 19. -- A bronze plaque in memory of Townsend Harris, first United States Minister to Japan, was unveiled today at Zempuguji Temple, the site of the first American Legation, by Ambassador Joseph C. Grew.

VIENNA, Dec. 19. -- Mr. Clodius, expert economic negotiator of the German Foreign Office, arrived under inauspicious circumstances this week to open the often-postponed economic negotiations provided for by the Austro-German agreement.

GLENDALE, Calif., Dec. 19 (.P.)CIr.-George Von Elm of Hollywood clipped two strokes off par for a third-round 70 to remain in the lead today in the $1.500 Southern California open golf tournament at the Oakmont Country Club.

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- The outstanding social event of the Christmas season at this resort will be the annual Ensign Ball of the Rhododendron Brigade of Guards, which will be held on Tuesday night at the Asheville Golf and Country Club.

Christmas is welcomed at New York's General Postoffice and the seventy-one substations, not with holly and turkey but with grueling work. The postal clerks have already handled and forgotten the Europe-bound Yuletide mail; now they are clearing the millions of letters and greeting cards that flow in and out of New York with the strength of a raging torrent.

In recent months dramatic events have taken place in Europe and in this hemisphere. The civil war in Spain has stirred blood and hatreds within that country and bitterness throughout the Continent: the abdication of Edward VIII made the world catch its breath.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 19 -- More than half of those 1936 graduates of New Jersey College for Women who answered a recent questionnaire sent out by the personnel bureau have obtained positions. Miss Fredericka Belknap, director of the bureau, said today that of 180 who had answered the questionnaire, 106, or 58 per cent, were employed in paid positions.

Norman Lewis, N.Y.U. senior, won the annual New York Athletic Club's invitation intercollegiate foils tournament for the second straight time when he finished first among a group of thirty-one fencers representing fourteen colleges on the Winged Poor strips last night.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 19. -- The organization of a co-educational extension division and a Summer school for Seton Hall College, New Jersey's first Catholic college for men here, was announced today by the Rev. Dr. James F. Kelley, president of the college.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., Dec. 18. -- The Will Rogers Shrine of the Sun, a feudal tower rising from a promontory half way up Cheyenne Mountain not far from Pike's Peak, is nearing completion and will be dedicated next Summer to the memory of the noted comedian and newspaper commentator.

MEDFORD, Mass., Dec. 19. -- The recent development of closer cooperation between the New England Model League of Nations and the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy here appears to be bringing considerable advantage to both parties. On one side, the Model League has obtained in the library of the Fletcher School a permanent repository for its records, while on the other, Fletcher students have been selected as legal advisers to the Model League.

UNTIL lately it was sometimes possible to see two little girls playing under the eyes of their nurses in a bit of railed garden opposite 145 Piccadilly while a Scotland Yard detective watched inconspicuously near by. Women who passed curtsied if one of the two children happened to look up from play and they always got a quick curtsey in reply.
TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 19. -- Governor Hoffman soon will appoint a committee to consider arrangements for representation of New Jersey at the World's Fair in New York in 1939.

On one side, the Model League has obtained in the library of the Fletcher School a permanent repository for its records, while on the other, Fletcher students have been selected as legal advisers to the Model League.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 19. -- Governor Hoffman soon will appoint a committee to consider arrangements for representation of New Jersey at the World's Fair in New York in 1939.

The unbeaten Union Temple five ran its string of victories for this campaign to six last night by repulsing the Williamsburg Y.M.H.A., 36 -- 15, on its own court. With victories in their last four games last season, the Templars now have won ten in a row.

Many of the patronesses will give children's parties at the double bill performance of "Hansel un Gretel" and "The Bat." a production of the American Ballet Ensemble, next Thursday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Children's Health Service of Greenwich House.

THE present turmoil in Spain has added another series of stamps to the class known as provisionals. This type comes into being whenever an Insurgent group gains control of an area so large that it is faced with the problem of maintaining public communications therein.

LAKELAND, Fla., Dec. 18. -- Florida is a house divided against itself over the question of whether Governor Dave Sholtz shall continue to maintain a patrol at the State line to turn back would-be Winter visitors who have little or no money and no job in sight.

TOKYO, Dec. 19. -- Through the clouds of mystery veiling the dramatic developments at Sian and their probable ultimate effect on China and Chinese relations with foreign powers, particularly Japan and Soviet Russia, certain clear-cut lines of thought and policy stand out clearly.

The agreements made in Washington in 1922, with those in London in 1930, for international control of naval construction expire Dec. 31. The agreements made in London this year were ratified by only one Power, the United States, and the nations now revert to complete independence and freedom of action.

The New England governor of National Aeronautic Association, George Mason, writes that Santa Claus, in the person of the veteran flier, Captain William H. Wincapaw, is ready to ride the skies again on Christmas Day to make his eighth annual flight to ninety-one lighthouses and Coast Guard stations along the rock-bound New England coast.

AN authority on interior decoration, Derek Patmore thinks that it is a very good thing for home owners to "have a little courage and experiment for themselves" in working out livable schemes for their houses and apartments.
I read with keen interest THE NEW YORK TIMES article "Roads Need More Money," by Harry Tucker, Professor of Highway Engineering, North Carolina State College.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt will spend an old-fashioned Christmas at home in the White House, surrounded by members of their family.

More than 100 attended the annual dinner and dance of the American Soccer League's Metropolitan Division at the Hotel Woodstock last night. William Low of the Brookhattan Club and past president of the league acted as toastmaster.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20. -- Bullish enthusiasm has entered the world's markets for grains and provisions, and prices have advanced on extensive speculative buying to the highest level in seven years. Fair reactions followed price appreciations, due to profit-taking, and while the trade as a whole is confident of higher levels the disposition is to take profits on all sharp price advances and replace on declines.

After advancing for two successive weeks, the prices of cotton showed easiness last week. On the New York Cotton Exchange old-crop contracts were 5 to 25 points lower, while the new-crop October advanced 5 points.

Loud in their praise of the skill of the pilot who had saved them, seven passengers and the steward of the Eastern Air Lines plane from Miami that made a forced landing on a heavily wooded hilltop near Port Jervis, N.Y., late Saturday evening arrived here by train yesterday afternoon.

A new American work was played for the first time anywhere and a European contribution by a contemporary composer had its first performance by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra when John Barbirolli directed that body yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.

Police officials and the District Attorney will confer today on what to do with John Macari, 13 years old, who confessed on Friday that on Sept. 18, in an abandoned tenement at 89 Madison Street, he killed Francis X. Laino, 10 years old, and hid his body in a closet.

DETROIT, Dec. 20. -- The world champion Red Wings protected their top position in the American Division of the National Hockey League tonight by defeating Boston, 4-3, for the second time this season, in a fast, hard game before 12,000 fans.
SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador, Dec. 20. -- Arrivals from the devastated city of San Vicente said tonight that only one prominent structure remained standing there -a tall tower in the central park.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Two alternate designs for a passenger ship to replace the Leviathan in the transatlantic service have been received by the United States Maritime Commission from the United States Lines.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20. -- Light to good rains fell in Texas, Oklahoma, parts of Kansas and Nebraska last week, but the precipitation was insufficient and more rain will be needed. The condition of the crops is only fair throughout that section. In the Middle West there was a little snow and rain, and crop conditions on the whole are satisfactory for the season.

GLENDALE, Calif., Dec. 20. -- George Von Elm of Hollywood, former national amateur champion, captured the $1,500 Southern California open golf championship today when he finished the seventy-two-hole tournament with a total of 279 -- 9 under par.

BERLIN, Dec. 19. -- The aggravation of the food outlook did not affect the Boerse this week and stocks advanced. The cereal situation had dealt a bad blow to the optimism of the government. At the farmers' congress at Goslar in November, a shortage of bread or cereals was officially declared inconceivable.

The annual financial statement of Swift Co. for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, announced today, shows a net profit of $12,103,750 after deductions for depreciation, depletion, interest, provision for taxes and other charges. No provision has been made for surtax on undistributed profits.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 20 (AP). -- Maryland lavished some of her choicest foods on Governor Landon today, these including the traditional terrapin and succulent oysters.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20. -- Corn was sold last week on all bulges on the Board of Trade and there was a closing of spreads between that grain and wheat. Country holders were more liberal sellers while the demand was not so sharp as it had been. White corn was picked up readily, with several sales of round lots to processors.

Miss Barbara Wall is chairman of the debutante committee for the Christmas tea and bundle party to be held today at the Continental for the benefit of Everybody's Thrift Shop. Her aides include the Misses Alma Nicoll, Mallory Mixsell, Lynda L. Dickinson, Sophie J. Kilbreth, Lisa Mabon, Lydia Hadden, Jane Will, Marie Trench and Mona Trench.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 20. -- The inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace will turn its attention during its closing days to the economic aspects of international relations in the Western Hemisphere.
NANKING, Monday, Dec. 21. -- The Chinese Government's reply to Japan's warning against concluding any anti-Japanese, pro-Communist compromise with Chang Hsuehliang will say in effect:

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., Dec. 20. -- The contrasting roles of seemingly certain victors and apparently certain losers were played alternately by Mrs. Alfred W. Paine and Archibald G. Thacher Jr. before they became definite winners of the Sleepy Hollow Country Club's invitation squash racquets mixed-doubles tournament today.

Congressional reapportionment on a fair non-partisan basis, extension of city home rule and longer terms for Governor and members of the Assembly are features of the legislative program of the Citizens Union, announced yesterday by William J. Schieffelin, its chairman.

Competing in a field which included one national junior breast-stroke champion and two former holders of the same crown. Mrs. Elsie Petri, metropolitan titleholder, cut through the water of the Women's Swimming Association pool yesterday in excellent fashion to annex the fifty-yard breaststroke scratch race.

Miss Madeline Dalton, 1935 women's national intercollegiate fencing champion, annexed the first of four foils tournaments for the Giorgio Santelli Trophy by winning both her bouts in a final fence-off on the strips of the Salle Santelli yesterday.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 20. -- The singing of carols, presentation of pageants and special sermons today marked the advent of Christmas week in the churches throughout Westchester County.

The complex troubles from which the world is suffering today * * * all go back to one root cause and can be adequately dealt with only if this cause is recognized. The world has become a unit, but it is not yet governed as a unit -- i. e., it is not governed at all.

" Stewardship" is declared to be the "bedrock upon which every policy and action of commercial banking should be founded," in a statement of principles of commercial banking which has been prepared by the American Bankers Association for distribution by its members among their customers.
Investors figured prominently as the buyers of apartment houses in deals announced in the metropolitan area over the week-end. Some of the properties were sold by savings banks.

BERLIN, Dec. 19. -- The week's stock market was relatively active, with prices first advancing steadily, preference being shown for steels, coals, chemicals and other raw materials corporations. Interest also was shown in electricals, automotives and breweries, while other manufacturing companies showed slight gains for the most part and some textiles reacted.
