GREENWOOD LAKE, N.J., Dec. 20. -- Stephen R. Gordon, consulting engineer of New York City and a resident of West Milford, N.J., was injured this afternoon when his iceboat overturned on him and dragged him many yards before it lost momentum.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20. -- Trade in lard was unusually active here last week, largely on speculative account. The output of the packing houses is large and consumptive requirements liberal. Wide price fluctuations in prices of hogs caused an unsettled feeling in the market for refined lard, supplies of which are above the average.
Foreign exchanges showed a firm undertone last week, a characteristic carried forward from the markets of the last several weeks. Business was on a fairly substantial scale throughout.

POTTSVILLE, Pa., Dec. 20. -- Governor George H. Earle came here to the center of bootleg mining operations tonight to begin a personal investigation into one of the most plaguing problems of his administration.

THE TIMES of Dec. 15 contained a most interesting item under the heading "Bill to End Slums Drafted for City." The bill, which will be introduced in the State Legislature early in January, was prepared by the New York County Republican Committee with the cooperation of some of the most competent students of housing in the city.

VERSAILLES, France, Dec. 20.--A woman who Pilot Pierre l'Allemant asserted shot him in the back as they flew together 1,300 feet in the air and then fled in their plane after he had brought it safely to earth was sought tonight throughout France.

Although opposition to the re-election of Irving M. Ives as Speaker of the Assembly continues, Republican leaders here expressed the opinion yesterday that the re-election would be "worked out" after considerable difficulty. William S. Murray, the new State chairman, is expected to hold conferences before the Legislature convenes with a view to bringing about an agreement.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 20. -- As several Westchester County communities prepared for a campaign to reduce automobile accidents, beginning tomorrow, Gordon M. Wagner, secretary of the Westchester Council of Utility Rates Committees, proposed that the county build its own plant to illuminate the parkway system, often criticized as inadequately lighted.

LONDON, Dec. 19. -- Interesting though the Bank of England's action in reducing the fiduciary issue by 60,000,000 may be, it is easy to exaggerate the importance of the move. The development is none too clearly understood abroad, as was evident from the rise of sterling which immediately followed its announcement.

The gales and heavy head seas that have prevailed over the North Atlantic during the last six days have delayed the westbound passenger liners so that even the fastest ships will arrive here from twenty-four to thirty hours late.
Staging a dramatic closing spurt, the New York Rangers turned what looked like certain defeat into a smashing victory over the Canadiens of Montreal at Madison Square Garden last night.

PARIS, Dec. 20. -- Illicit arms traffic to Spain is believed behind the arrest of Miss Suzanne Linder, a stenographer at the Quai d'Orsay, headquarters of French diplomacy, and Michel Rosenfeld, to whom she is alleged to have conveyed state secrets.
The abdication of King Edward VIII of Great Britain was the subject of both critical and tolerant comment in pulpits in New York City yesterday.

The plan to consolidate the Mohawk Hudson Power and the Niagara Hudson Power Corporations, announced Saturday, will provide for a restatement of assets which will entail a reduction of $58,500,000 in property, plant and investments as stated on the books of the Niagara Hudson system at the end of 1935.

A resolution demanding that the 45,000,000 Ukrainians now living under Russian, Polish, Rumanian and Czechoslovakian sovereignty receive their independence was passed yesterday at the seventh triennial congress of the United Ukrainian Organizations of the United States at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The importance of the church does not consist of its preaching missions or great personages, but in the thousands of congregations through which it does its work, the Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Knubel, president of the United Lutheran Church in America, declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Lutheran Church of the Advent, Broadway and Ninety-third Street.

Although last week's market repeated the preceding week's display of inertia, with its prices pretty much stationary, the forward movement of industrial activity continued unabated. Steel output rose from 76 1/2 per cent of capacity to 79, indicating the highest rate of production reached at any time since 1929 or 1928.

The supreme tragedy of the present threats to freedom lies in the fact that they menace the true things that gave mankind hope for the future, James G. McDonald of THE NEW YORK TIMES, former League of Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, said in a talk yesterday morning at the Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.
A vigorous attack on government taxation programs that cripple private philanthropy was made yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, in his annual report.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 20. -- Far from the rumbling uproar of pre-game enthusiasm, Pittsburgh and Washington gridiron warriors will settle down this week to intensive preparation for their New Year's Day clash in the Rose Bowl.

In his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES Jacob Bromberg says: "Rumania again mobilized against a defenseless Hungary." Whatever one may think of Hungarian claims to Slovakia, Transylvania and the Banat, there can be no excuse for clinging to the myth that the Rumanians deliberately attacked Hungary in 1919.

ROME, Dec. 20. -- Details of a serious situation that has been in existence between the Jewish community and the Italian authorities in Tripoli ever since Nov. 14 were revealed only today with the arrival in Rome of the Jewish newspaper Nostra Bandiera of Turin, which prints extracts from a local Tripoli newspaper, Avvenire di Tripoli.

Brachah Zfirah, Yemenite interpreter of Palestine and Oriental folksongs, and her husband, Nachum Nardi, composer-pianist, made their debut at the Adelphi Theatre last night before a large and demonstrative audience. Although Miss Zfirah was born in Yemen, she was brought to Jerusalem early in life and there she received most of her training in a school conducted by the Junior Hadassah of America, the young women's Zionist organization.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Campaign expenditure reports revealed today that Communist votes involving about $2.02 for each vote cast, topped the per-ballot expense list in the Presidential election.

In a formal and official way the British Government has protested to the German against German intervention in behalf of the Spanish Rebels. Of this, new and cumulative evidence has been forthcoming. One of our own correspondents in Spain was the first to note and report that German planes flown by German pilots were in the service of the Rebels.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- A review of the relief, employment and unemployment situation in Washington shows the following apparent paradox:
CANNES, France, Dec. 20 (AP). -Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson made known today "there is no possibility" that she will see the Duke of Windsor before Spring.

A museum portraying in graphic exhibits the advances of modern surgery and recording in rare documents and other material the history of surgery is to be established in New York with the aid of a fund set up by Mrs. William Randolph Hearst, wife of the publisher, it became known last night.

POTTSVILLE, Pa., Dec. 20. -- Attorney General Charles J. Margiotti alleged tonight that Joseph J. Bruno, fugitive political leader under a life sentence for the Kelayres election eve massacre in 1934, made his escape on Friday by being driven from the county prison, not to a dentist's office but directly to a rendezvous where a conveyance awaited him.

SYDNEY, Australia, Monday, Dec. 21 (Canadian Press) -- England dismissed Australia today with a first-innings score of 80 in their second test cricket match. The tourists completed the rout of Aussie batsmen shortly after the luncheon interval. Before luncheon they captured seven wickets at a cost of 67 runs.

The list of unbeaten major college basketball teams in the metropolitan district was cut in half during the past week as Manhattan, City College and Fordham fell by the wayside. Long Island University, New York University and the surprising St. John's outfit were the three that managed to keep their slates clean and all came through without serious difficulties.

Apparently the slightest bit self-conscious in the presence of their new coach, and therefore determined to make him see just what possibilities they possess, the New York Rovers pulled a game out of the fire yesterday afternoon, pushed a pair of goals into the net in the final period and topped the Baltimore Orioles, 2 to 1.

ALBANY, Dec. 20 (AP). -- The New York State World War Memorial Authority has virtually abandoned efforts to obtain Federal aid to finance construction of a proposed $12,500,000 memorial and State office building in Albany.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20. -- December oats on the Board of Trade here were bought last week by local and Northwestern interests and December closed at 51 3/4 cents a bushel, a net gain of 2 1/2 cents on the week. May finished at 50 7/8 cents, up 1 5/8 cents, while the July at 45 3/8 cents was 5/8 cent higher.

Harvard's champion team will encounter Yale this afternoon in the first round of the annual four-cornered tournament of the H.Y.P.D. College Chess League at the Marshall Chess Club, 23 West Tenth Play will begin at 2 o'clock.

Spreading of construction activity over a longer period to provide stability in the building industry is suggested by Ossian P. Ward, secretary of the Kentucky Chapter of the American Institute of Architects, in an appeal to architects to take the lead during 1937 in curbing what he says may be "the biggest building boom in history."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 20. -- Ducky Pond, Eli coach, today told at a meeting of football fans how Yale copied from Cornell the mousetrap play, used by the Ithacans in the Elis' first game of the season. This clever bit of strategy, which the Blue used to defeat Pennsylvania, was adopted by Penn and the latter finally worked it successfully on Cornell Thanksgiving Day.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Dec. 21. -The town of Huahsien, twenty miles southeastward of Sian, on the Lunghai Railway, was captured by government troops yesterday in the drive to rescue General Chiang Kai-shek from rebels led by General Chang Hsueh-liang.

Buying activity in the wholesale market here last week stressed holiday merchandise, with definite emphasis on gift items of the more expensive type, such as fur coats, higher-price perfumes, expensive toys and men's and boys' better-grade furnishings.

Tackling a gunman who leaped into his taxicab in front of the Hotel Plaza and tried to steal from his wife jewelry valued at thousands of dollars, Emile E.C. Mathis, French automobile manufacturer, routed the thug and several accomplices single-handed and unarmed early yesterday morning.

RYE, N.Y., Dec. 20. -- P.M. McHugh was the major winner at the traps of the Westchester Country Club today. He took the scratch cups in both singles and doubles. In the former event he had 38 out of 50 targets, while in the doubles shoot he finished with 32.

RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 20. -- In three indoor polo matches played today in the Red Bank Armory the 112th Field Artillerymen, Red Bank, defeated the East Orange Field Artillery riders, 12 1/2 to 6; Kilkare Farms of Elberon trounced the Red Bank Polo Club team, 8 1/2 to 2, and Winmont routed Silver Brook Farms, 11 to 3 1/2.

In the annual report of the War Department, the first section of which is published this morning, Secretary WOODRING outlines what he believes to be the army's needs in the immediate future. He places first the desirability of maintaining its enlisted strength at 165,000.

High winds swept in from Long Island Sound and made the shooting conditions exceedingly difficult at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. Competition was keen, however, although many of the scores were low.

The telegraph brings word that Sonja Henie, world champion figure skater and more recently the star of Fox's "One in a Million," is scheduled to arrive this morning at Newark. While here, the wire insists, she "will cooperate with scientists in several experiments, one dealing with calculation of friction coefficient of steel on ice, other with possibilities of incorporating anti-sinus gases with ammonia or other gases used for artificial-ice rinks."

CHICAGO, Dec. 20. -- Raisers of hogs took advantage last week of the recent advance in prices and did well for a time, but the increased receipts on the upturn in prices brought about a sharp decline so that most of the advance was lost.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 20 (AP). -- The Rev. John F. O'Hara, president of Notre Dame University, today described as "both sensible and practical" the program proposed by Dr. Lotus D. Coffman, president of the University of Minnesota, to improve intercollegiate athletics.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- National labor organizations are gradually taking over the representation of employes on most of the nation's railroads, the National Mediation Board observes in its second annual report.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 20 (AP). -- The deadlock in negotiations to end the eight-week strike in five plants of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company appeared certain today to extend over the Christmas holidays as mediators returned to their homes.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 20. -Princeton University has awarded scholarships to 389 undergraduates for the current academic year, according to a list published today by Dr. Robert K. Root, dean of the faculty and chairman of the university scholarship committee.

TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 21. -- Anxiety regarding the Cabinet's fate was revived by Moscow's blunt refusal to expedite discussions on the fisheries treaty. When the Soviet Foreign Minister, Maxim Litvinoff, saw the Japanese Ambassador, Mamoru Shigemitsu, on Saturday he told him, according to dispatches to the newspaper Asahi from Moscow, that the Soviet had been too busy to make a decision.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 20. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 83 per cent of capacity, up 2 points from the previous week. Except for five or six months in 1929 the daily tonnage output was the largest on record.

For Man of the Year I modestly nominate myself. I am neither monarch, dictator, Fuehrer, President or even a deposed king. Nor am I a movie star, postmaster, baseball champion, maestro or champion corn-husker. I am just an average American business man.
Today -- four days before Christmas -- the Neediest Cases Fund is lagging behind last year's fund at this date.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Employe representatives from forty-two steel plants between Cleveland and the Atlantic Coast at a meeting today formed the "C.I.O. Representatives Council," proposed a national convention of all steel workers and demanded $5 minimum pay for labor.

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 20. -- The Mexican Government is expected to announce shortly that 2,000 new primary schools have been established quietly this year and that the development of strictly non-religious education of Mexican youth will be accentuated.

Lawrence A. Seaver, Dongan Hills, S.I. -- I read with much interest your remarks in Wood, Field and Stream recently regarding the feeding of wildlife in our suburban and farm areas. I think the majority of New Yorkers would be surprised to know that they can have the pleasure of attracting wild birds right here in the borders of the Greater City, providing one's home is situated close to a bit of open field.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 20. -- Officials of the Inter-American Peace Conference worked today on plans for what it is hoped will be the final business session, scheduled for 10 o'clock tomorrow morning. They tried to combine all remaining recommendations from standing committees for approval by the plenary gathering of delegates.

The significance of Christmas was discussed by the clergy of various denominations in their sermons yesterday. From the pulpit it was suggested that the celebration of the Nativity gave a deeper meaning to spiritual joys and that Christmas festivities had become too pagan.

A protest against the proposed designation of Fourth Avenue as a one-way traffic thoroughfare was sent to First Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler yesterday by the Central Mercantile Association.

Mr. LA GUARDIA now knows he started something last Summer when he set up business offices in a Pelham Park Bay mansion. Stately mansions are now being proposed to the Mayor from all sides, and for residential use.
MOSCOW, Dec. 20. -- The Soviet Union charged today that the Soviet motorship Komsomol had been set on fire and sunk by a Spanish Rebel cruiser last Monday.

A meeting to raise funds to send men to fight with the Leftist forces in Spain was held yesterday afternoon at the Manhattan Lyceum, 66 East Fourth Street. The meeting, called by the Italian Anti-Fascist Committee, was attended by 300 persons.
An indication of the increased volume of Christmas buying was provided yesterday by the Railway Express Agency in an analysis of its business for the first two weeks of this month.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Dec. 20. -- Caught between floods of the Raritan River and Middle Creek, Martin Blomquest, 55 years old, perched in the branches of a spreading tree all day today after being washed out of an abandoned shanty where he went to sleep last night.

By way of celebrating the two-hundredth anniversary of the birth of John Singleton Copley, great early American painter, the Metropolitan Museum has arranged in Gallery D6 an exhibition that will open with a private view for members tomorrow and to the public on Wednesday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 20. -- A total of 187 awards have been made to players and managers of Fall athletic teams at Princeton University, and in addition a major letter has been given for the national rope-climbing championship, according to the list released today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics of the university.

The Viscose Company will establish an all-time rayon production record during 1936, despite a three-months' shutdown of its flood-swept plant at Lewiston, Pa., one of its largest units, according to Frank Griffith, vice president and general manager of production.

The Metropolitan opera season opens tonight with Wagner's "Die Walkuere." Kirsten Flagstad, Elisabeth Rethberg, Lauritz Melchior, Friedrich Schorr and Emanuel List head the cast and Artur Bodanzky conducts. In the other principal role Kerstin Thorborg will make her American debut.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -House Bill No. 1 in the forthcoming Congress is expected to be a measure by Representative Louis Ludlow of Indiana designed to aid in the stabilization of employment in commerce, industry and agriculture.

PARIS, Dec. 19. -- The tendency of the foreign-exchange market was still rather unfavorable to the franc at the beginning of the week, and the stabilization fund probably was called upon to satisfy foreign-exchange requirements.

WOODBURY, L.I., Dec. 20. -Some time between midnight and 8 o'clock this morning, presumably while the rain and wind storm was at its height, a second-story burglar entered the bedroom of Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury, in his home here on Jericho Turnpike.

The United Hospital Campaign Committee, through its chairman, Stuart M. Crocker, announced yesterday the receipt of a gift of $10,000 from Mr. and Mrs. George F. Baker and a second gift of $10,000 from an anonymous donor.
I would appreciate some information concerning Elliott V. Bell's article titled "Federal Loan Reveals a Paradox of Finance." Mr. Bell writes:

The governing board of the Emergency Relief Bureau has filed in Supreme Court a declaration that the holding of competitive examinations for ERB jobs, as ordered by the Municipal Civil Service Commission, would result in "irreparable injury" to the relief bureau and to the city's taxpayers.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 20. -- A message, prepared by Bishop Maurice F. McAuliffe, appealing to the people of Connecticut to cooperate for safety in highways, was the subject of a letter to all priests read in all the Roman Catholic churches of the State today.

BERLIN, Dec. 20. -- The high command of the Hitler Special Guard in its organ, the Black, Corps, has come out strongly in favor of nudism. The nudist movement in Germany was suppressed by Col. Gen. Hermann Goering on March 8, 1933, a little more than a month after Chancellor Adolf Hitler came into power.

With the company continuing to evince little concern over the situation, the Brooklyn local of the Amalgamated Association of Street and Electric Railway and Motor Coach Operators announced yesterday that the threatened strike on the bus lines of the B.M.T. in that borough would go into effect late Wednesday or early Thursday if the union's demands for higher wages and shorter hours were not granted.

BABYLON, L.I., Dec. 20. -- A wild ride through Main Street, Babylon, netted Steve Morocs, 60 years old, of Smithtown Branch, the maximum penalty permitted under the State Motor Vehicle Law for drunken driving as a first offender.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 20 (AP). -- Juliana, Crown Princess of the Netherlands, busied herself today with plans for her wedding next month and found the question of where to put her many relatives a paramount problem.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Dec. 20. -Princeton University leads the country in the number of its students nominated as candidates for Rhodes Scholarships, it was disclosed tonight at the office of Dr. Frank Aydelotte, president of Swarthmore College and American Secretary to the Rhodes trustees.

A campaign to raise $110,000 for the erection of a Lutheran chapel at Harvard University will get under way late in January, according to the Rev. Norman D. Goehring, Lutheran student pastor at the university. Land has already been purchased and the United Lutheran Synod of New York has agreed to aid in the drive.

AMSTERDAM, Dec. 19. -- The only officially known gold movement in Holland following devaluation of the currency was the transfer of 100,000,000 guilders from the Netherlands Bank to the equalization fund on Oct. 1, leaving gold in the bank at 569,000,000 guilders.

HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 20. -- The Dartmouth College athletic council today announced varsity schedules in track and swimming for the Winter season, as well as freshman schedules in basketball, hockey and swimming.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- A permanent peacetime army of 165,000 men and 14,000 officers and a greatly enlarged National Guard and officer reserve strength were recommended to President Roosevelt today by Secretary of War Woodring in his report for the fiscal year ended June 30. 1936.

Yale University's hockey team will make its first appearance in Madison Square Garden in five years when it opposes the New York Rovers tonight. The game promises to be an interesting one, bringing together as it does one of the strongest college teams in the East, and the sextet that many believe is the best in the Eastern Amateur League.
The Very Rev. Milo H. Gates, dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 110th Street, in his sermon yesterday morning, said:

The drama's first Christmas package -- there will be one every night this week -- is to be unwrapped tonight at the Lyceum, and the card will read "Aged 26," a new and romantic play by Anne Crawford Flexner. Robert Harris (in the role of John Keats), Kenneth MacKenna and Linda Watkins head the cast, which further includes Leona Powers, Matthew Boulton, A.G. Andrews, Fred Leslie, H. Cooper Cliffe, Anthony Kemble Cooper and Charles Trexler.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Woolen and textile companies averaged a higher rate of return on investment in the last six months of 1935 than for any half year subsequent to January, 1933, excepting the last half of that year, according to a report by the Federal Trade Commission today on its investigation of the textile industry.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Dec. 20. -- William E. Coyle Jr., young Montclair A.C. star and New York State champion, provided a stunning upset today by defeating the veteran Neil J. Sullivan 2d of the Germantown Cricket Club in the final round of the annual Ardsley Club invitation squash racquets tournament.

The New English Singers gave their third and final concert of the season at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. Their program included, as usual, carols and Christmas motets, madrigals, songs with lute and duets. There was a large audience, and the applause was prolonged and enthusiastic.

Martha Graham in her first performance of the season at the Guild Theatre last night revealed her latest and by far her most ambitious composition for soloist and group under the title of "Chronicle." The work, which runs for something over an hour, is devoted to a consideration of the "advent and consequences of war."

The death of John Norman Alexander, 25 years old, of Philadelphia, who was killed late Saturday night by a fall in an elevator shaft at the Yale Club at 50 Vanderbilt Avenue, near Forty-fourth Street, was declared yesterday by detectives of the East Fifty-first Street police station to have been accidental.

The schism among Soviet geneticists which led to the cancellation of the genetics conference grew in part out of a theory of inheritance which I printed privately in 1933. Several copies were sent to Russia. Professor Lysanko's attacks on the "classical geneticists" are well based.

ALBANY, Dec. 20. -- To his "sincere wish that this happiest time of all the year may be a safe and joyous season for all," Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, added a note of warning to drivers and pedestrians today to use extreme caution during the holidays.

SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 20 (AP). -The search for two lost aircraft of the West rose to spectacular proportions today with more than 8,200 men available, but the strange radio signals, which had stirred a hope of finding alive the nine missing persons, faded into silence.

A steady drop in temperatures brought a cold snap last night in the wake of a heavy downpour that drenched the Northeastern States Saturday night and early yesterday. The weather bureau forecast clearing skies and continuing cold weather near the freezing mark for today.

New York continues to grow in importance as a convention city, according to figures made public yesterday by Mayor La Guardia. The figures were contained in a letter to the Mayor from Richard C. Burritt, executive director of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- A "covert conspiracy to keep the United States in the islands" is seen as one of the manifestations of the new Philippine defense plan in a report published today by the Foreign Policy Association. A predominant objective of the plan, the report said, was the creation of a strong American military and naval base in the Philippines "as an outpost of American power in the Far East."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 20. -Gladys George, who stepped from the stage into screen stardom in Paramount's "Valiant Is the Word for Carrie," has signed a term contract with M.-G.-M. Her first assignment is "They Gave Him a Gun," scheduled to start after the holidays.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Dec. 20. -- Competition for Christmas turkeys brought twenty-eight gunners, one of the largest fields of the year, to the traps of the Crescent Athletic Club today. The event was a fifty-target skeet shoot, R.R. Bogie finishing with 46 for the high gun honors.

Both communism and Christianity seek asceticism, but the former imposes it, while the latter leaves it to one's own will, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the Catholic University declared in a sermon yesterday at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament, Seventy-first Street east of Broadway.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20. -- Earl Seibert's third-period goal gave Chicago its first victory in eight national Hockey League starts at home tonight, the Black Hawks defeating the New York Americans, 2 -- 1, before 10,000 fans in a fast, rough game.

VALHALLA, N.Y., Dec. 20. -Once you are "elected" to something in this hamlet you stay elected. Perhaps residents believe a place named Valhalla should defer to the idea of immortality, perhaps they are merely expressing their affection for a fellow villager.

In this season symbolic of peace and good-will all over the world, there are to be heard more discordant notes than usual. Suspicion between nations is rife. Actual fears of war, based on what appears to be a menacing situation between various countries, are expressed.

TALAVERA DE LA REINA, Spain, Dec. 20 (Uncensored). -- General Francisco Franco is determined to take Madrid whenever and however it can be taken. Until he has done it or failed again, he will not accept an armistice on that front.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Loans to farmers through the cooperative production credit system started under the Farm Credit Administration less than three years ago have just passed the $500,000,000 mark, it was announced today by William I. Myers, Governor of the FCA.

With all branches participating in the upturn, the textile industry is about to close one of the most profitable years it has experienced since 1919, according to Scheuer Co. Every organization operating in textiles has shared in the improvement in varying degrees, the company says.

In this season symbolic of peace and good-will all over the world, there are to be heard more discordant notes than usual. Suspicion between nations is rife. Actual fears of war, based on what appears to be a menacing situation between various countries, are expressed.

TALAVERA DE LA REINA, Spain, Dec. 20 (Uncensored). -- General Francisco Franco is determined to take Madrid whenever and however it can be taken. Until he has done it or failed again, he will not accept an armistice on that front.

MADRID, Dec. 20. -- Government forces launched a counter-offensive in the Pozuelo de Alarcon sector today, and fighting has been going on steadily since early morning. The situation there still remains unsettled, however.

MOSCOW, Dec. 20 (AP). -- Russia ordered a survey today of religion among the people, expecting to find growing disbelief in God. Whether he believes in God will be one of the five principal questions to be asked of each citizen over sixteen in the national census next month.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Loans to farmers through the cooperative production credit system started under the Farm Credit Administration less than three years ago have just passed the $500,000,000 mark, it was announced today by William I. Myers, Governor of the FCA.

With all branches participating in the upturn, the textile industry is about to close one of the most profitable years it has experienced since 1919, according to Scheuer Co. Every organization operating in textiles has shared in the improvement in varying degrees, the company says.

The railroads and Wall Street seem to be seriously disturbed by the refusal of the Interstate Commerce Commission to extend the existing emergency freight-rate increases beyond the end of the present month. It would be foolish to dismiss their concern offhand as unwarranted.
BERLIN, Dec. 20. -- The Rev. Martin Niemoeller, intransigent leader of the Confessional Synod, made it plain both in his sermon and in a ...

RIO DE JANIERO, Dec. 20. -- As a potential export product in Brazilian economy, cotton daily gains in ascendancy, filling the gaps left by the decreased exportation of other products, especially coffee.
DETROIT, Dec. 20 (AP). -- The industrial strike fronts were quiet today as labor leaders, manufacturers and the Stock Exchanges awaited developments Monday in a score of disputes.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine cited 319 policemen "for meritorious conduct performed in the line of duty" in a general order issued last midnight. The citations include recognition for intelligent work in apprehending criminals and for physical bravery beyond the ordinary call of duty.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20 (AP). -The first definite prospect of a break in the Pacific Coast maritime strike came tonight when Harry Lundeberg, leader of the Sailors Union, announced a complete tentative agreement with offshore ship-owners' representatives.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 20. -- President Raymond Walters of the University of Cincinnati reported today a continued sharp increase in enrollment in 593 approved universities and colleges in the United States, in his annual survey for School and Society, an educational journal.

LONDON, Dec. 19. -- The absence of any change in the general trend of British overseas trade is causing some misgivings here. With a further increase in the adverse visible trade balance in November, the total deficit for the eleven months is 68,598,G00 greater than in 1935, and it may be nearer 80,000,000 above 1935 by the year-end.

Instead of proposing more taxis as one method of aiding employment, it would be much more to the point to take off the streets a few thousand in order to relieve traffic congestion. I am sure that a careful study of the taxi situation would show that from around 10 in the morning to 4 in the afternoon, thousands of taxis are cruising without passengers, and hence obstructing traffic.

An elaborate reception program has been prepared for the delegation of French advertising executives, who will arrive here en Jan. 6 to tour the country for approximately a month in order to create interest in the Continental Advertising Convention to be held in Paris in July.
WHENEVER a major league ball club comes along to tear things apart, as did the Yankees in this fading year of 1936, there invariably follows a series of deep and apprehensive mutterings.

Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood has awarded owners of 632 acres of land, to be used as the World's Fair site, the sum of $3,638,939 for their property, it was announced by the Corporation Counsel's office yesterday. This is about 6 per cent above the value set by city experts.
SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador, Dec. 20. -- At least 200 persons were killed and 800 injured in an earthquake that virtually destroyed the city of San Vicente last night.

The new Federal law on corporate subscriptions to essential community charities makes it possible for business as well as individuals to share directly in such community responsibilities as the United Hospital Fund. It may well be that in the long run the constant service rendered by such funds to corporations will bring to the latter compensating returns.
BERLIN, Dec. 20. -- A return to Germany at this time produces an impression of changes -- distinct changes, somewhat foreshadowed, yet more extensive than anything envisaged two months ago.

I think it was Clarence Darrow who took the pessimistic view that people were kidding themselves when they spoke of their rights. He maintained that people who thought such existed were laboring under a delusion. I am inclined to be in agreement with this philosophy.

HAVANA, Dec. 20. -- President Miguel Mariano Gomez is preparing to veto the bill levying a tax of 9 cents a bag on raw-sugar production to finance army-controlled schools. He will send it back to Congress with a veto message, it is reliably learned.

Oliver D. Wells and Pierre Blanchet gave a large reception yesterday afternoon at the Cafe Bali for Mr. and Mrs. Edouard de Wardener, who returned recently from their wedding trip. Mrs. de Wardener is the former Miss Aurelie Murchison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth M. Murchison.
PARIS, Dec. 20. -- Portbou, a Spanish frontier station on the Catalan coast which suffered an air raid last week, was bombarded today from the sea.

The Electric Power and Light Corporation and subsidiaries have reported for the twelve months to Nov. 30 a consolidated net profit of $7,915,766 after all deductions. This was equal, after preferred and second-preferred dividend requirements, to 64 1/2 cents a share on 3,421,261 common shares.

The new traffic code could not be expected to deal in any definitive fashion with the city's most pressing traffic problem: street congestion in midtown Manhattan. To discover a practical approach to the solution of that problem will be the task of the conference which Mayor LA GUARDIA is planning to hold next month.
Three days before Christmas and the Neediest wait!

CHICAGO, Dec. 21. -- The Portland Cement Association will devote approximately 65 per cent of its 1937 advertising appropriation to newspaper space, according to W.D.M. Allan, advertising manager. The 1937 program will at least equal its 1936 efforts.
BATH, Me., Dec. 21 (AP). -- A huge mould was ready tonight to receive in molten form the lead keel for Harold S. Vanderbilt's America's Cup contender.

Free medical service for those who need it but are unable to pay, supported by State taxes, was advocated last night by Dr. Charles Gordon Heyd, president of the American Medical Association, at a meeting of the Medical Society of the County of New York at the Academy of Medicine, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 21 (AP). -- After finishing second Saturday, L.J. Marks's Mannerly came back today to defeat eight rivals in the mile and seventy-yard feature event at the Fair Grounds.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 21. -- Germany's recent rescinding of the expulsion of four Netherlanders of good repute living in Berlin has now caused the Netherland Government to rescind its expulsion of four Germans who had violated the regulations forbidding political activities by foreigners.

The Princeton Club's strongest team removed another obstacle in its path to the Metropolitan League Class B squash tennis championship yesterday when it turned back the Crescent Athletic Club of Brooklyn, 4 -- 1, on the Princeton Club courts.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21. -- Prices of hogs advanced today 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight, as receipts were smaller than had been expected. The top was lifted 10 cents above Friday's price to $10.25, while the day's average of $10.10 showed an advance of 15 cents and was in new ground for the Winter season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- The first step in consolidating government agencies will be taken by President Roosevelt in a few days with inclusion of the Resettlement Administration, an independent agency, in the Department of Agriculture.

Edward S. Abbott, 22 years old, a WPA actor and a former Yale student, was found dead at 8:30 A.M. yesterday hanging in a bathroom on the third floor of a rooming house at 9 East Seventeenth Street. On the floor was a pencil-scrawled note that explained that ill health, financial worry and fear of losing his job had prompted the suicide.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Dec. 16 shows increases for the week of $281,000,000 in total loans and investments, $137,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $250,000,000 in government deposits.

Under a persistent demand from domestic mills and the resulting removal of hedges, trading on the Cotton Exchange absorbed limited selling pressure yesterday and the list ended with a loss of 1 to 6 points. Though pre-notice day liquidation of January contracts tended to ease the near month, March displayed pronounced resistance.

ROME, Dec. 21. -- Well informed Italian circles expressed rather naive surprise this evening at what they term "the unnecessary fuss made by the world's Jewish press" over the flogging of two Jews in Tripoli and the imprisonment of another for three months for refusing to keep their shops open Saturdays.

The New York Rovers, playing their fourth game in four days, defeated the Yale University hockey team in the feature game of a double-header at Madison Square Garden last night. The Rovers, regarded as one of the strongest teams in the Eastern Amateur League, turned back the game New Haven aggregation by the score of 7 to 2.
The American Olympic Committee is not only out of the red but has more than $10,000 in the bank for the new year.

SELSEY, England, Dec. 21. -- Mrs. Marie Schemeder, the aviatrix from Villacoublay who left a French pilot with a bullet in his skull and flew away to England, slept soundly tonight in a farm girl's night dress.

Miss Mary F. Whalen, who learned stenography when it was taught only by a few expensive private tutors in New York City, and practiced it for forty-six years and one month in the offices of the Manhattan Railway Company, has been retired as of Jan. 1.

ALBANY, Dec. 21. -- The appointment of Justice Thomas F. Noonan of New York City as a Justice of the Supreme Court to fill the vacancy in the First Judicial District caused by the death of Justice John L. Walsh was announced by the Governor today.

With a number of companies that dropped advertising during the depression slated to resume campaigns and with account changes expected to be more numerous than usual, the prospects of new business for advertising agencies during the coming year are very bright, according to comment here yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21. -- Indiana University continued its winning streak by handing Villanova a 43-28 beating at the Arena tonight in the first part of the opening basketball double-header of the season before 5,000 fans. It was the fifth straight victory for the Hoosiers and closed their Eastern tour.

A strike by B.M.T. bus drivers in Brooklyn was sanctioned yesterday by the executive board of the Amalgamated Association of Street and Electric Railway and Motor Coach Operators, meeting in Detroit. This action was transmitted to the local organization of the amalgamated, which had set a strike of drivers of 635 B.M.T. buses for late tomorrow or early Thursday.

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- Business was slack on the Stock Exchange here today because of the approach of the holidays, but prices in most departments were steady. British Government securities moved within narrow limits.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the proposed transfer for $125,000 of the membership of C. Douglas Dillon to Joseph V. Perry, who, if elected, will become a partner in Cowen Co.

The referee's side of basketball was the principal topic of discussion at the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association luncheon yesterday at the Lincoln Hotel. Dave Tobey, well known Eastern official and Dick Bray, Cincinnati arbiter who has worked mostly in the Middle West, were the principal speakers.

PETER NORBECK was no boaster, but he did feel proud of being "the only well digger in the Senate." That occupation made the Norwegian minister's son almost a scriptural character, even if artesian wells are more difficult and scientific than those known to ISAAC and his servants.

NANKING, China, Tuesday, Dec. 22. -- W.H. Donald, Australian adviser to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, said upon his return from Sian, Shensi Province, yesterday that the outlook for early release of the generalissimo was hopeful, but several formidable obstacles remained to be overcome.

Salomon Brothers Hutzler obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $5,000,000 of short-term notes of the city of Boston, at a 0.80 per cent interest basis, plus a premium of $90. The notes, which will be dated Dec. 23, 1936, and become payable on Nov. 3, 1937, were reoffered on a 0.70 per cent interest basis.

DETROIT, Dec. 21. -- A conference with William S. Knudsen, vice president of General Motors Corporation, to discuss collective bargaining was asked today by Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers, in a telegram which said that a "crisis" in labor conditions made it necessary.

If only the skill of the actors and the motives of the author were to be acknowledged here, it would be a pleasant task to review "Aged 26," which was put on at the Lyceum last evening. The author is Anne Crawford Flexner, who dramatized "Mrs. Wiggs of the Cabbage Patch" these many years ago.

Mr. and Mrs. George Roberts of New York and East Hampton gave a tea dance yesterday in the ballroom of the Colony Club to introduce their daughter, Miss Constance Middleton Roberts. Mr. and Mrs. Roberts, together with Mr. and Mrs. James Duane Pell, will give a dinner dance Dec. 29 at the Pierre for their daughters, Miss Roberts and Miss Anne DeW. Pell.

" Take It Away," the forty-eighth annual production of the Princeton Triangle Club, made its New York debut last night at the Jolson Theatre, before a delighted audience of Princeton men, old and young, and their sweethearts, wives and daughters, who received it with uproarious acclaim.
Baron Gottfried von Cramm of Germany is placed ahead of Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif., in Frederick J. Perry's ranking of the world's ten leading amateur tennis players.

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- The long-expected reduction of the British Legation at Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, to a consulate-general was officially announced by the Foreign Office here today, after Sir Eric Drummond, the British Ambassador in Rome, had informed the Italian Government of the proposed change.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Victor and vanquished in the Presidential election swapped fishing stories today when President Roosevelt entertained Governor Landon of Kansas at the White House for an hour. There were reports that they also discussed economic conditions and the problems facing the country, but there was no affirmation from either of them.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP). -- A story of how a Supreme Court justice ran afoul of a law designed to give the nation's ducks a new deal came to light today.

RALEIGH. N.C., Dec. 21. -- Dr. Frank P. Graham, president of the Greater University of North Carolina, late today announced "a reorganization of the athletic set-up" at North Carolina State College here and a few hours later Dave Clark, alumni representative on the athletic council, announced at Charlotte he would test Dr. Graham's authority in the courts. State is a unit of the university.

Among the contributions to the Hundred Neediest Cases, many in the list published yesterday were in memory of those who, dear to the donors, cannot make gifts for themselves. Were they living they would no doubt be themselves receiving gifts and making them at this season.

Insisting that only through conservative and sound business administration can lasting profits be withdrawn from the post-depression period, The Management Review, published by the American Management Association, called upon business executives yesterday not to base expansion moves on "the easy profits of the day."

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 21. -- Twenty-six lengths behind the pace after the field had traveled three furlongs of the mile and a sixteenth journey, Mrs. Emil Denemark's chestnut 5-year-old, Chasar, turned on a mighty effort to win the Charity Day Handicap from seven other Class C horses today at Tropical Park.
MADRID, Dec. 21. -- Government troops strengthened new positions west of the capital today on a twelve-mile front touching the snow-capped Guadarrama Mountains at the north end.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- The joint resolution of 1934 which authorized the President to proclaim embargoes of arms and munitions against Bolivia and Paraguay, the combatants in the Chaco war, was upheld by the Supreme Court today in a decision drawing a sharp distinction between the right of Congress to delegate power to the Executive in foreign and domestic fields.

A verdict for $100,000 damages for the death of a locomotive engineer employed by the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad was returned against that company yesterday by a jury before Federal Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- The violent splitting of the earth's surface in El Salvador, with a loss of life and property greater than in any similar disaster for seventy years, was more than an earthquake -- more than a human tragedy -- to those service men, diplomats and engineers who are responsible for the national defense of the United States.

An issue of $20,000,000 of first mortgage twenty-year 4 per cent bonds, Series C, due on Jan. 1, 1957, of Armour Co. of Delaware, today will be offered to the public by a banking syndicate headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co. and including the First Boston Corporation, Brown Harriman Co., Inc.; Edward B. Smith Co., Blyth Co., Inc.; the Lee Higginson Corporation and associates.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 21.-- Quiet has fallen over the struggle between Glenn Frank, president of the University of Wisconsin, and the Board of Regents which seeks to oust him from the office he has held for more than eleven years. The calm is deceptive.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- The new Era of Good Feeling was officially launched on a sea of satire tonight at the Willard Hotel when the Gridiron Club, at its semi-annual dinner, lampooned contemporary events and personalities in the presence of the four principal Presidential candidates at the last election.
Several important works of art have been bought from dealers here by the Art Institute of Chicago.

Testimony in a hearing in which the Interborough Rapid Transit Company is accused of discharging heavy smoke from its power house at 600 West Fifty-ninth Street, at Eleventh Avenue, in violation of Section 211 of the Sanitary Code, disclosed yesterday that for more than seven months "dense, black smoke" was seen almost daily to pour from the power plant's towering chimneys and deposit soot in a public school building a block away.

CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE, N.J., Dec. 21. -- The vote of at least one dead man was cast in the election of a State Senator from Cape May County last Nov. 3, it was revealed today when the hearing before Judge Jayne in Circuit Court here of charges of vote frauds was resumed.
POTTSVILLE, Pa., Dec. 21. -- Governor Earle called upon the civic leaders of Schuylkill County today to tell him a just solution for the problem of bootleg mining, but they failed him.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Tuesday, Dec. 22. -- Thirty-two American Rhodes scholars, four of whom are from Princeton University, were elected yesterday by eight district committees which met in as many cities to interview nominees chosen last week by State committees.

I read with interest THE TIMES editorial on the proposed Traffic Code. As was invited by the Traffic Committee of the Board to draft the bill under its supervision, I hope you will not consider a brief statement from me as to its plan and scope out of place.

The three five-story houses at 32-36 East-Fifty-third Street, with a frontage of forty-one feet, have been acquired by Benjamin Winter, operator, who expects to tear down the present buildings and erect a two-story business structure there.

A group of twenty underwriters headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will offer today an issue of $27,500,000 of first mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds, due in 1966, of the Houston Lighting and Power Company. The bonds will be priced at 103 and accrued interest.
TOKYO, Dec. 21. -- Seldom in times of peace have any two countries conducted so ferocious a war of words as is now raging between Japan and Soviet Russia.
AKRON, Ohio, Dec. 21 (AP). -- Five members of the Stenographers, Bookkeepers. Typists and Assistants Union 19,266 gave the rubber workers' union a lesson in staging a sit-down strike today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP). -- Cotton of this year's growth ginned before Dec. 13 was reported by the Census Bureau today to have been 11,704,980 running bales, including 271,195 round bales, counted as half bales, and 12,260 bales of American-Egyptian.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 21. -- Mr. and Mrs. J. Jay O'Brien gave a dinner tonight at Villa Del Sarmiento, where Captain Alastair Mackintosh arrived today from London.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21. -- Thirty-four members of the University of Pennsylvania football team which won seven of eight games received varsity letters, according to an announcement made today by Dr. E. Le Roy Mercer, dean of the Department of Physical Education. This was six more than last year.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 21.-- Seventy-six members of the WPA camp at North Haledon who voted in the last general election, did so illegally, it was ruled today by Judge Joseph G. Wolber of the Passaic County Circuit Court. The court declared that such camps are of a temporary nature and hence none of the members could have any intention of making it their permanent home.
Cash dividend declarations announced yesterday amounted to $15,000,000, increasing the total for this month thus far to $371,000,000. Since Nov. 1, disbursements voted aggregate $1,254,200,000.

With sales gains practically universal, retailers and wholesalers in the grocery industry experienced the best week's business in eight months last week, according to reports gathered from all parts of the country by the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc.

A tentative proposal for settlement of the demands of Pacific Coast sailors who have been on strike fifty-three days was submitted last night to the San Francisco local union. Shipping men expected that a favorable vote would be taken, setting the stage for settlement of the demands of all striking maritime unions, but after the meeting it was announced that no vote had been taken.

Where is the great increase in the amount of installment buying going to bring us? Almost every store welcomes charge accounts and deferred payments. Finance companies are advertising the advantages of buying out of income. Loan companies are telling the public how easy it is to borrow money.
BERLIN, Dec. 21. -- National Socialism, which is making over all things in Germany to new patterns all its own, is putting a new face on Christmas.

In deciding to "sterilize" gold imports the Treasury has taken a course which was urged by Wall Street bankers six months ago and has since been actively discussed in financial circles as a means of meeting the problem of unwanted expansion of the credit base here through large imports of gold from abroad.

In deciding to borrow funds from the market with which to purchase imported gold, the Treasury is pursuing the course that has been followed by the British Equalization Account and is, incidentally, taking the advice that was given to it six months ago by S. Sloan Colt, president of the Bankers Trust Company, and Murray Shields, economist of the Irving Trust Company.

The Lincoln Cathedral Choir, which first came upon the national scene last Christmas Eve, when, at the White House, they intoned President Roosevelt's Christmas greeting on the radio networks with him during its first tour of cathedrals and concert halls, began its second pilgrimage to he East last night, its fifty-five members leaving Lincoln, Neb., for New York by train.

Louis H. Seagrave, former head of the United Founders Corporation group of investment companies and now chairman of the board of the American General Corporation, into which they were merged, testified yesterday in Supreme Court in the trial before Justice Louis A. Valente of a stockholders' suit against American Founders and other defendants, including Mr. Seagrave.

The youngest La Guardia, aged 6, unwittingly ran afoul of his male parent's ideas of propriety yesterday by asking for a gun as one of his Christmas presents, and was treated forthwith to a splendid example of Mayor La Guardia's veto power.
Contracts for the design of three buildings of the New York World's Fair of 1939 were awarded to architects yesterday by the fair corporation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Internal revenue collections for the first five months of the 1937 fiscal year amounted to $1,385,767,927, an increase of $163,981,867, while for November, receipts were $176,525,695, a decrease of $7,570,620 from November, 1935, the Internal Revenue Bureau announced today.

LONDON, Dec. 21 (AP). -- A picture of the whole world plunged into a naval race the moment the treaty lid is off Jan. 1 was drawn tonight in the new Jane's Fighting Ships. Old Washington and London naval treaties expire on the last day of the year.

BERLIN, Dec. 21. -- The Boerse generally was buoyant today, as reinvestment funds were liquidated from foreign securities. Gains of several points were frequent and even the turnover was somewhat larger than it had been lately.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 21. -- The British Royal Commission came here to try to find a solution of Arab-Jewish differences and is not prepared to deal with differences solely between Jews, declared Earl Peel at today's session.

Ninety per cent control of motion-picture sound recording and reproducing equipment was held by Electrical Research Products, Inc., as early as 1927. John E. Otterson, former president of the organization, testified yesterday at a hearing before the Federal Communications Commission at 45 Broadway.

BERLIN, Dec. 21. -- A curious light was thrown on the German-Japanese pact today by a public announcement that German industry had concluded a deal with the Chinese Railway Administration providing for the delivery on credit of 40,000,000 Chinese dollars' worth of German railway material.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- The Federal Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia today reversed the action of the National Mediation Board in issuing an order designating the eligibility of voters in a labor dispute election without holding hearings on the questions involved.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 21. -- The slight illness of Secretary of State Cordell Hull, who stayed in bed yesterday and today with a cold and a fever, is holding up among other things a decision as to whether he will announce before leaving Buenos Aires that negotiations for a reciprocal trade agreement with Argentina will soon be commenced.

Two freighters, the 3,700-ton Malang and the 5,550-ton Flomar, went aground in New York waters last night. The first, inbound from Buckport, Me., with woodpulp, stuck fast at the north end of Welfare Island, in the East River. The larger Flomar, in tow and outbound for Baltimore with a cargo of iron, grounded at the north side of the main channel near Sandy Hook. She was floated at high tide about 2 o'clock this morning.

That is an ambitious road-building program which Colonel Greene announces. To quote two sentences "Four-lane highways for most of the roads, and six-lane ones to be built when needed, are features of the plan. Safety lanes, or parkways, would be established in the middle of each four-lane road to divide traffic."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- The Supreme Court's ruling on the arms embargo was as follows:

The issuing of automobile license plates for 1937 began in New York yesterday, and Deputy Commissioner I. James Brody, in charge of the Motor Vehicle Bureau's local headquarters at 155 Worth Street, estimated that the first-day rush of applicants equaled, if it did not exceed, that of last year, when 15,500 plates were issued in the city.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 21. -- Stephen Hynes, a New Rochelle gardener, serving as foreman of a jury in a civil action in the Supreme Court here today, when asked to give the jury's verdict, replied, "Guilty as charged."

Billy Beauhold, Jersey City lightweight, kept his record as a professional fighter unblemished last night at the St. Nicholas Palace, gaining a draw in a spirited eight-round battle with Lew Feldman of Brownsville, before a crowd of about 3,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight that the tenders for two series of Treasury bills, to be dated Dec. 23, which were offered on Friday, amounted to $208,242,000 and that $100,082,000 had been accepted.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Abolition of child labor and a thirty-hour week were among the labor proposals suggested today by leaders of sixty international unions summoned to a conference by Secretary Perkins.

The view that it "may be well to economize government in business in order similarly to minimize the necessary eounterpart -- business in government," according to a study of cooperation and control in the re- tail trade by Dr. Ruth Prince Mack, formerly complaint adjuster with the Retail Code Authority of New York City, publication of which was announced yesterday by the Colum- bia University Press.

HAVANA, Tuesday, Dec. 22. -- A petition of accusations against President Miguel Mariano Gomez, which will bring him before the Senate in an impeachment trial, was approved by the House of Representatives this morning by a vote of 111 to 45.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Members of Congress arriving here daily for the forthcoming session are asking whether industry can absorb the still large number of unemployed so that the Federal Government may retire from "this business of relief."

Eleven eminent scientists of the United States and foreign countries were admitted to honorary membership in the New York Academy of Arts and Sciences, oldest scientific society in New York City, at the 118th annual meeting of the academy, held last night at the Hotel New Yorker.

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- Myles Standish, descendant of his famous namesake who is celebrated in Longfellow's poem, today became the first foreign service officer of the United States to be married under the State Department's restrictions made public Dec. 1.
NANKING, China, Dec. 21. -- The Japanese Ambassador, Shigeru Kawagoe, conferred for two hours today with Foreign Minister Chang Chun.

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- As a gesture of good-will to the new King and as an expression of confidence in the Baldwin government, Lord Nuffield, wealthy motor-car manufacturer, announced today a gift of 2,000,000 for the relief of areas of the British Isles reduced to virtual economic ruin by protracted unemployment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- The meaning of the word "interest" as it pertains to payments by member banks of the Federal Reserve System on deposits was defined today by the Federal Reserve Board in a regulation which will become effective on Feb. 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- The Household Finance Corporation of Chicago filed today a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 180,000 shares of $100 par, preferred stock and preferred-stock scrip, and 90,000 shares of no-par common and common-stock scrip, to be used in exchanges of stock and for reduction of bank loans.

" The policeman's lot is not a happy one," sing the Savoyards, but the New York cop, like the London bobby, is such a cheerful fellow, famous for his upstanding figure, his rough and ready humor and his casual expertness in keeping us alive and moving in the heaviest traffic jam in the world, that we often forget the risks he takes.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21 (AP). -- Collegiate football stars of the East and West enjoyed a final round of uncensored menus today before starting the training grind tomorrow for the annual New Year's day charity classic here.

Martin (Buggsy) Goldstein, 30-year-old reputed racketeer, and his bodyguard, Seymour Magoon, 30, recently sentenced to Sing Sing Prison on charges of coercion and conspiracy, won a new trial yesterday through an order handed down by Justice Henry G. Wenzel in Supreme Court in Queens.

Steve (Crusher) Casey, Irish newcomer to the American wrestling circuit, defeated Gino Garibaldi of Italy in the feature bout at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory last night before a crowd of 2,000. Casey weighed 230 pounds and Garibaldi 216.
With throngs of package-laden shoppers crowding the stores, Christmas trade here rose to the highest levels of the season yesterday.

Princeton defeated Dartmouth by 3 -- 1 and Harvard took a 2-1 lead over Yale in the first round of the annual championship tournament of the H.Y.P.D. College Chess League for the Belden-Stephens Trophy at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday.

What do the increasingly enthusiastic reports of the return of the eel grass mean? Do the beds, so promising in the Spring, continue to produce leaves, stems and seeds through the Summer and Fall to an extent that it is of significance as food for migratory water fowl?
ENZESFELD, Austria, Dec. 21 (AP). -- The way was opened tonight for the Duke of Windsor to participate more actively in Austria's social life. The former King's wardrobe arrived from London.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Twenty-eight junior members of the Diplomatic Corps, ranking in age from 4 to 13 years, broadcast Christmas messages in the language of the twenty-three countries they represented at the fourth annual International Children's Party held this afternoon at the Shoreham Hotel.
A gift of $20,000 from the New York Telephone Company to the United Hospital Campaign was announced last night by Stuart M. Crocker, chairman of the drive.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Dec. 22. -- General Chang Hsueh-liang's revolt, which started with the seizure of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek on Dec. 12, has spread throughout virtually all of Kansu Province, it was learned today.

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- Under the glare of Klieg lights and a battery of news cameras Haile Selassie's collection of English and foreign silver, which once adorned the palace at Harar, Ethiopia, was put on the block at Puttick Simpson's auction rooms today.

SYDNEY, Australia, Tuesday, Dec. 22 (Canadian Press). -- Australian batsmen enjoyed more success today in their second innings of the second test cricket match with England, compiling 309 runs for the loss of five wickets at the tea hour.

Former Riverdale fencers, now sporting the colors of Dartmouth and Princeton, were outstanding in the first invitation fencing meet conducted by the Riverdale Country School for secondary schools and college freshmen yesterday.

PRETTY soon the boys will be packing their duds and heading South for the launching of another baseball training season. The Yankees, moving perhaps more by instinct than anything else, will again assemble at St. Petersburg. They have been going to St. Pete for so many years no one can remember readily when they trained anywhere else.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederic G. Clark gave a dinner dance last night in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton to introduce to society Mrs. Clark's daughter, Miss Sibyl Young Hine. Tall standards of pink roses and smilax used in the decorations had transformed the ballroom into a garden.

ALBANY, Dec. 21. -- Continuing his tour of the State to become acquainted with county chairmen, William S Murray. Republican State Chairman, came to Albany today and conferred with Irving M. Ives, Speaker of the Assembly; Ansley Borkowski, Clerk of the Assembly; Hugh Boyden of the Assembly, and Charles C. Wing, County Chairman.

The Metropolitan Opera Association, Edward Johnson, general director, opened its 1936-37 season last night with one of the greatest music-dramas in the repertory, though not one commonly considered the most appropriate for a first-night offering.

The offices of sixteen garage owners associations and their chambers of commerce in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx were raided simultaneously at 11 A.M. yesterday by police detectives and investigators from the office of State Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr.

The Brooklyn Young Republican Club, meeting last night in the Towers Hotel. Brooklyn, adopted a resolution calling for the resignations of Charles D. Hilles and Mrs. Ruth Pratt as members of the Republican National Committee.

MADRID, Dec. 21. -- It was quiet on the Madrid front today, but yesterday's counter-attack by government troops west of the city appears to have been successful. The Insurgents lost some ground that they had gained in recent fighting and they abandoned six tanks, which Loyalist troops captured.
A Russian screen transcription of the Ukrainian operetta, "Natalka Poltavaka," will have its American premiere tonight at the Roose velt Theatre, Second Avenue and Houston Street.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 21. -- Represented by Julius S. Rippel of Newark, a banker, a minority group of stockholders today won a stay on an initial dividend to creditors of the New Jersey Fidelity and Plate Glass Insurance Company, whose affairs have been in the hands of the State Department of Banking and Insurance since May, 1932.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, continuing today its study of investment trusts and investment companies, disclosed that of the more than 5,000,000 shares of common stock issued by the Equity Corporation of New York only 204,000 shares were sold for cash.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- A public hearing was called today for Jan. 11 by the Securities and Exchange Commission on the application of Middlewest Corporation of Chicago for aproval of the acquisition of 4,248 shares of $1 par value common stock of the United Public Service Corporation, now held by the Middlewest Utilities Company of Canada, Ltd., a wholly owned subsidiary of the applicant.

In a setting reminiscent of semi-tropical Mexico. Miss Mary Rand Birch was introduced to society last night at a dinner dance given by her father, Stephen Birch of New York and Mahwah, N.J., in the roof garden of the Waldorf-Astoria. The entrance to the garden had been transformed into an avenue of coconut palms. Sago palms, Spanish moss, oleanders, hibiscus and Southern smilax decorated the roof garden.
SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 21 (AP). -- The wreckage of one of the two airliners missing in the Far West was reported sighted from the air today.

For a petty theft he committed in Italy when he was 14 years old, Salvatore Branchicella, a 33-year-old cobbler of Mamaroneck, N.Y., who has lived in the United States for sixteen years, eleven of which have been with his wife, faces deportation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Oberlin M. Carter, one-time army engineer, who characterized himself as another Dreyfus, must appeal to Congress to remove the stain of a dishonorable discharge from his record, Justice Joseph W. Cox ruled today in district court.

For finishing sixth in the American League pennant race after being among the red-hot choices to win it, the Boston Red Sox gained the dubious distinction of performing the biggest "floperoo" of the year.

Every year, just at this season, the Knoedler Galleries bring out a group of their Italian and Flemish primitives. It contains some delightful little panels, several of which have become old and valued friends.

Commodity futures were irregular in quiet trading yesterday, with the metals buoyant in the face of pre-holiday apathy. Rubber, hides and cocoa futures eased slightly and sugar, silk and wool tops were moderately higher. On the cash markets wheat and rye advanced and lead and wool tops made new highs.

Led by Captain Herb Rubin, who tallied 14 points, the Theodore Roosevelt basketball team scored a 30-to-16 triumph over Morris yesterday in an Upper Manhattan-Bronx P.S.A.L. contest in the Roosevelt gymnasium. It was the first triumph in four games for the winners and marked the third straight defeat of Morris in league competition.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 21. -- The Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace devoted a large part of its last plenary session today to formulating a new economic policy for the American nations as an important part of the machinery it has set up for preserving permanent peace in this hemisphere.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 21. -- The 1937 Westchester County budget, setting a tax rate of about $4.52 on each $1,000 of assessed valuation, or 55 cents more than the 1936 figure, was filed today with the Board of Supervisors by the committee on budget and appropriation and made a special order of business for next Monday.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 22 (Tuesday). -- At the first meeting of special session of the New Jersey Legislature, which began last evening and lasted until 1:30 o'clock this morning, an Unemployment Compensation Bill similar to the New York law and allowing the State to qualify for a rebate of $10,000,000 in Federal payroll taxes, was passed by both Houses.
Although the winning of the pennant by the Giants was generally attributed to their fine defensive play, Bill Terry's champions did not carry off the National League's fielding honors for 1936.
Miss Barbara Feigenspan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin C. Feigenspan of Newark and Bedminster, N.J., was presented to society last night at a supper dance given by her parents in the St. Regis Roof.

PARIS, Dec. 21 (AP). -- Suzanne Linder, the mother of two children, sat in a cell in the Paris women's prison tonight, across the capital from the jail that held the man for whom she was accused of having falsified French documents in an alleged arms smuggling plot.

The alertness of a truck driver returned a baby to its mother yesterday and brought about the arrest of the alleged kidnapper within twenty minutes after the child was taken from in front of a Brooklyn 5 and 10 cent store.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- The Kroger Grocery and Baking Company lost in the Supreme Court today a fight against an order of the Indiana Milk Control Board eliminating the differential between cash-and-carry and delivered milk prices.
The opera "faithful" -- those who don't mind standing in line for hours to earn the right to stand throughout the opening performance -- were on hand earlier than usual yesterday.

Members of the New York City Housing Authority, investigating the "poor man's housing shortage," listened yesterday to a proposal that government-subsidized limited-dividend companies embark on a program of rehabilitating old slum dwellings instead of replacing them completely with new structures.

Louis F. Sailer, vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, will retire on Dec. 31, having reached the retirement age of 65 years under the system of the Federal Reserve Banks announced in August.

Commissioner Valentine launched an inquiry yesterday into the absence of police in the vicinity of the Hotel Plaza just before dawn on Sunday morning when the French automobile manufacturer, Emile E.C. Mathis, routed two hold-up men in a rough-and-tumble fight to the accompaniment of his wife's screams as she sat in a taxicab.

After a fair show of strength early in the day, the stock market moved irregularly easier yesterday and became progressively weaker in the afternoon. Closing prices approximated the lowest levels of the day. Selling was unhurried but support for most stock groupings lagged.
Mayor La Guardia told the four men he has designated as thirty-day magistrates yesterday that they represented the type of public official developed under the present administration.
Miss Shirley Anne Weadock was introduced to society at a tea dance given by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Francis Weadock, yesterday at the Pierre.

The Metropolitan Opera launched its fifty-fourth year and fifty-second regular season last night with one of the masterpieces of the repertory, Richard Wagner's "Die Walkuere." It was an unconventional union -- behind the footlights, the exalted beauty of a great music-drama, and in the corridors and auditorium, the pomp and circumstance of the opera's first night.

MEXICO, D. F., Dec. 21. -- A Mexi- i can Congressman is believed dying, two persons are dead and another was wounded in a gun fight in front of the Capitol, where Congress was in session. About 100 { shots were fired on a corner in the heart of this city just at the evening rush hour.

The story of Jewish refugees from Germany is as familiar as it is pitiful. Now it appears that many Christian families, of unimpeachable Aryan descent, are fleeing or preparing to flee from religious persecution in Germany. To most people in the United States this will come as a surprise.

The New York Curb Exchange announced yesterday that approximately 260 pages, quotation clerks and reporters employed on the trading floor would receive on Jan 1 wage increases ranging from 6 to 11 per cent. The advance resulted from a wage study made by a special committee of the Exchange's board of governors which will be continued.

SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador, Dec. 21. -- The deaths in the earthquake that wrecked the city of San Vicente on Saturday night mounted to 250 today as the search of the ruins for bodies continued. The number of injured rose to 1,000.

There was little change in the character of bond trading yesterday from the closing sessions of last week. That the effect of the decision of the Interstate Commerce Commission to terminate the freight surcharges on Dec. 31 had not run its course was reflected by further selling pressure against a broad list of railroad obligations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- A memorandum setting forth New York State's objection to a rehearing on the State's Unemployment Insurance Law has been submitted to the Supreme Court. The court held the act constitutional in a 4-4 decision recently.

YESTERDAY the papers ran a story about Nicholas Murray Butler's annual report to the trustees of Columbia University. According to these accounts, Dr. Buffer feels that improper taxation may either cripple or destroy our "most respected, most beloved and most successful institutions of public service in the field of liberty" -- i.e., the colleges and universities dependent for their income and endowment upon personal benefactions.

The premiere performance last night of the Metropolitan Opera for the season of 1936-37 drew a distinguished audience representative of social, diplomatic and artistic circles of this nation and other countries.

The first of the storm-buffeted Atlantic fleet to arrive here was the Anchor liner Transylvania from Glasgow via Belfast, which docked at 4 P.M. yesterday, twenty-four hours late. She lost her fifty-five-foot foretopmast radio pole at 6 P.M. Tuesday in a hurricane from the westward.

ROME, Dec. 21. -- Arrangements were completed today for the visit Premier Mussolini's daughter, Countess Edda Ciano, will pay to America in January and February, accompanied by Marquis Leonardo Vitetti and his wife, the former Natalie Mai Coe of Long Island.

POTTSVILLE, Pa., Dec. 21. -- Attorney General Charles J. Margiotti charged tonight that the Schuylkill County Commissioners were hampering the State's investigation of county prison conditions that led to the escape on Friday of Joseph J. Bruno, serving a life term for murder.
Two new members were elected to the board of trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art at yesterday's meeting.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Brig. Gen. David L. Brainard, retired, last survivor of General Greely's Arctic Expedition of 1881-84, celebrated his eightieth birthday here today and became the first honorary member of the American Polar Society.

Bearing out predictions that late holiday shopping would be heavy, department store executives here reported that trade forged ahead sharply yesterday, following the sharp upturn in sales last Saturday. Comparison with the same days last year cannot be accurately made, due to the difference in number of days between the week-end and Christmas this year, as against 1935.

VATICAN CITY, Dec. 21. -- Pope Pius has decided to broadcast a brief Christmas message to the world the day before Christmas. He will speak, as usual, either in Latin or in Italian, but his words probably will be repeated immediately afterward in the principal languages.

The 1936 nominating committee of the New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday its official slate of twenty-one nominees for the seven places on the 1937 committee to be filled at an election on Jan. 11.
