The new committee will select the regular ticket of officers to be voted on in the Exchange's annual election on May 10, 1937.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21. -- Prices of wheat in the leading markets in North America fluctuated in an erratic manner today, declining early in sympathy with Liverpool, rallying sharply later on buying attributed to millers and then reacting, to close with net losses of 1/8 to 3/8 cent a bushel on the Board of Trade here.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 21. -- Civic-minded Pasadena decided to make the best of it today and share temporarily the glory of its famous Rose Bowl football attraction with two Southern California neighbors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP). -- The War Department announced today plans of the Commissioner of Plant and Structures in New York City for a temporary foot bridge across Sheepshead Bay at Nineteenth Street, Brooklyn.

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 21. -- That Mexico will attempt to negotiate a settlement of its funded foreign debt of some $267,000,000 appeared likely tonight after the Chamber of Deputies had voted to President Cardenas special powers in Treasury matters.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP). -- A Winter wheat crop of "slightly over 600,000,000 bushels" next year was estimated by the Agriculture Department today in reporting that seeded acreage this Fall was "by far the largest of record."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Representative William Lemke of North Dakota, Union party Presidential candidate in November, won in the Supreme Court today the promise of a review of the constitutionality of the amended Frazier-Lemke Farm Mortgage Moratorium Act passed by Congress after the court rejected the original law in 1934.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 21. -- Tallulah Bankhead arrived at the Selznick International studios early today from New York to undergo screen tests for the part of Scarlett O'Hara in "Gone With the Wind." Miss Bankhead has been reported slated for the role ever since the novel was purchased, but has always disclaimed any knowledge of such casting.

With an entry of 151 youngsters, the most representative group ever to participate in the fixture, the draw for the annual national indoor junior and boys' singles championships was announced at the offices of the United States Lawn Tennis Association yesterday.
The prospect of a happy Christmas and a new year of renewed hope grew more dim for many of the Neediest yesterday as the Fund again dropped behind as compared with a year ago.

A committee for holders of $19,200,000 of New York, Westchester Boston Railway 4 1/2 per cent bonds of 1946, guaranteed by the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, announced yesterday a plan of reorganization for the transit line, which is in bankruptcy.

Delighted at the conviction of his client, Edgar P. Feeley, an attorney of 586 City Island Avenue, the Bronx, announced yesterday that he would appeal the case in the hope that the superior courts would uphold the decision adverse to his client, which had been handed down by Magistrate William Klapp in Bronx Traffic Court.

The directors of the New York County Criminal Courts Bar Association, at a meeting behind closed doors yesterday in the Central Municipal Court at 8 Reade Street, designated three members to investigate complaints against the conduct of Magistrate Overton Harris on the bench.

ROME, Dec. 21. -- Today's action of Britain and France in giving de facto recognition to the Italian conquest of Ethiopia has created an excellent impression in Italy. The move opens the way for a resumption of full Italian cooperation with Britain and France and, what is even more important, it heralds Italy's return to Geneva, for it is deemed evident here that Ethiopia cannot continue in the League of Nations very much longer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Secretary Henry Morgenthau Jr. today announced a new policy whereby the Treasury will buy outright and sterilize newly mined and imported gold and not allow it to become a basis for new bank credits through the Federal Reserve System.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Mrs. Roosevelt gave her fourth "Gridiron Widows Party" tonight for about 400, including the wives of members of the Gridiron Club and women officials and newspaper writers.

MOSCOW, Dec. 21. -- The Soviet decision not to hold the genetics congress scheduled for 1937 was confirmed today by Izvestia, chief government organ. It states the congress "has been postponed for some time at the request of a number of scientists who have expressed a wish to extend their preparation for the congress."

The plea of workers in the Emergency Relief Bureau for a court order restraining the Municipal Civil Service Commission from holding competitive tests for ERB jobs went to trial yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag.

Mrs. Poe White gave an old-fashioned reception yesterday afternoon at her home, 21 East Fifty-fifth Street, to introduce to society her niece, Miss Polly Poe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles K. Poe of Seattle, and her god-daughter, Miss Lorraine Littlefield, daughter of Mrs. William L. Littlefield of Washington, D.C., and the late Captain Littlefield.
United States Department of Agriculture reat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

They will be putting on "All Editions" this evening at the Longacre, that same "All Editions" which is the work of Charles Washburn and Clyde North and which tells the story of a carnival spieler turned high-powered public relations expert.

They will be putting on "All Editions" this evening at the Longacre, that same "All Editions" which is the work of Charles Washburn and Clyde North and which tells the story of a carnival spieler turned high-powered public relations expert.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- The Roosevelt-Litvinoff agreement of 1933 by which the United States Government recognized Soviet Russia will be discussed before the Supreme Court in a case where the government seeks to obtain $25,438 deposited by the Czaristic regime with August Belmont Co.
It is getting to be a world in which almost any day now Governments may issue a decree prohibiting surrealism, or the Culbertson system, or the 5-3-3 formation for a plunge between guard and tackle.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 21 (AP). -- An impressive field of twenty-three was nominated today for the $5,000-added Christmas Day Stakes, feature race of Santa Anita's opening on Friday.
VIENNA, Dec. 21. -- Serious difficulties over the Nazi question have again risen in the Austrian Cabinet and they may cause some Cabinet changes.

Dr. and Mrs. Hugh Auchincloss and Dr. and Mrs. Albert R. Lamb jointly gave a large dinner dance last night in the Roof Garden of the Pierre to introduce to society their daughters, Miss Barbara Auchincloss and Miss Priscilla Lamb.

The President follows a custom hallowed in many families of reading the "Christmas Carol" aloud on Christmas Eve. At least one reader of THE TIMES has suggested that he take the nation into the family and read DICKENS'S immortal Christmas tale over the radio.

Net profit of the Madison Square Garden Corporation and wholly owned subsidiaries in the three months ended on Nov. 30 amounted to $137,447 after depreciation. Federal income taxes and other charges. The profit, which is equivalent to 48 cents each on the 286,900 shares of stock outstanding, compares with $62,554, or 22 cents each on 281,900 shares then outstanding, for the corresponding period last year.

The first step to provide an adequate pension system for public library employes in the city was taken yesterday at a conference of a special Board of Estimate committee and representatives of the three city library systems held in the offices of Controller Frank J. Taylor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- A radio dramatization last night of the forced landing of an Eastern Air Lines airplane near Port Jervis, N.Y., Saturday, was criticized in a telegram today by Captain Eddie Rickenbacker, vice president in charge of operations of the air line, to J. Monroe Johnson, Assistant Secretary of Commerce.

In an indictment handed by the Federal grand jury to Judge Mortimer W. Byers in United States District Court in Brooklyn yesterday, six men were charged with conspiracy to defraud the government of $5,600 by presenting false bills for lumber alleged to have been delivered to the WPA furniture factory at 67 Bolivar Street, Brooklyn.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 22. -- Army engineers announced here today, following a conference of Pennsylvania and New York flood-control authorities, that construction of the first flood-control projects in Pennsylvania could be started by Spring.
Tomorrow is Christmas Eve -- and still scores of the Neediest of all wait for the help that only you can give.

On the basis of expenditures by convention visitors, as reported by the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, the estimate of $1,000,000,000 of new revenue for New York City in 1939 as a result of the World's Fair is conservative, Richard Whitney, chairman of the Fair's Bond Sales Committee, said yesterday.

Six men were arrested yesterday afternoon on eight indictments handed up to General Sessions Judge Collins a short time before in the New York County grand jury's investigation of the so-called garnishee racket, in which hundreds of city employes are said to have been defrauded of about $2,000,000 in recent years.

With New Yorkers going in for the greatest buying rush in years and fattening the city's postoffice receipts with the dispatch of Christmas packages and other greetings to friends elsewhere, the city's public and private philanthropic agencies took steps yesterday to make sure that no child, however unfortunate, would be excluded from the holiday festivities.

In the Viennese Roof Garden of the St. Regis yesterday afternoon Mrs. Livingston Fountain gave a tea dance to introduce her daughter, Miss Marion Decker Fountain. The debutante, who received with her mother, wore a white chiffon gown embroidered with crystal, and carried a bouquet of white orchids.

Albert Stoessel directed the New York Oratorio Society of 350 voices and an orchestra of sixty musicians in the annual holiday performance of Handel's "Messiah" last night at Carnegie Hall. It was the 113th time the classic work was given by the society.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- President Roosevelt today approved promotion of Brig. Gens. John L. De Witt and Harry E. Knight to major general and seven colonels to brigadier general.

Emerging full-sized from the depression doldrums, sport in general is riding the crest of a new boom wave in the opinion of national experts participating in the sixth annual Associated Press sports poll.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 22. -- Smashing Australia by an innings and 22 runs in the second test match today, England needs only one victory in the three remaining international contests to clinch world cricket supremacy.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 22. -- Six weeks after the adoption of the Nassau County budget for 1937, which contained no item involving proposed salary increases, the Nassau County Board of Supervisors approved today pay rises amounting to about $23,000 for seventy-five county employes, most of whom hold their jobs by appointment.

The directors of the Western Electric Company, Inc., declared yesterday a dividend of $1.50 a share, payable on Dec. 28 to stockholders of record of tomorrow. The American Telephone and Telegraph Company owns 99.18 per cent of Western Electric stock.

BERLIN, Dec. 22. -- The Boerse was firm today, with the turnover small. Heavy industrial stocks showed strength, Bruderus gaining 1 point and Harpener 1 1/4 points. Potashes were firm. Among them, Aschesleben climbed 1 point.

Soft-footed proctors, most of them students from Columbia and New York Universities and City College, hired at $4 a day, kept sharp but sympathetic eyes yesterday on 316 police lieutenants taking the civil service examination for captain in the Federal Building Annex at Washington and Christopher Streets.
DETROIT, Dec. 22. -- William S. Sayres Jr., Federal court master in chancery, committed suicide this afternoon by a plunge from the twenty-eighth floor of the Book-Cadillac Hotel.

Although the number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was the smallest for any week this year, the total was above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES. For the week the arrivals were 364, as against 53l in the preceding week and 218 in the same period last year.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 22. -- Judge M.A. Musmanno, remembering the days of his youth and the heartbreak of "there ain't no Santa Claus," clamped down on doubters today and ruled them in contempt of court.
LONDON, Dec. 22. -- The Archbishop of York condemned former King Edward VIII today for his course after falling in love with another man's wife.

While the number of deaths from automobile accidents in the week ended Saturday totaled thirty-three as compared with forty-one the previous week, the rate continued high as is usual during the holiday season, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, announced yesterday.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 22. -- Dr. Glenn Frank, president of the University of Wisconsin, was ordered today by the executive committee of the Board of Regents to appear Jan. 6 to reply to allegations that he is not fitted as a business or educational administrator to retain his office.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 22. -- In this time of crisis in his personal affairs it is probable the public abroad does not realize the important influence of Christianity upon Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's character and official career since his conversion shortly after his marriage.

Four men, three of them armed with pistols, held up and robbed two women cashiers of the Hudson Laundries at 106 Bank Street at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon and escaped with $1,100. The women were Martha Berger of 1,040 De Kalb Avenue, Brooklyn, and Estelle Papier of 817 Sixty-eighth Street, Brooklyn.

Mayor La Guardia should be prevailed upon to stop his attacks on the State Housing Board, Joseph Platzker, secretary of the East Side Chamber of Commerce, told the New York City Housing Authority yesterday as that group continued its hearings on the "poor man's housing shortage."
A little ahead of schedule, St. Nicholas (the movie producer) today will bring three Yuletide offerings into theatres of the midtown sector.

Amy Ellerman, who appeared in recital at the Town Hall last night, is the possessor of a voice that has few peers in this country. It is an opulent, full-blooded contralto, velvety in texture and prodigal in amplitude. For those who can respond to the sheer beauty of a voice as voice, Miss Ellerman's singing is a source of constant pleasure.

MOSCOW, Dec. 22. -- Although the Soviet Government still gave no sign of taking any concrete action as a result of the burning and sinking of the Soviet merchant ship Komsomol, allegedly by a Spanish Rebel cruiser, on Dec. 14, the principal Soviet newspapers blazed out today with bellicose resolutions adopted by mass meetings throughout the Soviet Union.

A frontal assault on the American Bar Association as a reactionary organization representing only a small fraction of the lawyers of the country developed last night at the first open meeting here of the recently organized National Lawyers Guild. About 600 lawyers attended the meeting, which was held at the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

HAVANA, Dec. 22. -- The impeachment trial of President Miguel Mariano Gomez got under way this afternoon when he was cited to appear tomorrow afternoon at 4 o'clock before the Senate sitting as a tribunal under the presidency of the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court, Dr. Juan Federico Edelman.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Dec. 22. -- A family living at the edge of this air field and apprehensive for the last ten years that some day a plane would crash into their home nearly had their fears realized this afternoon when a new $90,000 army bomber fell into their yard just between the residence and a greenhouse.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 22. -- There seem to be reasonable grounds for expecting that the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace will crown its unusually successful deliberations by bringing about a definite settlement of the Chaco dispute between Bolivia and Paraguay.

PORT ARTHUR, Texas, Dec. 22 (AP). -- A young man found hanging from a crude noose at Port Arthur's pleasure pier was identified today as Larry Lothar Glass, 28, missing nephew of a New York manufacturer.

A large luncheon was given by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Henry Drew yesterday at Sherry's to introduce their daughter, Miss Marie Josephine Drew. The debutante, who belongs to the Daughters of the American Revolution, is a descendant of Brig. Gen. James Reed of Revolutionary War fame and is a great-grandniece of Powell Tremlett Wyman of Boston, colonel of the Sixteenth Massachusetts Regiment in the Civil War. She is a student at Vassar College.

Something or other about the art and science of publicity has been tossed into a three-act carnival entitled "All Editions" and played on a merry-go-round at the Longacre last evening. It is the product of Clyde North, a man-of-all-work in the theatre, and Charles (Three-Sheet) Washburn, press representative for George M. Cohan and George Abbott, author, historian, raconteur and a drama editor's best pal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- This year's celebration of Christmas at the White House began today with a children's party for Anna Eleanor Dall, grandchild of President and Mrs. Roosevelt, whose mother, Mrs. John Boettiger, will be the only child of the President absent from the family group now assembling here for the holidays.
The meeting of directors of the Wentworth Manufacturing Company scheduled yesterday was postponed to Jan. 5 owing to lack of quorum.

Illinois Wesleyan's basketball team worked out against Columbia at the Morningside Heights gymnasium yesterday, and from all indications a high-scoring game is in the offing when the Midwesterners meet Long Island University at the Hippodrome on Saturday night.
Rudy Dusek, Nebraska heavyweight, threw Bert Rubi, Hungarian, last night in 41 minutes 16 seconds of their finish struggle which served as the wrestling feature at the St. Nicholas Palace.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Asserting that at present the State banks "don't know who their master is" because of differences which arise under State and Federal policies, particularly those having to do with examinations, Dr. Luther A. Harr, chairman of the executive committee of the National Association of State Bank Supervisors, said today that the association intended to do its utmost to bring about uniformity of practices by the State and ...

PARIS, Dec. 22. -- Premier Leon Blum's efforts to settle the steel industries strike in the Lille district today met with refusal by the employers to accept arbitration unless the factories were evacuated and they received a free hand to dismiss workers.

The Gdynia America liner Pilsudski arrived yesterday several hours behind her schedule as a result of four days of stormy weather at sea. Officers of the ship said that at one time the wind struck them at a velocity of ninety miles an hour.

Alexander Hamilton High School moved into first place in the Section 1 race in the Brooklyn Division of the P.S.A.L. basketball tournament by handing Eastern District its first league setback in four starts in one of the outstanding circuit clashes yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Dec. 22. -- While Leftist prisoners in jail at Para awaiting trial in connection with the November, 1935, revolt threaten to go on a hunger strike, women in Sao Paulo are preparing a feast for political prisoners held there.

A further advance in the price of copper, the second within a week, was the incentive yesterday for one of the sharpest gains in copper shares this year. Anaconda Copper Mining and the Kennecott Copper were the most active of this group, gaining 2 7/8 and 2 1/8 points, respectively.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22. -- While there was some unevenness in the hog market today, the undertone was strong and sales generally were steady to 14 cents higher with the top of $10.30 a hundredweight showing 5 cents above yesterday and equaling the best figure of the Winter packing season.

A 20-year-old mother was burned to death and three other members of her family suffered severe burns and injuries last night when a kerosene stove exploded and set fire to their home at 117 Gain Court, in the Gerrittsen Beach section of Brooklyn.
LONDON, Dec. 22. -- The creation of an entirely new type of anti-aircraft warship was announced by the British Government today in a note delivered to the United States and Japanese Embassies here.

The Prudential Insurance Company of America, plaintiff, acquired at auction yesterday the six-story apartment block at 1,451-75 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, on a bid of $500,000. The sale was the result of an action against Rezim Realty Corporation for $1,169,925.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 22. -- At her own request, Ann Dvorak was released today from her Warner contract. Early this year she rebelled against the studio and was off the lot for eight months. Re turning recently to make peace, she worked in "Midnight Court" and "The Stuttering Bishop" and was farmed out to RKO Radio for two assignments.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Continuing the succession of employment increases that have been recorded each month since February, a survey today by the Department of Labor showed that there were 58,000 more workers employed in November than in October, while November payrolls were nearly $5,000,000 more than in the preceding month.

Closing the year, the Temporary Galleries of the Municipal Art Committee yesterday opened another exhibition of work by New York artists. This is the seventeenth in the series and brings to a total of 750 the number of artists who have thus been enabled to show their work.

POTTSVILLE, Pa., Dec. 22. -- Members of Governor Earle's party said that they had learned tonight of a movement by idle Northumberland County miners to defy a court order to keep them off private property.

CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE, N.J., Dec. 22. -- A Republican member of an election board at Wildwood was removed from his position five minutes before the polls opened last Nov. 3 because he had told his superiors he knew of fraudulent registration in his district, according to testimony today in the Circuit Court hearing here on charges of illegal voting.

The ten-story Morleigh apartment house on a plot 60 by 100 feet at 74 West Sixty-eighth Street was sold at foreclosure by Edwin J. McDonald yesterday to the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, plaintiff in an action against the Patchogue Holding Company on a $285,800 lien.
POTTSVILLE, Pa., Wednesday, Dec. 23. -- The Commonwealth of Pennsylvania has started a criminal action against four officers of one of the biggest mining corporations.

A new court action against Consolidated Oil Corporation, Harry F. Sinclair and twenty-four others for an accounting of more than $12,000,000 alleged to have been made in profits at the corporation's expense, was disclosed yesterday in the Supreme Court here.

Advertising has one of the most important tasks in its history to perform next year in framing copy which will meet the new demand of consumers for factual information concerning the value and quality of merchandise. Paul S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., said yesterday.

Victory paid its first visit in a long time to the New York Americans last night. The star-spangled skaters, whose last triumph was scored on Dec. 1, returned to their winning ways at the expense of the Montreal Maroons, whom they defeated by the score of 3 to 1 on the Madison Square Garden ice surface.

OFFICIAL baseball averages, running this week, are always more or less interesting and fascinating to the fan even if they reveal little that was not already known last October. The stamp of being "official" gives them added importance.

Business failures in the retail group in the week ended Dec. 17 totaled 107, compared with 88 in the previous week and 122 in the corresponding period last year, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Retail failures this year show a weekly average to date of 109.

The State of Maryland awarded yesterday a new issue of $1,053,000 of road commission bonds to a banking group composed of E.B. Smith Co., Alexander Brown Sons and the Metropolitan St. Louis Company on their bid of 100,829 for the securities as 2 1/4s.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 22. -- The final step toward Egyptian independence was taken at noon today at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs when instruments of ratification of the Anglo-Egyptian treaty of friendship and alliance were exchanged between Sir Miles Lampson, hitherto British High Commissioner, and Wassif Ghali Pasha, Egyptian Foreign Minister.

Members of the Marine Cooks and Stewards Union of the Atlantic and Gulf yesterday made their first move within the union to oust David E. Grange, veteran president. At a meeting at 273 West Twenty-third Street attended by about 250 men, virtually all strikers, a committee of nine was appointed to redraft the constitution to reduce the executive's powers and place control in the hands of the membership.

Despite yesterday's news of spreading revolt, the Chinese stalemate -- now prolonged for more than a fortnight -- may yet be resolved without civil war or foreign intervention. So long as negotiations for the release of Generalissimo CHIANG KAI-SHEK continue, and the Nanking authorities refrain from ordering an open military attack on his captors, there remains hope of a Chinese -- that is, a compromise -- settlement.

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 22. -- The negotiations for refunding Mexico's external debt on the basis of a reduction to nearly 25 per cent of its present size and the resumption of interest payments are nearing a successful conclusion, it was learned today in informed quarters here.

Mayor La Guardia signed the new Traffic Code recently adopted by the Board of Aldermen yesterday after disapproving four sections dealing with control of pedestrian traffic on the ground that city residents were not yet prepared for "goose-stepping" or formation marching.

POTTSVILLE, Pa., Dec. 22. -- Into the ears of Governor Earle today bootleg miners, clergymen, bankers, lawyers and editors of Pennsylvania dinned a hymn of hate against seven corporations which own 85 per cent of the hard-coal sources on this side of the world.

Three former officials of the defunct Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company were convicted in General Sessions at 11:20 o'clock last night of publishing a booklet on Dec. 15, 1932, that contained misleading information on the company's affairs.

TRENTON, Dec. 22. -- Asbury Park was ordered today by Judge Phillip Forman in the United States District Court to include in its budget each year, beginning in 1937, an item of $87,381 until it pays with interest a bondholders' judgment of $1,400,000.

Miss Rosanne Wigham made her debut last night at a dance given by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Reginald E. Wigham, in the ballroom of the Pierre. The debutante received with her parents before a background of ferns and pink chrysanthemums.

A recent letter to your columns complained of the unsatisfactory type of seats in cars of the Independent subway. It is apparently too late to change this condition, since those in charge of the system repeated the stupid layout of seats when buying the new cars.

Seven - year - old Lester Keating Seifert was one of the happiest boys in New York yesterday. Confined to his bed for two and a half years in the children's division of the Lenox Hill Hospital. Park Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street, with osteomyelitis, an infection of bone and marrow, he was happy because he was going home for Christmas.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22. -- A decidedly bearish construction was placed by the world's grain trade on the United States Government's report issued late on Monday placing the Winter wheat acreage at 57,187,000 acres, by far the largest on record. General liquidation developed in all of the leading markets today because of the surprisingly large seeded area.

Plans or small apartment houses in Manhattan and the Bronx were filed yesterday. Dwellings and commercial structures for sites in Brooklyn and in Queens also were listed. Among the plans presented were the following:

With the season two-thirds of the way over, the Harvard Club and the Squash Club Class B teams continue to dominate the race in Group 1 of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association, while the Downtown Athletic Club team remains in front of its rivals in Group 2.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 22. -- Trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad recommended today to the United States District Court the payment of $3,620,765 overdue interest on certain bonds and debentures secured by liens, including interest on those pledged as collateral with holders of short-term notes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- A total of 135 women, sixty of whom were re-elected, will serve in the 1937 Legislatures of forty-three States, according to the National League for Women Voters. This is a gain of five over the 1936 total.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Continuing its inquiry into the operations of the Equity Corporation of New York, the Securities and Exchange Commission today studied the intricate transactions involved in the acquiring of control by the Equity Corporation of the Eastern Shares Corporation, the American, British and Continental Corporation and the Reliance International Corporation, all major units in the Equity network of investment trusts.
DETROIT, Dec. 22. -- Mr. Martin, the head of the United Automobile Workers, said late this evening that the meeting between union and General Motors officials was satisfactory "as far as it went."
With regard to the relationship between the Communist party and the present government of Spain, it may be well to take into account the opinion expressed by the Communists themselves.

GIBRALTAR, Dec. 22. -- The German influence is playing a considerable part in the plans of General Francisco Franco, leader of the Spanish Rebels. Germans can be seen everywhere at the bases of the Madrid front, Avila, San Martin de Valdeiglesias and Toledo and all along the roads leading to the capital from those towns.

NANKING, China, Wednesday, Dec. 23. -- It was learned definitely today that when T.V. Soong returned here Monday he was filled with confidence that a way out of the Sian impasse could be found. His feeling was based upon conversations with the two rebels, Chang Hsueh-liang and Yang Fu-cheng, and with Generalissimo Chiang.

The project to settle oppressed Jews in the autonomous territory of Birobidjan, in Soviet Russia, received impetus last night with announcement here that the U.S.S.R. had authorized admittance of 2,000 families and 500 individuals from Poland for 1937.

MADRID, Dec. 22. -- A government airplane crashed to the ground in flames as a number of fliers drove off the attacking Insurgents. Another plane, believed to be piloted by piloted by a Rebel, also fell.

New York City's public and private philanthropic agencies have arranged hundreds of parties and entertainments so that no child need forego participation in ,he Yuletide spirit which this year is jamming stores and crowding all transit lines.

WASHINGTON. Dec. 22. -- Postmaster General Farley, as the guest of the National Press Club at a luncheon today, praised the "good sportsmanship of Governor Landon" and predicted a brilliant second term for President Roosevelt. He said he hoped for a strong Republican party, but did not want it to become "too strong."

The elderly proprietor of a dairy store and his son-in-law fought with two hold-up men in West 176th Street, the Bronx, about 10 o'clock last night and were both wounded. In the rough-and-tumble battle one of the thugs accidentally was shot by his confederate.

OSLO, Norway, Dec. 22. -- Leon Trotsky is en route to Mexico, where he has obtained permission to take refuge. It was officially revealed tonight that he left Norway at noon Saturday, twelve hours after his residence permit had expired.

VATICAN CITY, Dec. 22. -- Workmen were busy today wiring Pope Pius's bedroom for the Christmas message he will broadcast Thursday at 12:30 P.M. Rome time [6:30 A.M., New York time]. He will speak from his bed and to be understood by the greatest possible number will abandon his usual practice of using Latin and will speak in Italian.
A modern "deadline" for known criminals was established yesterday by Commissioner Valentine to protect women wearing jewelry in public, particularly in night clubs.

Mr. WILLIAM S. MURRAY, the new chairman of the Republican State Committee, brings a new temper to that office. He is making friends instead of enemies. At Albany he made a remark that must fill the New York Republicans with wonder, with hope, tinctured perhaps by the natural fear that it is almost too good to be true: "I do "not expect to have a row with any-"body."

Charging that for five months it had functioned under "the most difficult and disillusioning conditions," for which Don Oscar Becque, supervisor of the Federal Dance Project, was responsible, the audition board appointed by the WPA to examine dancers applying for jobs in the dance project sent its "final report" yesterday to Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, WPA Administrator.

Unlicensed venders of alcohol during the prohibition era have now a perfectly good standing in the State courts in any actions to collect old debts, Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink in Brooklyn ruled yesterday.

Renewal of motor-vehicle licenses for 1937 continued yesterday in what Deputy Commissioner I. James Brody described as a steady flow. The bureau's headquarters at 155 Worth Street were crowded all day and the branches in Brooklyn, the Bronx, Queens and Richmond also were kept busy.

Cuban politics had been so quiet -- one might say so abnormally quiet -- during many months that the upheaval which now seems imminent in the Government of the island comes as a surprise. The Cuban people have been sharing in the general world recovery. They had especially benefited by the reciprocal trade treaty with the United States.

A gift of $5,000 from Mrs. Edward S. Harkness to the United Hospital Fund campaign was among the contributions announced last night by Stuart M. Crocker, chairman of the drive. The campaign committee is seeking $2,881,644 to help eighty-eight voluntary hospitals carry on essential community service.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Dec. 23. -- With the early twilight of the year's shortest day darkening the Shensi Province plain, two haggard men and one nerve-racked woman last evening alighted from an airplane under the ancient city walls of Sian.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Reflecting further strength in the export market, the leading copper producers yesterday advanced the price of copper 3/8 cent a pound to 11 3/8 cents, the highest since June, 1930. Yesterday's advance followed an increase of a half cent a pound to 11 cents on Dec. 14.

Carl Guggino, Tampa (Fla.) lightweight, won an eight-round decision from Eddie Zivic of Pittsburgh in the feature bout before 6,000 fans at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx last night. The weights were even at 132 pounds.

The life of Mrs. ALBERT EINSTEIN should serve to remind us that the cause of science may be served in more ways than one. She was free to confess that she did not understand the theory of relativity herself. "My husband's time is so valuable," she used to say, "I don't want him to waste it "trying to explain the theory just for "me."
TRENTON, Dec. 22. -- The special session of the Legislature ended late tonight after enactment of an unemployment compensation law had been completed. Governor Hoffman signed the measure immediately.

PARIS, Dec. 22. -- Georges Bonnet, former Minister of Finance and of Commerce, has agreed to accept the diplomatic mission to the United States and will soon replace Andre de Laboulaye in Washington, it is learned on good authority tonight.

MOSCOW, Dec. 22. -- Academician N.I. Vaviloff, famous botanist and agricultural plant expert of the Soviet Union, presented to the Moscow bureau of THE NEW YORK TIMES today a communication for transmission to the New York offices.

POTTSVILLE, Pa., Dec. 22. -- Attorney General Margiotti charged tonight that Joseph J. Bruno, on his escape last Friday from a Schuylkill County prison guard, carried with him enough securities to "set him up comfortably" wherever he decided to settle.

MOSCOW, Dec. 22. -- Soviet writers who are resting on their oars and living on munificent royalties that continue to pour in from previous works are coming under the scrutiny of Communist party authorities. This raises the possibility that they may be brought under Joseph Stalin's dictum, "He who does not work shall not eat."
A powerful wrestling team from the University of Michigan repeated a triumph of last season by turning back the New York A.C. grapplers last night at the Winged Foot gym, 23 -- 11.

With a view to promoting the interests of small dealers in various trades, principally through legislative action, distributors at a meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania last night organized the Allied Retail Federation, which will represent groups throughout New York State.

The fifteenth annual Wightman Cup tennis matches, bringing together women's teams representing the United States and Great Britain, will be held on the courts of the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills next Aug. 20 and 21.

William S. Murray, new Republican State Chairman, who has dropped his regular vocation as a chemical engineer to become a peacemaker and harmonizer, declared the prospect of a united and "liberalized" Republican party in this State promising yesterday.

Angling superstitions die hard. Among the more persistent of the myths is that fresh-water anglers, particularly those in the rarefied reaches of the dry-fly realm, can see no good in salt water fishing.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will offer today $1,400,000 of 3 1/4 per cent first mortgage, Series F. bonds of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire. The bonds, which will mature on Dec. 1, 1966, will be priced at 101 1/2 and accrued interest.
The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday its approval of applications for listing of the following securities:

GENEVA, Dec. 22. -- The decision by London and Paris to change their legations in Ethiopia into consulates revives talk here of a special Assembly's being convoked in a few weeks, ostensibly to admit Egypt to the League of Nations but mainly to bring Italy back by unseating Halle Selassie's delegation.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22. -- At the age when most men, great or small, shut themselves up in blissful reverie, Connie Mack marches on.

Princeton's team drew three games with Harvard in the second round and then defeated Yale, 3 -- 0, in the third, to hold its lead in the annual tournament of the H.Y.P.D. College Chess League for the Belden-Stephens Trophy at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday.
I have just read Arthur Krock's article on the TVA power pool plan, and desire to compliment you on it.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 22. -- Tonight's outstanding social event was the supper dance for the benefit of the Post Times empty stocking fund at Club Madrid. The use of the club was donated to Major Barclay H. Burton, fund chairman.

Unsuccessful in their effort to force postponement of competitive civil service examinations by court action, employes of the Emergency Relief Bureau began sit-in demonstrations in forty-six ERB offices last night as a means of inducing the Municipal Civil Service Commission to order direct qualifying examinations for the 11,000 jobs in the Relief Bureau.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 22. -- The Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company is giving to its 6,000 striking employes money for their Christmas dinners.

BERLIN, Dec. 22. -- Nazi Germany decided on a fish sale with directions for cooking today and appealed to housewives to save bread crusts to cope with the food shortage and lessen the need for imports.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- President Roosevelt and Chairman McReynolds of the House Foreign Affairs Committee explored today the question of bringing major civil wars, like that in Spain, within the scope of the Neutrality Law.

Following the recovery of more than $1.50 a bale from low levels of last week, prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday developed an easier tendency and declined 5 to 9 points. Distribution of a block of March supplied the market with contracts and a break in wheat started selling by commission houses in the last hour.

ALBANY, Dec. 22 (AP). -- Lester W. Herzog, State Works Progress Administrator, said today $102,318,469 had been spent for work-relief projects in New York State in the year and five months of the WPA's existence.
Pay increases for 15,000 of the city's lowest-paid employes will become effective on July 1, 1937, under a local law signed at City Hall yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 22. -- The authority of the National Labor Relations Board to force employers to bargain collectively with their workers was upheld by the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals here today.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22. -- N.W. Ayer Son, Inc., advertising agency, announced today the reelection of Adam Kessler Jr. as a member of its board of directors.

At about half past 4 Sunday morning a visiting French automobile manufacturer and his wife, just about to get out of a taxicab in front of the Hotel Plaza, confronted several armed thugs. One of them tried to seize the wife's jewels. The Frenchman, Mr. MATHIS, displaying remarkable courage, kicked the intruder in the face and grappled with a second man who tried to enter the car, while Mrs. MATHIS screamed for help.

A decline in gross revenue and profits of the Electrical Research Products, Inc., following the enactment of "an optional service contract" more than a year ago, was revealed yesterday at the continuation of hearings into the activities of this corporation, before the Federal Communications Commission at 45 Broadway.

MADRID, Dec. 22. -- Civil war or no civil war, Spain must have its Christmas lottery. They are fighting hard at Pozuelo de Alarcon, and enemy airplanes came over the city at 3 o'clock, but nobody gave a hoot about anything except the numbers that won the lottery today and whether those numbers corresponded to the fractions of tickets that every good Spaniard possesses.

The total revenue of New York State for the current fiscal year ending June 30, 1937, will be $332,546,000, or about the same as for the last fiscal year, it was estimated yesterday by the New York State Commission on Revision of the Tax Laws.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Consolidation of thirty bus line subsidiaries of the Greyhound Corporation, with routes in forty-three States and Canada, into seven closely knit corporate units was authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission on the parent company's plea that the move was necessary to promote greater economy and efficiency in operation and to avoid a "confiscatory" capital-gains tax under the 1936 Revenue Act.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- If Congress should formulate and pass at this session modifications of the naturalization laws to condone illegal residence under certain conditions, temporarily, the motivation of such action will be disclosed when real unemployment statistics are subsequently collected and published by the government.

Salaries of the principal executives of the American Snuff Company and Spencer Kellogg Sons, Inc., were disclosed yesterday in annual reports to the Securities and Exchange Commission. Compensation was reported as follows:

Dr. Henry Moskowitz, a leader in civic, political and labor circles, who died on Dec. 17, bequeathed his residuary estate of undetermined value to the "Henry Moskowitz Memorial Fund" for public lectures by experts in the field of industrial relations or some subject connected with the ethics of industrial or community relations.
Raphael Store, in 471 Park Av.; ![. Morgenthau-Seixas Co., brokers.

As former members of the German Reichstag we want to make it clear that your statement under Topics of The Times of today is correct only in the sense that the parties of the Right which formed the government Hitler-Hugenberg polled a majority in the election of March 5, 1933.
A new two-lane roadway, which is expected to increase the vehicular traffic capacity of the Williamsburg Bridge by 50 per cent, was opened yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.
BOSTON, Dec. 22 (AP). -- The speedy Toronto Maple Leafs, back in winning stride, outskated the fighting Bruins for a 4-2 triumph tonight before 15,000 fans at the Boston Garden.
A telephone connection on the roof of a burning building was used last night to direct the activities of more than 100 firemen at a five-alarm fire on Ingraham Street in Brooklyn.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 22 (AP). -- Federal Judge Carroll C. Hincks allowed today the claim of Miss Jean Annett of Red Bank, N.J., injured in a train accident in 1913, as a common one against the New Haven Railroad in the amount of $161,577.

Members of the United States Army horse show team will be tendered a luncheon today in the India House by the Chile-American Association. It will be the last public function that the American officers will attend before sailing tomorrow for Chile, where they will take part in the international horse show which is to be held in connection with the celebration of the 400th anniversary of the founding of Valparaiso.

LONDON, Dec. 22. -- The stock market here continued to reflect the holiday lull today, most sections remaining extremely quiet. British Government issues in general were steady, but a few sagged due to lack of support. The most active group in the market was oil, which responded generally to the announcement of an increased dividend from the Apex oil fields.

The New York Athletic Club, largest and oldest organization of its kind in the country, is contemplating a new project, a tremendous outdoor swimming pool at its Travers Island Summer home, it was announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22. -- The Philadelphia Electric Company announced today that it had filed with the Pennsylvania Public Service Commission an application for authority to issue $130,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds bearing 3 1/4 per cent interest and maturing on March 1, 1967.

A moderate but irregular recovery in railroad bonds and continued easiness in United States Government obligations were features of relatively quiet trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Belated interpretations by traders of the I.C.C. decision to terminate the emergency freight surcharges on Dec. 31 brought heavy buying into the rail issues, which carried the average for that group up 0.23 of a point on the day.

ROME, Dec. 22. -- Reports printed in the Parisian press to the effect that the conclusion of an Anglo-Italian agreement regarding the Mediterranean will be followed by modification of the Italian attitude toward the Spanish situation are regarded here as a clear case of the wish being father to the thought.

Harry Brunette, bank robber and kidnapper, who pleaded guilty to kidnapping and took a consequent 100-year prison sentence to avoid the inconvenience of a trial last Thursday, pleaded not guilty yesterday to a new indictment based on the shots he fired at Federal agents who captured him.

MONTREAL, Dec. 22 (AP). -- The "old men" of the Canadiens went on a scoring rampage tonight to lead the way to a 4-to-1 victory over Chicago and send the Canadiens further out front in the National Hockey League's international division.

After five days of declining stock prices, the market rallied moderately yesterday under the leadership of the copper issues. The closing was irregularly higher. The volume of business on the Stock Exchange was further diminished, with the day's total amounting to 1,667,000 shares, compared with 1,762,000 the day before.

Crude oil production in the United States established another record last week with a daily average of 3,145,700 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This represents a gain of 26,200 barrels above the average of 3,119,500 in the preceding week, the former high level.

Paced by Dernell Every, who captured all three of his engagements, the New York Athletic Club's first-string fencing team defeated the University Fencing Club trio, 5 to 3, last night in the final of the open foils team competition on the strips of the Saltus F.C. in the Twenty-third Street Y.M.C.A.

Your editorial commenting on the election of Mr. Murray as chairman of the Republican State Committee deserves commendation. However, it seems to me that not all the ills of the party were pointed out.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 22. -- Sixty friends of Heartly W. (Hunk) Anderson tonight condemned what they termed "the arbitrary and illegal action" of President Frank P. Graham of the Greater University of North Carolina in refusing to permit the renewal of Anderson's contract as head football coach at North Carolina State College.

Having decided to make application for the registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the provisions of the Securities Act of 1933, as amended, of the certificates of deposit for the external dollar bonds of the Republic of Colombia, the bondholders committee for the Republic of Colombia bonds has suspended the issuance of certificates pending registration of those already issued, it was announced yesterday.

Among the varied realty holdings which figured in sales yesterday were an apartment site and several other properties in upper Manhattan, a Canal Street building which had been held for more than a century, and an East Side dwelling which will be remodeled by the new owner.

The annual report of the Royal Bank of Canada, extracts from which were made public here yesterday by the bank's local agency, shows total assets as or Nov. 30 of $855,000,000, a gain of $55,000,000 over the report of the year before. The bank reports a rise of $71,000,000 in deposits, which, added to the $679,000,000 reported a year ago, would indicate total deposits of $750,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Some advisers of President Roosevelt are talking of asking for an enlargement of the Walsh-Healey Contracts Act at the coming session of Congress.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP). -- Senator A. Harry Moore and Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, N.J., discussed with President Roosevelt today Federal financing of new construction in the midtown vehicular tunnel under the Hudson River.

" As regards VAVILOFF'S arrest," says the Moscow Izvestia with characteristic urbanity, "THE NEW YORK TIMES simply lied." Actually, it was not so simple. It seems that Professor VAVILOFF was not arrested for holding the wrong views on genetics, but Professor AGOL was arrested.

President Eugene A. Colligan of Hunter College lit the college Yule log yesterday morning at a Christmas ceremony in the Bronx Buildings, Bedford Park Boulevard and Navy Avenue, and expressed the wish that "Santa Claus bestow a new building on Hunter."

Maxwell Anderson's first play of the season -- there are three of them scheduled -- will open locally this evening at the Empire Theatre. Call it "The Wingless Victory," and a story of a New England sea captain who brings home to Salem a Malay princess he has married.

In order to stimulate interest in steeplechase racing and assure larger fields and better competition for the metropolitan tracks, thirty-six jumpers have been purchased abroad by the subscription committee of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association to be raced here next season.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 22. -- Mixwell, 3-year-old gelded son of Misstep, captured top honors in the Class C Delray Handicap, a six-furlong dash at Tropical Park today. The New England invader, third in his local debut, had the speed to outrun seven rivals and, under Jockey Johnny Deering's hard urging, drove home first by a length. He was the first favorite to register, paying $4.60 to $2. His time was 1:12.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- The following table shows effective registrations of securities with the SEC from July 27, 1933, to Oct. 31, 1936, in thousands of dollars:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- A drastic realignment of independent agencies and quasi-judicial commissions to fit them into the departments headed by Cabinet officers, at least so far as their administrative functions are concerned, will be a part of President Roosevelt's plan for reorganizing the Federal establishment.

The grand jury is expected to report to Judge Cornelius F. Collins in General Sessions today its findings in the deaths of five persons early last Friday in a fire in the rooming house at 273 West Seventy-third Street. Saul Price, Assistant District Attorney, questioned six more witnesses before the grand jurors yesterday, including Samuel Fassler, Commissioner of Buildings.
BERLIN, Dec. 22. -- Germany is now engaged in perfecting a national mobilization plan, for use in case of the outbreak of war, that it seems unlikely any other nation in the world can hope to rival.

DETROIT, Dec. 22. -- Acting in the troubled labor situation facing automobile production, William S. Knudsen, executive vice president of the General Motors Corporation, and Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers, conferred for several hours today in an office in the General Motors Building.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 22. -- Judge John J. Gore in Federal court signed a decree today temporarily enjoining the Tennessee Valley Authority from expanding its power program.

Weakness was the rule in moderate trading in local commodity futures markets yesterday, with rubber and silk somewhat firmer and copper soaring briskly to new highs. On the cash markets all the grains, cotton and lard declined, while copper and zinc made highs and silk and rubber gained.

Frank Iannicelli, rising young star of the New York Athletic Club, turned back E.P. Field Jr. of the Princeton Club in a bristling five-game battle to capture the Fall Class B and C championship of the National Squash Tennis Association at the Columbia University Club yesterday.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 23. -- On the expiration of the Washington and London naval limitation treaties at the end of the year Foreign Minister Hachiro Arita will intimate that Japan is ready to cooperate with the United States in establishing peace machinery in the Pacific appropriate to the new situation, the newspaper Nichi Nichi announces this morning.
Mr. and Mrs. Harold Joseph Roig of Great Neck, L.I., gave a supper dance last night in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis for their debutante daughter, Miss Jean Roig.

ENZESFELD, Austria, Dec. 22 (AP). -- Edward, Duke of Windsor, parted reluctantly tonight with his chauffeur of eighteen years, breaking another "last tie" with the England he left for love of Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- John J. Burns, former associate judge of the Superior Court of Massachusetts, and since July 31, 1934, general counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission, it is understood, will retire soon to enter private practice and will be succeeded by Allen E. Throop, now assistant general counsel.

St. Augustine's High strengthened its hold on first place in the Brooklyn Division of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association basketball tournament by virtue of a 22-to-17 victory over Brooklyn Prep on the latter's court yesterday. The conquest was the fourth in as many circuit engagements for the winners, while the setback was the first in three starts for the home forces.

BERLIN, Dec. 22. -- The Prussian Confessional Synod, the largest and most powerful remaining opposition Protestant body in Germany, has demanded the immediate resignation of the church administration appointed by Hans Kerrl, Minister for Church Affairs, and has adopted a series of resolutions which may revive throughout Northern Germany the old church struggle in its bitterest form.

The letter of William H. Matthews Jr., in your issue of Dec. 20, suggesting a new tax system which would restrict the franchise to those who pay direct levies, will create an impression in many minds that whatever merit his proposal may possess would be more than offset by disadvantages in opposite directions.

Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, says in his quarterly letter to stockholders that the only avenue to real progess is through increasing productive efficiency and lower rather than higher prices, making available "more goods for more people at less cost."

Activity in the midtown garment district featured commercial leasing yesterday. Brokers reported a brisk demand and higher rentals and predicted there would be a minimum of vacancies in a month's time. Williams Co., Inc., reported leasing approximately 125,000 square feet and Kane Co., Inc., more than 100,000 square feet.

LONDON, Dec. 22. -- The Bishop of Bradford, writing in The Diocesan Messenger, declared former King Edward's choice of Mrs. Simpson, rather than the throne, was "a human tragedy." He added that it was the people's "duty to wreathe the coronation with their prayers and self-dedication," appealed for avoidance of "cheap sentiment" and characterized as "silly" a report "that I am inviting you to paint the churches red, white and blue."

CHICAGO, Dec. 22. -- Mr. Florsheim went to work in the retail shoe store which his father, Sigmund Florsheim, had established in 1856, and in 1892 assisted in the organization of the manufacturing concern which became the Florsheim Shoe Company.
Acting on a report of the Emergency Relief Bureau, the Board of Estimate held a special meeting in City Hall yesterday to appropriate $26,598,000 for relief for the first three months of next year.

ALBANY, Dec. 22. -- Governor Lehman declared this afternoon that the State was not yet ready to abolish capital punishment for youths under 21 years of age. He made this statement at a hearing wherein clemency was asked for six young Brooklyn men who are now in Sing Sing's death house for the killing of Edwin Esposito, a B.M.T subway collector, during a hold-up in Brooklyn which netted the youths about $180.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Senators who are not definitely members of the Democratic party, yet are not listed as Republicans either will receive committee assignments as Republicans in the next Congress, and thus be able to preserve the seniority they would lose if reclassified.
Good tidings of great joy rang in many of the sombre homes along the "Street of Sorrow" yesterday as hundreds of persons bearing gifts came to the help of the Neediest Cases of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Registration statements for securities with estimated gross proceeds of $7,820,536,000 became effective under the Securities Act of 1933 in the period from July 27, 1933, when the registration features of the act became operative, through October 1936, according to a summary made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Fordham University closed its 1936 sport year last night when its basketball squad succumbed to a determined quintet from St. Peter's College, 31 -- 22, on the Maroon court.

The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $12,753,361 after all deductions for the year ended on Nov. 30. This was equivalent to $8.50 a share on the $6 preferred stock. It compared with $6.03 a share earned in the preceding year.

Paralyzed limbs and the dull routine of hospital life were forgotten by 100 crippled children at Bellevue Hospital yesterday afternoon as they laughed and shouted and caught the true holiday spirit at their annual pre-Christmas party.
Their first real test of the campaign was survived by the Blackbirds of Long Island University last night when they turned in their forty-first victory in succession.

BERLIN, Dec. 22. -- The German Government announced tonight that an agreement had been reached with Poland on the Polish corridor [Pomorze] traffic issue, which threatened for a time to become a rather serious political question.
Acting on a report of the Emergency Relief Bureau, the Board of Estimate held a special meeting in City Hall yesterday to appropriate $26,598,000 for relief for the first three months of next year.

ALBANY, Dec. 22. -- Governor Lehman declared this afternoon that the State was not yet ready to abolish capital punishment for youths under 21 years of age. He made this statement at a hearing wherein clemency was asked for six young Brooklyn men who are now in Sing Sing's death house for the killing of Edwin Esposito, a B.M.T subway collector, during a hold-up in Brooklyn which netted the youths about $180.
The Fund for New York's Neediest Cases passed the $200,000 mark yesterday as 721 persons gave $12,843.08 to aid those in worst distress in all New York.

Prizes for New York City merchants whose show windows ranked highest in the fourth annual show window contest conducted by the Electrical Association of New York were awarded yesterday at the annual Christmas luncheon of 1,000 members of the association at the Hotel Astor.

A gift of $15,000 from Mrs. Charles S. Payson to the United Hospital Fund campaign was announced last night by Stuart M. Crocker, chairman of the drive. He reported also a donation of $5,000 from Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Lamont.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Relief as a "vested interest" makes an extraordinary appeal to millions of men and women.

The unprecedented sending of Christmas mail, described by Postmaster Albert Goldman as a definite sign of added prosperity, shattered all records in the history of the New York Postoffice on Tuesday, when 16,336,676 pieces of first-class mail passed through the cancellation machines, bringing the postoffice during the day about $450,000 in revenue for this class, it was announced yesterday.

Sidor Belarsky, a Russian bass, who first was heard here six years ago, offered a program in Town Hall last night which was attentively followed by an enthusiastic audience. Mr. Belarsky's voice possessed plenty of volume, but he could file his naturally large tones down to a delicate pianissimo.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Governor Landon did a perfectly natural thing when he accepted an invitation to attend the Gridiron Dinner here this week. And during his stay in Washington he conducted himself in a perfectly natural manner. Free of counsel and cross-counsel, and of the responsibility of a party standard-bearer, he bore himself as Alf M. Landon, and as Alf M. Landon he captivated all of Washington.

MOSCOW, Dec. 23. -- The trial of thirty-four German citizens on charges of espionage, sabotage and terrorism against the Soviet Union in behalf of Germany will begin soon, according to unofficial sources. The trial will be public and is bound to have international repercussions because of the tension now existing between Nazi Germany and Bolshevik Russia.

Plans for two six-story elevator apartment houses were announced in connection with the sale yesterday of the southwest corner of Cruger Avenue and Maran Place, the Bronx. The property containing 20,000 square feet of space was sold by the Mott Haven Mortgage Corporation to Leeward Estates, Inc., Jacob Janos, president.

The Wesson Oil and Snowdrift Company, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the three months ended on Nov. 30 a net profit of $1,321,701 after interest, depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. After dividend requirements on the $4 preferred stock, the profit was equivalent to S1.75 a share on 585,414 no-par common shares.

PARIS, Dec. 23. -- Speaking at the weekly luncheon of the Anglo-American Press Association of Paris today, Premier Leon Blum declared that one of the happiest memories of his work as Premier was that during it the relations of France with Great Britain and the United States had been greatly improved.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The percentage of member trading to total volume increased slightly on both the New York Stock and the Curb Exchanges in the week ended on Nov. 28, compared with the previous week, but total volume and member trading were decidedly smaller, due in part to the Thanksgiving holiday on Nov. 26, according to a summary of round-lot transactions made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The Merchants Association joined with the Fifth Avenue Association yesterday in asking Mayor La Guardia to sign the ordinance passed by the Board of Aldermen to eliminate the holding of fictitious "bankruptcy sales, fire sales, liquidation sales" and other special sales of that kind.

The Labor Stage that was once the Princess Theatre yesterday afternoon housed the first American Ierformance of "Holy Night," a brief and tender little miracle play wrought originally in Spanish by Martinez Sierra and translated by Philip Hereford.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 23. -- Charged with selling a pistol to a former criminal who committed suicide here last night while engaged in a hold-up, the oldest member of the Hempstead Police Department was suspended and held without bail at local police headquarters tonight on a charge of unlawfully disposing of firearms entrusted to his care as a police officer.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 23. -- A three-point formula for a definite settlement of the Chaco conflict will be formally presented to the Bolivian and Paraguayan Ministers for Foreign Affairs here tomorrow, under the auspices of the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace.

DETROIT, Dec. 23. -- The "sit-down" strikers who have occupied the Kelsey-Hayes Wheel Company's two plants here voted tonight to accept the proposals made by the management, involving a return to work, and shortly afterward their fellow-strikers concurred in the decision.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Dec. 23. -- The first in a number of Berkshire holiday entertainments here was a dance given at the Hotel Wendell tonight by Mr. and Mrs. Carey Russell Kinney for their daughter, Miss Julia Ellen Kinney, a senior at Vassar College, and Carey R. Kinney Jr., senior at the Taft School.
Father Divine, Negro cult leader, told the Supreme Court yesterday that he had "dismissed from my vocabulary the custom of keeping any literary record of anything."

PARIS, Dec. 23. -- While Lille metal workers today resumed their strike, Premier Leon Blum accepted a compromise plan for the compulsory arbitration of labor disputes land drove it through a very confused late night sitting of the Chamber of Deputies.

In a communication published in THE TIMES of Dec. 19, Richard Hellman gave the public the benefit of his reactions to the commission's letter, which appeared earlier, relative to the effect of the use of the center track between East 180th Street and East 149th Street by Interborough trains originating on the White Plains Road line.

The Senior Get-Together dance, one of the largest holiday dances for future debutantes and younger men home from schools and colleges for the holidays, was held last night in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. The series was organized several years ago by Miss Edith Massena Benjamin, under whose direction they were held until taken over this year by Mrs. Frazier Murray.

LONDON, Dec. 23. -- Sixty men on the Sandringham estate dismissed by former King Edward just before his much-criticized tour of the depressed areas in South Wales were invited to continue in the royal employment by King George after a conference with the heads of all departments today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP). -- John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, asserted today that the General Motors Corporation had so far "evaded its responsibility" to bargain collectively with the United Automobile Workers.

Expert testimony as to the efficiency of the generating plant of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, which is said to have discharged dense smoke from its power house at 600 West Fifty-ninth Street, in violation of Section 211 of the Sanitary Code, was introduced by the defense yesterday in the third hearing before Magistrate George B. DeLuca in Municipal Term Court.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23 (AP). -- College sports would be wiped out if subsidization ever became a recognized part of athletic programs, Major John L. Griffith, Big Ten athletic commissioner and president of the National Collegiate A. A., said today.

Lord Beaverbrook, the British newspaper publisher, who is widely considered one of the closest advisers of the former King Edward, said on his arrival in New York last night on the North German Lloyd liner Europa that criticisms of the former King as expressed by prelates of the English Church were unjust and that they "could give satisfaction to nobody."

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 23. -- Mr. and Mrs. John Barry Ryan Jr. entertained tonight with a dinner at Villa Oheka, where Captain and Mrs. Alastair Mackintosh arrived today with their children, Lorna and Sheila. Mrs. Mackintosh and the children came from Ascot, England, and Captain Mackintosh from Villa del Sarmiento, where he has been visiting Mr. and Mrs. J. Jay O'Brien.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP). -- Secretary Perkins urged striking seamen and shipowners tonight to settle "all further problems" in their dispute "by the quickest and simplest formula, even if some sacrifice is necessary."
Here is something for the judges in Traffic Court and the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles to explain.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23. -- The world's wheat markets reversed their action today and displayed a decidedly firm undertone on what was regarded as a sensational estimate regarding the world supply and demand situation, and a resumption of United Kingdom and Continental European buying of cash wheat.

LEON TROTSKY is on his way to Mexico from Norway. He sailed last Saturday on board a ship of uncertain identity at the moment of writing. But it is a small vessel, apparently between one and two thousand tons, and the North Atlantic has been very rough of late.

MADRID, Dec. 23. -- The Insurgents spread their troops tonight in a flanking movement to the south, apparently in an effort to cut off Madrid's defenders from contact with the Leftist Government at Valencia.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 23 (AP). -- The first bit of pre-game bad luck hit the University of Washington football team today as the Huskies bore down in practice for their game with the University of Pittsburgh in the Rose Bowl Jan. 1.
The police will not begin at once to serve summonses for violations of the new traffic code, Commissioner Valentine said yesterday. Warnings and education of the public in general will come first.

The Transit Commission and the Board of Transportation sent to the Board of Estimate yesterday a joint request that the city, in order to assure adequate rapid transit facilities to handle World's Fair crowds in 1939, signify now its willingness to appropriate $1,850,000 for that purpose.
GLOVERSVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 23. -- Bernard W. Kearney, national commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, relayed to disabled veterans today a Christmas message from President Roosevelt, as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The need for greater uniformity among States in the matter of laws governing corporations was emphasized in a statement by David M. Milton, president of the Equity Corporation of New York and a son-in-law of John D. Rockefeller Jr., at the close of today's session of the Securities and Exchange Commission's investigation of investment trusts and investment companies.
T.O.M. Sopwith arrived on the North German Lloyd liner Europa last night not as one whose present concern is another bid for the America's Cup but in the role of a man going fishing.

Four thousand crippled, underprivileged or deaf and dumb youngsters from the five boroughs left their cares behind yesterday afternoon and lost themselves completely in the holiday gayety of a Christmas carnival staged by the WPA Federal Theatre Circus in Mecca Temple, 130 West Fifty-sixth Street.

Unionized workers of the Emergency Relief Bureau, who sat in their district offices all Tuesday night in the hope that they would thus win admission to the civil service without having to take competitive examinations, promised last night that they would not call an outright strike until all alternative attempts to avoid the competitive tests had failed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- A special form for the registration of issues under the Securities Act of 1933 by new mining companies, so prepared as to present as clearly as possible all information of interest to investors in such enterprises was made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Following is the text of Secretary of State Cordell Hull's speech which was read before the closing session of the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace, at Buenos Aires:
BERLIN, Dec. 23 (AP). -- Authoritarian Germany moved today to replace with "dyed-in-the-wool" Nazis two newspaper editors who refused to obey orders from the Propaganda Ministry.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 23. -- Surviving a photo finish, J. Weil's Double B., a 4-year-old son of Son O'Battle, took the five and a half-furlong allowance test which headed the Fair Grounds' card today.

BOMBAY, India, Dec. 23 (AP). -- A proposal to boycott the coronation durbar of King George VI was discussed tonight by Nationalist leaders as thousands assembled for tomorrow's opening of the Indian National Congress at Faizpur, a remote village in the northern part of Bombay Province.

HAVANA, Thursday, Dec. 24. -- President Miguel Mariano Gomez was removed from office early today by vote of the Senate, following his impeachment by the House of Representatives. He was not disqualified from holding office. The vote was 22 to 12.

" The Case off the Black Cat," the Warners latest mystery film, by Erle Stanley Gardner, will open an engagement this morning at the Palace. The principals are Ricardo Cortez, who has succeeded Warren William as Perry Mason, lawyer-detective, and June Travis as his secretary, Della Street. . . . Tonight the Cameo will present "Revolutionists," a new Russian film dealing with the uprising in 1905.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23 (AP). -- Art Raimo of Everett, Mass., may be lost to the Villanova College football team for its post-season game with Auburn at Havana, Cuba, on New Year's Day.

Hugh Brown, master of the steamship Southern Sword, owned by the Alco Steamship Company of 50 Broad Street; Austin L. Callahan, president of that line, and Robert Gottfried and Frank C. Nardone were convicted yesterday in Federal Court of smuggling 1,600 cases of alcohol into this port last March.

DETROIT, Dec. 23. -- Homer Martin, international president of the United Automobile Workers of America, is a college graduate, a former clergyman and a former national champion in the hop, skip and jump as a member of the Illinois Athletic Club track and field team.

Eighty-one New York University athletic representatives have been granted awards, according to an announcement yesterday by Graduate Manager Albert B. Nixon. Members of the Violet varsity and freshman football and cross-country teams were honored.

A "disinterested and authoritative investigation" of the Robinson-Patman Law and an amendment of the legislation "to correct any demonstrable defects of form and substance, which undoutbedly exist," were recommended last night by Charles Wesley Dunn, attorney, in an address before the Princeton Advertising Club at the Princeton Club.

POTTSVILLE, Pa., Dec. 23. -- Two Republican members of the Schuylkill County Commission were arrested this evening, charged with being "accessories after the fact of murder," as an aftermath of the escape on Friday of Joseph J. Bruno, former Republican leader of Kline Township, who was serving a life term for complicity in the Kelayres election eve "massacre" of November, 1934.

LONDON, Dec. 23. -- A split in the ranks of the Church of England over the issue of King Edward's abdication is evident today in the diocesan letters of three prelates who take occasion to discuss the issue, which seems to have upset the ordinarily serene course pursued by Great Britain's established spiritual advisers.

Turning back the Bushwick High School five, 32 -- 15, the Thomas Jefferson High quintet yesterday moved into a three-cornered tie with Eastern District and Brooklyn Tech for second place in the Section 1 race of the Brooklyn Division of the P.S.A.L.

LONDON, Dec. 23. -- The stock market here continued quiet today in anticipation of the holiday period, but the general price level was well maintained and some issues, notably copper shares, rose sharply. British Government issues were firm to steady, with a fractional advance in the War Loan.

An announcement by the Treasury that a trade agreement had been reached with Germany caused an improvement in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. Influenced by the possibility that barter would improve cotton exports, commission-house and professional operators took contracts from the market.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 23. -- Heroism and tragedy ended a gay Christmas vacation sailing excursion of four Brentwood and Santa Monica students today.

While more than 500 small boys and girls yelled their glee, August Heckscher, 89-year-old philanthropist and founder of the Heckscher Foundation for Children, visited the annual theatre party and Christmas fete at the Heckscher Theatre, Fifth Avenue and 104th Street, yesterday afternoon.

Christmas will be celebrated in the cathedrals and churches of this city beginning at noon today and continuing this afternoon, evening, midnight and tomorrow with services from 6 A.M. until evening. Most of tomorrow's services, however, will end with early afternoon.

Tenders have been invited by officials of the city of San Francisco for a new issue of $2,000,000 of tax anticipation notes, award of which will be made on Jan. 4. The notes will become payable on May 15, 1937.
Medals and cash awards were given to twenty-seven policemen yesterday by the Life Saving Benevolent Association, 49 Wall Street, at a ceremony in the gymnasium at police headquarters.

With Captain Jack Shanley and George Palmer doing most of the scoring, the St. John's University five came through with a 29 -- 19 triumph over the Brooklyn College quintet in its first major test of the season last night in the Degray gymnasium. It was the seventh straight victory for St. John's, which is undefeated this year.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23. -- Because the executors of the estate of Richard P. Crane Jr., president of the Crane Company, kept the assets virtually intact since his death in November, 1931, they were able to report in a final accounting today that the estate was valued at $33,161,869 as against about $5,000,000 five years ago.

LONDON, Dec. 23. -- Advices from Paris tonight indicate that France has given a stiff warning to Germany, and not for the first time, that if new German military reinforcements were sent to Spain it would become virtually impossible to maintain even the most empty appearance of neutrality.

Detectives Charles McCarthy and William O'Brian of the new "night club squad" acted swiftly yesterday to prevent any more hold-ups of women wearing jewels. Their action was so swift, however, that they could not prove it was a hold-up that they had averted.
