Mr. and Mrs. Herbert J. Stursberg of Norwalk, Conn., entertained with a dinner last night in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, for their daughter, Miss J. Louise Stursberg. Other guests were the Misses Elizabeth Mason, Sarah Hoskins, Anita Kelsey, Dorothy Macy, Elizabeth Jones, Audrey Paige, Mary-Alice Feistel, Margaret Allen, Catherine Burch, Betty Zimmerman, Betsey McCulloch, Stephanie Townsend, Betty Pierce, Lolita Silo, Pamela Brinton, Margaret Bradley and Mary Lathrop Allen.

LONDON, Dec. 23. -- As the holidays approach with their message of peace the British press and public are showing a sudden new anxiety to know just what war-like moves may be brewing across the North Sea.

Difficulties encountered by the Electrical Research Products, Inc., in its business of repairs for exhibitors and others using its motion-picture sound-recording and reproducing equipment, were enumerated yesterday at a hearing into the general conduct of the corporation's business before the Federal Communications Commission at 45 Broadway.

MANCHESTER, England, Dec. 23. -- Wallace Ford, British actor, has found his long lost mother living in an automobile trailer and today he fulfilled her most cherished dream, a little cottage in rural England. The mother is married to a blind match seller.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 23 (AP). -- A group of North Carolina College alumni, organized as the "Friends of Heartly W. (Hunk) Anderson," promised today to air the college's athletic situation before the 1937 General Assembly.

William H. Malone, former chairman of the State Tax Commission of Illinois and former Mayor of Park Ridge, a suburb of Chicago, returned last night on the North German Lloyd liner Europa to face a Federal indictment in Illinois involving alleged omissions in his income tax returns for 1929 and 1930.

The New York Stock Exchange and the New York Curb Exchange celebrated yesterday, each in its own way, the Christmas season. In the aggregate, more than 3,000 children from lower Manhattan schools were the beneficiaries.

Michael Hollander, president of A. Hollander Son, Inc., announced that all of the company's employes would receive Christmas gifts in cash. He also said the company would not deduct from the salaries and wages of its employes the sums required to be paid by them under the Old Age Pension division of the Federal Social Security Law.

OTTAWA, Dec. 23. -- With the help of the New York market, the Canadian Government will by this time next year have abolished Federal tax-free bonds, and the present intention is never to reinstitute them.

THE swiftly fading year of 1936 was not exactly a happy one for kings. In the wide realm of sport they toppled in great profusion, some stepping down voluntarily, most of them, though, as the result of a pretty stiff push.

WARRENTON, Va., Dec. 23. -- A colorful ball at North Wales was given this evening by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur White of Chilton, Middleburg, Va., to present to society Mrs. White's daughter, Miss Bettina Belmont.

PARIS, Dec. 23. -- Financial arrangements forming an important sequel to the Franco-Polish political and commercial conversations this Fall were approved today by the Finance Commission of the Chamber of Deputies. Under this measure a credit totaling 2,600,000,000 francs will be granted to Poland by France.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Recommendations calling for Congressional action to insure the nation's wheat farmers against losses in yield resulting from drought, flood or pest were forwarded to President Roosevelt today by his Committee on Crop Insurance. It urged the passage of authorizing legislation during the coming session so that the plan might be applied to the 1938 crop.

By defeating the Short Hills team, 4 to 1, last night the Columbia Club continued to stalk the leading New York Athletic Club team in the race for Class A honors in the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, denied at the White House today reports that he might resign unless the President allocated $750,000,000 for the continuance of relief work through the current fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Arrangements to facilitate trade relations with Germany were announced by the Treasury Department today. After placing countervailing duties on certain German products because of subsidization, the Treasury relaxed some of the restrictions.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 23. -- Funds given by Yale University in aid of students reached $1,000,000 for the year today as a new allotment of $327,676, affording assistance to 746 students, was announced. The total includes scholarships, employment assistance, and awards to graduate and professional school students.

Orie R. Kelly, president of the Lawyers Trust Company of 160 Broadway, was named last night by the nominating committee of the New York Athletic Club for president of that organization. He will succeed William A. Dalton, president for four years, who put the club through its reorganization and is retiring at his own wish.
Melvin T. Ott, compact little powerhouse of the Giants these eight or nine years, was the outstanding slugger of the National League in 1936, according to the official figures announced yesterday.

It is a satisfaction to have proof again that the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund, sponsored by THE TIMES, is a recognized and approved institution in the charitable life of this city. Already the persons and families aided have more than covered the special cases first presented on Dec. 6.
MADRID, Dec. 23. -- A period of consolidation of fortifications on the Madrid front is now taking place. Military activity is largely confined to artillery duels.

PARIS, Dec. 23. -- A conference between Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos and Count Johannes von Welczeck, the German Ambassador, tonight led to reports, which persisted despite official denials, that Mr. Delbos had informed the diplomat that German forces aiding the Insurgents in Spain must be withdrawn.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 23. -- Irene Dunne signed a contract today with RKO-Radio to appear in a musical, "The Joy of Living," from a story by Herbert Fields. It will be produced by Felix Young with music by Jerome Kern and lyrics by Dorothy Fields.

Following the example set by major colleges in football, Long Island University's basketball team will go to a training camp to prepare for its game with Stanford at Madison Square Garden next Wednesday.

In November, according to the indices of the Department of Labor, employment rose for the tenth consecutive month, though the seasonal tendency is for employment to fall in November. Secretary PERKINS now thinks that, if the increased number of agricultural and domestic workers were counted, "as many people are at work now as in 1929.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Establishment of an outdoor wildlife laboratory to supplement game species research into many problems that have been perplexing students in this field was announced today by Dr. Ira N. Gabrielson, chief of the United States Bureau of Biological Survey.
The Seton Hall quintet last night became the forty-second straight victim of the Long Island University team, losing by 62 -- 27 at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium.

LONDON, Dec. 23. -- The musical satire, "Your Number's Up," with book and lyrics by Diana Morgan and Robert MacDermot, and music by Geoffrey Wright, which opened tonight, falls below the usual standard of Gate Theatre productions whose tryouts are noted for their originality and boldness.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Violations of three sections of the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Act and Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act were charged today by the Federal Trade Commission in a complaint issued against Charles of the Ritz, Inc., and Charles of the Ritz Distributors Corporation, both of 9-11 University Place, New York City, engaged in the sale of cosmetics and toilet goods.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23. -- Before a brilliant audience that nearly filled the Academy of Music the Metropolitan Opera Association opened its Philadelphia series of six performances last night with Smetana's opera, "The Bartered Bride." With the cast almost entirely American, the text in English, first used in the popular-priced season of the Metropolitan in New York last Spring, was greeted with enthusiasm.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn yesterday appointed Thomas J. Towers, a Queens lawyer, to a lifetime post as Queens County Clerk. The appointment was the first made by the Appellate Divisions in the First or Second Judicial District under the constitutional amendment adopted by the voters in 1935, making county clerkships in New York City appointive offices and giving the power of appointment to the Appellate Divisions.

Following several days of backing and filling, the commodity futures markets resumed their upward trend yesterday. A sharp upturn in rubber to the highest level in more than six years probably was the feature. Cocoa futures also were higher.

MOSCOW, Dec. 23 (AP). -- Communist Russia granted a one-year extension of valuable Siberian fishing rights to Japan today, but indicated the grant was only a temporary expedient to lessen irritations between the two nations created by the Japanese-German anti-Communist agreement.

VIENNA, Dec. 23. -- Hundreds of parcels from all parts of the Continent and even from America and Africa are pouring into Enzesfeld's small postoffice for the Duke of Windsor. He also receives innumerable gifts of flowers from women in Vienna, Budapest and other capitals, while Austrian peasants send hams, bacon and other foods and rugs,

NANKING, China, Thursday, Dec. 24. -- The difficult problem of release of Chiang Kai-shek, who is now entering the thirteenth day of his detainment, has finally developed sharply into China's age-old conflict between family and State.
HAVANA, Dec. 23. -- President Miguel Mariano Gomez's statement in his own defense at his impeachment trial today follows:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Having sterilized gold, the Treasury took steps today to catch some of the yellow metal out of the air.

Steel ingot production for Christmas week will average about 78 per cent of capacity, but unless labor troubles in the automobile industry are settled speedily widespread shutdowns are likely to result. Iron Age said yesterday in its weekly summary.

HAVANA, Thursday, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Dr. Federico Laredo Bru, who as Vice President automatically succeeded the ousted President Miguel Mariano Gomez as Chief Executive of Cuba, was born in the town of San Juan de Los Remedios, Santa Clara Province, April 23, 1875.

Columbia, New York University, Yeshiva College, Cornell and the Carnegie Institute of Technology opened play in the annual tournament of the Intercollegiate Chess League for the Harold M. Phillips Trophy at the rooms of the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday.

A plot 166 by 206 feet at Parsons Boulevard and Bayside Avenue, Flushing, has been sold by the Brooklyn Trust Company, as trustee, to a client of Louis Winer, attorney. The buyer intends to erect a six-story apartment house, construction to commence in the Spring of 1937.

A man who was long a British Foreign Minister, Lord SALISBURY, used to say that any international dispute could be settled by four men sitting at a table. His successors at London today seem to be acting in the belief that this is true. For some weeks the British Foreign Office has been busily taking up one difficult question after another with foreign nations.

MOSCOW, Dec. 23. -- The Soviet railway system, which under L.M. Kaganovitch has made remarkable progress since his appointment as Commissar for Transport less than two years ago, is now slumping badly. The government is taking stern measures to remedy the situation.

Thirty men and women representing East Side tenants faced with eviction on Jan. 1 appealed to Mayor La Guardia yesterday for aid and were referred to Harry M. Prince, Deputy Tenement House Commissioner.

New York City's 1936 Christmas had a prologue yesterday which will be repeated today. Parties and entertainments were held in the schools, in business houses, hospitals, public buildings and scores of philanthropic agencies feted the unfortunates to whom Christmas otherwise would be only Dec. 25.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23. -- Hog prices advanced 15 to 25 cents to a new high since last October, the top of $10.40 a hundredweight being 10 cents above yesterday. The current price level is the highest for December in ten years. The day's average advanced 10 cents to $10.20.

The resignation of Don Oscar Becque as director of the WPA Federal Dance Theatre was accepted yesterday by Philip W. Barber, regional director of the Federal Theatre Project. Mr. Barber announced that Lincoln Kirstein, organizer with Edward M.M. Warburg of the American Ballet, would head the dance project in its next production.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The United States will adhere to its policy of avoiding exclusively bilateral discussions of broad Pacific problems with Japan or any other nation, but is expected to encourage consideration of peace machinery in the Pacific among all interested powers.
Five ships arrived here yesterday from Europe from twenty-eight to forty hours late because of North Atlantic storms.

Miss Mary McCord, a theatre matron licensed by the Health Department, who led 400 children from a burning motion-picture theatre on Sept. 15, received a city certificate of commendation yesterday from Mayor La Guardia in City Hall.

NANKING, Dec. 23. -- One foreigner was shot and killed by Chinese soldiers in Sian, according to definite word received here today in a letter put aboard the airplane that brought T.V. Soong to Nanking Monday.
BOSTON, Dec. 23. -- Doctors decided today that Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., who is recovering from throat and sinus infections, must remain in Massachusetts General Hospital "for a few more days."

Hotel operators have purchased $630,000 of New York World Fair debentures, it was announced yesterday by Frank W. Kridel, managing director of the Hotel Lincoln, at a meeting of the hotels division of the bond sales committee at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

PARIS, Thursday, Dec. 24. -- Pertinax and other experts on foreign affairs writing for the Paris newspapers tell of an important conference yesterday between Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos and the German Ambassador to Paris, Count Johannes yon Welczeck.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 23 (AP). -- Pittsburgh's steel mills distributed more than $6,250,000 of Christmas pay today to the 88,600 workers in the district, the biggest steel payroll since 1929.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Saul Streit, who was recently elected Judge of the Court of General Sessions, was sworn in yesterday by Surrogate James A. Foley in his court room in the Hall of Records. The ceremony was brief and was witnessed by Judge James G. Wallace of General Sessions, Ira W. Hirschfield, Judge Streit's law partner, several friends and the court attaches.

The development of musical taste in this city is perhaps nowhere more strikingly manifested than this season at the Metropolitan Opera House. Observe that the present season began Monday night with an eminently serious opera, not ordinarily considered a work for a first-night audience -- "Die Walkuere."

On the eve of their departure for Chile to compete in the international horse show at Valparaiso in February, the five members of the United States Army horse show team were bidden bon voyage at a luncheon given yesterday by the Chile-American Association at India House.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the week-end, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local private and public elementary and high schools:

Testimony contradicting the impression given by Robert L. Hoguet, president of the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, that banks controlled few of the old-law tenements on the lower East Side was given yesterday to the New York City Housing Authority by Mrs. Samuel I. Rosenman, wife of the Supreme Court justice.

If further evidence were needed to prove the desirability of prompt amendment of the present Federal mandatory deportation legislation, it was supplied by the Federal court proceedings at Mamaroneck a few days ago. The "moral turpitude" clause of the law left Judge FRANCIS G. CAFFEY no discretion: he could neither do justice nor show mercy.

Higher prices ruled over a fairly broad and representative list of issues in bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Price averages generally were moderately higher on the day in virtually all groups although the trading pace showed little change from earlier in the week.

Not even those New York families in direst need will have to do without complete Christmas dinners tomorrow, for seventy Salvation Army workers labored nine hours yesterday in the basement of Madison Square Garden, packing 5,000 bags with chickens, vegetables and all the "trimmings" for distribution today throughout the city.

VATICAN CITY, Dec. 23. -- Fears began to be expressed in the Vatican for the first time today that the Pope may never again be able to walk. Reports allegedly originating from his bedroom are being passed from mouth to mouth stating that the varicose veins of his left leg have reached such an advance stage that it is doubtful whether he ever will be fable to use it.
William Tatem Tilden 2d, his long head popping out of a big blue blanket, made plans yesterday for his seventh year as a tennis professional.

Maybe I am a back number, but going uptown in a Fifth Avenue bus today I came upon a racket that was new to me. Directly behind me sat a modishly dressed young woman, and it was not until she touched my shoulder several times that I realized she was trying to attract attention.

Su Lin, the baby giant panda that was captured in a Chinese rhododendron jungle near Tibet nearly two months ago, arrived at Grand Central Terminal yesterday, blinky, sleepy and hungry. It clung close to its adopted mother, Mrs. Williams H. Harkness Jr., the explorer, who has carried it half way around the world by wha-gar, pony, plane, train, ship and afoot.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 23. -- Although Brazil's Presidential election is a year off, political leaders are actively preparing for the campaign.

DETROIT, Dec. 23. -- Stockholders of the Kelvinator Corporation approved a merger with the Nash Motors Company at a special meeting here today. Announcement of the approval said that 878,772 shares had been voted for the merger and 1,200 shares were voted against it. The company has 1,196,800 shares outstanding.

I was so shocked by the report in THE TIMES of the fire in Seventy-third Street, in which five persons lost their lives, that I was prompted to look up the fire record in this city. It shows that approximately 36,000 fires occur in the city annually with losses of hundreds of human lives and millions of dollars of property.

A nominal bid of $10,000 was made yesterday by the Central Savings Bank, plaintiff, in taking over at foreclosure auction the twenty-four-story Kent Columbus Garage at the northwest corner of Columbus Avenue and Sixty-first Street. The sale was held by Edwin J. McDonald, auctioneer, in an action against the Columbus Realty Corporation, defendant, to satisfy a judgment of $1,028,395.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 23. -- Concluding his three-day visit to a region where public sentiment openly supports organized outlawry, Governor Earle pledged himself and his administration today to bring a new deal to the people of the anthracite coal fields.

Liquor and last-minute "pick-up" purchases came to the fore in holiday trade here yesterday. Main floor departments were particularly busy and store attendance during the afternoon shopping hours was heavy. Volume in general dipped under the previous two days of this week, but this was expected.

TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Japanese political leaders predicted today a bitter Parliamentary fight over the nation's foreign and financial politicies as legislators assembled for the convocation of the seventieth session of the Diet.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23. -- More than fifty of Connie Mack's friends, including former players, baseball writers and club associates, gave him a surprise turkey luncheon as he celebrated his seventy-fourth birthday today.

The grand jury's investigation of the so-called garnishee racket, in which hundreds of city employes are said to have been victimized of nearly $2,000,000 in recent years, took on added impetus yesterday when one of the thirteen men indicted last Tuesday agreed to testify.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 23 (AP). -- The Pittsburgh Hornets won an International-American Hockey League game from the New Haven Eagles tonight, 3 to 2, by virtue of an accidental assist by an Eagle player.

Twenty-seven hours after hearing a charge Tuesday afternoon at 4 o'clock, a jury in Federal court came in last night with a verdict of guilty in the case of fourteen men accussed of using the mails in 1933 and 1934 to swindle the public of $5,000,000 in the sale of stock of the Rayon Industries Corporation.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Dec. 24. -- At a request from T.V. Soong, former Finance Minister, telegraphed from Sian, Shansi Province, yesterday, the government at Nanking has granted another two-and-a-half-day armistice to General Chang Hsueh-liang's rebel troops who hold Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek prisoner.

Reductions of $5 in the 1937 cost of personal liability insurance and of $1 in the property damage rate for New York City rates were announced yesterday by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance. The new rates, effective in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Bronx and Western Queens, will be $90 for the standard $10,000 insurance on bodily injury and $18 for $5,000 on property damage.

Though it seems a little late for the news to be getting around, it develops that Walter Duranty and Maurice Hindus sat down a couple of years ago and wrote a play. About Russia, naturally. The title is "A New Day"; it is a picture of everyday life in a Moscow apartment house in 1930 and, according to Mr. Duranty, most of it was written by Mr. Hindus.

Mrs. Bayard Livingston Peck and Mrs. Theodore Burgess Brown of Brooklyn presented their daughters, the Misses Barbara Livingston Peck and Miriam Walley Brown, to society yesterday at a tea dance at the Ritz-Carlton.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23. -- More than fifty of Connie Mack's friends, including former players, baseball writers and club associates, gave him a surprise turkey luncheon as he celebrated his seventy-fourth birthday today.

The grand jury's investigation of the so-called garnishee racket, in which hundreds of city employes are said to have been victimized of nearly $2,000,000 in recent years, took on added impetus yesterday when one of the thirteen men indicted last Tuesday agreed to testify.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 23 (AP). -- The Pittsburgh Hornets won an International-American Hockey League game from the New Haven Eagles tonight, 3 to 2, by virtue of an accidental assist by an Eagle player.

Twenty-seven hours after hearing a charge Tuesday afternoon at 4 o'clock, a jury in Federal court came in last night with a verdict of guilty in the case of fourteen men accussed of using the mails in 1933 and 1934 to swindle the public of $5,000,000 in the sale of stock of the Rayon Industries Corporation.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Dec. 24. -- At a request from T.V. Soong, former Finance Minister, telegraphed from Sian, Shansi Province, yesterday, the government at Nanking has granted another two-and-a-half-day armistice to General Chang Hsueh-liang's rebel troops who hold Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek prisoner.

Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Stockwell Barringer gave a tea dance yesterday at the National Society of Colonial Dames, 215 East Seventy-third Street, to introduce their daughter, Miss Velona Barringer. The decorations were in keeping with the Christmas season.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 23. -- Running the fastest five and a half furlongs of the meeting, Elmer Dale Shaffer's two-year-old filly, Log, an invader from Kentucky, surprised the crowd at Tropical Park today by winning the featured Palmetto Purse.
JACKSON, Mich., Dec. 23. -- A three-channel radio reception system has been made available in all the 4,070 cells of the Southern Michigan prison here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- President Roosevelt and Vice President Garner concluded a deal today whereby they canceled the formal dinners which social custom decrees they shall tender each other annually.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 23. -- The battle for Madrid extended its front some 3,000 miles to include this former Spanish royal colony when Consul General Jacinto Ventosa had an encounter with a group of sympathizers of Generalissimo Francisco Franco which resulted in a scalp wound for the consul.

The Academy of Music at Fourteenth Street and Irving Place, once the leading opera house of old New York, was revealed in Federal Court yesterday as being so tangled up in modern mortgages that it is an unprofitable venture to the owners of the leasehold, even as a movie theatre.

According to our Washington dispatches, the President is expected to propose to the new Congress a thoroughgoing reorganization of the administrative machinery of the Government, but he has put out of his mind the thought that any great reduction of expenditures will automatically accrue from it.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission had under consideration today a plan to reorganize the Jersey Mortgage and Title Company of Elizabeth, N.J.

Charges that the Board of Education was awarding construction and alteration "plums" to "hand-picked" architectural firms at a cost far exceeding what it would be if the board's own bureau of construction and maintenance did the work were made yesterday afternoon by Colonel Walter Jeffreys Carlin, Democratic member from Brooklyn.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 23. -- The Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace ended tonight as the Foreign Ministers of Paraguay and Bolivia pledged that their countries would settle the Chaco dispute by pacific means.

The stock market continued yesterday the recovery that was started on Tuesday. Petroleum, steel, motor and various specialty shares made the widest gains, while the copper group, which featured Tuesday's market, moved irregularly. Trading increased on the recovery, with transactions on the Stock Exchange amounting to 1,868,000 shares, against 1,667,000 the day before.

The strength in the oil shares yesterday was attributed in part to the growing realization of the improved outlook for that industry in the coming year. The demand for oil products is expected to increase, and better prices for both crude oil and its products are in prospect.
The Chase National Bank is prepared to deliver definitive Narragansett Electric Company first mortgage bonds, Series A, 3 per cent, due on July 1, 1966, in exchange for temporary bonds.

Several hundred Christmas shoppers paused for a half hour late yesterday afternoon in the plaza of Rockefeller Center to listen to the Lincoln Cathedral Choir sing a group of carols. This was the first local program of the choir of almost sixty mixed voices that arrived yesterday at noon from Lincoln, Neb.
BEAUMONT, Texas, Dec. 23 (AP). -- The Beaumont Journal said today that the suicide of Larry Lothar Glass, 26, appeared to have been a result of his exile from Germany by the Nazis.

The message the Pope is determined to broadcast to the world on Christmas Eve will add to the cheer of a great many people outside his spiritual jurisdiction. They will be glad that PIUS XI is able to prove, in the way he wishes, that he is still alive. They will rejoice at the victory of a strong-willed patient.

While eight customers, including several women and a small boy, huddled behind a partition in the rear, a patrolman and a Negro hold-up man who died later of his wounds exchanged ten shots at 7 o'clock last night in an Atlantic and Pacific store at 2,058 Madison Avenue, near 130th Street.

PERHAPS the majority of the rhapsodic and articulate nature lovers of the past have lived in sections where nature was at once most kind and most firmly controlled. Strangers to either jungle or blizzard, they established themselves in wooded patches in the midst of settled, prosperous countryside, not too far from the conveniences of a large city.

Winning two of their adjourned games and drawing the other two for a total count of three points out of a possible four, Harvard's chess players once more emerged victoriously from the annual tournament of the H.Y.P.D. College Chess League at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday.

GLEN COVE, N.Y., Dec. 23. -- Many members of society who have their country homes on the North Shore have kept them open this year until after the holidays and more large family parties than have been held for several seasons are taking place over Christmas.

MOSCOW, Dec. 23. -- It appears increasingly probable tonight that the Soviet will take no concrete measures over the sinking of the Komsomol, one of its newest and best merchant ships, near Spain, Dec. 14.

As a college lecturer, professor and president, SIMEON D. FESS was in his proper element and environment. The head of Antioch College has a field and an opportunity of fruitful labor more momentous and lasting than most Senators and Representatives in Congress can cultivate.

The twenty-seventh annual Cinderella Dance, for young women who have not made their debut, was held last night at the Heights Casino, Brooklyn, under the chairmanship of Mrs. Adrian Van Sinderen. The dance, which is the oldest given consecutively in Brooklyn, was founded by Mrs. James Guthrie Shaw of Manhattan, formerly of Brooklyn.

LONDON, Dec. 24. -- Plans to stimulate trade by the barter of goods between the British Empire and Germany were revealed today when the formation of a private enterprise known as Compensation Brokers, Ltd., was made known in London.

While the New York Postoffice was ending yesterday the final twenty-four hours of the record-breaking Christmas rush, Postmaster Albert Goldman said that every effort would be made to have mail delivered for Christmas.

Hundreds of neighbors at dusk on Christmas Eve made their way afoot and in automobiles to the century-old thatched barn on the estate of Albert C. Fach, lawyer, on Manor Road, Four Corners, S.I., to see a life-size scene of the birth of the Christ Child in the manger.
PARIS, Dec. 24 (AP). -- The good Pere Noel, descending on wings instead of in the sleigh he uses in America, visited many French homes tonight.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association. Inc.:

With main floor and liquor sales outstanding, Christmas trade here came to an active close yesterday. Retail executives estimated that about half of the last-minute shopping was concentrated on main floors, with the toy and lingerie departments also making a good showing for the day.

A buoyant tone ruled in the more speculative sections of the bond market yesterday despite the usual pre-holiday atmosphere and smaller trading volume. Secondary railroad and leading sugar bonds led a spirited advance among the domestic corporate obligations, while South American Government and provincial loans continued their upward movement, with many reaching new high levels for the year.
GENEVA, Dec. 24. -- Switzerland's recognition of Italy's conquest of Ethiopia has caused a very bad impression in League of Nations quarters.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- A streamlined Resettlement Administration report, gay in a jacket of red, green and brown and detailing the activities of the agency, headed by Rexford G. Tugwell, during its first year added a touch of Christmas color today to President Roosevelt's desk.

Alderman Alexander Falk, one of the framers of the new Traffic Code signed this week by Mayor La Guardia, wrote a letter yesterday to Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., Chief City Magistrate, protesting against the jurist's reported statement that uniform fines would be fixed for offenses under the new code.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Several of the nation's leading athletes worked out today for New Orleans' third annual midwinter sports program, which will get under way Sunday with a track and field meet.

It was the day before Christmas, and all through the neighborhood of Park Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street a score of boys from the East River waterfront were scattered in cellar doorways, anxious eyes fastened on the entrance to the Union League Club.

BERLIN, Dec. 24. -- Well-informed sources tonight predicted that Chancellor Adolf Hitler and his chief aides would confer tomorrow or Saturday over Germany's entire future policy in the Spanish civil war.

MADRID, Dec. 24. -- Last evening's remarkable advance of three miles toward Boadilla del Monte, just west of Madrid, over terrain that it had taken the Insurgents ten days' fighting to conquer, holds elements of intense interest that it is too soon to gauge.

Without losing one game of eleven contested, the players of New York University took a long lead yesterday in the annual championship tournament of the Intercollegiate Chess League for the challenge trophy placed in competition by Harold M. Phillips, president of the Manhattan Chess Club, where play will continue daily until Tuesday.

The New York Rovers will be out to gain some ground on the league-leading Atlantic City Sea Gulls when the Red Shirts meet the Baltimore Orioles in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League clash at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Yoshe Kalb won't be able to show his face around here for a while; the Dybbuk will have to stay outside the seven-mile limit, for one Jacob Prager has written a Chassidic play to end all Chassidic plays, and it was presented by the Yiddish Art Theatre last night at the Forty-ninth Street as its second offering of the season.

The Carib Syndicate, Ltd., yesterday notified stockholders that its directors had decided to defer action on the sale of its holdings of 20.868 shares of the Colombian Petroleum Company. Stockholders recently approved the sale of this stock to bankers for $2,000,000, but court action was taken by a stockholder to prevent the sale.
Deals involving business and housing properties in three boroughs were announced yesterday.

Contrary to a usual quiet market on the eve of the holidays, trading on the Cotton Exchange broadened yesterday under as large a volume of business as at any time this season. Whether due to prospects of a freer export trade with Germany or to fears of political developments in Europe, a heavy foreign business was transacted early.

Miss Sarah Churchill, 22-year-old daughter of Winston Churchill, veteran British statesman, and Vic Oliver, stage comedian, who is sixteen years her senior, were married shortly before 10:30 A.M. yesterday in the chapel of the Marriage License Bureau in the Municipal Building.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 24. -- Gifts and bequests totalling $304,954 were received by Princeton University during the academic year which ended last June, it was disclosed today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university, in his annual report to the board of trustees. The total for the last academic year was $569,104.

OTTAWA, Dec. 24 (Canadian Press). --Dominion government deposits with the Bank of Canada declined$2,582,717 in the week ended yesterday, according to the weekly statement of the bank issued today. Deposits by chartered banks decreased $2,205.762.

Even when political controversies are heated, they cool off in Christmas week. Strident cries of politicians are a part of the "horrid din" which is said to vanish in the silent night of the Nativity. This year there has been no conflict, no noise of that kind, to be quieted.

ROSLYN, L.I., Dec. 24. -- Several hundred motorists lined three intersecting highways in Roslyn Harbor this evening to hear the concert of Christmas carols from the carillon at Brook Corners, estate of Arthur Williams, former vice president of the New York Edison Company and a member of the committee that planned the first lighted Christmas tree in New York about twenty-five years ago.

Arrangements have been completed to seat more than 1,000 persons expected to attend the Christmas Day concert by the Lincoln Cathedral Choir on the Park Avenue Terrace of the Waldorf-Astoria, where the a cappella choir sang last Christmas Day after its debut upon the national scene with President Roosevelt last Christmas Eve.

VATICAN CITY, Dec. 24. -- Pope Pius broadcast his announced Christmas message to the world from his Vatican sickbed promptly at 12:30 P.M. today (6:30 A.M. Eastern Standard time) and the people who still believed or even only hoped that he was not seriously ill were shocked and grieved by the voice coming to them over the radio.

John Brangwyn, author of "Everybody's Paris," has received an award of 25,000 francs from the French Government, according to word received by his publisher, Robert M. McBride. Mr. Brangwyn's book on Paris was judged the best work dealing with that city from a tourist's point of view.

PARIS, Dec. 24. -- In his Berchtesgaden villa Chancellor Hitler is called upon to solve the following problem: Will he send fresh troops to Spain or will he refuse to plunge deeper in Spanish affairs and reject unlimited liabilities?

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- Lighting Washington's community Christmas tree at dusk this evening in Lafayette Park, President Roosevelt counseled the nation to keep the Christmas spirit alive throughout the year.

A sharp gain in private construction contracts in the metropolitan area was made last month over November, 1935, according to the F.W. Dodge Corporation, which estimates that this class of construction accounted for $18,031,100 of the $24,284,500 total during the four weeks.

As a result of the sharp upturn in sales this year, amounting to 25 per cent, the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company will substantially increase its 1937 advertising and promotional budget over the campaign for 1936, H.S. Wherrett, president, announced yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Philip Kip Rhinelander and Mr. and Mrs. John Livingston Thomas gave their customary Christmas Eve party last night in their connecting apartments at 141 East Eighty-eighth Street. The celebration began with a family dinner in the Rhinelander apartment at which Major Philip Rhinelander, father of Mr. Rhinelander and Mrs. Thomas, was guest of honor.

Commodity futures resumed their advance yesterday in active trading. Rubber futures again established new high levels for the last six years in heavy trading. In the cash market, all grains, flour, cocoa, lard, cotton and rubber were higher, while butter, eggs and tin were lower.
ATLANTA, Dec. 24. -- California's Golden Bears invaded Atlanta today for a post-season game with the Engineers of Georgia Tech Saturday.

Income-tax liens aggregating more than $1,000,000 were filed against eight individuals and five corporations in Federal court yesterday by James J. Hoey and Joseph T. Higgins, Collectors of Internal Revenue for the Second and Third Districts, respectively.

When the Grace liner Santa Maria warped out of her berth at Pier 57 in the North River yesterday bound for Valparaiso, Chile, she had on board five members of the United States Army horse show team, ten jumpers and five orderlies.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, in an exchange of correspondence with a 14-year-old pupil of a New Jersey high school, has commended the study of Latin as a preparation for "intelligent understanding of the world."

While trading in wool goods was not quite as active this week, sales continued to run ahead of production and mills expanded their already substantial backlogs, with indications pointing to capacity operations through the first quarter of next year at least, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 24. -- Night Play, black 3-year-old in the Detroit-owned Bomar Stable silks of C.B. Bohn and P.A. Markey, scored with as much ease as any winner at the meeting in the Pahokee purse, six-furlong dash for all ages that commanded chief interest on today's program at Tropical Park.

MANHASSET, L.I., Dec. 24. -- One woman, an occupant of one of the apartments, was assisted from the burning building and four firemen were overcome by smoke while fighting a fire which swept a two-story combination store and apartment building at Plandome Road and Hillside Avenue, here, late today.
Elaborate electric displays on the large estates in the Oranges and Montclair, and the singing of carols in the streets featured Christmas Eve celebrations in New Jersey communities last night.

HAVANA, Dec. 24. -- Colonel Federico Laredo Bru, former Vice President, was sworn in as President of Cuba at noon today, succeeding Dr. Miguel Mariano Gomez, who was removed after impeachment early this morning.

Christmas stockings filled with toys will be given today to every child in the eighty-eight voluntary hospitals of this city, it was announced yesterday by the United Hospital Fund campaign committee, which is seeking $2,881,644 for the hospitals.
MOSCOW, Dec. 24. -- This country is preparing itself, materially and psychologically, for an expected war with amazing zeal and thoroughness.

Having just returned to London after an extended tour in Africa, I have only now seen the references to British building societies in your issue of Oct. 4 by the Federal Housing Administrator, Stewart McDonald.

LONDON, Dec. 24. -- David Lloyd George, the former war-time Prime Minister of Great Britain, who is spending a vacation in Jamaica, sent the following message today to Edward, Duke of Windsor, at Enzesfeld, Austria:

CHICAGO, Dec. 24. -- Prices of hogs soared 5 to 25 cents here today to a new ten-year high for December, with light kinds showing the most strength. Weights under 190 pounds led the upturn. The day's top of $10.45 a hundredweight showed an advance of 5 cents from Wednesday, while the day's average was 10 cents higher at $10.30.

The shining achievement of last night's Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra concert at Carnegie Hall was the performance of Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 5, known as the "Emperor." It had the benefit of Josef Hofmann's masterly playing as soloist, and he was companioned in a vibrant interpretation by John Barbirolli and the orchestra.

HAVANA, Dec. 24. -- The Cuban army, built up from 8,000 to 22,000 during the past three years, must be reckoned with not merely as an instrument of force but also as a powerful political force. Added to this is the military reserve of about 40,000 and 10,000 women reservists who, with relatives and friends, constitute a political nucleus of considerable importance.
NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 24. -- Hueu, heavily played favorite from Clyde Troutt's stable, made good today when he captured the six-furlong claiming feature at the Fair Grounds.
LONDON, Dec. 24 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 24. -- Assignments, promotions and transfers of twenty-three priests in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Newark were made today by Bishop Thomas J. Walsh to take effect next Wednesday.

Shouts of "we want jobs" mingled with the strains of "Adeste Fideles" in City Hall Park yesterday as two WPA groups unexpectedly came together near the foot of the lighted sixty-foot Christmas tree in City Hall Park.

The city of Chicago, announced yesterday that it would receive sealed bids on Jan. 5, for a new issue of $12,349,000 of judgment funding bonds. The bonds will mature in twenty years and will be optional, $4,000,000 in 1945 and 1947 and $4,349,000 in 1949. They will carry a fixed interest rate of 3 per cent.

The New York Stock Exchange has admitted to the list Freeport Sulphur Company (formerly the Freeport Texas Company) $10-par common stock and 6 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock in substitution for the same issues under the former title.

Forgetting official routine in real Christmas spirit, Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine and Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott took half an hour off yesterday to see that all was going well with the distribution of 30,000 toys to the city's poor children.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Dec. 25. -- A sensational development that means either the beginning of a large-scale civil war tomorrow or a definite, early arrangement for release of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek occurred at Nanking last night, when War Minister Ho Yin-chin telegraphed Chang Hsueh-liang in Sian sternly warning that there would be no more extensions of the armistice after tonight.

The New York City Tunnel Authority has been authorized to proceed at once with construction of the Manhattan ventilating shaft for the Queens Midtown Vehicular Tunnel. Arthur S. Tuttle, State director for the PWA, announced yesterday.

Igor Stravinsky, who arrived in New York yesterday on the Normandie, announced that his latest composition, a ballet of which the subject is a poker game, has been written exclusively for the American Ballet which dances at the Metropolitan Opera House, and will be produced there for the first time in April.
Two "profit-sharing" coupons issued by the same shop linked a 'bystander" at the hold-up of a Harlem grocery store to the robbers and resulted yesterday in his arrest.

The sign of the Red Cross, usually the guarantee of protection in war, has brought death and destruction to the Loyalist forces in the Spanish war because Italian planes aiding the Insurgents habitually strafe anything bearing the mark, it was charged yesterday by Ralph Bates. English novelist.
MADRID, Dec. 24. -- The Canadian blood transfusion service, directed by the Montreal surgeon Dr. Norman Bethune, is now operating at full force.

Three families were made homeless when two houses were destroyed by fire in Jersey City, last night. The two two-story frame buildings were situated at 510 Montgomery Street and 123 Fremont Street, a corner in the industrial section of Jersey City.
ROME, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Gayety and solemnity mingled in Italy's Christmas Eve celebration.

Frolicking animals of many species, emerging joyously two by two from Noah's Ark, are the chief characters in a mural painting recently completed by the WPA Federal Art Project in the children's playroom of First Houses. First Houses is the New York City Housing Authority's low-rent housing project of eight buildings at Avenue A and Third Street.

Pre-holiday dullness prevailed only in the security markets yesterday; commodities were active and strong. Stocks closed irregularly higher in the slowest trading for a full day since Oct. 27. The turnover on the Stock Exchange was 1,607,000 shares.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- Following is President Roosevelt's Christmas message to the country:

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 24. -- Baron Capelle secretary to King Leopold, emphatically denied today all reports that the King had become engaged and rebuked a section of the press for making free with his name.
As a result of the large dividend distributions, bonuses and holiday buying, bank clearings in the week ended on Wednesday rose to the highest point since Oct. 8, 1931.

New York flung itself yesterday into the merriest Christmas it has known in many years. Old records for travel, mail distribution, exchange of gifts, vanished in the almost unprecedented spending. Purses were loosened as never before in the nation's history.

Americans who have not lived in South America are prone to read with mild astonishment that the early opposition apparent in the Buenos Aires Peace Conference to a complete divorcement of the nations of the Western Hemisphere from the League of Nations arises from strong ties that bind the peoples of the southern continent to the Old World.

A young woman identified by personal papers as Anna Corcoran, 21 years old, of 33-18 Sixty-first Street, Woodside, Queens, was killed by a truck about 6 o'clock last night as she hurried across Van Dam Street at Varick Street with her arms filled with Christmas bundles.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- A survey of the relief and unemployment problem discloses that the lack of employability is one of the major reasons for the maintenance of millions of persons at public expense.
TOKYO, Dec. 24. -- The first words officially spoken in the new House of Representatives today were a challenge to the army's political ideas.

The two out-of-town teams which will perform in Madison Square Garden next Wednesday night will join forces in their efforts to make a successful showing against their New York City rivals. Stanford University, which meets Long Island University in one of the games scheduled, will travel to Washington tomorrow to oppose Georgetown in a practice scrimmage.

Spokesmen of the Pacific marine strikers and ship lines assured Secretary of Labor Perkins yesterday of their readiness to cooperate in ending the strike which has been under way fifty-six days, but each side charged that the other was to blame for the failure of efforts made thus far.

BERLIN, Dec. 24. -- The friendly German Christmas custom of recalling memories of the Fatherland not only to Reich citizens abroad but to all persons of German blood is being transformed into another occasion for political propaganda.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

On a Christmas when the spirit of peace and good-will seems conspicuous by its absence from the world of nations, and under its stars even the little town of Bethlehem lies guarded by grimmer sentinels than the shepherds of an older Judaea, it is still in the nature of man to hope and to look around the troubled earth for whatever signs there may be that the worst is not to come.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- Industrial production, wage payments and distribution of commodities to consumers increased from October to November, while wholesale prices have advanced steadily since the end of October, the Federal Reserve Board announced in its monthly review of business today.

Presiding Justice Francis Martin of the Appellate Division refused yesterday to take legal action to postpone , he competitive examinations for Emergency Relief Bureau workers scheduled for Dec. 30. He declared, however, that no rights would be waived by employes taking the examination.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Dec. 23, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,507,000,000, an increase of $11,000,000, compared with the preceding week and a decrease of $12,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

Several days ago the writer was sitting in the offices of the United States Bureau of Biological Survey in Washington, chatting with Stanley Young, dynamic chief of the division of game management. The activities of the law enforcement agencies of the bureau are included in this department.

Three transatlantic liners, the last of the Christmas ships to reach New York carrying mail and travelers bound for turkey dinners in American cities, arrived yesterday. Two of them docked at an unusually early hour to permit travelers to catch trains for inland points.

A couple of Clauses named Shubert are the heavy contributors to Christmas night along Broadway. They will usher into the Winter Garden the musical revue called "The Show Is On," the work also known, in its formative stage, as "that Lahr-Lillie show." Included in the proceedings, along with those two, are Reginald Gardiner, Mitzi Mayfair, Paul Haakon, Gracie Barrie, Charles Walters, Vera Allen, John McCauley, Evelyn Thawl and Ralph Riggs.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24. -- Football stars from East and West, training for the Shrine charity game New Year's Day, buckled down to blocking, scrimmage and downfield work on punts today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Wholesale prices again advanced in the week ended on Dec. 19, this being the eighth consecutive weekly increase, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average as 100, was 83.7, compared with 83.4 the preceding week and 80.4 a year ago.

BERLIN, Dec. 24. -- Politics, economic stringency, the clash of rival social systems and all that is disagreeable in life were forgotten in Germany tonight. German families are gathered around their Christmas trees.

Four women were treated for injuries sustained yesterday afternoon at a Christmas party in London Terrace in West Twenty-third Street between Ninth and Tenth Avenues, when a small porch, bearing about twenty persons, collapsed. They were treated by Dr. B.M. Shallette, a house physician, and taken to their apartments.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 24. -- Coach Jock Sutherland isn't saying a word but rumors creeping out of the Pittsburgh training camp whisper that the wily coach may be doping out a surprise to spring on Washington when his Panthers go into the Rose Bowl football game against the Huskies New Year's Day.

NANKING, China, Friday, Dec. 25. -- Evidently the negotiations at Sian for Chiang Kai-shek's release are proceeding extremely slowly, for no word of any kind has come of late from T.V. Soong, brother-in-law of the dictator, or from Mrs. Chiang Kai-shek.

Interest in the new open ice boat challenge trophy of the Rumson Country Club has resulted in a challenge being received from the Musconetcong Club on Lake Hopatcong. Other challenges are expected, particularly one from George E. Ruppert and George J. Gillig on behalf of their fast Pirate II of the North Shrewsbury Ice Boat and Yacht Club, it was learned yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 24. -- The Christmas season began in Westchester communities tonight with carol singing, pageantry, religious services and hundreds of family parties. Homes and lawns were ablaze with lights as colored electric bulbs were strung on trees and candles and wreaths hung on doors and in windows.

PEIPING, Friday, Dec. 25. -- The American and British military attaches, Colonel Jay Stillwell and Colonel Lovatt Fraser, left Peiping for Loyang today, hoping there to negotiate with government military leaders and arrange for evacuation of American and British citizens, mostly missionaries, at present trapped in the rebel areas of Shensi and Kansu Provinces.

PARIS, Dec. 24. -- On the eve of the three-day holiday the Bourse was irregular and closed weak. What little business was transacted was in the early hours. As closing time neared, business fell off and prices weakened, even among the international securities.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Tickets for National League baseball games in Crosley Field made up a part of the load Santa Claus left in Cincinnati tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- Progress in civil aeronautics in 1936 was greater than in any previous year in aviation history, Eugene L. Vidal, Director of Air Commerce, said today. He issued a statement reviewing the advances and achievements of the year, in which he said:

Well-informed little boys and girls know where is the ideal place to spend Christmas. It is on a transpacific clipper flying east. Thus the Philippine Clipper left Manila last Tuesday for California. It spent Christmas Eve at Wake Island, and this morning, Dec. 25, is on its way to Midway Island with a Christmas tree and fixings.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- Continuing its investigation of the operations of the Equity Corporation of New York and its numerous subsidiaries, the Securities and Exchange Commission contended today that Equity had used all the money it raised through the sale of its securities as well as substantial parts of the assets of subsidiaries to bring the United Founders group of investment trusts into the Equity network.

Current reports of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation continue to make cheerful reading. The pressure to which this useful agency of the Government was once subjected has long since lifted, and its assistance is no longer in great demand by the banks, mortgage companies and other private credit institutions which formerly borrowed heavily from it.

There has been a more or less conspicuous debut every night thus far in the Metropolitan season, and the fourth performance of that season was not an exception to this rule, for it introduced to the public of this city yesterday evening Mr. Johnson's new coloratura soprano, Miss Vina Bovy, who appeared as Violetta in "Traviata."
THE Christmas spirit is in the air and the time of the year has arrived when meanness is outlawed and generosity is king. Even Scrooge found that out.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 24. -- The motion picture industry celebrated Christmas today with expenditures exceeding the predepression era. Bonuses were paid by most of the studios to the lower salaried employes, and an estimated $250,000 was spent by agents, executives and stars in gifts for purely professional reasons. Hollywood and Beverly Hills merchants reported unprecedented buying of personal gifts.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 24. -- Following a precedent established three years ago, Mr. and Mrs. James Taylor Terry gave a tea today at their home. Christmas carols were sung by a group, dressed in medieval costumes, directed by Clegg Monroe, and by the guests.

The rise in "other loans," consisting chiefly of commercial loans, as reported by member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City, was carried $30,000,000 further in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the condition statement of the banks published yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 24. -- Dishwater skies, a thick fog and a forecast of unsettled weather threatened today to make Santa Anita's Christmas Day opening a damp affair.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 24. -- Conducted by Eugene Ormandy the Philadelphia Orchestra at its concert this afternoon, moved a day ahead on account of the holiday, played four numbers in recognition of Christmas.
The exhibition of rodeo impressions in sculpture, by Herbert Haseltine, current at the Carroll Carstairs Galleries, has been extended for the second time and will not close until Dee. 31.
The promotion of four sergeants to the rank of lieutenant was announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine.

More effective regulations of crude oil production by the States and an increase of nearly 10 per cent in gasoline demand, with an even greater gain in consumption of gas oil, distillate fuels and residual fuel oils enabled the oil industry in 1936 to work a steady improvement in all phases of its operations, according to W.S. Farish, chairman of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey in a year-end statement.

Gift divisions, with a sales increase of 45.5 per cent over last year, led the other sections in local department stores in November, according to the monthly analysis issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Furs, which were highest in the previous month, showed the second largest gain in November, the increase being 34.9 per cent.

The brokerage house of Secord Vanderpoel Co., Inc., which was the object of an injunction suit filed in 1935 by the Securities and Exchange Commission, Edward T. Vanderpoel, Washington Irving Vanderpoel. Lynn N. Secord, and thirteen office employes and salesmen of the company were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury.

LONDON, Dec. 24. -- Her travail at home and abroad momentarily forgotten in the festive spirit of Christmas, Britain joined the other nations of Christendom today in celebrating the eve of the holiday in her centuries-old fashion.

The importance of the Neediest Cases Fund as a philanthropic and educational institution in the life of the city was stressed yesterday in communications to THE NEW YORK TIMES by some of the directing heads of the charitable organizations that participate in the annual appeal.

George Blumenthal, for thirty years manager for the late Oscar Hammerstein and author of the book, "My Sixty Years in Show Business," revealed yesterday that he had discovered a statue of the impresario in a second-hand shop at 235 Centre Street.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed the reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.

Again the ships for the Neediest Cases have come in with gifts more precious than the cargoes which MASEFIELD, the sometime sailor and now Laureate of England, has listed in his verses: quinquireme of Nineveh from distant Ophir; stately galleon coming from the isthmus, and British coaster laden with coal and rails and ironware.

BERLIN, Dec. 24. -- The biggest land reclamation project in Europe, far surpassing Premier Mussolini's conversion of the Pontine marshes into fertile fields, is now being carried through with the driving power of the authoritarian National Socialist State in the northwesternmost corner of Germany, in Oldenburg, East Friesland and the Emsland along the Netherland frontier.

For the pathetic crippled music teacher of Case 134, for the "Six Thin Little Folk" of Case 239, for the "Old Mother and Crippled Son" of Case 283, as well as for scores of others of the Neediest, this Christmas Day will be a time of peace, of liberation from the tortures of despair.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 24. -- A total of 106 awards in Army Fall sports was announced today by Lieut. Col. J.L. Devers, graduate manager of athletics.
The New York Herald Tribune and THE NEW YORK TIMES remained alone this year in the newspaper field of fund collection for relief in New York.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 24. -- J. Victor D'Aloia, former police judge, announced today he had been retained to collect $3,500 which he said was owed by New Jersey to Pincus Fisch of Leipzig, Germany, and two sisters, for their loss of time and earnings in coming to Flemington as State witnesses in the trial of Bruno Richard Hauptmann for the kidnap-murder of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr.

GENEVA, Dec. 24. -- His faith in Kansas was rewarded when a fifteen-pound dressed turkey was delivered yesterday to David Vaage, Norwegian chief of the industrial safety service of the International Labor Office.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 24. -- Westchester County has no intention of refinancing its outstanding bonds, although it would like to do so were such a procedure found practical and economical, the budget committee of the Board of Supervisors today informed the Westchester County Taxpayers Association.

BERLIN, Dec. 24. -- New restrictions on foreigners' use of their own money blocked in Germany were issued yesterday. There is now little that a foreign investor can do freely with his funds even within the Reich's borders.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Dec. 24 (AP). -- Governor Chandler rejected today a plea that four Harlan County miners involved in the "battle of Evarts" receive their freedom as a Christmas gift.

POTTSVILLE, Pa., Dec. 24. -- Mrs. Antoinette Billig, charged with aiding in the escape from the Schuylkill County prison of her father, Joseph J. Bruno, was released from jail this afternoon in bail of $15,500. Judge Roy P. Hicks, presiding judge of the County Court, had raised the original amount by $500.

With thousands of last-minute shoppers crowding the stores, the largest Christmas trade here since 1930 came to its end yesterday. Sales surpassed expectations in many departments in the final surge of buying, and retail executives pointed to many empty shelves toward the end of the day as unmistakable evidence of the business done.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- Production and employment in both the cement and optical goods industries reflected substantial increases in 1935, compared with 1933, according to the biennial census of manufacturers issued today by the Commerce Department.

BETHLEHEM, Palestine, Friday, Dec. 25 (AP). -- Worshipers from many lands thronged the ancient Church of the Nativity and the adjoining St. Catherine's Church early today in a joyous celebration of Christ's birth here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- The General Motors Corporation and its subsidiaries have filed a denial of the complaint issued on Dec. 2 by the Federal Trade Commission charging twenty-one automobile and finance companies with false and misleading representation concerning the amount of interest paid by purchasers under deferred payment plans.

DETROIT, Dec. 24 (AP). -- A union demand for a "general conference" with officers of the General Motors Corporation to discuss collective bargaining was sent to the company tonight less than twenty-four hours after the settlement of two strikes in automotive parts factories.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- Mellowing with the spirit of Christmas, the Postmaster General of the United States -- in his capacity as chairman of the Democratic National Committee -- offered the Republicans a rich gift this week. In a speech at the National Press Club luncheon in his honor he expressed hope for "a strong Republican opposition -- but not too strong" -- as essential to good government.
SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Discouraged searchers failed again tonight to learn where two airliners crashed with nine persons.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24. -- Prices of wheat and rye advanced sharply today in one of the most active pre-holiday markets seen in several years. Aggressive commission-house buying and short covering swept aside all opposition, and closing trades on the Board of Trade were at the top with net gains of 3 1/4 to 3 5/8 cents a bushel.
BERLIN, Dec. 24. -- German trade with Spain has declined as a result of the Spanish civil war, but Germany has already taken measures to resume and increase that trade as opportunities offer.

RACINE, Wis., Dec. 24 (AP). -- The United Automobile Workers Union, involved in a dispute that has shut down the J.I. Case Company plants here for eight weeks, decided today to place before its membership a three-point peace proposal.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 24. -- Two men were killed and a third critically injured tonight when an automobile was in collision with the rear end of a parked oil truck on North MacQuesten Parkway, near Putnam Street.

Fearful of their personal liability in any suits which may be brought against them, the members of the School Relief Committee, which for the last five years has been supervising the distribution of daily free lunches to 100,000 needy school pupils, have resigned in a body, it was learned yesterday. The resignations were submitted to the Board of Education at an executive meeting of the board Wednesday night.
VIENNA, Dec. 24. -- The Duke of Windsor celebrated Christmas Eve quietly at Enzesfeld.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 24 (AP). -- The Argentine subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, the largest foreign oil company operating in Argentina, announced today it was negotiating for sale of its Argentine properties to the government.
VATICAN CITY, Dec. 24. -- The official translation of today's radio address of Pope Pius follows:

CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 24 (AP). -- The State Ballot Law Commission's second recount of ballots cast in New Hampshire's disputed First District Congressional election today gave A.B. Jenks, Republican, a two-vote lead over Alphonse Roy, Democrat.

Figures submitted by the first twelve railroads to report for November reflected a marked acceleration in the increase of both gross revenues and net operating income compared with previous months. The aggregate increase in gross reported by these carriers for November, compared correspondingly with 1935, was 21.8 per cent, whereas their gain in October was 16.7 per cent.

PARIS, Dec. 24. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler, at Berchtesgaden this week-end, must face the most important decision of his life, in the opinion of those here who, in the last few weeks, have been building up the diplomatic situation that reached a climax yesterday in Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos's interview with Count Johannes von Welczeck, the German Ambassador.

In a letter which you published Dec. 8 I endeavored to indicate that the proportional representation in the City Council could be obtained without the complexities of preferential voting and without the intricacies involved in counting the votes.

Radio listeners throughout this country, Canada and foreign lands were in tune yesterday afternoon with the first operatic broadcast this year from the Metropolitan stage -- Humperdinck's "Hansel and Gretel."

With the exception of grain markets in Chicago and other American cities, which will be open for business tomorrow, the principal securities and commodities markets of the country will remain closed until Monday morning. Foreign grain markets will observe tomorrow as a holiday, while the domestic grain centers will be closed on Jan. 2.
PARIS. Dec. 24 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 24 (AP). -- A Federal court jury today awarded David E. Kahn of Scarsdale, N.Y., $89,598.40 in a suit seeking $1,840,000 commission for his efforts to sell the Paris Medicine Company of St. Louis to Zonite Products Corporation in 1929.

BOSTON, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Scores of lonely Christmas Eve celebrations in Coast Guard stations and lighthouses along New England's jagged coast were brightened tonight by Captain William H. Wincapaw's annual good-will flight.

Last week Republican State Senators met at Albany and lovingly agreed that their leader in the Senate of 1937 should be PERLEY PITCHER of Watertown. This lesson in harmony should be repeated in the Assembly by the re-election as Speaker of IRVING IVES of Norwich.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Dec. 24. -- Homes for workers are the Christmas gifts offered by the Industrial and Commercial Institute, created in 1934 under President Getulio Vargas's New Deal social program. Employes can now buy at moderate rates homes constructed and financed by the institute.

LONDON, Dec. 24. -- The stock market, although generally quiet, celebrated a cheerful pre-Christmas session today before the close of business at noon. The principal trading features were continued gains among the commodities, with rubber advancing to 10 3/8d a pound, spot -- the highest price since September, 1929.

The city commission of Coral Gables, Fla., announced yesterday the details of a $11,200,000 debt refunding plan which, it was said, had been approved by holders of more than 90 per cent of the face amount of the city's obligations. A special election has been called for Jan. 15 to ratify the refunding ordinance already passed by the city commission.

The recommendations to the President of his Committee on Crop Insurance are much more conservative than they were widely expected to be. It is proposed that the plan be confined to wheat at the beginning and that it be applied to the 1938 crop. Under the recommendations the Government would pay administrative expenses, but the full cost of the actual risks involved would be placed upon the farmer.

POTTSVILLE, Pa., Dec. 24. -- Four officials of the Philadelphia Reading Coal and Iron Company were arrested today on charges of willful negligence and involuntary manslaughter in connection with the Gilberton mine disaster, which caused thirteen deaths in January, 1935. The prisoners were released on total bail of $65,000.

Mrs. Alfred M. Lefevre answered the doorbell of her apartment on the third floor of 1,080 Park Avenue, at the northwest corner of Eighty-eighth Street, about 2:20 P.M. yesterday, expecting a florist's delivery boy with a Christmas wreath.

The wages of the more than 15,000 employes of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company who participated in the wage adjustments of May 1 will he increased by 1 per cent on Jan. 1, Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver, announced yesterday.
BERLIN, Dee. 24 (AP). -- The Reichbank's statement as of Dec. 23 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- John Dickinson, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice, and one of the original members of the "little cabinet" of the Roosevelt administration, resigned today, effective Jan. 20, to engage in the private practice of law.
The Republican majority in the next Assembly may not "go New Deal," but the party in the State is set definitely for a liberal legislative program under its new leadership.

The American Museum of Natural History joins in the observance of Christmas week by bringing to our view, in the Hayden Planetarium, the skies as they appeared to the Magi from the East and to the shepherds in the fields near Bethlehem. What the effulgence was that gave a new glory to the heavens and caused the ancient astronomers and the men "keeping their flocks by night" to wonder is not revealed.

Controversy over the status of employes of the Emergency Relief Bureau has its source in an act of the State Legislature providing for the transfer of the functions of temporary relief agencies to permanent governmental bodies. In view of this proposed switch from an "emergency" to a "permanent" status, the Municipal Civil Service Commission summoned employes of the temporary agencies to submit to competitive examinations before being transferred.

The $27,000,000 extension of the Queens branch of the city's Independent Subway System from Roosevelt Avenue-Jackson Heights, the present terminus, to Union Turnpike-Kew Gardens, will be opened to the public at 7 A.M. Thursday, the Board of Transportation announced yesterday.
BOSTON, Dec. 25. -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, who rushed from the White House to spend Christmas in a hospital with her son, smilingly declared tonight that Franklin D. Jr. was "doing fine."

Although illegal traveling on trains and other forms of railroad trespassing continue to be a serious problem, the number of recorded cases of this kind declined about one-third in the six months ended on Oct. 31 compared with the same period last year, the Association of American Railroads announced yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 25 (Canadian Press). -- The most strenuous period of the long English Football League campaign started today when the eighty-eight clubs sacrificed Christmas Day festivities to perform before large crowds. Other full rounds of contests are scheduled for tomorrow and Monday.

Seventeen reporters at the Harvard Tercentenary won their varsity letters, so to speak. To each has gone a conference badge and a testimonial from the authorities. The latter says in part: "The press set a new high standard by the fullness and readable quality of its reports on the formidable range of subjects covered by the conference."

Recently the coaches of the National Football League picked their annual all-league team On the whole the squad seems rather well balanced and it is difficult to criticize the selections because they were made by the men who know most about the abilities of the players.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Dec. 26. -- At what appeared the gloomiest hour of China's greatest crisis in years. Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, her dictator, was freed from captivity on Christmas afternoon with dramatic suddenness.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Released from jail on Christmas Eve, Juanita Hansen, queen of movie serials twenty years ago, protested today her arrest on suspicion of violating the State Narcotic Act.

Once again Leon Trotsky, former Soviet war lord and co-leader with Lenin of the October revolution, is on the move toward a place of refuge. Exiled from Russia some seven years ago, when he lost his fateful battle for power with Joseph Stalin, he has never found a permanent place of residence.

Arthur Brisbane, one of the most widely read and highest paid newspaper writers in the world, died at his home, 1,215 Fifth Avenue, at 102d Street, of heart disease at 5:35 o'clock yesterday morning. He was 72 years old and had been employed by William Randolph Hearst for thirty-nine years, longer than any other of Mr. Hearst's employes.

Of Professor O.M.W. SPRAGUE'S thoughtful article on "Monetary Stabilization," in the current number of Foreign Affairs, it should first be said that this Harvard instructor, and recent collaborator with the Bank of England and the United States Treasury, accepts as inevitable for the future the gold standard of currency.

It seems to me that a radical change would be beneficial to the annual Rose Bowl game now played on the West Coast every New Year's Day. The custom of the Western team's continually inviting an Eastern rival to travel across the continent has slowly become annoying to the football teams of this section of the country.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- The Public Works Administration announced in a report today that money for 25,200 projects, costing a total of $4,071,750,926, had been allotted by the Federal and local governments. This includes the Federal and non-Federal programs and also the housing activities of the PWA.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 25 (AP). -- A flashy football team from New Britain, Conn., defeated Miami High, 32 to 13, in the eighth annual Christmas Day intersectional game today before 7,000 spectators. The visiting Connecticut champions scored in every quarter and held Miami scoreless until the last.

In these days many of us are somewhat concerned over the position of football, a sport which we have come to accept as a rare outlet for the energy, skill and spirit of our youth, enhanced by its college setting and with its sentiment and thrill and abundant joy.

LONDON, Dec. 25. -- The Right Rev. Henry Wilson, Bishop of Chelmsford, in his New Year's message to the diocese, made public today, stressed the services of former King Edward when he was the Prince of Wales.
WELLINGTON, N.Z., Saturday, Dec. 26. -- As prices rise and profits soar in the Socialist State, union labor mobilizes to end the court checks on the Laborite new deal.

BERLIN, Dec. 25. -- Rumors from all sides continue to indicate that Chancellor Adolf Hitler will resume tomorrow, after only one day of Christmas holiday, his study of affairs of State, especially discussion of the Spanish problem and the possibility of obtaining British cooperation in relieving German economic difficulties.
LONDON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Mayfair groped in family safes for sparkling tiaras tonight, the eve of London's first Winter international opera season in many years.

A far-reaching shake-up of the executive personnel of the Amateur Athletic Union was seen in the announcement from national headquarters yesterday of the selection of 1937 national committees by President Jeremiah T. Mahoney.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry H. Spencer of Brooklyn and Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Bulley of Greenwich, Conn., introduced their daughters, the Misses Nancy B. Spencer and Barbara W. Bulley, to society last night at a theatre party and supper dance.

Mrs. Rosina Rossi, 42 years old, who is the mother of five children, shot and critically wounded herself late yesterday afternoon after her 18-year-old son, Egidio, had refused to let her cut his birthday cake, according to the police.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- The Roosevelt administration in conjunction with the Power Authority of New York State has begun a frontal drive against major public utility combinations to win ratification of the St. Lawrence seaway-hydroelectric treaty with Canada at the coming session of Congress.
