PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 25. -- Only one week from their Rose Bowl battle, which they hope will offsett three previous beatings here, Pittsburgh's football Panthers assumed a chereful, even confident, mien today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- Representative George Holden Tinkham of Massachusetts announced today that he would introduce at the new session of Congress a joint resolution for a constitutional amendment to fix the Presidential term at six years and make a President ineligible for re-election.
SAN FRANCISCO. Dec. 25 (AP). -- Christmas was just another work day for football stars who will battle here New Year's Day in the annual East-West Shrine charity game.

VATICAN CITY, Dec. 25. -- The thoughts of all Italians turned today to Pope Pius whose broadcast to the world yesterday moved every one here very deeply and caused all hearts to go out to him in sympathy.

An audience that was obviously entertained listened last night in the Metropolitan Opera House to an English translation compounded from divers sources of Smetana's Bohemian folk-opera, "The Bartered Bride." This performance offered some commendable singing and excellent fooling, and was well received.

ROME, Dec. 25. -- In Italy, Christmas, although the year's greatest religious festival, has not the significance or importance given to it in Anglo-Saxon countries. It is celebrated in a manner calculated to satisfy grown-ups more than children, for its pleasures are chiefly gastronomical.
To the many problems that beset the police of Brooklyn was added another yesterday in the person of James Maher, 6 years old.

NANKING, Saturday, Dec. 26. -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek arrived here by plane at 12:20 P.M., today. He was greeted by Lin Sen. chairman of the national government: virtually all other prominent leaders, and a colorful throng of almost 100,000, and was triumphantly carried through beflagged and bannered streets amid the din of bursting firecrackers.

Catholic congregations in the Archdiocese of New York will hear read from the pulpits tomorrow a letter from Cardinal Hayes stating that he "most earnestly desires" that there be established in every parish a permanent active organization for youth.

ALBANY, Dec. 25. -- The names of 681 successful applicants for admission to the New York bar were announced today by the State Board of Law Examiners, composed of John Kirkland Clark of New York City, Philip J. Wickser of Buffalo and Rollin B. Sanford of Albany.

The railroads will enter 1937 with steadily rising traffic, according to a review by William H. Dayton of Lobdell Co. With carloadings running 20 per cent heavier than in 1935, the momentum of this recovery should carry through for the first half of 1937 at least, he asserts.
VIENNA, Dec. 25 (AP). -- The Duke of Windsor read the story of the Nativity from the lectern of Vienna's English Church today.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 25. -- Paradisical, one of the most consistent fillies in the country, raced to an easy and popular victory in the Christmas Handicap at Tropical Park today.

A .22-caliber rifle bullet, apparently fired from the roof of an adjoining building, caused the death yesterday of John Sullivan, 27 years old, of 35 Orchard Street, who was hit as he descended a stairway leading from the roof of the apartment building in which he lived.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- The family of President Roosevelt, thinned by the absence of several members, "made Christmas" today in the White House.

Two hundred elderly persons, many of them crippled, were guests at a Christmas dinner and party yesterday at the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue, where they dined heartily, sang songs and happily opened gifts.

Christmas joys in the Arnt Johnsen home at 247 Senator Street, Brooklyn, were cut short yesterday when Frances, 6 1/2 years old, the youngest member of the family of five, was struck by an automobile and injured fatally.

After the glamour and glory of the horse show at Madison Square Garden as a brilliant social affair, would it be too pertinent if the suggestion were made that the committee should try to obtain entries which would make the National Horse Show really an outstanding international competition, so far as that is possible in such classes as, for instance, the military and regular jumping events?
VIENNA, Dec. 25. -- Christmas dawned for Austria with none of her hopes of a year ago for political appeasement realized.

Christianity embraces, perfects and completes all that is best in the teachings and beliefs the world has had, the Very Rev. Milo H. Gates, dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, said in his Christmas sermon in the cathedral yesterday morning.

With spangles and a dewey eye, teasing Thespis last evening found a new temple for her higher art. Perhaps it was only natural that the scene was the old Warners' Theatre, where Vitaphone first carried the stuttering voice of the talking pictures and where two "real, living Minskys" -- the quote is from a program note -- are engaged in chaste commerce with Times Square.

Arthur Brisbane was one of the very few to make a fortune as a newspaper writer. He had a short, abrupt way of stating what he thought; a way that appealed to a vast mass of readers in the United States who never could get used to the long-spun and more literary style of the anonymous editorial writers.

The vanishing of professional sidewalk and department store Santa Clauses after Christmas Eve is a mystery that the management of the McAlpin Hotel tried to solve yesterday after its second annual attempt to entertain the city's jolly old saints on Christmas Day.

Mr. ARTHUR BRISBANE, whose death yesterday we regret to record, won his first fame as a newspaper reporter. He had a wonderfully keen eye for salient facts and personalities, with a remarkable gift for realistic description. Some of his earliest feats in that line became a part of journalistic tradition.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- In announcing today his proposal for a change in the Presidential term of office. Representative Tinkham declared that in "contradiction to the spirit of the Constitution, the Presidency has come to represent a party."

THE doorman at the Bavarian beer-garden in Hamburg raised his right arm and said with due solemnity: "Heil, Hitler." Four of the five Americans he greeted had been on German soil for precisely one-half hour. They were alarmed, amazed, aghast and, at the moment, personally affronted. Awkwardly they gazed at each other in open-mouthed consternation.

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 25. -- Aside from giving a dinner at the Muenchinger-King tonight, Thomas Powers of New York entertained the twenty-six children from the Home for Friendless Children at the hotel late in the afternoon with a Christmas tree, with presents for each of the children, a supper and an entertainment.
We in this country fervently wish to keep out of war. We intend to be strictly neutral in the next conflagration in Europe, or the extension of that which some believe has already begun. But can we?

NANKING, China, Saturday, Dec. 26. -- Intense excitement among the populace was evident in Nanking and many other cities today when news of Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek's release was circulated by radio, newspapers and telephones and by many automobiles rushing through the streets with shrieking sirens, trailing huge banners emblazoned with the welcome news.

I, as a rabid Brooklyn fan, disagree with the suggestion that the Brooklyn club be named the Stevedores as a tribute to a fine old man of baseball. Steve McKeever. I disapprove not because the judge is unworthy of the name, for he is worthy of it, but because a baseball team's name should not idealize the president but the players.

ATLANTA, Dec. 25. -- California's football team, favored for the battle with Georgia Tech tomorrow, reviewed the feats of Civil War fighters today in a Christmas observance combining business and pleasure.

Japan and the United States are both ready to talk about Far Eastern questions of common concern, but they are not agreed on method. Tokyo, as was indicated in a trial balloon loosed there last Wednesday, still hopes for bilateral exchanges. Washington, in its reaction on Thursday, showed that it remains firmly opposed to purely Japanese-American negotiations and insists that the proposed discussion should be participated in by all the nations interested.

The blessings of Pope Pius XI, sent to the world from his sickbed in Vatican City, were given by Cardinal Hayes yesterday morning to the 5,000 or more who filled St. Patrick's Cathedral for the colorful pontifical Christmas mass.

A riot broke out about 7:45 o'clock last night among forty women patients in Ward PQ2 in the psychopathic division of Bellevue Hospital and before the disorder was ended, nearly two hours later, bed clothes had been ripped apart, furniture broken and a nurse and a policeman bitten on the hands.

The Lincoln Cathedral Choir yesterday noon appeared in a Christmas Day concert on the Park Avenue Terrace of the Waldorf-Astoria in an hour's program which attracted more than 1,000 persons. The choristers, under the direction of John M. Rosborough, were also heard at the hotel in the evening in a special program.
LONDON, Dec. 25. -- On this Christmas Day the British and French Governments have taken a step that at the beginning of the new year may lead to momentous developments.

President Roosevelt, Governor Lehman, Mayor La Guardia, leaders in journalism, business and industry and others paid tribute yesterday to Arthur Brisbane in statements and in messages to members of his family. The tributes were as follows:

PARIS, Saturday, Dec. 26 (AP). -- The newspaper Le Temps envisaged today the possibility of a new four-power agreement for Western European peace if Germany agrees to remain neutral in the Spanish civil war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -Most of the nation's leading soft coal producers will meet next Tuesday at White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., to discuss what they want to do about a new Guffey coal control bill. Out of the conference, observers said today, may come decisions on two questions:

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
DETROIT, Dec. 25 (AP). -- The Red Wings and Black Hawks played a hard 1-1 tie tonight in a National Hockey League game before more than 12,000 fans.
William. J. Woods, 44 years old, broker, was killed yesterday morning when he accidentally fell fifteen stories from a window of his apartment at 51 Fifth Avenue.

The second set of games in the Metropolitan Indoor Polo League will take place tonight with a double-header at the Squadron A Armory, Ninety-fourth Street and Madison Avenue. The games will bring into league action three more teams, only one of the four having played a circuit game.

Retail distribution, on a unit basis, this week exceeded the figures for the corresponding period in 1929, in many instances, with the general dollar totals more than in 1930, due to the stress on high-priced merchandise, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP). --Officials of the Social Security Board, reviewing today an historic year of governmental activity in the insuring of workers against dependency, placed foremost the widespread acceptance of the unemployment compensation program by the States.

Thank you very much, Kris Kringle. In fact, much obliged. "The Show Is On" is on at the Winter Garden, where it opened last evening, and it is the best rowdy-dowdy that has kicked up its heels under that ancient roof. Although Vincente Minnelli's previous revues have been stunning and original, this is the finest of the lot, and Beatrice Lillie and Bert Lahr are in their top form as the chief performers.

For the fifth consecutive week, public utility borrowing led the new bond financing this week, accounting for $41,400,000 of the $71,390, 000 in new bonds placed on the market. It was an unusually active period for the investment market for a Christmas week.

Detectives Francis McVeigh and John Meehan of the new "nightclub squad," cruising about the recently established "deadline" for known criminals early yesterday, arrested two armed youths, who they said had admitted being in the area to follow and rob bejeweled women leaving night clubs.

With Brooklyn College coming upon the scene for the first time with four players, of whom much had been expected, New York University's chess team continued to pile up points in the annual tournament for the championship of the Intercollegiate League and custody of the Harold M. Phillips Trophy at the Manhattan Club yesterday.

NANKING, Saturday, Dec. 26. -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek arrived here accompanied by his wife and by W.H. Donald, Australian adviser to the Nanking govenment, whose spectacular flight to deal directly with General Chang Hsueh-liang, the generalissimo's captor, at Sian was followed quickly by today's dramatic release.

As a result of the recent report of the investigation held by the Public Service Commission, a reduction was made in the cost of installation, removal charges and other incidental services rendered by the telephone company. In the last report, a few days ago, it is again reported that a reduction will be made in the long-distance tolls.

In nine Salvation Army homes and shelters, nearly 6,000 men and women who otherwise would have gone without Christmas dinners sat down yesterday to roast turkey and all the trimmings amid festive holiday surroundings. Each of the Army centers had been arranged for the feasts, and no effort was spared to obtain huge Christmas trees and holly wreaths to bring the Yuletide atmosphere to the mess halls.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week amounts to only $4,826,500, representating fifty municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $10,036,575 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now is $26,636,223.

Striking seamen are prepared to picket the coming session of Congress to record their opposition to the Federal Government's plans regarding continuous discharge books for employes on American ships, it was announced yesterday by Joseph Curran, chairman of the strikers' strategy committee.

In one of the most sensational soccer games of the season at Hawthorne Field, Brooklyn before 4,000 fans yesterday, Brooklyn Hispano, leader in the American Soccer League's metropolitan division, won by 6 to 4 from the champion New York Americans, who only a week ago had received the Lewis Cup and medals at the league's annual dinner.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP). -- Three major proposals for expanding America's Neutrality Law during the coming session of Congress have been advanced in pre-session discussions of the vital problem.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, Dec. 25. -- An overloaded harbor launch, carrying a happy Christmas crowd, capsized less than a mile off shore today, bringing death to at least fifteen persons.

Miss Patricia Emmet was introduced to society last night at a supper dance give by her parents, Grenville Temple Emmet, United States Minister to the Netherlands, and Mrs. Emmet, in the Neptune Room of the Pierre. Mr. and Mrs. Emmet returned two days ago from Washington, where they were the guests of President and Mrs. Roosevelt at the White House.

This evening they are bringing "The Women" to the Ethel Barrymore Theatre, an all-feminine play telling the assorted antics of a group of Manhattan ladies of various ages and states of mind and being. Thirty-eight of them, there will be, and some of the names are Margalo Gillmore, Ilka Chase, Betty Lawford, Jessie Busley, Phyllis Povah, Margaret Douglass, Jane Seymour, Audrey Christie and Beryl Wallace.

" Over the Seven Seas," a motion picture record in sound and color of the ten-month expedition of Commodore William K. Vanderbilt in quest of new specimens for the famous Vanderbilt marine museum at Northport, L.I., will be shown at the first annual dinner of the New York Rod and Gun Editors Association to be held at the Hotel Commodore on Feb. 23.

Countess Tolstoy's Diary for the year 1910, which reaches its climax in the death of her husband, Count Leo Tolstoy, has been translated from the Russian by Aylmer Maude and will be published late next month by Oxford University Press. Extracts from Leo Tolstoy's diary are included, as are letters.
CHICAGO, Dec. 25. -- William Harridge, president of the American League, showed his staff of twelve umpires today there really is a Santa Claus.

The recent decision of the Treasury to set up machinery to sterilize further imports of gold -- that is to prevent them from becoming a part of the reserves of the member banks -- is new in this country as a method, but is not new as a policy. The same thing was accomplished during the Nineteen Twenties by putting gold in circulation through gold certificates.

In a Christmas radio message last night the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick urged Americans to unite, declaring our country could not do anything worth while for the world at large unless we became a real community, free of the class prejudices that lead to class wars.

Mr. LLOYD GEORGE was in Jamaica when the British constitutional crisis leading up to the abdication of EDWARD VIII was being worked out. But he seizes the occasion of Christmas to send greetings to the self-exiled monarch, in which his desire to score a political point is but thinly concealed.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 25 (AP). -- The Onondaga County Pomona Grange Milk Committee recommended to the New York State Grange today a program for retention and strengthening of the present State Milk Control Law.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 25. -- Goldeneye, 3-year-old gelding of the A.A. Baroni Stable, ushered in Santa Anita's opening race program before 40,000 turf fans today with a sparkling victory in the $5,000 added Christmas Stakes.

Staving off their rivals' last period bid, the New York Rovers turned back the Baltimore Orioles in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The New York contingent's winning margin was 5 goals to 2, but they had a much harder time triumphing than the figures indicate.

Two 17-year-old Negro girls, dressed as men and armed with home-made blackjacks made of eight-inch pieces of lead pipe, were arrested at 2:30 A.M. yesterday as they were trying the doors of a car parked on Morningside Drive at 121st Street.
MADRID, Dec. 25. -- Bombs and shells crashed into the streets of Madrid today, killing at least five persons, one of them a woman. A score were wounded.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- The help of Irish Americans in establishing the Irish Free State and the aid of American Jews in establishing a Jewish national homeland in Palestine were likened to each other today by Miss Sulasmith Schwartz, at the opening session of the annual convention here of Junior Hadassah.

LONDON, Dec. 25. -- While celebrating one of the merriest Christmases in recent years Britain received the news that at 11:20 A.M. today a daughter was born to the Duke and Duchess of Kent at their home, 3 Belgrave Square, here.

The schedule of uniform fines and penalties for violations of the traffic laws, as recently adopted by the Board of City Magistrates, does not restrict the freedom of any magistrate to impose whatever penalty he sees fit, Chief City Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. declared yesterday in a letter to Alderman Alexander A. Falk.

Unless the soothsayers are all wrong, Thursday night hereabouts in the night clubs, hotels and restaurants is going to be something sensational. Reservations are said to be heavier than they have been for a New Year's Eve since the lean years put a damper on celebrations, and the proprietors have racked extra stocks of bottled goods in anticipation of exceptional festivity.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 25. -- Every Christmas tradition was observed here today with homes, clubs and hotels, gaily decorated, settings for festive events.
Unseasonal warmth in New York and throughout the nation put no check yesterday on the merriest Christmas the country has known within the last decade.
WHEELER, Mont., Dec. 25. -- The Old West was rough and tough, but it could have learned something about celebrating from the mushroom towns now clustered about Fort Peck Dam.
The cheering Christmas response to the "silver anniversary" appeal for New York's Neediest Cases continued yesterday as 637 persons from many cities and States added $11,709.58 to the 1936 Fund.

By the time this reaches you the recent British crisis will have faded into history; but I trust you will print a point of view which has been rigidly barred in the British press from the very beginning.

Carl Owen Hubbell, whose lean left arm hurled the Giants to a pennant, virtually made a grand slam of the National League's major pitching honors for 1936, according to the official averages released for publication today.

One of the two longest winning streaks enjoyed by major college basketball teams is due to be snapped when Illinois Wesleyan meets Long Island University in the feature game of a double-header at the Hippodrome tonight.

WASHINGTON. Dec. 25. -- Examination of a variety of proposals for dealing with relief and unemployment discloses a remarkable contrast between the amount of public knowledge available concerning the millions of persons on work relief (including those eligible for employment) and the millions of idle not on relief.

Miss Helen Hull Jacobs of Berkeley, Calif., winner of the women's Wimbledon singles crown, is rated by Frederick J. Perry, England's great netman, as the No. 1 woman tennis player of the world, it was disclosed yesterday by Frank T. Hunter, who received the ranking list from Perry.
CHICAGO, Dec. 25 (AP). -- Chicago will become one of the nation's scientific centers next week with more than a score of scientific professional and educational societies meeting here.

Experiments to determine the value of insulin, the extract used throughout the world in the treatment of diabetes, in the alleviation of certain types of insanity, are being carried on in Bellevue Hospital, it became known last night.
CHICAGO, Dec. 25 (AP). -- Chicago will become one of the nation's scientific centers next week with more than a score of scientific professional and educational societies meeting here.

TROY, N.Y., Dec. 25 (AP). -- The beloved poem "'Twas the Night Before Christmas," heard in many an American home last night, brought only chagrin to its author when it was first published, 113 years ago, in a Troy newspaper.

ALBANY, Dec. 25. -- Donald Feiden, 7 years old, who called on medical science and "stay awake" pills in order to see the "real McCoy" Santa Claus, today was so awed by his success that he dodged his first newspaper interview.

Alfredo Salmaggi and his company continued its operatic productions at popular prices last night at the Hippodrome where a highly enthusiastic audience of 3,000 persons greeted the revival of Verdi's "Otello."

POTTSVILLE, Pa., Dec. 25. -- While the search was continued today for Joseph J. Bruno, escaped convict, friends quoted his daughter, Mrs. Antoinette Billig, as insisting that he had laid no advance plans for a getaway.

SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador, Dec. 25. -- Christmas in the quake-ruined city of San Vicente was not as sad as might have been expected. In a four-hour visit your correspondent found the people returning, cheerful and hopeful, despite the almost complete destruction of that once-thriving town.

CALLANDER, Ont., Dec. 25 (Canadian Press). -- A howling blizzard that raged in this northern Ontario settlement failed to interfere with the Christmas party of the Dionne quintuplets today. The five sisters entertained the rest of the family and saw their new brother, 5-month-old Oliva, for the first time.

The moon had a halo around it last night so distinct that it drew the attention of thousands of persons in New York City and the metropolitan area. To many the phenomenon on Christmas night appeared to have a possibly evil portent.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 25 (AP). -- Zevson, winner of the Thanksgiving Handicap here, romped to victory in the $2,000-added Christmas Handicap at the Fair Grounds today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 23 (AP). -- That old aphorism that a woman can't keep a secret is challenged in the case of Mrs. Daisy Tegtmeyer, 52 years old.
FARSON, Iowa, Dec. 25. -- More than sixty families here went back to the kerosene lamp era today in protest against rural electricity rates.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- A detailed analysis of holdings of equity securities of corporations by officers, directors and principal shareholders as of Dec. 31, 1935, and made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission showed that corporations which own shares of another corporation constituted the major group and held more than half of the total of 430,000,000 shares reported as held by all classes of the so-called "insiders.''

The fifty-fourth anniversary solemn high mass for the members of the New York Archdiocesan Union of the Holy Name Society will be held New Year's Day at 10:30 o'clock in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Cardinal Hayes will preside and it is expected that after the mass he will receive the officers in the ambulatory and give them a personal New Year's blessing.
OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 25 (AP). -- Undaunted by the "deportation" of himself and family from South Dakota, Lyman Lee is fighting his way back to independence.
CHICAGO (AP). -- The bookworm shows definite signs of turning, so say several Chicago dealers, in his provender.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 25. -- Walking on ice a half-inch thick on the pond at the northern end of Branch Brook Park early this afternoon, two brothers, Steve and Thomas Ferrara, 10 and 13 years old, respectively, crashed through and were drowned in six feet of water.

ATLANTA, Dec. 25. -- Laying their plans with a minimum of publicity in order to avoid an organized and perhaps militant opposition, leaders of the new State administration which takes office early in January expect to abrogate Georgia's bone-dry prohibition statutes, which have been in effect since 1915.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP). -- Farm life with city conveniences and opportunity for travel and recreation is the idea to which Albert B. Graham, former school teacher, has devoted half a century of service.
ATCHISON, Kan., Dec. 26. -- Two chemists predicted here today that power alcohol would become within ten years an economic force in American agriculture.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 26. -- The annual post-Christmas survey of the universe by America's leading scientists will begin here Monday when the American Association for the Advancement of Science, composed of a federation of learned societies representing all the major sciences, will open its ninety-ninth meeting, which will continue throughout the week.

With distribution during the Christmas holiday season closely approaching the volume during 1929, retail sales in 1936 will total between $37,500,000,000 and $38,000,000,000, according to preliminary estimates of the American Retail Federation.

Revival in the sale of American raw cotton and tobacco along with a number of other raw commodities to Germany is looked for early next year as a result of this government's action in permitting barter transactions.

Breaking 97 out of 100 targets, T.H. Lewis won the High-Over-All Cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. Thirty-five competed. J.R. Sprague annexed the handicap prize in Class A and N.E. Sprague took the Class B honors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- The final sections of the report of the Protective Committee Study of the Securities and Exchange Commission, dealing with defaults in bonds and reorganizations, on the basis of which recommendations will be made to Congress for legislation, are rapidly being completed.

The recent prediction of Secretary Wallace -- that food prices may climb 10 per cent early in the new year -- is expected to result in a great deal of quantity buying of staple products by consumers. At the same time there is likely to be increased demand for foods that will serve as substitutes for items that show the greatest advance.

A year ago Joe Platak, burly Chicagoan, furnished a surprise by winning the national A.A.U. four-wall handball championship, and he again proved that he is the king-pin performer in his sport by also contributing the standout performance of the 1936 handball season.

WELL, perhaps the Walrus didn't say it, but this still is the most propitious day to check back on the year just passing to see what Hollywood has wrought. By and large, it ha been a comfortable year, a prosperous year and an optimistic year in the cinema.

Dennis Cardinal Dougherty of Philadelphia, nominated by Pope Pius XI as his representative at the International Eucharistic Congress in Manila next February, sailed yesterday for Havre on the French liner Normandie, accompanied by thirty-six clergymen.

MOSCOW, Dec. 26. -- The Soviet Union is greatly perturbed over the recent sinking, apparently by a Spanish Rebel cruiser, of the Soviet merchant ship Komsomol, with the probable loss of the entire crew. There is anxiety lest more such incidents occur, since much of the Soviet's legitimate shipping must pass from the Black Sea through the trait of Gibraltar on the way to Western European ports.

A price "shakedown" in 1937, somewhat similar to that which occurred in 1934, following the sharp upswing in quotations as a result of the NIRA, was predicted here yesterday by some business executives. They said that the revision would not be as sharp or as serious as that of 1934, but expressed the opinion that many of the current wholesale increases are inflated and will find a more nearly normal level.

THERE were ninety-two instrumentalists in the orchestra pit of the Metropolitan Opera House last Monday night when the season opened with Wagner's "Die Walkuere." Thirty-five of these players were newcomers -- twenty-six in the strings, one in the woodwinds and eight in the brasses.

Whether rightly or wrongly, the election has been interpreted in many quarters as justifying, if not requiring, expansion of the powers of Congress, emancipation of the States to some extent from Federal restraint, and, possibly, limitation of the power of the courts.

PARIS, Dec. 26. -- Almost for the first time since the treaty of peace was signed with Germany in 1919 there has been during the past six months something like real cooperation and mutual confidence between the French and British Governments in their foreign policy.

Well-Known Chinese Author WHAT is happening in the Far East today reveals strikingly the great differences between the Chinese and Japanese. These differences must be understood if we are to forecast with any accuracy future developments in the Chinese-Japanese drama.

THE effect of radio on American speech is slight, according to W. Cabell Greet, Professor of English at Barnard College, who believes that a week's automobile trip in a distant State would have more influence upon an individual than the effect of a year spent at the side of a loud-speaker.
MADRID, Dec. 25 (Delayed). -- On this day of peace on earth, goodwill toward men, business went on as usual in besieged Madrid and so did the war.

TEL AVIV, Palestine, Dec. 26 (AP). -- Arturo Toscanini tonight received a tremendous ovation as he conducted the new Palestine Symphony Orchestra in its first concert. But he left the stage in a rage when a flashlight photograph was taken.

Carl Julin, 33 years old, of 1,160 Fifth Avenue, thought he was about to be kidnapped when a police patrol car, bearing Detective Osmond Blackburne of the night club squad pulled up at the curb by his side as he was walking along Fifty-eighth Street between Park and Madison Avenues at 5 o'clock yesterday morning.
The light of the moon will be temporarily dimmed tonight, provided clouds do not obscure the moon altogether.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Dec. 26 (AP). -- Josetta Labarge Wolfe, a supposed spinster who died three days after her sister, Augusta, succumbed to starvation and exposure, was revealed today as a mother and widow. The sisters were found Tuesday in their beds at their home here.

SELF-SATISFACTION, that ingredient that so prominently marks the attitude of the cinema, knows no bounds with the year that is closing. Never before has the past been viewed with such gratification nor the future with such assurance.

The Washington Canoe Club continued to dominate canoeing in this country in 1936, carrying off the national team title again, while one of its members, Harry Knight, remained among the topnotchers by sharing in two and four man championships.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP). -- The State Department cabled to Spain tonight for information on the alleged seizure at sea of a cargo of flaxseed consigned to an American mill.

Sanitation Commissioner William F. Carey has enlisted the aid of the radio stations as a part of his plans for snow removal, it was announced yesterday. The broadcasters have agreed, it was explained, to send out bulletins at frequent intervals in the event of a snowstorm, urging motorists not to park their automobiles in areas in which snow removal gangs are at work.
Gifts amounting to $4,168,05 were received yesterday by the Neediest Cases Fund, swelling this year's total to $236,628,51, two days after Christmas.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 26. -- John Harvard's "Twelve Wives," as the wives of members of the Class of 1912 are known, started a mutiny in Scarsdale, which, thanks to the none too diplomatic behavior of the "Twelve husbands," threatened for a time to shake the very foundations of old Harvard.

At a symposium recently held by Dr. S.S. GOLDWATER under the auspices of New York's Department of Hospitals to discuss genius and eugenics there was the expected castigation of the Nazis. More important was the appraisal of the gifted who come of a tainted stock.

BERLIN, Dec. 26. -- Whenever church bells have tolled the passing of an old year and welcome to a new one during the last decade, a supreme question has obsessed the minds of the thoughtful: Will it be peace or war in the coming twelve months?
NORTH ADAMS, Mass Dec. 26 (AP). -- Rex, a mongrel with the heart of a thoroughbred, kept a lonely vigil today by a limp and broken strap -- awaiting a friend never to return.

SELDOM has chance so unexpectedly favored an author as in the stroke of luck that has just befallen one of the professors of Edinburgh University. Though the chair he occupies is that of Sanskrit and Comparative Philology.

An upheaval of defending team champions that assumed landslide proportions took place in New York City's scholastic sports circles in 1936. Titleholders relinquished their crowns on an unusually widespread basis and the net result was perhaps the most extensive rout of team rulers in recent years here.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- Hotels and clubs report good bookings for New Year's. In the calendar of sports and socials arranged for the holidays, the outstanding event is the New Year's equestrian gymkhana, to be held at the horse show grounds New Year's Day.
Squash tennis and squash racquets enjoyed a flourishing year in 1936.
LONDON, Sunday, Dec. 27 (AP). -- Europe-wide discussion of prospects for return of some of Germany's pre-war colonies today gave the British Government a reason for anxious study.

TEL AVIV, Palestine, Dec. 26. -- "Nothing could describe this concert except the word divine," said Bronislaw Huberman at the close of the first concert by the newly organized Palestine Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Arturo Toscanini here tonight.

Safety and efficiency are the goals toward which the railway equipment manufacturing industry is directing its efforts, according to a recent statement by Charles J. Hardy, president of the American Car and Foundry Company.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP). -- Legislation to take away the citizenship of Americans volunteering to fight in foreign wars was being discussed today in influential Senate quarters.

Because of her graphic powers of description and the many contacts she has made during her wide travels of the past three years, which have taken her into various countries, the arrival of Frau Yettka Levy-Stein of Berlin this week has inspired much interest in a three-months tour of this country which she will begin early next month. She is a passenger on the Berengaria, scheduled to dock tomorrow.

REPORTS from automobile manufacturing companies indicate a steady increase in employment in December following the introduction of new models last November. . . . From the Chevrolet division of General Motors comes word that its six manufacturing and eleven assembly plants throughout the country are running at capacity, and the recent opening of the company's new commercial body plant at Indianapolis has resulted in additions to the payroll because of expanded facilities. . . .
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Christmas celebrations over, the capital made ready today for a bitter strug-
BOSTON, Dec. 25. -- A new luminary is rising in the Massachusetts political sky.

FLOODLIGHTS are showing the way for the tourist in Egypt. Recently this dramatic method of illumination was used to light up public buildings and monuments in and around Cairo, throwing into high relief the towers and mosques of this city of the Pharaohs.

THE loss of the Crystal Palace has been sadly mourned by the nation at large. Even the voice of those hardened heralds of storm and disaster, the announcers of the B.B.C., sounded sad and sorrowful as they told the story of raging flames, of twisted steel and broken, blackened glass.

Nineteen Thirty-seven does not immediately leap to the mind as a year of great American anniversaries, centenary, bi-, or ter-. Further thought identifies 1837 as the end of the second Jackson administration, and a Jacksonian centennial does have a timely meaning today.

On Jan. 3, 1933, President Hoover, his plans for reorganizing government departments blocked by Congress, declared: "Either Congress must keep its hands off now or they must give to my successor much larger powers of independent action than given to any President."

The Palestine Lighthouse for the Blind will be the beneficiary of the performance of "The Show Is On" the night of Jan. 12 at the Winter Garden which has been taken over by persons interested in the work of the organization to raise funds for its charitable enterprises in Jerusalem.

ALL-STAR FACULTY: "If you could select out of all the history of the world, and from any field of knowledge and work, ten individuals to add to the faculty, what ten would you select?" Voting on that question last week, the faculty of the University of Pennsylvania chose Socrates, Plato, Aristotle, Leonardo da Vinci, Shakespeare, Galileo, Newton, Darwin, Pasteur and Einstein.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- More than a million persons attended exhibitions of Department of Interior motion pictures during a span of twelve months, the department recently reported. In order to meet the growing demand for films of its many activities, the department, a year ago, set up a Division of Motion Pictures.

A settlement of $100,000 granted to the guardians of Lucy Cotton Thomas, wealthy 11-year old heiress of the late Edward R. Thomas, publisher and banker, was revealed yesterday when Surrogate James A. Foley signed an order approving the application of this amount to the child's estate.

The situation in wrestling, almost serene a year ago, was covered with confusion, so far as the world heavyweight title was concerned, in 1936. Claimants to the crown, which generally was regarded as in the sole possession of Dan O'Mahoney when the year was young, sprang up profusely, and as the months rolled by there was hardly a geographical location that did not have its "world champion."

With a dramatic but not unexpected twist, the tables are turned. CHIANG KAI-SHEK, the prisoner, is freed and flies to a triumphant reception in Nanking; and CHANG HSUEH-LIANG, the captor, is repentent and follows in another plane to submit himself to the will of the Nanking authorities.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 26 (AP). -- Mayor Daniel Hoan declared in a letter to the Mayor of New Orleans today that the latter's recent appeal for help in promoting the Chicago-to-the-Gulf waterway "actually overflows with railroad propaganda against the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence seaway."

In the opinion of Martin Conboy, former United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, who argued the government's side of the arms embargo case in the Supreme Court, the permanent importance of the court's decision last week upholding the constitutionality of the act was to be found "in a discussion of the authority of the Executive in the field of foreign affairs."

A COLLECTION of colorful wash drawings by Rodin, formerly owned by that sculptor's pupil, Ernest Durig, also a sculptor, has been placed on view at the Leonard Clayton Gallery to remain through January. A story has been told of Rodin that he liked to have several models at once, moving freely about the studio, and that he would suddenly call out to one of them to "freeze."
ATLANTA, Dec. 26. -- Georgia Tech and its razzle-dazzle football beat California's Golden Bears, 13 to 7, today in a spectacular display of gridiron tricks.
Golf turned the corner on two wheels in 1936, a very definite pick-up being noticeable in all directions.

DOLLAR FOR DUCKS: The senior in point of service among the eight Associate Justices of the Supreme Court, and second in years only to Jus tice Brandeis, is Willis Van Devanter. Appointed by President Taft twenty-six years ago, he has been aligned recently in the strict-constructionist group prominent in the invalidation of New Deal laws.

Following the arrests of his father and two other youths early yesterday morning, Brooklyn police broadcast a general alarm for John Ciabattari Jr., 18 years old, who, it is alleged, was the operator of an automobile which struck another car at Seventy-fifth Street and Tenth Avenue, Brooklyn, late Friday night, causing the death of a woman and injury to two other persons.

With the loss of but one seeded player in both divisions, the twenty-second annual national junior and the twentieth annual boys' indoor tennis championships progressed to the second round yesterday at the Seventh Regiment Armory. Favorites came through as expected in the opening day's encounters.

WHEN it was reported in the newspapers some weeks ago that Judge M.A. Musmanno in the Criminal Court in Pittsburgh had sentenced a man to six months in the workhouse for driving an automobile while intoxicated, although no accident had occurred, some readers thought that the punishment went something beyond fitting the crime, while others agreed that the judge's severity was suitable in the case.

TOKYO, Sunday, Dec. 27. -- Japan is not prepared to renew Article 19 of the Washington treaty governing fortifications in the Pacific Ocean but desires to enter a new agreement adapted to the changed conditions of today.

A NEW sense of pride has come over the Scottish village of Glamis, adjoining Glamis Castle, since the accession of George VI of England. This famous fortress is the ancestral home of Lord Strathmore, the father of Queen Elizabeth, and in sending a Queen to London it adds new luster to a long and colorful history.

About our homes, poinsettias and gay red bells glow in the windows all through the holiday season. Every one welcomes their warm cheer, for Christmas isn't a day; it embraces weeks of kindness and goodwill. But somehow our gardens do not keep the holiday pace -- or at least they never used to.
The Appellate Division has affirmed an order of a lower court upholding the divorce of Edward Browning from his first wife in Paris, it was disclosed yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26. -- A Negro youth whom he was arresting fired two bullets into the right cheek of a policeman today. As he fell, the patrolman, Neil Stinson, 41 years old, fired a shot at his fleeing assailant, striking him in the back, but the man was helped into a car by a companion and escaped.

VIENNA. WHILE practically every well- informed music-lover knows immediately what works of Beethoven's constitute his op. 101, 102, 106, 109, 110 and 111 probably not more than one in fifty could said offhand what his op. 105 and 107 consist of.
AMERICAN television program planners at Radio City report that jewels and gems sparkle so brightly under the glare of the powerful studio lamps that they cause streaks across the pictures.

Reporting the best Christmas trade since 1929 for several major sections of the country and citing gains ranging up to 15 per cent or more for the year drawing to a close, retail executives are notably optimistic regarding the outlook for 1937, according to a telegraphic and local survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

TOO often of late pleasure-bent tourists in Europe have been depressed by the spectacle of a country in the grip of a tragic emotion. But in the Netherlands the curtain is rising now on a spectacle in which there is only joy.

The ever-increasing use of "baby talk" constitutes one of the major speech difficulties which classroom teachers must encounter, Dr. Dorothy I. Mulgrave, Assistant Professor of Education in the New York University School of Education, declares in "Speech for the Classroom Teacher," published today by Prentice-Hall, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Capacity production in industry depends upon the employment of all seeking work and cannot be realized until every family has an annual income of $3,600, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, said today in a statement on the outlook for labor in 1937.

ATLANTA, Dec. 26 (AP). -- Endorsed by President Roosevelt, a national campaign opened in Georgia today for a permanent endowment of the Warm Springs Foundation for the treatment of infantile paralysis.

FROM the "Little Riviera" west of Toulon to vine-shrouded villas east of Monte Carlo the entire Cote d'Azur is ready for the fetes and carnivals of France's midwinter season. Hotels are booked to capacity and many houses that went unrented during depression years have a choice of tenants eager to join in the coming festivities.
The prospect for increased domestic consumption of sugar and for a return of prices to profitable levels warrants a highly favorable view of the sugar producing industry, according to Fenner Beane.

Another link in the general plan of promoting good-will and international peace through foreign exchange scholarships at City College has been added with the introduction this term of the foreign language exchange, which was initiated by Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president.

About 250 undergraduate college and university editors of various school publications representing more than eighty American institutions of higher learning will be delegates to the twelfth annual conference of the National Student Federation of America when it convenes from Dec. 28 to Jan. 1 at the Hotel Victoria, Fifty-first Street and Seventh Avenue.

IT has been a generation and more since the words "functional" and "functionalism," product of the gifted mind of Louis Sullivan, began to be accepted as having a precise meaning in discussions of architecture. Now it may be predicted that before long they will be bandied about as freely as "inhibitions" and "complexes."

HAVANA, Dec. 26. -- Before a wildly enthusiastic crowd of some 3,000 persons in Tropical Stadium today, Jesse Owens, in his initial professional appearance as a runner, sprinted 100 yards in competition with a racehorse. Owens covered the distance in 9.9 seconds and crossed the finish line approximately twenty yards ahead of the thoroughbred.

Under the auspices of the Good Shepherd Auxiliary the first in a series of lectures by the Rev. Cyprian Truss, will take place on Jan. 6 at Sheery's. The subsequent lectures in the series will be given Jan. 13 and 27.

Quite aside from the perhaps more important value in enjoyment of the outdoor world which they afford, the fish and game of the United States have been estimated to be responsible annually for business revenues of $1,000,000,000. This is the figure of the Bureau of Biological Survey.

THE cast for Malipiero's "Julius Caesar," in concert form, which will be performed by the Schola Cantorum on Wednesday evening, Jan. 13, at Carnegie Hall, includes Arthur Anderson, Richard Hale, William Hain, Jeanne Palmer, Arthur Gerry and William Mercer.

First closing of entries for the sixty-first annual dog show of the Westminster Kennel Club in Madison Square Garden Feb. 10, 11 and 12 has been set for Wednesday, Jan. 13, according to the premium list just sent out to exhibitors in the United States and Canada.

The Southern town of Landor (probably in Mississippi) has a deep, dark mystery concerning a bridegroom who, twenty years before our story opens, disappeared on the eve of his marriage to beautiful Lucy Lou Lyell. When Porter Gage, junior member of the firm which handles the legal business of the Lyell family, receives a telephone call from Lucy Lou, he has a hunch that something is going to happen.

The Institute on Marriage and the Home, which for six months has been in existence at East Orange, N.J., has been functioning as first aid to foundering marriages and tottering homes. After Jan. 1, however, for the first time it will be equipped adequately to extend help in those domestic crises and individual problems that crowd its files.

The annual midwinter festival and supper dance for the benefit of the Grand Street Settlement will take place on Jan. 15 at the Waldorf-Astoria. The ballroom suite of the hotel has been taken over for the occasion, with general dancing to be held throughout the evening in the main ballroom, the Jade Room and the west foyer.

A RAILROAD in the vicinity of the Arctic Circle was recently completed in Sweden. The new 170-mile spur connects Arvidsjaur and Jokkmokk and is part of the main line running from Kristinehamn on Lake Vanern, in central Sweden, to the iron ore district of Gallivare.

THE house of art contains many mansions, and Professor Guerard conducts the reader on a stimulating tour through all of them, with the ostensible purpose of finding some criterion by which the many varieties of artistic experience may meet in some common identity.

NEW ROCHELLE. N. Y., Dec. 26. -- The Brooklyn-Long Island Uni dergraduate Club of the College of i New Rochelle will hold it annual I Christmas dance Monday night at the avoy-Plaza Hotel under the auspices of the Greater New York Chapter of the Alumnae Association.

With the European markets closed and virtually no business done here, the foreign exchanges were mostly unchanged yesterday. The guilder fell 1 point to 54.75 cents, at which level it showed a gain of 1 point for the week, and the Swiss franc fell 1/2 point to 22.98 1/2 cents, which left it down 3/4 point net in the week.

Many dinners will be given in conjunction with the dinner dance for the benefit of the National Bureau for Blind Artists tonight at the French Casino. The bureau places blind musicians and singers in radio positions. Early next month a radio committee under the supervision of Miss Martha Atwood will sponsor a series of radio programs by blind artists.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 26. -- The Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace has closed its deliberations after achieving success beyond the expectations of even the most optimistic delegates. The heads of delegations were unanimous in describing it as the most successful conference held anywhere in recent years.

All the signs point to a prosperous New Year for education in this country, especially in the higher institutions. Colleges are crowded again, as in the expansive days of 1929; their revenues are rising. High school and junior college enrollments are setting new records.

CHARLES M. ANDREWS, who for nearly fifty years has been writing history, and chiefly American Colonial history, is now half through what must be regarded as the crowning work of his scholarly career. Two years ago the first volume of his "The Colonial Period of American History" came from the presses to receive the 1935 Pulitzer award for history.

The box office returns, the interruption of a winning streak and the almost phenomenal genius of one player for attracting the limelight throughout the campaign stand out in the retrospection of the 1936 college football season.

NANKING, Sunday, Dec. 27. -- An extraordinary 2,000-word document, published by the Nanking Government as the transcript of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's remarks to two rebel leaders. Chang Hsueh-liang and Yang Fu-cheng, indicates no promises were made in return for the generalissimo's release except the expression of the opinion that since they had decided to release him without hostilities he believed the central authorities might make a lenient adjustment.

LIKE the white-collar worker who, just for the vicarious thrill of it, pores over heaps of world-tour pamphlets before sighing and going off on his two-week vacation in the Catskills, James Cagney toys frequently with the idea of playing Irish drama.

BERLIN, Dec. 26. -- Germans hinted tonight that return of their colonial empire would do much to lessen the danger of European war and solve the crisis over foreign aid to the Spanish civil war combatants.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Allowing for seasonal recession, business volume has continued to increase in December, the Commerce Department said today in its weekly summary.

With store inventories on the average estimated as ranging 10 to 15 per cent lower than at this time last year, reflecting the heavy inroads of both seasonal and Christmas buying, early arrivals of buyers in the wholesale markets here beginning tomorrow are expected to be notably heavy.

TOKYO, Dec. 26. -- The wave of panic that swept over Premier Koki Hirota and other members of the Japanese Government -- even over most of the members of the Privy Council -- has now subsided and they have returned to sanity and a balanced viewpoint, a normal and realistic outlook on the world and on Japan's position therein.

With the arraignment of seven men yesterday in Harlem court charged with being collectors in the policy racket, it was revealed that a lieutenant and two detectives, in a raid made Wednesday at 117 West 122d Street, had broken up a policy bank which was doing about 25 per cent of the nickel and one-cent policy business in Harlem.

With the approach of the new year, in which there will be a city election, plans for Fusion already are under way. The difficulties in forming a combination of the various groups of the electorate to oppose the Democratic organization candidate for city offices are very great but they are not believed to be insuperable.

Many seats have been purchased for the performance of Katharine Cornell in "The Wingless Victory" Tuesday night at the Empire Theatre which has been taken over to augment the scholarship fund of the Wellesley Club of New York.

In a sport where almost weekly there were sensational, highly dangerous, speed-bettering performances in racing boats that go a mile a minute and faster, the honors and accolades belong not to a few but to a good-sized group of men and women.

PARIS, Dec. 25 -- Among the smart Christmas novelties are large clips set with multi-colored precious stones in imitation of miniature stained glass rose windows. Earrings made in this manner are especially effective.

A boat basin to be built at the north end of Flushing Meadow Park at a cost of $250,000 for use during the World's Fair will be completed within ten months and open to the public next Autumn, it was announced yesterday by Park Commissioner Robert Moses.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 26. -- The year 1936 at Princeton University not only brought several significant changes in the program of undergraduate study but proved to be a year in which students won praise for their conduct and scholarship.

NANKING, Dec. 26 (AP). -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, restored to his place as leader of the Chinese nation, announced tonight he would recommend that the government deal leniently with Chang Hsueh-liang.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 26. -- The villages of Hastings-on-Hudson and Larchmont have followed the example of Scarsdale in adapting their governments to the village-manager idea, while maintaining their status as ordinary villages under the general village laws of the State.
AUGUSTA, Ga., -- Golf, polo and a round of outstanding social affairs will enliven the week after Christmas here and make it one of the jolliest of the season thus far.

The main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton was the setting yesterday for a tea dance given by Mr. and Mrs. Russell L. Bradford to introduce their daughter, Miss Margaret Middleton Bradford. The room was decorated with green and silvered smilax against a blue background.
In the cold of last Winter, ice boating, which had been all but thawed out for two seasons, had a revival in many sections of the East, while the Midwest carried on as usual.

The annual round of discussions and resolutions which features Christmas week in New York City starts today. Coaches, trainers, faculty advisers, makers of rules, officials and general observers interested in the athlete in the colleges will meet in a series of conventions that last to the rim of the new year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- While building permits in November reflected the usual seasonal recession from October, the total in both number and estimated cost, showed a heavy gain over November, 1935, the Department of Labor announced today.

Youth, as represented by Charles Warren and John Murphy, carried off the honors in the year's biggest bowling event, the thirty-sixth annual renewal of the American Bowling Congress tournament, which ranks as the world championship.

KELLOGG, Idaho, Dec. 26 (AP). -- A tired trapper mushed into Kellogg today to report that he and three other men had found the wreckage of a Northwest Airlines transport plane in the snow-mantled North Idaho mountains.

There are three ways in which the ignorance that characterizes citizens of the United States and Latin America concerning the civilization of each other may be removed. The first is as the result of travel in each other's lands.

The Rev. Dr. Gustav A. Carstensen, rector emeritus of Holy Rood Protestant Episcopal Church, Fort Washington Avenue and 179th Street, who fourteen years ago abandoned his annual birthday jaunt on foot around Manhattan, praised Mayor La Guardia yesterday for vetoing the recently proposed ban on jay-walking.
Higher scores, keener competition and a revival of interest among clubs which had ceased to function or had grown inactive combined to make the sport of rifle shooting an eventful one in 1936.

BERLIN, Dec. 26. -- The German Government officially announced today the seizure of the German steamer Palos of the Oldenburg-Portuguese Line by Spanish Leftist naval forces, allegedly outside Spanish territorial waters near Bilbao.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, Dec. 26 (AP). -- Four hundred men became violently ill tonight and received hospital treatment for food poisoning after eating the evening meal at the Ohio Soldiers and Sailors Home here.
THERE will be only one repeat at the Metropolitan Opera this week. "Tristan und Isolde," which was done last Wednesday night, will be presented for the second time on Saturday afternoon.

Two international matches featured the play of United States polo teams in 1936. One of these was staged on foreign soil and won by this country; the other was held on the famous stretch of the International Field of the Meadow Brook Club on Long Island and saw the United States defeated.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- It is not the people in a district who are responsible for delinquency and crime; the district itself is to blame and the remedy for this situation is rehabilitation of the neighborhoods where crime flourishes.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26. -- Major Gen. Smedley D. Butler, who interrupted a marine corps career for a couple of years back in the Nineteen Twenties to take the job of Director of Public Safety here, was nearly mobbed by reporters this week when he visited the City Hall.

Lord Marley, Deputy Speaker of the House of Lords, sailed for London yesterday on the French liner Normandie after spending three and a half months here lecturing on foreign policy and studying American labor conditions, particularly among the sharecroppers in the cotton regions.

SHOULD an artist, asked the anxious teacher of a young singer who had made good in a big way, and been duly praised for it by a member of the press, thank a critic for an article which did much to increase his fortune and reputation?

DISCUSSING the subject of taste, historians maintain that a contemporary age chooses a past that best fits itself. There is the epoch when Murillo is consigned to the cellar and El Greco hung on the wall. Recent exclaiming crowds at Knoedler's would seem to indicate that a sizable proportion of the 1936 art-loving public has chosen work by the brothers Le Nain.
Ogden Phipps of Roslyn, L.I., dominated the game of court tennis in 1936 with the same invincibility which marked the long reign of the late Jay Gould for twenty years.

Gregory S. Mangin, the national indoor titleholder, heads the men's singles division of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association, according to the ranking list for 1936 which was released yesterday. He was ranked third a year ago.

A smoky fire which did little damage but interrupted about 1,500 diners caused the Brass Rail Restaurant at 745 Seventh Avenue, between Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets, to close its door for nearly two hours after 8:30 o'clock last night. Firemen ripped out a partition and extinguished the blaze in the insulation of electric wiring behind the Marine Grill.

Police Commissioner Valentine established new deadlines for known criminals last week and increased his undercover squad from about forty to one hundred men in an effort to provide greater safety for the wealthy revelers who go home at or about the time when the resorts close at 4 A.M.

Although it caused a flurry in the security markets when it was announced, the decision of the Interstate Commerce Commission denying the railroads a temporary continuance of the emergency freight rate surcharges which will expire at the end of the year is not considered by observers of the industry as serious a blow as it might have been under different circumstances.

Taking a swift backward glance at a crowded twelvemonth of activity in fishing, hunting and related fields, this department, adhering to an established policy, desires to emphasize that the paragraphs following are set down in no arbitrary spirit, but rather in the mood of one recording his own opinions and observations.
Mrs. Edmund J. Pickup of 28 Rutland Road, Brooklyn, gave a large luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn, in honor of her debutante daughter, Miss Jean Pickup.

The woodworking shop of the Capitol is busy these days preparing for the opening of Congress. Under the supervision of Arthur E. Cook, superintendent engineer, two dozen gavels are being turned out for use in the House of Representatives. Whether or not the Senate is more dignified than the Rouse is an open question, but the upper chamber manages to get along with one gavel, an ivory instrument without a handle.

HAVANA, Dec. 26. -- With the ousting by impeachment of Dr. Miguel Mariano Gomez, the first constitutionally elected President of Cuba since 1933, regarded as a complete victory for the military authorities, the Cuban people have been brought sharply to the realization that democracy is at an end in the islands at least for the moment.

Moscow. WHEN the Nazis came to power. Hans Goldberg, who almost thirty years before had been the director of the famous Folksbuhne, had to take sudden leave of his native city, Berlin. When the German Ufa Company was organized Goldberg was one of its first scenarists and his was the first major Ufa sound film.

Hunt racing in the United States continued its steady rise in scope and popularity, with new amateur events starting in various parts of the country, interesting and keen competition in the older classics of the sport and every evidence of continued growth for the future.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 26. -- Mrs. Emil Denemark or Chicago, whose horses gained such signal success in Florida last Winter, sent another winner to the post at Tropical Park today. As the 3-year-old filly, Genie Palatine, easily accounted for the Belle Glade Handicap, a Class C test of a mile and a sixteenth that featured the card.

Automobile racing had a banner year in the United States during 1936 with the 300-mile George Vanderbilt Cup race over the new Roosevelt Raceway serving as a spectacular climax. That event, reviving road racing here, was outstanding along with the 500-mile Indianapolis classic in which Louis Meyer created precedent in record-breaking time before a record-breaking crowd of 166,000.

Bobsledding was of particular significance to Americans in 1936, for it was in this breath-taking sport that the United States won its only gold medal at the Winter Olympics at Garmisch-Partenkirchen.

Mrs. William Warner Hoppin again heads the executive committee for the annual exhibition of amateur needlework, inaugurated by her two seasons ago for the benefit of the New York Association for the Blind, which will open on Jan. 11 at W. J. Sloane's, Fifth Avenue and Forty-seventh Street, and will continue there until Jan. 23.

CARLISLE, Pa., Dec. 26 (AP). -- Dr. W. Baird Stuart disclosed today that an automobile accident had led to the discovery that Gretna Bobb of Mount Holly Springs, for eleven years reared and dressed as a girl, is a boy.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., Dec. 26.-Miss Dail Schell and Edward and Herbert Schell of Cathedral Avenue gave a dinner dance at their home this evening.

A pleasing and profitable pastime for an amateur gardener some Winter evening between now and the turn of the year would be to go over the season's garden records and make from them notes which will be helpful in planning improvements for the coming year.

The City College team, defending champion of the Inter-collegiate Chess League, moved into first place ahead of N.Y.U. in the annual tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday. Columbia, Cornell, Brooklyn, Seth Low, Yeshiva and Carnegie Tech also are competing for the Harold M. Phillips Trophy.

REALMS OF GOLD IN CHILDREN'S BOOKS." which this volume supplements, is a survey of the history of five centuries of books for boys and girls, completed by these two compilers in 1929. "Five Years of Children's Books" covers the period from 1930-35, a time when so much of importance has been taking place in the field of books for children, and is, like "Realms of Gold," a storehouse of riches.

Injecting a note of caution, along with statements of increasing industrial and business activity in all parts of the country, the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, in its year-end report, yesterday pointed out that the best buying levels in many commodities markets have already been passed.

THIS is the record of a war correspondent's adventures with the Spanish Rebel armies, as set down in his dispatches between Aug. 22 and Oct. 1, 1936. Although the title leads one to expect a book about the historic siege of the Alcazar of Toledo, that outstanding event is not mentioned until page 174, and then its story occupies only eighteen pages.

MOSCOW, Dec. 26. -- The recent storm in Soviet scientific circles, centering on the Medico-Genetical Institute here, broke out again today in an editorial attack by the newspaper Pravda on G.N. Kaminsky, Commissar of Health of the Soviet Union, under whose jurisdiction the institute functions.

More than 60,000 members of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women were urged yesterday to promote the policy of peace as a special New Year's task, by their president, Miss Charl Ormond Williams of Washington.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 26 (AP). -- R.B. Nathan, agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today a $3,000 extortion plot was foiled by State and government officers with the arrest last night at Punta Gorda of a woman listed as Mrs. Maxine Chadwick White.
HUTCHINSON, Minn., Dec. 26 (AP). -- A Coroner's verdict of suicide today ended the mystery over the disappearance of Professor Arnold F. Hinrichs, 39, of Rhode Island State College.
CHICAGO, Dec. 26 (AP). -- The Christmas holiday rivaled the Fourth of July in tragedy as the nation's deaths neared the 500 mark tonight.
Police Commissioner Valentine declared yesterday that the crime situation after dark in park areas in Northern Manhattan was "not alarming but serious enough to warrant very special attention."

Even those who liked it least scarcely expected the "Anti-Red" League started by Hitler and Mussolini a few weeks ago, and which Japan theoretically joined, would show fissures so soon. But it seems to have been split pretty badly in the past week.
Frederick J. Perry, for the fourth successive year, won the major honors in tennis for Great Britain and himself in 1936 and at the end of the season left the amateur ranks.

THE possibilities for reducing the weight of automobiles and thereby decreasing the cost of manufacture were outlined by J.W. Greig, body engineer of the Hudson Motor Car Company, in a paper read recently before the Detroit section of the Society of Automotive Engineers.

Affecting more than 50,000 children and adults in New York City schools and community centers, a dramatization program has today, after two years of experimentation, proved its worth to Board of Education and WPA officials by helping to reduce truancy, aiding classroom discipline and improving diction, vocabulary and reading habits of participants.

THE title of Mr. Knight's book need not frighten the most ardent pacifists. The Dartmouth professor is on their side. He is possessed of a cold fury against war. Between the covers of his volume are 243 pages of sarcasm, of disdain for those whom he holds responsible for plunging nations into war.

DURHAM, N.C., Dec. 26. -- Miss Floy Paula Bassett has the distinction of heading more student organizations at Duke University than any other student enrolled in the Southern institution this semester.

The jaywalker abroad has long known the stern curb of the law. In Rome, Berlin, Moscow, Vienna and other capitals traffic policemen are stiff fellows who jerk their arms and swing their bodies precisely to signify stop and go. The pedestrian who does not obey, or who crosses where he shouldn't, may be reprimanded, fined or even imprisoned.

IT has remained for Frank J. Walter of Houston, Texas, to discover the secret of extracting the maximum of fun from a private menagerie. The Texan took up his hobby, as other amateur zoologists have done, because of a desire to see how many different species he could get together.

The course of the wheat market, on last week's estimate of the Agriculture Department on planting of Winter wheat, at least suggests that we may be entering now a new chapter in agriculture. Washington estimated 57,187,000 acres planted to Winter wheat, against 49,688,000 in 1935 and a previous high-record acreage of 51,391,000 in 1918.

KINGS may abdicate for the women they love, dictators may rail at Communists, Chinese warlords may prey on one another, Spanish Leftists and Rightists may attempt to blast each other out of existence, but science marches serenely on.

The problem of maintaining volume in the face of rising prices will be one of the chief topics of discussion at the annual convention of the National Shoe Retailers Association, in conjunction with the National Boot and Shoe Manufacturers Association, at the Palmer House, Chicago, from Jan. 3 to 6, Jesse Adler, chairman of the executive committee of the retail group, announced yesterday.
Enlivened by the visit of the Maccabees, champions of Palestine, soccer activities of 1936 in this country compared favorably with those of recent years.
MILLIONS of electrified words and countless musical notes, songs and jokes have been "pumped" off into space for another year -- all gone the instant they struck the mute microphone.

The French spheres of the Cameroons and Togoland, which are reputed to have been offered to Germany, have a combined square mileage of 181,893 and a population of about 3,500,000. They are approximately three and a half times the size of New York.

MADRID, Dec. 26. -- It is now known here that General Francisco Franco is reorganizing his forces completely, including his command, while he awaits his full contingent of Germans. That explains in large measure his inaction of this week, although it does not explain why he left the Boadilla sector.

In the matter of assessment the present capital stock tax is unquestionably the simplest of all Federal taxes. Declarations of value originate with the taxpayer and the government has no interest in its adequacy of amount or its inadequacy.

Twenty years ago, when the World War was two years and a half old and war clouds had for some time been gathering ominously over the Western Hemisphere owing to the sinking by Germany of neutral American vessels, the President of the United States gave expression to opinions which at the time seemed fairly incomprehensible to three auditors.

VIENNA, Dec. 18. -- Judging by the treatment of letters and mailed dispatches received in the Vienna office of THE NEW YORK TIMES from its correspondent in Athens, there seems to be a severe censorship of outgoing news in Greece. Telegrams are openly censored, and messages that the government does not desire to appear are not forwarded.

IT is a certain sea captain named Bruce who must be held in large part responsible for luring John Singleton Copley off to London, that eighteenth century goal of all ambitious American artists of the period.

COLLECTORS, dealers and philatelic speculators have been checking carefully on the size of the issue of each variety of United States stamps as a guide to their quantity purchases. They have fallen back on the time-tried theory of "supply and demand," and realize that as a rule the smaller issues usually rise in value over a period of years.

VANCOUVER, Dec. 26 (Canadian Press). -- Weather-worn steel wire, strung along fence-posts in settlements on British Columbia's coast stood today as a corroded monument to one of the most ambitious overland communication systems ever undertaken.

WHOLESALE murder in a Middle Western university, with possible motives ranging from stolen love to Hitlerism -- to say nothing of professional Jealousy among the members of the Department of Biochemistry.

IN exhibiting a case of Stradivari instruments that are virtually without price, the Library of Congress has done yeoman service in arousing public interest in this little known phase of the fine arts.

Many new plants from the Rocky Mountains, selected particularly with a view to their possible suitability for use in Eastern gardens, have recently been added to the herbarium collection at the New York Botanical Garden. They are being studied with interest not only by botanists but also by progressive gardeners and by students of the many horticultural courses being given in and around New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- While thousands of government employes in the national capital were enjoying the three-and-a-half-day holiday given to them by President Roosevelt, the President himself elected to spend most of today at work in his office in the Executive Office Building.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 26 (AP). -- Eleven members of the 1936 United States Olympic team will join other track and field stars in inaugurating the Sugar Bowl's greatest week of sports tomorrow. Eight events will be held at Loyola Stadium.

ST. BONAVENTURE, N.Y., Dec. 26 (AP). -- Patrick F. Scanlan, managing editor of The Brooklyn Tablet and director of the Legion of Decency, will receive the Catholic Action Medal for 1936, the Rev. Thomas Plassmann, president of St. Bonaventure College, announced today.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Dec. 26. -- Dr. Philip Marshall Brown, proffessor emeritus of international law at Princeton University, is in favor of a dog "curfew" law for Berkshire County to aid farmers in building up the sheep-raising industry.

One of the city's leading child welfare agencies, the New York Diet Kitchen Association, will benefit from the performance of "The Tales of Hoffmann," with Grace Moore and Lawrence Tibbett in the leading roles, on Jan. 14 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 26. -- Opposing sides in the maritime strike fired more accusations at each other today, but at the same time arranged for a resumption of peace negotiations on one of the most tangled problems of the fifty-eight-day tie-up.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- At the moment President Roosevelt is "No. 1 Relief Man" and it is to him that industry, labor, the unemployed and those on work-relief projects look for the formulation of a possible new policy on the entire problem of relief and unemployment.

President Justice Pelham St. George issell and Mrs. t3issell gave a dinner dance last night in the Jade and Basildon Rooms of the Waldorf-Astoria for their dbutante daughter, Miss Nancy Wemple Bissell, for whom they gave a reception at their home earlier this month.

Mr. and Mrs. William F. Straukamp of 1,317 Carroll Street, Brooklyn, presented their daughter, Miss Marguerite Straukamp, to society yesterday at a tea dance in the Embassy Suite of the Ambassador Hotel.

Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Semler gave a dinner dance last night in the Viennese Roof Garden of the St. Regis for their dbutante daughter, Miss Anne Parker Semler. and for Miss Holly Philbin, dbutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Holladay Philbin.

Once Christmas and the turn of the year are passed, the power yacht and motor boat folks know that just around the corner is the national exposition in Grand Central Palace, the annual fixture now thirty-two years old that signalizes another season afloat.

ONE of the interesting features of Max Reinhardt's production "The Eternal Road," the Franz Werfel play which will have its world premiere at the Manhattan Opera House, Jan. 4, is the musical setting by Kurt Weill, the German composer.
MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 26. -- Turkey shoots brought thirty-six gunners to the traps of the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. A skeet event drew twenty-two entrants. A 16-yard test brought fourteen.

RADIO'S salute to 1937 will begin in Europe and spread through the ether as the microphone follows the sun and the westward flight of time across the Atlantic, the American continent and on to Honolulu.

BOSTON, Dec. 26 (AP). -- The arrival of Miss Ethel du Pont, fiancee of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., coincided today with his physician's report that the son of the President was "convalescing perfectly."

With the trotting of the famous Hambletonian Stake for 3-year-olds, the light harness season reached the highest point of a most successful year from every viewpoint. A capacity crowd jammed the Good Time mile track at Goshen, N.Y., on the afternoon of Aug. 12, to witness the American trotting classic.
