ROME, Dec. 26. -- A couple of months of intense negotiations, although interrupted by the British constitutional crisis, have been sufficient to bring Italo-British relations back to the point where there may be definitely foreseen re-establishment of the traditional cordiality that has permitted Italy and Great Britain to live side by side in the Mediterranean for centuries without any friction.

Death struck with a heavy hand at the sporting world during the past year, as practically every sphere of athletic activity was hard hit by losses. All sports on the list from archery right down the alphabetical list to yachting suffered severely.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 26. -- The most important business development this week on the Pacific Coast was the last-minute release of strike-bound goods from warehouses which helped relieve the seriously depleted stocks in retailers' hands.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- An intricate machinery of accounting, which will keep books on more people than ever before have been listed on permanent government records, has begun to function as the administration of the Social Security Act gets under way.

AVIGOROUS young man from England now wields the baton of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society as its first permanent conductor in sixteen years. John Barbirolli came to New York from England as guest conductor; but soon after he had made his debut here the Philharmonic directors decided that he was the man for whom they had been looking, and promptly engaged him for a term of three years.

THE turn of the year finds business recovery advancing on a world-wide front; or at least in those nations where absolutism has not ousted bookkeeping. We can only conjecture what goes on beyond the veil where a dictator solves his economic problems by the simple device of ordering his subjects to pull in their belts.

The Misses Marie Bradford Trench and Mona Law Trench were introduced to society yesterday at a tea dance given by their parents, Mr. and Mrs. Stewart Power Trench, at the Pierre. The debutantes received with their grandmother, Mrs. Lewis C. Johnson; their mother and the Misses Mary Elizabeth Stevens, Marian Kennedy, Isabel Uppercu, Valerie Lathrop and Betty Chipman.
Miss Ruth Hughes Aarons of New York dominated the picture in table tennis both here and abroad during 1936, if number of championships can be taken as a criterion.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 26. -- According to Paris dispatches in the press here Chile has been negotiating with the French authorities for the disposal of a large quantity of nitrate of soda, for which airplanes will be taken in exchange.

City officials and others have accepted membership on the Gustave Hartman Memorial Appeal Committee, it was announced yesterday by former United States Attorney Charles H. Tuttle, chairman. The committee was organized recently to perpetuate the work of the Israel Orphan Asylum in memory of Gustave Hartman, a former Municipal Court Justice, who founded the institution and was its president until his death, Nov. 12.

NEW trails are blazed continually in the pursuit of odd hobbies. Recently an elaborate model of a church was built out of 16,237 matches by a Buffalo man who has been confined to his bed for nineteen years. The hobbyist studied photographs of St. Stanislaus Church at Buffalo as a guide to his design in matches and glue.

Wholesale business experienced a lull last week as retailers catered to last-minute pre-holiday shoppers, according to a special report prepared for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. The report continues:

RECORDS of importance in the air fell by the board during 1936. Among the more important were that for altitude, captured by the British; that for the crossing of the United States from coast to coast, broken by Howard Hughes, and a number of seaplane records for speed with load over long distances on the closed course, captured from the United States by France.

The Fusion majority in the Board of Education will mark the first anniversary of its assumption of power on Wednesday. The members feel they have achieved substantial accomplishments and hope to extend them in the year ahead.

Philippine women, under the terms of a bill recently passed by the National Assembly, will be permitted to vote on April 30, 1937, in a plebiscite to determine whether they want the franchise. If 300,000 so vote, the franchise will be theirs.

Those business concerns which have made huge dividend disbursements this year will receive extra attention from credit executives in 1937, according to comment here yesterday. The opinion was expressed yesterday that many such companies may have weakened their financial structure considerably by the unusually heavy payments and that, accordingly, they should bear watching.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Dec. 26 (AP). Harry Bridges of San Francisco, the Pacific Coast maritime strike leader, was booked at the city jail tonight and ordered held without bail pending an inquest into the death of a boy here in a traffic collision. Lieutenant O.H. Hoyt of the police announced.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Dec. 26. -- Mr. and Mrs. R. Gilbert Jackson presented to society Mr. Jackson's daughter, Miss Geraldine L. Jackson, tonight at a dance at the Garden City Hotel. The debutante wore a gown of white margauza over white satin and carried a muff of orchids.

With credit to Bold Venture for his fine victories in the Kentucky Derby and Preakness, the Gallant Fox colt, Granville, must be endorsed as the best horse of 1936, any distance, any age. It was a year of further expansion on the turf, so that horses now race the four seasons around and every day, Sundays excepted.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 26 (AP). -- Dean George F. Plimpton, who has charge of Harvard University's alumni placement and student employment services, announced tonight that employers were showing an increasing interest in hiring seniors just out of college.

THINGS turn out strangely in the theatre. No more than a year ago, the whole of London's West End was buzzing with excitement over a most remarkable production of "Romeo and Juliet." It was remarkable for many reasons, but one of the chief of them was the fact that it brought together as Shakespeare's star-crossed lovers two of the most extraordinary young people of the English theatre.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- This resort is preparing a rousing welcome for the New Year, and there will be more parties and affairs staged here next Thursday night than for the same time in any of the past eight years.

With many sections of the country reporting the heaviest volume of retail trade in years, buyers representing stores throughout the country will enter the wholesale markets this week to prepare for promotions next month and to shape their plans for Spring merchandising campaigns.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP). -- The Coast Guard is mobilizing a fleet of twenty vessels to break ice in the paths of commercial ships and barges. Ice-breaking became an official duty of the guard this week under an executive order of President Roosevelt, although it has aided in the work for several years.
HAVANA, Dec. 26 (AP). -- President Frederico Laredo Bru today promised the country "honesty in government" in the first meeting of the new Cabinet. Other pledges in the Cabinet session were:
CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- The American Association for Labor Legislation called today for prompt solution of the administrative problems of the social security laws.

Correspondent Janet White is one of a great number of people who believe that the drama critic is the Simon Legree of show business. And, no doubt, that this is so because he is not content to indulge in the Nazi method of drama criticism: merely describe the work -- and contemplate.

Miss Evelyn Luella French, daughter of Mrs. teven E. French of Orange, Mass., and the late Mr. French, was married here yesterday afternoon in St. Thomas Church to Francis Hartley Jr, -qon of Mr. and Mrs. Frank I-Intley of Belmont, Mass.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- A 14 per cent increase in retail sales this year over 1935 to a total between $37,500,000,000 and $38,000,000,000 was forecast today by the American Retail Federation. The federation said that while Christmas selling closely approached the level of 1929, business for the year was about 24 per cent under the volume for that year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- One of our most troublesome, most misunderstood and most misapplied statements of our national policy has become the joint policy of all the American Republics. Shorn of the imperialistic barnacles which have made it hateful to Latin America for a generation, the Monroe Doctrine has been restored to its original intent and has become the doctrine, not of the United States alone, but of the Western hemisphere.

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 26 (AP). -- The General Labor Confederation of Mexico tonight declared its approval of President Lazaro Cardenas's action in offering Mexico's hospitality to Leon Trotsky, Russian exile.

JAMES HUNEKER was a prodigious person. In him the volatile, richly imaginative mind of the Irish was fused with the musical appreciation and capacity for endless industry of the Hungarian. A tale is told of him that he once wrote 185,000 words longhand in three months.

IN these days, when it is considered necessary to devote unnumbered volumes to the instruction of the wholly untaught in music, it is something of an achievement to originate a novel device for that end. The object is to overcome what seems something like "sales resistance."

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- Fears that untoward political complications might develop in Europe over the week-end and persistent reports of a shortage of food in Germany dominated the action of the grain markets in this country today. The trade was without guidance in the way of cable dispatches, as all foreign markets, including Winnipeg, were closed for the Christmas holidays.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP). -- Democratic regulars in the Senate moved today to punish Senator Rush D. Holt, youthful and rebellious Democrat from West Virginia.

A series of model rooms, designed to demonstrate their possibilities as an efficient selling tool for stores availing themselves of the opportunities afforded by the widening home furnishings field, will feature the housing forum to be held in connection with the twenty-sixth annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania from Jan. 18 to 22.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Dec. 26. -- Ralph W. Ellis, president of the Springfield Five Cents Savings Bank, completed this year fifty-five years in the banking business, celebrated his eightieth birthday and established what probably stands as a world's record when he attended for the sixty-first time the annual football game between his alma mater, Harvard, and Yale.

ALTHOUGH the rush to Florida has been under way for several weeks, with transportation agencies taxed and roads swarming with southbound traffic, the "official" season begins right after the holidays. Hotels are now staging gala openings, and varied recreation programs are being announced daily by the suntan resorts.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 26. -- Leilah Kemerer, aged 6, was alive today as the result of her blind aunt rescuing her from the second floor of her blazing home in Duquesne early yesterday.

One of the biggest upsets in modern boxing history jarred the year 1936 out of the commonplace; gave it, in the matter of surprise and shock, even greater significance than was attached to the preceding year when James J. Braddock confounded the boxing world by winning the world heavyweight title from Max Beer.

Of the 3,800 orphaned and dependent children under the guardianship of agencies affiliated with the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City, two-thirds receive individual care in private homes under the personal attention of foster mothers, it was said yesterday in the annual report of Herman W. Clock, chairman of the child care committee of the federation.

The cross-country season had a distinctly collegiate tinge to it during the past year, as college youths romped off with all the major titles. The feature was the magnificent victory of Don Lash in the national A.A.U. championship run a month ago at Branch Brook Park in Newark.

THE first biography of Schubert is the manuscript formerly attributed to Schober, but now declared to be by another friend of the composer -- namely, Joseph von Spaun. That Spaun was the author of the biography, which is to be published shortly by the Atlantis Verlag of Berlin and Zurich, was discovered recently by George Schuenemann, director of the music division of the Berlin State Library.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- An acceleration of the tempo introduced with Christmas is apparent on this week's program. Many festivities revolve around New Year's Eve: others will take place New Year's Day, when the Winter colonists will be going from one informal "open house" to another to make calls.

THE year 1936 was not the most nor the least eventful of recent years in contract bridge. While there were no spectacular pair or team matches, apart from the usual string of tournaments, there were enough by-products of the game to sustain general interest week by week.
ENZESFELD, Austria, Dec. 26 (AP). -- A jolly Duke of Windsor made Christmastide merry today for the children of Enzesfeld.

MR. SCUDDER has had the happiest notion for a new book on Emerson by writing of him as notable Englishmen saw him oil his various European visits, as tourist or lyceum lecturer. It is Emerson of the "English Traits," but supplemented by all sorts of out-of-the-way information, some of it hitherto unpublished, from diaries, journals and newspapers of the time; and all of it delightfully displayed with infinite tact and scholarship.

In the first chapter of this book the reader is permitted to listen in while a murder is being plotted. He does not then know the identity of the plotters, but he is at all times one step ahead of Martin Crow, K.C., a retired London criminal lawyer who has undertaken to prove that Michael Maguire is not guilty of the murder of his aunt, Miss Jennifer Maguire.

WHETHER or not it commences a new cycle of the Savoy operas cannot be said, but for the third time, under the imprimatur of Rupert D'Oyly Carte, "comes a train of little ladies" together with a band of assorted sizes in men with a complete recording of "The Mikado" (Victor Album C-26).
MIAMI BEACH, Fla. -- A renewal of activities by the principal clubs, which every season play a prominent part in the life of the Winter colony, features resort activity this week.

The majority of State Constitutions forbid the use of public funds for the support of sectarian or religious education, according to a nation-wide survey of the legal provisions for State school supervision and aid under the auspices of the Institute of Catholic Educational Research of Fordham University.

CARTOONISTS have never had much of an opportunity to perform on the air, but television promises to glorify their talents. For example, "Cabaret Cartoons" was the title of a television show recently scheduled for London's air.

WHEN we saw Miss Lily Pons last week she had just come home breathless from posing for photographs in a shop with a goose named Sylvia that wore a blue coat and had obviously been a most enchanting fowl.
One chapter in the history of figure skating during the past year followed a rather romantic trail -- from Garmisch-Partenkirchen to Hollywood.

ALBANY, Dec. 26. -- Arrangements for the third inauguration of Governor Lehman on Friday were completed today, showing that the utmost simplicity will characterize the event. With the seating capacity of the Assembly Chamber limited to about 1,000 persons, arrangements have been made to place amplifiers in the Senate Chamber and in the Capitol corridors for the benefit of those unable to obtain seats.

THE year 1937 will bring to scouting one of the busiest twelve months of its history. In every branch of the regular program for the Cubs, the Boy Scouts and the Senior Scouts there will be heightened seasonal activities. And in addition the first national jamboree in this country will be held in Washington, D.C., to be followed by the fifth world jam boree, which will take place in Holland.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 26. -- A Federal grand jury is investigating alleged election frauds in Kansas City, where the Democratic party, under the direction of Thomas J. Pendergast, swamped the opposition last Nov. 3 and rolled up unprecedented majorities.
VATICAN CITY, Sunday, Dec. 27. -- Vatican hopes for Pope Pius's recovery dwindled with reports that paralysis had extended over his entire left side.

Records almost without end crashed to earth to be superseded by others in the year of sport now striding majestically to the wire. Some were national, others international and a few were practically incredible.

The formation of the American Society for Technical Aid to Spanish Democracy, with temporary quarters in the offices of The New Masses, 31 East Twenty-seventh Street, was announced yesterday by Waldo Frank, novelist and lecturer.

Gaining nothing more tangible than experience from the expedition, the American Olympic fencing team competed in the Olympic Games at Berlin last Summer, but failed to hold the advanced position it acquired at Los Angeles four years before.

QUARRYVILLE, Pa., Dec. 26. -- Three bells, named Tom, Dick and Harry, were hung from a massive oak frame in 1884 by a Quarryville hardware dealer to advertise his stock in trade, which included farm bells to summon the toilers from the fields at mealtime.

CARLISLE, Pa., Dec 26. -- The old Moore mansion, where the Confederate general, Fitzhugh Lee, formerly paid court to one of the three daughters of Johnston Moore, and which is rich in local tradition, has been acquired by Dickinson College. The trustees, headed by Boyd Lee Spahr of Philadelphia, have approved plans to start remodeling the mansion into a biology building and work has been started.

FOR some years back George Willard Bonte has been delving into old tomes, searching yellowed newspapers, looking for the "vital historical pictures hidden away on the dusty shelves of American libraries and museums."
CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- An assertion that labor was the only serious threat to the recovery movement was made today by James P. Maher of Shields Co. in a message to the brokerage concern's customers.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 26. -- Liquor may be telegraphed to New Jersey from other States, provided the transaction is handled by a commercial telegraph company, not by an out-of-State liquor retailer, according to a ruling today by Commissioner D. Frederick Burnett.

MELBOURNE. THE Great Barrier Reef of Australia, which parallels the coast of Queensland for 1,260 miles, is the scene of an important industry -- fishing for the trepang or beche-de-mer, the sea slug considered so great a delicacy by the Chinese.

Dorothy Gordon appeared in her annual costume recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon and brought before her large audience a "treasure bag of songs and stories from the children's corner." The program, which was delightful, consisted of folksongs of many countries.

LONDON, Dec. 26 (Canadian Press). -- Boxing Day soccer resulted in the English league championship race developing into a stern tussle. Arsenal, Sunderland, Brentford and Charlton Athletic went into a tie for the lead and as the teams prepare for the third game of the holiday schedule, Monday, only three points divide the first ten clubs.
Several dbutantes are aiding in the sale of tickets for the musicale and ballet in behalf of the Alice CJapin Adoption Nursery, which 'will take place Wednesday at tke Versailles.

The stentorian voice at the Olympic Stadium loud-speaker system repeated one phrase more than any other -- "Erste, Owens, U.S.A." Even with the German pronunciation of "Owans, Oo Ess Ah" the message was there for all to hear. James Cleveland Owens, the mighty Jesse, was first again.

The undefeated Brooklyn Tech sextet, which has yielded but two goals in five P.S.A.L. contests this season, conquered an alumni team, 6 -- 2, at the Brooklyn Ice Palace yesterday. Henry Brunjes, Chad Carpenter, Herman Langfur and Rubin Selcov tallied for the victors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- The British Royal Commission investigating conditions in Palestine was called upon to insist upon public testimony from Arab leaders by Rabbi Stephen S. Wise, rabbi of the Free Synagogue of New York and president of the Zionist Organization, in an address tonight before the convention of the Junior Hadassah.
Mr. and Mrs. Francis Hunt Geer gave a dinner dance last night in the ballroom of the Pierre to intro!duce Mr. Geer's daughter, Miss ]Helen Hartley Geer.

TOSCANINI has left for Paris and Palestine after giving us the most supernal performance of Beethoven's Mass in D that Vienna has ever listened to. Now, "ever" is a long time, the "Missa Solemnis" is over a hundred years old and to my knowledge there were no centenarians in the Musikverein Saal on this occasion.
The billiard world found 1936 somewhat of an off season, major competition in both professional and amateur ranks not being so lively as it has been in other years.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 26 (AP). -- Pittsburgh may or may not be developing a pass attack, but it is no secret that Washington, its opponent in the Rose Bowl New Year's Day, has a dangerous overhead game.

Professional football had another of its big seasons in 1936 with exciting pennant races in both Eastern and Western divisions of the National League. The Green Bay Packers and the Chicago Bears were tied until right up near the end when the Wisconsin powerhouse went on to win the Western crown.

Norman Thomas, Socialist leader and member of the American Committee for the Defense of Leon Trotsky, said yesterday that Mr. Trotsky's forthcoming arrival in Mexico from Norway might accelerate the movement for appointment of an international commission to investigate the trial of Trotsky and others in Moscow last August on charges of plotting the assassination of Stalin and other Soviet leaders.

The Lincoln Cathedral Choir of fifty-five mixed voices will participate in the afternoon service at Riverside Church, on Riverside Drive at 122d Street, today, on invitation of Dr. Harold Vincent Milligan, organist and music director.

While the number of legislative proposals designed to control business in some form or other is large for the forthcoming session of Congress, leading business men were inclined yesterday to doubt the possibility of passage of any considerable number of these bills.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 26. -- The Christmas trade held up to the last minute in the Eighth Federal Reserve District and retail stores reported increases of from 15 to 25 per cent over last year.

George Slocombe, British journalist and author, arrived from London yesterday on the Canadian Pacific liner Empress of Britain for a ten-week lecture tour in Chicago, Boston, Philadelphia and other cities. Mr. Slocombe said he did not believe there was danger of a general European war for several years, although the various nations had done their best to provoke one.

For most children the Mother Goose Rhymes are, as they should be the introduction to literature. Here little children find the rhyme and rhythm that they love, and the qualities of wonder and surprise. Mother Goose is timeless and universal and furnishes the child's imagination with landscapes and adventures that persist through the years.

The Long Island University and City College basketball teams regained much of the prestige lost by local colleges last week by scoring clean-cut triumphs over out-of-town adversaries last night at the Hippodrome before an overflow crowd that jammed every inch of space in the arena.
GREENWICH. Conn., Dec. 26,Baron and Baroness J. C. Van Eck will give a farewell dinner at their home tomorrow. They are leaving early in January to make their home in London.

MADRID, Dec. 26. -- Not long before THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent sat down to write this article some marksman at the business end of a six-inch cannon in the Case del Campo, four or five miles away, dropped a shell exactly in the center of the roof on the telephone building's fourteen-story high tower.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- In everything but name and declared purpose the Committee for Industrial Organization, headed by John J. Lewis, is a rival to the American Federation of Labor. This fact has become apparent in the last fortnight and especially in the last week as a result of events that have heightened the dispute between the federation and the C.I.O.

The holidays of ADOLF HITLER are not spent in simple enjoyment of the favorite German festival. In the steep-roofed chalet of his retreat amid the frosted fir trees and snowy mountain slopes of Berchtesgaden, the Nazi chief might suggest a brown figure in a typical Christmas-card setting.

HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 26 -- Dartmouth's new social science curriculum, designed to give every student a better understanding of human relationships, was virtually completed in outline last week with the announcement of plans for an integrated sophomore course and for the so-called "topical majors." The first third of the program, a required freshman course in social backgrounds, was begun this Fall.

AMERICANS who join the special "snow cruise" of the Paris on Jan. 16 will find themselves, when they reach St. Moritz ten days later, in the midst of the biggest Winter sports season on record. Things working together to this end include the return of prosperity and the devaluation of currency in Switzerland, France and Austria.

In the splendid Salon of Mirrors which graces the Presidential palace at Havana, Colonel Federico Laredo Bru, soldier, lawyer and judge, took the oath of office Thursday as fourteenth President of the Republic of Cuba.

LONDON, Dec. 23. -- Except for the usual galaxy of Christmas pantomimes and other flights into the realms of fantasy, London offers little in the way of new entertainment for the immediate future. No pretentious productions are promised until well after the new year has been ushered in.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26. -- Retail sales here ran approximately 12 per cent ahead of a year ago in department stores and slightly higher in chain and specialty stores, indicating a net increase for this December over last of about 13 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Looking ahead to 1937, Stewart McDonald, the Housing Administrator, foresaw today a possibility that 450,000 homes would be built in that year.

PARIS, Dec. 26. -- The deadlock between the Senate and the Chamber of Deputies over the Compulsory Arbitration Bill continued today and the Senate decided to hold a special Sunday session when it failed to reach an accord tonight.

The Baker sisters have an inexhaustible invention. In this, their latest book, they have turned aside from fairy tale and talking animals to recount the history of a wonderful doll, nearly a hundred years old, who is sent by Great-grandaunt Jessica to Diana on her fourth birthday.

The development of a new plan of architectural training at Princeton University and at the University of Minnesota, was noted yesterday by Dean William Emerson of Massachusetts Instittue of Technology, chairman of the education committee of the American Institute of Architects, in a report on progress in architectural education during 1936.

Friendly relations among the alumnae clubs of Eastern colleges for women may be even more closely knit in the future, if conferences among representatives result, as indications point, in a joint housing enterprise for the group comprising the "big seven."

The French liner Champlain won all honors for misfortune in her recent transatlantic crossings, with the elements and international labor complications combining to hamper her progress and prevent the unloading of her freight.
Two superb exhibitions, each supreme in its field, were the flashing beacon lights of the year in the canine world in the United States.

A few miles' climb above Berchtesgaden, high up in the southeastern Bavarian Alps, lies Haus Wachenfeld, the mountain home of Adolf Hitler. Towering above it are the mighty, snow-covered peaks which stand on the border between Germany and Austria. Below it stretch long Alpine fields, now buried under snow.

Problems and procedures of birth control clinics will be discussed at the conference on contraceptive research and clinical practice to be held at the Hotel Roosevelt Tuesday and Wednesday. Representatives from about fifty clinics will take part in the sessions.

NIGHTS in the South are brilliant, when it comes to parties and dressing. On gala occasions, at the Colony or the Everglades Club in Palm Beach, balloons are festooned in colored clusters and the loveliest of clothes are in order.

Skiing, which in the past has been shunted to the background of major Winter activities in the United States, enjoyed a phenomenal development last season, a growth that probably is unprecedented in the annals of sportdom.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 26. -- With holiday trade in the Fifth Federal Reserve District estimated at 12 per cent above that of last year, virtually all business and industry is enjoying a three-day rest preparatory to a resumption of the forward stride that is rapidly approaching the pre-depression peak.

With Phil Brady playing a beautiful game at back, Squadron A won its second straight game in the Metropolitan Indoor Polo League at its own armory last night and remained at the top in the league standing. The team took a four-goal handicap from Arthur Borden's Winged Foot trio to triumph, 11 1/2 to 4.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 26. -- Grants of $1,500 have been given by the New Jersey College for Women in the last few years to ten alumnae who have proved themselves outstanding scholars.

THIS is an excellent example of a book written for children with the same careful study of background and period, the same accuracy of detail, that would be considered necessary in book for adults. It is combined with an imaginative understanding of childhood, with humor and a fine power of characterization, so that a Connecticut country community of a hundred years ago promptly comes to life before the reader's eyes.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 26 (AP). -- Out to "get acquainted" and to work for harmony in party ranks, as he explained it. William S. Murray of Utica today paid his first visit to Syracuse since his election as chairman of the Republican State Committee.
Young men and women home from school for the holidays attended Miss Elsie Livingston Hepburn's Christmas Junior Assembly last night at Grace Church Parish House on Brooklyn Heights.
Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman was asked yesterday to punish Father Divine, Negro cult leader, for contempt of court.

The holiday influence was, of course, felt in the securities markets last week, in that trading was substantially diminished and prices moved irregularly -- irregularly higher in the case of stocks. In contrast, the markets for virtually all commodities were active and strong.

TWO Literary Fellowships for 1937, similar to those offered for the last two years, are announced by Houghton Mifflin Company. The purpose of these fellowships, each of which carries an award of $1,000, is to help writers of promise to secure the financial independence essential to their development.
The brilliant showing made by American men swimmers at the Olympics was the year's highlight in aquatic sports.

If the thermometer outside Commissioner William F. Carey's office in the Sanitation Department had dropped just a few degrees during the heavy rains of this month the city would have faced the tremendous task of removing 195,000,000 cubic yards of snow, with an average depth of more than five feet, from its streets.

Between the twilight of 1936 and the dawn of 1937, no special punctuation marks the division of the calendar year in the schedule of women's organizations. Contrast with the advances of former years, however, acquires a sharper outline and a new significance in the mid-seasonal lull, in the light of recent developments, as highlights of the ebbing year are reviewed.

AS a special holiday attraction for children, Junior Programs, Inc., will present four special matinees this week at the Bayes Theatre when the bill will consist of a ballet version of "Pinocchio," Collodi's popular story of the adventures of a marionette.
LONDON, Dec. 26. -- The United States Ambassador and Mrs. Bingham were among the guests at a reception given by the treasurer and masters of the bench in the hall of Lincoln Inn.

The Stanley Cup, emblematic of the world professional hockey championship, was won by the Detroit Red Wings in the 1936 campaign. With Jack Adams as manager, the Wings came through with the title for the first time since they were accepted into the National Hockey League in 1926.

Mr. and Mrs. Kingdon Gould gave a dinner last night at their home, 160 East Seventy-second Street, for Miss Priscilla St. George and her fiance, Angier Biddle Duke. Among the other guests were the Misses Consuelo and Elena Villa, Lucy Jeffcott, Eleanor Young, Thayer Gibbons, Eleanor Hoguet, Helen Barker, Lucy Sounders, Margaret Stevenson, Barbara Field and Edith and Silvia Gould, daughters of the host and hostess.

Highlights of 1936 in curling were the successful defense of the Gordon International Medal by the United States, the victory of the Utica Curling Club over the defender, Schenectady, in the Gordon National Medal and Brookline's retention of the Stockton Cup.

POTTSVILLE, Pa., Dec. 26. -- The lower anthracite region of Pennsylvania, covering most of Schuylkill and Northumberland Counties, is a section of contrasts and contradictions, where great corporations, modern machinery and wealth are losing out to a vast army of destitute unemployed who are mining coal in the most primitive fashion.

IT is always surprising when, as in the case of Julian Green. Ralph Bates and, recently, Kay Boyle, a writer is able to assimilate the spirit of an alien country. The trick seems difficult; the achievement remarkable.

AT home and abroad, Winter sports will hold the eyes of the world for the coming three months. The snow fields of Germany, Switzerland, Austria and France offer full programs for seasoned sportsmen. Nearer home, cold weather activities are sufficiently diversified to suit the most exacting outdoor fan.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 26. -- To settle pending economic matters needing readjustment between the United States and Brazil. Assistant Secretary of State Sumner Welles will leave the liner Southern Cross, on which the United States delegates to the Inter-American Conference are returning from Buenos Aires, at Santos and fly to Rio de Janeiro.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 26 (AP). -- Good Omen, a 3-year-old chestnut filly from Louise White's stable, took the measure of seven other sprinters in capturing the six-furlong feature at the Fair Grounds today.

Banks and Insurance companies in the fiscal year 1936 added to their holdings of government securities by an amount exceeding the total of new securities issued by the government, with the result that on June 30, last, these institutional investors held two-thirds of the total outstanding government debt, according to a survey by the American Banker, daily banking publication.

With Captain Eddie Rickenbacker as chairman of a special aviators' committee and several other noted wartime fliers assisting with details, the annual dinner and ball of the First Aero Squadron Club will be held on Jan. 9 at the Delmonico. Colonel E. Garnsey Brownell is I , . president of the club, which is composed of aviators who were in overseas service during the World War.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 26. All efforts to arrange some settlement of the Gran Chaco conflict between Bolivia and Paraguay under the auspices of the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace have failed.

THOUGH parents, husbands, children, lovers and friends are all very well, they are not dogs, remarks Elizabeth of "The German Garden" and "The Enchanted April." The reviewer must add with equal candor that it is the above-mentioned list of entities, rather than dogs, which forms the real theme of this book.

FOR the country as a whole the holiday trade just concluded ran about 12 per cent ahead of a year ago, averaging up reports received from many centers. The South, Southwest and some Middle Western areas enjoyed the best increases.
Principal honors in speed skating in 1936 went to Ivar Ballangrud, Norwegian veteran, who annexed three of the four Olympic tests in addition to the world and European championships.
RYE, N.Y., Dec. 26. -- Westchester will celebrate an unusually gay New Year's Eve, according to advance reservations listed at the country and yacht clubs.

RUTH HUNTINGTON was born in Boston in 1859, the daughter of the Reverend Frederic Huntington, who soon afterward became Bishop of Syracuse. By birth, upbringing, and circumstance she was a child of Victorian New England.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 26 (AP). -- A clash between Federal and State jurisdiction appeared impending tonight over prosecution of Levi Frost, 43, an Onondaga Indian who admitted in a statement today the Christmas slaying of Alvin Stout, 34, also an Onondaga, on the Indian nation's reservation south of Syracuse.

PARIS. THE vogue for embroideries is finding a place for itself in knitted resort wear. Kostia de War is showing handmade sweatshirts done in Venetian-red cotton and delicately embroidered with gold or silver metal threads at the neckline and the bottom of the sleeves -- which may be long or short.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP). -- The Justice Department and immigration authorities have in mind the wholesale deportation of white slavers.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 26. -- A new type of instruction is indicated for the high school of the future by the success of Syracuse University's recent revision of the curriculum for students preparing to teach the social sciences in secondary schools.

Two leaflets just issued by the Brooklyn Botanic Garden are of interest to gardeners in the metropolitan area. The first deals with "rare trees and shrubs of Kissena Park, Flushing," and is particularly timely because the old town of Flushing -- now included in the Borough of Queens -- is to furnish the site for the World's Fair of 1939, which will be located on the old "Flushing meadows."

Joe Hiestand was easily the dominant figure in trapshooting during 1936. The young farmer from Hillsboro, Ohio, won four championships at the Grand American tournament at Vandalia, Ohio, and another one at the amateur championships of America at Travers Island.

Timely preparations are already proceeding for improving the 1937 garden. Now cuttings are being made to increase one's shrubs, vines, berry plants and evergreens. No extra equipment and no especial nursing is required.

THE eye of the camera has given invaluable service to scholarship. It has caught and revealed, eloquently and concisely, what would otherwise have taken whole paragraphs of mere words to express. Similarly its predecessors, the artist and the illustrator, were able to portray figures and scenes that no quantity of language could describe with equal precision and clarity.

THE ancient Icelandic sagas which have come down to us number something over thirty in all, of which the Saga of Gisli is not one of the most momentous, although it is far from being of minor import. Indeed, it may be regarded as of major import for the light it sheds on ancient Icelandic culture, ethics and the general mode of life and living.

Cabaret, bar and dance hall owners can insulate themselves against curfew regulations New Year's Eve by paying $10 for a special permit to stay open all night. When Tom Cray was the New York police force 282 years ago, no such privilege was granted. He cried curfew at 9 P. M., the town went to sleep, and no quibbling about it.
PARIS, Dec. 26. -- For the first time since the World War there is apparent real and genuine concern in France over the economic distress in Germany.
PARIS, Dec. 26. -- France offered today to give back Germany's war-lost colonies in exchange for peace.

Verdi's "Il Trovatore," a work which refuses to age despite its eighty-four years of service in the lyric theatres of the world, was presented before a sold-out house last night at the Metropolitan. This first of the season's popular-priced performances was at best an acceptable routine affair, not overly enriched by distinguished vocalism.

THE year is ending with air conditions ideal for long-distance reception. Seldom has the clarity of short-wave broadcasts from all parts of the globe been so pronounced as during the past week. A log of the stations heard reads like a who's who of the international channels.

Mrs. Eugene W. Ong, /fanhattan chairman, is organizing a committee of other prominent women to assist with plans for the President's Birthday Ball to be held on Jan. 30 at the Waldorf-Astoria. This ball will be the main New York event {of the many birthday balls being held in the metropolitan area.

Joseph Curran, leader of the striking seamen in this port, asked President Roosevelt yesterday for an appointment at which he would present the argument of seamen in opposition to the new Federal requirement that employes on American ships carry continuous discharge books.

ALBANY, Dec. 26 (AP). -- Parents who bar children entirely from participation in the affairs of the home create for them an approach to fascism, in the opinion of Dr. Ruth Andrus of the New York State Department of Education.

KICK a barrel down a Hollywood studio at luncheon time, and you are sure to bowl over anywhere from five to a dozen famed writers. If you were rash enough to do this at Paramount, you might knock over Frederick Lonsdale, Brian Marlow, Sam Hoffenstein and Clifford Odets, and everybody would be annoyed at you because they work on million-dollar pictures, and you'd have done a lot of damage.

Perfect in setting, brilliant in presentation and unparalleled in performance, the Olympic Games of 1936 stand apart in history as the greatest sports event of all time. With the fanatical support of the entire German nation backing it, with 5,000 athletes from fifty nations competing and with the almost incredible number of 4,500,000 spectators witnessing the show, the Berlin festival set a standard of such superlative excellence that it may never be matched again.

Most of the laurels in lacrosse again were concentrated in the State of Maryland during 1936. This hotbed of the old Indian game produced not only the outstanding team in the country in the Mount Washington Club of Baltimore but it had the best college and secondary school teams as well.

HAVANA, Dec. 26. -- Colonel Fulgencio Batista, chief of staff of the Cuban Army, openly accepted responsibility today for the present administration headed by President Federico Laredo Bru when he announced the program of the new government.
C.E. Braddon of Cleveland became the all-around champion at the National Association of Scientific Angling Clubs' annual tournament at Portland, Ore., high spot of the year in competitive casting.

LAKELAND, Fla., Dec. 25 (AP). -- Nobody here was surprised by what nearly 100 witnesses for and against the proposed 200-mile Atlantic Gulf ship canal said before the Board of Army Engineers in Washington a few days ago, but the proceedings were followed with factional interest that portends a bitter fight.

Women's clubs, emerging from the depression, present a changed front to the world. Arts and crafts, which a few years ago struggled for a place in the year's program, have assumed major importance in suburban districts, while the study of international relations, abandoned in an era of nationalism, is again engaging the attention of these groups.
WILL the Chairman of the House Committee please make his report on the various happenings during the "fiscal" sports year?

Preparations for what is expected to be the most festive and joyful New Year's Eve since pre-depression days have been made by the various night clubs, hotels and restaurants in the metropolitan area.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP). -- Ten Senators who are retiring next week either by their own or the voters' choice were completing plans today to re-enter private life.

Another numerical increase marked the year in yachting. With a decided growth in the number of small sailing craft in competition, of the sizes that cost less than the cheapest automobile and afford a means of recreational escape from life's humdrum, all records unquestionably were broken in the number of sailing yachts striving for laurels.

BOMBAY, India, Dec. 26 (AP). -- The adoption of a resolution by the Indian National Committee to boycott the coronation ceremonies for George VI in India is considered by well-informed sources to be virtually certain.

Only one world champion retained his laurels in the field of cycling during 1936. This successful rider was Joseph Scherens, the Belgian who captured the professional sprint crown for the fifth year in a row.

MENA, Ark., Dec. 26 (AP). -- A citizens' committee condemned the "teachings and practices" of Commonwealth Labor College today and the chairman of the group said he would seek to have it closed "in a legal way."

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 26 (AP). -- Thirty-five thousand turf fans today saw Papenie, a juvenile outsider, capture the $3,500 Santa Maria Handicap, second-day feature of the 1936-37 Santa Anita racing season.

LONDON, Dec. 26. -- Benefactions in the last eleven years totaling more than 7,500,000 have established Nord Nuffield, former bicycle maker and now one of Britain's outstanding motor - car manufacturers, as one of the greatest philanthropists of modern times.

TOM JONES" continues to be a best seller in every generation, but few people, unless they read the novels of Samuel Richardson at school, ever read them at all. He, who so bitterly resented Fielding's ascendancy during their lifetimes, would stir in his grave did he know how unequally the scales are weighted today; yet it might console him to learn that much of the very best opinion tends to be in his favor.

The belief that the type of basketball played in the United States was a better brand than that on display anywhere else in the world was proved beyond any doubt last Summer when the American Olympic basketball team completely dominated the Olympic tournament -- the first ever to be held as a regular part of the games -- and stalked off with the championship of the world.

MONTREAL, Dec. 26. -- A goal by Stu Evans in the last minute of overtime gave the Montreal Maroons a 4-3 victory over the New York Americans in a National Hockey League fixture tonight before 5,500 fans.

WITH the Copley exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum, the Homer centennial at the Whitney Museum of American Art, the Dada and Surrealist show at the Museum of Modern Art and a spirited round of attractions, heretofore noticed, in the galleries of New York, the public cannot justly complain of a dearth of holiday cheer.

Twenty-seven years after Japan's good-will gift to this country of the famous cherry trees in the national capital a reciprocal gesture is being made by eighty women, members of the Garden Club of America. A shipment of 5,000 trees and plants found growing only in this country will be started tomorrow for the island kingdom from a nursery in Princeton, N.J.

PEYTON BOSWELL, founder and editor of The Art Digest, is gone. He died Dec. 18 at St. Francis Hospital in Trenton, N.J., at the age of 57. Ill for some time, Mr. Boswell had nevertheless enthusiastically carried on and was active to the last -- although he seems to have had a premonition of the approaching end, for in an editorial appearing in the Dec. 1 issue of his widely read magazine occurred this passage:

American chess players acquitted themselves with great credit abroad in 1936, and also held an official tournament for the United States championship, which, since the early Nineties, had been competed for regularly only in match play.
MADRID, Dec. 26 (AP). -- The Leftist army held its ground today as the eighth week of siege began.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Dec. 26 -- Pittsfield's leading families get up early at least one day in the year. That is New Year's morning when the Colts, the Wests, the Jones, the Hibbards, the Hulls, the Wilsons, the Paddocks and the Robbins's attend the sunrise prayer meeting next Friday at the old First Congregational Church.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 26 (AP). -- Four convicted conspirators in the "gift of God" baby case, including Mrs. Nellie Tipton Muench, were sentenced today to long terms in prison as a result of the sensational hoax which started Aug. 17, 1935, with the birth of a son to Anna Ware, an unwed servant girl.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 26 (AP). -- About four thousand teachers, members of eight State educational associations, will gather here next week for an annual conference to discuss readjustment of high school curricula and the evaluation of social studies as a "factor in fitting school students for citizenship."

What has become of the strong silent Englishman who used to sit in a corner of his railway carriage and never relax a facial muscle all the way from Liverpool to London? The question is a pertinent one because the most terrifying adventure which awaits American tourists on English railways is traditionally the massive and impenetrable silence of the gentleman in the corner.
Not in many a turn of the wheel has a baseball campaign provided its nation-wide public with so many thrills and unexpected developments as the season of 1936.

Declaring that the average Hunter College girl travels too much, eats hasty and inadequate lunches and is subject to the strain of "over-civilization," Dr. William J. Fordrung, head of the department of physiology and hygiene at Hunter College, yesterday commended the efforts of the college athletic association.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Dec. 26. -- Wildcats that menace ruffed grouse, pheasants and other bird life in Southern Berkshire are becoming fewer according to the $10 bounty claims filed with the County Treasurer, Mrs. Angeline S. Martin.

WHAT used to be called "the season" is beginning in Havana. Before the depression and a series of Cuban revolutions changed everything, this time of year would always see thousands of rich and well-to-do American begin their annual migration to the little island off the coast of Florida, to bask in semi-tropical sunshine and luxurious surroundings until Spring.

IN this little book a modern minister of religion sets forth a stirring challenge against all philosophies of defeat. "Triumph," he says, "is the fitting end of modern man." And, he adds, significantly, "man is a moral being first of all."

THIS week, as the old year slips out and the new year comes in, the eggnog bowl will replace the cocktail tray. Old friends and relatives and passing well-wishers will drop in on many hostesses for eggnog and fruit cake on the first afternoon of 1937.

WHEN Professor Hudson, in an English course in the University of Mississippi some years ago, gave his students English and Scottish ballads to read, he was surprised to be told that they had known these songs, in their own rural communities, all their lives.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 26 (AP). -- Rain today slowed practice of Eastern and Western football stars who will battle in the Shrine charity game here New Year's Day.

ATLANTA, Dec. 26. -- The broadest advances in six years were made by business in the Sixth Federal Reserve District this week. Leading department stores reported sales compared favorably with post-depression peaks. Several large corporations revealed their holiday turnover of goods the greatest in their history.

Many members of society already have subscribed for the special performance of "The Flying Dutchman," in which Kirsten Flagstad will make her debut as Senta, the afternoon of Jan. 7 at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Florence Crittenton League.

No more thrilling military competition has ever been witnessed in this country than the International Military Team Trophy event, which was the feature of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden in November, this record-breaking exhibition having been the climax of a notable horse show year.

The World War spoiled Germany's plan of being the Olympic host in 1916 and twenty years of frustrated desires went into the staging of the Olympic Games this year. The international carnival had become almost a religion with the Reich and the first worshiping at the shrine of the god Olympus on German soil was the Winter Olympics.

Debutantes of this and recent seasons as well as several young women who will make their debuts during next season will distribute programs at the Children's Mickey Mouse Carnival to be presented tomorrow and Tuesday at Carnegie Hall under the auspices of the Opportunity Shop, a permanent thrift shop maintained for the benefit of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor.

Saint-Saens opera, "Samson et Dalilah," was revived yesterday afternoon by the Metropolitan Opera Association, with Rene Maison, the Belgian tenor, and Mme. Wettergren in the title parts, with a new scenic setting, with stage management by Dr. Herbert Graf and with a new conductor, Maurice de Abravanel.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Dec. 26. -- Although thirty-two college and university students, representing all sections of the country, were elected on Monday as recipients of Rhodes scholarships, not one of them can be characterized as a "typical Rhodes scholar," according to Dr. Frank Aydelotte, president of Swarthmore College and American secretary to the Rhodes trustees.

A new set of champions stepped forward in national and metropolitan lawn bowling in 1936, with E.J. Lienert of Buffalo taking the national singles from fifty-seven rivals and the Pasadena (Calif.) squad, skipped by A. Dehner, the national and East-West rink team titles.

Green, essential in a pleasant window-garden composition, is frequently contributed by ferns. At windows which are well lighted, but where there is no sunshine, ferns dominate. Where the sunlight is strong, fewer ferns are used and they are set well back in the shadows on the room-side.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 26. -- While the recent labor disturbances have not yet affected plant operations in the Fourth Federal Reserve District except in the glass industry, the situation is being carefully watched, for any continued interruption to automobile assemblies would soon react on production schedules at many local plants.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- President Roosevelt this week confirmed the oft-repeated reports that one of his principal projects at the coming session of Congress will be a thorough reorganization of the administrative branch of the Federal Government.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Miss Mary S. Howes, daughter of the Acting Postmaster General and Mrs. William Washington Howes, was introduced to Washington society this afternoon at a reception in the Chinese Room of the Mayflower Hotel.

IF the American credo includes any declaration of principles about first-night audiences it probably runs: "All first-night audiences are hostile to the drama." Certainly something of that sort represents the popular superstition. Actors fear the audience that gathers for an opening performance; they go nervously to pieces as soon as the curtain goes up.

IN commemoration of the decisive defeat of General Santa Ana's army by General Sam Houston's men, which lifted the yoke of Mexican oppression, the State of Texas is constructing a tall shaft on the historic San Jacinto battleground, near Houston.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- A series of lectures on political and economic topics by authorities is being planned as a memorial to Senator Bronson Cutting of New Mexico. Mrs. W. Bayard Cutting of New York, mother of the Senator, has agreed to finance the series for three years.

General Alexander tosses off Lloyd George's criticism of General Pershing by blaming it all on "senile bile." I would call his attention to even stronger criticism from one who is far from senile, and a military man besides -- Captain Liddell Hart.

The American Law Students Association, designed to deal with legal, ethical, social and economic problems affecting law school students, was formed yesterday by students from the law schools of Columbia University, New York University, St. John's University and Brooklyn Law School in this city, and Harvard and Yale.
Mr. and Mrs. Adrian F. Paradis of Brooklyn introduced their daughter, Miss Jean Paradis to society last night at a dance at the Pen and Brush Club, 16 East Tenth Street, Manhattan.

ALONG the coast of South America is a "fringe of cities" easily seen by the most casual traveler. In the lush tropical interior savage tribes live in jungles still unexplored But "somewhere between. these two extremes lies a great and exciting land."
Notices last week of bonds called for redemption before maturity were fewer than in the preceding weeks of this month and mostly were for small amounts of municipal loans.
BERLIN, Dec. 26. -- Germany, in an ultimatum to the Spanish Leftist government, demanded tonight the release of the German freighter Palos and threatened "reprisals" if the demand was ignored.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 26. -- George A. Osborn, librarian of the Voorhees Library at Rutgers University, announced today the acquisition of a record book containing the "Transactions" from 1776 to 1786 of the Athenian Society, Rutgers' first literary group.

WARSAW, Dec. 26. -- An omission in the recent Senate speech of Colonel Josef Beck, Polish Foreign Minister, has had more notoriety than its contents. In his traditional review of the situation on Poland's borders, Czechoslovakia was not mentioned, although 600 miles of Poland's 3,000-mile frontier touches that country.

A NEW expression of luxury in the modern bedroom is the fabric-covered head and foot board. Although such decoration was in Colonial time applied only to the French-style bed in a strictly French interior, the decorator today exercises greater freedom, adapting it to prevailing mode.
Advances in chemical engineering will be reported at a two-day symposium on "Absorption and Extraction," which will open tomorrow at Columbia University.

The Christmas tumult in the shops is over for another year, but just about now some people may be wondering where they are going to put all the presents they got. Transparent closet and bureau boxes present a new answer to the annual problem.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26. -- Mr. and Mrs. George H. Houston of the Barclay gave a dance tonight in the ballroom of the Bellevue Stratford for their debutante daughter, Miss Mary Stuart Houston, who was formally presented in the Autumn.

BARCELONA, Spain, Dec. 26. -- An attempt to isolate Spain from France by the destruction of the important railway station at Portbou and the high bridge at San Miguel de Culera, about a mile away, is being made by Insurgent sea and air forces, as demonstrated by two attacks within the last few days.
DETROIT, Dec. 26. -- The Holzbaugh-Ford hockey team tonight routed the Dartmouth sextet, 15 to 4. Holzbaugh scored eight times before Dartmouth succeeded in getting the puck into the net.

THE public dinner season is on in London. Night after night societies, regiments, county associations, City companies and what not are holding their annual dinners under the tyranny of professional toastmasters. In essentials the ritual is always the same.

MODERN civilization is in such a dilemma that one naturally wonders whether the plans of the prophetic Woodrow Wilson may yet save peoples from threatening disasters. From what I have observed in Europe in the last three and a half years I am more convinced now than in 1920 that the American President did grasp the situation better than any other states man then in official position.

Mrs. Wiggs, Pinocchio and other characters of juvenile fiction will be dramatized for youthful audiences in a series opening tomorrow for the benefit of the Children's Welfare Federation. The organization is seeking funds to continue its work among underprivileged children and their mothers in the city.

MUCH of revealing nature has recently been added to Napoleonic literature, and so it is perhaps preferable to devote this space -- much as the underlying project of the book -- to the protagonist of a struggle that proved the nemesis of Napoleon, and whose indeterminate efforts are finding realization to this very day.

The final surge of Christmas buying last week brought department store Yule trade to a level 10 per cent or more above last year, according to estimates by retail executives. The late spurt offset the comparatively slow start earlier in the month and the final wind-up was about in line with merchants' expectations.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Dec. 26. -- Trustee approval of an experimental resident advisory system in fifteen fraternities at the Pennsylvania State College for the 1937-38 college year was announced today by Dr. Ralph D. Hetzel, president.

A full and exciting year in rowing was climaxed by America gaining its fifth successive triumph in the Olympic eight-oared event. Like the winners of the past, it was a college crew, the University of Washington, that earned the right to represent this country.

A solution to the problem of fixing values on merchandise delivered here Wednesday aboard the French liner Champlain will probably be left to the United States Customs Court through protests filed with that tribunal by importers. The boat made two trips to this port with the same merchandise, being unable to unload the first time because of strike conditions.

THE radio statisticians have released the lists of what they consider as their major broadcasts of 1936. A study of these reports reveals that the outstanding broadcasts came from without radio this year rather than being programs created by the broadcasters themselves.
The 1936 season was the best and most important that United States women field hockey players ever had.

STEADY and in some cases spectacular progress on many fronts have marked the closing year in aviation. There has been an unparalleled expansion of plane and engine construction both in the United States and abroad.

That the women of India will come into their own with international help and by their growing inner strength is the hope expressed in a memorandum to the League of Nations, sent by Indian women because the government of India wrote to the League on the civil and political status of women in British India without consulting women's organizations.

BEFORE me lie two books which, taking their mateterial from the history of the medieval German emperors, bear a certain inner relationship to each other, though they are the works of two different authors.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- Managers of ten theatres in various parts of the city were arrested tonight as they attempted to hold "bank night" drawings and "screeno" in violation of a formal prohibitive order issued today by Police Commissioner Allman.

PINEVILLE, Ky., Dec. 26 (AP). -- A second search was under way here tonight for Vivian Lee, 17-year-old former University of Kentucky student, who disappeared early today from her home at Colmar, Ky., several hours after being restored to her parents.

There are various ways of growing the lily-of-the valley, the fragrant flower with white bells pendant on gracefully arched pale green spikes. One way is to propagate them by the crowns or terminal buds known as "pips," which rise from the root-stocks.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Dec. 27. -- Chang Hsueh-liang declared after arriving in Nanking that he was ready for punishment, "however severe," for revolting at Sian two weeks ago and imprisoning Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek.

Staving off a brilliant second half rally by the losers, the unbeaten Union Temple quintet nosed out Brooklyn College, 34 -- 32, before a capacity crowd of 1,000 persons at the Union Temple court in Brooklyn last night.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- Preliminary estimates of a gain of about 15 per cent in Christmas retail trade here were substantiated by sales this week. The buying movement reached its peak on Monday and fell off thereafter as has been the case locally for several years.

WHEN a couple of Broadway citizens meet up and decide to present a play, the result is automatically a new producing firm. Well, then, there is a new producing firm. Ernest A. MacAuley, for many years a Schwab Mandel executive and more recently general manager for Philip Dunning, is half of it.

NANKING, Sunday, Dec. 27. -- Emergency meetings are scheduled today by high government organs to consider what punishment shall be meted out to Chang Hsueh-liang. It is believed likely he will suffer merely demotion, not formal exile, although he may travel abroad from considerations of personal safety.

GOODWELL, Okla., Dec. 26 (AP). -- College students and fellow workers hauled the unconscious form of Sam Terrill out of a water tower tank and lowered him down a narrow 100-foot ladder today while virtually the entire population of this Panhandle town watched the perilous rescue.

THE Ides of March are something for modern Romans in the theatre to beware of, if the Ides fall in any quintan dating from 1921. (To be perfectly honest, I just learned that one myself, and, to save a trip to the dictionary, it means: "Occurring as the fifth, after four others.")

BERLIN, Dec. 26. -- The Christmas holidays were featured in Germany this year by a series of conferences between Chancellor Adolf Hitler and his principal advisers, the outcome of which may well determine the course of events in Europe for some time to come.

WHETHER it be for the purpose of art, profit or altruism, the exploiting of a criminal is, without doubt, an undertaking subject to many hazards and disappointments; but when the person exploited is a born minstrel endowed with a big, booming voice, an inexhaustible repertoire of quaint songs and a remarkable talent for musical improvisation, there is little reason to fear that he will fail to attract large, curious-minded and sensation-loving audiences.

The men's metropolitan badminton singles crown did not change hands in 1936. When Kenneth J. Ridgway of Garden City defeated a clubmate, Mills P. Baker, in the final, it meant that Ridgway continued his reign as titleholder for the third year in a row.

BERLIN, Dec. 26. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler spent a quiet Christmas at his mountain retreat in Berchtesgaden, in Bavaria, with National Socialist friends who went there from Munich. He arrived there only on Christmas Eve, going by special train.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Dec. 27. -- Popover, sailed by O.H. Chalkley, and Penguin, sailed by Allan Clark, won in their respective classes in the Manhasset Bay Dinghy Regatta today. Each of the two boats won the first three of the five races held in her class, and Clark was second in the next two, but Popover didn't fare quite so well.

Josef Hofmann was again the soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under John Barbirolli at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. He played the Chopin F minor concerto in place of Beeoven's "Emperor," in which he was heard last Thursday and Friday.

TORONTO, Dec. 27. -- The recent discovery of high-grade gold ore at Gordon Lake, in the great Slave Lake area, 500 miles north of Edmonton, Alta., is believed to be the most important gold strike made in the Northwest territories.

PARIS, Dec. 27 (AP). -- Foreign Office sources said tonight unofficial I reports from Rome indicated Italy' l would agree to the Franco-British! I demand that enlistment of foreign volunteers in the Spanish war be! halted.
A goal by Mac Colville gave the New York Rangers a triumph over the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- The "in-law" problem in the Plains Indian family provoked discussions here today among anthropologists attending annual meetings of the American Anthropological Association, American Folk Lore Society and Society for American Archaeology.

The first opera concert of the season was given last night at the Metropolitan Opera House to a capacity audience. Eleven of the company's artists participated in the event, including Nicholas Massue, the French-Canadian lyric tenor who made his debut in the "Prayer" from Massenet's "Le Cid." Critical discussion must be deferred until Mr. Massue has more ample opportunity to divulge his talents.
The Neediest Cases Fund was increased yesterday by gifts amounting to $2,314.50, bringing the total received so far this year -- three days after Christmas -- to $238,943.01.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 27. -Washington's Huskies moved into Pasadena tonight for final training as the West's representatives in the Tournament of Roses football game with Pittsburgh New Year's Day.

PARIS, Mo., Dec. 27. -- Liza Sproul, 8, and George Nevins, 13, were honored tonight at a union church service for being the most polite and courteous children in this Northeast Missouri city during 1936, and especially during December. Each received a cash prize of $10.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 27 (AP). -- Police announced tonight that Bertillon records showed that a man captured today after he shot and wounded a policeman was not Claude McGee, widely sought Missouri slayer, who escaped, while under sentence of death, from jail at Benton, Mo.

If anything, last week's developments in finance and industry emphasized previous testimony to sustained activity. A slight decrease in steel production was ascribed to the impending Christmas holiday. Prices of stocks recovered all the loss caused by last week's announcement that the higher "emergency rates," under which railways had been working since March, 1935, would be suspended.

NANKING, China, Monday, Dec. 28. -- General Chang Hsueh-liang, who flew here Saturday to "face the music" for his seizure of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, had an hour-long interview with the dictator today over what were termed "private interests."

From Alberta, that fruitful mother of innovations, comes a new political theory. Mr. WALTER KUHL, Social Credit member for Jasper Edson, solemnly avers, and will aver more loudly at Ottawa next month, that since Dec. 11, 1931, the Canadian Senate and House of Commons have had no legal existence.

Christmas, which should be followed by increased happiness and strengthened faith, leaves those who do not comprehend its true significance disillusioned and unhappy, the Rev. Dr. W. Russell Bowie, rector of Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway at Tenth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 27. -- Archie San Romani, Kansas State Teachers flyer, defeated Glenn Cunningham, fellow Kansan, in the featured mile run of the second annual Sugar Bowl track and field meet today despite a desperate finish by the world record holder.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27. -- Supplies of breadstuffs the world over are reported to be more closely adjusted to consumptive requirements than at any time in recent year, and there is increasing activity on the buying side that carried prices to new high levels last week, at the same time establishing new records on all commodities.

Peace on earth will come only when God Almighty through Jesus Christ, the Prince of Peace, is enthroned in the hearts of presidents, dictators and the people, the Rev. Dr. Charles Clifford Peale, pastor of the First Methodist Episcopal Church of Olean, N.Y., said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

MADRID, Dec. 27. -- On this, the eighth Sunday since the start of the siege of Madrid, General Francisco Franco's Rebel forces are further than ever from entering the city. In fact, the government took the initiative today and made an advance toward Carabanchel that may well play an important part in the operations on this front.

The moon was obscured from New York by clouds from 10:50 to 10:55 o'clock last night so that the appulse of the moon, a celestial sight visible only about a dozen times in a century that had been predicted for 10:52 P.M., was not visible to earthlings in this area.
Please accept my sincere thanks for your fine editorial "A Chairman of Peace."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Gains in both the imports and the exports of Puerto Rico in the 1936 fiscal year, compared with the previous year, were stressed in the annual report of Governor Blanton Winship submitted to Secretary Ickes today.

DETROIT, Dec. 27 (AP). -- The Canadiens of Montreal, producing the fastest hockey seen here this season, defeated the champion Detroit Red Wings, 5 to 2, before 11,462 fans tonight to stretch their International Division lead to seven points.

The Salzburg Opera Guild, an operatic organization which achieved eminence at the Salzburg Festival last Summer, will come to this country for the first time next Fall, it was announced yesterday. It will give a season of classic and modern works not generally included in standard opera repertoires.
TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 28. -- Japanese newspapers gave prominence today to editorials concerning Chiang Kai-shek's release.

The appointment of the Rev. Dr. S. Tagart Steele Jr., rector of St. David's Church, Baltimore, as vicar of the Chapel of the Intercession, Trinity Parish, was announced by the Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming, rector of Trinity Church, at yesterday morning's service at the chapel, Broadway at West 155th Street.

General buying activity in the wholesale markets here last week diminished somewhat as retailers concentrated on pre-holiday selling efforts. "Rush" orders were received for gift items. Dress business was unusually good, with prints moving in all price groups and considerable volume being placed for January selling.

SPOKANE, Wash., Dec. 27 (AP). -The official searching party today reported finding the bodies of two Northwest Airlines pilots, thrown clear of the wreckage of their mail plane on a mountainside fifteen miles south of Kellogg, Idaho.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- The difference between communism and Zionism is the difference between dictatorship and democracy, Rabbi Edward L. Israel of Baltimore declared tonight at a dinner marking the convention of Junior Hadassah here.

" The Theatre of Angna Enters," which is an inspired phrase to describe the work of this most gifted of our mimes, gave its second performance of the season at the Alvin Theatre last night, with Miss Enters, as always, her own sole scenarist, designer, director and actor.

Edith Fenyes, 11-year-old daughter of Morris Fenyes, a printer employed by The Jewish Morning Journal, delighted him yesterday when she took second place in a radio spelling bee conducted by the National Broadcasting Company at Rockefeller Center between 9 and 10 A.M.

Stricter regulation of pedestrians was favored by 96 per cent of the spokesmen of chambers of commerce and safety committees who replied to a questionnaire sent out by the Fidelity and Casualty Company of New York, it was reported yesterday.

An unemployed bank clerk and a fox terrier he was walking on a leash were killed instantly at about 10:30 A.M. yesterday when an automobile driven by City Magistrate Henry W. Bridges swerved onto the sidewalk on Richmond Road in New Dorp, S.I., and pinned them against a stone wall.

Mr. LA GUARDIA is a good Mayor and Commissioner VALENTINE is a good police commissioner, but now and then they do show an excessive fondness for waging wars and conducting drives instead of just doing their duty.

Announcement of a $10,000 gift to the United Hospital Campaign from Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney was made last night by Stuart M. Crocker, general chairman. The gift was made through the women's committee, of which Mrs. William Woodward is chairman.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 27 (AP) -- A new speed indicator which will flash a red danger signal to a speeding motorist, just as a railroad engineer gets a "slow" or "stop" semaphore, was exhibited today before the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP). -- Air Commerce Bureau officials reported today the government has joined hands with private interests to search for methods for eliminating one hazard of Winter flying.

IRVINGTON, N.J., Dec. 27. -The Essex County Park Commission and officials of this town are playing a game of "put and take," with vocal interjections of "we shall" and "you shan't," using five wooden traffic barriers as the pawns.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 27. -- Rachel Ianniello, 7-year-old mute, whose disappearance on Armistice Day caused a kidnap scare in Westchester, was drowned in barely two feet of water in a steel drum used as a rain barrel nine doors from her home.

PARIS, Dec. 26. -- Conditions in the foreign exchange market here still are rather unfavorable to the franc. The strengthening in the currency which last week followed the speech of Finance Minister Vincent Auriol was short-lived and the stabilization fund had to operate again this week to satisfy the foreign exchange requirements against the franc.

LONDON, Dec. 26. -- The decision of the United States Treasury to sterilize gold imports caused no surprise here in financial circles. It is regarded as merely another step toward giving active expression to the already announced official determination to check unwanted credit inflation or an unrestrained stock market boom.

BERLIN, Dec. 27. -- The city's chief traffic center--Potsdamer Platz, Berlin's Times Square--was undermined by fire this evening which sent clouds of yellow smoke rolling up over the whole center section of the city. There were no casualties.

LONDON, Dec. 27. -- Millions of Britons listened tonight to a radio broadcast by the Archbishop of Canterbury in which he made a solemn "recall to religion." No doubt most of them thought and many of them feared that the prelate would make a further attack on former King Edward VIII after the manner of his address three days after the abdication.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Dec. 27. -- Traffic on the main line of the New York Central Railroad was delayed here today for several hours when more than 200 feet of a retaining wall thirty feet high collapsed on the tracks just south of the Peekskill station.

HAVANA, Dec. 27. -- A demand that large land holdings in Cuba be divided up among the poor was made upon President Federico Laredo Bru this morning when a demonstration of about 2,000 persons marched to the palace and sought an audience with the Chief Executive.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 27. -- The cotton market, after ruling comparatively quiet the greater part of last week, mainly because of pre-holiday influences and the natural desire to even up commitments, became more active and worked higher toward the end of the week, with good trade and foreign buying.
A 10 per cent increase in business was forecast for 1937 by Grover A. Whalen yesterday in a symposium on the outlook for the coming year broadcast over the WOR Forum Hour.

TICONDEROGA, N.Y., Dec. 27. -- The historic village of Ticonderoga, situated in the eastern part of the Adirondacks, is now making a serious bid to gain recognition as one of the most elaborate Winter sports playlands in the East.
