Robert Slavin, 20 years old, of 49 East Ninety-ninth Street, employed as a counterman, bragged to his uncle, William Lever of 1,715 Nelson Avenue, according to the latter, that he had entered the United States illegally from Windsor, Canada, to Detroit.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 27 (AP). -Eastern football stars, assembled for the annual East-West charity game here New Year's Day, braved rain and a slippery field again today for an outdoor workout.

The first of the season's substitutions because of indisposition will take place at the Metropolitan Opera House tonight, when the second week of the season begins. Vina Bovy, who made her debut in "Traviata" last Thursday night, will assume the role of Gilda in "Rigoletto" tonight in place of Stella Andreva, who was scheduled to make her American debut.

If it had been necessary to prove the romantic quality inherent in so much of Bach's music, this was demonstrated when Bernardo Segall, the young Brazilian pianist, included ten of the preludes from the "Well-Tempered Clavichord" on the program of his New York debut recital given last night in Town Hall.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Dec. 28. -Nine Central Government officials and military commanders, who had been under detention at Sian, Shensi Province, since Dec. 12, when Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek was seized, arrived at Loyang by airplane yesterday. The other captives are expected to be released today.

The Class I railroads had more freight cars and steam locomotives on order on Dec. 1 than on any corresponding date since 1929, according to J.J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads. The figures include equipment made in railroad shops, sometimes with reclaimed parts.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27. -- The American Public Welfare Association reported today that seventeen States would not receive their share of the 1936 payroll tax on employers under the social security program unless Congress extended the deadline for State legislative enactment beyond Dec. 31.
MOSCOW, Dec. 27 (AP). -- More guns, men and warships will be Communist Russia's New Year's greeting to developing world war dangers, authoritative sources said today.

Secretary ROPER'S report for the fiscal year 1936 covers a period of twelve months during which the recovery of trade and industry was carried forward without a single important interruption. During this period all the major indexes of business activity reached the highest levels achieved at any time since the early days of the depression.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The meat packing industry paid nearly $1,000,000 more a day for the farmers' livestock in 1936 than in 1935, William Whitfield Woods. president of the Institute of American Meat Packers, reported today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- Marketing of corn by country holders in the Middle West has increased the last few weeks, with offerings being absorbed largely by processors. Speculators are buying on all weak spots and selling on the sharp bulges, which make for an interesting market.
The Ring, boxing publication, nominated Max Schmeling as the world's No. 1 fighter yesterday in announcing its annual rankings for 1936 through The Associated Press.

MELBOURNE, Australia. Dec. 27. -- After seven months of negotiations with Consul General Kuramatsu Murai and Katsumi Niro, special delegate of the Japanese Foreign Office, Sir Henry Gullett, Minister of Trade Treaties, today announced settlement of the trade dispute with Japan.

Although steelworks operations were sharply curtailed last week because of the Christmas holiday, the national average declining 11 1/2 points to 68 per cent of capacity, producers expect to be operating again at substantially the same high levels as early last week, according to the magazine Steel.

Science students from high schools in the metropolitan area will assemble today and tomorrow at the American Museum of Natural History for the annual Science Congress and Christmas Lectures of the American Institute of the City of New York. More than 1,500 are expected to attend.

We print elsewhere on this page an impressive letter signed "Merchant." Its criticisms, directed against the undistributed profits tax on corporations, the income and inheritance taxes in their relations to corporations, and the Robinson-Patman act, cover a wide field.

One of your readers proclaimed in a letter the need of a Republican boss, urging, in the main, that the return of the political boss will result in the designation of competent persons to positions of responsibility.
A move to gain the support of union longshoremen and teamsters for the seamen's strike reached a climax of flying fists outside Webster Hall yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- A proposed "women's charter," defined by its sponsors as an intended "basis for common action by women throughout the world," and by its opponents as a new attempt to "stop equal rights," was issued today by Miss Elizabeth Christman, secretary of the National Women's Trade Union League, in behalf of a "joint conference group" of twenty-six women newly organized to enlist support for the proposal.

In New York there are doubtless many aged couples, alone and poor, who have gone through life together for fifty years or even longer but have not been able to celebrate their golden wedding anniversary.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27. -- While a group of Chicago motion-picture theatres announced today that they would discontinue "bank nights" and "Screeno" prize drawings until further notice, it was indicated that the theatre interests will take court action attacking the validity of the police order prohibiting the drawings.

BERLIN, Dec. 27. -- The British and the French Ambassadors delivered to the Foreign Office today separate but similar notes warning against the continued influx of foreign volunteers to the ranks of the contending factions in Spain. Both notes point out the danger to European peace of this influx and suggest that measures be taken to end it.

While the bird shooters and hunters of small upland game animals had little to cheer about this past season, deer hunters of New York State met with better than average luck. This is the conclusion to be drawn from the figures on the 1936 take of deer released yesterday by the Conservation Department.

Kilby Macdonald supplied a whirlwind finish to the Eastern Amateur League game between the New York Rovers and the Hershey sextet at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon when the Red Shirts' center poked in a goal in the last twenty-six seconds to give the home skaters a 2-1 victory.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 27 (AP). -- Duquesne University's Dukes were en route today from the chill, windswept bluffs above the Monongahela River to Florida's sunshine and their Orange Bowl gridiron contest New Year's day at Miami with Mississippi State.

THIS is about a novel of weight and stature that is at the same time dramatic, a stirring story hard to put down. It is about a novel that can be chewed, that has strength and originality, has a temperament and a point of view behind it, and that is also an engrossing narrative. The title of this rarity is "Shining Scabbard" (Farrar Rinehart, $2.75), and R.C. Hutchinson is the author.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 27 (AP). -- Picks and shovels of archaeologists have unearthed secrets more than 3,000 years old, indicating that the poet Homer's story of the fall of the ancient city of Troy in Asia Minor was founded on fact.

The best selling novels during those crucial days to the book trade between mid-November and mid-December were, according to Baker Taylor Company's actual count of their sales throughout the country, "Gone With the Wind," by Margaret Mitchell; "Drums Along the Mohawk," by Walter D. Edmonds, and "Yang and Yin," by Alice Tisdale Hobart.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association began its three-day meeting at the Pennsylvania Hotel last night with the annual national council dinner and executive session. This afternoon there will be a round-table conference.

The Rev. Dr. Gustav A. Carstensen, rector emeritus of Holyrood Episcopal Church, Fort Washington Avenue and 179th Street, celebrated the sixtieth anniversary of his ordination yesterday at the 8 A.M. services at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, 127th Street and Fifth Avenue.

Emphasizing the need for the rehabilitation of thousands of distressed Jews in Germany, Poland and other countries, the Greater New York Council of Jewish Organizations, at its annual meeting in the Hotel Commodore yesterday, urged Jews in this country to contribute as their minimum share $5,000,000 to the "rebuilding" of Palestine.
MOSCOW, Dec. 27. -- Classical genetics came under heavy fire at the conference of the Agricultural Academy of Genetics, which closed here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- A neutrality policy that would "stop all loans and credits and munitions" to belligerent nations was proposed today by Senator Vandenberg in a statement calling upon Americans to be realists and observe a "mind-our-own-business" code in the present unsettled condition of world affairs.

Decrying the failure of the church to combat the forces of evil, the Rev. Theodore C. Speers yesterday morning advocated a return to the creed of the early persecuted and martyred Christians. Mr. Speers spoke at the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, of which he is the pastor.
New York University looms as the new champion of the Intercollegiate Chess League as a result of games played yesterday in the annual tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27. -- Supplies of hogs declined last week in comparison with the previous week, causing an upturn of 15 cents in four days to $10.45 a hundredweight, a new high level for the Winter season and the highest for December in ten years.

FAIZPUR, India, Dec. 27. -- Opening the annual sessions of the National Congress party, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, president, urged the members not to accept any office under the Government of India Act.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 27. -Historians from all parts of the country will come here tomorrow for the annual meeting of the American Historical Association, to be held under the auspices of Brown University. The sessions will cover historical subjects ranging from Mayan civilization through aspects of the Resettlement Administration's work.

LONDON, Dec. 26. -- While the year-end is causing a seasonal curtailment of financial activity neither the security markets nor trade in general display any loss of vitality or lack of confidence in the future.
Purchase of a Bronx plot by builders and sales of properties in outlying sections composed realty activity in the metropolitan area over the week-end.

Nationalistic organizations like those in Germany will not get a foothold here if Cardinal Hayes's plan for parochial supervision of the leisure time of Catholic youth is successful, the Rev. John Campbell said yesterday morning in a sermon at St. Columba's Roman Catholic Church, 331 West Twenty-fifth Street.

F.A. Cauchois, C.S. Wills and A.L. Burns each broke 97 out of 100 targets to create a triple tie for the high-over-all scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. Only the two first-named gunners took part in the shoot-off however.

MADRID, Dec. 27. -- Madrid artillery battered Rebel lines for three hours today to curtain an offensive. Trench mortars roared steadily from the northwest along an encircling arc south to the Toledo highway. Militia gunners pounded Rebel lines in one of the fiercest attacks of the eight weeks' siege.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Senator O'Mahoney of Wyoming announced today that he will introduce a revised national incorporation bill which will prohibit the transportation of goods made by child labor into States which have anti-child-labor laws.

With a total of ninety-six players remaining in the two divisions following the completion of the first round of competition on Saturday, the national junior and boys' indoor tennis singles championships will continue today on the courts of the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan.
THE silver thatch of Daniel J. Ferris could barely be seen above the mass of correspondence on his desk. It looked as though Mr. Ferris had not answered a letter in at least a year.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 27. -- Nearly two months old, the shipping strike at Los Angeles harbor is costing unestimable losses not only to the shipping industry itself but to Southern California industry and agriculture.

The total volume of trade, including production, distribution and financial activity, adjusted for normal long-term growth and seasonal variations, has risen to about 25 per cent below the estimated normal level from the low point of 46 per cent below normal in March, 1933, according to the monthly business survey of the National Industrial Conference Board.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Dec. 27. -Bill Dodge of Mystic, Conn., brought out his Class X boat Moth Ball today in the dinghy regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club and rolled up a top score in that division of 131 points, to 125 for Harry Hall in the boat Wow.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP). -- The seizure of 10-year-old Charles Mattson by a masked man at Tacoma, Wash., tonight threatened to blemish the country's record of no major kidnappings in 1936.

TACOMA, Dec. 27. -- A masked kidnapper, armed with a gun, seized Charles Mattson, 10, on a sunporch at the home of his parents, Dr. and Mrs. W.W. Mattson, here tonight, threw an $18,000 ransom note on the floor and escaped with the boy in his arms. The kidnapping was at about 8:45.

Something like a capacity audience was waiting last evening at the Guild Theatre for Ruth Draper, whose habit it is to drop in at about this time of year with her character sketches. Like her other visits in recent years, this will be a limited one -- four programs -- and once more her material is not new.

A short but significant item of news may have escaped the attention of some of our readers. It reported the action of the German General Staff in sending a warning to HITLER. The effect of it was that the Dictator must not make any move which would involve Germany in a general European war, because the German Army was not yet ready for such a trial at arms.

Again from Washington comes the positive assurance that the President intends to urge Congress to grant him the power to reorganize Government Departments. The need for such a reform has long been crying. It is intensified by the great additions to the unclassified service made under the New Deal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- With all major industries contributing to the recovery movement, the indicated national income of at least $60,000,000,000 for the 1936 calendar year will probably equal income paid out for the first time since 1929, which would suggest that business as a whole was at last "out of the red," Secretary Roper declared today in his annual report to Congress.

HIGH POINT, N.J., Dec. 27. -Another of the many Winter sports centers that are cropping up about New York City was officially opened to inspection today as invited guests, headed by Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey, paid a visit to the picturesque High Point State Park near Port Jervis, N.Y.

BERLIN, Dec. 26. -- Conjectures as to how the importing of necessary cereals will be financed dominated this week's business sentiment here and caused a fresh decline in foreign-currency securities, the yield from which was used to push up domestic stocks.

LONDON, Dec. 27. -- In the face of an admittedly threatening international situation, the British Government refused to let itself be flustered or frightened today as it studied the latest events in Spain and their possible effects on peace in Europe.

DALLAS, Dec. 27 (AP). -- A pigskin pitching duel probably will inaugurate the Cotton Bowl football wars here New Year's Day. It will be Slingin Sam Baugh of Texas Christian University against Ray (Buzz) Buivid of Marquette, two of college football's ace marksmen.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 27. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at about 65 per cent of capacity, against 83 per cent for the preceding week. The estimate was based upon actual tonnage made in the week, against capacity for five working days, the holiday being counted out, but as the majority of mills were closed for about forty-eight hours the rate was pulled down.

Trade and labor unions of the city "should generously subscribe for the World's Fair debentures where possible," Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, declared yesterday in a statement asserting the exposition should create a "lively demand" for skilled and unskilled labor.

Considered as a whole, 1936 has been the most encouraging year to business since the advent of the depression and it closes with the general prospect more favorable than it has been at the end of any recent year, the Guaranty Trust Company declares in a review of the year and of the outlook for 1937, in the current issue of The Guaranty Survey, published today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec.27. -Hollywood's southern cycle will continue with two more productions with locales below Mason and Dixon's line. The chief of these, on the MGM schedule, will be McKinley Kantor's "Arouse and Beware," dealing with the flight northward of refugees during the war between the States.

PARIS, Dec. 26. -- No real tightness exists in the French money market on the eve of the year end. The discount rate in the open market still is at 2 to 2 1/2 per cent while the cost of day-to-day money has slackened from 1 3/4 to 1 1/4 per cent.

Tonight's entry, at 8:30 o'clock at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre, is Martin Flavin's "Around the Corner" -- and the billing says further: "An American play for the American people." It has also been known as "Sunday" and "Good Old Summer Time." Lodewick Vroom presents it, with these players: Charles Coburn, Dodson, Mitchell, Cyrus W. Kendall, Lillian Emerson, Boyd Crawford, Milburn Stone, Merle Maddern, Zamah Cunningham, Frank Tweddell and Edwin Cushman, Bertram Harrison directed.

The Golden Rule Foundation, with headquarters at 60 East Forty-second Street, opened a campaign yesterday to have the American public increase its church and philanthropic contributions nearly 800 per cent. Two cents on a dollar of income has been the average donation for twenty years, said Charles V. Vickrey, president of the foundation.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27. -- Charles F. Salkeld, a track star at Susquehanna University, slashed his wrists as he sat in his automobile outside Methodist Episcopal Hospital here today. Then, with pen and ink, he began to record his impressions of approaching death and to write notes to relatives and friends.

BURBANK, Calif., Dec. 27. -- A United Airlines plane was more than three hours overdue and unreported late tonight with twelve persons aboard, nine passengers and a crew of three, one of the passengers identified as the son of the Grace Steamship Line president.

I-Ioliday influences were plainly evident in the foreign exchange market last week. Business was at a minimum throughout and on Saturday, for instance, while the foreign markets were enjoying an added post-Christmas holiday, trading here was brought to a standstill and quotations we,'e purely nominal in character.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 27. -A new, highly improved model of a solar steam engine, which eliminates most of the serious defects of the earlier models and brings closer the era when man will be able to harness the vast energy of the sun to do his work, was shown here today for the first time.

PARIS, Dec. 27. -- During a special Sunday sitting to consider the much disputed compulsory labor arbitration bill, the Senate today for the fourth time changed the sense and general purport of the text. It will go back to the Chamber of Deputies Tuesday.
BOMBAY, Dec. 27. -- An appeal against "British imperialism" was sounded today by Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, president of the Indian National Congress, in an address open-
BOMBAY, Dec. 27. -- An appeal against "British imperialism" was sounded today by Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, president of the Indian National Congress, in an address open-

Orlando Barera, a young Italian violinist who made his initial appearance in this country last Spring, gave his second local recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Mr. Barera, a native of Ferrara, received his chief training at the conservatory of Bologna, where he was taught by his father, a professor.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 27. -Union negotiators stood by tonight, avowedly ready to continue maritime peace discussions with the ship owners, but employer spokesmen said they probably would not be able to muster their representatives before tomorrow.

WILLIAM GREEN, president of the American Federation of Labor, does well to take satisfaction in the great gains of labor in the past year, particularly as regards the growth of "collective bargaining." His objective of a still higher standard of living for the workers is one that every well-disposed person must share.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27. -- Banding themselves into the Tenants League. residents ordered to move from condemned houses in the slum districts began gathering signatures today to petitions calling for the razing of "blighted areas" and the setting up of a municipal housing authority to provide low-cost homes.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 27. -- The Rev. John Outwater, 31, a Roman Catholic priest who taught educational subjects at Seton Hall College, South Orange, N.J., was killed today and four relatives were seriously injured in an automobile accident.

It is my belief that the recent vote was an approval of the intentions of the Roosevelt administration, which are fairly well understood, but that the average voter has neither studied nor understood many of the laws enacted for the purpose of carrying out those intentions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- A substantial increase in new agricultural financing and greater importance of cooperative credit institutions during the coming year were predicted by Governor William I. Myers of the Farm Credit Administration today in his annual report to President Roosevelt.

ALBANY, Dec. 27. -- Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, today made public a report which showed a total of 16,956 private industry placements made by the New York State Employment Service during the month of November. Total placements in all fields for the month numbered 28,000.

MENA, Ark., Dec. 27 (AP). -- Commonwealth Labor College, charging an attempt to incite citizens against it, today asked a Federal investigation into "both Commonwealth and reactionary activities in the county and State."

Long Island University continued to run roughshod over its opponents during a comparatively slow week in intercollegiate basketball circles and boosted its winning streak to forty-three in succession. The Blackbirds played three games and were victorious in all.

Professor FRANZ BOAS of Columbia University, in the current number of Science, on the effects of American environment on immigrants and their descendants, reaches the conclusion from various approaches to the problem that "no race can be treated as a unit," but that in every case the individual "must be evaluated according to his own characteristics."

A 20 per cent increase in the number of passengers carried across the Atlantic on the ships of the Hamburg-American Line-North German Lloyd was achieved in 1936, John Schroeder, managing director of the lines, reported yesterday.
In the early part of last week cotton prices declined, but they subsequently recovered, and net gains for the week on the New York Cotton Exchange were 18 to 32 points.

HAVANA, Dec. 27. -- The Villanova football squad arrived this morning aboard planes from Miami to play Auburn on New Year's Day in the major event of the Cuban sports festival week which got under way yesterday.
Aided by the prevailing mild temperature, which reached a record high of 59 degrees for the date, holiday travel to and from the city continued to tax transportation facilities to capacity yesterday.

Swampland in Northern Palestine, adjacent to the Syrian border in the vicinity of Lake Huleh, will be reclaimed and developed for agricultural uses for the benefit of Jews and Arabs beginning in 1937, it was made known yesterday. When the marshy land is drained and connected with neighboring ground it will create an area of 14,000 acres on which 2,500 homesteads may be established.

Two Yale entrants, Hugh Auchincloss Jr. and Buell Hollister, led the way into the quarter-finals of the second annual invitation intercollegiate squash racquets tournament at the University Club by capturing their second-round engagements yesterday.

The Cathedral of St. John the Divine observed yesterday the day of St. John the Evangelist, its patron saint, and under the formal auspices of the Feast of the Dedication of the cathedral celebrated the holy day at the service at 11 A.M., and at the annual Christmas carol service at 4 P.M.
VATICAN CITY, Dec. 27. -- Pope Pius XI suffered intense and increased pain today, his fourth Sunday in bed since he was stricken with paralysis of the legs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- The external trade of the Philippine Islands declined 7 per cent in 1935, compared with 1934, but the balance of trade remained favorable to the Philippines, the chief of the Bureau of Insular Affairs said in a report to the Secretary of War, made public today.

The appointment of Byron Price as "the executive news editor of The Associated Press," with headquarters in New York City, was announced yesterday by Kent Cooper, general manager. In this newly created post Mr. Price, head of the Washington bureau since 1927, will be responsible only to the general manager for the general news service.

CHICAGO. Dec. 28. -- The airlines of the United States have just completed the best twelve months of their history from the standpoint of safety, Colonel Edgar S. Gorrell, president of the Air Transport Association of America, declared in a statement issued here today.
Lester Patrick's New York Rangers and Mervyn (Red) Dutton's New York Americans will furnish the action tonight on the Madison Square Garden ice in the third game of their city series.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 28. -- Hundreds of thrill seekers and would-be rescuers who started out for the scene of the United airliner wreck northwest of Burbank were themselves trapped in the hills by storm and darkness tonight and were the objects of intensive search by Sheriff's deputies.

Figures compiled by the office of First Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler yesterday showed a decline in automobile deaths for last week as compared with the corresponding period of 1935. For the week-end the deaths remained at three.

Sverre Kolterud, Norwegian star, gave the first of a two-day series of skiing exhibitions on the eighty-foot borax-covered slide at Wanamaker's picturesque Winter Villege yesterday. Kolterud, who took part in the recent carnival at Madison Square Garden, thrilled a large crowd both in the morning and afternoon with interesting programs which lasted thirty minutes.

ROME, Dec. 28. -- Countess Edda Ciano, daughter of Premier Mussolini and wife of the Italian Foreign Minister, has suddenly postponed her trip to the United States. Cabins aboard the Conte di Savoia for her and for Marquis Leonardo Vitetti and his wife, who were to accompany her, had been reserved for the trip next month.

Officials of Chicago announced yesterday that the amount of the judgment funding bond issue, bids for which will be received on Jan. 5, has been reduced from $12,349,000, as originally announced, to $11,000,000. The bonds will be dated Dec. 1, 1936, and mature on Jan. 1, 1956, and will carry a fixed rate of interest of 3 per cent.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 28. -- The good fortune pursuing this Adirondack Winter sports center this season deserted it for the time being today, as a scarcity of snow prevented the opening of the Lake Placid Club Snowbirds' annual college week ski tournament.

The coupon B-17 from the 6 per cent income bonds of the Compania Hispano-Americana de Electricidad, S.A., will be paid on and after Jan. 2, 1937, in banks abroad and in New York at the coupon department of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

When business was resumed on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, the upward movement in prices which was under way last week was continued and the list showed gains of nearly $1 a bale at one time. The advance above 12 1/2 cents a pound for the near months and over 12 cents for the distant positions attracted profit-taking, leaving final quotations 10 to 15 points higher.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Dec. 28. -- Miss Helen Bernhard of New York and Miss Hope Knowles of Philadelphia, seeded first and second, advanced to the quarter-finals of the girls' national indoor tennis tournament with easy victories at the Longwood covered courts today.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Dec. 28. -- The death of the Finnish Fascist leader Vistori Kosola which occurred on his homestead at Lapua Village -- where the notorious anti-Communist Lapua movement originated in 1930 with Kosola as the figurehead -- is wrapped in mystery and has given rise to rumors that he was poisoned.

The Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday became the college sport center of the country as delegates and officials of the National Collegiate Athletic Association and football and track coaches gathered for the meetings and conventions which are to feature the next few days.

NEW ORLEANS, Dee. 28 (AP) -- Holiday visitors gathering for the New Year's Day Sugar Bowl football game between Louisiana State University and Santa Clara witnessed some spectacular tennis in the opening round of the midwinter festival tournament today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28. -- Grain prices were on the upgrade in the early trading today on the Board of Trade, with wheat, corn, oats and rye selling at new high levels for the season. The advance, however, was not maintained, due to heavy profit-taking and the uncertainty created by the closing out of December contracts.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 28. -- A "sit-down" strike today by members of the United Automobile Workers' Union halted all operations in the Cleveland plant of the Fisher Body Company, a General Motors subsidiary. About 7,000 employees are affected.

DANZIG, Dec. 28. -- Fifty-nine members of the National Socialist party, including several party officials and commanders of motorized units of the Storm Troops, were arrested by the secret police Friday and Saturday on charges of conspiring with opposition parties and with Polish authorities.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- A design for mounting the motor of an automobile at the rear end instead of at the front of the car has been patented by Henry Ford, it became known today.

MONTREAL, Dec. 28 (AP). -- Although he failed to score a goal, Dave (Sweeney) Schriner of the New York Americans regained the National Hockey League scoring leadership during the past week, according to official statistics released today.

Under the handicap of a badly swollen left eye, Gino Salvatore, Chicago lightweight, waged a spectacular but losing battle against Carl (Red) Guggino of Florida last night in the feature bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace.

Aside from moderate buying enthusiasm for a few groups of stocks which lasted most of the day, the share market failed yesterday to maintain its early firmness and drifted downward. The closing was generally lower, many leading issues losing from fractions to two points; a few, more than that.

MIAMI, Dec. 28 (AP). -- Officials of the All-American air manoeuvres announced today the winners of The Detroit News trophies for which stock planes competed at the recent aviation meet here. The announcement was delayed because the winners had to be calculated by National Aeronautical Association executives at Washington.

LONDON, Dec. 28. -- The stock market reopened quietly today, but prices in most groups were firm. British Government issues were dull, however, possibly because of the usual year-end pressure for money. Iron and steel stocks, motors, textiles and breweries generally were strong.

Dave Levin of Jamaica, a former claimant to the world's heavyweight wrestling championship, threw Maurice La Chappelle of France last night in the feature bout of the weekly wrestling show at the New York Hippodrome.
A technical official of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company last night described the cause of the power failure in Newark as follows:

With an entry that assures first-class competition in all divisions, the two-day horse show of the Riding and Polo Club will open tonight at 7:30 o'clock in the ring of that organization at 7 West Sixty-sixth Street, an arena that has been the scene of many notable equine events over a long period.

NANKING, Tuesday, Dec. 29. -- The physical condition of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek is causing some concern. Since his return from imprisonment at Sian medical attention has been required daily. He has been unable to attempt hard work and a period of rest is necessary so he can regain his vitality.

All the seeded players had gained places in the quarter-final bracket of the second annual invitation intercollegiate squash racquets tournament at the University Club yesterday when three of the favored entrants won their second round tests.
Plans and preliminary studies for additional improvements In city and State parks in and near the Bronx were announced yesterday by Park Commissioner Robert Moses.
Savings banks figured in several real estate transactions reported yesterday involving holdings in Manhattan and the Bronx. Activity in the Washington Heights section continued to attract attention.
Mr. and Mrs. John F. Russell Jr. gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Janet Russell.

While the top seeded players in the junior division and all the seeded entrants in the boys' division progressed with ease into the third round of the national indoor tennis championships at the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday, some of the lower-listed juniors found trouble enough in maintaining their ranking.

City Court Justice John Byrnes was sworn in yesterday by Surrogate James A. Foley in the Hall of Records in the presence of his family, relatives and friends and a delegation from the Anawanda Democratic Club, of which both he and Surrogate Foley as members.

In 1911 Europe was startled by Kaiser Wilhelm's "panther-spring to Agadir." France wanted to annex Morocco, and England, having annexed the Sudan, joined France. There was an immediate danger of war. The British fleet was concentrated in the North Sea, and the whole world breathlessly followed the collision of the great powers.

Mournful thoughts vibrated in the thought-boudoir of The Emporia Gazette as Christmas was coming. Kansas has all the virtues. Her climate is better than that of any of her neighbors. Her paths drop fatness. She has what AGUR the son of JAKEH asked for -- neither poverty nor riches. Property is more evenly divided than in any other State:

Word that "Old Fish," the fish peddler, had left more than $83,000 in cash and mortgages when he died of pneumonia in Cumberland Hospital on Christmas Eve set housewives' tongues wagging yesterday in the Navy Yard district of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Resolutions urging the British Royal Commission now investigating conditions in Palestine to make recommendations that will "facilitate constructive building for all sections of the population" were adopted at the concluding session here today of the annual convention of Junior Hadassah, the young women's Zionist organization of America.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Vincent Dailey resigned today as New York State manager of the Home Owners Loan Corporation, a position he has held since July 20, 1933. Mr. Dailey submitted his resignation to Charles A. Jones and left later for New York.

ROME, Tuesday, Dec. 29 (AP). -- The Italian Government today modified its sweeping legislation against foreign motion pictures which film men asserted had threatened to block further imports of American pictures.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP). -- Justice Department agents threw all of their energies tonight into an effort to capture the kidnapper of Charles Mattson and maintain their record of solving such crimes.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 28. -- The State Public Utility Commission announced tonight that it would require the Public Service Electric and Gas Company to furnish auxiliary service hereafter to prevent a repetition of tonight's power failure.

The American Academy of Arts and Letters and the National Institute of Arts and Letters will initiate series of Wednesday evening concerts and lectures at the Academy Auditorium, 632 West 156th Street. on Jan. 6. when John Erskine is to be the speaker.

BERLIN, Dec. 28. -- The nearest thing to concrete information as to Germany's immediate plans in the question of Spanish volunteers was obtained here today when a generally unquestionable source revealed that 2,000 men had been recruited in the Munich district for Spanish service.

A sharp controversy over the best means of stimulating growth artificially in animals enlivened the seventeenth annual meeting of the Association for Research into Nervous and Mental Disease at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday. The meeting was devoted to the discussion of the pituitary gland.
One hundred and thirty-three persons gave $1,793.75 to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday, increasing the year's total to $240,736.76, an amount still short of last year's final figures.

The opera last night at the Metropolitan Opera House was "Rigoletto" and a large and fashionable audience attended to the matter. The cast had items of special interest, with Miss Bovy, the new Belgian soprano, substituting at short notice for another Metropolitan debutante who had suddenly been taken ill, as Gilda.

New York City is ready for its gayest and most lavish New Year's celebration in years. Hotels are beginning to report reservations for New Year's Eve sold out. All lines of transportation are handling the heaviest incoming traffic since before the depression.

" Black Limelight" will call it a run next Saturday night at the Mansfield, where it will have spent an even eight weeks. Its producers, the Messrs. Bushar and Tuerk, have just one show on their schedule -- "Marching as to War" -- but no definite plans for it. . .

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 28 (AP). -- Pasadena got its first real taste of the approaching Rose Bowl football classic today as the Washington Huskies staged their initial practice on local soil for the struggle with Pittsburgh New Year's Day.

Labor's buying power has been increased at least $12,000,000,000 by the general economic recovery and, as a result, the coming year is bound to bring a period of "tremendous prosperity," Gerald E. Stedman of Milwaukee, vice president and director of market planning for the Cramer-Krasselt Company, advertising agency, told members of the Sales Executives Club of New York, Inc., at its regular luncheon meeting in the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday.

" A scientist must be a good Fascist "before he is a good theoretical physi- "cist or biologist," thundered MUSSOLINI some years ago. HITLER echoes the principle and gives it a cruel racial twist. Now come the Russians with the pronouncement that, whatever genetics may say, all men and races are equal because MARX would have it so.

HAVANA, Dec. 28. -- Columbia University's basketball team defeated the Vedado Tennis Club quintet, 45 to 30, tonight in the feature of a double-header on the Vedado Club court. The games were on the program of the sports week festival.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 28. -- E.W. Butterfield, Education Commissioner for Connecticut, told teachers gathered for a meeting of five State educational organizations tonight that vocational agriculture should be taught in all city schools to provide pupils with a "rounded" training.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP). -- The United Mine Workers were said in well-informed quarters tonight to be willing to let the soft-coal industry write the marketing provisions of a new Guffey control bill.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- For the first time in its history, the Interstate Commerce Commission authorized today a carrier subject to its jurisdiction to issue preferred stock for the purpose of paying an extra dividend. It approved plans of the Greyhound Corporation to issue $1,950,900 of 5 1/2 per cent preference stock to pay dividends of 75 cents a share to holders of common stock.

Asserting that this country has evolved a "popular brand" of higher education not duplicated by any other country in the world, Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University, opened the twelfth annual conference of the National Student Federation of America yesterday at the Hotel Victoria, Fifty-first Street and Seventh Avenue.

Judge Jonah J. Goldstein, whose appointment to the General Sessions bench last Spring by Governor Lehman expires on Thursday, discharged the jury panel in his part of the court yesterday with the observation that "you can't please everybody in this court, because you can't play Santa Claus to defendants and at the same time protect the community at large."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Disclosure of the volume of "sterilized" or inactive gold will be made by the Treasury for the first time tomorrow in the Daily Statement for Dec. 24, Secretary Morgenthau announced today.
With 88.1 per cent of the 1936 real estate tax levy already collected. Controller Frank J. Taylor predicted yesterday that the year's collections would be better than in any year since 1927.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Dec. 28. -- Lieutenant Colonel Robert G. Sherrard of West Hartford, Conn., was killed instantly when an automobile in which he was riding was in collision with a truck that was just coming onto the main highway, two miles from here in Pennsylvania today.

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 28. -- President Lazaro Cardenas declared Mexico's public education program would be speeded as he presented Mexico's record budget of 330,993,000 pesos to the Chamber of Deputies today.

SEATTLE, Dec. 28 (AP). -- A navy blue hat pulled low above her tearstained face, Virginia Chatfield, 16, Seattle high school girl, came home by bus today from Tacoma, where she was a terrified witness of the abduction of Charles Mattson. She was a house guest of the Mattson children.
Respiratory diseases increased considerably during the last three days in New York City, but have not reached epidemic proportions, Health Department officials said yesterday.
Six boys, 11 to 15 years old, enjoyed a fifty-minute boat trip down the Hudson River yesterday, even though a police launch was needed finally to set them safely ashore.
Cash dividends declared yesterday totaled $5,000,000, lifting the total declared thus far in December to $431,000,000. Since Nov. 1, cash dividend declarations have amounted to $1,314,200,000.

Defeating Columbia by 2 1/2 -- 1 1/2 and gaining two additional points in games postponed from an earlier match with Cornell, New York University clinched the championship of the Intercollegiate Chess League at the Manhattan Club yesterday.

More than 70,000 persons in homes, factories and other places of business as well as Police and Fire Departments were affected by the Newark power tieup yesterday afternoon and night in the western area of Hudson County, N.J.

One of the first acts of the new Congress should be to repeal a tax which is so unjust and pointless that it is difficult to believe that it exists at all except as the result of an oversight. This tax will be payable for the first time on Jan. 31 next. Prompt action on the part of Congress would make its payment needless.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 28. -- The remarkable good fortune of Mrs. Emil Denemark with her powerful string of horses continued at Tropical Park today. The Chicago sportswoman was represented in the Ibis Purse, five and a half furlong feature for all ages, by the brown 3-year-old Blind Pig, an $11.80-for-$2 shot that Charlie Kurtsinger guided home first by two lengths in the fast time of 1:05 2-5.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- President Roosevelt spent a busy day in his office conferring with various advisers and officials on a number of subjects.

DETROIT, Dec. 28. -- Although a patent was granted today to Henry Ford for an automobile radically different from the current types, no officer or engineer at the Ford Motor Company would comment on the Washington dispatch.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Man is a newcomer to the North American Continent, according to Herbert J. Spinden, retiring president of the American Anthropological Association. Mr. Spinden told an audience of anthropologists meeting here today in annual convention that the first Indian crossed from Asia into North America no earlier than 2500 B.C. He pronounced "legally dead" theories that human beings reached America ten to fifteen thousands years ago.

HAVANA, Dec. 28. -- The House of Representatives this afternoon overrode the veto of former President Miguel Mariano Gomez on a bill to tax sugar 9 cents a bag to provide funds for army-controlled rural schools. The vote was 115 to 13. The measure will now become law immediately on its publication in the official gazette.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- The State Department announced today that the conference to be held here next Spring with President Manuel L. Quezon of the Philippine Commonwealth would carefully consider the economic and other needs of the Philippines and prepare a constructive program for reference to the two governments.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dee. 28. -- At Amado, Charles A. Munn gave a luncheon today for Lady Isobel Guinness and Loel Guinness, Mr. and Mrs. Harold W. Brooks, Mrs. M. Dorland Doyle, the Misses Frances and Mary Munn, Morris Legendre, George Kamir, George F. Baker Jr., Noel Munn and Charles Munn Jr.

The President and his advisers are now at work on a budget for the new Congress which will meet next week, and in preparing it they will have to consider not only its contents but the form that it will take. Hitherto the Administration has followed the practice (which it introduced soon after it took office) of reporting proposed expenditures under two different heads: "general" and "recovery and relief."

When darkness enveloped the Newark Airport last night during the power failure four planes were nearly due on the major airlines of the country and the operations departments of the lines were forced to resort to emergency resources.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Establishment of a central press and publicity bureau through which the government would maintain contact with newspapers, magazines and the radio and disseminate "information" on the policies and acts of the executive departments is being urged by some experts as a part of President Roosevelt's plan for governmental reorganization.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Working secretly, police pushed an investigation today into reports that Olmeda Alfaro, 15-year-old son of the Ecuadorian Ambassador, had been abducted Christmas night, robbed and held captive for five hours.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 28. -- New light on the action of X-rays on living substances, which promises to have important bearing on the study of cancer, was reported here today before the opening sessions of the American Association for the Advancement of Science by Dr. Hugo Fricke and Dr. Homer P. Smith of the Biological Laboratory of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28. -- Stanford's basketball team lived up to advance notices with a smashing 45-38 triumph over Temple University in the feature game of the double-header tonight at the Philadelphia Arena. In the first fray St. Joseph's and La Salle played a nip-and-tuck affair with the verdict going to the former, 25 -- 21.

Subscriptions and commitments amounting to $7,330,990, or more than one-fourth of the projected issue of $27,829,500 of New York World's Fair debentures, have been received, it was announced yesterday at a meeting of the fair's bond sales committee at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway, to receive the first report on sales of the bonds.

Japanese Fan Co.. store In 225 5th Av.; through Crt)ss Brown Co.; Paul Gorsteln. furriers' supplies, store in 320 7th Av.; Jacob Vinograd Fur Corp,, store in 128-34 V. 30th St.; 5ietropolitan Electrical Distributors, Inc.. 22.500 feet in 568 Broadway; Adams Co., Inc., broker.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP). -- Wide swings in the price of wheat in the next few months were forecast today by government grain experts as prices for the grain reached a seven-year peak in Chicago and then dropped 6 cents a bushel.

BERLIN, Dec. 28 (AP). -- German Fundamentalist ministers have become alarmed over the plans of Dr. Robert Ley, leader for the political organization of Nazidom, to become the "seelsorger" -- literally "soul caretaker" -- of the German people, as reported in the Berliner Tageblatt. The title heretofore has been reserved to clergymen.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 28. -- A new weight for the electron, the lightest particle in the material universe, recently determined by "atom-scales" fashioned largely of beams of light, was revealed here tonight. The announcement was made at the opening general session of the annual Winter meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science before a large gathering that included scores of America's most eminent scientists.

The Japanese militarists have received two hard blows during recent weeks: the public reaction against the anti-Communist treaty with Germany for which they were responsible; and the "unconditional" release of CHIANG KAI-SHEK, which was interpreted in Tokyo as an indication that the Nanking Government has agreed to the adoption of a firmer policy against Japanese encroachments.

The College Physical Education Association, which has as members the directors and instructors in physical education and athletics at men's colleges, held its fortieth annual meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

The estate of Harry Payne Whitney, capitalist and sportsman, who died on Oct. 26, 1930, showed a net increase of $4,244,969.30 between Nov. l, 1931, and Oct, 31, 1938, when it was valued at $63,250,498.16. This became known yesterday when an accounting was filed in Surrogate's Court.

Activity in the various merchandise markets yesterday was regarded as fair, considering the time of the season. More buyers than had been expected were in town and the malls brought a fair amount of business. January sales merchandise was sought chiefly, with some Southern stores taking Spring goods.

Christmas buying went over the 1929 mark in "a crescendo of last-minute shopping." Retail business which tops 1929 deserves to be called not only crescendo but also sforzando, allegro and molto vivace, if not quite fortissimo and maestoso.

LONDON, Dec. 28. -- The Foreign Office announced today it had ordered the removal of the British Embassy in Madrid to Valencia. The reason for the move remains something of a mystery, although an elaborate official explanation was issued tonight.

HASTINGS, England, Dec. 28. -- Reuben Fine of the Marshall Chess Club of New York, who made his debut in a European international masters tournament a year ago in this city by winning the first prize, played his first game today at the annual Christmas Congress of the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club.

Police reserves were sent to the Chelsea section of the North River waterfront yesterday morning when the picketing activities of about 1,200 striking seamen threatened to develop into an open clash with longshoremen on their way to work and truck drivers en route to the piers with freight.

A fire in the heart of Newark's electric power system cut off most of the New Jersey metropolis's light and energy at 3:34 o'clock yesterday afternoon, paralyzing the city and part of its suburban area.

Cross-examination of an engineer for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, which is charged with emitting dense smoke from its power house at 600 West Fifty-ninth Street in violation of Section 211 of the Sanitary Code, brought forth the statement in the hearing in the Magistrates Court Building at 300 Mulberry Street yesterday that by an expenditure of $100,000 the smoke discharge of the plant could be cut in half.
Steve (Crusher) Casey of Ireland pinned Charles Straak of Oklahoma in the feature wrestling match at' the Seventy-first Regiment Armory in Manhattan last night before 4,000 spectators.

Arthur Brisbane, newspaper editor and columnist, was buried yesterday in the family plot on his estate at Allaire, N.J., after a simple but impressive funeral service had been held for him at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street.

Electrical Research Products, Inc., has an investment of $2,000,000 in motion-picture production, according to testimony presented yesterday by Whitford Drake, executive vice president of the corporation, at a hearing before the Federal Communications Commission at 45 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- The fight of the "rank and file" con tingent or the International Seamen's Union against the continuous discharge book directed to be issued to seamen under the Ship Subsidy Act was carried directly to the White House today by a four-man committee representing seamen of the government-owned and operated steamship Cristobal.

VATICAN CITY, Dec. 28. -- Despite reassuring statements that continue to be put out by the Vatican about the Pope's health, the fact must be faced that he is very seriously ill. It is as yet an exaggeration to say, as some persons have done during the last few days, that he is at death's door.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- President Roosevelt will read his annual message to Congress at a joint session of the House and the Senate at 2 P.M. on Jan. 6, a few minutes after the Electoral College has canvassed the vote cast on Nov. 4 and declared him and Vice President Garner re-elected.

WASHINGTON Dec. 28. -- With the introduction of new models, foreign demand for American passenger cars resumed its upward trend in October and thus increased the total value of exports of automotive products for that month to $16,556,320, an increase of $3,260,620 from September and the largest volume for October of any year since 1929, the Department of Commerce reported today.

TACOMA, Wash., Dec. 28. -- A maniac was hunted throughout the Pacific Northwest tonight by police and Department of Justice agents as the man who last night kidnapped 10-year-old Charles Mattson, son of Dr. William W. Mattson, a wealthy Tacoma physician, and left a note demanding $28,000 ransom.

Brooklyn took the lead in prospective building operations for which plans were filed yesterday. The Department of Buildings in that borough reported a $500,000 improvement projected for the Beth-El Hospital property on Avenue A, and a new apartment house for East Eighteenth Street to cost $165,000.

CALDER, Idaho, Dec. 28 (AP). -- The bodies of Pilots Joe Livermore and Arthur Haid, killed in a mail plane crash in the Idaho Mountains ten days ago, were brought here tonight with seven pouches of salvaged mail.

Warrants to subscribe for additional capital stock of Sears, Roebuck Co. were mailed last night to stockholders with a prospectus covering an offering of 613,655 shares, of which about 488,655 are available to the stockholders at $72 a share in the ratio of one new share for each ten shares held.

BURBANK, Calif., Dec. 28. -- Crushed in the wreckage of a giant airliner, nine passengers and a crew of three were found late today in a brush-tangled ravine about twenty miles northwest of here. The plane disappeared last night while on a trip from San Francisco to Burbank.
Twelve properties, including several apartment houses, were sold at auction yesterday in Manhattan. In each case the property was bid in by the plaintiff. The list follows:

Mass production of "heavy oxygen," a goal for which research pioneers have been striving since the discovery of heavy hydrogen, has at last been achieved in the laboratories of Columbia University, Dr. Harold C. Urey, winner of the Nobel Prize in Chemistry, announced yesterday.

My attention has been called to the letter from Mr. Skevington and, while fully endorsing the well-deserved tributes he paid to the Duke of Windsor. I am constrained to contradict many of the statements made in his communication and to feel that they are likely to divert your readers' attention from the main issues revolved.

Again, as a year ago, the conduct of the American football public was assailed yesterday at the McAlpin Hotel as the Sportsmanship Brotherhood convened for its eleventh annual luncheon and meeting. Some 200 guests, who came to toast Dean Frank W. Nicolson of Wesleyan University, the honored secretary of the N.C.A.A., received an earful of complaints against the self-appointed alumni, who each week turn out in thousands at the most convenient stadia.

Few details are as yet known of the new agreement which France and Great Britain are trying to make with Italy and Germany. There is little doubt that its chief aim is to pledge all four nations to absolute abstention from meddling of any kind in Spain. This is regarded as the surest way to prevent the Spanish conflict from embroiling the whole of Europe.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Expressing a belief that "mass production and mass consumption of electricity" now being experimented with in the Mid-South may "open a new economic era," the Tennessee Valley Authority declared today that its development and sale of power had, by lowering rates in that area, broadened the market and increased business for private power companies.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28. -- Prices of hogs advanced 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight early today to the highest level since Sept. 17 and for a December in ten years. Part of this upturn was lost later when some local packers refused to follow the advance.

The National Power and Light Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on Nov. 30 a consolidated net income of $7,118,456, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1 a share on 5,456,117 profit common shares, compared with $6,001,619, or 79 cents a common share, in the preceding twelve months.

ONE-EYED CONNOLLY and the late Tammany Young, gate-crashers extraordinary, picked the wrong country in which to perform their operations. The United States is no place to indulge that nefarious art Germany is a gate-crasher's paradise. All one needs is a good front and sufficient command of the English language -- especially the latter.

Salvador de Madariaga, former Spanish Ambassador to the United States and shortly before the outbreak of the civil war, Spanish representative at the League of Nations, arrived last night from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 28. -- A few hours after application was made today for permission to incorporate the Pennsylvania Gas Transmission Company to supply natural gas to consumers in nine eastern counties of Pennsylvania Governor George H. Earle instructed the State Public Service Commission to "grant no more certificates of public convenience for the extension of natural gas lines pending a report of a committee investigating conditions in the anthracite goal regions."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Three hundred experts met today in a conference aimed at fighting the inroads of venereal diseases on the health of citizens.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Because Congress failed to include "civil wars" in the provisions of the Neutrality Act, passed in the closing days of the last session, the State Department had no alternative today but to issue a license for the shipment of airplanes, airplane engines and parts, valued at $2,777,000 to Spain.

Marion Telva, who was described in the program as a mezzo-contralto, gave her first New York recital at the Town Hall last night. She is, of course, familiar to patrons of the Metropolitan Opera House, where she has been a valued member of the company for more than a decade, not counting the recent absence of several years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- All ranks of official, diplomatic and resident society were represented in the large audience which attended this morning the opening concert given this season by Mrs. Lawrence Townsend at the Mayflower Hotel.

ALBANY, Dec. 28. -- The appointment of regional representatives of the Municipal Training Institute, sponsored by officers of the State Conference of Mayors and chartered by the regents, was announced today by Mayor Charles Stanton of Rochester, president of the institute and the Mayors Conference.

Milton Speiser, 54 years old, of 300 Central Park West, senior member of the law firm of Speiser Speiser at 29 Broadway, which is said to have the largest practice in negligence cases in the country, went on trial yesterday before Special Sessions Justices Kernochan, Bayes and Salomon.

ROME, Dec. 28. -- An exchange of assurances on the Mediterranean between Italy and Great Britain is expected to follow tomorrow's British Cabinet meeting, at which the main lines of the declarations the governments will make to each other will almost certainly be approved.

English companies which reinsured parts of cargoes and vessels insured by United States companies are not entitled to recover their fractional share of losses from payments made to domestic companies by a ruling of the Reparation Commission, Federal Judge John C. Knox decided yesterday.
VATICAN CITY, Dec. 28. -- Pope Pius, at last aware that he is gravely ill, was reported reliably to have told a prelate today:

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 28. -- The American Association of University Professors heard a report today by Dean M.M. Willey of the University of Minnesota on the "Effect of the Depression and Recovery on Higher Education." He declared that professors should organize for their economic welfare.

Determined to be in good shape for its game with N.Y.U.'s unbeaten basketball team tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden, Georgetown arrived in New York yesterday and promptly went to the Violet gymnasium for a short workout.

The compensation of principal executives of seven companies whose issues are listed on the New York Stock Exchange was disclosed yesterday in their reports for the last fiscal year to the Securities and Exchange Commission. They were as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Construction work with a total valuation of $1,622,862,000 was performed in 1935 by 75,047 contracting firms supplying data on their operations for the first report of the Census of Construction, made public today by William L. Austin, director of the Bureau of the Census, as part of the current Census of Business.
The first of the Colony Dances, a: ieries of subscription parties for fui ture dbutantes, was held last night in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton.

After squiring two ominously symbolic plays. Martin Flavin has squned a simple tale of the Middle West. "Around the Corner," which was acted at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre last evening. It is described in the program as "An American play for the American people."
MADRID, Dec. 28. -- Government troops claimed the capture today of strategic positions on opposite sides of the capital.

Three steamships are due to sail today on New Year holiday cruises to the West Indies, the North German Lloyd liner Europa with 1,200, the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria with 1,100 and the Canadian Pacific liner Empress of Britain with 400.

Armour Co. of Illinois and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended on Oct. 31 a net profit of $10,239,461 after taxes and other charges and including a profit of $54,969 from the retirement of its bonds. After dividend requirements on the preferred stocks of the parent company and Armour Co. of Delaware, the profit was equivalent to 76 cents a share on the 4,065,940 shares of common stock outstanding.

MADRID, Dec. 28 (Passed by the Censor). -- All British subjects remaining in Madrid were called to the embassy at 1 o'clock this afternoon and advised by Charge d'Affaires G.A.D. Ogilvie Forbes that orders had been received from the London.

The possibility of an eleventh-hour postponement of the competitive civil service examinations for social investigator jobs in the Emergency Relief Bureau was revived yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman signed an order requiring the Municipal Civil Service Commission to show cause at 10 A.M. today why a postponement should not be granted.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Dec. 23 shows an increase for the week of $66,000,000 in total loans and investments, decreases of $51,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, $113,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks, $112,000,000 in balances with domestic banks and $146,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve banks and an increase of $26,000,000 in borrowings.

Charles Herbert, business agent for Local 370 of the Schoctim Union, who has frequently been denounced as a racketeer in the kosher poultry industry, was sentenced yesterday to ninety days in the workhouse by Magistrate Myles A. Paige in the Jefferson Market Court.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 28. --Besides casting its usual shimmering glow on the Passaic River here tonight, the moon was the brightest thing in a town where candles were temporarily more valuable than pearls and empty elevators hung rigid in their shafts.

RYE, N.Y., Dec. 28. -- Scoring unassisted midway in the final period, Jake Stone led Colgate to a 2-1 victory over Cornell tonight in a thrilling hockey game at the Playland rink. Stone picked up a loose puck in mid-ice, skated around the Cornell defense and slipped the disk past Al Bosson for the goal that decided a game opening a week of collegiate hockey here.

Controller Frank J. Taylor has allowed District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn $45,230 on his total bill of $50,680 for the expense of Mr. Geoghan's defense of the Drukman grand jury's removal charges.

Dr. John L. Rice. Health Commissioner, reported yesterday nine cases of tularemia (rabbit disease), three of them fatal, in New York during the week ended last Saturday. Attacks of tularemia. Dr. Rice said, have been traced to the skinning and dressing of rabbits for cooking.

The business of catching up with the elusive Joe Cambria and closing the supposedly already concluded deal for the purchase of the Albany International League franchise apparently was still drawing a blank yesterday so far as the New York Giants were concerned.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 28. -- A new development in logic, supplementing the work of Professor Alfred N. Whitehead of England, was offered today to the meeting of the Eastern division of the American Philosophical Association by Dr. H. S. Leonard and Dr. H.N. Goodman of Harvard.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Secretary Morgenthau announced that tenders for two series of Treasury bills aggregating about $100,000,000 to be dated Dec. 30, 1936, which were offered on Dec. 24, amounted to $258,736,000, of which $100,073,000 was accepted.

Senator Vandenberg, who by prestige and ability is the actual (though not the nominal) Republican leader in Congress, has posed the question of a new "neutrality" law with his usual clarity and force. The subject is one of the most important for the session that will open next Tuesday, and it is immediate because the temporary law will expire within few weeks.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Dec. 28. -The Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. already has collected $3,025,896 of its pledges toward the $8.000,000 benevolence budget for the current year, according to Dr. H. C. Weber of New York, canvass director of the field committee on united promotion of the denomination.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- A registration statement has been filed under the Securities Act of 1933 by the Associated General Utilities Company, Jersey City, covering $5,000,000 of income debentures due in 1961 with interest cumulative at the rate of 4 per cent, subject to certain provisions of the indenture, and 250,000 shares of no par value common capital stock.

Conflicting views on the value of current State milk control laws were set forth yesterday at a conference at the Hotel Commodore of milk control officials of four States and spokesmen for various groups seeking stabilization of the dairy industry in the States in the New York milk shed.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 28 (AP). -- Cautious Andy Kerr, who would ban the word "perfect" from the football dictionary, almost went into superlatives today over his Eastern football charges.

The problem of providing satisfactory pheasant shooting is bothering Connecticut game officials, as it is those in most of the Eastern States. The Asiatic ringneck has become our most important game bird and the State commissions are none too happy over the failure of the crop during the past season.

Miss Jane Will was introduced to society at a dinner dance given by her parents. Mr. and Mrs. Harold H. Will, last night in the Tapestry Room of the Park Lane. Hanging baskets of yellow chrysanthemums were used in the decorations. During the evening groups of ballroom dances were given by professionals.

Mr. and Mrs. Morris Cassard Jr. and Mr. and Mrs. Norman Frederick Eastman jointly gave a dinner dance last night at Sherry's to introduce to society their daughters, Miss Marie Rose Cassard and Miss Barbara Eastman.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28. -- Retirement as rapidly as possible of the Federal debt incurred in fighting the depression by the imposition of the largest possible amount of taxes consistent with the requirements of recovery was urged by Professor Simeon E. Leland, Chicago University economist, in an address before the American Economic Association at its annual meeting here today in conjunction with twelve other organizations devoted to the study of economic and social problems.
Why should the city, State or nation, separately or in combination, spend billions of dollars razing the slums and building better housing for the poor?

Trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was in somewhat heavier volume than before the extended week-end holiday although prices lacked a uniform trend and the market generally displayed a highly mixed undertone. Transactions in all bonds totaled $17,198,400, the heaviest since Dec. 17, compared to a turnover of $12,271,400 on last Thursday.
FAIZPUR, India, Dec. 28. -- A resolution emphatically rejecting the new Federal Constitution was adopted by the Indian National Congress in plenary session today. It reads:

BERLIN, Dec. 28. --The Boerse reopened after the holiday with a boom in the "blue-chip" issues, caused mainly by the purchases for blocked-mark accounts resulting from the new decree that the use of blocked marks for such purchases must cease in the new year.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Simon Schuster report that "The Songs We Sing." by Hendrik Willem van Loon and Grace Castagnetta, had an average weekly sale of 2,890 copies during the immediate pre-Christmas season; that "Wake Up and Live," by Dorothea Brande, sold 2,695, and that "Enjoyment of Laughter," by Max Eastman, sold 2,635.

MOSCOW, Dec. 28. -- The reorganization of Soviet industrial plants along American lines to remedy the costly and crippling evils of bureaucracy was demanded today as a result of a vigorous calling down given to one big Moscow factory by Gregory K. Ordjonikidze, Commissar for Heavy Industry.

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 28. -- Gordon Ordas, Leftist Spanish Ambassador to Mexico and trusted representative of the Largo Caballero government, plans to leave at noon Thursday by plane for Washington for a conference with Fernando de los Rios, Spanish Ambassador to the United States, it was learned this evening.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 28. -- Armando Salles Oliveira, Governor of the State of Sao Paulo, will resign tomorrow to be a candidate for the Presidency. Many othe State officials, especially those holding high Federal posts, are expected to resign to help Governor Salles Oliveira.

Boom conditions prevailed in a few of the commodity futures markets yesterday. The cause was trade reports of tight conditions in the cash markets for several staples, particularly rubber, where price relations appeared to confirm the reports.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 28. -- The Westchester County Board of Supervisors adopted late this afternoon the 1937 county budget as presented a week ago, with the addition of $14,300 for lighting the county parkways. The Republican majority in the board voted down an amendment offered by the Democrats calculated to make savings of more than $123,000.

BERLIN, Dec. 28. -- The resumption of business today following the Christmas holidays brought back to their desks part of the staff of the German Foreign Office, but not the personages who alone can deal with the British and French notes delivered yesterday.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 28. -- Despite the contention of friends and relatives of 7-year-old Rachel Ianniello that she was the victim of foul play, Dr. Amos O. Squire, County Medical Examiner said tonight he had been presented with no evidence warranting a change in his verdict of accidental death.

There is a feeling amounting almost to a conviction among leaders in Tammany Hall that James J. Dooling, who for months has been confined by serious illness to his home, 460 West Forty-third Street, will not have recovered sufficiently to resume his leadership of the Tammany organization in time for next year's important Mayoralty campaign.

WRITING in his World-Telegram column yesterday Harry Hansen said: "I can't get up any steam for the common run of mystery stories. I sometimes wonder how the regular fans put up with some of the thin yarns that reach this desk."

A return to near-freezing weather that occurred during the night was expected to continue today after four days of Spring-like temperatures in which the mercury rose again yesterday to a record high for the date.

Since today is the last day on which sales of stocks can be made in the usual way to be completed this year under the third-day delivery plan of the Stock Exchange and the Curb Exchange, it is expected that the annual year-end flow of cash sales will begin tomorrow.
PEIPING, Dec. 28. -- Almost 100,000 narcotics addicts in Peiping were subject to possible death tonight because Korean dealers refuse to stop selling to them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- A net railway operating income of $65,906,297 in November, compared to $48,979,493 for November, 1935, an increase of about 34.5 per cent, was credited by the Association of American Railroads today to 101 Class I carriers which normally account for 91 per cent of the total railway operating revenues.

Following an improvement of about $2 a bale in the last few days, prices on the Cotton Exchange were set back 16 to 25 points yesterday. The rise above 12 1/2 cents a pound for the near months and 12 cents for the 1937 crop positions brought out more cotton and at thesame time the demand from both foreign and domestic interests became less aggressive.

Marking the final step in the refunding program of the Ohio Edison Company, a banking group headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., and Bonbright Co., Inc., as joint syndicate managers, will offer today a new issue of the company consisting of $26,834,000 of first mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds, due Jan. 1, 1972.

JACKSON, Ky., Dec. 29. -- A mountain woman, seeking to avenge the slaying of her son, loosed a burst of gunfire in Breathitt County court room today, killing the accused youth and wounding two spectators.

A writer in The Field, English outdoor magazine, portrays King George VI as fonder of field sports than was the brother whom he succeeded to the throne. While Edward had a wide diversity of interests in the world of sports, he was happiest when playing a round on the links.

Manhattan, now a "hopeless jungle of every-which-way traffic," must develop a city plan providing new arterial highways to stop losses resulting from congestion, in the opinion of Hobart B. Upjohn, president of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29. -- More than 1,500 guests attended the ball given tonight at the Bellevue Stratford by Mr. and Mrs. Peter A.B. Widener 2d of Elkins Park for Mrs. Widener's debutante daughter, Miss Joan Peabody.
Overcoming a 7-0 deficit early in the first period, the St. Francis College quintet went on to conquer Marshall College of West Virginia, 38 to 27, last night on the Butler Street court in Brooklyn.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Dec. 29. -The seedings in the girls' national indoor tennis championship ran true to form today on the covered courts of the Longwood Cricket Club in Chestnut Hill as all four favored players gained the penultimate round in straight sets.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 29. -Competing over a course barely clad with snow, Miss Elizabeth Flanders triumphed in a small but formidable field in capturing premier honors for the combined slalom and downhill event that comprised the college and junior women's ski tournament sponsored today by the Lake Placid Club Sno-Birds.

The New York Giants announced yesterday that the deal whereby they would purchase the Albany Club of the International League was ready for signing, but Joe Cambria, who owns the outfit, wasn't so sure.

ROME, Dec. 29. -- Consultations among Italy, Germany and Portugal have begun to establish a common line of policy toward the recent Anglo-French steps regarding non-intervention in Spain. Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Foreign Minister, today received the German Ambassador and the Portuguese Minister, remaining in conversation with each of them for almost an hour.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 29. -- Atma Singh, burly Sikh from British India, survived a hanging today when the rope parted and may recover from his injuries to find himself venerated as a holy man by his compatriots here.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29. -- Miss Frances A. Wister, president of the Women's Committee for the Philadelphia Orchestra and president of the Philadelphia Society of the Preservation of Landmarks, received the fifth annual $1,000 Gimbel Award today as this city's outstanding woman of the year.

A gift of $5,000 from Lazard Freres to the United Hospitals Fund campaign was announced last night by Stuart M. Crocker, chairman of the drive. He reported also that the Provident Loan Society of New York had increased its donation to $5,000, by making an additional contribution of $2.500.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 29. -Gustav Machaty, director of the controversial "Ecstasy," banned here after a prolonged battle between Washington and the Elekta people of Czechoslovakia, has signed a contract with Metro. While he has received no assignment, it is understood his first will be a picture with a European locale.

The second day of the twelfth annual conference of the National Student Federation of America opened yesterday at the Hotel Victoria with the commission on athletics recommending to the first plenary session, to be held today, that "a more open policy in the granting of aid to athletes" should be followed by American colleges.

The thirty-first annual conventions of the National Collegiate Athletic Association came to its close at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night after a day in which much time had been devoted to discussion of recruiting and subsidization.
