The convention, through adoption of a special report, once more placed the governing body of most college athletics firmly behind those who feel that these two forces are distinctly opposed to the tradition of college sport.

The twelve-story office and showroom building at the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and Thirty-second Street, known as 153-9 Madison Avenue, has been bought by Jesse H. Barkin, realty attorney, as an investment.

MADRID, Dec. 29. -- The Madrid front remains quiet and every indication points to its continuing to do so for some time to come. Interest in the military situation has shifted to Andalusia, where the Rebels have launched a powerful attack with the majority of the Germans under Generalissimo Francisco Franco's command.

Moving toward establishment of the three-platoon system in the Fire Department next year, the Board of Estimate in a special meeting at City Hall authorized yesterday the expenditure of $417,903 from the 1937 budget to start the system on Jan. 1.

The experts who, as Mr. Turner Catledge has learned, have suggested to the President that he funnel all official information henceforth through a single central press bureau are not trying to stopper the wellsprings of Washington news. They are not enemies of a free press.

FREDERICK, Md., Dec. 29. -- Among the many uses to which the "electric eye," or photoelectric cell, has been put, accurate measurement of the brightness of the stars is one of the most important scientifically, yet the sensitivity of the cell may soon be surpassed some 20,000 times, members of the American Astronomical Society, meeting at Hood College, were told today.

Much of the old-time brilliance and enthusiasm that have attended former opening nights was evident last night when the Metropolitan Opera Association's twenty-ninth season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music opened with Richard Wagner's "Die Walkuere."

Despite an increase of forty in pneumonia deaths, the general death rate for the week ending last Saturday declined to 10.4 per 1,000 population, as compared with 11.2 for the previous week, Dr. John L. Rice. Health Commissioner, announced yesterday. The total number of deaths was 1,463, as against 1,586.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- President Roosevelt said today he would include in his annual budget message to Congress his request for additional relief funds for the fiscal year 1937, which ends next June 30, and that the budget message would probably be sent to Congress on Friday, Jan. 8, two days after his message on the state of the Union.

More than 125 persons, including representatives of many Eastern institutions, attended the sixth annual football luncheon of the New York Alumni Association of Wesleyan University at the Hotel Martinique yesterday. George D. Beattys, halfback on the first Cardinal eleven at Middletown, Conn., in 1885, acted as toastmaster.

Robert Cuse, president and purchasing agent of the Vimalert Company, Ltd., of Jersey City, which buys and sells used aviation and marine equipment, and has obtained a license from the State Department for the shipment of $2,777,000 worth of airplanes, engines and parts to Spanish Leftists, asserted yesterday that the planes were commercial craft and denied that they were going to be converted into fighting machines.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- President Roosevelt made clear today that he believed something should be done by the government for the elimination of child labor, long working hours and starvation wages, but he left open to question whether he would make specific recommendations to Congress in the coming session.
PIERRE, S.D., Dec. 29 (AP). -Appointment of Herbert E. Hitchcock to the Senate today unsnarled the political situation which followed the death of Senator Norbeck.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- Registration statements under the Securities Act of 1933 for new securities with estimated gross proceeds of $266,026,000 became effective in November, bringing the total for the first eleven months of 1936 to about $4,366,000,000.

BOSTON, Dec. 29 (AP). -- A pair of unassisted goals by Bill Cowley within the short space of 40 seconds featured the Boston Bruins' 3-0 victory over the Montreal Maroons tonight before a crowd of about 16,000, largest of the season, at the Boston Garden.

Total sales of department stores in the metropolitan area for the Christmas shopping period were 12.5 per cent higher than a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. There was one more shopping day this year than last, however, and, for the corresponding twenty business days, sales were 8.9 per cent larger this year than in 1935.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 29. -- A reaffirmation of his faith in mathematics as the language of philosophy and a prediction that his "first love (symbolic logic)" will become the foundation of esthetics, ethics, and theology were voiced today by Professor Alfred North Whitehead, philosopher, who is retiring from the Harvard faculty next year.

RYE, N.Y., Dec. 29. -- Cornell University's hockey team closed a two-night stand tonight by defeating Union College of Schenectady, 4 -- 1, on the Playland Casino rink before a capacity crowd. The Red six lost its opener to Colgate last night.

With all the splendor with which it is accustomed to stage its shows, the wining-and-dining French Casino presented last evening the fifth in its series of Continental revues, soberly titled this time the "French Casino Folies."

Plunging fifteen stories, Miss Elizabeth Butterfield, 37 years old, member of a widely known Minneapolis family, was killed at 1:15 P.M. yesterday at the Hotel Barbizon-Plaza, Fifty-eighth Street and Sixth Avenue. The police listed the death as a suicide.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29. -- Miss Ginbar, a 3-year-old filly owned by E.N. Thompson, moved up a notch in class today and won her second straight race in accounting for the six-furlong dash for $2,000 platers at the Fair Grounds.

Rebuffed yesterday in its final attempt to force postponement of competitive civil service examinations for social investigator jobs in the Emergency Relief Bureau, the Association of Workers in Public Relief Agencies instructed its members to take the competitive test this morning under protest.

Sharp declines in the Japanese yen and the German registered mark were the principal developments yesterday in the foreign-exchange market. The movements, which were unrelated, carried both these units to their lowest quotations of the year.

With first and second places taken by New York University, winner of the Harold M. Phillips Trophy, and City College, victorious a year ago, yesterday's matches in the annual tournament of the Intercollegiate Chess League at the Manhattan Chess Club were significant mainly because of their bearing on the struggle for third place between Brooklyn College and Seth Low.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 29. -- With electricity flowing normally throughout this area today, the possibility loomed that the Public Service Electric and Gas Company might be compelled to construct an auxiliary power distribution system to bar a recurrence of the shutdown that plunged the city into darkness for more than four hours last night.

LINCOLN, Neb., Dec. 29. -- Nebraska not only will try out a one-house Legislature, but if Governor R.L. Cochran can carry through a policy laid down today it will be a nonpartisan chamber in fact as well as in theory.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- A claim of 200 votes for Representative O'Connor of New York for majority leader was made today by Representative Nichols of Oklahoma, one of Mr. O'Connor's managers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- The foreign trade of the United States, valued during the first nine months of this year at $3,500,000,000, was accompanied by the widest geographical distribution of American purchases and sales abroad in ten years, according to a survey made public today by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- Only with the backing of the public can venereal disease be wiped out, the 300 physicians and lay experts attending the conference on control of this disease were told today by Homer Folks, secretary of the New York Charities Aid Association.

PARIS, Dec. 29. -- Municipal employes, including those in the gas, electric, hospital and transport services, fought the police before the City Hall today and threatened to invade the hall where the Municipal Council was meeting.

If further evidence were needed, in order to demonstrate the folly of Congressional dictation of foreign policy, the latest incident occurring under the so-called Neutrality Act has furnished it. There is war in Spain -- war more bitterly waged than in the conflict between Italy and Ethiopia.

BURBANK, Calif., Dec. 29 (AP). -An inquiry to determine whether negligence was involved in the wrecking Sunday night of a United Airlanes plane on Oak Mountain and the deaths of the nine passengers and the crew of three was called for next week by Coroner Frank Nance, while pack and draft horses brought the bodies of the twelve victims out of Rice Canyon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- For the first time in a decade, Friendship, the estate of the late John R. McLean, where Alice Roosevelt and Nicholas Longworth visited on their wedding trip, will be opened on New Year's Eve for a revival of the annual parties which were famous in a former era.

Judging by the size and enthusiasm of the audience at Moriz Rosenthal's second piano recital at the Town Hall last night, the public, at least the section that is devoted to music, does not forget its heroes. The auditorium was sold out and there were about fifty persons seated on the stage.

A public offering of $2,450,000 first lien fifteen-year collateral trust 5 per cent bonds of Thermoid Company, with stock purchase warrants and sinking fund, is being made today by a banking group headed by Van Alstyne. Noel Co., Inc., at a price of 100 per cent and accrued interest.

The Dollar Line announced yesterday that the last cog of its world-wide shipping enterprise would cease moving this afternoon when the liner President Harrison reached her Jersey City dock. As a result of strikes on the West and Atlantic coasts one ship after another has signed off crews and remained idle at anchor or at Dollar Line piers in this and other ports.

The main body of stocks fluctuated narrowly yesterday and closed irregular. The usual year-end adjustments of speculative accounts, with tax selling in moderate volume and fair, though not necessarily sustained, demand, produced no definite trend of prices.

HAVANA, Dec. 29 (AP). -- The "All-America" boxing team of New York and New Englad amateurs won the Winter sports carnival tournament tonight with a total of 43 points scored in two nights of boxing. Cuba was second with 15 and the Miami Golden Gloves team last with 6.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29 (AP). -Three seeded stars led by the favored Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant of Atlanta moved into the semi-finals of the Sugar Bowl tennis tournament today in the third day of New Orleans' midwinter sports festival.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 29. -- In its first official action since the movement to oust Dr. Glenn Frank from the presidency of the University of Wisconsin became public, directors of the Wisconsin Alumni Association called today for the "elimination of political considerations in measuring the qualifications of a university president."

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 29. -- Opposition to teacher unionization in the American Federation of Labor, and to State laws requiring teachers' oaths of allegiance to the Constitution, was voiced by the American Association of University Professors here today at the closing sessions of the annual convention.

A wish that some of the New Year resolutions about to be made will include pledges to drive carefully on highways is expressed editorially by Bruce (Buster) Hoefer, 11-year-old editor, copyreader, reporter and printer of The Sheboygan Weekly in Wisconsin, which he calls the "world's smallest newspaper."

Compensation of officers and other expenses of fourteen companies which, in reorganization proceedings, have listed securities on the New York Stock Exchange, were disclosed yesterday in reports to the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Rallying in the last two sessions, Al Reid, Bronx featherweight, earned a draw with Pete Scalzo, former Golden Glove star, in the feature eight-round bout at the Coliseum last night.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 29. -- One of the urgent needs of all schools is transforming administration records nearly worthless for guidance purposes into scientific instruments for the continuous study of the individual differences in children, Dr. Richard D. Allen, Assistant Superintendent of Schools in Providence, told New York State high school principals today.

The Greyhound Corporation, now with its buses under the control of the Interstate Commerce Commission, needs funds to make additions and improvements. Under ordinary circumstances it would have made these additions out of its own earnings. But if it used these earnings now to make its proposed extensions and improvements, it would pay a thumping tax of $300,000 to the Federal Government for the privilege.

Although actual linage figures have not been compiled yet, magazines and radio program sponsors were believed to have taken more advertising space in newspapers in 1936 than in any previous year, according to comments here yesterday. Such a trend is a compliment to the effectiveness of newspaper advertising, it was said.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 29. -Chancellor Josiah O. Wolcott, on petition of Clarence A. Southerland, attorney for Loft, Inc., ordered sequestration today of all dividends declared by the Pepsicola Company which might accrue to Charles G. Guth, former president of Loft, Inc.

Sharp profit taking occurred yesterday in all commodity futures markets, except those for coffee, sugar and wool tops, which had not participated fully in the long advance of the other staples, and prices slid off in moderately active trading at intervals in the day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- The "lost race" of mound builders of the Mississippi Valley is not a mystery to archaeologists and is regarded merely as one type of early Indian culture, archaeologists said here today at the closing session of their annual meeting.

A new music publishing company has been organized by Samuel Fox, song publisher, under the name of Hollywood Songs, Inc., to exploit songs from screen musical productions. The company, which becomes active with the publication of song hits from the Twentieth Century-Fox film, "One in a Million," expects to confine its activities to the publication of songs from the six or eight most important musical pictures yearly.

The sixth sense that had preserved Oscar England from harm through the thirty-four dark years of his life betrayed him yesterday. One step too many in the B.M.T. Union Square station and he was wedged, lifeless, between a northbound express and the concrete platform.

VATICAN CITY, Dec. 29. -- The papal physician, Dr. Amanti Milani, administered a sedative to his patient last midnight, and Pope Pius slept for a few hours quietly under its influence, awaking in the morning considerably refreshed. The improvement, however, was brief, for intense pain in his left leg began again shortly afterward, quickly neutralizing the benefit derived from his rest.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 29. -- The Sporting News, baseball weekly, named six men today as the outstanding figures in major and minor league baseball during 1936.

The New York World's Fair of 1939 will be organized on a national basis with advisory committees in every State, an organization comparable to the Liberty Loan Drives. Announcement of the national advisory committee was made yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation, with the appointment of Winthrop W. Aldrich as chairman of the national committee and Mrs. Vincent Astor as chairman of the women's national advisory committee.

Cornell undergraduates yesterday made a sweep of the intercollegiate dinghy races held in a dual meet on opposite sides of Long Island Sound. The sailors from Lake Cayuga ran up 49 points against a nearest competitor tie of 44 between the tars from Yale and Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine characterized as "absurd" yesterday the rumor that two patrolmen formerly assigned to duty with the Department of Markets had been transferred because of influence brought to bear by friends of Charles Herbert, poultry racketeer, who was sentenced to ninety days in the workhouse on Monday. Herbert, convicted on a charge of disorderly conduct, was arrested by Patrolmen William E. Mundelak and Louis Calzaretta.

In your editorial regarding the present situation in the Emergency Home Relief Bureau you make the statement that past service is not being ignored. The fact is that no announcement has been made as to the credit to be given to present employes of the Emergency Home Relief Bureau.

SELMA, Ala., Dec. 29 (AP). -- Seven young society women were seriously burned and at least a dozen other persons were hurt tonight when a carelessly tossed match ignited the costume of a dancer at a gay ball at the Selma Country Club.

The preparation of a Dictionary of American History will start at once, Charles Scribner's Sons announced yesterday. James Truslow Adams, historian, yesterday accepted the position of editor-in-chief.
PARIS, Dec. 29. -- France has not taken any decision to give back to Germany her colonies and the question has not even been under discussion, it was stated today in official circles.

The financial interest of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in "allied commercial fields" prompted a plan to control several branches of the motion-picture industry three years ago, according to testimony of present and former officials of that corporation and one of its subsidiaries, at a hearing before the Federal Communications Commission yesterday at 45 Broadway.

Let well enough alone was the almost unanimous decision reached regarding the forward pass interference rule at the open forum of the American Football Coaches Association held at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

It threatens to be a bad year for the proverbs and the aphorisms, but not always with ill consequences. Here, for instance, is HENRY FORD patenting a new automobile with the engine in the rear. If this means anything it means that Mr. FORD is putting the cart before the horse, but people think it may be a big forward step in the motor world.

A strike of bus drivers on twenty-one routes of the B.M.T. in Brooklyn was ordered terminated last night by union officials after some of their number earlier in the day had termed the walk-out "premature" and "unauthorized."

Fourteen men convicted last week of mail fraud growing out of a scheme to sell stock of the Rayon Industries Corporation received prison sentences ranging from a year and a day to seven years when they appeared yesterday before Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard.

The American Council of Learned Societies has had as wide an interest in the humanities as the interests and activities of its component organizations added together and has projects that look even beyond the sum of all these. The major project of its sponsoring has had recent mention in these columns: the completion of the Dictionary of American Biography, a monumental undertaking of twenty volumes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- Declaring that the public interest is the guiding principle in its activities, the Federal Power Commission in an annual report today gave an accounting of its increased work under the provisions of the Federal Power Act.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 29. -- Moshe Shertok, witness before the Royal Commission of Inquiry here today, recalled the well-known letter of Ramsay MacDonald, as British Prime Minister, to Dr. Chaim Weizmann, president of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, in which Mr. MacDonald promised to Jews a proportionate share of employment on public works in Palestine.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,133,250 barrels, compared to 3,145,700 in the preceding week, a drop of 12,450, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decline of 4,900 barrels in the daily average output of California was the most important change.

Peter M. Daly of Astoria was sworn as justice of the Supreme Court by Justice Burt J. Humphrey in the special term of the Queens Supreme Court at Jamaica yesterday morning. He was a judge of the City Court in Queens for five years until he resigned following his election to the Supreme Court bench in November.

BERLIN, Dec. 29. -- The Boerse was weaker today. Heavy industrial stocks declined, Harpener losing 2 1/2 points, Vereinigtestahl 1, and Mansfeld 1 1/2. Among the machine issues, which softened, Orenstein Koppel fell 3/8 point. Chemical Securities fell, with the loss for I.G. Farbenindustrie 3/8 point.

Three hold-up men gathered loot leisurely for fifteen minutes at about 11 o'clock last night in the Three Deuces Bar and Grill, 222 Madison Avenue, between Thirty-sixth and Thirty-seventh Streets, unnoticed by six special guards patrolling the town house of J.P. Morgan across the street.
PARIS, Dec. 29 (AP). -- Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos disclosed to the Chamber of Deputies today that Poland had given France a guarantee to aid Czechoslovakia if the latter is attacked by Germany.

The letter of Emil F. Prantner contains at least two errors. He sneers at commercial banking, and says that "one puts in and takes out," and the banks are merely "cash registers." He is laboring under a curious misapprehension of fact, notwithstanding the lessened number of commercial loans.

Clinical birth control methods are approaching 100 per cent success; but cheaper, easier and equally harmless means must be found to help the millions to whom present methods are economically or geographically unavailable, Mrs. Margaret Sanger, director of the Birth Control Clinical Research Bureau, declared yesterday.

With entries from New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and the New England States, the two-day horse show of the Riding and Polo Club opened last evening in the arena of that organization at 7 West Sixty-sixth Street before a crowd of enthusiasts that packed the galleries and the reserved balconies.

Price-fixing features of current milk-control programs were sharply assailed yesterday at a conference in the Hotel Commodore of leaders in the dairy industry from the four States in the New York milk shed. These attacks, however, brought considerable floor discussion in which several said that removal of present controls might bring chaos in the industry.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 29. -- A possibility that civilized man may be headed by inexorable laws of nature toward the destiny that befalls lemmings, little animals in Norway that show a tremendous, unexplained increase in population, followed by mass suicide, was suggested here today at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science by Professor Raymond Pearl, biologist, of Johns Hopkins University.

Mrs. Margaret Auchincloss Colgate, widow of Richard M. Colgate, former president of Colgate Co., soap manufacturers, left an estate of $894,451 gross and $831,908 net when she died on Aug. 22, 1935, according to the non-resident transfer tax appraisal filed here yesterday.

While dozens claimed kinship to Christopher Hassett, known in the navy yard district of Brooklyn as "Old Fish," the fish peddler, who died on Christmas Eve apparently penniless, six persons have shown "documentary proof" that they were relatives, in the hope of sharing in his $83,000 estate, it was learned yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29. -- Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Welsh of Chestnut Hill gave a dinner dance tonight in the Mirage Room of the Barclay to introduce to society Mrs. Welsh's daughter, Miss Elizabeth Lawton.

CAPE MAY COURTHOUSE, N.J., Dec. 29. -- Mayor Doris W. Bradway of Wildwood, Republican, ordered Republican poll watchers to disregard instructions of the Cape May County Election Board during the general election last Nov. 3, it was testified today at the hearing in circuit court here of charges that a Republican State Senator had been elected by fraud.

The "Alice in Wonderland" of Lewis Carroll is so full of cruelty, fear and "oral sadistic trends of cannibalism" that its wholesomeness as child literature is questionable, Dr. Paul Schilder, Research Professor of Psychiatry at New York University, told members of the American Psychoanalytic Association meeting at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

TACOMA, Wash., Dec. 29. -- Search for an accomplice of the man who kidnapped ten-year-old Charles Mattson and indication that the abductor had attempted to kidnap the son of another family in the fashionable Tacoma neighborhood were developments today in the na tion's only major kidnapping mystery of 1936.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 29. -- The "regimentation of literature" was deplored by Howard Mumford Jones of Harvard, in an address here tonight before 1,500 delegates attending the annual convention of the Modern Language Association of America.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 29 (AP). -- With 15.000 turf fans in attendance, Jockey Willie (Smokey) Saunders rode Tempestuous to an easy victory today at Santa Anita Park in the $1,500 Monrovia Handicap.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 (AP). -- Commissioner John J. Merrill said today that the State Tax Commission would seek a reargument before the Court of Appeals on a controversy on a corporation dividend tax involving possible loss to the State of "upwards of $10,000,000" in revenue.

The journalist is every bit as eager -- and sometimes even more so -- to tell the truth to the world as is the research professor, Dr. John H. Finley declared yesterday before eighty of the young men and women who represent THE NEW YORK TIMES at colleges and preparatory schools in the East.

MADARIAGA has hit upon a good phrase in describing the purpose of his World Foundation as organized to promote "world patriotism" by non-political methods. It recalls one of the discourses of EPICTETUS who urged one never to say in reply to the question to what country he belonged that he was an Athenian or a Corinthian, but that he was a citizen of the world.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 29. -Two eminent archaeologists joined today at the opening of the annual meeting of the American Historical Association which is being held here under the auspices of Brown University in warning their listeners against charlatanism and undue emphasis on spectacular research in archaeology.

Stockholders of the National Investors Corporation and of its affiliated investment companies, the Second, Third and Fourth National Investors Corporations, approved yesterday a plan for the mutualization of the respective companies. This move will enable the companies to qualify for tax exemptions granted by the Revenue Act of 1936 to investment companies of the mutual type.

MOSCOW, Dec. 29. -- Soviet-German trade has declined in the past year in proportion to the increasing political tension between the two countries, it is shown in Soviet customs statistics released today.

Registration of visiting buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday was practically the same as in the preceding week. But the total was above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES. The arrivals for the week numbered 365, against 364 in the preceding week and 297 in the same period last year.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 29. -- A view that science might eventually outlaw war by removing the demand for mineral resources was expressed by Dr. William S. Bayley, former Professor of Geology at the University of Illinois and retiring president of the Mineralogical Society of America, at the joint convention today of that society and the Geological Society of America.

The Public Service Corporation of New Jersey reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on Nov. 30 a consolidated net income of $25,025,916 after all deductions, equivalent after preferred dividend requirements to $2.76 a share earned on 5,503,193 no-par common shares, compared with $24,175,483, or $2.60 a common share, the year before.

LONDON, Dec. 29. -- Afternoon diplomatic dispatches and news reports received today from Washington have done much to allay the anxiety that was felt this morning in the British Foreign Office over yesterday's announcement by the State Department that government licenses had been granted for the export of airplanes and engines to Spain.

A visitor to almost any Soviet office, remarks our dispatch yesterday from Mr. DENNY, is impressed by the battalions of clerks doing work that a small fraction of their numbers do in any American office. It is common, for example, for a factory to make out several hundred complicated order cards for the manufacture of one part, whereas in America two small cards suffice:

With many firms expanding their space or preparing to start the coming year in new quarters, brokers' lists of commercial rentals yesterday reflected the increased activity. Among the leases were many involving retail-store space or entire floors for offices. The contracts included the following:

Retail failures dropped to ninety-two in the week ended Dec. 24, compared with 107 in the previous week, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. There was a decline of four in the wholesale division, while in the manufacturing group there was an increase of one.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- On the heels of three airplane accidents this month, whose fatalities brought the year's total on transport lines to sixty, J. Monroe Johnson, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, announced today that a conference would be called soon to take steps to make air travel safer.

A committee headed by J.J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads, will confer with representatives of labor unions in Washington on Jan. 7 on the sixhour-day law proposed by labor and the railway pension law sponsored by labor, which the railroads are contesting in the courts.
Apartments and apartment house sites figured largely in deals reported in the Bronx yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29. -- Personal debts owed by employes of the American Chemical Paint Company at Ambler, a suburb, have been wiped out as a Christmas gift from J. Harvey Gravell, the president, it became known today.

Preliminary to the formal official inspection today several Public Works Administration officials, accompanied by newspaper reporters and photographers, traveled in a special train yesterday over the new section of the Queens line of the Independent Subway System and observed many of the new facilities.

Rules for the sale of alcoholic beverages and dancing on the morning of New Year's Day were issued yesterday by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine. The order, sent out to all borough commanders by Commissioner Valentine, reads:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP). -- An apportionment of $12,273,957 to Texas was the largest made today by Secretary Wallace in dividing a $200,000,000 highway and grade crossing fund among the States and Territories.
BERLIN, Dec. 29. -- The German Government announced through its official news agency today a partial victory in Spain in these terms:

Nicholas Rosenauer in a letter to THE TIMES referred to the delays he had experienced in transferring between local and express trains at stations on Inter-borough subway lines, and suggested that the commission endeavor to bring about a better coordination of the two classes of service.

BIARRITZ, France, Dec. 29 (AP). -- Basque authorities at Bilbao, releasing the German freighter Palos at the demand of the German cruiser Koenigsberg, announced today the incident was "closed." They refused to free that part of the cargo considered as war material.
The crew of the D.L.O. (Dead Letter Office) of the New York Post office has taken its annual "trip to the mountains."

HASTINGS, England, Dec. 29. -Reuben Fine of New York, only winner in today's second round, assumed the lead in the international chess masters' tournament when he defeated William Winter of London, British champion, after fiftyone moves. It was the American's second success. His record is 2 -- 0.
A $5,000 contribution and several other large donations helped to increase the amount received by the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday to $10,997.86.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company was ordered by Secretary Wallace today to discontinue practices held to be in violation of the Packers and Stockyards Act and alleged to give the company an unfair advantage over competitors.

Your editorial concerning the legal status of the present Emergency Relief Bureau employes is both fair and clear. Permit me to add a few remarks, which, in my opinion, will clarify the situation still further.

The national service award of the Phi Epsilon Pi fraternity was given last night to Rabbi Stephen S. Wise for being, in the judgment of the fraternity, the man "who has made during the year the most distinctive contribution to the creative life of the Jewish people."

While the number of influenza cases reported in the city in the twenty-four hours ended at 10 A. M. yesterday was almost as great as reported for the previous seventy-two hours, city health authorities continued to give assurances there was no indication of an epidemic.

Dr. Tracy Farnam, 57 years old, of New York and East Lyme, Conn., member of an old Connecticut family which has been associated with Yale University for many years and a brother of Thomas W. Farnam, associate treasurer of Yale, died about 4 P.M. yesterday in a taxicab at Thirty-seventh Street and Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- In a letter picturing the Securities and Exchange Commission as a "great adventure in social organization," President Roosevelt today accepted the resignation of John J. Burns as general counsel of that Federal agency, effective on Jan. 15, and praised him for his "splendid service" to the government.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- The government called on the farmer today to come out from behind his "No hunting signs" and make profitable peace with visiting sportsmen.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- President Roosevelt's expression of certainty that some new Federal action would be required to abolish child labor, shorten working hours and raise some wages seemed to set at rest any speculation that the problem would be tackled solely through action by the States, as some have suggested.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- President Roosevelt gave his approval today to plans of legislative leaders to have enacted immediately after Congress convenes next week an amendment to the Neutrality Act extending it to Spain and, with certain discretionary features, to all other countries where internal strife occurs.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29. -- The trend of State governments to enact price-fixing acts under the guise of "fair practices" was attacked today by Q. Forrest Walker, economist for R.H. Macy Co., Inc., before the National Association of Marketing Teachers, in session at the Stevens Hotel here.

President Franklin D. Roosevelt and Anning S. Prall, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, extended congratulations last night to the Mutual Broadcasting System on its coast-to-coast expansion when the Mutual network opened a nation-wide service. A special program, marking the event, originated in Washington, New York, Chicago, Cincinnati, Detroit, Boston, Philadelphia and Pittsburgh, and was heard here over WOR from 10 P.M. to 2:30 A.M. Eastern standard time.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29. -- An assertion that the progress of recovery had eliminated further need for expansion of public works or for Federal subsidies for construction to States or cities was made here today by the public works committee of the American Association for Labor Legislation, meeting in conjunction with the American Economic Association and other organizations.
The Home Owners Loan Corporation was plaintiff in six of the nine foreclosure actions which culminated in forced sales in the Bronx yesterday. Results of the day's offerings were as follows:

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Dec. 30. -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's first resignation as president of the Executive Council and chairman of the Military Affairs Commission having been rejected, the generalissimo decided today to resign again.
The development of a new engineering technique for purifying the smoke-laden air over big cities was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- The dollar value of sales on all national securities Exchanges in November, in which there were but twenty-two trading days, amounted to $2,824,195,708, an increase of 9.8 per cent over October, in which there were twenty-six trading days, and 10.9 per cent over November, 1935, according to a summary made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

CLEVELAND, Wednesday, Dec. 30 (AP). -- Wyndham Mortimer, international vice president of the United Automobile Workers of America, rejected early today any local settlement of the "sitdown" strike at the Fisher Body Company plant here.
INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 29. -- A new germ which interferes with the work of public health officials in testing water supplies was reported to the Society of American Bacteriologists here today.

AN orange rolled down the center of West Philadelphia station yesterday morning and plunked into a hat. Twelve Stanford basketball players chortled with glee. The "Laughing Boys" were having an impromptu bowling game while waiting for the train that was to take them to New York and their long-awaited engagement with undefeated Long Island University at Madison Square Garden tonight.

ONEIDA, N.Y., Dec. 29. -- Dr. Toyokichi Iyenaga, 74 years old, retired publicist, lecturer and Japanese diplomat, living at Fish Creek, near Oneida Lake, was drowned today while fishing through the ice.
Dr. and Mrs. Harold Ruckman Mixsell gave a dinner dance last night at Sherry's to introduce their daughter, Miss Mallory Mixsell.

NANKING, China, Wednesday, Dec. 30. -- Chinese officials are taking sharp exception to published versions of Sian events that attribute the solution of the situation to Chang Hsueh-liang's remorse after reading the generalissimo's diary.

John D.M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, talked yesterday with some of the leaders in the State about plans for clearing up the $901,000 deficit resulting from the late national campaign.

Robert L. Fisher, secretary of the New York Stock Exchange, advised its members yesterday that they might vote on Jan. 11 in the election of a new nominating committee by absentee ballot, as provided by the constitution of the Exchange.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 29. -- The touring Dartmouth hockey team put up a valiant fight tonight against the Big Ten champions from Minnesota, but went down to defeat in a fast game, 2 to 0.

In a bruising, exciting struggle, the Rangers conquered their city rivals, the Americans, at Madison Square Garden last night. Led by Butch Keeling, who scored three goals, the Patrickmen overcame a one-goal deficit in the first period to ride through to a 5-to-1 triumph over the fading star-spangled outfit.

Between the friends of Mr. RAYBURN of Texas and Mr. O'CONNOR of New York "a spirited contest" for the post of majority leader in the House has been going on for months, not without virulence. It will be decided next Monday. So far as we have observed, it has stirred little interest in the country at large.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 29. -- Air transports with cruising speeds of 300 miles an hour, land planes with top speeds of 425 miles an hour and seaplanes going at 500 an hour, will be realized within the next ten years, the aeronautics section of the American Association for the Advancement of Science was told here today by T.P. Wright, director of engineering of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation.

Max Pincus, 56-year-old Cafeteria Employes Union head who faced trial next Monday on an indictment in connection with the alleged $2,000,000-a-year restaurant racket recently exposed by Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey, committed suicide yesterday morning by dropping from a hall window of the apartment house in which he lived at 15 Marcy Place, the Bronx.

FLINT, Mich., Dec. 29. -- This center of operations of the General Motors Corporation, with more than 46,000 workers employed in the plants of the Buick, Chevrolet, Fisher Body and A.C. Spark Plug companies, is to be the scene of a conference Sunday called by international headquarters of the United Automobile Workers of America to prepare a basic agreement for collective bargaining in General Motors plants.

A ninth man was arrested yesterday as a result of the grand jury's investigation of the so-called garnishee racket, in which hundreds of city employes, including policemen and firemen, were defrauded, it was alleged, of nearly $2,000,000 in recent years through crooked practices in the Municipal Courts.

Plans for eight new apartment buildings, two in Manhattan and six in the Bronx, were filed yesterday with the aggregate cost estimated at $1,544,000. The Manhattan project included an eight-story house for Northern Avenue and a six-story building on West 184th Street.

Franz Werfel's successor to his "Musa Dagh" will be a 700-page book made up of four novels and four short stories depicting the final years of the Austro-Hungarian Empire. These eight works are linked with a prologue and seven connective passages.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 29. -- It will be some time before students of form forget the amazing things that happened at the Tropical Park track today. By the time the Lamar Stock Farm's Merrymood won the featured Marco Purse, fifth on the card, the figure experts were walking around shaking their heads.

Form held well as the junior and boys' national indoor tennis championships reached the fourth round at the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday. Only in the lower brackets of the boys' division were there any upsets of seeded players.

The 1937 National Automobile Show will be held in New York next year from Oct. 27 through Nov. 3, it was announced yesterday by Alfred Reeves, vice president of the Automobile Manufacturers Association and show manager. The opening will be two weeks in advance of the 1936 show.

LONDON, Dec. 29. -- The stock market here continued extremely quiet today in view of the fact that the account will close in two days and because of the normally slack conditions of the year-end. British Government issues were dull and irregular, with no notable changes.

TACOMA, Wash., Dec. 29. -- A friend of the family declared tonight that negotiations for the return of kidnapped Charles Mattson, 10, son of Dr. W.W. Mattson, were "definitely under way" and that the $28,000 ransom would probably be paid within twelve hours.

Walter Hoving, chairman of the board of Lord Taylor, will succeed Joseph E. Pridday as president of the store next month, it was announced yesterday by Oswald W. Knauth, president of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, parent organization of which the Fifth Avenue establishment is a unit.
Four unbeaten teams will be seen in action in the basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden tonight when Stanford faces Long Island University and New York University meets Georgetown.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29. -- Prices of wheat in North American markets today made a fair response in the early trading to the strength in Liverpool, but the upturn was short-lived and closing trades were about at the bottom. Net losses on the Board of Trade here ranged from 3/4 to 1 cent a bushel, while Winnipeg was off 1/8 to 5/8 cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- Inactive gold in the amount of $14,835,000 was acquired by the Treasury on last Thursday, it was shown in an item appearing for the first time in the Treasury's daily statement for Dec. 24, which was made public today.

The granting of tax exemption as a reward to landlords for rehabilitating slum tenements was opposed yesterday at a hearing before the New York City Housing Authority on the "poor man's housing shortage."

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (AP). -- Chicago's low-standing Black Hawks, flashing a powerful attack for the first time this season, upset the fast-traveling Montreal Canadiens, 5 -- 1, tonight in a National Hockey League battle before 6,500 fans, smallest crowd of the campaign here.

Mrs. E. Marshall Field gave a ball last night in the ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton for her debutante daughter, Miss Barbara Field. It was one of the largest debutante parties of the season, and was the fourth dance given for Miss Field this year.

Three witnesses for the State testified in Special Sessions Court yesterday that a lawyer and his "runner," now on trial, had asked them to sign false affidavits, to "forget" evidence and to give false evidence.

The United Hospitals Campaign will receive the proceeds from the sale of a group of charcoal sketches by Agnes Knox, to be exhibited, beginning at noon today, in the Penthouse Gallery of the Piccadilly Hotel, 227 West Forty-fifth Street.

With the exception of United States Government obligations and certain South American loans, bonds made little headway yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange despite heavier trading. Transactions in all bonds amounted to $18,041,700, compared with $17,198,400 on Monday, and although most of the activity centered in the domestic corporate section, prices displayed a highly irregular undertone.

The steel industry will enter 1937 with indications of continuing activity and with the greatest confidence that it has had in the last seven years, Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation, said yesterday in his annual statement on the status of the industry.

The Right Rev. Thomas E. Molloy, Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, was guest of honor last night at the second annual dinner of the Laymen's Retreat League of the diocese. The dinner was held at the Knights of Columbus clubhouse, 1 Prospect Park West, with 1,000 persons present.

The Board of Supervisors of San Francisco has decided to submit to the voters of the city at a special election on Feb. 16 a proposal for an amendment to the charter providing for the issuance of $50,000,000 of revenue bonds to finance municipal distribution of electricity, it was announced yesterday.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 29. -Tapering off preparations for their intersectional football battle in the Rose Bowl New Year's Day, the Pittsburgh and Washington squads went through lengthy signal drills today on slippery fields.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29. -- Hog prices declined 15 to 30 cents a hundred-weight today, with much of the late trading around the low point of the day except on sows, which were off 10 cents. Although the demand was relatively slow early, large packers came into the market on the decline and a good clearance was effected, except on lighter weights of poor finish.

Successful futures for budding young journalists who competed in the second annual amateur newspaper contest conducted by the Department of Parks were predicted yesterday afternoon by James V. Mulholland, director of recreation, at the judging of thirty monthly publications edited exclusively by playground youngsters.

Freedom of the press is not the privilege of the newspaper publisher, it is his responsibility, Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, told members of the Columbia University Alumni Association yesterday at their twenty-eighth annual holiday luncheon, held at the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street.

HEATH BOWMAN and Stirling Dickinson traveled through South America, quiet adventurers of the Johnny Appleseed school, avoiding all rows, finding good in ticks, frost, heat and dust clouds, making friends with all the fluent talkers, and enjoying a pleasant rather lazy time that rouses in readers of their book, "Westward From Rio" (Willett, Clark, $3), a sufficient envy and interest.

A five-story apartment at 260 Gregory Avenue and 99 Broadway, Passaic, N. J., was sold by the West End Building and Loan Association of Newark to Gregory Equities, Inc., it was reported yesterday by Ben Schlossberg, Inc., of Jersey City, who with David Cronheim of Newark negotiated the sale.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Dec. 30 (AP). -- Soft coal producers, definitely optimistic over prospects for agreement, decided today to continue next week in Washington discussions of a new Guffey coal control bill. A subcommittee was named to report on proposals.

We mark the last day of the Old Year as if it were reckoned accurately from the moment when time began to run. According to the Scripture record, "the evening and the morning were the first day" in creation. The count which the rocks have kept, with the aid of the helium clock, leads the geologist to estimate that they are as much as two billion years old.

DETROIT, Dec. 30 (AP). -- With a conference of union representatives from all of the General Motors plants called for Sunday at Flint Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, dispatched a telegram tonight to William S. Knudson, executive vice president of General Motors, asking for a conference between union and company officials.

Engineering construction awards in the United States, in the final week of 1936, according to Engineering News-Record, reached a total of $43,020,000. The report was for a short week, due to the New Year's holiday, and as there were fifty-three Thursdays in 1936 it was the fifty-third for the year in the compilation of these data.

Acting on the request of the interested parties, who submitted a favorable accountants' report, Federal Judge Julian W. Mack yesterday ordered a hearing to be held at 10:30 A.M. on Jan. 8 to determine whether the reorganization proceedings of the Associated Gas and Electric Company should be dismissed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- Donaldson Brown of New York City, an officer and director of the General Motors Corporation, sold last month 6,933 shares of his holdings of common stock of the corporation, and Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president, sold 6,436 shares, according to a summary of transactions in equity securities of corporations by officers, directors and principal stockholders for November, made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

FLINT, Mich., Dec. 30. -- Backed by the John L. Lewis Committee for Industrial Organization, the United Automobile Workers of America today started its campaign to include the nation's automobile industry within its ranks. It struck at the center of General Motors operations and halted activities in three of its unit plants here.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 30. -- The Atlantic Life Insurance Company here is expected to be sold to the Bankers National Investing Corporation of Wilmington, Del., although letters laying the offer of $175 a share before stockholders may not be sent out until Monday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30. -- A new record in fatalities from automobile traffic accidents has been set this year, according to the National Safety Council, which figures that the total is likely to be 37,450. This would be 450 above the 1935 record.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- Eugene L. Vidal, director of the Bureau of Air Commerce, was reported tonight to have submitted his resignation to Secretary Roper and President Roosevelt.

Catching a big fish isn't everything. Lots of us never get anything on the end of a line to brag about. Still, you get a big kick out of just going fishing. That isn't to say you wouldn't like to tie into a real big one sometime. And how!
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- Christmas business at postoffices was apparently the largest in the history of the service, Postmaster General Farley announced today.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 30. -- Today's session of the Royal Commission of Inquiry was marked by plain speaking by leaders of Jewish labor. Never before had the Palestine Administration been subjected to such scathing indictments in open court.

A statement by Oscar Johnston of the Commodity Credit Corporation that terms upon which loan cotton would be released had not been finally determined, although details were under discussion, served to steady the cotton market yesterday.

An indictment charging second degree manslaughter was returned by the New York County grand jury yesterday against William Hoffman, 44 years old, a jobless painter, who is accused of having smoked a cigarette in bed on Dec. 18 and of having caused a fire in a boarding house at 273 West Seventy-third Street, in which five persons were killed.
Seventeen men who saved persons from drowning during the year were rewarded yesterday afternoon by the Life-Saving Benevolent Association at 80 Broad Street. Three of them were old hands at the game.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 30 (AP). -- Use of a screeching sound to shake an immunizing substance out of streptococci, one of the most virulent families of human disease germs, was reported to the Society of American Bacteriologists here today.
BERLIN, Dec. 30. -- The Boerse showed some strength today following its sinking spell of yesterday. The turnover was small, and the market, it seems, is entirely under official control.

ALBANY, Dec. 30. -- Governor Lehman returned to Albany today and spent most of his time putting the finishing touches on his inaugural address, which he will deliver at noon on Friday in the Assembly chamber when he formally takes his oath of office for the third time.

The three-and-a-half-mile addition to the Queens branch of the city's Independent Subway, extending the line from Roosevelt Avenue, Jackson Heights, to a new terminus in Kew Gardens, was officially inspected yesterday by Mayor La Guardia and a large delegation of city officials and representatives of business and civic organizations.
AKRON, Ohio, Dec. 30 (AP). -- Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company employes received notice tonight that curtailed production would lay off several thousand workers or shorten hours or both.

EASTPORT, Me., Dec. 30. -- Culminating drilling operations carried on for five weeks, Quoddy engineers will set off late this week a rock blast involving nearly six tons of dynamite, by far the largest that the tidal power project has experienced.

The Board of Education decided last night to ask the Legislature to assure the nine members of the Board of Superintendents of permanent jobs at $10,000 a year in the event that they fail of re-election to their posts.
LONDON, Dec. 30. -- As church bells ring out the old year tomorrow night, the curtain will rise swiftly on a new act of the drama of world naval rivalry.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 30. -- The Chinese Government's widespread publicity campaign warning users of opium and other narcotic drugs that the death penalty clause of the Anti-narcotics Law will not be suspended again after the year's end is causing panic among opium smokers in many districts.

Cosmic rays that may have started their celestial journeys from some dying star long before the advent of man on this planet will be utilized to light up the man-made stars in the Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- Senator Vandenberg made public today a letter to Major Gen. Edward M. Markham, chief of Army Engineers, in which the Senator asserted that the report of a special board which found the proposed Florida Ship Canal economically justified was "untenable, unsupportable and denied by the facts."

A unique offering of the orchestral concert directed by Paul Stassevitch last night in the Town Hall was a C major symphony of Muzio Clementi, performed for the first time in the United States. This Clementi is the composer of the innumerable piano sonatas and sonatinas and the "Gradus ad Parnassum" which through a century tortured the fingers of all adolescent pianists.

Sam Pian, co-manager of Barney Ross, world's welterweight champion, yesterday was suspended indefinitely by the State Athletic Commission for failing to sign Ross for a title bout against Ceferino Garcia within the time limit set by it.

Leaders in the dairy industry in the four States included in the New York milk shed agreed yesterday after two days of conferences that conflicting views made it impossible to recommend a permanent plan to solve the industry's problems.

ROME, Dec. 30. -- Consultations are still proceeding among Italy, Germany and Portugal to lay down a common line of policy toward the Franco-British step of a few days ago regarding non-intervention in Spain.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Dec. 30. -- Three men from the United States and an Ecuadorean today made the first flights in history over Mount Chimborazc, the highest peak in the Andes of Ecuador. The two machines used were Curtiss monoplanes belonging to the Ecuadorean Military School of Aviation which were specially equipped for high altitude flights.

Herman Shumlin's proposed production of "To Quito and Back," by Ben Hecht, is to be listed as very uncertain. Though there will be further conferences about it during the next two weeks, the producer and author had not quite decided yesterday whether the show was actually to be presented or not.

More than 9,000 persons participated yesterday in the competitive civil service examination which will determine the assignment of 3,100 social investigator jobs on July 1, when the functions of the Emergency Relief Bureau are taken over by the Department of Public Welfare.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 30. -- More than a hundred students, alumni, parents and friends of the Palm Beach Private School attended the fifth annual subscription dance tonight at the school. The holiday motif prevailed in decorations of flowers, plants, garlands and balloons.

MONTREAL, Dec. 30. -- Formal notice of a judicial sale here on Feb. 3 next of the property and assets of Price Brothers Co., Ltd., newsprint manufacturers now in bankruptcy, was issued today by the Montreal Trust Company, trustee for the company's bondholders.

Supreme Court Justice Rosenman denied yesterday to "Dr." Anna Swift, middle-aged owner of the Danish Institute in West Seventieth Street, a certificate of reasonable doubt on her conviction in Special Sessions last Dec. 1 of maintaining a house of prostitution.

The jurisdiction of the Federal courts is much more varied and complex than that of any other courts on earth. In determining the constitutionality of the Federal laws it is ofttimes necessary to determine the constitutionality of State laws. All controversies between States, or citizens of different States, are determined by the Federal courts.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler directed yesterday that Hampshire House, thirty-four-story apartment hotel at 150 Central Park South, which has stood unfinished and unoccupied since 1931, should be completed by the trustees of the Series C-2 mortgage certificate issue of the New York Title and Mortgage Company.

In Sweden syphilis is a rare disease; in the United States at least 20,000,000 suffer from venereal afflictions -- about 16 per cent of the population. Imagine Kansas, Maryland, Nebraska, Utah, Vermont, Washington, Wyoming and the District of Columbia venereally ravaged, and the meaning of this 16 per cent is driven home.
Arrangements were made yesterday for the transfer of a membership in the New York Stock Exchange for $130,000, an advance of $1,000 from the last previous transaction, on Tuesday.

Most commodity futures rallied yesterday in active trading. Rubber, copper and tins declined. On the cash markets, rye, oats, cocoa and antimony sold at new high prices, and cotton, wheat, corn and lard advanced. Rubber, tins and silk declined.

The progress of recovery has now eliminated further need for expansion of public works or for Federal subsidies for construction to States or cities. Private construction, especially of residences, requires skilled labor, which should now be released by curtailment of all but the most urgent public works.

Robert Cuse, president of the Vimalert Company, Ltd., in Jersey City, should make from $1,500,000 to $2,000,000 gross profit from his sale of airplanes, engines and parts to the Leftists in Spain for $2,777,000, according to his competitors in the second-hand airplane business.

Miss Jane S. Bowers was introduced to society yesterday afternoon at a tea dance given by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Wesley C. Bowers, in the roof garden of the Pierre. The guests were received by the debutante and her mother, with the assistance of Miss Frederica Barker and Miss Sybil King, in a bower of tropical ferns, smilax and pink roses at the entrance to the roof garden.

BERLIN, Dec. 30. -- The old German classic gymnasium, the backbone of prewar German education, received probably a mortal blow yesterday when Dr. Bernhard Rust, the Minister of Education, ordered that in all communities where only one higher school is kept up English must be the main foreign language, with Latin in second place.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 30. -- Their plans thwarted by the most deplorable weather conditions ever experienced by this famous Winter sports center at this time of the year, the Lake Placid Club Sno Birds today were forced to call off their sixteenth annual college week invitation ski tournament.

Speaking over the radio from the Executive Chamber in Albany at 12:30 P.M. yesterday, Governor Lehman appealed to the people of New York State to reduce motor vehicle, industrial and other accidents by 10 per cent in 1937, and suggested the following New Year's resolution for every one:

TORONTO. Dec. 30. -- Fearful that death may reign over the year's biggest celebration. Canadian police will be mobilized across the country to oversee the extravagant New Year's Eve scene and keep its record as clean as possible.

Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo denied yesterday the application of Fred Rosenthal, minority stockholder of Carib Syndicate, Ltd., for a court order voiding the action of stockholders in approving on Nov. 25 the sale for $2,000,000 of Carib's 21 per cent interest in Colombian Petroleum Company, holder of the Barco oil concession in Colombia.

Charles T. Mattmann of Forest Hills and the Peddie School and Robert A. Low of New York City and the Choate School yesterday provided the only real drama that has developed to date in the junior national indoor tennis championships at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 30 (AP). -- Capturing one of the richest plums of the season at Santa Anita Park. Some Devil won the $10,000 added California Breeders' Championship today on a rain-soaked track.

Gifts from foundations, totaling $17,250, were received yesterday by the United Hospital Fund campaign committee, which is seeking a minimum of $2,881,644 for eighty-eight voluntary hospitals of the city, it was announced last night by Stuart M. Crocker, chairman of the drive.

A resolution embodying the establishment of a board of religion on each college campus to "coordinate and integrate the religious life of the college" through cooperation with local churches was adopted yesterday at the twelfth annual conference of the National Student Federation of America at the Hotel Victoria.
VATICAN CITY, Dec. 30. -- Pope Pius received another sedative last night from Dr. Amanti Milani, his physician, and enjoyed several hours of profound, restful sleep for a second successive night.

FREDERICK, Md., Dec. 30. -- The number of known chemical elements on the sun has been increased to sixty-one with the identification of three new ones during the year, Dr. Charlotte E. Moore, of Princeton University, told members of the American Astronomical Society, at Hood College today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30. -- Wheat made a tame start and a strong finish on the Board of Trade here today. The close was at the top, with net gains of 3/4 to 1 cent a bushel, with the May showing the most strength. Trading was of a pro-holiday character and part of the strength was due more to lack of offerings rather than aggressive buying.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30. -- Dr. Vladlmir N. Ipatyeff, 69 years old, at one time a general in the Czar's army and formerly a member of Soviet Commissariat for Industry, said today in regard to his expulsion from the Russian Academy of Sciences:
BERLIN, Dec. 30. -- The German cruiser Koenigsberg, stationed before Bilbao, Spain, now has been reinforced by the cruiser Karlsruhe. A German destroyer is also standing by.

Completing a record-breaking year of sales, Merck Co., manufacturing chemists, Rahway, N.J., will launch a more extensive advertising campaign in 1937. The new campaign will cover a variety of fields, such as pharmaceutical, medical, dental, photographic, agricultural and industrial.

Sales of six properties In Manhattan, the Bronx and Westchester County, all assets of title and mortgage guaranty companies in rehabilitation, were announced yesterday by the State Insurance Department.

The total volume of production and trade in this country in 1936 was about 15 per cent above that of 1935, according to a preliminary compilation by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, published in the bank's monthly review, issued yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 30. -- A plea for a "practical" code of ethics, created out of sound institutions and designed to permit men to fulfill a normal life cycle, to reach maturity, to perpetuate the species and to continue their life processes until death comes, was made today before the eastern division of the American Philosophical Association by Professor Harold C. Brown of Stanford.

Jean de Letrez's distinctly post-bellum farce, "Bichon," is very amusing. It was first put on at the Michodiere, Paris, five years ago and is still there, while several companies have been operating it in the provinces. Last evening, as it was presented by The French Theatre of New York, at the Barbizon-Plaza Theatre, a New York audience heartily laughed over it -- their glee found expression in numerous curtain calls.

Although no official figures were revealed, it is understood the terms of the deal are essentially the same as when announced by Stoneham the day previous, only to be denied in toto some hours later by Cambria in a spirited broadcast out of Baltimore.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- The Japanese Government has refused to permit two of its naval officers to give testimony, through the medium of letters rogatory, in the espionage trial of former Lieut. Commander John S. Farnsworth, it was revealed today in the Federal District Court.
" I see by the papers," said the Carpenter to the Walrus, "that the two of us have been going in for adventures of an astonishing cruelty."

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 30. -- Labor troubles at General Motors plants alarmed Connecticut manufacturers today. One member of the Manufacturers Association said that several hundred Connecticut factories, some vital to the prosperity of their localities, would be affected in the event that General Motors canceled orders for automobile parts and machinery.

Arthur Anderson was at sea yesterday and there did not seem to be much any one could do about it, although messages flew in a constant stream between his ship and shore points along the Atlantic Coast. The 13-year-old boy left his home in Saugus, Mass., on Tuesday and apparently secreted himself on the Norwegian tanker Beaulieu just before she put to sea for Tampico, Mexico.

HAVAHA, Dec. 30. -- In its third and most decisive victory of the basketball series in the Cuban Sports Festival Week, Columbia tonight rolled up a score of 52 -- 22 against the Athletic Club of Cuba on the Vedado Tennis Club court.

Bonds advanced briskly yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange under the leadership of second grade railroad issues. Virtually all groups participated in the upswing, which was the broadest and most extensive recorded in several weeks. There was little change in the trading pace as total transactions amounted to $17,773,300, compared to $18,041,700 on Tuesday.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 30 (AP). -- Wyndham Mortimer, international vice president of the United Automobile Workers of America, in charge of the Fisher Body Company employes' strike, said today that the union "must make common cause with the glass workers, who already have tied up the automobile manufacturers."
PHILADELPHIA, Dee. 30. -- Miss Anne W. Leisenring was presented to society tonight at a ball which her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Leisenring, gave at the Bellevue Stratford.

Jesse Owens lost his only major race of 1936 yesterday. Glenn Morris, the Olympic decathlon champion, beat out the mighty Brown Bombshell as the year's outstanding amateur performer and thus won the James E. Sullivan Trophy. This award is presented by the Amateur Athletic Union to the athlete who, by his performance, example and influence as an amateur and a man, has done the most during the past year to advance the cause of sportsmanship.
The police acted yesterday afternoon to break up the picketing activities of striking seamen in lower Manhattan and Jersey City but casualties were limited to minor bruises, and no arrests were made.

The American Power and Light Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended on Nov. 30 a consolidated net income of $10,495,730, which was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 28 cents a share on 3,013,813 common shares.

The stock market rallied yesterday on a broad front as did the bond market, while the tone in the various commodities ranged from firm to weak. In the share market, leading issues recovered 1 to 4 points on the day, with the result that THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks jumped 3 full points to 135.90, or the widest gain that this index has made in a single day since June 8, 1934.

Certain students of modern trends have ventured the opinion that there is really no possibility of another worldwide conflict because the means now available for conducting warfare are potentially so devastating that no responsible parties would dare to invoke them.
PARIS, Dec. 30. -- The Cabinet for the first time ordered striking workers ejected from occupied factories today in the food strike and its action enabled a compromise in the Senate.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Dec. 30. -- A sharp attack on what he called efforts to tear down established methods of teaching was made by Dr. Carleton Brown of New York University in an address before the convention of the Modern Language Association of America here today.

SEATTLE, Dec. 30. -- After a day of conflicting rumors, there is tonight no clue to the whereabouts of Charles Mattson, 10 years old, the kidnapped son of Dr. and Mrs. William W. Mattson, the certain identity of his captor or the status of ransom negotiations.

RYE, N.Y., Dec. 30. -- The Williams College hockey team opened its annual metropolitan two-game stand tonight by vanquishing the Colgate University six, 4 -- 0, before another capacity crowd at the Playland rink.

The issuance by the State Department of a license for the shipping to Bilbao of $2,777,000 worth of American aeronautical equipment is a direct challenge to the ideal behind the Neutrality Law as well as a test of its practicability.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- As the first of a series of moves toward reorganization of the agricultural arm of the government, President Roosevelt is expected to announce soon the appointment of M.L. Wilson as Under-Secretary of Agriculture, succeeding Dr. Rexford Guy Tugwell, and the appointment of Harry L. Brown, of Georgia, as assistant secretary, replacing Mr. Wilson.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- An application of the Texas Utilities Company for approval of the acquisition of substantially all assets of the New Mexico Utilities Company, both subsidiaries of the Community Power and Light Company, a registered holding company, has been granted by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30 (AP). -- Louisiana State's football Tigers were favored today to defeat the Bronchos of Santa Clara in the Sugar Bowl New Year's Day.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Dec. 30. -- In a statement appearing in the leading newspapers here, Sir Henri Deterding, chairman of the Royal Dutch Petroleum Company, explains his plan to purchase about 10,000,000 guilders' worth of Netherland cattle and agricultural products for the German food supply.

The Marine Midland Trust Company has been appointed liquidating agent of the Associated Rayon Corporation. Liquidating agent's certificates will be delivered for fractions of shares of underlying stocks.

Judge Goldstein in General Sessions yesterday sentenced Frank Hennessy, 37 years old, a WPA investigator assigned to the hospitals department, to a term of six months in the workhouse on his guilty plea admitting the theft of $62 from Miss Pauline Boppo of 260 Seaman Avenue.

J. Frederick Talcott, president of James Talcott, Inc., was host at a luncheon yesterday at the Union. League Club to the corporation's executives, sales managers and representatives from associated and correspondent companies in New York, Boston, Chicago and other cities.

LONDON, Dec. 30. -- The Duke of Windsor still has a strong hold on the affections of the British people if the applause that greeted the showing of his picture in a newsreel review of the year in one of London's biggest movie houses may be taken to mean anything.

As anticipated, sales of stock for cash, to complete deliveries this year for income-tax purposes, were extremely heavy yesterday. They were concentrated chiefly in issues which have done rather poorly this year and in which holders therefore would be able to establish larger losses.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- The Soviet Ambassador and Mrs. Troyanovsky were among the guests at a dinner given tonight in honor of Joseph E. Davies, newly appointed Ambassador to the U.S.S.R., and Mrs. Davies. The party was attended by 150 men and women prominent in official life at the capital.

The Rutland Railroad announced yesterday a plan by which interest paid on its bonds in the next four years would be reduced substantially. In accordance with the plan, the company will pay one-half of the interest due tomorrow on its three bond issues only to holders who assent to the adjustment.

Personally subscribing to $100,000 of the New York World's Fair 4 per cent debentures, James Speyer, senior partner of Speyer Co., expressed the hope yesterday that the exposition would help to dissipate some of the "unnecessary suspicion and mistrust" resulting from lack of adequate personal contact between Washington and New York, the nation's financial center.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 30 (AP). -- Dr. Arthur P. Coleman, 84-year-old Professor Emeritus of the University of Toronto, tonight became the ninth recipient of the Penrose Medal of the Geological Society of America.

Net profit of the Black Decker Manufacturing Company and subsidiaries, not including one in Australia, amounted to $898,240 for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30. The profit, which was after deducting depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes and other charges, equaled $2.74 each on 298,354 no par shares of common stock, after dividend requirements on the 8 per cent preferred.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Dec. 30. -- Assistant Secretary of State Sumner Welles of the United States began a series of conversations today with Finance Minister Arthur de Souza Costa on Brazilian-American trade relations.
The Academy of American Poets announced yesterday a "special prefatory award" of $5,000 to Edwin Markham for high merit and distinguished service in poetry over a long period of years.

LONDON, Dec. 30. -- A spurt in Rolls-Royce shares followed the news today that the directors of that company had decided to distribute a stock dividend of 25 per cent. Although some such bonus had been expected, this confirmation of the rumors had an immediate effect on the company's shares, which rose more than 3s.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 30. -- Dr. Dumas Malone, editor of the American Dictionary of Biography until its completion, in a speech tonight at the annual dinner of the American Historical Association discussed briefly the ten-year task of gathering data and editing this twenty-volume work.

DANZIG. Dec. 30. -- More arrests among Storm Troops and other members of the National Socialist party have been made in the last few days following the Christmas arrests of Nazi groups here. Altogether about eighty are detained. The utmost secrecy is maintained by the authorities about the arrests and the local press is not allowed to give the details.

SUFFERN, N.Y., Dec. 30. -- Due to the number of accidents in the air in the past month, Senator Copeland, chairman of the committee investigating air safety, said here today that he thought his committee should hold further hearings as soon as Congress convenes, before presenting its final report.

NANKING, Thursday, Dec. 31. -- A report widely circulated in Nanking and receiving a certain amount of credence in embassy circles says that while Chiang Kai-shek was imprisoned at Sian, General Cho Wen-lai, chairman of the Military Affairs Commission of the Chinese Communist armies, paid him three visits during which the two held long conferences.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30. -- An active demand for hogs developed here today as reports of snowstorms and floods in parts of Iowa influenced the views of buyers. Prices were unchanged to 10 cents a hundreds weight higher. Leading packers were in the market for supplies and shippers were too.

BERLIN, Dec. 30. -- The coming marriage of Princess Juliana of the Netherlands to Prince Bernhard zu Lippe-Biesterfeld and the cordial reception given by the Netherlanders to their future Queen's German fiance apparently aroused anticipations in National Socialist quarters which are now being rudely disturbed by events in the Netherlands.
Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Edward Hasler gave a dance last night in Viennese Roof of the St. Regis to introduce to society their daughters, the Misses Audrey and Shirley Hasler.

Twenty-eight deaths were caused directly by injuries suffered in football games in 1936, according to the sixth annual survey made by Professor Floyd H. Eastwood of New York University. This total was one fewer than in 1935.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- Initial steps were taken by the administration today at a White House conference toward framing discretionary neutrality legislation for prompt passage by Congress for application in connection with the civil war in Spain.

Rookies of the New York Fire Department -- 238 who will start training and fifty-nine who will be admitted to the uniformed force tomorrow -- were warned yesterday by Mayor La Guardia against being victimized by persons who may offer to get them certain assignments.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 30. -- Duchess Reigh, a gray 2-year-old daughter of Reigh Count-Valenciennes, owned by Horton Donnelly, today electrified a big crowd by winning the fourth race and paying the longest price thus far of the Tropical Park meeting, $159.70 for $2 in the mutuels.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 30 (AP). -- Ernest T. Weir, chairman of the $180,000,000 National Steel Corporation, asserted today that the issue in the John L. Lewis unionization drive was not one of wages and hours of work but whether industrial workers were to be dominated "by a ring of labor-politicians."

When funeral services for Mrs. George L.
