Kobbe, philanthropist and a director of the Humane Society of New York, are held this afternoon at 1 o'clock there will be scores of friends and relatives attending, but her best friend of all will be paying silent tribute from a taxicab outside, banned from the church because he is a dog.

By the narrowest of margins, the noted little dun mare. Pretty Good, owned and ridden by Patrick J. McDermott of Locust Valley, L.I., last evening captured the jumping championship of the two-day horse show in the arena of the Riding and Polo Club in West Sixty-sixth Street.
Housing properties in the Bronx and Manhattan formed the bulk of the realty turnover reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- Conflicting views toward the Copeland-Bland Ship Subsidy Act were presented by two seaman's organizations at the White House today for the consideration of President Roosevelt. There was no comment from the President.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 30. -- A drive to force the State to double the amount and number of scholarships offered students was ordered by the convention of the Associated Academic Principals of the State of New York as it ended its annual three-day holiday conference here today.

LONDON, Dec. 30. -- Two treaties that during the last fourteen years have put a brake on the expansion of naval armaments come to an end at midnight tomorrow. After that the lid will be off, for the London treaty of 1936, not yet ratified and possibly doomed to be ineffective, imposes no quantitative check.

Michael C. Bouvier, who at his death on July 29, 1935, was senior holder of a seat on the New York Stock Exchange and dean of Wall Street brokers, left an estate of $3,213,057 gross and $2,987,152 net, it was shown in the transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday.

YONKERS, N. Y., Dec. 30. -- An arson service that promised "marvelous results," showed actual samples, used an exclusive embalming fluid process and even arranged alibis was revealed here today by District Attorney Walter A. Ferris.

HASTINGS, England, Dec. 30. -- Maintaining the invincible form which recalls his success in capturing first prize here a year ago, Reuben Fine of New York today scored his third consecutive victory in the international masters' tournament at the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club.

LIFE may be, as the lyric writers would have us believe, just a bowl of cherries, but football certainly has developed into bowls of various descriptions. Tomorrow they all will see the light of day together. There will be the Rose Bowl, the Sugar Bowl, the Orange Bowl, the Cotton Bowl and the Havana festival. (How in the world did they ever miss naming that the Rum Punch Bowl, anyway?)

Hugh Brown, master of the Southern Sword, a vessel which carried 1,600 cases of grain alcohol into this port last March 17, was sentenced to a year and a day in prison yesterday by Federal Judge Grover M. Moscowitz.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the week-end, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local private and public elementary and high schools:
LONDON, Dec. 30. -- An influenza epidemic is sweeping the European Continent and the British Isles.

Two operas of popular appeal held the enthusiastic attention of large audiences yesterday at the Hippodrome. In the afternoon Alfredo Salmaggi and his company presented "Haensel und Gretel" before 3,600 persons, mainly children, and in the evening "Carmen" was the production before 2,500 persons.

Transoceanic radio facsimile entered a new phase of commercial application yesterday, when, for the first time, plans for the foundation of a building were speeded across the Atlantic from New York to Europe over short-waves.

VIENNA, Austria, Dec. 30. -- A Belgrade dispatch says the German commercial debt to Yugoslavia resulting from the recent trade agreement amounted at mid-December to more than $80,000,000, it is revealed by the Politika, which has close relations with the government.
GENEVA, Dec. 30. -- The Spanish Government has asked the League of Nations to help it against the danger of epidemic.

MADRID, Dec. 30. -- The United States State Department's permission to export arms to the Spanish Government came like "a light through the clouds" as the newspaper Politica stated today. After an uninterrupted series of discouragements in the international field it is held this development opens possibilities which are considered more important morally than materially.

The President's statement at his press conference on Tuesday that he believes something more should be done by the Government to improve labor standards ought to surprise no one. In the last speech of his campaign for re-election he said, with obvious sincerity, that he had "just begun to fight" for measures "to reduce hours "that are overlong, to increase wages "that spell starvation, to end the labor "of children."

With eviction day for hundreds of East Side tenement dwellers coming tomorrow, the New York City Housing Authority completed its hearings yesterday on the emergency situation caused by the decision of landlords to order buildings vacated Jan. 1 rather than to spend the money to bring them within the standards of the Multiple Dwellings Law.

The wholesale value of motor vehicles and such accessory products as tires and other equipment, replacement parts and service goods manufactured in the United States and Canada during 1936 totals about $3,626,612,000, according to the estimate of the Automobile Manufacturers Association, made public yesterday in a preliminary issue of "Facts and Figures."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, delving today into the affairs of the Liberty Share Corporation, sponsored by the Liberty Bank of Buffalo, disclosed losses totaling $5,949,000 in trading accounts, on nearly $500,000 more than the original capitalization of the trust.

After having made one false start for which, however, nobody was penalized, the Giants ventured another noble attempt yesterday to embark upon the business of chain-store baseball. This time the belief is they have made it.
Two days before the end of the old year, the Neediest Cases Fund rose yesterday to $257,154.87, exceeding last year's final total and reaching its highest mark since 1932.

A warning that professional gambling on college football games constituted a serious menace was issued yesterday at the closing meeting of the American Football Coaches Association. It decided to make an investigation of the situation and recommend what steps should be taken in order to curb possible ill-effects of wagering.
The Committee on Securities of the New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday the following rulings:

WALDO, Ark., Dec. 30 (AP). -- Travis Jackson, veteran Giant third baseman, said tonight that he hadn't "come to any agreement" on an offer from President Horace Stoneham to take over the managership of the Jersey City club.

Steel companies will enter 1937 with unfilled orders sufficiently large in some cases to maintain production throughout the first quarter of the year at approximately the present rate, 79 1/2 per cent of capacity, the magazine Iron Age states in its weekly review of the industry.
" Merchant's" letter is interesting and valuable. However, one or two points that it raises need further discussion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- The proposed conference of airline operators, Federal officials and others charged with responsibility of operating aircraft will be called for between Jan. 10 and 15, J. Monroe Johnson, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, said today.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 30. -- The City Commission voted today, after eighteen months' negotiating, to lease eighteen acres at Port of Newark to Swift Co. for fifty years so that a $3,000,000 vegetable shortening and edible oil plant might be built.

Japanese yen and German registered marks continued to decline in the foreign exchange market yesterday, following their sudden weakness on Tuesday. The yen dropped to 28.21 cents, a new low for this year, and closed at 28.23 cents, off 9 points.
GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Dec. 30. -- Andre Roosevelt made the first air plane flight over the 20,700-foot volcano of Chimborazo today and succeeded in taking motion pictures of the crater.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 30. -- The retirement of Sebastian S. Kresge as president of the Kresge Department Store here and the election of Hugh E. Barnes to succeed him was announced today. The board of directors has elected Mr. Kresge its chairman.

It would be naive to take either Japanese or Chinese political gestures literally. Two such moves, reported in yesterday's papers, should be interpreted in reverse. CHIANG KAI-SHEK twice formally resigned, confident that his withdrawal would not be permitted. The Kwantung high command in Manchuria announced that, "true to the spirit of Bushido," it shares the sorrows of neighboring China and offers its sincere cooperation.

Stanford University's fine basketball team finally put an end to Long Island University's long string of victories last night with a 45-to-31 triumph in the second game of the double-header at Madison Square Garden. In the opening contest Georgetown made it a clean sweep for the visiting teams by scoring over New York University, 46 to 40.

Mrs. E. Eldridge Thomas gave a luncheon yesterday in the Terrace Room of the Plaza for her daughter, Miss Virginia E. Thomas, later taking her guests to the matinee performance of "White Horse Inn" at the Center Theatre. Also in the party were the Misses Adelaide McAlpin, Emilie Iselin, Charlotte Binger, Mary Virginia Moore, Charlotte Whitman, Mary Edgar Riley, Edith Beadleston, Julia Richmond, Jane Emmet, Dorothy Given, Annette Locke and Allyne Gade.

Alfred E. Smith arrived at his office in the Empire State Building yesterday morning wearing a dark gray striped suit, a carnation and a brown derby, and equipped with the familiar smile and a fund of jokes, anecdotes and predictions for a new era of normal business conditions.

Bizet's "Carmen" was performed yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of a group of six Near Eastern colleges, with Gertrud Wettergren in the title role, and the cast above listed. The opera, as is usual, attracted a very large audience, and a delighted one.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 30. -- Southern California's "ideal" weather took another holiday today and it began to appear that the Washington-Pittsburgh battle in the Rose Bowl New Year's Day may be played under dripping skies.

Miss Mildred Stewart, women's intercollegiate fencing titleholder from Hunter, captured the gold medal in the Christmas invitation tournament for the second successive year at the Hunter strips last night.

The New York Stock Exchange obtained yesterday an order which may delay the payment of $40,836 in full restitution to the customers of the permanently enjoined German-American Securities Company, as directed by Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook on Dec. 19.
Another increase in the number of mild influenza cases was reported yesterday by the Department of Health, and it was said the increasing prevalence will continue for about ten days.

In a far-reaching decision yesterday, upholding the necessity of labor agreements to cover the gap left by the ending of NRA, Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook ordered two affiliated dress companies to abide by an agreement with garment workers' unions and move back to New York City machinery they had taken to Arch-bald, Pa.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30. -- Re-definition of the Constitution to remove the Supreme Court's interference with the nation's efforts to cope with modern economic and social needs was urged today by Donald R. Richberg, former Chief of the NRA, and Lloyd K. Garrison, dean of the University of Wisconsin Law School, in addresses before a joint meeting of the American Political Science Association and the American Association for Labor Legislation.

The New York Rangers will celebrate New Year's Eve by tackling the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. Both sextets, together with the Detroit Red Wings, are in the thick of the fight for first place in the American group of the league, and a torrid battle is expected.

Retail package deliveries for the week ended Dec. 26, covering the peak days of Christmas shopping, showed an increase of 11 per cent over the comparative 1935 week, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The week this year included Monday through Saturday, while, to make accurate comparison, the days included in the 1935 week were Friday through Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP). -- While hailing business recovery "on all fronts" during 1936, Secretary Roper warned today that "the importance of lingering aspects of the depression" should not be underestimated.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP). -- Thirty-five States have enacted unemployment insurance laws, the Social Security Board reported today, with a possibility that Delaware would join the procession before the year ends.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Dec. 31. -- Cash indemnity payments totaling nearly 130,000 Chinese dollars figure prominently in the final amicable settlement of the Chengtu and Pakhoi incidents, involving the murders of Japanese by Chinese mobs. Other considerations are: First, an official apology by the Chinese Government; second, punishment of the responsible officials; third, punishment of those guilty of the murders.

Although Delibes's "Lakme" concerns itself with an East Indian subject, its musical setting, for all of its quasi-Oriental atmosphere, is Gallic to the core. Only when given with the utmost refinement of style and full emphasis on the sensuousness and exoticism of the score, can the true character of the work make itself evident.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 30. -- Maxwell Anderson's play, "High Tor," was presented for the first time on any stage at the Hanna Theatre this evening before an approving audience. Burgess Meredith, the featured player, and Peggy Ashcroft, British actress making her first appearance in the United States, both had enthusiastic receptions.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 30. -- Robert Donat's appearance for RKO in "Clementina" will be delayed beyond the scheduled starting date of March 1 because of his assignment today to appear with Merle Oberon under the Alexander Korda banner in "Divorce of Lady X."

BROOKLINE, Mass., Dec. 30. -- Miss Helen Bernhard, 15-year-old New York City star, and Miss Hope Knowles of Philadelphia reached the final of the national junior girls' singles tennis tournament on the covered courts of the Longwood Cricket Club today.

MOSCOW, Dec. 30. -- The Soviet Government, through Foreign Commissar Maxim Litvinoff, has accepted the suggestion of the French and British Governments for the prohibition of further permits for foreign "volunteers" for Spain, agreeing with the French and British view that the present situation endangers European peace.
SHANGHAI, Thursday, Dec. 31. -- When the special military tribunal tries Chang Hsueh-liang this morning, it is expected that severe punishment wil be ordered after a brief hearing.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 30 (AP). -- The Cleveland Plain Dealer said John L. Lewis put the Committee for Industrial Organization tonight squarely behind the United Automobile Workers in Cleveland, Kansas City, Atlanta and Flint, Mich., who are coming to grips with General Motors Corporation.

Birth control in its positive and negative aspects was discussed in papers presented at the closing day's sessions of the Conference on Contraceptive Research and Clinical Practice at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday. The conference was attended by 200 physicians, nurses and social workers.

Frank J. Taylor, Controller of this city, issued yesterday a call for bids for a new issue of $50,000,000 of city corporate stock, award of which will be made on Jan. 12. The corporate stock will be dated Jan. 1, 1937, and mature on Jan. 1, 1977.

Another challenge for the Eastern Championship Ice Boat Pennant of America, the new open trophy offered by the Rumson Country Club Ice Boat Club of Rumson, N.J., is expected to be issued within a few days by Frank E. Campbell of Larchmont, N.Y.

PARIS, Dec. 30. -- Semi-official information received here from Berlin dispels any lingering doubt about Chancellor Hitler's attitude toward the Franco-British proposals concerning a ban upon volunteers in the Spanish civil war.
Watch night services will be held in virtually all the leading churches in mid-Manhattan and many will take place in other parts of the city.
New York will stage a New Year's party tonight which the police expect to be the biggest in its history. The cost may run well above $10,000,000.

Dr. FRANCIS GREENWOOD PEABODY, dead at 89, had perhaps outlived his modest fame as he had his Harvard classmates, among whom were FRANK MILLET, Dr. WILLIAM T. BULL and HENRY HOWE, once the chief American metallurgist. He used to refer humorously to the time when at baseball dinners he was honored as "the first man "who ever went to the bat against "Yale."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- A resolution asking an increase to $25,000,000 of funds provided by the Social Security Act for health aid in the States was adopted by the Conference on Venereal Control Work as it closed its sessions here today. It was suggested that a large part of this money be used in State campaigns against venereal diseases.

Approximately 130,000 babies in the United States will die during 1937 in the first year of their life, according to the recent trend in the mortality rate, it was said yesterday by George J. Hecht, publisher of The Parents Magazine. Declaring that a large number of these deaths could be prevented, he urged wider dissemination among parents of scientific information about child care.

LONDON, Dec. 30 (AP). -- A seventy-five-year oil concession opening 270,000 square miles of virgin territory in Afghanistan has been awarded to an American firm, the Inland Exploration Company of New York, high diplomatic circles said today.
Five policemen, all of whom have been with the force ten months, resigned yesterday to be transferred to the Fire Department.

William Belcher Whitney, lawyer specializing in copyright law, a student and collector of Tibetan Lamaist images, who died on Dec. 8, named educational and other institutions among his legatees and bequeathed his residuary estate to his brother, Edward S. Whitney of 28 South Mountain Avenue, Montclair, N.J.

MOSCOW, Dec. 30. -- The All-Union Academy of Sciences has expelled two members for failing to return to Russia after going on missions abroad. One is Dr. Vladimir N. Ipatyeff, who is now employed in America by the Universal Oil Company.

Jumping over a fence to get away from two policemen, one of whom was shooting at him, a 19-year-old fugitive led one of his pursuers to a fall of about sixty feet yesterday afternoon. The fence, about four and a half feet high, concealed a drop of about sixty feet.

BERLIN, Dec. 30. -- Colonel General Hans von Seeckt, founder of the post war German Army, was buried in military state today with the assistance of all the highest government officials and the Reich's armed forces.

A demand that the board of directors of the Merchants Ladies Garment Association, comprising coat and suit jobbers, be given a mandate to effectuate a change to a net basis for selling terms in the coat and suit industry, featured a membership meeting of the organization at the Hotel Governor Clinton yesterday.

Light rains began falling early last night after a heavy mist and fog had obscured the sun all yesterday and had disrupted shipping and flying schedules. All flights from Newark Airport were canceled last night when visibility and ceiling dropped to zero soon after sundown.

Postal receipts for the calendar year ending last midnight at the New York postoffice, which totaled $73,285,000, showed the largest increase for any single year in the history of the departments of Manhattan and the Bronx, according to Postmaster Albert Goldman.
A committee appointed by the 1936 Legislature to investigate gasoline prices prepared today to inquire into increases put in effect this week in the State.

On his arrival tonight from the football coaches' conference in New York, Dan Jessee, head baseball and football coach at Trinity, confirmed reports that he will stay at Trinity at least another year.

The hog market closed today at the highest level of the Winter season, prices advancing 15 to 25 cents as the result of general buying. The top moved up 20 cents to $10.70 a hundredweight, while the day's average was 20 cents higher at $10.50.

TACOMA, Wash., Dec. 31.--Dr. William W. Mattson has received a communication from the kidnapper of his 10-year-old son, Charles, saying the boy is safe, it was declared today by a source believed to be trustworthy.
With hotels and night clubs sold out, Philadelphians joined tonight in the most unrestrained New Year's Eve celebration since before the depression.
Alfredo Salmaggi and his company will give a double offering of "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" tonight at the Hippodrome.

The General Theatres Equipment Corporation announced yesterday that it had repaid a $2,000,000 loan to the Chase National Bank. This loan, on a 5 per cent note, was convertible into the corporation's 5 per cent debentures, which in turn were convertible into 133,3331-3 shares of capital stock.

Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Worrall Hyde have returned from their wedding trip to Mexico, D. F., and are at the Pierre before going to Greenwich, where they will make their home. Mrs. Hyde is the former Miss Katherine Lauder, daughter of Mrs. George Lauder.

Commodity futures were irregular in fairly light trading in yesterday's abbreviated sessions and gains appeared in most metals, silk, cottonseed, oil, cocoa and sugar while rubber and hides declined. On the cash markets, wheat, rye, cotton, eggs and rubber declined, and corn, oats, copper, lard, tins and wooltops rose.

Discoveries of the structure of molecules, replacing the "naively simple conceptions" which prevailed only a few years ago, were discussed here today at the opening of a three-day symposium of the Division of Physical and Inorganic Chemistry of the American Chemical Society.

DURING the past twelve months our government has continued to pursue a foreign policy the central objective of which is the promotion of peace, progress and prosperity. We have sought in every practicable way to improve the conditions which are fundamental to the attainment of this objective-a high level of international morality, integrity of international agreements, justice and fair dealing in the relations among nations and liberal economic practices.

The city is entering the new year without a balanced budget and with an indefinite financial program. In the absence of an official budget, City Controller Robert C. White is unable to open the books to make payments of any kind.

Otto H. Kahn, banker and patron of the arts, left a net taxable estate of only $3,970,869 when he died on March 29, 1934, it was revealed yesterday when the transfer tax appraisal was filed in Surrogate's Court by Deputy Tax Commissioner Jacob Manicoff.

Influenza and injuries have taken a heavy toll among.English soccer players this week and managers of several clubs, particularly northern squads that figure in holiday games tomorrow, are-puzzling how to juggle their forces into formidable elevens.

An unusually warm December ended yesterday with a high temperature that was within one degree of the record for the last day of the year. The record was set in 1932, when the temperature rose to 61 degrees.
Mrs. W. Atlee Burpee of Ford Hook gave a dance for 500 tonight at the Barclay for her debutante granddaughter, Miss Jeannetta Murray Burpee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Atlee Burpee Jr.
Coaches Maurice (Clipper) Smith of Villanova and Jack Meagher of Auburn tucked their football charges in bed early tonight and announced they were ready for tomorrow's "battle of the palms."

Dividend payments voted last month, while only slightly more than half of the record total ordered in November, were the largest for a December in six years. Shareholders were voted $474,924,217 by 1,614 companies, compared with $883,202,332 for 1,127 companies
The Popolo d'Italia, Premier Mussolini's personal newspaper, seizes the occasion offered by anti-Jewish articles appearing in the Paris Gringoire to print a strongly worded article against Jews.
A published report concerning the terms of a French loan to Poland was denied tonight by the Polish Embassy.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE NEW. YORK TIMES of Dec. 29, E. Gatewood poses the question: "Why should the city, State or nation, separately or in combination, spend billions of dollars raising the slums and building better housing for the poor?"

Current American writing was criticized sharply by Ellen Glasgow in a paper read today before the final session of the Modern Language Association's annual convention. The author was unable to attend the meeting at the University of Richmond because of a slight indisposition, but her paper was read by Allen Tate, Tennessee poet.

Edward A. Stevenson, graduate of Yale University, class of '88, and president of the Plainfield Yale Club for many years, died today at the home here of his son, Gordon Stevenson. He was born in New York and was 69 years old.

It was stated on excellent authority that the Serbian Patriarch threatened Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch and all other Orthodox members of the Cabinet and Parliament who vote for ratification of the concordat with the Vatican with excommunication.

Announcement was made here today of the establishment of the Johnson-New Brunswick Foundation and the gift by that organization of 130 acres of land in Highland Park and Pisoataway Township to Middlesex County for use as a county park.

Bold Venture, 1936 winner of the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness and one of the horses expected to have a major influence in the handicap division this year, will not race again. This was learned yesterday through his owner,
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling: Gold coin and bullion..decreased [pound]166,000 Reserve in banking

The police of Jersey City met striking seamen yesterday with tear gas, a machine gun and a special type of riot club that consisted of two-foot pieces of rubber hose, but after a hectic day of pushing and mauling found there had been no actual need for weapons.

A new symphony of a refreshingly unconventional nature, by Anis Fuliehan, was given its first performance anywhere by John Barbirolli and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. At the close of the performance, to applause long and loud, the composer bowed from the platform.

A conversation covering thirtyeight phonograph records was being transcribed today for presentation by District Attorney Walter Ferris next Monday to the Westchester grand jury as evidence against four men suspected of burning buildings worth $400,000 in Westchester County and Connecticut.
The train crew and eighty-seven passengers escaped injury this morning when the locomotive and six baggage, mail and express cars of a Chicago-Montreal passenger train were derailed here.
William Henry Lloyd, lawyer and educator, an authority on jurisprudence, died today at his home here after a stroke of apoplexy. He was 66 years old.
Frank J. Marshall, retired United States chess champion, yesterday made his debut as a competitor in the annual tournament for the championship of the Marshall Club, which was named after him.

Stocks closed year irregularly, with leading issues heavy; day's turnover, 1,760,305 shares. United States Government, South American and second-grade rails higher, other bonds steady but mixed; transactions, $15,437,200.

The New York Rovers will endeavor to extend one of the best hockey winning streaks of the current season when they tackle the Pittsburgh Yellow Jackets in a regular Eastern Amateur League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. The New York skaters, who have been playing almost as regularly as the sun rises and sets, have not lost a game since Dec. 19.
Stockholders in the $25,000,000 Atlantic Life Insurance Company of Richmond were invited today to sell their holdings at $175 a share to the Bankers National Investing Corporation of Wilmington, Del.

What seems to be the last decisive battle of Zionism against the reported intention to give to the Palestine mandate granted to Great Britain for the express purpose of establishing a Jewish national home, a new interpretation favoring Arab opponents was waged at tonight's session of the British Royal Commission by Leonard Stein, local adviser to the Jewish agency in London.
Captain and Mrs. Willis Gemmill Mitchell entertained at their home, 126 East Sixtieth Street, last night at a buffet supper in honor of their daughter, Miss Helen Annette Mitchell.
Five police sergeants were promoted to lieutenants yesterday afternoon in a ceremony at police headquarters. Chief Inspector John J. Seery and Chief Clerk Vincent J. Finn officiated.
M. W. Clement, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, said today in a year-end statement:
Although bank clearings for the five days ended on Wednesday fell short of the total in the full week preceding, they were substantially larger than in the corresponding period a year ago.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Trading was fair to slow. Veal, calf and lamb prices were strong to higher and other classes traefa meats mostly unchanged. Kosher beef opened steady, lamb about $1.00 higher, veal and calf mostly $1.00$2.00 higher.

Sales of apartment houses in Manhattan and the Bronx featured realty trading yesterday, the last day of the year. Banks figured as sellers in some of the deals. Julius Kahan, operator, who bought an apartment house in in Gerard Avenue on Wednesday, added to his Bronx holdings yesterday by purchasing the six-story elevator building at 1,140-50 Anderson Avenue.

Almost 100 conventions and trade exhibitions will be held in New York City during January, according to the monthly convention list issued yesterday by John R. Young, manager of the convention bureau of the Merchants Association of New York.

Acting on recommendations from the commission on international relations, the National Student Federation of America at its plenary session yesterday at the Hotel Victoria, adopted a resolution condemning "loyalty oaths, seditious bills and Red riders in States where they exist."
MANHATTAN DEUTSCH, HEYMAN (Nov. 11). Estate, $4,000. To Helen Deutsen, daughter, 350 W. 57th St. Martin and Harry Deutsch, sons, executors, 225 W. 86th St., one-third residue each.

An exchange of the last old year messages with various capitals this evening imposes the impression that the corning twelve months will be more than ordinarily important. The very first days of the new year must witness decisions of more than passing significance.
The marriage of Mrs. Martha Nelson Crego of 230 East Forty-eighth Street to Ledyard Heckscher of Bolingbroke, Radnor, Pa., will take place in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church on Jan. 9.
Superior Court Judge Herbert E. Wilson prepared today to file a formal order closing the receivership of the Indiana Railroad and liquidating the system as of Jan. 9.

Elmer Dale Shaffer's 2-year-old bull dog filly, Log, showing the same high brand of speed that marked her galloping victory her other time out at Tropical Park, made a show of ten others of her age today in the San Bias Handican.
After final workouts today the coaches announced the probable line-up for the Orange Bowl game tomorrow between Mississippi State College and Duquesne University.

Herman Livingston, an ardent yachtsman, and a descendant of Robert Livingston, the third and last lord of Livingston Manor, New York, died yesterday morning at his home, Oak Hill, Greendale, N. Y. He was 81 years old and had lived all his life in Greendale,

Miss Marcia Louise Hadzsits, daughter of Dr. George Depue Hadzsits, Professor of Latin at the University of Pennsylvania, and Mrs. Hadzsits, was married this evening to Robert L. Beachboard, son of Mrs. Louise Beachboard, at the home of her parents.

Insurgent leaders indicated they expected reinforcements shortly and would then launch a furious-offensive on Madrid. The Spanish Embassy in Paris likewise forecast a Rebel drive in midJanuary, saying Germany would send possibly "two full divisions" into Spain.

Writing on the thesis that military forces are to keep us out of a war, not to put us into one, Major Gen. Johnson Hagood, retired, is the author of a volume on national defense and foreign policy entitled "We Can Defend America."
The Hun School swimmers of Princeton, N. J., are scheduled to see action in nine meets this season, five of them dual encounters.
The American steamer Extavia sent out an S O S call today, reporting that she was having engine trouble off Casablanca, French Morocco. The salvage ship Geir hurried to the Extavia's assistance.

Burleigh Grimes, new manager of the Dodgers club, disclosed today a plan to tighten major league baseball races. He proposes that all second-division clubs on June 15 be permitted to carry twenty-five players for the remainder of the season-two above the number all teams are now allowed to have after May 15.

After visiting the Valparaiso naval base and warships in the bay, Foreign Minister Jose Carlos Macedo Soares of Brazil said farewell to President Arturo Alessandri at his Summer quarters in Vina del Mar and left Santiago by plane for Brazil.

An increase in the number of cases and deaths from pneumonia and influenza in New York City for the twenty-four-hour period ended at 10 o'clock yesterday morning was reported by the Department of Health.
MANHATTAN ANDERBERG, MARIE L. (Jan. 27, 1934). Gross assets, $7,438; net, a deficit. Satter lee Canfield, attorneys, 49 Wall St. BLOOD, KATHERINE ANTOINETTE (May 29, 1936). Gross asset, $767,359;

More than 200 chemists and physicists met in Frick Chemical Laboratory at Princeton University here today for a three-day symposium on molecular structure, under the auspices of the division of physical and inorganic chemistry of the American Chemical Society.
Mrs. Joan S. Wildberg, long active in Jewish charitable work, died yesterday in her apartment at the Hotel Langdon, 2 East Fiftysixth Street, of a heart attack. She was 56 years old.

Although Britain's revenue increased by [pound]7,369,447 to a total of [pound]443,293,814 in the first nine months of the financial year ended tonight, her ordinary expenditures mounted by [pound]32,198,035, to a total of [pound]582,148,067.

Calmly asserting that his "friend" Mr. Morgenthau would straighten out everything, Westy Egmont or Egmont Ruschke, who claims descent from the Count Egmont immortalized by Goethe and Beethoven, was charged yesterday with having forged the name of Secretary Henry Morgenthau Jr. to a false $500,000 contract to publish a history of the Red Cross.
On the eve of his third inauguration as Chief Executive of the State, Governor Lehman announced this afternoon that he had reappointed all the members of his present Cabinet.

The starting gun has sounded; the race is on. Last night at midnight the treaties which held naval competition in check since 1922 ceased to be binding. Today, except for the qualitative limitation of the London treaty of 1936, which may never be effective, the naval Powers are free to build what they choose.

Engagement of $3,150,000 gold in England was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This brought to $166,600,000 the total of gold bought in England for shipment to this country since Sept. 26, when the glod-bloc countries devalued their currencies.

J. D. Norris's chestnut colt, Danger Point, 12 to 1 shot, won the $1,200 Midwick Purse at Santa Anita Park today. Turning back a stretch challenge by Lake View, Danger Point ran the six furlongs for 2-year-olds in 1:14.3 over heavy going, beating Lake View by a length.

In accordance with declaration of Dec. 23, 1935, possibly in anticipation of an adverse Supreme Court decision in regard to the AAA, the President begins to liquidate the NRA, directly inapired by the fact that of more than 10,000 manufacturers polled by the National Manufacturers Association 82 per cent had voted against its revival in any form.

Economic recovery must be considered as an accomplished fact, and the nation must now approach the next problem, that of providing a greater amount of economic stability, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of General Motors Corporation, said yesterday in his annual New Year's statement.
A mysterious communication in the form of an anonymous letter, containing what is presumed to be bones, either animal or human, was received at the State House here today.

After temporarily allaying the fears of many tenant families on the lower East Side by assuring them that eviction notices issued against them by savings banks would not be enforced today, Tenement House Commissioner Langdon W. Post made public last night the first of a series of recommendations to Mayor La Guardia for meeting the city's low-rental housing "emergency."

Mrs. Abbott L. Baume, in 135 E. 74th St., through Douglas Gibbons Co.; Cornelius O. McLaughlin, in 308 E. 79th St.; Miss Frieda Sagebiel, in 321 E. 54th St.; Miss Josephine Riley, in 161 W. 54th St.; Miss Othilie Beck, in 116 W. 59th St.; Arthur D. Geissler, in 119 E. 84th St.; Pease Elliman, Inc., brokers.
Promotions The following Battalion Chiefs are hereby promoted to the rank of Deputy Chief, with compensation each at the rate of 6,300 (5,810) per annum:

The Marine Corps issued the following orders for week ended Dec. 29: Lt. Col. H. Schmidt, detail as assistant paymaster extended to include June 27. Capt. H. B. Enyart, Marine Barracks, Washington, D. C., ordered to home on Jan. 1, to retire March 1. 1st Lt. H. I. Larson, orders of Oct. 28 modified; detached San Diego, Calif., to Pensacola, Fla., reporting not later than Jan. 25.

Peter Felice, about 40 years old, husky racketeer, said to have been a beer runner for Jack (Legs) Diamond- for several years of the prohibition era, died early yesterday morning of a bullet wound received in an argument in a lower Harlem beer tavern.

The first tickets to aid the Warm Springs Foundation ever sold on foreign soil were purchased today when Governor Charles F. Hurley, Governorelect of Massachusetts, bought the first ten tickets for the Roosevelt Birthday Ball to be held at the Bermudian Hotel on Jan. 30. The first ticket goes to President Roosevelt and the second ticket to James Roosevelt, with invitations to attend the ball.
Aldermanic President-elect William F. Brunner of Queens will take the oath of office at 1 P. M. today in a ceremony at City Hall.

The marriage of Miss Catherine Dunscomb Ibbotson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward D. D. Ibbotson of this city, to Samuel Douglas Earl, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph D. Earl of Herkimer, took place here this afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church.

The tradition is that this day be dedicated to looking ahead. Close the book of the past. Fix your eyes on the future. Good resolutions and all that. Well, we have no quarrel with the values in this ancient and honorable custom.

The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Dec. 30, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,518,000,000, an increase of $11,000,000, compared with the preceding week and of $24,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in December was slightly less active than in the preceding month, but the largest of any December since 1931. Sales, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, totaled 48,605,047 shares, compared to 50,469,732 in November, and 45,590,420 in December. 1935.
The Court of Appeals will soon review its decision whereby it invalidated the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act, provisions of which have been upheld by the United States Supreme Court.
The Court of Appeals unanimously affirmed today the conviction of Alfred E. Volckmann, who killed 9-year-old Helen Glenn, daughter of a Greenville minister, after an assault.

154th St., 412 W., 20x99.11; Julia Fleischman to Lawyers Trust Co., trustee Julie F. H. Nevins, 160 Broadway; mtg., $13,000 ($14). 2d St., n. s., 149.6 ft. w. of Av. C, 24.9x106; 248 E. 2d St. Corp. to Five Boroughs Coal Co., 1,475 Broadway; mtg., $15,000. 12th St., n. s., 152 ft. w. of 5th Av., 18x. 100.11; 7 W. 112th St. Corp. to same; mtg.. $9,500.

The bond market closed yesterday the most active year since 1934 in a burst of strength which carried virtually all groups to substantially higher levels. Tax-exempt and higher-grade corporate loans advanced to close the year at or near their record high levels, while the secondary and more speculative domestic corporate issues responded to a spirited demand with goodsized gains.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Dec. 31.--A new concept of the structure of the atom, which promises a new vision of reality and a closer unity in man's understanding of nature, was presented here today as a New Year's gift to science at the meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
New members of Congress find a dreary prospect as they arrive in Washington. What is a Congressman without patronage? That prime political crop has been gathered.

Pope Pius passed another fairly good night and slept for several hours uninterruptedly. This is the third successive night he has slept at all for the last week or ten days and the first he has done so without artificial aid.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks 909,000 bales, against 882,000 a week ago, 834,000 two weeks ago, 825,000 three weeks ago and 722,000 a year ago; of which American 341,000 bales, against 334,000 a week ago, 305,000 two weeks ago, 298,000 three weeks ago and 385,000 a year ago.
Four Chicago radio broadcasting stations will pay the Chicago Cubs and White Sox annual fees ranging from $3,000 to $7,500 for the right to describe games over the air in 1937.
Judge John S. Candler, prominent 75-year-old Atlanta capitalist, married his secretary, Miss Martha Erwin, 33, today. It was Judge Candler's third marriage.

The appointment of the Rev. John F. Hurley, formerly a New York resident, as superior of the Jesuit Mission in the Philippines was announced here yesterday by the Rev. Thomas B. Cannon of the Philippine Jesuit Bureau, 51 East Eighty-third Street.

New Year's Eve was celebrated tonight at Friendship, the home of Mrs. Evalyn Walsh McLean, with a dinner dance given in honor of the "coming-of-age" of her son, John R. McLean, who will be 21 years old on Jan. 10. More than 600 guests attended.

The Yale Club of New York will honor the Eli football eleven which last Fall won the Big Three championship and defeated such outstanding rivals as Cornell, Pennsylvania and Navy. Invitations have been issued to a testimonial dinner and entertainment to be given at the Waldorf-Astoria Jan. 13.

A number of leases of entire floors were reported by brokers yesterday. Sinclair Knitting Mills, Inc., leased the tenth floor at 721-23 Broadway for manufacture and sale of bathing suits and knitted novelties, the Cross Brown Company reported.
The British Government possesses information proving that the military element in Japan feels it has been let down by the Germans in the anti-Communist pact.

Crowded stores, decorated streets and lavish spending attest to the new highwater mark of prosperity Japan attained in 1936, but the complacency and confidence that marked the utterances of leaders last year are absent from the government's New Year messages.
Despite reports of many influenza cases in various cities, the Publid Health Service said today the total for the nation is just about normal for this time of year.

Expressing a New Year's wish of happiness and prosperity to the nation and each citizen, Secretary Morgenthau today declared that the people had a right to look forward to 1937 with renewed confidence and courage.

New securities offered publicly here in December totaled $568,209,000, of which $534,637,000 was for seventy-one bond issues and $33,572,000 for twenty-one stock issues. The month's total compared with offerings of $275,322,000 in November, when $250,903,000 represented fifty-one bond issues and $24,419,000 thirteen stock issues.

Interest in large country properties on the North Shore of Long Island is greater than at any time in the past eight years, according to Pease Elliman, Inc. These brokers yesterday reported four sales of this type of property.
A tank of propane gas exploded in the Sun Shipbuilding and Drydock Company's plant here today, scattering debris among 500 workmen and hurling several of the employes through the air.

Alphonse Roy, Democrat, announced today through counsel he would file with the House of Representatives a protest against the seating of Arthur B. Jenks, Republican, as representative from the first New Hampshire district.

Discovery of a range of salt domes in the Gulf of Mexico, 180 miles long, was reported to the convention of the Geological Society of America today by Dr. Francis T. Shepard of University of Illinois.

Manufacturers of wool goods are entering the new year with a large volume of unfilled orders and with prospects bright for a steady increase in business over the next four to five months, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.

Armed with a hard-won 42-41 victory over the St. Thomas quintet at Scranton, Nebraska's basketball team arrived in Philadelphia today and went into last-minute training for a New Year's Day game with Temple University by taking a sight-seeing tour to the city's historical shrines.

Fieldston Rd., 4,630 (13-3415L); William A. Hannig to Prudential Insurance Co., 763 Broad St., Newark, N. J.; extends mtg. Jan. 1, 1957, at 5 per cent; $25,000. Mount Eden Av., 195 E. (11-2824); 3,201 Grand Concourse Realty Corp. to Helen J. Biggart, 2,265 Sedgwick Av.; five years, per cent: S10.000.

The ballroom of the Bellevue-Stratford was transformed into a scene from "H. M. S. Pinafore" tonight when Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Earle of Haverford gave a ball for their debutante daughter, Miss Edith Earle Lee, niece of George H. Earle, Governor of Pennsylvania. She was presented to Philadelphia society last September.
The staffs of three large hotels in Nice started a "sit down" strike today, and a conflict-apparently struggle between labor unions-resulted in rioting there tonight.

James J. Johnston, in charge of boxing at Madison Square Garden, announced yesterday that he had signed Joe Louis, Detroit's famed Brown Bomber, to meet Bob Pastor, Washington Heights heavyweight, in a scheduled ten-round bout at the Garden on Jan. 29.
A son of the ancient Romans, as we might call ARTURO TOSCANINI, directs a Palestine orchestra on the soil of the Holy Land.

The romance of Princess Juliana of the Netherlands was marred today when the entire German press opened a new barrage against her fiance, Prince Bernhard zu Lippe-Biesterfeld, to coerce him into a public protest against alleged insults to the German flag and national anthems during reception ceremonies for him.
Clubs, hotels and homes formed settings tonight for Palm Beach's greeting to 1937, with practically every colonist either entertaining or a guest at one of the numerous functions.

A contract for sale of the interests in Argentina of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey was signed here today. It provided that the Argentine Government's oil company, Vacimientos Petroleros Fiscales, should pay the American concern approximately 140,000,000 pesos.
Marriage licenses issued during 1936 at the Municipal Building Bureau totaled 30,425 as compared with 29,764 issued in 1935, it was reported last night by Julius Brosen, chief clerk of the bureau.

Frederic R. Kellogg, who was counsel for E. L. Doheny in trials growing out of the Teapot Dome oil scandals, left an estate valued in the non-resident transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday at $1,258,394 gross and $1,209,531 net. A member of the firm of Kellogg,

The Penn Yan village board said Happy New Year to 2,119 customers of its municipal electric plant with receipted bills for December totaling $5,000. This "extra dividend" has been maintained since 1930.

Thousands of celebrants ushered in 1937 last night at the leading hotels, restaurants and night clubs. Lavish entertainment was provided for their amusement and there was a record flow of champagne. Reports indicated the largest number of reservations and the gayest New Year's Eve celebration that New York has experienced in years, the fourth since repeal of prohibition.

Uinited States exports dropped from $269,838,000 in November, 1935, to $225,766,000 last month, while imports increased from $169,385,000 in November, 1935, to $196,423,000, the Department of Commerce reported today.

These National Guard orders were issued today: Paul, 2d Lt. Thurston T. Jr., Infantry, having qualified, is placed on duty. He is to report to commanding officer, Tenth Infantry, for assignment to headquarters company, 1st Battalion.

Dr. Rudolf Meyer Riefstahl, Professor of Fine Arts at New York University and a well known authority on decorative arts, particularly Islamic and Near Eastern art, died of pneumonia at 11 o'clock last night at the Park East Hospital. His age was 56, and he lived at 48 East Eighty-ninth Street.

The Illinois Boxing Commission, Chairman Joe Triner said today, will refuse to recognize the New York Athletic Commission's order suspending Sam Plan, co-manager of Barney Ross, world welterweight champion.

Pensioned On their own applications: LIEUTENANT-Bernard E. Clarke, 1st Division, at $2,000 per annum. Appointed Dec. 27, 1911. PATROLMAN-Arthur G. Grundig, 25th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Dec. 28, 1911.
More than $600,000,000 was spent for highway construction in 1936, the "best year since 1931," the American Roadbuilders Association reported today in an annual survey.
At midnight tonight a number of new laws will become operative with far-reaching social, economic and political effects on the British people in all walks of life.

Basil James Of Sunnyside, Wash., and Hirsch Jacobs of New York were crowned the champion jockey and trainer, respectively, of 1936, when the curtain fell on the year's racing yesterday, according to The Associated Press.
Australia scored 63 runs for two wickets by the time the lunch interval was called in the third cricket test match against England, which opened today.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 29: COMMANDERS Coman, R. G.. the Pennsylvania, to command the Vestal. Richardson, C. G., the Sirius, to the Staff of the Marine Corps School, Quantico, Va. Riefkohl, F. L., to the Idaho, as Executive Officer instead of the Philadelphia. Wiley. H. V., the Pensacola, to command the Sirius.

Edward G. Seubert, president of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana, said today that 1936 was "one of the best years the petroleum industry has seen." "Regarding the future," Mr. Seubert added, "the industry should be no less optimistic than it was a year ago."

Thomas S. Wheelwright, president of the Old Dominion Iron and Steel Works, Inc., and for many years prominent in the business, civic and social interests of this city died this afternoon at a local hospital. He was 70 years of age.

The "vicious" results of the historic system of land tenure and its resultant waste, and the next steps in a national program to remedy it, were discussed at the final session today of the meeting of the American Historical Association by Dr. L. C. Gray, assistant administrator of the Resettlement Administration.

With stories of t each other's adventures and none about their own, Bert Acosta, Gordon Berry, Eddie Schneider and Frederick Lord returned to Paris this morning from two months' experience in the civil war in Spain.

The body of Edna Tellin, 47 years old, domestic, who vanished from the home of Mrs. Ogden Reid, at 15 East Eighty-fourth Street, on Sunday, Nov. 22, her day off, was found in the Harlem River yesterday.

128th St., 246 W., 50x99.11; Linford Realty Corp. to Anthony J. Romagna, 1 Fifth Av.; purchase money; prior mtg., $40,000; five years, 6 per cent; $20,000. 135th St., 612 W., 38.7x99.11; Knox Estates, Inc., to United States Trust Co., trustee, Alice G. Fosdick; ten years, 3 to 3 1/2 per cent; $29,000.
A ten-pound baby boy in the Bronx and an eight and a half pound girl in Brooklyn vied this morning for the honor of being the first to be born in the city in 1937.
Add to tomorrow evening's closings, "Matrimony, Pfd.," which will depart from the Playhouse after playing there for seven and a half weeks. It won't tour.
Wilson Potter, New York architect and prominent in Masonic circles, died on Wednesday at his home, 1,158 Fifth Avenue. He was 68 years old and maintained offices at 22 East Seventeenth Street.

Retail trade here this week was about as good as, or, on a comparative percentage basis, even better than pre-Christmas shopping, according to merchants here yesterday. The response to special promotions was good, and department store executives estimated

J. P. Morgan is expected to leave by automobile tomorrow for Jekyll Island, Brunswick, Ga., where he will board his yacht Corsair for a Central American tour. The Morgan yacht is now at a Brooklyn shipyard and will leave at the same time.

The extra currency called into use for holiday spending before Christmas began to flow back to the banks with its usual rush in the final week of the year, it was disclosed in the Federal Reserve statement for the week ended on Wednesday, published yesterday.

New high levels for the season were established on wheat futures in Liverpool and. Winnipeg today, but the markets in this country were disposed to lag, although advancing around a cent a bushel in the early trading.

Issuance by Southeastern Greyhound Lines of $106,029 of preferred dividend scrip, 21,879 shares of 6 per cent non-convertible preferred stock and 123,480 shares of common stock was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

THE time has gone by for elaborate structures of pacts and treaties. What the League of Nations needs is not legal nostrums (elixirss merveilleux), but a moral and psychological cure at the centers of will and understanding. It was the responsibility of the great powers to make a peace A in Europe which could be based neither on an obstinate determination to keep the world unchanged nor on a system of force and intimidation.

The beautifully controlled hitting of J. N. B. Pell subdued George H. (Pete) Bostwick today in the first match of the sixteenth annual Gold Racquet court tennis tournament at the Tuxedo Park Racquet and Tennis Club.

The final impudent gesture of the 1936 cinema is RKO Radio's tossing of Lily Pons to a swing band. With this one fell swoop-which may be studied- at your leisure in "That Girl From Paris," at the Radio City Music Hall-the operatic cycle completes the revolution begun in Grace Moore's "The King Steps Out" and continued in Nino Martini's "The Gay Desperado."

The resignation of Thomas Newhall of Philadelphia from J. P. Morgan Co. and their Philadelphia branch, Drexel Co., was announced yesterday in a small legal notice inserted in afternoon newspapers. At the offices of Morgan Co. it was stated there was nothing to be added.
In a six-toone decision, the Court of Appeals today upheld local law No. 24 of New York City, in so far as it imposes a sales tax on dyers and processors of furs delivered for that purpose.

Atma Singh, burly British Indian and convicted murderer, sat up and took nourishment today after awakening from what started out as a death plunge. When he regained consciousness he gazed at policemen guarding his prison hospital ward and dazedly said, "I thought you were going to hang me."

Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the Social Security Board, 45 Broadway, asked yesterday that all employers covered by the old-age benefit provision of the Social Security Act be patient with employes who had not yet received their account numbers.

Hurled by a north-bound truck, operated by a hit-and-run driver, a distance of six feet into the path of a south-bound automobile, Aaron Levy, 60 years old, of 478 Third Avenue, was fatally injured at 8:20 o'clock last night at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

Matched against Sir George Thomas of London, several times champion of the British Chess Federation and acknowledged to be one of the steadiest and soundest players in England, Reuben Fine of New York, American representative in the international masters

The marriage of Miss Patricia Olds, daughter of Marshall Olds of this city, to Robert Mason Estes, son of Mr. and Mrs. James French Estes of Manchester, N. H., took place yesterday afternoon in Grace Church.

Purdue University's squash racquets team yesterday turned back Harvard's combination by a score of 3-2 at the Harvard Club courts. The Westerners, on an Eastern tour, lost to Yale, 5-0, Wednesday at the Yale Club.

Fifteen-year-old Miss Helen Bernhard of New York City won the national junior girls' indoor tennis singles championship today by defeating Miss Hope Knowles of Philadelphia, second seeded star, in a brilliant final-round match on the covered courts of the Longwood Cricket Club. The scores were 6-0, 8--6.

Forty-four hand-picked college football stars-eleven of them won all-America recognition-match brains and brawn tomorrow in one of the season's football classics, the annual East-West game played for charity.

The Rev. Lawrence J. Travers, pastor of St. James Catholic Church, died of heart disease today in the rectory of the church. He had been ill a week. Father Travers was born fifty-six years ago in Phillipsburg.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:
With Buddy Combs leading the assault, Cornell University's polo trio trounced the 109th Field Artillery team, 24 1/2 to 10 1/2, in a holiday game at the 109th Armory tonight.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 30: Honeycutt, Col. F. W., F.A.. Ft. Sam Houston, Texas, to Command and General Staff School, Ft. Leavenworth, Kan., as assistant to the commandant, about July 1.

The San Antonio Light, a Hearst newspaper, posted a bulletin today fixing a forty-hour, five-day week for editorial employes and setting salary minimums for copy desk and rewrite men at $40 weekly and for other editorial workers, retouchers, cameramen, reporters and artists of three years' experience at $37.50; one year's experience, $25; less than one year, $16.

The Giants were in the market for some good players of a Class AA caliber yesterday with which to stock their new farm. They have the franchise, through purchase of the Albany club of the International League.

Cooperative campaigns to promote State products, industrial sites and vacation facilities will achieve a new all-time high in 1937, it was predicted in advertising circles yesterday. The success attendant on many new promotions started this year is expected to attract

Claude Eggleston, 55, of Binghamton, a railroad engineer, died in a hospital here today of injuries he suffered when two locomotives crashed together in a snowstorm near the Little York station, Dec. 20.

Albert J. Kobler, publisher of The Daily Mirror from 1928 through 1934 and for many years before that president of The American Weekly, a Hearst publication, died yesterday in his apartment at the Madison Hotel, 10 East Fifty-eighth Street. He was 60 years old.

The terms of two Interstate Commerce Commissioners, Joseph B. Eastman and Hugh M. Tate, expired today, and it was not believed that their reappointments or the naming of their successors would be announced by President Roosevelt until after he is inaugurated on Jan. 20.
A client of Leonard S. Gans Company has purchased the apartment house at 381 South Broadway, corner of Cedar Street, Dobbs Ferry, Westchester, from Max Rosenfeld.

A "sit-down" strike of pumpers that paralyzed the big refinery of the Tide Water Oil Company here for about twenty-six hours was settled tonight after the management made partial concessions to meet the strikers' demands.

Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan has won the distinction of being the first city official to submit a 1936 departmental report to Mayor La Guardia. Mr. Levy's report was made public at midnight. Other reports will straggle into the Mayor's office for six months or more.

Deposits of the Dominion Government in the Bank of Canada increased $1,295,049 in the week ended yesterday, according to the weekly statement of the bank issued today. Deposits of chartered banks declined $844,357.
The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the receipt of applications to list the following securities:
The appointment of Terrence P. Cook as Far East traffic manager of the Barber Steamship Lines, Inc., was announced yesterday by Edward J. Barber, president of the company.
Following is the text of a letter of William S. Knudsen, executive vice president of General Motors Corporation, to Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America:

Professor Ainsworth O'Brien-Moore of the Yale faculty was killed about 1:30 o'clock this morning when his car, driven by his wife, crashed into a pole at the junction of the Sleeping Giant Road and Whitney Avenue in Mount Carmel.
It was a great day for the local lads, as the national junior and boys' indoor tennis championships moved into the final stages at the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday.

Byrnes MacDonald, Sixth Deputy Police Commissioner in charge of the Juvenile Aid Bureau, has been relieved of night touring duty, which is assigned in rotation to all deputy commissioners, it was learned yesterday.

With 38,400 workers idle, seven General Motors plants shut down, and five more affected--by strikes called by the United Automobile Workers of America in its campaign to -make a closed shop of the automobile industry, formal notice was served on the union tonight by the corporation that no conference to discuss collective bargaining would be considered until the union's sit-down strikers vacated all General Motors plants.

Pasquale Di Bernardi, 19 years old, of 2,408 Bathgate Avenue, the Bronx, died in Fordham Hospital yesterday morning of wounds received Wednesday afternoon when, running away from two policemen, he was shot in the left side and fell sixty feet from one level of ground to another.

The Standard Oil Company, a New Jersey corporation which is the holding company for the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, a Delaware corporation, accepted today a $50,000,000 assessment for 1936 on its registered office and paid the city of Newark $1,987,366.87 for taxes and interest.

Preparations for the 1939 New York World's Fair were advanced yesterday when the Park Department received bids for the grading and drainage of a parking field in the north end of Flushing Meadows Park, Queens, and awarded the contract to the Slattery Contracting Company, the lowest bidder, for $174,895.15.
The most memorable and unhappy year in the history of modern Spain ends today with the government forces on the offensive in every civil war sector except possibly Andalusia.

BENAVENTE-Anna (nee Baruch), of 600 West 163d St., on Dec. 31, 1936, beloved wife of Maurice, devoted mother of Leah Mack and Joseph Benavente. Funeral from Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 117 West 72d St., Sunday, 1 P. M.

The New York Rangers had a lead of two goals over the Boston Bruins early in the third period of their game at Madison Square Garden last night, but they could not hold it. Twice before the last session ended the Blue Shirts yielded goals to their rivals, and when it was all over, after ten minutes of overtime, the teams were tied at 2-all.

A loving cup inscribed with the names of judges of the Court of Appeals and d the seal of the State was presented today to Associate Judge Leonard C. Crouch of Syracuse, retiring r from the court at the age limit of 70 years.

" The game of golf shall be played with not more than fourteen clubs beginning Jan. 1, 1938." Thus does the United States Golf Association, final ruling authority of the ga? e in this country, announce one of the most drastic regulations it has ever made in the matter of implements of golfing warfare.

Sharp gains carried The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices 2.3 points upward for the tenth consecutive week, the index rising to 137.1 on Tuesday from 134.8 (revised) the Tuesday previous. Outstanding among the commodities to advance were wheat, steers, cotton, hides and leather, steel and rubber.
CHICAGO, Dec. 31.--Representatives of five leading railway brotherhoods will meet here Jan. 12 to discuss demands for a general wage increase, it was learned today.

The Manufacturers Trust Company has transferred $5,000,000 from its contingent reserve account to its undivided profits account, thereby increasing its capital funds by that amount, Harvey D. Gibson, president of the bank, announced yesterday. This transfer follows a similar move in July, when $5,000,000 was shifted from contingent reserves to surplus.
Miss Catherine Adamson gave a buffet supper at her home tonight and later took her guests to the New Year's Eve dance at the Garden City Casino.

It is a fixed and not unlovely trait of human nature to believe that we can drop everything bad in the old year as we enter the new. We know, in sober truth, that an arbitrary division of time counts for little or nothing in the development of character or in the. direction and activities of a national tendency.
A call for renewed moral and spiritual strength for 1937 was sounded from the pulpits of the city last night as chimes tolled in the new year.
A consolidated net income of $5,790,492 was reported yesterday for the eleven months to Nov. 30 by the Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore, after all deductions.

Dr. Reginald M. Rawls of 501 West 113th Street, gynecologist, obstetrician and consulting surgeon at the Woman's Hospital, where he had been a staff member for thirtyfive years, died of a heart ailment in the hospital on Wednesday night. He was 63 years of age.
A sudden switch of betting odds tonight made the outweighed Marquette University football team a 6-5 favorite over Texas Christian University for the Cotton Bowl game tomorrow.

Mrs. Katie Ullman, who had been identified for many years with Jewish charitable organizations, died yesterday of a heart attack at the country home of her daughter, Mrs. Doris Garfinkel, at Mount Kisco, N.T. Y. Mrs. Ullman, whose sixty-third birthday occurred yesterday, lived at 411 West End Avenue.
Thomas Heagney, 39 years old, a municipal fireman here for twelve years, was injured fatally this morning when he plunged off a roof in a frantic attempt to answer a fire alarm with his company.

A total of 19,158,601 feet of lumber was cut in 1935, a gain of 23.7 per cent over 1934, according to the Commerce Department's Census of Manufacturers today. The lath output increased 48.4 per cent and 26.8 per cent more shingles were produced.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

An explosion in the plant of the Standard Textile Products Company on Clifton Boulevard here this morning ended the lives of three workers, injured two others seriously, destroyed a large building and costly equipment and rocked this entire community.

On the eve of the third annual Sugar Bowl football game, matching Santa Clara and Louisiana State, before an expected crowd of 42,000 persons, rain threatened to mar the New Year's Day warfare. It appeared Tulane Stadium's turf would be soft for the colorful game.

Judge Jonah J. Goldstein's last act yesterday as a member of the General Sessions bench was to terminate the one-year probation of a Negro defendant with a homily on policy playing. Judge Goldstein who had come to court with a mild attack of influenza, at midnight completed a seven-month term on his appointment last May by Governor Lehman to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Judge Otto A. Rosalsky.

Senator Joseph W. Guffey of Pennsylvania suffered a fractured rib today when a taxicab in which he was riding was in collision with a mail truck. a Senator Guffey was taken to Emeragency Hospital where X-ray photographs disclosed the nature of his injury.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James T. Kilbreth of Hewlett, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sophie Kilbreth, to Ernest Patrick Bernuth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar M. Bernuth of 510 Park Avenue and Cedarhurst, L. I.
As the first booming stroke of Big Ben proclaimed the start of the New Year millions listening at their radios heard their first message from King George VI.

When the local branch of the Chase National Bank of New York announced a holiday bonus for its employes, workers in the National City Bank branch began to speculate whether they would have the same luck.
Starting times of the various New Year's Day football games (all Eastern standard): Pasadena, Pitt vs. Washington, 5:15 P. M. San Francisco, East vs. West, 5 P. M.
A daughter was born yesterday to Mr. and Mrs. Paul Mellon. Mr. Mellon is the son of Andrew W. Mellon, former Secretary of the Treasury.

The Montreal Maroons captured undisputed possession of second place in the National Hockey League's international group tonight, breaking a three-way deadlock with the Toronto Maple Leafs and the New York Americans by defeating Toronto, 3 to 1, in an exciting overtime contest.

Among the many New Year resolutions made yesterday was that of the Blackbirds of Long Island University to start a new winning streak which will outshine the forty-three-game string which the Stanford quintet cut on Wednesday.
Holiday and week-end prospects for skiing in New England are poor. Reports compiled by The Associated Press last night were as follows:

Mrs. Ida Frances Desmond Patterson of this city, widow of Dr. Frank Newhall Patterson, was married yesterday afternoon to Frank W. Perkins of Brooklyn in the small chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church. The Rev. Dr.

President Roosevelt made the first of his official moves today toward reorganizing the agricultural arm of the government by appointing Milburn L. Wilson of Montana, who has been Assistant Secretary of Agriculture, as Under-Secretary of Agriculture, to succeed Rexford G. Tugwell, who left the government service today to become executive vice president of the American Molasses Company.

Responding to representations by the United States, Spanish Loyalists today ordered the release of a $400,000 American cargo which was aboard a Spanish steamer drafted suddenly into the Loyalist service.

The twenty-ninth annual tournament of the Winter Golf League of Advertising Interests will start on Sunday, Jan. 17 at Palm Beach with a four-ball mixed foursome handicap event, it was announced by Ray P. Clayberger, president of the association.

Broadcasting to the French people on New Year's Eve, Premier Leon Blum said that his wishes for the coming year were peace and prosperity for France, and he added the conviction that both could be obtained. They could be achieved, he said, by unity and by all classes of Frenchmen working together.

Chandler A. Mackey has been renominated for a third term as president of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange Inc. The nominating committee has chosen F. Shelton Farr to be vice president and has renominated W. W. Pinney as treasurer.
Detroit's Red Wings protected their secondplace standing in the National Hockey League's American group with a smashing 4-to-2 triumph over the New York Americans befor 8,000 spectators tonight.

AIDA. opera in Italian in four acts. Music by Giuseppe Verdi; book by Ghislanzoni. Conductor, Gennaro Papi; stage director, Desire Defrere; chorus master, Fausto Cleva. Dances by the American Ballet Ensemble. Presented at the Metropolitan Opera House.

It would be news of the first order if the United States Government should announce today that it had made a New Year's resolution to stop borrowing money. No word of this kind is likely to come ticking over the wires while private citizens are recording private resolutions.

The eve of- the annual Tournament of Roses football game found oppcnents in the intersectional classic, Pittsburgh and Washington, ready for battle and 87,000 ticket-buyers wondering about the weather.

Mrs. Harold McCleave Brown of 157 East Eighty-first Street has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Isabella Stuart Brown, to Bradford Willet Stiles, son of Mrs. Francis W. T. Stiles of 122 East Seventy-first Street, and of the late Mr. Stiles.
Capt. Nadi, winner of his previous race just a mon?? ago, carried W. J. Sprow's silks to victory in the five and a half furlong dash for platers at the Fair Grounds today.

Many parties were held at clubs and private homes here tonight to usher in the new year. One of the largest, at the Round Hill Club, was "the Round Hill round-up," with members and guests dressed as cowboys and cowgirls.

Three children were burned to death tonight while the parents of two of the victims were celebrating New Year's Eve with friends. Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Kessler Sr. had called in Teresa Gallagher, 14 years old, a neighbor's child, to watch their small son and daughter during the evening.
Mr. and Mrs. Leon Stein of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Genevieve Helena Stein, to Floyd Kramer, son of Mrs. Rachel Kramer, also of Passaic.

One hundred and seven new contributions added $3,608.85 to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday, increasing the total to date to $260,763.72. Several givers expressed regret that their donations had come so late, not realizing that it is never too late to contribute to the Neediest of all New York.

The Treasury tonight closed its ledger on the first half of the fiscal year with the figures showing 61 cents collected in taxes for every dollar spent. This, officials were gratified to note, was almost an even dime more than was the case a year ago.
Mrs. Marion Cooper Hewitt was cleared today of a charge of being a fugitive from justice from California by Police Judge Anthony Botti in the First Criminal Court here, who dismissed the complaint.

Appearing at a public hearing yesterday morning before State Superintendent of Insurance Louis H. Pink, in the State Building, 80 Center Street, Mayor La Guardia appealed for lower automobile insurance rates for New York City.

Charles Ar Pinckney has purchased for occupancyy the six-room English type dwellng at 492 Fairbridge Terrace, Teaneck, S. J. H. J. Tulp, Inc., acted as broker. The New Jersey Title Guarantee and Trust Co., as executor under the will of Fosepli B. Hughes, sold to the D. Paradis no. the one-story brick garage, 5,124-26 Boulevard, northeast corner of 21st St., West New York.

The principal securities and commodities markets of the world will be closed today in observance of New Year's Day, but most of the former, including the New York Stock and the New York Curb Exchanges, will be open for Saturday's short trading session.

Two affiliated dress companies in New York City made agreements with garment workers' unions, in one clause of which the companies agreed not to move their factories from the present location to any place beyond the fivecent-fare zone.

Tentative plans for American war veterans to make a pilgrimage to battle monuments in Italy and France, to be dedicated next July, bore approval today of General John J. Pershing and the American Legion commander.

Fame has come to Miss Evelyn Booth, grayhaired and spectacled phrenologist and secretary of the London Phrenological Institution on Ludgate Circus. Opening a hatch in the consulting room through which she "reads" the heads of her clients, she found that she was fingering the head of the Duke of Kent.

Total net sales of 1,148 reporting wholesalers increased about 10 per cent in November from November 1935, and collections on account wert higher, according to a joint survey by National Association of Credit Men and the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

IN this list of more than 300 dead, over 60 per cent were recorded as having succumbed to pneumonia and none as the victim of a communicable fever; seven died violent deaths, including three suicides.

Dr. William Albert Landis, an instructor in mathematics at the Friends Seminary, 226 East Sixteenth Street, died on Wednesday at the Mountainside Hospital, Montclair, N. J. He was 43 years old and lived at 119 Chestnut Street. Montclair.

The estate of John Wanamaker Jr., son of the late Rodman Wanamaker and grandson of John Wanamaker, who died Nov. 29, 1934, which was believed to be worth $2,000,000 at the time of his death, was reported yesterday to be insolvent.

" Further and substantial gains" in the economic welfare of the nation were experienced in 1936, and "it seems as if we can look forward with confidence" to continued progress in 1937, Secretary Perkins said today in a formal year-end statement.

The new year brings but one film today, to wit, R. K. O. Radio's adaptation of David Lamson's "We Who Are About to Die." Occupying the screen of the Rialto, it is played by Preston Foster, Ann Dvorak, John Beal and J. Carrol Naish.

Business in the Pittsburgh district reflected a severe setback last week according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pitts burgh. Ordinarily industries curtail operations during the Christmas week and the volume of trade and shipments shows a decided shrinkage.
An unidentified woman about 30 years old was killed last night when she jumped in front of an I. R. T., Jerome Avenue Subway train from the station platform at 176th Street and Jerome Avenue.

Charles Breyer, 60 years old, a laundry owner, of 162 East Eightyfourth Street, tried last night to bring about a reconciliation with his estranged wife. but when he was repulsed he shot her dead, just missed one of his daughters with another shot, and fired a third bullet into his own head, according to the police.

This city's representatives scored decisive victories over their out-oftown rivals in the double-header held last night at the Hippodrome. In the feature engagement, C. C. N. Y. atoned for two defeats in other seasons at the hands of Geneva with a sparkling 43-29 triumph over its rival, while St. Francis had an easy time with Seton Hall in the opener, winning 3--19.

After being arrested nineteen times during the last seventeen years, but "always beating the rap," Pius Lanzetti, eldest member of the "Lanzetti Mob" of South Philadelphia, was shot and killed late this afternoon by underworld enemies. Two bystanders were wounded, one fatally.
In the six months ended on Nov. 30 the Duplan Silk Corporation earned $323,119 after making deductions for Federal income taxes and other charges, but before surtax on undistributed profits.
