Staging a whirlwind finish that saw five goals rattling off Harvard sticks in rapid succession, the tireless Crimson sextet conquered Clarkson Tech, 7-5, tonight at the Olympic Arena in an overtime contest that marked the start of the three-game holiday series between the teams.

It is officially admitted that negotiations are proceeding between Yugoslavia and Bulgaria for a pact of non-aggression and friendship. It is the first time in fifty years, after many wars, that the two countries are attempting to cooperate for peaceful development of their relations.
Albert S. Ritchie, Omaha attorney who successfully defended Pat Crowe in the kidnapping of young Edward A. Cudahy Jr. in 1900, died here today at the age of 68.

An immediate task facing President Roosevelt as the new year begins and his first term nears an end is the filling of more than twenty major Federal posts now either vacant or filled by acting officials or temporary appointees.
Aloysius W. Whalen, prothonotary's clerk, who was arrested and fined $12.50 for heckling Mayor S. Davis Wilson during a stormy budget hearing of the City Council on Dec. 23, got his money back today.

Courts is held to be unconstit tional by the Supreme Court. June 5-PWA's power program declared valid by D. C. Court. June 10-National Labor Relations Act declared unconstitutional by the Texas Court of Western Federal District.

Miss Leslie McGregor Bremer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifton Long Bremer of this place, has chosen Feb. 13 as the date for her marriage to Frederick Russell Moseley Jr. of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Russell Moseley of Charles River, Mass.
Commissioner of Health John L. Rice expressed gratification yesterday over the progress in health work in New York City in 1936.
Governor Hoffman renamed today fourteen persons to commissions to which he appointed them following the regular session of the Legislature.

AL. BOBKER, manager, 2,528 BroadwayLiabilities, $6,055; no assets. ALBERT A. LE BOU, salesman, 306 E. 171 St.-Liabilities. $22,614; no assets. DAVID B. POLLINS, rent collector, 1,571 Undercliff Av.-Liabilities, $4,268; no assets except insurance. JACOB SAMUELS, salesman, 1,201 Shakespeare Av.-Liabllities, $130,665; no asets except insurance.

IT is perhaps well to explain at the outset that this morning's column contains no references to the year just ended or to that just begun. It deals with a book about New England-Jennie F. Copeland's "Every Day But Sunday" (Stephen Daye Press, $2.50). Those seeking comment suitable to the season may look elsewhere in the paper, or at their own reflection in a mirror.

Mr. and Mrs. George Harris Dryden of Baltimore have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rosamond Harris Dryden, to John Paulding Farnham, son of Mrs. Paulding Farnham of this city and the late Mr. Farnham.

Ten years' imprisonment and five years' loss of all civil rights was the sentence imposed yesterday upon General Chang Hsuehliang for his Shensi revolt and kidnapping of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek.
None of the items in yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks reached a new high or low for the year, but the reserve ratio at the New York bank was at the highest for 1936.
The two-family house at 333 Eighty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by Mrs. G. Musgrove to a client of Bulkley Horton Company for occupancy.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 (AP).--Federal Judge William H. Holly dismissed today a petition which sought involuntary reorganization of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, one of the nation's largest holding companies.
Leo R. Sack, the United States Minister to Costa Rica, today announced that he had resigned his post and expected to return to the United States soon to become associated with a large corporation.

Stocks closed the year irregular with some of the leading issues heavy in tone. Mostly, the holiday spirit curtailed activity in the markets, and on the Stock Exchange, year-end festivities on the trading floor in the afternoon contributed to the diminution of business.

The long expected reaction of Cardinal de Faulhaber, Archbishop of Munich, to his interview with Chancellor Adolf Hitler early in November was contained in his New Year's Eve sermon to a congregation of more than 5,000 persons that filled his ancient cathedral to the last inch of standing room.
SIOUX FALLS, S. D., Dec. 31.--A terrific explosion of dynamite and black powder, reported to have been set off by a robber gang to kill one of their members, shook this city and vicinity tonight.

Supreme Court Justice Valente denied yesterday the motion of Anglo-Continentale A. G., a corporation of the principality of Liechtenstein, to compel the Southern Pacific Company, incorporated in Kentucky, to pay interest in Dutch guilders on bonds of the company held by the Liechtenstein corporation.
A gift of $3,000,000 to the University of Chicago from the General Education Board of New York was announced today by Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, president of the institution.

Supreme Court Justice Burt Jay Humphrey retired from the bench yesterday after having served the people of Queens County continuously in the judiciary since 1904. He took leave of office in his chambers at 89-31 161st Street, Jamaica, quietly remonstrating with attaches and secretaries who sought to make a ceremony of his departure.
A great second - half rally enabled Notre Dame to defeat Northwestern, 24-23, in their traditional New Year's Eve basketball game at Patten gym tonight before 5,900 fans.
Balked in his efforts to keep International League baseball in Albany, Mayor John Boyd Thacher today studied the possibility of obtaining the transfer of either the Toronto or Syracuse franchise.

Soviet Russia tonight is having the gayest celebration since the revolution. Perhaps it is the gayest night Moscow has ever had, because, though in Czarist days some elements of the population had New Year's Eve celebrations surpassing tonight's in lavishness and perhaps wickedness, the Soviet New Year's celebration tonight is spread over the entire population.

Due to the award of contracts for tankers and miscellaneous small tonnage, the privately owned shipyards of the United States showed a marked improvement during the last year, according to the annual report of H. Gerrish Smith, president of the National Association of American Shipbuilders, which was published yesterday.

Transfer of three memberships in the New York Stock Exchange and the prospective sale of another, together with changes in the partners of several member firms, were announced yesterday by the Exchange. The membership of Henry C.

The leading copper producers yesterday advanced the price of that metal to 12 cents a pound in the domestic market, the highest level since July, 1930. The increase, made to keep the domestic and foreign markets on a parity, followed one of five-eighths of a cent a pound to 11.625 cents about a week ago.

Jan. 20-George V dies and is succeeded as Emperor and King by Edward Albert, Prince of Wales, Edward VIII. Jan. 23-Rudyard Kipling is buried in Westminster Abbey. Feb. 17-A new Anglo-Irish trade treaty is published; duties still high, showing defeat of Irish Free State in economic conflict with Britain.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Dec. 30 unless specified: Acushnet, Washington Yard to Naval Operating Base, Norfolk. Brant, San Diego to Wilson Cove. Erie. at New York Yard. Hatfield, at St. Jean de Luz, Dec. 31. Henderson, at San Francisco.

The bondholders' committee for the Republic of Colombia, of which former Senator Robert L. Owen is chairman, indicated today that it would, probably within a week or ten days, file a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 for issuance of certificates of deposit in connection with approximately $162,000,000 of the external dollar bonds of Colombia,
Threat of a nation-wide strike of 500,000 bituminous coal miners was voiced tonight by John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America,

The present wave of influenza, while far less serious than the terrible epidemic of 1918, is nevertheless proving of great concern to the medical profession generally and the health officers of the various London boroughs.

President Roosevelt greeted the New Year quietly at the White House tonight, surrounded by children and grandchildren. There was no special observance except a family dinner followed by motion pictures.

242d St. (12-3390) n s, 95 ft, e of Katonan Av, 52x175; Adele Turret to Mortgage Commission Realty Corp., trustee. 175th St. (11-2899) s s, 80 ft e of Webster Av, 26x75; Aniela Roscicki to Loretta Modenick, 2,190 Bathgate Av. Nelson Av, (9-2521) w s, 97 ft n of 170th St, 103x100,1375 Realty Corp. to Nelton Realty Corp., 91-31 St. Charles Court, Queens: m $110,000.

An industrial crisis of great magnitude involving the automobile industry and its 500,000 employes and related industries, steel and glass particularly, and also threatening to affect the nation's 500,000 bituminous coal workers,

The appointment of Milo M. Thompson as chief of the Washington bureau of the Associated Press in succession to Byron Price, who becomes the executive news editor of the organization, was announced yesterday by Kent Cooper, general manager.

Topped by California and Rhode Island, two of the newest recruits to the sport, thoroughbred horse racing enjoyed its most prosperous season in many years during 1936, pouring $8,192,472 into the State treasuries. Last year the income totaled $6,958.562.
Bob Feller, youthful Cleveland pitching sensation, will meet with baseball officials in that city Jan. 9 for further discussions concerning a 1937 contract, W. H. Feller, his father, said today.

Freddie Steele, aggressive middleweight champion from Tacoma, Wash., will defend his title for the first time tomorrow in a ten-round bout against Bill (Gorilla) Jones, former holder of the N. B. A. crown.

The Grace liner Santa Lucia will sail tonight for the West Coast of South America, carrying passengers for the Panama Canal, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru and Chile. Among the passengers will be Kenneth Collins, executive vice president of Gimbel Brothers.
Ground was broken yesterday at the site of the ventilation building to be erected by the New York Tunnel Authority at the Manhattan end of the new Queens-Midtown vehicular tunnel.

ST. JEAN-DE-LUZ, France, Dec. 31--Spanish Leftists Government sources reported today that Insurgent pilots had slaughtered seventy-one of their own comrades when they machine-gunned Rebel trenches near Oviedo.

Group insurance in 1936 reached the highest level in history and is estimated at $12,000,000,000 for the United States and Canada, insuring 7,600,000 employes for an average of about one year's pay, according to Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Socity of the United States, which inaugurated the group plan twentyfive years ago.

Daniel W. MacCormack, head of the immigration and naturalization service of the Labor Department, died suddenly early today at Garfield Hospital. He was 56 years old. He had- held the post of Commissioner since March, 1933.
With the new year, the racing hull of Harold S. Vanderbilt's new $300,000 America's Cup contender will start rising above the completed 100-ton keel, cast at the Bath Iron Works Corporation.

The stock market enjoyed a fair volume of business today notwithstanding the fact that the day was both the eve of a holiday and the last day of the account. Price movements generally were irregular. British government issues were quiet, with fractional losses here and there.
The State law prohibiting suits for breach of promise to marry was unanimously sustained today by the Court of Appeals.

Miss Constance Emily Polan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Polan of Huntingdon, W. Va., was married to Robert Edward Salkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Loeb Salkin of New Rochelle, N. Y., yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Dr. Stephen S. Wise in his study at 40 West Sixty-eighth Street.

Miss Ruth M. Bender, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Welcome W. Bender of Newark Avenue, has chosen Jan. 16 as the date of her marriage to Sylvester A. Schramm, son of Mrs. Joseph J. Schramm of Newark and the late Mr. Schramm.

Buell Hollister Jr. of Yale outlasted Richard M. Dorson of Harvard to take the University Club's second annual invitation intercollegiate squash racquets tournament final yesterday in five games. The scores were 5-15, 15-14, 12-15, 15-12, 15-11. Hollister was seeded second to Dorson.

Furs valued at between $10,000 and $15,000 were stolen about 3 P. M. yesterday, when four men, two of them armed, walked into the offices of Cutler Ostrowsky, on the sixth floor of 242 West Thirtieth Street, held up four men and two women and escaped.

After beating a police matron unconscious, gagging her and locking her in a cell, Gladys Felicious, 18 years old, of 306 West 113th Street, a prisoner charged with grand larceny, escaped last night from the detention pen of the West 123d Street Police Station.

Member trading for own account in round lots on the New York Stock Exchange for the week ended on Dec. 5 followed the price trend, particularly in the case of orders initiated from off the floor, according to a summary of daily transactions made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Jack Sanderson, president of the Fleet Aircraft Corporation, announced here today that reorganization of the company had been completed. Known as Fleet Aircraft, Ltd., the new company is controlled by Canadians and capitalized at $1,000,000, fully paid up. Mr.

Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said today that while the principal emergency had been passed, there were certain situations in which the corporation could continue to be helpful and "if the President and Congress wish it,

Brig. Gen. Perry L. Miles, commanding the Second Brigade of the First Division. U. S. Army, at Fort Ontario, N. Y., has been assigned to command of the First Brigade of the First Division, with headquarters at the Army Building, 30 Whitehall Street.

Appointment of Frank J. Wilson, a former Internal Revenue agent, as head of the United States Secret Service to succeed William H. Moran, retiring after fifty-four years' service, was announced today by Secretary Morgenthau.

Robert Cuse, president of the Vimalert Company, Ltd., of Jersey City, insisted yesterday on his legal right to sell airplanes, engines and parts to the Spanish Leftists under the license he has obtained from the State Department for a $2,777,000 shipment.
Skies over Broadway quivered last midnight to the noisiest New Year's celebration Times Square had ever seen.

Persons from Manhattan and Brooklyn have made reservations for the annual New Year's Day open house, to be held today at the Heights Casino, Brooklyn. A buffet luncheon will be served and dancing will follow.
Gar Wood appeared sure tonight of keeping the Harmsworth Speedboat Trophy in America another year, no challenge for a 1937 race having been reported before the Jan. 1 deadline.

Large bequests to charitable and religious institutions, friends and relatives are made in the will of Mrs. Carolyn H. Lyon, filed in Surrogate's Court today and disposing of an estate valued at "upward of $1,000,000." Mrs. Lyon, who died Dec. 18, was the widow of Edmund Lyon.

Wholesale prices advanced again during the week ended on Dec. 26, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, rose to 84.1, from 83.7 the preceding week, and compared with 80.6 a year before.

Mrs. John Van Ryn, holder of the United States doubles tennis championship with Miss Carolin Babcock, was named today by the Middle States ranking committee to the No. 1 place for 1936. Miss Hope Knowles was rated first among the juniors.

The Rev. Dr. Wilfred Weaver Shaw, who in nearly forty years of ministerial service in the Presbyterian Church attained prominence as missionary, pastor and Moderator, died today at his home here at the age of 76.

The colorful career of Mexico's most famous rebel and bandit leader, "General" Lauro Rocha, was cut short at midday here when police killed him as he lay ill in bed in a hideout in the suburb of Villa de Guadalupe.

Charles Dunning, Finance Minister, and R. C. Matthews, president of the Ca- A nadian Chamber of Commerce, $5,79 pointed today to an increase of for 1 more than $200,000,000 in Canada's by t external trade in a year-end review Ligh of the Dominion's recovery.

Money rates in December were stationary at quotations unchanged for the last seven months. Neither the steadiness in rates nor their low level greatly influenced borrowings, which were restricted in part because of declining stock prices.
Physicians attending Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. said today that he would not be able to leave Massachusetts General Hospital for "another ten days." His condition, they reported,

John P. Mullarkey, former president of the Montreal Terminal Railway Company and former managing director of the Chateaugay Northern Railway of Canada, died yesterday morning of pneumonia at his home, 399 Park Avenue. He was 77 years old.

The publication Trabajo states today it has confirmed a report that a number of Argentineans and Peruvian citizens have been arrested by the authorities here for gathering information concerning coast fortification and warships.
The MacNeil of Barra and Mrs. MacNeil gave a dance tonight at the Sulgrave Club for Frederick C. Hicks, son of Mrs. MacNeil, who is passing his holiday vacation from Kent School.
The Tide Water Associated Oil Company has filed a registration under the Securities Act of 1933, covering $45,000,000 of fifteen-year 31/2 per cent sinking fund debentures due on Jan. 1, 1952;

Miss Florence I. Crandall of Brooklyn died yesterday in a hospital here at the age of 68. She had come to this city about two weeks ago to visit a nephew, Harcourt C. Vernon. Miss Crandall's ancestors were among early settlers of Rhode Island.

Officials of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union considered court action yesterday against a number of concerns as a result of the decision of Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook which, in effect, ordered the Blue Dale Dress Company to move back into New York.

Polite interest in the new extension of the city's Independent Subway in Queens from Roosevelt Avenue, Jackson Heights, to Union Turnpike, Kew Gardens, was shown by Queens residents along the route yesterday as the first regular schedule trains began rolling at 7 o'clock in the morning.

The engagement of Miss Nancy Etherington to Richard Wallace Banfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Eugene Banfield of Whitinsville, Mass., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Sandford Garland Etherington of 152 East Eighty-first Street.

William Moore Parke of 1 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, and Point o'Wood, L. I., announced at a small party last night at his home the engagement of his daughter, Miss Martha Hannah Parke, to Charles H. Carter 3d, son of Mrs. Edward H. McKeon and the late Julian Stuart Carter of Baltimore.
Miss Elisabeth Stillman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edgar Stillman, was presented to society last night at a dance given by her parents at their home, 6 Sutton Square.
Production and employment in the furniture industry increased in 1935 as compared with 1933, the biennial census of manufacturers of the Department of Commerce revealed today.

Miss Lillian M. Tierney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Tierney of Oradell, was married here this afternoon in St. Catherine's Church to Raymond B. Weatherby, son of Mr. land Mrs. Raymond A. Weatherby of Hackensack, by the Rev. John J. Finnerty.

Miss Sylvia Dinney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell Dinney of 110 Riverside Drive, was married last night at the Savoy-Plaza to Alfred S. Levitt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Levitt of Lawrence L. I., by the Rev. Dr. Stephen S. Wise.

The engagement of Miss Betty Nuthall, British tennis player and former American champion, to David Alexander Barclay of Paisley, Scotland, secretary of the British Cellophane Corporation, was made known today.
An application by Northern Paper Mills, a registered holding company, for exemptions from the holding company provisions of the Public

Insurgent Spanish warships Were reported to have appeared en masse off Santander, on the Bay of Biscay, this morning, drawing sharp fire from government coastal batteries, which eventually drove them off with the aid of planes.

Pimlico will increase its daily total purses by $2,460 during the Spring meeting, April 29 through May 15. Matt Daiger, secretary and general manager of the Maryland Jockey Club which operates the track, announced today the purses will average $12,380 a day,

Lumber production decreased last week, but due to the allowance for the holiday and the adjustment for seasonal variation the index advanced to 98.3 from 84.3, the revised figure for the previous week. The figure stood at 77.6 for the week ended Dec. 28. 1935.

The industry nas viewed with interest for some time the Seeing Eye dogs as possible subject matter for pictures. Producers, however, have hesitated because such films would necessitate canine stars and it is impossible to obtain high rentals from theatres for animal pictures.

Although the Stock Exchange, the bullion market and most of the commodity markets were closed today, there was a heavy turnover of money, with [pound]45,571,000 paid in interest and dividend disbursements.

Governor Hoffman disclosed today he had filed with Secretary of State Thomas A. Mathis yesterday ad interim appointments of six persons as members of the non-salaried commission to administer the new Unemployment Compensation Law.
Slingin' Sam Baugh, that passing man from Texas Christian University, paired with L. D. Meyer, unheralded end, to bury Marquette's Golden Avalanche, 16-6, in the Cotton Bowl football game today.

The appointment of Rear Admiral George H. Rock, U. S. N., retired, as an honorary fellow of the North East Coast Institution of Engineers and Shipbuilders of Great Britain, was announced here yesterday.

Winners of the 1936 music guild awards of the National Broadcasting Company were announced yesterday afternoon by Lenox R. Lohr, president of the company, during an hour and a half broadcast over the WEAF network in which the winning scores were played for the first time. All were string quartet compositions in sonata form.
Arthur J. Buston, founder of the firm of cotton brokers bearing his name, died today at his home at Salop, near the Welsh border. He was 70 years of age.

The annual Debutantes New Year's Ball took place last night in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria. The event drew a large attendance of younger members of society, including many debutantes of the season.
The death toll of a fire that turned a holiday ball into tragedy reached two today when Mrs. Tyler Wilby Cleveland died of burns suffered Tuesday night.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Carola de Peyster Kip, daughter of Mrs. Garrett B. Kip of 405 Park Avenue and Rhinebeck, N. Y., and the late Mr. Kip, to Benjamin R. Kittredge Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin R. Kittredge of Carmel, N. Y., and Dean Hall Plantation in South Carolina.

While a record-breaking crowd estimated at a million persons, jamming both sides of Broad Street, looked on, Philadelphia's traditional New Year "shooters" gamboled and pranced today in the gayest Mummers' parade in years.
Only a few hours after the expiration of the Washington Naval Treaty the keels of two 35,000-ton battleships were laid in British shipyards today.
The Public Health Service prescribed "rest in bed" today as the best medicine for persons who think they are catching influenza.

It is a gratifying report on the state of the city's health that Commissioner JOHN L. RICE presents-gratifying because widespread distress taxed the resources of the health authorities and because thousands left smaller communities to benefit by the larger generosity of the metropolis.
A crowd of 35,000 racing fans saw Tempestuous carry the colors of Mrs. T. Stevenson of Canada to victory in the $5,000 added New Year Stakes by a neck over Sangreal at Santa Anita today.

Many at homes and old-fashioned eggnog parties took place in the North Shore colonies today. Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. F. McCann had several hundred guests at the eggnog party in the Playhouse at Sunken Orchard, their estate in the Berry Hill section of Oyster Bay, in accord with their annual custom.

The electric companies of the Consolidated Edison System have filed new rates which will save $4,700,000 annually for consumers using current for commercial, manufacturing, wholesale and charitable purposes, the Public Service Commission announced yesterday.

Owing to a last minute dispute the French parliament spent all New Year's Day and most of tonight endeavoring to reach an agreement on bills which were supposed to have been passed by midnight yesterday.

Although the Chinese Government has announced that no promises were given to end the Shensi Province rebellion and that no compromise was made with General Chang Hsueh-liang, embassy circles are convinced that in order to gain his freedom Generalissimo ChiangKaishek agreed with certain "requirements" advanced by the Communist leaders.

A Stimson plane, piloted by Edwin Wormold of 715 East Nineteenth Street, Brooklyn, and carrying three passengers from Floyd Bennett Field on a tour over the city, made a forced landing yesterday at 10 A.M. at Marine Park, Brooklyn, because of carburetor trouble. No one was injured and the plane was undamaged.

Ogden Phipps advanced one steg nearer his goal of retiring the trophy in the Gold Racquet court tens. nis tournament at the Tuxedo.Parls Racquet and Tennis Club today by defeating Stanley G. Mortimer in one of four quarter-final matches staged in the sixteenth annual corn petition.

Frank H. Innes of New Brighton, S. I., dean of the Richmond County Bar Association and formerly an Assistant District Attorney, was appointed yesterday by Governor Lehman to succeed Thomas J. Walsh as District Attorney of Richmond County.

Winning a match that would do credit to any major tournament, Don McNeill of Oklahoma City and Kenyon College scored an 11-9, 6-4 victory over Melvin Lapman of New York to enter the final round of the national junior indoor tennis championship at the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday.

A supper dance was given last night by Miss Ann Van Stone of Jersey City at Sherry's. Among the guests were Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Garrison, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Bunker, the Misses Phyllis Cox, Gladys Harris, Barbara Dodge, Elizabeth Ann Daley,
Mrs. Frederica Koster Lowe of Buffalo was married to Robert J. Phair of this place this evening in the Huguenot Memorial Church here. The Rev. Dr. Willard P. Soper, the pastor, officiated.
More than 2,000 delegates of the New York Archdiocesan Union of Holy Name Societies attended yesterday the solemn high mass which is celebrated annually in St. Patrick's Cathedral on New Year's Day.

United States District Attorney Maurice M. Milligan began civil proceedings today to collect $3,500 in penalties assessed by the Air Commerce Department for alleged violation of regulations in Operation of a plane which crashed at Macon, Mo., May 7, 1935.
An attempt to assassinate General Plutarco Elias Calles, exiled "strong man" of Mexico, was foiled tonight by a private guard, Police Chief George Sears declared.
